title: Advertising;Food Court Signs Consumer Marketers
description: The Food Court Entertainment Network in Astoria, Queens, has signed four consumer marketers as the initial advertisers for Cafe USA, a planned network of television monitors in shopping malls. Two, the AT&T Corporation and the Lee Jeans unit of the VF Corporation, had run commercials on Cafe USA during a test last year; they are being joined by the ABC Entertainment unit of the Walt Disney Company and Sears, Roebuck & Company. Turner Private Networks in Atlanta, a unit of Turner Broadcasting System Inc., sells the commercial time on Cafe USA.

title: The Cable Indecency Decision
description: A badly splintered Supreme Court has issued a confusing set of opinions on the delicate issue of how to control the dissemination of indecent material on cable television. The opinions take some important steps toward protecting the free speech rights of cable operators from government censorship, but the reasoning adopted by the main opinion raises troubling implications for future free speech cases in new media.

title: Taking In the Sites;Fourth of July Celebrations Go on the Net
description: By the time America turns 220 years old on Thursday, you may have had your fill of patriotism, politics and maybe even apple pie. The World Wide Web, however, is bursting out with flags, history and firecrackers.

title: Bosnian Serb Offers Riddle: Is He Out Or Is He In?
description: The senior civilian administrator for the Bosnia peace accord announced today that the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, had resigned.

title: Lung Treatment's Effects Seem to Differ by Race
description: A lung treatment for premature infants sharply improved the survival rate of white babies but not black ones, a study in St. Louis has found.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;A Guitarist Joins in a Bit Of Coltrane
description: One of the more anticipated concerts of the festival season took place at the Knitting Factory on Friday night. It featured the Kenny Garrett quartet, which in turn featured the guitarist Pat Metheny. Mr. Garrett, one of the best alto saxophonists of his generation, had to endure Mr. Metheny's fans, who cheered every time he stood up from sitting; that's the price of a celebrity tie-in for jazz musicians. The concert, on Friday in the Heineken "What is Jazz?" Festival, was an advertisement for the group's new record, "Pursuance: The Music of John Coltrane" (Warner Brothers), and Mr. Garrett and his band performed material from it.

title: National Paper Planned for Black Readers
description: A new national weekly newspaper aimed at the black middle class is planning to publish by the end of this year and hoping to build a circulation of 350,000 within five years.

title: One Fight a Year Is Good Publicity'
description: The worst enemy you can have is one who was once your best friend," wrote Sherman Billingsley, who made plenty of both as the gatekeeper of cafe society at the Stork Club.

title: Sanwa Shutter Acquisition
description: The Sanwa Shutter Corporation of Japan has agreed to buy Overhead Door Inc., which makes garage doors and other automated entrances, for $470 million in cash, Overhead Door said today. Sanwa signed a definitive agreement to acquire Overhead Door's common stock, options and warrants and to redeem its preferred stock. The acquisition is expected to close this month, subject to regulatory approvals. Sanwa Shutter, based in Tokyo, makes shutters, exterior sliding doors and other housing products.

title: An English Yob Is a Toff, Is a Yob, Is a . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Minicomputer Pioneers Who Are Now Aging Quite Nicely
description: They are among the elders of the computer industry now, three men who, in fierce competition with each other, made the machines that ushered in the era of minicomputers -- a quaint name for hardware that when compared with today's chihuahua-sized laptops is about as "mini" as a St. Bernard.

title: Mohawks Elect Their Second Government in Less Than a Month
description: Members of the St. Regis Mohawk Tribal Council have elected their second government in less than a month, drawing the battle lines for a tribal leadership dispute.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Number of Parolees Grows
description: New Jersey now has the nation's second-highest percentage of parolees walking its streets, according to a Department of Justice study released yesterday. Only Pennsylvania had a higher number of parolees per 100,000 adults at the end of 1995.

title: No Markets Chart
description: The Tracking the Markets chart summarizing last week's stock and bond activity does not appear today. Charts of the top winners and losers in stocks market for the second quarter appear on Page D4.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Skirmish Over College Name
description: The battle over the rights to a college's name took a decidedly sophomoric turn over the weekend: Two Princeton University alumni were arrested Saturday for stealing signs proclaiming the former Trenton State College "The College of New Jersey." Trenton State chose the name last week over objections and the threat of lawsuits from officials at Princeton, which used the name until 100 years ago.

title: U.S. AGENCY WANTS THE PILL REDEFINED
description: In an unusual move tantamount to approving a new drug, the Food and Drug Administration plans to publish in the Federal Register a notice that says ordinary oral contraceptives can be safely and effectively used as "morning after" pills, according to a top agency official.

title: On Trial, But Not Indicted
description: The decision by Federal prosecutors to name Bruce Lindsey, a close adviser to President Clinton, an unindicted co-conspirator in the second Whitewater trial smacks of politics. There was no credible evidence linking Mr. Lindsey with any illegal act, which is why he was not indicted in the first place.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Cloak-and-Dagger Touches At Group of 7 Meeting When President Clinton's economic advisers carried heavy stacks of papers all over Lyons, France, during the summit meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations last week, it was not simply to exercise away calories from four-hour meals at three-star restaurants. In this era of free trade, economic espionage is rampant, security agents say, and they told the advisers to leave nothing important in their hotel rooms. [Page A1.]

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Debate on Drivers' Privacy
description: A bill that would require written permission from drivers before the state could sell or otherwise release information on their licenses has been approved by the Assembly. But the bill cannot be considered by the Senate until it reconvenes in late July.

title: Teaching and Nurturing Lower East Side Girls
description: In their own humble version of shop class at the end of each day, the 53 girls of Holy Child Middle School on the Lower East Side earn their education with sweat. Elizabeth Muniz mops the bathroom floors, Elizabeth Tineo scrubs the sinks, and Amanda Soto shines the wooden banister of the five-story stairwell.

title: LOOKING GLASS;Summer's Math Lesson: The Movies
description: Independence Day," the science-fiction thriller know for the aliens that make wood chips out of the White House, will land in thousands of theaters Wednesday. Its whomped-up special effects and drawn-out publicity campaign could herald a blockbuster, but only the weekend ticket sales will tell if it can live up to the challenge. An examination of others in the fraternity of superhyped summer flicks shows that the first week's sales determine the movies' earning potential. The drop-off after the opening weekend is usually steep and can accelerate with time if the buzz is negative. Here are some of the hottest and coolest summer selections, past and present. KRIS GOODFELLOW

title: Cirrus Logic Expects to Post Quarterly Loss
description: Cirrus Logic Inc. has said it expects to report an operating loss for the first quarter of fiscal 1997, another in a series of warnings from semiconductor manufacturers about softness in the industry.

title: ON BASEBALL;Lefties Have an Unshakable Grip on the Yankees
description: So, David Wells has the Yankees right in the palm of his hand. His left hand. Just like Chuck Finley, Mark Langston, Rich Robertson and Scott Aldred.

title: Gunman Kills 3 on Busy Street in Georgia
description: A gunman entered a man's home this morning and shot him dead, then walked out to a busy intersection, flagged down cars and kept shooting, killing two others including a 1 1/2-year-old boy, the police said. Four people were wounded.

title: INSIDE
description: Two Cubans Leave Team

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Plethora of Poshness
description: Driving conditions could have been a little more favorable a Silver Ghost that had not been wet since 1970 received a soaking -- but yesterday's heavy rains could not dampen the spirits of 154 Rolls-Royce owners who drove through Somerset County to set a Guinness world record for the longest procession of luxury cars. The caravan, which began at the Forbes family's Timberfield estate and snaked into Bedminster Township, broke the record of 147 Rolls-Royces set in Australia in 1992. Rolls-Royce Motor Cars organized the event to celebrate a 32 percent increase in sales in the United States during the first quarter of this year compared with 1995. ANDYNEWMAN

title: Few Little Empresses
description: To the Editor:

title: Shooting in Bronx Came in Struggle to Oust Drug Gangs
description: After a high-speed gun battle that raged along 20 blocks in the South Bronx Saturday night, leaving one suspected drug dealer dead and another critically wounded, law enforcement officials said yesterday that they believed the men were part of a powerful gang that has been operating within the city-owned Bronx Terminal Market.

title: Dole Is Heading to New Jersey for 2 Fund-Raisers
description: Bob Dole arrived in New York City last night to tap two vital lifelines to any modern politician's campaign: television and money.

title: Gray Skies and a Smaller Crowd, but High Spirits at Gay Pride March
description: The rain is not a metaphor," declared Thomas B. Stoddard, a civil rights lawyer and a grand marshal of yesterday's Gay and Lesbian Pride March, as he waited for the event to kick off. "The future of the movement is full of sun."

title: Quirk in Medicare Law Yields Bigger Bills for Outpatient Care
description: Because of a quirk in the Federal Medicare law, elderly people are being required to pay more than their normal share of the bill for hospital outpatient services. It is far more than Congress originally intended and the burden is rising rapidly as such services account for a larger portion of all health care in the United States.

title: SAUDIS OFFER U.S. FULL COOPERATION IN BOMBING INQUIRY
description: The Defense Department said today that King Fahd of Saudi Arabia had pledged "complete cooperation" in the investigation of the bomb attack that killed 19 American servicemen last week, even as it became clear that the Saudis did not cooperate fully with the United States after a bombing last year that killed five Americans.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Sports of The Times;Will Cuba Tolerate Many More Defectors?
description: YESTERDAY there were two, but in Atlanta, will there be more?

title: Selling One's Celebrity Carries Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Capitol Hill Fiat On HDTV Isn't The Last Word
description: When top Congressional leaders sent Reed E. Hundt a letter last week demanding that he turn over a new batch of digital channels to existing broadcasters, it appeared to be the kind of decisive political statement that would settle the decade-long battle over high-definition television.

title: Trade Laws That Punish Allies
description: Economic sanctions can be a legitimate and useful way for the United States to pressure other countries to change offensive policies. Banning American companies from trading with or investing in Iran, for example, makes Teheran pay a price for exporting terrorism, seeking to acquire nuclear weapons and grossly abusing human rights. It also adds credibility to Washington's diplomatic efforts to enlist European and Asian countries in the sanctions.

title: Emma Bowen, 81; Championed Rights Of Disenfranchised
description: Emma Bowen, a lifelong advocate for community causes and the rights of minorities whose reach extended to Washington, where she challenged broadcasters' and politicians' hiring practices, died last Monday at her home in Washington Heights. She was 81.

title: Advertising;People
description: Lorraine Ketch and Steve Le Neveu, group planning directors at TBWA Chiat/Day, Venice, Calif., a unit of Omnicom Group, were named co-planning directors at the New York office. They assume responsibilities held by Cathy Clift, who resigned. Also in New York, Eric McClellan, group creative director, was promoted to creative director, working with Marty Cooke, who was named to a new post, executive creative director.

title: Selling One's Celebrity Carries Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: As Olympics Approach, Homeless Are Not Feeling at Home in Atlanta
description: Tony Johnson says that in his eight years of being homeless in Atlanta, he has been bundled up like so much trash on the street by the police and carted off to jail more than 100 times, mostly for trespassing.

title: White House Links Dead Aide To Hiring of Ex-Security Chief
description: The White House said today that the initial decision to hire Craig Livingstone as the head of the office that handled F.B.I. background checks was made by Vincent W. Foster Jr., the deputy White House counsel who committed suicide in 1993.

title: No Headline
description: I knew he was gay!"

title: A Mystery Livens London Art Auctions
description: A mysterious German-speaking collector went on a wild shopping spree at Sotheby's last week, buying approximately $22 million worth of paintings by Chagall, Renoir, Klee, Miro, Dubuffet, Freud and Bacon, among others. She bid by telephone to Agnes Husslein, Sotheby's Vienna representative, who was here for the Impressionist, modern and contemporary art auctions. Since the buyer asked that the auction house not reveal her identity, Sotheby's would say only that she was a woman who lived in Europe.

title: Advertising;Poppe Tyson Buys Animated Systems
description: Poppe Tyson in New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, has acquired Animated Systems and Designs Inc., a provider of interactive new media in Palo Alto, Calif. Terms were not disclosed. Rae B. Callender, 34, president of Animated, will continue in that position, supervising 41 employees who work for clients like the International Business Machines Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation. Animated will operate independently, working on new business in conjunction with Poppe Tyson.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;2 Pianists Who Explore Contrasts
description: Sometimes bad concerts happen to good musicians, and at Carnegie Hall on Friday night, Ahmad Jamal and Herbie Hancock, two estimable pianists, handed in not much at all. There's a good chance that the sound system contributed to the mess; the musicians never were distinct, and the actual sound of the music seemed diffuse and dissonant. Finally it was painful, and members of the audience left well before the concert was over.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Programs for Elderly to Merge
description: In an effort to make dealing with the government easier for New Jersey's 1.4 million older adults, more than 20 state programs for the elderly will be consolidated under one new agency today: the Department of Health and Senior Services, formerly the Department of Health.

title: Economic Calendar
description: MONDAY

title: Don't Inflate Market For Iraqi Antiquities
description: To the Editor:

title: Benson Carlin, 80, Inventor of Devices Using Ultrasonics
description: Benson Carlin, an engineer and inventor whose expertise lay in ultrasonics -- vibrations too fast for the human ear to hear -- died on June 22 at St. Mary's Hospital in Langhorne, Pa. He was 80 and had lived in Langhorne since moving from Princeton, N.J., in the early 1990's.

title: Greek Orthodox Bid Goodbye to Their Archbishop After 37 Years
description: As thousands of worshipers huddled under umbrellas and a 300-member choir chanted Byzantine litanies, hundreds of girls bearing roses led a procession of altar boys and richly garbed priests and bishops to the Central Park Band Shell, transformed yesterday into the apse of a Greek Orthodox basilica.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stock prices were trading lower here today. At the midday break, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 41.90 points, or almost two-tenths of 1 percent, at 22,488.85. On Friday, the Nikkei gained 29.14 points.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-7

title: Metro Matters;Albany Snarl: School Boards and Reform
description: POLITICAL paralysis in Albany, part II:

title: THEATER REVIEW;Heebie-Jeebies in Check, Hal Thrives on Ferocity
description: Thanks to Laurence Olivier and Kenneth Branagh, "Henry V" has become everyone's idea of a swell Shakespearean action movie, be it patriotic (as in Olivier's version) or pacifist (per Mr. Branagh). On the stage, however, without cross-cutting, galloping steeds and moody landscapes, it can be an uphill battle.

title: Sarah Powell Huntington, 89; Aided Women Freed From Prison
description: Sarah Powell Huntington, who spent her life in social service, dealing with mental health issues and, particularly, the fate of women released from prison, died on June 23 at her home in St. James, L.I. She was 89.

title: Getting to the End of the Road, at Last
description: Some people say the Natchez Trace Parkway, which spans 424 miles that few drivers have any compelling reason to cover, is a road that goes nowhere.

title: SOCCER;Flag Waved Off as Germany Wins European Crown
description: The winning German goal was in the net and the penalty area of the world's most famous soccer stadium was littered with the bodies of fallen Czech defenders. Then, one by one, the Czechs looked up, hopped up and came back to life running.

title: CYCLING;A Penchant for Sprinting and Red Shorts
description: Best: He spoke immediately after he had won his third stage in the weeklong race.

title: Bridge
description: Teams from Chicago and New York seemed headed for victories in the International Team Trials here today, with the right to represent the United States in the World Championships on the Greek island of Rhodes in October as the prize.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a disturbance at a Harlem concert misstated its sponsorship and purpose. While tables for voter registration were set up, the concert was not part of a broader effort undertaken by black political leaders to increase voter registration in the city. The concert, organized by the musical group the Fugees, was primarily intended to promote the nonprofit Refugee Camp Project, which develops recreation and cultural programs for urban youth.

title: Buoyant at 79, Vietnamese Leader Denies Divisions in Party Over Reform
description: They will not let me rest!" said Do Muoi happily, striding up unexpectedly to a group of foreign reporters today during a break in the Communist Party Congress, where his term as the country's top leader had just been extended.

title: Put Safety Board in Charge of Air Travel
description: To the Editor:

title: Onetime Political Satire Becomes a Right-Wing Rage and a Hot Internet Item
description: Tipped off by an anonymous source named "nobody," Simon & Schuster Inc. and its literary police are engaged in the Internet equivalent of a high-speed car chase: tracking down a runaway book pirated on right-wing and anarchist sites on the World Wide Web.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The recipients of the 12th annual Kyoto Prize, Japan's richest award given by a private foundation, were announced last week, and all three of the 1996 laureates are from the United States.

title: Truck Plate Number May Be Clue in Bombing
description: F.B.I. agents have been told that a truck matching the description of one used in the bombing of an American military housing complex here was spotted in a suspicious location at the edge of the compound nearly two weeks ago by a Saudi woman.

title: TENNIS;Wimbledon's Survivors Gird for Week 2
description: After an upset-laden opening week that had even the defending champion Pete Sampras wondering if there wasn't something supernatural going on around here, the Wimbledon lawns got a rest today from the pitter-patter of pounding feet -- many of them attached to unheralded combatants.

title: Software Company Formed
description: Intel, Warner Music and Softbank, the Japanese publishing company, plan to announce on Monday the formation of the Palace, a company that will provide software for graphical, Internet-based "chat" systems.

title: Europe Better Understands Gentle Indonesians
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE REVIEW;Midsummer And Its Invitation To a Dance
description: Summertime became an enchanted time when previously unreviewed dancers were featured in George Balanchine's "Midsummer Night's Dream" at recent performances by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater.

title: Abroad at Home;Peace With Arafat?
description: I paid a price," Dr. Eyad Sarraj said, "but I have no regrets for that. My imprisonment helped the cause of human rights in a way. It made people understand the importance of freedom of expression."

title: Equity Offerings Planned During the Week Ahead
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Media
description: IT just seems so right for the 90's.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Mosquito Forecast for Fourth
description: The New Jersey mosquito forecast for the Fourth of July holiday calls for mostly clear conditions, with increasing chance of bites toward the end of the weekend. That is because just as April showers bring May flowers, heavy rains -- like yesterday's -- bring fresh broods of mosquitoes five or six days later.

title: O'Connor Reaches Out After Fires
description: With the Rev. Al Sharpton and two other black ministers sitting, at his invitation, in a front pew of St. Patrick's Cathedral, John Cardinal O'Connor yesterday denounced the apparent racism behind the burning of black churches in the South and asked Catholics to aid in the rebuilding of the destroyed houses of worship.

title: Man Held in Assault Of Brooklyn Boy, 11
description: An 11-year-old Brooklyn boy was sexually assaulted and stabbed over 14 hours but escaped after his male attacker fell asleep yesterday morning, officials said. The child was listed in stable condition yesterday at Brookdale Hospital Medical Center.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday, about Beijing's decision to let 16 international law firms open offices in China, misspelled the name of a Chicago firm. It is Alt heimer & Gray, not Grey.

title: Now Playing on the Connecticut River: Return of the African Queen
description: Eileen F. Hayes is pretending to be Katharine Hepburn. And why not? She's steering the African Queen.

title: To Keep an All-Male V.M.I., Its Alumni Consider Buying It
description: Reacting to a Supreme Court ruling on Wednesday that the Virginia Military Institute must admit women, the alumni offered this weekend to mount a $100 million campaign to buy the college from the state.

title: Burch Mann, Dance Troupe Founder, 87
description: Burch Mann, the founder and director of the American Folk Ballet, died on Tuesday at her home in Cedar City, Utah, after a long illness. She was 87.

title: BOXING;Fighters' Flight Is Latest Blow to Cuban Boxing
description: The apparent defections of Joel Casamayor and Ramon Garbey were the latest in a series of body punches the Cuban boxing team has suffered since the 1992 Summer Olympics.

title: Warsaw Journal;All You Strong-Minded First Ladies, Move Over
description: She has a mind of her own, a law degree and more interest in finance than her husband.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Europe Better Understands Gentle Indonesians
description: To the Editor:

title: William C. Trimble, Ex-Foreign Service Officer, 89
description: William Cattell Trimble, a retired Foreign Service officer, died last Monday in his home in Brooklandville, Md. He was 89.

title: Ex-Communists Lose In Mongolia Election
description: The opposition Democratic Union Coalition swept 48 out of 76 seats in parliamentary elections on Sunday, the General Election Committee said today.

title: SOCCER;MetroStars Shut Out Crew
description: Tony Meola posted his third consecutive shutout and fourth in the last six games as the MetroStars defeated the Columbus Crew by 4-0 today in Major League Soccer.

title: Arson Is Suspected At Another Church
description: Fire damaged a predominantly black church near here early today, and investigators reported finding evidence of arson.

title: Yeltsin Puzzle: How Is He?
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin failed again today to make any public appearances, fueling deepening concern over his health just three days before the presidential runoff election.

title: Fred Anderson, 59, Television Newsman
description: Fred Anderson, a television and radio newsman in Los Angeles for many years, died on June 23 at Glendale Memorial Hospital and Health Center, where he had undergone triple bypass surgery two days earlier. He had apparently suffered a heart attack the previous weekend, according to KABC-TV. He was 59.

title: Dominican Republic Holds Runoff, Capping Fierce Race
description: Both presidential candidates are men of the left who have scrambled back toward the center. As a result, the runoff vote here today has been transformed into a brutal struggle for power in which ideology means virtually nothing and personalities, feuds, grudges, innuendo and deal-making have determined almost everything.

title: Sorting Out Ups and Downs of the Nasdaq
description: Has the summer technology slump returned to Wall Street?

title: Turkey's New Prime Minister Lobbies for Parliamentary Support
description: Having assembled a Government, Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan, Turkey's first leader from an Islamic political party, has turned to the urgent task of winning parliamentary support in a vote of confidence expected next week.

title: Husker Icon Retires at 81
description: Bob Devaney, who won consecutive national football championships at Nebraska in 1970 and 1971, retired today as athletic director emeritus because of poor health. Devaney, 81, had a stroke in March 1995 and his health has continued to decline.

title: Hong Kong, Takeover Near, In Wary Dance With Destiny
description: Tucked among the coffin makers just off Wing Lok Street, on the edge of a hankie-sized park where old men play Chinese chess, a fading photograph shows a waterfront site, Possession Point -- the spot where the British flag was first planted, by Capt. Edward Belcher at 8:15 A.M. on Jan. 26, 1841.

title: George Barati, 83, Composer, Conductor, Cellist and Teacher
description: George Barati, a Hungarian-born composer, conductor and cellist who came to the United States in 1938 and played in a faculty string quartet with Albert Einstein at Princeton University, died on June 22 at the Good Samaritan Hospital in San Jose, Calif. He was 83 and lived in Soquel, Calif.

title: A Research Project Is Set by Europeans
description: A Government-backed European research initiative announced a $2.5 billion project last week to increase competitiveness and narrow the gap in microelectronics with the United States and Japan.

title: Corrections
description: The listing of lottery results yesterday misstated the Connecticut Daily number for June 29 in some copies. The correct number is 974.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Death-Penalty Deliberations
description: A jury is to begin deliberating today to decide if a man convicted of murdering a gas-station attendant should be sentenced to death. Robert W. Morton of Burlington City was found guilty last Wednesday of stabbing Michael Eck during a robbery of an Amoco station in Delran in February 1993. He maintained during his trial that a friend of his, who has also been charged with the murder and is awaiting trial, was the one who actually stabbed Mr. Eck 24 times. The death penalty would be applicable because Mr. Morton, 28, was convicted of murdering Mr. Eck while committing another crime.

title: Clinton Leads Two Memorials For Victims of Saudi Bombing
description: President Clinton led two memorial services today for the 19 airmen killed on Tuesday in a bombing in Saudi Arabia, telling their families, "America stands with you in your sorrow and in your outrage," and vowing that "we will not rest" until their killers are caught.

title: Huge Russian Company Is Biggest Yeltsin Backer
description: At its lavish headquarters, Russia's most powerful company makes no bones about which candidate it is supporting in the presidential election.

title: Progress Against Organized Crime
description: Consumers and businesses in New York City are overcharged hundreds of millions of dollars a year because of the grip that organized crime has on the city's vital functions, from garbage collection to the wholesale food markets. Thus it is a salutary development that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and his administration have begun working with Federal and local prosecutors to do something at last about a huge problem that has long been dismissed as beyond anyone's control.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Flying in the Face of Science and Making a Billion
description: SCIENCE ON TRIAL The Clash of Medical Evidence and the Law in the Breast Implant Case By Marcia Angell, M.D. 256 pages. W. W. Norton. $27.50.

title: Daniel J. Terra, 85, Founder of Art Museum in Giverny, Dies
description: Daniel J. Terra, an American businessman and art collector who founded two museums of American art, one in Giverny, France, and the other in Illinois, died on Friday at a hospital in Washington. He was 85 and had homes in Chicago, Washington and Vernon, in northwestern France.

title: Germany Wins Euro 96 With a 'Golden Goal'
description: LONDON  The "Golden Goal" does exist after all, to Germany's delight, though a doubt was raised with the linesman's flag in the arguable conclusion to the European Championship final on Sunday night.

title: Advertising
description: REMEMBER that chestnut about the quintessential article in The Reader's Digest, "New Hope for the Dead"? The results of an annual survey have indicated that for the first time in many years, there are signs of a turnaround in the strained and troubled relationship between agencies and clients.

title: Patents
description: GOLF requires occasional bursts of energy for a powerful swing, and that can be difficult for weak or poor players. So two California inventors have patented a golf club that detonates an explosive charge to fire the ball across the fairway so golfers don't have to swing at all.

title: Lou Galterio, 53, Opera Director For U.S. and Canadian Troupes
description: Lou Galterio, an opera director who created more than 60 productions for many of the major American and Canadian companies, died on June 20 at Barnes-Jewish Hospital in St. Louis. He was 53 and lived in St. Louis.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EMILY LOESSER, the singer and actress, was born -- literally -- to the role of Sarah Brown, the save-a-soul mission worker in "Guys and Dolls." She is a daughter of Frank Loesser, the musical's composer and lyricist, and sings the part in a new recording of the show.

title: BASEBALL;Mets' Defeat Spotlights Isringhausen's Struggles
description: When the All-Star Game break arrives in seven days and the Mets reflect on why their season hasn't been the success they had hoped, one of the glaring reasons will be the performance of pitcher Jason Isringhausen, who has been as futile this season as he was phenomenal in 1995.

title: Northwest to Buy A KLM Holding
description: Northwest Airlines Inc. said over the weekend that it would pay KLM Royal Dutch Airlines $378 million for 6,654 shares of Northwest preferred stock.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: MONDAY National City

title: Four Charged With Beating Two Officers
description: Four men were charged with beating two off-duty New York City police officers with baseball bats outside a Long Island bar early this morning, the police said.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Tap, in a Summer Home, Seems to Grow Up
description: The American Tap Dance Orchestra Inc. looked right at home at Dance Theater Workshop on Thursday night. Could the workshop become a summer home for tap each year? It is a happy thought.

title: Essay;Move the Embassy
description: At the heart of Israel's recent election was this question: Who would best keep its capital, Jerusalem, from being divided?

title: Albany Accord Over Hospitals Propels Budget
description: Overcoming one of the last major hurdles to an accord on the state's record-setting late budget, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders reached a tentative agreement late Sunday night on sweeping legislation to end New York State's decades-old practice of setting rates for hospital services.

title: HORSE RACING;Siphon Wins 4th Straight In Gold Cup
description: The rematch occurred halfway around the world and without their star attractions. This time, Richard Mandella got the best of Bill Mott.

title: BOXING;Two Cuban Olympic Boxers Flee To the U.S.
description: Just weeks before the Atlanta Olympics are set to open, two highly rated members of the Cuban Olympic boxing team fled the team's training camp in Mexico and sought asylum today at a border crossing near San Diego, a lawyer who said he represents the men said.

title: N.Y.A.C. Can't Keep Pace With the Money From the Shoe Companies
description: Somewhere on the outskirts of Niketown sits the New York Athletic Club, still practicing its own version of the ancient cult of amateurism. It will send 22 white male athletes to the Atlanta Games; admittedly, most are wearing the club's winged-foot logo because they couldn't swing a swoosh.

title: Technology
description: HUNDREDS of disputes are in progress over who owns valuable business domain names on the Internet -- those ubiquitous "acme.com" identifiers for E-mail addresses and corporate Web sites. This long-brewing controversy has pitted owners of domain names afraid of losing their names against trademark owners who contend that their marks are being compromised. And both sides now are clamoring for someone to do something. Someone, in this case, is Internic, an organization serving as the registry for the most recognized categories of Internet domains: .com, for commercial enterprises; .edu, for educational institutions; .net, for organizations that run networks, and .org, for research and nonprofit groups. Internic has registered some 400,000 names in these domains, first-come, first-served, since it was founded in 1993 through an arrangement with the federally backed National Science Foundation.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;'Other' Gymnasts Show U.S. Depth
description: It remains very much to be seen whether the American women will win their first gymnastics team gold medal when they fly south for the Summer Olympics.

title: Woman Charged in Killing
description: A 25-year-old woman has been charged with fatally stabbing her mother's fiance.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in Business Day on June 19 about Federal approval of the merger of Bank of Boston and Baybanks misidentified a company that is acquiring 20 branch offices from the two banks. It is USTrust of Boston, a unit of the UST Corporation, not the U.S. Trust Company, a New York-based unit of the U.S. Trust Corporation.

title: BALLET REVIEW;Amid Formal Gardens, Love as Obstacle Course
description: In the game of love, getting there is three-quarters of the fun. Or so the French would have us believe, in a literary tradition that dates back to the 17th century, when Louis XIV, no prude himself, founded the Paris Opera Ballet.

title: GOLF;Pepper Uses Old Clubs To Help Her Win Again
description: With her personal life settled, and with a set of clubs so old she calls them dinosaurs, Dottie Pepper's golf game is back in the groove.

title: Advertising;A Grand Prix To Ammirati Puris
description: A humorous commercial from the Netherlands featuring an elephant with an unusually long memory took top honors, winning the Grand Prix, at the 43d annual International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France, sponsored by the Screenvision Cinema Network.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Paris Star's Boyishness Flavors His Nobility
description: New York finally got its first chance to see Nicolas Le Riche, a gifted young principal of the Paris Opera Ballet, on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Mr. Le Riche, 24, is much acclaimed in Europe and his performance as Solor in the Rudolf Nureyev production of "La Bayadere" suggested an impressive instinctive understanding of how to infuse bravura technical display with quiet passion, and nobility with a boyishly rough edge.

title: GOLF;Weibring Says Illness Plays Role In Victory
description: Not many golf fans know much, if anything, about D. A. Weibring, even though he has been on the PGA Tour for 20 years, finished tied for third in the United States Open in 1988 and had won four tournaments, all of them in his native Illinois, including three at the same golf course in Moline.

title: Howard Colgan, 84, Partner in Law Firm
description: Howard O. Colgan Jr., a retired partner in the Manhattan-based law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, representing such clients as the New York Stock Exchange and Chase Manhattan Bank, died on Tuesday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. A longtime Ridgewood resident, he was 84 and lived in Vero Beach, Fla., and Wyckoff, N.J.

title: Economic Summit Subplot: Do French Walls Have Ears?
description: As Air Force One descended the other night for the opening of the 22d annual summit meeting of the world's biggest industrial nations, a security agent gathered the small army of Cabinet members and aides accompanying President Clinton and delivered a clear warning.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary yesterday about Irving P. Krick, a commercial weather forecaster, misattributed a comment about Dr. Krick's response to criticism of his work in some editions. It was Frederic Fox, president of Strategic Weather Services, who said: "He tried to do things that no one else claims you can do. His idea was you go out there and do it and prove it with the people that count -- the people that use it." The remark was not made by Loren Crow, a former colleague of Dr. Krick.

title: With U.S. as Partner, Ukraine's Ship May Be In
description: To the Editor:

title: Violations Found as Congress Follows Safety Rules
description: One of the first laws passed after the Republicans took over Congress last year -- making the House and Senate answerable to the same labor and safety rules that other Americans must obey -- has led to the discovery of a number of serious fire hazards, Congressional officials say.

title: Getting the Latest Version of Software Via the Internet
description: Nearly a dozen companies are on the verge of releasing products that will use Internet connections to offer an organized way to easily find, receive and install the latest versions of the software used on home computers.

title: Dolphin-Safety Laws Don't Harm Sea Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Has Esquire Gone Out of Style?
description: Edward Kosner would probably miss his office. The blond-wood rolling desk chairs that glide noiselessly up to the glass coffee table. The ample display space for his collection of classic model cars, like the 1941 Lincoln Continental and the 1947 Chrysler Town & Country. The airy privacy that allows him to lean back on his black leather couch and listen to tapes of Portuguese love songs undisturbed.

title: Advertising;Helene Curtis Line To Ogilvy & Mather
description: Helene Curtis Inc. has moved the account of its Suave line of shampoos, lotions, deodorants and other personal-care products to the Chicago office of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide after Helene Curtis and the brand's previous agency, Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago, mutually agreed to part ways. Though billings were not disclosed, according to Competitive Media Reporting in New York, which tracks advertising spending, Suave spent $11.4 million to advertise last year and $9.6 million in 1994.

title: Religion and Recreation Clash at Park
description: A dispute has arisen in the lush Black Hills between American Indians' religious beliefs and the rights of recreational climbers who also want to use the Devils Tower National Monument here.

title: In America;George's Curve Ball
description: Bernie Williams, the Yankees' best player, was streaking toward the fence in deepest center field. Bobby Bonilla (booed every time he came to bat) had launched a rocket from home plate. Now Williams was leaping, leaping, his glove extended over the fence, and he makes the catch!

title: AT&T to Provide Service in Britain
description: Turning up the heat in Europe's most competitive telecommunications market, the AT&T Corporation said Friday that it would start selling phone services to consumers in Britain for the first time this week.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks Are Frustrated as Mendoza Falters
description: Paper clips and rubber bands, makeshift binders at best, are able to hold things together to a certain point.

title: Presbyterians Pick Centrist
description: The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) has chosen as its leader the Rev. John Buchanan, who is considered a centrist.

title: Look Who Dropped In At the Stork
description: For a big chunk of the 20th century, from the speak-easy era to the Vietnam War, it was the nation's and perhaps the world's most storied nightspot, a plush oasis where starlets stalked millionaires, a headwaiter pocketed a $20,000 tip, and Ernest Hemingway scuffled with the warden of Sing Sing.

title: Intermedia Acquires Unit From Newhouse
description: Intermedia Communications Inc. said Friday that it had acquired the telecommunications division of the EMI Communications Corporation, a unit of the Newhouse Broadcasting Corporation, in a stock deal valued at about $30.5 million.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Kamsky Adjourns With Victory Near
description: Gata Kamsky, a pawn ahead yesterday at the adjournment of Game 13 of his world championship match with Anatoly Karpov, is expected to go for a victory today when play is resumed.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz Plan Post-Merger Cuts
description: Ciba-Geigy A.G. and Sandoz A.G., the two Swiss pharmaceutical giants that are preparing to merge, said yesterday that they intended to reduce their combined work force in Switzerland through layoffs and early retirement. The merger arrangement, announced in March, calls for the elimination of 3,500 jobs in Switzerland. The combined company will be called Novartis.

title: Opposition Party Wins Mayoral Election in Argentine Capital
description: In a major political setback for the ruling Peronist Party of President Carlos Saul Menem, the century-old Radical Party, once thought to be on the way out, won the first-ever election for Mayor of Buenos Aires on Sunday and re-established itself as a viable opposition party.

title: Russia Heads for Trouble
description: Boris Yeltsin's recent hiring and firing of several top aides has produced a strange euphoria among some Western experts on Russia. They predict that President Yeltsin will be re-elected in tomorrow's runoff election. They also interpret the dismissal of four hard-liners and the promotion of former Gen. Aleksandr Lebed as meaning that democracy has won out, that Mr. Lebed will be its guarantor and that economic reform can now forge ahead.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Honoring 4 Greats Of the Past
description: America has never produced a music more optimistic and redolent of pure enjoyment than the traditional jazz celebrated on Friday evening at the Kaye Playhouse, where the singer Barbara Lea and eight instrumentalists honored four jazz greats who died more than 20 years ago.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Jelly Roll and the Duke Join Wolfgang and Ludwig
description: Yesterday, New York became more of a jazz town than ever. In a ceremony followed by a Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra concert of Ellington, Jelly Roll Morton and standards, Jazz at Lincoln Center officially joined the New York Philharmonic, the Metropolitan Opera, and eight other organizations as a full-fledged constituent of Lincoln Center, the first one added since the Film Society in 1969.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Supreme Court Finds Shift By U.S. Unfair to S.& L.'s The Supreme Court ruled that the Government knowingly went back on its word through accounting changes that plunged three savings and loans into insolvency. The case could cost taxpayers billions in breach-of- contract damages.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the murder rate in Minneapolis reversed parts of the name of the city's Mayor. She is Sharon Sayles Belton, not Sharon Belton Sayles.

title: By Design;Double-Duty Cover-Up
description: Carrying a swimsuit cover-up for a weekend by the sea can mean one extra piece in an already crammed carryall. So the smart thing is to take a cover-up that has other uses, like an oversize man's shirt or a big cotton pareo that can double as a shawl. Here are some other ideas:

title: Two Hospitals Plan Vast Health Empire
description: In the second major hospital merger deal in a month, two of New York's largest teaching hospitals, Beth Israel Medical Center and Long Island Jewish Medical Center, announced yesterday that they intend to merge, creating a far-flung health empire tailor-made for the city and its suburbs.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Success and Sharp Elbows;One Woman's Path to Lofty Heights on Wall Street
description: When Morgan Stanley & Company needed to slice tens of millions of dollars in costs, a task neither pleasant nor the least bit glamorous, it turned to Elaine La Roche.

title: Critical Days in the State Legislature
description: After six months of posturing, Gov. George Pataki and leaders of the New York Legislature are at last negotiating agreements on a budget and other issues. As usual, the process is both sloppy and secretive as they struggle to close down the legislative session by Independence Day. Many details of their agreements have been disclosed, but even the members of the Legislature have been kept in the dark about overall accords being negotiated. With only a few days left, one thing the Legislature must not do is let important issues get lost in the frantic closing activity.

title: Witness in Arkansas Trial Says Lindsey Arranged Key Meeting
description: A longtime aide to Bill Clinton testified today that Bruce R. Lindsey, now deputy White House counsel, set up a meeting in 1990 so that an Arkansas banker could give Mr. Clinton thousands of dollars in campaign contributions and seek a state patronage job for his partner.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Music You Can Dance To
description: The rock instrumental has come a long way from "Telstar" and "Green Onions." Stretched out for dance music, extrapolated in soundtracks, dissected by dub reggae, shattered and reconstructed by hip-hop, the instrumental has sloughed off song form to take any shape its new practitioners want to try. On the albums reviewed here, instrumentals can be starkly utilitarian dance beats, explorations of texture and noise, chains of catchy riffs or soothing contemplations. These soundscapes seem uninhabited, awaiting the listener who wants a private sanctuary.

title: New Structure Agreed On For Accounting Foundation
description: A tentative deal has been reached on restructuring the Financial Accounting Foundation, the group that appoints the members of the organization that sets corporate accounting standards, people familiar with the talks said yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Divac Agrees to a Trade With Charlotte
description: VLADE DIVAC has backed away from his retirement threats and consented to a trade that could give the Charlotte Hornets and the Los Angeles Lakers the big man each covets.

title: Agreement Will Spare Historic Site
description: For the second time in two years, efforts by historians and preservation groups have saved what they regard as a hallowed piece of American history.

title: Market Place;Score one for S.& L. investors, who won a bet against the U.S.
description: JACKPOT!

title: Executive Leaves Digital Amid Hints of Trouble
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that Enrico Pesatori, the head of its computer systems division and a man whom many people believed might one day run the company, had resigned, effective immediately.

title: SPORTS BUSINESS;Islanders Get in Line To Try to Get Arena
description: The new arena/new owner virus has infected the Islanders. And why not? How can any team see the Philadelphia 76ers and Flyers get new owners and a new Spectrum and not be jealous? Or watch as the Quebec Nordiques morph into the Colorado Avalanche, win the Stanley Cup and get a new arena in 1997?

title: HFS Will Acquire Employee-Controlled Avis for $800 Million in Cash andStock
description: HFS Inc. said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Avis Inc., the world's second-biggest car rental company, for about $800 million -- approximately $500 million in cash and $300 million in HFS common stock.

title: BASEBALL;Boggs Voted In As Others Wait
description: Wade Boggs was the only Yankee who could exhale after learning he was voted yesterday to be the third baseman for the American League All-Star team. But which Yankees will exhale with Boggs when the 20 pitchers and reserves are picked today?

title: Bert Terborgh, Dancer And Teacher, 51
description: Bert Terborgh, a principal dancer and a rehearsal director with the Martha Graham Dance Company and a teacher at the State University of New York at Purchase, died on June 21 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 51 and lived in Manhattan.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRECISION CASTPARTS AGREES TO BUY NEWFLO
description: The Precision Castparts Corporation of Portland, Ore., agreed yesterday to buy the Newflo Corporation, a pump and valve maker, for $300 million, of which $100 million represents the assumption of Newflo debt. Precision Castparts plans to finance the Newflo purchase with $400 million in credit provided by the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association and Goldman, Sachs & Company. The company said the acquisition would reduce its dependence on the aerospace industry. Newflo, based in Austin, Tex., would become a unit of Precision Castparts. Newflo makes industrial fluid-handling products such as pumps, valves and measuring instruments. It had sales of $216 million in 1995.

title: In Science Fraud Case, Justice Is Denied
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Strength in U.S. Business Lifts Federal Express Earnings 32%
description: The Federal Express Corporation reported yesterday that earnings rose 32 percent in its fourth quarter ended May 31. The results well exceeded Wall Street's forecasts, as the company's American operations were strong.

title: In Research Scans, Telltale Signs Sort False Memories From True
description: THE truth of memory is infinitely hard to establish, as psychotherapists, lawyers and scientists know all too well. But for the first time, scientists may have captured snapshots of a false memory in the making.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Crude Oil Prices Soar on Signs Of Threat to U.N.-Iraqi Plan
description: Crude oil prices jumped on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday on signs that a United Nations plan allowing Iraq to sell a limited amount of oil was in danger.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Amstrad in Spinoff That May Aid Takeover
description: The British computer company Amstrad P.L.C. moved a step closer yesterday to being acquired by Psion P.L.C. after it agreed to spin off its consumer electronics business. Amstrad Consumer Electronics is to be split between Amstrad's majority-owned Betacom P.L.C. affiliate and a newly formed company called Digicom Technology.

title: Hanoi Names More Military Officers to Politburo
description: Vietnam increased the number of military and internal security officers in its political leadership today as it prepared to push forward with an economic liberalization program that has raised fears of a weakening of Communist Party control.

title: A Crafty Karpov Escapes With a Draw
description: Gata Kamsky strained through 34 more moves of a 90-move marathon yesterday, trying to break down Anatoly Karpov's defenses, but he finally had to acknowledge that his opponent had set up an impregnable fortress.

title: FILM REVIEW;Space Aliens, Action and a Chance to Save the Planet
description: For months we've been told that "Independence Day," the latter-day "War of the Worlds" in which extraterrestrials set their sights on 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, would be the mother of all this year's summer action movies.

title: Hispanic District's Makeup Is Challenged
description: In the wake of several Supreme Court rulings that have seriously undercut the use of race in legislative districting, a three-judge panel in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday was asked to block this year's Congressional elections in New York City and to declare the largely Hispanic 12th District unconstitutional.

title: Saudi Islamic Council Condemns Bombing
description: In a hint of the debate raging beneath the surface of Saudi society, Saudi Arabia's highest religious authority has issued a formal opinion concluding that the bombing attack that killed 19 Americans last Tuesday was a sin against Islam.

title: Judge Upholds Law Requiring Notice About Sex Offenders
description: A Federal District Court judge who had blocked New Jersey's law that requires the state to inform schools and women's groups of the names and addresses of paroled sex offenders today upheld the key portion of that law.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Earle Palmer Loses Two Big Clients
description: A large client of Earle Palmer Brown and an account handled in partnership with a second shop are both leaving the agency.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Alitalia Holders Approve $1 Billion Aid Package
description: Shareholders of Alitalia S.p.A. approved a capital increase of 1.5 trillion lire ($1 billion) yesterday to help the Italian national airline stay afloat. The company's main shareholder is the Government holding company Istituto per la Ricostruzione Industriale S.p.A., or I.R.I.

title: U.S. Charges 12 in Arizona Plot To Blow Up Government Offices
description: The Federal authorities today arrested 12 people it said were members of an Arizona paramilitary group and charged them with conspiracy to blow up a number of Federal buildings, the Phoenix Police Department headquarters and an Arizona National Guard center.

title: SUNY Board Chooses an Interim Chancellor
description: The trustees of the State University of New York yesterday turned to John W. Ryan, an experienced college administrator, as their interim Chancellor to fill the slot vacated by Thomas A. Bartlett in mid-June.

title: Q & A /John B. Ritch 3d : UN's Nuclear Watchdog Is Sharpening Its Teeth
description: Ahead of talks aimed at setting new powers for the International Atomic Energy Agency, or IAEA, to detect clandestine nuclear activities, John B. Ritch 3d, U.S. ambassador to United Nations organizations in Vienna, talked with Joseph Fitchett of the International Herald Tribune about the Clinton administration's view of the controversial reform.

title: Arafat's Oppression, Israel's Demands
description: The arrest, detention and release of Eyad Sarraj, a prominent doctor and human rights advocate in Gaza, has done more than expose the growing antidemocratic tendencies of Yasir Arafat and the Palestinian Authority. It also demonstrates that the peace process begun in Oslo three years ago is fundamentally flawed.

title: AUTO RACING;Around Speedways, Trucks Pick Up Steam
description: America is in love up to its axles with trucks, and that is why several thousand people were nearly that deep in mud Sunday at Nazareth Speedway.

title: Sports of The Times;Baseball's New Type Of Scout
description: THE college kid was the Columbia pitcher. But when he batted that day, he hit a monstrous home run that landed across West 116th Street on the steps of a university building. The kid's name was Lou Gehrig.

title: New Acquisition For Medpartners
description: Medpartners/Mulliken Inc., the largest manager of doctors groups in the United States, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Summit Medical Group for an undisclosed amount of stock.

title: Corrections
description: A table in Business Day yesterday listing the worst-performing stocks on the American Stock for the second quarter misidentified one issue. It was class B shares of EXX Inc., a toy maker, not shares of the Exxon Corporation.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;3 Who Avoid the Mainstream, With Trios
description: Saturday's lineup at the Knitting Factory, part of the Heineken "What Is Jazz?" Festival, brought together three veteran musicians who have avoided mainstream jazz. The pianists Horace Tapscott and Andrew Hill and the saxophonist Sonny Simmons, each playing with a trio and in front of a packed house, turned in sets that rarely used a conventional note.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Olivetti Sells Shares In Acorn Computer
description: Olivetti S.p.A. of Italy said yesterday that it had sold 14.7 percent of Acorn Computer Group P.L.C. to Lehman Brothers Inc. on Friday. Lehman did not disclose how much it paid, but at current market prices the sale would have brought about L33.5 million ($52 million) to Olivetti, which has been posting losses.

title: CHRONICLE
description: YANNA AVIS is making a debut of sorts today, not in a theater or a nightclub, but outdoors on the Piazza del Duomo in Spoleto, Italy, where the Spoleto Festival is taking place. Mrs. Avis is a singer and the wife of Warren Avis, the founder of the automobile rental company.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Improvising Against Cliches
description: Myra Melford's set at the Knitting Factory on Thursday night took its pleasure in extremes. Ms. Melford, a pianist, led her band through passages of near silence and loud free improvisations. Delicate written passages bled into an improvised urban roar. She arranged her pieces so that instrumental combinations kept changing quickly, with the quintet giving way to a trio or to an unaccompanied solo.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Driver Killed in Car Fire
description: A car caught fire yesterday in the parking garage of a six-story luxury condominium building, and its driver died, the authorities said. The building's sprinkler system apparently prevented the flames from spreading, and no one else was injured, said Lieut. Steve Kalman of the Hackensack Fire Department. He said the police did not know why the driver, who lived in the building, was unable to escape the fire.

title: Review/Fashion;Versace's Male Pinups Set the Pace
description: There could hardly be better pinups for the 1997 spring and summer season of men's fashion than Tupac Shakur and the British teen-age idol Robbie Williams, performing for Gianni Versace's fashion-music-model variety show that opened the collections on Saturday night.

title: Assembly Speaker Attacked on Crime Checks for Javits Center
description: The head of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center accused the Speaker of the Assembly, Sheldon Silver, yesterday of sabotaging efforts to purge the center of organized crime by blocking legislation that would require background investigations of employees and contractors.

title: Clinton Proceeds With Plan To Privatize Security Checks
description: The Clinton Administration is pressing ahead with a plan to transform background investigations of many Government employees into a profit-making business run by a newly created private company, despite protests from some members of Congress, Cabinet officials and investigators worried about confidentiality and security lapses.

title: Yeltsin's Wooden TV Talk Fuels Fear He Is Ill
description: Hours after he canceled yet another series of public meetings today, President Boris N. Yeltsin emerged from seclusion to deliver a stiff, brief television address urging Russians to vote for him on Wednesday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Devils Sign 19-year-old Czech Wing
description: General Manager LOU LAMORIELLO announced yesterday that the Devils have signed 19-year-old ZDENEK SKOREPA, the club's fourth selection in the 1994 entry draft, to a multiyear contract. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Frustrated Legislators Know When to Vote, Not for What
description: As the secret budget talks between Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders dragged on tonight, other lawmakers wandered about the Capitol, frustrated, befuddled and outraged that they will soon be asked to vote on a slew of complex bills in a fevered dash to end the legislative session by the Fourth of July.

title: Anti-Sub Seabed Grid Thrown Open To Research Uses
description: A GLOBAL network of undersea microphones, built by the Federal Government at a cost of $16 billion to spy on enemy ships and submarines, is beginning to rock to the beat of whales singing, fish schooling, seabeds shaking, volcanoes erupting and even nuclear arms exploding.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PACIFIC GAS AGREES TO SETTLE 650 CLAIMS
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company, the nation's largest utility, said yesterday that it would pay $333 million to settle 650 claims related to groundwater said to be contaminated in the 1950's and 1960's by a gas pumping station near Barstow, Calif. The plaintiffs contended they suffered a variety of diseases including lung, stomach and kidney cancer as a result of drinking the groundwater. The agreement calls for Pacific Gas to pay a total of $333 million to a fund to be divided among the plaintiffs. That amount includes $50 million the company has already paid, and $150 million it set aside earlier to cover the claims. Pacific Gas, based in San Francisco, agreed to submit the cases to binding arbitration in September 1994 with a maximum cap of $400 million.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Atop Peaks or Beneath Sea, Adventurers Have Company on the Internet
description: INTERNET users often talk about exploring the World Wide Web, and the analogy is a good one. The Web is a vast, unmapped region with exotic scenery, strange languages and customs, hidden treasures, dark alleys and treacherous technological jungles and rapids.

title: Patterns
description: Lauren Moves Up at Saks

title: Jones Will Assist Celtics Coach Carr
description: K. C. Jones, who has coached three teams in the National Basketball Association and guided Boston to championships in 1984 and 1986, was named an assistant to Celtics Coach M. L. Carr today.

title: Not So Rootless
description: To the Editor:

title: Employees' Letter Accuses Land Agency of Illegal Practices
description: In a letter to Attorney General Janet Reno, current and former employees of the Federal Bureau of Land Management have accused bureau officials of falsifying financial records, taking part in schemes to sell wild horses to slaughterhouses and obstructing Federal investigations.

title: TENNIS;Martinez Goes Quietly as Henman Makes Noise
description: A former Wimbledon champion, the dispassionate Conchita Martinez, fell by the wayside tonight. But Tim Henman, the stripling the host nation has hailed as its future Wimbledon champion -- preferably as soon as Sunday -- used three sets of highly impassioned tennis to become the first British man to reach the quarterfinals since 1973.

title: L.I. Bar Brawl Raises Issue Of Off-Duty Officers' Guns
description: A brawl outside a bar on Sunday that left two New York City police officers injured after one officer's gun misfired raised questions today about a city policy allowing the police to carry weapons off duty. But Long Island police officials said it appeared the officers acted appropriately.

title: City Council Takes a Step To Loosen Term Limits
description: Calling the term limit that voters adopted for New York City's elected officials three years ago a "bad law" in need of correction, members of a City Council committee yesterday overwhelmingly approved a proposal that would essentially extend the allowed term from 8 to 12 years.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;North Korea Says U.S. Is Hampering Oil Supply
description: North Korea accused the United States Congress today of trying to cut back on fuel oil that is supposed to be supplied under an agreement to freeze North Korea's nuclear weapons program.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Japanese stocks traded lower today. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 107.52 points, or about one-half of 1 percent, at 22,347.97.

title: Iranians Pose a Real Threat to Mideast Security;No 'Shining Moment'
description: To the Editor:

title: Iranians Pose a Real Threat to Mideast Security;What Price Oil?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;TANDEM COMPUTERS CONSIDERS NEW STRATEGY FOR UNIT
description: Tandem Computers Inc. said yesterday that it had hired Lehman Brothers to explore strategic alternatives for its UB Networks subsidiary, a major supplier of networking hardware and software products. UB Networks, a wholly owned and independently operated unit based in Santa Clara, Calif., has annual revenues of about $400 million. Tandem, based in Cupertino, Calif., said its strategic focus is server-based computing, electronic commerce and intranet and Internet solutions. Tandem's stock fell $1.375, to $11, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Don't Let Banks Hide Customer Fees
description: To the Editor:

title: Consumer Group Cites Illnesses in Urging Ban of Fat Substitute
description: A consumer group asked the Food and Drug Administration today to withdraw its recent approval of a fat substitute, olestra, on the basis of a study that found that 20 percent of people who ate chips made with the product had gastrointestinal problems, 3 percent of them severe.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL TO ACQUIRE BROOKTREE
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire the Brooktree Corporation for $15 a share in cash, or about $275 million. Rockwell plans to take a one-time charge estimated at $120 million, when it completes the acquisition, for research and development that is in progress. Brooktree, based in San Diego, manufactures high-performance digital and mixed-signal integrated circuits for computer graphics, multimedia, imaging and communications applications. It had sales of $138 million in the 1995 fiscal year and has about 575 employees. Rockwell has operations in automation, avionics, aerospace, military electronics, semiconductor systems and automotive component systems. Rockwell's stock fell 75 cents, to $56.625.

title: Injustice to Aetna
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7

title: BASEBALL;Mets' Problems Continue in Philadelphia
description: After losing two of three games in Houston, the Mets felt they might be in line for a respite with three games here at Veterans Stadium against the worst team in the National League.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Jets Have a New Name and a New Coach
description: The Winnipeg Jets officially became the Phoenix Coyotes yesterday and they finally hired a head coach, picking the Calgary Flames assistant, DON HAY.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Christie Will Sprint 100 and 200 in Atlanta
description: Britain's Linford Christie confirmed today that he will go to the Atlanta Olympics to defend the 100 meters title he won four years ago in Barcelona, Spain.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about two police officers at the New York City gay pride parade reversed their identities in some editions. Emma Llarado was at the left, Fran Debenedictis at the right.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Warriors Sign Their No. 1 Pick
description: North Carolina State center TODD FULLER signed a three-year contract with the Golden State Warriors yesterday. Terms were not disclosed. Fuller, 21, was the Warriors' No. 1 draft pick and selected No. 11 over all. (AP)

title: Mexico Sends Troops to Hunt New Rebel Group in the South
description: Units of the Mexican Army scoured the rugged hills of the Pacific state of Guerrero today looking for members of an armed group that calls itself the Popular Revolutionary Army, even as the Government denied that the group represented a threat to national security.

title: General Re to Buy Rival for $940 Million
description: The General Re Corporation, the largest property and casualty reinsurer, agreed yesterday to buy the National Re Corporation, a smaller competitor, for $940 million in cash and stock in a deal that analysts said might signal consolidation in the reinsurance industry.

title: Philadelphia Agrees to Pact With Unions
description: City officials and the two largest municipal workers' unions here agreed on a tentative four-year contract on Sunday night, hours before midnight, when the current contract was to expire.

title: Maryland May Become Rare in Hospital Rates
description: As New York abandons its system of setting rates for hospital services, as proposed in the state's 1997 budget, Maryland will remain the only state that sets rates through a regulatory agency. And while New York lawmakers say deregulation would drive down the state's health care costs, Maryland officials say their rate-setting has made hospital bills fairer and cheaper.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Evian Places Account in Review
description: The Great Brands of Europe unit of the Danone Group has placed in review the North American account of Evian water, which has been handled by TBWA Chiat/Day in New York for 18 years. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $15 million.

title: Iranians Pose a Real Threat to Mideast Security
description: To the Editor:

title: Hillary Clinton Visits Romania Children
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton began an 11-day tour of Central Europe today with a visit to children's programs in a country notorious for backward orphanages and a high rate of child abandonment.

title: Review Finds More Deception In Trading at Bankers Trust
description: Attempts to take advantage of customers, by employees of the Bankers Trust New York Corporation were far more widespread than the bank had indicated earlier, according to the conclusions of an investigation released yesterday by two independent lawyers.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFINGS;THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Washington Campaign Reform Calling the Tune

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Defying Age With Joy And a Horn
description: The concept was obvious when Benny Waters, a 94-year-old alto saxophonist, and Doc Cheatham, a 91-year-old trumpeter, headlined a JVC Jazz Festival concert on Saturday night at the Kaye Playhouse. Mr. Cheatham now performs seated; Mr. Waters is blind. The violinist Claude (Fiddler) Williams, 88, and the singer Etta Jones, only 67, were also featured. The music ignored the frailties of age; it projected youthful exuberance and the assurance that comes with longtime mastery.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ALLIED WASTE INC., Scottsdale, Ariz., acquired Container Corp. of Carolina Inc., in a stock swap valued at $61 million.

title: Tribune to Pay $1.1 Billion For Six Television Stations
description: In another example of the impact of telecommunications deregulation on the broadcast marketplace, the Tribune Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Renaissance Communications Corporation for $1.13 billion in cash.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;A music retailer whistles a new marketing tune to get heard above the cacophony  of competitors.
description: IF the premise of advertising is to raise share of mind or share of voice with consumers, then HMV Record Stores is gambling that an ambitious campaign can help gain share of ear in an increasingly clangorous and crowded market.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Long Bond's Yield Rises To 6.91%
description: Confidence that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates this week helped limit losses in the Treasury market yesterday, as a report showed new strength in manufacturing.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MORTON DOWNEY JR., the former talk show host known for his confrontations with controversial guests, has lung cancer and a message for young people: don't smoke.

title: Huizenga Adding ADT To Purchases
description: H. Wayne Huizenga, the Florida billionaire who has already built two business empires from scratch, took another step toward erecting a third yesterday.

title: Lawyer Raised in New York to Lead Dominican Republic
description: Overcoming his youth, lack of experience and a second-place finish in an initial round of voting six weeks ago, Leonel Fernandez Reyna was officially declared the winner today of the presidential runoff election on Sunday.

title: OPERA REVIEW;Two Women With Gumption
description: Paula M. Kimper and Wende Persons have been working for the last two years on an operatic version of "Patience and Sarah," Isabel Miller's novel about two early 19th-century Connecticut women who fell in love and became pioneers. American Opera Projects, at 463 Broome Street in SoHo, has presented several workshop versions of the piece over the past year and offered a semi-staged final draft, with piano accompaniment, last week. The final performance took place on Saturday.

title: Editors' Note
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on June 14, about a proposed public offering by Wired Ventures Inc., the publisher of Wired magazine, quoted Tony Perkins, publisher of The Red Herring, a magazine that follows the venture capital and technology markets, who criticized the price of the offering. The article should have noted that Mr. Perkins wrote an investing column for Wired until February, when he was dismissed by the magazine.

title: Chernobyl Reports a Small Radiation Leak
description: A small radiation leak was discovered over the weekend in the Chernobyl nuclear complex, the latest in a series of incidents there, and Ukraine's Environment Minister said the West was partly to blame for deteriorating safety standards.

title: Halliburton Will Acquire Landmark Graphics in Stock Swap
description: The promise of the Internet is one thing, but many companies are shopping for the sort of technology they can profit from right away. So the Halliburton Company announced an agreement yesterday to acquire the Landmark Graphics Corporation, a leading provider of computer software and services to help the world's largest energy companies find and produce oil and gas, in a stock swap currently valued at about $525 million.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Restated Loss Widens At Gemina of Italy
description: The shareholders of Gemina S.p.A., a diversified Italian holding company, approved company statements on Saturday that showed a 1995 deficit of 694.5 billion lire ($448 million) as internal auditors asked for more information on the losses. The restated accounts showed a loss 48 percent higher than the company had forecast at the end of last year after unexpected losses in its RCS Editori publishing unit.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Dodgers' Lasorda Leaves Hospital
description: Looking slimmer and walking slowly, TOM LASORDA left an Inglewood, Calif., hospital yesterday to recuperate from surgery and a minor heart attack. It was not known when the 68-year-old manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers would be back in the dugout.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Railroad to Drop Split Shifts
description: New Jersey Transit will eliminate the last of its night split shifts for engineers in September, agency officials said yesterday. That is the type of assignment worked by the engineer who investigators say may have been at fault in the fatal crash of two commuter trains in February.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KEMET REFUSES DEAL WITH VISHAY INTERTECHNOLOGY
description: The Kemet Corporation, a maker of electronic components, said yesterday that it was not interested in merger talks with Vishay Intertechnology Inc. Vishay had proposed a deal with a potential value of $1 billion. Kemet said that its "strong future prospects as an independent company make discussions with Vishay not in the best interests" of the company or its shareholders. Kemet, which is based in Greenville, S.C., said that it had adopted a shareholders' rights plan that would hamper a takeover move. Kemet makes capacitors -- indispensable components found in wristwatches, cellular phones and computers that control the flow of current in electronic circuits. Vishay, which is based in Malvern, Pa., also makes capacitors.

title: CYCLING;Cipollini Breezes Back With His Victory
description: This time, Il Magnifico lived up to his name. Mario Cipollini easily won the sprint finish in the second stage of the Tour de France today, one day after he came in third but then was bounced to 37th place for interfering with another rider.

title: 2 Bystanders Hurt In Brooklyn Shooting
description: Two bystanders -- including a city Housing Authority worker -- were hit by stray bullets near a Brooklyn housing project yesterday afternoon after two unidentified men settled a dispute on a basketball court with pistols, the police said.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Car Bomb in Corsica Kills Nationalist Leader
description: A car bomb exploded today on Corsica, a French island in the Mediterranean, killing a Corsican nationalist leader and injuring 16 other people.

title: Cuomo Is Departing As Radio-Show Host
description: Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced yesterday that he would leave his position as host of a nationally syndicated weekend talk-radio show, saying he plans to dedicate a substantial amount of time to the 1996 Democratic Presidential campaign.

title: PP&L Unit Acquires Stake in British Utility
description: The Southern Company's international arm said today that it had sold a 25 percent stake in South Western Electricity P.L.C. of Britain for $189 million to the Power Market Development Company, a subsidiary of PP&L Resources Inc. PP&L, whose Pennsylvania Power and Light Company supplies power to residents in eastern Pennsylvania, said in May that it was in talks to acquire a stake in South Western, the British regional electricity company that the Southern Company bought in October for $1.8 billion.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;The Dream Team Meets, as Miller Dreams of New York
