description: They did not come here to achieve a sense of majesty, because that has already been done. There was the first Dream Team in Barcelona, Spain, with Larry Bird on his last legs and Magic Johnson in an emotional return to the game. Then there will be all the others, including this one, to be judged against an unmatchable moment in time.

title: Steve Tesich, 53, Whose Plays Plumbed the Nation's Identity
description: Steve Tesich, the Yugoslav-born playwright and Academy Award-winning screenwriter whose popular movies and not-so-popular plays plumbed his own changing attitudes toward the United States, his adopted country, and Americans, died yesterday in Sydney, Nova Scotia, where he was vacationing with his family. He was 53 and had homes in Manhattan and Conifer, Colo.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Hero Becomes a Suspect
description: It would seem to have been an act of selfless bravery: a teen-ager reached into a burning car, pulled out another youth who had been shot in the chest -- fatally, it turned out -- and took him to the hospital. But the makeshift ambulance was a stolen Acura Legend, and its 15-year-old driver found himself charged with auto theft and driving without a license.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Arts Center Sells Its Name
description: First, the Continental Airlines Arena. And now, the PNC Bank Arts Center? Officials of the Garden State Arts Center plan to announce a name change today resulting from a sponsorship agreement with the Pittsburgh-based PNC Bank Corporation, said Joseph E. Buckelew, chairman of the New Jersey Highway Authority, which operates the center. The sponsorship deal appears to be part of an effort by PNC, which bought the Edison-based Midlantic Bank a year ago, to raise its profile in New Jersey. Last year, Continental Airlines agreed to pay the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority $29 million over 11 years for the right to rename the Brendan Byrne Arena at the Meadowlands. Mr. Buckelew would not say how much PNC is paying for the Garden Center name change. TERRY PRISTIN

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: European Championship

title: Chrysler Reports Strong Vehicle Sales in June
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that sales rose 1 percent last month to 228,828 vehicles as customers continued to snap up options-laded mini-vans and cars.

title: Forced H.I.V. Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan Is Planning Vast Increase in Science Research Budget
description: IN an effort to make Japan as strong in pioneering research as it is in product development, the Government is planning a vast increase in public spending on science and technology and an overhaul of the decrepit and rigid university system that many see as stifling creativity.

title: Strike by Fuelers Fails to Delay Planes
description: Four hundred workers who fuel airplanes at Kennedy International Airport went on strike early yesterday, but Port Authority officials said the walkout had not delayed flights at the airport.

title: Doles Campaign (for Book) in New York
description: From the morning talk shows to a lunchtime book signing in midtown, Bob Dole the Presidential candidate became Bob Dole the author yesterday, trading in the indignities of the campaign trail for the very different indignities of a book tour.

title: Rethink Ruling on Gay Ban, Appeals Panel Tells Judge
description: In the latest test of the Clinton Administration's "don't ask, don't tell" policy for homosexuals in the military, a Federal appeals court panel in Manhattan yesterday sent the case back to a district court judge to determine the constitutionality of the military's ban on homosexual actions.

title: The Limits of Innocent Confusion
description: The case of the mishandled F.B.I. files does not look any better with the passage of time. The latest White House gambit is to suggest the whole affair started with a hiring decision by Vincent Foster, the White House counsel who killed himself in 1993. It is too easy to place responsibility for this sorry episode on a man who cannot defend himself.

title: BASEBALL;A Blast and a Bunt Give Yanks' Key All He Needs
description: Mike Aldrete breezed around the bases, was mobbed in the dugout and then sneaked a peek into the left-field seats once and then twice. He was searching for the baseball that he had sliced for a home run off Roger Clemens. Perhaps he was also making sure the ball actually had found a home. It had.

title: Sale by Hancock Is Seen
description: The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company is negotiating to sell its brokerage subsidiaries -- Tucker Anthony Inc. and Sutro & Company -- to the units' managers for $150 million to $225 million, according to Tucker Anthony's chief financial officer, Lawrence Kirshbaum. Officials of the holding company for Tucker Anthony and Sutro met today with Hancock executives to begin formal talks, he said. A Hancock spokesman had no immediate comment about the talks. John Hancock said in May that it planned to hold sale talks with Freedom executives. With combined capital of about $100 million, the brokerage firms are tiny compared with Hancock's $50.78 billion of assets.

title: Dole Declares His Running Mate Could Support Abortion Rights
description: In a gesture of conciliation to moderates in the Republican Party, Bob Dole said yesterday that he could accept a running mate who supported abortion rights -- even Christine Todd Whitman, the New Jersey Governor who parted with Mr. Dole to support President Clinton's veto of a ban on a type of late-term abortion.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Checks in the (Early) Mail
description: Homestead Rebate checks, traditionally mailed at the end of October, will be sent out July 31, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's office said yesterday. Some 1.3 million elderly and disabled residents are eligible for rebates ranging from $35 to $500, depending on the recipient's income. The Homestead Rebate program, which was intended to reduce property taxes, was started in 1976 as part of the compromise reached by the Legislature and Gov. Brendan T. Byrne when the state income tax was enacted.

title: Justices Decline Affirmative-Action Case
description: Sidestepping a major controversy over affirmative action in higher education, the Supreme Court said today that it would not hear an appeal by the State of Texas from a ruling that barred public universities from taking race into account in selecting their students.

title: HIGH COURT FINDS DAMAGE TO S.& L.'S FROM RULE CHANGE
description: In a case that could cost the Federal Government billions of dollars in breach-of- contract damages to the savings and loan industry, the Supreme Court ruled today that the Government knowingly went back on its word through accounting changes that plunged three savings and loans into insolvency.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FPA MEDICAL MANAGEMENT TO BUY 2 DOCTORS GROUPS
description: FPA Medical Management Inc. said yesterday that it had bought two Foundation HealthCorporation physician groups and would buy 30 health care centers for a total of $220 million in cash and stock. FPA Medical, based in San Diego, expects the acquisitions to raise membership in its health maintenance organization by 294,000 members, to more than 630,000. The transactions is also expected to accelerate FPA's expansion into Florida and Arizona and add about $60 million to the company's revenue in 1996. On May 20, FPA said it would buy Sterling Healthcare Group Inc. for as much as $186 million in stock, making FPA the fifth-largest physician practice managers in the nation. FPA organizes and manages networks of doctors and negotiates contracts with health plans.

title: INSIDE
description: Refuting Saudi Militants

title: 2 More Hospitals Hasten to Join Forces
description: Two of New York's largest teaching hospitals, Beth Israel Medical Center and Long Island Jewish Medical Center, announced yesterday that they intend to merge, creating a far-flung health empire in the city and its suburbs.

title: Ex-Officer Admits Lying in a Shooting
description: A former New York City police officer who was accidentally shot by a colleague after a long night of drinking admitted that he had falsely reported the shooting as being the work of a mugger, according to Federal court papers.

title: William T. Cahill, 84, Former Governor
description: William T. Cahill, who as the Governor of New Jersey from 1970 to 1974, brought the New York Giants to New Jersey but was undone politically by scandals involving trusted friends and by opposition to his tax proposals, died yesterday at a daughter's house in Haddonfield, N.J. He was 84.

title: 10 Billion Breach of Contract
description: The Supreme Court probably socked taxpayers with a $10 billion bill yesterday when it ruled the Government was liable for breaking its contract with investors who took over failed savings and loan institutions during the 1980's. Despite the financial pain, the Court made the right decision. Investors took over bankrupt thrifts because the Government promised them regulatory and accounting relief. Congress later reneged on that promise, imposing large losses on investors.

title: Shanghai Journal;In 75 Years, a Party's Long March to Irrelevance
description: In a small brick home on a leafy side street in this city, a dozen idealistic young men gathered around a scuffed wooden table 75 years ago today to launch China's Communist Party, or so the history books say.

title: Woman Sets Mark in Vault
description: Emma George of Australia broke her own world record for the women's pole vault with an effort of 14 feet 6 inches at a women's track meet today. George topped her previous mark of 14-5 3/4.

title: Bomb-Plot Defendants Fight Evidence of Plan to Harm Pope
description: Lawyers for Ramzi Ahmed Yousef yesterday fought a request by prosecutors to introduce into his month-old terrorism trial the existence of a separate plot to harm Pope John Paul II during his visit to the Philippines in January 1995.

title: Psinet to Sell Consumer Internet Division
description: Psinet Inc., one of the country's largest Internet service providers, said yesterday that it would sell its consumer Internet subscriber base of about 100,000 customers and a support center to Mindspring Enterprises Inc. of Atlanta for $23 million.

title: Geraldine Bone Zorbaugh, 91, Broadcast Lawyer and a Trailblazer forWomen
description: Geraldine Bone Zorbaugh, a lawyer who was a trailblazer for women in the upper ranks of broadcast networks' legal staffs in the 1950's, died on Saturday at Moore Regional Hospital in Pinehurst, N.C. She was 91 and lived in a retirement home in Pinehurst.

title: Medical Sleuths in the Fruit Market;Tracking an Intestinal Ailment Possibly Linked to Berries
description: Three days after an intense bout of diarrhea, Maggie Simmons felt well enough to stick with plans for a tour of schools with her college-bound daughter. But the exotic parasite multiplying in her small intestine was just getting started.

title: OLYMPICS;Defections By Cubans Confirmed
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service confirmed today that two members of Cuba's Olympic boxing team had defected to the United States from Mexico on Sunday and said that they had been sent to a holding center about 100 miles east of San Diego until their case is processed.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Mongolian Centrists Win
description: The opposition Democratic Union Coalition upset the former Communists in parliamentary elections on Sunday, winning 50 of the 76 seats in parliament, the General Election Committee said today.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants Enlist Strahan For One More Season
description: The Giants have taken a big step in securing one of their best defensive players for at least one season by signing Mike Strahan. The question is: Will Strahan be a Giant after this season?

title: Pamela Mason, 80, An Author, Actress And Talk-Show Host
description: Pamela Mason, an author, actress, talk-show host and former wife of the actor James Mason, died on Saturday at her home in Beverly Hills, Calif. She was 80.

title: After 2 Years, Utility Ends Merger Plan
description: After spending $16 million over two years and getting past many regulatory hurdles, the Washington Water Power Company said yesterday that it would end its effort to merge with Sierra Pacific Resources.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Go the Distance With Tyson? Dream On
description: BRUCE SELDON has this dream about his July 13 fight in Las Vegas, Nev., against the heavily favored MIKE TYSON for Seldon's World Boxing Association heavyweight title. Seldon cuts Tyson in the early rounds. Then Tyson cuts Seldon. Seldon floors Tyson. Then Tyson floors Seldon. The fight is even going into the last round, and Seldon's trainer tells him he has to win the round to keep the title.

title: BASEBALL;With Voter Turnout Heavy, Griffey Tops All-Star Poll
description: Ken Griffey Jr. and Mike Piazza, winners of the annual popularity poll known as the All-Star Game balloting, continue to prove that no two routes to major league stardom are alike.

title: NYC;Here, Too, A Terrible Beauty
description: WOULD this fractious city be your idea of the perfect place to teach peaceful ways of settling disputes, especially to pilgrims from a land whose very name has come to mean endless conflict and hatred?

title: Researcher's Resentment Over Subpoena From City
description: New York City's investigation of an outbreak of an intestinal ailment caused by an exotic microbe has created an extraordinary conflict between the Health Department and a leading scientist over reporting cases of the ailment, cyclospora.

title: Tom Chauncey, Station Owner, Dies at 83
description: Tom Chauncey, a former owner of radio and television stations in Phoenix and Tucson and an influential collector of Arabian horses, died on Thursday at his ranch in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 83.

title: Portrait of Oklahoma City Bomb Case Fills Out
description: When Terry L. Nichols took his wife and child out of a house filled with guns and ammunition at 2:42 P.M. on April 21, 1995, two days after a bomb killed 168 people in the Oklahoma City Federal Building, three F.B.I. agents were already watching him. A single-engine F.B.I. airplane was circling overhead, and a surveillance team was on its way with orders to keep out of sight.

title: Mastercard Bars Banks From Links With American Express
description: Mastercard International Inc., the marketer of the second-most-popular credit card in the nation, said yesterday that it would no longer allow its member banks to issue some competing cards -- mainly those of the American Express Company -- in the United States.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 2 about a trend toward smaller, low-rise buildings in public housing projects referred incorrectly to the public housing due for demolition in Houston, Los Angeles, Kansas City, Denver, Atlanta and New Orleans. Those buildings are low-rise projects, not high-rise.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Figure in Amazon Killing Captured After 3 Years
description: The cattle rancher who ordered the slaying of an activist defending the Amazon rain forest in 1988 has been arrested after more than three years as a fugitive. The rancher, Darly Alves da Silva, was arrested on Sunday near the remote Amazon town of Medicilandia, about 1,250 miles north of Sao Paulo, federal police officials said today.

title: Teams Chosen for World Bridge Event
description: Teams from Chicago and New York will represent the United States in the 1996 world bridge championships to be played on the Greek island of Rhodes in October.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Excerpts From Ruling Against the Government on S.& L. Takeovers
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today in United States v. the Winstar Corporation, holding that the Federal Government breached its contracts with three savings and loan institutions and is liable to them for damages as a result of accounting changes made by the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery and Enforcement Act of 1989.

title: Madagascar Reptile Theft Hits Rarest Of Tortoises
description: SOMEHOW, one expects the scene of one of the heists of the century to be more dramatic: a vault shattered by dynamite, guards slumped dead at their posts, handfuls of missed diamonds scattered about, sirens wailing through the London or Zurich night.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;One Black Chosen for Irvin Jury
description: A woman who had been convicted of marijuana possession two years ago was the only black juror chosen yesterday for the 12-member panel in MICHAEL IRVIN's drug-possession trial. The only other minority member on the six-man, six-woman jury is an Asian woman. Both alternates are women; one is black.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;University of Miami Players Arrested
description: Two University of Miami football players suspended for taking part in the assault of a track star were arrested yesterday, the police said. Linebackers JAMES BURGESS, 25, and JEREMY TAYLOR, 22, surrendered to the police and were ordered by a judge to wear electronic bracelets so authorities can monitor their movements.

title: New Name in Kansas City
description: The Kansas City Power and Light Company and Utilicorp United Inc., planning a $1.7 billion merger, said today that they had chosen Maxim Energies Inc. as the name for the combined company. The merger is being contested by Western Resources Inc., which is taking its $1.9 billion offer for Kansas City Power directly to shareholders. Kansas City Power set Aug. 7 for a special shareholders meeting to vote on the Utilicorp merger. Utilicorp's meeting, announced earlier, will be on Aug. 14.

title: Aerospatiale Planning to Merge With Dassault Aviation in 1997
description: The French state-owned aircraft manufacturer Aerospatiale will merge in January with Dassault Aviation, a family-controlled builder of jet fighters, the Government announced here today.

title: The Bosnian Minuet
description: The tussle during the past few days in Bosnia between the Bosnian Serb leadership and the West was all hauntingly familiar.

title: Borland's Chief Executive Is Expected to Resign Today
description: Borland International will announce on Tuesday that its chief executive is resigning in the face of a disastrous quarter that ended last month, according to several people close to the software developer.

title: Observer;Beep Beep King
description: Let's pretend that the miracle of modern communications was as inescapable in 1776 as it is today. Imagine King George the Third glued to his television set. Is it the tennis at Wimbledon that fascinates him? Is it yet another John Payne movie on AMC?

title: U.S. Objects to Details of Plan To Let Iraq Sell Oil for Food
description: A plan allowing Iraq to sell limited amounts of oil to meet urgent civilian needs was thrown into jeopardy today when the Clinton Administration said Baghdad was trying to twist the exemption to import high-technology goods in violation of economic sanctions.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MICHAEL FOODS TO BUY EGG PRODUCTS COMPANY
description: Michael Foods Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Papetti's Hygrade Egg Products Inc. for $85 million in cash and stock and assume $28 million in debt. The Minneapolis-based Michael Foods had 1995 revenue of $536.6 million. The food processor and distributor has particular interest in egg products, refrigerated grocery products, frozen and refrigerated potato products and specialty dairy products. It said Papetti's annual revenue exceeded $275 million. The company, which is based in Elizabeth, N.J., makes processed-egg products. Shares of Michael Foods rose $1.625, to $13.25.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Microsoft Names Cohn & Wells
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it has selected Cohn & Wells in San Francisco to handle its business-to-business direct marketing account, which had been handled on a project basis by Anderson & Lembke in San Francisco, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies. Billings were estimated at $10 million. Greg Perlot, director for advertising and corporate research at Microsoft in Redmond, Wash., said the decision came after a two-month review. Anderson & Lembke continues to handle product and interactive advertising for Microsoft.

title: Legislature Tentatively Agrees to a Budget That Restores Many ofPataki's Cuts
description: Under tentative budget agreements coming together between the Legislature and Gov. George E. Pataki, legislative leaders have restored many of the Governor's cuts to mental health and higher education programs and rejected most of his criminal justice proposals, negotiators said today.

title: OLYMPICS;U.S. Women to Be Led By a Karolyi: Martha
description: From start to finish, the last night of the Olympic gymnastics trials belonged to the women. The early evening belonged to the seven American teen-agers who will potentially form the best women's team in United States history. Late night belonged to Martha Karolyi and Mary Lee Tracy, who were named the two coaches of that team after lengthy deliberation on Sunday by a selection committee composed entirely of women. It is the first time that both coaches are women.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WINSTAR COMMUNICATIONS PLANS TO ACQUIRE MILLIWAVE
description: Winstar Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Milliwave L.P., a company with wireless communications licenses reaching a potential 160 million customers, for $125 million. Winstar, a telecommunications-services concern based in New York, agreed to pay $40 million in cash and $85 million in stock for the closely held firm. Winstar said it would help manage and develop Milliwave's licenses before the sale closes in 1997. Winstar said Milliwave's licenses would add more than 50 new markets to Winstar's operating territory. Winstar's stock rose $4.0625, or 16 percent, to close at $29 in trading on the Nasdaq.

title: Consumer Spending Jumps And Manufacturing Surges
description: Consumer spending jumped in May and manufacturing activity surged last month, reports showed today, the latest signs of solid economic growth ahead of a meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers.

title: BASEBALL;Everett Asks to Be Traded
description: Carl Everett, who has been relegated to pinch-hitting and pinch-running duty, said today that he had asked to be traded from the Mets.

title: ON BASEBALL;Some Payback for '78? Yanks Laugh at Idea
description: Maybe Sunday was a false start. Maybe it's now that the Boston comeback will begin.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Life Haunted by a Seldom-Seen Weird Father
description: HALF A LIFE By Jill Ciment 210 pages. Crown Publishers. $23.

title: No to College Admission Case
description: The Supreme Court refused to hear an appeal by the State of Texas from an appellate ruling that barred public universities from considering race in selecting students. Page A12.

title: Mr. Karadzic's Last Evasion
description: Radovan Karadzic, the hard-line Bosnian Serb political boss, has once again outmaneuvered European and American diplomats and kept himself in position to undermine the credibility of Bosnia's forthcoming elections. The Dayton peace process cannot afford any more such setbacks.

title: Perot's Party Plans to Mail Survey to Select a Nominee
description: Organizers of the Reform Party will formally open their nationwide search for a 1996 Presidential nominee this week by mailing supporters a candidate-preference survey that mentions only the names of the party founder, Ross Perot, and former Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado.

title: Margaux Hemingway Is Dead; Actress and Model Was 41
description: The badly decomposed body of the actress and model Margaux Hemingway, who was once described as the face of a generation, was discovered by friends yesterday in her home in Santa Monica, Calif., the police said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Clinton Administration's handling of F.B.I. background checks referred incorrectly to George Stephanopoulos's appearance on a Sunday television interview program. ABC News invited White House representation on "This Week" after the network had scheduled Gary Aldrich, a former F.B.I. agent who has made allegations against the Clintons in a book. Mr. Stephanopoulos, senior adviser to the President, was not invited in response to a White House complaint about Mr. Aldrich's appearance.

title: Spanish Fly Effective When Mate of Choice Is Fire-Colored Beetle
description: ONCE thought to have the power to drive lovers into frenzies of passion, Spanish fly, a purported aphrodisiac that is thoroughly ineffective in reality, has long had a seedy reputation as a sexual snake oil. But in a redemption of sorts, scientists have found that Spanish fly can indeed make males absolutely irresistible -- if only to females with six legs and wings.

title: H.I.V. Risk From Blood Transfusion Is 2 in Million
description: The latest scientific calculations put the risk of catching the AIDS virus from a blood transfusion at just two in a million.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;For Birds and Their Watchers: 2 CD-ROM Guides
description: TWO classic series of bird books have recently been given the full-bore CD-ROM multimedia treatment. For about $50 each, Peterson Multimedia Guides: North American Birds (Houghton Mifflin Interactive, for Windows only) and National Audubon Society Interactive CD-ROM Guide to North American Birds (Knopf New Media, for Windows and Macintosh) manage to pack a great deal of data onto the familiar iridescent disks.

title: CHRONICLE
description: IMELDA MARCOS, the former First Lady of the Philippines, was taken to a Manila hospital Sunday for treatment of a heart condition, Reuters reported yesterday. Mrs. Marcos, who turns 67 today, is under observation, but her physicians were not available for comment.

title: Canadian Marks Holiday on Shuttle
description: A Canadian astronaut aboard the space shuttle Columbia sent down Canada Day greetings today to Government leaders in Ottawa.

title: Australian Foes Fight New Law : A Euthanasia Battle
description: SINGAPORE  A law permitting voluntary euthanasia came into force in Australia's Northern Territory on Monday, but legal challenges seem likely to prevent any terminally ill people from having their lives ended under its provisions.

title: Iranians Pose a Real Threat to Mideast Security;China and Cuba
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Child Who Rolls With the Punches
description: This is the realm of "the voiceless," Lenox Avenue between 133d and 134th Streets in Harlem, where Precious, the teen-age heroine of "Push," a new novel by the poet Sapphire, lives.

title: No Headline
description: It's a totally dysfunctional process. We're probably closer to the 1957 Bulgarian parliament than we are to a modern state legislature."

title: Despite Confession, Man Is Acquitted in Blaze That Killed Firefighter
description: A jury acquitted a man yesterday of setting a fire that killed a Manhattan firefighter in 1994, even though at least some jurors believed that he had set the blaze.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rail Line Revival Sought
description: By New Jersey Transit's estimates, restoring service on the West Trenton rail line would require an initial investment of $30 million and cost $2.5 million a year to operate -- all for a projected 577 regular riders. The line, which linked West Trenton with the Raritan Valley Line in Bound Brook, was discontinued in 1982. But today, United States Representative Bob Franks, Republican of New Providence, will join local officials at a rally to call for bringing back the line. They say it is needed because of population growth in Mercer and Somerset counties.

title: In Science Fraud Case, Justice Is Denied;Valid Concerns
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;TYCO INTERNATIONAL ACQUIRES THORN SECURITY
description: Tyco International Ltd. said yesterday that it had acquired Thorn Security Group Ltd., a British fire alarm and security systems company, for $214 million. Tyco, a diversified manufacturer based in Exeter, N.H., is already the world's largest manufacturer and installer of fire-protection systems. Thorn Security, based in Sunbury-on-Thames, England, was sold by Thorn EMI P.L.C., Hambro European Ventures Ltd. and the management at Thorn Security. Thorn Security has annual sales of about $300 million. Tyco makes disposable medical products, packaging materials, flow-control products, and electrical and electronic components. It operates in more than 50 countries and has more than $5 billion in revenues.

title: New Era in Albany Hospital-Rate Plan
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders have agreed on a wide-ranging plan to abolish New York's decades-old policy of setting the rates that hospitals can charge for medical care, from stitches in the emergency room to open-heart surgery.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Singers From Brazil Who Are Worlds Apart
description: Paulinho da Viola and Zizzi Possi, the Brazilian singers who shared a JVC Jazz Festival bill on Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall, have one thing in common. They both prize songs with sinuous melodies, thoughtful lyrics and musicianly twists. Beyond that, they were poles apart.

title: Q&A
description: Bearded Women

title: Mobil to Sell MCI Cards
description: The Mobil Corporation has signed a two-year contract with MCI Communications to sell prepaid long-distance calling cards, MCI said today. The cards will be sold, beginning this month, at as many as 4,600 gasoline stations and convenience stores.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about workers who use their office computers to retrieve sexually explicit images from the World Wide Web misstated the relationship between a mouse click and a hit. When a mouse click calls up a Web page, the page may consist of numerous files, and a hit is then recorded for each file.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Campbell-Ewald Promotes 3 Executives
description: Three executives at Campbell-Ewald Advertising, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in Warren, Mich., have been promoted as part of a long-planned reorganization as Richard D. O'Connor, chairman and chief executive, plans for his retirement on Jan. 1.

title: TV NOTES;WNYC-TV Signs Off
description: The public television station WNYC-TV ceased to exist this week, replaced by WBIS-TV, the new outlet formed by ITT and Dow Jones, the partnership that purchased the license of WNYC-TV from the city of New York for $207 million.

title: Meeting U.S. Envoy, Turkish Premier Takes a Pro-Arab Stance
description: Turkey's new Prime Minister, the first representing an Islamic political party since the founding of the republic in 1923, told visiting State Department officials today that Israel should withdraw from the Golan Heights and that he intends to seek closer ties with the Arab world.

title: Cost-Cutting By Hospitals To Accelerate
description: When the deal freeing hospital rates is signed in Albany, hospitals across the state will find themselves consolidating departments, merging with other institutions to give themselves greater bargaining power, cutting programs and services that lose money and laying off employees.

title: The Battle of the Strawberry Fields
description: The strawberry fields stretch as far as the eye can see here, the pickers jackknifed over the low-growing leaves as their knuckles graze through them, their fingers stained a sweet, sticky maroon.

title: Father Who Evaded Support Pleads Guilty
description: Jeffrey A. Nichols, the nation's most infamous deadbeat dad, who is believed to owe a record amount of unpaid child support, pleaded guilty yesterday to violating a four-year-old Federal law that prohibits people from crossing state lines to avoid making the payments.

title: Wine Talk
description: Downsizing? Unemployment? Lower standards of living? Economic uncertainty? Maybe where you are, but not 400 miles southwest of Paris in the staid old city of Bordeaux. These are heady days for the Bordelais: they're having their best wine year in a long, long time.

title: NASA PICKS MODEL FOR A NEW FLEET OF SPACE VEHICLES
description: NASA selected the Lockheed Martin Corporation today to build a futuristic experimental rocket that could lead to drastic cuts in the cost of putting payloads into space.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Forgoing Surprises For the Sake Of Fun
description: Is it a parable, or simple play? With Pilobolus, one is never quite sure. And that is the case with "Aeros," a new dance presented by Pilobolus on Monday night at the Joyce Theater, where the company performs through July 20.

title: Swiss Banking Group Shifts Leadership and Will Cut Jobs
description: CS Holding A.G., anxious to revive its lagging earnings, named a new chief executive and other top officials today and said it would cut 5,000 jobs and create four new divisions.

title: Russians, In Big Shift, Now Court South Korea
description: With breathtaking speed, Russia's Far East has switched in five years from propping up North Korea's Communist Government to welcoming South Korean investment and trade.

title: On Religious Conversions: From Luther's Folly to Our Own;A Most Precious Gift
description: To the Editor:

title: The Dangers of Trial by Dingell
description: In 1991, shortly after becoming director of the National Institutes of Health, I was summoned to Capitol Hill by the staff of Representative John Dingell, the powerful Democratic chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. The panel's Oversight and Investigations Subcommittee, which he also led, wanted to discuss draft reports being prepared by the fraud office at N.I.H. in two high-profile scientific misconduct investigations.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Water Main Break Cuts Stuyvesant Town Service
description: A 12-inch water main ruptured in Stuyvesant Town early yesterday, leaving the entire complex of 39 buildings and 20,000 tenants without water for much of the day.

title: Public Service Plans to Sell Exploration Unit
description: Public Service Enterprise Group, the New Jersey utility, said yesterday that it would sell its oil and natural gas exploration unit to Noble Affiliates Inc. for $775 million.

title: Cut Wine Prices
description: To The Living Section: I have just read Frank J. Prial's June 26 Wine Talk column inquiring into the reason for sluggish wine consumption and was amazed that you failed to discuss what I believe is the major reason: price! More specifically, it is the unconscionable restaurant markup of even ordinary wines. (At least in stores, reasonably priced wines are available.)

title: Sybase Sees Loss in Quarter And Plans Layoffs of 600
description: Continuing to stumble while its competitors prosper, Sybase Inc., the data base software company, said yesterday that it expected a $20 million loss in the second quarter, instead of the small profit analysts had expected, and that it would cut about 10 percent of its 6,200 employees.

title: An Ultramodern Design, Old-Fashioned Outrage
description: Throughout the 1980's and beyond, while France's Socialist Government embarked on a series of daring architectural projects that eventually transformed the face of Paris, Britain's Conservative Government refused to invest taxpayers' money in new museums, theaters or opera houses.

title: OLYMPICS;The Dream Team Plans To Take Fastest Route To Another Gold Medal
description: The public pronouncements of his coach sounded so ideal, it was as if Anfernee Hardaway had been placed in the perfect situation. There is nothing for the American men to hide in their pursuit of another gold medal. They will pressure end to end, push the ball up the floor and turn the Olympics into a 91-foot-10-inch game, as far as international rules will let them go.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jury Hears of Irvin's Prints
description: Prosecutors told the jury at Michael Irvin's drug trial today that fingerprints from two plates on which cocaine was found at a motel last spring matched Irvin's prints and that Angela Beck, who was with Irvin, was surprised when the drugs were found in her handbag.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Pork Tenderloin: Sweet, Sour and Easy
description: This quick meal of pork tenderloin paired with onions and peppers is perfect after a long day of work, when minimal cooking is quite enough. The lime-ginger marinade adds just the right touch of tartness and sweetness. If maple syrup is not in your cupboard, honey may be substituted.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MATTEL EXPECTS DISAPPOINTING SALES AND EARNINGS
description: The toy maker Mattel Inc. said yesterday that its sales and net income for the second quarter would be about the same as last year, meaning that they would fall short of expectations. Mattel, which makes the Barbie doll, said, however, that it still expected an increase of at least 15 percent in its earnings for the year. The stock of Mattel fell by $3.125 a share, to $26, on the New York Stock Exchange. In the second quarter of last year, the company, which is based in El Segundo, Calif., reported a profit of $67.5 million, or 24 cents a share. Analysts surveyed by First Call were expecting earnings of around 26 cents a share in the latest quarter. A spokesman for Mattel declined to comment on reasons for the disappointing results.

title: Diners Get More Discounts As Card Competition Rises
description: VALUE is the dining watchword of the 90's. And today, diners can take advantage of more discount programs than ever before.

title: Agents Seize Arsenal of Rifles and Bomb-Making Material in ArizonaMilitia Inquiry
description: With residential streets cordoned off for fear of an accidental explosion, Federal agents today seized about 90 high-powered rifles and hundreds of pounds of a bomb-making compound from the shabby bungalow of a man whom officials identified as the ordnance specialist of a local paramilitary group.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;With Rosie O'Donnell, Daytime Revisits Its Roots
description: Back to the future in jolly time. Rosie O'Donnell wants to return to the good old daytime-talk days of Merv Griffin and Mike Douglas, the days before unctuous hosts zapped dysfunctional guests with psychobabble. She wants her show to be positive, friendly, informative and entertaining. In just a few weeks, "The Rosie O'Donnell Show" has shaken up the daytime scene by demonstrating that something old can indeed be new again. The syndicated program can be seen on weekdays at 10 on Channel 7 in New York.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Lowe Group Buys Stake in Interfocus
description: The Lowe Group, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, said yesterday that it had acquired a majority stake in Interfocus, an integrated marketing agency in London that will be merged with the Brompton Agency, Lowe's own integrated marketing shop in London. Terms were not disclosed.

title: On Religious Conversions: From Luther's Folly to Our Own;Never a Convert
description: To the Editor:

title: Deepest Offshore Oil Platform Planned for Gulf of Mexico
description: The Shell Oil Company and three partners plan to build the deepest offshore platform yet in the Gulf of Mexico, Shell announced yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was a once-in-a-lifetime invitation, so how could CAROLE FRANCO of New Paltz, N.Y., refuse when her longtime friend ROBERT DAVIS called from London to ask her to be Lady Mayoress of Westminster?

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: 'Cool' Record Labels Regain the Beat
description: LONDON  Andy Saunders has a simple explanation as to why cutting-edge musical talents increasingly shun major record companies in favor of signing on with small independent labels like his.

title: World News Briefs;Czech Premier Appoints A Coalition Government
description: Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus of the Czech Republic formally submitted a proposed new coalition Cabinet to President Vaclav Havel today, a step toward forming a minority Government after inconclusive elections.

title: FILM REVIEW;John Travolta, Playing Nice, Gets Smart
description: Phenomenon" has all the ingredients of a pleasingly sentimental success: a neighborly setting in neo-Capra country, a director (Jon Turteltaub) whose last film was so beguiling ("While You Were Sleeping"), and John Travolta, himself no stranger to charm. But "Phenomenon" proves so different from what it first looks like that during the grimness of the film's final half hour, jaws may drop. A whopping wrong turn throws this lightweight, benign-looking movie terminally off course.

title: ATLANTA 1996: OLYMPIC PROFILE;Tulu Is Running for Herself and Millions of Sisters
description: On a suffocating night at the 1992 Summer Olympics, Elana Meyer of South Africa drew into the lead of the women's 10,000-meter race. With 16 of 25 laps completed, only Derartu Tulu of Ethiopia remained with her. For eight laps they ran alone. Meyer dripped sweat and sponged water on her head, and the strain of setting the pace began to show in her face. Tulu ran patiently and coolly, wearing a T-shirt as if she felt a slight chill on this muggy evening.

title: Pillsbury in Brazil Deal
description: The Pillsbury Company said today that it had bought a Brazilian dough and pasta business from a unit of the French brewer Danone Group for $50 million. The purchase includes plants in Sao Paulo and the Frescarini and Terra Branca brands. The Frescarini pasta business has annual sales of about $45 million, Pillsbury said. Pillsbury, the Minneapolis-based unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. of Britain, produces grocery items, frozen foods and refrigerated dough products.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Judge Tells Official She's Out
description: Maureen Kaman is giving up the keys to the tax assessor's office, but she is not giving up the fight. Ms. Kaman, Montague's tax assessor since 1992, was dismissed last week after the Township Committee determined that her term had expired in 1994 and that she had never been officially reappointed. But Ms. Kaman contended that the township's failure to take action on her $13,000-a-year part-time post in 1994 amounted to a de facto four-year reappointment. She refused to turn over the keys to the office and filing cabinets, according to a lawyer for the township.

title: Sears-Whirlpool Team
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said today that it had decided keep the Whirlpool Corporation as the sole supplier of its Kenmore washing machines, ending the biggest phase of a review of Sears vendors. Sears, the nation's largest appliance retailer, said it had wrapped up six months of negotiations with manufacturers of its Kenmore appliance lines, including laundry products, refrigerators, stoves and dishwashers. As a result of the evaluation, the Maytag Corporation's Jenn-Air unit will begin making countertop stoves for Sears. But few other changes were made in its relationships with vendors. Whirlpool has been making washing machines for Sears for 80 years.

title: FILM REVIEW;Testing 2 Theories on Pasolini's Death
description: The United States isn't the only country that enjoys feasting on juicy conspiracy theories. "Who Killed Pasolini?," Marco Tullio Giordana's investigative docudrama into the slaying of the Italian film maker, who was bludgeoned to death in 1976 in the Roman suburb of Ostia, suggests that it was a political assassination carried out by right-wing thugs. However tantalizing this theory may be, the movie offers no solid evidence to support it other than ominous rumblings and rumors of a plot.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMPUNET COMPUTER OF GERMANY AGREES TO BE SOLD
description: GE Capital Services, part of the General Electric Company, signed an agreement yesterday to buy Compunet Computer A.G., a German provider of computer services. G.E. did not disclose the price. Compunet, which employs 1,850 people, had sales of $1 billion in 1995. The company, which is closely held, specializes in helping large corporations make their computer systems work together. It is based in Kerpen, Germany, near the Belgian border.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BBN TO SELL MAJORITY STAKE IN SOFTWARE UNIT
description: The BBN Corporation, a provider of Internet access, agreed yesterday to sell a majority stake in its software-making unit, the BBN Domain Corporation, to an investment group led by ABS Capital Partners, which will buy $36 million worth of preferred stock in Domain. BBN, which changed its name late last year from Bolt Beranek & Newman, said it would retain a minority interest of 15 percent of the voting stock of Domain, which is based in Cambridge, Mass. ABS Capital, which is privately held, is based in Baltimore.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Broker Suspends 3 In Metals Investigation
description: A leading British-based metals brokerage firm, Rudolf Wolff, has suspended three employees in the Tokyo office of its Japanese subsidiary in connection with an inquiry into the Sumitomo Corporation copper-trading scandal, a spokesman for Wolff said yesterday.

title: Antitrust Case To End for I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Justice Department have reached an agreement to phase out the remaining terms of a 1956 antitrust decree, the Government said today.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday, showing the top executive woman at each of nine large Wall Street firms, misstated the responsibilities of one executive, Wendy L. de Monchaux of Bear, Stearns & Company. She is head of derivatives and the fixed income financing desk. The head of fixed income is Warren J. Spector.

title: Japanese Stocks Higher
description: Japanese stocks traded higher here today. At the close of trading, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 31.05 points -- or about one-tenth of 1 percent -- at 22,379.02. On Tuesday, the Nikkei index fell 107.52 points.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Peru Phone Offering Fetches $1 Billion
description: Peru has raised $1 billion by selling a portion of its stake in the phone monopoly, Telefonica del Peru.

title: At the Nation's Table: Fort Worth;Banning Murder From the Menu
description: When a restaurant opens in an infamous mansion, the scene of a sensational, unsolved double murder, is it realistic to expect that customers will come for the food?

title: CYCLING;Team From Paris Suburbs Is Showing It Belongs
description: Dozens of residents of the working-class Paris suburb of Aubervilliers drove north today for the third daily stage of the Tour de France, to support their hometown team in its initial tour -- and to watch their tax francs at work.

title: On Religious Conversions: From Luther's Folly to Our Own;Divisive Evangelism
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Leaves Key Operation Of Pepsico in Sudden Move
description: In an announcement that took executives and analysts in the beverage industry by surprise, Pepsico Inc. said yesterday that Christopher A. Sinclair, head of its $11 billion worldwide beverage operations, had resigned for "personal reasons" after fewer than four months in the job.

title: Satisfying Appetites As Varied as New York
description: NEW YORK is the best place in the world for people who like to eat.

title: Stretching a Fourth of July Holiday Into a Five-Day Weekend
description: Neil Bender finished all of this week's business meetings early yesterday morning. Then he went home to the West Village, put on khaki shorts and sunglasses, stuffed his computer in a briefcase and headed off to the Hamptons. His wife, Marika Marko, had ended her work week even earlier, on Monday evening. They were on the jitney by 1 P.M.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SAN DIEGO DEVELOPER TO SELL MOST OF ITS REAL ESTATE
description: Mission West Properties, a real estate developer, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell substantially all of its real estate assets to DMB/SVP California Investments L.L.C. for $42 million in cash. Mission West, which is based in San Diego, said it would use the proceeds to repay outstanding mortgage debt of about $31.3 million on the assets. After completion of the transaction, which is expected in late August, Mission West said it would distribute to shareholders a substantial portion of the remaining cash proceeds, after paying corporate taxes and transaction costs.

title: Official Plane Sold by Pataki
description: A 30-year-old state-owned airplane that carried three New York governors and became an issue in the race between George E. Pataki and Mario M. Cuomo has been sold.

title: After Fires, Some Black Churches Face Insurance Troubles
description: A few of the black Southern congregations whose churches have burned over the last 18 months are reporting problems in keeping insurance coverage or obtaining new policies.

title: In Hemingways' Story, a Turn Foretold
description: It was only in the final weeks of her unhappy life that Margaux Hemingway finally began reading the novels and essays of her grandfather, Ernest Hemingway, a literary icon of the 20th century.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BEACON GROUP INVESTMENT FUND TO ACQUIRE AMBAR
description: Ambar Inc., a provider of fluids and chemical and environmental services to the oil and natural gas industries, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by Beacon Group Energy Investment Fund L.P. for $18 a share, or about $67 million. The fund, which is affiliated with the Beacon Group, an investment fund in New York, has investments primarily in the energy industry. As part of the transaction, it has agreed to buy the 51 percent of Ambar's shares that are owned by Randolph M. Moity, the company's chairman, and the 6 percent owned by Kenneth Boutte, an Ambar director. The stock of Ambar, which is based in Lafayette, La., jumped $3.1875, to $17.6875, on Nasdaq.

title: G.M. June Sales Fell 1.2% As Strike Reduced Inventory
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that its sales slipped 1.2 percent in June from their levels a year earlier as consumer confidence weakened and auto dealers ran short of some models.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Agent Orange Panel Closes
description: This week is the start of the new fiscal year for state government, but for the New Jersey Agent Orange Commission, it is the end of the line.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Pilots Oppose Merger Of Air France Units
description: Air France said yesterday that pilots at its Air France Europe unit opposed a cost-cutting proposal that would allow a merger of its European operations.

title: BASEBALL;Gwynn Out for Four Weeks
description: Tony Gwynn, battling an inflamed right heel for much of the season, had the heel put in a cast this afternoon and will be out for at least four weeks because of a minor Achilles' tendon tear. The San Diego Padres right fielder will also miss next Tuesday's All-Star Game; he was voted as one of the National League's starting outfielders on Monday.

title: Nanny's Dismissal Creates Uproar in Israel
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has created quite a splash as Israel's first "American style" leader, with his catchy sound-bites, the echoes of John F. Kennedy in his speeches, the First Lady ever at his side and the publicized strolls with his small sons. But his American models might have warned him that the style has a price, which often comes with the suffix "-gate."

title: Margaux Hemingway Is Dead; Model and Actress Was 41
description: The badly decomposed body of the actress and model Margaux Hemingway, who was once described as the face of a generation, was discovered by friends on Monday in her home in Santa Monica, Calif., the police said. She was 41.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALAN ALDA likes to learn the language of a country he visits for the first time, so lately he has been practicing Czech. The actor arrived in Prague yesterday for the Karlovy Vary International Film Festival being held in Carlsbad for nine days, starting Friday.

title: Israeli Jets Attack A Guerrilla Base In Eastern Lebanon
description: Israeli warplanes rocketed a Palestinian guerrilla base in Lebanon less than five miles from the Syrian border today in apparent retaliation for an ambush last week in which three Israeli soldiers were killed.

title: TENNIS;Graf, Sampras and a Court of Pretenders Reign
description: Decorum and disruption prevailed in tandem today at Wimbledon, which this year has been nothing short of pretenders' paradise.

title: Victor in Russian Election Today Faces Economic Crisis Tomorrow
description: Russian voters will make a distinct and fateful choice in Wednesday's presidential election, but the economic and social problems that will surface after they cast their ballots will bedevil the Government no matter who wins.

title: Big Theaters Being Planned In Poor Areas
description: The head of a movie theater company partly owned by Magic Johnson said yesterday that the company was considering building multi-screen theaters in the economically depressed downtown areas of Jamaica, Queens, and Harlem.

title: Independence Day: A Guide
description: Events listed taking place tomorrow, except where noted

title: Clinton Seeks Money to Halt Church Fires
description: Declaring that he wanted to "maintain a wall of protection" around Southern black churches, President Clinton said today that he would seek Congressional permission to spend $6 million to help the local authorities halt a recent wave of arson attacks that has struck black houses of worship.

title: Communists In Mongolia Are Toppled After 70 Years
description: Breaking the Communists' hold on power in Mongolia after more than 70 years, the primary opposition coalition captured 50 of 76 seats in the single-chamber Parliament, official election results released today confirmed.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lockheed Martin Is Picked For Spacecraft Project NASA selected Lockheed Martin to build a rocket that could lead to drastic cuts in the cost of putting payloads into space. The X-33, a wedge-shaped reusable spacecraft, is a step toward replacing the space shuttle. The $1 billion project features the first new rocket design in 25 years, and will be built under a program intended to move much of the initiative for developing high-risk technologies out of NASA's hands and into those of private industry.

title: Whitman Insists That She Will Not Run With Dole
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's name may be popping up again as a potential Vice Presidential nominee, but the Governor insisted today that she would not accept the job, even if asked.

title: Dice, Slice And Cut On Plastic
description: THE Cutaway, a flexible mat made of white plastic, is promoted as a cutting board. But it can also be used as an impromptu plate, placemat, desk blotter, counter protector or mouse pad. At $4, it's almost indespensable.

title: Investigators Look to June Mishap for Clues to Crashes of 737's
description: Air safety investigators struggling with two unsolved crashes of Boeing 737's said today that an incident involving another 737 last month could provide important clues.

title: BASEBALL;All-Star Snub? Williams and Rivera Have Powerful Reply
description: With each amazing fastball Mariano Rivera unleashed, he throttled the Red Sox while also sending Cleveland Manager Mike Hargrove a powerful message. Overlook me for the All-Star Game? See you in October.

title: Soweto Journal;Dreamer With a Bookstore Wakes to Fiscal Facts
description: Soweto's first bookstore is now one year old. It is still the only bookstore in this immense black township. That probably won't be true for long.

title: Troubled South African Area Votes Peacefully, and Little Changes
description: After years of deadly political conflict, South Africa's KwaZulu/Natal Province held its first free local elections last week, and now that the votes have finally been counted, it appears that the province's archrivals have neither gained nor lost much ground.

title: Don't Let Cable TV Censor Programming
description: To the Editor:

title: Albany Bills Are Links in Tangled Chain
description: With the Legislature rushing to end its session in the next few days, budget negotiations between Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders increasingly resembled a raucous commodities exchange today where all sides were scrambling to win deals on a menu of pressing issues.

title: Personal Health
description: MOLES: we all have them. Some of us have only one or two, while others have dozens, even 100 or more. Caucasian men and women generally have 10 to 40 -- an average of 24 -- of the pigmented spots on their bodies. That adds up to nearly four billion moles on white Americans. This year, some 19,000 of those spots will be diagnosed as a malignant melanoma, a potentially lethal skin cancer that is increasing at an epidemic rate, faster than any other cancer.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOEING TO CREATE A BUSINESS JET WITH G.E.
description: The Boeing Company and the General Electric Company said yesterday that they had formed a joint venture to turn one of Boeing's most popular commercial airplanes into a line of business jets. The new company, called Boeing Business Jets, will modify Boeing's 737-700, doubling its range so it can fly from New York to Tokyo. Analysts say the venture will give Boeing low-cost access to the business jet market, now dominated by Bombardier Inc. and the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation. Boeing will be the controlling partner in the venture, which will be based in Seattle, Boeing's hometown. Financial terms of the venture were not disclosed. G.E., based in Fairfield, Conn., will be the first customer for the jet. G.E. is a co-owner of CFM International, which makes engines for the Boeing 737.

title: Ex-Dodger Yeager Is Sued by the City
description: A collectibles firm represented by Steve Yeager, a former catcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers, has been sued by the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs for allegedly deceiving investors into putting up to $3,500 apiece in a sports card brokering business.

title: Arabian Mirages
description: After meeting with King Fahd for an hour over the weekend, Defense Secretary William Perry pronounced the Saudi monarch fit and fully in charge. That may have seemed the case to Mr. Perry, but it has been an open secret in the Middle East for months that King Fahd was badly impaired by a major stroke last November and now rules the kingdom more in name than in fact.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HEALTHPLAN SERVICES ADDS 2 BENEFITS ADMINISTRATORS
description: The Healthplan Services Corporation, which provides managed- care services, said yesterday that it had acquired two closely held health-care benefits administrators for a total of about $126 million. Healthplan Services said it had bought Consolidated Group Inc., based in Framingham, Mass., for $62 million and the Harrington Services Corporation, based in Columbus, Ohio, for about $64 million in cash and stock. Healthplan Services, which is based in Tampa, Fla., now provides services to health plans with more than three million members, mainly in the Eastern United States. The acquisitions will add substantially to the revenue of Healthplan Services, which was $100 million in 1995. Consolidated Group reported sales of $74 million, and Harrington had revenue of $72 million.

title: U.S. Sees a Rise in Drunken Driving Deaths
description: Drunken driving deaths rose last year for the first time in a decade, according to a study made public today by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the homeless in Atlanta and the coming Summer Olympics misstated the role of the Atlanta Task Force for the Homeless in a lawsuit challenging city and state ordinances. Seven homeless people in Atlanta are the plaintiffs; the task force itself is not one.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Defy Odds Again By Losing to the Phillies
description: For the second successive evening, the Mets faced a starting pitcher who had five more defeats than victories. For the second straight night, the Mets could do little against him.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Poor Choice of Victims
description: When four members of the Essex-Union County Auto Theft Task Force drove to the F.B.I. Academy in Quantico, Va., last week to polish their skills, they got a bit more hands-on experience than they had bargained for.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;New Career on the Podium For an Injured Violinist
description: The arrival of a musically gifted new conductor is always cause to rejoice, though in the case of Peter Oundjian, who made his formal conducting debut at the Caramoor International Music Festival here this evening, it comes at a severe price.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Military Police Will Replace 1,200 Combat G.I.'s in Bosnia
description: About 1,200 American troops and their tanks will be removed from Bosnia by late this month and replaced by members of the military police sent to provide security during national elections there, the Defense Department announced here today.

title: Long Bond Hit by Strong Home Sales
description: Prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday, as traders were surprised by data indicating strong home sales even as the Federal Reserve's policy-making arm began the first of a two-day meeting to determine monetary policy for the months ahead.

title: Louisiana Court Upholds Drinking Age of 21
description: The Louisiana Supreme Court today upheld a state law that sets the minimum drinking age at 21, reversing a ruling that caused an uproar in March.

title: BASEBALL;On a Starry Night, Jeter Delivers a 4-for-4 Sparkler
description: Derek Jeter backed out of the batter's box, shaking his head over and over while staring at Brian O'Nora, the plate umpire. As if there was not enough pressure on the Yankee shortstop after the Boston Red Sox intentionally walked Jim Leyritz to load the bases in the tie game, Jeter now had to contend with a pitch he thought should have made the count 3-0. Instead, it was called a strike. The rookie simmered.

title: Help Poor Countries With Debt Reduction
description: To the Editor:

title: HORSE RACING;No Cigar for Belmont Weekend, But There's a Lively Racing Cast
description: Horse racing may be scrounging for stars, but Belmont Park will unfurl its grandest weekend of summertime racing this Fourth of July with seven stakes in five days, starting today with the Astoria for 2-year-old fillies and reaching a quick peak tomorrow with the 110th running of the Suburban Handicap.

title: World News Briefs;Canadian Company Invests in Cuban Tourism
description: A Canadian company has signed a deal with the Cuban state hotel company to build 11 hotels and other tourist attractions, Cuban news organizations reported today.

title: Karpov Overruns an Aimless Kamsky
description: Flaccid play by Gata Kamsky gave Anatoly Karpov the advantage he needed yesterday to win Game 14 and take a solid 9-to-5 lead in their world championship match in Elista, Russia. Another victory and another draw -- or three more draws without a victory -- would enable Karpov to seize the $937,500 prize.

title: Side Issues Are Impediments To Albany Budget Accord
description: The often-testy negotiations over the state budget, which continued today, have dragged on largely because the main combatants have tied any final agreement to progress on an array of other major bills. They have tried to hold these other issues hostage to wrest concessions from their opponents on their own pet proposals and the budget itself.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK;From Stark Cityscapes, Dreamscapes Develop
description: THE monuments of East Harlem are graced with the names of politicians -- Washington, Jefferson and Wagner wrought in drab brick. They commemorate an era when this thicket of housing projects was the ultimate in urban renewal.

title: Despite Dole's Best Effort, Softer Side Loses Ground
description: For a week when he and his wife were supposed to show their softer side and gain headlines for a book about love, marriage and Midwestern values, Bob Dole is getting into some surprising political scrapes.

title: On Religious Conversions: From Luther's Folly to Our Own;Future of Islam
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert J. McNulty, Hockey Executive, 74
description: Robert J. McNulty, an original owner of the Minnesota North Stars and developer of the Metropolitan Sports Center, died on Sunday. He was 74.

title: Twin v. Twin, Company at Stake;At Value Line, a Private Feud With Public Consequences
description: More than a half-century ago, as brother and sister growing up on a lush estate in Connecticut, Jean and Van Bernhard spoke the secret language of twins and bounced together on their beds to exult over their Christmas stockings.

title: Menendez Brothers Sentenced to Life in Prison
description: Lyle and Erik Menendez were sentenced today to life in prison without possibility of parole for killing their wealthy parents in a salvo of shotgun blasts in 1989.

title: Man Posing as Police Detective Bilks Elderly Victims at Banks
description: A con man posing as a police detective or F.B.I. agent, complete with a gold shield and a tough demeanor, has bilked a string of elderly victims of more than $20,000 of their savings in a two-week crime spree, police officials said yesterday.

title: Caterpillar Acquisition
description: Caterpillar Inc. said today that it would acquire Fried. Krupp A.G.'s diesel engine subsidiary, MaK Maschinenbau G.m.b.H. Officials at Caterpillar declined to disclose terms of the agreement. Caterpillar said the unit would retain the MaK brand name and operate as a distinct unit in association with Caterpillar's engine businesses. Based in Kiel, Germany, MaK had 1995 revenue of 541 million marks ($354 million). The company employs about 14,000 workers.

title: Everyone Has an Opinion on 'That Voice';The Human Touch
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Health O Meter Stays At Its Agency
description: Health O Meter Products Inc. in Bedford Heights, Ohio, which markets appliances and home health care products under brand names like Mr. Coffee and Health O Meter, said yesterday that it had decided to keep its account at Meldrum & Fewsmith in Cleveland, its agency for nine years. Billings were $10 million.

title: LEGACY OF A TERM -- A special report;In Supreme Court's Decisions, A Clear Voice, and a Murmur
description: The Supreme Court brought a long and difficult term to an end on Monday, leaving behind rulings rich in symbolic significance for women and homosexuals while at the same time providing abundant evidence of the extent to which the Court's discourse has shifted to the right.

title: After 18 Years In Prison, 3 Are Cleared Of Murders
description: In a Kafkaesque case of justice betrayed but finally honored, all charges were dropped here today against three men who had spent 18 years in prison for a double murder they did not commit.

title: Hope for Saving Voice Box in Cancer
description: Chemotherapy that preserves a patient's voice box and ability to speak is just as effective as surgery in treating some types of throat cancer, a study suggests.

title: THEATER REVIEW;An Epic War Resolved With a Gershwin Ditty
description: There's been unspeakable devastation in their name: countless dead, temples sacked, a once splendid city in ashes. But when Helen of Troy and her cuckolded husband, Menelaus, get back together in "The Trojan Women: A Love Story," this season's site-specific offering from En Garde Arts, their happy reconciliation might have been scripted at RKO in the 1930's.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AVIS EMPLOYEE-OWNERS MAY GET $35 A SHARE IN SALE
description: HFS Inc. said yesterday that it was prepared to offer employees of Avis Inc. about $35 for each share of Avis stock that they own, as part of HFS's plan to acquire the car rental company, of which the employees own 70 percent. On Monday, in announcing the plan, HFS said it would offer Avis employees at least $25 a share, double the $12.51 at which the shares were valued by an independent auditor last year. The stock does not trade publicly, but under the rules of an employee-owned company, a value is placed on the shares each year. The purchase is subject to approval from the employees and from the General Motors Corporation, which owns preferred stock convertible into a 29 percent stake in Avis. HFS, the hotel and real estate giant, is based in Parsippany, N.J.; Avis is based in Garden City, L.I.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Minor Agrees to Counseling
description: GREG MINOR, a guard for the Boston Celtics, has agreed to enter a program for batterers to avoid trial on charges that he assaulted his girlfriend in Louisville, Ky., last month. Minor was charged with fourth-degree assault for hitting CELESTYNE ROWAN in the right temple on June 21. Had he been convicted, Minor could have been sentenced to a year in jail and fined $500.

title: Bosnia's a Safe and Healthy Place, for the G.I.'s Anyway
description: Although a fear of American casualties has driven Washington's policy about military involvement in Bosnia, Army statistics show that the troops stationed in Bosnia have so far been safer, healthier and less likely to be killed than soldiers in the Army as a whole.

title: I.B.M. Is Suing Argentine Bank Over a Contract
description: I.B.M. said today that it had sued the state-owned Banco de la Nacion for revoking a $249 million contract that is at the center of a kickback scandal.

title: F.B.I. Director Leaves for Saudi Arabia to Meet With BombingInvestigators
description: Louis J. Freeh, the F.B.I. Director, left for Saudi Arabia tonight for two days of private meetings with American agents and Saudi officials who are investigating the truck bomb blast that killed 19 Americans and injured 250 last week.

title: Severe AIDS Effects Seen on Population of Africa
description: The AIDS epidemic raging in parts of Africa will depress population growth there much more severely than previously predicted, according to an analysis issued today.

title: Dmitri Pokrovsky, 52, Singer And Russian Ethnomusicologist
description: Dmitri Pokrovsky, a singer, composer, conductor and ethnomusicologist whose specialty was Russian folk music, dance and ritual, died on Saturday in Moscow. He was 52 and had homes in Moscow and Boston.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Agent Is Sentenced in Florida
description: The criminal investigation into a $6,000 buying spree at a Foot Locker store by Florida State football players has closed with an unregistered sports agent sentenced to a year in jail.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on June 23 about the Texas Republican Party's convention referred incorrectly to the opinions of the delegates shown. The delegates were reacting to a debate over rules in the party platform, not to a later debate that resulted in the rejection of national convention seats for several Dole supporters who back abortion rights.

title: The Dry Yields to the Droll, the Prosaic to the Provocative in CollegeOfferings
description: College-bound students flipping through their new course catalogues will come across offerings like "Great Hits of Medieval Literature" (Wesleyan University), "The Souls of Animals" (Bowdoin College), "Dinosaurs, Mass Extinction and Other Headlines From the History of Life" (Oberlin College), "Really Fantastic Fiction" (Princeton University) and "The Year My Voice Broke" (Sarah Lawrence College).

title: Ducking on Affirmative Action
description: In a hurtful blow to affirmative action in higher education, the Supreme Court said on Monday that it would not hear an appeal by the state of Texas from a lower court ruling that barred public universities from using race as a factor in selecting students. With this sidestepping, the Court left officials in at least three Southern states who are working to open educational opportunities for minorities in an untenable state of uncertainty. It also sowed confusion nationwide -- hardly an uplifting way for the Court to finish its term and head into recess. The Court should instead have seized the opportunity to reject the lower court's flawed pronouncement and reaffirmed its historic commitment to carefully designed affirmative action.

title: World News Briefs;Fireworks Explosion Kills 36 in China
description: An explosion at a firecracker factory in southwestern China has killed at least 36 workers and passers-by, local officials and state news media said today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CCB FINANCIAL CORP., Durham, N.C., reached an agreement to buy Salem Trust Bank of Winston-Salem, N.C., for about $39 million in stock.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: American General Corp., Houston, to Grey Advertising, New York, to handle corporate advertising for the insurance and financial services company, previously handled by Wells Rich Greene BDDP, New York, a unit of BDDP Worldwide. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: AS he walked down Fifth Avenue on Sunday in the Gay and Lesbian Pride March, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took some heat for his opposition to same-sex marriage. Perhaps the cheekiest remarks came from Paul Macias and Franco Polo, who live on the West Side and were watching the march from the sidelines at 43d Street.

title: Everyone Has an Opinion on 'That Voice'
description: To the Editor:

title: TENNIS;Washington Moves Into the Quarterfinal Ranks
description: For MaliVai Washington, 27 years old and already backpedaling in a career he thought would include a Grand Slam title at least two years ago, it is a long-overdue proving ground.

title: Sweet Serenity By the Scoop
description: BOTANICA, a delicious New Age frozen blend of tea infused with exotic fruit and herbs, made by Greater Pacific Foods in Pleasanton, Calif., is coming east. The delicately swirled confection is like a soft-serve sorbet. It comes in four lightly sweetened flavors: Ginger Mango Vitality, Peach Serenity, Lemon-Ginseng Sensuality and Wildberry Longevity. All are nondairy and fat-free. Though their names suggest beneficial properties, the main point is that they taste terrific.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bomb Sent to Vehicle Agency
description: The manila envelope was addressed to the Division of Motor Vehicles, not to an individual. And, as an employee using a letter opener discovered on Friday, it contained an unwelcome surprise: a mail bomb. The device did not detonate, but motor vehicle officials said yesterday that all employees who handle mail would be trained in spotting suspicious packages.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Morgan Stanley Profits Increased 81%
description: Morgan Stanley Group Inc., benefiting from surging investment banking and takeover business, yesterday reported an 81 percent increase in earnings for the second quarter.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IDEX TO BUY MAKER OF COLOR FORMULATION EQUIPMENT
description: The IDEX Corporation, which makes fluid handling and industrial products, said yesterday that it would acquire Fluid Management L.P. for about $135 million. Fluid Management, an affiliate of the Saranow Company of Wheeling, Ill., makes color formulation equipment for paints, coatings, inks, colorants and dyes. It has manufacturing operations in Wheeling and other operations in the Netherlands, Germany and Australia. Fluid Management has annual sales of about $90 million. The shares of IDEX, which is based in Northbrook, Ill., rose 75 cents, to $38.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Gas Grills, Overtaking Charcoal Briquettes, Come of Age
description: THERE are two ways to look at grilling: as a means to add the flavor of wood to food during cooking or as a means to cook with an open flame.

title: Clinton Stresses What He Didn't Do (or Allow)
description: President Clinton told a cheering crowd of elderly people today that they faced a clear choice in the coming election, and then went on to suggest in a long litany of not-so-subtle comparisons that they should not and would not choose the Republicans.

title: Borland's Chief Quits, Sending The Software Stock Down 15%
description: Shares of Borland International fell nearly 15 percent yesterday after its chief executive resigned and the company forecast a larger-than-expected loss in its fiscal first quarter as a result of disappointing sales.

title: Male Bonding at the Market (With Coupons)
description: MY father has always been obsessed with work. During the Depression, he delivered groceries and sold magazine subscriptions door-to-door after school. His siblings can't remember ever having seen him play.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Dying Poet's Meditation on the East and the Self
description: JOURNEY TOWARD THE CRADLE OF MANKIND By Guido Gozzano Translated by David Marinelli. 156 pages. Marlboro Press/Northwestern University Press. $49.95 cloth, $14.95 paper.

title: Single-Sex Schools and Double Standards
description: Under the constitutional principles announced and applied today, single-sex public education is unconstitutional," Justice Antonin Scalia lamented in his bitter, lonely dissent from the Supreme Court's decision last week ordering the Virginia Military Institute to admit women. Justice Scalia went on to protest that government support of private single-sex colleges, including tax exemptions for schools like Smith and Mount Holyoke, was now at risk as well.

title: INSIDE
description: More Austerity for Hospitals

title: At the Nation's Table: Brookline, Mass.;Pita, as It's Eaten In the Middle East
description: Pita bread stuffed with falafel is a familiar fast food of the Middle East, sold there by street vendors. Less known are flatbread pitas with toppings; sambusak, crescents stuffed with savory fillings, and semit, a soft bagel-like roll studded with sesame seeds and called "bagele" in Israel.

title: Sexual Harassment Declining, Women in the Military Report
description: Sexual harassment in the military remains a big problem, but not quite as big as it used to be, the Pentagon said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;CNN, New York City's development office and Microsoft keep Madison Avenue booming.
description: ALONG Madison Avenue, the second half of 1996 is beginning the way the first half ended: with a strong and steady stream of account news.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Malaysian Company Plans a Takeover
description: Konsortium Perkapalan, a Malaysian transport company, has offered $226.6 million for Pacific Basin Bulk Shipping Ltd. of Bermuda. Konsortium, which is controlled by a son of the Malaysian Prime Minister, is offering $16.22 for each Pacific Basin common share. Holders of Pacific Basin warrants will get 97 cents a warrant after the acquisition.

title: Sale of a Grand Rabbi's Home Is Upheld
description: Ending a tumultuous courtroom feud between factions of a leading Hasidic sect in Brooklyn, New York State's highest court yesterday upheld the purchase of the former Grand Rabbi's Brooklyn house by a dissident group.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about financing the last 20 miles of the Natchez Trace Parkway misstated the circumstances under which Representative Jamie L.
