Whitten, Democrat of Mississippi, left office. He retired in January 1995 and died in September of that year. He was not defeated for re-election.

title: Discipline Busboys
description: To The Living Section:

title: Everyone Has an Opinion on 'That Voice';Big Apple Sound-Bite
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Makers Set to License Data on Genes
description: Acknowledging that there may be many more possible gene-therapy drugs than the partners can research and develop on their own, the SmithKline Beecham Corporation and Human Genome Sciences Inc. said yesterday that they would license their human-gene data base to two other companies in deals worth more than $90 million.

title: David McCampbell, 86, Navy Ace in World War II
description: David McCampbell, naval aviation's ace of aces who shot 34 Japanese planes out of the sky during World War II in exploits that won him the Medal of Honor, died on Sunday at the Veterans Affairs Nursing Home Care Unit in Riviera Beach, Fla.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHURGARD STORAGE CENTERS MAKES BID FOR PARTNERSHIPS
description: Shurgard Storage Centers Inc. offered yesterday to buy three partnerships that own self-storage operations, in a deal valued at about $107 million. Shurgard offered to pay cash and stock for IDS/Shurgard Income Growth Partners L.P., IDS/Shurgard Income Growth Partners L.P. 2 and IDS/Shurgard Income Growth Partners L.P. 3. Shurgard, based in Seattle, owns a stake in the general partner of the partnerships and manages the 37 storage centers they own. Over all, Shurgard owns or operates about 265 centers.

title: Dole Criticizes Role Of Press and Foes In Tobacco Debate
description: In a contentious television interview broadcast this morning, Bob Dole charged that the "liberal media" were promoting the Democratic line in questioning his statement that tobacco may not be addictive to everyone. He also asserted that the Democratic Party was more beholden to tobacco interests than he was.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Iowa Hopes to Honor 1939 Star
description: Nile Kinnick died 53 years ago when his Navy fighter plane crashed into the Caribbean Sea. Now, some friends and former teammates of the 1939 Heisman Trophy winner from Iowa want to find the plane and bring it back to his alma mater. AL COUPPEE, GEORGE (RED) FRYE, ERWIN (HERB) PRASSE and others are working to find the plane, refurbish it and set it on a pole at the school's football stadium in Iowa City, which is named for Kinnick.

title: All Day, Every Day, a Global Forum on AIDS
description: THE first continuing global electronic AIDS conference has started here in an effort to provide vital medical information to doctors in developing countries.

title: Sports of The Times;The Future Is Unclear For Howe
description: NOW it is over. Maybe. For in years past it has been an unrewarding exercise to try to write the end of the sad, the tragic, the remarkable -- even, to be sure, the uplifting -- Steve Howe story. Each time it has been done, Howe somehow finds a way to add a new chapter. Seven times Steve Howe has been suspended from baseball for substance abuse. Seven times he came back -- perhaps some kind of perverse record in itself. But now, well, maybe now the baseball book is closed on his career.

title: BASEBALL;Braves Dominate N.L. Roster
description: The Atlanta Braves, with the most victories in the majors this season, now have the most All-Stars, too. Four Braves pitchers -- Tom Glavine, Greg Maddux, John Smoltz and Mark Wohlers -- and third baseman Chipper Jones joined the National League's starting first baseman, Fred McGriff, when pitchers and reserves for next Tuesday's game in Philadelphia were named yesterday.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Diane Mott Davidson;A Mystery Writer Has Proven Recipes
description: DIANE MOTT DAVIDSON didn't know a creme brulee from creme fraiche when she was a student at Stanford University. Nor did she make it into the university's creative writing course. Naturally, she became a writer -- and what else but a writer who uses a caterer as her central character.

title: No Headline
description: We're scared to go to work. Now, we know these people are here -- you don't know who your neighbor is."

title: More Testimony Describes a Clinton Meeting
description: Three more witnesses today described the circumstances surrounding a 1990 meeting at which an Arkansas banker, prosecutors say, handed then-Gov. Bill Clinton thousands of dollars in campaign contributions and pressed him to appoint the banker's partner to a political patronage job.

title: Cable Systems Swap
description: Tele-Communications Inc. and the Washington Post Company announced today that they had agreed to swap two cable systems they own in Missouri and California. Post-Newsweek Cable, a Post unit, will acquire the assets of a cable system serving about 53,000 customers in Springfield, Mo. TCI, the nation's largest cable company, will get a system serving about 48,000 customers in Santa Rosa, Calif. The exchange is expected to be complete by the end of the year. Bill Fitzgerald, senior vice president of corporate development at TCI, based in Englewood, said the deal represented another step in TCI's strategy to increase presence in key markets.

title: Boy in Coma After Rescue From Pool Is Dead at 14
description: A 14-year-old boy who spent 10 days on a life support system after he was rescued from a Philadelphia swimming pool during a school trip died yesterday, a hospital spokeswoman said.

title: Hold the Salt
description: To The Living Section:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Towns Canceling Fireworks
description: Fireworks are as much of a Fourth of July tradition as barbecues, picnics and parades, but an increasing number of New Jersey towns are deciding to forgo them. Officials cite concerns over injuries, liability insurance, crowd control and other logistical problems.

title: Foreign Affairs;The Oil Factor
description: The most striking thing about the response of the G-7 leaders to the latest bombing in Saudi Arabia was the decision they didn't take. Yes, they called for an unstinting effort to track down and punish the perpetrators, and that's essential. But an equally obvious response didn't seem to occur to them -- that the Western industrial democracies should also reduce their energy consumption and reliance on imported Middle East oil, which would be healthy for their economies, healthy for the environment, and make it so every bomb that goes off in Saudi Arabia doesn't become a world historical event.

title: Park Victim Is Discharged From Hospital
description: The woman who was nearly beaten to death in Central Park four weeks ago left New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center yesterday after uttering a simple "goodbye" to her doctors.

title: ExtendingJuly Fourth
description: The calendar may have said July 2 but across the New York metropolitan area, the celebrating was already under way. With the holiday falling on a Thursday and many people off on Friday, many workers just decided to take much of the week off and flee the city.

title: Compaq Regroups Into 3 Management Units
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said today that it had reorganized its management into three business units, putting a new executive in charge of its flagship corporate server business.

title: Business Travel;Hotel mini-bars are on the increase, despite their reputation for being expensive.
description: IN the United States, only 3 out of 10 hotel guests use mini-bars -- in Europe, it's 4 out of 10 -- largely because of overpriced snacks and drinks. And not helping matters are the irritating interruptions by staff to restock.

title: Pataki to Veto Bill on Chiropractor Payments
description: Gov. George E. Pataki has decided to veto legislation that would have required health insurance companies to pay for unlimited chiropractic services, bowing to the concerns of business groups, which contended that such a mandate would drive up insurance costs, administration officials said today.

title: Don't Let Cable TV Censor Programming
description: To the Editor:

title: Kurdish Suicide Bomber Kills 9 Turkish Soldiers
description: On Friday, less than 48 hours after the head of Turkey's Islamic Party, Necmettin Erbakan, took office as Prime Minister, Kurdish rebels sent him a harsh message.

title: Howard Crabtree, Playwright, 41
description: Howard Crabtree, a costume designer and a co-author of several Off Broadway musicals, died on Friday at his home in Bucks County, Pa. He was 41.

title: GIULIANI ATTACKS RECYCLING GOALS AS A SUIT IS FILED
description: Faced with a lawsuit that charges his administration with violating the city's own recycling law, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday denounced the goals contained in the law as "absurd" and "irresponsible" and vowed he would work to scale them back.

title: What Connects Izzy to Atlanta? (Just Guess!)
description: To the Editor:

title: The State's Promising Hospital Rate Plan
description: The plan that Gov. George Pataki is negotiating with legislative leaders to replace New York State's outdated system of regulated hospital rates with market-driven prices appears sound. The plan would reap the low costs and innovation of competition without sacrificing the ample financing of indigent care and medical training that exists now.

title: Crdit Suisse To Slash Jobs In Radical Restructuring
description: PARIS  Having failed to achieve a merger last April aimed at creating a European banking powerhouse, Switzerland's second-biggest banking group said Tuesday that it would launch a radical reorganization, slashing 5,000 jobs and replacing its chief executive.

title: Official Who Got Files Helped Heckle Bush
description: Craig Livingstone, the figure at the center of the controversy over the improper acquisition of F.B.I. files by the Clinton White House, listed on his resume that he had supervised a campaign operation in which President George Bush was heckled at a series of 1992 rallies by people dressed in chicken costumes.

title: Dole Campaign Files Complaint Against Clinton
description: Bob Dole's Presidential campaign filed a complaint today with the Federal Election Commission alleging that President Clinton's campaign illegally orchestrated the spending of $25 million by the Democratic National Committee, which is supposed to act independently of the President.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;New Police Head Confirmed
description: A divided City Council confirmed Joseph J. Santiago as Newark's new Police Director yesterday.

title: Comatose Mother Has Been Moved
description: A comatose woman who was raped in a nursing home last summer was moved from the hospital on Sunday, three and a half months after giving birth.

title: 1996 Data Show Crime Rates Are Still Falling in New York
description: After two consecutive years of plunging citywide crime rates, fresh New York City police statistics show that murder, burglary, robbery and other serious crimes are dropping sharply again this year across the city and once again at an accelerating pace.

title: Food Notes
description: Food and Fireworks

title: Real Estate;Revival in Chicago: a new but nearly vacant downtown office building is sold.
description: A DOWNTOWN office building that has been nearly vacant since it was completed in 1991 has been bought, heralding a revival of one of the larger projects that stalled when the commercial real estate market here collapsed.

title: Surprise Surge in Home Sales: Leap of 7.5%
description: Confounding analysts, builders sold new houses in May at the fastest pace in more than 10 years as buyers appeared remarkably indifferent to rising interest rates, Government figures showed today.

title: On Religious Conversions: From Luther's Folly to Our Own
description: To the Editor:

title: Freakish Blackout in the West Affects More Than a Million
description: A patchy blackout struck much of the West today when a large power line mysteriously failed, blanking out traffic lights and silencing air-conditioners for an hour or more in spots from Canada to Mexico.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Johnson's Next Goal: A Record In the 400
description: Nine days after setting a world record in the 200 meters, Michael Johnson puts his 53-race winning streak in the 400 meters on the line here Wednesday night.

title: CURRENCY MARKINGS;Dollar Tops 110 Yen on Signs Japanese Won't Raise Rates
description: The dollar rose above 110 yen for the first time in 29 months yesterday, as concern faded that the Bank of Japan would soon raise interest rates.

title: TV NOTES;Bad Case of Summer Flight
description: Every recent summer has been one of discontent for the broadcast networks. But this one is rapidly becoming the summer of disaster.

title: BASEBALL;Two Mets Join All-Stars
description: Todd Hundley would have been disappointed if he had not been named to his first All-Star Game. Lance Johnson expressed thanks, not to mention surprise. And Bernard Gilkey said he will use the time off to throw a first birthday party for his son.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;A Few Punches Between Bites
description: A lunchtime crowd of nearly 1,000 was treated to boxing in the open air yesterday when RIDDICK BOWE held a sparring session in a ring set up in Bryant Park in Manhattan. Bowe (39-1, with 33 knockouts), who meets the undefeated but untested Polish heavyweight ANDREW GOLOTA (28-0, 25 knockouts) at Madison Square Garden next Wednesday, mixed it up with three sparring partners in an hourlong workout. Golota skipped rope during his 15 minutes inside the ring.

title: Repressed-Memory Case Won't Be Retried
description: Prosecutors said today that they would not retry a man who was once convicted of a 20-year-old murder after his daughter testified about repressed memories, only to have the conviction overturned.

title: 156 Arrested Over Drugs In a Sweep In Hempstead
description: A dozen times in the last six years, the police have swept through a corner of this village arresting hundreds of people on drug charges. Now, with the state's help, the police have completed a three-month investigation, much of it on videotape, and arrested 156 people.

title: TV NOTES;Reiser to Be Emmys Host
description: ABC will dip into NBC's talent pool when the network broadcasts this year's edition of the Emmy Awards on Sept. 8. The host will be one of NBC's long roster of stars, Paul Reiser of "Mad About You." But that doesn't mean ABC won't be heavily represented during the telecast.

title: Market Place;For Digital, a Tunnel at the End of the Light
description: A few months ago, Robert B. Palmer, chairman and chief executive of the Digital Equipment Corporation, was saying that the company's worst days were behind it. Having bet its future on being first to market with a series of cutting-edge computer technologies, Digital seemed poised to cash in after facing extinction in the early 1990's.

title: Time Warner And the F.T.C. Gain in Talks On Turner Deal
description: Settlement talks between the Federal Trade Commission and Time Warner Inc. about the company's deal to acquire Turner Broadcasting System Inc. are back on track after an impasse two weeks ago, several people close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: POLITICS: A PRIMARY -- The Race for Congress -- Georgia's FourthCongressional District; A Redistricted Black Lawmaker Fires Back
description: Representative Cynthia A. McKinney, the only black Congresswoman ever elected in Georgia, slipped a cassette into a boom box, pressed the play button and began to boogie. As Elton John's 1975 hit "Philadelphia Freedom" blared through her campaign headquarters on Saturday, Ms. McKinney and her aides danced out the door to greet a busload of 40 campaign workers who had traveled 16 hours from Philadelphia to help canvass the neighborhoods of the Fourth Congressional District.

title: Don't Tar Minneapolis: Homicides Are Down
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Satellite-TV Plan by TCI Hits Hurdle
description: In a sign of its resolve to open foreign satellite markets, the Clinton Administration asked the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to withhold a ruling on whether Tele-Communications Inc. could beam its direct-broadcast television service from a Canadian satellite.

title: Victims Deserve a Place in the Constitution;Beware of Demagogues
description: To the Editor:

title: Checking Up On Camp Staffs
description: IT takes a dedicated crew of counselors, coaches, cooks, waterfront supervisors and arts-and-crafts teachers to make a summer camp run smoothly.

title: Mr. Dole's Smoke Rings
description: Just as President Clinton's lead in some polls was starting to diminish, Bob Dole reverted to an issue that can only embarrass him, the addictive potential of tobacco. Mr. Dole sounds disingenuous when he keeps expressing uncertainty about whether tobacco is addictive or not, and he has turned increasingly surly in defending his position. No less an authority than C. Everett Koop, a conservative and former Surgeon General, has declared that Mr. Dole "either exposed his abysmal lack of knowledge of nicotine addiction or his blind support of the tobacco industry." If Mr. Dole needs to distinguish himself from President Clinton, he would be best advised to find another issue. When it comes to tobacco, Mr. Clinton holds the high cards.

title: Irwin M. Gelernt, 60, Surgeon Specializing in Intestinal Disease
description: Dr. Irwin M. Gelernt, a surgeon at Mount Sinai Hospital Center who advanced the diagnosis and treatment of inflammatory bowel disease, died on Monday at Mount Sinai. He was 60 and lived in Manhattan.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Phillips Pleads Not Guilty
description: LAWRENCE PHILLIPS, the St. Louis Rams' top draft pick, pleaded not guilty to misdemeanor drunken driving. Phillips was not present. His lawyer entered the plea in Rio Hondo Municipal Court in El Monte, Calif. Trial was set for Aug. 28.

title: Auto Sales in June Slowed From May's Frantic Pace
description: Auto sales slowed from a frantic sprint to a slow jog in June, suggesting a slowdown in economic growth, economists said.

title: AT HOME WITH: Carl Hiaasen;Can Success And Satire Mix?
description: THE new house is unassuming, a plain, two-story concrete structure on stilts whose main selling points are on the outside -- Florida Bay just a few steps from the back door, a view of mangrove keys across the water, the privacy provided by palm and gumbo-limbo trees.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Olivetti Expected To Name New Chief
description: Olivetti S.p.A., the unprofitable Italian information technology company, is expected to name a new chief executive today, analysts say. The chairman, Carlo De Benedetti, may step down as co-chief executive, they said. The changes are expected to accelerate the shift by the company toward its telecommunications business and away from personal computers and office products.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CASINO AMERICA TO TAKE CONTROL OF PARTNERSHIP
description: Casino America Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire full control of its 50-50 partnership with Louisiana Downs Inc., which owns the Isle of Capri Casino in Bossier City, La. Louisiana Downs is a subsidiary of the Edward J. DeBartolo Corporation of Youngstown, Ohio. The price was about $100 million. Casino America, based in Biloxi, Miss., said that it would pay $85 million in cash and offer five-year warrants for 500,000 shares of its common stock at an exercise price of $10.50 a share. The stock slipped 18.75 cents yesterday, to $7.875, in Nasdaq trading. It would also pay $1.5 million a year for seven years, payable monthly beginning Oct. 1, 1998. Casino America operates four riverboat and dockside casinos in Biloxi and Vicksburg, Miss., and Bossier City and Lake Charles, La.

title: TENNIS;Upsetting Possibilities Are Staring At Sampras
description: Weirdness and wetness were co-conspirators today at Wimbledon, where all the matches were left unresolved and the three-time champion Pete Sampras, invincible in his last 25 matches here, was left with an imposing deficit to solve.

title: Make Mediations and Mergers, Not War
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Approves Huge Western Rail Merger
description: A Federal regulatory agency today approved the merger of the Union Pacific and Southern Pacific railroads, a $5.4 billion deal that will create the nation's largest railroad and nearly complete the consolidation of the freight rail system west of the Mississippi. Just two companies would carry 90 percent of the freight in this huge area of the country.

title: Preliminary Approval for Big GM Settlement
description: A Louisiana judge gave preliminary approval today to a settlement involving $1,000 coupons to resolve lawsuits alleging that some General Motors pickup trucks had potentially dangerous side-mounted gasoline tanks.

title: For the Fourth, Plenty of Variety
description: Across the country, Americans will celebrate the nation's birth in varied fashions.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Strike Is Scheduled At Air France Today
description: Unionized pilots and other workers at Air France are expected to strike today to protest the airline's plans to consolidate its European operations.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STARWOOD LODGING AGREES TO ACQUIRE 9 HOTELS
description: Continuing its buying spree, Starwood Lodging Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire nine hotels from Hotels of Distinction Ventures Inc. of Palm Beach, Fla., for $134 million. The hotels, with a total of 2,425 rooms, would be operated by Starwood Lodging Trust's affiliate, the Starwood Lodging Corporation, a hotel management and operating company. The hotels are in Atlanta; Needham, Mass.; Palm Desert, Calif.; St. Louis; Tucson, Ariz.; Minneapolis; Arlington Heights, Ill.; Allentown, Pa., and Winston-Salem, N.C. In the last 12 months, Starwood, which is based in Los Angeles, has bought properties that have about 11,300 rooms for $840 million. Its portfolio now includes stakes in 62 hotels with more than 16,400 rooms.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MICROSOFT TO CONTINUE BUYING BACK ITS SHARES
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it planned to continue its stock repurchase program in the 1997 fiscal year. Microsoft repurchased about 13.5 million shares for $1.38 billion in the fiscal year that ended last Sunday. Microsoft, which is based in Redmond, Wash., said the number of shares to be acquired in the fiscal year 1997 hinged on the level of employee stock option exercises, the price of shares of Microsoft and market conditions. Microsoft's stock was down 50 cents yesterday, to $121.125 a share on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Accountant Tells of Meeting in Which Clinton Got Money
description: A participant to a 1990 meeting at the Arkansas Capitol testified today how Bill Clinton, who was the Governor then, accepted thousands of dollars in campaign checks from a banker and then asked the banker whether his business partner would be suitable to be appointed to the state highway commission.

title: ART REVIEW;Esthetic Olympics, In 5 Shades For 5 Rings
description: Blockbuster art exhibitions often excel at superficiality, but "Rings: Five Passions in World Art" which opens on July 4 at the High Museum of Art, deserves a special award. The centerpiece of the cultural events surrounding the summer Olympic Games, the exhibition may set records for the most international art treasures traveling the greatest distances for the least curatorial purpose. It may also be the first blockbuster whose organizing principle is based on a logo.

title: Road Plan for Atlantic City Leaves All Casinos Flush
description: In a conciliatory move that seemed to deal winning hands to both competing casino operators and taxpayers, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced today a sweeping roadway and tunnel project for Atlantic City that will vastly improve its strained roads and bolster its transformation into one of the foremost gambling destinations in the country.

title: Calendar: A Cruise, Shows and Talks
description: New York Modernism The Lighthouse, 111 East 59th Street; (212) 501-3013.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Adversity Overcome, an Outdoor Chamber Series Resumes
description: There's nothing like the threat of rain hovering over an outdoor chamber music concert to charge the performances with an element of suspense. But the rain held off on Tuesday night for the third in a series of five free concerts presented by the Washington Square Music Festival.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;A Classicist Romps In a Revival Of Klezmer
description: Klezmorim, the itinerant Jewish musicians of Eastern Europe, soaked up all the music around them. Two concerts this week confirmed that current klezmer musicians are as flexible as their elders. At Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday night, the classical violinist Itzhak Perlman sat in with four klezmer groups. And on Sunday afternoon at Central Park Summerstage, the Klezmatics shared a double bill and collaborated with the Master Musicians of Jajouka, a Moroccan group that carries on a centuries-old ecstatic tradition.

title: Mayor Says Fireworks Mean Arrests
description: Warning of widespread arrests, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that the city would for the first time impose a "zero tolerance" policy on fireworks over the holiday.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Officer Pleads Guilty
description: A 39-year-old Trenton police officer accused of robbing banks in Ohio and New Jersey pleaded guilty in Cincinnati yesterday to robbery and drug charges.

title: CURRENTS;Welcome, Sweet Summer . . . With Your Breezy Ways
description: THE weather is too hot to lift a finger, much less a china plate or crystal goblet. But who needs them when there is everything for the table in whimsical plastics and colorful papers? (And these are also good shortcuts to most-favored-houseguest status.)

title: Liberty's Vast Empire
description: On July 4, 1803, the National Intelligencer of Washington reported that Napoleon had sold Louisiana to the United States. For Capt. Meriwether Lewis, it was especially memorable. On that day, he left Washington and headed west for his exploration of the Missouri River country and the territory west from the Continental Divide to the Pacific.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japan's Top Bureaucrat for Banking Is Out
description: The Japanese Finance Ministry said today that the head of its banking bureau, who has drawn criticism on several fronts, would retire this year, while the director general of its international finance bureau, who has helped the dollar rebound against the yen, would remain at his position.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Give Bonus Baby $1.6 Million
description: He received the heftiest signing bonus ever dispensed to an amateur by the Yankees as a 16-year-old. He has been called one of the best prospects in the world. He might be deemed a disappointment if he is not in the major leagues by his 21st birthday. He is named after Reggie Jackson. He does not own a razor and has not yet earned a high school diploma.

title: Testosterone Yields Bigger Muscles, Study Says
description: For every guy who ever wondered whether a blast of testosterone might transform him into pumped-up muscleman, scientists now have an answer. After four decades of learned debate, a new study has shown what weight lifters say their bodies have illustrated for years: a shot of testosterone can indeed turn a weakling into a bigger, more muscular fellow.

title: Bridge Traffic, Already Bad, Will Get Worse
description: When city officials began a $500 million overhaul of the Williamsburg Bridge eight years ago, it created almost constant traffic congestion.

title: Hillary Clinton Encourages Polish Women to Press for Wider Rights
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton came to talk with women in Poland today and found, six years after the end of Communism, much what she finds at home: issues that range from sexual harassment to credit access, from family violence to politics.

title: The Pop Life
description: A Bumper Crop of Recordings

title: Moscow Journal;A Parade, Unofficial but Always on Time
description: The Presidential voting in Moscow, Russia, was a certainty. But the Independence Day celebration in Moscow, Vt., is traditionally up in the air.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: Oliver H. Lowry, 85, an Expert In Precise Biological Measuring
description: Dr. Oliver Howe Lowry, a molecular biologist whose ever more sensitive methods of measurement and analysis found wide applications in biology and medicine, died on Saturday at a nursing home in St. Louis, his hometown. He was 85.

title: New Versions of Veranda Favorites
description: AH, summer. Time to head for the porch with a cold drink and watch the neighbors parade by.

title: Nagasaki Journal;Today's History Lesson: What Rape of Nanjing?
description: The greatest danger, Mizuro Fukushima warned gravely, his eyes gleaming fiercely, is that naive schoolchildren may come to believe that the United States dropped the atomic bomb because Japan had done something wrong.

title: BOXING;Bronchitis Stops Tyson: Seldon Fight Is Off
description: Mike Tyson is suffering from bronchitis, and his July 13 fight against Bruce Seldon for Seldon's World Boxing Association heavyweight title has been postponed to eptember or October.

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: IN THE RED BELT;Communists Pledge to Fight On . .  .
description: In this Communist stronghold, Gennadi A. Zyuganov's supporters do not intend to gently fade away.

title: Amid Flags and Fireworks, New Meanings of Patriotism
description: From urban high-rises and suburban cul-de-sacs, and from so many front porches in this Midwestern small town, American flags have unfurled, an enduring portrait of the nation, dressed for the Fourth of July.

title: Nurses' Union Planning a One-Day Strike
description: The union representing 1,500 nurses at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center is planning a one-day strike on Tuesday to protest the lack of progress in contract talks and the hospital's demand to have unlicensed employees do more of the work now done by registered nurses.

title: Meadville Journal;For Russians, Holiday Spirit Is Dusted Off
description: Most years here in Meadville, July 4 was little more than a date on the calendar to separate July 3 and 5. Family barbecues and picnics were not uncommon, and flags waved here and there. But as Independence Day, it never generated much in the way of community celebrations or spirit.

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE OVERVIEW;YELTSIN DEFEATS COMMUNIST FOE BY A SURPRISINGLY WIDE MARGIN; HEALTH ISSUE LOOMS  FOR 2D TERM
description: Rejecting a return to the Communist past that has defined 20th-century Russia, voters re-elected the country's first President, Boris N. Yeltsin, on Wednesday by an unexpectedly wide margin.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a proposed addition to the Victoria and Albert Museum in London misidentified the architect whose design for an addition to Britain's National Gallery was described by Prince Charles as a carbuncle. The design was by Peter Ahrends, not by Sir Richard Rogers.

title: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;President Urges Educators to Fight Truancy
description: President Clinton carried his bully-pulpit campaign on values down to the most basic bulwark of law and order today: the school principal's office. He announced a nationwide effort to discourage truancy and reward local school districts that set up programs to stop it.

title: New York City Investment Fund Isn't a First
description: To the Editor:

title: Houdini and the White House
description: Seances in the White House! Administration officials issue a denial! Last month's news? Try 1926. Calvin Coolidge's Administration was rocked by a claim that he and his family had entertained mediums and that the White House was a hotbed of believers in the supernatural.

title: Head of Fulton Market Group Pleads Guilty in Tax Fraud
description: The head of a dealers association at the Fulton Fish Market pleaded guilty yesterday to state tax evasion charges, in the first conviction to stem from a a city crackdown on corruption at the market more than a year ago.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;A Hearing For Unsung Composers
description: How long will it last? An incredible profusion of unfamiliar repertory has emerged on CD's in the last decade. Signs in the record industry point to a future crunch, but for now record stores are awash in oddities and obscurities. With the partial exception of Wilhelm Furtwangler, renowned for his conducting rather than his composing, the composers sampled below are not household names; yet their works have been recorded many times over. Three of these disks are lovely testaments to underappreciated talents. The Furtwangler, however, makes one wonder whether the record industry has gone completely mad.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Times Mirror in Two Deals To Bolster Legal Publisher
description: The Times Mirror Company said yesterday that it would trade its higher-education publishing division to the McGraw-Hill Companies in exchange for Shepard's, McGraw-Hill's influential legal research and annotation subsidiary.

title: For Pint-Size Swimmers, New Rules Are a Stretch
description: Nine-year-old Julio Bettencourt stood next to a fence post at the Hamilton Fish swimming pool on the Lower East Side and looked up, crestfallen. The ring of masking tape marking the 4-foot 1-inch height requirement for swimmers under age 16 was two agonizing inches above his head, shattering the day's plans.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Britain Leaves Rates Unchanged
description: The British Chancellor of the Exchequer, Kenneth Clarke, appeared to have left official interest rates unchanged at 5.75 percent yesterday after meeting with the Bank of England governor, Eddie George.

title: Mortgage Rates Down
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.14 percent this week, down from 8.29 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the lowest since May 30, when rates averaged 8.03 percent. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.94 percent, down from 5.98 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.67 percent this week, down from 7.82 percent a week earlier.

title: Echoes of Franco as Spain Fires Senior TV Reporters
description: When Jose Antonio Martinez-Soler was chosen by all of Spain's political parties to conduct interviews with candidates before the general election last March, he took it as a tribute to his journalistic impartiality.

title: POLITICS: Political Briefing;THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Georgia Public Broadcasting: Trouble for Gingrich

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;12th Miami Player in Trouble
description: TREMAIN MACK, a special teams player for the University of Miami, faces a July 12 arraignment in Texas on a bad-check charge, The Miami Herald reported.

title: Valujet Airline, Now Grounded, Seeks Approval to Resume Flying
description: Two weeks after the Federal Aviation Administration effectively ordered Valujet shut down, the agency said tonight that the airline had filed plans to resume operations.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by Dow Jones in the Company News column of Business Day on Tuesday about the proposed acquisition of the Newflo Corporation by the Precision Castparts Corporation misstated the role of Goldman, Sachs & Company in the transaction. Goldman, Sachs advised Newflo; it did not provide credit to Precision.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Even for a Rich Lawyer, City Life Can Be Murder
description: THE INTRUDER By Peter Blauner 397 pages. Simon & Schuster. $23.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Police Credibility Questioned in Irvin Case
description: Irving, Tex., police officers met with prosecutors five times to discuss what happened the night MICHAEL IRVIN was found in a motel room with cocaine and marijuana, testimony in the Dallas Cowboys receiver's drug trial showed.

title: Independence' Sets a Record
description: William van Roden spent as much time as it takes to fly from New York to Dallas -- human beings on a jet plane, not aliens on a slow-creeping spaceship -- on a Manhattan sidewalk yesterday, going nowhere. He killed the time doing a crossword puzzle and reading a novel and guarding his place with a sheet of paper that said 8:30 P.M.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices End Up Slightly
description: Treasury prices ended slightly higher yesterday on relief that Federal Reserve policy makers had left interest rates unchanged.

title: SPORTS BUSINESS;Insurance Rated Worth Risk
description: The rush by USA Basketball to buy disability insurance for free agents on the Dream Team, and for the players to buy policies for themselves, was a small blip in the ordinary process of coverage against the risk of injury.

title: Study Finds Rising Number Of Black-White Marriages
description: Marilyn Benoit, a black psychologist, recently went with her husband, who is white, to a concert in Reston, Va. Ms. Benoit was pleasantly surprised to see the number of interracial couples milling easily about the suburb, hardly drawing a curious, hostile or even a second glance.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: OLYMPICS;Four Make Equestrian Team
description: Four riders were selected yesterday for the United States team that will compete at the Atlanta Olympic Games. Chosen were BRUCE O. DAVIDSON of Unionville, Pa., with Dr. ELINOR JENNY's Heyday; JILL HENNEBERG of Voorhees, N.J., with her Nirvana II; DAVID O'CONNOR of The Plains, Va., on JACQUELINE MARS's Giltedge; and KAREN O'CONNOR of Plains, Va., with MR. and MRS. RICHARD THOMPSON's Biko. DAVID O'CONNOR with Custom Made, owned by JOSEPH ZADA, and DOROTHY TRAPP of Lexington, Ky., with her Molokai, were picked as individual competitors. (AP)

title: No Headline
description: Of course, he is now going to slow down. We know the character of our president very well. In moments of danger he is reborn like a phoenix, but in victory he tends to rest on his laurels."

title: POP REVIEW;Grand Old Men of Punk, Inspired by the Audience's Energy
description: The Buzzcocks, the late 70's British punk rock band inspired by the Sex Pistols, are one reason why critics of contemporary rock say that nothing is new. Before the latter-day punks in Green Day could even read the instructions on a bottle of hair dye, the Buzzcocks were already condensing verse-chorus-verse pop songs into catchy, bratty, high-speed two-minute tunes of alienation and boredom. Offering an equal balance of songs from their new album, "All Set" (IRS), and selections from their 70's punk canon in concert on Tuesday night at Irving Plaza, the Buzzcocks proved that little has changed in 20 years except for their hairlines and, at times, their effectiveness.

title: A Coffee Shop Bandit With Upscale Taste
description: He usually orders a large coffee and when the clerk turns his back, he pulls a knife and orders up the money.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Alumna Fights College Name
description: An assemblywoman incensed over Trenton State College's decision to change its name to the College of New Jersey announced plans yesterday to require public colleges and universities to seek legislative approval for new names.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: As Expected, Fed Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged A surprise move might have caused some early Fourth of July fireworks in the markets, but Federal Reserve policy makers stuck to the script, leaving interest rates unchanged after a two-day meeting.

title: Correction
description: A June 29 editorial, "Keep Trucks Out of Saratoga Park," erred when it said that the Saratoga Spa State Park includes two race tracks and bridle paths. The park does not include a bridle path and the two race tracks are located a few miles outside the park.

title: THEATER REVIEW;How a Mild German Professor Turned Into a Nazi Officer
description: Sixty-odd years after the rise of the National Socialist movement in Germany, the question of how it could have happened still haunts our collective psyche, inspiring films and books like Daniel Jonah Goldhagen's current best seller, "Hitler's Willing Executioners." C. P. Taylor attempted a stage exposition in "Good," a mesmerizing yet ultimately disappointing play that has been revived by the Barrow Group.

title: War Tribunal Paints an Ugly Picture of 2 Wanted Serbs
description: The international war crimes tribunal shuddered today at the details of mass murders as the court for the first time presented its evidence of the role that the Bosnian Serb commander played in the widespread killing of civilians in Srebrenica, once a city of refuge.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ANN TAYLOR SHARES FALL ON LOWER SALES EXPECTATIONS
description: The shares of the Ann Taylor Stores Corporation fell yesterday as analysts said they expect the retailer's June same-store sales to drop for the 13th straight month. The stock fell $2.125, or 10 percent, to $18.125 on the New York Stock Exchange. The monthly same-store sales for the women's clothing chain based in New York have declined during the last year as merchandising miscues caused stores to display a mishmash of different styles instead of its traditional classic wares. Analysts said, however, that the retailer is now selling more clothing at full price, which lifts margins. Jeff Edelman, an analyst at Deutsche Morgan Greenfell, said that he expected Ann Taylor's June same-store sales to fall about 5 percent. He said the retailer could begin to report increases in September or October.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AES PLANS TO ACQUIRE THREE POWER PLANTS IN HUNGARY
description: The AES Corporation, a power company based in Arlington, Va., said yesterday that it would acquire three power plants and a coal mine, giving it an 81 percent share of Tiszai Eromu Rt., a Hungarian electricity generation company. AES said it would pay up to $143 million for the stake. If offered, AES would acquire an additional 15 percent on similar terms. The plants represent about 20 percent of the electric generating capacity in Hungary. The sale would be the first investment by a United States company in the Hungarian energy sector.

title: Explosion Topples Contractor's Office
description: An explosion, apparently caused by a natural gas leak, leveled an electrical contractor's office in this Rochester suburb today.

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: IN WASHINGTON;Yeltsin's Health and Commitment on Economy Will Be Watched Closely by the U.S.
description: Amid the palpable relief in the Clinton Administration over Boris N. Yeltsin's victory in today's Russian election is some quiet wagering, officials say, over how quickly Mr. Yeltsin will have the bypass operation on his heart he so clearly seems to need.

title: Legal Aid Cannot Sue on Contracts
description: Saying that the statute of limitations had expired, a state judge yesterday dismissed a lawsuit by the Legal Aid Society that had sought to block the Giuliani administration from turning over nearly a tenth of its cases to new legal organizations.

title: BOXING;Cuban Boxers Are Released
description: Two highly rated members of the Cuban Olympic boxing team who are seeking asylum walked out of a detention facility today after being granted parole.

title: Company Briefs
description: CONAGRA INC., Omaha, said its poultry unit had bought the food processing business of Texas Smokehouse Foods Inc. of Lufkin, Tex., a maker of smoked and marinated meats and poultry products. Terms of the cash transaction were not disclosed.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Praise for Casino Road Plan
description: In a conciliatory gesture that left casino operators all declaring victory, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman yesterday announced a sweeping Atlantic City roadway and tunnel project that is intended to improve the city's overburdened arteries and smooth its hoped-for transformation into one of the gambling industry's foremost destinations. Her plan, which will cost at least $450 million, entails upgrading two highways and several local roads, and building a road and tunnel to new casinos in the Marina district. [Page A1.]

title: COMPANY NEWS;INDIVIDUAL BUYS NEWS SERVICE FOR $38 MILLION
description: Individual Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired Freeloader Inc. for about $38 million in cash and stock. Freeloader, based in Washington, is a personalized news service that retrieves information from the Internet's World Wide Web and delivers it to the personal computers of subscribers. Individual, based in Burlington, Mass., paid $2 million in cash and 1.9 million common shares for all Freeloader stock outstanding. Individual's stock fell $1.50 a share, to $15.75, in Nasdaq trading. Individual plans to integrate Freeloader's technology with its other customized news services.

title: ON BASEBALL;Mets' Gilkey Excels on Old-School Tactics
description: When you talk to the Mets' Tom McCraw about throwbacks, he does not pretend to remember the St. Louis Cardinals' Gas House Gang, the '27 Yankees or Ty Cobb.

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: IN THE CAPITAL;. . . As Yeltsin Camp Pops Champagne
description: Round midnight, while top Yeltsin campaign aides remained huddled behind closed office doors in the heavily guarded Presidential Hotel, champagne and cognac bottles were already uncorked across the hall, where young campaign aides gathered to celebrate the early, promising returns.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Lose Verbeek To Stars
description: The cost of doing business in the National Hockey League's 1996 free agent market apparently was too high for the Rangers regarding forward Pat Verbeek. Faced with having to pay him nearly $10 million over the next three years, the Rangers chose to let Verbeek go to the Dallas Stars yesterday, creating a hole that will be difficult to fill.

title: The Risks of Keeping a Promise;In Becoming an Icon, a Mill Owner Bets His Company
description: In his 60's, Aaron M. Feuerstein, awakening at 5:30 A.M., began to devote the first hour of his day to memorizing passages from Scripture and Shakespeare. He worried that age would erode his memory and this early- morning ritual became his daily antidote. Perhaps prophetically, he gravitated to Lear and Hamlet, each with his tragic flaw.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Entertainment-Media Deal
description: The Entertainment-Media Acquisition Corporation has agreed to acquire Overseas Filmgroup Inc., a Los Angeles-based independent film distributor, in a $24 million deal, the companies announced today.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;U.S. Accounts for Half Of Global Arms Exports
description: For the first time, the United States is providing more than half of the world's weapon supplies, according to a Federal report.

title: POLITICS: THIRD PARTY;Ex-Colorado Governor Nears A Decision on His Candidacy
description: Former Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado will hold a news conference at the University of Denver on Tuesday, prompting speculation that the maverick Democrat has decided to seek the Presidential nomination of Ross Perot's Reform Party.

title: HORSE RACING;Aces Rises to Top of Heap With Victory in Astoria
description: Seven very fast fillies, all of whom had won their debuts by as much as six lengths, stepped up into the stakes class yesterday for an encore at Belmont Park, and then only one of them was still undefeated: Aces, a daughter of Housebuster and grand-daughter of Secretariat.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GERIATRIC AND MEDICAL IN ACQUISITION TALKS
description: The Geriatric and Medical Companies said yesterday that it was in discussions with another party about a possible acquisition. The company said no agreement had been reached. James J. O'Malley, the company's vice president and chief financial officer, declined to name the other company involved or any financial details. Shares of Geriatric and Medical rose 50 cents yesterday, to $4, giving the company a current market capitalization of almost $62 million. The company, based in Philadelphia, is a health care concern.

title: Tiff on TV Takes Israel Cabinet Spat Public
description: In a blunt public confrontation with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, Foreign Minister David Levy threatened today to resign if his political ally, Ariel Sharon, is not appointed to the Cabinet by the time Mr. Netanyahu leaves for Washington on Monday for a meeting with President Clinton.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;2 Die From a Mattress Fire
description: A family's attempt to move a smoldering mattress touched off a fire that killed a woman and a young girl yesterday morning. The fire, at 16 Cortland Street in the Ironbound section, started when a candle fell on a bed in a second-floor bedroom, said Larry Krieger, a spokesman for the Newark Fire Department. The family of Madeline Matias, 3 years old, dragged the mattress out of their apartment, an act that Mr. Krieger said forced oxygen into the mattress in the same way that blowing on it would. The mattress burst into flames and ignited the apartment walls, trapping Madeline inside and also killing an upstairs neighbor, Rogeria Santos, 60.

title: U.S. Promises Arms if Muslims Join Croats
description: The Clinton Administration promised today to begin shipping weapons to Bosnia as early as this month if the Government here approves merging Muslim and Bosnian Croat troops into a single army.

title: Victims Deserve a Place in the Constitution
description: To the Editor:

title: Ferragamo, Italian Shoemaker, in Agreement to Acquire Ungaro
description: In a rare acquisition in the world of high fashion, Salvatore Ferragamo Italia S.p.A. said today that it had reached an agreement to buy Emanuel Ungaro S.A.

title: Sports of The Times;Summertime Blues Are Nothing New
description: FACES were long yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;U S West Unit In Media Deal
description: U S West Media Group Inc. has acquired a 10 percent equity interest in Preview Media Inc. for between $5 million and $10 million.

title: Speculation Swirls After Resignation of Pepsi Executive
description: As confused and startled employees of Pepsico Inc. debated yesterday the reasons why one of the company's top executives abruptly resigned, they faced one certainty: Roger A. Enrico, Pepsico's chief executive, is firmly in charge.

title: Giuliani Says Recycling Law Is Already Met
description: A day after declaring the city's recycling law an impossible standard to live by, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani altered his argument yesterday and said the city already recycles enough to meet the law's mandated levels.

title: Contractors Sued in Water Main Break
description: The city has filed a $10 million lawsuit against the companies that manufactured, supplied and installed the huge water main in Astoria, Queens, that ruptured in January after being in use for only five months.

title: Essay;'Their Just Powers'
description: In the days of Nixon's Donald Segretti, the disruption of opposition rallies was called "the black advance."

title: Canadian Rail Cutback
description: As part of a three-year plan to reorganize its rail network, the Canadian National Railway Company will dispose of 1,400 miles of railroad. The company said on Tuesday that the announcement was required under new legislation to make it easier for railroad companies to transfer noncore lines to short-line operators.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Stone of Scone to Return To Scots After 700 Years
description: The Stone of Scone, the ancient coronation seat of the kings of Scotland, is going home, 700 years after it was carried away to London by King Edward I, Prime Minister John Major announced today.

title: Corrections
description: The Metro Matters column on Monday, about the lack of movement in Albany on proposals to change the way New York City's schools are run, referred incorrectly to such a measure in the State Senate. While the Assembly has passed its competing bill, the Senate has not yet voted on a version.

title: Daiwa Says Broker Overcharged 2 Funds
description: Daiwa Securities USA said yesterday that a broker in its Los Angeles office had overcharged two mutual funds $300,000 for stocks it bought for the funds from 1988 to 1991.

title: 3 Charged in '78 Double Murder
description: For 18 years, Ira Johnson, Arthur Robinson and Juan Rodriguez got away with a double murder while four innocent men wasted away in prison, prosecutors said today.

title: Makers of the Pill Hide Behind Fears of Liability;Protests, Pro and Con
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Stocks Down
description: Stocks were trading lower here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues stood at 22,234.32, down 144.70 points, or nearly seven-tenths of 1 percent. On Wednesday, the index gained 31.05 points.

title: Federal Charges Weighed In Fireman's Death in Blaze
description: Acting partly in response to fierce criticism surrounding a Manhattan jury's acquittal of a man charged with setting a fire that killed a firefighter in 1994, Federal prosecutors said yesterday that they were looking into filing Federal arson charges against the man.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Escom Computer Seeks Creditor Protection
description: Escom Computer A.G. of Germany, Europe's second-largest computer retailer, filed yesterday for protection from its creditors.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ASTEA SHARES FALL 62% AFTER IT ANNOUNCES LOSS
description: The stock of Astea International Inc. plunged 62 percent yesterday after the company, a software maker based in Chalfont, Pa., said it expected to show a loss of 24 cents to 29 cents a share for the quarter that ended last Sunday. The company attributed its negative expectations to its failure to close contracts for several orders in the quarter as expected. But the company said it remained confident about its long-term direction. Analysts in a survey by First Call Inc. had expected Astea to earn 18 cents a share in the quarter, compared with 16 cents a year ago. Astea's shares tumbled $14.25 yesterday to close at $8.75 in Nasdaq trading of 5.5 million shares.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Rodriguez Replaces Gwynn for N.L.
description: Montreal Expos outfielder HENRY RODRIGUEZ was picked yesterday to replace the injured TONY GWYNN on the National League All-Star team.

title: homas Burke, 57; Helped Develop A Medicare Plan
description: Thomas R. Burke, a health economist and co-author of the Reagan Administration's failed effort to extend Medicare coverage to catastrophic illness, died on Monday at Alexandria Hospital in Virginia. An Alexandria resident, he was 57.

title: A Victory for Russian Democracy
description: The forces of democracy and reform won a vital but not definitive victory in Russia yesterday. It would be satisfying to declare the final defeat of Communism and the triumph of democracy and enlightened leadership. But Russia's reality does not justify euphoria today. Wary optimism seems more appropriate.

title: Drinks as Sweet as the Summer Air
description: WHEN the air-conditioning broke down at the Four Seasons Hotel in Manhattan three years ago, Rita Dever, the sous-chef, whipped up morale with "lemonades" made from all the fruit she could find: bing cherries, fragrant white peaches, tart blackberries.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Vibe Is Sold By Time Warner
description: Time Warner Inc. has sold Vibe magazine to Vibe Ventures, a partnership led by Quincy Jones and Robert Miller. Terms were not disclosed.

title: U.S. Markets Closed
description: All financial and commodities markets, banks and government offices in the United States are closed today in observance of the Fourth of July holiday. Most foreign markets are open.

title: Attack Widens on Clinton Staff Practices
description: The Clinton Administration sent detailed questionnaires to longtime White House employees asking them about their finances and their personal and political activities, the Pennsylvania Congressman leading an inquiry into the White House's handling of personnel information said today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Turnpike Alert on Fireworks
description: Traffic on the Newark Bay extension of the New Jersey Turnpike was so backed up during a fireworks display at Liberty State Park last July 4 that officials closed the eight-mile stretch of roadway and its interchanges at Bayonne, Jersey City and the Holland Tunnel to keep it clear for emergency vehicles.

title: Raiding a Vipers' Nest
description: Arizona and the nation may have been spared another burst of home-grown terrorism. Law enforcement officers moved swiftly to infiltrate, indict and this week disarm a disturbingly well-armed paramilitary cell called the Viper Militia.

title: OLYMPICS;Namibia's Fredericks Flirts With 100 Record
description: Frankie Fredericks of Namibia won a major pre-Olympic 100-meter dash tonight and came within one-hundredth of a second of Leroy Burrell's world record with a victorious time of 9.86 seconds.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Young Ensigns of Industry Face High-Tech Realities
description: For the goofy, laid-back heroes of "Pick Up Ax," Anthony Clarvoe's engaging business manual of a comedy at the 29th Street Repertory Theater, it's still possible to be a corporate executive without having blood on your hands. Still in their 20's, Brian Weiss (Thomas Wehrle) and Keith Rienzi (Neil Necastro) run their multimillion-dollar Silicon Valley company with minds clouded by marijuana smoke and a blissful ignorance of the competitive instinct.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Lufthansa Posts 47% Drop in Profit
description: Lufthansa said yesterday that its pretax profit fell 47 percent in the first half of the year. Lufthansa's chairman, Jurgen Weber, cited strong competition and a fire at the Dusseldorf airport, which cut traffic in April. Lufthansa said it had limited hiring at the parent company since February and had been offering discount fares to compete with other airlines.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Wetteland Is Rankled Over All-Star Queries
description: Minutes before the Yankees curiously postponed yesterday afternoon's game with the Boston Red Sox, John Wetteland was discussing the barrage of questions he has been fielding about the injustice of his fellow reliever Mariano Rivera not being selected for the All-Star team.

title: Economic Scene;Some second thoughts arise on the benefits of immigration.
description: WHILE the political system has long focused on whether heavy immigration is a burden and a threat, many economists have contended for years that foreign immigrants usually provide an overall benefit to the economy. But a new study from the Rand Corporation's Center for Research on Immigration Policy, "The Mixed Economic Progress of Immigrants," suggests that the economics profession is having some second thoughts.

title: F.D.A. Approves Sale of Nicotine Patch Without Prescription
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved the first nicotine patch for sale without prescription today to help smokers give up their habit.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Bridge
description: A Chicago team that has been knocking on the door for several years finally opened it last week at the International Team Trials in San Francisco. Larry Robbins, Jerry Goldfein, Gerald Caravelli, Gary Cohler, Steve Garner and Jack Oest defeated a series of star-studded teams to win the top honors, and will represent the United States in the world championships on the Greek island of Rhodes in October.

title: Gas Leakage May Delay Next Shuttle Flight
description: Hot gas seeped through joints in both rocket boosters during the launching of the space shuttle Columbia two weeks ago but did not damage the O-rings or endanger the shuttle or its crew, NASA said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Magnacom the Top Bidder in Wireless Auction
description: Magnacom Wireless L.L.C. offered the highest bids today on six licenses in the second round of a Federal Communications Commission re-auction of 18 wireless licenses.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Docks de France Shares Surge After Hostile Bid
description: Shares in Docks de France S.A., the French supermarket operator facing a hostile takeover bid, surged 13 percent yesterday in their first day of trading since they were suspended last month. The Docks shares closed at 1,233 francs, up 14 francs.

title: CYCLING;Breakaway Produces New Leader
description: The Tour de France, so quiet since its start last weekend, suddenly exploded today as the race turned east and began heading toward what was supposed to be its first big rendezvous in the Alps on Saturday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MET LIFE ASSUMES 25,000 POLICIES AND CONTRACTS
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, the second-largest United States life insurer, said yesterday that it had assumed nearly 25,000 life insurance policies and annuity contracts from the failed National Heritage Life Insurance Company. Met Life, which is based in New York, had said earlier this year that it would assume 20,595 annuity contracts and 3,888 policies of National's policyholders, retroactive to Jan. 1. National, based in Delaware, filed for bankruptcy in 1994 and was liquidated by insurance regulators in that state.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Hungary to Compensate Jews for Wartime Losses
description: The Government has agreed to compensate the Jewish community for property seized during World War II, a Jewish leader said today.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on June 23 about adjustment problems of Eastern European and Russian children adopted by Americans referred imprecisely to the role of the Family Resource Center in the adoption of a young boy, Alex, by Steve and Polly Taber in Wheaton, Ill. The center, an agency in Chicago, did an addendum to a home study for Alex's adoption by the Tabers. It did not place Alex with the Tabers for adoption, and it did not provide them information about him. Another agency placed Alex with the Tabers for adoption.

title: INSIDE
description: Giant Rail Merger Approved

title: Prayers for the 'Urgent Four'
description: There are moments when New York City sheds its frenetic, atomized personality and becomes a collection of several million souls, prayerfully preoccupied with the same event. This was true early last month, when a young woman was beaten nearly to death in Central Park. She arrived at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in a coma and without identification. An examination showed a fractured skull, probably caused when someone repeatedly smashed her head into the pavement. The staff named her "Urgent Four," signifying that she was the hospital's fourth unknown patient at the time.

title: A New Jordan Sneaker Inspires a Frenetic Run;A Planned Shoe Shortage, at $115 a Pair
description: Ulysses Coleman, who is 33 but nurses his obsession like a teen-ager, arrived at the Fulton Mall yesterday morning with blue bedroom slippers on his feet and a quarter wedged in his right ear. He turned out to be No. 3 in line, so the old slipper trick was unnecessary, though he swears it helped the last time the planet's most-hyped athletic shoe went on sale in Brooklyn.

title: How to Succeed' Closing
description: How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying," a revival of Frank Loesser's 1961 musical, with book by Abe Burrows, Jack Weinstock and Willie Gilbert, is to close after the matinee on July 14 at the Richard Rodgers Theater, 226 West 46th Street, Manhattan. That will be the play's 548th regular performance; it had 16 previews.

title: McGrath and Date Could Ruin Party
description: The presence of Steffi Graf and Arantxa Sanchez Vicario so close to the final round at any Grand Slam usually signifies curtains for their semifinal opponents, but this year at Wimbledon there are two fresh faces attempting to discourage the foregone conclusion of another Graf-Sanchez Vicario finale.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Watering Cactuses

title: A Porch, a Chair, No Care
description: IT'S as good a way of understanding liberty as any other.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Conflicts in Black Family Mirror Those on Streets
description: In a perverse way, it is a pleasure to watch a first-rate director (Walter Dallas) and cast try to impose conceptual unity on material that resists them to the end in the production of "In My Father's House," the new play by Samm-Art Williams at the Billie Holiday Theater in Brooklyn.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Dream Team Lesson: Image Is Everything
description: An invasion of suits took place near the end of practice. Mayor Richard Daley wanted to say hello to the Dream Team. Well- dressed onlookers wearing corporate name tags watched and smiled. A basketball team's preparation has been punctuated by the exchange of business cards, the presence of cellular phones and the ever-present offers of free merchandise.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Austere Struggles, Even Into Heaven, but Not All Bleak
description: Kei Takei's dances are austere yet not totally despairing visions of this world and perhaps the next. The Tokyo-born Ms. Takei moved to the United States in 1967 and soon became known for "Light," a cycle of short, powerful works. She last appeared in New York in 1989, and in 1992 she returned to Japan. The performance by her company, Moving Earth Orient Sphere, on Saturday night at La Mama showed that her choreography is as strong as ever.

title: Political Memo;Low-Altitude Campaign Frustrating Dole Aides
description: When Bill Clinton was in this pre-Democratic convention period four summers ago, he was battling not only President George Bush and Ross Perot but also a perception in his own dispirited party that he was heading for a third-place finish in November.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MELVILLE PLANS TO SELL OR SPIN OFF 34 BOB'S STORES
description: The Melville Corporation plans to shed its chain of 34 Bob's Stores in seven states as part of a reorganization. "A sale, a spinoff, an initial public offering -- anything is possible," a Melville spokeswoman, Wendy Kopsick, said. Bob's Stores also plans to open nine stores this year. Melville, based in Rye, N.Y., is splitting into two independent, publicly traded companies -- a drugstore chain and a shoe store chain. Melville, which posted a net loss of $657 million in 1995, has already shed Marshalls, Kay-Bee Toys and the This End Up furniture chain as part of its restructuring.

title: Elsewhere, Public Pools Are Less Strict
description: Most public pools across the New York region have rules about unaccompanied children that are less strict than the new regulations in New York City. And New York's approach, combining age and size, is rare. This year, New York City switched from requiring a chaperone for all children 8 and younger to requiring supervision for all children under 16 who are not eight inches taller than the deepest part of the pool.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Budget Impasse in Albany Extends Into the Holiday
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders conceded another setback on the budget today, saying they would be unable to reach agreement by their self-imposed deadline of July 4. Then they sent the Legislature home for the holiday weekend, virtually insuring that the longest budget fight in state history will drag well into next week.

title: BASEBALL;Ochoa Hits For the Cycle To Spark Mets
description: The Mets have gone to the greatest of pains to discourage the notion that Alex Ochoa is their savior. Fair enough. That would be more pressure than any 24-year-old could ever be expected to shoulder, especially when he has to play for a New York team.

title: Apple Names Technology Chief and Puzzles Many
description: Five months after beginning his overhaul of Apple Computer Inc., Gilbert F. Amelio put in place today the final -- and, perhaps, most crucial -- piece of the new management team that hopes to return Apple to its former position as the computer industry's top technological innovator.

title: DANCE REVIEW;An Eerie Comedy of Manners With Men in Dark Goggles
description: The Paris Opera Ballet's productions at the Metropolitan Opera House are certainly sumptuous, yet they can also seem insubstantial. "Le Parc," for instance, looks wonderful, thanks to its formal garden settings by Thierry Leproust and the way Herve Pierre's costumes combine 18th and 20th-century styles. The designs even strengthen Angelin Preljocaj's choreography in the eerie episodes involving men in dark-tinted goggles and black-and-gray outfits that make them resemble workers or racing-car drivers.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Erving's Son Arrested on Drug Charge
description: The 22-year-old son of the basketball legend JULIUS ERVING was charged with possessing drugs after the police said they saw him buy $5 worth of crack cocaine in North Philadelphia. CHEO ERVING, of Villanova, Pa., was arrested at 9:30 A.M. Monday. An undercover narcotics officer staking out a known drug peddler saw Erving drive up and make a deal, the police said. (AP)

title: Edward M. Brown, 66, Founder Of Lower East Side Drug Center
description: Edward Mason Brown, the president and founder of the Lower Eastside Service Center for treatment of drug and alcohol abuse, died on Friday at his home in Piermont, N.Y. He was 66.

title: Fed Leaves Rates Unchanged, and Focus Turns to August
description: The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged at the conclusion of a two-day meeting today, but analysts said the central bank might well push rates up later this summer unless there are pronounced signs that the economy is slowing.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Suit Seeks Minority Troopers
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has gone to court to try to get the New Jersey State Police to hire more minority troopers, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

title: Parents of Drowned Student Sue the Board of Education
description: The parents of a 13-year-old student who drowned on an overnight trip to Philadelphia announced a $75 million wrongful death suit against the Board of Education and the city yesterday, a day after a second youth died of injuries received in the same incident.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Amnesty Critical of Rate Of Executions in China
description: China has executed at least 1,000 people since it began a campaign against crime two months ago, Amnesty International said today. Most were executed immediately after unfair trials, the rights organization said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Store Owner Fatally Stabbed
description: The owner of a sneaker store was stabbed to death in her store on Red Bank's main shopping street yesterday morning, apparently during a robbery, the authorities said. The owner, Hae Sook Lee, 36, of Tinton Falls, was found in the back room of A & J Sneakers by an employee at 11:20 A.M., said Kevin Clark, assistant Monmouth County prosecutor. Mr. Clark said last night that investigators did not know what was taken from the store.

title: Independence Day: A Guide
description: FIREWORKS NEW YORK CITY Macy's fireworks display will be held over the East River at 9 P.M. F.D.R. Drive will be closed from 14th to 42nd Streets for spectators. Pedestrian access to F.D.R. Drive will be at 23d, 38th and 41st Streets.

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE FUTURE;YELTSIN DEFEATS COMMUNIST FOE BY A SURPRISINGLY WIDE MARGIN; HEALTH ISSUE LOOMS  FOR 2D TERM: A Future In Doubt
description: Nine months ago, Boris N. Yeltsin was hidden away in an elite Moscow hospital with severe heart problems. His popularity had sunk even lower than his health. It seemed improbable then that the ailing and discredited 65-year-old Russian President could run for re-election, let alone win.

title: Europe Begins Antitrust Inquiry on Airlines
description: The European Union began an antitrust investigation today into the planned alliance between British Airways and American Airlines, a subsidiary of the AMR Corporation. The organization said it would also investigate five existing linkups between United States and European carriers.

title: Metro Matters;Raising Hopes For Parents Of Disabled
description: FOR the first time in months, Judy and Stephen Goodhue may allow themselves to enjoy a holiday weekend. That is because, thanks to the State Legislature in Albany -- yes, that State Legislature -- it looks as though the Goodhues will not have to worry about the care of their profoundly disabled son, Jason.

title: African Peacekeeping Plan For Burundi Gains Ground
description: A regional proposal to send foreign troops into this country to stop an intensifying ethnic war between the Hutu and the Tutsi is gathering momentum, despite deep divisions in the Burundian Government about who would command the force and what its mission would be.

title: 8 Die as Blaze Erupts at Fireworks Store
description: A blaze erupted at a fireworks store busy with Fourth of July shoppers today, killing at least 8 people and injuring 12. Three people suspected of starting the fire were taken into custody, and one was charged.

title: Giuliani's Platform Doesn't Include a Vacation
description: It must be summer, because once again Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is refusing to take a vacation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;TV Rights Are Set For the World Cup
description: Kirch Group, a German television company, and Sporis Holding of Switzerland have been awarded the television rights for the 2002 and 2006 soccer World Cups, the sport's international governing body said today.

title: Liberties;Independence Day
description: Maybe it's all this talk about Hillary chatting up Eleanor. Or maybe the Fourth of July is putting me in a corny, bubbly, surrey-with-the-fringe-on-top state of mind.

title: Free Transit Transfers Penalize Some Riders
description: To the Editor:

title: I. D. Robbins Is Dead at 86; Pioneer in Low-Cost Homes
description: I. D. Robbins, a civic reformer and builder whose vision of low-cost single-family homes became reality for thousands of families in once-blighted areas of Brooklyn and the Bronx, died on Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 86 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: ROWING;3 Dartmouth Crews Sweep in England
description: Neither the wind, rain nor rough water on the Henley Royal Regatta's opening day could deter the Big Green of Dartmouth, which put three crews into competition today and brought home three convincing American victories.

title: Youth Crime Debate Is a Mirror to Society's Soul
description: To the Editor:

title: Study Finds the Pill Safer
description: The birth control pills now on the market do not appear to increase the risk of a stroke, a study has found.

title: Karadzic Says He Won't Run
description: The Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, said today that he would not run in the September elections in Bosnia. Under the peace accord Dr. Karadzic, who has been indicted for war crimes, was ineligible to run, but some supporters had urged him to do so anyway as an act of defiance.

title: Second Judge Overrules Crew On Suspension of Bronx Board
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew yesterday suffered another legal setback in his battle with troubled local school boards when a State Supreme Court justice set aside his suspension of School Board 9 in the Bronx, saying the Chancellor had exceeded his authority by unseating the board members in May.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;G.E.C. of Britain Posts 10% Profit Rise
description: The General Electric Company of Britain, a military and engineering giant, reported yesterday that it had a 10 percent rise in profit in the year ended March 31. (The company is not connected with G.E. of the United States.) The company's pretax profits rose by 10 percent, to L981 million ($1.53 billion). The annual dividend was raised 10 percent to 12.51 pence (19.46 cents) a share. (Reuters)

title: 800 Mourn Pilot From Long Island Killed by a Bomb
description: On a wooden fence across the street from Our Lady of Lourdes Church here, neighbors hung a red, white and blue banner with an epitaph scrawled in black marker: "Thank You Capt. Adams. God Bless You!"

title: Police Remove Popular Chief From Position
description: In a shake-up driven more by personality differences than by policy, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said yesterday that the Chief of Detectives, Charles G. Reuther, would be transferred and that the head of the department's Internal Affairs Bureau would replace him.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;A Hurricane With a Sax at Its Center
description: The road of excess is a superhighway through the music of the tenor saxophonist David Murray, who was his own triple bill at the Knitting Factory on Monday night. Concluding the Heineken "What Is Jazz?" Festival, Mr. Murray led an octet, a big band and a duo, only a few of the lineups he has worked with since he emerged in the 1970's. It was a night of sprawling solos, unbalanced ensembles and ad hoc structures. But with Mr. Murray at its center, the music regularly worked itself up to ecstatic peaks.

title: Makers of the Pill Hide Behind Fears of Liability
description: To the Editor:

title: Improved Helmets Make Cycling Safer
description: CYCLING purists may look down on mountain bikers, but these Olympic upstarts have improved the sport in one important way: safer helmets.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Fisher, Jones Get Contract Extentions
description: Two National Football League coaches who significantly improved the directions of their teams were rewarded with two-year contract extensions yesterday on their three-year deals.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section yesterday about discount dining programs referred incompletely to programs offered by Transmedia Services. The plan giving cardholders 25 percent off is available only to those who pay a $50 membership fee. A plan that started in January, available to organizations that provide the Transmedia card to their members, has no fee and gives a 20 percent discount.

title: TV WEEKEND;A Sioux Warrior of Destiny, Legend and Mystery
description: Continuing what it calls a "Native American programming initiative," Turner Network Television turns this Sunday to "Crazy Horse," the Oglala Sioux warrior whose battles to protect his people included the slaughter of George Armstrong Custer and his troops at Little Big Horn. Previous entries in this ambitious and laudable series have included "Geronimo," "Lakota Woman: Siege at Wounded Knee" and "Tecumseh: The Last Warrior."

title: Diner's Journal
description: Even the most jaded New Yorkers are excited about the reopening of Windows on the World; everyone I know is eager to eat there.

title: For Children
description: Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Bird Sanctuary

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on June 20 about the naming of Sicola Martin in Austin, Tex., to handle the Power PC technology advertising account for Motorola Inc. misstated the scope of the assignment. The assignment awarded to Sicola Martin was new; Anderson & Lembke, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, continues to work for Motorola, handling advertising for the Power PC Motorola RISC division.

title: Decision May Temper Effect Of Ruling on S.& L. Claims
