description: A new ruling by a Federal appeals court has raised concerns among savings institutions, which are studying it to see whether it undercuts a Supreme Court decision enabling them to pursue damage claims against the Government for breach of contract.

title: Holding Action in Hanoi
description: Vietnam's Communist Party ducked all the hard questions about its country's future this week. Instead of dealing with an aging leadership and the tensions produced by the development of a market economy in an authoritarian state, the Communists did some tinkering and left the difficult decisions for another day.

title: Why Prosecutors Choose Civil Forfeiture
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomas K. Thompson, 81, Church Executive, Dies
description: The Rev. Thomas Kirkland Thompson, an expert on church finances and fund raising, died last Friday at Doctors Hospital in Sarasota, Fla. He was 81 and a former resident of White Plains and Tulsa, Okla., who retired to Sarasota last year.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Rooted in Suburbia, Body and Soul
description: HOLY LAND A Suburban Memoir By D. J. Waldie Illustrated. 180 pages. W. W. Norton & Company. $24.

title: Two Cubans Wouldn't Toe Line for Olympic Glory
description: For both Ramon Garbey and Joel Casamayor, the years of training, success and intense political pressure, their frustrations and hopes, sports and personal identity, all came together a week ago in Guadalajara, Mexico.

title: Theater Official to Lead Covent Garden
description: The Royal Opera House at Covent Garden in London named Genista McIntosh, an experienced theater manager who is now the executive director at the Royal National Theater, as its new general director yesterday. She will take over next summer, when the current director, Sir Jeremy Isaacs, resumes his former career in television.

title: BASEBALL;Person Redeems Himself In Montreal
description: Robert Person isn't sure how long he will be in the big leagues, so he wants to leave behind a positive impression.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Boliw' Shrine Figures of the Bamana, Mali Peter Blum Gallery 99 Wooster Street SoHo Through Oct. 5

title: BASEBALL;A Bit Defensive? Kent Passes Buck
description: Jeff Kent made two sterling defensive plays tonight, snaring hard-hit ground balls in the second and fourth innings. Not bad for someone who had committed six errors in his previous five games and led the team with 19 errors.

title: 25 and Under
description: Is it too much to ask for a good Caesar salad?

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was not enough for HONOR MOORE, a poet and playwright, to write a biography of her maternal grandmother, Margarett Sargent. She also felt a profound need to take her grandmother's paintings out of storage and into the public eye.

title: ART REVIEW;Breaking Traditional Rules On What Makes a Craft
description: Without rehashing the old question Is it art or craft?, let's say there is a high proportion of engaging, energetic and quite singular work in "Breaking Barriers," the new show at the American Craft Museum. The exhibition is meant to emphasize the continuing liberation of crafts artists from the tight traditions of the field, which once decreed, among other strictures, that they should make functional things, demonstrating technical mastery, in the time-honored materials of clay, fiber, glass, metal and wood.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When he first agreed to conduct the Brahms "German Requiem" in Shanghai on July 12 and 13, JOHN NELSON assumed that it was to be performed in German, its original language. Then he decided differently. Mr. Nelson, who has conducted orchestras around the world, is a founder of Soli Deo Gloria, an organization that promotes performances of sacred symphonic and choral works in countries where they are not normally heard.

title: In Costume, An Issue Nags Dole
description: Tobacco has become a drag on Bob Dole, the presumed Republican Presidential nominee, partly because he is being shadowed through the land by Democrats in seven-foot, foam-rubber cigarette costumes.

title: Netanyahu Hints at Easing Barriers Against Palestinians
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said in an interview today that he was not a proponent of the travel restrictions that cost many Palestinians jobs in Israel and would consider loosening them if security conditions allowed.

title: Sex-Bias Decision Puts Crack in Glass Ceiling;  Female Authority
description: To the Editor:

title: Run and Take the Money
description: I'm a campaign fund-raiser, and this spring I weighed several offers to work for Congressional candidates. Except for the long hours, it's a charmed life: full control over the candidate's schedule, unlimited access to the candidate, plus a nice salary, free housing and a car.

title: Victor Lange, 87, Scholar of German
description: Victor Lange, a longtime Princeton University professor who was president of the International Society of Germanists for five years and received a University of California award in 1975 as the dean of German studies in the United States, died on Saturday in Princeton, N.J. He was 87 and lived in Princeton.

title: Sex-Bias Decision Puts Crack in Glass Ceiling;Women's Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Everyday 'Sale' Costs Chain
description: The newspaper advertisements touted televisions and washing machines as being "on sale." Only in very fine print did they mention that the items were on sale at their "everyday low price," according to a complaint filed in 1994 in Burlington County. Now American Appliance, a chain based in Pennsauken, has agreed to pay the state $50,000 to settle a false-advertising complaint, the Division of Consumer Affairs announced Wednesday. American Appliance was also accused of "bait and switch" tactics -- advertising an item at a very low price, then telling customers it was out of stock and trying to sell them a more expensive model. The company did not admit guilt in its settlement.

title: Drug Giant Ends Biopure Accord
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. is ending its agreement with the Biopure Corporation to develop Hemopure, a product being tested as a blood substitute in surgery.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: 12 Monkeys 1995. MCA/Universal. $102.31. Laser disk, $39.98. 130 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Changes Sought for Philadelphia Landmark
description: Again this year, thousands of visitors streamed past the Liberty Bell and into the urban park surrounding Independence Hall here today to observe the anniversary of the nation's birth. But under new proposals for the historic sites tucked into the narrow tree-lined streets of Philadelphia's Old City neighborhood, visitors in coming years could find a substantially altered vista.

title: Why Prosecutors Choose Civil Forfeiture;Measuring Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Ground Zero Chosen By Bijan Fragrances
description: Bijan Fragrances in Beverly Hills, Calif., has named Ground Zero in Santa Monica, Calif., to handle a campaign, planned for the fall, to introduce a fragrance named for the basketball star Michael Jordan. Billings were estimated at $20 million.

title: Beaches Are for People
description: To the Editor:

title: Real Estate;The market for family-size apartments on the Upper East Side is surging. Well, maybe.
description: A "HOT property" is not necessarily one that is soaring in market value.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;With Yeltsin's Re-election, Funds Look to Russia
description: Managers of mutual funds that invest in Russian stocks expect an increase in money flowing into the country with President Boris N. Yeltsin's re-election.

title: Sex-Bias Decision Puts Crack in Glass Ceiling;Not Physically Equal
description: To the Editor:

title: Abroad at Home;Down the River
description: Judge us by what we do, not what we say. If you apply that adage to what the Supreme Court and other courts have done on issues of race in recent months, the message is unmistakable. The legal effort to bring more blacks into the mainstream of politics and education is being derailed.

title: A Mountain of Money and Sacred Spirit
description: To the Editor:

title: Volatile Mix in Viper Militia: Hatred Plus a Love for Guns
description: On West Shangri-La Road, a quiet street where children pedal bicycles past ornamental cactuses and yellow desert blooms, the two men living at number 6748 led a suburban life that was, well, different.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Shanghai Triad 1995. Columbia Tri-Star. $97.51. Laser disk, $34.95. 109 minutes. Mandarin with English subtitles. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: A Hungarian Fairy Tale 1988. Fox Lorber. $89.98. 97 minutes. Hungarian with English subtitles. No rating.

title: Imperial Prize for Twombly
description: The American painter Cy Twombly was named today among the winners of this year's Praemium Imperiale, or Imperial Prize, which was created by the Japan Art Association in 1989 to reward excellence in areas of culture not recognized by the Nobel Prizes.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on June 18 about the Office of Alternative Medicine of the National Institutes of Health referred incompletely to its method of awarding research grants. Applications first undergo a review procedure by outside experts and by an advisory council of the appropriate institute of the N.I.H. Only then are applications reviewed by staff members and by the advisory panel of the Office of Alternative Medicine.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Many Districts Exceed Limit
description: More than half the state's school districts exceed the spending limits proposed recently by Governor Whitman, according to a study reported by The Record of Hackensack yesterday. For example, the study, prepared by the nonpartisan Office of Legislative Services, found that 87 percent of school districts in Morris County and 83 percent of Bergen County districts spend more than the Governor says they need to. Under the Governor's plan, proposed in May in response to the State Supreme Court's order to eliminate the spending gap between rich and poor schools, districts that want to spend more than $8,285 per student would have to get approval from voters.

title: Canada Geese Are Becoming Burgers
description: Clumps of beige baby fuzz still clinging to the fresh black plumage on their necks, dozens of flightless young Canada geese and a few of their parents scurried across the dirt here next to a lilypad-covered pond flanked by cottonwood, trembling aspen and black oak.

title: BAASEBALL;Gooden Looks Forward To a Strawberry Reunion
description: In returning to the Yankees, Darryl Strawberry will be reunited with Dwight Gooden, who has made his own remarkable comeback by way of a George Steinbrenner signing.

title: 3 Are Killed In 2 Shootings In Brooklyn
description: Three men were killed and five injured, one critically, in two shootings that occurred within one block and two hours of each other last night in the Sunset Park section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Restaurants
description: With my first bite of Thai food, I knew I had to go to Thailand. Tasting the flavors as they exploded in my mouth, I felt I had waited my whole life for that particular combination of hot and sweet spices.

title: The Police Department Glares, And Bombs Don't Burst in the Air
description: In a test of wills between the Giuliani administration and would-be pyrotechnists, hundreds of police officers fanned out across the city yesterday to enforce a "zero tolerance" policy against illegal fireworks, bringing an unusual Fourth of July quiet to many areas and transforming one Queens neighborhood into an armed camp to prevent an annual fireworks display.

title: Allied Products Bought by CRH
description: CRH P.L.C. of Ireland said yesterday that it would acquire the Allied Building Products Corporation, a New Jersey manufacturer of building materials, for $121 million in cash.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tax Relief Becomes Law
description: As a holiday crowd cheered and "Born in the U.S.A." blared from loudspeakers, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a $100 million property tax relief bill yesterday at a ceremony on Point Pleasant's boardwalk, The Associated Press reported. The measure, included in the $15.9 billion state budget, allows residents to deduct part of their rent or property taxes from income on their tax returns. It is expected to save the average family about $73 next year.

title: Inside Art
description: One British Treasure Is Lost

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Dream Team Exhibition Series
description: The United States women's national basketball team found itself in the middle of a controversy early in its exhibition tour last fall when REBECCA LOBO, the 1995 national college player of the year, did not start in a nationally televised game against her old team, the University of Connecticut. Sentimentality will not become an issue when the men's Olympic team begins its five-game exhibition series tomorrow afternoon at the Palace in Auburn Hills, Mich.

title: Home Video
description: Thanksgiving Releases

title: A Hard-Liner's Ballot Victory Doesn't Panic Israeli Markets
description: Benjamin Netanyahu's electoral victory in May wasn't the outcome investors in Israel had been hoping for. But little more than a month later, a consensus is growing that his ascension to power isn't anywhere near the setback they had feared.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-10

title: No Headline
description: I want to congratulate President Yeltsin on his re- election -- it has a nice ring to it."

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Drug Companies Step Up Promotion of AIDS Drugs Pharmaceutical companies are becoming more aggressive in marketing drugs for the treatment of the virus that causes AIDS. The promotions resemble the selling of ulcer treatments and cholesterol-lowering medications. The push comes as more AIDS drugs enter the marketplace. At least a dozen new drugs have just reached the market, are awaiting Government approval or are in the late stages of clinical trials. [Page A1.]

title: Suspect Arrested in Coffee Shop Raids
description: In the end, the police said, Manhattan's coffee bandit was not sitting at a Starbucks sipping a tall one when he was caught.

title: Bank's Good-Neighbor Efforts Yield Some Unwanted Returns;Risky Mortgages Force Eviction of Paying Tenants
description: Jillur Rahman has spent five years in his brick house in Midwood, Brooklyn, long enough to know every face on his block and for his 4-year-old son to know no other home.

title: Graft Inquiry in Mexico Ties Zedillo to Disputed Payment
description: A commission investigating Government corruption in Mexico has implicated President Ernesto Zedillo in a questionable Government payment to a company controlled by a leading supporter of his political party.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: Violence at Demonstrations on Immigration
description: Rival Independence Day demonstrations on illegal immigration erupted violently today when protesters beat one another with fists, picket signs and filled soda cans in front of the Federal building near the campus of the University of California at Los Angeles.

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE OVERVIEW;YELTSIN APPEALS TO NATION TO END POLITICAL BREACH
description: Pledging to "resurrect Russia" after his decisive victory over a Communist opponent, a visibly pleased Boris N. Yeltsin reappointed Viktor S. Chernomyrdin as Prime Minister today and appealed to the nation to overcome its political discord.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Old Name Is New for Casino
description: A familiar name returned to the Boardwalk yesterday after an eight-year absence. The Tropworld Casino and Entertainment Resort is now called the Tropicana Casino and Resort -- a change that restores a name cast off in 1988, when the hotel opened a $19 million indoor amusement park. That park, known as Tivoli Pier, has since become a poker pit.

title: INSIDE
description: Water Plan Opposed

title: Fatal Blaze in Fireworks Store Leaves Ohio Town Stunned
description: The black soot covering the red, white and blue letters that once spelled "fireworks" symbolized the feelings of residents who said the Fourth of July holiday here would never be the same.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Unlikely Credits for a Korean Movie Mogul
description: Miky Lee sees nothing odd in her family company jumping from making sugar, shampoo and swine feed to making movies with Steven Spielberg.

title: African Athletes at Home in South
description: Some will run with Nike on their chest. When the greatest distance runners in the world cross the finish line in the 1996 Summer Olympic Games in Atlanta, television cameras will record not only the pure joy and intense agony of their effort, but also the brand of their corporate sponsor.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the funeral of Christopher J. Adams, the Air Force captain killed by a terrorist bomb in Saudi Arabia, reversed the identities of two relatives in some copies. His grandmother, Bridget McNelis, was at the left, and his mother, Catherine, at the right.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;. . . and Gerald Wilkins Is Cut
description: The veteran guards GERALD WILKINS, Dominique's brother, and ERIC MURDOCK were released by Vancouver on Wednesday as the Grizzlies decided not to pick up options on their contracts worth about a combined $5 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * Bill Whitehead, president and chief operating officer at Bates USA, New York, and chief operating officer at Bates North America, both units of Cordiant P.L.C., was promoted to chief executive at Bates North America. That title had last been held by Frank Assumma, who left in September to join Wells Rich Greene BDDP, New York, a unit of BDDP Worldwide, as chairman and chief executive. * Larry Goodman, executive vice president for news and operations at Turner Broadcasting Sales Inc., New York, a unit of Turner Broadcasting System Inc., was promoted to a new post, president for news sales and marketing. Also, Joe Uva, executive vice president for entertainment sales and marketing, was promoted to a new position, president for entertainment sales and marketing.

title: Scalpers, Weather and Luck Mar Carrier's Visit to Dublin
description: The Irish, who have historically turned their backs to the surrounding sea, watching as the Vikings and other invaders created all the island's major ports, have been coming to Dublin Bay by the tens of thousands in recent days to see the largest warship ever to drop anchor in these waters.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Making an Alto Saxophone Sound as if It's a Tenor
description: Jackie McLean was Charlie Parker's protege 50 years ago and then graduated from three major modern jazz "universities" -- the bands of Miles Davis, Art Blakey and Charles Mingus -- before making some of the most inventive Blue Note recordings of the 1960's. On Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard, Mr. McLean showed off the intense, hard tone that has been his most consistent companion since he picked up the alto saxophone, determined to make it sound like a tenor.

title: Art in Review
description: Peter Waite Edward Thorp Gallery 103 Prince Street SoHo Through July 26

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: U.S. REACTION;Clinton Hails Election as a Spurning of 'Tyranny'
description: President Clinton today praised President Boris N. Yeltsin's election victory as a milestone in Russia's democratic progress, saying that Russian voters had "turned their backs on tyranny."

title: Pipeline Builders See Growing Opportunities : Linking Up Southeast Asia
description: SINGAPORE  Growing demand for natural gas in Southeast Asia is creating billions of dollars of opportunities for companies involved in gas pipeline construction.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;TV's Elvis Sightings
description: IT'S one thing to hear the conventional wisdom: that Elvis Presley once stunned television audiences and brought an irreversible wave of youth and sexual daring to the 1950's. It's a more entertaining thing to have the visual evidence in front of you. In his early television appearances, Elvis curls his upper lip, bends his knees, swivels his hips and looks as if he can barely restrain himself from leaping around the stage. His hair is in a glossy high pompadour and he has the aura of a man who knows he's gorgeous and irresistible.

title: U.S. Is Considering Dispersal of Troops Inside Saudi Arabia
description: The Pentagon is considering a plan to move hundreds of American troops from Saudi Arabian cities to installations elsewhere in the country where they would be better protected from the sort of terrorist attack that killed 19 Americans last week, Defense Secretary William J. Perry said yesterday.

title: For Safety, Pentagon May Scatter G.I.'s Around Saudi Arabia
description: The Pentagon is considering a plan to move hundreds of American troops from Saudi Arabian cities to installations elsewhere in the country where they would be better protected from the sort of terrorist attack that killed 19 Americans last week, Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Olivetti Picks Sole Successor To 2 Chiefs
description: Olivetti S.p.A. named a new chief executive today as Carlo De Benedetti, head of the company since 1978, stepped down, as expected.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Stir Strawberry Into the Mix Once Again
description: Rising out of the obscurity of an independent minor league in the Upper Midwest, Darryl Strawberry will return to the Yankees, most likely next week after the All-Star Game break, for his second last chance in less than a year.

title: Air France Sets a Merger Amid Protests
description: Air France introduced a long-anticipated plan today to merge its international and regional carriers despite fierce opposition from unions, which staged a disruptive one-day strike at the regional carrier, Air France Europe.

title: Arthur Ashe Statue Set Up in Richmond at Last
description: After months of rancor over where to install a monument to Arthur Ashe here in his hometown, a bronze statue of him was set atop a stone column on Wednesday on a street dedicated to Confederate icons.

title: Cover Me! I'm Going for Popcorn!
description: The other evening, my wife, Elizabeth, and I arranged to see one of the new blockbuster action movies we've heard about. After settling our daughter with her baby sitter, we got into the family Toyota. "It's wired!" Elizabeth shouted when I turned the key.

title: Pulitzer Acquires Scripps League
description: The Pulitzer Publishing Company has completed its acquisition of Scripps League Newspapers for the final price of $214.1 million.

title: Connecticut Hit By a Tornado, Hail and Floods
description: Scores of residents in the south-central Connecticut towns of Wolcott and Waterbury spent yesterday's holiday stretching plastic over caved-in roofs and clearing splintered trees from houses and porches after a tornado cut a swath through the towns on Wednesday morning.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: SPORTS BUSINESS;O'Neal's Web Site Is Underwhelming
description: As a new traveler in cyberspace, I am trolling for the specialness of the Internet, at least as it relates to sports. NBC's Web site is chock full of Olympic info (get your fencing schedule!). Clark Kellogg's site will provide a whole new lexicon of basketball terms ("squeezing the pineapple").

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;German Will Lead BMW's British Unit
description: In a surprise move, BMW said today that it was naming a German, Walter Hasselkus, to take over as chief of its British unit, the Rover Group.

title: The Spoken Word
description: WALTER MOSLEY, Book Revue, 313 New York Avenue, at Main Street (Route 25A), Huntington, N.Y. The author will discuss his new book, "A Little Yellow Dog." Tomorrow at 8 P.M. Free. Information: (516) 271-1442.

title: Yoko Ono in a Cross-Cultural Collage
description: New Yorkers are probably more musically sophisticated than the residents of many other cities because they are assaulted by such a wide variety of sounds. From the avant-garde saxophonist playing in the subway to the Jeep blasting hip-hop, from the salsa wafting from a bodega to the Hindi pop drifting from the doorway speakers of an Indian restaurant, New York City offers its musicians a lot of potential inspiration.

title: Up to 80 Die in New Violence in Burundi
description: The Tutsi-dominated army in Burundi said today that Hutu rebels had killed up to 80 workers and their families at a tea factory in the northwest of the ethnically torn country.

title: Celebrating July 4 Spirit, Undaunted But Damp
description: Some Fourth of July.

title: Russians Finally Exhale
description: For months Russia has been seemingly at war with itself, but the mood after the vote was not one of discord, but of reconciliation and self-congratulation. News analysis, page A6.

title: Sports of The Times;Can Darryl Carry Tune For Yankees?
description: THE Boss was born on the Fourth of July, to the crackle of fireworks and the blare of the brass bands. No wonder he loves Sousa marches and George M. Cohan grand-old-flag razzmatazz enough to inflict them on a symphony orchestra dedicated to classical music.

title: Blackout Inquiry Looks at Wyoming Plant
description: A Wyoming power plant may be to blame for blackouts that affected up to two million customers in eight Western states on Tuesday and, for two consecutive days, knocked out power to southwestern Idaho.

title: Critics of Watershed Plan See Tilt Toward Upstate Evolving
description: Last November, Gov. George E. Pataki, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and representatives of communities around New York City's 19 upstate reservoirs announced a $1.5 billion plan to protect the city's drinking water without the city's having to build a budget-busting $7 billion water filtration plant.

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE PRIME MINISTER;Premier Is Savoring Comeback Of His Own
description: Russia's usually stolid and unemotional Prime Minister, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, said today he was "all choked up," over President Boris N. Yeltsin's momentous election victory and could barely speak.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Nixon 1995. Hollywood. $100.72. Laser disk, $69.99. 191 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;City Split on Iverson Day
description: Plans by Hampton, Va., to honor the former high school star ALLEN IVERSON have stirred controversy with residents who said Iverson was not worthy of the recognition.

title: Mentally Ill Lose In Managed-Care Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: A Move to Hospitals-for-Profit Gaining Support in New York
description: With hospitals laying off record numbers of employees and falling behind in paying their bills, officials in New York's health care industry are contemplating something once considered unthinkable here: allowing public, profit-making companies to own hospitals in the state.

title: Drug Companies Turn Aggressive In Promoting New Drugs for AIDS
description: A few years ago, medicine's weaponry against H.I.V. consisted of a single drug, AZT, that did not work very well and had awful side effects. Today, at least a dozen new drugs for the treatment of the virus that causes AIDS have just reached the market, are awaiting Government approval or are in the late stages of clinical trials.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Building a Better Eraser
description: The built-in pencil eraser, though largely unchanged for decades, is far from a perfect invention. On one hand, a brand-new pencil has too much eraser -- it sticks too far out from its metal holder and tends to snap off under normal pressure. On the other hand, there never seems to be enough eraser to last for an entire pencil.

title: Clinton Tones Down Politics To Hail Glories of Democracy
description: With a nonpartisan nod to the glories of nature and nationhood, and applause for Boris N. Yeltsin's re-election in Russia, President Clinton marked Independence Day at a riverfront rally in this Midwestern swing state whose support he hopes will help insure his own re-election this fall.

title: NYC;At WNYC, Independence Has Its Price
description: ALL things considered, the two WNYC radio stations got off to a fine start flying solo this week, their first days of independence from their old master, the New York City government.

title: Pale Journal;With Flaming Palette, Artists Paint Serbian Rage
description: As Militch Stankovic put the finishing brush strokes on his newest work, "The Trial of the Disemboweled Heart: Mladic and Karadzic Accused," it was clear why he has earned reknown as the artist-of-choice among Serbs indicted on charges of war crimes.

title: THE RUSSIAN VOTE: THE PROSPECTS;Yeltsin's Moment: Can the President Build on His Victory?
description: For the last six months Russia has been a country seemingly at war with itself. There has been no fighting in the streets, but not one of the many candidates for the presidency could avoid mentioning the ominous possibility that the new Russia's first presidential election might end in civil war.

title: Hotels Are Showing the Job Vacancy Sign
description: In the face of high turnover in a rapidly expanding industry, the nation's hotels are experiencing the worst employment shortage since they began to recover from the recession that hit their market in 1988.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: After Encores, Big Time- Bound

title: Greek Orthodox Church Is Poised for Change
description: Delegates to a congress of Greek Orthodox Christians this week discovered the difficulty of charting a course for their church without knowing who would be at the helm.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SOCCER;Adidas Buys French Team
description: The Olympic Marseilles soccer club, plagued by one of France's biggest sports scandals, is being purchased by Adidas.

title: For Dole, Upbeat Crowd on a Spirited Day
description: Clutching a tiny American flag, Bob Dole marched briskly down Main Street here today, celebrating the Fourth of July in one of the most Republican communities in the nation with a parade of screaming fire engines, marching bands and grizzled contingents of other surviving veterans of the nation's wars.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Copycat Radio Station Challenges a St. Louis Institution
description: For decades, KMOX-AM, St. Louis, has been a dominant radio station in the Midwest. Its 50,000-watt, clear-channel signal allows it to be heard in at least eight states; its ownership by CBS Radio gives it the programming power and financial muscle to rank first in the local market, first among the CBS stations, and, at times, first nationally, as measured by market share. With a longstanding tradition of community involvement, the station was a St. Louis institution.

title: TENNIS;Sampras's Reign at Wimbledon Ended by Krajicek's Big Hits
description: Left hanging on a cliff a scant five games from defeat on Wednesday night, the three-time champion Pete Sampras was rudely pushed over the edge today by Richard Krajicek, the player who has come to be known around Wimbledon as the Dutch Destroyer.

title: Advertising;With aliens blowing up the White House, can anything provide 110 percent protection?
description: IT'S time again to ask 20 questions about advertising, marketing and the media.

title: Market Place;Valujet Stock: Short Sellers' Nightmare
description: Valujet, the ill-fated airline whose aged jet crashed in the Everglades in May, may or may not resume flights soon. But its stock is acting as if its success is assured.

title: CYCLING;This Road to Atlanta Swings Through France
description: Along with the 185 other riders left in the Tour de France, Lance Armstrong rode languidly due south today, heading toward the Alps and a long weekend of climbing.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Declaration Signer Honored
description: While most of the state celebrated Independence Day with picnics and fireworks, a white-gloved contingent from the Daughters of the American Revolution held a much more solemn ceremony yesterday in Princeton Cemetery to honor the only clergyman to sign the Declaration of Independence. Before a crowd of about two dozen, Ann Leadbetter of Chestertown, Md., dedicated a bronze plaque at the grave of her great-great-great-great-great-grandfather, the Rev. John Witherspoon, a Presbyterian minister and early president of what is now Princeton University.

title: Viper Militia Case Relied on Informer
description: The arrests of 12 members of the Viper Militia came after the group was penetrated by a wildlife officer who went undercover, took the "militiaman's oath" and agreed to kill infiltrators, a newspaper reported today.

title: HORSE RACING;Wekiva Springs in Control In the Suburban at Belmont
description: The stable that gave you Cigar and Geri gave you Wekiva Springs in his star-for-a-day role again yesterday, and the 5-year-old gray made it two in a row at Belmont Park, where he won the $500,000 Suburban Handicap over Mahogany Hall and L'Carriere.

title: Art in Review
description: Don Porcaro Kouros Gallery 23 East 73d Street Manhattan Through July 13

title: Paying Bills Without Any Litter;Visa Spearheads a Switch to All-Electronic Collections
description: It is like a scene from a futuristic movie of the 1960's. Truck after truck delivers mail to a vast loading dock north of downtown Los Angeles. Thousands of envelopes move briskly along a conveyor belt until they are sucked into a 30-foot-long contraption buzzing loudly with spinning rollers and flashing lights.

title: Cautiously, Karpov Glides Into a Draw
description: Anatoly Karpov took another half-step yesterday on the way to winning the International Chess Federation's world championship match in Elista, Russia. By drawing Game 15 with Gata Kamsky, Karpov edged the match score up to 9 1/2-5 1/2, and thus needs just one more point to win the series and the $937,500 prize. Either a victory tomorrow or a draw followed by another draw on Monday will do it.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;U.S. Ponders Gambling Study
description: The United States Senate is expected to vote this month on whether to form a commission to study the social and economic effects of gambling in America. The nine-member commission would be appointed by the President and the leaders of the House and Senate. Representative Frank A. LoBiondo, a Republican whose district includes Atlantic City, said the legislation, which passed the House by a voice vote, violated states' rights. "This commission is the first step in creating Federal control for what has been and should be a decision by individual states," Mr. LoBiondo said. He said the bill's sponsors were looking to ban gambling.

title: ART REVIEW;A Cold Eye On All That Joie de Vivre
description: BY now it's hard to see Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec's art with fresh and unjaundiced eyes -- or put differently, to recognize the jaundiced eye he brought to his art. Everybody today knows his posters of La Goulue high-stepping at the Moulin Rouge, and of Aristide Bruant of Le Mirliton in his black cape and hat and his signature scarf. You don't have to have come across them in museums or books, because they've been banalized on cocktail napkins and souvenir ashtrays so many times that they were long ago swallowed up, along with the Eiffel Tower and the Mona Lisa, in the great collective morass of popular culture.

title: GOLF;Charles, With 66, Leads U.S. Senior Open by 3
description: Bob Charles, the left-hander from New Zealand, played especially well on several of the dogleg holes of the Canterbury Golf Club to take a three-shot lead in today's opening round of the 17th United States Senior Open.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Dominique Wilkins Is Sued . . .
description: DOMINIQUE WILKINS, accused of faking injuries and being AWOL, is now unwanted and being sued by the Greek team he led to the European championship last season.

title: Art in Review
description: El Anatsui and Sol LeWitt Skoto Gallery 25 Prince Street SoHo Through July 27

title: ART REVIEW;Bright Lights and Big-City Dreams
description: Like New York City itself, "NYNY: City of Ambition" at the Whitney Museum of American Art is bold, tacky and a little dangerous. Organized by two of the museum's curators, Elisabeth Sussman and John G. Hanhardt, with layout and installation conceived by the designer Tibor Kalman, the show tends to err on the side of extravagance and overstatement, a very New York thing. If there were an Acoustiguide, it would probably be narrated by Liza Minnelli.

title: Transit Chief Gets Chance To Fill Posts
description: The Transit Authority's bus system and its long-term capital program, which have been dogged by problems and controversy in recent years, will be getting new leaders in the near future.

title: TENNIS;Sanchez Vicario In Final
description: Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, who has made a habit of reaching Grand Slam finals lately only to be eclipsed by Steffi Graf once she gets there, tonight raced into this year's Wimbledon final with a 6-1, 6-2 victory over unseeded Meredith McGrath in a match that lasted only 61 minutes.

title: Birth Control, the Morning After
description: A Government advisory committee has concluded that ordinary birth control pills can be used safely and effectively to prevent pregnancy within 72 hours after sexual intercourse. This seldom-mentioned power of the pills to serve as "morning after" contraceptives could help cut the number of unwanted pregnancies in this country and thus reduce the need for surgical abortions. The committee has performed a valuable service in alerting women and their doctors to the existence of a safe, available, private method of preventing a fertilized egg from progressing to pregnancy.

title: United Dominion Plans to Buy Apartments
description: United Dominion Realty Trust Inc. has agreed to buy 18 apartment communities for $184 million, extending its lead as the Southeast's largest owner of apartments.

title: Filegate' Was Bad Enough. Now This?
description: The F.B.I. called again last month. It phones several times a year to ask me about former students who are seeking sensitive Government jobs. I could verify that indeed it was the Federal Bureau of Investigation calling. The voice-mail message had the bureau's telephone exchange, and the agent talked the way agents do, unfailingly polite and right to the point.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Sex-Bias Decision Puts Crack in Glass Ceiling
description: To the Editor:

title: In America;More N.R.A. Mischief
description: For more than a decade the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has been studying the epidemiology and demographics of violence in the United States, treating violence as a major public health problem.

title: CREW;U.S. Rowers Survive the Gusts
description: Although the rain ceased, the wind increased today on the second day of this year's Henley Royal Regatta, making the River Thames more suitable for wind surfing than rowing, especially for the lightweight crews competing against their heavyweight brethren.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Microsoft in Joint Venture
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. and the Microsoft Corporation announced today a joint-marketing venture aimed at small businesses in Britain.

title: Art in Review
description: Byron Kim Dieu Donne Papermill 433 Broome Street SoHo Through July 27

title: Harold Ruvoldt Sr., Jersey City Lawyer, 85
description: Harold J. Ruvoldt Sr., a lawyer who practiced in Jersey City for more than 50 years, died on Monday at his home in Deal, N.J. He was 85.

title: DANCE REVIEW;More Savvy-Seeming, but Still Loyal to the Founders
description: Mystery, humor, sex and general mayhem were the order of the evening on Wednesday night when the Pilobolus Dance Theater presented the third and final new program of its 25th anniversary season at the Joyce Theater. Three classics and an adroit opening number suggested that the company had kept to its founding principles even as new performers brought a new kind of sophistication to the work.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Marketers Choose Different Agencies
description: Two consumer marketers are changing agencies.

title: DANCE REVIEW;A Surprise Before Intermission Ends
description: Mark Dendy made an entire theater an esthetic house of worship in "Ritual," the most spectacular of the three choreographically rich premieres that Mark Dendy Dance and Theater presented on Wednesday night as part of the American Dance Festival at Duke University here.

title: Markets Closing Early
description: Most financial and commodities markets in the United States are reopening today after being closed in observance of the Fourth of July holiday. But the trading sessions will be abbreviated. The stock market will close at 1 P.M. Eastern daylight time, while bond trading is to end at 2 P.M. The commodities exchanges in Chicago are open, but those in New York are closed. Most foreign markets were open yesterday.

title: Happy Trails Along the Hudson
description: FOR most of this century, the Hudson has been the John Barrymore of rivers, noble in profile but a sorry wreck. Decades of binging on toxic chemicals gradually took its toll, and although the river's grandeur could not be denied, most people, looking at the Hudson, could only shake their heads in sorrow. The mighty river, once home to porpoises and even reportedly a whale, had entered the final stages of decline, fit habitat only for a few funky fish.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * YM, New York, a magazine of the Gruner & Jahr U.S.A. Publishing unit of Bertelsmann A.G., to Hill, Holliday/Altschiller, New York, which is owned by Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, to handle its account. Billings on the account, which had been unassigned for 18 months, were not disclosed.

title: No' to Aggressive Panhandlers
description: With the support of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani, the City Council is on its way to adopting a new law aimed at cracking down on aggressive panhandlers on city streets and any form of soliciting or begging within 10 feet of an automatic teller machine. The law would also outlaw solicitation of any kind directed at cars in city streets, making it easier to stop "squeegee men" from harassing motorists. The proposed legislation would not outlaw begging itself, which is constitutionally protected as an act of free speech. In general, it has been carefully drafted to avoid trampling on civil liberties. Some of the language does cause concern, however, and should be amended before the legislation is adopted.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;Mostly African Scenes, All by Africans
description: Photography can be a deeply passionate medium, and a sense of that passion comes across in "In/sight: African Photographers, 1940 to the Present" at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum.

title: Scientists Say Toxin in Red Tide Killed Scores of Manatees
description: After months of urgent research, scientists at the University of Miami have concluded that a toxin from red tide is the cause of a record number of deaths among manatees in Florida this year.

title: In Mideast, Egypt Plays No Double Game
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Strictly Business: Yanks Get Victory No. 50
description: Sticking to the details over the distractions, the Yankees quietly and proficiently won yesterday for the 50th time in 82 games.

title: German Military Today: Job Grows, More Say No
description: When Falk Sauer received notification that he was eligible for the draft, he had no doubts about how best to serve himself and his country. The 24-year-old electrician joined the German Army as a conscript, later extended his military service in a transport battalion to four years and ended up running supply convoys into Bosnia as part of Germany's first military deployment to a place still scarred by memories of the Nazis.

title: Tours, Music, Fireworks And Holiday Festivals
description: Here is a sampling of activities this Fourth of July holiday weekend around the three-state region.

title: Correction
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about Carl Hiaasen, the best-selling author of "Striptease" and other novels, supplied an incorrect pronunciation of his surname. It is pronounced HIGH-uh-sen.

title: Man Charged in Store Inferno Had Lobotomy as a Teen-Ager
description: As Todd Hall was arraigned today on charges of involuntary manslaughter for a fire on Wednesday that killed eight people at a fireworks store, he giggled like a delighted child and mugged for the cameras.

title: Hourly Wage Jumps for 2d Straight Month
description: A big jump last month in hourly earnings, reported yesterday by the Labor Department, suggests that the wage stagnation plaguing so many Americans may be lifting, at least temporarily.

title: Hurdles Greet Newark Chief On His First Day
description: On his first day as Newark's Police Director, Joseph J. Santiago today received ribbon-decorated plants, a huge basket of mangoes, apples and peppermint candies, and official word of the indictments of two of his officers on charges of extorting money from a fellow officer.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Jobless Rate Falls To 5.3%, a Six-Year Low The nation's unemployment rate dropped to 5.3 percent last month -- its lowest point in six years -- as 239,000 new jobs were added to the nation's payrolls in June. The unexpected strength in jobs suggested that the economy was picking up speed. The Clinton Administration hailed the employment data as evidence that its economic policies were working.

title: Paul Alpert, 89; Economist and U.N. Aide
description: Paul Alpert, an economist, author and retired senior United Nations official, died on Wednesday at his home in Great Neck, L.I. He was 89.

title: Zedillo's Role In Payment Is Defended
description: Ruling-party members of a Mexican congressional commission investigating official corruption closed ranks behind President Ernesto Zedillo today and attacked an independent member of the commission who raised questions about the President's role in a subsidy payment in 1989.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;ALCOA (AA,N)
description: Alcoa, the world's largest aluminum producer, said yesterday that earnings fell nearly 40 percent in the second quarter because metals prices declined.

title: Building Lives on Brooklyn's Scaffolds
description: There are no brownstones in Bangladesh.

title: Fireworks Injuries Shrink and Arrests Expand
description: The number of injuries from fireworks over the Fourth of July was down sharply from last year and the number of fireworks arrests was up sharply, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday as he pronounced his crackdown on illegal fireworks a resounding success.

title: BEYOND 'OTHER': A special report.;More Than Identity Rides On a New Racial Category
description: Edward Cooper, a Portland, Ore., businessman, is black. His wife and business partner, Barbara McIntyre, is white. Their 12-year-old son, Ethan McCooper, is, like his name, a blend of his parents, and harder to classify.

title: OLYMPICS;Fredericks Hands Johnson His First 200-Meter Loss in Two Years
description: Michael Johnson, America's best hope for Olympic gold in men's track, saw his 21-race victory streak at 200 meters broken tonight as a former world champion, Frankie Fredericks of Namibia, won in a remarkable African-record time of 19.82 seconds around a tightly curved track on a windy, wet evening.

title: Signs of Unexpected Growth Send Markets Tumbling
description: Most of Wall Street took the day off, but those who came to work yesterday reacted with alarm to the disclosure that a lot more Americans were working than had been anticipated. The report renewed concern that the Federal Reserve would soon tighten credit, despite the fact it took no such action at a meeting that ended on Wednesday.

title: Charles Is Said to Offer Diana Huge Settlement
description: Will they let her keep her title? Will she be evicted from her rent-free home in Kensington Palace? And, perhaps most importantly: when Diana, the Princess of Wales, concludes her long and drawn-out divorce from her husband, Prince Charles, the heir to the English throne, how rich will she be?

title: Nextel Seeks Wireless Network Financing
description: Nextel Communications Inc. said today that it was negotiating with banks for $1.25 billion in financing to build its nationwide wireless network.

title: Cadbury Move in Texas
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C. said today that it would build a new headquarters in the Dallas suburb of Plano for its consolidated North American beverage operation. The London-based Cadbury, a maker of soft drinks and candy, said in May that it would consolidate in Dallas the separate offices it had maintained in Dallas and Stamford, Conn., since buying the Dr Pepper/Seven-Up Companies in March 1995. The company said today that it had decided to build a campus-style complex at Legacy Park in Plano, a northern suburb of Dallas, instead of renewing the lease on its current headquarters building in Dallas. Construction in Plano is expected to be completed by the middle of 1998.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Broker Links Sumitomo Officials to Trades
description: Sumitomo Corporation officials authorized accounts handled by the company's former chief copper trader, Yasuo Hamanaka, a brokerage firm for the Japanese trading company said today.

title: Fed Unanimous in May For Holding Rates Steady
description: The policy makers at the Federal Reserve were unanimous in their decision to hold interest rates steady at a May 21 meeting, even as they began laying the groundwork for future rate increases, according to minutes of the meeting, which were released today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Saving Horses from Knackers
description: Niatross, the champion standardbred horse, is touring New Jersey and other states to publicize an organization that finds homes for retired race horses to keep them from being sold for labor or winding up as dog or cat food. The six-year-old Standardbred Retirement Foundation is trying to find a farm where horses that have completed their harness-racing career can be kept while awaiting a home, Judith Bokman, the director of the foundation, said yesterday. Most of these horses were bred in New Jersey and more than half of the 100 horses that the foundation has placed found homes within the state. Niatross, who retired in 1980 after winning more than $2 million, was bred at Walnridge Farm in the Monmouth County community of Cream Ridge. TERRY PRISTIN

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;30 Arrested in Drug Sweep
description: Sixty-five detectives and sheriff's officers spent the Fourth of July swooping down on crack cocaine distributors, prosecutors said yesterday. Thirty people, including two minors, were arrested, and the authorities seized 375 vials of crack cocaine, a police scanner, two handguns and an automatic assault gun, said Edward M. Neafsey, Acting Prosecutor for Union County. Officials said the ringleader of the group, Antwan Johnson, 24, was among those arrested, but detectives were searching for a 19-year-old man who is believed to have played a role in the scheme.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn and Soybean Prices Fall On Better Weather Outlook
description: Corn and soybean prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday following forecasts that called for ideal Midwest growing weather, easing concern that extreme heat would harm fledgling crops.

title: Slain Brothers Wielded Knives, Police Say
description: Two men shot dead by police officers on Thursday night in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, were brothers who had threatened the officers with knives after arguing with each other, the police said yesterday. One man was shot 18 times, the city Medical Examiner's office said.

title: Don't Shift Air Safety To Investigation Board
description: To the Editor:

title: Clinton Cheers Another 'Comeback Kid'
description: President Clinton told reporters today that he had telephoned the freshly re-elected Russian President, Boris N. Yeltsin, and had congratulated him for taking "the 'Comeback Kid' label away from me."

title: G.M. in Venture For Saudi Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that its Delphi Automotive Systems unit had formed a joint venture to build a battery manufacturing plant in Saudi Arabia.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Dole Looking to 'Well-Known' Running Mate
description: Bob Dole will choose a "well-known figure" as his running mate and, though he expects to make his choice within a month, he has yet to begin contacting potential candidates for the job, the head of his Vice-Presidential search committee said today.

title: Coast Guard Won't Limit Boat Crowds
description: A day after a ferryboat collided with several vessels on the East River while the waterway was packed with boats for a Fourth of July fireworks display, the Coast Guard was investigating the cause but said it had no plans to limit the number of boats allowed on the river for such events.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Railway Chief In France Under Inquiry
description: The head of the deficit-ridden French national railway system began a second day in jail today in an investigation of possible corruption while he was chairman of Elf Aquitaine S.A., the biggest oil company in the country.

title: Inflation in Italy Drops Below 4%
description: The annual inflation rate in Italy has dipped below 4 percent for the first time in 18 months, but economists said the fall might not be sharp enough to bring a cut in interest rates.

title: One Term for the Secretary General
description: The main question at the United Nations is not whether Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali deserves a second term or if American objections to him are valid. The real issue is that the world's interests would be better served if the job of Secretary General was limited to one term of five years. In addition, the cold war practice of selecting that official by regional rotation should be dropped in favor of choosing the best man or woman available. Five years is long enough to accomplish needed reforms. Besides, the possibility of re-election destroys the independence of Secretary Generals. In effect, they campaign for a second term in their first five years and thus become a hostage to the five permanent members of the Security Council. (They choose him, and the decision is rubber-stamped by the General Assembly.)

title: First Arrests in New York Under Sex-Offender Law
description: Nearly six months after New York State enacted a law requiring convicted sex offenders to register with the police, at least three men have been arrested for failing to do so.

title: Give Judges Final Say on Weighing Confessions
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES PLUNGE AFTER GOLDMAN REVISES RECOMMENDATION
description: Shares of the Hewlett-Packard Company fell yesterday after the company was removed from the influential "recommended list" at Goldman, Sachs & Company because of slowing sales. Shares of Hewlett-Packard dropped $2, to $92.125, and 2.7 million shares were traded, making the stock the second most active on the New York Stock Exchange. Third-quarter orders will increase 14 to 16 percent, down from the second quarter's 24 percent rise because of slowing sales in Europe across all product lines, a Goldman analyst, Laura Conigliaro, wrote in a research report released yesterday. The stock is now rated "market performer."

title: COMPANY NEWS;WALDEN RESIDENTIAL PROPERTIES ACQUIRES 5 COMPLEXES
description: Walden Residential Properties Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired five Texas apartment complexes, with a total of 1,290 garden apartments, for about $39.5 million. The company, based in Dallas, said it financed the acquisition through a preferred stock offering and credit. Walden Residential Properties is a real estate investment trust that owns garden apartment communities serving middle-income residents.

title: BASEBALL;Riches-to-Rags Saga Takes New Turn
description: Darryl Strawberry was penniless and one step away from being incarcerated by Los Angeles officials for willful nonpayment of child support. But thanks to the largess of the Yankees, in a contract that will bring the former Mets slugger close to $400,000 this season, he is now on his way out of debt and one step away from the major leagues.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PETRO-CANADA AND NORSK HYDRO TO FORM ALLIANCE
description: Petro-Canada and Norsk Hydro A.S. will form an alliance and exchange some offshore interests in Canada and the North Sea, the oil companies said yesterday. Petro-Canada will gain access to two oil and gas reserves as well as production in the North Sea, while Norsk Hydro will gain interests in three projects off the Atlantic coast of Canada. Norsk Hydro, a Norwegian company, will pay as much as $65 million of Petro-Canada's share of capital costs in the Hibernia and Terra Nova projects off the Atlantic coast of Canada. The companies will also share technology and expertise in offshore operations, the companies said.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KERR OBTAINS MORE TIME TO RENEGOTIATE ITS DEBT
description: Kerr Group Inc. said yesterday that it had obtained waivers of certain financial covenants through July 31 under its receivables facility, long-term unsecured senior notes and $5,982,000 unsecured bank note payable. Maturity of the bank note had also been extended to July 31, the company said. Kerr, which is based in Los Angeles and is a maker of plastic products and consumer items including jars and mugs, has agreed to prepay to the lenders by next Friday $500,000 of the outstanding principal of the senior notes and bank note. The company said the agreement gives it time to renegotiate its debt.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Spain to Open Selloff With Gas Natural Stake
description: The Spanish Government will begin its sale of state assets with a share offering of its 3.8 percent stake in Gas Natural SDG as early as September, officials said yesterday.

title: Kielce Journal;50 Years After Pogrom, City Shrinks at Memory
description: Stanislaw Zak, a soft-spoken professor of literature, recalls the day 50 years ago when he witnessed a pogrom that left deep scars on this city. He saw the violent crowd, sensed the terror, but most of all he remembers his father coming home.

title: The Toll of Ethnic Revenge: Dead Women and Children
description: The dead are laid out on the ground in front of the still-smoldering tea factory. Someone has covered a few of the bodies with old shawls and rags. People who have come in search of their relatives tiptoe down the line of the dead, gingerly picking up the rags with shaking hands.

title: U.S. and North Koreans Begin a Wary Dialogue
description: After more than four decades of exchanging little more than threats, the United States and North Korea are beginning to engage in a dialogue aimed at enabling the North to end its isolation and become a debutante in international society.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;'Suspicious' Trading At Escom Under Review
description: Germany's Securities Trading Supervisory Office said yesterday that it was investigating possible insider trading in shares of Escom A.G., the computer retailer that filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday. The office said it noticed a surge in the number of Escom shares traded and a plunge in the share price in the weeks preceding the company's announcement.

title: CYCLING;An Ailing Armstrong Drops Out Of Race
description: As thunder roared and rain pelted down for another day, Lance Armstrong, the American leader of the Motorola team, decided today that an overnight illness had robbed him of his power and that he could not continue in the Tour de France.

title: BASEBALL;Mets' Rally Ends Curse Of Expos' Martinez
description: By all accounts, the Mets were all but finished. They were four runs down after six innings with Pedro Martinez on the mound for the Expos. That's Martinez as in 8-0 against the Mets with an 0.94 career earned run average.

title: More Work or Less Work Can Equal No Time Off;A Vacation This Year Is Out of the Question For a Growing Number of American Families
description: To the millions of Americans fighting traffic this holiday weekend, it may seem as if just about everybody is going on vacation right now. And more than three-fifths of all families intend to take a chunk of time off this year. But Fred and Joanne Andres, who had hoped to go on a cruise, will not be among them.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Deutsche Bahn to Name A Partner Next Week
description: Deutsche Bahn A.G. said yesterday that it would announce the winner of a 49.9 percent stake in its telecommunications subsidiary DBkom next week.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan Reports a Surplus Following Earnings Rise
description: The Japanese Finance Ministry announced yesterday that it had a national budget surplus of 616.4 billion yen ($5.5 billion), for the fiscal year ended March 31, caused in part by a rise in corporate earnings.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Gas Cheaper, Except at Pump
description: Wholesale gasoline prices have dropped 18 percent since their surge this spring, but consumers have yet to realize any significant drop at the pump, the New Jersey Board of Public Utilities said yesterday. Wholesale unleaded gasoline dropped from 80 cents a gallon in April to 65 cents a gallon as of July 1, the agency said. But consumers have seen prices drop only by about 1 cent a gallon at the pump to about $1.22 a gallon, according to the board's division of energy. It often takes time for a decline in wholesale prices to be reflected at the pump, and prices tend to rise in the summer, when the demand for gasoline is greatest, said Wendy Kaczerski, a spokeswoman for the board.

title: The Fireworks Crackdown Worked
description: Critics of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's crackdown on the trafficking and use of illegal fireworks have characterized the effort as ridiculously strict -- and "a vendetta" against organized crime figures that ends up spoiling the fun of ordinary citizens. But thanks to the Police Department's "zero tolerance" strategy on illegal fireworks, this July 4 was the safest -- and quietest -- in memory.

title: Air France Merger Wins Some Support
description: Representatives of workers at Air France today backed a plan by the airline's chairman, Christian Blanc, to merge the company with its domestic unit, Air France Europe, one day after a widespread strike.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks Hopeful on Strawberry Experiment
description: When Ruben Sierra saw a reporter approaching before last night's game with Milwaukee at Yankee Stadium, he had no doubt what the subject of conversation would be: how the arrival of Darryl Strawberry next week will affect Sierra's playing time.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Little Undeconstructing Puts the Fun Back in Will
description: Over the last 30 years, "A Midsummer Night's Dream" has been reinvented more frequently even than Cher. Blame the critic Jan Kott, if you want, whose 1964 essay on the comedy's sinister subtext banished forever the notion of a happy, gauzy fairyland. But ever since, it has been impossible to read about a new production without wondering if it's going to be Jungian or Freudian, feminist or phallocentric, ad infinitum.

title: Saudi Bombing Sets Off Alarm at Base in Turkey
description: It is more than a thousand miles from Incirlik to Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, but the 3,700 American troops based here felt shock waves from the truck bomb that killed 19 of their comrades in Dhahran last week.

title: Europe Seeks to Settle Pasta Rift With U.S.
description: The European Union called on the global trade watchdog, the World Trade Organization, today to settle its eight-year dispute with the United States over pasta exports.

title: S.E.C. Is Set Back on 'Viatical Settlements'
description: An investment plan that sells shares in a terminally ill patient's life-insurance policy is not subject to Federal rules that regulate the sale of securities, a Federal appeals court said today.

title: What a Choice: Ecology or Truck Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: Astronauts Complete Last Full Day of Tests
description: The crew of the space shuttle Columbia completed a final round of dizzying motion sickness tests today and prepared for one more day of blood sampling and muscle studies as their 17-day mission neared its end.

title: B. Gerald Cantor, Philanthropist and Owner of Rodin Collection, IsDead at 79
description: B. Gerald Cantor, who started out as a boy selling hot dogs at Yankee Stadium, became a wealthy financier and philanthropist, amassed the world's most comprehensive collection of Rodin sculpture in private hands and gave much of it away to dozens of cultural institutions, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles after a long illness. He was 79 and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: Presbyterians Limit Gay Ordination
description: The governing body of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) today approved a policy that allows the ordination of homosexuals as long as they remain celibate and disavow their past sexuality. The policy would also prohibit unmarried heterosexuals who are ordained from having sex.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GOLDEN POULTRY RISES AFTER COURT ORDERS PURCHASE
description: The shares of the Golden Poultry Company rose 23 percent yesterday after an Alabama judge ordered Gold Kist Inc. to purchase the 27 percent stake in the company owned by minority shareholders. Stock in Golden Poultry, a poultry and dairy products company based in Atlanta, rose $2.25, to $12, in Nasdaq trading. Gold Kist, a closely held farmers' cooperative that controls 73 percent of Golden Poultry's shares, said that a Jefferson County Circuit Court judge in Birmingham, Ala., had ordered it to pay "fair value" for the 3.92 million Golden Poultry shares held by minority investors. The order, while not final, would resolve a suit filed in 1993 by two farmers who accused Gold Kist officers of breaching their fiduciary duties.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Norsk Talks in Trinidad On Big Smelter Project
description: A subsidiary of the Norwegian industrial giant Norsk Hydro A.S. is holding talks with the Government of Trinidad and Tobago on the construction of a $750 million aluminum smelter, Trinidad's Energy Minister, Finbar Gangar, said. Hydro Aluminum, a subsidiary of Norsk Hydro's metal producing companies, is conducting feasibility studies for a smelter with a capacity of 200,000 metric tons a year. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Brain-Damaged Man's Conviction Upheld
description: The state's highest court today upheld the 1992 murder and rape conviction of Richard A. Lapointe, a brain-damaged man who said the police took advantage of his impairment to trick him into falsely confessing during a nine-hour interrogation.

title: HORSE RACING;Kelly Kip Shows He's No Fluke In Tremont
description: For an encore, Kelly Kip, the 2-year-old instant star of the Belmont Park season, made it two straight victories in his young career when he stepped into the stakes class and won the Tremont yesterday by 6 3/4 lengths.

title: Stork Club May Be Gone, but Stories Live On;A Tab to Remember
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;SEMITOOL TUMBLES AFTER ANNOUNCING LOWER EARNINGS
description: The shares of Semitool Inc. fell 15 percent yesterday after the company, a maker of semiconductor equipment, said it did not expect its earnings for the quarter ended Sunday to meet expectations. Stock in Semitool fell $1.875, to $11, in Nasdaq trading. Semitool said four tool orders valued at $5.4 million would be shipped in the fourth quarter, instead of the third. The higher cost of making new product lines will also narrow its margins, the company said. Semitool, based in Kalispell, Mont., said that orders for its tool product lines had increased its backlog by $20 million since March and predicted that its performance would improve in the fourth quarter.

title: A New Dominican President
description: Save for the risky political debts incurred by their candidate, voters in the Dominican Republic who backed Leonel Fernandez Reyna for President are right to be jubilant. In Sunday's runoff, the cleanest election in memory, the victor by a narrow margin was a 42-year-old street-smart lawyer who grew up in New York City. A Knicks fan who can sink a basketball from the three-point line, Mr. Fernandez offers a zestful contrast to the 89-year-old incumbent, Joaquin Balaguer, the republic's iron-willed and crafty President who has served seven terms over the last 35 years.

title: Honda, the Newest Name in Tables and Chairs
description: Japanese consumers may soon be able to buy Honda housewares as well as cars.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rutgers Names a New Dean
description: After a year-long search, a new executive dean of agriculture and natural resources has been named at Rutgers University and will begin work Monday. The dean, Bruce C. Carlton, was a co-founder of Ecogen, a Langhorne, Pa.-based company that develops and markets pesticides. He has taught at the University of Georgia and at Yale.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Eurotunnel Reports Gain In Cars Using Le Shuttle
description: The Eurotunnel Group, which operates the Channel Tunnel linking Britain and France, said yesterday that car traffic on its Le Shuttle cross-channel service rose 15 percent in June from the previous month.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Germany's Telecom Law Approved by Parliament
description: Germany's Parliament gave final approval yesterday to a law that would open the nation's telecommunications industry to competition by 1998. The law would regulate Germany's telecommunications after competition begins and allow for the initial public stock offering of the state-owned Deutsche Telekom, which the company said would occur in November.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. and North Korea Talk

title: Pass the Budget in Albany
description: The budget gridlock in Albany this year may be the worst ever. It has frozen nearly everything of consequence in the State Legislature. For weeks, the outlines of an agreement on a $64 billion budget have been clear. But passage has been held up by side issues, particularly a dispute over Gov. George Pataki's proposal to revamp the system of compensation for employees injured in the workplace. The budget leaves much to be desired, but the Legislature should act now to free it from unrelated matters, pass it and remove the fiscal uncertainty that has hurt every level of government in the state.

title: City Accord On Programs From WNYC
description: When New York City's polyglot public television station, WNYC-TV/ Channel 31, went into private hands this week, many of the independent producers of ethnic programming who leased time on the channel suddenly found themselves knocked off the air.

title: Private Eyes and Government Files
description: Checking the background and reliability of Government workers seeking security clearances is a sensitive job that can easily be mishandled, as the White House abuse of F.B.I. files shows. But the way to keep the system clean and efficient is not to turn it over to private business. The potential for misuse of privileged information is too great.

title: U.S.-Japan Flights Continue
description: Spokesmen for United Airlines Inc. and the Japan Airlines Company say the refusal by the Governments of the United States and Japan to approve already scheduled flights will not affect service -- at least for a week.

title: Princeton Crew Ousted
description: Rowing in the worst weather of the day, Princeton's intercollegiate championship varsity heavyweight crew was eliminated from the Henley Royal Regatta today, losing by one-and-a-quarter boat lengths to Cambridge University's boat-race squad, rowing as Goldie Boat Club, in a race that Cambridge had under control from the first strokes.

title: Fines Near $35 Million For Prudential
description: A report from state insurance regulators is expected to recommend that fines of as much as $35 million be levied against the Prudential Insurance Company of America, which has been accused of sales abuses from 1982 until last year, representatives from state insurance offices confirmed yesterday.

title: GOLF;A Late Flourish Puts Stockton in the Lead
description: A four-shot turnaround on the final three holes catapulted Dave Stockton into the lead and dropped Bob Charles to second place after two rounds in the 17th United States Senior Open today at the Canterbury Golf Club in this Cleveland suburb.

title: Dole's Military Card
description: So far, the Presidential campaign is being waged largely over domestic issues. Yet the difference between the parties is much wider when it comes to military matters.

title: Dior Drops a Bombshell:Ferr Out
description: PARIS  Christian Dior, one of the most famous fashion houses in the world, announced Friday that its designer of seven years is out, one of several bombshells changing the landscape of the luxury goods business on the eve of the high-fashion collections. At a time when sales of high-priced items are suddenly booming, the major players are engineering some of the most dramatic changes in this field in many years.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Minorco Sells Interests In Liberty International
description: Minorco S.A., a Luxembourg-based natural resources company that is a subsidiary of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa, said yesterday that it had sold its interests in Liberty International Holdings, the overseas arm of the South African financial services concern Liberty Holdings, for L56.6 million pounds ($88.5 million).

title: A. R. Baron, Accused by S.E.C. Of Fraud, Files for Bankruptcy
description: A. R. Baron & Company, a New York brokerage firm, and two of its principals have filed for bankruptcy protection following Securities and Exchange Commission charges that they defrauded customers, a commission lawyer said today.

title: Company Briefs
description: QUORUM HEALTH GROUP INC., Brentwood, Tenn., which owns acute-care hospitals and health systems, said it intended to acquire a majority interest in Doctors Hospital, an acute-care center and regional teaching center for the Ohio University College of Osteopathic Medicine in Massillon, Ohio. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TEVA PHARMACEUTICAL TRYING TO BUY EUROPEAN COMPANY
description: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, an Israeli concern, is negotiating to acquire a pharmaceutical company in Western Europe from a multinational corporation. According to Teva, the unidentified company had total sales of about $60 million in 1995. Teva Pharmaceutical develops, manufactures and markets human pharmaceuticals, bulk pharmaceutical chemicals, medical disposables, veterinary products and fermentation products. Its American depository receipts fell $1.375, to $35.875, yesterday in Nasdaq trading.

title: Serbs Object as Bosnian Dead Are Retrieved
description: Finnish experts working under United Nations auspices ignored Bosnian Serb objections today and recovered at least nine bodies believed to be those of Muslims killed escaping Srebrenica last year, said Alexander Ivanko, a United Nations spokesman.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Rumors of Crisis Denied By Deutsche Babcock
description: The German engineering company Deutsche Babcock A.G. said yesterday that market rumors that it was in a financial crisis were totally unfounded.

title: TENNIS;Graf Faces the Rival She Knows So Well
description: After working overtime on Thursday night after a day of rain delays, Steffi Graf punched in early at Wimbledon this morning to finish her uncompleted semifinal against Kimiko Date of Japan. Twenty-six minutes later, she had carved out a 6-3 third set to seal a 6-2, 2-6, 6-3 victory and secure a berth in the final against Arantxa Sanchez Vicario of Spain.

title: Democrats as Well as G.O.P. Profit From Tobacco
description: As they seek to cast Bob Dole as a tobacco villain doing the bidding of the cigarette companies that give millions to Republican campaigns, Democratic strategists are being forced to confront their party's own long financial relationship with the tobacco industry.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Canada Unemployment Climbs to 20-Month High
description: Canada's unemployment rate reached a 20-month high of 10 percent in June, Government figures showed yesterday. Economists had expected the jobless rate would be unchanged at 9.4 percent.

title: Allies Weigh Raid to Seize Bosnian Serb Leaders
description: The Clinton Administration, and its allies in Bosnia, have concluded that the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, will not deliver on his earlier promises to remove two Bosnian Serb leaders indicted on war crimes charges from their positions of power, American and European diplomats say.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MARKET HUB NOW OWNS 100% OF A GAS STORAGE OPERATION
description: Market Hub Partners L.P. said yesterday that it owned 100 percent of a gas storage operation after buying the remaining 50 percent stake for $26.6 million. Market Hub Partners, based in Leesburg, Va., is a developer of natural gas market centers. The company said its Moss Bluff Hub Partners unit bought the remaining interest in the Moss Bluff Gas Storage Facility in Liberty County, Tex., from the CMS Gulf Coast Storage Company.

title: Observer;The Spoiler's Confession
description: One year we decided to vacation on an island. Knowing nothing of islands, we consulted an Esso road map. That's how long ago it was. It was an Esso, not Exxon, map. Esso gave it away free. Big oil was not yet so threadbare that it had to sell road maps to survive.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Man Charged in Forest Fires
description: A 26-year-old man has been accused of setting more than 40 blazes in the Pine Barrens in a failed effort to start a forest fire, the authorities said yesterday. The man, John Lovrovic of Manahawkin, was arrested Wednesday night while trying to set a fire in Barnegat Township, arson investigators said.

title: Bridge
description: Three of the winners of the Women's Team Trials in San Francisco last week are involved in the management of Honors Club, 115 East 57th Street in Manhattan. They are Gail Greenberg of Manhattan, her daughter Jillian Blanchard of Riverdale, N.Y., and Irina Levitina of Teaneck, N.J. Their teammates were Juanita Chambers of Schenectady, N.Y., and Shawn Quinn of Katy, Tex. They had qualified for the trials by winning the 1995 National Women's Team with the late Lila Perlstein of Roslyn, L.I., as their sixth player.

title: U.N. Panel Says Qaddafi Violated Air Curbs
description: A United Nations sanctions committee said today that flights by Libyan aircraft taking Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, to and from an Arab summit meeting in Cairo last month violated sanctions imposed in 1992.
