The committee said it would consider seeking tougher curbs if the violation was repeated.

title: Arrest in Sex Abuse at Pool
description: A 13-year-old boy was arrested on charges of aggravated sexual abuse yesterday after groping a 12-year-old girl in a public pool in the Bronx, the police said.

title: BASEBALL;The Yankees' Scoring Spree Helps Gooden Get By
description: Dwight Gooden had planned his entire vacation for the All-Star Game break. Then the team owner, George Steinbrenner, called the Yankee trainers last night and said to tell Gooden to change those plans.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5

title: Official Says Militia Weighed Attacking Families of Agents
description: As the Viper Militia prepared to fight the Federal Government, one of its two women members suggested that the group "take action" against the families of some Federal agents, according to testimony today in Federal court here.

title: Bid to Prolong Ban on Law
description: New Jersey's Public Defender, Susan L. Reisner, asked a Federal appeals court yesterday to preserve an order that blocks the state from telling schools, women's shelters and youth organizations about paroled sex offenders who live in their neighborhoods.

title: No Headline
description: This demand of Aleksandr Ivanovich Lebed for broader powers is a serious mistake of a novice state leader."

title: U.S. Case of Rare AIDS Strain Results in Call for New Tests
description: Scientists have identified a Los Angeles-area woman as the first person in the United States known to carry a rare strain of the AIDS virus, a finding that will force changes in H.I.V. screenings to protect the nation's blood supply.

title: POP REVIEW;Blowing Off the Fetters Of Styles as Boundaries
description: America's founding fathers may not have envisioned the likes of George Clinton and the P-Funk All-Stars, who played a sold-out Fourth of July benefit concert for Central Park Summerstage. But as a diverse, ambitious bunch of people cheerfully abetting the pursuit of happiness, P-Funk made a fine utopian model for America.

title: OLYMPICS;Russian Gains Approval To Run Hurdles for Sweden
description: The chances that Gail Devers will win her first Olympic gold medal in the 100-meter hurdles instantly grew slimmer yesterday when the Russian Olympic committee agreed to let Lyudmila Engquist compete for Sweden.

title: Suits Accord By America Online Set
description: America Online Inc. will give away millions of hours of on-line time to some subscribers to settle a series of lawsuits, lawyers involved in the litigation said yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times;Town Doing Right Thing For Iverson
description: ALLEN IVERSON will have his parade this morning.

title: Mirage's Silence on Atlantic City Plan Raises Questions
description: When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced a new $405 million road and tunnel project for Atlantic City earlier this week, she stood in her State House office, flanked by a bevy of officials who have an interest in seeing the plan go forward.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasuries Drop After Jobs Report
description: Treasury prices plunged in thin trading yesterday, after an employment report showed surprising strength, immediately raising concern that the Federal Reserve might have to raise interest rates sooner than expected.

title: Finding a Way to Swing for the Fences;Softball Helps Recovering Addicts Learn Discipline and Teamwork
description: Precious is her name, but at the plate she is the power lady, the Babe Ruth of a no-nonsense league. She stares the pitcher hard in the eye as her bat revolves in tiny circles like a snake about to strike. The pitcher finally serves up a tasty offering. Boom! A grand slam -- Precious's third of the season.

title: Librarians' Challenge: Offering Internet
description: On the Fourth of July weekend, many Americans try to get away from it all. Not librarians. This weekend, 22,000 of them are attending the annual conference of the American Library Association in Manhattan. There are poetry readings, with exhibitions of a thousand new works. ("Not since the beats has there been such a revival of interest," reads the association's brochure.) There is a celebration of storytelling and a tour of "literary Greenwich Village."

title: Religion Journal;Presbyterians Choose a Leader Favoring Diversity
description: This week, the Rev. John M. Buchanan stepped into a religious job that bears more than a little resemblance to top-flight diplomatic service. As the new moderator of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.), he has joined the world of the high-profile frequent flier, holding a position devoid of administrative power, but requiring detailed knowledge of church policy, as well as no small amount of tact.

title: Court Removes an Obstacle To a New Stadium in Detroit
description: A court decision today moved America's oldest baseball stadium closer to retirement.

title: Lone Officer Kills Man in Subway Station
description: A transit police officer shot and killed a man in a Bronx subway station late Thursday night under circumstances that police officials said were veiled in mystery and needed to be investigated.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;State Lays Off 252 Workers
description: For 252 state workers, the newly enacted state budget had a very personal message: Yesterday was their last day on the job. The budget actually eliminated 400 positions as of yesterday -- nearly half of them in the Department of Environmental Protection -- but the state has been able to reassign 148 of the people holding those jobs, The Associated Press reported.

title: Medals for Metaphors
description: To resolve the ongoing debate on the literary canon, the Modern Language Association has at last persuaded Olympics officials to add fiction to the roster of medal sports for the 1996 Games. The place: Atlanta. The commentators: Mary Lou Retton and Alfred Kazin.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Panel Urges Queensland To Sell Off State Assets
description: A commission of audit set up by the government of the Australian state of Queensland has recommended that the state sell some of its assets including electricity utilities worth an estimated $9.8 billion Australian ($7.7 billion United States), surplus land, forestry operations, port authorities, the betting agency TAB and a travel agency. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Brownie Mary' Fights to Legalize Marijuana
description: If marijuana is ever legalized and "magic brownie" mixes ever appear on the shelves of America's supermarkets, there will be one obvious candidate to become the Betty Crocker, the Mrs. Field, the Sara Lee, of cannabis baking.

title: We Hold These Truths
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE REVIEW;Parisians Exude Their Past And Present
description: The Paris Opera Ballet closed its successful season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Wednesday night with another major New York debut: Marie-Claude Pietragalla, who was seen as Nikiya opposite Nicolas Le Riche in Rudolf Nureyev's version of "La Bayadere."

title: Russian Vote Sets Off Battle, This Time in Yeltsin's Camp
description: Two days after President Boris N. Yeltsin scored a resounding re-election victory, his top aides are involved in a bruising and very public struggle for power.

title: Stork Club May Be Gone, but Stories Live On
description: To the Editor:

title: LOWEST IN 6 YEARS
description: The nation's unemployment rate dropped to 5.3 percent in June, its lowest point in six years, as signs of inflation appeared suddenly to mount, Labor Department figures showed today.

title: Off-Duty Officer Arrested
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was being held in the Rockland County jail in New City early today after being charged with attempting to set a fire in an apartment building yesterday in Nyack, the police said.

title: John M. Meyer Jr., Banker, 89; Helped Ease Clearing of Trades
description: John M. Meyer Jr., a former chairman of J. P. Morgan & Company who helped develop some of the modern systems that allow for easier settlement of securities trades, died on Thursday at his home in Greenwich, Conn., said William G. McBride, a spokesman for J. P. Morgan. He was 89.

title: BASEBALL;Williams Wants a Comeback
description: Mitch Williams, the erratic reliever known as Wild Thing who helped Philadelphia win the National League pennant in 1993 before allowing the World Series-ending homer, will attempt a comeback with the Phillies, the team announced today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Behind Sumitomo Scandal, a Drive to Be the Copper King
description: When a typical Japanese trading company gets an order for copper in Bangkok, Thailand, it might take two months to move the metal from the mines in Africa to the docks in Bangkok.

title: Price of Whale Meat
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;PALM HARBOR IS BUYING REST OF NEWCO HOMES
description: Palm Harbor Homes Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the 58.4 percent of Newco Homes Inc. that it did not already own, for $52 million in cash and stock. Palm Harbor, a maker of manufactured homes, holds a 41.6 percent stake in Newco Homes, a Texas retailer of manufactured homes. Palm Harbor, based in Dallas, co-founded Newco in 1986. Palm Harbor said that the addition of 21 stores run by Newco "should translate into incremental annual sales of approximately $100 million." Palm Harbor had sales of $417.2 million for the year ended March 29. Its stock rose 75 cents, to $34.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Schools' Disability Evaluations Need Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Italy Investigates Philip Morris Tax Payments
description: Prosecutors in Naples say they are investigating the Philip Morris Companies for possible evasion of taxes on the earnings from $6.4 billion in revenue over the last decade.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STANDISH CARE AGREES TO BUY CAREMATRIX
description: The Standish Care Company of Burlington, Mass., said yesterday that it would buy the Carematrix Corporation for stock valued at about $250 million. Standish Care will issue 50 million shares to the closely held Carematrix in a combination of the two companies, which own assisted-living centers. The purchase will raise the number of Standish Care shares outstanding to 55 million. Shares of Standish Care fell 12.5 cents, to $5, in Nasdaq trading. After the acquisition closes, the company could change its name to Carematrix, Standish Care said. The headquarters will move to Needham, Mass., where Carematrix is based.

title: About New York;Silver Zlotys And a Dream Of America
description: FRANK MOCHA rooted through a drawer in the china cabinet, pushing aside letters and bills until he found a tiny white box. He plucked it like treasure from the pile of mundane papers, and slowly opened it.

title: OLYMPICS;Drug Lab Passes Test For Atlanta Drug Tests
description: Two weeks before the Summer Games begin, the laboratory that will conduct drug testing in Atlanta has been accredited by the International Olympic Committee, it was announced yesterday.

title: Recycle More and Spend Less
description: In his recent assault on New York City's recycling law, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani contended that the program was irresponsible and harmful to the recycling industry.

title: TENNIS;To Be Continued: A Semifinal Deadlock
description: They are not the two Americans who were supposed to be decorating the Center Court at this late stage of waterlogged Wimbledon, but Todd Martin and MaliVai Washington do not seem intimidated by their opportunity to fill in for the dethroned Pete Sampras and the deposed Andre Agassi.

title: Union Isn't Controlled by Organized Crime
description: To the Editor:

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Soars in Thin Trading As Higher U.S. Rates Are Seen
description: The dollar surged in thin, volatile trading yesterday, as a surprisingly strong United States employment report buoyed hopes for higher United States interest rates.

title: WEDDINGS;Margaruite Sims, Andrew R. Kass
description: Margaruite Sims, a daughter of Ophelia and Buddy G. Sims of East Cleveland, Ohio, was married yesterday to Andrew R. Kass, a son of Joan and Steven L. Kass of White Plains. The Rev. Michael R. Trogdon, a Presbyterian minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at Squire Valleevue Farm in Hunting Valley, Ohio.

title: INVESTING IT;Where the Education Is Built on Principal
description: TINY Berea College, nestled at the edge of Kentucky's Appalachian foothills, has bucked convention since its birth in 1855. Its founders were run out of the state for planning to educate blacks alongside whites. Today, the collision is not so dramatic. As other schools chase tuition-paying students to cover the bills, Berea chooses to play investment banker instead.

title: U.S. Bears Responsibility for Arrests in Bosnia;Consider Bosnian Serbs
description: To the Editor:

title: Elusive Liberalism
description: ISAIAH BERLIN By John Gray. 189 pp. Princeton, N.J.: Princeton University Press. $19.95.

title: World News Briefs;Colombia Frees a Leader Of Medellin Drug Cartel
description: Colombia has freed a founder of the Medellin drug cartel five and a half years into his prison sentence, angering United States officials.

title: THE CYBER-MAXIMS OF ESTHER DYSON
description: ONE MORNING RECENTLY AT A POSH DESERT RESORT IN TUCSON, ARIZ., HUNDREDS OF THE computer industry's elite huddled in small groups, swapping shop talk, making deals. In one corner, Michael Kinsley, editor of Microsoft's new on-line magazine, Slate, chatted with Bernard Vergnes, head of Microsoft's European operations. In another, Jim Barksdale, president of Netscape, talked sotto voce with Steve Case, chairman of America Online.

title: Article on Park Ave. Shelter Reinforces Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: On Jerusalem's Future, Israel Fosters Delusion;Arabist Heard From
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: A brief report on this page last Sunday on Michael Johnson's breaking the 200-meter sprint record in Atlanta misstated the elevation of the city. Atlanta is not at sea level, but 1,050 feet above.

title: Cuddly Quasimodo: Is This a Good Thing;Trivializing the Magnificent
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: NO MATTER HOW LOUD I SHOUT A Year in the Life of Juvenile Court. By Edward Humes. Simon & Schuster, $24.

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;2d-Stringer Wins Dwyer For Lukas
description: Unbridled's Song and Honour and Glory were both stalking Cigar, so the 79th running of the Dwyer Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday became a glowing opportunity for somebody else, maybe anybody else. And Victory Speech, who ran in the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness for D. Wayne Lukas, took full advantage of the chance to win the race on class and credentials.

title: Where's a Refund?
description: To the Editor: While traveling in Bolivia last year, I bought plane tickets from a travel agency in La Paz. Not being able to use the tickets, I returned them for refund of $289.70 to my credit card account. Back in the United States, I was surprised to see that the amount credited to my card was only $60.58, which corresponds to 289.70 Bolivianos.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Colts Give Harbaugh a Hefty Raise
description: JIM HARBAUGH, designated as the franchise player of the Indianapolis Colts, got nearly a 500 percent raise over his 1995 salary yesterday. The Colts and Harbaugh agreed on a one-year deal worth more than $4 million; he earned $850,000 last year when he went to the Pro Bowl for the first time after starting the season as a backup to CRAIG ERICKSON.

title: Sports of The Times;77 Worthy Old-Timers Are Only Receiving A Major League Snub
description: IT'S not as if they just had a cup of coffee, but now they're not even getting that.

title: OFF THE SHELF;The Invisible Hand Meets the Helping One
description: I KNOW what you're thinking: It's the Fourth of July weekend! Can't we hold the column outside today? Exactly my plan. Let's imagine the authors of our two books -- David Friedman and Fred Block -- at the same backyard barbecue in Northern California, where in real life both are university professors.

title: Cuddly Quasimodo: Is This a Good Thing;Stravinsky Was No Fan of Disney
description: To the Editor:

title: YOUR HOME;Of Windows That Leak And Rattle
description: THERE are few images more pleasant than lace curtains billowing into a cozy room.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Dresden
description: Dresden, once called the Florence of the North, is on the rise again. After much of the magnificent city was destroyed by Allied bombers in a devastating firestorm in February 1945, what remained was then subjected to more than four decades of no-frills Communist reconstruction.The few landmark buildings that survived were left to decay.

title: ON THE JOB;The Office as Comedy Club
description: All work and no play make the office a dull place. On many a day, nothing does more to banish tension than a good joke and a hearty laugh. So gather round the water cooler:

title: Bear's Boy
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cuddly Quasimodo: Is This a Good Thing;A Wake-Up Call
description: To the Editor:

title: DIARY
description: WALL STREET

title: Foreign Affairs;Morning In Moscow
description: Before all the Sovietologists who argued that Russia was congenitally incapable of democracy explain to you why the Russian elections don't really matter, before they warn you about the looming fiscal crisis in Russia, the shrinking arteries of Boris Yeltsin or the authoritarian twitches of Gen. Aleksandr Lebed, take just one moment to savor this moment. For the first time in history an independent Russian people -- not the oligarchs, not the bankers, not the mafia -- has chosen a president in a free and fair election. Despite all the hardships and uncertainties that have characterized life here since the collapse of the Soviet Union, an overwhelming majority of Russians actually voted for the candidate who promised to continue the wrenching transition to an open society with a free market. That is a big deal. It is a remarkable triumph of hope over hardship. While this single election doesn't guarantee that Russia will make it all the way to American-style free-market democracy, it does guarantee that the effort will move forward now with a solid popular mandate. The debate about where Russia is heading is over.

title: KEEPING SECRETS
description: As a psychotherapist-in-training, I read Maggie Scarf's article "Keeping Secrets" (June 16) on managed care and confidentiality with great interest. To what she wrote, I would add only one area of concern: the qualifications, or lack thereof, of the employees who pass judgment on the "appropriate" length, type and course of treatment for a given diagnosis. It is my understanding that most of these case managers have no training in the mental-health field. I cannot imagine how they can presume to know what is best for the patient.

title: Frank Eliscu, 83, Who Sculptured Heisman Trophy
description: Frank Eliscu, a New York sculptor who designed the Heisman Trophy, died on June 19 at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Florida. He was 83.

title: Why Worker Owners Sell Out
description: It might seem odd that Avis, the world's second-largest car rental company, would agree to sell itself to HFS, a hotel franchiser. After all, Avis is owned by its 13,500 workers. But it turns out that worker owners in many companies decide they would, in effect, like to fire themselves as boss. Worker-owned firms -- even those that are profitable like Avis -- have a tough time surviving from one generation to the next in a capitalist economy.

title: Beyond Plastic Surgery
description: To the Editor:

title: Gathering Power for Heat Waves to Come
description: THREE nuclear plants operated by Northeast Utilities and making up more than a third of Connecticut's generating capacity are shut because the Nuclear Regulatory Commission does not think they can be run safely. And they are likely to stay that way for a long time, possibly years.

title: Youth and Age Meet to Mutual Benefit
description: ONE hour in the life of a teen-ager can hardly be chronicled as it rushes by in a blur of classes, work, sports and dates. But if you're 80-something, and home alone, one hour can stretch interminably into a bleak future of more hours upon hours of immobility, loneliness and helplessness.

title: Silents, Exile, Cunning
description: To the Editor:

title: Picking Up The Vibes In Sedona
description: YOU come to Sedona, two hours' drive north of Phoenix's sprawl, to escape the blast furnace of the Sonoran Desert. You come to see a gorge, a river-carved slice in the ancient sedimentary rock, second only to the other big canyon, the one with the superlative Grand attached to its name. You come for the red rock wraparound scenery, the sandstone buttes and mesas with self-explanatory names like Coffee Pot and Bell Rock. But inevitably, what you go away with is a sense of a place that exudes its own quirky spirituality. Sedona is a shrine, the locals will tell you, of multiple-choice ethereal dimensions -- from the traditional to the truly wacky.

title: The View From: Bridgeport;City Youngsters Learn A Suburban Game
description: A GROUP of middle school students, about evenly girls and boys, ringed the practice green at the D. Fairchild Wheeler Golf Course in Fairfield on a recent afternoon. Several youngsters practiced chip shots. Others waited their turn.

title: Balancing Conservation and Economic Growth
description: ALMOST 100 years ago, International Paper, then a small company in Glens Falls, N.Y., acquired for logging thousands of acres along the Raquette River in the heart of the Adirondack Mountains. The Adirondack Park eventually surrounded this land and in the 1980's the State of New York considered buying some of it to include in the park. Budget shortfalls and voter rejection of a $2 billion bond act in 1990 prevented the state from acquiring the land.

title: COPING;Suspicion, Part 2: The Landlord's Story
description: THE landlord is fighting a cold and an eye infection, and perhaps the betrayal of a dream. Landlords can be idealists, too, although tenants rarely think so. Thirty-five years ago, Richard Ravitch, who is 63, envisioned four architecturally handsome towers of rental apartments on the East River in a racially and economically integrated enclave that would throb with a sense of community. It would be a monument to the liberal imagination, and eventually would turn a liberal profit.

title: ON LANGUAGE;Pass the Password
description: HACKERS ARE reading my mind.

title: HOME CLINIC;It Happens When You're Unprepared
description: MANY homeowners do not worry about home security, because they are under the impression that they don't have anything worth stealing.

title: Proceedings At State Agency
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: OTHER WOMEN By Evelyn Lau. Simon & Schuster, $20.

title: N. J. LAW;Downsizing in Blue: A County Police Force Faces Extinction
description: Late last month, Glenn Cunningham, the Hudson County Safety Director, shook hands with five recruits who had just completed 24 weeks of training at the police academy here, and congratulated them on having become county police officers.

title: AIDS Meeting: Signs of Hope, And Obstacles
description: The 11th international AIDS meeting opens here on Sunday with leading researchers' hopes as high as the sun-drenched mountains surrounding this Canadian seaport.

title: MAKING IT WORK;The Priest With the Bulletproof Vest
description: THE REV. JOHN JENIK is the priest with the bulletproof vest. But today he's not wearing it, and he is clearly uncomfortable. His face turns slightly red and he lowers his voice as he cautiously approaches the corner of East 194th Street and Decatur Avenue in the Bronx and points out a Tudor-style apartment building at 384 East 194th Street.

title: June 30-July 6;Giuliani's Gift to Clinton
description: News that reported crime is dropping in New York City has become almost routine, but the latest police statistics showing murder and other serious crimes declining at an accelerating rate can only enhance the holiday cheer in Gracie Mansion -- and the White House.

title: Connecticut Q&A: John Chang;In Pursuit of a Full Life After Paralysis
description: IT was 10 years ago this summer that John Chang, an immigrant from Taiwan who had hopes of becoming a doctor, broke his neck in a surfing accident and was paralyzed. He was 19 at the time, had been a star athlete in high school and had just completed his first year at Ursinus College in Collegeville, Pa.

title: Views on Disorder Questioned by Doctor
description: I take serious issue with Dr. Harold Koplewicz on the diagnosis and treatment of Attention Deficit Disorder [Long Island Q&A, June 16]. He advocates prescribing psychiatric medications in an unchallenged fashion, citing that he used to prescribe antibiotics to children with red throats without ever checking the cultures. It was precisely this type of practice that has led to the proliferation of antibiotic- resistant organisms. When parents express outrage over the widespread blanket description writing for the disorder, perhaps they are on to something.

title: A Lessening of Tensions, Not Influence

title: The Long Arm of Harassment Law
description: Last month, a Federal court struck down a ban on Internet indecency, saying the new medium "deserves the highest protection from governmental intrusion." But if you were expecting any Golden Age of free expression on line, think again. Kick the censors out the front door, and they climb back in the window via . . . harassment law.

Grainger of West Chester, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Fred Anderson performed the ceremony at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;A Modest Proposal For the Millennium
description: HOMER HOOKS, RETIRED from the citrus and phosphate games and living in Lakeland, Fla., has a good idea for the millennium. A great symphony is on his mind, music to perch on the fulcrum of this important calendar change.

title: A Dead Language, Yiddish Lives
description: WHEN I.B. SINGER RECEIVED THE NOBEL PRIZE FOR LITERATURE in 1978, he told the Swedish Academy - in Yiddish - that his beloved mother tongue had not yet spoken its last word. But even Singer would be amazed to discover the factions - from the Hasidim of Brooklyn to a surprising number of young gay Jews - who are now engaged in a struggle over the future of Yiddish. In seeking to redefine the modern meaning of an old language, the partisans of Yiddish are trying to redefine the very character of American Judaism.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;'Virtual Doormen' Who Accept Real Packages

Or maybe it was those trips to Federal Express, mailing apartment keys overnight to friends who would be arriving in town while he was at work. Somehow, Mike Rataczak thought, he had to get around the problem of not having a doorman.

title: Our Towns;Rolling Chair To the Rescue For Gamblers

title: Montana Cowgirls For a Week
description: WE were a wild orchestra, more than a thousand pieces, cowpoke and beast. Down the gully, up the butte, around the bend, we chased those cattle. Hooves drummed the dirt. A frenzy of cows clogged the barbed wire gate, then several charged through. Bawling, whinnying, snorting, hoots and howls filled the air. Cowboys swung their ropes. A hat flew off. The bellwether of some hundred pairs of cows and calves suddenly reversed direction.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;Debt Hybrids Gain by Mimicking Stocks
description: AMID the disappointments in the bond market this year, a little-known debt hybrid has escaped unscathed. Mutual funds investing heavily in convertible securities, or debt issues with both a lush yield and an option to exchange them for common stock, were up an average of 7 percent in the first half of the year, according to Morningstar Inc. That was somewhat behind the 10.8 percent return of diversified equity funds but infinitely better than the decline of 1 percent for the average bond fund.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;How to Get a Passport At the Last Minute
description: The New York Passport Agency has set up a system to allow people with immediate travel plans to telephone for appointments to apply for passports or renewals. The agency, at 630 Fifth Avenue, at 50th Street, serves only people who have tickets to travel within 14 days. The system, begun July 1, means applicants need visit the office only twice: once to submit the required documents and then to pick up the passport. The former initial visit, to make an appointment, is replaced by a call on a touch-tone phone to (212) 399-5290. The caller punches in a Social Security number, gives the date of the tickets and other information and receives a choice of three appointments.

In "You're Makin' Me High," the slinky first single to be released from Toni Braxton's second album, "Secrets" (LaFace), the pop-soul contralto dreams of "doin' it again and again" and moans, "The very thought of you makes me want to get undressed."

One such tree -- a 47-inch-circumference Callery pear that had endured the city's pollution and alkaline soil -- separated from its synthetic collar and descended like a drawbridge across the frozen Greenwich Street moat.

title: BOOKEND;The Reel Woman: A Fish Story
description: The idea of fishing secrets -- of arcane lore that will help us catch a fish -- has always been a driving force behind fishing books. One can't spend as much time failing as fishermen do without nurturing some mighty dream of better days; the magic that attracts us to books about fishing is the revealed wisdom, whether ancient and long lost or recently discovered. Though we pride ourselves on our pragmatism, most of us harbor at times a very nearly occult obsession with some imagined higher awareness, a state of knowing that will give us the right lure, the right bait, the right rod, the right profanity -- whatever it is that we're plainly not using now will be revealed to us, and we will become that most envied and lionized of fishermen, the expert. (I have fished with actual experts, and they really do catch at least twice as many fish as I do, which is to say that they spend 98, rather than 99, percent of their time catching nothing.)

title: Theater Review;I Love a Gershwin Tune Inspires 'Crazy for You'
description: RECIPE for a make-do musical hit: Take a dozen truly great Gershwin tunes. Who does not love a Gershwin tune? Lovable lyrics by Ira are included. Add another half-dozen or so -- less than great but more than good. Anyone who says a musical does not have to be more than music and, it follows, dancing, simply couldn't ask for anything more.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 16 about a stamp printed in 1939 for baseball's 100th anniversary misstated the issue's significance. It was the first American commemorative honoring an individual sport, not the first with a sports theme. In 1932, a stamp was issued for the Winter Olympics and two for the Summer Olympics.

title: FUNDS WATCH;Checkbooks Ready? Go!

title: POP VIEW;Reggae Is Reclaiming Its Songs of Freedom
description: JAMAICA MAY BE A PRIME destination for sun-worshiping vacationers, but to millions of reggae music lovers, the Caribbean island is the birthplace of the sultry yet rebellious sound ruled by drum and bass. When the reggae legend Bob Marley was singing in the 70's, the music's lyrics conjured up reveries of equality, unity and love, all with an underlying threat of revolutionary violence. In the 80's, the reggae world shrank to dance-hall size, transforming itself into a showcase for the sexual boasts and aggressive posturings of oversize egos. In the last two years, however, reggae has returned to its earliest themes.

title: DELIVERANCE
description: Yes, welcome to the 90's, Burt ("Deliverance," by Lynn Hirschberg, June 16). Burt Reynolds is beautiful and bold -- another Clark Gable. I am sick and tired of skinny, WASP-y actors like the two Toms.

description: THE educator James B. Conant once said, "He who enters a university walks on hallowed ground." Obviously, the famed Harvard president had never heard of Virtual U.

title: MUSIC;Sounds of the Theremin Again at Caramoor
description: ALONG with the Baroque furnishings and Renaissance art treasures in the museum at Caramoor in Katonah is a theremin. In the 1930's, Leon Theremin received considerable financial support from the original Caramoor owners, Lucie and Walter Rosen, and Mrs. Rosen herself played the electronic instrument that bears the inventor's name. Last year a documentary film featuring the theremin was shown, but until now there has rarely been a live performance at Caramoor.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION;A Sardonic Eye
description: In a hefty and companionable volume, entitled simply COLLECTED STORIES (Sun and Moon, $24.95), Djuna Barnes's biographer Phillip Herring has gathered 43 of her stories, written from 1914 to 1942. Perhaps best known for her 1936 novel, "Nightwood," Barnes displays in her shorter work an unflagging taste for the grotesque: In "The Head of Babylon," a Polish-American farmer marries off his quadriplegic daughter, who sits on a great dais between two candles and suddenly declaims a strange, biblical speech as she leaves with the groom. In "No-Man's-Mare," a captured wild horse, bearing a dead woman to the undertaker, veers from a path and disappears into the sea. Although Barnes experiments with narrative, her stories generally depend on a plot ending with an O. Henry twist, a format suited no doubt to the newspapers and magazines for which she often wrote. Her characters are not round, nor do they sustain and engage us with their conflicts. Rather, they are haunting emblems of human weakness, vice and, occasionally, virtue. Most striking is Barnes's particular use of language, which aligns her with Pound, Joyce and Stein: syntactical inversions, epigrams, puns, cliches and one-liners crowd her sentences. Witty and passionate, her stories are often reflexive, with asides to the reader and a sardonic tone that mocks the characters. And always they reflect Barnes's bleak view of existence. Gardner McFall

title: The Nation;Downsizing Comes to Employee-Owned America
description: FOR months now, the nation's employee-owned companies have been held up as one way to reduce layoffs and save jobs. The Clinton Administration has embraced the concept and the logic: surely worker owners don't want to fire themselves. But downsizing among employee-owned companies is turning out to be much more common than anyone realized.

title: Indiana Band Makes Itself at Home
description: DID someone say "Strike up the Band!"?

title: L.I. Sound Still Shy a Clean Bill of Health
description: THE signs are hopeful these days along the 577 miles of New York and Connecticut coastline that embrace Long Island Sound. Striped bass are more plentiful than they have been in a half-century; harbor seals have been arriving earlier and staying longer each winter; the amount of nitrogen released into the water from sewage treatment plants has leveled off in most places, and the massive fish kills of past summers have not been seen since 1987.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;Toys 'R' Us Ruling Hinges on Crates
description: It is the next-to-last chapter of a long legal struggle that has alarmed residents of an Upper East Side neighborhood and proved a thorn in the side of a $9 billion corporation with a world-famous brand name. The case has surprised City Hall with a far-ranging ruling that could affect other neighborhoods by changing the interpretation of a significant zoning law. And the argument turned on 20 crates.

title: Conversion Van's Converts: Pickups and Sport Utilities
description: THE conversion van emerged in Southern California in the early 1960's when crusty beach bohemians modified their Volkswagen and Ford Econoline vans, adding beds in the back, gluing shag carpet to the floors, the walls and sometimes even the steering wheel and building in wooden consoles and tables.

title: Ocean County's Grayer Pastures
description: WHEN their lives still stretched before them like a winding road, Jane and John Cameron would come to Ocean County for brief, blissful holidays. As newlyweds in the 1950's, they would dance past midnight at glittery seaside resorts. On summer afternoons, they would lie on the white-sand beaches and listen to the waves break.

title: Opportunities Knocked;Without Patronage, Is It Politics as Usual?
description: IN the blur of decisions that the United States Supreme Court handed down before ending its session last week, the Justices struck a blow against one of the oldest pillars of American politics -- patronage, the scratch-my-back practice that New York's Boss Tweed elevated to an art form.

title: The Sound Remains In Need of a Cleanup
description: THE signs are hopeful these days along the 577 miles of Connecticut and New York coastline that embrace Long Island Sound. Striped bass are more plentiful than they have been in half a century; harbor seals have been arriving earlier and staying longer each winter; the amount of nitrogen released into the water from sewage treatment plants has leveled off in most places, and the massive fish kills of past summers have not been seen since 1987.

title: TENNIS;Washington Shocks Wimbledon
description: Undaunted by the 5-1 deficit he faced as he and Todd Martin fought to the finish in the fifth set of their tumultuous two-day Wimbledon semifinal on Center Court today, MaliVai Washington pulled off what surely felt like a miraculous 5-7, 6-4, 6-7 (6-8), 6-3, 10-8 upset of the last remaining seeded player on the men's side.

title: House Of Real-Life Horrors
description: THERE are parts of Paris that never make it into the guidebooks, and the Fragonard Museum is in one of them. Its home, the little bedroom community of Maisons-Alfort, at the confluence of the Seine and the Marne just south of the Bois de Vincennes, is only 20 minutes upstream from the Louvre by even the slowest peniche, but a skein of T.G.V. tracks, elevated Metro lines and Peripherique off-ramps has lately transformed this nondescript suburb into a commuter belt no man's land.

title: More Mettle Than Medals
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: GOLF;Stockton Putts His Way to 7-Stroke Lead
description: It is not just the psychedelic grip on Dave Stockton's putter that has dazzled the field at the 17th United States Senior Open. Stockton is known for his putting ability, but his touch on the greens has been truly exceptional in the first three rounds of this tournament.

title: June 30-July 6;What a Deal!
description: The free market. It's a bedrock of what this nation was celebrating on Thursday. Sometimes, though, that pillar of capitalism can get a little strange.

title: 100 YEARS OF PICTURES
description: Your "100 Years of Pictures: 1896-1996" (June 9) is a powerfully moving historical record; the issue is destined for my permanent archives.

title: 12 Hurt, 6 Seriously, in Rupture of Gas Pipe in Coney Island
description: A roaring tower of flames erupted from a ruptured natural gas pipeline at a busy intersection in Brooklyn's Coney Island section yesterday afternoon as a construction crew tried to repair a water main break. Officials said that 12 people, most of them workmen, were injured, six suffering serious burns.

title: ART;A Mexican Village Becomes An Epicenter for Artists
description: A SELF-PROMOTING businessman wanted to donate a kitschy statue of Don Quixote to be prominently placed on a graceful avenue in the city of Oaxaca. The local authorities were all too pleased to accept.

title: WEDDINGS;Sandy Eckstein, John Buschhorn
description: Sandy M. Eckstein, a daughter of Evelyn and Julius Eckstein of Glendale, Queens, is to be married today to John P. Buschhorn, a son of Betty Buschhorn of Rego Park, Queens, and the late Jack Buschhorn. Rabbi Irwin Lowensheim is to officiate at the Church Center for the United Nations in Manhattan. The Rev. Henry Benack, a Roman Catholic priest, is to take part in the ceremony.

title: Correction
description: An answer in the Q & A column on June 23 carried an outdated reference to the dues for "aspiring members" of the Travelers' Century Club, people who have visited at least 75 countries, regions or island groups but fewer than 100. Since June 9, dues for these members have been $50 a year and there has been no initiation fee. Once 100 areas have been visited, the initiation fee is $100, and membership is $25 a year.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Long-Distance Aid for the Ill
description: AT the World Access Assistance Center in Richmond, which answers calls for help from people with trip insurance, nurses and a physician conduct "morning rounds" on the day's medical cases in a conference phone call. The patients are scattered around the world. Their progress is assessed after talks with medical personnel where the clients are being treated.

title: Reno, Beyond The Green Felt
description: THE price was hard to beat, even in Reno: $39.95 a night for a moderate-size room with a view of the Sierra Nevada -- and $25 cash back per night at check-in. The room was in the Riverboat, a downtown hotel with a small casino, and when I registered for five nights the clerk gave me a voucher to take to the cashier.

title: TRIBUTES;One Tough Governor: Remembering Bill Cahill
description: When conditions warranted, former Gov. William T. Cahill, who died last week at 84, was a bulldog. Raymond H. Bateman, who was Senate President through most of his term, called him "the best inside governor I ever saw."

title: WEDDINGS;Julie Leichtling, John C. Nacos
description: Julie Karen Leichtling, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Leichtling of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married last evening to John Christopher Nacos, a son of Dr. Brigitte Lebens Nacos and James J. Nacos of Sands Point, L.I. Rabbi Joel S. Goor performed the ceremony at the Water Club in New York.

title: WEDDINGS;Kempley Salerno and Charles Bryant
description: Kempley Atterbury Salerno and Charles Walsworth Bryant, teachers at the Episcopal Academy in Merion, Pa., were married on Friday in Cornwall, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Douglas Green performed the ceremony at the United Church of Christ, Congregational.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;Denounced and Then Endorsed
description: Three months after he led the denunciation of Councilwoman Julia Harrison over her remarks about Asians, Assemblyman Brian McLaughlin has endorsed Ms. Harrison's unopposed bid for district leader in the 25th Assembly District.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;A Building That Echoes A Protean Journey
description: PHILIP JOHNSON DOESN'T care about birthdays. Johnson cares about work. And the architect's 90th birthday finds him at work on one of the most ambitious jobs of his career: the Cathedral of Hope, a 2,000-seat house of worship commissioned by the Dallas branch of the Universal Fellowship of Metropolitan Community Churches, the nation's largest gay and lesbian religious denomination.

title: A Synagogue Finally Wins Itself a Home in Westport
description: LESLIE FUCHS was 7 years old when her parents joined the Conservative Synagogue, a small congregation that worships and studies in eight rented rooms above a Baskin-Robbins on Post Road East in Westport.

title: Cuddly Quasimodo: Is This a Good Thing;Disney Underestimates the Public
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 3/ The Muzak songs in elevators and doctors' offices may be catchy, but investors may want to sit out the company's initial public offering. By Reed Abelson.

title: WEDDINGS;Nicole M. Grundy, John E. Carroll 3d
description: Nicole Marie Grundy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Grundy Jr. of Stony Brook, L.I., was married on Friday to John Edward Carroll 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll Jr. of Hinsdale, Ill. Msgr. Charles A. Ribaudo performed the ceremony at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: WEDDINGS;Paul A. Moore, Amy L. Miller
description: Amy Leah Miller, the daughter of Sibyl and William Miller Jr. of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married on Friday evening to Paul Andre Moore, a son of Waveney and Phillip Moore of Brooklyn. The Rev. Dr. John Clinton Evans performed the ceremony at the Riverdale Presbyterian Church.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Free Funpass Tries To Perk Up the Metrocard

title: Cuddly Quasimodo: Is This a Good Thing;A Harm Done to Fairy Tales Too
description: To the Editor:

title: THE HARD WAY
description: Regarding his On Language column "The Hard Way" (June 16), William Safire may be interested to read the credo of my commanding officer in World War II: "The hard way is the best way. Not because it is the best way. But because it is the hard way!"

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Iverson Feted in Hometown Ceremony
description: In Hampton, Va., ALLEN IVERSON, the National Basketball Association's No. 1 draft pick, was given a hero's welcome by several thousand people yesterday in the town where he was known both as a basketball standout and as a convicted felon. The Philadelphia 76ers picked Iverson in last month's N.B.A. draft after he played two seasons at Georgetown.

title: WEDDINGS;Helen Burns, Jeffrey Olsson
description: Helen Burns, a daughter of Mary Burns and Dr. Gerard Burns of Old Westbury, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Peter Olsson, a son of Nancy and Prof. Richard Olsson of Princeton, N.J. The Rev. John Croghan performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in Rosendale, N.Y.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: TOMORROW IS ANOTHER COUNTRY: The Inside Story of South Africa's Road to Change By Allister Sparks. University of Chicago, $14.95.

title: Added Security, Planned Before Assault, Begins at Pools
description: With the sun blazing and temperatures near 90 degrees yesterday, hundreds of urban dwellers flocked to the city's public pools. There, along with mercifully cool blue water, they found security heightened a day after a 12-year-old girl was sexually assaulted at a city pool.

title: Cuddly Quasimodo: Is This a Good Thing;A Child May Pick Up the Book
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Nobody Want Me. Don't Nobody Need Me.'
description: PUSH By Sapphire. 179 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $20.

title: Their Maison Is Your Maison
description: BACK on a rainy February night, a summer trip through France based on stays in maisons d'hotes, private houses that receive guests, seemed like a great idea. It was a joy to riffle through the pages of an alluring little guidebook called "Maisons d'Hotes de Charme en France," which lists 382 bed-and-breakfasts throughout the French countryside.

title: No Plan to Hold Karadzic, NATO Chief Says
description: Despite a call by the Western allies to oust Radovan Karadzic, the separatist Bosnian Serb leader, NATO's commander in Bosnia said today that he had no plans to intimidate or to arrest him as a war criminal.

title: DINING OUT;Stressing Seafood, With Flawed Results
description: WITH little fanfare, the Aqua Grill burst on the East Hampton scene in mid-June in the beautiful quarters that had been Duke's.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Orioles Sign Two-Sport Star
description: RYAN MINOR, who was drafted in the major league baseball and N.B.A. drafts, agreed to contract terms with the Baltimore Orioles on Friday. Minor, a collegiate third baseman and shooting forward at Oklahoma, was drafted by the Orioles in the 33d round and the Philadelphia 76ers in the second round. He is scheduled to report to the 76ers' rookie camp next week and plans to play minor league baseball with the Orioles in July.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;Hong Kong's Hand-Over: To Celebrate or Not?
description: A YEAR from now, at precisely midnight on June 30, 1997, Hong Kong will look up in the night sky at a quintessential Chinese contribution to technology. Above the harbor, the most spectacular display of fireworks this territory has ever seen will burst against the sky, glinting off skyscrapers, the swiftly flowing harbor waters, illuminating the faces of hundreds of thousands of Hong Kongers.

title: June 30-July 6;A Painful Reality About Bosnia Sets In
description: The accords reached at an Air Force base near Dayton, Ohio, last November that were intended to give Bosnia a basis for peace assumed that the most prominent leaders of Bosnia's Serbs, Radovan Karadzic and Gen. Ratko Mladic, would be quickly shorn of power. No such luck.

title: THEATER;A Virtuoso Irish Director, Far From Home
description: NO ONE HAS TO REMIND Joe Dowling that he's a long, long way from the River Liffey. "I got here just in time for the worst winter in memory," he said, sitting among stage props in his new office at the Guthrie Theater. "The worst winter in memory in Minneapolis! I thought, 'What in the world am I doing here?' "

title: CUTTINGS;Putting 'Sweet' Back in Sweet Peas
description: Peter Grayson has promised to name a sweet pea for me. I've been glowing ever since he phoned to tell me, but I'm mystified about how I qualified for the honor. Granted, I spend an embarrassing quantity of time fussing over sweet peas when the appropriate season draws nigh, but the hours devoted to those brittle, pale green, tendriled vines with fragrant winged flowers are nothing compared with his involvement.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Mallon Is Disqualified

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;Western Deserts And Their Myths
description: Renault: "And what in heaven's name brought you to Casablanca?" Rick: "My health. I came to Casablanca for the waters." Renault: "Waters? What waters? We're in the desert." Rick: "I was misinformed." INFORMATION ABOUT DESERTS can be tailored to suit the fashion and adjusted to meet perceptions. The deserts and semideserts of the American West looked useless to the first explorers but seemed like an opportunity to those who followed. Anyway, we fought a war with Mexico for certain dry stretches of land, called the West, our frontier; just about destroyed an indigenous people to control it, then built an American mythology around it. We kept on rearranging the information and the land to accommodate changing ambitions and realities.

title: U.S. Bears Responsibility for Arrests in Bosnia;A Communist Revival
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTICED;Beyond Grannies: A Return to the Shades of Futures Past
description: JACQUI LEFTON admits that she owns "a lot of sunglasses." But this summer there is only one pair sitting on her nose -- her sleek, futuristic Black Fly wraps.

title: Demokratiya;The Election Shows Russia Is Russian
description: DURING the interval between the two rounds of the Russian presidential election, a somewhat morose Grigory Yavlinsky -- the reform leader who came in a weak fourth in the voting -- posed a question to an American correspondent he ran into at a party. "Tell me something," he asked nervously. "Have there ever been any politicians in the United States who were humiliated at some point in their careers but then came back to win the presidency?"

title: BASEBALL;At Age 34, Darryl Strawberry Grows Up
description: Darryl Strawberry has struck the various poses before.

title: Cuddly Quasimodo: Is This a Good Thing;It's All About Consumerism
description: To the Editor:

title: The World;Another Country, Another M.I.A. Mystery
description: THE camera closes in on a gaunt man balding, pale, probably in his 40's or 50's. "Dr. Kelton," as the character is called in this North Korean propaganda film, is an American double agent in the closing days of the Korean War. While much of his dialogue is dubbed into Korean, the American actor speaks in English, with a distinct Southern twang, and a few of his words can be made out clearly. "Human faith," he says cryptically, "is like the dew."

title: Fairfield, Bridgeport and a Trolley Shared
description: ONCE the trolley line was connected, Bridgeport residents of modest means could, for a mere 5 cents, enjoy a day at a Fairfield beach. The idea was so magnetic that by 1897 a summer colony known as "Little Bridgeport" had sprung up -- beachside cottages built off Reef Road by the trolley crowd. The trolley had created a new way of life, making it convenient to live in one place (suburban Fairfield) and work in another (Bridgeport).

title: WEDDINGS;Arlene Levinson, John R. Port
description: Arlene Renee Levinson, a national reporter for The Associated Press in New York, and John Robert Port, a special-assignment editor at the A.P., were married Thursday afternoon in the Conservatory Garden in Central Park. Acting Justice Harold Silverman of State Supreme Court in the Bronx performed the ceremony.

title: Responding to a Shortage of EMT's
description: PROVIDING speedy medical care to the sick and injured during weekday daytime hours has become so difficult because of a shortage of qualified workers that four neighboring fire districts -- Yaphank, Ridge, Gordon Heights and Middle Island -- have formed a group with paid emergency medical technicians, the first of its kind in New York State.

title: GARDENING;'Leaves of Three, Let Them Be' in Ivy Time
description: THOSE who work outdoors know there is one special menace to be especially alert to after the first flush of spring: poison ivy. If there is any doubt as to what this plant looks like, by all means clear it up. Poison ivy should be easily recognized by children as well as adults. Studying up on this problem plant is essential.

title: River Park Fighter
description: To the Editor:

title: Political Briefing;THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Idaho Actor Pushes Vote With a Vengeance

title: No Headline
description: Parents should know that when they serve a chicken dinner, they are not putting their children at risk."

title: SUNDAY, July 7, 1996: The Olympics;Atlanta Needs Flame! Notes From a Long Torch Trip
description: In 60 years of Olympic torch relays, never have so many carried fire so far. Before the last of 10,000 gleeful bearers legs out the homestretch in Atlanta on July 19, the flame will have traveled 15,000 miles through 43 states, supported by a staff big enough to quaff 80,000 ounces of (the official sponsor) Coke per day. Such grandeur wets many cheeks, but it also gives rise to fumbled Olympic moments. Follow as we relive the memories. April 7 Hungtington Beach, Calif. After arriving in Los Angeles from Athens, the flame sweeps through Southern California before getting a brief respite at a Holiday Inn, where it's nestled inside a smokeless safety lantern. "We moved a lamp off a table so it had a place to go," says Roy Gonthier, the hotel's general manager. Georgia state troopers keep the first of 83 consecutive all-night vigils to guard the torch.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE;Record Collectors' Mecca Raided for Bootlegging
description: Second Coming Records, a small shop on Sullivan Street, drew all sorts. Punks came in for hard core. Rude boys stopped by for ska disks. Collectors combed through the bins for 60's rarities. Then there were the undercover agents who went there looking for bootlegged recordings and counterfeit compact disks.

title: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;A Tale of Two Cities And the Deficit
description: I UNDERSTAND that Lehman Brothers has an analyst who specializes in the Government's effects on business. From where I sit, this is a smart move.

title: Is the U.N. Inefficient? U.S. Critics Draw Retort
description: Stung by charges of waste and mismanagement from Congress and the Clinton Administration, United Nations officials are fighting back against criticisms that they say are politically motivated and based on misinformation or no information at all.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Ravens Taking Band Under Their Wing
description: The team may change, but the band remains the same.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE;New Life, New Gripes for Avenue A
description: Not long ago, Avenue A was a drug-infested no man's land, a forlorn strip given over to vagrants, anarchists and punks. At least that's how Karazona Cinar, 30, a local entrepreneur, remembers it. "Because of businessmen like me, things are much better," said Mr. Cinar, a Kurdish immigrant who owns Stingy Lulu's, a restaurant on St. Marks Place off Avenue A, and Robots, a bar on Avenue B.

title: What It's Like to Walk on Someone Else's Bunions
description: What is it like to walk around the aisles of a grocery store with kernels of popcorn in your shoes, or to pick packages off the shelves with Popsicle sticks tied to your fingers? Employees of four Shop Rite stores in Ocean County are discovering that it can be an enlightening experience.

title: Residential Resales
description: In the following reports, the "listed at" price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;White-Knuckle Ride for the Small-Stock Flotilla
description: BY the beginning of June, managers of small-cap mutual funds must have thought they had it made. The stocks of companies with market values of less than $1 billion had soared, giving small-company funds an average gain for the year of 17 percent, nearly double the rise in the broad market.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: SAMARKAND By Amin Maalouf. Interlink, cloth, $35; paper, $14.95.

title: The Fresh Air Fund;On Visit to Farm, City Girls Confront Hard and Soft Reality
description: The city girls visiting the model farm in Fishkill would not flinch at the sight of a hurtling subway train. But when Priscilla the goat took a wobbly step toward them, they screamed.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;Software for Steering Through That Maze of Funds
description: WITH more than 7,200 mutual funds competing for investors' dollars, choosing the right handful for your portfolio can be a daunting task.

title: STYLE;The Alchemist
description: In a self-proclaimed age of minimalism, when people are stripping their homes of decoration and wearing no jewelry, Line Vautrin has, improbably, become a cult figure once again. The first time around, during the 50's in Paris, she commanded a boutique in the Faubourg Saint-Honore and, later, a 26-room town house in the Marais, where 40 artisans executed her designs for jewelry, buttons and decorative objects. Now in her 80's, she listens with amazement to accounts of her work turning up at flea markets and auction houses, selling for prices she could never have imagined. Young journalists who hadn't even been born when, at the age of 50, she closed her business and turned to teaching, come to interview her. Her work is the subject of a recent book, "Line Vautrin: Sculptor, Jeweler, Magician." And now Bergdorf Goodman is offering a selection of her pieces on exhibit and for sale (through Aug. 31).

title: VIEWS;Once a Bumpy Game of the Streets, Roller Hockey Takes Off
description: Forty years ago, on urban and suburban streets, kids with quads (the old clamp-on roller skates with pairs of side-by-side wheels) spun bumpily over asphalt in a pickup game that looked like ice hockey at half speed. It was roller hockey and it was clearly a hybrid sport.

title: Genevieve Blatt, 83, Who Held Prominent Posts in Pennsylvania
description: Judge Genevieve Blatt, the first woman to be elected to statewide office in Pennsylvania and to serve on the state's appellate court, died on Thursday at a retirement home in Hampden Township, Pa. She was 83 and a former resident of Harrisburg.

title: Exclusive Club Celebrates Stature
description: As Matthew Langmaid walked up Third Avenue yesterday morning, not one person asked him how the weather was up there. Not one per son called him Treetop, or demanded to know whether he played professional basketball. It was a nice feeling, he said, just to blend in.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;The Medium That Defies Sharp Focus
description: OLIVER SACKS, THE NEUROLOGIST AND writer, regards his patients from a smart, specific perspective. Whether he is visiting an autistic child who is a gifted painter or a surgeon with Tourette syndrome, he views his subjects with much warmth. He likes them. Yet there is always a part of his own brain that is wondering what's wrong with theirs. As he says in the recent book "An Anthropologist on Mars," he sees "with a sympathetic or friendly eye as well as an anthropological one."

title: Yesterday's Hero
description: The Gorbachev Factor By Archie Brown. Illustrated. 406 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $30. NOW that the Russian presidential election is finally over, it is useful to examine again the extraordinary life and times of a man whose popularity was once equal to none, but whose dream of an electoral resurrection last month came to a bitter end. That Mikhail S. Gorbachev's star had ceased to shine in his own country has long been clear to everybody -- everybody, that is, except himself. But it had dimmed, too, in the European news media and even among the crowds in Germany, France and Britain that had turned out to listen raptly to his speeches since his fall from power, thus feeding his conviction that he was, as ever, the top man in the tent, a person still destined for greatness.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;Furniture That Said, 'Made in New York'
description: NEW YORK IS TODAY recognized as an international hub of finance and culture. But what remains virtually unknown is that 200 years ago, when New York was briefly the nation's capital, it was also the furniture capital of America, the city where national decorating trends were set.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-9

title: Another View Of Polo Fans
description: Polo matches took place at Bridgehampton last summer without incident. Nevertheless "Tourist Lures Draw Law Suits on East End" [June 10] adopts the hysterical and catastrophic scenario portrayed by the petitioners' attorneys.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;It's Time to Bid for (Not So) Free Agents
description: At noon Tuesday, Eastern time, phones throughout the National Basketball Association will begin to ring like crazy.

title: Theater Review;New Works Shaped by Audiences
description: COME summer, the buzz of plays in progress 15 in one developmental phase or another -- attests to the waking up of theater in the environs of Westchester. And that process, ordinarily generated behind closed doors, is open to the public in various spaces on the campus of Vassar College here.

title: POSTINGS: 'Restoration Directory';Conservancy's Best Seller
description: The sixth edition of "Restoration Directory: A Listing of Services in the New York City Area," issued this year by the New York Landmarks Conservancy, is a best seller. All 500 copies sold out after a couple of months.

title: WEDDINGS;Rebecca Michaels, Peter C. Klinger
description: Rebecca Michaels, the daughter of Dr. Meredith Wilson Michaels of Amherst, Mass., and Dr. Walter Benn Michaels of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Peter Christopher Klinger, the son of Marilyn D. Glass of New York and Richard D. Klinger of Los Angeles. John Alley, a justice of the peace in Tisbury, Mass., performed the ceremony at the summer home of the bride's mother in Gay Head, Mass.

title: WEDDINGS;Chaz Vagt, Ted Smith
description: Mary-Lauren Vagt, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry T. Vagt Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married on Thursday to Warren Theodore Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren M. Smith of Lodi, Calif. The Rev. Kamala Dietz, an interfaith minister, performed the ceremony at Sequoia Grove Vineyards in Oakville, Calif.

title: Ideas & Trends;What Happens When the Brain Can't Remember
description: SIX years into what has been declared the Decade of the Brain, the great efflorescence of understanding sometimes seems overwhelming. Breakthroughs follow breakthroughs follow breakthroughs, like the announcement last week that scientists peering inside a brain with a device called a PET scanner could tell true memories from false ones.

title: Jackie Robinson Helped Break Golf's Color Bar
description: To the Editor:

title: The Race For Congress '96 -- Alabama's Fourth Congressional District; Retirements a Hurdle for Dixie's Democrats
description: The main road into this northern Alabama town winds past Bevill State Community College, the Bevill Industrial Park, and, of course, the Walker County airport, Bevill Field.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Belgium Celebrates The Comic Book
description: Belgium came late to comic strips -- 33 years after "Yellow Kid" was born in the United States -- but the Belgians then embraced comics as an art form with a passion equal to Americans', and they are marking the 100th anniversary of comics with a yearlong, countrywide celebration.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: ART;A Print Show by 12 Workshop Members
description: MIMICKING a twig is the way some caterpillars elude predators. But the print that would be a painting or sculpture -- anything but a print -- is this camouflage or is it a symptom of romantic discontent, the same that prompts individuals to change their sex?

title: TENNIS;All England Is All Graf A 7th Time
description: First there is Steffi Graf, and then there are the rest. The No. 1-ranked German, while a reluctant participant in the debate about her place in history, proved once again that in this era and at this time, she simply has no peers in the women's game.

title: You Saved, but They Didn't. So Now What?
description: HERE'S the nightmare. You've socked away every stray penny in retirement accounts, resisting the temptation to live it up, in order to accumulate a comfy nest egg. Now it's payoff time: Hawaii beckons. But all the aging spendthrifts -- the folks who bought fishing boats instead of mutual funds -- persuade Congress to tax your savings and slash your Social Security checks in order to spread the wealth.

title: SUNDAY, July 7, 1996;QUESTIONS FOR: The Piercing Pros
description: Ahna Edwards and Tracy Faraca, professional body piercers based in Portland, Ore., recently helped the state write a sweeping new set of health regulations for the rapidly growing industry.

title: THE SONG IS ENDED
description: Jesse Green's "The Song Is Ended" (June 2) was impressive, but he omits mention of the damage Dick Clark did to pop music in the 1950's and 1960's. "American Bandstand," as I bitterly recall, stopped my listening to music on TV and radio.

title: The Best Way to Save Dolphins
description: The environmental community is engaged in a rare and bitter brawl over competing Congressional bills aimed at protecting a beloved environmental symbol -- the bottle-nosed dolphin. Each side thinks it has the better scheme to protect dolphins that are incidentally trapped and killed by the giant nets used by tuna fleets. This is a complex, emotional issue and all the disputants are animated by the best of intentions. But the approach contained in a measure sponsored by Representative Wayne Gilchrest, a Maryland Republican, and supported by the Clinton Administration, offers the dolphin a better chance than the alternatives.

title: WEDDINGS;Adrienne Zicklin And David Kanter
description: Adrienne Victoria Zicklin, a daughter of Carole and Robert Zicklin of New York, was married on Friday evening to David Morris Kanter, a son of Gail and Carl Kanter of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Stephen Klein performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Backtalk;The No. 1 Seeding Belongs to Wimbledon
description: Almost everything has changed at Wimbledon since I first played there in 1978: the setting, the ambiance, the players, the equipment and, therefore, the game. But the truth of the contest remains exactly the same. The feeling among the top players is that Wimbledon is the pinnacle and the All England Lawn Tennis Club -- though more crowded and commercial than a decade ago -- is the palace guarding the history, the drama, the triumphs and tragedies of the game.

title: Medium Spare
description: CONSPICUOUS PRIVACY IS A BIG DEAL in the Hamptons -- it took three meandering trips on a mountain bike just to find this place, tucked away at the end of a narrow, crunchy driveway that seems to go on for miles, fortified by the tallest, densest, most crisply pruned hedges imaginable.

title: Cuddly Quasimodo: Is This a Good Thing;Reinterpretations Can Be Good
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Judge Stresses Women's Legal Gains
description: THE state's highest-ranking jurist addressed the Westchester Women's Bar Association here recently in a speech that stressed both the strides of women in the legal profession and the importance of an independent judiciary.

title: A Short, Corrective History of Violence in Popular Culture
description: BOB DOLE MAY HAVE DRAWN FIRST blood last year when he lashed out at "Money Train" and other cinematic "nightmares of depravity," but as both the Presidential campaign and the summer movie season heat up, we can expect ever-escalating rhetoric about family values and degrading entertainment. At this point, the debate isn't even partisan: Bill Clinton got into the act in recent months, pressuring the television industry to reduce its violent content and pushing the carnage-blocking V-chip legislation through Congress. Of course, Hollywood doesn't help, filling screens with make-believe mayhem; this weekend alone, the alien invasion epic "Independence Day" trumped "Eraser" and "The Rock," not just killing millions but also blowing away the nation's capital.

title: MEAT INSPECTIONS FACING OVERHAUL, FIRST IN 90 YEARS
description: President Clinton today announced the most sweeping changes in the Government's meat inspection system since it was created nearly a century ago, outlining new rules that would, for the first time, impose scientific tests for disease-causing bacteria.

title: June 30-July 6;Forgoing the Gold
description: For Ramon Garbey and Joel Casamayor, highly-rated members of Cuba's Olympic boxing squad, defection from a Mexican training camp last week was an emotional adventure to gain freedom and perhaps harbinger of more problems for Cuba. The two landed in an American detention center, but were released, happy to be in Los Angeles and showing no bitterness over their abandoned hopes for Olympic gold.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Strawberry Fields

title: Cuddly Quasimodo: Is This a Good Thing;Rest Easy: the Classics Live On
description: To the Editor:

title: Down Payment Hurdle Is Getting Lower
description: A FEW months ago, Todd and Melissa Greenberg, who had moved to New York City from the Midwest, started looking for a house in Westchester County. The Greenbergs, both of whom work in the health-care industry, knew they earned enough to buy a house but were concerned about getting a mortgage without a substantial down payment.

title: Commercial Property/Recycling;A New Factory and New Jobs? For New York? Yes
description: ALMOST in the shadow of the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, a new factory is being built to process part of the city's trash into paper that will be used to make cardboard boxes. The $250 million factory, on 35 acres facing the Arthur Kill, is one the largest industrial investments in the city in recent decades and a small reversal of the exodus of factory jobs from New York.

title: A Dead Language, Yiddish Lives
description: WHEN I.B. SINGER RECEIVED THE NOBEL PRIZE FOR LITERATURE in 1978, he told the Swedish Academy - in Yiddish - that his beloved mother tongue had not yet spoken its last word. But even Singer would be amazed to discover the factions - from the Hasidim of Brooklyn to a surprising number of young gay Jews - who are now engaged in a struggle over the future of Yiddish. In seeking to redefine the modern meaning of an old language, the partisans of Yiddish are trying to redefine the very character of American Judaism.

title: MUSIC;Beethoven and More
description: CHAMBER MUSIC PLUS holds its 14th season of "Beethoven Bravo" recitals on the next three Tuesday evenings at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. This week Beethoven's G Minor Sonata for cello and piano begins the 8 o'clock concert, and the group's founding duo, Harry Clark and Sanda Schuldmann, proceed to Chopin's "Polonaise Brilliant," and, with the actor John McDonough, Liszt's "Lenore." Also on the program: Robert Starer's "Remembering Felix" for narrator, cello and piano.

title: DINING OUT;Bring the Children
description: A GREAT place to sit outside and drink iced tea," a friend says when I tell her I'm going to Panevino Ristorante. She forgets to add that it's probably the only restaurant in New Jersey where you can eat salads dressed with olive oil imported from the Fattoria Dell'Ugo in Tuscany, and feel comfortable bringing children. More baby carriages converge in these aisles at lunchtime than they do at the local McDonald's.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;Gone Before It Ever Really Arrived: The Quotron
description: The residents of TriBeCa can breathe easy. The city's Economic Development Corporation will not be building a tall, obelisk-shaped tower capped by a stainless steel American flag and flashing the latest stock prices on a lonely stretch of lower Washington Street after all.

title: Bob Dole's Centrist Foreign Policy
description: Bob Dole is finding it hard to pick a foreign policy fight with President Clinton. It is not for lack of effort. In two blistering speeches in recent weeks, Mr. Dole called Mr. Clinton and his advisers "would-be statesmen still suffering from a post-Vietnam syndrome" and faulted the White House for "weak leadership, vacillation and inconsistency." But the broad outlines of Mr. Dole's foreign policy agenda have more in common with Mr. Clinton's policies than the shrill rhetoric or tactical differences would suggest.

title: BASEBALL;After Key's Emergency, Record Save Caps Shutout
description: It figured. On the night when John Wetteland broke Lee Smith's major league record with a save in his 20th consecutive appearance, the main news at Yankee Stadium was that Darryl Strawberry was on his way to wearing pinstripes again, four days early.

title: WEDDINGS;Jo Clark, Matthew Cohen
description: Jo Clark, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Clark of New York, is to be married today to Matthew Scott Cohen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Martin Cohen of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Leonard Goldstein is to perform the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: ENCOUNTERS;In the Maelstrom of Animal Medical Studies
description: ALREADY, when you make a first impression, you are preparing the groove for a memory. And so I will remember Dr. Jan Moor-Jankowski, world expert in the scientific use of chimpanzees, standing in a doorway, in a stiff rather military dress jacket with brass buttons, with a portable telephone in each hand, his tall body at peace somehow with the low ceilings and walls of this early 19th century whaler's cottage in Orient.

title: AT THE GATE;Will Elevator Music Climb in the Stock Market?
description: MUZAK is no stranger to anyone who has ever ridden an elevator or visited the dentist. The company, the oldest purveyor of "business music," says its sanitized versions of tunes by artists from George Gershwin to Boyz II Men are heard by tens of millions of people around the world each day.

title: A LA CARTE;Standard and Superior Dishes by the Water
description: SUNSETS rarely accompany sunset meals, but at the Port Royal on Fort Pond Bay in Montauk they do. The often spectacular orange and red waterfront scenes at dusk are accompanied by soaring sea gulls, children romping on an adjacent beach, trains chugging along the curve of the shore to the Long Island Rail Road's last stop and a three-course $19.95 sunset dinner worth checking out.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;Angling for Parking Space Near a Hospital
description: On tree-lined East End Avenue, just beyond the gates of Gracie Mansion, a white Volvo sedan is defiantly angle-parked. Last week, four parking tickets were jammed underneath a windshield wiper.

title: The Joys of Paris
description: To the Editor: I particularly enjoyed the article about Paris, "We'll Always Have . . . Questions" by Ann Burack-Weiss (June 2). Yes, the light timer known as a minuterie does save money for the host. Hand-held showers are a royal pain: you turn the water off while soaping up.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Intradivision Play Beats Balance
description: If the owners are watching, if they are not distracted by a plot to devise a way to create an impasse in labor negotiations and gain judicial permission to impose their own work rules on the players, they might have noticed over the past 10 days or so the excitement that intradivision games can create.

title: John M. Meyer Jr., 89, Banker Who Eased Securities Trading
description: John M. Meyer Jr., a former chairman of J. P. Morgan & Company who helped develop some of the modern systems that allow for easier settlement of securities trades, died on Thursday at his home in Greenwich, Conn., said William G. McBride, a spokesman for J. P. Morgan. He was 89.

title: Cuddly Quasimodo: Is This a Good Thing;Painting On a Happy Face
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuddly Quasimodo: Is This a Good Thing;Nothing Diminished or Demeaned
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE BOOK;The Doles Tell Their Two Tales, and Hope for One Happy Ending
description: Elizabeth Dole carefully read and reread her wedding vows; Bob Dole elected to wing his.

title: June 30-July 6;An Inquiry in Mexico
description: Pesky Congressional committees have long haunted American Presidents, Bill Clinton included. But in Mexico, where the Congress is often mocked in editorial cartoons as a flock of sheep, the recent formation of a multi-party commission on corruption is a novelty.

title: Milton Goldfine, 74, Manager at NASA
description: Milton T. Goldfine, who oversaw the test and launching operations for the spacecraft Galileo in the 1980's, died on June 21 at the University of Tennessee Medical Center in Knoxville. He was 74 and lived in Tellico Village, Tenn.

title: A Fee at a Rockefeller Park? Shocking!
description: LAST month, almost 10 years to the day after the dedication of the Rockefeller State Park Preserve here -- the largess of the famous family -- visitors arriving by car for a hike or a stroll discovered a startling sight: a tollhouse.

title: IN BRIEFS;Making Gains in the Battle Against Childhood Disease
description: New Jersey ranks 27th in the percentage of 2-year-olds who have received immunization shots, but Health Commissioner Len Fishman says that statistic does not reflect a dramatic recent improvement.

title: FRUGAL TRAVELER;In Quebec City, Costs Translate Nicely
description: THE Francophile in me had long been yearning to visit Quebec City, which I pictured as a sort of mild-tempered second cousin to Paris, or a New Orleans without dark corners. Then, too, I was attracted by the city's past, which lingers along narrow winding streets, in the doorways of handsome 17th- and 18th-century row houses and on the banks of the beautiful St. Lawrence River.

title: Arthur R. Silsdorf, Ocean Beach Mayor, 77
description: Arthur Richard Silsdorf, a longtime mayor of the Fire Island resort village of Ocean Beach, died on Tuesday at his home there. He was 77 and also lived in Manhattan.
