title: FATAL LAPSES -- A special report.;How U.S. Missteps and Delay Opened Door to Saudi Blast
description: Significant shortcomings in planning, intelligence and basic security left American forces in Saudi Arabia vulnerable to the recent bombing that killed 19 Americans and seriously wounded 148, interviews with Government officials and private security experts show.

title: WEDDINGS;Juliana McIntyre, Nicholas Sowles
description: Juliana Stevens Cuyler McIntyre, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Bigelow McIntyre of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Nicholas Payne Sowles, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James Homer Sowles of Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Sarah Motley, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the McIntyres' home in Greensboro, Vt.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Indelible 'Evita,' Authentically Conceived
description: The real star of "Evita" is Harold Prince. It follows that the second-best man in the world to replicate Mr. Prince's staging is Larry Fuller, his second-in-command and the choreographer of the incomparable 1979 Broadway production.

title: DIARY: AEROSPACE;Space Travel Inc.
description: One short generation ago, space travel was a wondrous novelty, one that only Washington's wondrously deep pockets could bankroll. Now it's just another business. Last week NASA picked Lockheed Martin to build a possible replacement for the space shuttle; it would be this nation's first major new spacecraft in 25 years. NASA, you see, no longer wants to be in the business of owning and launching rockets -- it wants to stick to research. The goal is to have a fleet of rockets owned and operated by industry, hauling stuff aloft that's both public and private. And Lockheed says that with the X-33, it can do it at one-tenth the cost -- and one-tenth the risk. For one thing, all those things that drop off the current shuttle -- like booster rockets and fuel tanks -- will be gone. The X-33 stays in one piece.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: THE AMERICAN FAMILY Discovering the Values That Make Us Strong. By Dan Quayle and Diane Medved. HarperCollins/Zondervan, $25.

title: FOOD;Ripeness Is All
description: THERE THEY ARE, MELON UPON MELON, FAT and serene. They crowd farm stands from June to October, revealing little beyond their supreme self-assurance, which can be maddening.

title: Correction
description: A review on June 9 about "A New Name for Peace: International Environmentalism, Sustainable Development, and Democracy," by Philip Shabecoff, referred incorrectly to the author's career at The New York Times. He covered environmental issues for 14 years, not 25; earlier he was a foreign correspondent and a White House correspondent. His years at The Times totaled 32.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CONEY ISLAND;Accord on Sports Complex Breaking Down
description: Two weeks ago, Brooklyn representatives in the State Assembly and Senate, both Democrats and Republicans, were celebrating the meeting of the minds on a proposed 12,000-seat sports complex in Coney Island. It was the first time since the arena was conceived nine years ago that Brooklynites in Albany agreed to a plan to raise $70 million to build it.

title: Man Killed in Shooting Outside Queens Bar
description: One man was killed and another critically wounded in a shooting outside a bar in the Howard Beach section of Queens last night, the police said.

title: An American Place;As Incomes Polarize, A County Does, Too
description: The disparity between what top managers are paid and what rank-and-file workers receive has always been a source of friction, and that has been particularly true lately in Stark County, Ohio, especially in light of the salary concessions workers at some factories have been asked to accept. A company that makes automated teller machines has felt the tensions intensely.

title: The City That Made Itself Up
description: As we hammer and paint and plant flowers and sign leasing agreements and set up 16 zillion portable toilets here at Ground Zero of the 1996 Olympic Games, Atlantans are gripped by more than a little anxiety.

title: A Private School That Promotes Black Culture and Self-Pride
description: A TYPICAL day at Bereshith Cultural Institute begins at 7:30 A.M. and ends around 6 P.M. Parents from all over Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, Greenburgh and the Bronx arrive at the South Fifth Avenue center with their children dressed neatly in navy blue and white school uniforms. Some arrive by car and private bus, others on foot.

title: Meat Safety Rule No Longer 'Catch as Catch Can'
description: The new inspection system announced today by the Clinton Administration provides for the Government and the industry to share responsibility for monitoring and testing meat and poultry all along the processing chain from slaughter to the grocery shelf.

title: Legacy of Immigrants' Uprising: New Jail Operator, Little Change
description: After a melee erupted at a detention center for illegal immigrants in Elizabeth, N.J., a year ago, the Immigration and Naturalization Service pronounced the center a double failure: the private company that ran it for the Government did so with underpaid, poorly trained guards who harassed and degraded immigrants, and the immigration service itself fumbled its supervisory role.

title: Tour de States
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: History 101 Not
description: To the Editor:

title: Carnage and Glory, Legends and Lies
description: FOR THE RECORD, I KNOW THE DRILL. I've saluted my superiors and spit shined my shoes and marched till my arches were aching. I've aimed a rifle and reeled at the awful result. In short, I'm a typical American paradox, a veteran who still boils at the Beltway blockheads who bloodied his generation and a former marine who will always step forward for his beloved corps.

title: College That Keeps Eye on the Job Market
description: THE academic and business career of Dr. Arnold K. Weinstein has stretched from New York to Australia with posts in Europe in between, but now he has a job closer to his home in New Rochelle.

title: World News Briefs;14 Hurt in Knife Attack At Train Station in Japan
description: A man who said he had received a divine message stabbed and slashed at least 14 people today at a crowded train station in southern Japan. The police said at least two people were in critical condition.

title: Liberties;A Comedy Of Terrors
description: One day in the blessedly not-too-distant future, the single greatest event in modern history will occur. The baby boom generation will go boom. Finally, we will die off, and there will be a great cosmic sigh of relief.

title: WEDDINGS;Melissa Karmen, Michael Boxer
description: Melissa Ann Karmen, a daughter of Myrna Karmen and Dr. Anatole Karmen of East Hills, L.I., was married on Wednesday to Michael David Boxer, a son of Enid and Leonard Boxer of New York. Rabbi Richard Thaler performed the ceremony at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Ailing National Parks Look to Rescue, at a Price
description: Welcome to America's oldest national park, just "one step from insolvency," as a brochure from a half-smiling ranger at the entrance informs a visitor.

title: Woman Who Defaces Park Doesn't Deserve Exposure
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Resurgent Mets Win Their 4th In a Row
description: Just when you figured these Mets would stagger into the All-Star Game break playing like a team headed nowhere, they come to Montreal and play three games that leave you wondering if there might be hope after all.

title: EXIT REASONABLE RIGHT
description: I thoroughly enjoyed Claudia Dreifus's article "Exit Reasonable Right" (June 2) on the retiring Senator Alan Simpson. I had the opportunity to meet and chat with him two years ago and am an admirer of his wit, courage and common sense. The article's Q. and A. format was an ideal way to show Simpson at his best. He has always been known on the Hill for his ability to handle hardball questions.

title: Hey Kids, How's Business?
description: For millions of students, summer is a time to earn and learn. Jobs help pay tuition and provide valuable experience. Or do they? What have you really done this summer? And how will it appear on your resume? Any advice for shaping up corporate America? Send your story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Pirates Release Smith and Shake Up Staff
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates shook up their pitching staff yesterday, releasing ZANE SMITH, a left-hander, and moving relievers JON LIEBER and DAN MICELI into the starting rotation. Miceli (1-4), who had 21 saves as a rookie last season and began the season as their closer, will start today against St. Louis. He has not started a game since 1989, when he was in high school. (AP)

title: Sophia Delza Glassgold, 92, Dancer and Teacher
description: Sophia Delza Glassgold, a modern dancer and teacher and an expert in the ancient Chinese exercise form called tai chi, died on June 27 at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan.

title: Beyond Plastic Surgery
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Susan K. Landers, Joseph E. McGuire
description: Susan Kay Landers, a daughter of John and Sandra Landers of Pelham Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Joseph Edward McGuire, a son of Edward and Lucy McGuire of Mahwah, N.J. The Rev. Edward F. X. Kennedy performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help in Pelham Manor.

title: Cuddly Quasimodo: Is This a Good Thing;To Roar or Not to Roar
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: PROSPECT PARK;Fishing Hole Where Dough Is the Lure
description: CARP, bass and catfish are all in the Prospect Park Lake waiting to be caught (and then thrown back).

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'WOMEN'S WORLD'

title: June 30-July 6;Netanyahu Sets Some Terms
description: In his Government guidelines, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel made clear that he will not accept a Palestinian state or a divided Jerusalem. Lately, he has given some indications of what he would accept -- Palestinian self-government in areas where Palestinians live, without formal borders and under overall Israeli control.

title: Presidential Prerogative
description: To the Editor:

title: CHATTER;Legislating Who Can Say 'I Do'
description: More than two dozen lawmakers have introduced a bill to outlaw same-sex marriages in New Jersey. What do you think of this proposal? (Ten people responded to the question; all oppose the legislation.)

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Deals and Discounts
description: AUTUMN IN INDIA -- A 10-day, three-city tour of India priced at $1,499 a person, double occupancy, including scheduled flights from New York on Air-India, is available beginning in September from a New York company called Smartours. Departures are monthly through May of next year. A discount of $200 a person is offered to those who reserve the September or May departure by July 31. The trip goes to Delhi, Jaipur and Agra, with accommodations in deluxe and first-class hotels, buffet breakfast daily and sightseeing. A 14-day tour that adds Khajuraho, Varanasi and Katmandu in Nepal to the 10-day itinerary costs $2,099 before the early booking discount. A departure Dec. 20 costs $300 extra. Information: (800) 337-7773.

title: SUNDAY, July 7, 1996: RETAILING;Tobacco, Unbound
description: Smokers are the largest abused minority in the U.S.," maintains John Roscoe. "We treat them with respect." Roscoe, 66, is the California marketing patriarch behind Cigarettes Cheaper! -- a new "smoker friendly" discount chain that's growing at a breathtaking rate. (Now up to 273 outlets nationwide; 500 promised soon; world domination vowed before century's end.) Founder of the Cheaper! grocery-store chain, Roscoe is famed as a maverick price slasher and no-prisoners libertarian. Along with cheap (sorry, cheaper) cigarettes and related flotsam -- including Marlboro 15-speed bikes -- the stores feature shopping bags printed with Roscoe's testy political screeds. (This month Simon & Schuster will publish a collection, "Bagatorials.") Oddly, the chain's employees aren't quite so liberty-enriched: hopefuls are treated to a drug test and prying questions like "What weapons do you own?" "We're not antigovernment," Roscoe explains. "But we are for self-government, I suppose."

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MILL BASIN;Wresting a Dwindling Living From the Sea
description: Wearing a madras shirt and navy pants and sporting the deep wrinkles and sun-hardened skin of a man who has spent years muscling through ocean waters, Vincent Marinello prepared once again recently to search for fish.

title: WEDDINGS;Grace Lombardo, Antonio Chavez
description: Grace Ann Lombardo, a daughter of Sally Ann and Anthony Lombardo of Bay Shore, L.I., is to be married today to Dr. Antonio F. Chavez, the son of Carmen Chavez of Chatsworth, Calif., and the late Antonio Chavez. Rabbi Michael Irlick is to officiate at the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I.

title: MARKET WATCH;A Lagging Fund Wipes Out Profits
description: There was a time, and not so long ago, when Paul Wick was viewed as a genius, and his fund was the hottest one around. The Seligman Communications and Information fund rode the semiconductor boom to phenomenal returns, and became the best-performing fund in the country.

title: WEDDINGS;Savannah Basinger, Robert Jahrling
description: Savannah Lee Basinger, the daughter of Jeanine and John Basinger of Middletown, Conn., was married on Friday to Robert Francis Keoki Jahrling, the son of Roberta Naauao Jahrling and Frank Jahrling of Honolulu. The Rev. James L. Davis performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Madison, Wis.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;North-South Split on the West Side
description: Correction Appended

title: Baby's Death a Homicide
description: The death of a newborn girl found Friday night behind a Brooklyn apartment building has been ruled a homicide, a spokeswoman for the New York City Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

title: Peggy and Goliath
description: THE GIANT'S HOUSE A Romance. By Elizabeth McCracken. 259 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $19.95. THE heroine of "The Giant's House," a librarian named Peggy Cort, is an old maid. In the 1990's, I suppose, we'd have to call her "matrimonially challenged" -- a woman nobody wants. But in the course of the novel, this secret romantic's hard shell cracks open in the heat of a most peculiar passion.

title: Dole Seeks to Curb Crimes by Juveniles
description: Bob Dole announced his vision for overhauling the juvenile justice system today, in the weekly Republican radio address.

title: Beyond Plastic Surgery
description: To the Editor:

title: June 30-July 6;Chilling a Hotbed
description: Score one for Arizona in the race to be the hottest bed of right-wing paramilitary activity. Last week Federal authorities arrested 12 members of a group called the "Viper Militia" in and around Phoenix and charged them with conspiracy to promote civil disorder and various weapons charges. The authorities said the 10 men and two women were preparing for an "upcoming war" with the Federal Government, practicing with illegal weapons and explosives in remote areas, and learning how to blow up Federal buildings, the Phoenix police headquarters and the National Guard headquarters. STEVEN A. HOLMES

title: FILM;This Woman Refuses To Play 'the Girl'
description: DESPITE HER SOMETIMES CANDY-BOX prettiness and a fistful of complimentary reviews, Kyra Sedgwick has spent most of the last decade bobbing along at the edges of mainstream attention. Her resume includes bright, brief moments in theater and television specials and a succession of supporting roles in films. But she did nothing that would constitute a breakthrough until last year, when she appeared as Julia Roberts's mordant, blowzy younger sister in the movie "Something to Talk About."

title: Fragile Scrolls Cast New Light on Early Buddhism
description: For 18 months, scholars at the British Library have been poring over 13 scrolls of birch bark that were found rolled up inside clay pots, convinced they were looking at ancient manuscripts.

title: Henry Williams, 84, Lawyer For Rep. Powell and a Judge
description: Henry R. Williams, a lawyer who represented Rep. Adam Clayton Powell Jr., headed the Model Cities program's Harlem office and was a Civil Court judge, died on June 29 at the New York Hospital Medical Center of Queens. He was 84 and lived in Harlem.

title: Woman Dies and 5 Are Hurt in a Fire in Queens
description: A 63-year-old woman died yesterday when fire swept through the two-story frame house in Richmond Hill, Queens, where she lived with her son and his family.

title: W. H. Hogeland, 68, Lawyer and Analyst
description: William H. Hogeland, a former managing partner in the law firm of Webster & Sheffield, died June 29 at his home in Manhattan. He was 68 and also had a home in Blauvelt, N.Y.

title: GOOD EATING;Intricate Asian Fare In Chinatown
description: JOE'S SHANGHAI ** (212) 233-8888; 9 Pell Street, near Canal Street; (c) no credit cards

title: ON THE STREET;Summer Exposures
description: The exposed midriff, fashion's popular erogenous zone, has mass appeal for the young. Flashes of bared midriff have been seen even under business jackets. For some, the office cover-up is a sweater, removed and worn around the shoulders when outdoors. The abbreviated shirts and sweaters expose anywhere from an inch to a foot of torso. The newest look includes a narrow gold or silver midriff chain (bottom, far left and second from left) worn on the bare skin.

title: The View From: White Plains;Taking Some of the Terror Out of Being Admitted to a Hospital
description: GORGEOUS" is not the sort of word one usually hears in reference to a hospital, yet within an hour three doctors and just as many administrators had used it to describe the new wing at White Plains Hospital Center here. Tours were being given of the Flanzer Pavilion, as the addition is called, and with pristine white walls, bedspread and curtains in a soothing shade of blue and cherry wood accents have just about everyone oohing and aahing.

title: Young, Virginal and Needed
description: THE two teen-age girls had only one thing in mind when they jumped onto the uncrowded Yokohama subway car: to steal advertising posters.

title: Mahonri Young, 84, An Art Historian
description: Mahonri Sharp Young, an art historian, writer and former museum director, died last Sunday at his home in Bridgehampton, L.I. He was 84.

title: ART;Portraying the Dignity of the Downtrodden
description: AT the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford, the retrospective of the work of John Biggers -- which includes 127 drawings, prints, sculptures and paintings -- qualifies as a blockbuster in every way. It is a big, powerful and emotionally moving show. The only thing missing is celebrity status. But as the show (organized by the Museum of Fine Arts in Houston) travels around the country, and Mr. Biggers's work is seen and discussed by a wider audience, that omission should be taken care of.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;To Market, to Market
description: CASINOS never have a good day.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: SUNNYSIDE Love, Complications And Spanish Theater

title: ON THE MAP;In Fair Lawn, Getting to Know a New Language and a New Land
description: They arrived in Fair Lawn strangers in a strange land, Jews from Russia who have carved out a shtetl among the other 30,500 residents of this Bergen County suburb. Assisted by volunteers from northern New Jersey's Jewish community, many of the immigrants have occupied the El Dorado Village apartment complex in the borough's Radburn section, a planned community established in 1929.

title: 100 YEARS OF PICTURES
description: I keep the morgue of a weekly newspaper in a small town. The mug shots of elected officials, performers, the convicted and the deceased are easily labeled. It's the old photos, with nothing noted on the reverse side, that are the most haunting in their mystery.

title: WEDDINGS;Ms. Schuchinski, Mr. Weintraub
description: Susan Esther Schuchinski, a daughter of Vivian and Luis Schuchinski of Upper Montclair, N.J., was married on Wednesday to Leonard Weintraub, a son of Paul Weintraub of Fairfield, Conn., and the late Flora Weintraub. Rabbi Dan Ehrenkrantz performed the ceremony at the Crystal Plaza in Livingston, N.J.

title: Pow! Sock! Arrghhh!
description: Derby Dugan's Depression Funnies By Tom De Haven. Illustrated. 290 pp. New York: Metropolitan Books/ Henry Holt & Company. $23.

title: SIGNOFF;Maniac Abroad: Antics in England
description: FEAR knows no boundaries, so why not put the Crypt Keeper on the Concorde and send the cackling maniac to England?

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: HARLEM;The Police Saturate a Drug-Peddling Zone
description: After years of complaining that Broadway had become an open-air drug market between 135th and 145th Streets, residents have seen some relief. On June 20, after a series of meetings between community members and police officials, a flood of uniformed officers descended on 139th Street.

title: National Lampoon
description: THE AGE OF CARICATURE Satirical Prints in the Reign of George III. By Diana Donald. Illustrated. 248 pp. New Haven: The Paul Mellon Center for Studies in British Art/Yale University Press. $60. IF, like me, you have always been in awe of James Gillray's draftsmanship but puzzled by the meaning of his complex, grandiloquent allegories, take heart. Edification is at hand. In "The Age of Caricature: Satirical Prints in the Reign of George III," Diana Donald tells us all we need to know to decipher not only Gillray's drawings but those of Thomas Rowlandson, Isaac and George Cruikshank and others whose talents made the end of the 18th century the high point of English caricature.

title: Training Steps Are Rigid For Becoming an EMT
description: IN addition to having jobs outside their residential area and many volunteers working more than one job, New York State mandates rigid training and retraining programs for people seeking certification as emergency medical technicians on various levels.

title: DEAD AS A DOLLAR
description: James Gleick's excellent article "Dead as a Dollar" (June 16) makes a point that is heard too seldom in the current anti-Government atmosphere. He notes that if the Government does not step in and take a position on electronic cash, the decisions will be made by large corporations.

title: WINE;Summer Lightness Of White Zinfandels
description: WHITE zinfandel continues its warm-weather popularity, and a blind tasting of six best-selling brands shows that they offer a wide range of bouquets and tastes.

title: Look Who's Hugging Trees Now
description: THE KONKOLVILLE STEAKHOUSE IS A SHRINE TO RED MEAT AND RAW TIMBER, STITCHED TO A HALF-CENTURY old sawmill on a creek in Orofino, Idaho. There is a certain goofy charm to Orofino, home of the Maniacs, a nickname some people say is drawn from the state mental institution nearby. The high-school emblem, a cartoon of a screaming, wild-eyed man, has survived years of scorn to become something of a rebel icon for teen-agers. Big-wheeled cars tool around with bumper stickers that read, "Are You an Environmentalist, or Do You Work for a Living?" So it was with some trepidation that a handful of people who make their livings trying to restore wolves, bears and other big fauna to the Rocky Mountains showed up at the old steakhouse recently for a night of chewing beef with loggers and mill owners. It would be an understatement to say that the two groups, as a general rule, do not get along -- nature haters and property rights wackos versus eco-freaks and humor-impaired granola crunchers.

title: High on Atlanta
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: REGO PARK;Suspect Arrested in Co-op Fraud
description: He was once a prominent Asian-American in New York City politics. Now, James C. Jao, a former City Planning Commissioner, sits in a California jail awaiting extradition to New York to stand trial on charges that he defrauded a co-op in Rego Park and jumped bail.

title: Elvis and the All-Night Bowling Alley
description: THE SEVEN-YEAR ATOMIC MAKE-OVER GUIDE And Other Stories. By Christine Bell. 186 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $21. UNTIL a few weeks ago, I would have thought it impossible for an author in the 1990's to write about Elvis's lost twin brother without resorting to heavy doses of post-modern irony. Then I read "A Pillow and a Rock," by Christine Bell. This short story -- from "The Seven-Year Atomic Make-Over Guide," Ms. Bell's first collection -- begins with the premise that the notorious Jesse didn't really die at birth, but rather was kidnapped by the Presleys' midwife. And while that may sound like the starting point for a campy ride through Las Vegas, Hollywood and the hidden soundproof basement at Graceland, Ms. Bell (the author of the novels "Saint" and "The Perez Family") has a very different journey in mind. Shunning the easy absurdity that seems to attach itself to all things Elvis, she takes us into the unglamorous life of Hanna Worth, a poor backwoods midwife who finds herself saddled with an unwanted baby and a profound moral choice. The resulting story, reminiscent more of Jayne Anne Phillips than of Mark Leyner, is unexpectedly -- even improbably -- consequential.

title: Cuddly Quasimodo: Is This a Good Thing;Collaborating With the Enemy?
description: To the Editor:

title: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;Saying Yes to Small Stocks, Even After a Nail-Biting Ride
description: THE small-capitalization stock market has been on a roller-coaster, exploding higher at the start of the second quarter this year and then falling just as hard toward the quarter's end before recovering just a bit. So it is not surprising if investors feel a little dizzy.

title: Colleges Seek Reasons for Rejections
description: THE torn envelopes and damp tissues of college rejection letters are gone. Now many high school seniors are in the reverse position of saying no to some of the colleges and universities that had accepted them.

title: Court Reporters Led Way In a Union for Freelancers
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: FLUSHING;RKO Keith's Battle Drags On
description: With its ornate Spanish baroque decor, shimmering ceiling lights and hydraulic stage, the RKO Keith's theater was a place where fancy met reality. It opened on Christmas Day 1928, and for decades moviegoers flocked there to see films featuring everyone from Burns and Allen to Bob Hope to Darth Vader.

title: The Election Shows Russia Is Russian
description: DURING the interval between the two rounds of the Russian presidential election, a somewhat morose Grigory Yavlinsky -- the reform leader who came in a weak fourth in the voting -- posed a question to an American correspondent he ran into at a party.

title: INSIDE
description: Two Die in Jet Accident

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;Philip Johnson, Work in Progress
description: Philip Johnson turns 90 tomorrow, and he is still trying to find himself. Or so it would appear, given that after half a century of architectural practice his stylistic preferences still fluctuate more than the Dow Jones average, and his intense, restless mind jumps from subject to subject with the speed of an Olympic athlete. Is it not time, at 90, to settle down and stand for something?

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Chevrolet 1500 Van Conversion;A Manhattan Apartment on Wheels
description: WE were oozing -- no, floating -- down the parkway, vanning to Kennedy International Airport. Hunter, my 2-year-old grandson, was in a safety seat behind me. Jay, my son, was riding shotgun and reminding me of another van, the '67 Ford Econoline that I had bought from a farmer in Pennsylvania a long time ago.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;From the 20's, an Instrument Made for Cybertimes
description: IN 1928, THE COMPOSER Sergei Rachmaninoff, other musicians and socialites were invited to the Plaza Hotel in New York for a demonstration of the theremin, an electronic instrument with antennas that respond to the slightest movement of the hands or body in the surrounding space. At the end of the performance, an enraptured young woman at his side reportedly shouted: "Bravo! Magnifique!"

title: ART REVIEW;City Without Walls Expands Its Reach
description: CITY WITHOUT WALLS may be a nonprofit gallery, but it has assets. These include an attractive storefront premises, at 1 Gateway Plaza here; a slide registry that is the largest gallery-owned operation of its kind in the state, with over 2,000 artists on file, and an exemplary director in Richard Sennott.

title: WEDDINGS;Randi Freier and Joshua Rievman
description: Randi Elise Freier, a daughter of Dr. Judy Freier of Stamford, Conn., and the late Henry Freier, was married on Wednesday evening in Mamaroneck, N.Y., to Joshua Daniel Rievman, a son of Ellen and Alan Rievman of Denver. Rabbi Joseph Ehrenkrantz performed the ceremony at the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club.

title: DINING OUT;Following the Scent of Grilled Offerings
description: AFTER months of renovation, Tuscan Oven, a trattoria that has already made its reputation at smaller quarters in Mount Kisco, has put its winning formula to work in a spot where a string of restaurants have failed. Even now this occupant looks as though it may have a long lease.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;Punching the Stop Button Before the VCR Takes Over
description: THE PAINFUL MOMENT OF truth about my VCR habit came on a rainy spring Saturday as I was chucking out a kitchen drawerful of old Chinese takeout menus. Reaching for a bunch, I felt the tip of my right index finger impaling itself on a bent staple still protruding from a menu that had once been fastened to a brown paper bag in which the General Tso's Chicken, or whatever the dish was from some long-forgotten dinner, had been delivered in.

title: The Perfect Summer Sunday
description: There's a scene in the movie "The Way We Were" in which the characters played by Robert Redford and Bradford Dillman are sailing aimlessly on sun-dappled waters on a Sunday afternoon waxing nostalgic about best moments in their lives: "Best Saturday afternoon." "Best month." "Best year."

title: Sports of The Times;Olympians Have a Life After Games
description: BEFORE we get too caught up in the handful of millionaire stars having an interesting summer-camp experience after Wimbledon and the N.B.A. playoffs, it is worth remembering that most American athletes in the 1996 Summer Games are still within the traditional range of Olympians. They go to school. They have other careers. They worked their way to Atlanta.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Happy Birthday, Voter

title: WEDDINGS;Kristin A. Cabral, John J. Beaulieu
description: Kristin Ann Cabral, a daughter of Judith and Albert Cabral of Princeton Junction, N.J., was married yesterday to John Joseph Beaulieu, a son of Nancy Trecha of Detroit and Rodney Beaulieu of Troy, Mich. The Rev. Paul McCarren, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Dahlgren Chapel at Georgetown University in Washington.

title: DANCE VIEW;Taking the High Road Through Ballet's Rush Hour
description: HAVING BATTLED UPHILL for half a century to become an establishment company, New York City Ballet now performs 23 weeks a year at the New York State Theater. But a dance troupe that appears in its home city more frequently than any other troupe in the world can also be taken for granted.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on June 23 about comic German films referred incorrectly to a relationship experienced by the central character of "Maybe . . . Maybe Not," a heterosexual man named Axel. He is the object of a homosexual's crush, not the person who develops the crush.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 7, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction

title: Streetscapes/Catholic Apostolic Church;On West 57th Street, a Striking Victorian Sanctuary
description: ESTABLISHED in England as a new branch of Christianity in the 19th century, the Catholic Apostolic Church built a striking midblock sanctuary in 1886 far west on 57th Street, where the congregation worshiped for more than a century. But convinced that Jesus' return to earth was imminent, they never established a permanent church organization. Last year the building was taken over by the Lutheran Church, which is restoring and renovating it.

title: With Match Victory Near, Karpov Blunders and Loses Game
description: Just when he was within sight of the $937,500 prize, Anatoly Karpov made one blunder after another yesterday and lost Game 16 of the world championship match to Gata Kamsky in Elista, Russia. Thus Karpov now has a 9 1/2-to-6 1/2 advantage in the series, and still needs another point to wrap it up.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: MAKING IT WORK 3 A tour of mean streets with Father John Jenik, the priest with the bulletproof vest.

title: Yeltsin Victory Is No Gain for Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: The Book on This Campaign;The Making of Political Best Sellers, 1996
description: WHEN Theodore H. White wrote "The Making of the President, 1960" after John F. Kennedy defeated Richard Nixon, his book provided a groundbreaking look inside the political industry. Now, nine campaigns later, the hawking of books about Presidential politics has become an industry unto itself. And it's ever harder to tell quite where explanation ends and exploitation begins.

title: The Girls of Summer
description: To the Editor:

title: ART;'Insolent' Collages and L.I. Landscapes
description: Cut, Paste and Screw B. J. Spoke Gallery, 299 Main Street, Huntington. Through July 14. 549-5106.

title: LIVES;An Ethnic Trump
description: What my son, Luke, age 4, goes to Chinese-culture school seems inevitable to most people, even though his father is of Irish descent. For certain ethnicities trump others; Chinese, for example, trumps Irish. This has something to do with the relative distance of certain cultures from mainstream American culture, but it also has to do with race. For as we all know, it is not only certain ethnicities that trump others but certain colors: black trumps white, for example, always and forever; a mulatto is not a kind of white person, but a kind of black person.

title: THE NIGHT;Party Spot, Tickertape Galore
description: WHEN the movie "Multiplicity," opening this month, had its premiere party at the New York Stock Exchange on June 25, the frenzy on the floor was over Michael Keaton and Andie MacDowell, who star in it, not stock prices. It was their second visit to the exchange that day, which started at 9:30 A.M. with their ringing the bell to begin trading.

title: POP/JAZZ;Even After Death, Marley Endures
description: FIFTEEN YEARS after the death of the reggae superstar Bob Marley, his legacy is still being felt in ways both expected and unexpected.

title: June 30-July 6;Recycling Gets Trashed
description: Seven years after recycling became the law in New York City, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani declared last week that requiring New Yorkers to sort out 25 percent of their garbage into piles of paper, glass, plastic and metal was not only an unrealistic mandate, it was an impossible one to meet. The city now recycles about 14 percent of its residential garbage, and will be violating its own law on July 14 -- the deadline for meeting the 25 percent goal.

title: COVER STORY;Crazy Horse, Warrior and Mystic
description: IRENE Bedard is one of the stars of "Crazy Horse," a two-hour movie that has its premiere on TNT tonight at 8. She protrays Black Buffalo Woman, lover but never wife to the famous Oglala warrior, depicting her from her teen-age years into motherhood and middle age.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Purchase, N.Y.;Boom Times in Big-Home Country
description: THE neighborhood known as Purchase, part of the Westchester town of Harrison, has earned its reputation as an exclusive enclave of baronial houses surrounded by expansive, exquisitely manicured lawns and acres of rolling countryside.

title: INVESTING IT;From Kitchen Table to Keyboard
description: JEFF BROUWS and the other members of his "gang of six" investment club in Santa Barbara, Calif., were surfing the Internet one Sunday afternoon last year when they happened upon a bit of information about the Iomega Corporation, a maker of computer disk drives. A fellow investor on the East Coast had reported that his parents had driven past the company's headquarters in Utah and noticed that the parking lot was full.

title: Strolling Down Punk-Rock Lane
description: THE Class of 1976 held a reunion in the lobby of the Gershwin Hotel late last month. While inspecting a photography exhibition documenting their youth, several hundred New Yorkers gawked, caught up and swapped war stories. Familiar faces eyed each other with collegial recognition, extrapolating the passage of two decades behind fashions no longer matched in style or station.

title: DEAD AS A DOLLAR
description: Gleick cites studies that indicate people actually spend more when their money is on cards than when they must part with cash. With larger purchases, we might be willing to spend more money drawn from a card because of its similarity to credit-card transactions. However, who plunks down a credit card for a 50-cent purchase (like a pack of gum)? This kind of impulse spending might actually go down with money on cards.

title: WEDDINGS;Colena A. Johnson, Ramon K. Kemp
description: Dr. Colena Arlene Johnson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin H. Johnson of Roanoke, Va., was married last evening to Dr. Ramon Karmel Kemp, a son of Yvonne Murphy and Kenneth Kemp, both of Los Angeles. The Rev. Carlotta Cochran performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Roanoke.

title: Correction
description: The Commercial Property column on June 16, about renovation of the shopping area at Citicorp Center, identified the building's architects incompletely. Hugh Stubbins & Associates was the design architect, in association with Emery Roth & Sons.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Crime
description: I thought I would never get through THE BROKEN PROMISE LAND (Mysterious Press/ Warner, $22.95), Marcia Muller's 17th series novel with Sharon McCone, her humorless but savvy San Francisco private eye. The story starts cleanly when McCone signs on to handle security for her brother-in-law, Ricky Savage, a country-and-western superstar who has been getting hate notes. The billets-doux that infiltrate the cordon McCone's people throw up around the singer, his wife and six kids, and his entourage escalate in intensity, and by the time Savage goes on the road to promote his new album, you could use his strung-out nerves for bass strings.

title: CYCLING;Indurain Crumbles; Berzin Gets Tour Lead
description: In a rare sight in the Tour de France, Miguel Indurain cracked today on the final climb in the first day in the Alps and struggled in so far behind many of his rivals that his chances for a sixth successive victory in the great bicycle race are seriously compromised.

title: Habitats/Hudson View Gardens;In a Leafy Tudor Enclave, Touches From the 1920's
description: IS this 1996 -- or 1924?

title: WEDDINGS;Karen Bloom and Bryan Rozencwaig
description: Karen Beth Bloom, a daughter of Leslie and Salie Bloom of Rye Brook, N.Y., was married on Thursday evening to Bryan Lance Rozencwaig, a son of Lorenzo and Luisa Rozencwaig of New York. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the Fountainhead in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: ON POLITICS;Voila! A Balanced Budget! (Don't Try This at Home)
description: Governor Whitman and the Republican-controlled State Legislature did it again. They cut taxes for the third year in a row, and the golden dome on the State House has not caved in (though it is badly tarnished).

title: A Statue Finds a New Home In Windsor
description: MAJ. JOHN MASON, or rather his statue, rededicated in Windsor last month, is serving to introduce a new era of peaceful co-existence between the descendants of American Indians and the descendants of the state's earliest English settlers, say state and town officials.

title: NEW JERSEY & CO.;Bograd's, Paterson's Stylish Survivor, Moves On
description: Joseph Bograd was two days old when his father and uncle moved their growing furniture business into a larger building on Main Street in Paterson 61 years ago. Over the years, Bograd's grew in prestige and became a landmark in the old industrial city's landscape.

title: Man Killed by Police After Market Robbery
description: A man who fled from a Brooklyn market with $300 in cash and a loaded revolver late Friday was fatally shot by two police officers after he aimed the gun at them, the police said.

title: Cuddly Quasimodo: Is This a Good Thing;Disney Got the Cathedral Right
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Killed in Jet On Runway After Engine Breaks Apart
description: A mother and son were killed this afternoon on a Delta Air Lines jet in Pensacola, Fla., when an engine on the plane broke up as it was preparing to take off, sending debris into the cabin. After the takeoff was aborted, at least five other people were injured while being evacuated from the jet, which was bound for Atlanta.

title: SOAPBOX;Our Fractured City
description: A LONG, wide scrape, a creased street-side door and a smashed mirror greeted me as I approached my car. A length of molding, along with bits of glass and broken plastic lay in the roadway on East Ninth Street, where I had parked overnight. Oh rats, sideswiped. Don't get upset, I told myself, it's an old car.

title: WOMEN WHO CUT THEIR HAIR AND THE MEN WHO LOVE THEM
description: Mary Tannen isn't quite getting it when she claims that lesbians wear short hair as a way to discourage male advances ("Women Who Cut Their Hair and the Men Who Love Them," June 16). Puhleeze: get the guys off center stage.

title: WEDDINGS;Katharine Cornell, Sebestyen Gorka
description: Katharine Fairfax Cornell, a daughter of Mrs. Mortimer Ryon of Solebury, Pa., and M. Keen Cornell of Mountaintop, Pa., was married yesterday to Sebestyen Gorka, the son of Zsuzsa and Pal Gorka of Sopron, Hungary. The Rev. Istvan Babos performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Sopron.

title: World News Briefs;At Least 300 Are Killed In Severe China Flooding
description: Flooding brought on by heavy rains has killed more than 300 people, severed electrical lines and knocked down buildings, and the seasonal storms headed north today through China.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND;John Tesh Proves You Can Go Home Again -- to Garden City
description: YOU can go home again, if your parents had the foresight to opt for aluminum siding. "It looks just the same!" John Tesh exclaimed as his black stretch limousine pulled up to a split-level in Garden City. It was the house that Mr. Tesh, the musician and former television personality, grew up in and had not stepped into since he left Garden City shortly after high school graduation in 1970.

title: Q. & A.
description: Q. I live in a rent-controlled apartment. The landlord wants to put in new windows. I have been told that the landlord can either divide the amount spent on improvements to my apartment by 40 and then increase my monthly rent by that amount forever, or he can increase my monthly rent by that amount for only 40 months. Which, if either, is true? Also, the landlord is fixing up the building in general. Can building improvements, such as an upgraded lobby, be passed along to tenants in the same way that improvements to a specific apartment can be passed along . . . Alex Wolf, Manhattan. A. Alan Kucker, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that the monthly rent increase for improvements to individual apartments -- which is calculated as 1/40th of the cost of the improvement -- is permanent.

title: FILM VIEW;Real Men, an Endangered Species on Film
description: IN TODAY'S POLITICIZED SEXUAL climate -- in which any definition of masculine and feminine is liable to elicit accusations of stereotyping -- the lives of ordinary men and women tend to be ignored on film. That may be one reason Hollywood is so obsessed with macho caricatures.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Owning Up to Responsibilities
description: Jerry Reinsdorf rarely goes into the locker rooms of the teams he owns, the Chicago Bulls and the Chicago White Sox, since he believes, more or less, that he should leave the running of the teams to the general managers and the coaches and field managers, and the counting of the cash income to himself.

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION
description: CALL TO HOME African Americans Reclaim the Rural South. By Carol Stack. Basic Books, $21.

title: AN AMERICAN PLACE -- Worries Over Wages;Canton's Economic Seesaw: Managers' Fortunes Rise as Workers Get Bumpy Ride
description: Robert Mahoney was hired as a senior vice president for Diebold in 1983 at a salary of $150,000 and became chief executive two years later.

title: POSTINGS: Tenants Sought for 2 Planned Office Buildings;In Jersey City, Some Action on the Waterfront
description: Plans are advancing for two office buildings along Jersey City's Hudson River waterfront that, if realized, would end a five-year lull in commercial construction at the river's edge.

title: Word for Word/A Gathering of Skeptics;They Shoot Down the Paranormal, U.F.O.'s and Other Flights of Fancy
description: THEIR acronym is unintentional, they say. The Committee for the Scientific Investigation of Claims of the Paranormal -- Csicop -- is a group of skeptics (physicists, astronomers, magicians included) who police the creep of pseudoscience (psychics, "ufologists" and ideologues included). Waving its banner in the face of a trend toward junk science, Csicop recently held its 20th anniversary conference, titled "Science in the Age of (Mis)Information," at the Amherst campus of the State University of New York. Panelists took swipes at U.F.O.'s, creationism, spiritualism and radical feminist scholarship. What a bunch of party poopers!

title: Business Best Sellers
description: HARD COVER

title: Books in Brief: NONFICTION;Nazism as Theater
description: The Nazi era was captured largely in black-and-white photographs. The primary visual records of Hitler, Nazi Party rallies, book burnings, ghetto roundups, even the Nuremberg trials, are colorless. Leni Riefenstahl used black and white to glorify her subjects in "Triumph of the Will." Fifty years later Steven Spielberg shot "Schindler's List" in monochrome to echo the collective memory. But in 1939 an amateur film club shot color movies of the theatrical parades and pageants leading to the opening of the House of German Art, which Hitler built as a monument to Volk culture. This extraordinarily well-preserved, candid record of Nazi pomp, circumstance and banality was released a few years back by the BBC as a documentary with the title "Good Morning, Mr. Hitler!" WEEKEND IN MUNICH: Art, Propaganda and Terror in the Third Reich (Pavilion/Trafalgar Square, $40), by Robert S. Wistrich, a professor of modern European history at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, is a selection of stills from this amateur film, sandwiched between a history of Nazi propaganda that was not part of the BBC program and comments by spectators at the festival. The book is disquieting in the way these color photographs do, in fact, reduce Nazi villains to everyday people. Color somehow defangs even the most heinous of the bunch, like Heinrich Himmler and Julius Streicher. Yet the most disturbing image of all is not in color; it is a black-and-white snapshot of two pageant participants drinking Coke in front of a German Coca-Cola sign. Steven Heller

title: L.I. Vines
description: Classic Red Peconic Bay Vineyards, Cutchogue, nonvintage. About $10.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Down by 17, the Dream Team Rallies to Avoid Ridicule
description: There was C. M. Newton, president of USA Basketball, sitting still and silent and shocked on the sideline, barely moving until he popped something in his mouth. Maybe it was a mint. But it looked like a Rolaids.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS QUARTERLY REPORT;Fund Investing on the Net: Beyond Window Shopping
description: MIX Internet hype with mutual-fund frenzy and what do you get? Junk mail -- lots and lots of junk mail.

title: Brakettes, Back to Winning Ways
description: GROWING up in Stamford, Alison Hirsch knew a lot about the Raybestos Brakettes. For one thing, they were perhaps the world's most famous softball team. For another, Allison Rioux, a team star, was from Stamford. And then, too, Hirsch got to see them play, close up.

title: Compass Points
description: To the Editor: The interesting and informative article "Point North. Uhhh . . ." by W. D. Wetherell (May 5) spoke of compass-oriented natural events and phenomena, including the "cooling, restorative winds" from the Northwest.

title: The World;A Secular Land Takes a Gamble
description: THE ancient Black Sea port of Sinop is known for producing people who dare to challenge the established order. Perhaps its most famous son was the Greek philosopher Diogenes, who outraged local rulers by proclaiming that the only way one could hope to find an honest man thereabouts was to search through the streets at night with an oil lamp.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Study Tours of Midway Island
description: For the first time since 1941, the public is being allowed to visit Midway Atoll, site of the first United States naval victory against Japan in World War II. Starting Aug. 7, study tours ranging from four to eight days to the three-islets, 1,135 miles northwest of Pearl Harbor, are being offered by Oceanic Society Expeditions of San Francisco, with twice-a-week departures from the island of Kauai, Hawaii.

title: Beyond Plastic Surgery
description: To the Editor:

title: Luxury Golf Course At a Turning Point
description: THE Hudson National Golf Club, which has been open for business on weekends only on its hill-top site here, has reached a turning point in its efforts to begin full operations. That may be good news for those who view the new luxury course as a tax boon for the village, but environmentalists here are wary.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UNIVERSITY HEIGHTS;New Leader for Community College
description: The City University of New York has named a Los Angeles educator who has been a teacher and administrator at community colleges for 25 years as president of Bronx Community College.

title: OUTDOORS;A Salmon Angler's Dream at the Pristine Pavilion in Canada
description: Looking down the steep bank from the dirt road about 150 yards above Little Indian pool on the St. Jean River, Bill Taylor, a fishing buddy as well as the president of the Atlantic Salmon Federation, remarked: "Look at all those dark shapes. I'm sure some of them are salmon."

title: WEDDINGS;Alison A. Keany and Joseph N. Locke
description: Alison Arwen Keany, a daughter of Susanne and Sutton Keany of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Joseph Neal Locke, a son of Anna Lee Locke of Sacramento, Calif., and the late Dr. Alexander Locke. The Rev. Dawson Ambosta performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: The U.S. and the U.N.;Now, Who Needs Whom More?
description: THE apparently innate desire of Americans to remake the world cheaply in their own self-image is on display again in the United Nations, with the usual results: anger and resentment there, and a grudging recognition that in a one-superpower world, the United States can be simultaneously the United Nations' biggest deadbeat and biggest gun.

title: Erna Lane, 92, Dancer and Artist
description: Erna Lane, a dancer who as a child was one of the first students of Elizabeth Duncan, Isadora Duncan's sister, died on June 28 at Hillcrest Hospital in Pittsfield, Mass. She was 92 and lived in West Stockbridge, Mass.

title: DINING OUT;In a Train Station, Exquisite Italian Fare
description: A LITTLE Italian restaurant in a train station." That's how Paci in the eastbound station house in Southport was described to us, which is a little like calling the Library of Congress a reading room.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;Transit Authority Faces a Bumpy Road in Plan to Reroute Buses
description: Bus lines to downtown Brooklyn were once abundant in the northwest chunk of the borough where the Farragut Houses meet the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: Robert Dunn, 67, Dance Avant-Gardist, Dies
description: Robert Ellis Dunn, whose classes in improvisation and choreography were the laboratory in which postmodernist dance was born in the early 1960's, died on Friday at his home in New Carrollton, Md. He was 67.

title: WEDDINGS;Jenifer Osorno, Sean M. Fahey
description: Jenifer Osorno, the daughter of Judy Osorno of Corpus Christi, Tex., and Fernando Osorno of Mexico City, was married yesterday to Lieut. Sean Matthew Fahey, a son of Richard and Elizabeth Fahey of Annapolis, Md. Lieut. Comdr. Debra E. McGuire, a chaplain, performed the ceremony at the United States Naval Academy Chapel in Annapolis.

title: BASEBALL;Lachemann Fired by Marlins
description: Rene Lachemann, the only manager the expansion Florida Marlins have ever had, was dismissed today. Lachemann, 51, became the first major league manager to be fired this season. The third-base coach, Cookie Rojas, manager of the California Angels in 1988, was chosen by General Manager Dave Dombrowski as the interim skipper.

title: The Huge New Railroad Menace
description: The merger of two railroad giants, the Union Pacific and Southern Pacific, constitutes a colossal blunder by the fledgling Surface Transportation Board in its first major merger decision. Created last year by Congress, the board decided to allow these two railroads to join forces even though they serve as each other's only competitors in large swaths of south, central and western regions of the country. The merged system would become the largest railroad in the nation.

title: Turkey's Islamic Government
description: Turkey, a key American military ally straddling Europe, Central Asia and the Middle East, now awaits parliamentary confirmation of its first Islamic-led Government since Mustafa Kemal Ataturk overthrew the sultans and proclaimed a secular republic in 1923.

title: Clinton Testifies on Tape in Trial of Bankers
description: Sitting in the White House under the gaze of video cameras, President Clinton gave a sworn deposition today in the trial of two Arkansas bankers charged with making illegal donations to his 1990 campaign for Governor.

title: Corrections
description: The chessboard diagram yesterday with an article about Game 16 of the world championship match between Anatoly Karpov and Gata Kamsky mislabeled the player in the white position. It was Mr. Kamsky, as noted in the list of moves.

title: POLITICS: A POLITICAL LIFE;Abortion, Dole's Sword in '74, Returns to Confront Him in '96
description: It was, at the time, the most expensive campaign Kansas had ever seen, and may still rank as the ugliest.

title: Bridge
description: The effort to promote bridge classes in Manhattan schools continues to bear fruit, thanks in part to the efforts of Anita Strauss at "Library Power." There were 12 schools in the program this year, and there may be more next year if additional instructors can be found. Volunteers should write to Barry Rigal, 196 Sixth Avenue, 6B, New York, N.Y. 10013.

title: Power Up, and Let the Games Begin;High-Technology Companies Hope to Score a 10 (at Least a 9.8) in Atlanta
description: The Centennial Olympic Games in Atlanta represent the most ambitious civilian telecommunications and technology experiment since the space program -- and like a mission to the moon, it is a high-risk venture.

title: Troubling Issues in a Silicon Valley Spy Case
description: On a brisk May afternoon last year, a frantic Argentine man carrying a stack of papers and videotapes knocked on the doors of several American newspaper offices here.

title: Guinness Denies Planning a Big Takeover
description: The brewing and distilling giant Guinness P.L.C. denied today that it was planning a L13.2 billion ($20.54 billion) bid for Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.

title: Sports of The Times;The Yankee Motto: We. Us. Team. George.
description: BOB WATSON sat in his office last week bracing for the beginning of the circus.

title: Gaborone Journal;Few Want Stocks; Now Livestock, That's Different
description: Officially, the opening bell had rung and Botswana's year-old stock exchange was open for business. But in reality, no one here bothers with a bell and the country's only official trader, Martin Makgatlhe, was out.

title: On Air Traffic Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Stocks Lower
description: Stocks were trading sharply lower here today in early trading. At the midday break, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 361.64 points, or 1.63 percent, at 21,870.78. On Friday, the Nikkei fell 60.49 points, bringing the total loss for the week to 298.33 points. The decline was blamed, in part, on the surge in United States jobs reported last week.

title: OLYMPICS;Dream Team Gets Back to Normal
description: The United States men's basketball team had become this cardboard caviar, a bland delicacy, so rich and yet so boring.

title: Mexican Stocks Off As Wall St. Falters
description: Mexican stocks fell sharply Friday, closing at their lowest level since April 11, in sympathy with a drop in the United States stock and bond markets, traders said.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;New Jerseyan Wins Pageant
description: She did fine in the evening gown and casual wear segments, but Meghan Rainone really impressed the pageant judges in the talent show, where her hands told a touching parable about a handicapped puppy. Ms. Rainone is deaf, and she returned home last night from Portland, Ore., as the new Miss Deaf America. The 19-year-old, 5-foot-2 college student was tops in a field of 32 young women at Friday night's pageant, sponsored by the National Association of the Deaf. She won a $3,000 scholarship, which she plans to apply to her studies in criminal justice at the Rochester Institute of Technology.

title: Shooting in Bridgeport Leaves 2 Men Dead
description: Two men were killed today and a third was wounded in a shooting that broke out after three people came to the city for drugs, the police said.

title: CONCERT REVIEW;A Summer Return for Bernstein
description: There are really two music festivals at Tanglewood every summer. One is the Tanglewood Music Center, an intensive, free-tuition training program for young performers and composers who study with a renowned music faculty and present a full schedule of chamber, vocal and orchestral concerts. That program, which promises some major undertakings later this summer, has been up and running for three weeks.

title: Don't Paint Israel as Root of Arafat's Misdeeds;Egypt's Performance
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigators Gather Remnants of Jet Engine
description: The investigators trying to determine why an engine on a Delta Air Lines jet blew apart here on Saturday, shooting debris into the cabin and killing a mother and son, gathered pieces of metal that were thrown as far as a quarter of a mile away.

title: More Taped Testimony
description: Facing videocameras in the White House Map Room, President Clinton gave a deposition in the trial of two bankers charged with making illegal donations to his 1990 campaign for Arkansas Governor. The taping was his second in two cases brought by the Whitewater prosecutor.

title: Japanese Trade Surplus Shrinks 46.4%
description: Japan's trade surplus shrank 46.4 percent to 361 billion yen, or $3.26 billion, in May, from 674 billion yen last year, the Ministry of Finance said today.

title: BASEBALL;Strawberry and Yanks Stymied by McDonald
description: In a way, it was fortunate that Darryl Strawberry was there to make his 1996 major league debut at Yankee Stadium yesterday. Thanks to Ben McDonald, the Yankees did not provide the 35,242 patrons on hand much else to cheer about.

title: No Skating, Please, at Bethesda Fountain
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Vallone's Tough Sell
description: The leaders of New York's City Council have been haunted by the prospect of term limits since voters approved a two-term maximum in 1993. Speaker Peter Vallone claims that, if the law is not changed, the Council will suffer an almost complete turnover five years from now, leaving it stripped of leadership and institutional memory. Mr. Vallone's arguments have some merit, but he will have to do a serious selling job to persuade the electorate.

title: Publisher Burda to Sell Europe Online Stake
description: The German publisher Burda G.m.b.H. said today that it planned to sell its 36 percent stake in Europe Online S.A., an Internet service provider.

title: Investigators Seek Fingerprints On Improperly Acquired Files
description: Investigators for Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, have begun checking the fingerprints on hundreds of confidential F.B.I. files improperly acquired by the Clinton White House, law-enforcement and Congressional officials said today.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Assault Conviction Protested
description: In 1995, Majied Muhammad, an official in a Newark mosque of the Nation of Islam, was convicted of assault for shoving a police officer at Kennedy International Aiport. But according to the Nation of Islam, the account that Officer Kenneth Kodak gave an insurance company contradicted his testimony at Mr. Muhammad's trial. Tonight at 5 P.M., the Nation of Islam will hold a protest on the steps of Newark's City Hall to urge New York authorities to grant Mr. Muhammad a new trial. Officials of the organization said that several Newark City Council members would be on hand to lend support.

title: Filegate' May Be Good for Us
description: Filegate" may have a silver lining. Civil libertarians have long been concerned about the Government's extensive files on American citizens, but have been thwarted, mostly by Republican judges and politicians, in their attempts to rein in the Federal Government. Now that Republicans are outraged that the Clinton Administration obtained F.B.I. files on more than 300 prominent Republicans, maybe the average American citizen can finally get some protection.

title: Prisons in Japan Are Safe but Harsh
description: Three months after being put in a Japanese prison, Kevin M. Mara was about to sit down to a meal when the jailer called out his name.

title: Journalist as Broker in Mixed Marriage Next Week of Microsoft and NBC News
description: Today, Merrill Brown may be stepping around paint cans and sawhorses in the MSNBC studios still under construction in Fort Lee, N.J., dressed in the white shirt, rep tie and conservative suit of a network television executive.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Homosexuals Criticize 2 Drug-Free Ads
description: Two commercials for the Partnership for a Drug-Free America have been labeled "patently homophobic" by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation, which has asked for their withdrawal. The partnership, however, disputes the complaint and says it has no plans to recall the spots.

title: Romario Won't Face Brazil
description: Romario says he won't play for a FIFA all-star team against Brazil during next Sunday's exhibition game at Giants Stadium.

title: INSIDE
description: New Scrutiny for F.B.I. Files

title: World News Briefs;Russia Fails to Remove Checkpoints in Chechnya
description: Russian troops largely ignored a deadline yesterday in the peace agreement with separatists in Chechnya, failing to dismantle all Russian checkpoints as promised.

title: Treasury to Sell Bills and Notes This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to bills and notes, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. The Treasury will auction a 10-year note tomorrow.

title: K-III Acquires Football Weekly
description: The K-III Communications Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Pro Football Weekly magazine and its affiliated businesses.

title: FEDERAL PROGRAM WILL TRACK SALES OF GUNS TO YOUTHS
description: President Clinton will announce today the creation of a Federal computer system to track the illegal sale of guns to young people as part of an initiative to help local police cut off the supply of those firearms and halt the sharp rise in gun violence among young people.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Sounds From Artists Breathing the Paris Air
description: The Summergarden series at the Museum of Modern Art is as workable a collaboration between institutions as one is likely to find in New York City. For the last 10 years, the museum has sponsored the free performances and presented them in its Abby Aldrich Rockefeller Sculpture Garden, and the Juilliard School has provided both the programs and the young musicians to play them.

title: TENNIS;Krajicek Captures Wimbledon
description: This was the day that Wimbledon 1996, already fraught with upsets and the unprecedented, made the final transformation to Never Never Land. From a finale contested by two unseeded players, a situation this Grand Slam had never faced before, there emerged a champion from the Netherlands, a nation that had never before produced a Grand Slam champion.

title: Malaysia Company Buys Phone Operations
description: Time Engineering said it would buy majority stakes in Sapura Telecommunications's pay phone and cellular phone businesses for the equivalent of $482 million.

title: No Headline
description: It's the old contest between man and machine." PHILLIP L. HENSON, on the new Olympic method for raking the sand at the long jump pits. [C3:3.]

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Listed below is a partial list of dividend meetings this week.

title: Consumers Get the Credit for Expanding Economy
description: President Clinton claims the credit for himself, and analysts cite an array of other possible factors, but the most important source of the economy's remarkable resilience and vibrancy this year appears to be the consumer.

title: Oil Companies Join Forces
description: Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, or Adnoc, said today that it was forming a joint venture with Borealis, owned by Neste Oy of Finland and Statoil of Norway, to market products from their planned petrochemical plant. The proposed plant, to be owned 60 percent by Adnoc and 40 percent by Borealis, is expected to begin producing 450,000 tons of polyethylene a year when it goes on line in 2000.

title: A Film Maker Crosses A Frontier of His Own
description: The latest epic documentary in the genre known to public television viewers as "the Ken Burns film" is due on PBS in September. And although it's a Ken Burns film, it isn't by Ken Burns.

title: HORSE RACING;Long Shot's Speed Wins At Belmont
description: You put five zesty sprinters on the same fast track early in July and seven furlongs later any one of them might be flying in front. That's what happened yesterday at Belmont Park when the long shot Kayrawan outran the even longer shot Cold Execution in the Tom Fool Handicap, and they both outran the favorites.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Starry Eyes Look Back at Koppel and 'Nightline'
description: NIGHTLINE History in the Making and the Making of Television By Ted Koppel and Kyle Gibson Illustrated. 477 pages. Times Books. $25.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Lobbying Intensifies Before Minimum-Wage Vote On the eve of a crucial Senate vote to raise the Federal minimum wage for millions of workers, organized labor and business groups are running an all-out lobbying campaign to swing the outcome their way.

title: Equity Offerings Scheduled for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Corrections
description: A note to readers yesterday about previous articles in a series on the political year as seen from Canton, Ohio, referred incorrectly in some copies to the Internet address at which the series is available. It is http://www.nytimes.com/specials/ canton.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Court to Hear E-Mail Dispute
description: Must a computer on-line service reveal the identity of an account holder believed to have sent a threatening E-mail message? Lawyers for America Online and the Morris Township School District will argue the question today in Superior Court. Dwight Pfennig, the Morris Schools Superintendent, says he received a message last month in the midst of contract negotiations with the teachers' union warning that he was in "big trouble" for "playing both sides of the fence."

title: Giuliani Aide Hints Gresser May Be Ousted
description: Two days before the Board of Education is to vote on a president, the Giuliani administration yesterday raised the possibility that the Mayor might seek to oust Carol A. Gresser from the job, the Queens Borough President said.

title: Abroad at Home;Crime and Blunder
description: Secretary of Defense William Perry is ordinarily an unflappable man, radiating inner confidence. But the other day, while on a visit to Bosnia, he blew up at a reporter who asked him why NATO forces did not arrest Radovan Karadzic, the accused war criminal who leads the Bosnian Serbs.

title: OLYMPICS;What's That Raking the Sand Pit?
description: Believe it or not, there was a time when the sand in a long jump pit was smoothed by human beings using common garden tools like rakes and brooms. And in a bygone era, the winners of shooting competitions were determined by judges who eyeballed paper targets and measured the distance from bullet hole to bull's-eye.

title: Sports of The Times;Washington Leaves His Own Shadow Across Center Court
description: ARTHUR ASHE casts a monumental shadow in more ways than one. On Wednesday, a statue of him holding books and a tennis racquet will be officially dedicated in his hometown of Richmond -- on historic Monument Avenue.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Jobs Cut by Seafood Chain
description: Long John Silver's seafood restaurant chain plans to shed 130 jobs at its headquarters here to improve efficiency. The company, which employs 18,000 people in 36 states, said last week that most of the workers had been laid off immediately; the rest are to follow within 60 days. The company has closed offices near Atlanta, Dallas and Kansas City, Mo.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Financial Hub for the G.O.P.
description: For Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, Representative Richard A. Zimmer and many other Republicans around the country, the road to political prominence runs through an industrial park on the edge of Princeton. The connections between a half-dozen political action committees and consulting firms at 741 Alexander Road allow corporations and other big donors to get around Federal laws limiting campaign contributions. While tenants of the complex say that criticisms of their activities are politically motivated, Federal election officials are investigating complaints that the companies are being used to illegally finance Mr. Zimmer's campaign for the United States Senate. [Page A1.]

title: CHRONICLE
description: BOB DOLE may not exactly be a hero to members of the Log Cabin Republicans -- the Presidential candidate returned a $1,000 contribution from the gay political organization last year -- but the chairman of his campaign, Senator ALFONSE M. D'AMATO, certainly is.

title: Giuliani Questions Smoking Ban at Jails
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the Correction Department's recent decision to impose a ban on smoking in the city's 16 jails would probably have to be softened.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Radio Doctor Faces Charge
description: To thousands of listeners of his weekly "infomercial" program on WOR-AM radio, Dr. Eric Braverman offered an alternative to the medical establishment. But according to a complaint filed by state prosecutors, Dr. Braverman's practices in his Montgomery Township office frequently crossed the line into malpractice. On Wednesday, the state Board of Medical Examiners will decide whether to suspend Dr. Braverman's license. According to the complaint, Dr. Braverman routinely performed unnecessary tests, many of which he was not trained to administer, on his patients. One patient who came to him with wrist pain, for example, was subjected to a dozen costly and unnecessary procedures, including testosterone and lung function tests, urinalysis and a psychological profile. Dr. Braverman did not respond to a telephone call seeking comment; calls to his attorney, Steven I. Kern, were not answered yesterday.

title: Metro Matters;Travel Hints for a Mayor Staying Put
description: It must be summer, because once again Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is refusing to take a vacation."

title: Unseeded Krajicek Captures Wimbledon Crown
description: WIMBLEDON  In the roles of Boris Becker and Arthur Ashe were a Dutch son of Czech immigrants and a 27-year old African-American with four tournament victories in his life.

title: MTV, Listening To Real World, Creates a Spinoff
description: One of cable television's defining networks, MTV, has decided to create a spinoff music channel called M2, focused more tightly on music and aimed at a slightly older audience.

title: Fleeing to Asylum, And Going Nowhere
description: Immigration experts and advocates for refugees say there are severe flaws in the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service's program to release asylum seekers who have credible claims, pose no danger to society and have ties here.

title: Taking In the Sites;Catching the Atlanta Games on Line
description: For casual fans of sports like gymnastics, basketball and track, the Olympics on network television are considered a good break from summer reruns. But for serious fans of the equestrian competition or weight lifting, NBC's 171.5 hours of coverage can be agony -- hours wasted wearing a hole in the living room carpet waiting for a fleeting glimpse of a triumph or failure.

title: World News Briefs;Mandela Endorses Aide To Succeed Him in Job
description: President Nelson Mandela of South Africa has endorsed a longtime aide in the struggle against apartheid to take over as President when Mr. Mandela steps down in 1999.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Good Season for Trenton
description: It has been a great season so far for Trenton's three-year-old minor league baseball team, the Trenton Thunder. The team leads the Southern Division of the AA Eastern League by six and a half games. It is also first in the league in attendance, with 231,000 over the first 40 games. And tonight, it will serve as host of the league's all-star game at Mercer County Waterfront Park, with the pitching ace Carl Pavano (9-5) among three Thunder players on the team. Governor Whitman will throw out the first ball at 6:45 P.M. ANDY NEWMAN

title: San Diego Wants People Not to Take This Plunge
description: Andrew Shaw, 23, calls it "the big separator." For generations, a leap from a 20-foot seashore cliff called the Clam by neighborhood residents of the La Jolla section of San Diego has demonstrated youthful courage.

title: Texas Law School Was Integrated in 1950
description: To the Editor:

title: In Pursuit Of Freedom, Only to Find Prison Bars;Immigration Officials Try to Discern Those Fleeing Persecution
description: The highest administrative tribunal in the nation's immigration system never doubted the harrowing story of Hawa Jama, a 26-year-old Somali woman who sought asylum in the United States in 1994.

title: Media: PRESS;Financial pressures hammer at the wall between the business and the editorial sides.
description: THERE was a time not long ago when newspapers were so profitable that some small-town owners were said to lie about their family's vacation plans. "Just taking the kids to Miami," they would tell their friends -- and their advertisers at the Rotary or at the country club -- without adding that the next stop would be Rome or Hong Kong.

title: By Now, the Budget Fight Isn't Really About the Budget
description: More than half a year after Gov. George E. Pataki introduced his budget and precisely 14 weeks after the state's fiscal year began on April 1, Mr. Pataki and legislative leaders can confidently agree on one thing: the longest budget fight in New York State history no longer has much to do with the budget itself.

title: Dancers Follow the Olympic Flame, and the Money, to Atlanta's StripClubs
description: After years of working out, toning her body and honing her skills, Audrey Hillicker will be one of the starry-eyed young people going for the gold here during Atlanta's Olympic summer.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Technology: CONNECTIONS;'Real, silicon life forms' and a 'science' of artificial life: Orwell is not dead.
description: A CONFESSION: many of my cyber-children have died before their time, most because of my own ineptitude or neglect. Some have learned the rudiments of language, and begun to explore their world -- eating when hungry, playing with toys, taking naps. One, a quick learner, spent a few minutes experimenting with elevator buttons; another, a bit dense, touched a hot oven three times before he got the point.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Daniels, City Legend, Wants Spot on Nets
description: Lloyd Daniels, the New York City high school basketball legend, is serious about making the Nets' roster this season. With the National Basketball Association's free-agent signing period beginning tomorrow, Nets Coach John Calipari is serious about giving him the chance.

title: William H. Kolberg Dies at 70; Advocated Better Worker Training
description: William H. Kolberg, retired president of the National Alliance of Business, a nonprofit group based in Washington, and a former government official, died on Wednesday at George Washington University Medical Center in Washington. He was 70 and had lived in Washington.

title: World News Briefs;Protestants Are Barred From Marching in Ulster
description: The police and military prevented about 2,000 Protestant demonstrators from marching through a Roman Catholic area of Portadown today after local residents said the march intimidated them.

title: At One Office, Intricate Links In New Jersey's G.O.P. Funds
description: For Gov. Christine Todd Whitman, Representative Richard A. Zimmer and numerous other Republicans around the country, the road to political prominence runs through a spartan industrial park on the outskirts of this Ivy League town.

title: In Hope of Winning Clinton Over, Netanyahu Visits U.S. This Week
description: Benjamin Netanyahu leaves on Monday for his first visit to the United States as Prime Minister of Israel, his Government struggling with dissension and his plans for the Middle East peace effort still unclear, yet determined to win over the country where he was raised and educated.

title: Tourists in Search of the 'Real' New York
