description: They whooshed to the summit of the Empire State Building and ogled the city's steel and stone glories. They jostled the bustling gray suits on a blue-chip afternoon on Wall Street. But what most fascinated the Hackl family of Austria on their first visit to New York City were not the must-see sights, but the mundane ones.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on June 24 about plans to tear down Greater Exodus Baptist Church in Atlantic City to make room for a road project misstated the financing plan for a replacement. The church is to be built with donations from parishioners and money raised by New Jersey through parking taxes. It is not being built solely with state money.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Remain Optimistic Despite Loss to Expos
description: While Todd Hundley and Lance Johnson head for the All-Star Game in Philadelphia, the rest of the Mets packed their bags late this afternoon ready for travel to their homes and a three-day break. They leave generally feeling good about themselves and their prospects for a successful second half that could make for a meaningful September.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
description: * Dugan Valva Contess, Morristown, N.J., was named the 1996 Agency of the Year by Promo Magazine.

title: U.S. SHELVES PLAN TO LIMIT REWARDS TO H.M.O. DOCTORS
description: Facing a torrent of criticism from health maintenance organizations, the Clinton Administration has temporarily shelved new rules that would have restricted the common H.M.O. practice of rewarding doctors who cut costs and control the use of services by Medicare and Medicaid patients.

title: Labor and Business Fight For Senate Vote on Wage
description: On the eve of a crucial Senate vote to raise the Federal minimum wage for millions of workers, organized labor and business groups are waging an all-out lobbying campaign to influence the outcome.

title: Church Fire in Northwest
description: An arson fire caused about $80,000 worth of damage to a black church here over the weekend, the authorities said.

title: Assassin, in Appeal, Calls Rabin a Traitor
description: The convicted killer of the Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin told the country's Supreme Court today that the man he shot was a traitor, while his lawyers suggested that a second gunman had committed the murder.

title: India Suddenly Leads in H.I.V., AIDS Meeting Is Told
description: India has quickly emerged as the country with the largest number of people infected with the AIDS virus, only a few years after it was first detected there, the head of the United Nations AIDS program said as the 11th international AIDS meeting opened here today.

title: Livery Driver Fatally Shot
description: A livery-cab driver was killed early yesterday in an apparent robbery in East Flatbush, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: New Orleans Journal;Cosmopolitan City Relishes Being 'All-America'
description: The dessert of choice here is the beignet, a vaguely triangular French doughnut. It has no hole. The city's professional football team, the Saints, wears helmets decorated with the fleur-de-lis.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Best Ad Ever? One Group's Choice
description: A winsome 1987 commercial for the Hamlet brand of cigars has been selected as the best commercial ever by a panel of journalists.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;To hook more marketing executives, Newsweek casts another line and dangles a new Web site.
description: NEWSWEEK is stepping up efforts to woo media decision makers by casting a wider net on the Internet.

title: POP REVIEW;Hip-Hop Professor Gives His Own Take on History
description: At the beginning of his concert on Saturday at Tramps, KRS-One, the rapper and lecturer who emerged from the South Bronx a decade ago as the leader of the hip-hop purists Boogie Down Productions, told the audience there were three reasons why the night's show was special. First, it was being recorded for an album. Second, it was being shown live on the Internet. And third . . . KRS-One never explained the third reason. Instead, he and his crew began a hard, strong and energetic hourlong show, using just voice, turntables and microphone, that proved to be one of the best hip-hop concerts in recent memory that didn't involve live instruments.

title: Texas Law School Was Integrated in 1950
description: To the Editor:

title: A Movie and High Heels: So What's Not to Like?
description: On Mulberry Street in Little Italy, romance was in the air. Or something like it. As the cameras prepared to roll, Bette Midler stood at attention in front of Angelo's restaurant, closed her eyes and struggled to attain deep concentration.

title: Ireland Mourns a Slain Reporter
description: Veronica Guerin, the prominent Irish investigative reporter who was shot to death in her car on June 26, was a relative newcomer to journalism who took her trade by storm.

title: Progress Seen in Talks On Workers' Insurance
description: After a holiday weekend respite, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders resumed their talks tonight on breaking an impasse over changes to the workers' compensation system, reporting by evening's end that they had made progress for the first time in weeks.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Wheaties Lands Another Big Hitter
description: The baseball player Ken Griffey Jr. is joining athletes who peddle Wheaties cereal for General Mills Inc.

title: Report Says Global Warming Poses Threat to Public Health
description: As international negotiations on global warming resume, United Nations health and environmental agencies are warning of serious threats to public health if actions to reduce climate change come too slowly.

title: In America;Can We Talk?
description: The founders of a new national organization, called the Campaign for America's Future, are asking the question, "What kind of society do we want to have in the 21st century, and what will it take to build it?"

title: BASEBALL;Strawberry on Day 1: Standing O, and 0 for 4
description: Joe Torre just wanted to get the inevitable media circus out of the way. That -- and the fact that a right-handed pitcher was starting for the Brewers against the Yankees -- is why Darryl Strawberry made his 1996 debut with the team yesterday instead of on Thursday in Baltimore.

title: Evergreen Buys Station
description: The Evergreen Media Corporation is acquiring WEDR-FM, a Miami radio station, from the Rivers Group for $65 million in cash. Evergreen said last week that it planned to pursue more acquisitions. Evergreen, based here, owns AM and FM radio stations in about a dozen large urban markets.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefing;Whitman to Tour Prison
description: Governor Whitman will take a tour today of what will be, upon its completion, New Jersey's biggest prison. South Woods State Prison, with a capacity of 3,200 inmates, is expected to help -- but not cure -- the state's prison overcrowding problems. New Jersey prisons are 50 percent over capacity, even with 5,000 state inmates now being housed in county jails. The $235 million prison is about one-third finished, said Bob McHugh, a Corrections Department spokesman, and is scheduled to open next spring.

title: Bosnian Serbs Threaten To Attack U.S. Troops
description: Bosnian Serbs threatened to fire on American helicopters, touching off a weekend standoff between Bosnian Serb forces and American peacekeeping troops, an American commander said today.

title: The Worldly Business of Bribes: Quite Battle Is Joined
description: Two years in Kenya as director of World Bank operations there convinced Peter Eigen of what he had begun to realize when he focused on Latin America: corruption was endemic, and, to put it mildly, seriously undermining development.

title: POLITICS: THE TOBACCO ISSUE;Clinton Campaign to Use Anti-Smoking Pitch to Attack Dole
description: The Clinton-Gore campaign plans to begin broadcasting on Monday its first commercial attacking Bob Dole on tobacco, seizing the issue to portray Mr. Clinton once again as protecting families and Mr. Dole as failing them.

title: World News Briefs;Right-Winger Concedes Defeat in Ecuador
description: The rightist Christian Democratic candidate, Jaime Nebot, conceded defeat tonight in Ecuador's runoff presidential election to a populist, Abdala Bucaram.

title: Politics, City Council And Rent Don't Mix
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Paint Israel as Root of Arafat's Misdeeds
description: To the Editor:

title: Yale Wins Regatta Title
description: Yale University's freshman heavyweight crew capped an undefeated collegiate season today by capturing the Temple Challenge Cup at the 157th Henley Royal Regatta. The Yale team became the only American eight-oared crew to win a title at this year's regatta, which drew entries from Princeton, Dartmouth and Georgetown among the 49 American crews in this oldest of all rowing regattas.

title: Questions on the Rupture Of a Coney Island Gas Pipe
description: As authorities investigated a fire that ignited after a natural gas pipeline ruptured in Coney Island, attention focused yesterday on whether workers at the scene Saturday afternoon knew they were operating in potentially hazardous conditions. Twelve people were injured, six with severe burns, when the fire ignited.

title: GOLF;Stockton's Big Lead Is Barely Enough
description: With Dave Stockton holding a seven-shot lead going into the last round of the 17th United States Senior Open, it seemed that the only question was who would finish second.

title: Helping Stop Crime Via a Police Web Site
description: New Yorkers can now help the state police solve crimes via the Internet.

title: Economic Calender
description: Listed below are the expected release dates for major economic inicators this week.

title: Nicaragua Said to Raise Vote Hurdles for Ex-Rebels
description: Nearly 300,000 Nicaraguan peasants rode on mules, trudged down mountain trails and forded rivers in recent weeks to register to vote.

title: Don't Paint Israel as Root of Arafat's Misdeeds
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: WOODY ALLEN has called on DICK HYMAN, the Emmy Award-winning jazz pianist, numerous times to do the music for his films, among them "Hannah and Her Sisters," "Bullets Over Broadway" and "Mighty Aphrodite." So when Mr. Hyman invited Mr. Allen to play the clarinet in his "Jazz in July" series at the 92d Street Y, how could he refuse?

title: CYCLING;Uphill Ride Solidifies Berzin's Top Spot
description: People have been saying all season that Yevgeny Berzin, the young Russian who startled Miguel Indurain by beating him in the Giro d'Italia in 1994, was concentrating too hard on his time-trialing skills and neglecting his climbing ability.

title: Man Charged In Slaying Of Peacemaker
description: A man was charged yesterday with fatally shooting an off-duty New York City firefighter who had tried to stop an argument outside a bar in Howard Beach, Queens, on Saturday.

title: Net-Surfer Politics Proves to Be Mixed Bag
description: As if American politics were not already factionalized enough, what with militiamen and retirees and farmers and heterosexuals and fundamentalists and animal lovers and heaven knows how many other splinter groups, now comes word of yet another voting bloc for the politicians to reckon with: netizens.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: A Maker of Generic Zantac Wins a Round From Glaxo
description: Novopharm Ltd. cleared a legal hurdle in its race to obtain the first United States rights to make a generic version of Zantac, an ulcer medicine, when a Federal judge in North Carolina ruled Friday that it could produce the drug without infringing on one of two patents held by Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C.

title: OLYMPICS;Man Held in Torch Incident
description: A distance runner remained in jail today after his arrest four days earlier for running uninvited alongside Olympic torchbearers during the flame's tour through Miami.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Rocking Not So Gently in the East River
description: It was rough sailing at Bargemusic on Thursday, the Fourth of July. Ordinarily the barge moored to the Fulton Ferry Landing below the Brooklyn Bridge rocks gently in the course of a performance, but holiday boat traffic on the East River launched some heavy swells into a robust patriotic program of Gershwin, Copland, Barber and Dvorak. The evening's pianist, Rita Sloan, seemed to suffer loss of concentration as a result; crystalline passage work alternated with sketchy playing in the Gershwin Preludes and the piano part of the Dvorak Piano Quartet in E flat.

title: Record Shuttle Flight Ends and Tests Begin
description: Columbia and its crew glided through an overcast sky today to conclude a seven million-mile, 17-day journey for medical science, the longest flight for any space shuttle.

title: Dole Doesn't Let Smokers Off the Hook
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents;A 'fish' with a mission: hang out in shallow waters and listen for anything, say, fishy.
description: IT sounds like the makings for a scene from a Tom Clancy novel: a surveillance device disguised as a fish detects the presence of an enemy frogman laying a mine in a busy harbor.

title: Options for New York City's School Board Presidency"
description: Carol A. Gresser

title: Now, NATO Should Grow
description: The question of NATO expansion has been overshadowed for the last year by the Russian election. Western governments, concerned with a possible Communist or nationalist victory, adopted a go-slow approach.

title: Kuwait Deal for Conoco
description: The Kuwait National Petroleum Company, the state-owned refiner, signed a one-year technical services pact with Conoco Inc., a unit of the Du Pont Company, the official Kuwaiti news agency said. Conoco is to help improve the industrial, maintenance and development operations of Kuwait National, owned by the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation.

title: BASEBALL;Rodriguez Gets to Play Every Day, Plus One
description: His refuge could have been to wallow in self-pity or drown in his own sorrow or spend the passing months crying, "Why me?" Few would have blamed him.

title: On Counterterrorism, Alarms Rang Years Ago
description: To the Editor:

title: Japan-TCI Venture in Asia
description: The Sumitomo Corporation of Japan, Tele-Communications Inc. and the Tokyo Broadcasting System have agreed to form a venture in Singapore to broadcast Japanese-made television programs by satellite through the Asia-Pacific region. The venture will be set up in September, with $15 million in capital backing broadcasts in English, Chinese, Thai and Japanese.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MOTOROLA SHARES CLIMB ON EARNINGS EXPECTATIONS
description: The shares of Motorola Inc. rose yesterday on optimism that its earnings would exceed expectations because of stronger-than-expected sales of its lightweight cellular phone. Motorola shares rose $1.875, to $67.75, on trading of 6.5 million. In a report yesterday, Albert Lin, an analyst at Cowen & Company, projected that Motorola could earn as much as 85 cents a share in the second quarter. The maker of computer chips and electronic equipment based in Schaumburg, Ill., had been expected to report per-share earnings of 69 cents, according to the average estimate of 20 analysts surveyed by IBES International Inc.

title: BASEBALL;Injuries Hurting the Big Stars of the All-Star Game
description: As major league baseball's All-Stars gathered today for the 67th clash between the American and National Leagues, the run of injuries continued to take an alarming toll, adding a sense of vulnerability to the lineups for Tuesday night's game.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Prices End the Day Unchanged
description: Treasury prices ended virtually unchanged yesterday, as a market still reeling from a sharp selloff on Friday paused to ponder what a strong jobs report meant for interest rates.

title: Head of N.A.A.C.P. Attacks Internal Discord
description: Kweisi Mfume, the new leader of the beleaguered National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, told its convention today that he would "fight like hell" any efforts to sow discord within the organization.

title: Market Place;ADT deal may unravel, and accountants hold the string.
description: ONCE again, it may be up to the accountants at the Securities and Exchange Commission to decide whether a big corporate takeover goes through. And Wall Street is worried that the accountants will block it.

title: Tokyo Stocks Up Slightly
description: Japanese stocks were showing very small gains this morning after registering steep losses on Monday. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 16.68 points, less than one-tenth of a percent, at 21,941.62. On Monday, the Nikkei lost 307.48 points.

title: Greek Goddess Back in Italian Arms
description: When the prominent New York art dealer Richard L. Feigen bought a 2,000-year-old marble sculpture of Artemis, the chaste Greek goddess of the moon, little did he know that the $130,000 purchase would turn out to be one big headache.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNIT OF BAIN CAPITAL IN DEAL FOR A RIVAL
description: Wesley-Jessen, a contact lens maker, signed an agreement yesterday to acquire a rival, Pilkington Barnes Hind, for about $79 million. Pilkington, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., a seller of contact lenses, reported sales of $125 million in its latest fiscal year. Wesley-Jessen, which is based in Chicago and expects 1996 revenue of $125 million, is owned by Bain CapitalInc., an investment firm in Boston with holdings in more than 80 companies.

title: Chronology: City Hall v. 110 Livingston Street
description: August 1993: As a mayoral candidate, Rudolph W. Giuliani criticizes Mayor David N. Dinkins for his lack of control over the Board of Education. Mr. Dinkins had been frequently frustrated in attempts to steer educational policy because four of the seven board members tended to vote as a bloc against his wishes. The bloc ousted Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez earlier in the year over the objections of Mr. Dinkins.

title: Hague Tribunal Weighs International Arrest Warrants for 2 Top BosniaSerbs
description: A prosecutor urged the international war crimes tribunal today to issue international arrest warrants for the two top Bosnian Serb leaders, who he said were guilty of "crimes which have shocked the conscience of the world."

title: Review/Fashion;Sensuality and Aggression From Gucci and Prada
description: Katharine Hamnett sent out men in "La Cage aux Folles" drag, singing to the austere men's wear industry audience that they loved them a bushel and a peck. Vivienne Westwood showed cross-dressing under the guise of historic accuracy. "Men gave up luxury and frivolity, and from the 19th century this became the preserve of women," she wrote in her program. "My man is starting to reclaim his rights in this area." Moschino offered a fairly offensive stereotype of fey gay men walking out on a pier runway to wave foppishly at a muscular man on a banana-shaped raft in a pool.

title: Chicago Board's London Link Is Delayed
description: The Chicago Board of Trade and the London International Financial Futures and Options Exchange said today that they had been forced to delay a planned trading link because of difficult technical hurdles.

title: Nassau Legislature Ratifies Pact for Community College
description: Nassau Community College's full-time faculty members, whose salaries are among the highest in the country, won a modified five-year contract today that will eventually raise their earnings by as much as 11.4 percent.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Murder-Suicide by a Trooper
description: The bodies of a state trooper who fatally shot his wife and then killed himself were found in their home on Sunday, the authorities said yesterday. Andrew P. Seals, 27, and his wife of two months, Kris Nicole Taylor Seals, 25, had been dead for several days, The Associated Press reported. Trooper Seals joined the state police 14 months ago.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Free Agents Are Ready and Eager to Be Courted
description: When the Knicks pick up the telephone today, Gary Payton, Reggie Miller and Allan Houston will be ready to listen.

title: Isolated and Corrupt, Serbia's Economy Stagnates
description: You can still buy a small, boxy Yugo car here, but you have to wait for months. When cars are finally delivered, the more fortunate buyers find they are missing mirrors, upholstery panels or ash trays. The unfortunate ones must clank their way to the nearest garage, where work immediately begins under the hood.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UROHEALTH TO ACQUIRE MAKER OF MEDICAL PRODUCTS
description: Urohealth Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Richard-Allan Medical Industries for $55 million. Urohealth, which makes products used to treat urological disorders, would pay $27.5 million in cash and the rest in stock. Richard-Allan Medical, a privately held company based in Richland, Mich., makes disposable products for surgical and gynecological use. It had sales of about $21 million for its fiscal year that ended on June 30. Urohealth is based in Costa Mesa, Calif. Its stock gained 12.5 cents yesterday, to $14.25.

title: BATTLE AT THE BOARD OF EDUCATION: THE PRESIDENT;Used to a Fight, Gresser Vows to Press This One
description: Though the votes seemed solidly against her, Carol A. Gresser said yesterday that she had not given up hope that she could be re-elected president of the Board of Education this morning. But she made it clear that whatever the result, she felt blindsided and that she wondered whether the man who seemed likely to succeed her, William C. Thompson Jr., would do as good a job.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Hanson to Revalue Some Mineral Holdings
description: Hanson P.L.C. said yesterday that it would sharply reduce the book value of the mineral reserves in two units -- Cornerstone Construction and Peabody Coal -- to comply with American accounting rules. It also said Peabody would revise provisions for payments to miners with black lung disease, cutting the division's operating profit by L70 million ($108 million). The changes are part of Hanson's plan to spin off three units worth more than L6 billion ($9.3 billion). (Bloomberg Business News)

title: COMPANY NEWS;BANKBOSTON IS THE NEW NAME FOR MERGED BANKS
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation said yesterday that the holding company for its bank and Baybanks Inc. would be known as the BankBoston Corporation after the closing of the $2 billion merger of the banks, which is expected later this month. The new name would become the single brand for all branches, products and operations worldwide when the systems are converted in 1997. After the closing, BankBoston would have assets of $60 billion.

title: Fatal Gunshot Fired by Police Officer Hit Man in Back, MedicalExaminer Says
description: An unarmed Yonkers man who was fatally shot by a transit officer on a Bronx subway platform last Thursday night was struck in the back by a single bullet, the Medical Examiner's Office said yesterday.

title: BATTLE AT THE BOARD OF EDUCATION: THE ALBANY FRONT;Efforts to Alter School System Stall in Albany
description: Even as Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani maneuvered today to install a new president of the Board of Education, talks in the State Capitol on revamping the governance of the school system were stalled, largely because of a debate over whether a mayor should be able to exert the influence over the board that Mr. Giuliani is demonstrating.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;3Com Reviewing $15 Million Account
description: The 3Com Corporation, which markets computer networking products, said yesterday that it had placed in review its business-to-business account, which has been handled for six years by the Anderson & Lembke unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in San Francisco. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $20 million.

title: A Web Guide To New York Is Acquired
description: City Search Inc., an Internet start-up company with national aspirations, has acquired Metrobeat, the publisher of one of Manhattan's most popular city guides on the World Wide Web.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Late Surge From Bonds Wins Homer Contest
description: As soon as Barry Bonds hit the ball, he flipped his bat in the air and practically danced away from home plate. The ball soared over the right-field fence at Veterans Stadium, making the San Francisco slugger the winner of the Gillette Home Run Derby, the highlight of the festivities on the day before the All-Star Game.

title: Q&A
description: Warding Off the Sun

title: Cab Driving Termed Riskiest Job in U.S.
description: Most victims of workplace homicide have jobs in retail, and the most likely workers to be killed are cab drivers, according to a study made public today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;New Bids Are Said to Be Requested for MGM
description: Potential buyers of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc. are being asked to submit new bids by Thursday at 2 P.M., according to a person familiar with the discussions.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SAM WATERSTON, the actor, is going to Cambodia, and JUDY COLLINS, the singer and songwriter, is off to Vermont this week to promote the same humanitarian cause: the removal of land mines.

title: Polish Anti-Semitism Is Not Going Away
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Amex Account Lost By Bronner Slosberg
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that it had ended a 13-year relationship with Bronner Slosberg Humphrey in Boston on its direct marketing account.

title: Karpov Adjourns Play In a Drawish Endgame
description: Gata Kamsky and Anatoly Karpov broke off play yesterday in Game 17 of the world championship in an endgame that appeared headed for a draw. Each player has a knight and two pawns, and that should bring about an impasse when the game resumes today.

title: Upgrading the Safety of Meat
description: The nation's outmoded system for inspecting meat and poultry is about to undergo a historic transformation. Under the sweeping changes just announced by President Clinton, the antiquated "sniff and poke" method long used by Agriculture Department inspectors to certify that carcasses are safe will be replaced by a system that uses scientific testing to detect disease-causing bacteria.

title: A Dolphin Glossary
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE LAUGH METER;Did You Hear the One About the '96 Campaign?
description: Some may tremble at the statistic, but 40 percent of people under 30 say they learn something about Presidential politics from late-night television comedy.

title: Ivory Coast Sells Itself as West African Powerhouse
description: A multimedia show as grandiose as this country's economic ambitions opened recently in Abidjan's premier hotel.

title: Study Says Job Cuts Rose 28% in First Half
description: The number of job cuts jumped 28 percent in the first half of 1996, a study said today. But the study by Challenger, Gray & Christmas Inc., an outplacement firm, also contained some good news for American workers: Some companies that cut hundreds of thousands of jobs earlier in the 1990's are hiring again.

title: Consumer Debt Is Increasing At Slower Rate
description: The growth in consumer debt slowed sharply in May, climbing at an annual rate of just 4.9 percent. Some economists attributed the slowdown to a tightening of credit standards by lenders worried about rising delinquency rates.

title: At AIDS Meeting, Experts Find An Uneasy Mix of Hope and Fear
description: People attending the international meeting on AIDS being held here this week find themselves caught between hope and fear.

title: Wall St. Tries To Rebound But Falters
description: On the day after the holiday plunge, the bond market teetered and then steadied. The stock market teetered, steadied and then fell further.

title: TENNIS;Krajicek Served Up Unusual Event
description: There they were, two perennial underachievers turned history-makers who came out of the woodwork and survived the cold, wet, star-killing crucible that was Wimbledon in 1996.

title: World Court Condemns Use of Nuclear Weapons
description: By a narrow margin, the International Court of Justice advised today that the use or threat of nuclear weapons, "the ultimate evil," should be outlawed. But it could not decide whether they should be banned in self-defense.

title: The Workers' Compensation Struggle
description: The long-overdue New York State budget is being held up by an unrelated fight over how to reform the state's system for insuring workers injured on the job. We have urged Gov. George Pataki and the Legislature to drop the issue so the budget can be passed. But they clearly need to reform workers' compensation soon because it has become too onerous for New York business.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Jaz Drive: A Lot of Backup Insurance in a Small Package
description: NEWS for the paranoid: Now you can keep the entire valuable contents of your one-gigabyte hard drive close to your heart, right in your shirt pocket. On the heels of its popular little Zip drive, the Iomega Corporation has introduced the Jaz drive, which is significantly faster, more capacious and more expensive. Although units were initially hard to find, that seems to be changing. Last week, the company cut the price by $100.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Olczyk Signs With Kings
description: ED OLCZYK, a free-agent center who has 294 goals in 12 National Hockey League seasons, signed a two-year deal yesterday with the Los Angeles Kings. Olczyk, 29, had 27 goals and 22 assists in 51 games last season for Winnipeg. He was a member of the Rangers' 1993-94 Stanley Cup championship team and also played for Toronto. (AP)

title: 60 Million Federal Grant to Add 800 City Police Officers
description: At a time of sharply declining crime rates, New York City will receive a $60 million Federal grant over the next three years to put 800 new police officers on the street, Federal and city officials said yesterday. The money could raise the size of the force from a current 37,500 members to 38,300, close to its all-time record, by early next year.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Irvin Defense on the Attack
description: Defense attorneys attacked a police officer's account of events and officers' evidence-collecting procedures as the felony drug possession trial for MICHAEL IRVIN resumed in Dallas yesterday with yet another twist.

title: BOXING;Foreman Talking Comeback
description: When George Foreman is not eating, he is busy talking. And yesterday he did a little of both at a book signing and cookout in the Bronx, where he talked about getting into the ring again.

title: Russian Emigre Convicted of Extortion
description: In a verdict hailed as a major strike against the growing influence of Russian organized crime in the United States, a Federal jury in Brooklyn yesterday convicted a man who the authorities say is the most powerful Russian mobster in the country.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Life After Drag: Unreality Endures
description: The world of the drag queen might look glamorous these days. Chic research projects have included Mike Nichols collecting information on the international club circuit for his film "The Birdcage" and Mick Jagger preparing for a transvestite role in his next film, which apparently needs an Estelle Winwood look-alike. But as tonight's "P.O.V." presentation, "The Transformation," makes abundantly clear, the real world of transvestites is far more complicated and unsettling than the glitzy images being cleverly marketed by RuPaul.

title: Heine Securities Urges Delay Of Planned Spinoff at Dial
description: The Heine Securities Corporation, the investment firm led by the money manager Michael Price, urged the board of the Dial Corporation today to delay its planned spinoff into two publicly traded companies.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Boy, 15, Falls in Brook
description: A 15-year-old Passaic boy was critically injured yesterday when he fell into Weasel Brook, the police said. The youth, whose name was not released, was on life support at Beth Israel Hospital in Passaic and was in extremely critical condition, a hospital spokeswoman said.

title: Chrysler Extends Rebates on Some Models
description: The Chrysler Corporation extended its sales incentives until Oct. 7 on select 1996 models that were set to expire today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Unigate of Britain Buying Kraft Units
description: Unigate P.L.C. agreed yesterday to acquire the European margarine and spreads business of Kraft General Foods Inc. for L77.2 million ($120.2 million). The acquisition includes the Vitalite and Golden Churn brands in Britain and the Valle brand in Italy. In 1995, the Kraft unit had sales of L65.8 million ($102.4 million) and operating profit of L13.9 million ($21.6 million). Kraft is a unit of the Philip Morris Companies. (Dow Jones)

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S. Investigates American-British Airways Link
description: The Justice Department has opened an antitrust investigation of the proposed alliance of American Airlines and British Airways to determine whether the arrangement would unfairly dominate the main air avenues to England and Europe.

title: TV SPORTS;Fox's Baseball Pre-Game Show Riddled With Errors
description: The Fox pre-game baseball show is floundering. A distant third in quality to its football and hockey studio programs, the program greatly lags the quality of ESPN's "Baseball Tonight" or its baseball segments on "Sportscenter."

title: No Headline
description: I don't see my job as raising people's awareness on certain issues, or making a certain point, or trying to 'tell it like it really is, man.' Anybody learning anything from my show would disturb me. I would worry grievously for America's future."

title: A New Byatt Novel With a Novel Within
description: Deep into A. S. Byatt's new book, "Babel Tower," the third in a projected quartet of novels about the interplay of life, language and literature in postwar England, the protagonist offers pithy summaries of the landscapes of contemporary writers: "Murdochian moral intricacy, Sparkian wit and bizarrerie." Asked in a recent interview if she could similarly characterize her own work, Ms. Byatt said, "The two words I would most like to have applied are empiricism and elegance." To those, her readers might add intellect and imagination.

title: Genetic Questions Are Sending Judges Back to Classroom
description: QUERY judges about their science backgrounds and they blush. Most say that they studied biology in 10th grade. Some muddled through "physics for poets" in college. Embarrassingly few have had any formal training in genetics.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Parents and Girl Die in Crash
description: A Brooklyn couple and their young daughter were killed early yesterday when the father fell asleep while driving and crashed into a tree on the median of the Palisades Interstate Parkway, the police said. Piotr Kuziora, 29, his wife, Zifoa, 24, and their 22-month-old daughter, Monika, died. The couple's 3-year-old daughter, Aleksandra, was taken to Hackensack University Medical Center, where she was listed in critical condition yesterday.

title: Review/Fashion;Slim, Sophisticated Men's Wear in Paris
description: Here is some simple arithmetic: there are millions more men who can afford good men's-wear design than women who can afford couture. And couture has become redundant, offering the same ideas as are shown in ready-to-wear collections but for a minuscule clientele.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football NEW YORK GIANTS--Re-signed DE Michael Strahan and WR Arthur Marshall. Waived DT Gradt Stretz.

title: Hurricane Bertha Roars Across Caribbean, Leaving as Many as 5 Dead and20 Missing
description: With winds gusting as high as 100 miles an hour, Hurricane Bertha ripped through a string of Caribbean islands today, leaving as many as five people dead and 20 missing. The storm also cut off electricity, forced people into shelters, shut down businesses and left vacationers' plans in shambles.

title: Observer;Man and Product
description: The Republican Dole has been soundly press-whipped for scowling on television during an NBC breakfast-show interview with Katie Couric. This shows how lamentably the press has fallen in with the merchandising philosophy that corrupts Presidential politics. In this view candidates are merely products being marketed to gullible masses, and how in the world are you going to sell the saps a New Miracle Crispy Chief Executive Packed With Crunchy Goodness if it goes around scowling on television? Humans scowl. Products simper and smile while barkers, nowadays always called "handlers," promise twice as much of whatever you want. And for lower prices than ever before!

title: BOXING;Futch, 84, Imparts the Wisdom of the Ages
description: Last week, Riddick Bowe's trainer was unhappy with some of the things the heavyweight was doing in training. So the trainer climbed into the ring and showed him what to do.

title: Ulster Protestants in Anti-Police Protests
description: Thousands of angry Protestants continued anti-police demonstrations today, some of them violent, across this predominantly Protestant British province for the second straight day.

title: Review/Fashion;Three Revolutionaries Decide to Play It Safe
description: If you were a high-profile businessman or a male architect, artist or musician, there were three designers who won you over in the 1980's. They made you feel cool, plugged in, edgy, confident. They were Rei Kawakubo for Comme des Garcons, Giorgio Armani and Yohji Yamamoto.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;New scented ads promise magazine readers aromas mimicking toothpaste and leather.
description: ALL it photography for the nose.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;News Corp. May Sell Stake In Children's Programming
description: The News Corporation is considering selling stock in its children's programming operations to the public, several people with knowledge of the discussions said yesterday. Such a sale could provide the company with money to start children's cable channels, should it choose to do so.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;DeMatha Coach Hospitalized
description: DeMatha High School basketball Coach MORGAN WOOTTEN, one of the few high school coaches to win more than 1,000 games, was listed in critical condition yesterday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. A spokeswoman for the hospital would only give Wootten's condition, saying his family had requested the hospital not give out any other information.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Judge Allows Residency Rule
description: A Federal judge denied yesterday a motion that sought to block the city of Bayonne from enforcing a residency requirement for public employees. Judge William Walls said the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People had failed to show that Bayonne had discriminated against blacks by requiring its employees to live in the city. The N.A.A.C.P. had argued that since the city's population was only 4.5 percent black -- compared with 14 percent in Hudson and Essex counties -- fewer blacks would be able to apply for city jobs. But when the residency requirement was lifted from 1990 to 1994, the increase in applications from blacks was minimal, said Tarquin Bromley, special counsel for Bayonne.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Copper Prices Up as Supplies Fall Near the Shortage Level
description: Copper prices rose in New York yesterday after the London Metal Exchange reported a drop in its stockpiles and the strong economic data from the United States pointed to hefty demand.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Early Skirmish For the Giants And Strahan
description: He tries to keep his composure but clearly Giants defensive end Michael Strahan is upset. Extremely upset. Strahan recently signed a tender offer from the Giants, basically a one-year deal worth $785,000. But he says he did so because the Giants threatened him, saying, according to Strahan, that if he didn't accept the offer they would sign him to a lower-paying deal that could have cost Strahan hundreds of thousands of dollars.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Pixar Plans End To Commercials
description: Pixar Animation Studios, best known for its work on the film "Toy Story," said today that it would stop making commercials after finishing its current slate of projects so it can concentrate on longer-format and interactive entertainment.

title: POLITICS: Political Briefing;THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Georgia A G.O.P. Candidate Complains of Clones

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Separatists in Kashmir Take Journalists Hostage
description: Separatist Muslim guerrillas in India's Kashmir region took 19 journalists captive, then freed them today after a 10-hour standoff in which four of them were threatened with death.

title: C. E. Wiegand, A-Bomb Physicist, Dies at 81
description: Clyde E. Wiegand, a physicist who helped to detonate the first atomic bomb but suffered a crushing disappointment a decade later when he missed out on a Nobel Prize for helping discover a new atomic particle, died on Friday at his home in Oakland, Calif. He was 81.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Pat Haegele, vice president and general manager at the Newspaper National Network, New York, part of the Newspaper Association of America, was promoted to the new post of president.

title: BASEBALL;The Belle of the 70's Praises The Belle of the 90's -- Belle
description: Outside of Cleveland, it would be very difficult to find more than a handful of people who would call themselves supporters of Albert Belle.

title: BATTLE AT THE BOARD OF EDUCATION: THE OVERVIEW;SCHOOL BOARD SET TO OUST PRESIDENT AT MAYOR'S URGING
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has lined up the votes to oust Carol A. Gresser, the school board president and a frequent antagonist of City Hall, and replace her at today's meeting with the Brooklyn board member, William C. Thompson Jr., mayoral aides said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Fuji Bid Beats Out Kodak In Deal for Wal-Mart Plants Fuji will buy six photofinishing plants from Wal-Mart and supply the retail chain's in-store photo labs, helping Fuji in its war against Kodak for a bigger share of the American photofinishing market. [Page D4.]

title: Verdict Is Called Blow to Russian Mob
description: In a verdict hailed as a major strike against the growing influence of Russian organized crime in the United States, a Federal jury in Brooklyn yesterday convicted a man whom authorities say is the most powerful Russian mobster in the country. The man, Vyacheslav Kirillovich Ivankov, faces up to 20 years in prison when sentenced.

title: Islamic-Secular Coalition Cabinet Is Approved in Turkey
description: In a break with Turkey's 73-year record of zealous secularism, the Turkish Parliament gave narrow approval yesterday to a coalition government led by an Islamic party that has campaigned to restore the country's Muslim identity.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Jazz CD's;Imagination Touching Tradition
description: Kenny Garrett's 'Pursuance'

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about a push toward electronic bill payment by Visa International and other companies misstated the ownership of Meca Software Inc., whose president was quoted on Visa's efforts. It is owned by five banks -- Nationsbank, BankAmerica, Royal Bank of Canada, First Bank System and Fleet Financial Group. Meca was sold by H & R Block last year.

title: POLITICS: THIRD PARTY;Reform Party Awaits the Mail To See Who Will Be Running
description: Public figures who win the support of at least 10 percent of the people who answer a mail-in candidate preference survey will be eligible to compete for the Reform Party's Presidential nomination, a top party official announced today.

title: ON BASEBALL;An Old Tale of Two Leagues Focuses on the D.H.
description: They had a home run contest yesterday without the National League's leading home run hitter, and tonight they'll have an All-Star Game without a designated hitter.

title: Debating A Sculpture With a Name And 4 Faces
description: Is it high time for a clock at Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts?

title: OLYMPICS;Johnson Starts a New Streak
description: Michael Johnson began what he hopes will grow into a new winning streak with the sixth-fastest time ever at 200 meters tonight in the Galan Grand Prix.

title: Mr. Netanyahu Comes Calling
description: The first visit of any new Israeli prime minister to Washington is a significant occasion, helping to set the tone for relations between the Jewish state and its most vital ally. In the case of Benjamin Netanyahu, the importance is greater than usual. President Clinton backed his rival, former Prime Minister Shimon Peres, in the recent Israeli election. In addition, many Americans and Israelis fear that Mr. Netanyahu will abandon Mr. Peres's quest for peace.

title: NYC;People . . . Who Needs People?
description: THE atomization of New York life continues with no relief in sight, the latest threat to person-to-person contact coming from the phone company.

title: CYCLING;Riis Takes Lead in the Tour
description: Yevgeny Berzin, the man without a team, should have benefited today when overnight snow, intense cold and high winds in the Alps wiped out two major climbs and shortened the key mountain stage by three-fourths in the Tour de France.

title: Citicorp Opens Islamic Bank in Bahrain
description: Citibank, a unit of Citicorp, said today that it had opened an Islamic bank in Bahrain to offer investments that conform to Islamic religious principles.

title: Atlanta 1996: Olympic Profile;In Rough Water, Riley Races to Stay Afloat
description: By most accounts, Samantha Riley is an admirable young woman: engaging, dedicated, attractive and a remarkably gifted swimmer. She even has a humanitarian for a boyfriend: the Norwegian winter Olympic hero and UNICEF ambassador, Johann Olav Koss.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GLENBOROUGH REALTY TRUST ADDING 17 PROPERTIES
description: Glenborough Realty Trust Inc. said yesterday that it intended to buy 17 properties from four sellers for securities, cash and the assumption of debt totaling $73 million. Glenborough, a real estate investment trust based in San Mateo, Calif., said the acquisitions consisted of six industrial properties, five office properties, three retail properties, two multifamily properties and one hotel.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Russian Rights Activist Suffers Heart Attack
description: Russia's leading human rights campaigner, Sergei Kovalyov, suffered a serious heart attack today and was in a Moscow hospital.

title: THEATER REVIEW;So Many Loving Friends and Relatives
description: It's easy to see why a talented cast, led by the formidable Julie Harris, would be attracted to "Sonya." All the principal characters in this new play by Leon Katz are clearly defined, and each has one or more moments to display vivid emotion, usually anger or anguish.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RYKA GETS MERGER PROPOSAL FROM KPR SPORTS
description: Ryka Inc., a maker of women's athletic shoes, said yesterday that companies owned by its chairman and chief executive, Michael Rubin, had proposed that Ryka acquire them in a stock deal valued at $61.6 million. Mr. Rubin owns KPR Sports International Inc. and its affiliates. KPR markets the Apex One and Yukon shoe brands. Last year, KPR had sales of $43 million. Under the proposal, Ryka would issue about 140 million shares to KPR shareholders. Ryka's stock rose 1 cent, to 39 cents. Ryka, based in King of Prussia, Pa., would be the surviving company in the merger. It makes shoes for aerobics, aqua conditioning, walking and running. The merger proposal also provides that Ryka would effect a 1-for-20 reverse stock split.

title: Justice Knocks at Door of a Wrathful Mayor of Paris
description: You would expect the Mayor of one of the most beautiful and lavishly government-subsidized cities on earth to look as if he didn't have a care in the world. But Jean Tiberi, the Mayor of Paris, has plenty to worry about these days.

title: Sealing Nuclear Waste, Ending an Atomic Dream
description: Using giant mechanical arms controlled from behind 4-foot-thick steel and concrete walls, technicians welded shut a five-ton canister of intensely radioactive waste from a rusting steel tank here today. In so doing, the Federal Government began to back out of one of the greatest dead ends in American industrial history.

title: Executive Changes
description: LEHMAN BROTHERS HOLDINGS INC., New York, said it had named Joseph Gregory head of equity capital markets and Jeffrey Vanderbeek head of debt capital markets.

title: BASEBALL: MIDSEASON REPORT;Mets Dare to Whisper The Words 'Wild Card'
description: The Mets take their All-Star Game break having won 8 of their last 13 games, easily their best stretch of baseball since they left Florida last April. The optimism that abounded during spring training has been renewed with visions of contending for a wild-card spot. But is it realistic to think that a team that spent May 9 through June 17 in last place in the National League East can wind up playing baseball in October?

title: COMPANY NEWS;PROFFITT'S TO ACQUIRE PARISIAN STORES
description: Proffitt's Inc., which operates regional specialty department stores, signed an agreement yesterday to buy Parisian Inc., which has 38 stores in eight states, for about $110 million in cash and about 2.9 million shares of its common stock. The total equity value of the deal is about $221 million and Parisian has debt of about $243 million, Proffitt's said. For the year that ended on May 4, Parisian, which is based in Birmingham, Ala., had sales of $674.5 million. On a combined basis, the company would operate 141 department stores in 19 states with annualized revenue in excess of $2 billion. The deal was announced after Proffitt's stock closed at $34.50, up 37.5 cents, in Nasdaq trading.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;2 Reduce Stakes In British TV Operation
description: Carlton Communications P.L.C. and Granada Group P.L.C. said yesterday that they had sold 12 percent of Independent Television News Ltd. to United News and Media P.L.C. for L12.3 million ($19.1 million) in cash. The sales reduce each company's stake to the 20 percent limit set by the British Government.

title: Corrections
description: A book review yesterday about "Nightline: History in the Making and the Making of Television" (Times Books) referred incorrectly in some copies to the South African Foreign Minister who debated Bishop Desmond Tutu. He was Pik Botha, not F. P. Botha.

title: Picking Up Good, and Subtle, Vibrations from Steel
description: STEEL drums turn out to vibrate with a wide range of subtle resonances that are captivating not only listeners but physicists who investigate how musical instruments cast their distinctive spells.

title: Natural Gas Pipeline Planned Off Louisiana
description: The Marathon Oil Company, the Shell Oil Company and Leviathan Gas Pipeline Partners L.P. said today that they planned to build a $220 million natural gas pipeline system to serve growing production areas in the central Gulf of Mexico.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Linear Thinking: Dead. Barney and Gak: Alive.
description: PLAYING THE FUTURE How Kids' Culture Can Teach Us to Thrive in an Age of Chaos By Douglas Rushkoff 279 pages. HarperCollins. $25.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GERMAN AMERICAN BANCORP TO BUY PEOPLES OF OHIO
description: German American Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Peoples Bancorp and its National Bank and Trust Company in a stock swap worth about $21.1 million. Shareholders of Peoples Bancorp are expected to receive common stock of German American valued at about $35.56 a share. There are 593,334 shares outstanding of Peoples Bancorp. Shares of Peoples slipped 87.5 cents, to $23.125, in Nasdaq trading. German American, based in Jasper, Ind., said it could issue as many as 659,375 shares to shareholders of Peoples Bancorp, depending on the price of German American shares during a period preceding the acquisition. Peoples, based in Marietta, Ohio, is the holding company for various banks in Ohio.

title: Utility Says It Sought to Halt Repairs Before Gas Pipe Broke
description: Before the rupture of a gas main ignited a blaze that injured 12 people in Coney Island, utility workers had asked a contractor to stop work at the site because of safety concerns but were refused, a spokesman for the Brooklyn Union Gas Company said yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: F.A.A. Critic Resigns

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;RTZ-CRA to Cut Back On Mining Exploration
description: RTZ-CRA Group, the world's largest mining company, said yesterday that it would shrink its exploration activities and eliminate 330 jobs in an attempt to cut operating costs $50 million a year. The company, created by the acquisition of CRA Ltd. of Australia by RTZ P.L.C. of Britain late last year, said a review had found overlapping activities. RTZ-CRA spent $317 million last year on exploration. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Gazans' Plea to Netanyahu: Stop Closing Us Out of Jobs
description: In Jerusalem and Washington, people ask whether Benjamin Netanyahu will withdraw from the Golan Heights, share Jerusalem or permit the Palestinians a state. These are among the questions likely to be on the agenda on Tuesday when Mr. Netanyahu pays his first visit to the White House since his election as Prime Minister.

title: Easy Money In Vegas
description: The city is as up front as it ever was, for it can deny neither its purpose nor its psychology.

title: Science-Fraud Case Leaves Insidious Aftermath;The People's Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;TANDY SHARES FALL ON REPORT OF LOWER EARNINGS
description: The shares of the Tandy Corporation tumbled yesterday after the company said it expected second-quarter earnings to decline as much as 30 percent because of weak same-store sales and higher interest costs. Tandy shares fell $4.625, to $40.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Before charges, the company expected to earn 40 cents a share, said the chief financial officer, Dwayne Hughes. A charge of $25.5 million, or 26 cents, to close two stores would reduce net income by about 15 cents a share, he said. Tandy, which operates the Radio Shack and Computer City electronics chains, was expected to earn 51 cents a share, according to the average estimate of 14 analysts polled by Zacks Investment Research. A year earlier, the company earned 55 cents a share.

title: BATTLE AT THE BOARD OF EDUCATION: THE CHALLENGER -- Man in the News;A Knack for Compromise: William Colridge Thompson Jr.
description: William C. Thompson Jr. says he is adamantly opposed to giving Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani direct control over the city school system. He has firmly rejected the idea of relinquishing to the police the Schools Chancellor's ultimate responsibility for school security, as the Mayor demands. And he has forged ties on the Board of Education with some of Mr. Giuliani's harshest critics.

title: Brooklyn Girl, 7, Falls to Her Death
description: A 7-year-old Brooklyn girl fell to her death yesterday from the roof of her apartment building after her mother left her in the care of her 12-year-old brother while she went grocery shopping, the police said.

title: Patterns
description: Rowley's New Jewelry

title: Work Threatened at Russian Outpost
description: THE precarious foothold Russia tries to maintain on the White Continent was sorely tested last month when the 38 scientists at Mirny Station came close to starving.

title: Crack Found In Jet Engine That Killed 2 In Pensacola
description: Federal investigators have discovered a deep crack inside the titanium rotor of a Delta Air Lines engine that may have caused it to blow apart while preparing to take off last weekend, killing two passengers.

title: BASEBALL: MIDSEASON REPORT;So Far, Nothing Has Slowed The Yanks
description: From the moment the Yankees started this season's ride of uncertainty on a frigid April day in Cleveland, their stunning drive to the finest record in the American League has been less joy than jostle.

title: Sports of The Times;Despite 30 Homers, He Bats 8th
description: THE other sluggers are out of central casting. Mark McGwire, with those fearsome forearms. Albert Belle, with that menacing glare. Ken Griffey Jr., with that lean and cheerful look. Barry Bonds, with that shrill arrogance. Frank Thomas, with muscles that resemble the limbs of a redwood tree.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Union Head Admits Warning
description: The head of the teachers' union acknowledged yesterday that he had warned the superintendent of the Morris School District by E-mail that he would be "in big trouble" for "playing both sides of the fence" in contract negotiations. A hearing had been scheduled to determine whether America Online should be forced to reveal the name of the subscriber who sent the message to the superintendent, Dwight Pfennig, but the disclosure by Anthony Gervasio, the president of the Teachers Education Association of Morris, made the hearing moot.

title: Sharon Joins Netanyahu's Cabinet at Last
description: After weeks of political haggling and last-minute crises, Ariel Sharon was sworn in as a Cabinet minister today, strengthening the hard line in Israel's new Government as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu flew to Washington to meet President Clinton.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;SFX Sells 3 Radio Stations
description: SFX Broadcasting Inc., based in New York, said yesterday that it had sold three radio stations in Washington to the Bonneville International Corporation, a subsidiary of the Deseret Management Corporation, for $25 million. The stations are WXTR-FM, WXVR-FM and WQSI-AM. Bonneville, based in Salt Lake City, is a closely held company.

title: Antarctic Ice Core May Help Predict Start of Next Ice Age
description: ICE that has lain undisturbed for hundreds of thousands of years is yielding clues that may foreshadow our own future when Earth's present warming trend gives way to a new era of glaciation and cold.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Guilty Plea in Export Case
description: It was 1991, and modern Western appliances were hard to come by in Siberia. So a Soviet-owned oil company, looking to help its employees, sent $2.2 million to Lev Model, a Russian national in Englewood Cliffs who ran an import-export company. Mr. Model was supposed to ship back thousands of television sets, washing machines and dishwashers for the oil company to sell to its workers at low prices.

title: F.D.A. Allows Drug As a Heart Medicine
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it might now sell its cholesterol-lowering drug Pravachol to prevent heart attacks and death in patients who do not yet show symptoms of heart disease.

title: Chief of St. Martin's Press to Retire in January
description: After more than a quarter-century as the chief executive officer of St. Martin's Press, Thomas J. McCormack announced yesterday that he would retire this January, making way for a 38-year-old successor from outside the company who has experience in the video and multimedia markets.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Europe-Japan Chip Gains Seen
description: Japan and the European Union reached an understanding today on how to proceed with drafting international policy on semiconductors, according to a European Commission spokesman.

title: Films Vault To the Top With Tricks, Not Stars
description: By this afternoon, "Independence Day" had taken in $100 million at the box office, making its first six days in release the most successful movie opening ever. In this season of the disaster epic, the success of this film, which is about an enormous alien invasion, and of "Twister," which is about an enormous tornado invasion, underscores the fact that a movie with great special effects does not need high-priced stars to become a bonanza. And this is one summer school lesson that has not been lost on the executives who run the studios here.

title: Science-Fraud Case Leaves Insidious Aftermath
description: To the Editor:

title: A Promising Medical Specialty Emerges to Help Torture Victims
description: IT was a peaceful Copenhagen cafeteria, perfectly safe, but the woman's panic started to well up the moment a man came to her table with a roll, egg and coffee on his breakfast tray, sat down and started to eat his breakfast. The woman, a refugee who had been tortured in her own country, was suddenly flooded by a hideous memory of how her torturer would carry that same meal in on a tray and calmly eat his breakfast in front of her before starting her daily torture session.

title: But Will That Meat Pass Your Inspection?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kathy Ahern, 47; Started L.P.G.A. Career at 17
description: Kathy Ahern, a former child prodigy of a golfer who turned professional while still a teen-ager, died on Saturday at her home in Phoenix. She was 47.

title: POLITICS: BEHIND THE SCENES;Hired Hands Carrying Democracy's Petitions
description: There was a time when volunteers collected signatures to put an issue or an insurgent candidate on the ballot. They acted out of ideology, party loyalty, the expectation of a patronage reward or a commitment to a particular candidate.

title: Summertime, and the Movies Are Weird
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-10

title: Senate Debates Minimum-Wage Increase
description: Senate Democrats and Republicans debated today whether a 90-cent increase in the Federal minimum wage would throw an economic lifeline to millions of workers or force small businesses to lay off hundreds of thousands of them.

title: By Design;Summer's Many Lengths
description: Shorts and long pants may be traditional but they are not the whole summer story. There are several lengths in between, from just below the knee to just above the ankle, that bring a new look to a casual wardrobe. They come in solids and a variety of prints but are always cut on the straight and narrow.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The phrase "old school tie" has acquired a new meaning at New York University, thanks to a fund-raising idea of Dr. L. JAY OLIVA, the school's president. A design from the school seal embellishes a new silk tie from the venerable house of Ferragamo. And a reproduction of the seal -- featuring the Washington Square Arch, which is at the heart of the campus, and the school color, violet -- are on a Ferragamo silk scarf.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Islanders Name New Executive
description: The Islanders yesterday named GORDIE CLARK their director of player personnel, a post that includes supervision of the team's scouting staff. Clark, who had been the Boston Bruins' chief of scouting, served as assistant coach under MIKE MILBURY, the Islander general manager, when Milbury coached at Boston.

title: Charles DeForest, 72, Composer Who Sang in Piano Bar's Heyday
description: Charles DeForest, a singer, pianist and songwriter who performed continuously in Manhattan nightclubs for more than four decades, died on Saturday in Penn Yan, N.Y., at the home of his nephew. He was 72.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;In Japan, Saturn Signs Car Dealers
description: The Saturn division of the General Motors Corporation announced today that it had signed the first six dealers to begin selling its cars in Japan next spring.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;African Nations Back 2d Term for U.N. Chief
description: African leaders, meeting today in Cameroon, appeared to give Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali qualified backing for a second term, diplomats said here.

title: Leslie D. Holmes, 39, a Lawyer Who Fought for Tenants' Rights
description: Leslie D'Cora Holmes, an advocate of tenants' rights who was a member of the New York City Rent Guidelines Board, died on Friday at a hospital in Albany. She was 39 and lived in Brooklyn.

title: For the Sake of Salmon, California Dam Gets an $80 Million Alteration
description: If chinook salmon embryos and fry could sweat, they would drip with perspiration in water exceeding 56 degrees. In water over 57.5 degrees, they begin to die.

title: Outspoken F.A.A. Critic Quits Transportation Post
description: Mary Fackler Schiavo, the inspector general of the Transportation Department whose harsh public criticism of the Federal Aviation Administration after the Valujet crash in Florida two months ago set off a debate about the safety of flying, resigned yesterday.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Coaches Hired For Van Gundy
description: The Knicks have hired Brendan Malone and Tom Thibodeau as assistant coaches, completing their staff for next season. They will join Don Chaney and Jeff Nix as assistants under Jeff Van Gundy.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ERNST & YOUNG L.L.P., New York, the accounting and consulting firm, announced the acquisition of closely held Wright Killen and Co. of Houston, consultants for the energy and chemical industries. Terms were not disclosed.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Airbus Group Sets Goal of Stand-Alone Status
description: The supervisory board of Airbus Industrie said today that the consortium of four European plane makers planned to restructure to become a stand-alone company by 1999.

title: An Old Story for Migrant Farm Workers;Advocates Fear a New State Code Will Have Little Impact on Their Hardships
description: It's high season here in the black dirt mucklands. The air smells like sweet young onions, rows of green shoots stretch clear to forever and the migrant workers have tons to do.

title: Murdoch and Germany's Kirch Take Aim at a $5 Billion Marke : 2 Media Giants Seal European TV Alliance
description: PARIS  Rupert Murdoch and Leo Kirch, two of the world's most potent media tycoons, joined forces on Monday in a surprise alliance that will try to dominate Europe's biggest pay-television market.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Single Name for Sprint
description: The Sprint Corporation said today that its telephone companies would operate under the Sprint brand name, effective immediately. Sprint's local phone operations had functioned under names including United Telephone, Centel, Central Telephone and Carolina Telephone.

title: Science-Fraud Case Leaves Insidious Aftermath;Fascism's Nest Egg
description: To the Editor:

title: An Increase in Wages May Hurt Some Teen-Agers
description: At one time, Sidewinder Pumps Inc., in Lafayette, La., would hire a dozen or more young people to work each summer at minimum-wage jobs like weeding or expanding the parking lot -- tasks that were not really essential to the company but that let it give teen-agers a taste of what paid work is like.

title: In Georgia House Race, Color Doesn't Matter
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;News Corp. In Pay TV Deal With Kirch Of Germany
description: The News Corporation, formally breaking an alliance with Bertelsmann A.G., announced a deal today with the Kirch Group of Germany to supply digital pay television in Europe.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Opposing a Holiday Change
description: The Pleasantville School Board recently voted to make the October anniversary of the Million Man March a school holiday. To make room for it on the school calendar, the board voted to eliminate the traditional Veterans Day holiday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
description: Wilder Baker, chairman, president and chief executive at Warwick Baker O'Neill, New York, and Philip Guarascio, vice president and general manager for marketing and advertising at the North American operations of General Motors Corp., Warren, Mich., were elected chairman and vice chairman of the American Advertising Federation. Steve Jekogin, consumer research director at Joseph E. Seagram & Sons, New York, was named president of the board of the New York chapter of the American Marketing Association.

title: Trustee Plan In Accounting Is Approved
description: Bowing to pressure from the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the trustees who oversee the Financial Accounting Standards Board agreed today to fill half their seats with public members.

title: New Gauge for Shorter Day of Past
description: BY counting microscopic stripes in sedimentary rock imprinted by the rise and fall of ancient tides, a team of planetary scientists and geologists has calculated that 900 million years ago, the length of a day was only about 18 hours and 10 minutes.

title: Corrections
description: The Economic Scene column on Thursday, about a debate on the economic benefits of immigration, misstated an estimate by Lawrence Katz of Harvard University on the impact of competition from immigrants on the wages of high school dropouts. He has estimated that competition accounts for a decline in their wages of roughly 3 percent, not one-third. Such a drop represents one-third of the relative decline of their wages in the last few decades.

title: Brewer Plans a Stock Offering on Internet
description: The Spring Street Brewing Company said yesterday that it planned to raise $3.3 million through an Internet stock offering, joining a handful of entrepreneurs using the global computer network to sell shares directly to the public.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: United States

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Fuji in Deal With Wal-Mart For Photofinishing Plants
description: The Fuji Photo Film Company fired a fresh salvo yesterday in its war against the Eastman Kodak Company for a bigger share of the American photofinishing market. It announced that it would buy Wal-Mart Stores' six photofinishing plants at a price that analysts estimated to be about $200 million.

title: A Victory for Midwives Who Aren't Nurses
description: A State Department of Public Health hearing officer has upheld the right of midwives who are not nurses to practice in the state.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CALENERGY BUYING 3 NATURAL GAS-FIRED POWER PLANTS
description: The Calenergy Company said yesterday that it would buy three natural gas-fired power plants for $226 million from Falcon Seaboard Resources Inc. Calenergy, of Omaha, said it also expected to work with Falcon on international joint ventures. Falcon, a closely held concern in Houston, said it would use the proceeds of the sale for its oil business and international and domestic projects. Falcon's power plants are in Pennsylvania, New York and Texas. They sell their output to the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation, the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation and the Texas Utilities Company. Calenergy is a developer of geothermal energy. It has interests in power plants in California, Nevada, Utah, Washington and Oregon.

title: Climate Session Opens With Words of Warning
description: United Nations officials and scientists today urged governments to agree in the coming two weeks on tighter targets for limiting the emissions of the greenhouse gases that are blamed for global warming. The officials, speaking at the start of the United Nations' Climate Change Convention, also issued a strong affirmation of the notion that economic activity is the main cause of global warming, dismissing critics of that view as industry lobby groups.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Account Reviewed By Value Rent-a-Car
description: Value Rent-a-Car in Boca Raton, Fla., a division of Mitsubitshi Motor Sales of America, said yesterday that it had placed its account in review after five years at Harris Drury Cohen in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Billings were estimated at $7 million to $8 million.

title: Moscow Journal;The Americans Who Saved Yeltsin (Or Did They?)
description: Victory finds a hundred fathers, it is said, while defeat is an orphan. But three American political consultants to President Boris N. Yeltsin's campaign say the victory was theirs alone.

title: A Wave of Casinos Hits Mississippi's Gulf Coast;Las Vegas Operators Hope to Build Biloxi Into a Top-Tier Gambling Port
description: Here in the South's Monte Carlo among the magnolias, casino companies are transforming the Mississippi coast from a strip of decaying motels and dilapidated mansions into the nation's hottest new gambling hub.

title: SMART' WEAPONS WERE OVERRATED, STUDY CONCLUDES
description: During and after the Persian Gulf war, the Pentagon dramatically oversold the effectiveness of its most expensive high-tech aircraft and missiles, the most thorough independent study to date has found.

title: Polish Anti-Semitism Is Not Going Away;Misplaced Blame
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Johnson's All-Star Surprise: 9 Innings
description: There were more than a few eyebrows raised when Bobby Cox selected Lance Johnson to the National League All-Star team. Then, when Cox announced that Johnson would be his starting center fielder after Tony Gwynn was not available to play, the move was met with more surprise.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Safety Board Finds Airplane Maker at Fault in 1994 Turboprop Crash
description: The National Transportation Safety Board said today that the main reason for the 1994 crash of an American Eagle turboprop was that the French manufacturer and the French Government did not tell airlines, pilots and the Federal Aviation Administration everything they knew about the model's vulnerability to ice.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RED LION HOTELS BUYING SHERATON GRAND IN HOUSTON
description: Red Lion Hotels Inc. said yesterday that it would buy the Sheraton Grand Hotel in Houston for $21.8 million. Red Line, based in Vancouver, Wash., said it would rename the hotel, which has 319 rooms, as the Red Lion Hotel-Houston. Red Lion operates 53 full-service hotels with 14,000 rooms in the western United States. Red Lion's shares closed up 88 cents, at $21.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: At Crossroads of Democracy, South Korea Hesitates
description: This is a country that prides itself on its democracy and talks of using computers and the Internet to turn itself into an information society.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;High School Coach Needs Transplant
description: MORGAN WOOTTEN, one of the nation's top prep basketball coaches during a 40-year career at DeMatha High School in Baltimore, needs a liver transplant in the next two weeks or he will die, his doctor said yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;R. R. DONNELLEY TO CLOSE A SOFTWARE PLANT IN INDIANA
description: R. R. Donnelley & Sons, the world's largest commercial printer, announced yesterday that it would close a software plant in Indiana, eliminating about 1,000 jobs. The cuts will come at Donnelley's global software business, Stream International, which produces computer diskettes and printed software manuals. Donnelley, based in Chicago, said it would also cut 300 jobs at its book-return processing operation, which the company earlier announced was moving to Louisville, Ky. The company said the moves were part of a cost-cutting effort that it had announced in March.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Examining Father Coughlin, Hate Radio Pioneer
description: RADIO PRIEST Charles Coughlin, the Father of Hate Radio By Donald Warren Illustrated. 364 pages. The Free Press. $27.50.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Vote on Rutgers Tuition Rise
description: Rutgers University's board of governors will vote today on a 6 percent tuition increase for the coming school year. The proposed $242 increase, which would bring tuition for state residents to $4,028, will cover salary increases, higher utility and regulatory costs and debt service on a new law school building, said Nancy Winterbauer, the school's vice president for university budgeting. Last month, Rutgers raised room and board charges by $200 a year.

title: New Police Agency Chief
description: The Giuliani administration yesterday named Mel P. Barkan, a former Assistant United States Attorney and now a lawyer in private practice, as the new chairman of the Civilian Complaint Review Board, which investigates allegations of police misconduct.

title: Maps for Diners And Picnickers
description: A NEW map listing 59 places in Manhattan that are suitable for a picnic is available free at D'Agostino supermarkets.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Red Wings Extend Bowman's Contract
description: SCOTTY BOWMAN, the Detroit Red Wings' coach, will be back next season and have his staff intact, with a contract that calls for him to remain director of player personnel for the two following seasons. Bowman, 62, led Detroit to 62 victories, a National Hockey League record, last season, but Detroit lost to the eventual Stanley Cup champion, Colorado, in the Western Conference finals. Terms of the contract were not disclosed yesterday, but The Detroit Free Press said the deal was expected to pay Bowman about $950,000 next season.

title: Cable Concern Plans a Fight Against Nynex
description: For five years, Liberty Cable and Time Warner Inc. have waged a David-and-Goliath battle for cable-television customers in Manhattan. Now, David is taking on an even greater Goliath.

title: Picture Billboards and Elk on Your Postcards;Joe Camel in Nature?
description: To the Editor:

title: BATTLE AT THE BOARD OF EDUCATION: THE FIGHT;Some Old Grudges Converge To Oust School Board Head
description: The campaign to oust Carol A. Gresser as president of the New York City Board of Education had been building for weeks.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COLONIAL BANCGROUP ADDS 3 ASSETS WORTH $101 MILLION
description: Colonial Bancgroup Inc. completed three acquisitions in the last week worth about $101 million combined. The acquisitions increased Colonial's asset base to about $4.5 billion from $4 billion and gave it a greater presence in the Atlanta area and central Florida. Colonial, based in Montgomery, Ala., completed the $46 million acquisition of Commercial Bancorp of Georgia and the $50 million purchase of the Southern Banking Corporation last week.

title: BASEBALL;Cuban Pitching Star Defects
description: The star pitcher for the champion Cuban baseball team defected to the United States today, escaping from the team's hotel in Georgia and heading here with a sports agent who has helped several other athletes defect from Cuba.

title: Chancellor At Berkeley Will Quit Job Within a Year
description: The chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley, Chang-Lin Tien, said today that he would leave his post in the next year to return to teaching and research.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Schools Fall Short of Goals
description: Five years after the state assumed control of Paterson's troubled school system, education officials say the district is not ready to operate on its own. State Education Commissioner Leo F. Klagholz plans to recommend to the state's Board of Education next month that the takeover be extended for at least a year, a department spokesman said yesterday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: OLYMPICS;Woman Accused of $1 Million Scam
description: A woman accused of taking more than $1 million from reporters to house them during the Olympics was jailed on theft charges yesterday after they said she reneged on the deal.

title: TV Notes;Cadmus? Not Cezanne?
