description: A major art exhibition at one of the nation's top museums gives a culturally minded public television station like Channel 13 a natural tie-in opportunity. A documentary on the artist would fit the bill nicely.

title: Photographer Testifies at Ex-Wife's Trial
description: In a courtroom here today, O. Winston Link, the celebrated photographer, faced a dreary reality that seemed incompatible with the innocence of the bellowing steam engines and pot-bellied stoves in the photographs that made him famous.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A peek into the life of another octogenarian former head of state, RONALD REAGAN, is contained in the July/August issue of New Choices magazine.

title: Clinton Likely to Visit China in 1997 if He Is Re-elected
description: Celebrating an apparent warming in relations, Chinese and American officials said today that they expect President Clinton to visit China sometime next year if he is re-elected. In return, President Jiang Zemin would visit Washington.

title: Low-Impact Workout, No Sneakers Required
description: DOUG STERN'S deep-water running class doesn't look like much more than 26 heads bobbing on the water's surface. But below, the legs are moving, unhindered and graceful.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Inside Art column of Weekend on Friday about Christie's London auction of paintings and objects from the Bute Collection misstated the location of the Isle of Bute. It is off western Scotland, not northwestern England.

title: A Birth-Control Pill May Enhance Sexual Desire
description: The type of birth-control pills a woman uses may enhance her sexual desire and satisfaction, according to a study of sexually active California university students.

title: Mongolia Swaps Leaders
description: Eight centuries ago, the Mongols startled half the world as Genghis Khan's mounted archers swiftly mastered most of Asia and Europe, founding history's biggest overland empire. Last week the conqueror's descendants set a different example by peacefully voting out of parliamentary power the party that has ruled Mongolia for 75 years, first as Communists and since 1990 as former Communists. It could not be a more timely counterpoint to the claims by Chinese, Indonesian and Burmese authoritarians that multi-party elections and political accountability are somehow alien, un-Asian ideas.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-7

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Miscellany
description: The Publishers Information Bureau, New York, reported that the number of magazine advertising pages rose 1.3 percent in June, to 17,134, from June 1995. For the first six months of the year, ad pages fell 1.9 percent, to 101,960, from the corresponding period a year earlier.

title: Tests Raise Doubts About Justification of Shooting
description: Police ballistics tests indicate that a Bronx transit officer who fatally shot an unarmed Yonkers man in the back on a vacant D train platform last week fired at him while he was running away, a senior police official said yesterday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Docks de France Seeks Alternatives to Bid
description: Docks de France S.A., the supermarket operator sought by a rival, Auchan S.A., in a hostile $3.1 billion bid, said key shareholders had unanimously rejected the bid. It added that it was studying other solutions that "might better suit the company and its shareholders." A spokeswoman said Docks de France had until July 25 to present alternatives. The Financial Times reported yesterday that Tesco P.L.C., Europe's largest supermarket chain, was considering a bid.

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;Dole Retreats From His Call To Void Ban On 19 Guns
description: As he did with the explosive issue of abortion, Bob Dole seemed to take another step toward the political center today, backing off his earlier opposition to an assault-weapons ban enacted two years ago.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Won't Alter Plans
description: The delay in free-agent signings should not alter the Knicks' game plan. Assuming that the moratorium on signing contracts ends tomorrow, New York is still expected to focus quickly on four free agents -- Reggie Miller, Allan Houston, Gary Payton and Juwan Howard.

title: EATING WELL;Despite New Guidelines, Meat Can Still Be Risky
description: BEFORE you lick your chops over visions of rare hamburgers and chicken cooked until just pink, consider this: Even when the new, more stringent regulations for inspecting meat and poultry go into effect, there will still be plenty of harmful bacteria to go around.

title: How Senate Voted On Raising Wage
description: Following is the 74-to-24 roll-call by which the Senate voted to increase the minimum wage to $5.15 an hour, from $4.25, over the next year. A "yes" vote was a vote both to raise the wage and to approve a package of tax breaks for businesses. A "no" vote was a vote to oppose the increase and the tax breaks. Voting "yes" were 47 Democrats and 27 Republicans. Voting "no" were 24 Republicans.

title: Mexico Panel Cites No Zedillo Impropriety
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCK REVIEW;Lonely, but All Made Up for Loving
description: Like other pop stars, Robert Smith sings about love and kisses, dreams and tears. Teen-aged girls flock to the Cure's concerts to hear his songs confess that he's lonely, infatuated, suffering or giddy with desire. But he sings in a choked-up, distraught voice, and he doesn't fit the teen-idol prototypes of pretty boy or bad boy; like his most dedicated fans, he's gawky and fond of makeup.

title: Motor Backfiring Prompts Recall by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it was recalling 292,860 cars because of a defect that might cause the motors to backfire and in rare cases lead to fires.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Milk mustaches are sticking around, but can they stay fresh?
description: A POPULAR national campaign that places mock milk mustaches on the upper lips of the likes of Lauren Bacall, Kate Moss, Pete Sampras and Steve Young is being expanded with a larger budget, a new theme and added endorsers, from sportscasters to Spike Lee to the most exotic of celebrities, a long-married Hollywood couple.

title: Prosecutors in Bomb-Plot Case Turn to Suspect's Computer
description: After nearly six weeks of often soporific testimony and cross-examination, prosecutors moved yesterday to the heart of their terrorism case against Ramzi Ahmed Yousef by introducing the contents of a laptop computer in which they say he stored details of his failed plan to blow up American airliners in Asia.

title: Tense Vigil For Family As a Sister Disappears
description: They are fighting hard to talk about Anne Marie Fahey in the present tense.

title: A Director's Vision for Celebrating Food, Wine and Film
description: FRANCIS FORD COPPOLA is directing, as usual.

title: Capitol Hill Takes to Cyberspace, Though in Fits, Starts and Stumbles
description: No lawmaker is more responsible for pushing Congress into the on-line realm of the World Wide Web and electronic democracy than Speaker Newt Gingrich.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MACROMEDIA PLUNGES AFTER REPORT OF LOW GROWTH
description: Shares of Macromedia Inc. fell sharply yesterday, one day after the software maker warned that it would report disappointing results for the latest quarter. Macromedia sank $3.875, to $15.375, as almost 12.1 million shares were traded on the Nasdaq market. The San Francisco-based company said late on Monday that its revenue growth in its fiscal first quarter ended June 30 would be less than it had hoped for earlier. It also predicted that its earnings for the quarter would be 18 cents a share, compared with Wall Street's estimates ranging up to 22 cents a share.

title: Clinton Is Criticized by His Own AIDS Panel
description: President Clinton's own AIDS council has called on the White House to show "greater courage and leadership" in taking steps to prevent H.I.V. transmission and to protect people with the virus from discrimination.

title: Once Again, A Cozy Deal Leads to Court;Municipal-Bond Cases So Far Are Showing Mixed Results
description: In a cavernous courtroom here, decorated with brass chandeliers and oil paintings of seascapes, a drama of kickbacks, corruption and big-ticket finance is unfolding. Each actor is a star: The judge presided in the infamous New Bedford, Mass., pool-table rape case that cemented the place of television cameras in courtrooms; the defense lawyer's client roster is a who's who of Boston politics, and the defendant was once a powerhouse in municipal finance.

title: ON BASEBALL;Past and Future in the Stars
description: Immortality is on the run in baseball, especially in the All-Star Game, as shown by both the absence of Kirby Puckett and the presence of the soon-to-retire Ozzie Smith, who brought tears to grown men, including himself when he batted for the final time as an All-Star last night.

title: Metro Matters;Board Change Means Nothing For Students
description: THE HALL OF THE BOARD at 110 Livingston Street, the large auditorium at Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn, is quite a room. It has marble floors and marble walls, and carved, gold-leafed ceilings and formal mauve draperies behind the well where the board members meet.

title: AIDS Researchers Differ on Vaccine Strategies
description: Despite nearly universal agreement on the need for a vaccine to prevent AIDS, many scientists, public health officials and political leaders are sharply divided over when and to begin the first large-scale trials and which product to test.

title: No Headline
description: While soldiers are on a hunger ration, while officers wait to get a flat for more than 10 years and get no salaries for months, those close to the Defense Minister are literally living it up."

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Vaughn Starts, With a Push From His Dad
description: Mo Vaughn figures he owes his father one now.

title: BATTLE AT THE BOARD OF EDUCATION;Comments by Gresser and Thompson at School Board Meeting
description: Following are transcripts of the statements by Carol A. Gresser, outgoing president of the Board of Education, as she cast her vote at yesterday's board meeting, and William C. Thompson Jr., after his election as president, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANDREW GIULIANI, 11, the Mayor's son, broke his wrist playing baseball yesterday, but he is expected to be back in the lineup in about four weeks, The Associated Press reported. "It's been put in a cast," Mayor RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI told the A.P. yesterday. "It's expected that he'll make a full and complete recovery. He's in some pain, but his real upset is that he won't be able to play baseball for the next four weeks."

title: SENATE PASSES BILL FOR RAISE, TO $5.15, IN MINIMUM WAGE
description: After four months of incessant Democratic pressure, the Senate approved a bill today to raise the Federal minimum wage to $5.15, virtually assuring a 90-cent-per-hour pay increase to more than 10 million Americans.

title: New Owners Plan to Bring New Life to the Blighted Kenmore Hotel
description: The Kenmore Hotel, a dilapidated, crime-infested residence near Gramercy Park that was seized by the United States Government two years ago, will be renovated by new owners who plan to turn its 641 cell-sized rooms into 326 air-conditioned studio apartments.

title: Hot Lead Is Early Favorite
description: Hot Lead, whose 10 victories this season have come at the Meadowlands, was made the 9-5 favorite today when a field of 10 3-year-olds was drawn for the $1 million Meadowlands Pace Saturday night.

title: TV Notes;Programming for Children
description: By this week, the Federal Communications Commission was expected to have established its new regulations mandating that television stations provide three hours a week of educational or informational programming for children.

title: Gannett to Sell Its Outdoor Advertising Unit
description: The Gannett Company said yesterday that it would sell its outdoor advertising division, the largest in North America, to Outdoor Systems Inc., a much smaller competitor, for $690 million in cash.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the film maker Stephen Ives referred incorrectly to some writers of his coming television documentary series "The West." Along with Geoffrey C. Ward, the writer is Dayton Duncan, not Mr. Ives and Ken Burns.

title: On Tolerating Casualties and Other Costs of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Luis Rodriguez, 59; Cuban Fighter Held Welterweight Title
description: Luis Rodriguez, a Cuban boxer who won 107 of his 120 professional fights and held the world welterweight title briefly in 1963, died on Monday at South Shore Hospital in Miami Beach. He was 59.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MGM GRAND TO PUT RESORT ON BOARDWALK
description: MGM Grand Inc. said yesterday that it had chosen a site for a $700 million "majestic destination resort" it plans to build on Atlantic City's Boardwalk. The company, which disclosed plans to enter Atlantic City two months ago, says it will build on 30 acres next to Showboat Casino Hotel. The number of rooms and the size of the casino have not been decided. MGM, which says it needs 30 acres, must acquire most of the land. MGM has reached agreement with a shopping mall developer, the Forest City Ratner Companies, which controls a 13-acre site next to Showboat, on a plan to include that property in the project.

title: INSIDE
description: Nynex Faces Unlikely Rival

title: ATLANTA 1996: FIELD HOCKEY IN INDIA;The Once, and Perhaps Future, Kings of Hockey
description: When Indian athletes arrive in Atlanta for the Olympic Games, they will be daunted, as well as spurred, by one of the most disappointing sporting records of any major nation.

title: OLYMPICS;Boxers Work Out Under Armed Guard
description: Armed guards kept watch over the United States Olympic boxing team's workouts today, one day after one of the boxers was struck from behind by an unknown assailant.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Italy and Turkey Dumped Pasta, U.S. Agency Rules
description: The International Trade Commission ruled yesterday that Italian and Turkish companies had imported and sold pasta in the United States at less than fair value. The American agency, in a 5-to-1 vote, ruled that pasta from Italy and Turkey had "materially injured" the domestic industry, which authorized the Commerce Department to impose anti-dumping duties on pasta imports from the two countries. The commission's decision can be appealed to the United States Court of International Trade in New York.

title: A New Man, Having Shed 300 Pounds
description: To judge by the media crush -- 8 television camera crews, 20 photograpers, a snake pit of microphone cords and enough cars and vans to force a street closing -- the event might have been the surprise return of the Pope.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Dollar's Strength Has U.S. Executives Grumbling
description: With the dollar near its highest level against the Japanese yen in nearly two and a half years, industrial leaders in the United States are beginning to express concern that the currency's strong rebound may undermine American competitiveness against foreign rivals.

title: After Draw, Match Hangs By Half Point
description: Without further play, Anatoly Karpov and Gata Kamsky agreed to a draw yesterday in Game 17 of the world championship match in Elista, Russia. Thus, Karpov holds a 10-to-7 lead over Kamsky and can clinch the International Chess Federation series today with a draw.

title: Second School Attack Alarms Britain
description: It was the second serious and random attack on a group of British schoolchildren in four months and, inevitably, memories of March's horrific murders at a primary school in Dunblane, Scotland, came flooding back.

title: Above All, Don't Dress Up As a Cow
description: Do not run toward the bulls."

title: Albany Budget Delay Brings Eviction Threat to Loft Tenants
description: With the state budget 100 days late, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders failed again today to settle major differences, setting up a potential crisis for thousands of New York City loft tenants.

title: Grading Time for School-to-Work Act
description: When she first began working as a hospital apprentice here two years ago, Lillybeth Serrano said, she had little enthusiasm for school, not to mention college, and her grades showed it.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: EMPLOYEE SOLUTIONS INC., Phoenix, the temporary help and benefits-management company, agreed to buy Penske Truck Leasing Co.'s Leaseway Personnel permanent and temporary help unit for $23 million, including the assumption of debt.

title: POLITICS: THIRD PARTY;Lamm, Ex-Governor of Colorado, Seeks Reform Party's Nomination
description: Richard D. Lamm, who left public office a decade ago after serving three terms as Governor of Colorado, announced today that he would seek the Presidential nomination of Ross Perot's Reform Party, setting up a possible showdown with Mr. Perot.

title: OLYMPICS;Women's Crew Route Seems Paved in Gold
description: At first glance, rowing might seem easy, a sport requiring strength but no particular skills. In the past, an occasional beginner may have found himself on an Olympic crew a year later.

title: Private Sector Can Handle Security Inquiries
description: To the Editor:

title: Working Woman Chooses Top Editor
description: Nancy Smith, the former executive editor of Conde Nast's Self magazine, was named editor in chief of Working Woman magazine yesterday. She succeeds Lynn Povich, now consulting editor at the new media venture begun by Microsoft and NBC.

title: Vacco Seeks Death Penalty In Police Officer's Shooting
description: Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco announced today that he would seek the death penalty against a man charged with killing a police officer during a Bronx shootout in March. The politically charged case now becomes the first prosecution in New York City under the state's new capital punishment law.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Kantor Takes Up Brown's Bosnia Mission
description: Commerce Secretary Mickey Kantor will set out on Wednesday to complete the trip on which his predecessor, Ronald H. Brown, died, escorting American business executives through Bosnia and Croatia to explore opportunities to reconstruct a land divided by war.

title: Death Penalty Sought In an Officer's Killing
description: The man accused of killing a police officer in the Bronx will be prosecuted under New York's death penalty statute, the first time that the law has been used for a crime in New York City. The decision was made by the State Attorney General, Dennis C. Vacco, who took over the politically charged case after the District Attorney Robert T. Johnson of the Bronx was removed from it because he would not commit to pursuing the death penalty in the slaying.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MALT-O-MEAL EXTENDS CEREAL PRICE-WAR TO VALUE PACKS
description: The Malt-O-Meal Company cut the price yesterday on 10 of its bagged cereals by an average of 12 percent, extending the cereal price war to value-priced packages. The cereals affected are Apple Cinnamon Toasty O's, Tootie Fruities, Corn Bursts, Golden Puffs, Honey Nut Toasty O's, Marshmallow Mateys, Colossal Crunch, Coco-Roos, Frosted Flakes and Toasty O's. Value-priced cereals, both bagged and store-label brands, represent the fastest-growing segment of the ready-to-eat cereal category over the last 10 years, the company, which is based in Minneapolis, said, citing recent data from A. C. Nielsen. So far, Kellogg, General Mills, the Post and Nabisco cereal division of Philip Morris and Quaker Oats have cut prices, but only on their branded boxed products. Late in June, the Quaker Oats Company, which also makes bagged cereals, said it would expand that product line but did not change its bagged cereal prices.

title: OLYMPICS;Worker Killed On Games Site
description: A construction worker died and another was injured today after copper tubing they were handling touched a power line on the roof of a building under renovation for use during the Olympics.

title: Rocking His Own Way, After Lollapalooza
description: In 1991, Perry Farrell, then the singer in Jane's Addiction, one of the bands that put alternative rock on the map, founded Lollapalooza. A traveling festival for today's teens and twentysomethings, Lollapalooza, like Woodstock, quickly became a symbol for a generation. But, disheartened by his loss of control of the festival, which is now run by music executives, Mr. Farrell disassociated himself from Lollapalooza last year. Now he is competing with the festival he founded.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Youth Guilty in Shootings
description: A teen-ager who prosecutors said was trying to settle a score when he fired shots through the window of an Atlantic City apartment last October was convicted yesterday in the slaying of one child and the crippling of another. The jury took less than four hours to find Maurice Williams, 16, guilty in the murder of 4-year-old Kareem Davis and the attempted murder of Kareem's 2-year-old brother, Taqiyy, whose spinal cord was severed by a bullet. The intended victim was the children's uncle, said Murray A. Talesnik, an assistant prosecutor for Atlantic County.

title: BATTLE AT THE BOARD OF EDUCATION: THE VOTE;Schools President Pledges Unity Behind Chancellor
description: Catapulted into the presidency of the Board of Education by a unanimous vote, William C. Thompson Jr. pledged yesterday to unify the disparate interests of the board, the Mayor, the City Council and the state behind the efforts of Chancellor Rudy Crew to bring reform to the nation's largest school system.

title: Intestinal Ailment Is Linked To Latin American Raspberries
description: Raspberries imported from Latin America have been linked to an intestinal ailment that has struck 114 New Jerseyans since May, health officials said yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SYMANTEC DECLINES AFTER LOW REVENUE REPORT
description: The stock of the Symantec Corporation fell yesterday after the company said its first-quarter revenues would fall short of estimates. Analysts had been expecting Symantec to report revenues about 5 percent higher than the level a year earlier of $109.9 million. Earnings for the period ended June 30 were expected to be about 20 cents a share, up from 13 cents a share a year ago, but analysts said that figure might also be adversely affected. The software utilities maker, based in Cupertino, Calif., declined to provide specifics. On the Nasdaq stock market, Symantec stock fell $1.375, to $10 a share.

title: Journal;An F.O.B.'s Lament
description: Tired of Clinton-bashing books featuring false allegations of liaisons at the Marriott and overhyped accounts of tete-a-tetes with Eleanor Roosevelt? "Stranger Among Friends," the new memoir by David Mixner rolling into stores this week, would seem the perfect antidote. Mr. Mixner, a prominent 60's activist who grew up to be a Democratic Party insider, has been a friend of Bill Clinton's since anti-war protest brought them together in 1969. He raised over $1 million for the '92 Clinton-Gore campaign. Speaking by phone from Los Angeles on the eve of his book tour, he says he will "absolutely" vote for Mr. Clinton this year and urges others "to do the same." What more sympathetic author could the President get?

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Joblessness Up Slightly Last Month
description: German unemployment rose by 3,000 after seasonal adjustment last month, to nearly 3.93 million people, as warmer weather failed to help the job market, the Federal Labor Office said yesterday. The unadjusted jobless rate, however, slipped to 9.9 percent in June from 10 percent in May. Last June, the rate was 9 percent.

title: Six Flags Plans to Build a 200-Acre Theme Park Near Foxwoods Casino
description: The nation's second-largest theme park company announced today that it wanted to build a park on 200 acres that the Mashantucket Pequot Tribe owns seven miles from its Foxwoods Resort Casino.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Sir EDWARD HEATH, the former British Prime Minister and leader of the Conservative Party, turned 80 yesterday, but one day of festivities was not enough to fill the bill. All told, eight parties are scheduled to celebrate the occasion. The first was on Saturday, and they will continue through the month. Yesterday, Sir Edward was honored at a private luncheon with Queen Elizabeth at Buckingham Palace, then attended a banquet at the palace for Nelson Mandela.

title: For Mississippi's Governor, Another Fight Over Power
description: Even in the annals of rough-and-tumble disputes between chief executives and state legislators, Gov. Kirk Fordice's in-your-face style stands out. But the Mississippi Governor's decision to appoint four white men to the board that governs the state's university system has touched off a battle royal with overtones of race and power politics.

title: CYCLING;Defiant Indurain Shows Some Signs Of Heating Up, as Does the Weather
description: Imagine the scene this morning in the Jet Hotel in the Italian town of Caselle Torinese. Miguel Indurain awoke to an unfamiliar light seeping through the curtains. His roommate, his brother Prudencio, was singing in a sweet tenor "O Sole Mio."

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: THE morning following our fairy-tale wedding at the Essex House, my new husband woke and stared out at the magnificent view of Central Park from our bridal suite on the 34th floor. Then he became very quiet. Some 10 minutes later, he turned to me with a stricken expression and said, "Honey, I don't know if I should tell you this or not. . . . "

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Barkley Awaits Verdict On His Team of Future
description: All the National Basketball Association's now-you-see-it, now-you-don't lockout did was prolong the expected flurry of trades and free-agent signings another 48 hours. It is 48 hours Charles Barkley could do without.

title: Hurricane Is Likely to Skirt U.S. Coast, Forecasters Say
description: Swirling out of the Caribbean with four people dead in its wake, Hurricane Bertha whipped up force today, menaced the Bahamas and headed for the eastern seaboard of the United States.

title: TV Notes;Those Busy Aliens
description: Seldom has a television network been better positioned to piggyback on the buzz from a big movie than NBC is in the enormous box office wake of "Independence Day."

title: Real Estate;Hoechst Celanese is moving its headquarters to a new building in Warren Township, N.J.
description: IN the largest office leasing transaction in New Jersey this year, the Hoechst Celanese Corporation, the fifth-largest chemical company in North America, will move its corporate headquarters to 30 Independence Avenue, a five-story, 207,727-square-foot building now under construction at the Somerset Hills Corporate Center in Warren Township.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Rollins to Join Edelman Office
description: Edward J. Rollins Jr., the Republican political consultant, is joining the New York office of Edelman Public Relations Worldwide as executive vice president and general manager for public affairs. Mr. Rollins, 53, succeeds James O. Cox 3d, 49, who joined the New York office of Hill & Knowlton, a unit of the WPP Group, as senior managing director for corporate communications.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Ellis Island Dispute in Court
description: New Jersey's lawsuit against New York for control of most of Ellis Island moves to the United States Supreme Court building today. A special master, Paul Verkuil, will hear New Jersey's claim that 24 acres of landfill added to the 3-acre island over the last century actually belong to New Jersey.

title: POLITICS: MAN IN THE NEWS;Sacred Cows Are His Favorite Prey: Richard Douglas Lamm
description: Blunt of speech and flinty of nature, Richard D. Lamm has long prided himself on displaying the hardness of his adopted Rocky Mountains.

title: What Inflation?
description: The economic news on Friday was so good it was a disaster. Unemployment has fallen to 5.3 percent, the lowest it has been in six years. June payrolls increased by 239,000 jobs. And the average hourly wage rose by 9 cents, the biggest one-month jump ever recorded, a level "noticeably above the inflation rate," as The New York Times reported.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Megan's Law' Is Questioned As Injunction Is Extended
description: With New Jersey prosecutors poised to resume informing schools, women's shelters and others about paroled sex offenders living near them, a Federal appeals court today blocked the notifications for the immediate future.

title: SAUDI BOMBERS GOT OUTSIDE SUPPORT, PERRY TELLS PANEL
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry said today that an "experienced and well-financed international terrorist organization" appeared to have provided support to the bombers who killed 19 American military airmen in Saudi Arabia last month.

title: ATLANTA 1996: NINE DAYS TO GO;Kenya Threatening to Ban Some of Its Athletes
description: With the opening ceremony of the Olympics a week from Friday, and Kenya desperate not to further dilute its prominence in international distance running, an ultimatum has been issued by the East African country's greatest sports hero to its current athletic stars: Get to the pre-Olympic training camp in Mississippi by Wednesday or risk being banned from the Summer Games.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Motorola Earnings Fall, Missing Forecasts
description: Hurt by declining sales of its semiconductor chips and cellular telephone equipment, Motorola Inc. reported lower-than-expected second-quarter earnings yesterday, missing most Wall Street forecasts by a wide margin.

title: A British Outsider Embraced With a French Blockbuster
description: Like many other cities, Paris now routinely uses blockbuster shows to revive interest in artists ranging from Poussin to Cezanne. But what distinguishes the major retrospective of Francis Bacon that just opened at the Georges Pompidou Center is that the British artist died only four years ago. Already, it seems, his work is considered ripe to be rediscovered.

title: Japanese Stocks Down
description: Japanese stocks were lower here today. At the close of trading, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 140.88 points, or more than six-tenths of 1 percent, at 21,778.94. On Tuesday, the Nikkei lost 5.12 points.

title: Invasion of the Audience-Snatchers
description: Independence Day," the new invaders-from-another-planet action movie, has been so fabulously successful in its opening week that people will be analyzing its Deeper Meaning well into the football season. This summer has already given us killer tornadoes that travel in herds, and Arnold Schwarzenegger fighting off Central Park Zoo alligators with the size and temperament of velociraptors. Yet it is the computer-generated space aliens that seem to have grabbed the nation's imagination.

title: Picture Billboards and Elk on Your Postcards;Let Freedom Cost
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Irvin Defense Casts Doubt on Evidence
description: The tiny amount of cocaine found on the only item belonging to MICHAEL IRVIN could have been spread inadvertently by the police's sloppy handling of evidence, a narcotics officer testified yesterday during the felony drug possession trial of the Cowboys star in Dallas.

title: Disregarding Pure Politics
description: As a matter of pure politics, Republicans in Congress have handled the minimum wage as an exercise in snatching defeat from the jaws of defeat. Or at least snatching prolonged, painful defeat from the jaws of quick, change-the-subject defeat.

title: Melvin Belli Dies at 88; Flamboyant Lawyer Relished His Role as Kingof Torts
description: Melvin Belli, an impressario of a lawyer who pioneered new techniques and huge settlements in personal injury cases and who defended Jack Ruby, the man who shot and killed Lee Harvey Oswald, died yesterday at his home in San Francisco. He was 88.

title: New Curators at Guggenheim
description: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum announced three new appointments yesterday. Robert Rosenblum and Mark Rosenthal will be curators of 20th-century art, and John G. Hanhardt will be the senior curator of film and media arts.

title: First Job for the New School Team
description: For the first time in many years, New York City's Mayor, Board of Education and Schools Chancellor appear capable of working in harmony. Yesterday's unanimous election of William Thompson Jr. as the new board president might actually open up an era when all the people in charge of the million-student system are pulling in the same direction.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the role of late-night television comedy in Presidential politics misspelled the surname of the influential columnist cited as the archetype of election commentators in an earlier age. He was Walter Lippmann, not Lippman.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KANSAS CITY POWER RESISTS HOSTILE TAKEOVER
description: The Kansas City Power and Light Company formally recommended yesterday that shareholders reject the latest attempt by Western Resources Inc. at a hostile takeover of the utility -- a $1.9 billion direct offer -- and reaffirmed its decision to merge with Utilicorp United Inc. Western Resources, based in Topeka, Kan., is offering Kansas City shareholders $31 a share in Western Resources stock in exchange for their Kansas City stock in a tax-free deal valued at $1.9 billion. The friendly merger offer by Utilicorp, which is based in Kansas City, Mo., is valued at about $1.67 billion. Kansas City shareholders are scheduled to vote Aug. 7 on the proposal.

title: Republican Primary for Nunn's Senate Seat Leads to a Runoff
description: A wealthy Atlanta businessman who nearly won Georgia's 1994 gubernatorial campaign finished first tonight in the six-man race for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate seat being vacated by Sam Nunn.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Teen-Ager Dies After Storm
description: A Passaic teen-ager who sought refuge from Monday night's storms in a flood tunnel at Weasel Brook Park died yesterday at Beth Israel Hospital in Passaic. The Clifton police said that Roberto Gonzales, 15, and a friend, a 15-year-old girl, were in the tunnel when the water began to rise rapidly. Sgt. Richard Berdnick said that Roberto helped the friend scale a concrete retaining wall and chain-link fence but was unable to escape himself.

title: Licensing-Exam Cheaters Face N.A.S.D. Ban
description: Dozens of stockbrokers have been caught paying others to take the basic licensing exam that allows them to work as brokers, an official of the National Association of Securities Dealers said yesterday. He said the association would try to kick those brokers out of the industry permanently.

title: POLITICS: COLIN POWELL;On a New York Visit, Political Questions Buzz Around Powell
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell resurfaced yesterday, going from one Manhattan broadcast studio to another and zipping through the South Bronx neighborhood where he grew up. Everywhere he went, the one topic he seemed not to want to talk about -- Republican Presidential politics -- kept coming up.

title: Picture Billboards and Elk on Your Postcards;Keep Gateway Marina
description: To the Editor:

title: Aging, and Clasping The Mortal Coil;Raves for 'Shakespeare With Bob'
description: Sir, in my heart there was a kind of fighting

title: Prudential Agrees to Pay $35.3 Million In State Fines
description: The Prudential Insurance Company of America, the largest life insurer in North America, agreed yesterday to pay a record $35.3 million in fines and reimburse customers across the country as a group of state regulators issued a sweeping, stinging rebuke to what it called widespread abuses by the company in the sale of life insurance.

title: Mansura Journal;Of College Girls Betrayed and Vile Chewing Gum
description: If it is true, as it is whispered here, that certain young women in this provincial capital have let their moral standards lapse, then no one wants to believe they fell prey to hormones alone. No, the cause -- the curse, it is said -- was ordinary-looking chewing gum laced with aphrodisiacs capable of transporting the most innocent female into a sexual frenzy.

title: Well-Services Acquisition
description: Dawson Production Services Inc., which provides contract services to oil and natural-gas producers that have wells in Texas and Louisiana, has agreed to acquire the Taylor Service Company. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Taylor, which had sales of $17 million in 1995, provides fluids that are circulated in wells during drilling to cool and lubricate the bit and remove well cuttings. The company operates in eastern and central Texas.

title: Nurses' One-Day Strike: Jobs vs. Cost Cuts
description: After 22 years as a nurse at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, Sheila O'Rourke says she has a big fear: that the hospital is abandoning its altruistic mission in favor of a corporate mentality in which workers are laid off or shuffled around like pawns.

title: Private Sector Can Handle Security Inquiries;My Summer Internship
description: To the Editor:

title: Wine Talk
description: ONCE upon a time a week or two ago it sometimes seems -- the western reaches of the Loire river were a long way from Paris. The trip took a day or two, down through Chartres and Le Mans to meet the river, then along its banks to Ancenis and finally Nantes, where the sky is pale and clear, the air smells of the sea and the tense, gritty capital is out of sight and mind.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;U.S. Bonds Rise as Yield Falls to 7.13%
description: Treasury prices recovered somewhat yesterday, following robust demand at an auction of new 10-year notes.

title: HOCKEY;Amicable Parting of Ways For Islanders and Flatley
description: The Islanders cut their last tie to the glory years of the early 1980's yesterday when they released their captain, Patrick Flatley. Although Flatley did not play for any of the Islanders' Stanley Cup championship teams from 1980 to 1983, he was a rookie on the 1984 team that lost to the Edmonton Oilers in the finals.

title: COMPANY NEWS;NATIONAL GOLF BUYS 4 GOLF COURSES IN THE WEST
description: National Golf Properties said yesterday that it had exercised options to purchase four golf courses for about $31.6 million. The courses are the Ancala Country Club, a private country club in Scottsdale,Ariz., for $8.5 million; Arrowhead Country Club, a private country club in Glendale, Ariz., for $6 million; Blacklake Golf Course in Nipomo, Calif., for $11 million, and Painted Desert Golf Course in Las Vegas, Nev., for $6.1 million. Each course would be leased to the American Golf Corporation, the biggest golf course management company in the United States. National Golf Properties, based in Santa Monica, Calif., is a real estate investment trust that owns 90 golf courses in 23 states.

title: Personal Health
description: MOST of us are not and will never be Olympic athletes. We are not obliged to train day after day to improve our performance in a particular activity. Yet many amateur players and ordinary fitness buffs act as if their chosen activity was the only one they could or would want to do. They are the Johnny One Notes of exercise.

title: Military School's Equal
description: To the Editor:

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;A Polenta for Today And for Tomorrow
description: Today's recipe for polenta is good when first made and as a leftover. Reheat it in a microwave or in the oven. Serve it with a mesclun salad from the supermarket, invigorated with strongly flavored herbs and greens.

title: Food Notes
description: Bastille Day Fetes

title: Officials Urge Parents Not to Panic Over School Ruling
description: Seeking to dispel fears about forced busing and redrawn school boundaries, top state officials today called for calm in the wake of the landmark state Supreme Court decision declaring the segregation in the Hartford schools a violation of the state's Constitution.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Birdie Amsterdam, 95, a Pioneer for Female Judges in New York
description: Justice Birdie Amsterdam, who achieved several judicial firsts, including being the first woman elected to the New York State Supreme Court, died on Monday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 95 and lived on the Lower East Side, just steps from where she was born.

title: IN THE KITCHEN WITH: Marcus Samuelsson;From Africa to Sweden to Aquavit
description: THE lunch crowd, exuding expectation, has arrived at Restaurant Aquavit, a Swedish restaurant in a onetime Rockefeller-family brownstone that has been earning raves for its young executive chef, Marcus Samuelsson.

title: A Start-Up Gets Licensing Deal
description: Sony Electronics Inc. and the Philips Consumer Electronics Company have decided to license technology from a Palo Alto, Calif., start-up company, Webtv Networks,for a set-top box for viewing the Internet

title: K.E. Fields, Engineer Who Led Atomic Energy Unit, Dies at 87
description: Brig. Gen. Kenneth E. Fields, whose military career took him from the pinnacle of his class at West Point to battle for the bridge at Remagen, Germany, and on to the Manhattan Project and then to civilian eminence at the Atomic Energy Commission, died on July 1 at the Homestead, a nursing home in Stamford, Conn.

title: Hartford Court Bars Imbalance In the Schools
description: Connecticut's Supreme Court ruled today that the racial segregation in Hartford's public schools is unconstitutional, and called on the General Assembly to remedy the disparity between suburban schools and those of the city, which serve black and Hispanic students almost exclusively.

title: Foreign Affairs;Speed Bump Ahead
description: Ever since Russia and China embarked on their separate paths of reform there's been a competition between the two over who got it right. In this race, China was always viewed as the hare, which rushed ahead with economic reform, leaving political reform for later. Russia was always viewed as the tortoise, which, stupidly in the minds of the Chinese, tried to do political and economic reform at once. Well, don't count the tortoise out yet.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PETCO AGREES TO ACQUIRE PET NOSH FOR $16 MILLION
description: Petco Animal Supplies Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Pet Nosh Inc., a closely held operator of pet food and supply stores in the New York area, for about $16.6 million in Petco stock. Petco said it would issue about 615,000 shares of its common stock to acquire all the outstanding shares of Pet Nosh. Based on Petco's closing price of $27 on Monday, the transaction is valued at about $16.6 million. Petco shares were up 50 cents yesterday, at $27.50, in Nasdaq trading. Pet Nosh operates eight pet food and supply stores in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. It had sales of about $26 million for the latest 12 months. With the addition of Pet Nosh, Petco will operate 75 stores on the East Coast and 274 stores nationally.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Senate Passes a Bill To Raise the Minimum Wage The Senate approved a bill to raise the Federal minimum wage to $5.15 an hour, virtually assuring a 90-cent pay increase for as many as 13 million Americans. The final vote was 74 to 24, with 27 Republicans joining all 47 Democrats in favor. But the crucial vote came earlier, on a Republican amendment that would have exempted many employers from paying the new wage. Five Republicans joined the Democrats to defeat the amendment.

title: METROPOLITAN GOLF REPORT
description: Westchester Open

title: Key Russian Legislator Accuses Leading Military Officers of Graft
description: In an early test of President Boris N. Yeltsin's promise to root out corruption if re-elected, the retired general who heads Parliament's defense committee has accused some of Russia's highest-ranking generals of enriching themselves from the military budget.

title: Six Makers of CD's Accused of Price-Fixing
description: The nation's six largest makers of compact disks have been accused of scheming to keep CD prices artificially high in a lawsuit that could result in payments to millions of buyers.

title: Tapie Is Declared Bankrupt and Faces Prison
description: PARIS  Bernard Tapie, a symbol of France's easy-money culture in the 1980s, was confirmed as being bankrupt on Tuesday by the highest appeals court in France, making it more likely that he will serve time in prison.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Merger Creates Giant Cocoa Company
description: Callebaut A.G., a unit of the Swiss company Klaus J. Jacobs Holding, agreed yesterday to buy the French cocoa processor Cacao Barry, creating a giant in the world cocoa market. The combined operation will be called Callebaut Barry and will be based in Zurich. "The new company will process approximately 15 percent of the worldwide cocoa bean crop," Callebaut said.

title: BASEBALL;National League Subs Top American League's Best
description: Replacement players led the National League to a 6-0 victory over the American League in the All-Star Game tonight, but there was no replacement for Cal Ripken Jr. despite the broken nose he suffered before the game in a bizarre mishap.

title: Sports of The Times;All-Star Tale: A Godfather And Godson
description: WHEN the Los Angeles Dodgers drafted Mike Piazza as a teen-age catcher in the 62d round in 1988, the front office did it as a favor to Tom Lasorda, his godfather. And in last night's All-Star Game, the godson from nearby Phoenixville, Pa., returned the favor.

title: On Tolerating Casualties and Other Costs of War
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Deal Is a Lock, Not a Lockout, For the N.B.A.
description: In a bizarre day of negotiations, the National Basketball Association ended the shortest lockout in sports history yesterday by reaching a tentative agreement with its players on a collective bargaining agreement.

title: FILM REVIEW;Life as a Sleuth Is Good, Until Her Nanny Moves Out
description: It would be a shame, but not a surprise, if a very young audience weaned on action-adventure cartoons finds the film adaptation of Louise Fitzhugh's 1964 children's book, "Harriet the Spy," too sweetly demure to capture their imagination. This mutedly poignant film about a smart young girl's up-and-down relationship with her sixth-grade peers is virtually gadget-free. When it revs its engines, the volume never rises above a polite hum.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Johnson Still Unsigned by Jets
description: With rookie camp opening on Sunday, the Jets have yet to sign Keyshawn Johnson, the top pick over all in the National Football League draft. Until they do, he, like any unsigned player, will be unable to participate.

title: U.N. Starts Digging Up Mass Grave in Bosnia
description: United Nations war crimes investigators exhuming a mass grave in Bosnia unearthed nearly a dozen bodies today at a site believed to hold the remains of some of the thousands of Muslims slain last year by Bosnian Serbs after the fall of Srebrenica.

title: Boxed In
description: People say I can't have it both ways. Yes, I'm part black and part white, but every day I am forced to choose one or the other. On mortgage applications, school forms and on the decennial United States census, I've been asked to pick from four exclusive categories: black, white, American Indian and Asian and Pacific Islander.

title: Enron Can Resume Big Indian Power Project
description: The Enron Development Corporation received approval today from the Indian Government to proceed with a controversial $2 billion power project in a western state of India.

title: U.S. Ready to Supply Muslim-Croat Army
description: President Clinton announced today that the American-led effort to train and equip the army of the Muslim-Croat Federation in Bosnia would begin immediately, now that the federation has adopted a law to merge the Muslim and Bosnian Croat armies.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;McDonald's Plans Olympics Promotion
description: The McDonald's Corporation will introduce a consumer promotion on Sunday that is tied to its sponsorship of the Summer Olympics in Atlanta. The promotion, called "USA wins you win," runs through Aug. 4 and is based on the medal-winning performances of American athletes at the Games. It offers prizes valued at more than $5 million, which include automobiles, vacations and free menu items. Game pieces will be affixed to packaging of products like the Arch Deluxe sandwich, french fries and soft drinks. The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago will handle consumer advertising for the promotion, which was created by Simon Marketing in Oak Brook, Ill.

title: Candidates for President Turn to the Web
description: With a sense of mingled urgency and uncertainty, Bill Clinton and Bob Dole are stepping up their campaigns in cyberspace.

title: Business Travel;The cost of doing business on the road is expected to increase by 4.7% next year.
description: THE cost of traveling for business will rise 4.7 percent next year, led by an 8.5 percent increase in car rentals and a 7.5 percent advance in lodging costs. Air travel, which amounts to about 41 percent of total travel spending, and ground transportation will each increase 4 percent.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Acquisitions Set By National Media
description: The National Media Corporation in Philadelphia, which specializes in infomercials, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire another infomercial company, Hawthorne Communications Inc. in Fairfield, Iowa. Terms of the deal, which is expected to be completed this month, were not disclosed. Hawthorne has created infomercials for large marketers like Apple Computer Inc. and the Braun A.G. unit of the Gillette Company. The news of the acquisition came a day after National Media completed the purchase of two other companies specializing in infomercials -- Prestige Marketing, which is based in New Zealand, and Suzanne Paul, which is based in Australia -- for about $22 million in cash and stock.

title: Key Anniversary for Protestants Brings Tension in Ulster to a Boil
description: The British Government refused today to rescind a police order that has led to three days of demonstrations and violence by thousands of Protestants in Northern Ireland.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Picture Billboards and Elk on Your Postcards
description: To the Editor:

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Soars on Sale to Egypt; Natural Gas Prices in Retreat
description: Wheat prices surged on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after Egypt bought more than 10 million bushels from the United States, ending a recent lull in export sales.

title: Executive Changes
description: ADVANSTAR HOLDINGS INC., Boston, a closely held unit of the investment firm Hellman & Friedman, said it had named Robert Krakoff as its chairman and chief executive.

title: Netanyahu Airs Differences With Clinton on Peace Issues
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, after his first meeting with President Clinton, made it clear today that his new Government had important differences with the Americans on the approach to peace in the Middle East.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Celebrating a Drugstore
description: In many places, the opening of a new Rite-Aid drugstore would not be cause for major municipal celebration. But in Newark, where Rite-Aid has been the biggest revitalizing force on the retail scene during the last decade, today's ribbon-cutting at a 6,000-square-foot store on Clinton Avenue is expected to draw a large crowd of city leaders.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Since 1994, VINCENT La SELVA, the founder and director of the New York Grand Opera, has been leading the company through the 28-opera Verdi repertory, to be done in chronological order over seven years.

title: Warmer China Talks Yield Plan for Visits
description: After two days of meetings in Beijing that gave signs of warming relations between the United States and China, both sides said yesterday that they expect President Clinton to visit China next year if he is re-elected. In return, President Jiang Zemin of China would visit Washington.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: OLYMPICS;Greek Basketball Team Disrupts Flight
description: Members of the Greek Olympic basketball team refused to stop smoking on a flight from Athens to New York yesterday and had to promise to behave before getting on their connecting flight to the Atlanta Games.

title: Skirmishes in a Tug-of-War With a Refrigerator Door
description: BLAME the talking pig.

title: Brother of Ex-Agriculture Chief Is Indicted by Federal Grand Jury
description: A Federal grand jury in New Orleans today indicted Henry W. Espy Jr., a brother of Mike Espy, the former Secretary of Agriculture, on charges of making false statements to obtain bank loans to pay off campaign debts.

title: Slower Takeoffs for Delta After Deaths
description: Delta Air Lines advised its pilots today to take off more slowly to reduce engine stress, after Federal investigators said a crack in a metal hub might have been the cause of an engine's ripping apart on Saturday, killing two passengers on a Delta jet taxiing for takeoff here.

title: BOXING;Poland's Great Hope Is Ready For Bowe
description: Boxing -- especially heavyweight boxing, with its capacity for instant justice -- is always about the possible.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday, about the changing length of a day on Earth, misstated a new finding. Scientists' figures suggest that one year, or one orbit, once lasted 481 days, not that Earth once took 481 times as long as it does now to complete one orbit of the Sun.

title: Market Place;People close to Apple don't rule out a sale of some of its parts.
description: ARE slices of Apple Computer up for sale?

title: An Unbalanced Labor Law Proposal
description: The Republican-led Senate, after grudgingly handing workers a well-deserved boost in the minimum wage, is to vote today on handing employers an undeserved gift. The Team Act would undermine a 61-year-old prohibition on company-dominated unions by permitting managers in non-union workplaces to pick workers with whom to discuss subjects like wages and working conditions. Current law limits such conversations to representatives of labor picked by workers, not by management. There may come a time when these restrictions can be lifted, but that time is not now.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Big, Bold, Outside: Billboards Back in Fashion
description: All of a sudden, it seems, outdoor advertising is growing again to be as big as -- well, all outdoors.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the lawyer Melvin Belli that was published in some copies yesterday misidentified several of his six children. They are Richard R. Belli, Johnnie Ballantine, Jeannie Belli, Suzi Coffman, Melvin Caesar Belli and Melia Belli. (The obituary is reprinted today on page B13.)

title: School Principal Is Accused of Rape
description: A high school principal has been charged with raping a girl in his hometown of Stafford, the police said today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Schools Won't Mark March
description: Students in Pleasantville will not mark the anniversary of last October's Million Man March as a school holiday after all, the city's school board president said yesterday. The board had approved a calendar change in May that also canceled the traditional Veterans Day holiday. On Tuesday, the Atlantic County Board of Freeholders voted to ask the board to reconsider. Lincoln Green, the school board president, said all nine members favored restoring the Million Man March anniversary as a school day but without giving students Veterans Day off. The board will vote on July 23.

title: U.S. Oil Dependency
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawmakers Survive First Tests
description: Two black members of Congress from Georgia won impressive victories in Democratic primaries in newly drawn, white-majority districts on Tuesday, a testament to the power of incumbency, organization and maybe, just maybe, the diminishing influence of race on Southern politics.

title: Atlanta 1996: 8 Days To Go;Atlanta's Restaurants Set for Feeding Frenzy
description: The way Ken Storr sees things, the only difference between his Olympic event and the on-field competition is that the Olympic athletes are allowed to sleep.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;U.S. and Japan Apart on Chips
description: Japanese and American trade negotiators made little progress in two days of discussions about foreign access to Japan's semiconductor market, a United States official said today.

title: Kamsky, Trudging On, To Play Another Day
description: Anatoly Karpov and Gata Kamsky adjourned Game 18 of the world championship in an even position yesterday in Elista, Russia. So, until play is completed today, the match score remains Karpov 10, Kamsky 7.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Patented Plants

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Of Love, Fear and Quantum Physics
description: ON WITH THE STORY Stories By John Barth 257 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $23.95.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Sony, CBS and Talent Firm Join in TV Production Deal
description: CBS and the television production studio of the Sony Corporation announced a partnership yesterday with 3 Arts Entertainment Inc., a growing Hollywood management firm, to create an entity that will produce television shows for the network.

title: G.I.'s in Baltic Maneuvers
description: United States troops are joining the first land-based military exercise under a NATO banner held in the Baltic states, once a Soviet front-line area, military officials said today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Joyner Back in Padres' Lineup
description: WALLY JOYNER, sidelined since breaking his left thumb June 2, will rejoin the San Diego Padres' starting lineup tonight at Colorado. "I'm ready to go. Thumbs up," Joyner said yesterday.

title: BASEBALL;Conquering More Than Strike Zone
description: There was trouble with Dwight Gooden. Mel Stottlemyre popped out of the Yankee dugout and made his way to the mound to talk to the tall, sweating pitcher as the Brewers threatened in the fifth inning of a game last week.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Auto Quietly Poisons Couple
description: A couple who apparently did not realize that their luxury car's quiet engine was left running died of carbon monoxide poisoning Tuesday night, the authorities said. Irwin Stern, 69, drove his Infiniti into his garage and forgot to shut off the engine, Melaine Campbell, the Acting Somerset County Prosecutor, said yesterday. Mr. Stern and his wife, Elinor, 68, died when the central air-conditioning system circulated carbon monoxide from the garage through the house, Ms. Campbell said.

title: No Headline
description: We are seeing things that are 20 times better than we had seen on Ganymede before. Coming into the lab the last two weeks, it's been like Christmas every day."

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;China Shuns U.S. Partners for 100-Seat Jet
description: China's main manufacturer of civil aircraft announced today that it would team up with European and Singaporean partners to build a planned 100-seat commercial jet, dealing a blow to the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

title: 5 Nations Discuss Steps to Oust Indicted Bosnian Serb Leaders
description: Representatives of the five-nation "contact group" on Bosnia met here today to discuss what to do about the continued power of the Bosnian Serb political leader, Radovan Karadzic, and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the military commander -- both of whom have been indicted for war crimes and, under the Dayton peace accord, are supposed to be arrested.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Barkley Helps U.S. Roll Before Hometown Fans
description: The Chinese Olympians brought watches. The Americans gave them T-shirts.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Camden Starts on Reforms
description: Some good news from Camden, for a change. After being criticized by the state for mishandling its finances, the city has put more than 50 recommendations into effect, including cutting down on overtime and eliminating personnel, The Associated Press reported. These changes have netted $10 million in savings and revenues, according to a report by a city task force that was released yesterday. "We see this report as a step in the right direction," said Jane M. Kenney, State Community Affairs Commissioner. But she said Camden needs to develop "a more comprehensive management strategy." TERRY PRISTIN

title: COMPANY NEWS;J. C. PENNEY IN TALKS TO BUY FAY'S DRUGSTORES
description: The J. C. Penney Company is in talks to buy Fay's Inc., a move that would expand J. C. Penney's Thrift Drug chain. Fay's, the 12th-biggest drugstore chain in the United States, has 272 stores, less than half the number owned by Thrift Drug, the 9th-biggest chain, with 645 stores. Fay's stock rose $1.375, or almost 16 percent, to $10. At that price its market capitalization is about $209 million. Sales at Fay's, based in Liverpool, N.Y., rose 5.5 percent in the first quarter, to $248.6 million, with same-store sales, or sales in stores open at least a year, rising 4.4 percent. Thrift Drug's sales in its latest fiscal year rose to $1.85 billion from $1.54 billion in the period a year earlier.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Dallas Extends Newton's Deal
description: NATE NEWTON, an All-Pro offensive guard, signed a one-year contract extension with the Dallas Cowboys. He will be under contract through the 1998 season. Terms of the extension were not released. (AP)

title: Hoechst Will Cut Its Drug Unit Free
description: The German chemical and drug company Hoechst A.G. said today that it would announce plans early next year to turn its core drug business into an independent legal entity, opening the possibility of a later stock market listing.

title: LEADERS IN ALBANY CLEAR ROADBLOCK TO A NEW BUDGET
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and state legislative leaders announced a tentative agreement late Wednesday night on revamping the state's $5 billion system of compensating injured workers, opening the way for final passage of the latest budget in state history.

title: World News Briefs;Colombia Announces Major Cabinet Shake-Up
description: The Government announced today that Foreign Minister Rodrigo Pardo had resigned and would be replaced by the Education Minister, Maria Emma Mejia. No explanation was given for Mr. Pardo's resignation.

title: In Netanyahu, Congress Sees Familiar Spin
description: The new Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, put his deep knowledge of American politics and lingo to work today, moving with verve through the stations of official Washington and spreading his message of Israeli self-reliance and skepticism about Arab intentions.

title: Brutal Attack Kills 3 Queens Women; 2 Others Survive
description: Three women were killed and a fourth was bludgeoned into unconsciousness in a house in South Jamaica, Queens, early yesterday morning. A fifth woman, who was assaulted and nearly strangled, escaped the carnage by jumping from a second-floor window.

title: Birobidzhan Journal;A Promised Land in Siberia? Well, Thanks, but . . .
description: The capital of the Jewish Autonomous Region does not have a synagogue.

title: BOXING: NOTEBOOK;Bowe Is Back in Town And Ready for a Fight
description: Although he wears his New Yorkness with as much pride as he once held the heavyweight crown, Riddick Bowe has not fought in his hometown for more than three years.

title: COMPANY NEWS;P.& G. TO BUY BACK UP TO $1 BILLION OF STOCK
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said yesterday that it planned to buy back up to $1 billion of its common stock in its current fiscal year. Based on the company's recent stock price, the buyback represents up to 11 million shares, or about 1.6 percent of its 686 million shares outstanding. Share of P.& G. rose 25 cents, to $88.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. The buyback is in addition to a program that P.& G. began last year to buy back 4 million to 5 million shares annually. P.& G.'s board also raised its annual dividend to $1.80 a share from $1.60, an increase of 12.5 percent. The first quarterly dividend at the new rate will be paid on Aug. 15. P.& G., which is based in Cincinnati and whose products include Tide laundry detergent and Crest toothpaste, has annual sales of more than $33 billion.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Financing Secured By Deutsche Babcock
description: Deutsche Babcock's main banks have agreed to provide financing for reorganizing the money-losing German engineering company, a spokesman for BHF-Bank A.G., said. Babcock's major banks also include Commerzbank, Deutsche Bank, Dresdner Bank and Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale. Officials from several of the banks said about 500 million German marks, or $327 million, was to be provided.

title: Evacuations Ordered as Hurricane Heads Toward U.S.
description: With Hurricane Bertha moving at 10 to 15 miles an hour toward the United States mainland, meteorologists with the National Hurricane Center here spent today issuing odds on the chances that the storm would strike cities on or near the Atlantic Ocean.

title: AT HOME WITH DR. MICHAEL PALMER;From Despair To Best Sellers
description: AT various times in his life, some overlapping, Dr. Michael Palmer has been a best-selling author of medical thrillers, an emergency-room physician, an actor, a tournament bridge player, a biochemist.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Betty Turock, the departing president of the American Library Association, included an outdated description of her position at Rutgers University. She is a former chairwoman of the Department of Library and Information Studies at Rutgers; the chairman of that department now is David Carr.

title: Man Linked To Mob Loses Spot at Market
description: In recent years, Joseph Macario, the owner of a successful company at the Fulton Fish Market, acquired the nickname Joe Chief.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;It's Summer, So It's Time Of Course For Mozart
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra's opener at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday offered gentle entry into what will be the busiest musical midsummer in recent memory. The Lincoln Center Festival '96, now two weeks away, is preparing the kinds of cultural jolts this ingratiating evening would have recoiled from. Here, indeed, were two tried-and-true Mozartean masterpieces, prefaced by a cheery, harmless Concerto Grosso in D by Gottfried Heinrich Stolzel and separated by speeches of mutual congratulation by various Lincoln Center officials and city politicians.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;Strauss In Varied Moods
description: When American soldiers threatened in 1945 to commandeer Richard Strauss's Alpine home, the aging composer declared from his porch, "I am the composer of 'Rosenkavalier' and 'Salome.' " Improbably, the soldiers knew the music and left him alone. Those operas have remained Strauss's most famous and his most often recorded. "Elektra" and "Capriccio" show the composer in a less accommodating mood. One is all coiled terror; the other, lyrical melancholy, layered with jests.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: Budget Roadblock Is Cleared Governor Pataki and state legislative leaders announced a tentative agreement on revamping the state's $5 billion system of compensating injured workers, opening the way for final passage of the latest budget in state history. The deal also allowed the Legislature to extend for 36 hours a law that protects thousands of loft tenants in New York City just as it was set to expire. [Page A1.]

title: Ashe Statue Joins Those of Confederates
description: The city that barred young Arthur Ashe from its whites-only tennis courts dedicated a monument to him today on a boulevard lined with statues of Confederate heroes.

title: BASEBALL;All-Star Game Rating Declines
description: The All-Star Game on Tuesday night on NBC generated a 13.2 Nielsen rating, down from a 13.9 in 1995, and the lowest it has ever achieved in prime time.

title: U.S., Enforcing Cuba Curbs, Punishes Canadian Company
description: The Administration struck today for the first time against foreign companies operating in Cuba, informing the top executives and the biggest shareholders of a Canadian mining concern that they and their families will be barred from the United States, State Department officials said.

title: POLITICS: REFORM PARTY;Perot Proclaims His Willingness To Carry His Party's Banner
description: Just one day after former Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado launched his bid for the Presidential nomination of Ross Perot's Reform Party, Mr. Perot went on television this evening and reiterated his willingness to run again if that is what party supporters wanted.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VOLUNTEER CAPITAL TO SELL ITS WENDY'S FRANCHISES
description: The Volunteer Capital Corporation said yesterday that it would sell its Wendy's franchised restaurants to Wendy's International Inc. for $28 million so that it could focus on restaurants that offer casual dining. The company, which also operates J. Alexander's restaurants, has been one of the largest Wendy's franchisees. The sale is expected to include 52 of 58 Wendy's in four states, and the remaining six units would be sold or closed. Volunteer Capital said the sale would have a negative impact on its earnings for the next 18 months. The company's shares rose 50 cents, to $10.25.

title: AT&T Plans to Bill Customers Directly For Long Distance
description: The AT&T Corporation said yesterday that it would send bills directly to its New York customers, starting next month.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANGELA BUCHANAN will become a co-anchor of "Equal Time" on CNBC, replacing Mary Matalin as the conservative counterpoint to Dee Dee Myers, The Associated Press reported yesterday. Ms. Matalin will leave the program after three years. Bay Buchanan, as she is called, the former treasurer and campaign manager for the bid by her brother Patrick J. Buchanan to become the Republican Presidential candidate, said she looks forward to the career shift and to working with Ms. Myers.

title: Assembly Adds Its Approval to Bill That Alters Election Law
description: The State Assembly unanimously approved legislation tonight that would make one of the biggest changes in decades to New York's election law, doing away with many of the niggling rules that incumbents have long used as a weapon to throw challengers off the ballot.

title: INSIDE
description: 3 Women Slain in Queens

title: BASEBALL;Yanks Don't Want to Make Waves at Top
description: Joe Torre, who has proved to be a shrewd manager for the Yankees in the first half of the season, was observant enough to know that Darryl Strawberry's return to the Bronx would overshadow any events on the field. So Torre decided to summon Strawberry from Class AAA Columbus last Sunday and desperately hoped the distractions would disappear when the Yankees initiated the second half tonight in Baltimore.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Rivers Heading to the Booth
description: DOC RIVERS, the former Knick guard, was hired yesterday as a broadcast analyst by Turner Sports. (AP)

title: Hartford to Seek Voluntary Desegregation
description: Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut said yesterday that he wanted to use voluntary measures to remedy the segregation in Hartford schools that the state's high court ruled unconstitutional, such as letting urban parents choose to send their children to suburban schools.

title: Robbing The Garden's Cradle
description: IT wasn't until I lived in Provence that I discovered the joys of the potager. In this classic French kitchen garden -- a mingling of herbs, vegetables and a few cutting flowers designed to provide a home with food and bouquets the year round -- I found almost instant gratification. And if you don't have a rural plot, never fear. The lessons of a potager can be followed in a side yard, on a sunny city terrace or in a reclaimed neighborhood lot.

title: A Trump Garage Sale
description: DONALD J. TRUMP is selling himself again. Last year he paid $7.5 million for Seven Springs, a 200-acre estate in Bedford, N.Y. On Tuesday, he is auctioning 140 pieces of furniture and art from a 14-bedroom chateau on the property, along with 10 pieces from Mar-a-Lago, his estate in Palm Beach, Fla. The auction will be at Christie's East in Manhattan.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Free Agents Line Up In Force For Tip-Off
description: Charles Barkley is probably headed to Houston. Larry Johnson could be headed to the Knicks. And many free agents are headed for the bank.

title: Market Place;The S.E.C. says it happened: a corner in the Treasury market.
description: CORNER the Treasury market?

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Justice Clouded By Doubt
description: The ideal of journalistic balance, elusive at best, is pursued once again in tonight's unusual collaboration between HBO and Court TV. The HBO documentary "Mumia Abu-Jamal: A Case for Reasonable Doubt?" will be shown on Court TV at 9. It will be followed at 10 by a Court TV panel discussion, "Fair or Foul? The Case of Mumia Abu-Jamal," about the documentary and legal issues raised by the case. The result: something approaching oversaturation.

title: For First Time, Woman Heads Supreme Court
description: The first woman to preside over the New Jersey Supreme Court, Deborah T. Poritz, was sworn in as Chief Justice today in a festive ceremony held before an audience of state legislative leaders, cabinet members, judges and former governors.

title: Probe of Jupiter Finds Surprises On a Big Moon
description: On its first close encounter with Jupiter's huge satellite Ganymede, the Galileo spacecraft has found evidence that this largest moon in the solar system behaves in many surprising ways like a full-fledged planet.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;Clinton Presses Dole on Assault Weapons Ban
description: President Clinton today moved to box in his Republican challenger, Bob Dole, on an issue that divides Republican voters: restricting assault weapons.

title: Crime (and Punishment) Rages Anew in China
description: The corpse of the taxi driver was still warm in the back seat when Liao Yongxiong, age 29, pulled up in front of the Lian Yuan Street branch of the Industrial and Commerce Bank here in the car he had just hijacked.

title: Court Promotion Raises Questions of Nepotism
description: As chairman of the Suffolk County Republican Committee, John Powell helped to elect George E. Pataki as Governor by producing more votes than any other county in the state. This fall, he hopes to help elect a President by delivering a winning majority of New York State voters for Bob Dole.

title: Piety, but No Help, On Illegal Aliens
description: When Republicans regained control of Congress two years ago, few promises from the new majority struck a deeper chord with Americans than the one to free communities from unfair and unfinanced mandates imposed by Washington. Congress passed a bill prohibiting the practice, and, with great flourish, President Clinton signed it into law.

title: Proposed Rule on H.M.O.'s Didn't Meet Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayhap to Dwell In a Morris House
description: WILLIAM MORRIS, that eminent Victorian entrepreneur, would have relished the commercial zeal his centenary has inspired. Along with a blockbuster exhibition at the Victoria and Albert Museum, and lectures, conferences and books, Morris devotees can also buy ceramics, wallpapers, tapestry kits, fabrics and a new spectrum of paints, all inspired by his designs.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Infinity Chief Makes $22 Million on Stock
description: Mel Karmazin, chief executive of the Infinity Broadcasting Corporation, made about $22 million last week by selling 750,000 of the company's class A common shares.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CLEAR CHANNEL TO PROPOSE MERGER WITH TICHENOR MEDIA
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc., which is buying the Heftel Broadcasting Corporation, said yesterday that it would propose a $184 million merger between Heftel and Tichenor Media System Inc. The merger would expand Heftel's presence in Spanish-language broadcasting. Clear Channel is acquiring the remaining 79 percent of Heftel it does not own for $183.6 million. Under Clear Channel's plans, Tichenor Media holders would exchange their stock for about 5.7 million Heftel class A common shares and about $3.2 million in cash. Heftel's shares rose 75 cents, to $32.50, in Nasdaq trading. Tichenor Media, based in Dallas, operates 20 Spanish-language radio stations in six markets. Heftel, based in Las Vegas, Nev., operates 17 radio stations.

title: 90 Stranded on Tram
description: Ninety visitors to the Bronx Zoo were stranded on a tram over a tiger enclosure for more than two hours yesterday, the police said.

title: POLITICS: CONSTITUENCIES;After Dole's Snub, N.A.A.C.P. Greets Clinton Warmly
description: President Clinton and the N.A.A.C.P. warmly embraced each other today as Mr. Clinton, in an address to the organization's annual meeting, touted his Administration's economic record in creating jobs, condemned a wave of arson against black Southern churches and vowed to veto Republican efforts to roll back gun control legislation.

title: Court Upholds Removal Of Prosecutor From Case
description: A state judge yesterday upheld Gov. George E. Pataki's removal of the Bronx District Attorney from prosecuting the case of a murdered police officer, a rare step that the Governor took because he believed the District Attorney would not seek the death penalty.

title: Japanese Trade Practices on Trial
description: The United States and Japan meet today in Geneva to begin a process of resolving their latest trade dispute without the destructive bombast that has marked their previous disagreements. The Clinton Administration properly decided to take its unfair trade practices case against Fuji Photo Film and the Japanese Government to the World Trade Organization rather than imposing sanctions. American sanctions would violate international trade rules and make Washington's bullying tactics the issue rather than Japan's suspicious trade activities.

title: Israel Violates Rights With Gaza Strip Closure;Why Double Standard?
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Possible Interest In Barneys Is Seen
description: Barneys New York, the upscale specialty retailer that filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this year, has been approached by several companies interested in acquiring it, a person close to Barneys said last night.

title: In Spirit of Games, an Honor Roll for All U.S. Olympians
description: A black granite monument bearing the names of every United States Olympic athlete since 1896 -- nearly 10,000 in all -- will be unveiled next Wednesday in Atlanta, two days before the opening ceremony of the Centennial Summer Games.

title: HORSE RACING;A Healthy Unbridled's Song To Challenge Cigar in Chicago
