description: Unbridled's Song, star-crossed all year with injuries and ailments, was declared sound yesterday and was immediately booked for a flight to Chicago tomorrow on the same airplane with the superstar Cigar. And the two charismatic horses will meet Saturday at Arlington Park when Cigar tries to match Citation's record of 16 consecutive victories.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ROCKEFELLER CENTER PROPERTIES IS SOLD TO INVESTORS
description: Rockefeller Center Properties Inc. said yesterday that a group of investors led by Goldman, Sachs & Company and David Rockefeller had completed their $1.2 billion purchase of the company. The company holds the $1.3 billion mortgage on New York landmark Rockefeller Center. Under the terms of the acquisition, the Goldman-Rockefeller group is paying about $8 a share and assuming $870 million in debt. Rockefeller Center is home to the NBC television network's broadcast studios and Radio City Music Hall.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;F.C.C. Plan for Children's TV Loses Support Of Key Member
description: In an abrupt reversal, a powerful Federal regulator said yesterday that he would oppose new rules requiring broadcasters to run three hours of children's educational programming each week.

title: About New York;In 9th Ave. El's Shadow, a Symbol of Saner Times
description: ON Christmas Eve 1965, Lawrence Stelter's father took him for a ride on the Third Avenue El, whose route by then existed only in the Bronx. But 8-year-old Lawrence felt a pull to Manhattan, like the tug of a phantom urban limb cut off at 149th Street.

title: Doctor Of the Deadbolt;A New York City Locksmith Is the Ultimate Insider
description: To the locked-out and the lock-needy, a buoyant, meditative man named Joel Kostman is their savior. As he navigates his way among the city's venues, lugging his implements in a worn doctor's bag and opening doors that resolutely refuse admittance to their very own inhabitants, he regards himself as one of the people who holds the keys to the city.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AEROSPACE GIANT TO REPURCHASE $500 MILLION IN SHARES
description: The Rockwell International Corporation said yesterday that it planned to buy back an additional $500 million of its common stock. The company, based in Seal Beach, Calif., had an average of 217.3 million shares outstanding as of March 31. Rockwell stock dropped 62.5 cents, to $53.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. The company, which makes aerospace and semiconductor products, said that it has spent about $2.6 billion in repurchasing shares in the last 12 years.

title: ON BASKETBALL;Wallace's Early Lessons Are Exhausting
description: Adrian Autry and David Johnson shared a bit of Orange humor after the Knicks' practice yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HAMBURGER HAMLET FILES PLAN WITH BANKRUPTCY COURT
description: Hamburger Hamlet Restaurants Inc. of Sherman Oaks, Calif., said yesterday that it had filed a reorganization plan with the United States Bankruptcy Court that would cancel its shareholders' rights to company property. The company said the filing was in response to an offer on Tuesday from Grill Concepts Inc. of San Vicente, Calif., to buy some assets, including as many as 19 restaurants, from Hamburger Hamlet for about $10 million in cash, notes and warrants. Under the reorganization plan, the amount paid by Grill Concepts and any remaining assets would be distributed to pay Hamburger Hamlet's creditors and the costs of its bankruptcy case. Shareholders would not receive anything for their stock.

title: Investment by Deutsche Bank Stirs Talk of Industry Mergers
description: Deutsche Bank A.G. said today that it had acquired a 5.21 percent stake in Bayerische Vereinsbank, a move that aroused speculation that German banking might be headed for a wave of mergers and consolidation.

title: POLITICS: CAMPAIGN FINANCE;Ex-Aide to Dole Campaign Admits Illegal Contributions
description: A former vice chairman of Bob Dole's Presidential campaign finance committee agreed today to plead guilty to making illegal campaign contributions totaling more than $100,000 by giving cash to his employees and having them write checks in equivalent amounts to political candidates.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Hewlett Earnings to Drop; Omen for Computer Stocks?
description: In news that could roil technology stocks again today, the Hewlett-Packard Company said late yesterday that orders for its products were slowing and that its profitability for the current fiscal quarter would probably be hurt as a result.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Trucker Admits Abduction
description: A truck driver from Minnesota pleaded guilty yesterday to kidnapping a 24-year-old waitress from a Mahwah hotel and also admitted that he sexually assaulted her as he drove across the country making his deliveries. The driver, David J. Ward of Duluth, grabbed the woman last December as she left work at the Courtyard by Marriott Hotel, Federal prosecutors said. He kept her handcuffed and bound with duct tape in the sleeper cab of his truck and raped her at least four times before she escaped in Indianapolis, said Mark J. McCarren, an assistant United States attorney.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Health page yesterday, about the international meeting on AIDS in Vancouver, British Columbia, omitted a byline in some copies. It was written by Lawrence K. Altman.

title: Australian Deal by Dana
description: The Dana Corporation has acquired the Australian filter maker James N. Kirby for undisclosed terms. Kirby, which is closely held, makes air filters for cars and trucks. Dana, based in Toledo, makes automotive components and industrial products.

title: Heinz in Share Buyback
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said today that it planned to buy back an additional 15 million common shares. The food company said the buyback would begin after its current 10-million-share buyback.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Rise Again; Fed Rate Action Is Doubted
description: Treasury prices ended higher yesterday for a second consecutive day, bolstered by speculation that the Federal Reserve was unlikely to raise interest rates in the next few weeks.

title: Careful Employers Should Curb Internet Access
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday of Justice Birdie Amsterdam, the first woman elected to New York State Supreme Court, misstated the given name of a surviving sister. She is Ruth Sanders, not Cynthia.

title: Currents;The Inspiration That Is Rome
description: ROME'S architectural drama has inspired designers for centuries, among them Michael Graves, who said he savored "the antiquity, the Renaissance, the Baroque and a little modern, one flowing into the other," when he was a fellow at the American Academy in Rome in the early 1960's. Now, he has given something back. He has designed pro bono the academy's Barbara Goldsmith Rare Book Room, named for the writer. It is a serene and glowing study with pear wood walls and furniture and room for 6,000 books. Book lovers note: Cases are lined in steel to prevent discoloring.

title: Workers' Compensation
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Globby Fungus Is on the Attack
description: PESKY flying objects have been attacking random houses, cars, office buildings, plants -- and in at least one case, a woman's derriere.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;First Bank's Quarterly Net Jumps 84%
description: First Bank System Inc. reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings jumped 84 percent, while its operating profits advanced 21 percent, paced by rising fee revenue from its trust and corporate payment systems units.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Have High Hopes But Lots of Gaps, Too
description: If the Mets have turned the corner, then what lies ahead? An oncoming train? Quicksand? Or an escalator to the top of the National League East standing?

title: OLYMPICS;Kenyan Just Misses Record in 800 Meters
description: Wilson Kipketer, the Kenya-born runner who competes for Denmark, ran the fastest 800 meters in 11 years today and just missed a world record in the Nikaia Grand Prix meet.

title: Currents;Houses For Dogs, Pro Bono
description: FOR some, the dog days of summer have arrived. Asked to design a doghouse to benefit the Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons' People United With Pets program, which cares for pets of terminally ill people, Jaquelin T. Robertson, the Manhattan architect, puzzled, "What do dogs want?" He came up with "Hotel D" (top), a replica of a pavilion designed by Thomas Jefferson. It and 21 other houses will be on view at Vered Gallery, at 68 Park Place Passage in East Hampton, L.I., on Saturday from 9 P.M. to midnight, continuing through Aug. 2. They will be auctioned in Manhattan in the fall.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Scanlon Leaves Firm That Handled Crises
description: John Scanlon, the longtime public relations executive who has been at the center of several corporate controversies, is leaving Abernathy MacGregor Scanlon, a financial and crisis communications agency in New York where he has been a partner since June 1993.

title: Russian Company To Bid for Fokker
description: One of Russia's leading aircraft makers said today that it planned to buy Fokker N.V. for about $216 million, but Fokker, the bankrupt Dutch plane maker, said it was not yet close to a deal.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Courier in New Jersey Event
description: After a first-round loss at Wimbledon, where he pulled a quadriceps muscle, JIM COURIER said he needed a good warm-up for the United States Open. He will get that chance Sunday when he faces off against MICHAEL CHANG in the A&P Tennis Classic in Mahwah, N.J. The match will begin at 7 P.M.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAUL O. HEYER, the president of the New York School of Interior Design for the last six years, is leaving his post at the school on East 70th Street this week, but he is not retiring.

title: Liberties;See Dick Run
description: So what exactly is the point of Lamm for President?

title: Currents;Windows of Opportunity
description: IN planning an addition to Public School 14 in Corona, Queens, Warren Gran and Joseph Sultan were faced with a site on a diagonal. The architects turned an idiosyncrasy into a virtue with an annex whose facade zigzags, giving each classroom two walls of windows -- "one more than the typical classroom," Mr. Gran said. Even on a recent overcast day, light poured in. The 35,000-square-foot, three-story brick-and-limestone annex provides a bridge between the existing four-story school and neighboring three-story houses. Along with the luxury of light, the architects added gleaming tiles of soaring birds, leaping fish and prickly cactus along the corridors. The annex opened in September, with landscaping and lighting completed in May. The project cost $12 million, including renovations to the original school.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Two Italian Grocers Agree to Merge
description: Vege Italia and A & O S.p.A., two Italian grocery retailers, said yesterday that they were pooling their supermarkets to create Italy's second-largest chain, with annual sales exceeding 11 trillion lire, or $7.3 billion. Details of the transaction will be released on Tuesday. The companies said the result would be a 2,687-store network stretching from the Swiss border to Sicily. A & O and Vege said the combined entity would be second only to Coop, which has 13.2 percent of the grocery market.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ITALIAN OVEN'S CHIEF RELINQUISHES RESPONSIBILITIES
description: Italian Oven's chairman and chief executive, James A. Frye, relinquished his responsibilities but will remain on the board, the company said in a statement yesterday. As reported last month, Mr. Frye, who founded the restaurant chain in 1989 and is its largest shareholder, turned over control to Cornerstone Capital Advisors Ltd., the company's temporary manager. In a cost-cutting effort, Italian Oven also suspended or laid off 10 employees, more than 25 percent of the corporate staff, at its Latrobe, Pa., headquarters. The company also said that Wheat First Butcher Singer Inc. has agreed to help it explore financing options and potential partnerships.

title: Bail Set in Appeal of Sex Abuse Conviction
description: The Rev. Nathaniel T. Grady, who has been in prison for more than a decade on a conviction of sexually abusing children at a Bronx day care center, was to be released on $200,000 bail today pending a new appeal.

title: Fatal Subway Shooting Followed Report of a Stalking
description: The fatal confrontation between an unarmed Yonkers man and a transit officer last week began after the man was reported to be stalking a woman on a Bronx-bound D train, a senior police official said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It is no secret that Francois Mitterrand, the former President of France who died last January, was something of a swain: both his wife and his longtime mistress were front and center at his funeral. Now it turns out that in his youth, Mr. Mitterrand also fancied himself as a romance novelist.

title: Software Maker Settles Charges
description: Syncronys Softcorp agreed today to settle Federal charges that it had misrepresented the performance of its software programs, which consumers snatched up on claims that they could double the memory of personal computers.

title: Saudi Exile Warns More Attacks Are Planned
description: A militant Saudi dissident has warned that the terrorists who carried out bombing attacks against American soldiers in Saudi Arabia will also strike at British and French military personnel, adding that those responsible for the bombings in Riyadh and Dhahran that killed 26 "have a deep understanding in choosing their targets."

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Gasoline Soars as Supply Drop Stirs Hopes for High Demand
description: Gasoline prices surged on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after a report showed a larger-than-expected drop in inventories, reviving speculation of a record pace of consumption this summer.

title: World News Briefs;Backers of Niger General Say He Won Election
description: The military ruler who seized control in January strengthened his grip today when he was declared the winner in a presidential election that the opposition said was tainted. The officer, Gen. Ibrahim Mainassara, immediately banned opposition parties and public meetings.

title: Israel Violates Rights With Gaza Strip Closure
description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Gives Church Treasurer More Than Maximum Sentence
description: After issuing a tongue-lashing and ignoring a plea for leniency, a Federal judge today sentenced the former treasurer of the national Episcopal Church to five years in prison for embezzling about $2.2 million in church money from 1990 to 1995.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Playmobil USA, Dayton, N.J., to Anda & Scott Advertising, New York, to introduce broadcast advertising for the toy manufacturer in the United States. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million. Bay View Federal Bank, San Mateo, Calif., a unit of Bay View Capital Corp., to Headlands Communications Inc., Mill Valley, Calif. The account had been handled on a project basis by Cramer-Krasselt, Phoenix. Billings have not been determined.

title: Political Briefing;THE CAMPAIGNS AND THE ISSUES
description: The Republican Primaries A Bonus Proposal For Late Contests

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CARRAMERICA REALTY CORP., Washington, which owns office properties, agreed to buy 10 office buildings and some land in and around Austin, Tex., for $100 million in cash, debt and securities.

title: Bridge
description: There is always an element of mystery surrounding the Worldwide Pairs, which was played in June for the 11th time, with Alcatel, an international telecommunications corporation based in France, as sponsor. The World Bridge Federation names Omar Sharif as master of ceremonies and Eric Kokish as analyst, but never offers any explanation of how the deals are selected or scored.

title: Melvin Belli Dies at 88; Flamboyant Lawyer Relished His Role as Kingof Torts
description: Melvin Belli, an impresario of a lawyer who pioneered new techniques and huge settlements in personal injury cases and who defended Jack Ruby, the man who killed Lee Harvey Oswald, died on Tuesday at his home in San Francisco. He was 88.

title: Capital Cities Closes Wire
description: Capital Cities/ABC Inc. is closing its United States-based financial news wire, Derivatives Monitor, effective Friday. A spokeswoman for Capital Cities, which is owned by the Walt Disney Company, said the company would try to find assignments in the Capital Cities financial publications unit for the 30 staff members affected by the shutdown. Derivatives Monitor provides information on the swaps and over-the-counter derivatives market carried on Reuters and Bloomberg terminals.

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;Read Their Lips: The Other Guy Is the Candidate in Favor of Big Tax Increases
description: Turning to what both sides said would be a central issue in the Presidential race, the Clinton and Dole campaigns today introduced television advertisements in which each portrayed the other's candidate as a steadfast proponent of big tax increases.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Abbott's Net Up by 10.9% In 2d Quarter
description: Abbott Laboratories reported yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 10.9 percent, reflecting strong American drug sales and international growth in all its businesses.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Girl's Parents Attack Article
description: Richard and Maureen Kanka denounced an article yesterday that raised questions about the law named after their daughter Megan. The New Jersey Law Journal reported that before Megan Kanka's 1994 abduction and murder, many neighbors were aware that a convicted child molester lived across the street from the family. A roommate of that man is awaiting trial for the child's slaying.

title: With Rent-a-Dad, Who Needs Movers?
description: TO move or to be moved?

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Government to Decide Whether Kenyans Run
description: After threatening to replace 30 runners on Kenya's Olympic team because they were racing in Europe instead of training in the United States, Kip Keino said today that he was leaving the final decision on the runners' participation up to the Kenyan Government.

title: The Other Land Deal Dogging the Clintons
description: The imbroglio known as Whitewater is named after the patch of Arkansas woods where Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton joined a banker, James B. McDougal, in a bungled real-estate partnership. But now a different tract, an industrial park called Castle Grande, has assumed equal importance in the affair.

title: Careful Employers Should Curb Internet Access;Dire Consequences
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip Johnson Icon Grows Moon Rocks
description: UNDER any circumstances, the job of altering a house by Philip Johnson would be enough to daunt any architect.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Car Falls From Garage; 2 Die
description: Two elderly women were killed yesterday morning when their car crashed through a concrete-and-steel wall and plunged 44 feet from the fourth floor of a new parking garage at the Claridge Casino Hotel, the Atlantic City police said. The $27 million garage, which opened just two weeks ago, was closed indefinitely pending an investigation by the city building department. Police said they did not know what caused the accident.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Whitewater Investigation's Focus: Another Tangled Arkansas Deal
description: James B. McDougal wanted to build a road in 1985 to property he owned just south of Little Rock, Ark., but the only route crossed an industrial park. So he asked his real-estate scout, a semi-retired businessman named Seth Ward, to drive out and look into securing an easement.

title: Fight Over Ellis Island Puts History on Trial
description: Lawyers for New York snarled that their learned colleagues from across the water were blind to history. The New Jersey side shot back that New York was living up to its name as the Empire State, seeking to expand in every direction.

title: Pawns of Politics
description: New York State Legislators hold it as a political truth that most voters don't notice late budgets because they aren't hurt by them. But tonight, Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders came very close to harming many people by holding hostage to their budget fight a law that protects thousands of New York City loft tenants.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Duke Albrecht Is Dead at 91; Pretender to Bavarian Throne
description: Duke Albrecht of Bavaria, head of a dynasty more than 800 years old and pretender to the Bavarian throne, died on Monday at an ancestral home, Castle Berg, near Munich, his family said. He was 91 years old.

title: Pollution Backsliding in New Jersey
description: The people who live in New Jersey care about the environment. They have voted for some of the toughest pollution controls in the country. Their Congressional delegation, including many Republicans, has honorably resisted the G.O.P.'s yearlong effort to dismantle the nation's basic environmental laws. There is no mystery to this. New Jersey is a densely populated state with an economy dominated by petrochemical complexes and other heavy polluters. It has more Superfund sites than any other state, and 85 percent of its waterways remain unfishable and unswimmable.

title: Heineken Quits Its Burmese Venture
description: Heineken N.V. announced today that it would pull out of Myanmar, which was formerly known as Burma, and stop exports there under pressure from a boycott of its products.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GT INTERACTIVE ACQUIRES HUMONGOUS ENTERTAINMENT
description: The GT Interactive Software Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired Humongous Entertainment Inc., a developer and publisher of children's software based in Woodinville, Wash., for four million shares, or about $76 million. It was GT Interactive's third acquisition in two weeks. Last week, it acquired Formgen, publisher of the Duke Nukem 3D computer game, and the Wizard Works Group. GT Interactive's shares fell 50 cents, to $19, in Nasdaq trading. GT Interactive, based in New York, produces interactive software. Its best-selling titles include Doom II and Mortal Kombat 3.

title: V.M.I. Holding Back on Move To Obey Justices on Women
description: It looked like the battle was over.

title: Get Smarter on Smart Weapons
description: In the wake of America's spectacularly successful air campaign against Iraq five years ago, selective reporting from the Pentagon and weapons manufacturers painted glowing accounts of the battlefield performance of a new generation of advanced high-tech weapons like stealth fighter planes, laser-guided bombs and Tomahawk missiles. Based on those accounts, subsequent Pentagon procurement budgets invested heavily in these extremely costly weapons systems, with nearly $60 billion allocated to "smart bombs" alone.

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;Dole Hammers Foe No. 1: Bureaucracy In Washington
description: Bob Dole spent his day campaigning today at two nonpartisan events in which he emphasized an anti-Washington message rather than an anti-Clinton message.

title: DESPITE A TRUCE, RUSSIANS ATTACK CHECHEN VILLAGES
description: Less than a week after President Boris N. Yeltsin won re-election promising to end the devastating war in Chechnya, Russian forces today carried out their fiercest attack in months on the secessionist southern region. Local officials said dozens of civilians were killed during the bombardment of two villages about 20 miles south of Grozny, the Chechen capital.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about a study that found an increasing rate of interracial marriages misspelled the surname of one of the authors of the study. He is Douglas Besharov, not Besherov.

title: How Broadway Resents And Relies on TKTS
description: The setting was Broadway. But inside the TKTS booth, it looked a lot like the fifth race at Aqueduct.

title: Where Warts Are Superior to Ideology
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Fugitive U.S. Financier Faces Trial in Cuba
description: Robert Vesco, the fugitive American financier who has been in custody in Cuba for 13 months, is to go on trial there within weeks, American officials said today, but charges that could have brought the death penalty have been dropped. Instead, the charges will be limited to economic crimes, the officials said.

title: POLITICAL MEMO;He May Still Be a Noncandidate for Now, But Powell Is Not a Nonissue
description: It is as if Colin L. Powell never said no.

title: Douglas G. Chapman, 76, Expert In the Demographics of Whales
description: Douglas G. Chapman, an expert on wildlife statistics who became especially influential and outspoken in the field of whale conservation, died on Tuesday in Seattle. He was 76 and a longtime resident of Seattle.

title: Head of Drug Gang Is Convicted in 7 Murders
description: A Federal jury has convicted a man who uses a wheelchair of ordering seven murders while running a vicious Manhattan drug organization that investigators say dominated the crack and heroin trade in the University Heights section of the Bronx.

title: A.C.L.U. on Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Merger Plan by French And Belgian Banks
description: Credit Local de France and Credit Communal de Belgique S.A. agreed yesterday to a merger that would create Europe's 19th-biggest bank. Each bank will own 50 percent of the other through holding companies, whose combined assets are one trillion French francs, or $192.3 billion. Credit Local will pay existing shareholders a special dividend of 626 million francs to compensate for the greater value of Credit Local shares.

title: The Pop Life
description: Mickey Hart's New Life

title: Banker Denies Wrongdoing Over Money For Clinton
description: An Arkansas banker took the stand today in his own defense in the second Whitewater-related trial and adamantly denied charges that he broke any laws to ingratiate himself with Bill Clinton in 1990, when Mr. Clinton was Governor of Arkansas.

title: Powerful Aide Is the Focus Of Board Fight
description: On his first full day as president of the Board of Education, William C. Thompson Jr. said yesterday that one of his top priorities would be to figure out what precisely the secretary to the board, Bruce E. Gelbard, does -- even though the two have worked only a few doors apart for the last two years.

title: OLYMPICS;His Eye on Major Leagues, Top Cuban Pitcher Defects
description: At 2:30 Tuesday morning, a knock was made on the door of Cuba's Olympic pitching ace. He had been told to dress in dark clothes and carry nothing from his hotel room. Three cars were stationed near the hotel, prepared in case Cuban security attempted to intervene. For several weeks, Rolando Arrojo had talked about defecting. Now the time had come.

title: Fugitive Bosnian Serb Has Legal Team Ready
description: Radovan Karadzic may appear no closer to surrendering real power or to giving himself up to NATO forces. But the Bosnian Serb leader does seem to be preparing to confront charges that he is a war criminal by appointing lawyers to represent him at the war crimes tribunal here.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Sore Foot Might Put Thomas On Chicago's Disabled List
description: FRANK THOMAS, the power-hitting first baseman for the Chicago White Sox, said a sore left foot might put him on the disabled list for the first time in his career. It would also end Thomas's consecutive games streak of 346, second in the major leagues behind CAL RIPKEN's.

title: SOCCER;Donadoni, a Master Builder, Lead Stars
description: The two best players for the MetroStars, Roberto Donadoni and Tab Ramos, came through for the team in a time of need again tonight. Two marvelous efforts by Donadoni and one by Ramos led to three goals and a 3-2 triumph over the Dallas Burn before a crowd of 17,416 at Giants Stadium.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ALLIED SIGNAL PREDICTS IT WILL MEET CASH TARGET
description: The industrial conglomerate Allied Signal Inc. said it would meet its 1996 target of $400 million in additional cash even though it had a cash deficit of $200 million in the first half of the year. In a memo to Allied Signal executives, Lawrence Bossidy, the company's chairman and chief executive, said that in order to reach its goal, the company would have to bring in about $650 million in the next six months. Allied Signal makes products for the aerospace, automotive and engineered-materials industries. Shares of Allied Signal fell $1, to $56.75.

title: Careful Employers Should Curb Internet Access
description: To the Editor:

title: ON BASEBALL;Everybody Flex: N.L. Shows It Has Power, Too
description: The Mets' Lance Johnson may not weigh as much as a Mo Vaughn bat. And the Colorado Rockies' Eric Young may not be able to wrap both hands around a Mark McGwire bicep.

title: Sculptural Clock Wins a Vote
description: A proposed sculptural clock for the plaza of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts won the endorsement of the Arts and Acquisitions committee of the Lincoln Center board yesterday. The vote, with one absention after top Lincoln Center executives voiced support for the clock, appears to move the project by the architect Philip Johnson and the watchmaker Movado to a semi-final stage. It now faces review by the New York City Art Commission.

title: Sports of The Times;Big Daddy Comes Home To the Kids
description: AFTER two long months, the kids were waiting to see their daddy, the heavyweight affectionately known as Big Daddy. Riddick Jr., age 10, modeled a red Bulls jersey, a Michael Jordan "45." Riddicia, 8, and Brenda, 6, wore matching dresses. Julius, 2, stood at his mother's knee as she fed 11-month Diamond a bottle on her lap.

title: Punish Employers, Not Children
description: Four million illegal aliens reside in the United States, and their number grows by 300,000 every year. This is on top of the three million granted amnesty in the late 1980's.

title: New Israeli Leader's Visit Elicits Curiosity and Ambivalence
description: When Benjamin Netanyahu arrives in New York today for his first visit to the city as Prime Minister of Israel, he will be greeted by a Jewish population excessively acquainted with his American-style political sagacity but deeply ambivalent about the direction he may lead Israel.

title: N.A.S.D. Forms An Investor Unit
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers has created a new individual investor education department and appointed Michael Jones as its director.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Poland Joining O.E.C.D., A Step Further Into Europe
description: In a major psychological boost for its increasingly healthy economy, Poland is set to join one of the world's premier capitalist clubs, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

title: CLOSE TO HOME;Don't Worry, There's No Racial Hatred Here
description: THERE is no reason to ask "Why" since to ask "Why" is to enter some dark and crazy spot where one presumes there is "reason," and a reason that will make sense, which is not to say that there is a craziness: I don't believe this is crazy, but rather mean . . . hateful . . . ugly -- though not ignorant, because there is a knowledge here and there is a purpose here but there is no reason. People who will burn a cross will burn a church.

title: Stocks Rise in Japan
description: Stocks were trading higher here today. At the close of trading, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 113.64 points, or 0.52 percent, at 21,892.58. On Wednesday, the Nikkei closed down 140.88 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent.

title: Economic Scene;A rigid Japan Inc. could tumble from the top industrial ranks.
description: AFTER shuffling in place for much of the 1990's, the Japanese economy is growing again. But before the Japan bashers get a chance to sound the alarm, consider this analysis of the economy's long-term prospects by Robert Alan Feldman of Salomon Brothers.

title: Investment Firms Talk Of Merging
description: LGT Asset Management, a mutual fund and private banking unit of the Liechtenstein Global Trust, said yesterday that it was in talks to acquire Chancellor Capital Management, a New York-based institutional investment management firm.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;New Leader for School Board
description: A father of four who owns a heating oil company in Bridgeton was elected president of the State Board of Education yesterday. Robert A. Woodruff of Alloway Township will succeed Anne S. Dillman, who led the board for four years.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Transplant for DeMatha Coach
description: MORGAN WOOTTEN, the DeMatha High School coach who sent a dozen players to the National Basketball Association, had a life-saving liver transplant yesterday, and his doctor said he might be able to coach next season at the Hyattsville, Md., school. The five-and-a-half-hour operation on Wootten went as planned, said Dr. JAMES BURDICK, the director of the kidney transplant program at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. Wootten was listed in critical condition in the surgical intensive-care unit. Burdick said that the prognosis was good and that Wootten could be released next week. (AP)

title: Stock-Fund Cash Flow Slows; Magellan Gets More Bad News
description: Investors scaled back their purchases of stock mutual funds in June, but the cascade of new money remained strong enough to confirm what all of Wall Street expected: Investors put more money into funds that invest in stocks in the first six months of 1996 than in any previous full year.

title: Robert Kenyon, 87; Led Magazine Group
description: Robert Edwin Kenyon Jr., a former president of the Magazine Publishers Association, died on Monday at Greenwich Hospital in Connecticut. He was 87 and most recently resided in Old Greenwich.

title: Currents;Lanterns on a String
description: PAPER lanterns aren't wildly functional. They're hard to read by and even harder to sew by. But they are festive.

title: Shell and Exxon Plan Merger Of Fuel Additives Businesses
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group and the Exxon Corporation said today that they had agreed to merge their fuel and oil additives businesses, which produce a quarter of the $6 billion in annual sales for such chemicals.

title: HOCKEY;Gretzky and Rangers in No Rush
description: Wayne Gretzky is not in a hurry to sign with anybody. And the Rangers do not appear to be in a rush to go out and sign the player who was once hockey's best.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Mercedes-Benz Reports Big Half-Year Demand
description: Mercedes-Benz A.G. said yesterday that its worldwide car deliveries climbed 7.2 percent in the first six months of the year, making the period the best half-year in the company's history. Mercedes, the auto-making arm of Daimler-Benz A.G., said it had shipped 315,000 cars and expected to deliver more than 600,000 cars for the year.

title: Deutsche Bahn Deal With Mannesmann
description: Deutsche Bahn A.G., Germany's national railway, chose a consortium headed by Mannesmann A.G. today as a strategic partner in a German telecommunications venture.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Washington Exits Early

title: Firearms Agency Settles Bias Suit for $5 Million
description: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms has settled a discrimination lawsuit brought by black agents, agreeing to pay $5.9 million in damages and fees.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the crash of a French-built turboprop airplane in Roselawn, Ind., in 1994 referred incorrectly to a report by the French Government on the causes of the crash. The report, which was submitted to the National Transportation Safety Board in Washington, was from the Bureau Enquetes-Accidents, which is the French counterpart of the safety board. It was not from the Direction General a l'Aviation Civile, the French regulatory agency, which was also involved in the investigation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Clinton Uses Sanctions Against Canadians The Clinton Administration took specific action for the first time against foreign companies operating in Cuba, informing top executives and shareholders of the Sherritt International Corporation, a large Canadian mining concern, that they and their families would be barred from entering the United States, State Department officials said.

title: Sea Containers Buys Hotel
description: Sea Containers Ltd. has bought the Reid's Hotel on the island of Madeira, Portugal, from the Blandy family for $30 million. Sea Containers said the 171-room property, about 400 miles off the coast of Morocco, opened in 1891, and the Blandy family had owned it since 1937. The company, which is based in Bermuda, plans to expand the hotel and raise occupancy rates.

title: A Case Study: Man Kills in April, Is Executed in May
description: The leg irons on the defendant clanked gently as he shuffled into the courtroom.

title: Senate Acts on Labor Measures Opposed by Clinton and Unions
description: The Senate delivered a setback today to one measure that would undermine the strength of labor unions, but approved another that would give companies greater leeway in setting up their own employer-employee groups.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Aikman Shows Support of Irvin
description: TROY AIKMAN spent yesterday afternoon sitting alongside MICHAEL IRVIN's family during the Dallas Cowboy star's cocaine possession trial, making him the first of the defendant's teammates to appear in the Dallas courtroom.

title: Employee-Owned Stores Expect Better Odds
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE PLATFORM;Democrats Draft Abortion Plank Proclaiming 'Party of Inclusion'
description: After quiet negotiations designed to avoid a public squabble over abortion, the White House has drafted language for the Democratic Party platform that would recognize "the individual conscience of each American on this difficult issue."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;LG Group to Build Plants in Britain
description: LG Group of South Korea said yesterday that it would invest $2.6 billion to produce semiconductors and electronics in Britain. LG Group said the project in Newport, Wales, would be the largest single investment in Europe by a non-European company and predicted it would create 6,100 jobs. LG, South Korea's third-largest conglomerate, already makes televisions and microwave ovens in Britain.

title: Independent Investigation Of Mattel Data Is Questioned
description: Earlier this year, Gary Lynch, a former top enforcement official at the Securities and Exchange Commission, was hired by Mattel Inc. to conduct an independent inquiry into allegations of questionable accounting practices at the toy maker. But now, a misdialed fax machine may raise questions about the independence of that investigation.

title: Powerful Response Reported In a Combined AIDS Therapy
description: When used in combination, two members of a new class of drugs have forced the amount of AIDS virus down to virtually undetectable levels in infected people, according to very early results of a small study reported today at an international meeting here on AIDS.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Picking the Brains That Build the Images
description: Yes, there are minds behind television's mindlessness. You can visit with them on "Signal to Noise: Life With Television," a quirky three-hour exploration from the Independent Television Service that begins with a look at the people who concoct commercials and the people who swallow them.

title: Ford to Take Full Control Of Ailing Budget Rent a Car
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would take control of the money-losing Budget Rent a Car Corporation.

title: For Children
description: 'Civil War Encampment' Historic Richmond Town 441 Clarke Avenue Richmond Town, S.I. (718) 351-1611 Recommended for all ages Tomorrow and Sunday

title: The Spoken Word
description: "JUMBALAYA," Nuyorican Poets Cafe, 236 East Third Street, Lower East Side. Readings and a forum titled "Are the Media Designing Colored Intellectuals?" Sunday at 2 P.M. Admission: $5. Information: (212) 674-3778.

title: ROCK REVIEWLollapalooza, No Longer So Ambivalent About Bigness
description: The Lollapalooza Festival, which started a two-day engagement on Wednesday at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island, used to be ambivalent about bigness. Its founders believed that alternative rock had a potential audience beyond the club and college-radio circuit, and they were right. But in five previous annual tours, Lollapalooza exploited the tension between the supposed small-scale integrity of alternative rock and the impersonal, unsubtle blare of arena rock. The festival has always included a second stage (and since last year, a third one) presenting lesser-known bands, bridging club and arena. As festival headliners like Smashing Pumpkins and Sonic Youth moved from the club and theater circuit to face more than 10,000 people, seeing those bands respond was part of what made Lollapalooza different.

title: Market Place: Stocks Plunge on More Signs of Weaker CorporateEarnings; Some Wonder if Party's Over For Technology High-Fliers
description: The list of corporate casualties in the technology field is lengthening. It's easy to dismiss an Apple Computer or a Digital Equipment as troubled companies bedeviled by problems of their own making. But with two blue-chip bellwethers, Motorola and Hewlett-Packard, surprising Wall Street this week with announcements of slowing business, it raises questions about the outlook for technology shares in general.

title: Police Say a $50 Drug Debt Was Reason for 3 Killings
description: While detectives searched for a convicted drug dealer in the murders of three Queens women, senior police officials said the slayings were motivated by a $50 drug debt.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Kukoc Might Miss Olympics
description: TONI KUKOC's broken left thumb may be a more serious injury than first thought, and Croatia could lose him for the Atlanta Olympics. The Chicago Bulls forward sat out last night's exhibition game against Canada, the same national team he was injured against Tuesday night. Croatia Coach PETAR SKANSI said Kukoc could miss four weeks. (AP)

title: Netanyahu, in New York, Promotes His Views on Peace and InvitesInvestments
description: Returning with new stature to an intimately familiar venue, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel switched his oratorial skill and boyish charm to full volume yesterday as he urged New York City's Jewish population to embrace his approach to peace in the Middle East and to invigorating the Israeli economy.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Mustaf's Cousin Gets Life
description: LeVONNIE WOOTEN was sentenced to life in prison yesterday for murdering the pregnant girlfriend of his cousin, the former Phoenix Suns player JERROD MUSTAF.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: Buchanan Declines to Attend Dole Lunch
description: Hoping for a pre-convention show of Republican unity, Bob Dole had invited his primary rivals to lunch next week, but he was snubbed today by Pat Buchanan.

title: Can We Talk?
description: One year ago, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was teetering on the brink of irrelevancy. Infighting and fiscal mismanagement together with charges of sexual harassment, financial impropriety and sexism threatened this once stellar champion of civil rights.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Police Lift Ban on March By Ulster Protestant Group
description: Four days and nights of violent demonstrations by tens of thousands of Protestants across this British province forced the police today to reverse an order barring a traditional Protestant patriotic march that would pass through a Roman Catholic area of this village in County Armagh, 30 miles southwest of Belfast.

title: G.O.P. Report Faults Reno in Texas Siege
description: House Republicans said today that Attorney General Janet Reno had been "highly irresponsible" and negligent in approving the Federal raid that left more than 70 people dead at the compound of the Branch Davidian sect near Waco, Tex., and they asserted that President Clinton should have accepted her offer to resign in 1993.

title: Astronaut May Stay in Orbit 6 Weeks Longer, NASA Says
description: Dr. Shannon Lucid says she is not worried about extending her five-month stay in space. After all, she brought along plenty of books to read.

title: U.S. Strips Colombian President of His Visa
description: Invoking a clause in the Immigration and Naturalization Act that makes anyone who has "assisted or abetted" drug trafficking ineligible to visit the United States, the State Department said today that it had canceled the visa of President Ernesto Samper of Colombia.

title: ART REVIEW;City Sophistication Spends The Summer on Long Island
description: AS a place for artists and their doings, Long Island is an extension of the city: you won't find much that can't be seen in Manhattan. Yet the Island still retains a local charm, reflected in the East End landscapes of Jane Wilson, on view at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton, and in a number of works by Long Island artists in the current flower show at the Heckscher Museum of Art in Huntington.

title: A Challenge to Ross Perot
description: Richard Lamm enjoyed not much more than a day in the spotlight as a Presidential candidate before Ross Perot made it clear that he, too, wanted to be the Reform Party's nominee. Poor Mr. Lamm did not even get a decent chance to make the rounds of the Sunday morning talk shows before he was upstaged.

title: Federal Report Promotes Commonplace Exercise
description: Burning as few as 150 calories a day by walking the dog, washing the car, working in the garden and climbing the stairs can reduce the risk of heart disease, high blood pressure, cancer and diabetes, according to the first Surgeon General's report on physical activity, issued today.

title: 102 DAYS TARDY, ALBANY REACHES DEAL ON BUDGET
description: Finally producing what has become the tardiest state budget in the nation's history, Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature announced a $66 billion spending plan on Thursday that rejects most of the cuts and policy changes that Mr. Pataki had advocated.

title: OLYMPICS;Latest Cuban Defector: Live Arm, No Passport
description: When pitcher Rolando Arrojo defected from the Cuban national team in the wee hours on Tuesday in Albany, Ga., he had to leave behind a significant piece of identification: his passport.

title: Rail Defect Is Blamed in 1994 Derailment
description: A little-understood track defect was apparently the cause of a train crash that injured more than 100 passengers near Batavia, N.Y., in 1994, Federal safety inspectors said today.

title: Home Video
description: Where the VCR Rules

title: Stocks Plunge on Weaker Corporate Earnings and Rate Fears;Dow Drops 83.11 Points; Nasdaq Plummets by 3.1%
description: Investors fled the stock market yesterday as more signs of weakening corporate profits further shook confidence already undermined by fears of higher interest rates.

title: Freeholders Eliminate County Police In Hudson
description: The Hudson County Board of Freeholders said it had no choice, but when it voted this evening to disband the county's 82-officer Police Department, the officers who packed the meeting room said they had been betrayed.

title: Inside Photography
description: The images are startlingly beautiful, given the horrific subject. One, by Galina Sanko, shows the fine boots on a snow-covered German soldier lying alongside the frozen head and shoulders of a fallen comrade. An impressionistic photograph by Georgi Zelma showing a tank churning up swirls of snow in the heart of Stalingrad predates by a year the Robert Capa picture of an American soldier swimming to shore on D-Day. Yet another picture, by Yakov Ryumkin, with members of the Red Army racing past rubble and up the steps of a devastated Reichstag in Berlin, would be darkly theatrical if it were not about war.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BURLINGTON RESOURCES TO SPEED UP SELLOFF OF WELLS
description: Burlington Resources Inc., an oil and natural gas concern, said yesterday that it would speed up its sale of wells as part of a plan to reduce its regional offices to three from five. The company, based in Houston, also said it planned to cut its 1,750-member work force by 20 percent, or 350 jobs. Burlington said it would sell its interest in about 20,000 wells in the next 12 months. The move is part of a reorganization under which Burlington has sold more than 9,000 wells since 1994. The company also announced a new 10-million-share buyback plan yesterday. Burlington, which has 126 million common shares outstanding, has already repurchased 1.4 million shares this year. The company also reported net income of $48 million in the second quarter, up from only $2 million a year earlier.

title: Comex Said to Fault British Exchange on Copper Trading
description: Just five months ago, in a rococo conference room at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, a top official of the New York Mercantile Exchange bitterly complained to a British counterpart about mysterious developments in the copper market that British officials seemed to be ignoring.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KMART AND DAKA TO FORM JOINT RESTAURANT VENTURE
description: The Kmart Corporation of Troy, Mich., said yesterday that it would team up with the food-service concern Daka International Inc. to improve restaurant operations. The joint venture would run restaurants in 1,850 Kmart and Super Kmart stores. Daka, which operates Daka Restaurants and owns or franchises the Fuddruckers and Champps restaurants, will have 51 percent interest in the venture and Kmart will have 49 percent. The companies will invest a total of $100 million in three years. Despite the announcement, Daka's stock plunged $5.875, to $15, as the company also disclosed that its fourth-quarter earnings would be substantially less than expected.

title: Perot Declares He Will Seek His Party's Presidential Nod
description: Ross Perot declared today that he would seek the Presidential nomination of the Reform Party, a move that immediately recast what for months had essentially been a two-man race for the White House and deepened anxiety among Republicans.

title: Frank Waugh McCulloch, 90, Head of Labor Relations Board
description: Frank Waugh McCulloch, a liberal Democrat who was chairman of the National Labor Relations Board in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, died on Tuesday in a hospice in Charlottesville, Va. He was 90 and a longtime resident of Charlottesville.

title: Critic's Choice/Rock;Handicapping 450 Bands At 18 Clubs
description: For music fans, freedom of choice can become a burden when events like the Macintosh New York Music Festival take over downtown Manhattan clubs. For six nights, beginning on Sunday, those who shell out $50 for a festival pass can experience what it is like to have a nightly itinerary as hectic as a campaigning politician's. Four hundred and fifty bands are scheduled to perform at 18 clubs, and squeezing in just a tenth of them will be a minor miracle.

title: Alexander G. Shulman, 81; Used Ice for Burn Treatment
description: Alexander G. Shulman, a physician who instinctively plunged his hand into cold water when he accidentally seared it with boiling grease one day in the 1950's and thereby altered medicine's approach to the emergency treatment of burns, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81.

title: President Announces Plan To Encourage School Repair
description: Seeking to expand the Federal role in repairing public schools, President Clinton announced today that he would ask Congress for $5 billion to help straighten sagging roofs, seal cracked foundations and fix other problems nationwide over the next four years.

title: Company Briefs
description: COLONIAL PROPERTIES TRUST, Birmingham, Ala., a real estate trust, said it would buy a mall in Myrtle Beach, S.C., for $42.2 million.

title: At Home Abroad;A Soft Landing?
description: To most Americans it is an obscure corner of the world, not on the radar screen of concerns. But the Korean Peninsula in fact presents one of the most dangerous and difficult challenges to U.S. policy today.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Is Hurt by Stock Slump And Rate-Rise Hints in Europe
description: The dollar ended mostly lower against leading currencies yesterday, weakened by a stock market slump and fresh signals that European nations might be ready to raise interest rates.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Devils and Housley Far Apart
description: The Devils appear to have little intention of signing Phil Housley, the only unrestricted free agent on the team.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ANOTHER STOCK BUYBACK PROGRAM FOR DOW CHEMICAL
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that it would begin a stock repurchase program for another 20 million shares. On June 30, Dow finished buying back 25 million shares under a plan announced in July 1995. Since the beginning of 1995, Dow said, it has repurchased 39.3 million shares, or about 15 percent of its stock outstanding. The shares would be bought on the open market or in private transactions. Dow's stock rose 50 cents yesterday, to $79.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 2 Bombings Complicate Yeltsin's War Against Crime
description: For the second day in a row, a bomb ripped through a trolley bus in central Moscow this morning, wounding at least six people.

title: BASEBALL;Act II Opens With Some Mistakes, a Jeter Homer and a Victory
description: Joe Torre's pre-game prediction about things not progressing as well for the Yankees in the second half hung over Camden Yards like an ominous cloud for most of last night. When the Yankees faltered, the manager's words seemed eerie. Does Torre have a Ouija board?

title: Minister Is Released in Child-Abuse Case
description: After 10 years behind bars for child-abuse crimes he swears never happened, the Rev. Nathaniel T. Grady walked out of prison today and into bright sunshine and the bear hugs of friends.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Rothschild Bank Confirms Death of Heir, 41, as Suicide
description: Amschel Rothschild, the man who many people believed was in line to lead the Rothschild family's legendary banking dynasty, committed suicide this week, the company said today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Errors Cited in PATH Deaths
description: The accident near Harrison last December that killed a PATH track foreman and a laborer occurred because the foreman neither obtained permission to work on the track nor posted a watchman, and because the engineer of the train that hit them was inattentive, the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday. In addition, the board found, an engineer and an operations examiner whose train passed through the area shortly before the accident failed to warn the trainmaster that the track workers were on the job without a watchman.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Serving on the bench is less nerve-racking than being on stage -- so says ROBERT BEACH, 66, who was a circuit judge in St. Petersburg, Fla., for 25 years before retiring in 1993.

title: OLD AND UNPROTECTED: A special report.;Problems of the Aged Overwhelm an Agency
description: On Oct. 20, Michael Joseph Gallagher, a hunchbacked, disoriented 72-year-old man, was evicted from the Bronx apartment he had lived in for 27 years. A month later, he was dead, discovered frozen in a Bronx park with a plastic bag draped around him for warmth.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows and exhibitions in Manhattan that are to close soon:

title: EU and Canada Vow to Adopt Tough Retaliatory Measures : Allies Press U.S. To Back Down On Cuba Sanctions
description: PARIS  European and Canadian leaders on Thursday threatened tough retaliation against the United States unless President Bill Clinton agrees to soften key provisions of a U.S. law that would impose sanctions on companies doing business with Fidel Castro's Cuba.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Recalling Ella Fitzgerald, With Love and Songs
description: When it was announced some months ago that Carnegie Hall would present two concerts in early July paying tribute to Ella Fitzgerald, who knew that what was intended as a celebration would end up being a memorial?

title: From Microsoft To Venture Firm
description: Russell Siegelman, the former head of the Microsoft Corporation's on-line service, will join the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers on Sept. 1.

title: Time Warner and Turner to Meet F.T.C.
description: Meetings have been scheduled for next week between Time Warner Inc., the Turner Broadcasting System and members of the Federal Trade Commission as the companies seek approval for the planned sale of Turner Broadcasting to Time Warner.

title: ART REVIEW;In Connecticut, the Old Meets the New
description: IN a completely noncombative way, Connecticut's summer shows oscillate between what might be called the old guard and the new. At one extreme is an exhibition of 18th-century Massachusetts silversmiths in New Haven, and at the other, a show in Ridgefield of emerging black artists, one of four exhibitions that together wend their way through several generations of minority artists, black and Hispanic.

title: G.I.'s in Saudi Arabia on Alert as Plan for Attack Is Reported
description: American troops in Saudi Arabia have been put on the highest possible state of alert because of "concrete reasons" to fear that terrorists may be planning other attacks on military installations there, the Defense Department said today.

title: Don't Ask. My Signature Is Not for Sale.
description: To the Editor:

title: TV WEEKEND;Yes. More On the Trial That Won't Go Away
description: The "trial of the century" continues to dribble across television screens as something of an entrenched cultural artifact. Hardly a day goes by without a new bit of trivia concerning O. J. Simpson. The Learning Channel aims, not entirely successfully, for a touch more depth on Sunday night with two documentaries: "The Trial of O. J. Simpson: An Insider's View With Dominick Dunne," and "The O. J. Simpson Trial: Beyond Black and White."

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a plan by the Chrysler Corporation to stop producing vehicles powered by natural gas misstated the timing. The plan will take effect after the 1996 model year, not the 1997 year.

title: New Jobless Claims Up 18,000 in Week
description: The number of Americans filing first-time claims for unemployment benefits jumped by 18,000 last week, the Labor Department said today. The size of the increase surprised economists, who had been looking for a more modest gain of around 3,000.

title: BOXING;Garden Brawl Erupts After Bowe Is Awarded Victory
description: A heavyweight bout between Riddick Bowe and Andrew Golota dissolved into a frightening brawl involving fans, cornermen and even managers at Madison Square Garden last night, evoking the darkest evenings of boxing's controversial past.

title: New Senate Chief Dresses Down Colleagues
description: Barely three weeks into his new job as the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott summoned his colleagues into the Senate chamber today and upbraided them at length for malingering, obstructing and generally refusing to pass laws.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN ONCOLOGY STOCK FALLS AFTER REPORT
description: The stock of American Oncology Resources Inc. skidded nearly 44 percent yesterday after the physician-management company gave a disappointing earnings forecast for the quarter that ended on June 30. The company, which is based in Houston, said it expected to earn 9 cents or 10 cents a share, compared with 6 cents a share a year earlier adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split. Analysts surveyed by the First Call Corporation had predicted earnings of 11 cents a share. The company also predicted revenues of $47 million, up from $24.7 million in the period a year ago. The company cited rapid expansion for the disappointing forecast. American Oncology shares sank $6.25, to $8.

title: Multiracial People Must No Longer Be Invisible
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;BARRICK GOLD MAKES OFFER FOR AREQUIPA
description: The Barrick Gold Corporation, which is based in Toronto, offered yesterday to buy Arequipa Resources Inc., a Canadian gold mining company, for $668 million (United States). The bid is the second huge takeover effort in recent years by Barrick, the world's largest gold miner outside South Africa. In 1994, it acquired Lac Minerals for $1.6 billion. Arequipa has never mined any ore, but the company has promising gold and copper properties in Peru. On the Toronto Stock Exchange, shares of Arequipa surged above Barrick's offer of $27 (Canadian), or $36.94 (United States), closing at $28.60, up $6.60.

title: COMPANY NEWS;QUESTOR INVESTMENT GROUP TO BUY BUMBLE BEE
description: Questor Public Fund L.P. agreed yesterday to buy Bumble Bee tuna from the Unicord Company of Thailand in a deal that would represent a major shift in the global tuna industry. Terms were not disclosed, but people knowledgeable about the deal said Questor, an investment group in Southfield, Mich., would pay more than $200 million. As part of the deal, Questor would sell three Bumble Bee tuna production plants to the H. J. Heinz Company, based in Pittsburgh, whose Star-Kist Foods Inc. unit would pack Bumble Bee tuna for Questor. The move would allow Heinz to consolidate its Star-Kist plants with Bumble Bee's.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;New Credit Line For Deutsche Babcock
description: Deutsche Babcock A.G. said yesterday that its banks had agreed to provide 600 million marks ($393 million) in a new credit line for a drastic reorganization of the company, an unprofitable German factory builder and machinery maker. The reorganization includes plans to sell the company's special machinery unit, Schumag A.G.

title: In America;Trampled Dreams
description: Ask Cicih Sukaesih about her dreams and you will hear a long, long silence. She has none. In Indonesia, a woman who is 32 years old, unmarried, broke and unemployed keeps her thoughts focused on the short term. Each day is an emergency.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the coming resignation of Chang-Lin Tien, chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley, misstated his age. It is 60, not 66.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Holan Released From Hospital
description: Anaheim Mighty Ducks defenseman MILOS HOLAN, who had been hospitalized since April with complications from a bone-marrow transplant, has gone home.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Thompson Partner Quits in Revamping
description: Jerry Dominus, senior partner and director for national broadcast at J. Walter Thompson USA in New York, is leaving the agency, he said, after his responsibilities were eliminated in a restructuring.

title: Volunteers Search for Missing Girl, 14, in Party Underworld
description: They were surreal scenes: the lawyers at Lollapalooza, the bankers talking to bouncers, the middle-aged accountant interviewing a child with green spiked hair. They came in their jackets and ties bearing fliers and an urgent question: Has anybody seen a girl named Missy?

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;49ers Sign Identical Twins
description: SEAN and SAM MANUEL, identical twins, have signed identical contracts with the San Francisco 49ers, the team announced yesterday.

title: T. F. Gilroy Daly, 65, U.S. Judge, Is Dead
description: T. F. Gilroy Daly, a senior United States District judge in Connecticut whose hallmark as a trial lawyer was winning the freedom of a man wrongly convicted of murder in 1976, died yesterday at his home in Roxbury, Conn. He was 65.

title: AT&T Plans to Offer Internet Over a $500 Wireless Phone
description: Aiming to make it easier to connect wirelessly to the Internet, AT&T's cellular company said today that it planned to introduce a new cellular phone and a related service for sending and receiving data over existing cellular networks.

title: Man Beaten Outside Nightclub Is Back Home
description: Shane L. Daniels spent his first full day back home today, beginning with french toast for breakfast and a meeting this afternoon with his new visiting nurse.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Kidnapped Boy Is Found
description: One June day in 1992, law enforcement officials say, Charles Lee Davis, recently divorced, picked up his 8-year-old son, Brian, from school. He never brought him back. Yesterday, Brian Davis, now 12, was reunited with his mother, Sharon Scott of Scotch Plains, two days after relatives spotted father and son in a department store in Watchung, only 20 miles from the boy's former home. The F.B.I. found Mr. Davis at his Maplewood home yesterday morning, arrested him on kidnapping charges and took Brian back to his mother. Agency officials said that Mr. Davis had fled with Brian to Akron, Ohio, in 1992 but that they had lost track of him there. Ms. Scott had no problem recognizing her son. "He looks like the same kid," she told The Associated Press. "Just 8 years old blown up." TERRY PRISTIN

title: Was That an Old-Boy F.A.A. Farewell or What?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Case Of Honor And Lies
description: ''COURAGE UNDER FIRE" is framed as an inquiry into the death of Capt. Karen Walden, a Medevac pilot whose actions during a gulf war battle have made her a candidate for the Medal of Honor. These facts are known unequivocally about Captain Walden: that she cried under pressure, that she fired a gun at her own men and that she is played by Meg Ryan. Ms. Ryan is not about to be found starring in the first big-budget Hollywood drama to paint a female United States Army officer as a coward.

title: Sports of The Times;Boxing Takes One Below the Belt
description: FOUR low blows produced an even lower blow for boxing last night.

title: Rebuke for Senators
description: Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader for just three weeks, summoned his colleagues into the Senate chamber to criticize them at length for refusing to pass laws. He told Democrats and Republicans alike that the Senate had gotten "all balled up here, and it's not my fault."

title: Where Art Thrives Beyond New York City
description: AS in years past, the summer art season outside New York City has its rewards, though, for whatever reason, fewer of them this year come in the form of temporary exhibitions. That is, except on Long Island, which, as always, is virtually an extension of SoHo.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MCCOWN BUYS TRANSKRIT FOR $86 MILLION
description: McCown De Leeuw & Company, a closely held investment firm, said yesterday that its National Fiberstok Corporation had bought the Transkrit Corporation for $86 million from Rogers Communications Inc. of Toronto. Transkrit, based in Roanoke, Va., makes and markets mailers. National Fiberstok, based in Atlanta, makes envelopes, direct mail products and pressure sensitive labels. McCown, which has offices in New York and Menlo Park, Calif., manages about $450 million in capital and specializes in buying and building middle-market companies in partnership with management.

title: Restaurants
description: Celebrities go next door to TriBeCa Grill. Big spenders vie for tables up the street at Nobu. The limousines block traffic while the people spill outdoors to sip cocktails and wait for tables, blocking the sidewalk. Sometimes they wander down to Zeppole, just to see what is going on. They never stay long; there is no scene to entertain them and they back out the door, a little shocked that this sibling of those glamorous restaurants seems so ordinary.

title: Advertising;A Saatchi & Saatchi survey indicates women are still unhappy with how they are depicted in ads.
description: DESPITE some progress, women are still quite unhappy with the way they are depicted in advertising, according to a new survey by Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising. They believe it frequently treats them as sex objects, and often does not realistically portray their changing roles as wives and mothers.

title: Famine Peril Returns to Sudan as Aid Is Blocked
description: Half a million or more Sudanese are in greater danger of starving in a province in the southern Sudan because the Government in Khartoum will not permit relief officials to fly a C-130 cargo plane over the area to drop food, the executive director of the World Food Program said here today.

title: Across the Region, All Roads Lead to Art Exhibitions
description: Here is information about the art exhibitions that are mentioned in these art reviews. Unless noted, admission is free.

title: An Doai Journal;The Day the Giant American Fell From the Sky
description: Thirty years ago, Douglas Peterson threw a fright into the villagers in this tiny farming hamlet not far from Hanoi. He plummeted out of the sky and landed at the foot of a mango tree.

title: HORSE RACING;Fleet 16: Cigar Sets Out To Tie a Record Streak
description: Bill Mott stood calmly in the midst of the organized clamor of Barn 25 at Belmont Park, surrounded by exercise riders, grooms and walkers and dozens of valuable race horses, and considered the implications of what he was trying to do with his greatest horse, Cigar: match the record of winning 16 straight races, set half a century ago by Citation.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LOCKHEED MARTIN TO DELIVER SATELLITE TO CHINA IN 1997
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation will deliver a telecommunications satellite to a Chinese company in September 1997 in the first commercial launch cooperation between China and the United States, the New China News Agency said early today. Lockheed and China first announced an agreement on a communications satellite in August 1995. The satellite will be equipped with 48 36-megahertz transmitters, equal to the number of satellite transmitters China now has, and will cover the whole of China and most of Asia, the press agency said. China resumed its launch program last week, after delays caused when a rocket blew up within seconds of liftoff in February.

title: After a Spring Revival, Retail Sales Rose Modestly in June
description: American retailers lost some of spring's glow, and Wall Street was quick to punish some of them yesterday when they reported slower sales in June after four months of strong growth.

title: AUTO RACING;Winston Cup Race Roars Toward Texas
description: Bruton Smith, the chairman of the new Texas Motor Speedway near Fort Worth, finally made the announcement yesterday that auto racing fans in the Southwest were anticipating: The $110 million race track will hold its first Winston Cup race next April 6.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Bam Morris Avoids Prison
description: BAM MORRIS, the leading rusher of the Super Bowl and a Texas high school and college football star, was fined $7,000 for possessing marijuana yesterday but avoided jail time.

title: Draw and Match: Karpov Triumphs
description: Anatoly Karpov became the International Chess Federation's world champion yesterday when he and Gata Kamsky agreed to a draw in Game 18 of their match in Elista, Russia.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Beach Closings Dwindle
description: New Jersey closed fewer of its beaches to swimming during the summer of 1995 than in any other year since 1988, according to a report released yesterday by the Natural Resources Defense Council. In all, 86 beaches were closed last year, compared with 238 in 1994. Beach pollution has decreased because of upgraded sewage treatment plants in northern New Jersey, efforts to remove debris from New York Harbor, and improved dumping practices at the Fresh Kills landfill on Staten Island, said John Spinello, special assistant in the State Department of Environmental Protection's office of compliance and enforcement.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SIDNEY BERNSTEIN, 92, has been a theatergoer for almost all his life, but never before has he felt the urge to invest in a play.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GENESIS HEALTH TO ACQUIRE GERIATRIC AND MEDICAL
description: Genesis Health Ventures, based in Kennett Square, Pa., said yesterday that it would acquire the Geriatric and Medical Companies, which is based in Philadelphia, for $91 million in cash and the assumption of $132 million of debt. Genesis offered $5.75 cash for each Geriatric share. Shares of Geriatric gained $1.344, or nearly 34 percent, to $5.344, in Nasdaq trading. Geriatric, which has 19 facilities for long-term care and eight residential care and independent living facilities, said last week that it was in merger talks with an unidentified party. The company will be merged into a subsidiary of Genesis, which operates in five major metropolitan markets in the Eastern United States and serves more than 70,000 customers.

title: Edward P. Ney, 75; Searched the Skies for Cosmic Particles
description: Dr. Edward Purdy Ney, whose early work on the atomic bomb in World War II led him to stalk cosmic particles in the sky and background radiation on earth, died on Tuesday at his home in Minneapolis. He was 75.

title: POP REVIEW;Sinning but Still Ready for Salvation
description: For years, Willie Nelson concerts have been like chocolate candies with different types of filling. Despite varying consistency, the chocolate has always been the same -- a tried-and-true collection of original hits and pop and country standards -- but the filling has varied, depending on the nature of Mr. Nelson's current project. When Mr. Nelson performed at the Beacon Theater last year, the filling was sickly sweet: the orchestra-enhanced ballads of his then-current "Healing Hands of Time" album. On Wednesday night at the Supper Club, the filling was just right: Mr. Nelson's slick and wistful Tex-Mex-flavored paean to love and loss, "Spirit" (Island).

title: Not Only Judges Need a Grasp on Genetics
description: To the Editor:

title: Japanese Stocks Fall
description: Stocks were trading lower here today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues stood at 21,655.14, down 237.44 points, or 1.08 percent. In trading on Thursday, the index advanced 113.64 points, to 21,892.58.

title: NYC;Netanyahu: U.S. Style, Israeli Content
description: ABOUT a year ago, Benjamin Netanyahu was fast-walking on a leafy street in Jerusalem when he bumped into someone who lived there, a man he had met many times before. When the man expressed surprise, Mr. Netanyahu, who was then Israel's opposition leader, explained that he had just moved into the neighborhood.

title: Local Politicians Line Up To Meet With Netanyahu
description: As Benjamin Netanyahu chatted with elected officials on some of the city's plushest hotel couches yesterday, a strict rule of protocol applied: there must always be a plate of fruit or cookies between the various leaders and it must never be touched.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on June 25 about the Rev. Dr. Suzan Johnson Cook misstated her role in the publication of the book "Sister to Sister: Devotions For and From African-American Women." She was its editor, not its author.

title: Sports of The Times;Jordan's Bunker View On Sneaker Factories
description: MICHAEL JORDAN, pancake cap turned backward on his head, was seen yesterday on a television film clip blasting a golf ball out of a bunker in Fresno, Calif. Jordan is on vacation, for about three months, obviously enjoying a much-deserved rest after leading his team to another National Basketball Association championship. It is a much greater rest than that enjoyed by many of the people who, at bottom, help make him one of America's richer people.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Cry, the Beloved Country 1995. Miramax $100.72. Laser disk, $39.99. 120 minutes. Closed captioned. PG-13. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Mortgage Rates Climb
description: The national average for 30-year mortgages climbed sharply this week, rising to 8.42 percent, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. It was the highest level in nearly 17 months, since 30-year mortgages averaged 8.62 percent in early March 1995. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 6.01 percent, up from 5.94 percent last week. Mortgages with a 15-year term averaged 7.93 percent this week, up from 7.67 percent last week.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Radio Doctor Loses License
description: After a hearing that lasted nearly 11 hours, the Board of Medical Examiners early yesterday suspended the license of a doctor who promoted alternative medicine on his weekly radio show on WOR-AM. Eric Braverman may not practice medicine until a hearing before a judge that is not expected to occur for several months, said Tom Lowe, a spokesman for the state Office of Administrative Law. The board found that Dr. Braverman, who has a practice near Princeton, repeatedly misdiagnosed serious ailments and prescribed inappropriate treatments for his patients.

title: Shares of Managed Care Companies Fall
description: The stocks of managed care companies plummeted yesterday as the United Healthcare Corporation joined a parade of health insurers disclosing bad news to investors.

title: Term Limits (Longer Ones, This Time) Go Back on the Ballot
description: Three years after New Yorkers voted overwhelmingly to impose term limits on the city's elected officials, they will be asked to reconsider their decision in a vote this fall on whether to extend the limit from 8 years to 12.

title: Bomb Items Found; Shop Owner Charged
description: A Brooklyn man, who the police say was setting up a bomb ordering business, was arrested yesterday after a raid by investigators uncovered materials that could make up to 1,000 pounds of dynamite.

title: Adult Smoking Is Leveling Off
description: After years of slowly declining, the proportion of adults who smoke appears to have leveled off in 1993 at about 25 percent, according to a study released yesterday by the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Pancho Villa's Wife, 100
description: Soledad Seanez Holguin, the widow of the Mexican revolutionary hero Pancho Villa, died here today. She was 100.

title: INSIDE
description: Pork in Wage Bill

title: Chaos in Burundi Could Sow Misery Next Door
description: When Burundi's divided Government recently asked neighboring countries to send troops to help quell ethnic violence, it represented the first breakthrough in a deadly three-year stalemate between Hutu and Tutsi political leaders.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the TKTS booth for discounted theater seats referred incompletely to the advance sales for the musical "Big." The $1 million figure was the advance for July only; the total advance is $3 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Novartis Communications, Basel, Switzerland, the company being formed by the merger of Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz Pharmaceuticals, to Ruder-Finn Inc., New York, to handle advertising and communications. Billings were estimated at $45 million to $50 million.
