title: Britain to Retain Reliquary Casket Dating to 1195
description: After a week of public outcry that an 800-year-old reliquary casket commemorating the martyrdom and burial of St. Thomas a Becket had been lost to England, the casket's owner agreed yesterday to let the National Heritage Memorial Fund and the Victoria and Albert Museum buy it from him.

title: ART REVIEW;Rediscovering Upstate Collections
description: THIS summer's art season in Westchester and the Hudson Valley seems best for what's not new. Yes, there are new exhibitions like the shows opening on Sunday at Bard College in Annandale-on-Hudson. One of these surveys the work of Boris Mikhailov, the Ukrainian photographer, and another brings together art by three recent generations of Hungarian modernists. (They're on view through Sept. 21.) The Katonah Museum of Art is showing, through July 21, recent poster art from Poland.

title: Get Serious About Mr. Karadzic
description: The major powers agreed this week in London that Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb political leader, belongs in The Hague standing trial for war crimes, including the mass killing of civilians in Srebrenica one year ago this week. Yet the American, British, French, German and Russian Governments failed to agree on any new diplomatic or economic pressure to achieve this worthy goal.

title: Senior Bosnian Serbs Face New Warrants
description: The United Nations war crimes tribunal issued international arrest warrants for the Bosnian Serbs' political leader, Radovan Karadzic, and their military chief, Gen. Ratko Mladic, both charged with genocide in the four-year Bosnian war.

title: Dole Says N.A.A.C.P. Invitation Was Leader's Bid 'to Set Me Up'
description: Bob Dole said today that the president of the N.A.A.C.P. was "trying to set me up" by inviting him to address the black organization's annual meeting earlier this week. Mr. Dole, the likely Republican Presidential nominee, said he would look for friendlier audiences that "I can relate to."

title: Mike Leigh's New Film Will Open the New York Festival
description: Secrets and Lies," a British film directed by Mike Leigh, will open the 34th New York Film Festival on Sept. 27.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Raiders Sign Their Top Pick
description: The Oakland Raiders' top draft pick this year, tight end RICKEY DUDLEY, agreed to contract terms and will be among the players at the opening of training camp, the team said. Dudley, the ninth overall choice in the draft out of Ohio State, was the first top 10 draft selection to agree on a contract. Dudley didn't play football at Ohio State until his junior year so that he could concentrate on basketball. He had 37 receptions for 575 yards his senior year. (AP)

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOEING IS PLANNING AN EMPLOYEE STOCK FUND
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that it was establishing an unusual $1 billion stock fund for its 108,000 employees that could lead to big bonuses for workers in the next decade. Under the plan, Boeing would establish an investment trust fund of 11.3 million shares of its stock, about 7.8 million of which would be purchased on the open market in the next few months. Returns over an average 3 percent a year, including appreciation and reinvested dividends, would be distributed to employees every two years beginning in 1998. An average annual total stock return of 15 percent would result in a pre-tax distribution of $1,150 in stock for each worker in 1998 and an additional $2,750 in 2000, according to figures provided by the company.

title: Council Seeks Raise for Contract Workers
description: Upset that many companies doing work for New York City pay their workers the minimum wage, the City Council overwhelmingly approved a bill yesterday that would require those private contractors to pay 3,500 workers far more.

title: Multiracial People Must No Longer Be Invisible;What History Shows
description: To the Editor:

title: Keep in Mind
description: PROFESSIONAL TREE CLIMBERS' JAMBOREE, a competition among tree climbers from the New York State Arborist Association. Among the competitive events are the "work" climb, in which climbers ascend to three work stations in a tree and are judged on safety, technique and poise; aerial rescue, in which they are judged on their ability to save someone safely; throwline, which involves throwing a weight through targets, and the speed climb, on a 40-foot vertical rope. Tomorrow, 10:30 A.M., at the New York Botanical Garden, Southern Boulevard and 200th Street, Bedford Park, the Bronx. By subway, take the D or No. 4 train to Bedford Park Boulevard. Admission: $3 for adults and $1 for children 6 to 16. Information: (718) 817-8700.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Facelift for Tunnel Plaza
description: The Lincoln Tunnel toll plaza is getting a $42.5 million facelift. The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey voted yesterday to build new tollbooths, resurface roads and upgrade the toll supervisor's building at the plaza. The renovations will also set the stage for electronic toll collecting. The project is to begin next summer and be completed in 1999, Port Authority officials said. Construction will be limited to off-peak hours, and four temporary tollbooths will be built.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Warning of Hot, Dry Weather Drives Up the Price of Corn
description: Corn and soybean prices surged at the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday after weather forecasters warned that hot, dry weather could arrive in the days ahead, stunting agricultural growth as crops enter crucial stages of development.

title: Big Sale in the Hamptons? Not So Fast
description: ABC Carpet and Home has flourished as a home furnishing giant in Manhattan, but has found itself unwelcome on Long Island's affluent East End.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Jackson Re-signs With Packers
description: KEITH JACKSON, who missed the first six weeks of last season in a holdout and then starred in Green Bay's 27-17 upset of San Francisco in the playoffs, signed a two-year free agent deal with the Packers yesterday.

title: Republicans Shift Strategy in Bid to Avoid Welfare Bill Veto
description: At Bob Dole's urging, Republican Congressional leaders moved today to either enact welfare legislation or force President Clinton into a veto they could use against him in the election campaign.

title: Was That an Old-Boy F.A.A. Farewell or What?
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;New Interest Reported In Bankrupt Fokker
description: The Dutch Economics Ministry said yesterday that new companies had emerged as possible rescuers of the bankrupt plane maker Fokker N.V., but it declined to give names. "There is interest in Fokker from international companies," said a spokesman, Luuc van Zijp. He added that the Economics Minister, Hans Wijers, had informed the Russian aircraft companies Yakovlev and Tupolev they were not the only aerospace concerns in the running for Fokker.

title: Leaving the White House To a Medley of Memories
description: Col. John R. Bourgeois has had a closeup view at the White House for 38 years. He has played every Presidential Inauguration since 1961, and he let Bill Clinton, when he was still just the saxophone-playing Governor of Arkansas, jam with him at a governors' dinner at the White House.

title: Congress Is Faulted on North Korea
description: The Clinton Administration accused Congress today of jeopardizing an international agreement under which North Korea consented to freeze its nuclear program.

title: FOOTBALL;With Douglas, Jets Rush In
description: For the first time in the 1990's, the Jets have found a full-time pass rusher. At least, they hope so.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: SCIENTISTS DISPLAY SUBSTANTIAL GAINS IN AIDS TREATMENT
description: Results from several studies showed today that whether people were infected for weeks or years combinations of new and older drugs suppressed the virus below the limits of detection for long periods of time.

title: Poland to Join O.E.C.D.
description: Poland agreed today to join the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development later this year, after the treaty is ratified by the Polish parliament.

title: Islamic Party Walking A Tightrope in Turkey
description: For the last six months, Turkish politics have been paralyzed by an untested question: if a popular Islamic party joined the Government, would that put the pro-Western, secular foundations of the Turkish state at risk?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Group to Re-edit TV Commercials
description: The Partnership for a Drug-Free America has agreed to re-edit television commercials that had been labeled "patently homophobic" by the Gay and Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation.

title: A Hong Kong Image Maker Takes Long Look at Barneys
description: Here in Hong Kong, where New York is regarded as somewhat of a distant backwater, the big news about Dickson Poon recently had nothing to do with reports that he was interested in buying Barneys, the bankrupt New York clothing retailer.

title: Multiracial People Must No Longer Be Invisible;Don't Label Me
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Angels and Insects 1995. Evergreen. $98.32. Laser disk, $39.99. 117 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Stock Decline Helps Bonds Rise 3d Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities gained for a third consecutive session yesterday as investors focused on inflation data due today and a swirl of opinions about Federal Reserve monetary policy.

title: Senate Sees an Opportunity and Seizes It
description: To the public, the last-minute fight this week over raising the Federal minimum wage centered on a Republican amendment that would have sharply reduced the number of people entitled to it.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Eye for an Eye 1996. Paramount. $99.12. Laser disk, $39.98. 102 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Minimum-Wage Bill Gets Maximum Additions To the public, the last-minute fight over raising the Federal minimum wage centered on a Republican amendment that would have sharply reduced the number of people entitled to it. But to the Senate, the real last-minute issue was how many provisions could be tacked on to one of the few bills likely to be enacted anytime soon -- and probably the only tax bill Congress will approve this year.

title: No Headline
description: Whatever it takes to leave a better country for our children and grandchildren, if anybody should do it, I should do it."

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;4 Miami Players, 3 Court Cases
description: The Miami Hurricanes' recent rash of troubles reached the courtroom yesterday with four players arraigned in three cases. All four pleaded not guilty.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Back Up Words With Bats
description: The Mets had talked a good game just before the All-Star break. They had convinced themselves that their best baseball was still ahead of them and that with some good fortune their season might be meaningful after all. Last night it was time to walk the walk.

title: Corrections
description: A movie review of "Independence Day" on July 2 misstated its rating. It is PG-13 (Parents strongly cautioned), not PG (Parental guidance suggested).

title: CHRONICLE
description: PADDY MOLONEY, the leader of the Chieftains, the traditional Irish music group, is not a soap opera aficionado, so when it was proposed that his group appear on "One Life to Live," he had his doubts.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;An Ex-Conservative Indicts the Right
description: UP FROM CONSERVATISM Why the Right Is Wrong for America By Michael Lind 295 pages. The Free Press. $23.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets' Offer Is Far Short Of Childs's Expectations
description: It seemed as if point guard Chris Childs had the leverage to pry as much money as he wanted from the Nets, but the team's offer to him today was not an act of desperation.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Higher Sales Posted By Ciba and Sandoz
description: The Swiss pharmaceuticals giants Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz, which have agreed to merge, both reported sales growth for the first half of the year and said they were confident they would receive approval to proceed with their merger. Ciba-Geigy reported that first-half sales grew by 4 percent, to 11.43 billion Swiss francs ($9.1 billion), and Sandoz said its six-month sales rose by 7 percent, to 7.87 billion Swiss francs ($6.24 billion).

title: Schoenberg Archives to Leave U.S.C.
description: The University of Southern California has agreed to give up its vast collection of musical scores, papers, drawings, writings and tapes of the composer Arnold Schoenberg and to pay half the cost of transferring the collection elsewhere, ending a bitter dispute with the Schoenberg heirs.

title: FILM REVIEW;Time Travelers With Bad Breath and Worse Manners
description: When a pair of time travelers from 12th-century France find themselves accidentally deposited in the year 1992, what do you suppose it is about them that most horrifies the fastidious French? Of course, it is their rotten teeth, their horrible breath and their tendency to get violently carsick when riding around in what they refer to as "chariots."

title: Democrats Drafting a Platform With a Corner for Dissent
description: Ostentatiously unified, a group of Democratic Party officials today finished the first stage of drafting a party platform that reflects President Clinton's policies across a range of issues but tries to remain broad enough so that Democrats who disagree with the President on particular points will not be antagonized.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rock Traffic Doesn't Roll
description: Truckin' they weren't. Traffic on the New Jersey Turnpike was slowed yesterday by fans flocking to a seven-hour rock concert at Liberty State Park in Jersey City, creating delays that continued well into the evening rush.

title: House Passes Budget Bill; G.O.P. Rejects Clinton Items
description: Ignoring a veto threat from the White House and rejecting Democrat efforts to rescue some programs that are dear to President Clinton, the House early today approved a $285.6 billion spending plan for next year for Labor, Health and Human Services, and Education.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Chase Hornets' Johnson as N.B.A. Resumes Business
description: As the National Basketball Association resumed its off-season business yesterday, several players were traded, but Anthony Mason was not one of them. Not yet.

title: Give Dole a Break
description: Ever since Bob Dole suggested that tobacco is not addictive for everyone, journalists and anti-smoking activists have been reacting as if he had declared that the earth is flat. But while the Republican candidate for President spoke somewhat loosely, the gist of his comments on smoking is so obviously true that it is hard to see what all the fuss is about.

title: Sony to Sell PC in Japan
description: The Sony Corporation, which last month showed its first personal computer, said today that it planned to sell PC's in Japan next spring that will be similar to what it will begin selling next month in the United States.

title: About Real Estate;On Palisades, 2- and 3-Family Homes
description: Here on a ridge carved from the Palisades and overlooking the Hudson River, an enclave of two- and three-family homes is beginning to rise.

title: Wall St. Uneasy As Stocks Slide
description: Stocks tumbled yesterday, as signs of weakening corporate profits further shook the confidence of investors already worried about the prospect of higher interest rates.

title: Bosnian Serbs Celebrate Srebrenica
description: Most of the world regards it as the date on which the worst war crime began in a war covered in crimes, but Bosnian Serb leaders have given it a new name: Liberation Day. And today, many of Srebrenica's new Serbian residents celebrated the anniversary of the capture of the town from Muslims one year ago.

title: Council Term Limit Proposal Offers No Change
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA REVIEW;An Evening in the Park With Rarely Heard Verdi
description: Wednesday night's performance of Verdi's "Alzira" by the New York Grand Opera Company in Central Park was the kind of event that makes you feel good about New York. Whereas so many summer music festivals play it safe, this scrappy outfit and its dedicated artistic director, Vincent La Selva, are engaged in a daunting seven-year project to present staged performances of all 28 Verdi operas in chronological order. "Alzira," the first offering of the project's third summer, is so little known and unavailable that Mr. La Selva had to have the individual orchestra parts copied by hand from the full score.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Old Lady Who Walked in the Sea 1995. Evergreen. $98.32. Laser disk, $39.99. 94 minutes. French with English subtitles. No rating.

title: Kielce Should Bury The Communist Canard
description: To the Editor:

title: Diner's Journal
description: Ansonia, the ambitious new restaurant where Memphis used to be, is open until 2 A.M., and already it has become a hangout for chefs. They drop in to munch on the late-night menu of Thai-inspired spare ribs, sourdough onion rings, clams and oysters on the half shell or American farmstead cheeses. If they like, they can choose from an awesome selection of beers or an appealing wine list.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Strike Plan Dropped By British Airways Pilots
description: British Airways P.L.C.'s pilots' union said yesterday that it had called off plans for a strike to begin next Tuesday after British Airways raised its pay offer and made other concessions. The union called the new offer a "great success." It said British Airways had agreed to increase the pay of pilots in its operations at Gatwick Airport in London and to drop a plan to shrink crew rest areas on Boeing 747 jets.

title: Potlatch to Close a Mill to Make Repairs
description: The Potlatch Corporation said today that it planned to close its pulp and paperboard mill in Lewiston, Idaho, during the fourth quarter for repairs.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: Time for Playing It Straight

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-11

title: After Standoff, Both Sides Can Take Credit for Victories
description: By holding the budget hostage for more than three months, Gov. George E. Pataki gambled that he could pressure legislative leaders into enacting major changes in several areas of state government. But in the end, he felt the pressure as much as the legislators did, and ultimately settled today on a budget deal that gave all sidessomething to walk away with.

title: Storm Prompts Exodus From Carolinas' Coast
description: As the first major hurricane of the season bore down on the coasts of North and South Carolina this evening, Monica Cioffi's family practically had the beach here to themselves.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Fidelity to End Sale of Funds By 3d Parties Like Schwab
description: Fidelity Investments, in a major shift in how it markets its mutual funds to individual investors, will stop selling its most popular funds through third-party retail channels, including Charles Schwab & Company's Mutual Fund Marketplace and similar programs at other discount brokerage firms, Fidelity said yesterday.

title: Multiracial People Must No Longer Be Invisible;On Raising Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Palestinians Voice Dismay At Comments By Netanyahu
description: As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu uses an American tour to vow steadfastness on Jerusalem, Palestinian officials are expressing new dismay at what they describe as a deliberate effort to inflame tensions between peace partners.

title: As Germans Seek Sun, Economy Clouds Future
description: Almost casually, Parliament voted this week to raise the retirement age so that Germans will have to work until they are older to receive full pensions. Then the deputies, their job done, went off for a full seven weeks of summer vacation.

title: When Liberty Is a Step Off a Bus;Freed Inmates Carry Worldly Goods and Pocket Change
description: Before the sun rises over the East River each weekday morning, a peculiar ritual is performed in the heart of Queens.

title: ART REVIEW;New Jersey Shares Worldly Treasures
description: THIS is a fairly low-key summer in New Jersey art museums, with one really spectacular exhibition unfortunately ending its run this weekend in Newark.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Top 800-Meter Runner Is No Closer to Games
description: The Danish Olympic Committee has asked that the world's top 800-meter runner, Wilson Kipketer, be allowed to compete in the Summer Games as a stateless athlete, but there appeared to be little chance that the native of Kenya would run in the Atlanta Games.

title: Multiracial People Must No Longer Be Invisible;Diminishing Us All
description: To the Editor:

title: Security Levels To Set a Record At the Olympics
description: The largest peacetime security operation for a public event in American history is being mounted to protect the Atlanta Olympics, with three times as many guards as athletes, computerized credentials that recognize hands and can be turned off by remote control, ubiquitous television monitors (including some in a blimp overhead), and intelligence agents preparing an "antipathy matrix" of who in the world is angry at whom.

title: Battle Lines Drawn In Fight for Barneys
description: As the fall season's Armani jackets were filling the racks at Barneys New York, executives from the Hong Kong retailer Dickson Concepts skulked around the store. They eyed the pricey knit tops, the exclusive cosmetics, the $40 antique buttons. They touched displays, sized up snazzy shoes. They liked what they saw so much, in fact, that they decided they just might take it.

title: Broader Warrants Issued for 2 Bosnian Serbs
description: The United Nations war crimes tribunal issued international arrest warrants today for the Bosnian Serbs' political leader, Radovan Karadzic, and their military chief, Gen. Ratko Mladic, who are charged with genocide and other crimes in the four-year Bosnian war.

title: ON BASEBALL;Yanks Play Smart by Playing Small
description: Darryl Strawberry, the embodiment of the three-run homer, arrived here yesterday to play against the team whose legendary manager, Earl Weaver, forever underlined the importance of such power.

title: Albany's Addiction to Delay
description: New York State's budget finally seems on its way to passage, more than 100 days behind schedule. It was the 12th late budget in a row, and this one may be the latest for any state budget in modern American history. Voters might well ask what the point was of all this delay. The package, after all, is essentially the one legislative leaders agreed to back in May. On the deal-breaking issue of workers' compensation, Gov. George Pataki wrested some reforms out of the Assembly Democrats. But the changes were so modest and reasonable they could have been agreed to long ago if the state's budget process were more rational.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Lloyd's and State Regulators Set Accord on Suits in U.S.
description: Lloyd's of London said yesterday that it had reached an agreement with a group of state regulators to resolve lawsuits brought on behalf of American investors who contended that they were were defrauded by the international insurance syndicate.

title: 25 and Under
description: From the "now you see it, now you don't" department:

title: Trade Body Finds Japan Overtaxes Imported Liquor
description: The World Trade Organization said that Japanese taxes illegally penalize imported alcoholic drinks, including Scotch whisky and cognac, and ordered Japan to end the discrimination.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column on Monday, about the Wimbledon men's tennis final, misstated the birthplace of the winner, Richard Krajicek. It was the Netherlands, not Czechoslovakia.

title: A Market Ripe for Manipulation;Laxity in London Opened Door for a Sumitomo Trader
description: Anyone who has taken Economics 101 knows that the price of goods and services is determined by supply and demand.

title: FOOTBALL;Almost 7 Years Later, Walker a Cowboy Again
description: Herschel Walker and the Dallas Cowboys met, talked and pondered their needs in recent days, then left with this idea: Let's do it again. And so they have.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * Philip S. Press was named to the new position of executive director at Media Inc., New York, a unit of Western International Media, which is owned by the Interpublic Group of Cos. He had most recently been executive vice president for sales and marketing for the television stations owned and operated by CBS.

title: The Senate Strangles Itself
description: Trent Lott, the new majority leader of the Senate, exploded in frustration on the floor this week, complaining that Democrats were exploiting the rules to block Senate action. That they certainly were, and so were Republicans -- holding up bills on everything from nuclear waste to domestic violence. But what did he expect?

title: Whitewater Defendant and Prosecutor Clash Over Testimony
description: As his cross-examination began today, a defendant in the second trial brought by the Whitewater independent counsel bristled repeatedly in response to a prosecutor who ridiculed his earlier testimony.

title: Beliefs
description: As the White House discovered when Hillary Rodham Clinton's brainstorming sessions with Jean Houston, a self-described "sacred psychologist," became a media moment, the New Age movement is still capable of provoking sharp reactions.

title: Astronaut's Ride Home Is Delayed for 6 Weeks
description: NASA yesterday delayed by six weeks the return of Shannon Lucid to Earth from a Russian outpost so as to replace rocket boosters on the shuttle that was to bring her home.

title: Arena Gets Tidy Profit From a Messy Match
description: Thursday night's fight card at Madison Square Garden featuring the Riddick Bowe-Andrew Golota bout resulted in a frightening brawl -- and a profit for the Garden of about $100,000.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMMERCIAL INTERTECH BOARD SEEKS BID REJECTION
description: The board of the Commercial Intertech Corporation of Youngstown, Ohio, recommended yesterday that shareholders reject a $500 million bid from United Dominion Industries Ltd. Instead, the board reaffirmed a plan that includes spinning off its Cuno Inc. filtration unit and buying back up to 2.5 million of its 15.5 million shares. United Dominion, meanwhile, began its offer to buy Commercial Intertech shares directly from stockholders for $27 each. That offer expires on Aug. 8. United Dominion, a building-products maker in Charlotte, N.C., also filed a complaint against Commercial Intertech, its directors and the Ohio Securities Commissioner. The complaint asks that a Federal court declare unconstitutional provisions of an Ohio law related to the merger.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Vikings Bid for Carter
description: The Minnesota Vikings signed the free agent All-Pro cornerback DALE CARTER to an offer sheet yesterday and the Kansas City Chiefs have one week to match it to retain him. Carter, 26, was a first-team All-Pro selection for the Chiefs last year. He was the National Football League rookie of the year for Kansas City in 1992. If Kansas City does not match the offer, the Vikings will not be obligated to send the Chiefs any compensation. (AP)

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Christie Loses Again
description: Linford Christie's Olympic buildup took another major blow Friday when he finished second to Jamaica's Michael Green in his last race before he defends the title in Atlanta. Although running into a headwind, Christie also had a modest time as both men clocked 10.26 seconds at Crystal Palace in London. (AP)

title: MUSIC REVIEW;The Tokyo Quartet With a New Leader
description: Lincoln Center has an opportunity to test two entirely opposing philosophies of arts presentation this summer. At the Mostly Mozart Festival, which opened this week at Avery Fisher Hall, the underlying assumption is that audiences want their summer evenings untroubled by programmatic or interpretive provocations, and will flock to hear performers they've come to know and love. The other side of the coin is to be tested in a few weeks, when the new Lincoln Center Festival '96 offers provocation as a virtue and stakes its bankroll that there is an audience for performers, works and even art forms that are virtually unknown in New York.

title: Classy Lincoln Center Deserves a Classic Clock
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Media Business page on June 20 about a conditional approval of the Thomson Corporation's purchase of the West Publishing Company misstated the ownership of 58 legal publications that the Justice Department has required to be sold. Thirty-six of the publications are owned by Thomson; not all 58 are owned by West.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Graf's Father Near Trial
description: STEFFI GRAF's father will go on trial in September on tax-evasion charges, the District Court in Mannheim, Germany, announced yesterday. PETER GRAF and the family tax adviser, JOACHIM ECKARDT, are charged with failing to report $28 million of his daughter's earnings to evade $13.3 million in taxes between 1987 and 1993. The exact date of the trial has not been set, but it is most likely to start in the first half of September, the press office of the court said. (AP)

title: Pancho Villa Widow, 100
description: Soledad Seanez Holguin, the widow of the Mexican revolutionary hero Pancho Villa, died here on Thursday. She was 100.

title: Musician for Smashing Pumpkins Dies of Apparent Drug Overdose
description: A keyboard player touring with the Smashing Pumpkins, one of alternative rock's most popular bands, was found dead of an apparent heroin overdose in his room at the Regency Hotel in Manhattan yesterday, and the band's drummer, Jimmy Chamberlin, was arrested on drug possession charges, the police said.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Huge Deal Will Keep Jordan With Bulls
description: While Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls completed a huge deal yesterday, the Knicks' Anthony Mason-for-Larry Johnson trade remained on hold, probably until Monday.

title: BASEBALL;Rainy-Day Concern For Yanks: Pitching
description: The discussion in Manager Joe Torre's office before and after tonight's game between the Yankees and Orioles was rained out focused on pitching, and the various scenarios ranged from brilliant to bleak. While the Yankees have a seven-game lead over second-place Baltimore, they still have mounds of pitching concerns.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ADCO TECHNOLOGIES AGREES TO BE ACQUIRED BY ASTOR
description: Adco Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by the Astor Corporation, a specialty chemical company, for $10.25 a share, or $54 million in cash. Adco, a maker of sealants and adhesives based in Michigan Center, Mich., said the deal had been approved by the boards of both companies. Astor, based in Raleigh, N.C., is owned by Aurora Capital Partners L.P. of Los Angeles.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report in the Company News column of Business Day yesterday about the sale of the Bumble Bee tuna business by the Unicord Company misstated the name of the buyer. It is Questor Partners Fund L.P., not Questor Public Fund.

title: Murder Indictment to Be Sought In Teen-Ager's Fatal Beating
description: After the death of a 13-year-old boy whose beating in January led to assault convictions against three schoolmates, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes of Brooklyn said yesterday that he would ask a grand jury to consider a murder indictment.

title: Insurance Industry to Offer Aid To Black Churches Hit by Arson
description: Reacting to criticism that black churches recently torched by arsonists have been denied coverage, the insurance industry said it would help find insurance for any previously covered house of worship destroyed in such an attack.

title: Deal Is Expected In U.S. Inquiry Into Nasdaq
description: The Justice Department is preparing to announce a settlement with about 30 securities firms following a two-year-long investigation into allegations that Nasdaq market-makers colluded on pricing, several brokerage firm excecutives and lawyers said yesterday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;2 Brazilian Banks In Talks to Merge
description: Banco de Credito Nacional S.A., one of Brazil's largest nonstate banks, and Banco Itamarati S.A. are holding talks to merge, the two banks said yesterday. Control of the newly formed bank, which would rank among Brazil's five largest, was not immediately clear. Further details will be supplied when talks are concluded, the banks said.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Moceanu Making Progress
description: Dimitry Moceanu was watching his 14-year-old daughter from the stands in Greensboro, N.C., and remembering what it was like to watch the United States Olympic trials with her sitting next to him.

title: Turn Those Frowns Around, Boomers
description: To the Editor:

title: HORSE RACING;For Cigar, The Star Treatment In Chicago
description: They were met by no marching bands or police escort or officials offering keys to the city, but they were undoubtedly the stars of the show when they landed at O'Hare Airport in midafternoon and were driven to Arlington International Racecourse for the showdown. It takes place on Saturday between Cigar, gunning for his record-tying 16th straight victory, and Unbridled's Song, his traveling companion and chief challenger.

title: Alex Manoogian, 95; Perfected Design of Single-Handled Faucet
description: Alex Manoogian, the Armenian immigrant responsible for making the single-handled faucet a ubiquitous fixture in modern bathrooms and kitchens throughout the United States and around the world, died on Wednesday at St. John Hospital in Detroit. Mr. Manoogian, who lived in Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., was 95.

title: Retail Sales Fell in June; Producer Prices Up Slightly
description: Retail sales fell in June, while producer prices rose modestly last month, the Government reported today, in two reports that eased some concerns about inflation and interest rates.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HORIZON CELLULAR GROUP SELLING LICENSES TO SYGNET
description: Horizon Cellular Group said yesterday that it would sell cellular licenses in four markets in Pennsylvania and New York -- about a third of its business -- to Sygnet Communications Inc. for $250 million. Horizon also completed the sale of a Georgia market to Palmer Wireless Inc. last week for $35 million. The closely held Horizon Cellular, based in Malvern, Pa., has been exploring strategic options, including the sale of the company, since August. It reached a definitive agreement with Sygnet, a closely held cellular phone service provider, based in Youngstown, Ohio, for sale of the four licenses. The licenses stretch from near Pittsburgh north to Buffalo and Rochester and represent about 1.3 million potential customers, said Bruce Hernandez, a Horizon spokesman.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WASHINGTON FEDERAL IS ADDING METROPOLITAN BANCORP
description: Washington Federal Inc. has agreed to acquire Metropolitan Bancorp, another Seattle-based banking company, in a stock deal worth about $66.8 million, the companies said yesterday. Under the agreement, Washington Federal will offer $18 worth of its stock for each of Metropolitan's 3.71 million shares outstanding in a tax-free exchange. In connection with the merger, Phoenix Mortgage and Investment Inc., a subsidiary of Metropolitan, will be acquired by Phoenix's management. Washington Federal has an option to acquire up to 19.9 percent of Metropolitan's stock if the deal does not close under certain circumstances.

title: Having Had It Before, Kerkorian Seeks Control of MGM
description: Kirk Kerkorian just cannot seem to stay away from Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Inc.

title: If U Cn Rd This . . .
description: The conventional wisdom these days is that the art of penmanship is vanishing and that the culprit is electronic. As a Michigan teacher recently told The Chicago Tribune, "Handwriting has taken a big beating because of computers and keyboards."

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Donors Increase Fund To Rebuild Cambodia
description: International donors and lending agencies pledged today to give an additional $500 million to help Cambodia rebuild its economy after years of war. Japan is the largest contributor, promising up to $90 million in development aid and $2.5 million to clear land mines.

title: How the House Voted on Gay Marriages
description: Following is the roll-call of 342 to 67 by which the House today voted to define marriage in Federal law as a legal union of one man and one woman, no matter what states may say. Voting "yes" were 224 Republicans and 118 Democrats. Voting "no" were 1 Republican, 65 Democrats and 1 independent. Voting "present" were 2 Democrats. An X denotes members who did not vote. There is 1 vacancy in the 435-member House.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Balancing Terror and Cheesiness
description: Roger Corman had good reason for choosing the title of his entertaining autobiography, "How I Made a Hundred Movies in Hollywood and Never Lost a Dime." As a director and producer, he managed to wring the maximum horror, sex and campy humor out of minuscule budgets. Without him the world wouldn't have "The Terror," in which Jack Nicholson meets Boris Karloff.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Texas Man Charged In Church Burning
description: A man was arrested in connection with an arson fire that caused about $100,000 in damage to his church, the police said today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Bulls Renounce Knight
description: Rather than offer a required three-year guaranteed contract to the first-round draft choice TRAVIS KNIGHT, the Chicago Bulls yesterday surrendered all rights to the 7-foot center from UConn. Bulls General Manager JERRY KRAUSE said that under the previous labor agreement, the coaches would have been able to see Knight play in a summer league before offering him a contract. (AP)

title: For an Exclusive With Netanyahu, Just Get in Line
description: He made his debut as the celebrity spokesman for WINS radio's traffic reports. He served as the utility "exclusive interview" of the day. He facilitated the distribution of ice cream coupons. And, figuring "Why not?" on a summer Friday afternoon, he went to the movies.

title: Europe Court Backs Ban on British Beef
description: The European Union's high court ruled today that the 12-nation organization was within its rights to halt worldwide sales of British beef in response to concern over so-called mad cow disease.

title: Charles and Diana Agree on Divorce Terms
description: It began as an old-fashioned fairy tale but soon became just another failed modern marriage, brought down by anger, tears and adultery. And today, almost 15 years after the wedding between Lady Diana Spencer and Charles, the Prince of Wales, the consummately incompatible couple announced that they had finally reached an agreement on the terms for their divorce.

title: Traverse City Journal;Utility Customers Put a Premium on Wind Energy
description: This time of year, the fields on the high bluff west of Traverse City begin to yield all sorts of crops: cherries, peaches, cucumbers and corn. Seven weeks ago, though, Terry Lautner's alfalfa field sprouted something the neighbors are still talking about: a giant windmill to generate electricity.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;In Testimony, Irvin Accused Of Drug Use
description: A woman testified today that she used marijuana and cocaine with Michael Irvin on several occasions before the Dallas Cowboys wide receiver was found during a police drug bust four months ago.

title: Doctor Helps Couple Avoid Adoption Trouble
description: The diapers, baby bottles and formula are all packed, along with the small stuffed toy bear.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn Prices Soar to Records And Soybeans Join in Rally
description: Corn and soybean prices surged a second day on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, following forecasts for scorching, dry weather in the Midwest that threatens to ravage late-planted crops.

title: IN PERFORMANCE;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Aiming for Equality In Some Tricky Exercises Tamaki Kanaseki and Yuzo Kakeya Violinist and pianist Weill Recital Hall

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Chrysler Quarter Profit Surges but Stock Takes a Hit
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced today that its second-quarter earnings surged more than sevenfold, meeting Wall Street's expectations, but its stock fell as investors worried about slowing auto sales and growing competition in key markets like sport utility vehicles and mini-vans.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Princeton Sues Over a Name
description: Princeton University has made good on its threat to take Trenton State College to court for changing its name. In a complaint filed Thursday in Mercer County Superior Court, Princeton accused the other school of engaging in unfair competition when it changed its name to the College of New Jersey, the name by which the Ivy League university was known from 1746 to 1896.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bonds Extend Price Gains To a 4th Day
description: Treasury prices rose yesterday for a fourth consecutive session after reports on producer prices and retail sales eased worries that the Federal Reserve would quickly raise interest rates.

title: INSIDE
description: Agreement Seen on Welfare

title: Bank Profits Rose by 8.6% in First Quarter
description: The profits of United States commercial and savings banks rose 8.6 percent in the first quarter, helped by higher interest income and gains from securities sales, according to a study by a consulting firm.

title: Group Disputes G.O.P. Ad on Cost of Tax Increase
description: A central assertion in the Republicans' latest advertisement attacking President Clinton -- that the typical family's Federal tax bill has increased $1,500 under Mr. Clinton -- has been disputed by the nonpartisan organization that the party cited as the source of the information.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SWEDISH MEDICAL CONCERN ADDS TO MDT BID
description: The Swedish medical technology company Getinge A.B. said yesterday that it had increased its bid for the MDT Corporation by $1, to $5.50 a share. Getinge also extended the duration of the tender offer, which will now expire on July 25. It said Heartland Advisers Inc., which holds approximately 19.8 percent of the shares in MDT, had declared itself willing to sell its holding to Getinge at the new price. Getinge said it had effective control of 40.6 percent of the shares in MDT, excluding the stake now held by Heartland.

title: Sports of The Times;Boxing, Brawling, Blaming
description: BY noon yesterday, Madison Square Garden was back to breathing normally.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;I.O.C. Says Kipketer Can Run for Kenya
description: Wilson Kipketer, the Kenyan 800-meter runner who had been denied permission to run in the Olympics under the flag of his adopted country, Denmark, will be allowed compete as a citizen of Kenya, the International Olympic Committee ruled yesterday.

title: 5 Nations Agree on a Strategy To Monitor Lebanon Cease-Fire
description: The United States and four other countries have given final approval to long-stalled arrangements to monitor a cease-fire in Lebanon, the State Department said today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Up to $100 Million for Cities
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed legislation yesterday that will provide up to $100 million a year for development projects in urban areas. The new law creates the New Jersey Redevelopment Authority, which will have the power to issue bonds, borrow money and issue loans for construction and development in urban areas. The legislation was designed to make blighted neighborhoods more attractive to developers, said State Senator Richard J. LaRossa, Republican of Trenton.

title: Intel Revamps The Pricing Of Its Chips
description: The Intel Corporation said yesterday that it was fine-tuning its pricing practices to try to lift sluggish sales of personal computers to the home market and to increase its profits.

title: Dole and the N.A.A.C.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: UNDER PRESSURE, DOLE RECONSIDERS ABORTION PLANK
description: Bowing to threats by abortion opponents who said they would disrupt his convention in August, Bob Dole reversed himself today and said he would abide by their wishes concerning language in the Republican Party platform.

title: A Boom With a Difference;Oil Services Get More Savvy
description: Eight years ago, jobs in the oil-service industry were so scarce that a classified ad for a handful of openings drew hundreds of job seekers to the Global Marine Drilling Company parking lot by the time the manager, Bill Watson, arrived at 6 A.M.

title: For Yankee Fans, a Ferry From Wall St. to the Bronx
description: With strains of "Take Me Out to the Ball Game" hanging in the air, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday a new private ferry service linking Wall Street and neighborhoods on Manhattan's East Side to Yankee Stadium.

title: About New York;Not in the Dark As Observers Of Visual Art
description: THE art world can be daunting enough with black-clad gallery attendants hovering haughtily in the background as you squint your eyes and rub your chin as if to summon the muses of appreciation. It certainly bothers Nuria Chang sometimes when she visits galleries and museums knowing that some people are probably questioning her ability to comprehend an artist's vision.

title: Proposals on Tolerance and on Abortion
description: Following are the texts of the Republicans' proposed platform plank on tolerance and their existing plank on abortion:

title: The Cuba Boomerang
description: The mischievous Helms-Burton law pits the Clinton Administration against Canada, Europe, Latin America and even small children. The law is meant to punish Cuba's Castro regime. It allows lawsuits and travel curbs against foreign companies and their officers who allegedly "traffic" in American property seized by Cuba years ago.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Retail Sales Fell in June; Producer Prices Edge Up Retail sales fell in June, while producer prices rose modestly. The two Government reports eased some concerns about inflation and interest rates. Retail sales fell two-tenths of 1 percent, to $205.2 billion last month, as demand for everything from new cars to clothing waned after several months of strength. The Producer Price Index edged up two-tenths of 1 percent in June, after falling one-tenth of 1 percent in May. Energy costs fell last month, but those declines were offset by a rise in food prices. [Page 34.] Treasury prices rose after reports on producer prices and retail sales eased worries that the Federal Reserve would quickly raise interest rates. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32 , to 879/32 . The bond's yield fell to 7.03 percent from 7.05 percent on Thursday. [44.]

title: ATLANTA 1996: 6 DAYS TO GO;Swim Coach For Chinese Fires at Critics
description: Off to one side of the pool at Auburn University, Le Jingyi of China swam her morning workout today, a week before she will enter the Summer Olympics as the world's fastest sprinter and one of the most mysterious.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Dream Team Routs Australia
description: Ready, aim, fire. Charles Barkley walked off the court at halftime, locked and loaded his right thumb and index finger at Australia's Shane Heal, and pulled the trigger. Another one blown away.

title: John Chancellor, Professorial Anchor And Commentator at NBC, Is Deadat 68
description: John Chancellor, who covered 20 political conventions, a dozen space shots and a handful of wars in 41 years at NBC News, died yesterday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 68.

title: BASEBALL;Cardinals Show Clout: 7 Homers at Wrigley
description: Cardinals 13, Cubs 3

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: From Anonymity to Dignity;Homeless Murder Victim Receives a Military Burial
description: The mystery of the murder was figuring out who the victim was. The body of a man, bludgeoned and disfigured, was discovered in broad daylight across the street from Lincoln Center shortly after 4 P.M. on June 10. The man was homeless. There was no identification.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in some editions yesterday outlining a study's findings on three different drug combinations to treat AIDS misstated one combination. The third and least effective combination, according to the study, was 3TC with AZT, not with indinavir.

title: Ulster March By Protestants Passes Calmly
description: After days of violent protests, tens of thousands of Protestants marched today, accompanied by booming fife-and-drum bands, in hundreds of generally untroubled parades to celebrate Ulster Protestantism's proudest event: the victory on July 12, 1690, of the Protestant William of Orange over his Catholic father-in-law, King James II, at the Battle of the Boyne.

title: In Albany, a Dash To Complete Work As Vacation Nears
description: The New York State Legislature made a harried dash toward adjournment on Friday and early this morning, passing bills to enact a long-delayed budget and moving toward the approval of legislation that would deregulate hospitals and authorize a $1.75 billion environmental bond act.

title: Immigration Service Needs a Major Overhaul;Farm Workers' Plight
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Is the relationships with your spouses of such fragility that the fact that I have a committed, loving relationship with another man jeopardizes them?"

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Stakes Are High for Childs
description: It's like a game of truth or dare.

title: Muslim Widows in Bosnia Try To Rebuild Lives Without Men
description: Compelled by the laws of courtesy, Mila Ahmetovic dropped her remaining coffee beans into the cylindrical grinder. Sitting on a homemade bench, she cranked the handle as she spoke with her guests, seven women dressed in the long pantaloons, billowy blouses and head scarves that nearly conceal traditional Muslim women in rural Bosnia.

title: Fish Market Business Wins Court Reprieve
description: A businessman accused by New York City officials of being a Mafia figure and ejected from the Fulton Fish Market on Wednesday won a court reprieve yesterday to resume operations there.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Clearance Is Seen For Sandoz-Ciba Merger
description: The European Commission is expected to clear the merger of the Swiss pharmaceutical giants Sandoz and Ciba-Geigy next Wednesday, but with conditions. A European Union insider declined to say what conditions were likely, but in the past the commission has demanded divestments of some operations.

title: Bridge
description: Players who open pre-emptively are like Hollywood stunt actors: the greater the risk taken, the more likely that disaster will follow. Traditionally, an opening three-bid, vulnerable, is supposed to be based on a strong seven-card suit, but most players relax that requirement, particularly in third seat.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Ballot Fraud Charges Filed
description: Andrew Amato, a Hoboken City Councilman, was indicted yesterday on charges that he paid seven people $40 each to apply for fraudulent absentee ballots on behalf of the Republican candidate for Hudson County Executive. The candidate, William Macchi of Jersey City, was easily beaten by Robert C. Janiszewski, the incumbent, and was not aware of the illegal activity, said Patrick Sharkey, an assistant prosecutor for Hudson County. Some of the voters thought they were being paid for work on the Macchi campaign, Mr. Sharkey said.

title: After Selloff, Stocks Drop But Only a Bit
description: Many investors waded back into the stock market with caution yesterday, stemming two days of heavy price declines, which had led many analysts to wonder if the long bull market on Wall Street was coming to a close.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about the trial of a former Lazard Freres banker on fraud charges referred incorrectly to the background of a consulting firm, Decision Quest, which is assisting his defense in jury selection. The firm worked for the prosecution, not the defense, in the O. J. Simpson case.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Arms-Control Program Backed by 30 Countries
description: Negotiators from more than 30 countries agreed today on a pact to control the arms trade.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Lloyd's of London Finally Posts Profit
description: Lloyd's of London announced yesterday that it had record profits of nearly L1.1 billion ($1.71 billion) in 1993, returning to the black in spectacular style after five years of heavy losses. The insurer's chairman, David Rowland, said the 1993 profit was one of the best results in Lloyd's 308-year history. Lloyd's reports three years in arrears to allow time to process claims. The result was helped by a rise in rates, combined with a low incidence of major catastrophes.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Sailors Dodge Bertha
description: Olympic sailors resumed their training in the water Friday after Hurricane Bertha bypassed the Georgia coastline. The 500 athletes were allowed to resume practices after missing a half-day Wednesday and a full day Thursday. (AP)

title: COMPANY NEWS;INVESTOR GROUP CUTS MICRON TECHNOLOGY STAKE
description: A group that includes the Idaho investor J. R. Simplot has cut its stake in Micron Technology Inc. to 6.6 percent, according to documents released yesterday. In a recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it had sold 4.2 million common shares of Micron, a memory chip maker based in Boise, Idaho, on July 11 at prices ranging from $20.38 to $24 a share. The group now holds about 13.9 million shares. A company of Mr. Simplot, a billionaire potato tycoon, separately owned a 12.7 percent stake in Micron Technology at last filing.

title: COMPANY NEWS;THERMO ELECTRON COMPLETES OFFER FOR SENSORMEDICS
description: The Thermo Electron Corporation said yesterday that it had completed its acquisition of the closely held Sensormedics Corporation for about $70 million. An agreement was announced in April, but no price was disclosed at the time. Thermo Electron said the price included the issuance of about 1.2 million shares of its stock, options to buy another 150,000 shares, and the assumption of certain liabilities. Thermo Electron, based in Waltham, Mass., a maker of biomedical products and energy systems, said the acquisition would expand its line of medical equipment for respiratory care.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, a letter published yesterday from Norma P. Munn of the City Club said that New York City's term limits law did not require that all New York City Council members leave after two terms. In fact, the law requires that members leave after two terms, one of which must be for four years. In addition, the City Club believes that the Council's proposed referendum on the staggering of terms is likely to be seen as self-serving.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Berlioz for 3,200 Organists at St. John's
description: Since the annual convention of the American Guild of Organists opened last week, dozens of performances at local churches and concert halls have been open to the public. Naturally, the convention organizers wanted Tuesday night's performance of Berlioz's sprawling Te Deum, the main musical offering of the week, to be open to the public as well. Alas, even the Cathedral of St. John the Divine was barely large enough to accommodate the convention participants, some 3,200 organists from around the country. But any performance of the Te Deum is an event that warrants a report.

title: Despite Brawl After a Match, Bouts Will Stay at the Garden
description: A day after a bone-crushing brawl between rival retinues and angry fans who began landing blows once the professional fighters had been stopped, Madison Square Garden officials said yesterday that they would continue staging boxing matches.

title: IN PERFORMANCE;DANCE
description: In a Chair or Banging a Drum, All Outside in the Evening Dances for Wave Hill Wave Hill

title: Ex-Wife Guilty of Stealing Rail Photographer's Prints
description: The former wife of O. Winston Link, the photographer who made railroad pictures into an art form, was found guilty today of stealing more than $1 million worth of his famous prints.

title: Missing Teen-Ager Found in New Jersey
description: A Connecticut teen-ager who was missing for six days after she took a train to New York City was reunited with her family early yesterday after the police found her at a New Jersey home where she was staying.

title: IN PERFORMANCE;DANCE
description: The Sounds of Costumes Upstaging the Steps Die Audio Gruppe The Kitchen

title: HOUSE PASSES BAR TO U.S. SANCTION OF GAY MARRIAGE
description: The House of Representatives voted overwhelmingly today to bar Federal recognition of same-sex marriages and to allow each state to ignore such marriages performed in any other state.

title: While S.E.C. Watches, Milken and Ex-Accountant Settle Suits
description: Michael R. Milken and his former accountant have quietly settled lawsuits between them, removing one worry as Mr. Milken's recent business activities continue to be scrutinized by Securities and Exchange Commission investigators.

title: Journal;Grumpiest Old Man
description: It takes demonic genius for a Presidential candidate to get in public dust-ups with four beloved Americans in two short weeks. So give Bob Dole a hand for the sheer ingenuity of provoking rapid-fire tussles with Katie Couric and C. Everett Koop over tobacco, Sarah Brady over assault weapons and Colin Powell over snubbing the N.A.A.C.P.

title: Mandela Ends Triumphant Visit to Britain
description: It was officially labeled a state visit, but as it ended today, Nelson Mandela's four-day triumphal sweep through London looked more like a coronation.

title: Black Congressman In Louisiana Decides To Skip a Senate Bid
description: Representative Cleo Fields, whose Z-shaped, black-majority Fourth Congressional District was dismantled by a Federal court, ruled out running for the Senate or the House today and signaled his interest in a Clinton Administration job.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Patriots Sign Top Pick
description: TERRY GLENN signed a big contract yesterday after he had a heart-to-heart talk with the New England Patriots' owner, BOB KRAFT, who said he wants the first-round draft pick to understand his responsibilities and drive more carefully.

title: A Benefit for Whom?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and Bosnia Sign Pact on Investment
description: The United States and Bosnia signed an agreement today to provide incentives to American businesses to help Bosnia recover from the war.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a former vice chairman of Bob Dole's campaign finance committee who admitted to making illegal campaign contributions referred incompletely to his plea agreement with prosecutors. The former official, Simon C. Fireman, agreed to plead guilty in exchange for the Government's recommendation that he serve a prison sentence of six months and pay $1 million himself and $5 million on behalf of his company, Aqua-Leisure Industries Inc. He reserves the right to ask the judge to let him serve his sentence at home or in a halfway house, rather than in prison.

title: Mad Loner Builds Perfect Bomb
description: Some historian of the law of unintended consequences may devote at least a footnote to the strange case of Theodore J. Kaczynski, the suspect in the Unabom case, who was an avid reader of Joseph Conrad's novels, especially "The Secret Agent."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Mall Becomes Landing Strip
description: Luckily, it was only 6:42 A.M. when John D. Losh's four-seat airplane ran out of fuel. Mr. Losh was forced to crash-land the plane in the parking lot of the Rockaway Townsquare Mall, but the mall had not opened yet and the lot was empty, said Capt. Christopher Linne, a spokesman for the Morris County Prosecutor's office. Mr. Losh, of Barto, Pa., received minor head injuries and his passenger, Grant Gable, of Hereford, Pa., was not hurt. Mr. Losh was charged with drunken flying, Captain Linne said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Dog Can Get Victim Money
description: A trained German shepherd named Tara can qualify for payments from the Victims of Crime Compensation Board after being emotionally injured by teen-agers throwing rocks, a state appeals court ruled yesterday. Tara's owner, Lillian Kline, 49, of Folsom, relies on two dogs to help her with many chores because she has cerebral palsy, The Associated Press reported. As a result of the 1994 attack, Tara's temperament changed, and it became difficult to take her outdoors, according to her owner. The board must now rule on an award; Ms. Kline said she would use any payments toward the purchase of a new dog. TERRY PRISTIN

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;2 Arrested in a Slaying
description: Two men were arrested Thursday and charged with the November killing of a mattress manufacturer who had interrupted a robbery at the home he shared with his mother, prosecutors said yesterday. Howard Lewis, a co-owner of the Sealy Mattress Company in Paterson, had left work early to take his mother to the doctor when he confronted the robbers. Investigators were led to the two suspects, Felix R. DeJesus and Erwin Torres, both of Paterson, after a friend of Mr. DeJesus used one of Mr. Lewis's credit cards, said Sharyn Peiffer, an assistant prosecutor for Bergen County.

title: Calling All Unsung Superstars: 'Rent' Needs Singers
description: It didn't take much to send hundreds of young people lining up through the night and day yesterday in the East Village: just a call for "raw singers who truly have a quality of street life, can move well, and have a good time onstage."

title: Immigration Service Needs a Major Overhaul
description: To the Editor:

title: Cry for Help: 'Paul, How Do I Vote?'
description: His hair still damp, looking as if he had just rushed out of the shower, Robin L. Schimminger staggered onto the floor of the New York State Assembly this morning and was suddenly asked to vote on a complex public education bill.

title: Kenneth Bernstein, 67 Former NBC Journalist
description: Kenneth M. Bernstein, a veteran journalist and travel writer, died on July 3 at his home after a long illness. He was 67.

title: In 3 Years, Who'll Pay New N.Y.P.D. Officers?
description: To the Editor:

title: HORSE RACING;Meadowlands Driver Stays With Favorite
description: As the usual driver of A Stud Named Sue, the 2-year-old pacer of the year in 1995, George Brennan had visions of driving the favorite in this year's $1 million Meadowlands Pace on Saturday night. But the colt has been sidelined with a hoof injury.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: COMPANY NEWS;GRUPO TELEVISA COMPLETES TV STATION PURCHASE
description: Grupo Televisa S.A. of Mexico has bought an English-language television station in Tijuana from Bay City Television Inc. and Radio Television S.A. for $114 million in cash, company officials said yesterday. Televisa, the world's largest Spanish-language television programmer, will now have three English-language stations along the United States border. Televisa will also assume $62 million in debt and other liabilities as part of the deal. The Tijuana station is affiliated with the Fox television network, a unit of the News Corporation, and its signal is available to viewers in San Diego.

title: G.O.P. Leadership Backs Out on a Bill To End Preferences
description: Amid continued criticism that their party is insensitive toward minorities and women, the House Republican leadership has withdrawn its support from a bill that would end all Federal affirmative-action programs. The move scuttles any chance that the measure will pass this year.

title: Clinton Proposes Initiatives On the Scrambling of Data
description: Under increasing pressure from Congress and the computer industry, the Clinton Administration proposed a series of new data-scrambling policy initiatives yesterday that it said would address the Government's national security concerns while also permitting American companies to compete more effectively overseas.

title: Elation, and Deflation, Over AIDS
description: It is hard not to feel a surge of elation at the rapid progress reported at the international AIDS conference in Vancouver this week. For the first time since the early days of the epidemic, scientists seem actually to be gaining ground in treating a viral menace that has been largely incurable and almost invariably fatal.

title: In Fatiguing Chess Struggle, Experience Overcomes Youth
description: The struggle in the International Chess Federation's world championship over the last six weeks came down to youth versus experience, and experience triumphed. The 45-year-old Anatoly Karpov of Russia, veteran of a half-dozen title matches, defeated Gata Kamsky, a 22-year-old Brooklyn grandmaster who emigrated with his father from the Soviet Union in 1989 and who was playing in his first championship. The score in the series, held in Elista, Russia, was Karpov 10 1/2, Kamsky 7 1/2.

title: Berlusconi Faces Trial With Craxi
description: PARIS  Silvio Berlusconi and Bettino Craxi, two former prime ministers who have dominated Italian politics in recent years but who now face multiple corruption investigations, were indicted Friday and ordered to stand trial together on fraud and illegal party financing charges.

title: Another Trolley Bombing In Moscow Leaves 30 Hurt
description: Fear and anger swept across the Russian capital today after a second bomb in less than 24 hours tore through a trolley bus in Moscow at the height of the morning rush hour.

title: Venezuela Gets Big I.M.F. Credit, Backing Market Reforms
description: Venezuela was awarded a $1.4 billion credit from the International Monetary Fund yesterday, a distinction that also serves as a seal of approval on the country's economic reform package.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Roche Says Sales Rose 8% in First Half
description: The Swiss drug company Roche HoldingA.G. said yesterday that its sales in the first half rose 8 percent, to 7.77 billion Swiss francs ($6.18 billion), from 7.199 billion francs a year earlier. Roche's first-half earnings will be issued in late August or early September.

title: Classy Lincoln Center Deserves a Classic Clock
description: To the Editor:

title: Fishermen Save 6 After Crash of Small Plane
description: Four fishermen plucked a family of five and a pilot out of the Connecticut River late this morning, just minutes after their single-engine, six-seater plane crashed into the water about a hundred yards away from the fishing boat.

title: ON BOXING;Newman's Emotions Often Invade the Ring
description: Rock Newman has always had his fighter's interest at heart. "It is the manager's job to get his guy the easiest fight for the most money," he has said. And that fervor has indeed made tens of millions of dollars for Riddick Bowe, although it has come at the cost of a heavyweight championship as well as chances to fight for it again.

title: Cracking Down on Teen-Age Homicide
description: In the heated and occasionally hysterical debate over gun-related youth violence, scant attention has been paid to stopping the flow of the weapons that have made teen-age crime more deadly. Now, using new computer technology, the Clinton Administration has embarked on a welcome effort to identify and bring to justice the dealers who sell firearms to teen-agers.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Red Cross, Under Threat, Delays Burundi Convoy
description: The United Nations refugee agency said today that it had suspended plans to send an aid convoy to the Cibitoke region in Burundi after a threat of attack.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-5

title: COMPANY NEWS;EUROGAS PURCHASES DANUBE INTERNATIONAL PETROLEUM
description: Eurogas Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the closely held Danube International Petroleum Ltd. for $38 million in cash and stock. Eurogas will pay $3 million in cash, 2.5 million restricted common shares of Eurogas, 1.25 million nonvoting preferred common shares (convertible in one year to 2.5 million restricted common shares), and five-year warrants to buy up to 5 million more common shares at $3 a share. The Dallas-based Danube has majority stakes in oil and gas reserve ventures in Slovakia and the Czech Republic. Eurogas's stock was down 78.1 cents, to $4.844, in Nasdaq trading.

title: G.A.O. Puts Cost of S.& L. Bailout at Half a Trillion Dollars
description: The General Accounting Office today released the most comprehensive Government study so far on the costs of the savings and loan bailout, placing a total price tag on the debacle of nearly half a trillion dollars, including more than $130 billion from taxpayers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GARDNER DENVER MACHINERY TO ACQUIRE NORAMPTCO
description: Gardner Denver Machinery Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Noramptco Inc., which makes centrifugal blowers and exhausters, for an undisclosed price. Gardner Denver, based in Quincy, Ill., will buy all of the closely held Noramptco, which markets its products under the brand names Lamson and U.S. Turbine. Gardner Denver makes industrial and oil-drilling equipment. Its 1995 revenue was $192 million. Noramptco, based in Syracuse, had 1995 revenue of $41.3 million.

title: 7 Bosnia Candidates Ousted After Attack
description: The Western group supervising this fall's elections in Bosnia has disqualified seven candidates from the Government's ruling Muslim party as punishment for a violent attack on a rival Muslim politician.

title: Company Briefs
description: LOCKHEED MARTIN CORP., Bethesda, Md., the aircraft maker, agreed to buy $90 million of spare parts from Taiwan.

title: BASEBALL;Sight Makes Puckett Quit Game He Loves
description: Kirby Puckett, a superstar so well liked by his peers that they openly lamented his absence at this week's All-Star Game, will play in no more major league games of any kind. The Minnesota Twins outfielder announced yesterday that the eye ailment that has kept him from playing this season will force him to retire.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Telstra of Australia Cutting 9,000 Jobs
description: The Telstra Corporation, Australia's state-owned telecommunications company, said yesterday that it planned to cut 9,000 jobs, or 12 percent of its work force, because of growing competition. The company, which has about 74,000 employees, will make the job cuts in its current fiscal year ending next June. Frank Blount, Telstra's chief executive, said declining profit margins and pressure on market share and prices had forced the job cuts. The Australian Government plans to sell one-third of Telstra for around $8 billion (Australian), or $6.4 billion (United States). (AP)

title: White House Is Optimistic About Chances of Welfare Bill With NewG.O.P. Moves
description: The White House today hailed the latest Republican steps on welfare, saying they could lead to passage of welfare legislation this year, even though Democrats in both Congress and the Administration are deeply divided over the merits of the Republican plan.

title: Observer;Capering With the -gates
description: Now we have "Filegate." Since it involves many files, it should logically be "Filesgate," but skulduggery purists thought "Filesgate" sounded too much like a butler. "Filegate" sounds more like a scoundrel, and scoundrels, not butlers, are at the root of -gate genealogy.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Barkley Sued in Ohio
description: A Spencerport, N.Y., man sued CHARLES BARKLEY yesterday, seeking damages from the pro basketball player and the bar in Cleveland in which they got into a fight. JEB TYLER, 23, alleges in a civil suit that the 6-foot-6-inch, 252-pound Barkley punched him several times in the face and head at a Cleveland dance bar early last Sunday.

title: 2 in Phone Alliance On Midwest Service
description: The Ameritech Corporation and Time Warner have cleared the way for some residents of Ohio, Indiana and Wisconsin to have a choice of local telephone companies next year.

title: Anticipation Ends as Hurricane Slams Into North Carolina's Coast
description: The first hurricane of the season slammed into the North Carolina coast today, with driving rain and winds up to 105 miles an hour, damaging houses, toppling trees and power lines and pushing waves eight feet above normal onto low-lying areas.

title: Ms. Schiavo Quits
description: Mary Schiavo, the Transportation Department's inspector general, was not a conventional government watchdog. For one thing, she barked. Most other Federal internal police officers are content to audit and report quietly to their superiors about small irregularities. Ms. Schiavo, a former prosecutor who freely acknowledged "I love the hunt," preferred to make noise -- especially about the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: ROCK REVIEW;The Dead Who Refuse to Die Draw 18,000
description: Even the clouds looked tie-dyed as the sun set over Liberty State Park in Jersey City on Thursday evening. The park was crowded with 18,000 Dead Heads who endured nightmarish traffic snarls to attend the Furthur Festival, a package tour that could be redesignated as a night of the living Dead.

title: Corrections
description: Articles on Tuesday and Thursday about the fatal shooting of a man by a police officer on a Bronx subway platform, and another article on Thursday about the removal of the Bronx District Attorney from the case of a man accused of killing a police officer, misstated the title of Norman Siegel at the New York Civil Liberties Union. He is executive director; the president is Lesly I. Lempert.

title: Staten Island Won't Ever Get Rich on Refuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexico's Elite Caught in Scandal's Harsh Glare
description: They were friends who moved in the elite world of money, politics and thoroughbred horses in Mexico. They were rich and wanted to be richer. Tens of millions of dollars passed between them, but there was never a contract or a signature.

title: BASEBALL;Reynolds Stays Hot by Cooling Off Mets
description: The Mets went into last night's game against the Houston Astros knowing they had little margin for error, especially facing right-hander Shane Reynolds, who was coming off the best two outings of his career.

title: Immigration Service Needs a Major Overhaul
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Conviction in Chief's Death
description: John DeVenter, 65, a retired Hanover police chief, was shot to death in a Newark cemetery last July 14 when he came to the assistance of two friends who were being accosted by carjackers. Yesterday, Thomas Cross, 24, of Irvington, was convicted of murder and robbery in Mr. DeVenter's death. Mr. Cross faces a sentence of life imprisonment.

title: North of Storm, Rough Water Draws Surfers and Kills One
description: High surf powered by the Hurricane Bertha storm system killed a New Jersey man today, one of many daredevils drawn to beaches along the East Coast.

title: Freed After 10 Years, a Pastor Accused of Sex Abuse Says He Was Never Shackled in Spirit
description: One of the worst moments of the Rev. Nathaniel T. Grady's decade in prison did not happen behind bars, but in an Albany hospital, where he had been taken for treatment of an eye ailment. Shuffling in leg shackles, he was led through the door.

title: A First Lady's Duties Include Enduring Criticism
description: Sara Netanyahu, Israel's first American-style First Lady, spent this week in the United States in activities Hillary Rodham Clinton would find familiar. She visited a school for the learning disabled, took her children to "Beauty and the Beast," got a facial at Bloomingdale's, went to an East Side ladies' lunch, chatted with Barbara Walters -- and faced a barrage of criticism in the Israeli press for trying to be an American-style First Lady.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;United International To Sell Brazil Stake
description: United International Holdings Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its stake in the Brazilian cable TV operator Net Sao Paulo for about $78.1 million. The Denver-based company said it would sell its 25.5 percent interest in Net Sao Paulo to Globo, a Brazilian television broadcaster, for $70 million. The company said it had an unrelated prior contractual obligation to sell an 8.5 percent interest in Net Sao Paulo for about $8.1 million. (Dow Jones)

title: Seoul Journal;In Sexist South Korea, the Girls Even the Score
description: The greatest advance for women in South Korea so far this year came about because a 14-year-old girl named Juhee did not study hard enough for her exams.

title: JULY 7-13;Fires of Ulster Orange
description: In Northern Ireland, the unthinkable often turns out to be inevitable, especially early in July. This is when the tens of thousands from the British province's Protestant majority march in parades to celebrate the victory on July 12, 1690 of William of Orange over his father-in-law, the Catholic King James II. The victory established for centuries the English Protestant ascendancy in Ireland.

title: CYCLING;Indurain Is Held Back By Flat Tire and Team
description: Miguel Indurain and his Banesto teammates went on the attack today in the Tour de France, raising an already high speed at the start of the final three climbs in the 13th stage in an effort to move the defending champion up in the standings. To a point, the ambush worked, but only to a point.

title: MUNICIPAL BATTLEGROUND;Coney Island's Worn Welcome Mat
description: STRIP away the age-old air conditioner known as the Atlantic Ocean, the concession stands offering buttery cobs of corn and sleek hot dogs, the iridescent Wonder Wheel and the riders screaming as the chattering Cyclone drops. Remove the old-timers playing handball, the sunbathers on white bed sheets and the promise of prizes inside the arcades. What's left is a graying boardwalk, a welcome mat made of wood. The Coney Island boardwalk has a storied history. It has connected visitors to the rides and the green-water ocean since 1923. For generations, it has been a seaside front porch for millions of bathers, players, strollers and lovers. At 80 feet wide and more than two and a half miles long, it stretches from the populace of Russian immigrants in Brighton Beach to the private community of two-story homes in Sea Gate. But beyond the romantic vision of the boardwalk lies a piece of infrastructure that demands as much maintenance as any city sidewalk or roadway. Its version of potholes: cracked and loose boards, shifting pilings and gaps caused by fires. And its version of missing parking signs is missing bars from its beach-side aluminum railing, stolen by scavengers of scrap metal.
