"For us to keep it mint condition, we'd have to take care of it all of the time," said Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern, whose department maintains the boardwalk. "What money we get to repair and take care of the boardwalk, we use." While city officials say weather, age and vandalism are the greatest threats to the grandeur of the boardwalk, people in the neighborhood often say the city's indifference. "The city isn't doing anything for Coney Island," said Gregory Bitetzakis, 60, who has been selling shish kebabs there since 1948. "It seems they want to do away with it." During a recent visit to the boardwalk, Martin Levine, chairman of Community Board 13, said the Coney Island peninsula was treated as second-rate, noting that it took until July 4 for the Parks Department to open all of the area's beaches this year because of a shortage of lifeguards, while most city beaches opened Memorial Day weekend. Parks Department officials dismiss the charge, citing a recent allocation of $180,000 for repairs to the boardwalk and $20 million from the Borough President's office over the last 15 years to maintain and improve the wooden esplanade. The department says it does not keep track of how much it spends on routine maintenance of the boardwalk. Brooklyn has only three year-round Parks Department carpenters to do the kind of skilled maintenance the boardwalk requires almost weekly. There had been eight as recently as 1990, said Parke Spencer, a spokesman. "This whole boardwalk is a mess," said Sam Kravitz, a resident of Bensonhurst, as he strolled by a section of the boardwalk that had not been fixed since a fire destroyed it last fall. "We used to walk on the boardwalk without shoes. Now, with all the nails popping out, you can't." Visitors can no longer go under the boardwalk, a traditional place to cool off or find romance. Two winters ago, the beach level was raised to meet the boardwalk to curb crime and discourage the homeless from camping out. But perhaps most frustrating for local leaders is the damage done by city vehicles. After a survey of the boardwalk last year, Brooklyn Borough President Howard Golden branded city vehicles as a boardwalk scourge. Like a rash of noshing termites, the vehicles bend the wooden planks and force nails and screws to jut out. A fire truck fell through the boardwalk two years ago. Last week, Mr. Levine said he spotted a Parks Department all-terrain vehicle cruising across the boardwalk. The driver, John J. Natoli, who is the chief engineer for construction, said he was inspecting recent repairs. Still, cars and loose boards were not of much concern to many people on the boardwalk last week. Some defended it as glorious. Others pointed to the sparsely populated beach, tumbling litter and abandoned amusement sites like the charred Thunderbolt as more poignant examples of a languishing Coney Island. "The beauty of Coney Island is gone," said Joe Perez, who grew up and lives in the neighborhood. "We walk and nobody's here. It's desolate."

title: The Death of Ricky
description: Ricky was a hard-working 19-year-old with an adorable smile who came up from Tlapa, Mexico, two years ago. He and his roommate Sergio, washed dishes in the tavern on Jane Street where I hostessed two nights a week. They hung out with other young Mexicans working to send money home. Ricky never learned English. One Sunday, Aurelliano, the 17-year-old busboy, asked me, ''Yes or no, correct, will you to be my girlfriend?'' Seeing I was somewhat taken aback, he explained that Ricky needed me to write out the words along with possible answers.

title: Out at the Inn
description: To the Editor: Our recent, very enjoyable trip to the Brandywine Valley took a decidedly sour turn when we arrived at the National Hotel in Frenchtown, N.J., where we had planned a stopover on May 25 our way home. I had made our reservations on March 11.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;Dessert as an Olympic Event
description: TOM VACCARO'S daily Olympic training regimen calls for the consumption of chocolate. Lots of chocolate.

title: POSTINGS: $5 Million Building in East New York Section of Brooklyn;Care and Housing for AIDS Patients
description: Brooklyn's first facility combining housing for the homeless and day treatment for AIDS and H.I.V. patients is to open next June at 2626 Pitkin Avenue, at Fountain Avenue, in the East New York section.

title: Perspectives;On the Playing Fields of Flanders
description: On the way to the battlefield they stopped to buy wooden shoes. The 14 American women of the 1920 United States Olympic team, their chaperones and an Army driver were going sightseeing in the killing fields of Flanders where, the poet wrote, poppies grow.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: ATHENA

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: N.Y. BOOKSHELF;The City Skyline And Landscape
description: MOST New Yorkers think little about the fact that they spend most of their indoor lives surrounded by strangers, separated only by walls and floors. Above and below, to the left and to the right, lie other apartments or offices, other families or businesses. Tall buildings have become such a humdrum component of city life that to look up at them is to risk being branded a tourist. But city dwellers have grown a bit more introspective lately about their towering surroundings. Perhaps the unexamined life is not worth living after all. A museum dedicated to the history of the skyscraper is being planned for Lower Manhattan, and a number of authors have delved into the topic. Here are four books that examine Manhattan's skyward growth.

title: Achtung! (Aktung?) Bonn Bans Some H's
description: It has been rushed through in mere decades, but finally German-speakers the world over are to have a new system of spelling.

title: COPING;Ain't Over Till It's Over: An Addict's Fight
description: THIS is no success story, at least not yet. "My mother kicked me, hit me with her hand, a stick," said Andres Andino, who is now 43. "She had five kids, nobody knew about stress, depression then. I think she couldn't stand how much I looked like my father. One day I stopped crying. I wasn't going to let her see my pain. All the anger got stuck inside me. "I went out on the street and I paid her back -- drugs, armed robbery. I cut guys up. And I look around up here, and I can cry now seeing all the kids who remind me of me." Mr. Andino, a handsome, muscular man, had just finished mowing the grass of a baseball field on 100th Street between First and Second Avenues that belongs to Harlem RBI (Reviving Baseball in Inner Cities), a privately supported program of games and mentors for about 225 local youngsters from 7 to 18. Last summer, mellow on heroin, Mr. Andino looked out of a nearby apartment window and saw Inge Hanson, the group's executive director, struggling to set down the white-powder foul lines. A former ballplayer with more than a dash of macho, he came downstairs to show her how. He soon became a volunteer, then a coach. It was a fellow coach, Mike Colon, who found Mr. Andino when he bottomed out in a stairwell last March. He was bleeding from self-inflicted slashes on his arms. He had swallowed 90 pills, Prozac, Benadryl and Valium. Mr. Colon brought him to Metropolitan Hospital nearby, where he went through yet another detox. Ms. Hanson got him into the rehab program at Holliswood Hospital in Queens. He was there a little more than a month. He's been clean for almost four. "I consider this the longest ever," he said. "Once I didn't use for six months, but I had reservations -- it was to get through parole. In the upstate prisons it's too hard to get drugs, so I don't count that either. "I started using marijuana in Franklin K. Lane High School. My mother gave me $7.50 every day. That was my share of my father's Social Security. He got stabbed to death by a girlfriend he was abusing. I'd buy cigarettes, weed, Gypsy Rose wine. I'd gamble on handball games; I was very good, took money off the African kids in Bedford-Stuyvesant. "We'd bring junior high school girls back to the apartment. My mother was a seamstress in the garment center. I got busted by a neighbor. My mother came home early and there was two couples in her bed. She swept us out of the house with her broom." Mr. Andino dropped out of high school. He wandered back and forth from his native Puerto Rico. He began using heroin at 18. He had jobs -- five years loading trucks, seven years in the garment center in which he rose to fabric cutter, even some cooking -- but the getting, selling and using of heroin always brought him down. He was arrested 10 times and spent more than 3 1/2 years behind bars. It was often easier to use in city jails than on the street, he said, because your family would always send you money in jail, figuring you couldn't get dope there. On the outside, he went into detox programs to placate his wife, a city employee who supported him and their two children and four more of her own. She looked down on him, he says, as a "dirty IV user." She considered her cocaine habit "sophisticated." They are separated after 16 years, and she is now in a rehab program, but their two children have been placed in foster care. His goal, he says, is to get them back. He makes a little money from RBI and has begun living with a girlfriend who has some money of her own, in Westchester. * Kids from the neighborhood projects began drifting onto the block, smacking their gloves, making their way under a hot sun to the ballfield. The scent of the fresh-mowed grass tickled nostrils. "People look at me, they say, 'Andy, you come a long way, you look good,' and that sometimes scares me," he said. "I got to remember where I been, how low and dirty. I remember one time, I was messing around in my marriage; I'm a fool for girls, skinny girls, and this girl gave me a bunch of flowers after a weekend we spent together. "I went home and gave the roses to my wife. That is dirty. And I used to con the parole officers by turning in my own kids' urine for my tests. That's dirty. "But that's why these kids here can trust me and talk to me. I know everything you can do bad. When they cry, I feel good; it means the anger's coming out. "Sometimes I'm shaky and scared for myself. I'm always scared for them because I am what happens if someone doesn't rescue them."

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;The Dorset, the Place to Meet for Media Elite, Fades Out
description: With the plan for a huge addition to the Museum of Modern Art inching forward, a small corner of city culture will sink quietly into MOMA's wake on July 25. That is when the Hotel Dorset, acquired by the museum, will bid adieu to its last guests.

title: Sports of The Times;Atlanta Sends Up The Balloons
description: IN five days, this city will belong to the paying fans, the runners and the jumpers, and the rowers and the swimmers, but for now, Atlanta still belongs to the people.

title: ART;What the New, Big Country Looked Like a Century Ago
description: THE 1800's in America saw a vogue for reproductions of picturesque scenery, because there was a widespread desire to see what the new, big country looked like. To satisfy this need, prints of panoramic vistas as well as intimate vignettes were published in magazines as well as in editions for framing and hanging in parlors. Picturesque implies that certain conventions had to be followed, and visitors to the Connecticut Graphic Arts Center in Norwalk who pay close attention to "Picturesque America: A Selection of 19th-Century Views" will note the almost constant clear division of compositions into foreground, middle and background areas, as well as the repeated appearances of cows, small boys lying on flat rocks and well-dressed men pointing out to each other the magnificence of the scene in view.

title: THEATER;Julie Harris in 'Sonya,' A Phoenix Production
description: DURING the first act of "Sonya," the wife of Leo Tolstoy is pointed out as a "soul in need" by a doctor and disciple of the literary and philosophical icon. In Act II, a Russian Orthodox priest tells Sonya how he understands her "cry from the heart." Such are the playwright Leon Katz's florid elucidations on the overwrought behavior of Countess Sofya Andreyevna Tolstoy, who spends much of her namesake play's three hours making a nuisance of herself, demanding to be let into the cottage where her husband of 48 years lies dying, while hostile forces keep her out. The year is 1910. Since Julie Harris is possessed of the power to communicate an interior life, her enlightened presence gives a playwright the golden gift of time. He can save it. He can cut words. He can redirect priorities. Bluntly put, he can rework his play. As Sonya, Ms. Harris reveals the depth of distress, the ambivalent pull of fierce love and eternal devotion in conflict with ideological discord. In a single moment, the actress sums up her reason for being there: to put the stamp of finality and forgiveness -- the buzzword is closure -- on a troubled, unreconciled life with a sainted man. Their "totally opposite ideas of the meaning and purpose of existence," in the words of a letter Tolstoy wrote to Sonya four months before his death, led to estrangement. Sonya could not forsake the materialism that a spiritually converted Tolstoy renounced, or understand his loyalty to his leading disciple, Vladimir Gregorievich Chertkov, with its intimations of homosexuality and an idealism that eluded her. While the puzzling and fascinating ramifications of an extraordinarily volatile marriage that produced 13 children, 4 of whom -- 2 daughters and 2 sons -- figure among an eye-popping stageful of 15 characters, are unexplored, the ravings of Sonya are overexplained. Neither historically lucid nor dramatically fulfilling, Mr. Katz's play reveals a gaping hole at the center, an unsettling inconclusiveness. That Tolstoy remains unseen in a many-peopled play is an interesting challenge Mr. Katz has created, but he has failed to give a revered man a rich offstage life. Yet no playwright could reasonably expect, in three weeks' playing time, a more solid ensemble or a more bountiful production than the Phoenix Theater Company has lavished on "Sonya." It all starts with the audience's gasp at the sight of Campbell Baird's imposing setting, a whopping train that revolves in an obscure railroad station, Astapovo. That happened to be the title of the first professional version of Mr. Katz's play; previously it was called "A Death at Astapovo") The first professional version was performed at the Yale Repertory's Winterfest series in 1983 under Lawrence Kornfeld's direction. Reno Roop (as Tolstoy's oldest son) is a holdover from that production, which also had Charles S. Dutton and John Turturro in small roles and Jan Miner as Sonya. For this production, the artistic director of the Phoenix, Bram Lewis, orchestrates the feuding and fussing family, the invading press -- Tolstoy's retreat into the woods at 82 was some media event -- and the stars' iridescent moments as though there were real drama somewhere in there. Ms. Harris, in a flash, retreats into the reassurance of memory, madness and considerations of suicide, shades her voice to the darkest reaches of the virago who means business and glancingly acknowledges the comedy inherent in any photo-op, amid all her protestations. In support, note a capital cast. Philip Baker Hall (Chertkov) is an unrelenting threat, and Timothy Jerome (Dushan) is a well-tempered adversary. Jennifer Harmon, Miriam Healy-Louie, Jud Meyers and Mr. Roop are so intensely and individually effective as the Tolstoy daughters and sons -- Sonya's "jailers" -- that they make it theatrically clear that every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way. If only Mr. Katz had written just how. "Sonya" by Leon Katz, produced by the Phoenix Theater at Purchase College in Purchase. Performances continue through next Sunday. Box office: 251-6290.

title: Stating the Case Against Lilco
description: Re: ''Lilco Was Guilty; Customers Still Pay'' $(June 16$). I agree with the writer, Gregory Palast, about the case against Lilco except for the statement: ''Well Mr. Hurley, if it's any comfort, a jury did find Lilco officers guilty of giving perjured, fradulent testimony about the Shoreham nuclear power plant.'' Believe me, Mr. Hurley is well aware. In fact, I have written many times to the judge, Jack Weinstein, pointing out errors in his 60-odd page decision that lets Lilco off the hook for this massive crime.

title: Dispatch Plan Offers Data Wealth
description: WHEN a 911 call is placed in Yonkers, dispatchers see not only the name, address and telephone number of the caller but also a concise history for the address, which enables police officers and firefighters to know when and why they might have previously been called to the address, if they should be on the lookout for someone wanted for a crime and whether hazardous materials are being stored there.

title: VIEWS;Tricks That Make the Movies
description: Walk into any suburban multiplex, and you can watch the White House being blown to bits in the blockbuster summer film "Independence Day." But if you've already seen it three times and you're longing for a fresh adrenaline rush, the Liberty Science Center has an alternative: the Imax version, which proves that you can't always believe what you see.

title: No Headline
A Daredevil Becomes a Rival Of Bubka's
description: SEARCHING for a way to show his appreciation for the world's greatest pole-vaulter, for his tenacity and the way he sinks his teeth into the event, Okkert Brits named his pit bull terrier Bubka.

title: No Headline
description: Vernon knows a lot of stuff about the President and his personal life, but he'll never trade on it. Vernon understands how power works better than anybody I know."

title: A Living Memorial In Israel
description: I would like to comment on a recently published article, ''From Parents' Worst Tragedy, A Living Memorial in Israel'' $(June 23$). Lynn Gettenberg spoke about her daughter Rachel's diagnosis, eventual death from a brain tumor and the establishment of a recreational center, Neve Rachel, for children with cancer in Israel.

title: Even a Weakened Bertha Packs a Wallop
description: The storm known to the southeastern United States as Hurricane Bertha reached metropolitan New York yesterday afternoon in the diminished form of a tropical storm, but its gusty rains still carried enough clout to knock out power lines, flood roadways and batter shorelines.

title: The Thought-Diver
description: MELVILLE A Biography. By Laurie Robertson-Lorant. Illustrated. 710 pp. New York: Clarkson Potter. $40.

title: THEATER TICKETS;Struggling Students Can't Afford Them
description: To the Editor: I find Bruce M. Robinson's tolerance, if not defense, of today's high-priced theater tickets [Letters to the Editor, June 16] insensitive to all of us who struggle with the economics of value.

title: School Plan Faces Skepticism
description: In Crown Heights, the Brooklyn neighborhood that, accurately or not, has come to symbolize black-Jewish friction, educators and community groups are nurturing plans to establish a public school they hope will bring together black and Jewish youngsters and deepen understanding among the neighborhood's ethnic groups.

title: No Headline
TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Harriet the Spy Michelle Trachtenberg, Rosie O'Donnell, Vanessa Lee Chester, Gregory Smith, Sport the dog, Robert Joy, J. Smith-Cameron, Eartha Kitt Directed by Bronwen Hughes Rated PG 96 minutes

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;American and British Air Try for a Partnership
description: WHEN American Airlines and British Airways announced last month that they would join forces as marketing partners, they became the latest pair of foreign and domestic airlines to engage in this sometimes bewildering practice.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;TRACK AND FIELD
description: THE MONDO TRACK at Olympic Stadium, built just within the legal limits of hardness and energy return to a runner's legs, facilitated 10 performances that were the best in the world this year at the United States Olympic trials. Thus, there is great anticipation about track and field, particularly in the sprints, where the Americans have shown dominance through the years.

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;Dole Calls for a 'Fairer, Flatter' Tax System
description: In what has become his own weekly radio address, Bob Dole today sought to capitalize on the Republican Party's historic image as the party of cutting taxes. He said it was "high time for a fairer, flatter and simpler" tax system, although he did not make a specific proposal, adding that the 1040 tax form should "go the way of the Berlin Wall."

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Lido Beach, L.I.;Bay, Ocean, Private Homes and Condos
description: LIDO BEACH in the 50's and 60's was synonymous with private beach clubs. There were five south of Lido Boulevard -- the Colony Club, the Coral Reef, the Monaco, the Sands and the Shelborne. They drew thousands of day-trippers who arrived early to use the cabanas, beaches, pools and courts and stayed late for the restaurants and nightclubs with big-name entertainers.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;GYMNASTICS
description: NO MORE SOVIET UNION. No more Unified Team, which stayed unified just long enough to extend Soviet dominance through the 1992 Summer Olympics. Gymnastics has entered a more egalitarian era in which coaching expertise and talent have been diffused.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: July 14, 1996
description: Weeks This On Week List Fiction

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A Monte Carlo caper, an updated opera, a contemporary horror film and a sophisticated mystery stand out on this week's movie roster.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: BIKING;Have Jacket, Will Travel
description: Two-wheeled tours aren't limited to bicyclists. Eaglerider, a Los Angeles company, organizes motorcycle tours aboard Harley-Davidsons. For a traveler who has only a black leather jacket, the company includes the motorcycle rental. One Eaglerider tour, a 16-day excursion through four Western states, stops at Indian cliff dwellings, the Grand Canyon, Yosemite and Las Vegas. The price -- $4,695 a rider and $1,396 for co-riders -- includes insurance, helmet, Harley rental, guide services, support vehicle and accommodations. If you take your own motorcycle, the total cost is $95 a day; a motorcycle license is required. Among the dates are Aug. 16 and Sept. 6. A Baja Peninsula tour is also available. Call (800) 501-8687.

title: Spells for an Age Of Mobile Phones
description: HAVE you been sitting by the phone, pining for a call from that special someone? Try casting a spell instead. All you need is a touch of oregano, some fennel, dill and caraway seeds. Add to that one cotton ball (it might be a good idea to invest in a whole box for future use).

title: JULY 7-13;House Votes to Ban Gay Marriages
description: Anticipating that a gay-rights court case could lead Hawaii to legalize homosexual marriages, the House voted overwhelmingly last week to ban Federal recognition of same-sex marriages and to allow states to ignore gay marriages performed in other states.

title: WEDDINGS;Eileen Kelsh, Kenneth Ambach
description: Eileen Kelsh, a daughter of Kathleen and John Kelsh of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Kenneth Emory Ambach, a son of Lucy and Gordon Ambach of Washington. Edward Cunningham, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at St. Anne's Church in Garden City. The Rev. Robert Lamar, a Presbyterian minister, took part in the service.

title: STYLE;Let the Games Begin
description: Forget Atlanta. New Yorkers have their own competitive spectacle 60 miles from Times Square. Of course, to compete in the Hamptons, it helps if you're a Player. While anybody with a credit card can enter such generic events as social climbing and overpaying, to be a real contender, you need a track record and a publicist.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Why Fidelity Doesn't Want You to Shop at Schwab
description: AT the mutual fund industry's annual get-together in Washington in May, the hallway chatter focused all week on the possibility of fireworks at the final session, when two industry titans with no love lost between them would face off: Edward C. Johnson 3d, chairman of Fidelity's vast mutual fund empire, and Charles Schwab, king of the discount brokers.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: SCULPTURE;Guided Tour
description: Outdoor sculpture gardens are like highway rest stops for the soul. Now there is a book listing where to find them. "A Guide to the Sculpture Parks and Gardens of America," by Jane McCarthy and Laurily K. Epstein, a 304-page paperback, describes 85 sculpture gardens and 120 other outdoor sculptures. To order, contact Michael Kesend Publishing, 1025 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10028; (800) 488-8040. The guide costs $18.95, plus $2.50 for shipping.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Huffing and Puffing ON Fridays, after Pete Bradley has finished another hard week of work, he heads for his pleasure palace. Not the local bar. The local cigar store. Mr. Bradley spends free time at the Village Tobacconist in Babylon, where visitors can buy cigars and light them up. "Once a day I enjoy a cigar," Mr. Bradley, of Copiague, said. "It's my celebration for the end of the day." Part of the delight for cigar lovers is socializing while smoking, said Dan Raser, owner of the cigar shop. So he allows customers to smoke in the shop. "We have a Smoke-Eater here," he said. He also has wingback chairs and antique stand-up ashtrays. The front of the store looks like a living room. Which makes sense, he said, "because a lot of men aren't allowed to smoke in their own homes. The wife says it makes the rugs and curtains stink. So men come here to smoke." That can take some time. Mr. Bradley averages 45 minutes to an hour to finish one of his favorite Avo cigars. That seems longer than the Presidential campaign speeches on the harm of smoking. "I don't inhale, though," Mr. Bradley said. With five or six smokers puffing at once, the air in the shop can become a bit smelly. "We haven't had any complaints yet," Mr. Raser said. Not even about the strict antismoking law in Suffolk County. "I spoke to my lawyer," Mr. Raser said. "He told me to offer my customers membership. So everyone who buys a cigar is a member. It's kind of a club. But there are no dues or minutes." Before becoming a seller of cigars, Mr. Raser was a seller of bonds. "People would give me cigars as gifts," he said. "The better the market was doing the more expensive the cigar I would get." Now he is hooked. "I enjoy the smell," he said, "and just the whole feeling you get from sitting down and smoking. You can be a ditch digger. But you buy a $5 cigar and take a few puffs and you feel like Donald Trump." He even has his Marla. "My fiancee, Denise McWilliams, allows me one cigar a day," he said. Ms. McWilliams smokes cigars, too. "When we go out to dinner," Mr. Raser said, "I light up my big stogie and she lights up her little one." Ms. McWilliams also helps in the shop. "We sell before-dinner cigars and after," Mr. Raser said. "There are also aged cigars. It's just like wine." And becoming as popular. He recently opened a second shop, in Port Jefferson. "People do work there while they smoke," he said. "They bring their laptop. I have one customer who is a tree surgeon. He had his customer meet him here. They contracted for a job." The shop seems to offer all the accouterments associated with cigar smoking, except the brandy. "Oh, the customers bring their own bottles," Mr. Raser said. "Port or cognac. I keep their bottles in the back. I put little stickers on them with the customers' names."

title: In Rich Hong Kong, Cages as Homes for the Poor
description: A rusty, sour odor skewered the gloom that enveloped ranks of steel cages jammed into a third-floor chamber of a decaying tenement. Dimly, the silhouettes of men appeared, one by one uncoiling from the stack of cages like cicadas casting off their shells. Ma Kwai-han, a feather of a man clad in a skimpy white undershirt and baggy gray pants, padded into a dim circle of light.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;Planetarium Plan Worries a Block
description: The blocks surrounding the American Museum of Natural History are among the most desirable on the Upper West Side. But some of the residents of West 81st Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue fear they will have to bear the brunt of the museum's ambitious plan to build a new planetarium, outdoor restaurant and underground parking garage to accommodate more visitors. About 40 residents of the block attended a meeting on July 2 at which Community Board 7 approved the museum's preliminary environmental-impact statement with a few recommendations.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;At Twin Towers, the Ice Rink Goeth
description: It opened to great fanfare in January: an ice-skating rink between the twin towers of the World Trade Center, heralded as a boon that would attract tourists and new residents alike to lower Manhattan as the neighborhood seeks to recover from the recession that sapped its real-estate market. Now, less than six months later, the rink, Recreation World Ice Chalet, is padlocked. And in one of the biggest skating squabbles since Tonya Harding versus Nancy Kerrigan, a court battle has erupted between the rink's operator, Recreation World, and the Trade Center owner, the Port Authority.

title: Explosion Destroys Oklahoma Motel Room
description: An explosion and fire destroyed a motel room here on Friday night, and the police arrested the occupant after finding four pipe bombs.

title: Sanitation Workers Robbed at Gunpoint
description: Two Department of Sanitation workers were robbed at gunpoint early yesterday morning as they collected garbage outside a housing project in Brownsville, Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Bertha Schizer, 102, Pharmacist Pioneer
description: Bertha Schizer, who started working as a pharmacist in Brooklyn when that profession was dominated by men, died on July 3 at University Hospital in Brooklyn. A longtime Brooklyn resident, she was 102.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Huffing and Puffing

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Thomas's Troubled History
description: Tampa Bay Buccaneers receiver LAMAR THOMAS threatened to kill himself over problems with his girlfriend, went to jail and was admitted to a mental hospital last year, a newspaper reported yesterday. Thomas, 26, was charged Wednesday with beating his pregnant fiancee, and was released a day later from Dade County Jail on $10,000 bond. He faces two counts of aggravated battery for beating EBONY COOKSEY, 22, at a Fourth of July party in the Plantation, in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;DIVING
description: THE UNITED STATES returns all three of its 1992 medalists to the Atlanta Games, but, as in swimming, the American divers in the post-Greg Louganis era will again have to contend with favorites from China and Russia.

title: Republicans Questioning Federal Deal With Union
description: On Nov. 4, 1994, Arthur A. Coia, president of the 700,000-member laborers' union, received two documents he will never forget.

title: Texaco Accused of Bias in Suit by Blacks
description: THE lawsuit contends that her employers called her uppity. She says she was merely asking questions. But the bottom line is that Bari-Ellen Roberts, a black senior financial analyst at Texaco Inc. here, believes she hit a glass ceiling.

title: The View From: Rye;Neither Storm Nor Fire Can Defeat Shenorock
description: TO see it now, one would never know that the Shenorock Shore Club was virtually destroyed by the nor'easter of 1992. On a recent sultry evening, as members celebrated its 50th anniversary, the place was the essence of polished gentility: the pale gray clubhouse with freshly painted white trim was perfectly picturesque against the summer dusk; on the veranda, with its awning-shaded tables and rows of potted red geraniums, sun-tanned men and women sipped drinks and nibbled shrimp while admiring the view of Long Island Sound. Yet it was this same body of water that three and a half years ago rushed up the beach, turned the free-standing cabanas, in the words of one member, into "floating boxes" and filled the clubhouse with several feet of ruinous water. On that winter day, members -- many having been summoned by spouses on their cellular phones -- came to the club and cried.

title: Reminders of an Elegant Quartet
description: THE Cleveland Quartet played its farewell concert last December, but reminiscences of the elegant ensemble will be a highlight of Saturday's 8 P.M. recital at the Norfolk Festival. The founding violinist and the cellist of the Cleveland -- Donald Weilerstein and Paul Katz -- and its last violist, James Dunham, are appearing in a program including Beethoven's String Trio in G, Opus 9 No. 1, Dvorak's ''Dumky'' Trio, and a suite from Stravinsky's ''Histoire du Soldat.'' The other participating artists that evening are the violinist Syoko Aki, the clarinetist David Krakauer and the pianist Vivian Hornik Weilerstein.

title: VOTES IN CONGRESS
description: Senate

title: 15 G.O.P. Freshmen In Abortion Arena
description: A leading abortion rights organization, trying the militant approach more often associated with the other side of the issue, is planning a vigorous effort to defeat 15 House freshmen, hoping the representatives' voting records over the last two years will work against them.

title: WEDDINGS;Casey Hagerman, Michael J. Bobo
description: Casey Clark-Bostwick Hagerman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David S. Hagerman of South Hamilton, Mass., was married yesterday to Michael James Bobo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Keith L. Bobo Jr. of Longview, Tex. The Rev. Richard C. Weymouth, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the United Church of Christ Chapel at Dartmouth College in Hanover, N.H.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: DOUGLASTON;2 Suits Slow Plans for a Speedier Long Island Expressway
description: The state's plan to add a fourth lane in each direction to the Long Island Expressway east of the Cross Island Parkway has run into two lawsuits that aim to hold off construction of the Queens segment. One suit, by a group of elected officials led by State Senator Frank Padavan, focuses on the impact of the project on residents. The other, by the city's Parks Department and Borough President Claire Shulman, asks the State Transportation Department to delay construction of the 1.1-mile stretch between the Cross Island and the Nassau line until a plan is made to protect a grove of tulip trees in Alley Pond Park. The suits, filed last month in State Supreme Court in Queens, also demand further environmental-impact studies.

title: A Living Memorial In Israel
description: I would like to comment on a recently published article, "From Parents' Worst Tragedy, A Living Memorial in Israel" [June 23]. Lynn Gettenberg spoke about her daughter Rachel's diagnosis, eventual death from a brain tumor and the establishment of a recreational center, Neve Rachel, for children with cancer in Israel. Mrs. Gettenberg also mentioned the Long Island Infant Developmental Program, which provided educational and therapeutic services to Rachel at home. The infant development program is a home-based early intervention program providing infants and toddlers with educational and/or therapeutic (occupational and physical therapy, and speech-language pathology) services. Complete comprehensive developmental evaluations, psychological and social work services along with a full array of support services are also offered.

title: Continent of Conquest
description: FIELDS OF BATTLE The Wars for North America. By John Keegan. Illustrated. 348 pp. New York:

title: JULY 7-13;The F.A.A.'s Gadfly Quits
description: After the Valujet crash in May, Mary Fackler Schiavo, inspector general of the Transportation Department, courted controversy by saying that the Federal Aviation Administration's lax oversight led to the accident. She ruffled a lot of feathers, but Congressmen also applauded her as a determined watchdog.

title: The Net Is a Waste of Time
description: I COINED THE WORD "CYBERSPACE" IN 1981 IN ONE OF MY first science fiction stories and subsequently used it to describe something that people insist on seeing as a sort of literary forerunner of the Internet. This being so, some think it remarkable that I do not use E-mail. In all truth, I have avoided it because I am lazy and enjoy staring blankly into space (which is also the space where novels come from) and because unanswered mail, E- or otherwise, is a source of discomfort.

title: The Victims of Cold Calls
description: To the Editor:

title: 8-Day Heat Wave Claims 20 Victims in Texas and Oklahoma
description: A heat-wave in Texas and Oklahoma killed at least 20 people last week, some of them elderly people who could not afford to use their air-conditioners.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week. Tickets are available through Ticketmaster, (800) 736-1420.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;YACHTING
description: THE UNITED STATES yachting team usually does well in the Olympics. It has 49 medals, the most of any country. It has also logged the best single Games performances: In 1984, the team won 7 medals in 7 classes; in 1992, it claimed 9 medals in 10 classes. This year, the 16-member American team comes to the sailing event after highly competitive trials. THE SETUP Logistics are apt to be difficult. A new Day Marina has been set up on floating barges at an ocean site about eight miles from the Olympic Marina in downtown Savannah, Ga. Athletes will be shuttled by boat down the winding Wilmington River each day to the 150,000-square-foot sailing base. The floating launch will house team tents, shower and storage facilities, tie-downs for the boats, food and technical support.

title: Doctors at Work To Regain Some Power
description: ST. VINCENT'S Medical Center in Bridgeport, the PHP Healthcare Corporation of Reston, Va., and hundreds of Fairfield County health professionals have joined forces in a new company called Connecticut Health Enterprise. At a time when the rules of the health-care system are increasingly set by cost-conscious insurance companies, officials of the new partnership say their venture will return authority to doctors.

title: Samaria Gorge
description: To the Editor: In October 1995 I took a three-week group trip arranged with Adventures Abroad of Vancouver, British Columbia, that included three days on Crete. One of the major attractions was an optional hike of the Samaria Gorge.

title: Bea Dolen, 83, Headed Board Of Elections for New York City
description: Bea Dolen, the unflappable ringmaster who oversaw the often chaotic election process in New York City for 14 years beginning in 1974, died on Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 83 and lived on the East Side of Manhattan.

title: THE ATHLETIC ESTHETIC
description: As Brubach points out, for years women have rejected the role of femininity by adopting men's fashion. The appropriation of muscles simply internalizes the effort.

title: Bond Market Listens to Savers, Not Bears
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HUDSON RIVER PHOTOS

title: 'Sonya': Troubled Life With a Sainted Man
description: DURING the first act of ''Sonya,'' the wife of Leo Tolstoy is pointed out as a ''soul in need'' by a doctor and disciple of the literary and philosophical icon.

title: Books in Brief: NonFiction
description: The Spirit of Black Hawk A Mystery of Africans and Indians. By Jason Berry. University Press of Mississippi, $20.

title: Young, Gifted, but Who Are They?
description: THEIR FACES EVOKE NO spark of recognition and their names -- Billy Crudup, Anne Heche, Liev Schreiber, Skeet Ulrich, Rachel Weisz, Renee Zellweger -- sound like roll call in your high school algebra class.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ODD BOATS

title: WEDDINGS;Sheila Mastrangelo, David Srere
description: Sheila Dorothy Mastrangelo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Angelo A. Mastrangelo of New Vernon, N.J., was married there yesterday to David Benson Srere, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benson M. Srere of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Donal R. Fox, an uncle of the bride, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Christ the King Church.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Women Apply Pressure
description: Just when the Italian Olympic team seemed capable of challenging the undefeated pre-Olympic record of the United States women's basketball team, a relentless, full-court defensive effort by the Americans held Italy to a single basket over 15 minutes 54 seconds. At the end of the 86-46 United States' victory last night in Indianapolis, the last game before a preliminary-round meeting with Cuba next Sunday at Atlanta, one last huddle celebrated an opportunity that is about to arrive.

title: Have We Forgotten Pinko Space Aliens?
description: To the Editor:

title: In Gulf War, Precision Air Weapons Paid Off
description: To the Editor:

title: Coney Island's Worn Welcome Mat
description: STRIP away the age-old air conditioner known as the Atlantic Ocean, the concession stands offering buttery cobs of corn and sleek hot dogs, the iridescent Wonder Wheel and the riders screaming as the chattering Cyclone drops. Remove the old-timers playing handball, the sunbathers on white bed sheets and the promise of prizes inside the arcades. What's left is a graying boardwalk, a welcome mat made of wood.

title: A MISSISSIPPI PROJECT;Don't Forget The Screenwriter
description: To the Editor: Rick Bragg, in his article on Rob Reiner's film about the pursuit of Medgar Evers's killer, failed to mention Lewis Colick's contribution as screenwriter for the project ["To Bind Up a Nation's Wound With Celluloid," June 16]. Whatever the reason for this oversight, more respect should be given to the screenwriter's craft. The screenwriter, whether on the set or not, is an inextricable part of the process; he is the storyteller. Sometimes the stories told are more about car chases than the human condition. But when a screenplay journeys into the ghostlands of a national nightmare, literature is possible.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: UPPER EAST SIDE;All That Jazz, and an Art Exhibit, Too
description: A CELEBRATED photograph of 57 jazz legends and some of the musicians themselves will be at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday for an evening that joins art exhibit and concert. The event was inspired by Art Kane's 1958 photograph of the 57 jazz greats gathered on the stoop of a Harlem brownstone, below. Survivors from the photograph will play with well-known musicians from the current scene, and the art exhibit will feature the original Kane photograph and nearly 100 other jazz photos, including one, taken this year by Gordon Parks for Life magazine, of 10 survivors from the 1958 photo. The evening opens "Jazz In July," a two-week series of jazz, ragtime and blues.

title: Lou Gottlieb, 72, the Bass Player For 1960's Folk Trio Limeliters
description: Lou Gottlieb, the bass player for the popular 1960's folk trio the Limeliters, died on Thursday at Palm Drive Hospital in Sebastopol, Calif. He was 72 and lived in Sonoma County, Calif.

title: What the New, Big Country Looked Like a Century Ago
description: THE 1800's in America saw a vogue for reproductions of picturesque scenery, because there was a widespread desire to see what the new, big country looked like. To satisfy this need, prints of panoramic vistas as well as intimate vignettes were published in magazines as well as in editions for framing and hanging in parlors.

title: Three Months Later, Navy Yard Still Needs Captain for Long Haul
description: Three months after the president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation was dismissed amid an investigation into an improper purchase of office furniture, a permanent chief has yet to be selected to head the 260-acre, city-owned industrial park.

title: Advocacy Group Aids Troubled Students
description: KIDS are allowed to make some mistakes,'' said Lisa Syron, the director of Student Advocacy, a nonprofit organization helping Westchester, Rockland, Putnam and Orange County students solve school problems.

title: RESTAURANTS;Of Time and the River
description: A FRIDAY afternoon in summer is not the time to be heading south on the Garden State Parkway. That's why we're so happy the wedding to which we've been invited is in Baltimore. Since my parents have been kind enough to take the children for the weekend, we're going to inaugurate our 48 hours of child-free splendor with an overnight stay at Evermay on the Delaware, a bed-and-breakfast just across the river from Frenchtown.

title: How to Make a Corpse Talk
description: JUDGING BY HER JACKET PHOTOGRAPH, Patricia Cornwell is the spitting image of her lead character, the one who has just got her a $24 million advance on three crime novels and made her a bundle on the previous seven, the most recent of which, "Cause of Death," was published this month. But Patricia Cornwell doesn't really resemble Dr. Kay Scarpetta, chief medical examiner of Virginia. Her hair, possibly lightened for the pictures, isn't blond and her eyes appear a less-vivid blue. Still, she has walked Kay Scarpetta's walk, talked Kay Scarpetta's talk, and if she has not been the target of a serial killer, as Kay Scarpetta was in her first novel, "Postmortem," she has been stalked and is as fully aware as her fictional protagonist of the terrible power of evil.

title: Editorial Notebook;The Second Daley's Legacy
description: Downtown Chicago is an architectural dream, a place where bold skyscrapers stand mirrored in Lake Michigan and vivid against a vast Midwestern sky. But encircling this scene is a calamity of staggering dimensions -- the poorest and, until quite recently, worst-run public housing system in the United States.

title: Halting the Stampede
description: To the Editor:

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;A Heavy Hitter Returns Home
description: The Louisville Slugger factory is back in its namesake town in Kentucky, after 20 years in Jeffersonville, Ind., across the Ohio River. And this Wednesday a baseball museum is scheduled to open, with tours of the new factory, now at 800 West Main Street, eight blocks from its old home.

title: Change of Plan
description: To the Editor: According to Iceland air's timetable and our ticket, Flight 642, Reykjavik to Amsterdam on April 21, was a nonstop flight. My wife and I were taken aback when, shortly after takeoff from Reykjavik, the captain announced that we were first headed for Luxembourg instead of Amsterdam. Later, we were told by the cabin crew that there were more passengers traveling to Luxembourg than to Amsterdam. In other words, passengers flying to Amsterdam ranked below those flying to Luxembourg.

title: A Desert Hardy That Can Bloom in New England
description: EVERY spring, John Spain of Middlebury is notified of the same death. A friend calls to tell him that the garden Mr. Spain started for him did not survive the winter.

title: Powell Seeking At Least One More Leap of Faith
description: MIKE POWELL stood on the runway for his sixth and final long jump at the Olympic trials last month in Atlanta, and, like a pilot, he went through his pre-flight checklist.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Underground Connections
description: Daniel Presburger freely admits to being a subway lurker. It's where he finds the best Olympic pins.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;TENNIS
description: OLYMPIC TENNIS, anyone? Well, Olympic tennis apparently is not for everyone, particularly the world's top male players. Several turned down their invitations to Atlanta. Some cited a case of the "been there, done that" syndrome, some cited other obligations of the money-making kind, and some, like Austria's occasionally top-ranked Thomas Muster, just plain didn't want to compete in the heat.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 5/ Pinching pennies may be unfashionable, but it's the proven route to riches. By Jane Birnbaum.

title: Neither Storm Nor Fire Can Defeat Shenorock
description: TO see it now, one would never know that the Shenorock Shore Club was virtually destroyed by the nor'easter of 1992. On a recent sultry evening, as members celebrated its 50th anniversary, the place was the essence of polished gentility: the pale gray clubhouse with freshly painted white trim was perfectly picturesque against the summer dusk; on the veranda, with its awning-shaded tables and rows of potted red geraniums, sun-tanned men and women sipped drinks and nibbled shrimp while admiring the view of Long Island Sound.

title: THE FRESH AIR FUND;Teaching City's Children Not to Grow Up Too Fast
description: In 1969, when Aubrey Jernigan was 10 years old, he got his first taste of life beyond Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: Sunday: July 14, 1996 -- GAMBLING;Luck, Be a (Little) Lady Tonight
description: The craps crowd -- you know how tough they can be," says Tom Henshaw, a gravelly-voiced Atlantic City pit-crew member. Yep. Not to mention the table itself, whose priesthoodly complexities often send beginners cringing back to the slots. In response to this and a broader sense that the gambling industry needs to meet neophyte customers halfway, Henshaw, his brother Larry and a fellow crewie, Gary Serowik, have developed Crap Shoot, a miniature version of craps, recently introduced in Atlantic City and Las Vegas. A Crap Shoot table measures 8 feet by 3 feet (full size is 14 by 4) and is ringed with eight comfortable chairs. Henshaw says tyros appreciate the opportunity to sit rather than stand and to learn the ropes in a small, quiet amphitheater, untaunted by cackling crowds. But note: all the dollars you will probably lose still measure 100 cents each.

title: HORSE RACING;Close, but No Citation: Jones Has His Say on Cigar
description: Jimmy Jones, an 89-year-old horse trainer with his memories, sat today and prepared to watch Cigar run against the record set half a century ago by the great Citation, and said that the horse he had once trained for Calumet Farm was "in a class by himself."

title: Bearing the Torch for Art and Quarters
description: JENNIFER STEWART is poised in front of the bathroom mirror in her Brooklyn Heights apartment, primping and preening for another day at the office.

title: Sports of The Times;Scoring a Few Points Amid Life's Excesses
description: WELCOME to the Excess Games, sports fans, where N.B.A. stars fearlessly jump from their agents' laps onto huge piles of unsoiled cash. Now let's go to our financial analyst for a little pay by pay.

title: The Big City;We Want to Be Alone
description: ACCORDING TO EXPERTS IN COUPLES therapy, it is generally advisable to start rethinking your marital relationship if you come home one evening and find your belongings in a heap outside the door. This is more or less the situation between Manhattan and Staten Island. The citizens of the "forgotten borough," home of the municipal landfill at Fresh Kills, have finally told us what to do with our trash. They've extracted a promise from Mayor Giuliani to close down the landfill within five years. Now that they won't be storing our garbage anymore, it's time to ask: What did we ever see in that borough? Shouldn't it be forgotten once and for all?

title: Acres of Primary Colors In an English Legoland
description: LEGOLAND WINDSOR, the new theme park just west of Heathrow Airport in London, lives up to its toy store namesake both on esthetic grounds (we are talking acres of primary colors) and on philosophical grounds (few supersonic rides, no piped-in music, no junk food, but much to delight the imagination).

title: Playboy of the Eastern World
description: THE WINTER'S HERO By Vassily Aksyonov. Translated by John Glad. 428 pp. New York: Random House. $27.50.

title: ART VIEW;For the Omnivorous Esthete
description: Contrary to what is often supposed, the accepted notion of a good book on art is volatile, unstable and seasonal.

title: Connecticut Q&A: John B. Larson;Universal Internet Access, Fall of '96
description: ON Sept. 28, community volunteers are to start wiring Connecticut's schools and libraries, providing access to and home pages on the Internet. The initiative is called ConneCT96 and is being led by John B. Larson, a former gubernatorial candidate, past president of the state Senate and a former elementary and high school teacher. Mr. Larson, currently a senior fellow at the Yale University Bush Center for Child Development and Social Policy, said that any school or library that, by tomorrow's deadline, has established a planning team, signed up for the program and raised $600 to $800 for the connection kit, qualifies for the program. The Southern New England Telephone Company will provide 60 hours of free Internet access each month to each participating institution during the 1996-97 school year.

title: Children's Books;Bookshelf
description: WILMA UNLIMITED: How Wilma Rudolph Became the World's Fastest Woman. By Kathleen Krull. Illustrated by David Diaz. Harcourt Brace. $16. (Ages 7 to 12) Here's the inspiring story of the great American runner who won three gold medals at the 1960 Olympics.

title: Liberties;General Snipe
description: The general set me up.

title: MUSIC;Reminders of an Elegant Quartet
description: THE Cleveland Quartet played its farewell concert last December, but reminiscences of the elegant ensemble will be a highlight of Saturday's 8 P.M. recital at the Norfolk Festival. The founding violinist and the cellist of the Cleveland -- Donald Weilerstein and Paul Katz -- and its last violist, James Dunham, are appearing in a program including Beethoven's String Trio in G, Opus 9 No. 1, Dvorak's "Dumky" Trio, and a suite from Stravinsky's "Histoire du Soldat." The other participating artists that evening are the violinist Syoko Aki, the clarinetist David Krakauer and the pianist Vivian Hornik Weilerstein. The Tokyo Quartet, which has been at the Norfolk Festival for more than 20 seasons, offers Beethoven's Opus 131 along with Schubert's A Minor Quartet at the Music Shed on Friday night at 8. Of further note at Norfolk this week is a free 8 P.M. Wednesday lecture about composers and performers who appeared at Norfolk in the early years of the Festival; there's also a young artists' recital scheduled at 7:30 the following evening. For reservations or driving directions, call 542-3000.

title: In the Region/Connecticut;In Danbury, a Short Street That's Long on Hope
description: THE rehabilitation of a short street named for one of this city's notable natives, the late composer Charles Ives, has provided a focus for its effort to rejuvenate its downtown, which went into a sharp decline following the opening of the 1.5-million-square-foot Danbury Fair Mall in 1987.

title: Gimme Shelter
description: Back in the 1950's and 60's, the chill wind of the cold war permeated even my small, suburban elementary school, sending me and my classmates under our desks in duck-and-cover drills to prepare for the possibility of nuclear attack. Our family, like many others who followed the advice printed in public safety pamphlets, gamely designated a corner of our basement as a "bomb shelter," and I vividly remember helping my mother stockpile canned goods and water jugs. For a time around the Cuban missile crisis, the mere sound of a jet overhead was enough to propel me to the basement to reassure myself with an inventory of the cans of evaporated milk and cling peaches, and to check our flashlight batteries.

title: 300 Years Plus of Hartford's Black Heritage
description: IN a second-floor room at the Connecticut Historical Society, a manacled and faceless black mannequin stands as a symbol of the most sweeping exhibition ever about the black population of Connecticut's capital city.

title: ART;Power and Imagination in Original Work
description: Carroll Dunham Guild Hall Museum, 158 Main St., East Hampton. To July 28. 324-0806. For 10 years Carroll Dunham has been on most everyone's list of young talents to be watched. He manages to pack power, imagination and energy into paintings that seem original, effective and right for our time. In his latest canvases fields of activity are filled with free-flowing doodles and glandular forms that appear to be mining the science fiction in his subconscious. Like much contemporary art, this work explores physicality in new ways. The lush sensuous color is gutsy; cartoonish creaturelike architectural forms burst with an uncanny vitality, and sizable round spores protrude from the surface, spreading in a manner that seems out of control. There is a tendency to interpret the clusters of spores as human or technological viruses, or both. Paintings are crowded and abstract, yet suggestions of real-life content can make them appear unexpectedly edgy. Sometimes the organic forms seem part of fantasy narratives or undefined incidents. It is not unusual for the image to be disquieting and for the tension to build through contrasts between the man-made and the anthropomorphic, the firm and the pliable, the solid and the vulnerable. Scale is unsettling when human characteristics are assigned to geometric buildings. "Tower," with its tilting pink structure, gives the impression of a wired world gone crazy and is one of the show's best examples. Signlike and immediate, "Visible Language" suggests a cell magnified into a single icon. Line is basic to all Mr. Dunham's work, because it is his primary way of opening the flow of invention. Be sure to see the wonderful drawings in paint and graphite on papyrus in an area adjacent to the main gallery. "Carroll Dunham: Paintings and Drawings" was organized by the Santa Barbara Contemporary Arts Forum, which is circulating the exhibition.

title: DIARY: THE OLYMPICS;What Cashless Society?
description: For all the talk of microchips, Web sites, hand-recognition systems and other technology, the arrival of the Olympic Games also means a festival of cash. Just to make sure that visitors have enough in hand to pay for all the liquids that doctors recommend be consumed in the Atlanta climate -- as well as the huge variety of official Olympic merchandise -- rolling automatic teller machines are being provided.

title: The View From: Middlebury;A Desert Hardy That Can Bloom in New England
description: EVERY spring, John Spain of Middlebury is notified of the same death. A friend calls to tell him that the garden Mr. Spain started for him did not survive the winter. And every year, Mr. Spain visits a friend's garden and proclaims the cactuses, although shriveled, very much alive and no worse for the snow, harsh winds and sub-zero temperatures. It seems even Mr. Spain's friends have a hard time believing his cactus claim: hundreds of varieties of cactuses, including the well-known prickly pear, can be grown outdoors in Connecticut and survive the winter. There is even a cactus that is native to Connecticut, a wildflower. But Mr. Spain is doubted still; the plants are perceived as much a symbol of the desert as rattlesnakes and scorpions. A retired Uniroyal training executive, Mr. Spain says he has one of the largest collections of winter-hardy cactuses in the country. He grows hundreds of varieties in his backyard, a slice of the Southwest that is only a few yards from rhododendron and fern. The cactuses may seem out of place, but they thrive north of the Mason/Dixie line and can carry a bed all by themselves. They come in various shapes, sizes and blooms of yellow, orange, pink and red. A 60-foot-long bed of cactus only is the centerpiece of Mr. Spain's backyard garden. For the size of his cactus garden, he said he puts in few hours; cactus, of course, require little water. Also, few diseases afflict them in the state, and they do not seem to be part of the food chain for beetles, deer or other pests. But, for all these assets, outdoor cactus gardening in Connecticut is, well, novel."People are always surprised," Mr. Spain said. Most people in the state, including experienced gardeners, know little about cactus and generally assume they can't grow them outside, he said. Mr. Spain is always eager to correct misconceptions, and people who meet him soon learn that cactuses grow near the Arctic circle and in trees. They can be 20 years old and still no bigger than a golf ball, and the plants are native only to North and South America. Some gardeners are aware that cactuses can be grown in Connecticut, but are often mislead at nurseries where the perceived wisdom is that only one yellow-blooming variety is hardy to the region, he said. Before Roseann Richard, owner of Walnut Hill Greenhouse in Litchfield, met Mr. Spain about 10 years ago, she knew of no one who grew cactuses outdoors year-round in the state, and she did not think it possible. "He proved you could if you treat them a certain way," she said. "Nobody knew which ones you could grow until he came along." Through trial and error for more than three decades, Mr. Spain has assembled a list of plants that can grow in cold climates, and he has developed ways to help them adapt. When he started, he said, he found only two suppliers of winter-hardy cactus in the entire country. Unlike someone trying to grow roses, Mr. Spain was not going to find answers to his horticultural problems in the local library or nursery. Due to this dearth of information, for almost as long as Mr. Spain has been growing winter-hardy cactuses, he has been educating the public about them. He and a few others successfully lobbied the Northeast Rock Garden Society to accept the cactus as a legitimate alpine plant, with a rock garden pedigree. Mr. Spain, a resident of Connecticut for 24 years, is also a founder and first president of the Connecticut Cactus and Succulent Society. He published a book on winter-hardy cactuses, helped many gardeners start their own collections, and is on the garden-club-speaker circuit. "He has definitely been the introducer of winter-hardy cactus in the state," said Jack Phillips, the current president of the cactus society. "He has been willing to share time with anyone interested in this hobby." Mr. Spain's passion for cactus developed by chance in 1966 due to a greenhouse too small for his ambitions. He said he wanted to spend his hours coaxing blooms from orchids, but could not because of the expense involved, and was frustrated with begonias because they took too much room. Then he found the cactus. After a trip to Colorado, he returned with a few cactuses for his three young boys. Though thrilled at first, the boys lost interest in about 20 minutes. "So then they were mine," he said. "I discovered I could have a whole lot of them and you don't have to water every day." Easy care is essential for a gardener who travels frequently and has a spouse more interested in needlepoint than horticulture. Soon after, Mr. Spain, then living in Michigan, met a person who grew cactus outdoors and that was the start of his winter-hardy passion. To keep costs down, he has grown many of his plants from seed. While some grow fast, others can take a year and a half just to be the size of a matchstick head. Mr. Spain said there are three main families of cactus that grow in cold climates: echinocereus, coryphantha and opuntia. However, within these families, there are hundreds of varieties. To survive the Connecticut climate, the cactuses need full sun (at least five hours) and excellent drainage. He suggests mixing a lot of sand and gravel into the soil and using raised beds. Mr. Spain said cactuses do like humus-rich soil though. "They will be growing out of a rock, but don't be fooled, because inside the soil is black as can be," he said. A few favorites growing in his own outdoor gardens include one that is 11 years old "and still that tiny," he said, pointing to a plant no bigger than a small loaf of bread. He also dotes on one particular opuntia fragilis, Bronze Beauty, which has pads that turn bronze in winter. He likes it because he got to name it. The plant is unlike its closest relatives and Mr. Spain has been unable to find any documentation of it, so he took the honors of giving it a name. And even though he grows a few orchids now, he is more apt to talk about his opuntia polyacantha Crystal Tide. It has a near-white flower with a blood red center, and he unequivocally calls it the most beautiful of the opuntia blooms. "I am really not an orchid person," he said.

title: A Frosty Reception for the Golden Arches
description: Sprayed in white paint on the front of what had been a bank on Ninth Avenue near 49th Street is a particularly harsh review of a restaurant that has not even opened.

title: Botswana Is Pressing Bushmen to Leave Reserve
description: The 1,000 Bushmen on this vast reserve are often described as the last Bushmen on earth living their traditional hunter-gatherer life. But this is a romantic view.

title: Collectors Lend Pieces, From Superb to the So-So
description: THE word in Westchester is that the King of England, presumably William III, offered John Harrison all the land he could ride in a day. Harrison rode and, presto! The town bearing his name.

title: The Silent Stones of Brittany
description: WE first saw them from the road: six towering slabs of unshaped grayish-white stone. Too orderly to be a natural formation, indeed almost human in appearance, they seemed caught in midtrudge across the windswept landscape -- a sextet of hitchhikers frozen by a sorcerer's curse.

title: Millions of Cards in Pursuit of Missing Children
description: VINCE GIULIANO is a big and enthusiastic bear of a man who loves to talk about his work. But his eyes can tear up, unashamedly, when he thinks about the children still missing, or dead.

title: Different Recollections on 'Trial by Dingell';Not a Proper Forum
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC;Globetrotting Tenors in a Stadium Near You
description: WHATEVER else you think about the Three Tenors concerts, you must concede that Luciano Pavarotti, Placido Domingo and Jose Carreras have earned their musical stripes, and that they work steady. As the ABC anchorman Peter Jennings said on a recent newscast, everyone has heard of the tenors, "even those who don't know a legato from a lawn mower."

title: Infant Falls To Her Death In the Arms Of Her Father
description: Daphney Nerette lay down to sleep Friday night, her infant daughter at her side and her fiance, Marcus Calcador, reading religious literature in another room.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;The Going Rate in the World of Haute Coiffure: $500
description: Sherrerd Stewart sat on a black banquette of the Frederic Fekkai hair salon at Bergdorf Goodman, her feet wrapped in white foam while newly painted Chanel pink polish dried on her toes and fingernails. She talked about hair. "Sometimes I find it hard to believe I have $500 hair," said the 30-something Manhattanite, with subtle blond highlights and an above-the-shoulder tousled layered cut. "My friends think I'm ridiculous." But Ms. Stewart, an advertising account executive, is not alone. While the $300 haircut (and $200 highlights) used to be for models or the very well-to-do, it has also become a must for chic young Upper East Siders and well-heeled Connecticut matrons. Waiting lists go from a few months to a year for appointments with many of the high-end stylists of the moment -- John Sahag, Garren at Henri Bendel's, Kim Lepine, Steven Knoll and Mr. Fekkai. "High-end hair is making a comeback," said Charles Booth, owner of the Madison Avenue salon La Coupe for 30 years. Ms. Stewart said: "Everything is competitive in New York. Great hair may just give you the edge. It makes you think you will do better in the dating market, in the workplace." High-end hair fits the style of the 90's, in which people express affluence in relatively subtle ways, said Annemarie Iverson, the beauty and health director at Harper's Bazaar. "A haircut," she says, "is a quiet way to express wealth." The hair salons are capitalizing on the trend. Frederic Fekkai in a joint venture with Chanel, is taking his business, along with his high-profile clientele (like John F. Kennedy Jr. and Christie Brinkley), from a half-floor space at Bergdorf's to a five-story "town house in the sky" in the Chanel building at East 57th Street in mid-August. On Thursday afternoon at his present salon, while Ms. Stewart sat drying her toes, lines of women walked by, in the latest Prada bags and Gucci loafers, waiting for their appointments. There was almost no room to sit. The customers get to wear black monogrammed smocks and drink their fill of coffee, tea or ice water with a twist of lemon. They can order lunch from a menu while their bill is running up to $90 to $295 for less than an hour's work, typical of the high-end salons. The trend, Mr. Fekkai said, is "very simple short hair, the length between the neck and chin." Ms. Iverson said: "It's not necessarily the best haircut in the world. You can pay $60 and get the same thing, but it's the luxe element of going to these salons. People can say they got their hair cut next to Sigourney Weaver." MONIQUE P. YAZIGI

title: Books in Brief: NonFiction;Faking It
description: On the run from the first ominous stirrings of will would become World War II, a young journalist embarks on a tempestuous pocket-Baedeker tour, passing through Monte Carlo, Vienna, Belgrade, Madrid and eventually the Caribbean islands, always pursued by -- and in constant pursuit of -- his memories of the past. Peter Furst's autobiographical novel, DON QUIXOTE IN EXILE (Northwestern University, cloth, $39.95; paper, $15.95), tells an extraordinary tale in marvelously impressionistic language. It is part diary, part dream book, part thriller -- and all the parts blend beautifully. Mr. Furst's prose is sensuous and sinewy, using odd symbols and sudden reactions to capture the dislocation -- linguistic, cultural and emotional -- that his hero feels every step of the way. He tells of faking reports from the Spanish Civil War while comfortably ensconced in a Vienna coffeehouse; of picking cacao beans and poisoning rats in the Dominican Republic; of watching fellow Jews die at border points across Europe even as his German passport (he describes himself as a "Christian Jew" because he was baptized) opens the doors to freedom. Alcohol is a friend, while faceless, inane and often evil bureaucrats are the ultimate enemy. Chance encounters lead to quick romance, and even a rambunctious yet doomed marriage, though the ghost of his first love weighs heavy. Mr. Furst's book is perhaps the exile's tale nonpareil: the moving story of a man without home or homeland but able to adapt almost anywhere. Erik Burns

title: Survivors Report Torture in North Korea Labor Camps
description: She has recovered her health to the point that she can hobble again, with a limp to remind her of the whips and racks and water-torture kettle. But as she tells it, the greatest trauma was not to her body but to her mind: the memory of a friend who stole a beet.

title: On Ritalin and Prozac For Children
description: The interview with Dr. Harold S. Koplewicz [ong Island Q&A, June 16] on the subject of prescribing Ritalin and Prozac to children did not include the following issues: The child feels like help is coming from the outside (in the form of a pill) and from an authoritarian figure rather than through efforts on the child's part. The controls are coming from without; not developed from within.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;FUNDS WATCH
description: Some Different Paths In the Search for Yield

title: Barbecuing In a Style Of Africa
description: IN the mood for some monkey gland sauce? Don't worry -- there isn't any monkey in it. The spicy sauce is a South African delicacy made of chutney and other ingredients, and its name is of unknown origin. You can get it at the Fourth Annual Braai -- Afrikaans for barbecue -- to be held at Ridge Park in Hartsdale next Saturday from noon to 6 P.M.

title: Say What?
description: To the Editor:

title: Appearances;Under The Influence
description: My friend Daryl took me on a fragrance buying trip -- not to the main floor of Macy's or Bloomingdale's where the sales force stands with spritzers at the ready -- but to Enchantments on East Ninth Street, a kind of witch supply store. Daryl had recently locked on to some scents that had worked for him in a big way. One was Crown of Success oil. Soon after he started using it, he won $100 in a contest and then out of the blue was offered an exciting new job. When Daryl wore the other scent, Venus, to a basketball game, a stranger asked the name of his cologne; she wanted to get it for her boyfriend.

title: No Raiding Allowed
description: To the Editor:

title: Fatal Production
description: THE VIPERS' CLUB By John H. Richardson. 293 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $24.

title: WEDDINGS;Ms. Gaughan, Mr. Cummings
description: Maureen Catherine Gaughan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Gaughan of Fairfield, Conn., was married yesterday to Daniel Patrick Cummings, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel P. Cummings of Tamarac, Fla. The Rev. Charles Allen performed the ceremony at St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Fairfield.

title: Artists and the Map Do Not a Left Bank Make
description: To the Editor:

title: Cable's Gift to Schools
description: The cable television industry has pledged to provide nearly every school in the country with access to the Internet -- the network of millions of computers around the world that offers on-line information. The offer will bring fabulous educational resources to schools too poor to provide an advanced Internet hookup on their own.

title: FOOD;For Summertime Variety, Try Potatoes
description: IN the summer, I eat a lot of potatoes. One of my favorite ways of cooking them is to cut them into chunks with their skins left on, steam them and then finish them on the grill, where they brown over the coals at the same time as meat or fish. Potatoes cooked this way come out nicely crisp -- and with no more fat than a plain baked potato.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;SWIMMING
description: AT THE 1994 world championships in Rome, Chinese women won 12 of 16 gold medals. In the fall of 1994, at the Asian Games in Hiroshima, Japan, Chinese swimmers were made to submit to an unannounced, out-of-competition drug test. This time, seven Chinese women, including two world champions, tested positive for banned substances and were given two-year suspensions.

title: In the Region/Long Island;Long Beach Rent Battle Focuses on Vacancy Rate
description: A DISPUTE between landlords and the City of Long Beach over the continuation of rent stabilization there could, according to lawyers representing both sides, lead to new guidelines for all municipalities that have adopted the Emergency Tenants Protection Act of 1974.

title: Books in Brief: NonFiction
description: REFIGURING LIFE Metaphors of Twentieth-Century Biology. By Evelyn Fox Keller. Columbia University, $20.

title: Our Towns;For Triathlete, The 4th Event Is Juggling
description: JIM QUINN, tall and lithe as a dancer, slid stealthily behind four men fishing, through an open field and into a thicket of pin oaks, where he would quietly zip off his clothes and jump in the lake.

title: Books in Brief: NonFiction
description: MAKE-BELIEVE TOWN Essays and Remembrances. By David Mamet. Little, Brown, $22.95.

title: OUT THERE: ATLANTA;Nightclub Olympiad Takes Shape
description: IF you build it, they will come.

title: A U.S. Envoy Tries to Court The Court Of St. James's
description: The American Ambassador, William J. Crowe Jr., was speaking to British business leaders some months ago when a man rose to berate the Clinton Administration for not wholeheartedly (by his lights) supporting Northern Ireland's inclusion in Britain. Hammering home his point, the man finally spluttered, "How would you feel if Mexico took back Texas?"

title: At Yonkers Funeral, Mystery and Grief
description: As hundreds of mourners gathered to remember Nathaniel Levi Gaines Jr. today, one question angrily pushed its way into their grief: Why did a police officer in the Bronx fatally shoot the unarmed young man in the back?

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;FENCING
description: THERE WILL BE no Zorro, Douglas Fairbanks Jr. or Errol Flynn, but 220 men and women from 46 nations will compete in this traditional sport that has been part of the Olympics since their revival in 1896.

title: THEATER TICKETS;A Lot for Grown-Ups
description: To the Editor: I take my hat off to Mr. Robinson for being able to arrange his budget to see more than eight shows a month. If one were to buy half-price tickets for only four shows a month -- one each for a Broadway, Off Broadway, Off Off Broadway and regional show -- it would add up to $1,261 a year. I don't know where Mr. Robinson got his pocket money in college, but most students (and their parents) would think this sum is a lot. As a matter of fact, it's a lot for grown-ups, too. NIKKI HARMON New York

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ODD BOATS

title: IN PERSON;Terminally Serious? Try Laughing
description: FOR th stressed-out, overworked office worker, Paul McGhee has a simple message: Lighten up.

title: Russian Troops Continue Attack On Rebels in Chechen Village
description: Russian troops ended their fierce assault on one Chechen village today but kept up a siege against another, which they contend is the headquarters of the top rebel leader.

title: ON THE MAP;In Neptune, a Museum Offers Lessons for Students of All Ages
description: Hundreds of years ago, the area drained by the Shark River in what is now Neptune Township was home to the Lenape people, known as the Delaware Indians to the English who came to the region. Within 100 years of the Europeans' arrival, the population of 15,000 to 20,000 Lenapes had been reduced to about 300.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HUDSON RIVER PHOTOS

title: The Nation;When a Justice Suffers From Indecision
description: LATE in the Supreme Court term that ended last month, in the course of an opinion addressing Government regulation of indecent programming on cable television, Justice Stephen G. Breyer did something unusual. He acknowledged publicly that he was not sure how to decide the case.

title: EARNING IT;For Employee-Owners of Avis, a Bittersweet Deal
description: IT may be No. 2 in the rental-car business, but Avis Inc. is regarded by many as the No. 1 employee-owned company. When United Airlines was sold to its employees two years ago, for example, Avis was held up as a model for getting workers to participate in the company.

title: INVESTING IT;Rich, if Not Famous, in 15 Minutes
description: TIME is money. But on Wall Street, real time can mean real big money.

title: Mind Games and More: Swimming the 50
description: Photo: Amy Van Dyken will be competing in at least four events in Atlanta: the 100-meter freestyle, 100 butterfly, 400 freestyle relay and the 50 freestyle, where she is America's best hope for gold. In her words, here is what it will take to win the 50. BEDEL SAGET

title: Gold Digger of 1868
description: LOST AND FOUND The 9,000 Treasures of Troy: Heinrich Schliemann and the Gold That Got Away. By Caroline Moorehead. Illustrated. 307 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95.

title: The Changing Ways of Health Care
