description: FACED with increasing costs and fewer inpatient stays, many hospitals and doctors are joining together to take a more active role in how health care is provided. Instead of being controlled by insurance companies, they are aiming to establish their own managed-care companies. ''Hospitals are looking at ways of reinventing themselves and participating in the health care market,'' says Karen Smigel, a financial examiner with the Connecticut Insurance Department. She says she gets three to four inquiries each week from hospitals interested in starting an H.M.O., but estimates that only one in 100 files an application. ''An H.M.O. is a different mindset,'' she said. ''It's not as easy at it looks. You have to interact with other hospitals not as a competitor but as a provider in your network.''

title: A Literary Magazine Starts in Hamptons
description: AFTER writing a short story set in Southampton about ''the indulgent rich,'' Barbara Stone asked herself last winter where she could submit the work to have it published.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: CLINTON;A Frosty Reception for the Golden Arches
description: Sprayed in white paint on the front of what had been a bank on Ninth Avenue near 49th Street is a particularly harsh review of a restaurant that has not even opened. "Keep It Real! No McDonald's In Hells Kitchen!!" reads the graffito, a barometer of the level of anxiety among some local residents about plans by the McDonald's Corporation to open one of its trademark fast-food restaurants at the site. They fear it will undermine a successful community policing program begun five years ago after residents and merchants complained about the student rush hours.

title: WEDDINGS;Vandy Woods, David Boudreau
description: Louisa Van der Marck Woods, the daughter of Leslie Woods Rogers of New York and the late Brewer Cochrane Woods, was married yesterday to David Kenneth Boudreau, a son of Janice Fayard Boudreau of Point Clear, Ala., and Dr. F. T. Boudreau of Mobile, Ala. The Rev. Robert Babb, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Trails End Ranch in Aspen, Colo.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;Campaign Trail, Over Internet, Up to Vermont
description: It may seem a bit nutty that Prof. August St. John, who teaches marketing and future studies at the Brooklyn campus of Long Island University, commutes from Vermont. But the 68-year-old academic, who specializes in economic forecasting and is known in his home state as "Dr. Doom and Gloom," rarely takes the conventional route to anything. Besides, said Professor St. John, who teaches on Tuesdays and Wednesdays but is off for the summer, those 10 driving hours are the prime moments of a prophet's work. "It's quiet," he said, "and I get these thoughts."

title: Different Recollections on 'Trial by Dingell'
description: To the Editor:

title: VIEWPOINT;Have Spinoffs Spun Out of Control?
description: THOUGH spinoff companies are not a new phenomenon, never before have so many been created.

title: INSIDE
description: New AIDS Dynamics

title: To Be Young, Gay, Healthy . . . and Alienated;New Support Groups for the H.I.V.-Negative Handle Guilt, Fear and Isolation
description: Early last year, Nick Mattsson was asked to envision his future and he found, distressingly, there was nothing he could see.

title: San Francisco Tells Pizza Shops to Hold the Excuses
description: Neighborhoods in this city can change as fast as the weather: stately Victorians sliding rapidly into forlorn hovels, well-tended flower beds giving way to weeds and refuse. No one knows this better than pizza deliverers, who have been threatened, robbed, assaulted and even killed in the line of duty.

title: Union Alleges Border Patrol Faked Results In Crackdown
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service is investigating the United States Border Patrol operations in San Diego after accusations that supervisors there falsified reports to make a crackdown on illegal immigrants appear more successful than it was.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;CYCLING
description: OLYMPIC CYCLING provides two firsts this year. Professionals will be allowed to ride, which means that many of the best road racers from the Tour de France will compete. And mountain bikes, which account for two-thirds of all bicycle sales in the United States, will become part of the Olympic program.

title: WEDDINGS;Patricia K. Nasey, David L. Goldberg
description: Patricia Kathleen Nasey, the daughter of Patricia DeLuca of San Francisco and Laurence Nasey of Hillsborough, Calif., was married last evening to David Lloyd Goldberg, a son of Rosalie and Richard Goldberg of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Judith Schindler performed the ceremony at Studio 450, a photographer's studio in New York.

title: MUSIC;Outdoors Concerts Are Now in Full Swing
description: THE outdoors beckons at this time of year, and many opportunities to hear music al fresco are at hand, among them the yearly Valhalla visit of the New York Philharmonic, chamber music at Caramoor, a Sunset Serenade at Lyndhurst, Summer Dances at Wave Hill and a Cajun Festival in Croton Point Park. When the New York Philharmonic comes to Westchester Community College next Saturday at 8 P.M., residents will have their first opportunity to meet Eiji Oue, music director of the Minnesota Orchestra. Four orchestral showpieces make up the Japanese-born conductor's free program: Moussorgsky's "Night on Bald Mountain," Stravinsky's "Firebird" Suite, the "Don Juan" tone poem by Richard Strauss and Respighi's "Pines of Rome," all capped with fireworks. If it rains, the fireworks will be canceled, but the concert will move to the County Center in White Plains. For more details, call 242-6300.

title: SCHOOLS;In Newark, 'Promotional Enrichment'
description: One year after state education officials took control of this city's troubled school system, summer programs are in flux, particularly at the elementary level. Roughly 2,000 pupils in first through eighth grades are in class this month, mainly because they performed poorly on standardized tests. But instead of relying on textbooks, teachers are trying a new approach.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Signage Is 'Overkill'
description: Dr. LeRoy T. Walker, president of the United States Olympic Committee, became the latest person to express his displeasure with the cluttering proliferation of tents, signs and logos erected by corporate sponsors that looms over the Atlanta Olympics.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;When a Change of Address Comes With a New Anthem
description: AT THE 1992 Barcelona Olympics, Alina Astafei won a silver medal in the high jump for Romania. She is favored to win another medal in Atlanta, but if she does, she will win it for Germany.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;WEIGHT LIFTING
description: EACH WEIGHT CLASS will produce Olympic records because starting on Dec. 31, 1992, the international weight lifting federation threw out the old weight classes and introduced new classes, a few pounds heavier or lighter than the old. The idea was to eliminate drug-tainted records. Weight-lifting people say the sport is much cleaner now, with more drug testing and lifetime bans for those who test positive for steroids. THE SETUP There are three gold medals in each of the 10 weight classes ranging from 119 pounds to superheavyweight (over 238 pounds).

title: ELLA FITZGERALD;Strokes of Genius
description: To the Editor: After days of Ella, Ella, Ella (and her fellas) on the radio and on my player, it was nice to close out the week with Jonathan Schwartz's lovely tribute. Plus, of course, that wonderful Al Hirschfeld drawing (speaking of geniuses).

title: OLYMPICS;Gymnast Strikes Remarkable Balance
description: Last month's high-speed collision between Amy Chow's face and a Boston balance beam was not forceful enough to knock her off the Olympic team. Nor was that most public and painful slip at the women's gymnastics trials forceful enough to knock Chow off her singular course.

title: WEDDINGS;Deirdre O'Dea, Stephen Corcoran
description: Deirdre Ellen O'Dea, a daughter of Eileen and James O'Dea of Brooklyn, was married on Friday to Stephen Patrick Corcoran, a son of Margaret and James P. Corcoran, also of Brooklyn. The Rev. James Joyce, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Holy Name of Jesus Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;TEAM HANDBALL
description: RELATIVELY POPULAR in Europe and parts of Asia but largely unknown in North America, team handball has nothing to do with a ball ricocheting off four walls. Instead, it requires its practitioners to throw, catch, dribble, leap, defend and, above all, score goals. In the 1992 men's Olympic final, the Unified Team (composed of former Soviets) beat Sweden, 22-20, which was hardly high scoring by handball standards. THE SETUP Holger Nielsen, a Danish teacher, codified the sport in the early 20th century to help Danes stay in shape during the winter. Nielsen's game has been called water polo without water, basketball without dunks and soccer with hands. As in water polo, there are seven players to a side. As in basketball, players advance the ball up the court by passing and dribbling. As in soccer, players shoot past a goalie.

title: Failure of Legislative Talks Dooms School System Plan
description: Last-minute talks fell apart early this morning on a plan to revamp the way that the New York City schools are governed, probably ending any chance that the Legislature will make significant changes in the troubled system this year.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-11

title: DINING OUT;Exciting Blend of the Local and Global
description: VISITORS to Montauk are familiar with the famous lighthouse at the point. It is the symbol of Long Island. But there is a second, smaller lighthouse at Star Island on Lake Montauk. It too is a symbol. It is the logo of the Montauk Yacht Club and the inspiration for its restaurant, the Lighthouse Grill. Years ago, when this was a private club, the Whitneys, Vanderbilts and Astors were counted among its members. Today, the pretty, airy, white-walled and window-dominated dining room is filled with vacationing families who stay here. Montauk locals and visitors from other hotels are attracted by the bargain $19.96 sunset meal, the water views and the exciting food created by its chef, Douglas Peckham.

title: With Few Frills, VanDerveer Wins
description: TARA VANDERVEER seems to need this right now, a view of something unpretentious and unspoiled, the sight of hills dipping into a lake little more than a coin flip away from her parents' porch in Chautauqua, N.Y.

title: Harry Wedeck, 102, Observer of the Odd
description: Harry E. Wedeck, a linguist, scholar of the classics and observer of spheres beyond the norm, died on Monday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 102 and lived on the Upper East Side.

title: Two Attacks On Foreigners Raise Tension In Bosnia
description: Two attacks on foreigners, including the shooting of an American working for the United States Embassy, have heightened tensions in Bosnia and may also increase concerns that any attempt by NATO forces to arrest Bosnian Serb leaders for war crimes could result in retaliation against foreigners.

title: COVER STORY;A Marathon of Summer Olympics: 17 Days With 170 Hours of Events
description: ON Friday, the onslaught will begin: 171.5 hours of the Summer Olympics, NBC's 17-day, wrapped-in-the-flag marathon from Atlanta starring sprinters, gymnasts, rowers, boxers, divers, long jumpers, wrestlers and Bob Costas.

title: WEDDINGS;Gabriela M. Haas, Charles Clough 3d
description: Gabriela Miriam Haas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julius R. Haas of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Charles Ingalls Clough 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Clough Jr. of Concord, Mass. The bridegroom's father, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Church in Chatham, N.J.

title: The Mess in Mexico
description: Bordering on Chaos Guerrillas, Stockbrokers, Politicians, and Mexico's Road to Prosperity. By Andres Oppenheimer. Illustrated. 367 pp. New York: Little, Brown & Company. $25.95.

title: Paying Their Own Way
description: RAYMOND MAKORI, 19, has his eye on a car, a sporty used Mitsubishi Starion. So at 3 P.M. five times a week -- more often, if he can get the overtime -- he takes a bus from his home here to the gatehouse at the sprawling Panasonic headquarters in Secaucus to begin an eight-hour shift as a security guard.

title: ATLANTA IS BURNING
description: Y'all please note: As a native New Yorker and six-year resident of Atlanta, I contend that Paul Goldberger over-researched and under-considered his subject. It may be amusing to trash a city just before its moment of world scrutiny -- especially one as pretty and "easy" as Atlanta -- but it isn't especially fair.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: MARKET WATCH;Market Dip Sparks Recession Talk
description: The only thing we have to fear is everything.

title: Q and A
description: Around-the-World Air Fares

title: Netanyahu Stresses Cultural Bonds for Jews in New York and Israel
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel popped open his big black umbrella yesterday, the final day of his hectic visit to New York City, and braved gusty winds and drenching rain as he walked up Madison Avenue to Sabbath services at an Upper East Side synagogue.

title: Governors Praise Congressional Move Toward Welfare Change
description: Leaders of the National Governors' Association today welcomed the prospect of Congressional action on a welfare bill this month but said they still hoped the final legislation would give them more flexibility and fewer controls.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;VOLLEYBALL
description: THE LAST TIME the Olympics were held on American soil, in 1984, the home teams seized the opportunity and carved out a larger following for their sport. The men, led by Karch Kiraly and middle blocker Craig Buck, won the first of consecutive golds; the women, led by Flo Hyman, won the silver. Twelve years later, Americans are no longer the dominant force in volleyball (at least not without sand between their toes). THE SETUP The men's and women's events in Atlanta each will include 12 teams. The first phase is round-robin competition with two pools of six teams. The top four teams in each pool advance to the quarterfinals, where the teams with the poorest records play those with the best.

title: Irish Troubles Spill Over to Canary Isles
description: Hundreds of British and Irish tourists fought on the Spanish island of Tenerife after an argument about Northern Ireland turned into a brawl, the local police said today.

title: The War of Nerves Downtown
description: Correction Appended

title: No Headline
Holistic Rendering of My Lamentable Past'
description: FROM BONDAGE Volume 3 of "Mercy of a Rude Stream." By Henry Roth. 397 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $25.95.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Chenin Blanc

title: A Hot Place For Spiritual Renewal'
description: Even though I understand that David Bouchier's approach in his article on "A 'Hot' Place for Spiritual Renewal" [Out of Order, June 23] was that of tongue-in-cheek satire, I find it extraordinary that anyone could approach the subject of spiritual life without mentioning the fact that many churches and a number of synagogues are alive and flourishing in the Hamptons.

title: Columbia University Entices An N.Y.U. Image Enhancer
description: Columbia University, which is trying to raise its public profile in part out of irritation with New York University's success at doing just that, has hired away from N.Y.U. one of the top guardians of its image.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;A Matter of Survival: Gilders Leave SoHo for Brooklyn
description: From 1966 until last week, there was a loft in the red-brick building at 285 Lafayette Street where the Bible, the Torah, the Koran and invitations to the White House met: the factory of R. Marchetti and Bro., edge gilders. The six-story building once housed 12 manufacturers in printing or allied trades, but the others left during Manhattan's manufacturing exodus in the early 70's. At its peak, R. Marchetti was a thriving factory that employed 30 skilled workers to lay gold on the edges of book and announcement cards. Now, its lease expired and its staff numbering 11, the business is moving from its top-floor space to Greenpoint in Brooklyn. Gone are the days when the sunlight would stream in from eastern windows and bounce off stacks of freshly gilded books.

title: Class Consciousness
description: THE REMEDY Class, Race, and Affirmative Action. By Richard D. Kahlenberg. 350 pp. New York: A New Republic Book/Basic Books. $25.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;WATER POLO
description: THIS IS A TYPICAL sport in the soccer-hockey-basketball family, only rougher. Perhaps the most famous game was the 1956 Melbourne Olympic final between the Soviet Union and Hungary, one month after Soviet troops had invaded Hungary to quell an uprising. The game was so rough that there was blood in the water, and it was ended prematurely with Hungary winning the gold medal, 4-0. THE SETUP Although women play the game internationally, Olympic competition involves only 12 men's teams in two divisions. After round-robin play in each division, the two leaders in each division advance to direct-elimination semifinals and final.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Charging Into the Skies
description: EVERY week, it seems, there's a new way to accumulate, or spend, frequent flier miles. Keeping up with them, and keeping track of the miles, can be a time-consuming proposition. But it can also be worth the time.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;The African Queen Off Connecticut's Shores
description: Travelers who know the river boat African Queen from the 1951 Hepburn-Bogart movie can now find out what it was like to be aboard. Until November, the 30-foot steam launch, built in 1912, is available for 30-minute trips on the Connecticut River and Long Island Sound out of the Saybrook Yacht Basin on Ferry Road in Old Saybrook, Conn.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;ROWING
description: SOME ROWERS can actually draw a crowd on land. Thomas Lange can in Germany. Steven Redgrave can in Britain, and Silken Laumann definitely can in Canada. But the bulk of these dedicated and often highly educated athletes toil in obscurity and may be the closest the 1996 Games will come to Baron Coubertin's long-outdated ideal. THE SETUP Eight men's events and six women's events will be contested on Lake Lanier, and at least 10 different nations could win gold medals. The standard Olympic rowing course is 2,000 meters (approximately one and a half miles). For the first time, lightweight rowers also will compete for medals. Lightweight men can weigh no more than 160 pounds; women no more than 130 pounds.

title: MANHATTAN UPDATES
description: HARLEM An officer has been reassigned from the 32d Precinct after an investigation into complaints that a pail of water was tossed onto a woman who had come to the station house to file a missing persons report.

title: You Can't Go Home Again? Don't Tell That to Him
description: Charles Wadsworth already had a national reputation as the man who had brought chamber music to the masses when he made a surprise visit to his hometown, Newnan, Ga., in the mid-1970's. He had been touring the South with the soprano Beverly Sills as her accompanist, and she had insisted on the detour to that sleepy hamlet, 30 miles southwest of Atlanta, having arranged a homecoming dinner for him at Sprayberry's restaurant.

title: WEDDINGS;Melissa Perlen, Scott Greenbaum
description: Melissa Beth Perlen, the daughter of Myra and Stuart Perlen of Kings Point, L.I., was married on Thursday evening to Dr. Scott Greenbaum, the son of Renee and Dennis Greenbaum of Brooklyn. Rabbi David Posner performed the ceremony at the Rainbow Room in Manhattan.

title: WEDDINGS;Ellen Scott, James Delaney
description: Ellen Baldwin Scott, a daughter of Mary Lyons Scott and William Scott of Hanover, N.H., was married yesterday to James McLaughlin Delaney, a son of Margaret and Joseph Delaney of Syracuse. The Rev. Andrew Kline officiated at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in Hanover.

title: POSTINGS: New Law Sets $198.5 Million in Abatements;City Co-ops and Condos Get 3 Years of Tax Relief
description: A bill aimed at providing tax abatements to owners of co-ops and condominiums in New York City was signed into law on July 2 by Gov. George E. Pataki. The law, based on a proposal sent to the State Legislature by the New York City Council last month, earmarks about $198.5 million in tax abatements to owners of co-op and condominium apartments over the next three years.

title: THEATER;Boy Meets Girl Again In a Retro Romance
description: DON'T even try to track down the video. It never came out. And the play doesn't come around much anymore.

title: Ideas & Trends;The Guy Who Ate a Cow And Other Olympic Stars
description: A HURRICANE missed Atlanta last week, but of course figuratively the wind will blow hot and heavy this week as the Summer Olympics finally get under way amid what seems an interminable media drum roll. Hype enough for you?

title: GARDENING;Ones That Win a Special Place in the Heart
description: IT'S possible to have a love affair with plants. The romance just happens when certain plants perform exceptionally well or have such beguiling flowers, they win your heart.

title: Planetarium Plan Worries a Block
description: The blocks surrounding the American Museum of Natural History are among the most desirable on the Upper West Side. But some of the residents of West 81st Street between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue fear they will have to bear the brunt of the museum's ambitious plan to build a new planetarium, outdoor restaurant and underground parking garage to accommodate more visitors.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Phenomenon John Travolta, Kyra Sedgwick, Forest Whitaker, Robert Duvall Directed by Jon Turteltaub PG 117 minutes

title: INVESTING IT;A Call for Level Heads
description: HERE is some advice for investors worried about a stock market correction: Don't just do something; sit there.

title: Legislator, 72, Defies the Odds
description: THEY call him the Iron Man of politics and ''the people's choice'' as he campaigns in a wheelchair for an unprecedented 14th term on the County Board of Legislators.

title: ALSO INSIDE
description: F.Y.I. 2 Why they call it Starbuck's.

title: Learning Economic Lessons From the Former Soviet Bloc
description: WITH the contentious Russian presidential campaign over, many people are focusing on what the former Communist bloc's troubled transition to a market economy might mean to them.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT;MANHATTAN UPDATES
description: HARLEM An officer has been reassigned from the 32d Precinct after an investigation into complaints that a pail of water was tossed onto a woman who had come to the station house to file a missing persons report. Emma Chapman, a 51-year-old Harlem resident, said that she was physically thrown out of the station house, on 135th Street, after an argument with the desk officer, who had refused her request to file a missing persons report on her niece. As Ms. Chapman complained to passers-by, she said, someone threw water on her head from the fourth floor of the station house. "They really showed their colors," Ms. Chapman said. Her niece, she said, is still missing.

title: Fred Hift, Journalist and Film Executive, 74
description: Fred Hift, a journalist and former film executive, died on July 6 at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 74 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Undertow
description: Bettelheim A Life and a Legacy. By Nina Sutton. Translated by David Sharp in collaboration with the author. Illustrated. 606 pp. New York: Basic Books. $35.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Knott's Berry Farm Gets an Update
description: The Roaring 20's section of Knott's Berry Farm has been reborn as the Boardwalk -- a salute to Southern California's seaside culture. The 76-year-old, 150-acre theme park opened the updated area in May.

title: Hellman and Hammett
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: NonFiction
description: DYKE LIFE From Growing Up to Growing Old, a Celebration of the Lesbian Experience. Edited by Karla Jay. Basic Books, $23.

title: A Matter of Survival: Gilders Leave SoHo for Brooklyn
description: From 1966 until last week, there was a loft in the red-brick building at 285 Lafayette Street where the Bible, the Torah, the Koran and invitations to the White House met: the factory of R. Marchetti and Bro., edge gilders.

title: William S. Lee, 67, Former Chief of Duke Power
description: William S. Lee, former chairman and chief executive of the Duke Power Company and a strong supporter of nuclear power, died on Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center while visiting New York City from his home in Charlotte, N.C. He was 67.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: CROWN HEIGHTS;School Plan Faces Skepticism
description: In Crown Heights, the Brooklyn neighborhood that, accurately or not, has come to symbolize black-Jewish friction, educators and community groups are nurturing plans to establish a public school they hope will bring together black and Jewish youngsters and deepen understanding among the neighborhood's ethnic groups. This mission, they acknowledge, faces formidable barriers. "It's a community where there has been a lot of suspicion," said Don Murphy, a former Crown Heights schoolteacher who is now president of People About Changing Education, one of the groups behind the proposal. "The history has not been good."

title: Delia Goetz, 100, Children's Author
description: Delia Goetz, whose travels as an education specialist for the United States Government provided her with material for more than a score of children's books, died on June 26 at her home in Washington. She was 100.

title: Moynihan's Tax-Break Bill Could Foil Dreams of Fields
description: At a time when New York City has mounted a major drive for new stadiums for the Yankees and Mets, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan may have thrown a wrench into its efforts with a bill that would eliminate Federal tax breaks for new professional sports arenas.

title: EARNING IT;You Work at Home. Does the Town Board Care?
description: WHEN many government officials peek behind bedroom doors, institute "don't ask, don't tell" policies or ask people to "come out of the closet," they are not prying into residents' sex lives -- they are just trying to exercise some control over the booming growth of home offices.

title: SCHOOLS;It's Hot, Boring, Slow and Necessary. It's Summer School.
description: First, the heat: it spreads through the halls like ether, dulling the senses and slowing down time. Eyes glaze over, heads droop low and the textbooks spread across sticky desks go unread.

title: Sunday: July 14, 1996 -- ENVIRONMENT;Can Green Rads Be Tamed?
description: When you're hanging off a bridge and the protest banner is flapping out of control," barks Ingrid Gordon, "the climbing must be second nature." Gordon is haranguing 30 men and women who, with mixed results, are roping their way up a 60-foot training tower in Montana's Bitterroot Mountains. Some wriggle up fast. Some are wheezing just thinking about it.

title: WEDDINGS;Karen A. Hovsepian, Philip N. Ayoub
description: Karen Ann Hovsepian, the director of event marketing in New York for the National Hockey League, was married yesterday to Philip Norman Ayoub, a tax and business consultant in New York. Msgr. William Belford performed the ceremony at St. Catharine's Church in Blauvelt, N.Y.

title: Universal Internet Access, Fall of '96
description: ON Sept. 28, community volunteers are to start wiring Connecticut's schools and libraries, providing access to and home pages on the Internet. The initiative is called ConneCT96 and is being led by John B. Larson, a former gubernatorial candidate, past president of the state Senate and a former elementary and high school teacher.

title: Word for Word/Late-Night Comics;Joking About Bill, Bob and Hillary With Dave, Jay and Conan
description: THE President is trying to destabilize his wife, who is testing disguises and new hairdos to duck the law. The Republican candidate lacks a smile -- not to mention a pulse. Meanwhile, the women come and go, smelling of french fries.

title: A Shorthand Reporter at 90 and Still Fast
description: AT a time when sophisticated equipment is becoming more common in courtrooms as a way to record testimony, Martin J. Dupraw of White Plains still does his recording the old-fashioned way -- with a pen and note pad. At 90, using Gregg Shorthand, he can still take 220 words a minute.

title: Scratch 'n' Spend;Muting the Lotteries' Perfect Pitch
description: A RECESSION, layoffs and economic dislocations have made these punishing times in California, but the state government spends millions of dollars broadcasting a simple piece of advice for helping people deal with the stress: play the lottery.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;ARCHERY
description: WHAT IS UNDOUBTEDLY the most famous Olympic archery event was not a competition at all, but the memorable lighting of the Olympic cauldron at Barcelona, Spain, in 1992 by a flaming arrow. Still, the often-overlooked sport has its share of drama because medals are decided in an extended series of head-to-head matches. THE SETUP Before competition begins, the 64 men and 64 women are seeded in a ranking round. The single-elimination tournament begins with archers firing 18 arrows -- 6 groups of 3 arrows -- at a target 70 meters away. They are allowed only 40 seconds between shots. The top 16 teams in the individual competitions advance to the men's and women's team competitions.

title: Children's Books
description: The Bone Detectives How Forensic Anthropologists Solve Crimes and Uncover Mysteries of the Dead. By Donna M. Jackson. Photographs by Charlie Fellenbaum. 48 pp. New York: Little, Brown & Company. $16.95. (Ages 10 and up)

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;Three Months Later, Navy Yard Still Needs Captain for Long Haul
description: Three months after the president of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation was dismissed amid an investigation into an improper purchase of office furniture, a permanent chief has yet to be selected to head the 260-acre, city-owned industrial park. An interim chief, Marta Moczo-Santiago, was appointed by the corporation's board after the dismissal of the former president, Elizabeth Colon. But Ms. Moczo-Santiago left more than a month ago when she was appointed Commissioner of the city's Department of Juvenile Justice. The board has not named a new interim president, nor has it formally appointed a search committee to select a permanent chief executive. The board is not scheduled to meet until September.

title: The City Skyline And Landscape
description: MOST New Yorkers think little about the fact that they spend most of their indoor lives surrounded by strangers, separated only by walls and floors. Above and below, to the left and to the right, lie other apartments or offices, other families or businesses. Tall buildings have become such a humdrum component of city life that to look up at them is to risk being branded a tourist.

title: ATLANTA IS BURNING
description: With apologies to Coca-Cola, Paul Goldberger's "Atlanta Is Burning" (June 23) "hits the spot." Businesses have provided job opportunities and a pleasant way of life for those who have sought them. Living here, however, is somewhat like living in a vacuum-cleaner bag. Once you get sucked into a city that is clean and green with good schools, you find there is not much else. No doubt there is a seed of culture that has not fully developed, but there is hope. With office buildings, highways, malls and the Braves in first place, who needs culture?

title: CUTTINGS;Ginseng Is a Tonic for Its Growers
description: Whether ginseng gives you energy, improves your love life or helps you live longer has yet to be proved. But the people who swear by it -- and the growers who make up to $100,000 an acre from it -- say they don't care.

title: Losing Power, Storm Still Pummels East Coast
description: The hurricane that battered North Carolina on Friday weakened to a tropical storm today as it moved up the East Coast, but still whipped areas from Virginia to New England with high winds, heavy rains and surging seas.

title: THE ATHLETIC ESTHETIC
description: I read Holly Brubach's "The Athletic Esthetic" (June 23) with great interest. Yet I could not join in her (admittedly guarded) optimism about the influence of female athletes on our perceptions of female beauty. Brubach herself points out both the alarming rate of eating disorders among female athletes and the fact that, along with other current ideals of female beauty, the athletic form eliminates hips.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Another Trial in Michael Irvin's Life
description: Michael Irvin sought that exciting push, that explosiveness off the line of scrimmage that had become his style, but it simply was not there. It was training camp in 1990 and this Dallas Cowboys receiver was only a few months back from major reconstructive surgery on his right knee. It was only his third season in the National Football League after a memorable career at the University of Miami.

title: 2-Year Ban Issued So Sturgeon Stock Can Be Replenished
description: HOPING to see more American sturgeon leaping out of the Hudson River and elsewhere this summer, the Federal Government has issued a two-year ban on catching or possessing American sturgeon anywhere on the Atlantic Coast.

title: WOMEN MUSCLE IN
description: I was delighted by your issue. Although I spent most of my time in phys. ed. avoiding any form of exertion and planning a book on 20 ways to get sidelined without actually lying, I did have the special pleasure of having Dawn Staley, a member of the U.S. women's Olympic basketball team, as a student in my advanced 12th-grade English class in 1988.

title: Westchester Q&A: Martin J. Dupraw;A Shorthand Reporter at 90 and Still Fast
description: AT a time when sophisticated equipment is becoming more common in courtrooms as a way to record testimony, Martin J. Dupraw of White Plains still does his recording the old-fashioned way -- with a pen and note pad. At 90, using Gregg Shorthand, he can still take 220 words a minute. Mr. Dupraw, by training a lawyer, learned Gregg Shorthand in the 1920's and found it was a way to support himself and his family in the Depression. He went on to win state and national competitions. During his long career, he "took" the speeches of many world-renown people, including Winston Churchill and Franklin Delano Roosevelt, and the testimony of a number of infamous criminals.

title: EVENING HOURS;In the Twilight And the Limelight
description: The long days of summer bring outdoor benefits for young scholars and a museum, along with indoor tributes to a jazz great and the punk-rock era.

title: BOOKEND;The T.S. Eliot Problem
description: It's hard to understand why Anthony Julius's book about T. S. Eliot's anti-Semitism has burst upon the trans-Atlantic scene with such vigor, given that the material is not particularly revolutionary nor the viewpoint particularly well argued. The fact that the author is Princess Di's divorce lawyer may have lent the book a certain frisson in some quarters, but I doubt that it can explain all the attention. There is clearly something in "T. S. Eliot, Anti-Semitism, and Literary Form" that galvanized the journalistic imagination in a way that more delicately nuanced pieces on the same subject (for instance Christopher Ricks's "T. S. Eliot and Prejudice," or Cynthia Ozick's essay in "Fame & Folly") have failed to do.

title: WOMEN MUSCLE IN
description: I was overjoyed when I saw Sheryl Swoopes on the cover of your magazine. She and Mia Hamm are my role models. I am 12 years old and enjoy sports greatly. I am not a girl who wants to look like Barbie. I've seen small blurbs or articles about women athletes, but never a whole magazine devoted to women's sports. Thank you.

title: BASEBALL;Strawberry Strikes Twice, And the Yanks Take Two
description: Do not worry about studying the American League East standings. Do not fret over the occasional loss. Save your vacation for October. If you are a Yankee fan, these tips will help you glide through the rest of the summer because the supposed divisional race might have unofficially ended tonight with Darryl Strawberry's impressive statement and the continuing collapse of the Baltimore Orioles.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Kipketer Turns Down Kenya
description: Wilson Kipketer, the expatriate Kenyan, has declined an invitation to run in the 800 meters under the Kenyan flag.

title: A Harder Line From Israel
description: Benjamin Netanyahu made good use of his personal charm, political savvy and mastery of the American vernacular during his five-day visit to Washington and New York. But Israel's newly elected Prime Minister disappointed those who expected him to use this visit to signal more moderate and pragmatic foreign policy directions now that he bears the responsibilities of government.

title: Market-Rate Rents In Manhattan:
description: THE Manhattan residential rental market is roil-ing, sometimes jetting spikes in prices to previ-ously unseen heights, and the impact is beginning to be felt in the other boroughs.

title: Political Briefing;THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: California Brown May Have Last Laugh Yet

title: The World;Poland's Leader Leaves A Marxist Past Behind
description: WHEN Aleksander Kwasniewski went to Washington for his first visit as Poland's President last week, he had one overall objective: to dispel the loaded tag-line, "ex-Communist."

title: Power and Imagination in Original Work
description: Carroll Dunham

title: Gottfried von Einem, Composer, Dies at 78
description: Gottfried von Einem, a composer whose eclectic theatrical style made him Austria's best-known postwar composer, died on Friday at his home in Obernduernbach, a village about 30 miles north of Vienna. He was 78.

title: THE FIRST FRIEND -- A special report.;Being Intimate With Power, Vernon Jordan Can Wield It
description: When President Clinton needed a prominent representative to attend, and then brief him on, the inauguration of Taiwan's first democratically elected president last May, his choice was Vernon E. Jordan Jr.

title: Sicily Hill Town
description: To the Editor: My thanks to Theresa M. Maggio for her article "The Hill Towns of Sicily: Above the Fray," June 2. My grandparents came to the United States in 1904. For years I heard about the hill town of Polizzi Generosa. And for years I tried to find out about how this wonderful little town received its name.

title: Not Necessarily About Julia
description: In an alley in lower Manhattan, Lyle Lovett is checking out a motorcycle. He's wearing a black suit, buttoned high; his hair, formerly an "Eraserhead" pompadour, has now recognized the law of gravity. The motorcycle is a limited-edition Ducati, a sleek red-and-white machine with a larger engine than the standard model; there are only 50 of them in the United States. "It has its own sound, very smooth, kind of throaty," Mr. Lovett says. "Once you hear it, you'd recognize it."

title: WEDDINGS;Judy Fleming, R. S. Wagner
description: Judy Ann Ethel Fleming, the daughter of Albert W. Fleming of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Irene Fleming, is to be married today to Richard Scott Wagner, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jack Wagner of New Rochelle, N.Y. The Rev. James Zwernamann, a Lutheran minister, is to perform the ceremony, in which Rabbi Hirshel Jaffe is to take part, at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;SHOOTING
description: THE FIRST GOLD MEDAL of the 1996 Olympic Games will be awarded in shooting, and there's an excellent chance that an American will win it. Nancy Napolski of Downer's Grove, Ill., won the air rifle gold medal at the Atlanta World Cup earlier this year, an event that brought 800 shooters from 90 countries to the Olympic venue. A co-favorite in the event is Elizabeth Bourland of Wichita Falls, Tex., gold medalist at the 1995 Pan American Games. THE SETUP Anything that shoots -- rifles, pistols (fired by air or gunpowder) and shotguns -- are used in the 10 men's events and five women's events. Targets are as close as 10 meters or as far as 50 meters. All of the medals are individual.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;SOCCER
description: THE AMERICAN WOMEN and the American men come into the Olympic soccer tournaments from totally different angles. This is the first time women's soccer has been included in the Summer Games, and the American women come into it as a favorite. Meanwhile, the United States men have been perennially outplayed in the Summer Games by promising young stars from traditional soccer powers, but that could shift. THE SETUP In keeping the recent Olympic practice of spreading soccer games to other cities, both the women's and men's tournaments will be held in Miami, Orlando, Fla., Birmingham, Ala., and Washington, with medal rounds to be held in Athens, Ga. No games will be played in Atlanta.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Airports Are Safest In North America
description: An airliner is eight times as likely to crash at Latin American airports as in North America, according to a recent study by Flight Safety Foundation, an industry-financed research organization in Virginia.

title: WEDDINGS;Regina A. Gore, Bryan J. Cavaliere
description: Regina Anne Gore, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph E. Gore of Clifton, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Bryan Joseph Cavaliere, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph N. Cavaliere of Chagrin Falls, Ohio. The Rev. Peter J. Doody, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony in the Immaculate Conception Chapel at Seton Hall University in South Orange, N.J.

title: SOAPBOX;School Finance: A Way Out
description: THE State Supreme Court gave the Legislature until September to come up with a law eliminating the spending disparities between rich and poor school districts and providing equal educational opportunities to poor students. But now legislative leaders say the lawmakers will not be able to meet the deadline.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Horse Play Hurting Equestrians
description: A tradition among equestrians of pre-Olympic competition in soccer, water skiing, swimming and softball has resulted in several injuries to riders.

title: Fighting Notions About the Disabled and Setting World Records
description: WHEN asked in kindergarten to discuss his father around Father's Day last month, Nicholas Oehler said, ''Some day I hope to run with my dad.''

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;MODERN PENTATHLON
description: A CANDIDATE for Olympic extinction, modern pentathlon has transformed itself into a recipe for Olympic exhaustion. The five-sport event that was once contested over five days is trying to increase its limited appeal by packing its disciplines into one day (July 30). The team competition has been eliminated. THE SETUP Modern pentathlon was inspired by the example of a messenger in Napoleon's army who, caught behind enemy lines, had to make use of his talents as a marksman, fencer, rider, swimmer and runner to extricate himself from a tight spot. Clearly, Napoleon could have used E-mail.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: THE GOLDEN AGE OF PROMISCUITY By Brad Gooch. Knopf, $24.

title: Max Factor Jr., 91, Dies; Popularized Makeup
description: Max Factor Jr., a cosmetics company executive who helped his father refine theatrical makeup for the movies and later retailed the glamorous look of Hollywood to ordinary women, died on June 7 at his home in West Los Angeles. He was 91.

title: CHICAGO BUILDINGS;Still Magnificent, And Thriving Too
description: To the Editor: As Alderman of the 42d Ward, where the Magnificent Mile is situated, I am vexed by Paul Goldberger's allegations that we are ravaging our heritage and destroying the architectural environment here in Chicago ["In Chicago, a Tale of Lost Magnificence," June 16]. The tone of his article is highly inflammatory, endeavoring to stir up controversy where none should exist. This is insulting to all of us who have worked hard to insure the economic prosperity and esthetic beauty of Chicago's central boulevard.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDESports of The Times; On Fourth Try, America's First 'World' Olympics
description: ONE is remembered for a boycott, another for a Babe, the third for a song. And all three for something that was missing.

title: FROM THE DESK OF;Getting My Two Cents In Corporate America
description: THE big-ticket business decisions -- the downsizing, the optimizing, the cost-cutting, the mega-mergers-- are all quantified in terms of multimillions, if not billions, of dollars. In this age of deal-making and the computer, no one cares too much about what happens to the right of the decimal point.

title: Legislature Passes a Budget, Finally Ending a Long Session
description: The New York State Legislature adjourned today after one of its longest and most contentious sessions in memory, finally enacting the long-delayed state budget and passing bills that would protect patients in managed care plans and authorize a $1.75 billion environmental bond act.

title: The Ante Rises In East Asia
description: IT looks like a private club. Guarded door. Tea served in plush green chairs. Marble fountain. Chandelier.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;JUDO
description: JUDO IS a hundred-year-old sport, invented in Japan as a safe alternative to dangerous martial arts, and the International Olympic Committee no longer considers it a martial art. It differs from karate and taekwondo because it emphasizes technique rather than force, although its arm bars, chokes and hold-downs are not for the dainty. THE SETUP Competition will involve 400 men and women (called judokas, or players) from about 60 nations. For the first time, women can earn medals. There are seven weight classes for each.

title: FOOD;A Fishing Exposition
description: JIM PETERSON, WHO STEEPED HIMSELF IN GRAVY FOR his first cookbook, "Sauces," has spent the past three years knee-deep in fish. "Fish and Shellfish" is a result of his efforts. It is a serious work.

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;Short Songs, Tall Tales and O. J. in E Flat
description: The slow summer months offer a chance to recall a few shorter, odder news items that may have been overlooked during the recent season. Notes and jottings, as it were, from a reporter's notebook. Not all of them are necessarily true.

title: In the Region/New Jersey;Attached Housing Comes Back in Detached Country
description: CHARLES INGENITO and Regina Hrostek, who are getting married in September, set their sights on living in North Jersey to be near their jobs and families. He is a lawyer in Bergen County; she is a saleswoman for a Stamford, Conn., information technology consulting concern.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER EAST SIDE;Learning the Chinese Point of View
description: Nancy Jervis shudders when she remembers the China Institute's first summer seminars for New York City public school teachers. The teachers "were interested in chopsticks and bound feet and other notions," said Ms. Jervis, an anthropologist who is the institute's vice president for programs. "And I said to myself, you could either throw up your hands in despair, or work hard to make the Chinese human beings for these teachers."

title: CITY LIFE;Rolling Out an Ordinance Against Reckless Skating
description: The Sponge loves in-line skating. Does it most of his free time, almost anywhere he can, jumping over curbs, zipping down thoroughfares, riding stair railings and gliding along marble steps.

title: For Bank's Boy Wonder, Gray Hairs and Lessons
description: I'VE made every mistake that anybody in the business has made," John S. Reed says, twirling his half-glasses in his hotel-room armchair.

title: Adjusting to Office-Market Realities in Westchester
description: IN the halcyon days of suburban office development in the 60's, 70's and 80's, a handful of entrepreneurial companies dominated the Westchester County market.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDESports of The Times; You Mean There Are Men Also Competing in Atlanta?
description: THIS was after the gymnastics trials in Boston three weeks ago. A sparkling little girl and her mother were riding on the Orange Line subway near me, when they spotted my press pass.

title: Dams Revive Marsh Fisheries
description: THE marshy inlets of Accabonac Harbor and Northwest Creek in East Hampton seem pristine to the eye. The waterways, just off Napeague Bay, are a vibrant blue punctuated by scenic green marshland. Tall reeds sway gently at the shoreline.

title: Long Island Q&A: Gerrit Wolf;Learning Economic Lessons From the Former Soviet Bloc
description: WITH the contentious Russian presidential campaign over, many people are focusing on what the former Communist bloc's troubled transition to a market economy might mean to them. Gerrit Wolf, an organizational psychologist at the State Univerity at Stony Brook's Harriman School of Management and Policy, has been drawing parallels between the workers on Long Island and those in Central and Eastern Europe since 1993.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;BADMINTON
description: TENNIS STARS turn heads in nearly every time zone; badminton players are only stars in East Asia and, rather incongruously, Denmark. But the Danes, Indonesians, Chinese, Koreans and Malaysians may be on to something.

title: School Can Wait for Soccer
description: JULIE FOUDY has been accepted to medical school at Stanford University this fall, but she gives the very distinct impression that she could postpone it for the mere hint of a major professional soccer league for women in the United States. No matter what happens in the 1996 Summer Games, Foudy finds it hard to think about retiring at 25.

title: Ulster Without a Net
description: For nearly two years, the Northern Ireland peace effort has been an incredible balancing act, like a team of acrobats bicycling across a high wire. One performer is riding the bike, another sits on his shoulders and two others hang on either side. If any one leans over too far -- or if the bicycle comes to a halt -- they all fall down.

title: A Good News/Bad News AIDS Joke
description: There has been much recent excitement about protease inhibitors, a new class of drugs that promise to prolong markedly the lives of and in some cases possibly help cure those with H.I.V. But because of the cost, a great many who would benefit from such drugs will not have access to them.

title: July 7-13;Moon Behaves Like Planet!
description: In its first close encounter with the largest of Jupiter's satellites, the Galileo spacecraft has surprised and delighted scientists with sharp pictures and other observations of an icy moon with remarkable planetary attributes.

title: River Runs Wild and Town Finds Profit
description: Who says you can't improve on Mother Nature?

title: Roots of Wilentz Justice Go Deeper Than Wilentz
description: To the Editor:

title: Sunday: July 14, 1996 -- Gossip;Terror Stalks the Ice Belt
description: With the quiet self-assurance of a killer android, Cheryl Johnson waltzes uninvited into a St. Paul, Minn., benefit for Senator Paul Wellstone, a Democrat up for re-election this year. The most popular columnist for The Minneapolis Star Tribune -- and the only hard-core gossip writer to rip scalps in the polite Twin Cities -- she's quickly spotted and decried. "Why'd you come, C. J.?" moans a Wellstone fan. Johnson happily strides on. "Wellstone hasn't liked me since I reported that his daughter stiffed the guy who taped her wedding," she says.

title: Correction
description: The Correspondent's Report on the Travel Advisory page on June 23, about excavations of ancient forums in Rome, misstated the connection between the emperors Domitian and Nerva. Nerva was Domitian's successor but not his son.

title: Samaria Gorge
description: To the Editor: "In Deep in Crete" reminded me of a trip my wife and I took through the Samaria Gorge several years ago.

title: SIGNOFF;A Show You Can Dance To
description: DAVID SALTZ has strange ideas about the tools of his trade. "Everything about music is incompatible with television," he says. When stacked up against hearing a live concert or listening to a CD in headphones, music on television simply can't measure up because, as he puts it, "it's always second best."

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Stardust in Times Square, Without the Usual Fanfare

title: BASEBALL;'How About That Alex Ochoa'
description: Alex Ochoa was sitting in front of his locker in the Mets' clubhouse Friday afternoon, submitting to an interview while the rest of his teammates where watching the Cubs and the Cardinals play on television.

title: OLYMPICS;Lewis and Torrence Wash Out in Tuneup, but Say They're Not Washed Up for Games
description: A rainstorm momentarily disrupted the last Olympic tuneup meet for some of America's top track and field athletes tonight, but not before Carl Lewis and Gwen Torrence had already delivered major washouts.

title: WEDDINGS;Rhona Chambers And Eric Gural
description: Rhona Joan Chambers, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Chambers of Salt Lake City, was married yesterday to Eric Michael Gural, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Gural of New York. Judge Roger Hayes of the Bronx Criminal Court officiated at Allerage Farm, the Gurals' farm in Stanfordville, N.Y.

title: Furious George
description: CUSTER The Controversial Life of George Armstrong Custer. By Jeffry D. Wert. Illustrated. 462 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $27.50.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Around the World, Cheers for Small Stocks
description: OVER the last six months, small-company international stock funds have come into their own. While the average foreign stock fund has risen 9.2 percent in the first half of the year, the small-company stock funds that invest primarily abroad have returned 14 percent. Over the last 12 months, they have also outperformed an index of larger-company stocks, the Morgan Stanley Europe Asia Far East index, 19 percent to 13.3 percent.

title: A Winner From the 30's
description: GRANDPA VANDERHOF was ''a man who made his peace with the world long, long ago, and his whole attitude and manner are quietly persuasive of this.''

title: At Twin Towers, the Ice Rink Goeth
description: It opened to great fanfare in January: an ice-skating rink between the twin towers of the World Trade Center, heralded as a boon that would attract tourists and new residents alike to lower Manhattan as the neighborhood seeks to recover from the recession that sapped its real-estate market.

title: Integration Suit: 7 Years Later
description: MILO SHEFF was an 11-year-old fourth grader in 1989 when his mother, Elizabeth Horton Sheff, helped bring a landmark desegregation lawsuit on behalf of her son and 16 other plaintiffs seeking racial balance in Hartford's predominantly black and Hispanic public school system.

title: OLIVER NORTH ON FILM;Giving Credit Where It's Due
description: To the Editor: Thank you for Todd S. Purdum's insightful examination of the film "A Perfect Candidate" ["Tracking the North Campaign, From Dirt to Ashes," June 16]. His understanding of the film as a window on the dark underbelly of the American political process captured the intentions of all those involved in its creation.

title: Learning the Chinese Point of View
description: Nancy Jervis shudders when she remembers the China Institute's first summer seminars for New York City public school teachers. The teachers ''were interested in chopsticks and bound feet and other notions,'' said Ms. Jervis, an anthropologist who is the institute's vice president for programs. ''And I said to myself, you could either throw up your hands in despair, or work hard to make the Chinese human beings for these teachers.''

title: Trying to Reinvent Summer in the City
description: The countdown continues at Lincoln Center Festival '96, and backstage it's one eclectic check-in. A cyberopera and a trombone choir approach the gate, along with orchestral musicians from St. Petersburg, Russia, actors from Dublin, dancers from Lyons and water puppeteers from Hanoi.

title: THEATER;A Winner From the 30's
description: GRANDPA VANDERHOF was "a man who made his peace with the world long, long ago, and his whole attitude and manner are quietly persuasive of this." "You Can't Take It With You," in a 60th anniversary production by the Connecticut Repertory in Storrs, takes place in Martin Vanderhof's home. Customarily called a living room, "the room we see" the stage directions say, is an "every-man-for-himself room." It is there that "meals are eaten, plays are written, snakes collected, ballet steps practiced, xylophones played, printing presses operated -- if there were room enough there would probably be ice skating. In short, the brood presided over by Martin Vanderhof goes on about the business of living in the fullest sense of the word. This is a house where you do as you like, and no questions asked."

title: Children's Books
description: SPRING A Haiku Story. Selected by George Shannon. Illustrated by Malcah Zeldis. Unpaged. New York: Greenwillow Books. $16. (Ages 5 and up)

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: DIET;Veggies in 12 Languages
description: Vegetarian travelers may not always be able to get the food they want when they don't speak the language. To help, The Vegetarian Traveler sells a set of cards with translations of food requests in 12 major languages, including Chinese, French, Greek, Russian, Swedish and Turkish. The packets cost $9.95 plus $1 for shipping and handling, and can be ordered for vegan diets (no meat, eggs or other dairy products), lacto (no meat or eggs) and ovo-lacto (eggs and dairy products allowed). Other languages are available for $5.95 each. Contact The Vegetarian Traveler, Post Office Box 410205, Cambridge, Mass. 02141.

title: Plan for a Tower Surprised Board
description: To the Editor:

title: Notes From Under Cover
description: REFLECTIONS OF A COLD WARRIOR From Yalta to the Bay of Pigs. By Richard M. Bissell Jr. with Jonathan E. Lewis and Frances T. Pudlo. 268 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $30.

title: THE ARTIST'S MUSE;In Real Life, Friends Indeed
description: To the Editor: I don't know how long I talked to Dinitia Smith about my relationship with Sam Shepard for her piece "How Creative Artists Court the Muse" [June 30], but it was close to half an hour.

title: WEDDINGS;B. E. Nickoll, Christine Armstrong
description: Christine Mitchell Armstrong and Benjamin Edward Nickoll were married last evening at a farm rented for the occasion in Salisbury, Conn. Rabbi Joel S. Goor officiated, and the Rev. Dr. James Petty, a Church of Christ minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: THE NIGHT;A Premiere For the Young Set
description: THE ocean was barely warm enough for swimming last weekend when the East Hampton Cinema had its third private movie premiere of the summer. This one was for "Harriet the Spy."

title: WEDDINGS;Michelle Jacobs, Christopher DeLong
description: Michelle Keri Jacobs, a daughter of Sue and Robert A. Jacobs of New York, was married last evening to Christopher Lord DeLong, a son of James V. DeLong of Washington and Fonya Helm of Cabin John, Md. Rabbi Mark N. Goldman performed the ceremony at the Puck Building in New York.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;N.F.L.'s Summer School Will Be in Session
description: If major league baseball is beginning the second half of the season, if the Summer Olympics will start this week in the sweltering heat and humidity of Atlanta, if hurricanes are spoiling a nice day at the beach, that means only one thing:

title: Family Affairs
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;SOFTBALL
description: THIS BRAND-NEW Olympic sport will have women-only competition, if competition is the word. The United States team is so good that is is being compared to the United States men's basketball team, and anything less than a gold medal will be regarded as a catastrophe. In its cross-country tour over the last three months, the United States team ran up a 60-1 record and outscored the opposition, 441-3.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;BASEBALL
description: TAKE A GOOD LOOK at the United States Olympic baseball team because this may be the last one built according to the old model of amateurism. A vote later this year will determine whether baseball will choose to go the Dream Team route, replacing emotional first glimpses of future stars with photo opportunities for major leaguers (and their shoe companies). This team's preparation has been a more extensive version of the old approach, a team built with college stars, some of them high draft choices, the way the Olympics used to be. A change for the 2000 Games could create a frightening combination -- Ken Griffey Jr. and an aluminum bat.

title: Not for Those Who Would Eat Cake
description: The pedigree of an object may add considerably to its value, as was demonstrated in April at the auction of the Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis collection. The prices fetched seemed incredible, but when it comes to prices at auction, even more impressive sums are paid for the possessions of Marie Antoinette.

title: BOXING;After Being Carried Off, Duva Returns to Carry On
description: Lou Duva was smiling through his perpetual growls yesterday. Nothing energizes a 74-year-old boxing trainer one day out of the hospital more than the realization that he has a heavyweight contender.

title: YELTSIN'S TOP AIDE ASSERTS CHECHNYA IS PART OF RUSSIA
description: Sounding more like a hawkish military commander than the man most Russians thought would finally bring an end to the war in Chechnya, Aleksandr I. Lebed, the new national security adviser to President Boris N. Yeltsin, today took a far more bellicose stance on the war there than he ever has before.

title: Diners Now Serving Cutting-Edge Cuisine
description: YESTERDAY'S commonplace diner is becoming today's classic. Diners from the 1930's, 40's and 50's are being painstakingly restored and made into resplendent restaurants that serve carefully planned crazyquilts of cutting-edge cuisine and old favorites.

title: HA HA;When Poking Fun Knows No Boundaries
description: IN a cartoon in The New Yorker, a dumpy woman is walking down the street with a T-shirt that says "DKNJ." The caption: "Donna Karan's worst nightmare."

title: Singapore Subway
description: To the Editor: A letter to the editor on May 12 under the headline "Keep the Stub" warned that one must keep your subway ticket stub in Budapest or risk being arrested. My wife and I had a worse experience in Singapore. We were threatened with arrest even with our ticket.

title: On Ritalin and Prozac For Children
description: The interview with Dr. Harold S. Koplewicz $(ong Island Q&A, June 16$) on the subject of prescribing Ritalin and Prozac to children did not include the following issues:

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Rangers Hope This Summer Is '96 in the Shade
description: Yet again the Texas Rangers will learn if they can take the second-half heat.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;BOXING
description: TWO SOUNDS SURE to be heard inside the Alexander Memorial Coliseum: the familiar ringing chants of "U.S.A. U.S.A." and the Cuban national anthem. The former, of course, signifies hope and optimism for the host nation. The latter signifies reality, because the Americans' chief ring rivals are again more powerful and polished. Though the Cubans are not as strong as they were in Barcelona -- the recent defections of the light heavyweight Ramon Garbey and the bantamweight Joel Casamayor did not help -- they still have more quality fighters than any other country.

title: A Fundamental Problem
description: BOB DOLE DOES NOT MAKE SMALL TALK EASILY, but as his plane idles this campaign morning, he gives it a go. He sheds his suit coat and strolls back to the press cabin, where, in a starched shirt, he stands and starts chatting about his dog. Dole mentions the going-away party that awaits him in the Senate and flatters reporters by promising to have them home early, in time to take the afternoon off.

title: Rail Stoppage Seems Likely As Talks Near The Deadline
description: All major freight railroad lines and many passenger operations may come to a halt at 12:01 A.M. on July 24, when the last of a series of "cooling off periods" in labor talks expires and a strike or lockout is permitted under Federal law.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 30 about the corporate deal makers of the 1980's misstated a holding of the family of Jay A. Pritzker, the Chicago financier. The family has a partial interest in Royal Caribbean Cruises Ltd.; it does not own Regency Cruises Inc.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Muster Shows a Generous Side
description: THOMAS MUSTER, Austria's clay court specialist and No. 2 in the world tennis rankings, gave the shirt off his back and then some to aid needy children.

title: YOUR HOME;Using The Roof In a Co-op
description: IT'S hot, it's humid, it's sticky, it's summer. Wouldn't it be nice to slip into something comfortable and saunter out your apartment door onto your own private rooftop paradise?

title: Bochco Gets a Chance to Try a Laugh Track
description: In the smoke-free back rooms of the television business, Steven Bochco has been called a lot of things over the years: genius, golden goose, "utterly impossible." But "funny" is one adjective that rarely springs to mind when describing the intense auteur of such dramas as "Hill Street Blues," "L.A. Law," "N.Y.P.D. Blue" and "Murder One."

title: WEDDINGS;Catherine O'Brien, Richard Yaffa Jr.
description: Catherine Margaret O'Brien and Richard Alan Yaffa Jr., record company directors in New York, were married yesterday at the Larchmont (N.Y.) Yacht Club. Justice Eugene L. Nardelli of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Star Turns From a Home in the Firehouse
description: IT'S bingo night at the Greek Orthodox Church of the Archangels in Stamford. The regulars, maybe 100 of them, sit enough distance apart to spread out their 20 or so game cards. There is no talking, even from the two children there.

title: Philadanco Finds Ways to Make a Virtue of Flux
description: A few weeks ago, while rehearsing a duet for the Philadelphia Dance Company with Edward Franklin, Swan Pouffer ground to an unchoreographed halt. For the next few beats he stood with his eyes fixed on Mr. Franklin, who whirled across the studio like a polished stone skipping along the water.

title: Arthur DePhillips, Civil Court Judge, 86
description: Arthur E. DePhillips, a former judge on New York City's Municipal Court and its successor, the Civil Court, died on Tuesday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 86, and a lifelong resident of Greenwich Village in Manhattan.

title: Sports of The Times;The New York State Athletic Omission
description: AS the most primal sport, boxing is a survivor. It has been condemned since Cain and Abel, but it's still here and, whether on barges or in barrooms, in arenas or outside casinos, it always will be.

title: Landmark Studies Change Outlook of AIDS Treatment
description: New findings reported at an international AIDS conference this week promise to transform AIDS from a usually fatal disease into a chronic one that is treatable, many experts say.

title: SECRET SPENDING -- A special report.;Tradition and Politics Allow Legislators' Hidden Largess
description: Over a year ago, officers of the White Otter Fish and Game Club in the southern Adirondacks set out to raise $150,000 for a new clubhouse where its dues-paying members could comfortably lounge, drink and swap stories after their duck hunts.

title: WOMEN MUSCLE IN
description: At 61 years of age, I'm not about to set any new Olympic records or break any glass ceilings, but I must tell you that the Olympics special issue "Women Muscle In" (June 23) made me proud to be a woman. Thank you for giving young girls of today some examples to live by.

title: WEDDINGS;Alexandra Callen, James Bailey
description: Alexandra Hope Callen, a daughter of Hope and Brock Callen of Chilmark, Mass., was married there yesterday to James Cunliffe Bullock Bailey, the son of Mrs. H. O. Winsor Jr. of Highland Beach, Fla., and the late Solon I. Bailey. The Rev. Robert Edmunds, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Chilmark Community Church.

title: The Nation;The Revolution Is on Hold
description: THE incredible shrinking Republican Congressional agenda, hailed in January as a rare opportunity to test competing political philosophies so the voters could have a choice on Election Day, is now down to spending bills, welfare, the minimum wage increase, safe drinking water, gay marriages and a few maybes.

title: Revitalizing Stone Street
description: To the Editor:

title: SOAPBOX;The Death of Ricky
description: Ricky was a hard-working 19-year-old with an adorable smile who came up from Tlapa, Mexico, two years ago. He and his roommate Sergio, washed dishes in the tavern on Jane Street where I hostessed two nights a week. They hung out with other young Mexicans working to send money home. Ricky never learned English. One Sunday, Aurelliano, the 17-year-old busboy, asked me, "Yes or no, correct, will you to be my girlfriend?" Seeing I was somewhat taken aback, he explained that Ricky needed me to write out the words along with possible answers. "Who's the girl?" I teased, but Ricky wouldn't tell. It's Ellen, the weekend bartender, Aurelliano confided later; Ricky wants to know, Does she have a boyfriend? Yes, I said, he's sitting at the bar. Ricky reappeared from the kitchen. Much giggling and excited talk. "What's going on?" I asked. "Ricky's happy," Aurelliano replied with a grin. "He think's her boyfriend's ugly." When Ricky left that night, he skipped jauntily out the door, smiling, twirling his hands in the air, confident of his blissful future with Ellen, who unknown to him, scarcely knew he existed.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets Start Camp Without Johnson
description: The Jets, hoping to recover from their worst season, are holding an early training-camp start today for rookies, quarterbacks and other veterans who are recovering from injuries.

title: Outdoors Concerts Are Now in Full Swing
description: THE outdoors beckons at this time of year, and many opportunities to hear music al fresco are at hand, among them the yearly Valhalla visit of the New York Philharmonic, chamber music at Caramoor, a Sunset Serenade at Lyndhurst, Summer Dances at Wave Hill and a Cajun Festival in Croton Point Park.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: CITYWIDE

title: At Meeting in Moscow, Gore Is to Urge Russian Reform
description: Vice President Al Gore will urge President Boris N. Yeltsin to capitalize on the mandate for reform that he won with his re-election when the two men meet in Moscow, probably on Monday, American officials said this week. Mr. Gore is to arrive in Moscow tonight.

title: Calling the Races, Without Needing Horseshoes for Luck
description: FROM his distant perch at Olympic Stadium, Tom Hammond will peer at the track through binoculars to discern who is leading as runners rush toward him or head around the oval for more laps. To Hammond, a veteran horse racing announcer with a degree in equine science, his work in Atlanta will not be very different from a day's worth of calling races at the annual Breeders' Cup.

title: Disabled Group Receives $250,000
description: One of the big names in the computer software industry returned to Westchester recently with a $250,000 contribution for Westchester ARC, a nonprofit agency serving people with developmental disabilities, including his own sister.

title: Holiday Travelers Make Room for Grandma
description: Famished and fatigued after a seven-hour pull behind the wheel on Interstate 95, Steve Benton stepped down from his white van in the parking lot of a rest area 30 miles north of Baltimore, mopped his brow and uttered a comic-strip exclamation: "Whew!"

title: An American Abroad
description: HOUSE ARREST By Mary Morris. 271 pp. New York: Nan A. Talese/Doubleday. $22.95.

title: ART REVIEW;High-Flying Statements of Group Identity
description: SINCE the beaten path in art from West Africa is carved masks, statuary and textiles, the Morris Museum's main summer offering will be a revelation for most viewers. "Asafo! African Flags of the Fante," a traveling exhibition organized by the London-based curator Peter Adler, shows a little-known, freewheeling side of West African art. The more than 100 vibrant banners embody proverbs intended to promote group solidarity.

title: Through the eyes of Antonio Diaz, City Lifeguard
description: The mood was calm and playful as sunbathers lined the decks and children romped through the turquoise waters last week at the Highbridge pool in Washington Heights. A shrill unison of whistles broke the mood as eight men wearing neon orange swim trunks signaled for everyone to leave the pool for the daily break.

title: JULY 7-13;Court TV, Starring Bill
description: President Clinton spent last Sunday afternoon under the gaze of cameras at the White House, taping testimony for two Arkansas bankers charged with illegal donations to his 1990 gubernatorial campaign. It was the second time he has given video testimony in a case brought by the Whitewater special prosecutor.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER MANHATTAN;How Close Is Too Close for Parole Office?
description: First, residents of Battery Park City were upset by a plan to place a welfare-processing center near their luxury condominiums. The plan fell through, but their relief was short-lived: now the state is preparing to open a parole office in the same building, at 19 Rector Street. It is expected to draw around 150 parolees a day. "This is an even more obnoxious use of the site than the other," said Stanley H. Epstein, one of the residents opposed to the project. "It will bring convicted felons to an area that is about 300 feet from a playground."

title: Between the Diner and the Belt: A Very Urban Farm
description: Ken Mondschein is no farmer but he was the closest thing to one that a Girl Scout troop from Brooklyn had ever seen. Before Mr. Mondschein, a 21-year-old college student from Manhattan, was to send the girls and their one honorary boy member into a plot for some old-fashioned digging and planting, he held out a small plant.

title: SPECIAL TODAY;A Guide to the Games
description: Established stars like the sprinter Michael Johnson, left, as well as lesser-known champions-to-be are featured in an Atlanta Summer Olympics section. It offers a comprehensive look at the Olympic sports and the people who play them, along with a complete TV schedule.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;EQUESTRIAN
description: THE EQUESTRIAN DISCIPLINES are unlike any other Olympic competition. The men and women compete head-to-head in all events, equestrian riders reach their prime in their mid-30's and half of the athletes are horses. But aside from what makes equestrian so different, there are traits it shares with the other sports. Even basketball fans can appreciate the elegance of dressage, the thrills of show jumping and the intestinal fortitude of the three-day event. THE SCORING Olympic competition consists of three disciplines: dressage, show jumping and three-day event. All three have team and individual competitions. In dressage, judges score the competitors on a series of moves, called a test, at designated areas around the ring. The percentage of a perfect score is then calculated. Usually, the medalists score in the 70-80 percent range. The top 24 individuals advance to the Gran Prix Special, of which the top 12 advance to the freestyle. The scores are added to determine the individual medalists.

title: LIVES;Mind Games
description: 1950. STUYVESANT HIGH SCHOOL. GEOGRAPHY. ROOM 312. I SAT IN THE THIRD ROW, NEAR THE TALL windows through which the sunlight flowed, providing me the opportunity to make interesting shadow shapes with my fingers on the surface of my desk. Mr. Dediase had been explaining the Mercator projection (which I knew about) for some time, drawing stuff on the board, talking about peeling grapefruit. Finally, Dediase pulled down an enormous map of the world. Its size and brilliant colors caught our attention.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Vatican Museums Show A Spruced-Up Raphael
description: Raphael's masterwork fresco, "The School of Athens," which decorates the library and study of Pope Julius II in the Vatican Museums, can again be seen by the public after two years of restoration. The fresco, begun in 1508 when Raphael was 25, forms part of the series of rooms known as the Raphael Stanze.

title: Greenspan, the Oracle;An Economy Waits for the Magic Words
description: NEARLY every sentence uttered in public by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, is parsed, as soon as it leaves his lips, for clues to the direction of interest rates. On Thursday morning, those who track monetary policy will be listening particularly intently when Mr. Greenspan outlines his views on the economy to a Congressional committee.

title: Test-Tampering Charge to Be Investigated
description: Nicholas A. Cioffi, the former State Public Safety Commissioner, has been hired to oversee the investigation of alleged test tampering at the Stratfield School, a public elementary school where higher than usual numbers of answers were changed on two standardized tests.

title: Dogged;Perot's Back. But Did Voters Ask for an Encore?
description: ROSS PEROT'S folksy utterances may still get splashed on the front page and the evening news. His every public word is monitored by the minions of President Clinton and Bob Dole. And there remains a chance that his could single-handedly tilt the election results on Nov. 5.

title: JULY 7-13;Sizing Up Netanyahu
description: Benjamin Netanyahu returned last week to the United States, the country where he cut his diplomatic (and telegenic) teeth; the United States now in turn must sharpen its own diplomatic and public relations skills to deal with him as Israel's new rightist Prime Minister.

title: WEDDINGS;Rakesh Khurana, Stephanie Ralston
description: Stephanie Joan Ralston, the daughter of Rita and Trent Ralston of Harwood, Md., and Rakesh Khurana, a son of Anjana and Ram Khurana of Ridgefield, Conn., were married yesterday at the Swedenborg Chapel in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. George S. Salzmann, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated, and Pundit Narain Dutt Sharma, a Hindu priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: IN BRIEF;2,000 Miles of Trails Mapped in Revised Booklet
description: New Jersey has more than 2,000 miles of mapped hiking, biking and canoeing trails, according to the new state Trails Plan issued by the Department of Environmental Protection. The plan is the first comprehensive update of the state's trail system since 1982.

title: INVESTING IT;I'll Take 'Investment Strategies' for $500, Please
description: AS a contestant on TV's "Jeopardy," Bradley C. Plovan had all the answers. He knew the name of the composer buried next to Beethoven in Vienna ("Who was Schubert?").
