He knew the title of the speech William Jennings Bryan delivered at the 1896 Democratic Convention ("What is the 'Cross of Gold' speech?"). He even knew the nickname of Irwin Handelman, a character on the sitcom "Family Ties" ("What is 'Skippy?' ").

title: Helping Youths Resist Drug Use
description: SUMMER offers a welcome respite from the tight schedules that so many children follow during the school year. Such freedom, however, can sometimes lead to pre-adolescent and teen-age experimentation with drugs and alcohol.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;A New Backcourt: Childs and Houston Join the Knicks
description: The Knicks agreed to contract terms with Allan Houston and Chris Childs yesterday, giving themselves a new starting backcourt and drastically changing their team for next season.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: CANARSIE;Between the Diner and the Belt: A Very Urban Farm
description: Ken Mondschein is no farmer but he was the closest thing to one that a Girl Scout troop from Brooklyn had ever seen. Before Mr. Mondschein, a 21-year-old college student from Manhattan, was to send the girls and their one honorary boy member into a plot for some old-fashioned digging and planting, he held out a small plant. "Smell this," he said to the group. "This is basil. It's an herb. Do you know it?" No answer. "Have you ever had pesto sauce?" he continued. "Well, it's in that." So began another day on the Urban Farm, an acre of land hard by the Belt Parkway on Rockaway Parkway. At the Seaview Diner next door, patrons can look out not at the sea but at children raking rocks, pulling weeds and patting soil. They used to see stones and a teepee. A group of Mohawk Indians laid claim to the land last year until the Parks Department removed them. Now a leader of the group, John Crosstheriver, returns to give the children lessons in local Native American lore. The tract was adopted this spring by New Perspectives, an economic development corporation in Canarsie, with permission from the Parks and Recreation Department. A $12,000 grant from the State Department of Parks paid for the crops, fence and shovels. The parcel had to be cleared of trash and resoiled. The groups of children who do the planting are supervised by senior citizens from two local centers who make sure the novices are planting the harvest of eggplant, tomatoes, basil and peppers properly. The older men and women show concern as they stand over the boys and girls. After all, once the food is grown, New Perspectives plans to feed it to the seniors at the centers. "I've desperately wanted to plant stuff for years," said 10-year old Felicia Spano who was holding a pink hand shovel. "People should be thinking about plants." Last year, the Mohawk group built an encampment on the land when it was still strewn with rocks and discarded junk. From October until Dec. 31, the men meditated inside a sweat lodge and spent the nights there. Visitors were welcome to learn about their traditions. But the group, which wanted to build a museum there, had a permit to use the site only until the end of the year. They refused to leave after the Parks Department asked them to and the agency tore down the teepee and the lodge. Alan Weisberg, executive director of New Perspectives, said he has tried to include the Mohawks in the farm but they have not informed him of their plans and could not be reached for comment. MARK FRANCIS COHEN

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;Pasts to Forget, Scores to Settle, Medals to Win
description: FOUR YEARS AGO, Michael Johnson ate spoiled ham before the Barcelona Olympics, which caused him to lose 10 pounds, a week of training and any chance he had of winning a gold medal at 200 meters.

title: HOME CLINIC;Veneering: Old and Respected Craft
description: VENEERING is the craft of gluing a thin layer of select wood on a common board. Generally, it is done to provide a better looking surface, but, in some cases, veneering may be used to strengthen a piece as, for example, in the manufacture of plywood.

But the politically popular idea has inspired Democratic rivals to compile their own lists of New York's most pressing small annoyances. Here, some pending concerns.

title: Sunday: July 14, 1996 -- Sports;Thrill of Victory. Agony of Muktuk.

But that's about it for similarities. These sports, invented years ago by Arctic nomads, were designed as no-frills tests of strength and skill. Here are some samples, culled from the program and "Inuit Games," a book on Eskimo athletics.

It's when Dr. Brakish Okun, the scientist with long gray hair and glasses, appears on the screen. Yes, Trekkies, it's the platinum-toned android Lieutenant Commander Data from "Star Trek: The Next Generation," a k a Brent Spiner.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;The Invisible Man at Ellington's Elbow
description: The New York apartment building where Billy Strayhorn lived through the 1950's, 15 West 106th Street, is now called Ellington West. This is not the only example of Ellington's name pasted over Strayhorn's. It's still a fairly common experience to go to a jazz concert and hear "Lush Life," "Chelsea Bridge," "The Star-Crossed Lovers," "Lotus Blossom" or the band's signature, "Take the A Train," announced as a piece by Duke Ellington. All were written and copyrighted by Strayhorn.

title: ON THE STREET;This Way To Happily Ever After
description: Filing into New York City parks for photographs was a highlight for many a bridal party last month, as well as for the parkgoers who enjoyed the pageantry. Spectators found the tiny flower girls dressed as exact miniatures of the bride especially enchanting. The youngest ring bearer, right, was 15 months old. These doll-size attendants, a tradition in the city's Latino communities, led the wedding parties into the parks just as they led them down the church aisle. The tiny facsimiles of the bride helped supply a fairy-tale touch to wedding parties on the sweeping stairways and under the rose-covered trellises of Central Park's Conservancy Gardens and the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Campaign Trail, Over Internet, Up to Vermont
description: It may seem a bit nutty that Prof. August St. John, who teaches marketing and future studies at the Brooklyn campus of Long Island University, commutes from Vermont. But the 68-year-old academic, who specializes in economic forecasting and is known in his home state as ''Dr. Doom and Gloom,'' rarely takes the conventional route to anything.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;CANOE/KAYAK
description: WHITEWATER CANOEING and kayaking have close ties to the recreational community. The discipline is developing a devoted set of followers, many of whom are apt to be paddling the same roily rivers of America. Sprint events rely more on tradition than mass appeal. THE SETUP As many as 120 canoes and kayaks on teams worldwide will be racing at two different sites for the 1996 Games. The United States is sending 25 men and women. The four whitewater slalom events are being staged on a turbulent 400-meter section of the Ocoee River in Tennessee, about 130 miles northwest of Atlanta. The flatwater sprints are on Lake Lanier, near Gainesville, Ga., about 55 miles from Atlanta. Sprinters in 12 divisions race in heats of nine paddlers, each in a lane about nine meters wide.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;Rainout Causes Off-Field Fallout

The Orioles blamed the Yankees for being greedy and making inordinate demands when the possibility of playing a day-night doubleheader today was discussed. The on-the-field rivalry between the two teams might have received an unexpected boost from this off-the-field spat.

title: Books in Brief;Mostly the Good Parts
description: Right off the bat, Alan King tells us what not to expect in NAME-DROPPING: The Life and Lies of Alan King (Scribner, $23), the scrappy memoir he has written with Chris Chase. "This book is not going to be heavy drama -- I don't want Robert De Niro playing my life," he says. "I'm not going to remember the bad stuff, I'm only going to remember the singing and dancing." True to his word, this most quick-witted of comedians nimbly sidesteps his fractious childhood as Irwin Kniberg -- a "very angry, very tough kid" who was thrown out of every high school in Brooklyn -- to get to the good parts, which began when he was 15 and landed his first job as a comic in the Catskills. Mr. King tells priceless stories about Bugsy Siegel (his patron during the Las Vegas days, "when everybody I worked for got killed"), Frank Sinatra (who was declared the winner of their tomato sauce cookoff by judges named Willie the Nose and Morey the Mouth), and a host of other beloved old cronies including Jack Benny, Joe E. Lewis, Milton Berle and Sammy Davis Jr. But like the cocky street fighter he once was, Mr. King has an instinct for someone's weak spots, so the stories that really floor you are about wounded comrades like Dean Martin and Judy Garland. As for his own underbelly, Mr. King allows as how he's got a rotten temper and carries around a load of rage. (But he has nothing but compassion for his father, a Jewish immigrant embittered by real poverty and imagined failure.) "Most comedians are angry, it's their edge," he says. "When I get angry, I'm better." Mr. King leaves it to his wife, in a sweet and unaffected chapter called "Jeanette's Turn," to bring up uncomfortable subjects like the comedian's jaw cancer and certain unspecified problems with their children. We always knew that Alan King was a funny guy; now we know what made him so keen and caustic. Marilyn Stasio

title: Virtually Asleep
description: To the Editor:

title: THEATER;'Sonya': Troubled Life With a Sainted Man
description: DURING the first act of "Sonya," the wife of Leo Tolstoy is pointed out as a "soul in need" by a doctor and disciple of the literary and philosophical icon. In Act II, a Russian Orthodox priest tells Sonya how he understands her "cry from the heart." Such are the playwright Leon Katz's florid elucidations on the overwrought behavior of Countess Sofya Andreyevna Tolstoy, who spends much of her namesake play's three hours making a nuisance of herself, demanding to be let into the cottage where her husband of 48 years lies dying, while hostile forces keep her out. The year is 1910. Since Julie Harris is possessed of the power to communicate an interior life, her enlightened presence gives a playwright the golden gift of time. He can save it. He can cut words. He can redirect priorities. Bluntly put, he can rework his play. As Sonya, Ms. Harris reveals the depth of distress, the ambivalent pull of fierce love in conflict with ideological discord. In a single moment, the actress sums up her reason for being there: to put the stamp of finality and forgiveness -- the buzzword is closure -- on a troubled, unreconciled life with a sainted man. Their "totally opposite ideas of the meaning and purpose of existence," in the words of a letter Tolstoy wrote to Sonya four months before his death, led to estrangement. Sonya could not forsake the materialism that a spiritually converted Tolstoy renounced, or understand his loyalty to his leading disciple, Vladimir Gregorievich Chertkov, with its intimations of homosexuality and an idealism that eluded her. While the puzzling and fascinating ramifications of an extraordinarily volatile marriage that produced 13 children, 4 of whom -- 2 daughters and 2 sons -- figure among an eye-popping stage full of 15 characters, are unexplored, the ravings of Sonya are overexplained. Neither historically lucid nor dramatically fulfilling, Mr. Katz's play reveals a gaping hole at the center, an unsettling inconclusiveness. That Tolstoy remains unseen in a many-peopled play is an interesting challenge Mr. Katz has created, but he has failed to give a revered man a rich offstage life. Yet no playwright could reasonably expect, in three weeks' playing time, a more solid ensemble or a more bountiful production than the Phoenix Theater Company at Purchase College in Purchase, N.Y., has lavished on "Sonya." It all starts with the audience's gasp at the sight of Campbell Baird's imposing set, a whopping train that revolves in an obscure railroad station, Astapovo. That happened to be the title of the first professional version of Mr. Katz's play; previously it was called "A Death at Astapovo." The first professional version was performed at the Yale Repertory's Winterfest series in 1983 under Lawrence Kornfeld's direction. Reno Roop (as Tolstoy's oldest son) is a holdover from that production, which also had Charles S. Dutton and John Turturro in small roles and Jan Miner as Sonya. For this production, the artistic director of the Phoenix, Bram Lewis, orchestrates the feuding and fussing family, the invading press -- Tolstoy's retreat into the woods at 82 was some media event -- and the stars' iridescent moments as though there were real drama somewhere in there. Ms. Harris, in a flash, retreats into the reassurance of memory, madness and considerations of suicide, shades her voice to the darkest reaches of the virago who means business and glancingly acknowledges the comedy inherent in any photo-op, amid all her protestations. In support, note a capital cast. Philip Baker Hall (Chertkov) is an unrelenting threat, and Timothy Jerome (Dushan) is a well-tempered adversary. Jennifer Harmon, Miriam Healy-Louie, Jud Meyers and Mr. Roop are so intensely and individually effective as the Tolstoy daughters and sons -- Sonya's "jailers" -- that they make it theatrically clear that every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way. If only Mr. Katz had written just how. "Sonya," Phoenix Theater at Purchase College, Purchase, N.Y. 914-251-6290. Performances continue through next Sunday.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Jaguars Sign Top Draft Pick
description: Linebacker KEVIN HARDY, the No. 2 overall pick in last April's draft, has agreed on a six-year contract with the Jaguars, becoming the highest draft pick to agree to terms so far this year. The deal is believed to be worth about $16 million, including a $6 million signing bonus. The deal means the Jaguars will have all 82 players on their roster signed when camp starts on Thursday. They are the only team with every player under contract. The sticking point throughout the negotiations had been the length. The six-year deal means that Hardy could be a free agent in 2002, when there would be no salary cap under the current collective bargaining agreement. (AP)

description: Science on Trial The Clash of Medical Evidence and the Law in the Breast Implant Case. By Marcia Angell. 256 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $27.50.

title: NEIGBORHOOD REPORT: QUEENS/BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;Butterfly Hunt: Few Ladies, Many Snouts
description: Checkered whites and buckeyes darted across the runways at Kennedy International Airport. There were hairstreaks in unusual places, painted ladies and Delaware skippers in Queens and snouts down at Jamaica Bay. But hardly any American ladies flitted around the city. So goes the butterfly count around New York, taken each July during mating season, according to 17 members of the New York City Butterfly Club, which gathered for its monthly meeting in a living room in Forest Hills last Monday night. The consensus among the butterfly watchers who combed Queens and Brooklyn with their binoculars last Sunday is that the species count is down this year because the larvae of some species may not have survived the cool, wet spring.

title: WEDDINGS;Miss Gennerich, Mr. Mazza

title: Stating the Case Against Lilco
description: Re: "Lilco Was Guilty; Customers Still Pay" [June 16]. I agree with the writer, Gregory Palast, about the case against Lilco except for the statement: "Well Mr. Hurley, if it's any comfort, a jury did find Lilco officers guilty of giving perjured, fradulent testimony about the Shoreham nuclear power plant." Believe me, Mr. Hurley is well aware. In fact, I have written many times to the judge, Jack Weinstein, pointing out errors in his 60-odd page decision that lets Lilco off the hook for this massive crime. My basic contention is that we never needed Shoreham (that's Shoreham 1) to say anything about 2 and 3 or the four other nuclear plants that Lilco wanted at Jamesport. Now that we don't have the plant, the lights are still on, and even die-hard Shoreham supporters write that the Island is "overpowered." I wonder if His Honor still thinks that the public will "rue the day Shoreham closed"; or if he now realizes that if we don't need it -- we don't need it.

title: ON POLITICS;The Subplot Thickens In G.O.P. Home Movies
description: When a group of black businessmen and women decided to hold a fund-raising cocktail party in Washington for Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Englewood Democrat who is running for the Senate, they were surprised to learn just how dirty the New Jersey Senate race had become.

title: ON LANGUAGE;Facially Valid
description: SOMETIMES A LAWYER GETS HUNG UP on a term of art and shoots it through his entire brief. "As long as the forms were facially valid," wrote Howard M. Shapiro, F.B.I. general counsel, reporting on the bureau's curious handling of White House requests for its confidential files, "the F.B.I. was legally entitled to assume that their author was acting within the scope of his or her authority." He added, "We have been institutionally inclined to process facially valid White House requests without reflection."

title: ART;Collectors Lend Pieces, From Superb to the So-So
description: THE word in Westchester is that the King of England, presumably William III, offered John Harrison all the land he could ride in a day. Harrison rode and, presto! The town bearing his name. Fact or fiction, the story adds spice to Harrison's 300th anniversary celebration, an important part of which may be seen in the Neuberger Museum at Purchase College here. For this, Gail Harrison Roman (no relation) combed the town, seeking out its collectors.

She is six feet tall, grew up in Portland, Ore., and is slim enough to wear cigarette pants, but she also looks as if she could change a tire or chop wood if necessary. A graphic designer in the art department at Bride's magazine, she said she never dreamed of becoming a bride.

title: Sunday: July 14, 1996
description: Lightning, the Crackling Raptor: 1. Prime lightning season starts right about now, so know this: between 1940 and 1991, atmospheric bolts killed more Americans (8,316) than did tornadoes (5,731) or floods (5,828). 2. "Strike channel" temperatures can hit 60,000 degrees. 3. In a typical year, lightning causes 20,000 residential blazes. 4. The worst known lightning disaster occurred in 1963, when 81 people died in a zapped Boeing that crashed near Elkton, Md. 5. Steve Marshburn -- founder of Lightning Strike and Electric Shock Victims International, a support group -- was hit while working inside a bank; the bolt entered through a drive-in teller's ungrounded speaker. "Lightning," he says, "can find you anywhere."

title: U.S. to Send Holbrooke to Discuss Indicted Bosnian Serb Leaders
description: Richard C. Holbrooke, the Clinton Administration's former chief negotiator in the Balkans, will return to the region next week in an effort to convince Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia to live up to the peace accords reached in Dayton, Ohio, and bring about the ouster of two Bosnian Serb leaders, a senior Administration official said today.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;WRESTING
description: FREESTYLE WRESTLING was shaken last winter when Dave Schultz, a 1984 gold medalist attempting to make an Olympic comeback, was shot to death, allegedly by the chemical company heir John DuPont, the sport's biggest benefactor. The United States has fielded another strong team for these Games, and Schultz's memory will preside over the competition and provide a certain wistfulness and motivation. THE SETUP Olympic wrestling is divided into two styles, freestyle and Greco-Roman. The difference, essentially, is that freestyle wrestlers can use their legs to execute moves, such as tripping or lifting an opponent, while Greco-Roman wrestlers cannot. Both styles feature 10 weight divisions, and each match consists of one five-minute round.

title: WEDDINGS;Shari L. Targum, Andrew L. Yarrow
description: Dr. Shari Lynn Targum, a daughter of Justice Anne E. Targum and Dr. Emanuel Targum of New York, is to be married today to Andrew Louis Yarrow, the son of Dr. Marian Yarrow of Bethesda, Md., and the late Dr. Leon Yarrow. Rabbi Phyllis Shapiro is to perform the ceremony at Le Chateau, a restaurant in South Salem, N.Y.

title: L.I. Vines
description: Chenin Blanc Paumanok Vineyards, Aquebogue, 1995. About $10. If I suppressed a desire for a gin and tonic or a snappy late-afternoon lemonade in favor of its wine sibling, this zesty white would fill the bill neatly. It is Ursula and Charles Massoud's best chenin blanc to date. Citric and cooling, it is both appetite-whetting and -slaking, depending on one's mood. It is easy to fantasize the presence of a grapefruit infusion. The aftertaste is long long long. This is not a wine for the ages. It is a wine for scallops. And oysters. And grilled light-flavored fish in butter sauce. Chenin blanc is a minor player in East End vineyards. The Massouds have been at it gamely since 1991. In this just-released latest version -- a young wine, intended to be drunk young -- they have brought the acidity under control and heightened the fruit. This equates to balance. When really icy, it is refreshing in a severe way; when cool, it is smooth and quite fruity; when finished, it invites a second bottle. Only 250 cases were made. HOWARD G. GOLDBERG

title: HARNESS RACING;Hot Lead Sets the Pace
description: Hot Lead held off late surges by Stout on the outside and Gee Gee Digger on the inside to win the $1 million Meadowlands Pace tonight. Stout finished second by a nose and Gee Gee Digger finished third by a neck.

description: To the Editor:

title: SPENDING IT;Nasty Calls at 6 A.M.: Dunners Who Go Too Far
description: LORETTA BROADWAY of Meriden, Conn., owed $373 to a catalogue merchandiser in 1993 when she received a letter from what she assumed was a law firm. The letter threatened to have her car and bank account seized if she did not pay up. On the letterhead were the scales of justice and the name of the firm, Goldman & Levine.

title: Ruling Favoring Toys 'R' Us Is a Miscarriage of Justice
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs;Sucked Into the Wrong Vacuum
description: It may be time to revive the hot line between the U.S. and Russia. Seriously.

title: Diner Destined to Close Is Rescued by Two Longtime Patrons
description: BY all outward appearances, the Muscoot Inn, an eating establishment off the junction of Routes 35 and 100 here, has always been easy to miss. The weather-beaten diner has a decidedly ramshackle look. Inside the wooden floors are slanted, the doors slightly aplomb. But loyal patrons of the restaurant known affectionately as the Muscoot have always liked it that way.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;TORONTO
description: TORONTO has never been so much fun, or so outlandish. That's literally outlandish, as in the Oxford English Dictionary's archaic definition: "of or belonging to a foreign country . . . not native or indigenous." The city that earlier in this century prided itself on its bastion-of-Empire character has changed. "New Canadians," as they are called, have been transforming Toronto for about four decades, and they include large numbers of Italians, Portuguese, Chinese, South Asian and Caribbean peoples.

title: WEDDINGS;Paige Cottingham, Donald Streater
description: Paige Lynne Cottingham, the daughter of Gwendolyn and Robert Cottingham Sr. of Orange, N.J., was married there yesterday to Donald Allen Streater, the son of Lenora Lewis of Washington and the late Hampton Streater. Canon Gervais Clarke performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany.

title: How Close Is Too Close for Parole Office?
description: First, residents of Battery Park City were upset by a plan to place a welfare-processing center near their luxury condominiums. The plan fell through, but their relief was short-lived: now the state is preparing to open a parole office in the same building, at 19 Rector Street. It is expected to draw around 150 parolees a day.

title: F.Y.I.
description: Big Whale, Strong Java

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WASHINGTON HEIGHTS -- ON THE LOOKOUT;Through the eyes of Antonio Diaz, City Lifeguard
description: The mood was calm and playful as sunbathers lined the decks and children romped through the turquoise waters last week at the Highbridge pool in Washington Heights. A shrill unison of whistles broke the mood as eight men wearing neon orange swim trunks signaled for everyone to leave the pool for the daily break. One was Antonio Diaz, 28, the head lifeguard and father figure in the crew of 18 lifeguards, all of whom are from the Dominican Republic. For Mr. Diaz, who grew up in the neighborhood, swimming was something that kept him off the streets; teaching it at a private club gives him a wintertime livelihood.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Carter Wants to Leave the Chiefs
description: DALE CARTER, the Kansas City Chiefs' All-Pro cornerback, says he would rather play for his brother's team. Carter, who started in the 1996 Pro Bowl, told a news conference in Minneapolis on Friday that he hopes the Chiefs don't match an offer he has signed from the Minnesota Vikings. Joining the Vikings would put Carter on the same team with his older brother, wide receiver JAKE REED. They played on the same high school team in Covington, Ga.

title: 'A Hot Place For Spiritual Renewal'
description: Even though I understand that David Bouchier's approach in his article on ''A 'Hot' Place for Spiritual Renewal'' $(Out of Order, June 23$) was that of tongue-in-cheek satire, I find it extraordinary that anyone could approach the subject of spiritual life without mentioning the fact that many churches and a number of synagogues are alive and flourishing in the Hamptons.

title: POLITICS: POLITICAL MEMO;Dole's Free-Form Style Upsets Campaign Plans
description: Bob Dole's Presidential campaign has taken to keeping a political calendar detailing the themes Mr. Dole will address each day. Last Saturday was juvenile crime day, Wednesday was reserved for welfare reform, and the topic for Thursday was the United States' relations with Israel.

title: Q. & A.
description: Tenant's Refusal To Pay

title: Books in Brief: NonFiction
description: CULTURES OF HEALING Correcting the Image of American Mental Health Care. By Robert T. Fancher. Freeman, $23.95.

title: In Piermont, the View Is Unsurpassed
description: JUST a mile or so north of the center of Piermont is the restaurant Piermont on the Hudson, a spot that quite likely has the the very best waterfront view in Rockland County.

title: 2 Suits Slow Plans for a Speedier Long Island Expressway
description: The state's plan to add a fourth lane in each direction to the Long Island Expressway east of the Cross Island Parkway has run into two lawsuits that aim to hold off construction of the Queens segment.

title: County's Olympic Hopes Rest on Four Athletes
description: CRISTINA TEUSCHER and the water formed their bond very early.

title: July 7-13;Her Royal Common-ness
description: Three and a half years after formally separating, the Prince and Princess of Wales announced last week that they had at last agreed on a divorce settlement.

title: BEST SELLERS: July 14, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: Out of Nazareth
description: THE GOSPEL OF CORAX By Paul Park. 297 pp. New York: Soho Press. $25.

title: CHOICE TABLES;Denver Becomes a Dining Boom Town
description: CONSIDERED by many travelers as a place to slip through on their way to skiing or hiking vacations in the Rocky Mountains, Denver has not been noted for its dining. But that may be changing.

title: The Survivors of Avebury
description: THE megaliths of Avebury, in the rolling Wiltshire downs of southern England, are often compared with the stones of Carnac. This is traditional sheep-grazing country, thousands of acres of bare chalk grassland swept into shallow hills and valleys, supporting into this century a way of life unutterably remote, the life of the shepherd on the hills. It is also old sacred country: a mile or so south of the ring stands Silbury Hill, the biggest manmade mound in Europe; just to the north runs the Ridgeway, a primeval track running northeast to southwest, and at Avebury itself a deep circular ditch encloses such stones as survive from a giant ring, the largest relic of its kind in Europe.

title: A Scramble to Thwart High-Tech Thieves
description: YOU park at the airport, remove your luggage, push the button on the key fob to lock the doors, and walk away thinking your car will be secure until you return. Think again.

title: ELLA FITZGERALD;Nothing Artificial
description: To the Editor: Mr. Schwartz's loving tribute to Ella Fitzgerald ["The Divine Pleasures of an 'Absent Genius,' " June 23] helped me realize that what could be considered a deficiency in her singing was, in fact, her strength. Her special gift of purity and her approach to a lyric did not prod the listener into an artificial emotional response but allowed the listener to interpret them and respond on their own terms. I suppose that in today's jargon this would be called "empowering the customer." LES BLOCK Minneapolis

title: Economic Agency Puts Businesses First
description: WESTCHESTER is open for business. But even more important, Westchester is open to business because the state's business climate has changed, say New York State economic professionals.

title: WEDDINGS;Susan R. Berube, Peter A. Dutton Jr.
description: Susan Rebecca Berube, the daughter of Nancy and Verne Berube of Casco, Me., was married yesterday to Peter Alan Dutton Jr., a son of Raquel and Peter Dutton of Manorville, L.I. The Rev. Joseph E. Whitlock performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Bridgton, Me.

title: Habitats/19 East 79th Street;From Brazil to Boca to a Co-op in a Former Mansion
description: IN an age of bleached wood floors, sisal rugs and beige furniture, it is somewhat shocking to come upon an apartment immaculately done over in a style that can only be labeled opulent, lush with polished Brazilian cherrywood and gilt and Aubusson rugs and busts of Roman senators, soignee to its freshly plastered walls.

title: A Bistro-Bar Joins the Lively SoNo Scene
description: SOUTH NORWALK continues its metamorphosis. First Washington Street had a revival; now it is South Main Street's turn, and the street is coming to new life as a restaurant and entertainment area. It is evident in the new Tra-Peze Bistro & Bar, ensconced in the double storefront space formerly occupied by Miche-Mache.

title: POLITICS: THE HOUSE;Abortion Rights League Plans to Challenge 15 Freshmen
description: Taking a militant page from the opposition's strategy manual, the abortion-rights lobby is singling out 15 vulnerable freshman Republicans in the House for defeat, preparing to publicize their votes on more than a score of anti-abortion measures as too fervid for their moderate suburban constituencies.

title: A LA CARTE;Diners Now Serving Cutting-Edge Cuisine
description: YESTERDAY'S commonplace diner is becoming today's classic. Diners from the 1930's, 40's and 50's are being painstakingly restored and made into resplendent restaurants that serve carefully planned crazyquilts of cutting-edge cuisine and old favorites. The hot Crazy Dog at 123 Montauk Highway in Westhampton (288-1444), where the old Westhampton Diner had been, is just such a new wave hybrid. It has a lunch counter with swivel stools; is open seven days a week for all three meals; offers dishes like pancakes, waffles and french toast at breakfast, burgers and meatloaf sandwiches at lunch and can serve a three-course meal in less than an hour.

title: Time Out
description: Gold watches for the leisure classes.

title: ATLANTA IS BURNING
description: I agree that Atlanta is not yet a great international city. But as an American city that was destroyed by war -- and a young one even then -- it has come a long way in a very short time. Its achievements should be an inspiration rather than an opportunity for cynicism.

title: JULY 7-13;Hurting Canada Over Cuba
description: When Cuba shot down two small planes flown by a Cuban exile group in February, President Clinton, mindful of his need for support in Florida, signed legislation he had opposed, the so-called Helms-Burton law penalizing foreign companies doing business in Cuba. Last week the State Department informed nine top executives and shareholders of a Canadian mining firm, Sherritt International, that they and their families would be barred from the United States because Sherritt operates installations Mr. Castro expropriated from Americans in 1959. Mexican and Italian executives are about to receive the same notice.

title: DINING OUT;In Piermont, the View Is Unsurpassed
description: JUST a mile or so north of the center of Piermont is the restaurant Piermont on the Hudson, a spot that quite likely has the the very best waterfront view in Rockland County. From the tiered levels of the dining room or from the capacious deck, which seems to catch the breeze on the warmest of nights, diners can see the blue lights of the Tappan Zee Bridge arching across the river. Also likely to come into view are Canada geese and small craft puttering into their slips at the nearby boat basin. Clearly at such a time, outdoors is the place to be. Everything suggests ease, holiday, the gifts of summer.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;BASKETBALL
description: THIS SECOND OLYMPIC Dream Team, less revered but healthier and quicker than the 1992 gold-medal winner, has retained enough of a Hall of Fame pedigree to remove any suspense from the Georgia Dome.

title: JULY 7-13;Sino-U.S. Back-Scratching
description: American and Chinese officials are making nice again, after more than a year of unpleasantness over Taiwan, human rights and trade disputes. All three issues have receded, but remain unresolved.

title: A Dolphin Swimming With the Sharks
description: HE HAD ALREADY talked for much of the morning about Platonic doctrine, military strategy and prima ballerinas.

title: Perspectives;A Man's Road to Athens: Amateurism in Its Finest Sense
description: As today's athletic endorsements go, these were meager deals, totaling less than $20,000. But they caused soul-searching among the descendants of Robert Garrett.

title: Julie Harris in 'Sonya,' A Phoenix Production
description: DURING the first act of ''Sonya,'' the wife of Leo Tolstoy is pointed out as a ''soul in need'' by a doctor and disciple of the literary and philosophical icon.

title: The Dorset, the Place to Meet for Media Elite, Fades Out
description: With the plan for a huge addition to the Museum of Modern Art inching forward, a small corner of city culture will sink quietly into MOMA's wake on July 25. That is when the Hotel Dorset, acquired by the museum, will bid adieu to its last guests.

title: Civic Virtue
description: Religion in Public Life A Dilemma for Democracy. By Ronald F. Thiemann. 186 pp. Washington: A 20th Century Fund Book/ Georgetown University Press. Cloth, $55. Paper, $17.95.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Roaf May Become the Best-Paid Saint
description: Offensive tackle WILLIAM ROAF's new eight-year contract is the biggest in New Orleans Saints history and makes him the best-paid National Football League offensive lineman ever. General Manager BILL KUHARICH and the agent LAMONT SMITH would say only that the total package exceeds LEON SEARCY's five-year, $17.5 million deal with Jacksonville, although it does not equal Searcy's average salary. The Times-Picayune reported yesterday that Roaf, a Pro Bowl player in two of his first three seasons, will get a total of $27.4 million, including a $5.5 million signing bonus.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Stylish to Cozy In TriBeCa
description: ARQUA**

title: WEDDINGS;Martin T. Meehan, Ellen T. Murphy
description: Ellen Theresa Murphy, the vice president for public affairs at Lawrence (Mass.) General Hospital, was married yesterday to Representative Martin Thomas Meehan, Democrat of Massachusetts. The Rev. John Hanley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Merrimack College Chapel in North Andover, Mass.

title: WEDDINGS;Heather Fricke, Scott Montgomery
description: Heather Jean Fricke, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David W. Fricke of Owings, Md., was married yesterday to Scott Warren Montgomery, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Warren R. Montgomery of Floral Park, L.I. The Rev. Robert Hahn performed the ceremony at the Evangelical Presbyterian Church in Annapolis, Md.

title: JUST BUY IT
description: In "Just Buy It" (The Capitalist, June 23), Michael Lewis is way off base when he chastises Nike for its current promotion, which encourages women to play sports -- to go out there and just do it. As an elementary-school teacher, I have observed a big difference between girls who participate in sports and those who do not. Part of the athletic process is to push yourself to be the best you can be. That in itself is rewarding for young women. Playing sports affords girls the opportunity to be part of a group with common goals, something that is rare in other areas of the curriculum.

title: Delays on Megan's Law Are Frustrating State Prosecutors
description: The monthly meeting of New Jersey's 21 county prosecutors was just breaking up in Trenton last Tuesday when word arrived from the Federal appeals court in Philadelphia: they could not send out detectives to schools, camps and women's shelters with the names, addresses and pictures of paroled sex offenders living nearby.

title: Ruling Favoring Toys 'R' Us Is a Miscarriage of Justice
description: To the Editor: This month's decision by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court regarding the megastore Toys "R" Us proposes for 80th Street and Third Avenue seems a gross miscarriage of justice by both legal and logical standards ("Toys 'R' Us Ruling Hinges on Crates," July 7). How four of five justices could interpret the placing of 20 crates for two years in an otherwise dormant 16-story warehouse as a continuation of "substantially all" of an enterprise's operations is beyond me. Semantics and technicalities aside, zoning laws are supposed to be protective devices. A store that size with three loading docks for tractor-trailers on a narrow one-way city street would be disastrous for this neighborhood. Vehicular traffic would be a nightmare, parking unfathomable, noise and air pollution sickening and hordes of new pedestrians (and the accompanying litter and fast-food joints) oppressive and stifling. In short, it would cease to be a residential neighborhood. Tens of thousands live here precisely for the quiet ambiance and small neighborhood stores, and a great many of us and our political representatives are vehemently opposed to a megastore at this location. If we allow this or other residential neighborhoods to be jeopardized by inappropriate megastores, we will be dangerously and irrevocably tipping the scales toward making our city unlivable, destroying the city itself.

title: ART VIEW;Currier & Ives, as Telling as Ozzie and Harriet
description: The prints of Nathaniel Currier and James Merritt Ives flooded America in an unstaunched flow from before the Civil War to the eve of World War II. But they are barely part of anyone's active cultural vocabulary today.

title: AFTER SCHOOL;A Helping Hand for Those Who Help Themselves
description: NOW that July is here, Andrea Douglas is really getting down to work.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: REARVIEW MIRROR By Ellen Feldman. Delacorte, $22.95.

title: How to Be a Producer, in One Instant Lesson
description: On a sunny Saturday at the end of June, this sleepy New England college town has been stripped of students. The rolling lawns look a bit lonely. Most of the buildings at Williams College stand quietly behind their classical Greek columns, closed up like pocket watches.

title: WEDDINGS;Kate O'Shaughnessy, Jeremy Smith
description: Kate Wharton O'Shaughnessy, the daughter of Ann W. Thayer of Manhattan and William O'Shaughnessy of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jeremy Grover Smith, the son of Jeanne Sholl of Southboro, Mass., and Anthony W. Smith of Triumph, Idaho. The Rev. Saral Burdette, a nondenominational minister, performed the ceremony at the Four Seasons Biltmore in Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: Objects of Art
description: CHARDIN By Marianne Roland Michel. Illustrated. 293 pp. New York: Harry N. Abrams. $125.

title: HORSE RACING;Cigar Rolls Into Racing History With His 16th Victory in a Row
description: Cigar relentlessly and gracefully swept to his 16th straight victory today, winning the Arlington Citation Challenge by 3 1/2 lengths and matching the winning streak set half a century ago by Citation.

title: Streetscapes/39 and 41 Commerce Street;Two 1830's Homes, and a Garden Big Enough for a 3d
description: THE rain leaks into the house at 41 Commerce Street through loose mortar, peeling paint and holes in the roof -- indeed, it looks as if little has been done since 1832, when the structure was built as one of a curious pair with 39 Commerce Street. Now the owner is spending $60,000 on the little building, but if things go right, a passer-by won't be able to tell the difference.

title: ATLANTA: A VIEWER'S GUIDE;FIELD HOCKEY
description: THIS SPORT'S MAVENS insist on calling it hockey, not field hockey, because they consider their game to be the original, not that slippery version played on ice. Archaeology appears to bear them out. A tomb drawing from Egypt's Nile Valley that dates to approximately 2000 B.C. shows two men holding curved sticks with a round object between them. In America, field hockey became popular with women in the Northeast but has never become popular with American men. In Pakistan and India, however, the men's game means as much as Tom Osborne's running game does in Nebraska.

title: Exciting Blend of the Local and Global
description: VISITORS to Montauk are familiar with the famous lighthouse at the point. It is the symbol of Long Island. But there is a second, smaller lighthouse at Star Island on Lake Montauk. It too is a symbol. It is the logo of the Montauk Yacht Club and the inspiration for its restaurant, the Lighthouse Grill.

title: 13, on the Air and Pushing Peas
description: MOVE over, Howard Stern! Here comes 13-year-old Evan Roberts, live from his bedroom in Woodmere, L.I.

title: Ain't Over Till It's Over: An Addict's Fight
description: THIS is no success story, at least not yet.

title: NEW JERSEY & CO.;More Arduous Than Childbirth, It's the Time to Pick a Swimsuit
description: Linda Basch brings me a bathing suit that she says has been working for women who want to attract attention, well, upward. No wonder. The bottom of the suit is plain black, but the top third is a wacky, bold, black-and-white checkerboard on a weird slant, somehow reminiscent of the Op Art movement of the 1960's. Well, maybe it works for some women, but the leg on this suit is cut so high that it reveals parts of my body I've never noticed -- probably because of strong psychological defense mechanisms.

title: Big Fish in an Obscure Pond
description: WITH his long dreadlocks, skin color and warm-weather roots, Jackson Richardson bears more than a passing resemblance to another French athlete who rose to the top of his profession.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;New Commissioner for the C.B.A.
description: The former Arizona State basketball coach STEVE PATTERSON will be appointed commissioner of the Continental Basketball Association, which may move its headquarters to Phoenix.

title: CHICAGO BUILDINGS;An Architect's Lab
description: To the Editor: After reading Mr. Goldberger's piece, I came away thinking that his analysis of the changes taking place on the Magnificent Mile lacks a true appropriation of the facts. I left Port Harcourt, Nigeria, in the early 80's to study architecture at the University of Illinois at Chicago. One requirement was to choose different sections of the city to sketch, dissect and analyze.

title: A Grungy Shocker on Heroin Comes Ashore
description: A FEW WEEKS AGO THE PARTnership for a Drug-Free America introduced its first national campaign aimed at fighting heroin. "You have a whole new group of young people who don't know the terror, the horror, the tragedy of heroin," explained Richard D. Bonnette, president of the organization.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Bearing the Torch for Art and Quarters
description: JENNIFER STEWART is poised in front of the bathroom mirror in her Brooklyn Heights apartment, primping and preening for another day at the office.

description: CITYWIDE Lighting Sparks For Tennis

title: Charges Are Lifted for a Boy, 6, In the Severe Beating of a Baby
description: A 6-year-old boy who had been charged with attempted murder in the severe beating of a month-old baby in April will not be facing assault charges in the near future, a judge ruled today.

description: * Ronnie Cooke Newhouse was named creative director at CRK Advertising, New York, the in-house agency of Calvin Klein Inc., succeeding Fabien Baron, who had handled those duties as a consultant and will continue as a consultant to Klein. Ms. Cooke Newhouse had most recently been vice president and creative director at the Barneys New York unit of Barney's Inc. * Peter M. Winter was named president of Cox Interactive Media, a new unit of Cox Enterprises Inc., Atlanta. He was vice president for market development at Cox Newspapers.

title: Stocks Decline in Tokyo
description: Stocks were trading lower here today. This morning, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 107.21 points, or half a percent, at 21,549.24. On Friday, the Nikkei fell by 236.13 points.

description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Rank a Perfect 10 After Sweeping the Orioles
description: Thousands of fans rose to their feet and hollered as John Wetteland secured two strikes on Jeff Zaun with two outs in the ninth inning, transforming Camden Yards into Yankee Stadium South for one more exhilarating moment. Some of the fans wielded brooms, sending a reminder to the shocked Orioles about how the Yankees were sweeping them into oblivion and maybe even out of the American League East race.

title: Luring Adults To the Movies In the Summer
description: Opening a movie is nerve-racking enough for a director. Opening a serious movie in the middle of a summer packed with hit films about alien invasions, impossible missions and nutty professors can be downright terrifying.

title: Warnaco to Buy Maker of Speedo
description: The Authentic Fitness Corporation, the maker of Speedo swimwear and fitness apparel, said today that it had agreed to be reacquired by Warnaco Group Inc. in a deal valued at $438.6 million.

title: Adopting Branch Libraries
description: At a time when libraries in many cities are withering from neglect, the New York Public Library is fighting to preserve and even expand its system through creative public-private partnerships. The partnerships are yielding marvelous results and deserve to be expanded.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Hearing on School Financing
description: The debate on how to pay for public education opens to the public this week. A hearing at Parsippany Hills High School in Parsippany on Wednesday will give residents of North Jersey a chance to comment on Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's latest court-ordered attempt to close the spending gap between rich and poor school districts.

title: Some of What Lawmakers and Pataki Agreed On
description: After months of intensifying arguments, flaring tempers and a high-stakes game of chicken in which all the players refused to blink, state lawmakers and Gov. George E. Pataki agreed on a broad array of New York legislation over two whirlwind weeks. These were some of the highlights:

title: BASEBALL;Mets' Offense Wins One After Bullpen Loses One
description: Amid their struggles, the Mets have shown resiliency this season. Despite their relative youth, they have the ability to quickly dispatch heartbreaking defeats and bounce back with renewed vigor and determination. That was the case during a long doubleheader against the Houston Astros yesterday afternoon at muggy Shea Stadium.

title: Storm Brews Along Shore: Amtrak Plans Alarm Boaters;Threat of Bridge Tie-ups Could Derail an Effort To Add Faster Trains
description: David J. Carol likes to take his son to Dad's Restaurant on Main Street here to sit on the deck and watch the Amtrak drawbridge over the Niantic River open for sailboats and fishing boats and close for trains.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-6

title: A G.O.P. Policy Meeting May Put Pressure on Dole
description: Citing the lack of an economic message in Bob Dole's Presidential campaign, some top Republicans are planning a policy meeting in an apparent effort to spur Mr. Dole into announcing and campaigning on a platform of tax cuts.

title: Power of School Board Secretary Emerges From Bureaucratic Shadows
description: Soon after Dr. Rudy Crew became Schools Chancellor in October, he began drafting a new organizational chart that he hoped would streamline the much-maligned bureaucracy at Board of Education headquarters in downtown Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a chart last Monday with an article about technology at the Olympic Games misidentified the company whose equipment verifies the identities of athletes by reading the contours of their hands. The company that developed that technology is Recognition Systems Inc. of Campbell, Calif., not Sensormatic Electronics Corporation of Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Many Turning to Internet for Aid With Suicide
description: Shirley Cline did not, herself, surf the Internet. She did not even own a computer. But when she flew to Michigan last week to die with Dr. Jack Kevorkian, Mrs. Cline, a cancer patient from Los Angeles, knew that the latest trend in the right-to-die movement -- the Internet -- was responsible for getting her there.

title: Turner Purchase Said to Hit Hurdle at F.T.C.
description: Staff members at the Federal Trade Commission have rejected a proposal from Time Warner Inc., Turner Broadcasting System Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc. in which the first two, when merged, would spin off the Time Warner stock owned by Tele-Communications into a new company, people close to the talks said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Brigadier Gen. Amadou Toumani Toure, known as the father of Mali's democracy, and Chief Bisi Ogunleye, a women's leader in Nigeria, have been named the winners of the Hunger Project's 10th annual Africa Prize for Leadership for the Sustainable End of Hunger.

title: Lawsuit Claims L.I. Town Shuts Out Minority Voters
description: The Federal Voting Rights Act was passed in 1965, but Samuel Prioleau, a retired high school teacher, says that the ballots of black residents of Hempstead, the most populous township in the United States, still do not count the way they should.

title: World News Briefs;Russians Keep Pressure On Villages in Chechnya
description: Russian troops blockaded several villages in southeastern Chechnya today, contending that rebel fighters are hiding in them.

title: OLYMPICS;The Swimmer Who United a Nation
description: She may have been Germany's richest and most famous teen-ager, but Franziska van Almsick was also its most jet-lagged. Her body arrived at the pool with Germany's other Olympic swimmers on Saturday morning, but her mind and her luggage were elsewhere.

title: Falling Yen Puts Car Makers In Japan in the Driver's Seat
description: For a decade after the dollar began its long slide in value against the yen in 1985, American auto makers and other manufacturers enjoyed a special form of protection from Japanese competitors, whose imported products became almost inexorably more expensive in the United States.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Bozell Worldwide Expands in Chicago
description: Bozell Worldwide, in its fifth acquisition in Chicago in two years, has agreed to buy the office there of Wells Rich Greene BDDP and merge it with the Bozell office in Chicago. Terms were not disclosed.

title: MEDIA: BROADCASTING;Television programmers return to box-office hits.
description: BY the time a hit movie reaches network television, it has already been through several thousand theaters, been rented on videocassettes a couple of million times and been shown on television to more than 25 million customers who pay for premium cable channels like HBO and Showtime.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;N.B.A. Giving Birth To 9-Figure Contract
description: Now top this. You're Gary Payton, feeling pretty good about an $85 million deal you've just agreed on to stay in Seattle, until Alonzo Mourning makes it feel like some kid's allowance after it is reported that he may become the first $100 million man in team sports with a seven-year, $105 million pact with the Miami Heat.

title: Corrections
description: An article on June 27 about an impending shortage of electricity in Connecticut misstated the distance that power lines serving the state will be allowed to stretch this summer when they are loaded to their limit (under heavy loads, the lines heat up and hang closer to the ground). They may be allowed to sag to as low as 25 feet above the ground, not within a few feet of the ground.

title: AUTO RACING;Six Killed in Racing Mishaps
description: The driver Jeff Krosnoff and a course worker were killed today in a crash at the Toronto Molson-Indy race. The accident ended the race, which was won by Adrian Fernandez of Mexico. Dr. Hugh Scully, the race's medical director, said Krosnoff and the worker, Gary Avrin, died instantly.

title: Who's a Nincompoop on Illegal Immigration?
description: To the Editor:

title: POP REVIEW;Happy Disorientation Under the Bridge
description: Vibration became almost tangible when Cultural Alchemy's Soundlab took over the Anchorage on Friday night, turning the tall brick vaults beneath the Brooklyn Bridge into 50-foot-high subwoofer enclosures. The event opened Creative Time's Music in the Anchorage series, which continues through July 27.

title: Saudis Find Car Used by Bombers of G.I.'s
description: The authorities have found the getaway car used by bombers who killed 19 American servicemen in Saudi Arabia last month, officials said today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;An Israeli Athlete Sets His Sights on a First Gold Medal for His Country
description: When the Israeli flag was raised in a welcoming ceremony at the Olympic Village today, Boris Polak knew he had finally arrived as an Olympian.

title: Official Is Charged With Driving Drunk
description: A deputy state corrections commissioner has been arrested for drunken driving, the police said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Publicis/Bloom Ends Bradlees Ties
description: Publicis/Bloom in New York and Bradlees Inc., the discount department store chain operating under Federal bankruptcy protection, are parting ways after a year. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: A Chill in Spain
description: Jose Maria Aznar won election as Spain's new Prime Minister last March in part by convincing voters that he had thoroughly modernized his right-of-center Popular Party, ridding it of all nostalgia for the anti-democratic practices of the Franco dictatorship. Now he will have to convince them once again following the heavy-handed firing of Spanish Television's New York bureau chief, Jose Martinez-Soler, and four other correspondents.

title: At Home Abroad;Enemy At Scarsdale
description: It is hard to imagine war coming to a place so bursting with prosperity and consumerism. Seoul is a city of 10 million now dotted with skyscrapers. Shoppers crowd colorful street markets and new shopping malls.

title: World News Briefs;Al Gore Meets in Moscow With Russian Premier
description: Vice President Al Gore, opening a three-day visit to Russia, met here today with Prime Minister Viktor S. Chernomyrdin to discuss economic reforms and the expansion of NATO.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;New Security for Parkers
description: After a spate of car thefts from the park-and-ride lot at the Vince Lombardi service area of the New Jersey Turnpike, New Jersey Transit has instituted new security measures. Starting today, the 700 commuters who drive to the Ridgefield lot to catch buses will have to show their parking stubs to a guard in a new booth before they can leave with their vehicles. Three cars were stolen from the lot last Monday, bringing the total for the last year to 24.

title: Battered by Labor's Ads, Republicans Strike Back
description: Four months before Election Day, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s advertising campaign has buffeted House Republicans from coast to coast, forcing them on the defensive on issues like Medicare and generating a fierce counterattack from Republicans and their allies that is expected to broaden in the weeks to come.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the campaign advertisements of Bob Dole and President Clinton referred incorrectly in some editions to the amount that the 4.3 cent increase in the Federal gasoline tax would probably cost an average family. It is $30 a year, not $360.

title: There Oughta Be a Law
description: Laws -- the theoretical variety, not those made by governments -- have been part of science since before Sir Isaac Newton, his apple and what became known as Newton's Law of Gravitation. But the practice among physicists of observing a phenomenon, creating a testable hypothesis, then sometimes elevating that hypothesis to a named law has become a popular hobby in other fields. For example, the laws of motion in physics have been joined by the laws of markets in economics.

title: Fred Pressman, Who Elevated Barneys New York, Dies at 73
description: Fred Pressman, the man who transformed Barneys New York from a men's discount suit shop into a repository of cutting edge designer fashions, died yesterday at his home in Harrison, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

title: Bridge
description: The most dramatic deal in the Eastern Regional Championships in May, and perhaps of the New York tournament year, occurred on the diagramed deal from the second round of the Reisinger Teams. West opened four hearts, which was not what his partner was hoping for, and when South balanced with four spades North tried five diamonds, a cue-bid suggesting a spade slam.

title: Patents;Computer code has kept at bay many people who wanted to create their own programs. No more.
description: As technology becomes increasingly user-friendly, products are evolving to allow people to make their computers work for them in ways that previously required an expert software programmer. Already, off-the-shelf kits let novices create World Wide Web home pages after clicking, dragging and dropping the right icons into place. No more need to learn HTML, or hypertext markup language.

title: DANCE REVIEW;The World Of Nature, Freshly Perceived
description: Nai-Ni Chen is the rare modern-dance choreographer who chooses nature as a frequent subject. Ms. Chen trained in traditional Chinese dance in her native Taiwan and has studied and taught modern dance in New York since 1982. The dances her impressive young company performed on Saturday night at the La Guardia High School theater as part of the Fiorello Summer Dance Festival stood out for their remarkably smooth blend of the new and the old, as well as for their confident, intensely personal approach to nature.

title: Cluttering the Constitution
description: To resist joining the bandwagon for a popular cause is not easy, especially for politicians in the midst of an election campaign. This helps to explain why both Bob Dole and Bill Clinton have endorsed a constitutional amendment to protect victims' rights. But political expediency is no excuse for altering the nation's bedrock charter before anyone understands the likely impact on either individual rights or the criminal justice system itself.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Browns and Fans, Together Again
description: Contrary to reports, the Cleveland Browns are still alive. The team may be in Baltimore, soon to play under an alias as the Ravens, but the spirit and the memories of the Browns remain in Ohio.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Listed below is a partial list of dividend meetings this week.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about a brawl after a boxing match at Madison Square Garden Thursday night referred incorrectly to Stephen Bowe, one of the men arrested. He is a nephew of the boxer Riddick Bowe, not his brother. He attended the bout as a spectator, not as a member of the boxer's ring entourage.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Rising Dollar Undercutting U.S. Business vs. Japanese As the dollar slid in value against the yen during the decade beginning in 1985, American manufacturers enjoyed a special form of protection from Japanese competitors, whose products became more expensive in the United States. But as the dollar now strengthens, the sheltered years are ending.

title: Modest Storm Was a Major TV Event
description: Bertha was far from the biggest hurricane of recent years, but anyone who turned on a television set anytime from Thursday morning to Saturday night may not have known that.

title: BASEBALL;Once Again, Sierra Sits and Stews
description: Ruben Sierra stared while a throng of reporters surrounded Darryl Strawberry's locker Saturday to quiz him about hitting two homers. Perhaps Sierra was envious. When a smaller group of reporters milled around Sierra's locker to ask about his struggles today, he shooed them away. Unlike Strawberry, the sullen Sierra was speechless.

title: From AIDS Conference, Talk of Life, Not Death
description: In San Francisco, as he picked up the newspaper each day last week, Armistead Maupin almost could not believe all the good news cascading south from the international AIDS conference in Vancouver, British Columbia.

title: Multiracial' Category May Address Only Fear
description: To the Editor:

title: Who's a Nincompoop on Illegal Immigration?
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE REVIEW;Sharing a Vision of an Untroubled Past
description: Removed From the Palace," the new work that was presented here on Friday night as part of the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival, honored both a great Asian dance form and the spirit of early modern dance.

title: Discussing the Roles Of the Other Clintons
description: Officials planning the Democratic National Convention in Chicago are debating the delicate issue of how to present the First Family.

title: COMPLICATIONS IN CARE -- A special report.;Patients With Difficult Illnesses Fight New H.M.O.'s to Get Help
description: Millions of New Yorkers have recently enrolled in H.M.O.'s, and most have slowly learned to navigate the system. But a growing number, mostly with chronic conditions or serious diseases, say they are being denied desperately needed care. And instead of battling their illness, they find themselves fighting with their health plans for permission to get treatment.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Property for Thomas Edison
description: New Jersey's virtual college is expanding into some very real real estate. Officials at Thomas Edison State College will break ground tomorrow on a $12.7 million project to turn a row of five historic town houses into headquarters for the school's electronic classrooms and training and conference centers. Thomas Edison, which calls itself a "distance learning school," has no regular classrooms. Rather, its 3,000 students, located in all 50 states and 65 foreign countries, take courses via computer, video and correspondence.

title: Storm Leaves North Carolina Farms in Ruin
description: Julian Williford, who is 77 years old and has been farming here since he was a boy, knelt this afternoon amid the uprooted stalks of what had been his tobacco crop. "It's pretty well ruined," he said.

title: Quiet Boomlet in Vehicles Using Compressed Natural Gas as Fuel
description: City sanitation trucks use it. Some Transit Authority buses use it. A few yellow cabs use it. New York City, not known as home to many an environmental movement, is riding a boomlet in vehicles that run on clean-burning compressed natural gas.

title: As Market Shifts, Bad Old Days Of Finding an Apartment Return
description: Finding a rental apartment in Manhattan has become as complicated as, and in many buildings and neighborhoods even more costly than, it was in the mid-to-late 1980's, when soaring rents and prices, sprouting condominium towers and co-op conversions helped define the character of an economic boom.

title: Local Operators Are Standing By;After the Bells and Their New Rivals Have It Out, Consumers Will Get an Earful
description: Competition is about to sweep into the local telephone business. But before consumers can savor the fruits, they will have to endure clamorous confusion as the phone companies squabble over all sorts of sticky issues -- not the least of which involves Velcro patches.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Accident Inquiry Continues
description: Authorities investigating how a car plunged off the fourth floor of a casino parking deck, killing two sisters from Brooklyn, will begin examining the car itself today. The sisters, Erna Martin, 77, and Gertrude Martin, 65, were killed on Thursday when their car crashed through a set of steel restraining cables in the Claridge Casino's new $27 million garage and fell 44 feet to the ground. The police, city building inspectors and the casino's engineers have spent four days inspecting the parking deck, which met all structural code requirements when it opened two weeks ago.

title: Mayor Finds Old Issue Emerging In New Way
description: For more than two decades, Atlanta was led by civil rights giants, men not just respected but revered among blacks for their service to the movement and their barrier-breaking elections.

title: More Angst for First Family: Convention Roles
description: Officials planning the Democratic national convention are debating two ticklish First Family issues: Should Hillary Rodham Clinton be given a prominent speaking role, despite the political controversies that surround her? And should Chelsea Clinton address the delegates, despite the Clintons' insistence on protecting their daughter from the spotlight?

title: U S West Has Rise in New-Service Orders
description: U S West Communications Inc. said it recorded record growth in new-service orders and new lines during the first half of 1996, while making strides in improving service.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Sports Illustrated and Nike hope girls just want to read about women's sports and female athletes.
description: THE Cyndi Lauper song "Girls Just Want to Have Fun" is becoming a marketing mantra for a leading media company and a large advertiser as they play up sales efforts aimed at young female athletes.

title: INSIDE
description: Taking Stock of Damages In Wake of Hurricane Bertha

title: In AmericA;Hidden Agenda
description: Dr. Elliott Vichinsky runs a large program at Children's Hospital in Oakland, Calif., that specializes in the treatment of two genetic blood disorders -- sickle-cell anemia, which occurs most often in black people, and thalassemia, which is frequently found in people of Mediterranean and Southeast Asian origin.

title: BOMBING OF HOTEL DIMINISHES HOPES FOR ULSTER PEACE
description: A luxury hotel here was ripped apart early this morning when a bomb in a silver-colored jeep exploded only moments after 250 guests and wedding party revelers were evacuated.

title: Bertha Brings Virgin Islands New Worries About Tourism
description: Still suffering from a storm that struck 10 months ago, damaging most homes and battering the tourism industry, the tiny islands of St. Thomas and St. John are reeling from the additional lashing they received from Hurricane Bertha, which hit here on Monday.

title: The Doctor's Call
description: The American Medical Association voted overwhelmingly recently to maintain its opposition to doctor-assisted suicide. It did so despite the fact that this spring, two Federal appeals courts brushed aside concerns about doctors' professional integrity to hold that assisted suicide is a constitutionally protected act in 12 states, including New York and California.

title: Belgrade Journal;In Yugoslavia, Traditional Gypsy Bands Play On
description: Brass instruments and snare drums dangling from black leather straps stretched across their chests, the musicians of the Unity Orchestra crept on tiptoe down a small, dimly lighted street in the Belgrade suburb of Zemun.

title: BASEBALL;Mets-Astros Loses Air Time
description: Now you see them, now you don't. Although WWOR Channel 9 was scheduled to televise both ends of yesterday's Mets-Astros doubleheader, the second game was knocked off the air by the length of the first one.

title: Pandro Berman, 91, a Producer of Classic Films
description: Late Edition - Final, the Hollywood producer whose films brought fame, fortune or both to Fred Astaire, Ginger Rogers and other stars and skilled entertainment to American filmgoers from the Depression Era through the 1960's, died on Saturday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 91.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Stravinsky's 'Rake' At New Jersey Festival
description: The Rake's Progress" met with cavils and questions when it first appeared in 1951. Had Stravinsky gone too far in his imitation of Baroque models? Did the libretto by W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman sacrifice dramatic force for satiric ingenuity? Despite all the second-guessing, the opera has tenaciously clung to the edges of the repertory, and it has been heard more often of late. Scattered flaws aside, it is one of relatively few completely viable operas in English, even if Stravinsky's musical personality keeps a curiously low profile.

title: Central Europe Is Newest Arena For Arms Race
description: On a hectic day in June when the Hungarian Parliament was debating a new constitution, Imre Mecs spent the morning listening to a sales pitch from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and American military officers. As the day ended, he hurried to a party organized, he thought, by Lockheed.

title: Girl Saved From Drowning
description: A child who wandered into the deep end of a pool in the Rockaways yesterday afternoon nearly drowned, but was rescued by lifeguards and revived at a nearby hospital.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING

title: Sports of the Times;Doors Opened and Closed at Meet
description: THEY called this the Gold Rush track meet, a final tuneup for world-class athletes before the Summer Games in Atlanta.

title: GOLF;British Open's Stern Course: 200 Bunkers, Nothing Fancy
description: The reigning United States Open champion stood on the ninth tee at Royal Lytham and St. Annes Golf Club, hard by the railroad tracks and just across from a red brick row of pensioners' homes, when the 2:30 train from Blackpool to Preston slowly rolled past.

title: Jerusalem Road Is Secular-Religious Battleground
description: When Avraham Cohen sits down with his family on Saturdays for a festive meal marking the Jewish Sabbath, he hears the hum of traffic passing under his porch on Jerusalem's busy Bar-Ilan Street.

title: HORSE RACING;Cigar Will Rest a Bit, Then Take On No. 17
description: They left as they had arrived two days earlier: sharing a horse van and a cargo airplane. But there was no greater study in contrasts than the one seen today between Cigar, who won again, and Unbridled's Song, who lost again.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;O'Donnell Is Seeking Winning Answers
description: For any other quarterback on any other team, the number would be an exaggeration. But Neil O'Donnell, the new quarterback of the Jets, seemed believable when he said: "I was asked the question a million times in the off season. How are the Jets going to do?"

title: Weatherproofing the Data When a Hurricane Blows
description: Nail plywood to windows. Hoard batteries. And now, a new ritual: Batten down the hard drive.

title: Mongolian Democracy Deserves U.S. Gesture
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Composer From Paris, A Premiere In the Rain
description: Unlike most outdoor music festivals, Summergarden, which performs in the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art, has never had a program completely washed out by rain. Joel Sachs, the artistic director of this adventurous series, wisely schedules two performances of each program on consecutive weekend nights.

title: POP REVIEW;On the Road to Spiritual Glam-Rock
description: It was clear that Porno for Pyros was finally finding a direction when they performed the first of two sold-out shows on Thursday night at Irving Plaza. Before forming the group four years ago, Perry Farrell had built up a large fan base as the leader of the alternative-rock stalwarts Jane's Addiction and a founder of the Lollapalooza traveling festival. But Porno for Pyros' self-titled debut recording was feeble, with Mr. Farrell's high-pitched voice wailing over the most generic of rock backdrops. On its new album, "Good God's Urge" (Warner Brothers) the music gets atmospheric, experimental and interesting. In concert it became clear that the band was pioneering a stylistic mish-mash all its own: spiritual glam-rock.

title: Market Place;Viacom's High Hopes Turn Disappointing
description: Last week, Viacom Inc. joined an illustrious list of companies that have won dubious awards at the annual media conference held by Allen & Company, the investment banking firm. The award: worst-performing media stock of the year.

title: Teamsters Chief Expects Convention Challenges
description: Five years ago, Ron Carey, a former United Parcel Service driver from Queens, barnstormed the country in an old green Chevrolet with a bodyguard at the wheel. It seemed a quixotic campaign to take control of the mob-infested teamsters' union, then, like now, the biggest in the A.F.L.-C.I.O.

title: Barnum Didn't Say It
description: To the Editor:

title: Low Price in British Energy Privatization
description: The British Government learned today that it would receive L1.41 billion, or $2.19 billion, from a sell-off of most of Britain's nuclear power plants -- barely half what it expected when it announced the sale plan in March. BZW Securities, the stockbrokers acting for the Government, said individual Britons who applied for shares in British Energy P.L.C. would pay a total of 198 pence, or $3.08, a share, and institutional investors 203 pence, or $3.15, both in two stages. Trading in the shares begins Monday.

title: Buchanan Sees A Perot Danger
description: Another Ross Perot campaign for the Presidency poses a "mortal threat" to Bob Dole's chances of winning the November election, Patrick J. Buchanan said today.

title: Chirac, Resolute on Austerity Plan, Marks Bastille Day With Cake
description: Marking his second Bastille Day today as President of France, Jacques Chirac told his disgruntled compatriots that, in effect, they couldn't have their cake and eat it, too -- that years of high deficit spending and mismanagement meant that they would have to sweat through high unemployment and high taxes to pay off accumulated deficits for at least another year before recovery set in.

title: Lloyd's Says Most States Support Settlement
description: Lloyd's of London said yesterday that regulators in states representing 84 percent of its American investors had agreed to a proposal under which they would drop lawsuits in which they contended that the insurance market had deceived them about the risk of their investments.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Productive Dead End, An Escape by Computer
description: AFTER THOUGHT The Computer Challenge to Human Intelligence By James Bailey Illustrated. 277 pages. Basic Books/HarperCollins. $25.

title: Disney Park To Celebrate California
description: The Walt Disney Company will disclose as early as Monday its plans to invest at least $1 billion in a new theme park next to Disneyland in Anaheim, a city councilman said this weekend.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;New Yorker Goes to Deutsch
description: The New Yorker magazine, owned by Advance Publications, has named Deutsch Inc. in New York to create a trade campaign. Billings were not disclosed. The print and outdoor campaign, which is scheduled for early fall, will focus on "the impact of The New Yorker, what happens when something appears in the magazine," said Thomas A. Florio, president of The New Yorker. The magazine has not run a trade campaign for more than two years. Its most recent previous agency of record was the Ammirati Puris Lintas unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, which conducted research for The New Yorker in 1995.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the expected release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: Bitter Newspaper Strike Grinds On in Detroit
description: A heavy bronze plaque hangs above the Coke machine in the lobby of the Detroit Teamsters headquarters here on Trumbull Avenue, up the road from Tiger Stadium. It memorializes the locals that built the glazed yellow-brick building in 1941, and the Newspaper Drivers and Handlers Local 327 is one of them.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;It's a Blockbuster Day for Knicks
description: Five years ago, with trade rumors swirling and his contract extension in the balance, Patrick Ewing was persuaded to stay in New York. The promise from management went something like this: If you stay, we will put people around you who can play.

title: Perelman Deal for King World Is Expected
description: After months of on-again, off-again negotiations, New World Communications Group Inc., the broadcasting company, is set to acquire King World Productions Inc., the production company that distributes "The Oprah Winfrey Show," "Jeopardy" and "Wheel of Fortune," according to several people close to the discussions.

title: POP REVIEW;Irreverent Folkies in Back-Porch Jam
description: Sometimes it seems as if history was unfair to the Holy Modal Rounders, whose members Peter Stampfel and Steve Weber reunited on Friday night at the Bottom Line. In the 60's and 70's, the Holy Modal Rounders circulated in New York's music and art underground along with bands like the Fugs, playing psychedelic, irreverent leftist folk abstractions that were as warped as they were musically learned.

title: Offerings Expected This Week For Equity and Convertible Debt
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: THEATER REVIEW;An Eternal Child, Sadder but Little Wiser
