description: Buried in the third act of "A Thousand Clowns," Herb Gardner's 1962 paean to noncomformity, is a line that barely registers in the revival of the play at the Roundabout Theater. But that one sentence, a short and devastating question, provides a key to a listless, strangely elegiac interpretation of what is fondly remembered as a buoyant, madcap comedy.

title: V.M.I. Board Won't Rush Coeducation
description: The governing board of the Virginia Military Institute voted this weekend to develop a plan to admit women, but rebuffed a member who argued that women should be let in immediately.

title: Treasury Offering Only Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the bills market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. On Thursday the Treasury will auction a one-year bill.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The actor Gregory Peck has undergone surgery for appendicitis in the Czech spa town of Karlovy Vary.

title: When Bonds, Lawyers and Politicians Meet
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Survey Finds World Rich-Poor Gap Widening
description: In the wake of reports that gaps between rich and poor in the United States are wider than they have been in half a century, a United Nations survey to be published on Wednesday finds that the phenomenon is worldwide, and that the wealthiest and poorest people -- both within and among countries -- are living in increasingly separate worlds.

title: No Headline
description: It's the first time labor's been truly relevant politically in at least a decade or a decade and a half." CHARLES COOK, political analyst. [A8:1]

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;U S West Media To Kirshenbaum
description: U S West Interactive Services, a division of the U S West Media Group in Englewood, Colo., has named Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York to handle its account, which had been handled on a project basis by Rubin Postaer & Associates in Santa Monica, Calif. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $10 million. The decision came after a five-week review that had been narrowed to Kirshenbaum Bond; the CKS Partners unit of the CKS Group in Portland, Ore., and I-Mark in New York, owned by Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

title: Robert Ellis Dunn, 67, a Pioneer In Postmodern Dance Movement
description: Robert Ellis Dunn, whose classes in improvisation and choreography were the laboratory in which postmodernist dance was born in the early 1960's, died on July 5 at his home in New Carrollton, Md. He was 67.

title: TV SPORTS;A Surreal Moment With Samaranch
description: The interview was over. Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, had spent a bizarre half-hour with Frank Deford of Home Box Office's "Real Sports." He called the Olympics "more important than the Catholic religion," excused his bestowal of Olympic honors on murderous dictators, like Nicolae Ceausescu of Romania, because they advanced the "Olympic movement," and argued that Atlanta's weather was like Barcelona's.

title: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Should an extension of current copyright law, tweaked a bit, govern the Internet?
description: YET another new Internet law, this one governing copyright on the global computer network, has found its way into the legislative sausage grinder on Capitol Hill. But it looks as though this one might not make it into the frying pan any time soon.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Fine in Tree Trimmer's Death
description: In February, a tree trimmer named Robert Spear died when he came into contact with a 13,000-volt wire. Now Mr. Spear's employer, the Downes Tree Service of Woodcliff Lake, has been fined $4,000 by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, The Associated Press reported. The agency found that the accident could have been prevented if the crew had followed Federal regulations and stayed at least 10 feet from the live wire. The OSHA report, which was released last week, also faulted the company for not providing a safety rope for Mr. Spear, who was hoisted 50 feet above the ground by a crane as he attempted to prune a tree.

title: Metro Matters;Cab Partitions: Helping Driver But Not Rider
description: THE anecdotal evidence is so convincing that emergency room doctors want to start keeping records, insurance premiums are going up and the relevant city commissioner says there ought to be a law.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;16 Arrests at Greekfest
description: There were 16 arrests, and parking, as always, was in short supply, but the Greekfest -- a large beach party sponsored by members of black college fraternities -- went off without major problems yesterday.

title: POP REVIEW;Bill Laswell Moves Indoors, Taking Diversity With Him
description: When Tropical Storm Bertha thwarted a concert by Bill Laswell and the Axiom All-Stars in Central Park on Saturday, the producers of Summerstage moved the show downtown, to the Knitting Factory at 1 A.M. on Sunday. Mr. Laswell's fans packed the club, since he rarely performs outside the recording studio.

title: Pushing Free Speech Too Far
description: The current Supreme Court is the fiercest defender of the First Amendment in the Court's history. None of the great names in First Amendment theory -- Holmes, Brandeis, Black, Douglas, Brennan -- ever sat on a Court so protective of speech.

title: Another Airline Safety Challenge
description: The National Transportation Safety Board has put most of the blame for the October 1994 crash of an American Eagle turboprop on the French manufacturer and French aviation officials. According to the board, the French failed to share developing knowledge of the unusual effects of freezing rain and drizzle on the airliner at low altitudes. Stuck in a holding pattern near Chicago, the plane went down in an Indiana bean field, killing all 68 people aboard, after ice on its its wings forced it to spin violently out of control.

title: ON PRO BASKETBALL;Quick as 1-2-3, the Knicks Grab A Shot at a Third Championship
description: Good things have been happening for the Knicks lately, and in packages of three.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Trial of Police Chief to Begin
description: The misconduct trial of the suspended West Orange Police Chief, Robert A. Spina, begins tomorrow in Superior Court in Newark. Chief Spina is accused of alerting a suspect in 1991 that she was the target of a drug and child abuse investigation. Chief Spina, the son of the West Orange Mayor, Sam Spina, had also been charged with assaulting his wife and condoning a harassment campaign against his predecessor. Prosecutors had sought to try him on all of the charges, but a judge partially dismissed two of the three indictments in April on procedural grounds. Prosecutors are seeking to refile the dismissed charges.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: Youth Is Killed Riding on Roof Of Subway Car In the Bronx
description: A young man who was "subway surfing" by riding atop a No. 2 train in the Bronx early yesterday was killed when he hit a signal light and was hurled onto the tracks, the police said.

title: For Pataki, Success Hinges on an Evolving Agenda
description: As the 1996 legislative year staggered to a close Saturday afternoon, Gov. George E. Pataki unfolded his lanky frame behind a Capitol podium and proclaimed that, for all the session's record-setting delays and partisan rancor, he still felt deeply satisfied because he and his administration had "stuck to our principles."

title: Taking In the Sites;Each Fed Web Site Has Its Own Form and Flavor
description: The secretive Federal Reserve, for decades the arbiter of monetary policy and regulator of banks, has recently undertaken a new and very public sideline: developing sites on the World Wide Web.

title: Odd Allies in Song Royalties Battle
description: On Capitol Hill, curious alliances between interest groups are common, but none is more curious than that of religious broadcasters and owners of bars and restaurants, who are fighting together to reduce the royalties they pay to songwriters.

title: An Inkblot in Every Pot, or Something
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Say Musician's Death Leads to Run on Heroin Brand
description: As the police investigate an apparent heroin overdose that killed a keyboard player on tour with the rock band Smashing Pumpkins, narcotics investigators said yesterday that word of the musician's death had caused a strange -- but increasingly common -- ripple effect on the Lower East Side's heroin trade.

title: Technology's Growth Is a Challenge to Systems Managers
description: Corporate computer specialists are running as fast as they can -- and it is still not fast enough. And the way Frank Calabrese sees it, the World Wide Web is the culprit.

title: SOCCER;World's Best Delight a Record Crowd at Giants Stadium
description: Memories of the World Cup were revived for soccer aficionados this afternoon at Giants Stadium, where a crowd of 78,416 -- a record for any sporting event here -- and a television audience in 120 countries watched a doubleheader.

title: Capitalist Tools Benefit Ukraine Collectives
description: Across Ukraine, great plains of tall, tawny wheat are ripening under hot skies and gentle breezes in what was once the breadbasket of the Soviet Union.

title: World News Briefs;Fatal Shootout Reported At Libyan Soccer Match
description: At least 20 people were killed last week at a soccer match in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, after bodyguards loyal to the sons of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, fired at spectators who were shouting hostile slogans, diplomats said today.

title: Clinton Officials Back Broadcasters On Advanced TV
description: Technology advisers in the Clinton Administration have sided with broadcasters and consumer electronics makers and against major computer companies, strongly endorsing the broadcasters' preferred technology format as the standard for the next generation of television.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WELLS FARGO AND LOOMIS FORMING ARMORED CAR COMPANY
description: The Borg-Warner Security Corporation agreed yesterday to merge its Wells Fargo Armored Service unit with Loomis Armored Inc., a unit of closely held Wingate Partners, to create an armored car security company with $350 million in annual revenue. Borg-Warner and shareholders of Loomis Armored would each own 50 percent of the yet-to-be-named company, which would provide armored transportation, cash services and automated teller machine maintenance. It would employ 8,500 people.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;3 Times Holy and Still a Battlefield
description: JERUSALEM One City, Three Faiths By Karen Armstrong Illustrated. 471 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: Applegate in Eden
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Doctor Sentenced in Abuse
description: A doctor from East Brunswick was sentenced to six months in jail yesterday and ordered to pay $9,000 in fines for molesting nine female patients between 1987 and 1990. Frank Graves, an assistant prosecutor for Middlesex County, said that Dr. Benjamin Levine, 55, got some of the women to grope him during examinations. Dr. Levine was convicted in May.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: GOLF;Watson Will Miss British Open
description: Tom Watson, the American golfer who is an adopted son of the old sod, will not be competing in the 125th British Open when it begins at Royal Lytham and St. Annes Golf Club Thursday.

title: Equestrians and Opera in Next Wave Festival '96
description: The 14th Next Wave Festival is to include the premieres of dance pieces by Karole Armitage, Meryl Tankard, Sankai Juku and Donald Byrd as well as recent operas by Philip Glass and Meredith Monk, theater pieces by Robert Lepage and Wole Soyinka and performances by the Kronos Quartet, the Trisha Brown Company and the Brooklyn Philharmonic. The schedule for the festival, which runs from September to December, was announced by Harvey Lichtenstein, the president and executive producer of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Counties Lose on Medicaid
description: A state appeals court yesterday turned down a request by 14 counties to share in a windfall the state is getting as reimbursement for treating the poor at psychiatric hospitals and residential homes for the mentally disabled. Because of a rules change, the Federal Government has agreed to pay New Jersey $816 million for patients who were previously ineligible for Medicaid, The AP reported. The court wrote that it would be "impermissible judicial intrusion" for judges to intervene in a dispute between the counties and the state.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Gasoline Jumps as Supplies Are Drawn to the West Coast
description: Gasoline prices jumped on the New York Mercantile Exchange Yesterday on indications that surging prices on the West Coast were drawing supply away from East Coast markets.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;More Arrests Expected In Fracas at Garden
description: The State Athletic Commission said yesterday that it expected more arrests by the New York City police in the wake of last week's melee at Madison Square Garden that followed the RIDDICK BOWE-ANDREW GOLOTA bout.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Times and NBC in a Program Venture
description: Saturday evenings of the Sunday issue of The Times on the new cable news channel MSNBC, the two organizations announced yesterday.

title: POP REVIEW;Playfully Wondering at Life's Quirks
description: Casualness reached some kind of apotheosis at the Bottom Line on Sunday night, in a tribute to the songwriter Vic Chesnutt that was also a benefit for the Sweet Relief Foundation and part of the Macintosh New York Music Festival. With Victoria Williams as host, everyone seemed to take his time, playing songs as if the tunes were jerry-built and just about to come apart. Actually, the songs were sturdy, while the performances echoed Mr. Chesnutt's vision of life as wondrous and arbitrary.

title: Dole's Sagging Campaign Affects G.O.P. Morale, Poll Finds
description: Former Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign has stumbled so badly that 7 in 10 Americans -- and nearly half of those who say they plan to vote for Mr. Dole in November -- expect him to lose to President Clinton.

title: Buckle Up -- in the Taxi, Too
description: For years safety-minded New Yorkers have urged taxi passengers to wear seat belts, given that violent stops are a fairly common feature in city traffic. A 1994 law that required bulletproof partitions between passengers and drivers has made seat belts more vital than ever.

title: TENNIS;Garrison Jackson Toughs It Out
description: Zina Garrison Jackson has not played much tennis this year. And after beating Erica O'Neill, 6-2, 7-5, in the first round of the A&P Tennis Classic today, she said she felt the effects of the time off.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Drechsler, Injured, Withdraws From Long Jump
description: Jackie Joyner-Kersee's chances of winning the Olympic long jump title improved considerably today when the defending champion, Heike Drechsler of Germany, withdrew because of a knee injury.

title: A Catholic Protester Is Mourned in Ulster
description: Under a leaden sky thousands of Catholic mourners gathered on a bluff overlooking the Catholic slums of Bogside today, assembled for the funeral service of the sole victim of a week of street violence in Northern Ireland.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Plans for Chip Plant In Britain by Hyundai
description: The Hyundai Electronics Industries Company of South Korea said yesterday that it had decided to build a European chip plant in Britain, perhaps in Dunfermline, Scotland, where its executives have visited.The $1.3 billion plant would make memory chips. But Hyundai has not made a final decision to go ahead with the plant.

title: Japanese Schools Struck by Food Poisoning
description: An outbreak of food poisoning attributed to school lunches has left nearly 4,000 Japanese children ill and forced widespread cancellation of classes.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Quake Hits Mexico City And a Resort Region
description: A strong earthquake struck southern Mexico today, shaking the capital and frightening tourists in Pacific resorts but causing no casualties, the authorities said.

title: Museums Getting Together to Track Stolen Art
description: In a drive against the booming trade in stolen art, world cultural groups, police agencies and insurance experts are drafting a simple new standard to help track lost masterworks and antiquities.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PENTLAND TO VOTE AGAINST AUTHENTIC FITNESS DEAL
description: Pentland Group P.L.C., the largest shareholder of the Authentic Fitness Corporation, said yesterday that it would vote against Warnaco Group Inc.'s proposed acquisition of Authentic Fitness for $400 million in stock. London-based Pentland, which holds a 23 percent stake in the swimwear and exercise-clothing maker, said Warnaco's offer did not reflect the company's growth potential. Authentic Fitness is the licensee for Pentland's Speedo swimwear brand in North America, Mexico and the Caribbean. Warnaco, a maker of intimate apparel based in New York, offered to exchange 0.82 share of its stock for each share of Authentic Fitness. Warnaco's stock fell $2.125, to $22, while Authentic Fitness's stock closed unchanged at $17.25.

title: ATLANTA 1996: 3 DAYS TO GO;It's Official: North Korean Flag Is Raised
description: In their blue blazers and white golf hats, North Korea's two dozen Olympic athletes were welcomed into the Olympic Village today, confirming that the final nation to accept a bid to compete in the Atlanta Games will actually participate.

title: Thomas Sandefur, Tobacco Leader, Dies at 56
description: Thomas E. Sandefur Jr., a dedicated and unapologetic tobacco salesman who, as chairman of the Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation testified before Congress that he did not believe nicotine was addictive, died on Sunday at Baptist Hospital East in Louisville, Ky. He was 56.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Irvin Given Probation In Plea Deal
description: Dallas Cowboys receiver Michael Irvin pleaded no contest today to a felony charge of cocaine possession, striking a deal that allows him to avoid a jail sentence but could make him subject to suspension by the National Football League.

title: Torricelli Outstrips Zimmer in Fund Raising
description: In what is expected to be one of the most expensive and closely contested United States Senate races this year, Representative Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic candidate for the seat being vacated by Senator Bill Bradley, reported having more than twice as much money on hand as his Republican rival, Representative Richard A. Zimmer.

title: Lloyd's Wins Voting On Recovery Plan
description: Thousands of investors in Lloyd's of London gave their resounding support today to a landmark recovery plan that virtually guaranteed the insurance market's survival.

title: New Plan to Save the L.I. Shore Is Announced
description: After almost every major storm of the last 10 years, Congressmen have been holding news conferences on the beach here to promise tens of millions of dollars that never materialize to restore the receding dunes and battered jetties.

title: Budget Agency Says Welfare Bill Would Cut Rolls by Millions
description: The Congressional Budget Office said today that a new Republican welfare bill moving quickly through both houses of Congress could eventually cut the Federal welfare rolls by 30 percent to 40 percent.

title: BASEBALL;Mendoza Hit Hard As Yanks Skip a Beat
description: If the Yankees could not avoid a so-called letdown behind their No. 1 starter, Andy Pettitte, the last time they faced this situation, they could not reasonably have expected their No. 5 starter, Ramiro Mendoza, to get them past it tonight.

title: Bosnia Election Campaign Postponed Over Karadzic Issue
description: The Western diplomat in charge of overseeing the coming Bosnian elections today postponed the start of the campaign until Friday, to give the Bosnian Serbs a few more days to oust their political leader, Radovan Karadzic.

title: Friends' Cast Bands Together To Demand a Salary Increase
description: The entire six-member cast of "Friends," the NBC series that is television's third-highest rated show, has decided to hold out for a salary increase from their production studio, Warner Brothers, executives familiar with the demands said yesterday.

title: Observer;Hotness, Hemlock . . .
description: All right, you few precious doomed printheads out there, once again it is time for our annual do-it-yourself column day. The following material, lifted verbatim -- complete with headlines! -- from our file of potentially great column ideas, points you toward the subject. All you have to do is write the column. Then read it to several friends. Then send yourself some abusive or flattering letters. Let's go: What Is This Thing Called Heat?

title: COMPANY NEWS;NORTH FORK TO ACQUIRE NORTH SIDE SAVINGS BANK
description: North Fork Bancorp said yesterday that it would buy North Side Savings Bank for $210 million in stock, continuing its string of acquisitions in New York City and the Long Island suburbs. North Side agreed to the acquisition after vowing to resist a takeover by New York Bancorp. North Side, based in Floral Park, L.I., has 17 branches on Long Island and in Queens and the Bronx. It had assets of $1.7 billion at the end of June. North Fork, based in Melville, L.I., agreed to pay 1.556 share for each North Side share, bringing the offer price to $42.79 a share at Friday's closing price. North Side's shares jumped $3.25, to $38.50, in Nasdaq trading. North Fork's shares slipped 87.5 cents, to $25.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Oklahoma Will Get Closed-Circuit View Of Trial in Bombing
description: A Federal judge today approved a closed-circuit television broadcast of the Oklahoma City bombing trial from the courtroom in Denver to a limited audience in Oklahoma City.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Molinari Chosen as Keynoter
description: Bob Dole has chosen an abortion rights supporter, Representative Susan Molinari of Staten Island, to give the keynote address to the Republican National Convention. Woman in the News, page A15.

title: Albany Shifts Fiscal Burden of Train and Bus Improvements to Riders
description: The New York Legislature approved a striking change last weekend in the way subway, bus and commuter railroad improvements are paid for, shifting the burden from government to riders and relying heavily on borrowed money, which critics say will lead to sharply higher fares in a few years.

title: A Third Person Is Shot Dead Near Double-Murder Scene
description: With police officers swarming around the scene of a double murder in an East Harlem housing complex, a brazen gunman fired two bullets yesterday point-blank into the chest of another man, killing him just 40 feet from police barricades. Investigators said the three slayings might have been connected.

title: SOCCER REPORT
description: Major League Soccer

title: No Headline
description: What we are trying to do is create an environment where girls can flourish. Talk to any young woman and they will tell you that what the school culture teaches you is, 'Don't be too smart, or certainly don't be smarter than the boys.' "

title: New Approach Needed to U.S.-Cuba Relations;Shades of McCarthyism
description: To the Editor:

title: Banker Testifies He Offered to Finance House for the Clintons
description: Herby Branscum Jr., a defendant in the second trial brought by Whitewater prosecutors, testified today that he offered to finance a new home in Arkansas for Bill and Hillary Rodham Clinton shortly before they went to Washington in 1993 for the Presidential inauguration.

title: A Missed Chance On Civil Rights
description: In spurning an invitation to address the N.A.A.C.P.'s annual convention last week, Bob Dole missed an opportunity to deliver an unfiltered message to African-American voters about his lifelong commitment to inclusion, fairness and equal opportunity for all Americans. As a policy adviser to the Dole campaign, I wish Republican strategists would stop running away from African-American voters.

title: Giuliani Leads Contributions
description: Widely outpacing his potential Democratic rivals, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has raised $1.6 million in campaign contributions in the last six months, according to reports filed yesterday with the Campaign Finance Board.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Mother Accused of Assault
description: A Newark woman was charged with aggravated assault yesterday after shoving her 9-year-old daughter through a department store window, the police said. The 30-year-old woman, who was not identified by the police, got off a bus at Broad and Market Streets with her three children and discovered that $900 she had hidden in her baby's diaper bag was missing, Sgt. Derek Glenn said. After reporting the loss to a police officer, the woman accused the 9-year-old of losing the money and pushed her through a window at the CiCi Department Store, Sergeant Glenn said. The girl was in stable condition at University Hospital with multiple cuts.

title: Tokyo, Where Streets Are Noodles
description: The emergency call sent Hisaharu Endo and his ambulance team racing through the city the other day, and they quickly found the caller's street. The problem was that all 15 homes on the lane have exactly the same address.

title: Forget Money; Nothing Can Buy Happiness, Some Researchers Say
description: WHEN it comes to that quintessential American passion, the pursuit of happiness, the news from science is mixed. The good news is that the sting of life's slings and arrows is surprisingly short. The bad news is for vacationers: the mellow glow from a week or two away will fade just as surely.

title: Judge Clears 2 Officers of Rape; Prosecutor Cites Lack of Jury
description: A judge acquitted two New Rochelle, N.Y., police officers yesterday of charges that they raped a police dispatcher almost a year ago, prompting the Westchester County District Attorney to assert that prosecutors should have a say when defense lawyers seek to have a case heard without a jury.

title: A POWER STRUGGLE IS SEEN AS YELTSIN ENTERS SANITARIUM
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin today heightened alarm about his health and gave new impetus to a power struggle in the Kremlin when he abruptly left Moscow for a sanitarium.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;China Asserts It Curbs Inflation but Not Robust Growth
description: After three years of tight monetary policy, China has sharply cut inflation without slowing the robust growth rate of its economy, an achievement that few economists thought possible when credit was tightened in July 1993, economic officials asserted today.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Disaster Recovery: There's a Catch
description: CATCH 95, the pretzel logic that occasionally trips up users of America's best-selling operating system, continues to blossom in unexpected ways. One of the least amusing involves the question of what may happen if your hard drive or Windows 95 itself fails catastrophically.

title: COMPANY NEWS;F.D.A. PANEL APPROVES ABBOTT'S SCHIZOPHRENIA DRUG
description: Abbott Laboratories' new drug to treat schizophrenia won the backing of a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel yesterday. The panel found that the drug was effective in treating the psychotic symptoms of schizophrenia. It also found the drug was safe, by a 4-to-2 vote. Earlier, the F.D.A. staff had raised concerns about potential heart problems that could be caused by the drug, known as Serlect or sertindole. Several committee members said the drug's label should reflect the agency's safety concerns. Still, committee members said the drug should be available to schizophrenics who desperately need new treatment options. Shares of Abbott, based in Abbott Park, Ill., fell 75 cents, to $43.50. Schizophrenia affects about 2.5 million Americans and about 20 million people worldwide.

title: New Approach Needed to U.S.-Cuba Relations
description: To the Editor:

title: New Approach Needed to U.S.-Cuba Relations
description: To the Editor:

title: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;Discussing Possible AIDS Cure Raises Hope, Anger and Question: What Exactly Is Meant by 'Cure'?
description: Can AIDS be cured?

title: PRO FOOTBALL;For Brown, Off Season Was No Vacation
description: There may be no quarterback in the National Football League who worked harder in the off season than the Giants' Dave Brown. He has done everything except eat footballs for breakfast and sleep with game film under his pillow. And who knows, maybe that's next.

title: Lester Robbins, 90, Who Built Row Houses for Public Housing
description: Lester Robbins, a developer of tract housing in the United States after World War II who became a moving force in Brooklyn's highly praised Nehemiah Plan of the 1980's, died on Sunday at his home on Manhattan's Upper East Side. He was 90 and also lived in East Hampton, L.I., and Lantana, Fla.

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNITED DOMINION RAISES OFFER FOR COMMERCIAL INTERTECH
description: United Dominion Industries raised its offer yesterday to buy the stock of the Commercial Intertech Corporation to $30 a share from $27 a share. Including the assumption of debt, United Dominion, a building products maker based in Charlotte, N.C., put the value of its new offer at $550 million. On Friday, Commercial Intertech advised its stockholders to reject United Dominion's offer to acquire their shares and reaffirmed two moves designed to raise the price of its stock: a buyback of 2.5 million shares and the spinoff of its Cuno filtration unit. Commercial Intertech, based in Youngstown, Ohio, makes hydraulic components, building systems and fluid purification systems.

title: Sports of The Times;Gymnastics Draws Crowd For Training
description: THE athletes strode into the arena for their final training session and they heard the buzz of the crowd. This is not the normal way gymnasts train for big events -- but they could grow to love it.

title: REPUBLICAN ALLIES EXPRESS WORRIES ON DOLE CAMPAIGN
description: Bob Dole's run of difficulties has begun to stir concern among some of his most steadfast supporters, who are now worrying aloud that Mr. Dole has yet to find and articulate the central theme of his Presidential campaign. They say they are also concerned that he has allowed himself to be tied up in tangential disputes that have cast him in an unfavorable light.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Battaglia Joins Bengals
description: The Cincinnati Bengals signed three of their draft choices, including their second-round pick, MARCO BATTAGLIA, as the team opened summer training camp yesterday.

title: East Meets West Meets Queens;Buddhist Temple Ministers to a Growing Thai Population
description: The Thai Buddhist monk measured how far he had journeyed from Bangkok when, on a wintry morning, a police officer stopped him outside his temple in Elmhurst, Queens. Staring at the monk's shaved head and flimsy saffron robe, the officer advised him to put on a hat and gloves.

title: HORSE RACING;Unbridled's Song Suffered Cracked Bone in Race
description: In yet one more misadventure in his troubled career, Unbridled's Song suffered a clean crack in the splint bone in his left foreleg Saturday while trying to catch Cigar in the Arlington Citation Challenge, and he will finally be forced to take the long rest that racing people are convinced he should have taken three months ago.

title: Seen From a Rut, the Lottery Is Essential
description: To the Editor:

title: Pataki Allies To Give Data On Donations
description: A State Supreme Court justice today ordered fund-raisers for Gov. George E. Pataki's inauguration and transition to release their financial records, and after 18 months of resisting such demands, the Governor's supporters said they would comply within 40 days.

title: Merrill Is Told to Pay Broker $2.1 Million
description: Merrill Lynch & Company must pay $2.1 million to a former commodities broker who contended that the brokerage firm defamed her.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Women's Concerns at the Fore
description: Although a record number of women will compete in the Atlanta Olympics, the absence of female competitors from 35 nations has drawn concern from one human rights organization.

title: TV SPORTS;Viewers Stay Tuned To Nightmarish Rout
description: What motivation exists to endure a 128-62 Dream Team rout? What was behind a 4.6 overnight Nielsen rating for Sunday afternoon's devastation of Greece?

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Huge Deal Tilting O'Neal to Magic
description: Heads in Los Angeles were hanging about as low as smog yesterday, with those inside the Lakers' organization beginning to think that location, location, location may not lure Shaquille O'Neal to Hollywood.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: McLEOD INC., Cedar Rapids, Iowa, a provider of local and long-distance telecommunications services, said it would acquire Ruffalo, Cody & Associates Inc., also of Cedar Rapids, for $21 million in cash and stock.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Coca-Cola Reports Profit Was Up 17% in 2d Quarter
description: Buoyed not only by its growing share in international markets and its high-margin sales of concentrate syrup but also its high-profile advertising in preparation for the Centennial Olympic Games, the Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday that its profits had soared 17 percent during the second quarter.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks traded sharply lower here today. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed down 347.07 points, or 1.06 percent, to 21,406.35.

title: BOXING;U.S. Boxer Is Haunted By a Case Of Assault
description: When Lawrence Clay-Bey was confronted last month by reports of his involvement in a sexual assault case, he was stunned and puzzled. One month before he thought he would be fighting for a superheavyweight gold medal in the Atlanta Olympics, his world was spinning. He talked to his parents. He met with Al Mitchell, the coach of the United States Olympic boxing team. He fretted that everything he had worked for was slipping out of his grasp.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Siemens Posts 17% Rise In Profits for 9 Months
description: Siemens A.G., the German electronics company, said yesterday that its profits rose about 17 percent in the nine months that ended on June 30, helped by strong international sales that offset lower sales in Germany. Siemens said it earned 1.65 billion marks ($1.08 billion) on sales of 64.5 billion marks, up from a profit of 1.41 billion marks on sales of 60.2 billion marks in the corresponding period last year. Siemens said its foreign sales rose by 15 percent, while German sales fell 2.7 percent. The Siemens communications and automotive businesses led the growth.

title: Grahamstown Journal;With Apartheid Done For, What's a Festival to Do?
description: It seems appropriate that the headquarters of Africa's biggest arts festival looks like a fortress.

title: Canada Strike Against G.M. Called 'Likely' By Union Chief
description: The president of the Canadian Automobile Workers said today that a strike against the General Motors Corporation in Canada was "very likely" this year and that he planned to bolster the union's strike fund for a protracted showdown.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9

title: ON BASEBALL;Most Valuable Yankee? This Year, It's the Boss
description: The Yankees lead their division with the largest margin in the major leagues, they have the best won-lost record in the American League and they lead the world in candidates for comeback of the year.

title: Ellis Island Becomes Courtroom For a Day
description: With sea gulls flapping overhead and a court stenographer straining to hear over the wind and lapping waves, a small crush of lawyers, court officials and television camera crews huddled yesterday at the edge of Ellis Island, where the battle resumed between New York and New Jersey over ownership of the windswept rock.

title: Ken Norton, 82, Former Coach Of Basketball at Manhattan
description: Ken Norton, the head coach at Manhattan College during the golden age of New York-area college basketball, died last Thursday at his summer home in Hendersonville, N.C. He was 82 years old.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Top U.S. Marathoner Will Run
description: Bob Kempainen, winner of the United States marathon trials, ended the suspense yesterday by affirming he would compete in the games.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TAURUS EXPLORATION TO BUY METHANE PRODUCER
description: The Energen Corporation said yesterday that its Taurus Exploration unit had agreed to acquire methane-producing properties from Burlington Resources Inc. for $61 million. Energen said that along with the $26 million it has invested in conventional oil and gas reserves already this fiscal year, sole ownership of these properties would place it on track toward significantly improved financial performance in its 1997 fiscal year.

title: When 2 Turtles Call Texas Home, It's Good News for Species
description: INSIDE a humid shed on the Padre Island National Seashore, a faint stirring under sand packed in a white foam cooler shows that a controversial 10-year experiment to establish a nesting colony of endangered sea turtles on Texas's Gulf Coast is paying off.

title: In Railroad Merger, Size Presents No Menace;Yes, Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: Venus's Remade Face Offers Hints of Cataclysm
description: VENUS was long thought of as the Earth's twin. It comes closer to our neighborhood than any other planet in the solar system, its orbit slightly nearer the Sun. And its size and composition, mass and density, are quite Earthlike. For many years the big difference was thought to be that Venus has a veil of thick clouds that block most terrestrial telescopes from seeing the hot Venusian surface.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bidding Said to Be Over In French Sale of MGM
description: The Consortium de Realisation, an affiliate set up in the French Government's bailout plan for Credit Lyonnais S.A., said yesterday that it did not expect to receive further bids for MGM Inc. or to extend the offer period again. The consortium closed a second round of bidding for the Hollywood studio last week. It declined to comment on the bids received and said it would sell MGM this summer, probably reaching a decision on the winning offer in the next few weeks.

title: G.E. Gives Airbus a $2.5 Billion Jet Order
description: Continuing a spending spree for commercial aircraft, the General Electric Company's aircraft leasing business said yesterday that it would buy more than $2.5 billion worth of planes from Airbus Industrie.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;New Movie Stars Often Surprising
description: AFTER years of being type-cast as the villains, personal computers have become the new action heroes of American cinema.

title: New Approach Needed to U.S.-Cuba Relations;Trapped in the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: 5th Death in Race Mishap
description: A fifth person died today from injuries sustained when a car driven by the Belgian Jos Sterkens hit a bump and flew into a crowd of spectators Sunday in the Inter-Nations Cup, a European championship race contested on a track that is part asphalt and part dirt.

title: Pataki and G.O.P. Report Big Increase In Raising of Funds
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and the New York Republican State Committee raised $6 million in campaign contributions during the first half of this year, an amount that state officials believe is a record.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ORACLE TO DISCUSS DETAILS ON INTRANETS
description: The Oracle Corporation plans to provide details today about its strategy for software that would allow corporations to build intranets, following both the Microsoft Corporation and the Netscape Communications Corporation. Based on Internet technology, intranets permit corporations to distribute information more efficiently to employees and to build corporatewide messaging and conferencing systems. Oracle executives said the company, based in Redwood Shores, Calif., had an advantage in such areas as the distribution of video and text retrieval as well as database retrieval and transaction processing. Computer-industry analysts believe that the market for corporate intranets will be at least as lucrative as the current Internet market.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Paperless Stock Trades For British Market
description: The Crest electronic share settlement system began operating yesterday in Britain, bringing paperless settlement of stock trades to Europe's largest equity market. The Crest system, developed by the Bank of England in the last three years, is owned by 69 financial institutions.

title: Netscape Program to Get Tighter Security
description: The Netscape Communications Corporation said today that the Government had granted the company permission to distribute within this country a version of its popular Navigator browser software containing substantially stronger encryption technology.

title: Brown Crash Spurs Charges By Air Force
description: The Air Force will discipline several officers, including at least two generals, in connection with the April crash that killed Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and 34 others, Pentagon officials said today.

title: Republicans in Congress Renew Push for Vote on School Prayer Amendment
description: Congressional Republicans are reviving their efforts to bring a constitutional amendment for organized school prayer to a vote, well before Election Day. While the amendment has long been a goal of House Republicans in particular, the new urgency appears to be, in part, an effort to help lift the fortunes of Bob Dole, the likely Republican Presidential nominee.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;Prolific In Names And Songs
description: Prince's 3 New Albums

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Palestinian Name Upheld
description: The International Olympic Committee today rejected a proposal by Israel's new government not to allow the first Palestinian team in the Summer Games to compete under the name of Palestine.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Sudan Lifts Flight Ban On Food to Rebel Area
description: The Government of the Sudan has agreed to allow the World Food Program to fly a C-130 cargo plane over its territory for the rest of this month to drop emergency food supplies in a southern province where half a million people are in danger of starvation.

title: 10,000 Prize for Dance Festival Leader
description: Charles Reinhart has won the 1996 Capezio Dance Award of $10,000. Paul Taylor is to present the award to Mr. Reinhart, co-director of the American Dance Festival, on Thursday in a ceremony before a performance by the Paul Taylor Dance Company at Duke University in Durham, N.C., where the festival is held each summer.

title: INSIDE
description: Quick Start in Senate Race

title: Arkansas Governor Resigns After Furor
description: Gov. Jim Guy Tucker resigned today after four hours of chaos in which he effectively held the governorship hostage and was threatened with impeachment by his successor.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Prices for Treasuries Slip, Falling Late in the Session
description: Treasury prices fell yesterday for the first time in more than a week.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Violations at Louisville
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has told the University of Louisville that violations found in a preliminary inquiry of the men's basketball program are "major in nature," the school said yesterday.

title: U.S. Backs Suspension of 2 School Boards
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has won at least partial support from the United States Justice Department in his effort to keep 15 re-elected community school board members from taking their seats in three districts.

title: Must NPR Sell Itself?
description: When the board of National Public Radio meets on Thursday and Friday, it will consider a contradiction: how to transform a nonprofit company financed to secure an independent voice into a money-making enterprise that builds joint ventures with media conglomerates.

title: IN PERFORMANCE;DANCE
description: Stretching Limbs and Spirit In a Bluesy Downpour Lula Washington Dance Theater Movin' Spirits Dance Theater Rumsey Playfield

title: Government Moves to Restrict Hazardous Chemicals on Planes
description: Federal regulators moved today to restrict the transport of certain hazardous materials on airliners and to increase surveillance of companies that send or transport hazardous materials in any way.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Sony Replaces Tristar Chief Amid Talk of More Trouble
description: Sony Pictures Entertainment, which has gained a reputation as the most troubled studio in Hollywood, was seized by further turmoil yesterday, including an executive shuffle and rumors of high-level infighting and more departures.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Odd Pair Of British Sleuths
description: Joining Poirot, Marple and Morse on A&E's "Mystery Movie" lineup, much of it adroitly wrested from public television's "Mystery" schedule, are Dalziel and Pascoe, the seemingly mismatched Yorkshire sleuths created by Reginald Hill.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Capital One Bank, Falls Church, Va., is selling $200 million of senior bank notes due in 1999 through Lehman Brothers. The noncallable notes carry an interest rate of 7.2 percent and are priced at par. The issue is rated Baa3 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBB- by the Standard & Poor's Corp.

title: Patterns
description: A Moment for Leather

title: Stocks Plunge as Dow Loses 161 And Technology Rout Continues
description: All news was bad news yesterday in the stock market, where there was a sharp drop in the shares of every sort of company, big and small, high technology and low, consumer and industrial.

title: Irvin Agrees to Plea On Cocaine Charge
description: Michael Irvin of the Dallas Cowboys, one of pro football's best wide receivers, pleaded no contest to a felony charge of cocaine possession, an agreement that allows him to stay out of jail. However, he could be suspended by the National Football League under its substance-abuse policy. The league normally imposes a four-game suspension for first time offenders. He still intends to report to the Cowboys' training camp, which begins Wednesday.

title: Plan for Harlem Girls School Faces Concern Over Sex Bias
description: A prominent philanthropic couple, an education research organization and a Harlem community school district are working together on plans for a school for underprivileged girls, which, if it opens as scheduled this fall, will be the first single-sex public school in New York City in a decade.

title: Nationsbank to Grant Options to Workers
description: The Nationsbank Corporation said yesterday that it would grant some 16 million stock options to more than 60,000 employees, ranging from part-time workers to vice presidents.

title: EU Vows Retaliation if U.S. Doesn't Waive Cuba Sanctions
description: BRUSSELS  Issuing their bluntest threat yet to Washington in the trans-Atlantic dispute over Cuba, European Union foreign ministers on Monday promised swift retaliation if President Bill Clinton goes ahead with fresh U.S. sanctions on foreign companies trading with the Castro regime.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Havas Unit Chosen By Oppenheimer Funds
description: Oppenheimer Funds Inc. said yesterday that it had named the Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG unit of Havas Advertising in New York to create advertising for its mutual funds. Billings on the account, which has been inactive for a decade, have not been determined.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Microsoft and NBC's TV-Internet Service Trips in Debut
description: Even as executives from NBC News and Microsoft were holding an elaborate news conference yesterday to kick off their MSNBC cable-television and Internet service, which they said heralded a new world of news delivery, MSNBC fell victim to some old-world glitches.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Torricelli Ahead in Cash
description: In what is expected to be one of the most expensive and closely contested United States Senate races this year, Representative Robert G. Torricelli reported having more than twice the money on hand as Representative Richard A. Zimmer.

title: South Korea Democracy Is on a Steady Course
description: To the Editor:

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Hockey Fields Are Up to Snuff
description: The much-criticized field hockey playing surface, or pitch, has been repaired to the satisfaction of the athletes, members of Britain's men's team said today.

title: Science Set Free From Truth
description: Last month, at a conference in Buffalo called "Science in the Age of (Mis)information," scores of scientists railed against "anti science," including the vile trend known as postmodernism. Hearing the denunciations at this meeting, one might guess that distinguishing truth lovers from truth defiers is child's play. The forces of rationality sport shiny white jump suits, like the hero of "Toy Story," while the epistemological subversives skulk about in black T-shirts and berets.

title: Dole Names Keynote Speaker And Sends Message to Women
description: Bob Dole said tonight that Representative Susan Molinari, a Staten Island Republican who supports abortion rights, would be the keynote speaker at the Republican National Convention in August.

title: Sega's U.S. Chief to Resign As Company Sales Fall Short
description: Amid disappointing sales of its next-generation video-game player, Sega of America said yesterday that Thomas J. Kalinske, its president and chief executive, would resign to join a new company founded by Michael R. Milken and Lawrence Ellison, the chairman of the software maker, the Oracle Corporation.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Ewing Sees Bulls Within Reach
description: Patrick Ewing could have speed-dialed two members of the reigning league champions and left curt, ominous messages on their answering machines, something like, "Hey, Michael, don't scratch my trophy" or "Scottie, did I mention we're back?"

title: IN PERFORMANCE;CABARET
description: In a Bastion of Sophistication, A Singer Breathes Bucolic Air Phillip Officer Oak Room

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in Weekend on Friday about "Secrets and Lies," the film chosen to open the New York Film Festival on Sept. 27, misstated the surname of one star. She is Brenda Blethyn, not Blythe.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Woman in the News;Candidate's Complement: Susan Molinari
description: In announcing Representative Susan Molinari as his keynote speaker for the Republican National Convention, Bob Dole picked someone tonight who, political party aside, is nearly his complete opposite.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Casillas Back in Dallas
description: Defensive lineman TONY CASILLAS, released by Dallas two years ago because of the salary cap, made it back to the Cowboys yesterday for the same reason. After being squeezed out of Dallas in 1994, Casillas signed with the Jets, who cut him last March while clearing salary-cap room for quarterback NEIL O'DONNELL. (AP)

title: IN PERFORMANCE;CABARET
description: From the 'Altar of Merman,' A Religion Called Excess Laurie Beechman Sam Harris Rainbow and Stars

title: Q&A
description: Fat Flies

title: Parents Take Charge, Putting Gene Hunt Onto the Fast Track
description: A SMALL foundation made up of parents of children with a rare genetic disease has taken a bold step to make sure that scientists find the gene that bedevils their offspring. Since the gene has not been of great interest to molecular geneticists, the group has contracted out its own gene search, paying a leading scientist more than a million dollars to do the work.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets' Duffy Proves A Loyal Subject
description: Roger Duffy is a solid citizen (305 pounds worth at that). He visits children in hospitals. He was the only Jets offensive lineman to start every game last season.

title: COMPANY NEWS;REGIS TO BUY SUPERCUTS IN A STOCK SWAP
description: The Regis Corporation said yesterday that it would buy the discount haircut chain Supercuts Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $150 million. Under the deal, each Supercuts shareholder would receive four-tenths of a Regis common share, or about 4.6 million shares total. Supercuts stock rose $1, to $9.75, in Nasdaq trading after reaching a 52-week high of $11.375 earlier. Regis's shares plunged $6.641, to $26.359. Regis, which has 1,950 hair care salons worldwide, plans to operate the San Francisco-based Supercuts, which has 1,168 United States stores, as a separate unit. Regis expects to take a one-time charge against earnings to account for the acquisition.

title: IN PERFORMANCE;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: From a Berkshires Festival, The Broad Humor of Mozart Aston Magna Corpus Christi Church

title: Carl M. Shoffler, 51, Officer Who Arrested Burglars at Watergate
description: Carl M. Shoffler, one of three Washington policemen whose arrest of five burglars 24 years ago touched off the Watergate scandals and ultimately brought down a Presidency, died on Saturday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 51 and lived in Bowie, Md.

title: Allen H. Postel, 70, Surgeon Specializing In Treating of Shock
description: Dr. Allen H. Postel, a surgeon who was one of the first doctors to treat shock by lowering the body temperature of the patient, died on Sunday at his home in Katonah, N.Y. He was 70.

title: OLYMPICS;Not All Dream Team's Memories Are Golden
description: The one thing I remember is going up to get the medal," David Robinson said. He was thinking back eight years to a moment he thought would provide a once-in-a-lifetime thrill. That was in Seoul, South Korea, in 1988, long before Olympic basketball became little more than the marketing of a dream. The Americans were college players. The medal was supposed to be gold. Their legacy was cast in bronze.

title: Spring Is Earlier Than 20 Years Ago
description: RESEARCHERS say they have evidence that spring is arriving a week earlier in the Northern Hemisphere than it did 20 years ago, perhaps because of a gradual rise in global temperatures.

title: On Giving Dole a Break
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Russian Troops Blockade 5 Villages in Chechnya
description: Russian troops blockaded villages in southeastern Chechnya today, and Chechen rebels attacked a Russian armored vehicle in Grozny, the capital.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;New Look for Wrestlers
description: It will not be hard to spot the United States Greco-Roman wrestlers when they show up in Atlanta: They will be the bald guys.

title: The Grading Becomes Stricter On H.M.O.'s
description: Managed-care plans love to boast about their services and their satisfied customers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOISE CASCADE LOSS LARGER THAN EXPECTED
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation reported a wider-than-expected loss for the second quarter yesterday, compared with a profit in the comparable period a year earlier, on lower paper sales and a stronger dollar. The company, which makes paper and office products, reported a loss of $17 million, or 55 cents a share, in contrast to a profit from operations of $93.3 million, or $1.59 and net income of $105.9 million, or $1.82 a share. Sales fell seven-tenths of 1 percent, to $1.26 billion from $1.27 billion. The per-share loss was greater than the 42-cent average estimate of 14 analysts polled by Zacks Investment Research. Company shares fell $3.75 yesterday, to $32.875.

title: Gentile Professor, Citing Bias, Quits As School's Head Of JewishStudies
description: Two weeks ago, Queens College appointed Thomas E. Bird as the new director of the college's Jewish studies program.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;3 Agencies Plan Expansions
description: Three agencies have announced business deals, terms of which were not disclosed.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;E.P.A. Fines for 6 in State
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency said yesterday that it had fined six New Jersey manufacturers for failing to release information on their toxic chemical releases, as required by Federal law. The largest fine, $102,000, was levied against the American Products Company of Union. The others companies were Tetley Inc. of Morris Plains, the Molecu Wire Corporation of Wall Township, Columbia Textile Service of Paterson, the Economy Color Card Company of Elizabeth and EWAL Manufacturing of Belleville. The companies can appeal. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Market Place;The Curtain Descends on a Near-Record Stock Run
description: One of the best stock market runs in history has ended. But if history is any guide, that does not mean disaster is inevitable.

title: In Hudson, Prehistoric Survivor Is Facing Threat
description: The Atlantic sturgeon, a giant fish long prized as a source of delicate smoked flesh and caviar, is rapidly dwindling in the Hudson River, its last refuge.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Trash Rules Unconstitutional
description: New Jersey regulations that require all trash be disposed of in the state are an unconstitutional violation of interstate commerce because they discriminate against out-of-state waste haulers, a Federal judge ruled yesterday. Judge Joseph E. Irenas of United States District Court in Camden gave the state two years to prepare its waste flow regulations for interstate competition, The Associated Press reported. The state is developing new regulations to meet the court's ruling, which affects curb-side municipal trash.

title: New Jersey Has Acted To Clean Up Waterways
description: To the Editor:

title: Transformer Explosion Burns 6 Cars In Queens
description: An underground Consolidated Edison transformer exploded early yesterday in Queens, shooting flames several stories into the nighttime air and engulfing six cars in a spectacular fire that took more than 100 firefighters an hour to douse and kept hundreds of onlookers watching from nearby sidewalks before dawn.

title: Hambrecht Halts Stock Offering
description: Hambrecht & Quist Inc., an investment bank in San Francisco that specializes in bringing technology companies public, has delayed its own plans for an initial public stock offering, four people at the firm said today.

title: Chess
description: Joel Benjamin, a Manhattan grandmaster, won the $1,000 first prize in the Hawaiian International Tournament in May at Waikiki, Maui. He scored 8 1/2-1 1/2 in the 10-round, 35-player, Swiss-system event, surpassing the grandmasters Eduard Gufeld of the Georgian Republic and Pavel Blatny of the Czech Republic, who tied for second place with 8-2.

title: Review/Fashion;What's New in Couture? Nothing
description: It seems fitting that couture, the most exclusive and elitist of fashion's arts, should be hanging by the silken threads of one-man's purse strings.

title: Delegate Battle Delays Teamsters Meeting
description: A raucous battle between the partisans of two candidates for the presidency of the teamsters union drowned out an attempt by a United States Senator to address the union's convention today and halted the proceedings for more than two hours.

title: SDNB Sale Approved
description: The SDNB Financial Corporation said today that its directors had approved the sale of the company to the FBOP Corporation, a privately held financial company, for $26.6 million. SDNB Financial, of Encinitas, Calif., said shareholders would receive $7.95 to $8 a share in the transaction. SDNB's shares did not trade today. They last closed at $6.25 on the Nasdaq stock market. FBOP, based in Oak Park, Ill., owns and operates community banks.

title: U.S. Still Alone in Opposition to New Term for Boutros-Ghali
description: Nearly a month after deciding to block a second five-year term for Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali, the Clinton Administration has received no pledges of support for its position from any of the other 14 Security Council members, diplomats said today.

title: The Kamikaze Campaign
description: Bob Dole's campaign for President has not gotten off the ground yet, despite innumerable lumbering attempts at takeoff. At a point in the election season when the novice candidate Bill Clinton had already released an entire book detailing his positions, Mr. Dole has not yet come up with a tax plan. He has gotten into public disputes with everyone from Colin Powell to Katie Couric. Now, the unkindest cut of all, he has been attacked by Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York, a member of the campaign's inner circle.

title: Tomorrow, the World Wide Web!;Microsoft, the PC King, Wants to Reign Over the Internet
description: As a captain of industry and the richest man in America, William H. Gates has often been compared to industrial titans of the past.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Rout in Stocks Continues, With Every Sector Hit Few investors or companies avoided the carnage on Wall Street as shares of every sort of company, big and small, high technology and low, fell sharply. Technology stocks suffered the most, with the Nasdaq composite index falling 3.92 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 161.05 points, or 2.9 percent, to 5,349.51. [Page A1.]

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Two Athletes Face Doping Bans
description: Doping cases involving two top-level international athletes emerged four days before the opening of the Games.

title: Corrections
description: A music review yesterday about a production of "The Rake's Prog ress" by the Opera Festival of New Jersey on Friday night at the Kirby Arts Center in Lawrenceville misstated the timing of a scene in which Baba the Turk reveals her beard. It is at the end of Act II, Scene 2, not at the end of Act I.

title: Legal Services on the Ropes
description: House Republicans are continuing their drive this week to destroy the Legal Services Corporation, the federally financed program that assists poor people with civil legal problems.

title: Ford Offers White-Collar Early Retirement Plans
description: The Ford Motor Company will offer early retirement packages to white-collar workers in an effort to shed 2,000 employees from its auto operations around the world by the end of the year, helping the auto maker reduce costs and bring in employees with new skills.

title: THE OTHER DOLE -- A special report.;Elizabeth Dole Is Eager To Keep Strength Subtle
description: The men and women running Bob Dole's Presidential campaign are happy to tell people what Elizabeth Dole is not. She is not, they say, Hillary Clinton, and she would not be an unelected policy maker as First Lady.

title: Business Inventories Drop And Growth in Sales Eases
description: Business inventories fell in May even as companies reported a slowdown in sales growth for the month, Government figures showed today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BUZZ ALDRIN, who made history when he became the second man to set foot on the moon, is on a voyage of a different sort this summer -- a book tour -- and he is returning to some of the earthbound haunts of his astronaut days. This afternoon, for example, he will be at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, where 27 years ago today he blasted off on the historic Apollo 11 lunar mission.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;F.C.C. Rejects Canada-to-U.S. Satellite TV Plan
description: The Federal Communications Commission denied an application today by Tele-Communications Inc. and Telquest Ventures to use Canadian satellites to beam television programming to American viewers.

title: COMPANY NEWS;APPLIED MATERIALS SHARES DECLINE 9% ON REPORT
description: Shares of Applied Materials Inc. fell 9 percent yesterday after it said its third-quarter results would be lower than analysts expected as chipmakers slow orders for the company's equipment. Shares fell $2.625, to $25.375, on trading of almost five million shares. The company said sales would be about $1.1 billion and earnings about 90 cents a share for the three months ending July 28. Wall Street was expecting the Santa Clara, Calif., company to earn $1 a share, according to the average estimate of 17 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research Corp. A year earlier, net income was $139.2 million, or 79 cents a share, on sales of $897.7 million.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers Explore Acquiring Gretzky
description: If Neil Smith, the Rangers' president, had been waiting for the green light from his superiors at Madison Square Garden to pursue Wayne Gretzky, he has seemed a little ambivalent about it at times.

title: Limits Seen On Questions In Archer Case
description: Critics of a proposed $45 million settlement of a class action lawsuit against the Archer Daniels Midland Company and two other makers of animal feed additive may not be able to question a senior A.D.M. executive they contend was involved in price fixing.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tougher Animal Cruelty Law
description: In March 1995, a swan was clubbed and decapitated as she guarded her eggs in Point Pleasant Beach. Yesterday, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a law inspired by that incident and designed to strengthen the penalties for animal cruelty. The law imposes a minimum fine of $250 for each incident and a maximum penalty of six months in jail and a $1,000 fine. It also imposes a mandatory penalty of 30 days' community service. Previously, the maximum penalty was $250.

title: New York State Needs a Biennial Budget Cycle
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;WPP Group Names 2 New Board Members
description: The WPP Group, which owns agencies like Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide and the J. Walter Thompson Company, said yesterday that it had appointed to its board Hamish Maxwell, former chairman and chief executive of the Philip Morris Companies, and Eric Salama, the strategic director of WPP in London.

title: BASEBALL;Wilson Returns; DiPoto Returns to Form
description: It was billed as the return of Paul Wilson, the rookie right-hander, who had been out for six weeks with tendinitis in his right shoulder. But it was the return of Jerry DiPoto that drew raves from Manager Dallas Green as the reliever played a key role in the Mets' 7-5 victory over the Phillies last night at Shea Stadium.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about the composer Gottfried von Einem misstated the performance history of his opera "The Visit of the Old Lady." The work had its American premiere in San Francisco in 1972. The New York City Opera production scheduled for next season is to be the New York premiere.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;After $5 billion is bet, marketers are racing to be noticed amid the clutter at  the Summer Games.
description: IF commercialization and ambushing were Olympic sports, the Summer Games, which start on Friday, could be called off before they began, because the United States would have already won more gold medals than Atlanta has grits.

title: Ulster's Battered Peace
description: The bombs, barricades and bombast of sectarian strife have returned to Northern Ireland after a 22-month grace period that once seemed likely to bring a lasting peace.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Another American romance goes awry. JAMES BURNS, a 32-year-old security expert who once worked for Doris Duke, the late tobacco heiress, filed a palimony suit last week in Los Angeles Superior Court against her 43-year-old adopted daughter, CHANDI GAIL HEFFNER.

title: Europeans Agree On Steps to Retaliate For U.S. Cuba Curbs
description: European nations angry over a law passed by the United States that punishes other countries for doing business with Cuba agreed today on possible steps to retaliate, including blacklisting American companies and requiring visas for business travelers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: St. Peter's College, Jersey City, to Big Idea, New York, to handle its account, previously at Linett & Harrison, Millburn, N.J. Billings were estimated at $1 million. Ticketmaster Inc., Los Angeles, to the Pearlman Group, Los Angeles, to handle its account, previously in-house. Billings were not disclosed.

title: In Railroad Merger, Size Presents No Menace
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Acknowledges 21 Had Extra Drug Tests
description: The Secret Service stepped up drug testing on 21 White House staff members two years ago after they revealed they had experiences far more extensive than an experimental puff of marijuana in college, a White House spokeswoman said today.

title: New SUNY Budget Allows Flexibility, Officials Say
description: Officials of the State University of New York said yesterday that the state budget approved this weekend would give them some new flexibility to lower tuition on five campuses and to allow colleges that achieved savings to use the money themselves.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Chicago, Tugging The Sleeve And Heart
description: When Scott Turow was growing up in Chicago, his grandfather told him a true story. The grandfather, an immigrant whom Mr. Turow describes as "a typical Chicagoan, bright as they come," had bought a gas station, only to find that his investment came "with more strings than a hammock." The 13-year-old Scott, even then a budding lawyer, asked why his grandfather hadn't sued. Mr. Turow lapses into an affectionate though not-too-convincing Russian-Jewish accent as he recalls his grandfather's answer: "A poor man like me? I couldn't afford to buy a judge."

title: By Design;Autumn Is the Time to Shine
description: Metallic leather. Metallic lace. Metallic silk. Metallic eye shadow. Just about everything in the fashion realm is getting a high gloss for fall. And metallics are for day as well as for evening.

title: F.C.C. Sells Wireless Licenses for $905 Million
description: A Federal auction ended today with seven companies pledging $905 million for licenses to provide the next generation of mobile telephone and data services.

title: Sanofi Buying An American Drug Concern
description: The French pharmaceutical company, Sanofi S.A., a unit of Elf Aquitaine S.A., said today that it would buy an American pharmaceutical company, the Bock Pharmacal Company.

title: Big Board Seeks Volume Changes
description: The New York Stock Exchange is demanding a recount in its rivalry with the Nasdaq market.

title: Police Extending Crackdown on Narcotics
description: The New York City Police Department is preparing to extend a major anti-drug initiative that has already cut crime rates in northern Brooklyn to Washington Heights and northern Harlem, the primary wholesale crack cocaine markets in the metropolitan area.

title: Compuserve Expects to Post a Loss; Shares Fall Nearly 20%
description: The Compuserve Corporation said yesterday that it would report a loss in its first complete quarter as a public company, surprising Wall Street and driving the company's share price down nearly 20 percent.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DIAL'S BOARD ENDORSES SPINNING OFF VIAD
description: The board of the Dial Corporation unanimously reiterated its support yesterday for the planned spinoff of the Viad Corporation services business, despite opposition from a large shareholder. The chairman of Dial, John W. Teets, who will be 63 in September, said he would continue as chairman and chief executive until the spinoff, when he will take those roles with Viad before retiring on Jan. 1. Dial, a diversified consumer products and services company, is based in Phoenix. Dial said it was selling noncore assets, including its interest in the Phoenix Suns basketball team. Dial shares closed at $26, up 12.5 cents. The conglomerate's subsidiaries make Dial, Brillo, Renuzit and Breck products.

title: OLYMPICS;Quest for Finnish Gold Is a Father-and-Son Act
description: Until six years ago, Esa Sievinen was a carpenter. He built desks, not championship swimmers. But his son, Jani, moved like a dolphin in the water. No Finnish swimmer had ever won an Olympic medal. Maybe his son would be the first.

title: TV Notes;Limbaugh to Fox News?
description: Is Rush Limbaugh headed for the new 24-hour Fox News channel?

title: TV Notes;Questions of Vulgarity
description: Television network entertainment chiefs deliver their own State of the Union speeches each summer at the annual gathering of TV critics and journalists in Pasadena, Calif., known as Press Tour. Yesterday Warren Littlefield of NBC got to go first, appropriately, perhaps, since NBC finished first last season in virtually every viewership category that counts.

title: ATLANTA 1996: 2 DAYS TO GO;Romanian Women Are Uneasy Favorites
description: In gymnastics, going first is no honor, but that is exactly what the Romanians will do when the Olympic women's competition begins on Monday with the compulsories.

title: Jewish Studies Isn't an Exclusive Scholarship
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Nation's Table: Providence, R.I.;In Honor of Indians And Yankees
description: Here in Providence, which has become known for fine European and Asian restaurants, a pair of longtime local restaurateurs are reinvigorating culinary traditions begun by the area's early British colonists and their Indian neighbors and embellished by later European arrivals.

title: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;White House Report Foresees A Sharp Decline in the Deficit
description: The Clinton White House issued its midsummer revised economic forecast today, predicting that the Federal budget deficit this fiscal year would be $116.8 billion -- $29 billion less than the Administration forecast just this spring and only a third of its level when Mr. Clinton took office.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;In the Long Run, an Injury
description: Five months ago Wednesday, Bob Kempainen won the United States Olympic marathon trials, qualifying him for the gold-medal race Aug. 4 in Atlanta. Today, the 30-year-old physician from Minneapolis told how close he and his tendinitis-ridden right knee and hip had come to forgetting about the Olympics.

title: POLITICS: THE AIR WAVES;G.O.P. Seeks to Entertain With TV-Savvy Convention
description: Republican strategists have been watching entertainment television, and now, they say, they understand why their 1992 convention flopped. It was dull.

title: Shadowy Rebels Pose New Problems for Mexico
description: A half-hour's drive from Acapulco into the backlands of Guerrero state, the pulsing beat of the resort's jet-set discos fades into the splash of mothers pounding the family wash on river stones and the cries of children with rotten teeth and dysentery.

title: GOLF;Ballesteros Is Off on a Sentimental Mission
description: The banner has barely faded with time. It hangs from a window of a red brick house, across the railroad tracks from the second tee at Royal Lytham and St. Annes Golf Club, just as it did eight years ago. It is a simple Spanish message, heartfelt.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Contrite Irvin Isn't Heading to Camp
description: Just hours after a state judge approved his plea of no contest to a felony charge of cocaine possession, the Dallas Cowboy star Michael Irvin apologized today to his family for the pain he had caused them.

title: Seattle Journal;For 5 Hours, a Work of Protest Art Brings a City to Its Knees
description: On Monday, one of the hottest days of the year in a city not known for heat waves or acts of excess, an artist named Jason Sprinkle told friends that he was going to go out and "commit public art."

title: Perelman and Murdoch In Talks on Acquisition
description: In a last minute turnaround, New World Communications Group Inc. apparently broke off its pending acquisition of King World Productions Inc. yesterday, the day it was set to be approved, and is in negotiations to be acquired by the News Corporation in a deal estimated at $2.5 billion, according to several people with knowledge of the discussions.

title: POLITICS: THE PLAYERS;Designated Keynoter Is Besieged, Happily
description: One day after being selected to deliver the keynote speech at the Republican National Convention, Representative Susan Molinari said yesterday that her life had been converted at once into a whirlwind of calls from news organizations, friends and advisers.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;New Knick Johnson Says Right Things
description: Larry Johnson and Jeff Van Gundy sat and talked basketball today in the office of the Knicks' coach at SUNY-Purchase. They both wanted to get to know each other.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary on June 17 about Mel Allen, who broadcast New York Yankees games from 1939 to 1964, misstated the number of home runs hit by Joe DiMaggio at Fenway Park in Boston in the first three games after his return from injury in 1949. It was four, not three.

title: Helmsley Is Released From Her Probation
description: After serving 18 months in a Federal prison, performing community service and paying $6.3 million in fines, Leona Helmsley has been released from probation after insisting to a judge that she had paid her debt to society and was in poor health.

title: Gasoline Prices Fall Again
description: Gasoline prices at the pump in the United States fell for the second consecutive month in the period that ended on July 15 after reaching 15-year highs for the spring in May, the American Automobile Association said yesterday. Average United States prices for self-serve regular unleaded gasoline fell 2.9 cents, to $1.274 a gallon, the association said.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Iverson Displays Summer Toughness
description: Allen Iverson grimaced as he walked from the court at the Doral Arrowwood Summer League last Friday night in White Plains. It was difficult to tell if it was because he scored 36 points and his Philadelphia 76ers still lost to the Knicks in overtime, or if it was because his body was tired and bruised.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ARBITRATOR RULES J.& J WRONGFULLY FIRED AN EXECUTIVE
description: An arbitrator ruled yesterday that a former Johnson & Johnson executive who had sought the return of an H.I.V.-testing company that he sold to J.& J. in 1993 was wrongfully terminated as president and chief executive of the Direct Access Diagnostics subsidiary of J.& J. last year. The former executive, Elliott Millenson, said that the arbitration ruling would force J.& J., a maker of health and pharmaceutical products with its base in New Brunswick, N.J., to return the Confide at-home H.I.V. test to him so that he can resell it to other investors. The company, however, denied that it has to return the H.I.V.-test technology, for which it received approval from the Food and Drug Administration in May.

title: Miller Brewing to Cut Jobs
description: The Miller Brewing Company plans to eliminate 200 production jobs at its Milwaukee brewery in October, as part of a program to cut costs at the plant. Miller, a unit of the Philip Morris Companies, also plans to make about $20 million worth of improvements in equipment and procedures at the plant in the next year, Dianne Markut, a spokeswoman for Miller Brewing, said. The job cuts affect about a fifth of the plant's hourly employees.

title: Diversity at N.A.A.C.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Ukraine Prime Minister Survives Bomb Attack
