description: Prime Minister Pavlo Lazarenko survived an assassination attempt today when a powerful, remote-controlled bomb exploded near his car as he rode to the airport. He was treated for a shoulder injury, officials said.

title: POLITICS;Unity Lunch in the G.O.P.
description: With one very conspicuous absence, Bob Dole today gathered losers of the Republican Presidential primary campaign for a "unity lunch."

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Kodak's Strong Profit Rise Helps Pull Dow Out of Slide
description: The Eastman Kodak Company reported surprisingly strong earnings yesterday -- news that lifted the company's stock and helped the Dow Jones industrial average end its wild day with a small gain.

title: G.O.P. Platform Plank
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: A Bid to Halt Global Warming

title: Pacific Officials Fail to Reach a Consensus
description: Trade ministers at an Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum have failed to gain a group-wide consensus on a number of important trade issues before the first ministerial World Trade Organization meeting in Singapore in December.

title: About as Old-Fashioned as 26 Gigabytes
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Mendoza Sent to Columbus
description: The Yankees performed an inevitable transaction when they optioned the erratic rookie Ramiro Mendoza to Class AAA tonight and recalled reliever Jim Mecir from Columbus to assume his roster spot. Unless the Yankees acquire another pitcher, Mark Hutton will probably start Saturday in Mendoza's place against Milwaukee.

title: OLYMPICS;Injuries Force Sampras and Graf to Skip Games
description: The Olympic tennis competition lost two of its top contenders for gold-medal honors in the space of a single afternoon yesterday when not only Pete Sampras, the world's No. 1-ranked male player, but Sampras's counterpart at the head of the women's game, Germany's Steffi Graf, also withdrew because of injuries.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Wall Street's Big Tumble Echoes Around the Globe As Wall Street rode a record-breaking roller coaster, stock exchanges across the globe took their cues from Monday's bloodbath. Though the declines were less severe than in the United States, the global selloff was a panicky reaction to the carnage. [Pages A1 and D7.]

title: COMPANY REPORTS;J. & J. Results Cheer Investors; Eli Lilly Profits Stir Concerns
description: Johnson & Johnson and Eli Lilly & Company both reported earnings gains yesterday for the second quarter. But after looking hard at the results, investors showed their approval of Johnson & Johnson and displayed concerns about Lilly.

title: Corrections
description: A listing of entertainment events that appeared on Saturday was published in error. It referred to music and dance events for the following Saturday, July 20.

title: At the Nation's Table: Rock Springs, Ariz.;Packing Them In In a Tiny Town
description: It doesn't come any more rustic than the Rock Springs Cafe, about 30 minutes north of Phoenix: wood plank floors, a squeaky screen door, pressed-tin ceiling, paper napkins and placemats, and a couple of waitresses who call you "darlin'."

title: COMPANY NEWS;NATIONSBANK APPROVES $1.59 BILLION BUYBACK OF SHARES
description: The Nationsbank Corporation's board has authorized the repurchase of up to 20 million shares, or 6.6 percent of its shares outstanding. At current prices the buyback would cost $1.59 billion to complete. The company said it would buy back shares from time to time in the open market in the next three years. The shares of Nationsbank, based in Charlotte, N.C., closed down 12.5 cents, at $79.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Time Warner Cash Flow Jumps 20%
description: Time Warner Inc. reported yesterday that operating cash flow for the second quarter jumped 20 percent, to $1.03 billion, from $830 million in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Revenue rose to $2.14 billion from $1.9 billion.

title: AUTO RACING;Coroner to Look Into Accident at Toronto Track
description: The accident at the Molson Indy-car race in Toronto on Sunday that killed Jeff Krosnoff, a driver, and Gary Avrin, a flagman, is being investigated by the office of Dr. Robert Huxter, the regional coroner for metropolitan Toronto, with the assistance of the city's police department.

title: OLYMPICS;With Dunk in Atlanta, Leslie Figures to Become The Center of Attention
description: Her first Olympic basketball game is five days away. For most of Lisa Leslie's peers, near the end of an intense preparation process that began last October, it is time to taper. Leslie, a center for the United States, continues to spend three to five sessions a week in the weight room. She plans to continue the routine to the end in Atlanta. "Because I am so small," she said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;VW Sales Up 28% In Asia-Pacific Region
description: Volkswagen A.G. said yesterday that sales to the Asia-Pacific region rose 28 percent in the first half of this year. During the same period, the company sold 8.4 percent more cars in Western Europe, according to preliminary figures from the European Automobile Manufacturers Association.

title: CYCLING;Riis Leaves Field and Indurain Far Behind
description: Bjarne Riis did it and Miguel Indurain didn't.

title: Myron Goldsmith, Architect And Engineer, Is Dead at 77
description: Myron Goldsmith, an architect and engineer whose work merged the jewel-like precision of Mies van der Rohe with the greyhound-sleek forms of Pier Luigi Nervi, died on Monday at his home in Wilmette, Ill. He was 77.

title: U.S. Give Warning to Japan on Air Cargo Access
description: The Transportaion Department said today that unless Japan relaxed restrictions on Federal Express by the end of this month, it would block Japan Airlines from flying cargo planes to this country that carry freight originating in the Philippines, Indonesia and China.

title: OPERA REVIEW;England And 'Lulu': A Collision Of Sweet And Sour
description: Lulu" is an unlikely guest at the Glyndebourne Festival Opera this summer, but there it was tonight in a new production by Graham Vick: Alban Berg's elegant paean to inhumanity set down in the middle of this soft English country scene. Unwholesomeness meets civility at Glyndebourne, a paradox of subject matter and setting.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Pharmacist Is Charged
description: For at least a year, Morris County prosecutors said, Henry B. Rabin, a pharmacist at a Shop-Rite in Chatham Township, sneaked pills out of the store and sold them on the street. Yesterday, prosecutors said the police had arrested Mr. Rabin, 53, of Florham Park, and five others and had seized more than 32,000 tablets worth $549,000. Some of the drugs were distributed at William Paterson College in Wayne, said Capt. Christopher Linne, a spokesman for the prosecutor's office.

title: Flawed Policies at Protective Services Agency
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Affairs;Turkey Wings It
description: While traveling, you are often asked what you do for a living. Lately I answer that I'm a foreign affairs columnist and that means I cover wars -- occasionally wars between countries but more often the wars between economic winners and losers within countries. Because it is these domestic wars that increasingly shape international affairs, from Russia to Mexico to Turkey.

title: Metro Digest
description: NEW YORK

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Youth Killed in Shooting
description: A 15-year-old boy was killed and four people were wounded, two of them critically, late Monday when two men armed with a shotgun and a handgun opened fire on the group in a residential neighborhood, the Paterson police said yesterday. The gunmen fired several shots, and fled on foot, Lieut. Al Clark said. The dead youth was identified as Tyeen Price of Paterson. The police said they did not know what prompted the shooting.

title: What Price Cable's Internet Gift to Schools?
description: To the Editor:

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Moses Called an Inspiration
description: South Africa is profiting from the guidance and experience of the former Olympic champion Edwin Moses at the Atlanta Games. The South African Olympic Committee president, Sam Ramsamy, today thanked the American, a strong opponent of apartheid in sports during the days of white rule in the republic, for "the inspiration he has brought to our team."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Kraft and Q Lube Shift Accounts
description: Two large marketers have consolidated advertising acccounts.

title: Lack of Regret In Confessions By the Suspect In 4 Beatings
description: John J. Royster told the police he was bothered, sitting in the 19th Precinct station house on the morning of June 13. But it wasn't the memory of the crimes to which he had just confessed -- savage beatings of four women in Manhattan and Yonkers, one fatal -- that was upsetting him.

title: BASEBALL;Dodger Fans Salute Lasorda
description: Tommy Lasorda was not sure how his return to Dodger Stadium would go. Back at the ball park for the first time since undergoing a heart procedure on June 26, Lasorda, the major leagues' senior manager, found the experience poignant and uplifting as he chatted with and hugged his players and coaches before Monday night's game against the San Diego Padres.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Patriot Is Wounded
description: BRUCE WALKER, a defensive lineman for the New England Patriots, incurred a stab wound in his chest while he and a friend were throwing a steak knife at each other Saturday night in a grocery store parking lot in North Attleboro, Mass. The police said that Walker suffered the wound when he missed a catch. He was treated at Southwood Community Hospital in Norfolk and required several stitches, police said. The 6-foot-4-inch, 310-pound nose tackle told The Sun Chronicle of Attleboro that he was puzzled by the interest in the incident, saying "nothing happened." (AP)

title: New Study Questions Radon Danger In Houses
description: A major study has failed to connect indoor radon exposure with lung cancer, raising new uncertainty about public health warnings that the colorless, odorless gas is responsible for as much as 10 percent of the United States' lung cancer.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Schering of Germany To Buy Leiras of Finland
description: Schering A.G., the German drug company, said yesterday that it would buy the Finnish contraceptive device maker Leiras Gruppe for 466 million German marks ($306 million). Leiras specializes in nonoral contraceptives and hormone treatments that Schering expects will complement its oral contraceptive business.

title: FILM REVIEW;Friends Facing Life's Insults With Humor
description: Walking and Talking" was shown as part of this year's New Directors/ New Films festival. Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 29. The film opens today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;George Signs
description: The Heisman Trophy winner EDDIE GEORGE agreed to a five-year contract with the Houston Oilers yesterday. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: A Faulty Heart, A New Chance
description: JAMES TAYLOR, 72, marvels that he is still alive four years after getting a new heart, one considered to be in such poor condition that it had been turned down by several heart transplant centers.

title: OLYMPICS;Iranian-American Sets Sights on Greco-Roman Gold
description: With his freshly shaved head, Matt Ghaffari presents a stark appearance. Appropriately, he looks at the Olympic Greco-Roman wrestling competition in stark terms.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;No Offers for Libraries
description: After officials closed three branches of the Paterson Public Library, they figured they could sell the buildings and perhaps use the proceeds to computerize the remaining half-dozen branches. But the problem at yesterday's auction, said Anna-Lisa Dopirak, Paterson's business administrator, was that nobody wanted the libraries -- at least not at the minimum bids, ranging from $130,000 to $250,000, that the city was seeking. A few nonprofit groups have expressed interest, she said. TERRY PRISTIN

title: THEATER REVIEW;Deathbed With a Comforter of Laughter
description: Grace is a 90-year-old illiterate Virginian who has been sent home from the hospital to die of cancer.

title: No Headline
description: We've taken a look at the opportunities that a national convention can provide in the modern age, as opposed to the late 1900's. And we've tried to create a program which is exactly that -- a television program, that has a political message."

title: Tree Men Hard at Work After Hurricane Leaves
description: The tree men were barreling down the highway from Tennessee last Thursday, heading into the path of Hurricane Bertha, even as people up and down the North Carolina coast were fleeing inland. The tree men, some of them veterans of Hurricanes Andrew and Hugo, drove their trucks through blinding rain and gale-force winds.

title: Clinton Grants, Then Suspends, Right to Sue Foreigners on Cuba
description: Seeking to weave his way between conflicting domestic and foreign pressures, President Clinton today granted American citizens the right to sue foreign companies that are using American plants seized by Cuba over 35 years ago, but he immediately suspended those suits for at least six months.

title: A Law Aimed at Terrorists Hits Legal Immigrants
description: In the three months since a tougher new counterterrorism bill was signed into law, many immigrants who have been living legally in the United States for years have been placed in detention by the Immigration and Naturalization Service and are facing deportation.

title: F.B.I. Files and Personnel Security: A Matter of White House Laxity?
description: Wearing a walkie-talkie, a beeper and his usual self-important air, Craig Livingstone sidled up to a young White House aide early in the Clinton Administration and began needling her about a prank from her sorority days.

title: Lost Without War in Northern Ireland
description: In the 1970's, as a young Catholic man, I spent three years in various prisons in Northern Ireland as a detainee, an uncharged political suspect and as a sentenced "special category" prisoner held on a firearms-possession charge. Soon after my release in 1978, I left Northern Ireland, but my life and much of my writing have been shaped by the Troubles.

title: Mr. Yeltsin's Health Problems
description: President Clinton and Vice President Gore may find it politic to downplay Boris Yeltsin's latest physical setback, but that is no reason for the rest of us to ignore what is happening. The freshly re-elected President of Russia is once again in precarious health. Should he become incapacitated, the ability of Russia's fledgling democracy to effect an orderly transfer of power will be put to a severe test.

title: Those Slam-Dunk Salaries
description: Free-agent season opened for National Basketball Association players last week, with dazzling financial rewards for a handful of superstars. Michael Jordan, the world's best player, won the sport's best salary -- a reported $25 million for one year. Shaquille O'Neal, the gargantuan center for the Orlando Magic, was reportedly offered over $95 million for seven years by the Los Angeles Lakers -- a contract the Lakers expect Mr. O'Neal to rip up after three years to collect much more. But Shaq will have to balance that against a $115 million seven-year offer to stay with the Magic. Juwan Howard, a 23-year-old player for the Washington Bullets, jumped to the Miami Heat for $98 million over seven years. That would make him only the second-best-paid player on the Heat, which reportedly offered its center, Alonzo Mourning, about $10 million more.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MERCK OF GERMANY TO EXPLORE GENETICS TECHNOLOGY
description: Merck K.-G.a.A. of Germany said yesterday that it would pay $50 million to form an alliance with SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. and Human Genome Sciences Inc. to explore genetics. The agreement would allow Merck to conduct research on new pharmaceuticals using genetic technology developed by SmithKline and Human Genome. The agreement would last until June 2001. Earlier this year, the three companies had said they were exploring such an alliance. SmithKline and Human Genome has announced similar alliances with the Schering-Plough Corporation and Synthelabo S.A. Human Genome's shares closed at $27.50, up $2.25 in Nasdaq trading.

title: Gioia Braga, 80, Promoter of Italian Culture
description: Gioia Marconi Braga, the founder and chairwoman of the privately supported Marconi International Fellowship Council, who promoted scientific and cultural relations between Italy and the United States, died on Monday at Englewood Hospital. She was 80 and lived in Alpine, N.J.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about fund raising by Gov. George E. Pataki and the New York Republican State Committee included an erroneous total for their combined receipts in the first half of this year, based on an overestimate supplied by the Governor's aides. Mr. Pataki raised $79,392, not $1.58 million. With the state committee's figure added in, the total was $4.49 million, not $6 million. An article explaining the discrepancies appears today on page B4.

title: Fitness Helps, Even for Smokers
description: COMING on the heels of the Surgeon General's report last week recommending moderate exercise for good health, a new study provides one of the strongest incentives yet to walk and not drive, and to take the stairs and not the elevator. The study found that low fitness is a risk factor of the same order as smoking. In the study, smokers with high blood pressure and high cholesterol who were in moderately good shape lived longer than nonsmokers who were healthy but sedentary.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;In picking a new name, D.M.B.& B. reaches into its history instead of making one up.
description: THE name of one of the best- known, most honored copywriters in advertising is regaining a place of prominence more than a decade after disappearing in an agency merger.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Church Damaged by Fire
description: A Pentecostal church with a predominantly black congregation was extensively damaged Monday night in a fire that was probably started by lightning, fire officials said. Dozens of black churches, mostly in the South, have been burned in the last 18 months, but Fire Marshal Ken Northrop said said that arson was not suspected in the fire at the Greater Emanuel Temple Pentecostal Church in Neptune.

title: Sports Authority Head Resigns as State Investigates His Business
description: The chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority abruptly resigned today, as state officials said he was the subject of a state investigation involving his private maintenance business.

title: 11 Officers Are Accused Of Failure to Pay Taxes
description: At least 11 New York City police officers have been accused of failing to pay any Federal taxes for several years by declaring they each had 98 dependents and by insisting that the Government had no right to tax them, according to officials and court papers released yesterday.

title: Ruling Lets Wives Sue For Injuries
description: In a ruling that broadened the rights of battered women filing for divorce, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that they may seek separate jury trials to hear their claims for damages for injuries they suffered at their spouses' hands.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IMATION STOCK DROPS IN FIRST DAY OF TRADING
description: The Imation Corporation, the $2.25 billion company spun off by the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, began trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of Imation, a data storage and imaging business, closed at $23.125, down from $24 in its final day of when-issued trading Monday. It started trading on a when-issued basis at $32 on June 26. The company, based in Oakdale, Minn., sells about 10,000 products in 60 countries ranging from computer backup tapes, X-ray film and photographic film to medical imagers and a color proofing machine for graphic artists.

title: Study Rebuts Aspirin as Anti-Cancer Agent
description: Despite animal and human studies that suggested that aspirin might lower the risk of breast cancer, a new study indicates that it offers no protection.

title: Suspect's 'Rage Inside Me'
description: The following are excerpts from statements that prosecutors said were made by John J. Royster, the suspect in the brutal beatings, one fatal, of four women in Manhattan and Yonkers:

title: A Giuliani Supporter Is Under Investigation
description: The former executive of a Queens-based nonprofit agency who is at the center of a Federal investigation into the awarding of $43 million in city welfare contracts was one of the chief fund-raisers for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's campaign during the first six months of this year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Workers Dismissed At True North Unit
description: R/GA Digital Studios, the unit of the TN Technologies division of True North Communications that specializes in special effects and graphics, has dismissed employees in Los Angeles and New York.

title: Ex-Leader Quits and 3 Return in New York Child Welfare Shake-Up
description: Calling it a major step in the overhaul of the city's child welfare agency, the Giuliani administration yesterday announced a wide-ranging shake-up of its top management, a reorganization that included the reappointment of three people who had once run the long-troubled agency.

title: BASEBALL;Strawberry Hits Rocket Against Clemens
description: Darryl Strawberry's sweet swing connected with one of Roger Clemens's fatter fastballs tonight, and bat destroying ball resulted in a precious sight. Strawberry's power rocketed the ball to the deepest part of Fenway Park, where it caromed off the 17-foot center-field fence 420 feet away. The unprotected fans were lucky the speeding bullet never reached them.

title: Chase Profits Meet Forecasts; Wells Fargo Falls Short
description: The two biggest bank mergers in history showed very different results in the first three months since their consummation.

title: How 1996 Is Like 1987, and How It Isn't
description: If investors were holding their breath yesterday, it was with good reason.

title: En Garde! New Yorkers Are at Top Of Noble Art;On Crowded Streets, Good Neighbors Make Good Fencers
description: My one wound was beginning to make itself felt. My valiant adversary appeared to be bleeding from everywhere. There were three wounds in his arm, two in almost the same spot, and three in his chest. How I reached his body without hurting him seriously is a mystery, or a miracle, which I have never been able to explain.

title: BASEBALL;Suddenly, Wild Card Is in Sight For Mets
description: The Mets are scoreboard watching these days, for the first time in years.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Rape Trial Canceled
description: The trial of four Clemson football players accused of gang-raping a woman, then an 18-year-old freshman, in a campus dormitory abruptly ended yesterday in Pickens, S.C., when the woman refused to testify. The charges of first-degree criminal sexual assault and conspiracy to commit first-degree criminal sexual assault against ADRIAN DINGLE, 18, of Holly Hill, S.C.; ERIC WILLIAMS, 18, of Blenheim, S.C.; BENNIE ZEIGLER, 19, of St. Petersburg, Fla., and CHRISTOPHER RICE, 19, of Starkville, Miss. -- all freshmen -- were dropped and cannot be refiled, court officials said.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Limiting New York Parkers
description: Too many New Yorkers on all-day outings have been using the best parking spaces at Bergen County's Van Saun Park, said Richard Mola, director of the county Board of Freeholders. Today, the board is to take a final vote on Mr. Mola's proposal to restrict three of the park's dozen lots to New Jersey residents and to issue $42 tickets to violators.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Horses Seeking Some Shade
description: It is unlikely that any combination of heat and humidity in Atlanta will force the postponement of equestrian events, officials of that sport said today.

title: Gregory T. Frazier, 58; Helped Blind See Movies With Their Ears
description: Gregory T. Frazier, a San Francisco visionary who hit on the idea of providing simultaneous electronic audio descriptions for the blind so they could enjoy more than the dialogue of movies, television and theater performances, died on Sunday at a hospital in San Francisco. He was 58 and president of Audiovision, a struggling not-for-profit company he formed to translate his vision into routine reality.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;In Old West, a Nice Girl Turns Wild
description: TIE MY BONES TO HER BACK By Robert F. Jones 271 pages. Farrar Straus Giroux. $23.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIRST UNION BUYS A $458.7 MILLION MORTGAGE PORTFOLIO
description: First Union Capital Markets Group has bought a $458.7 million master servicing portfolio from the Bear Stearns Mortgage Capital Corporation. It was the second time in two years that First Union had bought a mortgage servicing portfolio from Bear Stearns, and it increased the value of serviced mortgages to more than $7 billion, covering about 74,000 mortgages in all. Of that, fewer than 50 are commercial mortgages. The Bear Stearns portfolio includes about 4,900 residential mortgages.

title: Industrial Output Gains, And Inflation Stays Low
description: The economy remained healthy and balanced last month, displaying solid gains in industrial production and no signs of surging inflation, the Government reported today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Traffic Deaths on the Job
description: Traffic deaths were the leading cause of on-the-job deaths in New Jersey in 1994, accounting for 25 of 114 fatalities, state officials said yesterday. The workplace death rate of 3 in 100,000 workers was less than the national average of 5 in 100,000, according to a report released by the state Department of Health and Senior Services. Homicide, which took 22 lives, was the second leading cause of death at work sites, the department said.

title: Pataki Fund-Raising Total Overstated
description: Gov. George E. Pataki released his campaign records for the first half of the year today, and they showed that his aides had overstated how much he had raised when they announced the totals on Monday.

title: POLITICS;In Their Own Words
description: BOB DOLE Speaking via satellite to the National Governors' Association conference in Fajardo, Puerto Rico, yesterday:

title: Real Estate;Stores, offices and a 500-room hotel are planned to go with a Seattle convention center expansion.
description: WITH construction in downtown Seattle picking up, a developer has been chosen to build a project that includes stores, offices and a 500-room hotel.

title: Food Notes
description: Custom-Made Lunch

title: Teacher's Aide Charged in Death of Newborn
description: A 26-year-old teacher's aide has been charged by a Nassau County grand jury with manslaughter after her newborn son drowned in a toilet, officials said today.

title: Office in Files Affair Got Little Oversight
description: The question of whether the Clinton White House misused confidential F.B.I. personnel files for political purposes may never be answered.

title: POLITICS: THE MESSAGE;CLINTON WILL LIMIT THOSE ON WELFARE TO 2 YEARS OF AID
description: President Clinton announced today that he was taking action to require welfare recipients to go to work within two years, and he said they would lose benefits if they did not.

title: Cause for Sibling Rivalry at Teamsters
description: Close to 30 percent of the 1.4 million members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters are women. So does it matter that so many members of the brotherhood are actually sisters?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CALLAWAY GOLF CO., Carlsbad, Calif., a maker of golf clubs, acquired an 80 percent interest in Golf Trading G.m.b.H. as part of a plan to increase its international sales. The purchase involved an undisclosed amount of cash and stock options.

title: Toys 'R' Us Ordered To Pay $46 Million
description: Toys "R" Us Inc. has been ordered to pay $46 million plus interest to a Kuwaiti trading firm that contended that the toy retailer wrongly terminated a 1982 agreement to operate franchise stores in the Middle East.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Fresh Tomatoes in a Salsa for Fish
description: Tomatoes will never be better than they are from now until the first frost, so use them as much as possible. In this menu they are used in a salsa that complements a simply prepared, delicate-tasting fish.

title: Man Asks Official to Blow Up School
description: After sharing a few cocktails with a friend at a local pub, a 40-year-old New Hyde Park man placed a call to his local congressman and offered him $2,000 to help him blow up the high school building where he once worked as a custodian, Nassau County police said today.

title: 50-Year Celebration Of Seeing Liberty
description: THE skies threatened and delivered on Monday night, but the rain had little effect on a celebration at the Statue of Liberty. The reception hall in Liberty's base was the setting for a black-tie dinner for the 50th anniversary of George Lang's arrival in America from Hungary -- to the day.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Genie, His Magical Boombox and a Boy in Need
description: Memo to Shaquille O'Neal: Don't give up your night job.

title: Jewish Studies Isn't an Exclusive Scholarship;No to Ethnic Studies
description: To the Editor:

title: Making a Dud of the Bombs in Conrad's Plot
description: To the Editor:

title: Repackaging the Convention
description: To try to make the Republican convention more exciting to television viewers, officials will use show business techniques -- and will keep most speeches short. Page D21.

title: An Unsteady-Looking Yeltsin Finally Meets Gore
description: Appearing wan and stiff, President Boris N. Yeltsin met with Vice President Al Gore today in a session that failed to dispel nagging questions about the Russian leader's health.

title: Maple Creek Journal;A Prison Where the Great Spirit of Healing Dwells
description: Four years ago, Bridget Bruyere, 24, a Saulteaux Indian from Fort Alexander, Manitoba, was a prostitute in Winnipeg. She picked up a customer, accompanied him to his apartment and knifed him to death.

title: Mitsubishi Acts in Sexual Harassment Case
description: Saying it is trying to resolve a huge Federal sexual harassment lawsuit, Mitsubishi Motors Manufacturing of America Inc. outlined training programs today that are intended to protect and promote women and minority workers.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;No Insurance Grace Period
description: The state Supreme Court ruled on Monday that insurance companies could cancel policies immediately if drivers failed to pay premiums on time. Yesterday, Assemblyman Sean F. Dalton, Democrat of Turnersville, said he was drafting a bill to give New Jersey drivers a five-day grace period.

title: Use of Drugs While Pregnant Is Ruled Abuse
description: Women who use illegal drugs during pregnancy can be prosecuted for child abuse, the South Carolina Supreme Court has ruled.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Jeffires Joins Saints
description: The veteran wide receiver HAYWOOD JEFFIRES, a free agent from Houston, signed with the New Orleans Saints and started practice yesterday. Jeffires, with nine years in the National Football League, becomes one of the two most experienced players on the roster of the Saints, who lost their top receiver, QUINN EARLY, to free agency. New Orleans' next three receivers after Jeffires and MICHAEL HAYNES have a total of just three starts among them. Jeffires, 31, led the Oilers in catches in 1995 with 61 for 684 yards and 8 touchdowns.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Scientology Suit Is Thrown Out
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan dismissed the last element yesterday of a $416 million libel suit brought by the Church of Scientology International against Time Warner Inc. and Time magazine, involving a 1991 article that described the Scientology movement as "global racket."

title: OLYMPICS;For U.S. Women, Winning Is Hot Issue in Field Hockey
description: Everybody else in this city is giving thanks for the moderate temperatures so far, but the United States women's field hockey players will not mind if the weather cooks up by Saturday morning when they open their Olympic competition against the Netherlands.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: TV Notes;Imus in the Morning News
description: NBC's new 24-hour news channel, MSNBC, is to announce a deal today with Don Imus, the outspoken radio talk host, that will bring his program to the cable channel live each morning.

title: Sorbet Made in 10 Minutes From Canned (Really!) Fruit
description: GO ahead, put on a wig and sunglasses, duck into the neighborhood supermarket, and buy canned fruit. Yes, it's mid-July, the produce stands overflow with ripe peaches and plums, but even serious cooks might consider the canned kind.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AGCO AND RABOBANK NEDERLAND FORM JOINT VENTURE
description: The Agco Corporation said yesterday that it would sell a majority stake of its Agricredit retail finance subsidiary to Rabobank Nederland for about $26 million in cash, forming a joint venture that Agco said would help it sell more farm equipment in North America. The joint venture would be in addition to three European financing joint ventures with Rabobank, known collectively as Massey Ferguson Finance. Under the agreement, Agco will retain a 49 percent stake in Agricredit, allowing Agco, based in Duluth, Ga., to remove about $500 million in bank borrowing from its consolidated balance sheets. When a company owns 50 percent or more of another company, it must include that company in its balance sheets.

title: OLYMPICS;Everything but Medals at the Olympic Village
description: Manuel Passarinho, the team doctor for Portugal's judo players, had a major problem with the Olympic Village. The food was too good. His athletes were putting on a few pounds, what with 150 items to choose from at each meal, and inviting choices to be made among 22 kinds of breads, 15 different cheeses and 18 varieties of fruit. Judo players fight in various weight classes, and they can't afford to lose the battle of the bulge.

title: Campaign Reform, Deformed
description: If there were a prize given for political impudence, Republicans in the House of Representatives would surely win hands down. Speaker Newt Gingrich and his colleagues have set aside the next few days for what they grandly bill as "Reform Week," supposedly to address the corrupt system of campaign financing. Americans need to pay close attention to the fine print.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Arianna Huffington;A Phoenix of the Right Rises
description: AN editor's phone call interrupts the post-deadline languor of Arianna Huffington, striving columnist and firebird of right-wing Republican polemics, at Coco Pazzo, the East Side restaurant, where she is lingering over caffe latte and the dregs of her husband's failed 1994 race for the Senate.

title: Clinton Aide and Prosecutor Clash at Arkansas Bankers' Trial
description: In an often confrontational cross-examination today, a Whitewater prosecutor took on Bruce R. Lindsey, President Clinton's longtime friend and top aide, and suggested that he might have illegally conspired to hide large cash withdrawals by the 1990 Clinton campaign for governor.

title: Girls School May Violate Little-Known City Law
description: Forgotten amid this week's furor over a proposed all-girls public school in Harlem is a little-known city law that forbids single-sex public schools.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Money and Business on Sunday about a push by Citicorp into emerging markets overseas referred incompletely to comments by the Citicorp chairman, John S. Reed, on the prospects for a sale or spinoff of the company's corporate banking operations. He said in an interview that there would be pressure for a sale or a spinoff in three to five years. But he also said there would be no reason for such a move so long as the corporate banking and consumer banking operations continued to complement each other.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Peace Talks Resume In Ulster, but in Anger
description: After a week of riots, Northern Ireland's politicians returned to peace talks today but spent the day denouncing one another.

title: Business Travel;Buying a share of a private jet can prove surprisingly cost effective for some companies.
description: COMPANIES seeking more efficient use of their executives' travel time have an option that can be surprisingly cost effective: buying a share of a business jet.

title: Sports of The Times;Magic Gives The Mayor An Assist
description: A crowd had gathered in the shimmering heat outside City Hall around noontime yesterday. Folding chairs and a lectern had been arranged on the steps of the building, and directly across the way a basketball backboard with hoop and net had been rolled in for the occasion.

title: Israel's Meretz Party Defends Secular Turf
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;24 Players Are Eligible For Arbitration
description: Three members of the Stanley Cup champion Colorado Avalanche, including goalie PATRICK ROY, are among 24 players eligible for salary arbitration, the National Hockey League said yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For ANN STOCK, the White House social secretary, lunch yesterday may have been a social occasion, but it was a respite from the hundreds of state dinners, receptions, parties and teas that she oversees every year. She was the guest of honor at a luncheon given by MICHAEL BERMAN, the president of George magazine at Remi on West 54th Street.

title: TV Notes;Some Friends More Equal
description: If the six stars of "Friends" believed they could easily squeeze a little extra money out of their studio, Warner Brothers, by threatening a mass holdout from the Aug. 12 start-up of new production on the NBC series, they may wind up first shocked and then burned.

title: Placement Offices Leave Old Niches To Become Web-Surfing Job Bazaars
description: In this era of corporate downsizing, colleges are being pressed as never before to insure that their students can slide into jobs when they graduate. Parents -- some of whom have been laid off themselves and are paying hefty tuition bills -- want reassurance that they are making a good investment.

title: Chief Who Preserved Mill Jobs Is Now Cutting 450 Positions
description: Aaron Feuerstein, the chairman of Malden Mills Industries who became a national folk hero for his loyalty to his workers, is backing away from a promise to preserve the jobs of all 3,200 employees at the family-owned textile company in Lawrence, Mass.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Palestine, 2 Strong, Hoists Its Flag
description: Two runners stood quietly at attention in the Olympic Village today as the national anthem of Palestine was played and the Palestinian flag was raised for the first time at an Olympiad.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on June 27 about a move in Congress to curb fees for the use of automated teller machines included one bank erroneously among those that charge fees. The First Chicago NBD Corporation, cited in a survey by Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, does not impose a fee on customers of other banks who use its machines.

title: Netanyahu, Home, Finds Honeymoon Is Waning
description: Fresh from an American tour and boasting that Washington did not try to "twist my arm," Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has returned to new pressures at home, and is bracing for some arm-twisting by his Arab neighbors.

title: A WILD DAY ON WALL STREET: MARKET PLACE;Trading Pause Saved the Day For Wall Street
description: The circuit broke, and the market was saved.

title: Aquatic Aerobics
description: To The Living Section:

title: Wine Talk
description: SHOULD you happen upon Gidleigh Park in strolling through the Internet, you will find an entry that begins:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Philip Morris Profit Up 15% As Tobacco Gains Overseas
description: Providing further evidence that big consumer-products companies are countering the second-quarter slump among technology and health care leaders, the Philip Morris Companies announced strong second-quarter earnings gains yesterday. The results were fueled by a turnaround in the company's food business and strong growth in the overseas tobacco business, which could soon overtake its domestic cigarette operations.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Essays Inspired By Games
description: Everyone is playing the Olympics game, but no one is doing it more energetically than NBC, the network that has spent a fortune for the live-coverage rights.

title: In Shift, U.S. Will Seek Binding World Pact to Combat Global Warming
description: For the first time, the United States will seek a binding international agreement to reduce the kinds of air pollution, chiefly from burning fossil fuels, that threaten to warm the global climate, Administration officials said today.

title: Ethics Bill for Advisers Is Backed
description: A House subcommittee today approved legislation that could subject outside White House advisers to conflict of interest laws and ethics rules.

title: COMPANY NEWS;EMERSON RADIO INCREASES ITS OFFER FOR JENSEN SHARES
description: The Emerson Radio Corporation said yesterday that it was willing to increase to $10 a share from $8.90 its offer for William Blair Leveraged Capital Fund's shares in International Jensen Inc. Emerson, based in Parsippany, N.J., also said it was willing to buy all of Blair's stock immediately. Jensen has already agreed to be acquired by the Recoton Corporation, based in Lake Mary, Fla., for $101.7 million, in the form of $11 a share to holders other than Jensen's president, Robert Shaw, and Blair, and $8.90 a share for Mr. Shaw and Blair. Mr. Shaw and Blair together control 63 percent of Jensen. Emerson's new offer is its latest for Jensen, based in Lincolnshire, Ill., a loudspeaker manufacturer and distributor.

title: A WILD DAY ON WALL STREET: THE MARKET;Stocks on Roller Coaster, But Finish Little Changed
description: The stock market rode out the busiest day in its 204-year history yesterday, and the wildest day since the 1987 market plunge, to end basically unchanged.

title: Fire Delays L.I.R.R. Trains on Three Lines
description: A fire beneath a car on a Long Island Rail Road train in Queens last night delayed service for up to an hour on three lines, an official said.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Merrill Lynch Reports Surge Of 53% in Net
description: Despite the wildly fluctuating stock market yesterday, Merrill Lynch & Company demonstrated how rich Wall Street's boom has been, as the nation's largest securities firm reported a 53 percent surge in second-quarter earnings that exceeded analysts' expectations.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Inmate Wants Confidentiality
description: John M. Martini, the death row inmate whose plea to be executed without further appeals was rejected by the New Jersey Supreme Court last month, asked the court yesterday to prevent a judge from receiving confidential information he had given to his former lawyers in the state Public Defender's office. The nature of the information has not been disclosed, but Judge Bruce A. Gaeta of Bergen County Superior Court could decide to make it public after a closed hearing on July 26. The Public Defender's office wants to use the information in an attempt to overturn Mr. Martini's sentence. Mr. Martini's new lawyer, Alan L. Zegas, contended that releasing the information to Judge Gaeta would violate attorney-client privilege.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PLY-GEM DECIDES AGAINST SALE OF THE COMPANY
description: Ply-Gem Industries, a maker of building products, said yesterday that it had decided against selling the company because a fourfold increase in second quarter earnings had demonstrated that its efforts to increase profits appeared to be working. Last August, Ply-Gem hired the investment bank Bear, Stearns & Company to explore a sale of the company. Ply-Gem shares closed down 12.5 cents yesterday, at $12.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock traded as high as $19.875 last August.

title: Ex-Governor Apologizes For Trying to Stay in Office
description: The former Governor apologized today to the new Governor and the state. The new Governor accepted, but the state may take its time.

title: The Talk and Tastes of Bleecker Street
description: TWO sweets purveyors in homey-looking storefronts -- painted white, pale yellow and lime and decorated with vintage kitchen accessories -- have opened on Bleecker Street in Greenwich Village.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Consultants Joining To Form a Company
description: Alvin Achenbaum, a longtime agency consultant and executive, is joining Pete Bogda, president and managing principal of the M/A/R/C Consulting Group, to form a consulting company, Achenbaum Bogda Associates.

title: 16 Indicted On Charges Of Internet Pornography
description: The case began last spring with familiar horror: a 6-year-old girl returning home from a slumber party with a tale of sexual abuse by the father of one of her young friends.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Sprint and Ameritech Post A Rise in Their Earnings
description: Two of the nation's largest telephone companies posted higher second-quarter earnings yesterday, reflecting increases in phone traffic and in demand for more phone lines.

title: FILM REVIEW;The Doublemint Twins Times 2, Plus Chaos
description: Cloning is no new idea among Hollywood hit makers, but Harold Ramis's "Multiplicity" actually treats it as a comic premise. The idea is that life would be easier with the help of full-scale replicas, making it possible for the overstressed, overburdened individual to be in more than one place at one time. This would be funnier if fewer of us found it so true.

title: Robert Manners, 82, Anthropologist
description: Dr. Robert Alan Manners, professor emeritus and founding chairman of the Department of Anthropology at Brandeis University, died on Friday at his home in Newton Center, Mass. He was 82.

title: Personal Health
description: AS millions of recreational runners, tennis players, golfers and swimmers have sadly discovered, you do not have to be training for the Olympics to suffer the pain and physical limitations of overuse injuries. Among the walking wounded are runners with shin splints, stress fractures and Achilles tendinitis; racquet and club swingers with tennis and golf elbows, and swimmers with sore shoulders.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Anderson Heading Out West To Blazers
description: Point guard Kenny Anderson can go from spectacular to uninspiring almost between dribbles, the trademark inconsistencies that made the Nets almost relieved he didn't take their offer of a six-year, $39 million deal a year ago.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Monday about the history of Royal Lytham and St. Annes, the site for this week's British Open golf tournament, misidentified the player whom the Scots called the Wee Icemon. He was Ben Hogan, not Bob Jones.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-8

title: At the Nation's Table: Washington;Asian Street Food Comes Indoors
description: As Mark Miller, the owner and creator of Raku, a lively new restaurant on Dupont Circle, describes his intent: "It's not about a meal at Raku. It's about a place to hang out with friends."

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Intel Earnings Surpass Expectations of Analysts
description: Offering jittery technology investors a dose of confidence, the Intel Corporation, which makes the microprocessor chips that power most of the world's personal computers, reported stronger-than-expected second-quarter results today, surpassing most analysts' expectations by a wide margin.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Garelick Farms, Franklin, Mass., to Leonard/Monahan, Providence, R.I., to handle advertising for the dairy company, previously handled by Harcomm Associates, Cambridge, Mass. Billings were estimated at $2 million to $4 million. State of New Jersey Department of Transportation, Trenton, to the Lunar Group, Whippany, N.J., to handle its advertising and public relations account, previously at Wenzel & Co., Pennington, N.J. Billings were estimated at $1.6 million for two years.

title: Bomb Threat Delays Flight to Moscow
description: A bomb threat and a thief with $6,000 in his pocket delayed a Moscow-bound Aeroflot jet at Kennedy International Airport yesterday for more than four hours, officials said.

title: Investors Pull Money Out of Stock Funds
description: Mutual fund investors, shocked by a turnaround in stock prices so sharp and so sudden that in some cases it erased a year's worth of gains in a few weeks, have pulled money out of stock funds at several of the country's biggest mutual fund companies the last two days.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Dolphins Want Mitchell
description: The Miami Dolphins say they still hope to reach an agreement with the free agent tight end JOHNNY MITCHELL, who spent the last four seasons with the Jets.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: COMPANY NEWS;INTERAMERICAS ACQUIRES COMPANIES IN ECUADOR
description: The InterAmericas Communications Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire 52.6 percent of Conecell S.A., a cellular phone company in Ecuador, for a total of about $100 million of cash, notes and common stock. InterAmericas, a telecommunications company based in Key Biscayne, Fla., also plans to acquire 52.6 percent of Conecell's sister company, Corptilor, which provides paging services to more than 1,200 subscribers in Ecuador. Conecell has about 30,000 subscribers in its network area.

title: A Sip and a View, Without the Grit
description: IN New York, the best places to sit outdoors, sip a glass of chilled pinot grigio and gaze at a stunning or provocative sight are not necessarily sidewalk cafes. The most seductive places are recessed from the street, far away from car exhaust and the rush of hot, sweaty bodies.

title: Swastikas on Army Doors
description: Red swastikas were smeared early today on eight doors in a Fort Bragg, N.C., Army barracks housing Special Forces soldiers, the Pentagon announced, and the authorities restricted 350 soldiers to the base during their investigation into the incident.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;G.M.'s Net Declined 16.7% in 2d Quarter
description: The General Motors Corporation reported a 16.7 percent decline in second-quarter net income because of a one-time $328 million charge indirectly relating to its spinoff last month of the Elecronic Data Systems Corporation. But the profits from continuing operations were better than most Wall Street analysts expected.

title: Bipartisan Agreement Reached Regarding Chemicals in Foods
description: A bipartisan group of House members said today that they had reached agreement on a compromise pesticide bill that would guard consumers against dangerous chemicals in food while ending what they described as an outdated law that threatened to keep many useful substances away from growers.

title: Silver-Gun Rapist' Suspect Is Charged in Queens Assaults
description: A parolee from Queens was arrested yesterday on charges that he attacked 10 women in eastern Queens in the last month, sexually assaulting three of them, the police said.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Caterpillar Posts a 16% Rise In Profit Despite Lower Sales
description: Caterpillar Inc. said today that earnings rose 16 percent in the second quarter despite a decline in equipment sales.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Strahan Seems to Be Poised To Reject Offer by Giants
description: Contract negotiations between the Giants and defensive end Michael Strahan continued this week with the Giants making a substantial offer that, if accepted, would lock up Strahan into the next century.

title: Beware Anorexia
description: To The Living Section:

title: Mattel Cleared of Accusations of Accounting Irregularities
description: An independent investigation of Mattel Inc. has concluded that there were no irregularities in the toy manufacturer's accounting practices, according to a statement released yesterday by members of the audit committee of the company's board.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Technology Improves Detection
description: New drug-testing technology introduced for this year's Olympic Games could push the window of detection for anabolic steroids back as far as 18 months, the director of the laboratory said today.

title: Potluck Now, Cookbook Later
description: MITCHELL DAVIS organized a cookbook party. Once his guests arrived, he began working on the book.

title: Of Sexuality as Darwinian Olympics
description: You don't have to be an art-world insider to be fascinated by the cinematic world of Matthew Barney, the 29-year-old performance artist whose body-centered exhibitions have made him one of the most talked-about figures in New York art circles. Mr. Barney's gallery performances and their related films, which have involved elaborate tests of physical endurance, are seriocomic rituals that whimsically address the fantasies of a culture obsessed with beauty, sex and competitive physical performance.

title: School Board to Remove Its Secretary, a Bane to Chancellors
description: Bruce K. Gelbard, the secretary to the Board of Education who infuriated a succession of Schools Chancellors with the sway he held over the board, has lost the support of a majority of its members and will be dismissed today, officials said yesterday.

title: Target for Hostage-Takers: U.N. Unit
description: Western officials have expressed strong concern about possible reprisals against NATO troops if Bosnian Serb leaders are arrested for war crimes, but some Bosnian Serb authorities are zeroing in on what could be the most vulnerable group in the country, the United Nations international police monitors.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets' No. 2 Rookie Receiver Is First Rate
description: Alex Van Dyke will have to wait for another day to catch a pass.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Food Poisoning Spreads Among Children in Japan
description: The number of victims in a food poisoning outbreak in Japan grew to almost 6,000 today, most of them children.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nestle Says Sales Rose 6% in First Half
description: Nestle S.A. said yesterday that its sales rose 6 percent in the first half of the year to 28.4 billion Swiss francs ($22.69 billion). The company also predicted that sales for the year would rise more than 6 percent, and that it would see "good growth" in profits.

title: HFS Plans Share Buyback
description: HFS Inc. said today that it might begin repurchasing company stock as part of a buyback plan approved in December 1994. HFS, the nation's largest hotel and real-estate franchiser, approved the plan to buy back up to $50 million in common shares from time to time in the open market or in privately negotiated transactions. An HFS spokesman said the market had been soft and it "may be advantageous for the company to take advantage of the company's low stock price." HFS stock closed at $51.375 a share today, down $6.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Those 'Smart' Weapons Are a Good Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: A WILD DAY ON WALL STREET: THE FOREIGN STOCKS;A Tremor On Wall St. Reverberates Overseas
description: The rest of the world didn't stand a chance.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Reichel Back to Flames
description: The Czech center ROBERT REICHEL, who left the Calgary Flames last season because of a contract dispute, will return to the team as soon as his German league deal is dissolved. Reichel and the Flames' general manager, AL COATES, have agreed to a three-year contract worth $4.4 million. However, Reichel still has a three-year deal with the Frankfurt Lions. Reichel, 25, had 137 goals in 355 games with the Flames, including 40 each in 1992-93 and 1993-94.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The PRINCESS of WALES took yet another step into her new life as a single woman by resigning her leadership or membership in almost 100 charitable organizations, the Press Association of Britain reported yesterday.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn Prices Decline on Signs Of Ebbing Need for Stockpiles
description: Corn prices tumbled on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday on signs that recent record prices had reduced demand for the inventories left over from last year's crop.

title: U.S. to Tell Serbs They Face New Sanctions
description: Richard C. Holbrooke, the special American envoy to the Balkans, plans to tell President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia on Wednesday that economic sanctions will be reimposed on Serbia unless the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, is both removed from power and leaves Bosnia, two senior Western officials said.

title: Kerkorian Group Plans to Buy MGM Studio for $1.3 Billion
description: Kirk Kerkorian is back in show business. Mr. Kerkorian, the wily billionaire who bought and sold Metro Goldwyn Mayer Inc. twice before, is buying it one more time.

title: New Ban for New Mexico St.
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today placed the New Mexico State basketball program on three years' probation and restricted the school from offering scholarships to junior college transfers for two years.

title: Journal;Dole's Snowe Job
description: Olympia Snowe, the pro-choice Republican Senator from Maine, had heard rumors Friday morning of an imminent announcement about her party's abortion plank. But when her office checked with the Dole campaign, it was told the rumors were wrong. Ms. Snowe then went off to give a luncheon speech blasting President Clinton's "abysmal record" while heaping praise on Bob Dole for championing the Federal Glass Ceiling Commission and financing the Violence Against Women Act. "It's ironic that even with Bob Dole as our nominee," she told her audience, "Republicans should have a gender gap problem."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;U.S. Tax Auction Tonight
description: Houses acquired through foreclo sure most selling for less than $100,000 -- will be auctioned tonight, the state office of the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development said. Sixty-nine houses and condominiums in the northern part of the state will be auctioned at the Sheraton at Woodbridge Place in Iselin.

title: Wall Street Is Calmer As Stocks Rise Again
description: Shoulders dropped a little on Wall Street yesterday, as a reassuring day ended with all the major market benchmarks higher in extremely heavy trading. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 18.12 points, and the badly battered Nasdaq composite index, rose 33.18 points, or 3.15 percent -- the index's largest single-day jump ever.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Rewe of Germany Buys Austrian Grocery Chain
description: The German retail company Rewe has acquired Billa, an Austrian chain of 1,600 supermarkets, for 10 billion to 15 billion schillings ($1 billion to $1.5 billion) in Austria's biggest takeover ever. Billa, which had sales of 50 billion schillings last year, is Austria's largest private employer and biggest retail company, with a market share of about 28 percent. Rewe, with sales of 43.13 billion marks, or $29 billion, is Germany's biggest retailer.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Arrest Leads to Release
description: LAMAR THOMAS was released by Tampa Bay, a week after he was arrested and charged with two counts of aggravated battery against his pregnant fiancee.

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;Dole Attacks Clinton on Education Issues
description: Depicting President Clinton as a "pliant pet of militant teachers' unions," Bob Dole today described the nation's public schools as overrun by crime and mediocrity. And Mr. Dole attributed their decline to what he said was Mr. Clinton's loyalty to unions and adherence to a generation of failed ideas.

title: Keeping Your Cool . . . Staying in Town;The Crosstown Bus
description: The city whispers on summer weekends -- it's a lover saying, "Come discover what I really am."

title: President Says Cuts Are Too Deep in Republican Welfare Plan
description: On the eve of a House vote, President Clinton today raised a dozen objections to a major Republican welfare bill and urged Congress to send him a bipartisan substitute that makes more modest cuts in future welfare spending.

title: In New Rebuff to Leader, Teamsters Vote to Remain a Brotherhood
description: By almost two to one, delegates voted not to drop the "brotherhood" from the name of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: New Pan Am Agrees to Buy Carnival Air for $100 Million
description: A reborn Pan American World Airways, the most famous carrier in airline history until it flew into bankruptcy in 1991, has reached a tentative agreement to buy Carnival Air Lines. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed, but the price was known to be about $100 million -- about half in Pan Am stock.

title: Currents;A Versace Rehab That's Fit for a Vanderbilt
description: THE imperious fashion designer Gianni Versace is known for his 200-store family retail empire. He should also be known for his obsessive devotion to architectural preservation, evident at stores like the rejuvenated 1932 Roger et Gallet Building in Paris. They are as classically restrained as his clothes are provocatively kitsch.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WHIRLPOOL PLANS TO CUT 550 TO 800 JOBS IN INDIANA
description: The Whirlpool Corporation said yesterday that it planned to simplify its top-mount refrigerator manufacturing operations in Evansville, Ind., in a move that would eliminate 550 to 800 jobs. Whirlpool, based in Benton Harbor, Mich., said the actions would focus more of the production at the Evansville plant on Whirlpool's recently redesigned midsize refrigerator line. It added that it was considering elimination of several older refrigerator models that were less popular. Layoffs could begin as early as the first quarter of 1997.

title: Calendar: Blooms, Pictures
description: Gardens and Garden Art Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue, near Eastern Parkway; (718) 622-4433.

title: U.S. Law Respects Cuba Investor Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: 35 States Approve Lloyd's Accord Proposal
description: Lloyd's of London said yesterday that 35 states had approved a proposed settlement that would reduce the debt of its American investors, or "names."

title: Serb Stands Firm in Face of U.S. Effort to Oust Karadzic
description: A round of high-profile American talks to persuade President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia to remove the Bosnian Serb leader, Radovan Karadzic, from power in Bosnia ended without progress today, the special United States envoy to the Balkans, Richard C. Holbrooke, said.

title: An Accord That Could Help Murdoch
description: Time Warner and the Turner Broadcasting System are the obvious victors in yesterday's agreement between Time Warner and the Federal Trade Commission. But the deal could also be a big windfall for a media mogul with no ties to either company: Rupert Murdoch.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sema Group Buys Olivetti Unit
description: Sema Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it would pay L64.2 million, or $100 million, for Syntax Processing, an information technology unit of Olivetti S.p.A. Sema, a British-French technology services company, said it would pay L32.1 million for Syntax now, L22.6 million on Dec. 31, 1997, and a further L9.5 million to acquire the Syntax brand name.

title: France to Cut a Third of Its Army Regiments
description: France will disband 38 of its 129 army regiments, including 11 stationed in Germany, and close barracks, army hospitals and air bases around the country as part of a plan to cut the uniformed armed forces from 500,000 to 350,000 by 2002, the Defense Ministry announced today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES TO BUY NORA BEVERAGES
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. signed a letter of intent yesterday to acquire Nora Beverages Inc., producer of Naya brand Canadian spring water, for about $117 million. The payment would be made in cash and stock at the discretion of the seller, the investor Ahmed Hbouss, who holds 60 percent of Nora's stock and would remain on the management team. Coca-Cola Enterprises, based in Atlanta, is the largest distributor of Naya, handling about half of the worldwide volume. In 1995, Nora, based in Mirabel, Quebec, had operating revenues of $46 million. Coca-Cola Enterprises is the world's largest bottler of soft drinks, distributing about 57 percent of the Coca-Cola Company's bottle and can volume in the United States.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: Giant Pumpkins

title: Secret Service Details Findings on Drug Use
description: Of several hundred Clinton Administration officials who were screened for access to the White House in late 1993 and early 1994, about 40 had a history of drug use that went beyond youthful experimentation, Secret Service agents said today.

title: Currents;Pottery That Puts The Surprise Inside
description: HEATHER McCARTNEY, the daughter of Linda and Paul McCartney, is stepping out from their very tall shadows to begin a career as a potter with a collection of impeccably detailed terra-cotta vessels at Felissimo, 10 West 56th Street, starting in September. They are fired raw on the outside and glazed inside in pretty flower garden colors. Ms. McCartney, 34, developed her inside-out pots while living with the Tarahumara Indians in Mexico. They will cost about $350 each.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JOHN HORTON MURRAY, a tenor, thought he was getting away from opera when he took a few days off last week to go camping in Italy. On a lark, he went to see a performance of "Carmen" on Sunday at an amphitheater in Verona, and by evening's end, he was singing the role of Don Jose.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Sony's Chairman Is Hospitalized
description: The Sony Corporation said yesterday that its chairman, Norio Ohga, had been hospitalized for sunstroke and would probably miss a meeting of United States and Japanese officials trying to resolve differences over semiconductor trade. Mr. Ohga, who is 66, began to feel ill while playing golf in Hawaii on Friday and checked into a hospital on Monday for tests after his return to Tokyo, the company said.

title: OLYMPICS;Horses' Safety Is Questioned
description: America's largest animal welfare group called for the three-day equestrian event to be made safer or removed from the program at future Olympics.

title: The Better Welfare Bill
description: The House plans to vote today on two welfare bills. The Republican version could push a million children into poverty, victimize legal immigrants and leave no ironclad Federal safety net underneath families that search for but cannot find work. The bipartisan alternative, sponsored by Mike Castle, Republican of Delaware, and John Tanner, a Tennessee Democrat, is also needlessly punitive but at least removes the cruelest fangs of the G.O.P. measure.

title: Preventing AIDS Is Still the Best Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Dolphins Sign Mitchell, Finally
description: After days of speculation, tight end JOHNNY MITCHELL signed with Miami yesterday.

title: Building Starts on Homes Took Strong Jump in June
description: Construction starts on new homes rose unexpectedly in June, the Commerce Department said today, in the latest evidence of the resiliency of the housing market.

title: After Record Delay, Pressure Builds for Budget Reform
description: With voters, school officials and business leaders across the state expressing deep dismay and even disgust with this year's record-long budget fight, the Republican leader of the State Senate offered a time-honored government remedy.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Scheduling Adjustment Gives Viewers a Better Look at Johnson
description: Michael Johnson is emerging as a prime-time television attraction in his bid for a 400-200 track and field double.

title: Kenneth Bainbridge, 91, Chief Of First Test of Atomic Bomb
description: Dr. Kenneth T. Bainbridge, the physicist who directed the first test of an atomic bomb, died on Sunday in Lexington, Mass., where he lived. He was 91.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SAFEGUARD SCIENTIFIC STOCK RISES STRONGLY
description: The shares of Safeguard Scientifics Inc. jumped yesterday after the company said it would distribute to its shareholders the rights to buy shares of closely held Sanchez Computer Associates. Safeguard's business is finding promising private companies, taking stakes in them and helping sell shares to the public. Safeguard shareholders would receive the right to buy the shares first. Shares of Safeguard, based in Wayne, Pa., rose $6.375, to $67.375. Sanchez Computer develops accounting software for the financial services industry.

title: Keeping Your Cool . . .;Is There Any Air Stirring Here?
description: ON a sticky shirt-drencher of a day, it can be breezier underground than it is on the Brooklyn Bridge or at Pier 17 at the South Street Seaport.

title: 600 City Employees Suspected in a Plot For Evading Taxes
description: At least 600 New York City employees are suspected of failing to pay Federal and state income taxes in what officials said may have been the result of loosely organized schemes at several city agencies. Some of the employees, including 15 police officers, claimed they were not subject to United States tax law.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Guilty Pleas in College Theft
description: Two men who prosecutors say belong to the Genovese crime family pleaded guilty yesterday to money-laundering charges for their role in stealing nearly $1 million from Seton Hall University in Newark and South Orange in 1990 and 1991, The Associated Press reported.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Another Local Phone Service
description: Sprint Communications yesterday became the latest long-distance company authorized by the state Board of Public Utilities to provide local telephone service in New Jersey.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about stock trading on Tuesday misstated the change in the Nasdaq market's composite index in some editions. It fell 6.72 points, or about six-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,053.47.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Stork to Purchase Fokker Assets
description: Stork N.V., a Dutch machinery maker, agreed yesterday to pay 302.5 million guilders, or $178 million, for Fokker Aviation N.V., the holding company for the bankrupt aircraft maker's viable businesses. Stork said that 222.5 million guilders was for Fokker Aviation's shares, while 80 million was to take over a loan.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasury Prices Show Little Change
description: Treasury prices were nearly unchanged yesterday, while in the corporate bond market, Lucent Technologies Inc. sold $1.5 billion of notes in its first public debt offering.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Judge Allows Sale of Campus
description: The city's school district may go ahead with plans to buy the former campus of Upsala College for $4 million, a Federal bankruptcy judge ruled on Tuesday. The 38-acre campus has been dormant since the school folded in May 1995, owing creditors more than $12 million.

title: Politics Didn't Dictate U.S. Loan to Ukraine;Misguided Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THE THIRD PARTY;Reform Party's Crucial Surveying Runs Into Problems
description: Many New York State supporters of Ross Perot's national movement have yet to receive a preference survey that they are supposed to return by mail no later than this Saturday to help determine the finalists for the Reform Party's Presidential nomination, an official of an allied party says.

title: CYCLING;Indurain Is Still the King With His Fans in Spain
description: El Rey Miguel Indurain V came home a hero today in the Tour de France.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Italian High Jumper Banned
description: Antonella Bevilacqua of Italy, who is among the six best women's high jumpers in the world, will be banned from the Atlanta Olympics in a doping controversy Thursday, Italian officials said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Time Warner and F.T.C. In Accord on Turner Deal Time Warner and the Federal Trade Commission reached an agreement that would clear Time Warner's acquisition of Turner Broad- casting. But the F.T.C. required the new company, which would be the world's largest media concern, to carry a second news channel as a competitor to its own Cable News Network. [Page A1.]

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Politics Didn't Dictate U.S. Loan to Ukraine
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;European Union Clears Sandoz-Ciba Merger
description: The European Commission said yesterday that it had approved a $36 billion union between the Swiss drug makers Sandoz A.G. and Ciba-Geigy A.G. with only minor amendments. The commission, the executive agency of the European Union, authorized the creation of the new company, Novartis A.G., after Ciba and Sandoz agreed to license the production of methoprene, an ingredient used to make animal flea-control products, and to "use their influence" to guarantee competition in gene therapy.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: VASTAR RESOURCES INC., Houston, an oil and gas concern, acquired Conoco Inc.'s 30 percent working interest in the West Cameron 66 fields in the Gulf of Mexico for $37 million. Conoco, based in Houston, is owned by Du Pont.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Timothy Cohrs was named to the new position of vice president and executive creative director at Lai, Venuti & Lai Advertising, Santa Clara, Calif. He had spent 18 years at the in-house agency of Gap Inc., San Francisco.

title: BASEBALL;Mets Are Looking Ahead After Sweeping Phillies
description: Dallas Green would rather everyone cooled all this talk about a wild-card playoff berth. His 41 years in baseball have taught him that mid-July is no time to be thinking about what might happen in October.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Wetland Rule Halts Rail Job
description: The United States Army Corps of Engineers has ordered New Jersey Transit to temporarily halt work on a $448 million rail transfer station because of a permit violation.

title: Wall Street Exhales as Dow Gains 18 and Nasdaq Soars
description: Shoulders dropped a little on Wall Street yesterday as a deliciously reassuring day ended with all the major market benchmarks higher in extremely heavy trading.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Charming Shoppes Inc., Bensalem, Pa., is selling $120 million of convertible subordinated notes due in 2006 through Lazard Freres & Co. The notes which are callable in three years, carry an interest rate of 7.5 percent and are priced at par. The issue is rated B2 by Moody's and B- by S.& P.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Iraq Again Blocks U.N. Arms Inspectors
description: Less than a month after promising access, Iraq blocked United Nations weapons inspectors from a site on the outskirts of Baghdad, the head of the team told the Security Council today.

title: CONCERT REVIEW;Followers and Fireworks For the Philharmonic
description: When last encountered in Central Park, a year ago, the New York Philharmonic was holding forth in Sahara-like conditions, on a Great Lawn laid waste by the Walt Disney Company's "Pocahontas" juggernaut. On Tuesday evening, with the Great Lawn under repair, the Philharmonic was banished to the park's North Lawn, where the Metropolitan Opera had drawn indifferent crowds a month before.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Jobless Rate At 5-Year Low in June
description: Britain's jobless total in June slipped to a five-year low, but the unemployment rate stayed steady at 7.7 percent, the same as in May, the national statistics office said yesterday. The figures showed that unemployment dropped by 14,300 in June, to a total of 2,152,000. (Reuters)

title: COMPANY NEWS;PETROLEUM GEO-SERVICES TO SELL ITS SOME OPERATIONS
description: Petroleum Geo-Services A.S.A. agreed yesterday to sell its remaining two-dimensional data library and its remaining two-dimensional seismic vessel and related operations to Norex A.S., based in Norway, for about $31 million. Oil and gas companies use seismic data to develop their fields. Though the two-dimensional data, based on relatively old technology that generates underground pictures in slices, has generated positive sales and margins in recent years, Petroleum Geo-Services said the overhead associated with developing, selling and managing the product had eroded profitability. Petroleum Geo-Services, based in Houston, said it would focus more on higher technology products.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PHOENIX TECHNOLOGIES IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE VIRTUAL CHIPS
description: Phoenix Technologies Ltd. agreed yesterday to acquire Virtual Chips Inc. for stock worth about $20 million. Virtual Chips, which is closely held, makes synthesizable cores, the building blocks of integrated circuits used in personal computers and digital cameras. Phoenix, based in Santa Clara, Calif., creates interconnect software, which allows computers to communicate with peripherals. Phoenix will offer Virtual Chips stockholders, who still must approve the acquisition, 1.4 million shares of newly issued stock, valued at about $20 million. Shares of Phoenix rose $1, to $16.625, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Keeping Your Cool . . . Staying in Town;A Public Theater
description: I will never understand why millions of New Yorkers, after weathering wretched winter storms and gallons of April showers, pack up and head out of the city just when it's peaking at its sun-ripened sweetest.

title: OLYMPICS;Olympics Are a Mixed Blessing for Atlantans
description: They are stocking up on medicine, canceling trips to the mall and digging in for the long haul at Judith Barash's senior citizens high rise.

title: INSIDE
description: A Change on Pesticides

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Ugandan Boxer Is Charged
description: A Ugandan Olympic heavyweight boxer was charged today with passing counterfeit currency after he tried to buy women's underwear and shoes with fake $100 bills.

title: Chas Chandler, 57, Bassist and Manager
description: Chas Chandler, a veteran British rock musician whose bass playing helped the Animals to fame with the 1964 hit "The House of the Rising Sun," died today at Newcastle General Hospital. He was 57.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;In West End: Big Splash, Few Ripples
description: As theatrical events are measured, they don't come much bigger than "Martin Guerre," which, after six years in the making and a production cost of about $6 million, opened last week at the Prince Edward Theater. This is Cameron Mackintosh's big, solemn, operatic musical based on the same true story that served as the basis of the 1983 French film "The Return of Martin Guerre." The hopes were that "Martin Guerre" would bring some much needed excitement to a depressed West End, where even well-received shows have been closing too soon. No business.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Even in Eden, It Seems, War Was Hell
