description: WAR BEFORE CIVILIZATION By Lawrence H. Keeley Illustrated. 245 pages. Oxford University Press. $25.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;AMR's Net Rose 64.6% For Quarter
description: American Airlines' parent company reported today that its earnings rose an unexpectedly strong 64.6 percent in the second quarter, while Trans World Airlines Inc. reported nearly a fivefold jump in profits, but its results fell short of Wall Street's expectations.

title: 6 Are Accused of Violating Trademark Laws
description: An investigation into counterfeit designer clothing, sunglasses and watches led to sweltering, hazardous sweatshops where teen-agers worked 70-hour weeks for below-minimum wages, the Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said yesterday in announcing the arrests of six men on charges of violating trademark laws.

title: Editorial Notebook;Bulls, Bears and the White House
description: For sheer drama, the stock market has certainly surpassed the sluggish race between Bob Dole and President Clinton this summer. More striking, however, is what the two phenomena have in common. Both politics and the markets can be moved by mysterious, irrational forces. While Mr. Dole is trying to figure out why he cannot do better against a President with low poll ratings on character and integrity, Mr. Clinton may be wondering why the strong economy has not led to more stable markets.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Apple Surprises Wall Street by Cutting Losses
description: Defying gloomy predictions from Wall Street that have sent its stock to its lowest point in 10 years, Apple Computer reported a surprisingly small quarterly loss yesterday and said that it had stemmed a slide in its revenues.

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Get Rocked By Red Sox In Ninth
description: On a wild and unpredictable night of baseball at Fenway Park, one question actually caused a bleary-eyed, weary-looking Joe Torre to force a smile. That was a significant accomplishment, because "Torre" and "smile" did not belong in the same sentence tonight.

title: Metro Matters;While Albany Fiddled, Many Got Burned
description: THE Legislature and Governor relaxed last week after finally reaching agreement on the latest state budget ever. Lawmakers got their pork -- money for pet projects back home. And Gov. George E. Pataki, though an abject failure in meeting his goal of bringing in a conservative budget on time, nonetheless pronounced himself deeply satisfied because, he said, he and his administration "stuck to our principles."

title: AT HOME WITH: Sarabeth Levine;Spreading Joy and Marmalade
description: SHE is choking. Sarabeth Levine is standing in her kitchen, her real kitchen, in her Upper West Side apartment, a few blocks from one of her three restaurants, turning the same shade of coral as her toenails.

title: Finally, Taking Computer Design Out of the Model T Age
description: PERSONAL computers are marvels of technology. The computing speed of new machines doubles every 18 months, a march of progress so reliable that it has been called a law, "Moore's Law" (after Gordon Moore, a co-founder of Intel, whose microchips power most personal computers).

title: Keeping Your Cool . . . Staying in Town;It's Heaven That's Hot
description: You know that guy, the first one you notice on the sidewalk on Sunday night when you're pulling off the F.D.R. Drive on your way back from the country? That's me!

title: Columnist's Mea Culpa: I'm Anonymous
description: After months of emphatic denials, the anonymous author of a best-selling tale of political intrigue and deceit emerged yesterday at a hastily called news conference to reveal his own true colors: "My name is Joe Klein and I wrote 'Primary Colors.' "

title: POLITICAL BRIEFING: THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: North Carolina A Timing Question On Redistricting

title: OLYMPICS;Chinese Gymnasts Set to Roll
description: They have never won a team gold medal in gymnastics at the Olympics, but nobody would have known that by watching the Chinese men confidently work their way through their optional exercises today.

title: 500,000 Strike in Israel to Protest Netanyahu's Economic Plans
description: Opponents of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's plans for Israel's economy today closed factories, banks and Government offices across the country with a general strike, which also crippled hospitals, public utilities and the national airport.

title: Uncommon Stock Advice
description: Wondering about the real reasons for the recent jolt in the stock market? Here is a list of possible ones: Presidents Clinton or Reagan, program traders, "terrible management," companies that are "huge dogs," an "imminent" invasion of South Korea by its northern neighbor and the likelihood of a "right-wing coup in Russia that will be associated with an outbreak of World War III."

title: John Panozzo, 47, 70's Rock Drummer
description: John Panozzo, a co-founder and drummer of the rock group Styx, was found dead of a gastrointestinal hemorrhage in his home here on Tuesday, the Cook County Medical Examiner's Office said. He also suffered from cirrhosis of the liver as a result of chronic alcoholism. He was 47.

title: Politicians Resume Ulster Peace Effort Halted by Week of Riots
description: As Northern Ireland remained quiet for a third successive day after last week's riots, politicians met in various forums today to assess the political damage the disorder caused, to repair frayed relations and even to try to get the peace efforts back on track.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Another Fire Kills 29 in China Boom Town
description: Thick smoke from a restaurant fire spread to an upstairs hotel here today, killing 29 people. Another 13 people were injured, said Li Xiaogan, a local government spokesman in Shenzhen, a booming city near Hong Kong and the scene of some of China's worst fires.

title: Convention Underscores Hispanic Consumer Market, and Complaints ofBias
description: At the National Council of La Raza convention here, a recruiter from Wal-Mart was busy today handing out glossy brochures that boasted of the career opportunities that the discount retailer could offer Hispanic employees.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Golden Corral Selects Richards
description: The Golden Corral Corporation, a unit of the Investors Management Corporation that operates 450 buffet grill-style restaurants, said yesterday that it had named the Richards Group in Dallas to handle its account, which has billings estimated at $7 million to $8 million. The account had been handled by the Richmond office of Earle Palmer Brown for two years until that agency and Golden Corral parted ways in May.

title: Keeping Your Cool . . . Staying in Town;Now Playing . . .
description: There is something perversely delicious about New York City in summer. The discomfort is so absurdly extreme -- the sour stench of taxis, the swelter, the women in nylons on subway platforms in 98-degree heat.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Senate Votes Gambling Study
description: A bill that would create a commission to study the relationship between gambling and crime was approved yesterday by the United States Senate.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Alitalia Forecasts $784 Million Loss
description: Italy's national airline, Alitalia, will probably post a loss of 1.2 trillion lire, or $784 million, this year, the chairman of its holding company said yesterday. The executive, Michele Tedeschi, said the figure included 800 billion lire, or $522 million, in restructuring costs. Mr. Tedeschi's company, IRI, which controls 90 percent of Alitalia, has agreed to provide 1 trillion lire immediately.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Several Large Banks Post Strong Results for 2d Quarter
description: Four of the biggest American banks reported strong second-quarter earnings yesterday, in several cases shrugging off increased loan losses.

title: A Former Army Leader Is Arrested in Haiti
description: Claude Raymond, a feared army chief during the Duvalier dictatorship who is suspected of carrying out a massacre of voters in 1987, was arrested on Tuesday on charges of subversion, police officials said.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE SCENE;Accidental Witnesses to Airborne Tragedy
description: Is that pyrotechnics in the sky?" someone on the radio asked Master Sgt. D. M. Richardson.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Time Warner Near Approval In Turner Deal
description: The Federal Trade Commission effectively cleared the way for the merger of Time Warner Inc. and Turner Broadcasting System Inc. yesterday but will require the new company's cable-television system to carry a second news channel as a rival to its own Cable News Network.

title: Mysterious Amnesiac Found on Hawaiian Beach Is Identified as L.I. Man,37
description: Three and a half months ago, a man was found face down on a beach on Oahu, fading in and out of consciousness and complaining of a pounding headache.

title: Revamped Giants Put Emphasis On Youth
description: Jumbo Elliott remembered some time back how he looked around as he left Giants Stadium for the final time last season and knew that the team he played on was drastically different from the team that would be put on the field this season. Even Elliott, now with the Jets, could not have foreseen the dramatic change the team went through.

title: AT&T to Market Satellite Dishes
description: The AT&T Corporation plans to market the DirecTV satellite broadcast system through the Sharper Image Corporation and Tower Records retail stores. Terms were not disclosed.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Lakers Up Offer to O'Neal to $140 Million
description: The Los Angeles Lakers have raised their offer to Shaquille O'Neal, reportedly offering the free agent center a seven-year, $140 million contract, according to several league executives.

title: Preventing AIDS Is Still the Best Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE AIRLINE;Rising Hopes Turn Hollow For Company On Rebound
description: Trans World Airlines, an airline that has twice resuscitated itself after seeking bankruptcy protection, thought yesterday that it had finally turned the corner.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in some copies of The Living Section yesterday, with an article about the 50th anniversary of the arrival of the restaurateur George Lang in the United States, was published in error. Along with Jenifer Harvey Lang, Mr. Lang's wife, it showed Andrew Young. In other copies, the correct picture showed Mrs. Lang seated at a table and Mr. Lang standing, clasping her hand and wearing a ribbon tied in a bow.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;GTE and BellSouth Report Strong Net Income Results
description: The GTE Corporation and the BellSouth Corporation, two of the nation's local phone companies, posted strong second-quarter earnings results yesterday, mostly because of higher demand for second phone lines in American homes and an increase in sales of new services. GTE's earnings rose 10 percent, matching estimates, as the company increased phone lines by 7 percent and simultaneously posted initial success in the long-distance phone market. The combination resulted in the largest revenue increase in more than four years at GTE.

title: Arthritis Researchers Try Gene Therapy
description: Researchers in Pittsburgh yesterday performed the first gene therapy on a patient with rheumatoid arthritis, an effort to use a radically new approach to block the progress of the incurable, crippling disease. The treatment marks the first time gene therapy has been tried for a chronic disease that is not life-threatening.

title: CHRONICLE
description: A sure sign of the dog days of summer: HENRY J. STERN, the New York City Parks Commissioner, is giving a birthday party at noon today in Tompkins Square Park for his dog, Boomer, who turns 5.

title: For City Children, Sprinklers Have Animal Magnetism
description: HOT and bothered? Marlon Brando in leather tearing up the town and Arnold Schwarzenegger terminating his environs in an inferno of electronic parts don't hold a candle to an overheated toddler on a sunny day in July.

title: Earth's Inner Core Rotates At Faster Rate Than Surface
description: Scientists yesterday reported finding strong evidence that Earth's inner core is spinning freely and slightly faster than the rest of Earth, making it virtually a planet within a planet.

title: Militant Killed in Kashmir
description: Indian troops shot dead one of Kashmir's most wanted militants today, a man the police said directed bombings that have killed 70 people in India's capital, New Delhi, since November.

title: The Sad Juncture of 2 Troubled Lives;For Second Time, Focus Is on a Doctor After a Patient's Death
description: Their lives overlapped for only a few weeks. She was a spirited but troubled girl who at 17 was in the Westchester County Jail for attempted robbery and assault. He was a 75-year-old psychiatrist who had managed to put behind him his own macabre criminal history and was working uneventfully, treating inmates at the county jail.

title: MORE ON THE CRASH
description: Before Devastating News, T.W.A. Saw a Revival Ahead

title: Telling the Truth
description: Now that Joe Klein has come clean and admitted that he was the Anonymous behind "Primary Colors," a more complicated question takes the place of the original hunt for the writer, at least among reporters and editors.

title: Profits Jump at SGS-Thomson Microelectronics
description: SGS-Thomson Microelectronics N.V., Europe's biggest independent chip maker, reported a sharp gain in second-quarter profits today despite a slowdown in the chip market.

title: Paul Touvier, War Criminal, Is Dead at 81
description: Paul Touvier, the only Frenchman to be convicted of war crimes against humanity and for half a century a troubling reminder of his country's ambivalence about World War II, died yesterday at a prison hospital near Paris. He was 81.

title: Mr. Pataki's Legislative Scorecard
description: Gov. George Pataki has rightly been blamed for much of the confusion in Albany that produced the latest budget of any state ever. But Mr. Pataki scored other achievements in the 1996 New York State legislative session that deserve notice.

title: Zimmer Fund-Raiser Is Asked to Step Down
description: Michael D. Francis, who resigned Tuesday as chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, has been asked to step aside from his fund-raising role for Representative Richard A. Zimmer's campaign for the United States Senate, a campaign spokeswoman said today.

title: Deal by American Home
description: In the latest foray into genome research by a big pharmaceutical company, the American Home Products Corporation has agreed to pay $90 million over seven years to Millennium Pharmaceuticals Inc. to develop new treatments for diseases of the central nervous system, a spokesman for Millennium said yesterday. Under the deal, Wyeth-Ayerst, the pharmaceutical unit of American Home Products, based in Madison, N.J., would also pay royalties based on eventual sales of drugs that Millennium hopes to develop initially for psychiatric disorders, including anxiety, depression and schizophrenia. Millennium, based in Cambridge, Mass., would get additional "milestone" payments if it achieves certain research and development goals.

title: Buyer of AIDS Patients' Insurance Quitting
description: A company that buys life insurance policies from AIDS patients so they can get money before they die is suspending the business, acknowledging that new medicines may take away its customers.

title: Hondurans in 'Sweatshops' See Opportunity
description: Each morning, the workers spill off the buses and past the guards at the front gates of the industrial parks here, rushing to punch the clock before the 7:30 start of their workday.

title: Bridge
description: To appreciate the full flavor of the diagramed deal, cover the East-West hands. Then plan the play in a wildly optimistic three no-trump. The spade four is led to the ace and the suit is returned. South wins with the king and notes the two on his left, showing that West began with five spades.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MILLBROOK CAPITAL OFFERS TO BUY EASTERN
description: Millbrook Capital Management, a firm owned by the former New York City Deputy Mayor John S. Dyson, offered yesterday to buy the Eastern Company for $15 a share, or about $36.6 million for the shares it does not already own. Millbrook Capital, based in Millbrook, N.Y., made the offer with an Eastern shareholder, Ernst Ohnell. Shares of Eastern, a 138-year-old security-products and construction concern in Naugatuck, Conn., jumped $2.625, or 22.3 percent, to $14.375, on the American Stock Exchange. Mr. Ohnell is chief executive of the Communications Supply Corporation, a closely held distributor of data, phone, and cable hardware in Stamford, Conn.

title: ATLANTA 1996: 1 DAY TO GO;Miller Adds Maturity and Difficulty to Her Repertory
description: The top two American gymnasts at the 1992 Olympics were back on the podium on Tuesday, but they were no longer wearing the same uniform. While Shannon Miller was sporting her red, white and blue leotard and practicing her routines, Kim Zmeskal was wearing brown shorts and a short-sleeved shirt, bustling about the floor as an administrative assistant for the Atlanta organizing committee.

title: For Breezy Pursuits
description: PEOPLE can tell just by looking at you that you've had a wonderful weekend. The tan is a dead giveaway, not to mention the scuba-diving stories and the golf stats that roll off your tongue.

title: Yeltsin's Kremlin: A Mystery Wrapped in a Riddle
description: With a zeal that belies his obvious illness, Boris N. Yeltsin has over the past month turned the Kremlin into a hive of intrigue and caprice so dense and imponderable, so filled with lieutenants famously at odds with one another, that even one of the world's greatest chess masters cannot seem to draw meaning from it all.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Fighting Over Defections
description: The defection of two Cuban boxers will have no effect on the United States Olympic boxing team, said the world champion Antonio Tarver.

title: House Retains Abortion Rule In Federal Jobs
description: The House voted 238 to 184 today to retain a law that forbids Federal employee health plans to pay for abortion services except when a pregnant woman's life is at risk, or in cases of rape or incest.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: U.S. Force in Saudi Arabia: Isolation as a Key to Safety
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry announced "drastic changes" today in measures to protect American troops in Saudi Arabia from chemical and biological weapons, and from terrorist bombs four or five times as large as the one that killed 19 American airmen last month.

title: Keeping Your Cool . . . Staying in Town;Weekend Splendors
description: When I first moved back from Paris three years ago, one major difference struck me between the New York fashion industry I left and the one I came back to.

title: Europe Gives Cold Shoulder To Clinton On Cuba Law
description: President Clinton's decision to suspend for six months that part of a law allowing lawsuits against foreign companies that use confiscated United States property in Cuba got only a lukewarm welcome today from the 15-nation European Union.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. DIAGNOSTIC LABS TO BUY MEDICAL IMAGING
description: U.S. Diagnostic Labs Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Medical Imaging Centers of America Inc. for about $37.6 million. Medical Imaging would receive $11.75 in cash or stock of U.S. Diagnostic Labs, a manager of physicians' practices based in West Palm Beach, Fla., for each of its shares. Medical Imaging valued the transaction at $37.6 million. Medical Imaging, based in San Diego, said it had agreed in principle to be acquired by Diagnostic Imaging Services Inc. for $11.50 a share. But Diagnostic Imaging Services, based in Culver City, Calif., said yesterday that it had terminated its acquisition talks. Shares of Medical Imaging rose $1.375, to $10.50, in Nasdaq trading. U.S. Diagnostic stock rose 50 cents, to $10.375.

title: GOLF;Forecast Full of Surprises at British Open
description: Davis Love 3d was squinting through the sun into the distance from the tee at the 10th hole at Royal Lytham and St. Annes, focusing on the distant spire of a church for the best line for his tee shot.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE SECURITY;Precaution Measures at Airports Were Already on Increase
description: Airline security has been higher than usual in recent months for several reasons, including the Olympic Games, the trials of domestic and international terrorism suspects and the bombings in Saudi Arabia, industry security experts said today.

title: In Albany Chaos, Humor Leavens the Serious
description: To the Editor:

title: Terror Case Hinges On Laptop Computer
description: In the seven weeks since the trial of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef began, the case, charging a plot to blow American jumbo jets out of the sky, has come to hinge on one off-white laptop computer.

title: Paxson Prepares for Deal
description: The Paxson Communications Corporation may sell or swap its two network-affiliated television stations here as part of a plan to expand its infomercial and radio businesses. Paxson has hired Alex. Brown & Sons to advise on options for WPBF-TV, an ABC affiliate, and WTVX-TV, a United/Paramount Network affiliate. Paxson owns 36 TV stations dedicated to infomercials and will own 39 radio stations, 6 radio networks, and 332 billboards after completing pending deals.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;NORTHROP GRUMMAN CORP. (NOC,N)
description: The Northrop Grumman Corporation yesterday reported an 8.9 percent increase in earnings for the second quarter, reflecting the March acquisition of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation's military electronics businesses.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Earnings Climb by 35% For Computer Associates
description: Perhaps belying some recent worries that corporate spending on information technology might be slowing, Computer Associates International Inc., which supplies software to medium-sized and large businesses, reported strong results yesterday for its fiscal first quarter.

title: Economic Scene;Another Government bailout, a mere $18 billion at risk.
description: READY to ante up for another financial fiasco generated by regulatory myopia? Just when you thought the cost of the savings and loan debacle was pretty much past, the next Government bailout is about to hit, revolving around federally insured mortgages on subsidized housing for the poor.

title: POP REVIEW;Zulu Music And Tunes Of the West Join Hands
description: On Sunday afternoon, one of the world's most potent pop blends came to Central Park Summerstage. Two South African bands, Mahlathini and the Mahotella Queens followed by Johnny Clegg and Juluka, mixed Zulu music and Western pop and rhythm-and-blues to come up with songs that were as fit for thinking about as they were for dancing to.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bond Sale to Be on Ballot
description: Business leaders, government officials and environmentalists yesterday celebrated the signing of a ballot measure intended to keep Port Newark and Port Elizabeth competitive with other harbors.

title: No' to a Chelsea Speech
description: President Clinton's 16-year-old daughter, Chelsea, will not address the Democratic National Convention in August, the White House said today.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Puckett to Aid Stadium Effort
description: KIRBY PUCKETT, who retired as a Minnesota Twins outfielder last week because of vision troubles, will help the team's campaign for a new stadium to replace the Metrodome.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on July 2 about Mongolia misstated the ideology of the party that was defeated in elections on June 30. The Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, which had ruled for 70 years, changed in 1991 from a Marxist-Leninist ideology to a "national democratic" platform, adopting market-oriented economic policies and allowing multiparty elections.

title: Keeping Your Cool . . . Staying in Town;Take the A Train
description: Like many people born in Greenwich Village, I have spent my life working my way uptown. Still, when a friend told me to take the A train to 181st Street for a picnic, I thought she was crazy.

title: HORSE RACING;Maria's Mon Runs Second in Return
description: Remember last year's juvenile champion, Maria's Mon, the horse who was supposed to lead Unbridled's Song and Hennessey and other members of his class into this year's Triple Crown trials?

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Chamber Society Takes an Energetic Approach to Mozart
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has weathered its share of criticism for underprepared performances over the years, and many New Yorkers have come to take the group for granted as one of the countless ensembles that putter along competently, if not always excitingly, from season to season. But in his four years as artistic director of the society, David Shifrin has refined the ensemble, bringing in players whose interpretive sympathies are congruent, and who regularly work together outside the society.

title: Bully-Boy Foreign Policy
description: Recently, I asked an editor of a foreign policy journal why he wasn't publishing any criticism of legislation like the Helms-Burton Act, which penalizes foreign companies dealing with Cuban properties formerly owned by American businesses. Everyone knows that such extraterritorial sanctions don't work, he replied, so what would be the point?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Pontiac turns back the clock three decades to tout its wide track 1997 Grand Prix.
description: PONTIAC is reaching back to an old slogan to promote its redesigned midsized car in a campaign that starts Saturday.

title: Sprint's Alliance in Europe Wins Approval
description: Europe's antitrust regulator said today that it would allow the Sprint Corporation's alliance with the German and French phone monopolies.

title: Yes, Pilobolus Has a Mother, Too
description: Alison Chase could have been mistaken for a pleasant, no-nonsense den mother as she sat and talked the other day in a Chelsea restaurant. That is a role Ms. Chase has spent the last 25 years playing, on and off the stage, with her own three children and with a large, fluctuating and rowdily creative family called the Pilobolus Dance Theater. It was in the classes she taught at Dartmouth College that the founding members of Pilobolus, which is performing at the Joyce Theater through Saturday, discovered dance a quarter-century ago. Ms. Chase was soon drawn into the company's activities, as a performer and a choreographer.

title: Ex-Inspector Tells Senators About Suspicions on Valujet
description: The former Inspector General of the Transportation Department said today that the department's chief of staff had responded to her suspicions of safety problems at Valujet by telling her about the airline's complaints about her investigation.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on July 8 about Newsweek magazine's World Wide Web sites misstated the address of one site, Newsweek International. It is http: //www.newsweek-int.com.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Rison Goes to the Jaguars
description: The Jacksonville Jaguars signed the free agent ANDRE RISON yesterday, hoping he can put his worst season behind him and give them badly needed speed at wide receiver.

title: CHRONICLE
description: EIJI OUE, the music director of the Minnesota Orchestra, faced -- or rather had his back to -- many more than 18,000 people Tuesday evening, when he conducted the New York Philharmonic in Central Park.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Konica Business Machines U.S.A., Windsor, Conn., to Mason & Madison Inc., New Haven, to handle its account, previously at Keiler & Co., Farmington, Conn. Billings were estimated at $4 million.

title: OLYMPICS;Cyclist Traels In Fastest Circles
description: Marty Nothstein remembers his first bike, and not fondly.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Congress Cedes Park Land to Capital
description: Since they were created decades ago by dredging the Anacostia River, Kingman Island and Heritage Island have remained grubby spits of Federal land, used in recent years only as dump sites for garbage, dead leaves and tree stumps.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FOXMEYER HEALTH AGREES TO SELL A BUSINESS TO SHOPKO
description: The Foxmeyer Health Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its Carestream Scrip Card operation to Shopko Stores Inc. for $30.5 million in cash. Scrip Card is Carestream's pharmacy benefit management business, which offers drug benefits consulting and claims processing services to more than 1,900 health groups. If the deal closes by Aug. 1, Shopko expects additional revenue of $100 million to $115 million from the Scrip Card operations for the current fiscal year. Foxmeyer, based in Carrollton, Tex., said that it was selling Scrip Card at a substantial gain. Shopko, based in Green Bay, Wis., owns 129 stores in 15 states. Shares of Foxmeyer rose $1.50, or 25 percent, to $7.50, and Shopko rose $1.125, to $14.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Currents;Quick Dimensions
description: CAPTAIN KIRK, eat your heart out. Leica has introduced a hand-held distance meter called Disto, a $1,495 device that uses laser beams to measure and record distances up to 330 feet within an eighth of an inch. An upgraded model can transfer measurements into a computer. The tool won a top award for product performance from Buildings magazine, whose editor, Linda Monroe, said, "It allows individuals to single-handedly measure building dimensions, but most important, the optional Sketchright software allows measured data to be transformed seamlessly and error-free into a PC to recreate a room." Information: (800) 367-9453.

title: J. Michaels Sets A Distribution
description: J. Michaels Inc., a furniture retailer that plans to liquidate its assets and merge with Muriel Siebert Capital Markets Inc., a discount stock brokerage firm, expects to distribute at least $15.6 million, or $17 a share, in liquidation proceeds to shareholders.

title: Et Tu, A.C.L.U.?
description: The opposition of the American Civil Liberties Union to an experimental public junior-high school for girls only reflects a rigid view of sex discrimination, which is not mandated by existing law.

title: BOXING;Low Blows Still Baffle Golota
description: It remains a bittersweet time for Andrew Golota, who lost a fight he was winning against Riddick Bowe last week in what would have been the culmination of Golota's American dream.

title: Japanese Stocks Gain
description: Stocks were trading higher here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues stood at 21,514.07, up 101.19 points, or 0.47 percent. On Wednesday, the index advanced 6.53 points.

title: U.S. Law Respects Cuba Investor Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Croatia's Threat To Peace
description: Richard Holbrooke, whisked back to the Balkans to rejuvenate the ailing Dayton accord, has not succeeded in persuading President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia to arrest Radovan Karadzic and Gen. Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serbs indicted for war crimes. But the accord is not being thwarted by the Serbs alone.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Seven Network Criticized For MGM Purchase
description: Analysts and investors were skeptical yesterday about the entry by Seven Network Ltd., Australia's second-ranked television network, into the Hollywood movie business with its involvement in a successful $1.3 billion bid for MGM Inc. Seven is part of a syndicate led by MGM's chairman, Frank Mancuso, and by a former MGM owner, Kirk Kerkorian, that has bought the studio.

title: Pesticide Measure Advances In House, Without Rancor
description: With a remarkable absence of rancor, long-divided factions on the House Commerce Committee voted unanimously today for fundamental changes in the regulation of pesticides in food.

title: MGM's Tortured Tale, Part III: Kerkorian Gets Studio for $1.3 Billion
description: PARIS  A storybook ending it is not. But the $1.3 billion sale of the legendary Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer by an ailing French state bank to a group led by one of America's most eccentric billionaire investors is certainly a twist worthy of Tinsel Town.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Jackson Says He'll Expand Boycott Against Mitsubishi
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson vowed today to step up a boycott against the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation and to extend it eventually to other Japanese car companies if they do not expand opportunities for members of minorities to become executives and to own dealerships in the United States.

title: 2 Seized in Gambling Raids
description: Two New York men were arrested after the authorities raided restaurants and stores in four Connecticut cities and seized illegal video gambling machines, including some that were disguised as Pac-Man and other popular children's video games.

title: Police Allowed Inside Garden For a Concert
description: To prevent the kind of brawl that erupted at a Madison Square Garden boxing match last Thursday, Garden officials allowed the New York City Police Department to station a small number of officers inside the arena last night during a rock concert by the Who. They were stationed as an early-warning system in case of any large-scale disturbance, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said.

title: Launching of Shuttle Is Set
description: NASA today tentatively set Sept. 12 as the launching date for space shuttle Atlantis, which has been grounded by problems with its rocket boosters. The shuttle was supposed to blast off on July 31 for the Russian space station Mir to pick up the American astronaut Shannon Lucid, who has been on Mir since March. NASA delayed the flight last week to replace the Atlantis's solid-fuel rocket boosters. Hot gas seeped into booster segment joints during the shuttle Columbia's launching last month, most likely because of a new adhesive. The same adhesive was used in the Atlantis's boosters.

title: Executive Changes
description: AIRWAYS CORP., Orlando, Fla., a regional airline, named Robert Swenson, its chairman and chief executive, to the additional posts of chief executive and president of its Airtran Airways unit, replacing John Horn, who retired.

title: U.S. Wouldn't Be First to Legalize Gay Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Volkswagen Goes With Speed Racer
description: Volkswagen of America is joining the ranks of those singing "Go, Speed Racer, go!" The auto marketer has signed an agreement for Speed Racer -- the lead-footed cartoon hero of the animated series by that name -- to make his first product endorsement by appearing in a television commercial for the Volkswagen GTI. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Keeping Your Cool . . . Staying in Town;An Instant Rapport
description: Swinging from limb to limb alone in Manhattan, I occasionally stop by the upstairs bar at Sardi's, where Joe, the bartender, is my very good host. And there, particularly on summer evenings, I listen to the accents of regional America, whose speakers come to Sardi's or Broadway or the theater district and are delighted to run into a local, indeed a denizen of Times Square, and talk about themselves. For as Elwood P. Dowd once said, "Nobody brings anything small into a bar."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;America Online Forms Alliance for News
description: America Online Inc. said today that it had teamed with the Tribune Company to expand the local news and services it offers to 88 local markets on the Internet.

title: Audit Is Ordered of School Board Office
description: The new president of the Board of Education ordered an audit yesterday of the office run by its powerful secretary, Bruce K. Gelbard, then joined a majority of the board in dismissing him over concerns that he had overstepped his authority during his six-year tenure.

title: Widespread Calls to Overhaul Protective Services for Adults
description: Citing repeated examples of mismanagement and incompetence, elected officials and the heads of social service agencies across New York City called yesterday for the complete overhaul of Protective Services for Adults, the agency charged with protecting many of the city's most vulnerable residents.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the counterterrorism law's impact on permanent residents with criminal records misstated the date of the Oklahoma City bombing. It was April 19, 1995, not April 24.

title: POLITICS: CONSTITUENCIES;Rifle Group Threatens to Withhold Endorsement of Dole
description: Furious that Bob Dole has backed off his opposition to a ban on assault weapons, officials of the National Rifle Association threatened today to withhold the organization's endorsement of his Presidential campaign.

title: ATLANTA 1996: 1 DAY TO GO;Van Dyken Is Buoyant In and Out of Pool
description: When she was 6 or 7 years old, Amy Van Dyken realized that she was different from the other kids.

title: Keeping Your Cool . . . Staying in Town
description: IT is 6:30 on a Friday evening, and you are creeping like a caterpillar across the Tappan Zee Bridge, wishing for Woodstock by midnight. You are stranded in the gloom of the Queens-Midtown Tunnel, slouching toward Bridgehampton and sputtering toward a breakdown.

title: Currents;A New Club Throws Open Its Flaps
description: ONE day hot, next day not: the fickle and nomadic nature of the New York bar and club scene may have inspired Tim Higgins, a designer, to erect a portable summer nightclub in West New York, N.J. -- in a tent. Mr. Higgins, a protege of the design guru Milton Glaser (Trattoria dell'Arte and Aurora restaurants), decorated his open-air Club Cafe with leaping dolphins, monkeys and a giant fruit bowl, all by Jordan Steckel, known for the noses at the Trattoria. The cafe frames a view of Manhattan. From Manhattan: Weehawken ferryboat from the West 39th Street New York Waterway pier; free shuttle connects to the club. Cover charge is $3 to $5; (201) 601-8076. Ferry information, (800) 533-3779.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK

title: COMPANY NEWS;FHP INTERNATIONAL TO SPIN OFF MEDICAL MANAGEMENT UNIT
description: The FHP International Corporation said yesterday that it planned to spin off the Talbert Medical Management Corporation, its physician practice management company, to shareholders. Talbert generates more than $450 million in annual revenues and serves more than 300,000 patients. Talbert would continue to serve FHP members after the spinoff, which is expected by the end of the year. FHP, based in Fountain Valley, Calif., said it planned to focus on its health maintenance organizations and insurance businesses. Shares of FHP rose $2.125, to $24.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE OVERVIEW;T.W.A. JETLINER LEAVING NEW YORK FOR PARIS CRASHES IN ATLANTIC; MORE THAN 220 ABOARD
description: A Trans World Airlines 747 airliner bound for Paris from New York City plunged in a fireball into the waters off Long Island last night with more than 220 people aboard.

title: OLYMPICS;Testy Time For Some On Dream Team
description: The frayed nerves take several forms, from the competition in practice, to daily availability to discuss stalled contract negotiations, to a team tournament that ended with a disputed outcome. At the end of practice today, Hakeem Olajuwon wore the type of wide belt that boxers and wrestlers wear. The front of the belt had this engraving:

title: Jaguar Considers A Small Model
description: Jaguar, the British luxury auto maker owned by the Ford Motor Company, is considering a small car to compete with some of the best-selling models of BMW and Mercedes-Benz of Germany.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Crude Oil Prices Fall as U.S. Hints Iraq Has Met Conditions
description: Crude oil prices fell on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday on signs that the United States would not object to Iraq's revised plan for distributing humanitarian aid bought with the proceeds of a limited oil sale. Comments from a United States official led traders to speculate that Iraqi oil was nearer to coming to market.

title: Woman Says She Will Sue Officers Acquitted of Rape
description: A 27-year-old New Rochelle police dispatcher announced yesterday that she would file a civil suit against two New Rochelle police officers who were acquitted on Monday of charges that they raped her after a night of drinking at a local bar.

title: Keeping Your Cool . . . Staying in Town;Of Time and the River
description: One of the best views in the city can be had from a laminated red-and-gray tile couch that sits on a little mound of grass-green carpeting on the edge of the East River in Long Island City, Queens. The couch actually faces a laminated television set. It's called "American Dream," by Barbara Grygutis, and it's one of the more permanent works of art at the Socrates Sculpture Park. But it's the river that I like to watch.

title: Panel Rejects Bid to Block Congressional Election
description: In a case questioning use of racial and ethnic considerations in drawing up legislative districts, a three-judge panel yesterday denied a request to block this year's Congressional elections in New York City. But the panel left open the question of whether it would declare the largely Hispanic 12th District unconstitutional.

title: Grain, Hogs and Videotape;U.S. Investigation of Archer Daniels Goes Global
description: Operation Harvest King has moved into high gear.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;The Voice of Experience
description: The dedication of the Rings of Fame Fountain at the Nissan Pavilion brought together about 40 former United States Olympians, including 94-year-old Nick Carter, who competed in the 1,500-meter race in 1928 and is the oldest living Olympian, and the four-time discus champion Al Oerter, who offered words of wisdom to this year's competitors.

title: Lebed Gains Victory in Defense Ministry
description: The Russian Army general chosen today by President Boris N. Yeltsin to head the Defense Ministry represents a bureaucratic victory for the administration's new security adviser, Aleksandr I. Lebed.

title: People Who Do Glass Repairs Sometimes Throw Stones, Stores Find
description: In this city of limitless opportunity, the spirit of entrepreneurship comes in many and varied forms.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Last Laos Refugees Leave Thailand Camps for U.S.
description: The last Hmong tribal people in Thai refugee camps started leaving for the United States today, part of an effort to close the camps and end one of the final chapters of the Indochina war.

title: Improper Parts Used By Airline, U.S. Says
description: Skyway Airlines, a small Midwestern commuter carrier, flew some planes with emergency landing gear that did not work, broken fuel gauges and improper parts, Federal prosecutors said today.

title: Deal Reached in Civil Suit Over Collusion on Nasdaq
description: The Justice Department, after two years of investigation, settled a civil antitrust suit today with 24 securities firms that were charged with colluding to inflate their profits from trading shares on the Nasdaq stock market.

title: Market Place;Initial public offerings drift back to earth.
description: IN this month's market carnage, few areas have been hit harder than once-hot initial public offerings. Stocks that soared on hopes of great future successes have been among the most vulnerable to a change in market psychology, in which investors are interested in what can go wrong, as well as what can go right.

title: Bosnia Case Is Reopened
description: Citing new evidence of misconduct, an army commander ordered a second investigation today into charges that Canadian peacekeepers beat patients and had sex with nurses at a mental hospital in Bosnia.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Changes in Store for Nagano
description: Olympic organizers from Nagano, Japan, have been asked to make their downhill ski run longer and their opening ceremony shorter, the director general of the Nagano Organizing Committee said today.

title: POP REVIEW;A Durable Fable of Youth Revived as an Extravaganza
description: When the Who released "Quadrophenia," Pete Townshend's second full-length rock opera, in 1973, Mr. Townshend was looking back barely a decade at the teen-age Mods and Rockers whose battles terrorized England's seaside resorts in the summer of 1964. (The early Who, originally called the High Numbers, were the Mods' favorite band.) "Quadrophenia" returned as a 1979 film, which turned the opera's story into a realistic narrative about Jimmy, a Mod trying to define his identity. With the film, "Quadrophenia" anointed the Mods, and the Who, as rightful precursors to the punks who had just shaken up British rock.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;A Castro With Charisma but No Cigar
description: No one is likely to quarrel with Dan Rather when, at the end of tonight's visit with Fidel Castro, he observes that "television, which loves simple labels, is stymied" about how to appraise the enduring Cuban ruler. The program's solution is to use pairs of labels like "murderer or martyr." Alliteration runs rampant. "The Last Revolutionary" begins with the news that Mr. Castro has brought his island care and coercion, and opportunity and oppression, along with bread and bitterness, and it notes along the way that in Cuba these days protest brings punishment.

title: Blood From Placenta Can Aid Leukemia Patients, Scientists Say
description: Blood from a newborn infant's umbilical cord and placenta, normally discarded in the delivery room, can provide urgently needed treatment for patients with leukemia and other diseases that damage the blood and immune system, scientists reported yesterday.

title: GARDEN NOTEBOOK;What's Under The Bushes?
description: AS you enter the garden at Sylvester Manor, which has been tended by the same family since 1652, you walk between great rumpled boxwoods -- the very first to come to America.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;PFIZER INC. (PFE,N)
description: Pfizer Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose more than 22 percent in the second quarter, bolstered by strong sales of its newer drugs.

title: Anillaco Journal;A Hometown Boy: Call Him Carlos the Bountiful
description: Arrogant residents of Buenos Aires are famous for saying that not much matters in Argentina outside the capital, which is the economic engine of the country and home to a third of its population.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Ousts Bergen Chief for Remark
description: At a time of increased debate among blacks about the educational value of desegregating schools, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has ousted one of its local officials for openly criticizing the organization's policy on integration.

title: An Amnesiac Struggles To Fill in the Blanks
description: Three and a half months ago, he was found face down on a beach on Oahu, fading in and out of consciousness. His pockets were empty, and so was his memory. Thanks to a detective, he now knows his identity: he is a former diplomat and a language expert from Massapequa, L.I. But he still cannot definitively recognize his family. And no one has solved the riddle of how he ended up in Hawaii.

title: M.T.A.'s New Debt Plan Will Break Riders' Bank
description: To the Editor:

title: More Can Be Done to Guard Your Renoirs
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberties;Liddy, Hillary, Nancy
description: Liddy Dole scares me.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Ford Posts A Big Profit For Quarter
description: The Ford Motor Company posted stronger second-quarter earnings today than analysts had expected, including solid profits from financial services and an improvement from its North American car-making operations. The results spurred a rally in auto issues and helped steady the stock market.

title: Neighborhood-Patrol Groups To Get High-Technology Help
description: In yet another White House ceremony designed to showcase his support for programs against crime, President Clinton announced today that the cellular telephone industry would contribute 50,000 cellular telephones and free air time to citizen patrols and block-watch groups around the country -- and has promised to keep providing phones as long as new patrols keep forming.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Baumgartner to Carry Flag
description: Bruce Baumgartner, a two-time Olympic gold medalist in freestyle wrestling, was chosen tonight to carry the flag at the head of the United States team at Friday night's opening ceremony.

title: Preventing AIDS Is Still the Best Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE SEARCH;Rushing to Pluck Sinking Bodies From a Waterlogged Hell
description: The bodies floated, some in clusters, in the dark, choppy waters that swelled two or three feet, eerily lit by an orange glow of rescue lamps and the oily flames of chunks of wreckage.

title: Sports of The Times;Evans Seeks A Career as Landlubber
description: JANET EVANS was eating lunch alone at the Olympic Village the other day. This happens when you get to be a senior citizen of 24 and realize it's all right to sit in a corner by yourself once in a while.

title: OBITUARY : Paul Touvier, Jailed French War Criminal, Dies at 81
description: PARIS  The only Frenchman imprisoned for crimes against humanity during World War II died Wednesday in prison, closing a chapter on France's collaboration with its German occupiers.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Nebraska Executes Man Who Killed 3 Boys
description: A man who said he enjoyed the "power and domination" of killing was executed in the electric chair early today for murdering two boys in 1983.

title: New Rebel Group Is Suspected in Ambush of Mexican Army Truck by Armed Gunmen
description: Attackers wielding AK-47 assault rifles ambushed a Mexican Army truck along a mountain road in Guerrero state on Tuesday evening, killing one civilian who drove into the gunfire and leaving one soldier and another civilian wounded.

title: No Headline
description: I play a game where there are rules. I see the movement of each piece on the board. But this is something entirely different. If there are rules to this game, then they are rules made and understood by one man only."

title: COMPANY NEWS;STANLEY WORKS SELLING NONSTRATEGIC OPERATIONS
description: Stanley Works Inc., which has been reorganizing its operations in the last year, said yesterday that it had begun to sell certain nonstrategic segments. Among the segments being sold are the United States manufactured paint applicator, mail-order safety products and drywall-tape products businesses. The businesses had combined revenue of less than $200 million in 1995, a fraction of Stanley's $2.6 billion in annual revenue. The company, a tool maker based in New Britain, Conn., said additional costs to continue reorganizing its remaining businesses would lower earnings by an undetermined amount in the third quarter. Shares of Stanley Works rose $1.75, to $28.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Office-Supply Expansion
description: BT Office Products International Inc. has acquired three distributors of office products in Germany and four in the United States for a total of about $30 million. According to BT Office, which is based here, the American companies are Apollo Stationers of San Diego; Kights of Jacksonville, Fla.; McWaters of Columbia, S.C., and Morris Sanford of Cedar Rapids, Iowa. The seven distributors have about $70 million in total annual sales.

title: Clinton Denies Trading State Jobs for Gifts
description: In videotaped testimony played in a courtroom here today, President Clinton repeatedly denied that he had ever traded patronage jobs for campaign contributions when he was Governor of Arkansas.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Early Exit for Some
description: Housing and logistics problems have apparently caused some members of the Olympic international volunteer police force to leave Atlanta.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bond Rating Remains High
description: For the sixth year in a row, New Jersey's bonds have received an AA+ rating, the second-highest, from the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The state is a good risk because of its "demonstrated ability to balance its financial operations and maintain adequate balances in an environment of slowed economic growth," Standard & Poor's said Wednesday. Moody's Investors Service also gives New Jersey's bonds its second-highest rating, Aa1.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Outlook For Inflation Is Low
description: More expensive food led German wholesale prices up two-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Government said yesterday, while new signs of economic weakness suggested that consumer inflation would remain slow.

title: Sports of The Times;Shaq Is Now California Dreamin'
description: FAREWELL, Central Florida Waffle Houses; hello, Southern California beachfront properties. Can anybody explain why this decision took so long for Shaquille O'Neal to make?

title: Olympics Come to Atlanta, Promising Drama and Profits
description: ATLANTA  For the next two weeks the world's broadcasters will find magnificent promise in their pictures of the Atlanta skyline. There are other perspectives, too, and as you wander among the skyscrapers they look more and more like the beams of an unfinished house.

title: OLYMPICS;Games Are a Small Trial In the Life of One Kayaker
description: Ten years ago, Cliff Meidl of Redondo Beach, Calif., then a 20-year-old apprentice plumber, was in nearby Hawthorne drilling with a jackhammer.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Evans May Miss Start of the Season
description: The euphoria of making it to the National Basketball Association has vanished into disappointment for BRIAN EVANS. His pro debut will be delayed by another dislocation of his right shoulder.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: THE AFTERSHOCKS;Most Passengers Are Tense, But Take Comfort in Odds
description: Though things looked normal yesterday in airports around the country, people were unmistakably on edge as they contemplated their own lives -- and flights -- and mused about danger, chance and mortality.

title: BOXING;Better Late Than Never For Boxer's Jab at Glory
description: His life was clouded often then, so Antonio Tarver does not remember where he was or what exactly he was doing. Only the image on the television and the name remained clear: Roy Jones Jr.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Merck Profits Were Higher In 2d Quarter
description: Merck & Company said yesterday that earnings rose 13 percent in the second quarter, paced by sales of the cholesterol-lowering drug Zocor and newer products.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: THE SEARCH;Scouring an Imaginary Grid, Finding Specks of a Disaster
description: Under a blazing sun and against otherwise peaceful waters, the United States Coast Guard laid an imaginary grid over 240 square miles of the Atlantic Ocean today to help in the meticulous recovery of the airplane shards, personal effects and bodies that rained from the sky Wednesday night when a Boeing 747 exploded off eastern Long Island.

title: Revised Plan for Criticized Courthouse
description: Four years ago, a plan to enlarge the Federal courthouse at the edge of the Brooklyn Bridge perished in a storm of ridicule after Brooklyn Heights residents got Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan to use his clout to kill it.

title: Bullies, Bullets and the Happy Genes Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: Ousted Official Says He Was Smeared
description: Michael D. Francis, who resigned under pressure as chairman of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, said today that he had been unfairly smeared. He also said allegations that an individual associated with organized crime influenced and won contracts at the sports authority were untrue.

title: Summer at the Center;Restaurant Critics Select Their Favorites
description: THIS is the dark mystery of the New York restaurant world: Why are there so few good restaurants on the Upper West Side?

title: Keep In Mind
description: "BATS, BUGS AND THE BIG DIPPER," an evening program about sounds and sights of summer nights: bullfrogs calling; bats flitting; crickets cricketing; fireflies lighting, and the stars. A bat detector will also allow listeners to hear bats, and a telescope will bring home the stars. Sunday (and Aug. 4) from 8 to 9:30 P.M. at the Flat Rock Brook Nature Association, 443 Van Nostrand Avenue, Englewood, N.J. Registration: (201) 567-1265. Admission: $4 a person.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Times Co. Net Advances 8.2%; Results of Newspapers Are Cited
description: the second quarter, helped by improved performance from its newspaper and broadcasting operations and by gains from investments in paper mills.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: VICTIMS;Lives of Beauty and Business, Sports and Scholarship, Youth and Age
description: A peripatetic couple, married for more than 56 years, who chose the city of romance to mark an 80th birthday. A prominent decorator prowling for antiques. A high school teacher who steered Joe Mantegna into acting. An 11-year-old exchange student from France who could not get his fill of pistachio ice cream. And 16 teen-agers from a French club in Montoursville, Pa., bent on what they hoped would be a memorable and merry adventure to the city of their dreams.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TRANS TEXAS SELLS SOME NATURAL GAS FIELDS
description: The Trans Texas Gas Corporation said yesterday that it had sold some natural gas fields for a total of $95.2 million as part of its strategy to reduce its dependence on the Lobo Trend field in south Texas. It sold two properties for $72.2 million to the North Central Oil Corporation and the Houston Exploration Company. The areas represent proven developed natural gas reserves of 63.3 billion cubic feet, and 64.1 billion cubic feet of undeveloped reserves. Trans Texas, which is based in Houston, said it also sold 48.5 billion cubic feet of proven reserves for $23 million to an undisclosed buyer. Shares of Trans Texas fell $1 yesterday, to $8.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Lesbian Perspective
description: Sometimes a cigar is not just a cigar, and a Venetian fritter is not just a Venetian fritter. In "Just Desserts" and "Peach," two of the strongest movies in "Girlfriends," a program of eight short lesbian films, food is a tantalizing metaphor (and in "Just Desserts" an uproariously explicit one) for awakening sexuality.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Montage of Other Movies
description: You can hardly blame Laurence Fishburne in "Fled" for glowering like someone who has just bitten into an apple and swallowed a mouthful of worms. This shoddy super-violent thriller -- Mr. Fishburne's action-adventure debut -- is so far beneath his talents that throughout the movie he exudes a palpable sense of disgust. Even when rocketing around on a motorcycle and romancing Salma Hayek, he looks as if he would like to be anywhere but stuck in a brainless chase film that tries (and fails) to make Atlanta look as glamorously sleazy as Miami.

title: Blood Ties
description: If the Indian Child Welfare Act of 1978 had been law when my husband and I were ready to start our family, we could not have raised our son.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BOEING ANNOUNCES $510 MILLION ORDER FROM CHINA
description: The Boeing Company, the world's biggest civil aircraft manufacturer, has sold three long-range 747-400 aircraft to China for $510 million, a company spokeswoman said in Beijing early today. The planes will be used by Air China, a national carrier. Air China has an option to buy two more 747's, which would raise the value of the contract to about $915 million. Boeing is continuing to discuss other possible sales to China involving 747, 777 and 737 aircraft, said the Boeing spokeswoman, Cindy Smith."We intend to be China's premier supplier," she said.

title: Asking $1 Billion, Hartford Sues 7 Tobacco Companies
description: The State Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, sued seven tobacco companies for $1 billion today, charging that they had engaged in "a conspiracy to mislead, deceive and confuse" Connecticut and its residents about the debilitating and addictive effects of cigarettes.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800;Storm Delay Saves a Life
description: They were just a fluke of the weather, the storms that ripped through the Midwest yesterday afternoon, grounding Eileen Rence in Chicago for a few hours longer than she was supposed to be there.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: THE OVERVIEW;INVESTIGATORS SUSPECT EXPLOSIVE DEVICE AS LIKELIEST CAUSE FOR CRASH OF FLIGHT 800
description: Federal law enforcement officials said yesterday that the most likely explanation for the fiery crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 was that a bomb or, perhaps, a missile sent the airplane plunging into the Atlantic Ocean off Long Island on Wednesday night, killing all 230 people on board.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Georgia 1995. Miramax. $100.72. Laser disk, $39.99. 117 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: THE NEWSPAPERS;Papers Were Wary This Time, And Didn't Jump to Conclusions
description: The explosion that killed 230 people aboard T.W.A. Flight 800 last night prompted newspapers around the country to raise the possibility that a bomb caused the blast. But the memory of how many newspapers jumped to conclusions after the Oklahoma City bombing seemed to deter editors from speculating who might have been responsible.

title: Burmese Dissident Urges Western Sanctions to Oust Military
description: In a videotape smuggled out of Myanmar and made public today, the campaigner for democracy and winner of the Nobel prize, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, issued a call for international sanctions to be imposed on her country to force political change on the military rulers.

title: Decades Later, Tales of Americans in Soviet Jails
description: Time has stooped Vladimir Trotsenko's shoulders, but his memories are as clear as his cobalt blue eyes: the American flyer, his right arm in a new cast, in a Soviet military hospital ward. The American, he recalled, would slowly repeat, "America -- San Francisco, Cleveland, Los Angeles, Chicago."

title: 25 and Under
description: Consider these three restaurants: One is a bar that also serves barbecue and seafood; the second is a coffee bar that serves sandwiches and some Jamaican specialties; the third is a pizzeria that also has a long Italian menu. Judged as a whole, none are out of the ordinary. Yet each has at least one extraordinary dish.

title: Corrections
description: A sports picture caption in some editions on Wednesday about the women's gymnastics dress rehearsal at the Olympics misidentified the American gymnast. She was Kerri Strug, not Dominique Moceanu.

title: NBC, Paced by 'E.R.,' Leads in Nominations For Prime-Time Emmys
description: The top-ranked broadcast network, NBC, dominated the list of prime-time Emmy Award nominations announced today in Los Angeles by the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences. NBC received 88 nominations, including 17 for "E.R.," the nation's top-rated show. The awards will be presented on Sept. 8.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Performing artists have many associations with the stages on which they perform, and when RICHARD LEECH, the tenor, performs at the Hollywood Bowl tonight and tomorrow, he will be returning to a place he knew as a child.

title: Netanyahu and Mubarak Talks Clear the Air
description: On his first visit to an Arab capital since taking office, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel met here today with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt in talks that resulted in "clearing the air," but offered little sign of progress toward bridging the rifts that divide the Arab world and the new Israeli Government.

title: Market Place;Despite Stocks' Bounce, Profits Remain a Worry
description: Never mind.

title: THE PASSENGERS;Disaster in Air Unites Widely Varied Lives
description: C. Kirk Rhein Jr. Insurance Executive, 42

title: OLYMPICS;After Yearlong Road Trip, U.S. Women See Pot of Gold
description: Lisa Leslie philosophized. Venus Lacey fidgeted. Jennifer Azzi tweaked the National Basketball Association.

title: Detroit Strike Is Not Led by Teamsters
description: To the Editor:

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: THE FRENCH CLUB;A Pennsylvania Town Asks, 'Why Us?'
description: At noon on Wednesday, a Susquehanna Trailways bus stopped in front of the high school here to take 16 students from the French Club and 5 chaperons to John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York City to begin a 10-day trip to France. Luggage was loaded. Hugs, kisses and farewells were traded.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Yachtsman, 54, Knows Way Around
description: The first person ever to compete in 10 consecutive Summer Olympic Games says he is concerned about the increasingly large sums of money needed to stage the Games.

title: THE PASSENGERS;Disaster in Air Unites Widely Varied Lives
description: Rico Puhlmann Fashion Photographer, 62

title: THE PASSENGERS;Disaster in Air Unites Widely Varied Lives
description: Pamela S. Lychner Victims Rights Worker, 37

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Levy Is Reinstated by the Cardinals
description: The Arizona Cardinals added wide receiver CHUCK LEVY to its team roster yesterday, nearly a year after the National Football League suspended him for substance abuse.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Gain in Natural Gas Supplies Pushes Prices Sharply Lower
description: Natural gas prices tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday after a report showed a steady rise in inventories.

title: Marco Rivetti, 52, Marketer Of Italian Designer Labels
description: Marco Rivetti, the Italian entrepreneur who helped turn European designer labels into household names worldwide, died last Saturday at his home in Turin. He was 52.

title: Art in Review
description: Simon Leung Pat Hearn Gallery 530 West 22d Street Chelsea Through July 26

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800;A Partial List of Those Aboard Flight 800
description: Following is a partial list, provided by Trans World Airlines, of people aboard Flight 800, which the airline said carried 230 people. All hometowns were not available.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Chase in Talks To Sell a Japan Unit
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it was in talks to sell its trust banking unit in Japan to Deutsche Bank A.G. Norman Scott, general manager of Chase Manhattan's Tokyo branch, said a deal would probably be concluded by the end of the month. He said the unit, the Chase Manhattan Trust and Banking Company, had a book value of 1.1 billion yen ($10.1 million).

title: COMPANY NEWS;PERFUMANIA GROUP DROPS PLAN TO TAKE COMPANY PRIVATE
description: Perfumania Inc. said yesterday that the management group that proposed taking the discount perfume retailer private by buying the shares it doesn't already control for $6 each has withdrawn its offer. On June 28, a group controlled by Simon Falic, the chairman and chief executive, and other executives had said it would buy out other holders. The main reason for the withdrawal "is that the largest shareholder wouldn't come on board with me," Mr. Falic said. The largest shareholder, with about 1.5 million shares, is the former chairman and chief executive of the company, Ilia Lekatch. The company had 6.69 million shares outstanding as of May 4. The stock of Perfumania rose 9.4 cents, to $3.531.

title: The Color of Mendacity
description: American journalists have long believed that Government intrusion is the greatest threat to the profession. That may still be true when it comes to issues of independence and secrecy. But when it comes to the credibility of the American press, the most damaging recent wounds have been self-inflicted. The mimicking of salacious British tabloids, the raucous Washington talk shows, the fad for intellectually flaccid "civic journalism" have all done damage. The latest damage comes from the political columnist Joe Klein's revelation that he lied, often and energetically, about being the anonymous author of "Primary Colors" and that his top editor at Newsweek cooperated in the subterfuge.

title: U.N. Chief Approves a New Plan To Allow Iraq to Start Selling Oil
description: Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali approved an amended Iraqi plan today for distributing food and other relief supplies bought with proceeds from oil to be sold under an exemption to international sanctions.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: PARIS;Reunions in France 'Canceled'
description: The 30 or so people who went to Charles de Gaulle Airport expecting to pick up passengers from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 this morning found the word "canceled" on the big board, under the plane's 8:15 A.M. expected arrival time, in Terminal 1.

title: Trucks Hit Disney Road
description: Two of the most successful new ideas in American motorsports -- truck racing and the Walt Disney World Speedway -- are combining, it was announced yesterday. The Nascar Craftsman Truck Series will open its 1997 season next Jan. 19 with a race at the one-mile oval in Lake Buena Vista, Fla.

title: Restaurants
description: What has happened at Dawat?

title: COMPANY NEWS;EVERGREEN MEDIA TO ADD CHICAGO RADIO STATION
description: The Evergreen Media Corporation of Irving, Tex., agreed yesterday to buy the radio station WPNT-FM in Chicago from the Century Broadcasting Corporation for $68 million. The acquisition would give Evergreen Media six FM stations in the nation's third-largest market. Since the recently enacted Federal telecommunications law allows for ownership of eight radio stations in one market, but just five of one service, Evergreen said it would sell one of its FM stations in Chicago, WEJM-FM. That sale would largely offset the purchase of WPNT-FM. Evergreen Media has 37 radio stations in 13 markets around the country, with options or agreements to buy four stations and sell three. Its stock jumped $4.75 yesterday, to $45.25.

title: Chris Komar, 48, Dancer For Cunningham Company
description: Chris Komar, assistant artistic director of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company and a leading Cunningham dancer, died on Wednesday at Beth Israel Hospital. He was 48 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Former Scott Paper Chief Named To Top Position at Sunbeam
description: The Sunbeam Corporation said today that it had hired Albert Dunlap, the former chief executive of the Scott Paper Company, who is known as an aggressive cost-cutter, to try to turn the appliance maker around.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: TELEVISION;Crash Coverage Is Fed By 24-Hour Guesswork
description: Not long into CNN's continuous coverage of Wednesday night's crash of T.W.A. Flight 800, a "terrorism expert," one of the mysterious cadre that has found a place in the television Rolodex (but what do they do between disasters?), said flatly that he thought the airliner had been brought down by a bomb.

title: Albany Plans To Act Against Failing Schools
description: The New York State Board of Regents plans to vote Friday to approve an aggressive new policy that would compel state education officials to close or reorganize the poorest-performing schools, most of which are in New York City.

title: Peter Kurzman, 63, Volunteer for Blind
description: Peter Hess Kurzman, who was the volunteer president of the National Association for Visually Handicapped, died on Monday at his weekend home in Erwinna, Pa. He was 63 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The City of Lost Children 1995. Columbia Tri-Star. $97.51. Laser disk, $34.95. 112 minutes. Closed captioned. French with English subtitles. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: THE PASSENGERS;Disaster in Air Unites Widely Varied Lives
description: Judith Connelly Delouvrier Philanthropist

title: U.S. Presses Effort to Remove Indicted Bosnian Serb Leader
description: Negotiations here that the Clinton Administration hopes will succeed in ousting Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb political leader, and thus pave the way for smooth elections in Bosnia and Herzegovina dragged on inconclusively into the early hours of thise morning.

title: Teamster Chief Outmaneuvers Foes at Meeting
description: Using the power of the convention gavel, the teamsters' union president, Ron Carey, has stifled a widespread and frequently unruly attack on his control over an institution that had become a national symbol of nepotism, embezzlement and mob ties.

title: ATLANTA 1996: THE GAMES BEGIN;In Atlanta, Festivities Touched by Sorrow
description: The most inclusive Summer Olympics in a century of the modern Games will open Friday night, but anticipation is being tempered by concerns over security, heat, transportation, commercialism and the image of the South as portrayed by the pickup truck.

title: Cuts in Legal Services Cost Everyone More
description: To the Editor:

title: A Victory for Rudy Crew
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, posted a victory when the Justice Department ratified his decision to bar 14 local school board officials from assuming office at the beginning of their new terms. A 15th case is pending, and should be ruled on soon.

title: METRO
description: THE CRASH

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800;Remarks by Clinton About the Crash of Flight 800
description: Following are remarks from President Clinton's news conference about the explosion that killed 230 people aboard a Trans World Airlines 747, as transcribed by The Associated Press yesterday.

title: In Paris, A Painful Wait And Grieving : Trauma Center Counseling (folo)
description: PARIS  Max Berley of the International Herald Tribune reported:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Royals Sign Their Founder's Grandson
description: The Kansas City Royals have signed pitcher GEORGE KAUFFMAN, a grandson of the late Ewing Kauffman, who founded the franchise in 1969 and whom the Royals' home park is named after. George Kauffman, a right-hander from Stetson, Mo., was sent to the Royals' rookie team in Fort Myers, Fla. (AP)

title: HOUSE APPROVES SHIFT ON WELFARE
description: The House today approved a bill that would reverse decades of social welfare policy, ending the Federal guarantee of cash assistance for poor children and instead giving states vast new authority to run their own welfare and work programs with lumps sums of Federal money.

title: Trade Deficit Jumps Again, Particularly With China
description: The nation's trade deficit surged in May for the third consecutive month, to $10.88 billion, the Commerce Department reported today. It said that China nearly supplanted Japan for the first time as the country with the biggest surplus in trade with the United States.

title: Mesa Holdings Sold After Failed Bid
description: In the wake of his failed attempt to take control of Mesa Inc.'s board, shareholder Dennis Washington has sold most of his stake in the company.

title: In America;Grief and Justice
description: The small house on Warburton Road in Yonkers is shut tight, as if to keep the memories from escaping. The doors are locked and the dark and heavy drapes are drawn against the summer heat.

title: Art in Review
description: Keith Tyson David Zwirner Gallery 43 Greene Street SoHo Through Aug. 2

title: Bonn to Pay Refugee Fares
description: The Government said today that it would help some 320,000 Bosnian refugees in Germany to return home by paying their fares.

title: INSIDE
description: Greenspan Cheers Markets

title: OLYMPICS;Final Gymnastics Warm-Up Event: Grumbling
description: The Georgia Dome has been divided in two for the Summer Olympics. One half has been set aside for the oversized stars: the Dream Teamers and their overmatched basketball opponents. The other half has been set aside for the undersized stars: the gymnasts whose sport is considerably less lopsided.

title: Archer Daniels Executive Elects To Not Testify in Pricing Case
description: A top executive of the Archer Daniels Midland Company has asserted his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination rather than testify about his knowledge of a possible price-fixing scheme involving the company in a Federal court hearing scheduled for today in Chicago.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Brown Leaves Nets for the Heat
description: P.J. BROWN left the Nets and signed with the Miami Heat yesterday, saying he wanted to play with a team "going in the right direction." Brown's seven-year contract is worth a reported $36 million.

title: Home Video
description: Next month, Disney will get back into a genre that it likes but treats warily: sequels that don't play in movie theaters but go straight to video stores.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: IN COURT;Bombing Jury Told by Judge To Skip News
description: Reverberations from the Trans World Airlines explosion reached yesterday into a Manhattan courtroom where three men are standing trial on charges that they plotted to bomb American jetliners in Asia.

title: OLYMPICS;Agassi Welcomes Chance To Pin a Gold on His Lapel
description: The tennis millionaires who have temporarily suspended their free-agent life styles in order to represent the United States at these Olympics all wore the same shiny sweatsuits this afternoon, a rarity in this sport of sponsor-driven individualists. And they all spoke of keeping all the tennis medals right here on their home turf.

title: Bullies, Bullets and the Happy Genes Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: ON BASEBALL;Mets in Shuffle for Wild-Card Spot
description: To use Joe McIlvaine's term, the Montreal Expos arrived at Shea Stadium last night in their second "bad and ugly" period of the season. The earlier period, in the latter half of May, sent the Expos plummeting out of the National League East lead; the current period has brought them back to the rest of the field in the N.L.'s fourth division.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japanese Fund For Loan Losses
description: The Japan Securities Dealers Association said yesterday that the securities industry would contribute a total 21 billion yen ($23 million) to a fund of 1 trillion yen ($920 million), which will help cover losses resulting from the dissolution of seven debt-laden housing loan companies.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants Open Albany Camp To the Delight of the City
description: Welcome to the new home of the Giants' training camp. To say the locals have gone bonkers over the team, which moved its camp here from New Jersey, is an understatement. A local television reporter did a broadcast at about 11 P.M. Wednesday from a pitch-black practice field, two days before the first practice. The Mayor was here today; the Governor is expected. From people's reaction, you would think there was a Beatles reunion taking place.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;2 Japan Brokers Record Big Profits
description: Two leading Japanese brokerage firms, Nomura Securities and Daiwa Securities, reported strong profits yesterday for the three months that ended on June 30.
