Nomura posted a current profit of 36.42 billion yen ($337 million) for the first quarter of its fiscal year, up sharply from 2.35 billion yen ($21.7 million) for the comparable period a year earlier. Current profit is pretax profit including gains or losses stemming from nonoperating activities like securities investment.

title: Company Briefs
description: UNITED ASSET MANAGEMENT CORP., a provider of investment management services, announced plans to acquire Clay Finlay Inc. of New York, a global equity investment firm with more than $6 billion in assets. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Woman, 19, Found Slain in Bathtub
description: A 19-year-old was found slain yesterday morning by her mother in the bathtub at their house in Queens, law enforcement officials said. The young woman's throat was slashed, and five bullets were lodged in her chest, the officials added.

title: Frances Tyler, 92, Long a Resort Owner
description: Frances J. Tyler, longtime owner and operator of the Tyler Place, a family resort in Highgate Springs, Vt., died last Friday at the Northwest Medical Center in the nearby town of St. Albans. She was 92 and lived on the grounds she managed.

title: About Real Estate;On the Rise: Instant Selling Success
description: The New York City real estate market is full of tales of sellers who put their houses or apartments on the market, clean them every morning just in case an agent comes by with some eager buyers, only to wait and wait for an offer that seems to never come.

title: Art in Review
description: Steven Brower Downsize' Lombard Fried Gallery 470 Broome Street SoHo Through July 271

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK: Summer at the Center;Lincoln Center's Enduring Vision
description: LINCOLN CENTER FESTIVAL '96, the performing-arts jamboree that opens on Monday, should at least offer the charm of contrast. The three-week festival, organized by John Rockwell, features works by Robert Wilson, Merce Cunningham, Tod Machover and other famously progressive artists. Lincoln Center, meanwhile, has long stood as a monument to conservative taste. Classically symmetrical, heavily encrusted with travertine marble, the center's buildings and public spaces were designed to confer Campidoglio-like dignity on New York's once-decaying Upper West Side.

title: Fix the Air Security System
description: At this early stage in the investigation of the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 on Thursday night, it is still premature to speculate about its cause. Forensic experts will provide an answer to that question in a fairly short time, unless large parts of the aircraft are unrecoverable,

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHATEAU PROPERTIES TO ACQUIRE ROC COMMUNITIES
description: Chateau Properties Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Roc Communities Inc. in a transaction valued at $287 million, creating the nation's largest owner of manufactured housing communities. The two companies would form Chateau Communities Inc. Shareholders of Chateau Properties would have a 55 percent stake in the new company, and shareholders of Roc would have a 45 percent stake. The new company would own or operate 160 properties in 30 states with about 50,000 sites. It would have about $125 million in annual revenue. Shares of Chateau Properties rose 87.5 cents, to $23.125, on the New York Stock Exchange. Shares of Roc rose $1, to 23.

title: Digital Equipment to Dismiss 40 Workers
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said today that the head of its network product business unit had resigned to lead another company and that it had dismissed 40 workers in its Internet software business.

title: OLYMPICS;A Site for Computer Users
description: Starting tonight, additional Olympic coverage is available to computer users from The Times's two services -- The New York Times on the Web, at http://www.nytimes.com, and @times on America Online, including these highlights:

title: SUMMER AT THE CENTER;A World of Performances, Indoors and Out
description: Lincoln Center Festival '96, three weeks of indoor and outdoor performances, runs from Monday through Aug. 11 mainly at locations in and around Lincoln Center. Some performances are free; otherwise, tickets range from $12 to $100. Tickets for the Beckett Festival at the John Jay Theater, 899 10th Avenue, between 58th and 59th Streets, are $45 for each performance. Lincoln Center Festival tickets can be purchased at the festival box office at Avery Fisher Hall, or at box offices at the New York State Theater and the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street; and through Center Charge, (212) 721-6500. Festival hot line: (212) 875-5132. From July 26 through Aug. 4, the New York Video Festival will offer screenings and discussions at the Walter Reade Theater. Admission is $8 ($5 for members of the Film Society of Lincoln Center). Schedule and other information: (212) 875-5600. Here is the schedule of events for the Lincoln Center Festival:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Military Business Lifts McDonnell's Profit
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that profits from its military aircraft operations helped lift earnings 11 percent in the second quarter, despite a strike at the company's plant in St. Louis.

title: Butterflies on the Street
description: Reading about the recent volatility in the stock market and of the convoluted actions and reactions of investors, I recalled an experiment I carried out in one of my probability classes several years ago.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows in the New York metropolitan region that are to close soon:

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: THE AIRLINE;Fiscal Weakness Aside, T.W.A. May Be All Right
description: If a T.W.A. plane had crashed into the Atlantic as recently as two years ago, Trans World Airlines might have been scuttled as surely as Pan American was when its Flight 103 went down over Lockerbie, Scotland, in 1988.

title: After the Crash
description: The explosion of a Paris-bound T.W.A. jumbo jet minutes after taking off from Kennedy Airport has stunned the nation and raised the anxiety level of virtually all those who use the airlines. At this point investigators have no firm idea exactly what sent the plane plunging in a fiery descent into the waters off Long Island, taking 230 lives.

title: OLYMPICS;Bitterness Lingering Over Carter's Boycott
description: On the eve of the gala opening ceremony for the 1996 Summer Olympics, former President Jimmy Carter, who was once accused of trying to wreck the Games, is hovering gingerly at the fringes of the hoopla.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: TERRORISM;New Questions About Security For Airports
description: After a terrorist bomb disintegrated Pan American Flight 103 on Dec. 21, 1988, scattering the bodies of 259 passengers and crew members across the bleak, snowy landscape of Lockerbie, Scotland, the Government drew up strict new regulations to protect air travelers.

title: FILM REVIEW;Ghosts All Over the Place
description: The special-effects fiesta that is "The Frighteners" unleashes so many spooks, demons, subplots and secondary characters that there seem to be crowd-control problems on screen. As directed by Peter Jackson, whose "Heavenly Creatures" looks sedate by comparison, it's a technically impressive horror-comedy-romance in desperate need of a story editor or a cold shower.

title: HOCKEY;Krupp of Germany Out of World Cup
description: Germany will not have its biggest hockey hero for the World Cup. Defenseman Uwe Krupp decided to rest his right knee rather than take the chance of re-injuring it, Coach George Kingston said today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;British Biotech's Stock Surges 9.2%
description: The stock of British Biotech P.L.C. surged 9.2 percent yesterday in London trading even as the company announced it had sold only 49 percent of the shares in a rights offering. Investors said there was relief that the number of shares ordered by investors was not lower, because investor interest in British biotechnology shares has been lagging.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: THE VIGIL;Clinging to Slimmest Hopes, In a Long Night of Waiting
description: For as long as they could, the relatives of Judith Connelly Delouvrier clung tenaciously to hope, finding reason upon reason to believe their worst fears might not be true.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TRANSAMERICAN WASTE INDUSTRIES TO MERGE
description: Transamerican Waste Industries agreed yesterday to merge with closely held Waste Industries in a deal it valued at $209 million. Transamerican said the chief executive of Waste Industries, Lonnie Poole Jr., would become chairman and chief executive of the combined company and the headquarters would move to Raleigh, N.C., from Houston. Transamerican would issue 59 million shares to Waste Industries, bringing the total outstanding to 90 million. Transamerican closed at $2.75, up 25 cents in Nasdaq trading.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: THE PLANE;Aircraft Had Long Record Of Problems, None Major
description: The Boeing 747 jet that exploded on Wednesday night south of Long Island, killing all 230 people on board, had a long record of minor safety-related difficulties that are not unusual for such aircraft.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Parcells Explains Trimmer Contract
description: BILL PARCELLS opened the New England Patriots camp yesterday with both his contract and his weight reduced.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-8

title: Dole Backs School Choice Through Vouchers
description: Bob Dole today embraced a $5-billion-a-year proposal that would allow parents to use government-issued vouchers to pay their children's tuition at whatever school they chose, private, public or parochial. He described the drive for school choice as "a civil rights movement of the 1990's."

title: Detroit Mayor Leads Democrats In Attack on Dole Urban Policy
description: Hours before Bob Dole arrived here this afternoon, the city's Mayor attacked the Republican Presidential candidate's urban policies, part of a new and organized effort by Democratic mayors to criticize Mr. Dole as he campaigns across the country.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Sprinter Has Other Plans
description: Marie-Jose Perec says no one told her she was trying for double gold medals in the women's 200 and 400 meters. Now she is telling anyone with that idea to forget it.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: THE OLYMPICS;As Summer Games Open, Fears Heighten
description: Although Trans World Airlines Flight 800 crashed off Long Island, much of the psychological debris landed 800 miles to the south, in Atlanta, where heightened fears about terrorism muted some of the celebratory anticipation for the opening of the Summer Olympic Games on Friday.

title: Castro Scornful of Clinton
description: President Fidel Castro today derided President Clinton's decision to approve new sanctions against some companies investing in Cuba but to suspend action for six months.

title: William Mayer, 67, Medical School Chief
description: Dr. William Dixon Mayer, a pathologist who was president of Eastern Virginia Medical School in Norfolk from 1979 to 1986, died on June 30 in Virginia Beach. He was 67 and lived in Virginia Beach.

title: MORE ON THE CRASH
description: THE CREW -- The men who lost their lives together in the cockpit of Flight 800 had many decades of combined experience in the air. Page B7.

title: For President, the Olympics Will Be an Enviable Stage
description: In the first century, the Roman Emperor Nero magnified his glory by bribing Olympic officials to confect new events and let him win. So who would begrudge President Clinton the political lift he will surely receive on Friday by simply uttering 15 words to open the Games?

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Japan Limits Flights By U.S. Cargo Carriers
description: Japan will not allow two American cargo carriers to fly to destinations in Asia from Japan, the Ministry of Transport said yesterday. Japan said it would not allow Federal Express and Northwest Airlines to fly through Japan to Manila and Cebu in the Philippines; Singapore, and Kuala Lumpur and Penang in Malaysia.

title: From Italy, a Model T for the 90's;Fiat Joins Race to Build a Car With Worldwide Appeal
description: When Fiat, with Latin frenzy, brought out its "world car" in Brazil in April, the big Italian auto maker called it the Palio, after the breakneck horse race that the Tuscan city of Siena has staged in its cobbled lanes since the Middle Ages.

title: Key Management Changes Made at Sybase
description: In a move that many analysts had been advocating, Sybase Inc.'s chief executive, Mark B. Hoffman, stepped down yesterday as president and chief executive of the troubled data base software maker and named Mitchell E. Kertzman as his successor. Mr. Hoffman plans to stay on as chairman.

title: No Survivors Among 228 In N.Y. Jetliner Explosion
description: NEW YORK  Rescuers scoured the waters off New York on Thursday searching for clues to the mystery of whether a bomb caused TWA flight 800 to explode into a fireball and plunge into the ocean with 228 people on board.

title: Collin Wilcox, Mystery Writer, 71
description: Collin Wilcox, a mystery writer who set most of his 30 books in San Francisco, died on July 12 at his home. He was 71.

title: Art in Review
description: 'Space, Mind, Place' Andrea Rosen Gallery 130 Prince Street, at Wooster Street SoHo Through Aug. 7

title: ART REVIEW;Portraits of the Artists (With Clothes)
description: An exceptional show at the Robert Miller Gallery reminds us that there is more to Philip Pearlstein's well-made art than his perversely clinical paintings of cadaverous nudes exuding palpable ennui in harsh, unflattering light. There are, for one thing, Mr. Pearlstein's portraits -- mostly of other artists, critics, curators, art historians and the like -- of which 14 are gathered here.

title: Lamm Sees Less Perot In Reform Party's Future
description: Richard D. Lamm, the Presidential candidate who is daring to crowd Ross Perot at his own rich game of political solitaire, was in his element, discussing the future before a convention of futurists enthusiastic about "watershed visions," "a day in 2035" and "sustainability thinking" in the next millennium.

title: U.S. and Georgia-Pacific Settle Environmental Case
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation agreed yesterday to spend at least $26 million on environmental improvements and pay a $6 million fine. The agreement settles a Federal enforcement case that the company had tried to derail in Congress last year through a provision in a Senate bill sponsored by Bob Dole.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bidding Rules Are Tightened
description: Before an audience of building and construction trade union leaders, Governor Whitman signed a Republican-sponsored bill yesterday that is aimed at discouraging unscrupulous bidding practices. The bill would allow the losing bidder to sue the winning company if that company violated prevailing-wage or other labor laws in pursuing the contract. To win the lawsuit, the losing bidder would have to show that its bid would have been lower than the other company's if the applicable laws had been followed.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WARNACO PLANS TO BUY BODYSLIMMERS
description: Warnaco Group of New York said yesterday that it would buy Bodyslimmers Inc. by Nancy Ganz for an undisclosed price in cash, tapping into Bodyslimmers' popularity with baby boomers. Bodyslimmers, also based in New York, makes and sells body slimming undergarments. The company said that it had 1995 revenues of $30 million to $34 million. Nancy Ganz, founder and president, would run the operation for Warnaco as president of the new Nancy Ganz/Bodyslimmers division.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Rumble in the Bronx 1996. New Line. Laser disk, $39.99. 87 minutes. Mandarin dubbed in English. 87 minutes. R.

title: Bullies, Bullets and the Happy Genes Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: Looking Both Ways on Cuba
description: Faced with reprisals by the European Union, Canada and Mexico, President Clinton chose to retreat from enforcing the most obnoxious section of the Helms-Burton Act, which imposes new sanctions against Cuba. He could have waived the section, known as Title III, for six months. Title III says that any foreigner who "trafficks" in American property seized by Cuba will be judged as causing damage to former owners, including Cubans who have since become American citizens.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;High Jinks, Discoveries and a Passion for Yosemite
description: ANSEL ADAMS A Biography By Mary Street Alinder Illustrated. 489 pages. Henry Holt. $30.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Trying to Ease Aid Cuts
description: Legislation to save school districts from sudden drastic cuts in state aid -- which could occur under Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's school financing proposal -- was introduced yesterday in the State Assembly. The measure would allow the cuts to be phased in over several years, as recommended in a report by the Assembly Speaker's Task Force on Education Funding, which was also released yesterday. The New Jersey Supreme Court has ordered the state to come up with a plan to bring about parity in spending between rich and poor districts. In response, the Governor has proposed that school districts that choose to spend more than a level set by the state should have to seek the additional money from local taxpayers.

title: BASEBALL;Martinez Beats Heat And Mets in Laugher
description: It had been almost six years since the Mets had played in what could be called a meaningful series. And the way they were talking going into last night's opener of a four-game set with the Montreal Expos, the Mets were taking this series as a showdown for the wild-card spot in the National League -- even though it is only July.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;BANKERS TRUST N.Y. CORP. (BT,N)
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that its second-quarter net earnings climbed 65.9 percent, helped by increased revenues from its investment banking business, to $151 million, or $1.67 a share, from $91 million, or 98 cents, a year earlier.

title: U.S. and Britain In Airline Talks
description: Talks between Britain and the United States began today in an effort to negotiate an "open skies" pact for trans-Atlantic air traffic.

title: For Children
description: 'Shakespeare in Brooklyn II' Brooklyn Children's Museum 145 Brooklyn Avenue, at St. Marks Avenue Crown Heights (718) 735-4402 Recommended ages: 5 and up Sunday

title: ART REVIEW;Sculpture With Video and a Lot of Activity
description: In the short history of video art, Shigeko Kubota goes back a long way. A painter and sculptor involved in the 1970's with the neo-Dada Fluxus group, she did her first video piece, "Video Chess," in 1975, inspired by a visit to the grave of her idol, Marcel Duchamp. Since then she has conceived her sculpture in terms of video, creating works that reflect her own life and her interest in nature as well as Duchampian jokes and ironies.

title: Tamil Rebels Report Overrunning Sri Lankan Base and Killing 500
description: Separatist Tamil Tiger rebels overran a key army camp in northeastern Sri Lanka on Thursday and said today that they had killed more than 500 Government troops in the attack.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Like Father, Like Son and Vice Versa
description: At some point in his life, nearly every man nervously asks himself how long he has before he turns into his father. The speculation rears its anxious head in "Da," Hugh Leonard's Tony-winning, autobiographical play, and it gets a specific response (at least in terms of theater chronology) in the sturdy new revival of the work at the Irish Repertory Theater.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PLASMA AND MATERIALS AGREES TO BUY ELECTROTECH
description: Plasma and Materials Technologies Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Electrotech Group in a cash and stock deal worth about $159 million. Both companies make semiconductor production equipment. Plasma and Materials, based in Chatsworth, Calif., plans to pay $75 million in cash for Electrotech, a closely held British company. It would also exchange 5.6 million shares of its common stock, valued at $84 million based on its closing price of $15, up $2.375. Electrotech reported 1995 earnings of $8.7 million on revenue of $54.4 million.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Cigarette Tax Rise Advances
description: The Assembly also passed a bill yesterday that would ask voters to authorize using the proceeds from a 25-cent-a-pack increase in the cigarette tax for school construction. The bill, approved by a vote of 68 to 5, goes to the Senate.

title: No Headline
description: The Bible says life is a vapor. For them, it was. They were old and gone at 15."

title: NCR Reports a Small Profit After Reducing Expenses
description: The NCR Corporation, the troubled computer division that the AT&T Corporation plans to spin off at the end of the year, said yesterday that it had a small operating profit in the quarter ended in June for the unit's first time in the black since 1994.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: AT&T Earnings Rise 10%, But Rivals Perform Better AT&T, whose dominance in long-distance phone service is being chipped away, said its second-quarter earnings rose 10 percent, failing to perform as strongly as either of its two chief rivals or as well as several regional Bells. AT&T also said it expected to complete the spinoff of Lucent Technologies, its phone-equipment unit, in September.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Abdul-Jabbar Is a Dolphin at Last
description: KARIM ABDUL-JABBAR signed with the Miami Dolphins yesterday after Coach JIMMY JOHNSON said further delays might result in the U.C.L.A. running back's finding himself buried on the depth chart. Terms of the deal with Abdul-Jabbar, a third-round pick, were not announced. But a team source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Abdul-Jabbar signed a three-year contract worth $920,000.

title: GOLF;U.S. Open Is Looming For Bethpage Black
description: All day long, through what would build up to a sweltering heat, a small gallery alternately congregated and disassembled here at the starting point of the tree-lined terrain of Bethpage State Park's Black Course.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: THE THEORIES;Multitude Of Ideas, But Little Evidence
description: In public, Government officials were careful today to refer to the fiery plunge of T.W.A. Flight 800 as an accident. But in private, law-enforcement officials said their investigation was by necessity premised on the worst-case scenario: that the downing was caused by a bomb or maybe even a terrorist's missile.

title: Natalie Lieberman, Literacy Worker, 86
description: Natalie Lieberman, the founder and president of Learning Through Art/The Guggenheim Museum Children's Program and a member of the museum's board, died on Wednesday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. She was 86 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: GOLF;American Golfers Feel At Home in British Heat
description: It certainly was a peculiar first round of the British Open today here in Palm Springs, er, San Diego, uh, Royal Lytham and St. Annes. Yes, that's it, Royal Lytham here on the northwest coast of England, where summer has suddenly busted out all over and the American players who bothered to come over for the 125th running of this championship felt as though they had somehow been transported back home.

title: Rothschild Setting Up A New Fund
description: Wilbur L. Ross Jr. and his colleagues at Rothschild Inc. are setting up the Rothschild Recovery Fund to invest in distressed securities.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Casino Dickers on Road Cost
description: Mirage Resorts is negotiating with New Jersey officials about paying cost overruns on a $330 million tunnel and road designed to bring gamblers to its planned $2 billion complex, Bloomberg Business News reported yesterday. The state expects the Las Vegas-based casino company to pay for any excess roadway costs. Governor Whitman disclosed on July 3 that Mirage had agreed to pay $55 million and lend $180 million to the project, which will connect the Atlantic City Expressway to the Marina district. "The company appears to be concerned about this open-ended liability," said Jason Ader, an analyst at Bear Stearns & Company, who said he talked with Mirage officials earlier this week. Mirage officials haven't made any public statements since the Governor's announcement.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Dole's Daughter to Campaign
description: In an effort to boost her father's standing among women voters in New Jersey, Bob Dole's daughter, Robin Dole, will make her first campaign appearance in the state today. Ms. Dole, a former real estate lobbyist from Alexandria, Va., is scheduled to join Governor Whitman at the Morristown Town Green to meet local residents, merchants and public officials. Unlike Governor Whitman -- but like her father -- Ms. Dole opposes abortion rights. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Bill Protects Dolphins
description: To the Editor:

title: Boy, 10, Accused of Shooting Best Friend to Death
description: A 10-year-old Brooklyn boy arguing with his best friend outside a church in Williamsburg yesterday used a gun he had taken from his grandmother's bedroom to fatally shoot the other boy, also 10, the police said.

title: Summer at the Center;Mixing Art and Cocktails: Cheers!
description: IT is in the nature of art to provoke questions, doubly so for the more daring explorations of the avant-garde. If all goes as planned at Lincoln Center Festival '96, if the art does its job, audience members will be wrestling with the big imponderables. What does this work mean? Does it represent a breakthrough or breakdown? Does the artist hate me? Where is the nearest bar?

title: Gingrich's Health-Care Speech Is on the Record
description: To the Editor:

title: John Nuveen Buying Flagship
description: The John Nuveen Company agreed this week to acquire the mutual fund company Flagship Resources Inc. for $63 million and to merge the companies' tax-exempt mutual fund businesses.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Netscape And Sun Post Gains
description: Two companies that are actually making money from the Internet craze, Sun Microsystems and Netscape Communications, reported strong earnings and revenue growth yesterday.

title: Abortion Pill Reaches New U.S. Juncture
description: A Federal advisory board is to meet today in Gaithersburg, Md., to consider a most unusual application to market a new drug. The drug's sponsor is a nonprofit organization, but the names of its manufacturer and its distributor are being kept secret. If the drug is approved for marketing, the distributor's name will be revealed. But the manufacturer's name will not.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;'Refuse to Lose' and Pay Calipari
description: He may not have been the first to use it. Or even the first to try to cash in on it.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Prodigy Ends Account With Cliff Freeman
description: The Prodigy Services Company, the computer on-line service, and the Cliff Freeman & Partners unit of Cordiant P.L.C. in New York unexpectedly said yesterday that they had parted company after a year because of "different goals." Billings were estimated at $10 million.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Ex-Officer Indicted in Irvin Murder Plot
description: A former Dallas police officer, JOHNNIE HERNANDEZ, was indicted yesterday in connection with an alleged plot to kill the Cowboys star MICHAEL IRVIN. Grand jurors indicted Hernandez, 28, on one count of criminal solicitation of capital murder and one count of bribery, a charge unrelated to the alleged Irvin plot.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;New U.S. Ski Head
description: Bill Marolt, a 1964 Olympian who was the United States Alpine skiing director during one of the team's most successful years before taking over as the University of Colorado athletic director, was named president and chief executive officer of U.S. Skiing on Wednesday.

title: FILM REVIEW;Cinderella Flees to Paris And Her Visa Expires
description: In "Celestial Clockwork," a charming trifle of a Cinderella story with a multicultural heart, the fairy-tale magic that propels an aspiring Venezuelan opera singer, Ana (Ariadna Gil), from housecleaner to movie star is everywhere she turns. At one critical juncture, a poster of her idol, Maria Callas, comes alive for a second, just long enough to tweak the slender plot along for another five minutes.

title: Advertising;Manhattan museums pool resources for a newspaper campaign.
description: COURAGE, Philadelphia: New York will begin its advertising response to the "Cezanne" exhibition on Sunday.

title: Galileo Finds That Moon Io Has New Face
description: When the Voyager 1 spacecraft flew by Jupiter in 1979, it made the striking discovery that the moon Io throbbed with erupting volcanoes spewing sulfur across its mottled orange and white landscape. Now the Galileo spacecraft, renewing Jovian explorations, has transmitted a photograph showing that volcanism has transformed much of Io's surface over the last 17 years.

title: Greenspan Sees Robust Growth Slowing Down
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said today that the robust economic growth of recent months should moderate later this year, but he warned that the central bank might have to raise interest rates anyway to insure that the slowdown happened promptly enough to avert a surge in inflation.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: There's a Battle in London . . .

title: Ex-MCA Chief In Music Venture
description: Al Teller, the former chairman of MCA Music Entertainment, said yesterday that he would start an independent music company with $100 million in financing, principally from the Wasserstein Perella Group.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;3 Youth Guards Charged
description: Three corrections officers at Essex County's juvenile detention center were indicted yesterday on charges that they sexually abused female detainees, prosecutors said. One guard, Odell Graham, 44, was charged with 15 counts of abuse, including aggravated sexual assault, against four girls ages 14 to 17 during 1993 and 1994. The separate indictments against Mr. Graham, Robert C. Lee and Francisco Hernandez arose from an investigation into allegations of physical abuse at the center, said Ray Weiss, a spokesman for the county prosecutor's office.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;DEAN WITTER, DISCOVER & CO. (DWD,N)
description: Dean Witter, Discover & Company reported a slight increase in second-quarter earnings yesterday despite an 8 percent rise in revenues. The company attributed the performance to an industrywide increase in credit card delinquencies and bankruptcies.

title: TV SPORTS;NBC's Money Shots Prove It: They Love a Parade
description: As he narrated the parade of nations during the opening ceremony in Barcelona, Spain, four years ago, Bob Costas described too much, spit out too many morsels from NBC's vast reservoir of research. But the temptation to spit is great. So much is contained in the black loose-leaf binders, and so much more is being verified, confirmed and added by the minute by NBC's staff of 25 researchers. Take a page from any binder.

title: O'Rourke Changes Course On Jail Health Contract
description: In a surprise move, the Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, today reversed his decision to cancel the contract of EMSA Correctional Care, a private health care company that employed a doctor who stopped giving antidepressant medication to a 17-year-old jail inmate who later committed suicide.

title: Thuong Tin Journal;Old Crafts Open a New World to Vietnam Villagers
description: For a toll of 20 cents, a boy will lift a bamboo pole and let a car pass down a bumpy dirt road into an ancient village transformed by capitalism.

title: THE PASSENGERS;Disaster in Air Unites Widely Varied Lives
description: Jed Johnson Interior Designer, 47

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMMERCIAL INTERTECH REJECTS UNITED DOMINION OFFER
description: The board of the Commercial Intertech Corporation has voted to reject an increased offer of $550 million from United Dominion Industries, calling it inadequate and saying a plan to spin off its filtration unit and buy back shares provides a better value to shareholders. On Monday, United Dominion, based in Charlotte, N.C., raised its cash offer to $30 a share from $27 for Commercial Intertech's common stock. The transaction would include assumption of some debt. Commercial Intertech, a hydraulic components maker based in Youngstown, Ohio, set Aug. 30 for a shareholder meeting to vote on the offer. The company's shares rose 12.5 cents, to $29.50, and shares of United Dominion rose 12.5 cents, to $21.875.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Seamy View of Marseilles
description: Bye Bye" was shown as part of this year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 22. The film opens today at the Quad Cinema, 13th Street, west of Fifth Avenue, Greenwich Village.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: THE PASSENGERS;Disaster in Air Unites Widely Varied Lives
description: Jack O'Hara TV Producer, 39

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROSALYN COLEMAN, an actress in August Wilson's Broadway play "Seven Guitars," has had an important part of her past restored. On Wednesday, for the second time, she received the Outer Critics Circle Award that she and the six other cast members were given in May for outstanding ensemble acting.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: THE INTERNET;More Than Just News Draws Throngs to Web
description: Early yesterday, Trans World Airlines' colorful page on the World Wide Web showcased a contest for a free-trip. But by midday, the promotion was superseded by a stark, somber announcement of the crash of Flight 800 that avoided mention of any fatalities, though dozens of charred bodies had already been pulled from Moriches Bay.

title: Westchester Reversal On Health Contract
description: Reversing his decision, the Westchester County Executive will not cancel the contract of a health care company that hired a psychiatrist who stopped giving antidepressant medicine to a 17-year-old prisoner who later committed suicide.

title: AAR Buys Aircraft Parts
description: The AAR Corporation, a supplier of new and used aircraft parts, bought 22,000 components today from a unit of the United Technologies Corporation for substantially less than the catalogue price of more than $200 million. The parts were made and sold by Hamilton Standard, a division of the Hartford-based United Technologies.

title: Bodies of Russian 'Slaves' Found in Chechnya
description: Authorities found the bodies of 10 Russian prisoners of war today who military officials say were used as slave laborers, then tortured and executed by Chechen rebels.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Seattle Drops Sweeney
description: Seattle waived center JIM SWEENEY, who started all 16 games for the Seahawks last season, after he refused to accept a salary cut and demotion to a backup role. Sweeney, a veteran of 11 seasons with the Jets who will be 34 years old next month, will be replaced in the lineup by KEVIN MAWAE. The team signed ED CUNNINGHAM as a reserve. (AP)

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Lakers Get O'Neal In 7-Year Contract
description: Insisting repeatedly that money was not the issue, Shaquille O'Neal today justified the relentless gamble of the Los Angeles Lakers by accepting a seven-year contract believed to be worth $121 million.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;Freezing Forever the Motions of Dancers Dancing
description: Dance photography has always been haunted by Zeno's paradox, "the absurd proposition," as Henri Bergson mockingly called it, "that movement is made of immobilities."

title: THE PASSENGERS;Disaster in Air Unites Widely Varied Lives
description: Edwin B. Brooks and Ruth D. Brooks Retired Executive, 82, and His Wife, 79

title: BASEBALL;Gooden Can't Find the Plate As the Yanks Take a Beating
description: The questions about Dwight Gooden's mysteriously ineffective right arm will definitely escalate after his sluggish performance tonight rekindled thoughts of his dismal first three weeks of the season. Gooden could not throw strikes, he looked lost again and the dead arm that was supposed to heal has not. The Yankees could have a serious problem.

title: Westminster Journal;Football Returns, With a Difference
description: This is hallowed ground, the football field at Western Maryland College. For 16 summers through 1971, the Baltimore Colts practiced here for the season ahead and lived in nearby dormitories. Over the years they became beloved citizens of the community as frequent visitors to restaurants, movie theaters, even the barber shop on Main Street.

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;Suspicions Over Chinese Divers
description: Add Ron O'Brien, the United States diving coach, to the list of those who are suspicious about the Chinese training methods.

title: Bill Stops Forcing States To Educate Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: OLYMPICS: NOTEBOOK;French Plan a Protest
description: The French delegation at the Atlanta Olympics said it would stage a protest at Friday's opening ceremony against government plans to cut funding for sport. Henri Serandour, president of the French national Olympic committee, said his team would be led during the opening ceremony parade by a group of trainers dressed in track suits. Under Olympic rules, delegations have to wear official team uniforms at the ceremony.

title: EXPLOSION ABOARD T.W.A. FLIGHT 800: THE CREW;For Families and Friends, Memories
description: Steve Snyder and Richard Campbell began flying for Trans World Airlines only a few years apart in the 1960's.

title: Binding Pact On Emissions To Be Sought
description: Encouraged by a United States policy shift, government ministers today urged industrialized nations to make legally binding commitments to reduce so-called greenhouse gases.

title: Dr. Narciso Garcia, 55, Physics Researcher
description: Dr. Narciso Garcia, a physics professor at Queens College whose experiments with photons and microwave radiation offered a powerful demonstration of the resemblance between light and matter established by quantum theory, died on Wednesday at his home in New Hyde Park, L.I. He was 55.

title: Inside Art
description: The Getty Waits for a Guercino

title: COMPANY NEWS;QUARTERDECK BUYS A DIRECT-MAIL MARKETER
description: The Quarterdeck Corporation, based in Marina del Rey, Calif., said yesterday that it had bought Vertisoft Systems Inc., a publisher of utility software and a leading direct-mail marketer, for about $31 million worth of stock at yesterday's closing price. The company said the acquisition would give it direct-mail operations to complement its telemarketing abilities and a new channel for selling Internet and utilities products. Quarterdeck is paying for Vertisoft, which is based in San Francisco, with 3.5 million shares of its stock. Its shares closed at $8.875, up $1.25, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Mexico's Ruling Party Cuts Off Investigation Involving Zedillo
description: Mexico's ruling party, making blunt use of powers it has long wielded, has shut down a congressional investigation that was examining the role of President Ernesto Zedillo in a Government payment that had raised suspicions of corruption.

title: HOCKEY;Rangers' Interest in Gretzky Remains High, to a Point
description: Dave Checketts and Neil Smith said yesterday that although the Rangers are involved in discussions concerning Wayne Gretzky (discussions that appear to have turned more serious), they will not pay the 35-year-old free agent more than the player Checketts called "probably our most famous sports star at the Garden."

title: Sports of The Times;Games Are Putting A Brand on Atlanta
description: NOT that many years ago when Atlanta was growing into the South's staunchest son, a rookie resident had a theory.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;For Starters, Murrell Aims to Run Complete Show
description: The other runners had played themselves out of starting roles. And then one day last season, Adrian Murrell, the summertime flash, the man with the third-down reputation, became the starting running back for the Jets.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Greenspan's Testimony Spurs a Rally
description: Treasury prices rallied yesterday after the market interpreted comments from Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to mean that an increase in interest rates was not imminent.

title: Another Deal In Auto Parts Consolidation
description: Johnson Controls Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy the closely held Prince Automotive for $1.35 billion in a cash deal that would bolster its position as one of the world's largest suppliers of car and truck interiors.

title: AT&T and Wells Fargo Investing in an Electronic Cash Card
description: Betting that consumers will go for cash loaded onto a card with a chip on it, AT&T and Wells Fargo & Company said yesterday that they would form the American affiliate of Mondex, an emerging global electronic cash program.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Cement Acquisition Planned in Brazil
description: The Swiss cement company Holderbank Financiere Glarus A.G. said yesterday that it would buy Companhia de Cimento Portland Paraiso of Brazil for $200 million. The acquisition of family-owned Paraiso will make Holderbank the No. 2 cement company in southern Brazil, Holderbank said. In adding Paraiso's 2.2 million tons of annual capacity, Holderbank's capacity in Brazil will total 5.2 million tons a year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Anheuser-Busch Apologizes for Ad
description: Anheuser-Busch Inc. apologized yesterday "to anyone who was offended" by a TV commercial that included brief film clips from the 1936 Summer Games in Berlin.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section yesterday about cool summer retreats included two places erroneously. The grounds of Castle Village and Hudson View Gardens, prewar apartment complexes in northern Manhattan, are private property, open only to residents, not to the general public.

title: FILM REVIEW;Bad Taste in a Vile Story Doesn't Rule Out Fun
description: The needle goes in. The floorboards open. And Mark Renton (Ewan McGregor), the acidly attractive hero of "Trainspotting," drifts into the druggy oblivion that this film depicts with such dead-on, calculating ingenuity. For better or worse, sometimes strictly for the sake of shock value, the stylish irreverence of "Trainspotting" mimics that drug high and delivers its own potent kick.

title: NYC;When Terror Becomes Part Of Daily Life
description: THIS may seem to be jumping the gun, since so much is still not known about what brought down Trans World Airlines Flight 800. But it is probably time for Americans to accept terrorism as a fact of life requiring certain impositions, like personal searches in public places, to preserve communal safety.

title: Stocks Flat in Tokyo
description: Japanese stocks were flat in morning trading. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was off 4.82 points, or just two one-hundredths of a percent, at 21,561.60. In lackluster trading on Thursday, the Nikkei advanced 153.54 points.

title: A Beefed-Up Portrait Of Ex-Mayor Beame;Lightly Retouched by Years and Memories
description: Abe Beame looks at least 12 feet tall, biceps bulging, pecs ever so Schwarzeneggeresque. Shivering in his shadow, barely reaching his waist, are three of his opponents, one of them so nervous his hair stands on end. At the end of Mr. Beame's Popeye-puffed arms, his strapping hands hold a scroll of paper: "New York City Repair Plans," it reads.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Lower Costs, Better Sales Bolster Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company reported today that its performance was strong in the second quarter, a result of lower costs and robust sales at its Sears stores and furniture, hardware and other specialty stores.

title: Genocide Jurisdiction
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Let Boaters Sink Amtrak's Expansion
description: To the Editor:

title: Fox to Start a News Channel For Cable Viewers in October
description: The latest entrant in the 24-hour news business, a cable network from Fox, will begin appearing on Oct. 7 and will be called the Fox News Channel, or FNC, Roger Ailes, the chairman of Fox News, announced here today.

title: Critic's Choice/Pop;Writhe, Squeal and Scrape
description: For 12 years, Mickey Melchiondo and Aaron Freeman (better known by their pseudonyms, Dean and Gene Ween) have been recording crude, idiosyncratic odes to eggs, weasels, ticks and bodily functions in Southern New Jersey.

title: How Lawmakers Voted On Welfare Overhaul Bill
description: Following is the 256-to-170 roll-call vote by which the House today passed a major overhaul of the welfare system. Voting "yes" were 226 Republicans and 30 Democrats. Voting "no" were 4 Republicans, 165 Democrats and 1 /independent. X denotes those not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Unforgettable 1996. MGM/UA. $105.51. Laser disk, $34.98. 116 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Judith Connelly Delouvrier, who died in the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800, misidentified a group on whose board she served. The group, which encourages philanthropic leanings in children, is Common Cents, not Common Sense.

title: POLITICS: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;Dole Holds His Tongue, But Strain Is Showing
description: Bob Dole is striving these days to curb the unscripted remarks that have distracted his Presidential campaign, but it became clear this week that the switch might not be so easy. The former Senate majority leader spent his career fielding questions, and he is now responding to the silence imposed on him by his campaign with a collection of shrugs, grins, grimaces and grunts.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Student Admits Sex Crimes
description: A pre-med student from the University of Virginia pleaded guilty yesterday to sexually assaulting two women, and attempting to assault a third, while he was home in South Orange during school vacation. Christopher McAllister, 23, also pleaded guilty to three burglaries in South Orange and Maplewood in 1994 and 1995, said Ray Weiss, a spokesman for the Essex County Prosecutor's office.

title: GOLF;Aging Nicklaus Plays Like the Nicklaus of Old
description: He thought he might not come here at all. His back was questionable; his golf game was worse. As late as Thursday morning, he could barely get out of bed and was thinking about pulling out. Jack Nicklaus didn't want to embarrass himself, didn't want a couple of rounds of sympathy applause and another weekend off to think about what used to be.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1 -- NOTEBOOK;Excluded From Ceremony
description: The Norwegian yachtsman Herman Johannessen lost an index finger in an accident five years ago, but it did not complicate his Olympic dream until now.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: NOTEBOOK;Ewing Likes His Chances With or Without O'Neal
description: Knicks center Patrick Ewing will not miss all that bumping and chest-thumping under the basket with Shaquille O'Neal, the former center for the Orlando Magic. But watching O'Neal go west to play for the Los Angeles Lakers does not come as a relief to someone who believes that his team can win the Atlantic Division, Shaq or not.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICA ONLINE EXPECTS TO DOUBLE ITS EARNINGS
description: Trying to avoid being splashed by bad news from its rival Compuserve Inc., America Online said yesterday that it expected to at least double its fourth-quarter earnings -- meeting or exceeding Wall Street analysts' expectations. Compuserve, the No. 2 on-line service after America Online, said on Tuesday that it expected to post an operating loss in its quarter ending July 31. America Online's chairman, Steve Case, said yesterday that his company expected to meet or exceed analysts' predictions of 16 cents a share for its fourth quarter, which ended on June 30; it reports financial results Aug. 8.

title: Taxicabs and Seat Belts and the People Who Demand Them;Front Seat Dangers
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;HOLOGIC AGREES TO MERGE WITH FLUOROSCAN
description: Hologic Inc. agreed yesterday to merge with Fluoroscan Imaging Systems Inc. in a stock swap valued at about $59 million. In the merger of two makers of X-ray machines, Hologic, based in Waltham, Mass., will issue about 1.5 million common shares for all of Fluoroscan's common shares, stock warrants and stock options. Fluoroscan rose $2.875 a share, to $10.75 yesterday, in Nasdaq trading, and its warrants more than quadrupled. Hologic stock fell 87.5 cents, to $38.50. Hologic will also reserve an additional 300,000 shares to issue to holders of Fluoroscan stock options. Fluoroscan, based in Northbrook, Ill., makes a small X-ray machine designed for minimally invasive surgery.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Spanish Companies in Crossfire of U.S.-Cuba Battle
description: Before Fidel Castro took over Cuba, Irenee du Pont Sr. owned a three-story beach house, a golf course and a private dock on the island's northern coast as a retreat from his family's Delaware chemical company.

title: Religion Journal;New Millennium, Great Expectations
description: As the year 2000 approaches, declarations that a vast metaphysical change will coincide with the turn of the chronological odometer have not lacked an audience.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about Aleksandr I. Lebed, national security adviser to President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, misidentified the person at a public forum who Mr. Lebed said sounded "like a Jew." It was a supporter of Mr. Lebed, not a reporter.

title: William Easton, 80, Fossil-Coral Expert
description: William Heyden Easton, a University of Southern California paleontologist and an authority on fossil corals, died at his home in Westlake Village on July 7. He was 80.

title: Observer;Ending With a Whimper
description: What a disappointment. The mysterious Anonymous, author of the political novel "Primary Colors," has been unmasked by The Washington Post. He is a political writer named Joe Klein.

title: TOP BOSNIAN SERB AGREES TO RESIGN
description: Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb political chief who led his people in a brutal war of ethnic separation, has agreed to give up political power immediately, the special United States envoy, Richard C. Holbrooke, said here today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;West Japan Railway Plans to Sell Shares
description: The West Japan Railway Company will sell 1.7 million shares next month in an initial public offering, after postponing the equity sale twice since 1994. A sluggish stock market and an earthquake forced the public railway to postpone earlier plans for the sale, which is part of a Government effort to put Japan's railways into the private sector.

title: Judge Clears Accord on Class-Action Suit Against Archer Daniels
description: A Federal judge gave final approval today to a $45 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit accusing the Archer Daniels Midland Company and its competitors of fixing prices for the animal feed supplement lysine.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SUNBEAM SHARES RISE ON NEWS OF CHIEF'S APPOINTMENT
description: The stock of the Sunbeam Corporation soared yesterday on news that the former chief of the Scott Paper Company, Albert Dunlap, an aggressive cost-cutter, had been hired to recharge the consumer products and appliance maker. The stock rose $6.125, to $18.625, a 49 percent increase, on the New York Stock Exchange. Sunbeam announced on Thursday that Mr. Dunlap had been named chairman and chief executive, replacing Roger Schipke, who left the company in May. Analysts predicted that Mr. Dunlap, who was known as the Chainsaw when he ran timber companies and has engineered eight corporate turnarounds, will take an ax to Sunbeam.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Former Lineman Gets One-Year Sentence
description: A judge in Phoenix yesterday sentenced the former N.F.L. lineman LUIS SHARPE to one year in prison for violating his probation by using illegal drugs. Maricopa County Superior Court Judge MICHAEL D. RYAN said Sharpe, 36, was a danger to the public and to himself. He also ordered Sharpe to spend 35 months under house arrest and to undergo long-term treatment for drug addiction. Ryan sentenced Sharpe to three years' probation on May 22 after a series of arrests for drug possession and assault. Sharpe played 13 years for the St. Louis and Phoenix Cardinals. (AP)

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Canucks End Negotiations With Gretzky
description: The Vancouver Canucks said yesterday that they have ended negotiations with WAYNE GRETZKY following reports that the National Hockey League's career leading scorer was set to return to Canada. "There is no outstanding offer from the Vancouver Canucks," General Manager PAT QUINN said in a statement.

title: An Attempt to Deter Agents
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association special committee on agents and amateurism is proposing ways to crack down on sports agents who attempt to sign student-athletes. The proposals will attempt to counteract the lure of agents by providing student-athletes with an opportunity to supplement their incomes.

title: INSIDE
description: Growing Divisions in Mexico

title: Investors Pull Money Out of Stock Funds
description: Investors were clearly rattled by wild swings in the stock market, withdrawing $4 billion from stock mutual funds -- the largest weekly withdrawal in four years.

title: Hospital Urged for Suspect
description: A brain-damaged man accused of setting a fatal fire in a fireworks store belongs in a medical institution, his lawyer has argued after the man fought deputies in jail.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Delta Beats Earnings Forecasts
description: The shares of Delta Air Lines fell today as the company's prediction that it would not meet a cost-cutting goal overshadowed better-than-expected results.

title: In Performance;ROCK
description: Everything That's New Becomes Old, but That's O.K. Sparklehorse Maxwell's

title: Education Board to Expand Private Custodial Services
description: The Board of Education voted yesterday to expand its privatization of custodial operations to an additional 29 school buildings, saying that the year-old program had resulted in generally less expensive and more effective maintenance services than those provided by the custodians' union.

title: Truth Comes to Those Scientists Who Work at It
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: SECURITY;Airport Sweeps Leave One Thing Unchecked: The Planes
description: For almost a year, Kennedy International Airport has been especially conscious of security.

title: An Unwelcome Record
description: Gov. George Pataki and the Republican State Committee have been making history this year. Together they took in $4.49 million in campaign contributions during the first six months of 1996. No New York Governor and his party have ever raised so much, so fast, this early in the election cycle.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ESSILOR OF AMERICA TO BUY DUFFENS OPTICAL
description: Essilor of America Inc. said yesterday that it would buy Duffens Optical for about $40 million in cash and notes. Duffens, based in Topeka, Kan., generated revenue of about $50 million in its latest fiscal year and operates 12 laboratories in the Midwest and south-central United States, Essilor said. The Midwestern optical company has distributed Essilor's Varilux lens products since 1979, Essilor said. Although some executive management changes will be made, Duffens, with 550 employees, will keep its name and continue to operate from its current sites, Essilor said.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;German Data Lift Hopes For an Early Rate Cut
description: German money-supply growth slowed abruptly in June, the Bundesbank said yesterday, providing new evidence of a sluggish economy and fanning hopes for interest-rate cuts as soon as next week. The Bundesbank said the M-3 money supply, a leading indicator of inflation, grew at an annual rate of 9.6 percent in June, slowing from a 10.5 percent rate in May.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Saving a Cable Factory
description: Founded in 1848, the Roebling Company in Trenton designed and built the steel cables for such famous structures as the Brooklyn, George Washington and Golden Gate bridges. This week, a private group was awarded a $1.25 million matching grant to turn the 106-year-old machine shop at Roebling's Trenton complex -- which shut its doors in 1974 -- into a museum of New Jersey technology. This was one of $11 million in grants awarded by the New Jersey Historic Trust for 27 projects ranging from the 148-year-old Absecon Lighthouse in Atlantic City to the 90-year-old Essex County Courthouse. The trust is financed through state bond issues, said Harriette Hawkins, its executive director. TERRY PRISTIN

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1;The Heat Becomes Another Opponent
description: When all is said and done, perhaps the most recognizable symbol for these Summer Games may not be the five rings but the plastic water bottle.

title: Man Is Arrested In Queens Killing
description: The police arrested a Manhattan man yesterday on charges that he slashed and shot his girlfriend to death, and then dumped her body in a bathtub.

title: Company Briefs
description: VOICE CONTROLS SYSTEMS INC., Dallas, a supplier of speech recognition and other voice services for the telecommunications industry, agreed to acquire the closely held Voice Processing Corp., Cambridge, Mass., for about $28 million in stock.

title: A Field of Visions Is His Dream;Catskills Man Sees Tourist Draw In World's Largest Kaleidoscope
description: Wading hip-deep in the sparkling Esopus Creek, two men cast delicate trout flies into green swirling pools. In a forested retreat in the woods nearby, Zen Buddhists meditate.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE PUBLIC;Politicians Provide Comfort And Criticism After Crash
description: Alternating between words of comfort for the victims' families and words of belligerence about terrorism and airline performance, many of the New York region's elected officials have thrust themselves into the public discussion of the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800.

title: Peg Weiss, 63, Kandinsky Scholar and Historian
description: Peg Weiss, an art historian, research professor and leading scholar on the Russian modernist Wassily Kandinsky, died on Wednesday at her home in Syracuse. She was 63.

title: Journal;The Summer Kingdom
description: I think there's a pattern here.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Reltec of U.S. to Buy Rainford of Britain
description: Reltec, an electronics company controlled by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, said yesterday that it would buy the Rainford Group, a British maker of cabinets for electronic equipment, for L80 million ($124 million). Reltec said Rainford had accepted an offer of 335 pence a share. The stock closed at 340, up 25 pence. For Reltec, with headquarters in Ohio, Illinois and Texas, the acquisition expands its $513 million telecommunications business to Britain and elsewhere in Europe. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Rain of Biblical Proportions Pours Out of Midwest Skies
description: If it doesn't rain again until the millennium, Don Feldott won't shed any tears.

title: Credit Unions Help Finance a Bid for Reinstatement by a DismissedFederal Regulator
description: Federal oversight of the nation's 12,000 credit unions is mired in an unusual political dispute between the Clinton Administration, which favors stricter rules, and a recently dismissed regulator who opposed tightened rules and whose bid for reinstatement has been partly financed by the credit union industry.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE INVESTIGATION;Searching for Clues On Countless Fronts
description: Unraveling the mystery of the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 is as sophisticated as a high-tech underwater device being shipped to the scene to listen for the electronic beep of the missing flight data recorder. And it's as simple as investigators knocking on doors along the Long Island coastline to ask if anyone saw anything unusual in the sky.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1;2 Dreamers From the Olympic City
description: They shared the same hometown, but came from different backgrounds, with different personalities and philosophies. And as the spotlight of the Atlanta Olympics landed on Billy Payne and LeRoy Walker during tonight's opening ceremonies, their shared celebration was the culmination of career dreams.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1 -- NOTEBOOK;No TV for Soccer Opener
description: Long shots for Olympic medals, America's men's soccer team is playing for respect, members of the team said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: High-Tech Rubber Hits the Road;Tire Makers Struggle to Stand Out From the Crowd
description: For the first nine years of its televised life, the Michelin baby did little but look cute as it frolicked around a tire. That was plenty: even competitors concede the cuddly tyke made Michelin's name synonymous with tire safety.

title: Mexican Group Says It Carried Out Ambush
description: A self-proclaimed guerrilla group that first made its appearance three weeks ago has taken responsibility for an ambush on an army jeep and a civilian delivery truck this week that killed at least one person.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1;NBC's Restrictions Protested
description: ABC News, ESPN, CNN, CBS News and Fox Television today protested restrictions imposed by NBC, which is broadcasting the Summer Olympics, that limit the use of footage from news conferences held at the Games' main press center.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;This Wine Has a Presidential Seal
description: With his four sons, Saul Menem, a poor Syrian immigrant who spoke little Spanish, started a small winery in this arid farming village in northwest Argentina 65 years ago.

title: CYCLING;A Master of the Attack Looking for His Moment
description: Kamikaze First Class Eros Poli would like to deny the report that he has grounded himself.

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;Organized Labor Goes on the Offensive, and the Republicans Cry Foul
description: House Republicans, seeking to get a damaging A.F.L.-C.I.O. advertisement about Medicare off the air, are telling television stations that the advertisement is a lie and that broadcasting it may invite libel suits against them.

title: World News Briefs;Tamils Continue Battle With Sri Lanka Troops
description: A Tamil rebel suicide squad blew up a naval gunboat today and pinned down a squad of elite commandos, killing its commander, in one of the fiercest battles of their 13-year war for independence.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1 -- NOTEBOOK;Traffic Gets Off to a Gridlocked Start
description: It may have been the worst traffic jam in the history of Atlanta, a city already known for highway nightmares.

title: 'Possibility of Criminal Act,' Says U.S. Aviation Official
description: NEW YORK  As sonar located large sections of TWA Flight 800 on the Atlantic seabed, a top government aviation safety official said Friday that the fiery explosion and crash that killed 230 people could well have been "a criminal act."

title: Rates on Mortgages Dip
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.23 percent this week, down from 8.42 percent last week, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. It was the lowest since July 3, when rates averaged 8.14 percent. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 5.97 percent, down from 6.01 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.76 percent this week, down from 7.93 percent.

title: BASEBALL;Expos Leave Mets Deflated Again
description: He is the Mets' biggest enigma this season. There have been questions about his work habits, his maturity, his confidence, his shoulder, and even his fastball. And last night Jason Isringhausen did little to end the head-scratching.

title: An Editor at The Atlantic to Lead U.S. News
description: James Fallows, the Washington editor of The Atlantic Monthly, whose recent book criticizing media coverage caused something of a stir among journalists, was named editor of the weekly news magazine U.S. News & World Report yesterday.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE FAMILIES;For Families, Few Answers Except the Ones They Fear
description: Their days now are bracketed by briefings.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Morrison Is Briefly Hospitalized
description: Legally prescribed drugs caused the former heavyweight boxer TOMMY MORRISON to suffer a seizure and receive brief hospital treatment on Wednesday, his promoter said.

title: Russell H. Dorr, 89, International Banker
description: Russell Higginson Dorr, a retired international banker and Government official involved with postwar Europe and the Far East, died last Saturday during a visit to the Galapagos Islands. He was 89 and lived in Point O'Woods, N.Y., and Fort Myers, Fla.

title: POLITICS;Powell Will Attend G.O.P. Convention
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell will be bumping elbows with former Presidents George Bush and Gerald Ford on what Bob Dole promises will be a fast-paced opening night for the Republican National Convention.

title: Panel Advises F.D.A. To Allow Abortion Pill
description: Meeting in a windowless building here amid unusual security precautions, a committee of advisers to the Food and Drug Administration recommended today that the agency approve for marketing the abortion-inducing drug RU-486, or mifepristone.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Chiefs Match Vikings' Offer for Carter
description: The Kansas City Chiefs matched a contract offer from the Minnesota Vikings yesterday to retain rights to cornerback DALE CARTER, a mainstay in one of the National Football League's top defensive units. The Vikings' offer was believed to be for three years, with base salaries escalating from $400,000 to $2 million to $3.5 million, and a signing bonus of $1.8 million.

title: Colorado Booms, and Some Worry
description: With 600 head of Santa Gertrudis cattle grazing on 4,000 acres of grass dotted with ponderosa pine, Cherokee Ranch is a Charles Russell tableau, squeezed into a 1990's frame.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Man Dies at Ex-Wife's Home
description: A Bronx man who was under a court order to stay away from his former wife died early yesterday in a struggle with a friend of hers after going to her house with a gun, the police said. The man, Gowkarran Dyal, 36, apparently was strangled by the friend, Jeff Diamond, 37, in a struggle in which at least one shot was fired, said Chief Charles Zisa of the Hackensack Police Department.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1 -- NOTEBOOK;Package Causes Scare
description: The police evacuated part of the Olympics' International Broadcasting Center late this afternoon after a suspicious package was found there just hours before the opening ceremony.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BACHMAN INFORMATION COMPLETES CADRE TAKEOVER
description: Bachman Information Systems Inc. completed the acquisition of the closely held Cadre Technologies Inc. yesterday for $27.3 million. Under terms of the agreement, the companies formed a newly named entity called Cayenne Software Inc. Based on Bachman Information's closing price on Thursday of $6.625, the acquisition is valued at $27.3 million. The acquisition creates a company that is among the 50 largest independent software companies in the world, the companies said. Cayenne, based in Burlington, Mass., will have annual sales of about $70 million. Bachman Information develops and markets data base design software. Cadre Technologies, of Providence, R.I., makes software for personal computer networks installed by corporations.

title: Sports of The Times;Long Opening Ceremony Finally Gives the Games to the Athletes
description: FINALLY, the Summer Games belong to the athletes after six years of dreaming and last night's opening ceremony, topped by the emotional perfect touch of the legendary Muhammad Ali, slowed by Parkinson's syndrome, lighting the Olympic caldron.

title: All-Girl Schools Duck the Issue
description: The problem is well known. Teachers, often unwittingly, direct most of their attention toward boys. They call on boys more often than girls, allow them to blurt out answers and ask them more complex questions.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1;Agassi Draws a Tough First Round
description: Confronted by an Olympic tennis draw that contained 65,000 possible permutations, officials turned to a computer today to produce what they believed to be the first wholly computerized draw of a major sporting event.

title: A Jewish Studies Leader Must Know Hebrew
description: To the Editor:

title: Uncovered Short Sales Decline On the Big Board and the Amex
description: Despite the stock market's recent gyrations, bearish investors have been trimming their bets a bit, based on the open positions of short sales reported yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants' New Camp Marred by Graffiti
description: Not everyone was making the Giants feel welcome on their first day of practice at the State University at Albany.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Hewlett-Packard Expands
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company, maker of high-technology products, is planning to invest another 218 million Irish pounds ($348 million) in its inkjet printer cartridge manufacturing operation in Ireland. The state industrial development authority, IDA Ireland, is supporting the investment, which will create 836 new jobs at the plant and bring Hewlett-Packard's total investment to 320 million Irish pounds. In February 1995, Hewlett-Packard announced it was establishing the plant to assemble inkjet printer cartridges.

title: A Jewish Studies Leader Must Know Hebrew;Bizarre Arguments
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Executive Changes
description: AIRWAYS CORP., Orlando, Fla., a regional airline, named Robert Swenson, its chairman and chief executive, to the additional posts of chief executive and president of its Airtran Airways unit, replacing John Horn, who retired.

title: Sports of The Times;In Search Of a Spirit In the Dark
description: BY two o'clock Friday morning, even the hardiest of souls at Deacon Burton's Soul Food Restaurant and Grill were beginning to have their doubts. An expanding nucleus of 15 patrons had been waiting since 11 for the Olympic torch to come down Hurt Street in the southeastern part of the city.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE AIRLINE;Agents Say Passengers Are Keeping Travel Plans
description: Travel agents and officials at Trans World Airlines said yesterday that relatively few passengers had canceled tickets for domestic or international flights on T.W.A. or any other airline since the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 off the coast of Long Island on Wednesday night.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1;Olympic Honors, 60 Years Late
description: The tall, white-haired woman in blue blouse and slacks had just arrived at the airport here this afternoon when she was approached by two young girls seeking her autograph.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE FRENCH CLUB;In a Small Pennsylvania Town, 21 Lives Touch Every Family
description: In his print shop, Ronald F. Paulhamus shakily ran his index finger down the list of people from his town who were aboard the doomed T.W.A. Flight 800 and ticked off the links that he -- like many of his neighbors -- had with almost every one.

title: Drifter Charged in Case That Gay Groups Said Showed Police Bias
description: At first, the killing of Sylvia Lugo seemed to be one of a series of robberies, sexual assaults and beatings of women in the brownstone neighborhoods of Park Slope and Boerum Hill.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Animal Protection Is Popular
description: Animal protection is hot this season. Earlier this week, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed legislation that would increase penalties for animal cruelty. Yesterday, three Republican legislators said they would introduce a bill to let pet owners be compensated for emotional distress if their animals are harmed or killed. A second measure would increase penalties for stealing a pet to 18 months in prison -- five years if the thief intended to sell the animal -- and a $7,500 fine. Current law links penalties to the pet's value, and treats most thefts as disorderly persons offenses.

title: Metro Digest
description: THE CRASH

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Wall Street's Busiest Week Ends on a Down Note Capping the busiest week of trading in Wall Street history and one of the most volatile, stocks closed on a down note, but far more calmly than they began the week when the market plunged on fears of weak earnings. The Dow Jones industrial average lost 37.36 points, closing at 5,426.82. For the week, it was down 83.74 points. The Nasdaq Composite index fell 12.14 points to 1,097.68.

title: 2 New Cereals By Betty Crocker
description: General Mills Inc. said today that it would introduce two new cereals under its Betty Crocker brand name, adding to its lineup of products that includes Wheaties, Cheerios, Total and Lucky Charms.

title: Resignation at Quaker Oats Over Snapple's Poor Sales
description: Donald Uzzi, a key executive in the Quaker Oats Company's struggle to turn around its Snapple beverage operation, resigned today, touching off a new speculation about whether Quaker would be pressured to split its beverage and food operations.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Ever Wincing At Her Roots Yet Unwilling To Let Go
description: When people talk about a writer's vision, they usually don't mean it in any real anatomical sense. But Sandra Tsing Loh, an essayist, novelist and performance artist, actually has eyes that seem to match her point of view.

title: Rules Approved To Let Trading Resume Faster
description: Federal regulators yesterday approved rules to allow the stock market and the stock index futures market to resume trading more rapidly in the event either is forced to halt trading by plunging prices.

title: In Performance;CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Looking for a Challenge: Difficult Works for Piano Eric Himy Frick Collection

title: Stirrings in Indonesia
description: Thirty years of military rule has stifled the political life of Indonesia, the world's fourth-most-populous country. Now, with President Suharto nearing the end of his sixth and possibly last term, open debate about the country's future and institutions is beginning to revive.

title: Man Who Killed 3 in Family Is Executed
description: A man who killed his former wife, her father and her 10-year-old stepson in 1985 was executed by injection here early today.

title: In Performance;ROCK
description: When It's All in Knowing What to Borrow or Blend Dead Can Dance City Center

title: World News Briefs;Catholic Bishops Regret Anti-Aborigine Policy
description: The Roman Catholic Church in Australia has apologized for its part in a Government assimilation policy aimed at breaking the cultural identity of Aborigines by removing tens of thousands of children from their parents.

title: Multiracial Americans Ready To Claim Their Own Identity
description: For Alison Perry, being multiracial has meant moving through life as if she had a giant question mark drawn on her forehead. Strangers frequently approach and begin a vexing guessing game: "Are you Israeli?" "Are you a Latina?" "Where are you from?"

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Rights Official Dismissed
description: Nearly three months after he sued the borough and township of Princeton for racial discrimination, the director of the Joint Commission on Civil Rights has been dismissed. Ovie E. Lattimore, who is black, had accused the municipalities of putting him on part-time status last March to punish him for helping parents of minority high school students file complaints against the school system. "He performed his job too well for Princeton's taste," his lawyer, Edward J. Boccher, said yesterday. Michael Herbert, the attorney for Princeton borough, said Mr. Lattimore was dismissed Thursday because of unsatisfactory job evaluations.

title: Chevron Settlement Put at $700 Million
description: The Chevron Corporation has been ordered to pay an estimated $700 million in a lawsuit over the Gulf Oil Company's 1982 decision to call off its $5 billion acquisition of the Cities Service Company.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 7 about security lapses at American bases in Saudi Arabia misstated the role of the Central Intelligence Agency in assessing the threat of terrorism there. The agency did not reach an official conclusion that Saudi terrorists could not build a bomb larger than 200 pounds.

title: World News Briefs;Palestinian Convicted In U.S. in '85 Hijacking
description: A Palestinian who admitted killing two passengers -- including an American -- during a hijacking in the Mediterranean in 1985 was convicted today of air piracy.

title: Truth Comes to Those Scientists Who Work at It
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: When the cognoscenti argue about the identity of the world's best individual player, they usually focus on Americans, mentioning Bob Hamman, Bob Wolff, Jeff Meckstroth and Eric Rodwell, with some support for the cosmopolitan Pakistani, Zia Mahmood.

title: Newark to Get More Teachers But Fewer Jobs
description: More than 600 employees of the state-operated school district here will lose their jobs as part of a plan to move money from the central administration to classrooms, state education officials announced today.

title: Retire in the Apartment-Starved City? Yes!
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Haselrig May Leave Jail for Rehabilitation
description: CARLTON HASELRIG, a former Jets and Pittsburgh Steelers guard, may leave jail to enter a drug- and alcohol-rehabilitation program in Johnstown, Pa., Allegheny County Judge DAVID CERCONE said Thursday. Haselrig, 30, a former Pro Bowl selection who left the N.F.L. after problems including drunken driving and a fight with the police, was jailed July 6 after the Johnstown police spotted him driving a motorcycle with his helmet on backward. He was accused of several traffic counts, which violated terms of his probation for drunken driving in 1994, and was jailed. (AP)

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1;Samaranch Has Only Praise for the Games
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch today pronounced the Olympics healthy, played down the Games' extraordinary commercialism and judged the modern Olympics' 100th birthday more momentous than his own 76th, which he celebrated here on Wednesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about playground sprinklers, including the waterworks in the playground at Battery Park City, misstated the surname of the landscape architect for the Battery Park City Authority. She is Susan D. Kaplan, not Kahn.

title: No Headline
