description: The German Olympic Committee was making an attempt at making amends, and I thought, I can't hold the sins of the fathers and grandfathers against the new generation. After all, many of them hate what Hitler and the Nazis did, too."

title: Constitution-Bashing
description: Last week, by a lopsided margin, the House approved the Defense of Marriage Act. This is an ill-advised piece of legislation that would ban Federal recognition of same-sex marriages and allow each state to ignore such marriages performed in any other state.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE PASSENGERS;Reunions and Homecomings Never Fulfilled and Sudden End to a Vacation
description: Eric and Virginia Holst were finally getting away. They had been working too hard, Eric at Moriches Dental Associates, where he was a senior associate, and Virginia from the condominium they had bought two years ago in Center Moriches, L.I., where she was trying hard to get a telemarketing business off the ground. Then Europe called.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ROADMASTER SELLING BICYCLE AND SLEDS DIVISIONS
description: Roadmaster Industries said yesterday that it would sell its Bicycle division and Flexible Flyer line of sleds and wagons to the Brunswick Corporation for $212 million. Under the agreement, Roadmaster will sell the Roadmaster trademark to Brunswick and adopt a new corporate name. The remaining Roadmaster Sporting Goods Group will retain the Flexible Flyer trademark for use on other toys. Roadmaster said the proceeds of the sale would be used to reduce its debt and make additional funds available for reinvestment in the company's remaining toy and fitness-related businesses or for general corporate purposes.

title: Public Broadcasting Can Survive Alone
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;AMERICAN ENTERPRISES SEEKS YALE INTERNATIONAL
description: American Enterprises L.L.C. began a cash tender offer yesterday for the remaining 80 percent of Yale International Inc., formerly known as Spreckels Industries, for $79.2 million. The offer amounts to $16.50 a share. The stock jumped $2.875, to $18.375, a new 52-week high. Last December, American Enterprises, a Richmond group formed in 1995 primarily to invest in Spreckels offered to buy the Charlotte, N.C., company for $11 a share, or $67 million. Spreckels rejected the offer. Since then, a group that includes Bedford Falls Investors L.P. and which holds about a 10.58 percent stake in the company, has voiced its desire that Yale pursue a sale or merger.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1 -- NOTEBOOK;A Team Now Scattered
description: In 1992, the Unified Team won the men's gymnastics gold medal with ease. All six members of that team of former Soviets are back for this Olympics, but they are now divided between four nations. Vitaly Shcherbo, winner of six golds in 1992, is here for Belarus. Grigory Misyutin, Rustam Charipov and Igor Korobchinsky are here for Ukraine. Aleksei Vorapayev is here for Russia and Valery Belenky for Germany.

title: Teachers Take On the Arts, and the Arts Teach Them
description: Take about 850 teachers and school administrators and loose them on Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts for a few weeks each summer. Give them plays, dance recitals, concerts. Take them to museums. Make them talk about it. Make them draw. Make them perform.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE MEDICAL EXAMINER;Families Urged to Provide Records to Speed Identification of Bodies
description: Amid complaints that his office is working too slowly, the Chief Medical Examiner of Suffolk County said yesterday that only five victims of the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 had been identified, and he urged relatives to gather dental and medical records to speed the process.

title: Truth Comes to Those Scientists Who Work at It;Venus's Face
description: To the Editor:

title: Taxicabs and Seat Belts and the People Who Demand Them
description: To the Editor:

title: In Performance;JAZZ
description: An Old Photo of Musicians Inspires a Film and a Concert Jazz in July 92d Street Y

title: Everybody Must Not Get Stoned
description: After the heroin death last week of yet another musician Jonathan Melvoin, a keyboard player for the Smashing Pumpkins -- I found myself asking the same old question about the music industry. Why can't we solve our drug problem?

title: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;Clinton Tells U.S. Athletes, 'I Want You to Mop Up'
description: With some of the tightest security measures ever, President Clinton came here today to open the Centennial Summer Olympic Games, pausing during a whirlwind day to give American athletes a pep talk and to meet more than two dozen other heads of state at a garden party.

title: Scots To the Death
description: The movie "Trainspotting" has hit the United States, offering a celluloid romp of Scotland's heroin-using youth underclass and a chance to examine the current allure of contemporary Scottish literature and culture.

title: 9 Caribbean Nations Open Waters to U.S. Drug Pursuit
description: In what American officials describe as a significant advance in the effort to combat drug trafficking in the Caribbean, the United States has negotiated "hot pursuit" agreements under which nine nations have opened their territorial waters to Coast Guard vessels.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: Mutual Fund Withdrawals Up Sharply
description: Mutual fund investors, rattled by an increasingly volatile stock market, withdrew $4 billion from equity funds in the week ended Wednesday, more than in any single week in the last four years, according to data released yesterday.

title: POLITICS;Gingrich on Medicare
description: Following is an excerpt from remarks made by Speaker Newt Gingrich to a Blue Cross/Blue Shield conference on Oct. 24, 1995, in Washington. The words in boldface are broadcast in an A.F.L.-C.I.O. advertisement that Republicans are trying to persuade television stations not to run.

title: Richard W. Long, 46, Builder Of Bicycles for Olympic Team
description: Richard W. Long, a college dropout who used a personal-injury settlement from a motorcycle accident to build a multimillion-dollar bicycle business that is supplying the most advanced equipment to the United States Olympic cycling team, died on July 12 when his motorcycle and a truck collided on a winding mountain road east of Los Angeles. He was 46 and lived in San Juan Capistrano, Calif.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;SKF of Sweden Says Profits Tumbled 21%
description: SKF A.B., the world's leading maker of ball bearings, said yesterday that its pretax profit fell 21 percent in the six months that ended on June 30. The company was stung by a stronger Swedish krona and weakness in Europe.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE OVERVIEW;Rough Seas Hamper Search for Clues in Plane Crash
description: Rough seas frustrated the search for the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 yesterday, as Federal agents mounted an investigation in search of the method and motives behind what they think was a criminal act that blew up the plane in midair.

title: For Israeli Settlers, a Dream Revived
description: For nearly three years, Yaldena Nawi and her young family have gazed wistfully at a house that stands empty in this remote Jewish settlement on a rock-strewn hillside surrounded by Palestinian villages.

title: Income Gap in Mexico Grows, and So Do Protests
description: One simmering Sunday in May, a hundred peasant farmers stormed a luxurious hillside mansion here and, in a scene out of an old newsreel of the 1910 Revolution, pounded on the gates with machetes and their clenched fists until the wealthy owners abandoned their brunch and fled.

title: Dow Jones and the Nikkei: Partners or Strangers in the Night?
description: For much of this week, the Tokyo stock market followed Wall Street on its roller-coaster ride. When stocks in New York plunged on Monday, they fell sharply in Tokyo on Tuesday. When Wall Street began to recover in the next two days, so did Tokyo.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Interest Rates Cut by Canada
description: The Bank of Canada cut key short-term interest rates today, citing a sluggish economy and an inflation rate near the bottom of the central bank's target range.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1;Promised Renewal Has Been Less Than Olympian
description: In the buoyant, everything-is-possible afterglow of Atlanta's victorious bid for the 1996 Summer Olympics, politicians and planners dreamed of using the Games as leverage to revitalize 15 of the city's most blighted and forgotten neighborhoods.

title: In Performance;JAZZ
description: Reworking Be-Bop Standards, But With Subtle Dynamics Tommy Flanagan, pianist Iridium

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Unichem Gains a Step In Lloyds Chemist Deal
description: Unichem P.L.C. said yesterday that it expected to meet British Government conditions on a purchase of Lloyds Chemists P.L.C., while the German counterbidder, Gehe A.G., said the requirements might be too onerous. Unichem and Gehe, Europe's biggest drug wholesaler, are vying for Lloyds Chemists to expand their pharmacy and drug wholesaling chains in Britain. Gehe's latest offer of L649.9 million ($994 million) topped Unichem's increased cash-and-share offer of L617.3 million.

title: Taxicabs and Seat Belts and the People Who Demand Them;Search and Surprise
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Wife Convicted, an Old Man Still Can't Get His Photos
description: On a calendar at the home of the photographer O. Winston Link in South Salem, N.Y., under Friday, July 12, a message clearly inscribed in pen reads like an epitaph: "Conchita. Guilty. 1st Degree Larceny. 12:45 P.M."

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF IOMEGA SLIDE ON DISAPPOINTING EARNINGS
description: The shares of the Iomega Corporation plunged 19 percent yesterday after the disk drive maker's second-quarter earnings disappointed some analysts and investors. In addition, Iomega told analysts yesterday on a conference call that third-quarter sales, especially in Europe, could be weak. European sales declined in the second quarter, Iomega said. Iomega's stock fell $5.50, to $22.50, in Nasdaq trading of almost 18.3 million shares yesterday. Iomega said late on Thursday that sales of its popular Zip and Jaz disk drives had pushed second-quarter profit to $14.1 million, or 11 cents a share, compared with a loss of $1.9 million, or 2 cents, in the period a year earlier.

title: Truth Comes to Those Scientists Who Work at It
description: To the Editor:

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: TENNIS;Peter Graf's Tax Evasion Trial Is Set
description: The tax evasion trial of PETER GRAF, STEFFI GRAF's father, will open Sept. 5, his lawyer in Munich, Germany, said yesterday. Graf, who has been jailed in Mannheim since August, is charged with failing to report $26 million of his daughter's earnings. (AP)

title: After Kaczynski Was Seized, Bomb Blew Up Near Cabin
description: Four days after the authorities arrested Theodore Kaczynski in April as a suspect in the Unabom case, a bomb exploded near his remote Montana cabin, according to prosecution documents released today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Bacteria Found at F.A.A.
description: A routine test turned up evidence of the bacteria that cause Legionnaires' disease in the sediment of a pond at the Federal Aviation Administration's technical center, the agency announced yesterday. The F.A.A. said it planned to drain and sterilize the pond, which contains water used for cooling two buildings. Officials said they had restricted access to the pond area and insured that air circulating through nearby buildings was properly filtered. No cases of the disease have been reported at the center, where 2,500 people work, said Les Dorr Jr., an F.A.A. spokesman.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Talley Out After Tearing Up Left Knee
description: This is not how the first day of Giants practice is supposed to go. Linebacker Ben Talley is a player many people may never have heard of, but he was expected to be an integral part of the team.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1;Hot Athletes, Hot Contests and Hot Weather
description: When the summer sweat briefly stops dripping, dripping, dripping after the first day of Olympic competition on Saturday, the following things will probably have happened:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Jobless Rate Unchanged
description: For the second month in a row, New Jersey's unemployment rate stood at 6.1 percent in June -- half a percentage point lower than it was in April, the state Labor Department reported yesterday. The state added 5,100 service jobs, but lost 2,600 jobs in manufacturing. Despite the improvement, New Jersey's unemployment rate exceeds the national rate, which was 5.3 percent in June.

title: In Performance;JAZZ
description: Giving His Tunes An Outside and an Inside Jonny King Sweet Basil

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1;The Olympics Open Amid Pageantry, and Anxiety
description: After six years of preparation, Atlanta welcomed the world tonight for the opening of the centennial Summer Olympics, which began with idealistic hopes for peace among nations moderated by anxiety about terrorism in the wake of the explosion aboard Trans World Airlines Flight 800.

title: Jailed Chief of the French Railroad Resigns
description: The head of the French National Railroad resigned today, one day after an appeals court refused to release him from jail in a corruption inquiry.

title: G.M. to Consolidate Car and Truck Offices
description: The General Motors Corporation will consolidate the administrative offices of its car and truck divisions at its new headquarters in downtown Detroit over the next five years, officials said today.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1;South African Runs and Remembers
description: For all the crass commercialism of recent Olympics, for all the medal-stand exhibitions of X-brand shoes and Y-brand warm-up suits, for all the $20 T-shirts and $5 sausage dogs and $4 local cola, there are still defining moments that make the Olympics a treasure.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;A Setback for Mariners' Johnson
description: The Seattle Mariners left-hander RANDY JOHNSON, who has been sidelined since May 12 with a back injury, is at least two weeks away from pitching in a game. Johnson, the 1995 American League Cy Young Award winner, was scheduled to start last night for Class A Lancaster of the California League. But he was examined by a back specialist yesterday in Los Angeles and advised to continue his rehabilitation exercise and throwing program, the team said. (AP)

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800;F.B.I. Seeking Crash Witnesses
description: In its investigation into the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has asked Long Island residents to get in touch with the agency if on the night of the crash they saw "events in the sky, events of things falling out of the sky" that might be related to the crash. Witnesses are asked to call (888) 245-4636 or send e-mail to newyork

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1 -- NOTEBOOK;Georgia Flag Protested
description: Just a few hours before the Olympic torch was lighted in Centennial Olympic Stadium, about 50 people gathered to set fire to the Georgia state flag.

title: Senators Vote to Cut Off Benefits for Legal Aliens
description: The Senate voted today to deny most Federal benefits and social services to legal immigrants who have yet to become citizens, and it blocked Democratic efforts to aid children in families who lose public assistance under a welfare bill moving swiftly through Congress.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Comsat Chief Executive Quits As Quarterly Profits Fall 74%
description: The Comsat Corporation said today that its chief executive had resigned and that he had been succeeded by the executive who led the company's international business. The company, struggling to manage its diverse satellite communications and sports businesses, also said its second-quarter earnings fell 74 percent .

title: Chrysler Raising Prices by Average 1.9%
description: The Chrysler Corporation is raising prices for its 1997 cars and light trucks an average of 1.9 percent, or $422, over comparably equipped 1996 models.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: LONG ISLAND;Aftermath Of a Crash On Beaches And Psyches
description: With one of the deadliest air disasters in the nation's history having occurred just 10 miles from their shore, vacationers and year-round residents here found some incongruous sites on their treasured beaches today. Police cars and emergency vehicles crawled along the water's edge. Beachcombers stumbled upon pieces of crash debris. And some townspeople reported seeing F.B.I. agents dressed in suits walking along the seashore.

title: BASEBALL;Pettitte Plummets Yanks To Season-Worst Streak
description: The Yankees have not employed a secret formula while barreling into first place in the American League East. Their approach has been basic. When the Yankees pitch precisely, they usually win. When the Yankees pitch poorly, they usually lose. No secrets.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Raiders Sign Maryland as a Free Agent
description: The Oakland Raiders signed the free agent RUSSELL MARYLAND to bring playoff experience to their defensive line. Maryland spent the past five seasons with the Dallas Cowboys and has three Super Bowl rings to show for it. He will be teamed with CHESTER McGLOCKTON to give the Raiders two of the better defensive tackles in the N.F.L. (AP)

title: Taxicabs and Seat Belts and the People Who Demand Them;A Call for Cool Air, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;RYDER STUDIES SALE OF CONSUMER TRUCK RENTAL UNIT
description: Ryder System Inc. said yesterday that it was considering selling its consumer truck rental division and was in serious talks with possible buyers. The company said it had hired the investment firm Goldman, Sachs & Company to explore the sale of the unit, which accounts for about 10 percent of the company's revenue. On the New York Stock Exchange, Ryder's stock closed up 62.5 cents a share at $26.875. The division for sale has 35,000 trucks, from 10 feet long to 24-footers. The commercial truck rental division is not for sale. The consumer truck rental unit, which operates in the 48 contiguous states and in Canada, had revenue of $500 million in 1995.

title: World News Briefs;Chechen Commander Apparently Still Alive
description: Kremlin officials warned today that a man who claimed this week to be a Chechen military commander who had been reported dead could rally rebel fighters to attack Russian troops.

title: Frederick J. Stock, 88, Pharmaceutical Executive
description: Frederick J. Stock, a pharmaceutical-industry executive who supervised the nation's large-scale production of penicillin and other "miracle drugs" during World War II, died Tuesday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 88 years old.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 1;Americans to Meet Powerful Cubans Early in the Boxing Competition
description: The United States-Cuba collision is taking a short course. The two powers of amateur boxing always get in the way of each other's pursuits and passions and usually settle matters during a medal match.

title: Council's War On Term Limits Finds Backers With Means
description: City Council leaders raising money for a referendum measure to extend term limits for the city's elected officials to 12 years from 8 have received nearly all their contributions this year, in $10,000 and $5,000 increments, from real estate magnates and a city union, city records show.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HUNTSMAN OFFERS TO PURCHASE REXENE FOR $442 MILLION
description: The Huntsman Corporation offered yesterday to buy the Rexene Corporation for $14 a share, or $442 million, including the assumption of $175 million in debt. Rexene's shares rose $4.25, or 46 percent, to $13.375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Jon Huntsman, chairman and chief executive of Huntsman, made the offer in a letter, the company said. Huntsman is the country's largest privately held chemical company. Richard Durham, president and chief financial officer of Huntsman, said the offer would expire on Tuesday. A Rexene spokesman, Neil Devroy, said the company was evaluating the offer.

title: A Twist in the Metallgesellschaft Saga
description: PARIS  In a remarkable about-face in one of Europe's longest-running corporate disputes, Metallgesellschaft, the German industrial conglomerate, is preparing to make a cash payment and withdraw all charges of wrongdoing against the former chief executive it fired two years ago after a $1 billion oil trading scandal.

title: Israeli Troops Stop Battle Over Land
description: Israeli troops hurled tear-gas canisters and fired in the air today to break up a violent land dispute between Palestinian villagers and Jewish settlers.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Metallgesellschaft, in a Shift, To Settle With Former Chief
description: In an about-face, Metallgesellschaft A.G. is preparing to settle with a former chief executive who was ousted in December 1993 after the company was shaken by huge oil trading losses.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg Business News in Business Day yesterday about trading in the credit markets on Thursday included two municipal bond deals erroneously. The offerings, by the New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority and by the Clark County, Nev., school district, occurred in May, not on Thursday.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks May Sign Morris as Stopgap
description: While the Yankees ponder what is wrong with the struggling Dwight Gooden and his weary right arm, another former All-Star right-hander could soon join their rotation.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Rolls-Royce to Quit Steam Power Generation
description: The British engineering company Rolls-Royce P.L.C. said yesterday that it would leave the steam power generation business, putting two companies up for sale and warning of up to L170 million ($263 million) in charges. The company's money-losing business, which designs and builds steam turbines, has 2,500 employees in two companies: Parsons Power Generation Systems and International Combustion. Rolls-Royce said it hoped to find a buyer by the end of 1997. The charges would be taken in the second half of this year.

title: Berlin Journal;A Relic Who's Red and Unrepentant
description: Today's political fashion dictates that those who helped run deposed Communist governments should apologize for their years of folly, condemn Marxism and proclaim themselves born-again social democrats. But that path is not for Heinz Kessler, the former East German Defense Minister.

title: Dispute Still Simmering Over Aegean Sea Islets
description: There are thousands of islands in the Aegean Sea some no bigger than a dollop of stone in the clear blue waters that lie between Greece and Turkey. But every single one, no matter how small or barren, is worthy of a full-blown international dispute, as the Mayor of this Greek island, eight miles off the Turkish coast, has helped to prove.

title: Big Money Spoils Spirit of the Olympics
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Anne Glusker And Scott Busby
description: Anne Glusker, the daughter of Lilyan and Irwin Glusker of New York, was married yesterday at her parents' house in Bridgehampton, L.I., to Scott William Busby, a son of Valerie and Robert Busby of Pawling, N.Y. Judge Bruce M. Kaplan of Family Court in the Bronx officiated.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE FAMILIES;Grieving Relatives Survey Site Of the Crash
description: Hoping to comfort the families of the passengers lost on Trans World Airlines Flight 800, Government officials agreed yesterday to fly eight relatives across the tossing waters that swallowed the plane, allowing them to see the crash site and search efforts for the first time.

title: ART VIEW;Art for Science's Sake Is a Whole Other Story
description: THE ANNOUNCEMENT THAT BILL GATES would lend America a brief glimpse of his Leonardo da Vinci notebook, the Codex Leicester, was less surprising than the venue he chose: the American Museum of Natural History. Notwithstanding the possibility that the notebook might temporarily push the Haida canoe out of its mooring in the 77th Street lobby, Leonardo himself would have felt right at home. For him, the investigation and representation of reality went hand in hand. Scientist and artist were indivisible.

title: Ulster Protestants Want Power, Not Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on July 7 about reggae music's renewed ties to Rastafarian beliefs referred incompletely to the Ethiopian Emperor Haile Selassie. Rastafarians do not acknowledge that Selassie, whose birth name was Ras Tafari, died in 1975; they believe he is a living god.

title: Conversations/Ray Laverty;Echoing in the Streets of Belfast, The Most Unexpected of Songs
description: IT was 10:30 on a winter's night, in the slums of East Belfast, that I heard a strain of music I'll never forget. The wind was chilly, the streets were deserted and a blanket of coal smoke hung over the area, sweetly pungent.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Helping Businesses Is a Business in Itself
description: CAROL DOWGIALLO just happened to see a small newspaper announcement. Renee M. Barnes saw the same notice. And so did Edward M. Stowe Sr. And being resourceful business people looking for assistance, all three quickly called Eileen Baxter, director of a small business center with a big name: the Information Access Center for Women and Minority Owned Businesses, which is based at Iona College.

title: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;A Street-Sign Salvo Against Cuba
description: On the corner of 38th Street and Lexington Avenue, a little bit of the cold war is still being fought. But instead of a face-off between Washington and Moscow, it's Gracie Mansion versus Havana, with a dissenting chorus located around Murray Hill.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Earning Miles for Cars, Hotels and Airlines
description: American Express and ITT Sheraton have issued a credit card, the Club Miles Card, that gives miles for every dollar charged; the miles can be redeemed for free hotel stays, car rentals or airline tickets. Club Miles Card holders who charge their billsat any of the almost 400 participating Sheraton hotels and 50 resorts around the world can earn as many as four Club Miles per dollar.

title: No Need to Keep Crowd From Preserve
description: In the article on the new parking fee at the Rockefeller State Park Preserve in Pocantico Hills ["A Fee at a Rockefeller Park? Shocking!" July 7], the preserve manager, John R. Middlebrooks, is quoted as saying that the fee "will reduce overcrowding, particularly on weekends."

title: HORSE RACING;My Flag Breezes To Victory At Belmont
description: My Flag, the royally bred princess of the Ogden Phipps barn, took another giant stride toward the filly championship yesterday when she won the Coaching Club American Oaks by more than four lengths at Belmont Park.

title: Habitats/147 West 22d Street;Bitten by the 'Loft Bug'
description: CHELSEA was really the last place Steven Chudney and Michael Eisenberg wanted to live.

title: Hamptons Festival Plans 20 Concerts
description: RICHARD ADLER, the creator of "The Pajama Game" and "Damn Yankees," is no stranger to both classical music and music festivals. He just has not been too involved in either lately.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE CHAPLAINS;Kennedy Airport Provides a Sanctuary for Catholics, Protestants and Jews
description: The day before T.W.A. Flight 800 exploded in flames and plunged into the Atlantic, a traveler stopped into Our Lady of the Skies Chapel at Kennedy International Airport and penciled a plea to God in the visitors' book: "Let everyone be safe."

title: GOVERNMENT;Garbage Ruling Leaves the Counties in a $1.7 Billion Hole
description: New Jersey's garbage market was set free last week. The state's complex and widely unpopular "flow control" law, which curbed New Jersey's reliance on out-of-state landfills but helped create the most expensive trash-hauling system in the nation, was declared unconstitutional by a Federal judge in Camden.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ASIAN FESTIVAL

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HORSE RACING;British Jockey Crushed to Death
description: A British jockey died Friday in Nottingham, England, after his horse fell, rolled over and crushed him during a race. Richard Davis, 27, died at the Queen's Medical Center after undergoing surgery for internal bleeding, a hospital statement said.

title: Over the Volcano
description: MENTION climbing volcanoes in Ecuador, and visions arise of the big ones, those glacier-capped giants such as Chimborazo, the highest of them at 20,577 feet, as well its as close cousins Cotopaxi, Cayambe, Antisana and others sprinkled along the north-south Avenue of the Volcanoes in the Andes.

title: Another Plan for Baby Boomers
description: CONNECTICUT will take to the airwaves soon with a $15,000 advertising campaign to persuade baby boomers to plan for the future.

title: BASEBALL;After Balk by Morris, Yankees Retract Their Offer
description: Jack Morris agreed to make one start for Class AAA Columbus. The Yankees wanted the 41-year-old pitcher to make two starts. The other contract terms had been reached, but the Yankees soured on Morris today and revoked their minor league contract offer. Morris was shocked.

title: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST VILLAGE;The Invasion of the Highway Rats, a True Story
description: Tolerance is a vaunted tradition in liberal Greenwich Village, a place where the persecuted and the unloved can find refuge from an unkind world. But tolerance, it seems, has its limits.

title: WEDDINGS;Charlotte Johnson, M.J. Amorello
description: Charlotte Ethel Johnson, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Mayo Johnson of Beverly, Mass., was married yesterday to Matthew John Amorello, a son of Eunice Amorello of Grafton, Mass., and the late Edward Amorello. The Rev. James H. Purdy performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Beverly Farms, Mass.

title: WEDDINGS;Laura M. Massaia, Gregory K. Smith
description: Laura M. Massaia, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ugo M. Massaia of Oradell, N.J., was married yesterday to Gregory K. Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan C. Smith of East Windsor, N.J. The Rev. James R. Egan officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: A Dutch Tour by Bike
description: EVERYTHING in the Netherlands is on the smallest scale: the River Ijssel, once the country's mightiest waterway, stretches barely 78 miles from Arnhem to the Ijsselmeer, formerly the Zuider Zee. In 1932 engineers finished construction of an enclosing dike that turned the Zuider Zee, or Southern Sea, into a lake, necessitating a change in name; hence Ijsselmeer.

title: CYCLING;A Briton Refocuses From Tour To Atlanta
description: To use his own word, Chris Boardman has had a disappointing Tour de France, and now, like so many other riders, he is looking forward to the Olympic Games for solace.

title: Orthodox Jews Battle Police In Jerusalem
description: Violent protests broke out again here today as thousands of ultra-Orthodox Jews tried to block a main street as part of an increasingly bitter dispute between religious and secular Israelis.

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: Recycling Is Garbage" is a refreshing rebuttal to the pervasive "recyling at all costs" approach, and I appreciated Tierney's attempt to compute all the household labor and storage costs of recycling. But he inflated the value of the New York real estate occupied by recycling bins in the kitchen. The weekly rent for that space would be closer to $1, not $4, which would mean that the total cost to sort and store a ton of recyclables would be about $1,500, not $3,000. His argument still holds -- at that price for a ton of glass, metal and plastic, we'd be better off buying a used car -- but we'll have to opt for a Yugo now instead of a Toyota. GEORGE R. WILLIS Jacksonville, Fla.

title: TV SPORTS;Here's How Ali Got Up There
description: As he lay in a hospital recovering from neck surgery two months ago, Billy Payne, the president of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, received a videotape that had one raison d'etre: Have Muhammad Ali light the Olympic cauldron.

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: T o promulgate the idea that the last 25 years of recycling have been a waste of time and money is criminal. Recycling may not be cost efficient in the short run, but the goal is to save natural resources in the long run -- not money. It's called ecologically delayed gratification. The whole premise that recycling should be cost efficient and self-supporting is alarmingly imperialistic. Tierney's trickle-down-ecology hypothesis makes him sound like a spinmeister for the G.O.P.

title: WEDDINGS;Gina S. Kim, Ira A. Apfel
description: Gina Soon Kim, a daughter of Drs. In-Soon and Young Wook Kim of Yardley, Pa., was married last evening in Bryn Mawr, Pa., to Ira Aaron Apfel, a son of Fanchon and Jerome B. Apfel of Gladwyne, Pa. Rabbi Julie Greenberg performed the ceremony in Thomas Great Hall at Bryn Mawr College. The Rev. Poong W. Kim, a Presbyterian minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: The Fresh Air Fund;Meeting Urban Musicians At a Camp in the Country
description: The Fresh Air Fund campers sat riveted or stood up to dance in place, singing along and seemingly oblivious to the final lashings of a rainstorm outside the giant tent that protected them. In the front row, deaf children guided by a sign-language interpreter sang the rap and hip-hop lyrics with their hands. In back, on a raised platform, children in wheelchairs wiggled to the rhythms. And in between, ecstatic campers rose up from time to time in a great sea of waving arms and jumping bodies.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- BASKETBALL;A Victory Not Quite The Stuff Of Dreams
description: For any other basketball team in the world, the margin of victory would have been considered more than comfortable. But the words margin of victory are the curse of the Dream Team, part of an unreachable standard it has been assigned to reach.

title: SOAPBOX;Ants in an Ink Bottle
description: BE back at six," I had written on the note I left for Sandy.

title: Heavenly Hana'
description: To the Editor: Thank you for the excellent articles on Hawaii on May 26. I was especially touched by Susan Spano's "On Maui, Free Splendor on the Outskirts of Luxury" describing her visit to Hana, often called (appropriately) "Heavenly Hana."

title: ON THE MAP;In Elizabeth, a Family Offers the Cold Comfort of Italian Ice
description: Eighty-one years ago, a couple from Vallata, Italy, moved to Elizabeth, built a one-story shop and started selling Italian ice from its front door. Neighbors -- most of them also immigrants from Vallata -- stopped by until midnight on hot summer nights to have a glass of the lemon ice that Catherine Di Cosmo mixed with her own secret recipe.

title: G.O.P. Divided As Two Battle For Congress
description: IN a race that has attracted national attention because it has divided some conservative members of Congress and reflects the Republican Party's split on abortion, Joseph J. DioGuardi is the candidate who won't go away, and Representative Sue W. Kelly is the incumbent trying to deliver the final knockout punch.

title: Dublin
description: To the Editor: I agree with Susan Spano that finding economical lodgings in Dublin is a challenge ("Dublin's Charms Are as Quiet as Its Fog," June 9). However, I strongly disagree with her recommendation of the Avalon House hostel. Last May, encouraged by several guidebooks, I reserved a twin with bath there and was told it would be ready by 11 A.M. When we arrived at 10 A.M., we learned that the room would not be ready until 1 P.M. We put our bags in the luggage room and left. When we returned we were told that we had missed the 1 P.M. luggage-room opening and would have to wait until 2 for our bags. My effort to explain was sternly rebuffed. We returned at 2 and had to wait 10 minutes for the man with the key.

title: WEDDINGS;Barclay Gessner, Scott A. Schraff
description: Barclay Anne Gessner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard E. Gessner Jr. of New Orleans, was married yesterday to Scott Austin Schraff, a son of Ann Schraff Keating of New Canaan, Conn., and Austin R. Schraff of Rowayton, Conn. The Rev. Donald Frampton performed the ceremony at the St. Charles Avenue Presbyterian Church in New Orleans.

title: Waterside Tenants Have Reason to Be Suspicious
description: To the Editor:

title: Who's Hanging Together? Club Owners
description: IT is no secret that New York club life is hurting.

title: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT: GARMENT DISTRICT;Glitzy Days, Mystical Nights On 7th Avenue
description: By day, Showroom Seven International is a hot spot in the fashion industry, a space used by two dozen designers and a photography studio that sets up shoots on the roof with models like Cindy Crawford. But on Thursday evenings, it becomes a gathering place for people searching for spirituality by studying the basics of ancient Jewish mystical teachings called the cabala.

title: FRUGAL TRAVELER;Rambling in Sleepy Hollow Country
description: WHILE I was waiting for a New York Waterway shuttle bus at West Houston Street and Seventh Avenue in Lower Manhattan on the last Friday in May, a man mistook me for a tourist and offered to give me directions. I was three blocks from my apartment.

title: INSIDE
description: Market's Big Scare, Wall Street's Big Fear

title: WEDDINGS;Elizabeth Levine, Ronald H. Reede
description: Elizabeth Joan George Levine and Ronald Howard Reede were married yesterday at the Quinnipiack Club in New Haven. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony.

title: WEDDINGS;Christina Naeder, Kristopher Kile
description: Christina Dianne Naeder, the daughter of Alida Naeder and Richard Naeder, both of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Dr. Kristopher Trenton Kile, the son of Sharon Kline of Kissimmee, Fla., and Doug Kile of Niles, Mich. The Rev. Robin J. Hammer, an interfaith minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's grandmother Mrs. Dante V. Bizzarri in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: ART;Artists and Their Students at Work
description: THOUGH the eras covered are widely disparate, shows in two galleries in Kent share a concept: the work of famed artists paired with that of their students or their assistants. The idea is the brainchild of Jacques Kaplan, who has run the Paris-New York-Kent Gallery for more than a decade. He pitched the concept to the new kid in town, the C. & J. Goodfriend Gallery, which specializes in original prints and drawings from the 15th through the 20th centuries. The Goodfriend gallery has been in Kent for only two months but has been a private print dealership in New York City for 28 years.

title: FLIGHT 800;First, the Quick Answers. Then the Truth.
description: THE crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 last week set off a replay of a familiar but flawed script. Soon after the 747 jet, bound from New York to Paris with 230 people on board, went down in flames off Long Island Wednesday night, breathless theories emerged about the possible cause.

title: Olympic Fever in New York
description: The Olympics got under way in Atlanta this weekend with a spectacular display of international spirit and distinctly Southern heart. From Gladys Knight's "Georgia on My Mind," to the tribute to the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., to the touching moment when an ailing Muhammad Ali grasped the Olympic torch, the ceremonies were a reminder of why a city reborn as a place of tolerance and fair competition is an appropriate place for these international Games.

title: ON THE STREET;Tortoise Shell, Or Is It The Mock?
description: Not since the late 1930's and wartime 40's have handbag designers used mock tortoise shell in such a bold way as today. Back then it was Bakelite, one of the first plastics, the invention in 1907 of the Belgian-born Leo Baekeland. This season, the Italian designer Miuccia Prada has revived the mock-tortoise look with giant link handles in place of the frames that marked the bags of that earlier era. The products of other manufacturers, far right -- top, bottom and second from bottom -- are already following the Prada lead: eyeglass chains, necklaces and even links to decorate tanktops. The shoe at far right, also a Prada design, uses the links as ornaments.

title: Atlanta in Black and White
description: WHERE PEACHTREE MEETS SWEET AUBURN The Saga of Two Families and the Making of Atlanta. By Gary M. Pomerantz. Illustrated. 656 pp. New York: A Lisa Drew Book/Scribner. $27.50.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- SHOOTING;First Gold Medal Comes Down to the Last Bull's-Eye
description: The first medal of the Summer Games was won today by Renata Mauer of Poland, on as dramatic a turnaround as any sport could have.

title: Teen-Ager Confesses to Burning Church
description: A black teen-ager already jailed on a charge of setting fire to a vacant house has admitted setting fire to a black church here, the authorities said.

title: Q. & A.
description: Evicting Regulated Tenant

title: Pro-Beijing Lawyer Running For Hong Kong's Top Post
description: If eagerness, self-promotion, campaign speeches and tub-thumping professions of loyalty were any measure, Lo Tak-shing would be well on his way to succeeding Hong Kong's last colonial Governor, Chris Patten, as the first chief executive under Chinese sovereignty, which begins on July 1 next year.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: MariaElena's, With Help From Mom

title: Sports of The Times;The World Outside The Stadium
description: IN the spring of 1937, at a railroad station in Stuttgart, Germany, Bruno Lambert waved goodbye to Margaret Bergmann as she left for a ship that would take her to Am,erica. Margaret did not know whether she would ever see Bruno again, did not know, in fact, whether he would ever be able to leave Germany, and leave there alive.

title: The Engine That Couldn't
description: ARAMIS Or, The Love of Technology. By Bruno Latour. Translated by Catherine Porter. Illustrated. 314 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. Cloth, $45. Paper, $19.95.

title: MAKING IT WORK;In This Club, Some Runners Run For Their Lives
description: THE 12 men took their places on the running track in Red Hook Park, already breaking a sweat under a scorching afternoon sun. From the front of the pack, a runner shouted, "Vamos!" From the back, another made the sign of the cross over his chest and asked the Virgin Mary to bless his tired legs. With that, the Mexican running club was off for a speed workout of laps and 800-meter sprints.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- NOTEBOOK;Rubin Withdraws in Tennis
description: Chanda Rubin became the second United States tennis player to withdraw from competition today when she pulled out because of an injury to her right wrist.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- SWIMMING;Chinese Women Falter, but Still Strike Gold
description: The Chinese women returned unevenly to international swimming today after a two-year absence, winning an Olympic gold medal in the 100-meter freestyle, but losing three of their top four swimmers in the preliminary rounds on a day of fire alarms and false alarms.

title: EARNING IT;On 'The Price Is Right,' Her Weight Wasn't
description: HOLLY HALLSTROM, a model for 19 years on "The Price Is Right," knows that television game-show models must stay slim to stay on the air.

title: Synagogue Seeks a Second Rabbi to Share Rabbinical Duties
description: LAST July, the Jewish Community Center here expanded its name to Congregation Kol Ami -- "The voice of My people" -- to make clear, Rabbi Shira Milgrom said, that it was a religious and not an athletic organization. Now the synagogue is further refining its identity with what some are calling a pioneering step.

title: Some Moderate Women Are Taking a New Look at Dole
description: Katy Moser, a 47-year-old homemaker in Sacramento, Calif., has been a solid supporter of Republican Presidential candidates for nearly three decades.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND;Love Conquers All
description: KELLY ANN SMITH remembers the first kiss. "It was last summer on Smith Street in Ronkonkoma," she said.

title: July 14-20;Abortion Pill Gets A Recommendation
description: For abortion rights proponents, it was a long time coming. For abortion opponents, it happened much too soon. On Friday evening, after spending a day barricaded in a windowless building under tight security in Gaithersburg, Md., an eight-member advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration recommended that the abortion pill known as RU-486 in France and mifepristone in the United States be approved for sale. The F.D.A. usually abides by its advisory committee's recommendations. But in a final nod to abortion politics, the drug's sponsor, the Population Council, is keeping the name of its distributor secret until the drug is approved. And it will never reveal the name of the manufacturer, fearing boycotts or violence from abortion foes. GINA KOLATA

title: CHICAGO MUSEUM;With the New Comes the Old
description: To the Editor:

title: GOLF;The Chase Is On at the British Open, With Faldo Pursuing Tom Lehman
description: An eerie sort of golf symmetry descended on the Lancashire coast today and covered the British Open. Senior golfers acted their age, obscure major pretenders drifted out to the Irish Sea and the major players positioned themselves for either a Masters reprise or a Grand Slam blowout.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Watch column last Sunday, about possible recession signals in stock prices, misstated the given name of the new president of the Nasdaq stock market. He is Alfred Berkeley, not Albert.

title: Streetscapes/The Manhasset;New Crown for an Upper Broadway Wedding Cake
description: IT seems like a huge wedding cake, with multiple layers rising to a rich crown. Now the Manhasset, on the west side of Broadway from 108th to 109th Street, is in the middle of both a landmark-designation process and a major project to rebuild its huge mansard roof -- added as an afterthought, six years after construction began.

title: POSTINGS: A New Life for 45 Wall;Former Insurance Tower To Have 437 Apartments
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani slammed a sledgehammer into the limestone facade of 45 Wall Street last week to begin construction work on one of the first office towers to be converted to residences under New York City's Lower Manhattan Revitalization Plan. The 28-story building, spanning the blockfront on William Street from Wall Street to Exchange Place, has been vacant for several years.

title: WEDDINGS;Robin M. Weiser, Peter O. Bodnar
description: Robin Melanie Weiser and Peter O. Bodnar are to be married this evening at the Essex House in New York. Cantor Audrey Halpern is to perform the ceremony.

title: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN;New Hopes, Old Worries Over Big Mall
description: At Triangle Sports on Flatbush and Fifth Avenues, Bill Shapiro keeps a framed photo of his grandmother, Bessie. It was taken in the summer of 1916, when Bessie Shapiro first opened the shop and posed next to a sign advertising Army cots for $3.50.

title: From Studying Anthropology to Writing Espionage Novels
description: WHEN the office secretary awakens the hero of Alan Furst's latest espionage thriller, "The World at Night," she is "sticky" from the Champagne and sex they have just had. With "breath like a dragon," she informs her boss, Jean-Claude Casson, that France and Germany are at war. When another paramour of Casson's arrives in Nazi-occupied Paris, he recognizes "a long train ride," licorice drops and Gauloises cigarettes on her breath and her overall scent of "good soap."

title: Girls School in Harlem Is Unlike Virginia Case;Boys Need More Help
description: To the Editor:

title: IN PERSON;Chasing the Future
description: THERE is the summer job. Then there is the summer internship.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE POSSIBILITIES;Tips, Leads and Theories Are Flooding In
description: With investigators still searching for evidence that would show conclusively that the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 was not an accident, the Federal authorities have been barraged with tips, leads and theories about who or what may have downed the plane.

title: Crew, Unsung Elegance at the Olympics
description: NOT many people know much about crew, a somewhat arcane sport engaged in mostly by a handful of universities and clubs in the United States and abroad. And though it has been an Olympic sport since the second modern-day Olympiad was held in 1900, don't expect to see it on television or find it given much space in newspapers during the Summer Games in Atlanta, which got underway Friday.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE INVESTIGATORS -- Surveillance andAviation Experts; Top F.B.I. Investigator Is Known for Bluntness
description: James K. Kallstrom, the head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's New York City office, is a technical wizard who has bugged, wiretapped and generally bedeviled mobsters, terrorists and other criminals for more than two decades.

title: A Man's $11 Million Gift to a College Marks a Rare Friendship
description: As Harvey Wexler lay dying from cancer last year, some of his friends were concerned that he might not have enough money to pay his medical bills.

title: Against Doctor-Assisted Suicide;Rush to a Lethal Judgement
description: MANY YEARS AGO, A PSYCHIATRIST WHO was treating someone I loved asked me to remember that she had the right to kill herself if she wanted to. Sometimes, he said softly, the decision to commit suicide is the decision of a rational mind, a reasonable if tragic answer to the question of whether life is worth continuing.

title: Still Waters
description: A RIVER LOST The Life and Death of the Columbia. By Blaine Harden. Illustrated. 271 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $25.

title: THE GREAT OUTDOORS;It's Hot, but Why Not Keep A Good Bet Going?
description: With his shoulder-length blond hair and trendy metallic sunglasses, Ron Filera, 26, looks more like a rock star than a mail carrier. And indeed, his face has been seen around the world -- on CNN, if not MTV.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- NOTEBOOK;Let the Dieting Begin
description: At least four American weight lifters are overweight and one could have difficulty making weight, Coach Dragomir Cioroslan said today.

title: Crime
description: A jolting thriller like THE TRIGGERMAN'S DANCE (Hyperion, $21.95) delivers more than a rush -- it gives you the faith to believe in the preposterous. The fantastic scenario of T. Jefferson Parker's domestic spy story has an innocent woman mistakenly shot to death by a sniper, and the two men who were rivals for her love joining forces to infiltrate and destroy the paramilitary group whose white supremacist leader was responsible for her death. Even among the right-wing fringes of Orange County, Calif., where the novel is set, this is a pretty kooky premise. But when Mr. Parker is finished with his brutal tale of vengeance, you do believe.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Midwood;A Rich Ethnic Mix in Mid-Brooklyn
description: ABOUT a decade ago, an influx of Russians that turned into a torrent began in the central Brooklyn neighborhood of Midwood, which is anchored by Brooklyn College.

title: SUNDAY: July 21, 1996;A QUESTION FOR: Bill Shannon
description: Bill Shannon, an official scorer for the Major Leagues since 1979, has worked for both the New York Yankees and the New York Mets.

title: EARNING IT;A Marathon of Disruption For Corporate Atlanta
description: OR most of his working life, Mike Sweeney has donned the corporate uniform of suit and tie and driven to work for an ordinary business day as an administrator in the midtown Atlanta offices of the Nationsbank Corporation.

title: IN THE PUBLIC INTEREST
description: IN FRANKFURT, THE AMERICAN ARCHITECT FRANK GEHRY HAS JUST COMPLETED THE kind of housing project he has long dreamed of building in the United States. Located in a parklike setting outside the city, the project bears no resemblance to the image of bleak vertical barracks for the poor that is usually associated with "public housing." Nor is Gehry's design just a flashy star turn, an artistic tour de force by America's most respected living architect. Rather, it is a modest, deeply humane project in which innovative design has been placed at the service of social responsibility.

title: Descendants of the Black Napoleon
description: SHAKA'S CHILDREN A History of the Zulu People. By Stephen Taylor. Illustrated. 416 pp. New York: HarperCollins World. Paper, $12.

title: TELEVISION;On (Very Brief) Assignment in the Movies
description: IN THE NEW FILM "Independence Day," we know that the aliens have landed because the Fox 11 news team has told us so. And if that's not proof enough, we also see the regulars from "The McLaughlin Group" trading barbs as they argue over the political ramifications of the invasion.

title: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE;Homeless Man, Local Town Crier, Faces 'Eviction'
description: There are few certainties in this changeable city. But on Avenue A and Sixth Street, a place that has been convulsed by change in recent years, one thing has remained constant through the riots and real-estate booms: Merlin, a 41-year-old homeless man who uses only one name, has made the intersection's southeast corner his residence for eight years. Neither blizzards nor blistering heat have routed him from atop a set of wooden pallets in front of a Con Edison substation.

title: The Nation;The G.O.P.'s Problem With Women
description: WHAT does a Republican woman want?

title: WEDDINGS;Wendy S. Miller, Tony J. Fisher
description: Wendy Sara Miller, a daughter of Judy and Gerald Miller of New York, is to be married today to Dr. Tony Jared Fisher, a son of Dr. Lillian Fisher of New York and the late Prof. William Fisher. Rabbi Camille Angel is to officiate at the Water's Edge in Long Island City, Queens.

title: MUSIC;Pops Concerts Close Tonight at Burke Estate
description: IT is Pops in the Park tonight, the Westchester Philharmonic closing out its summer set of free outdoor concerts at the Burke Estate in Hastings, as Paul Lustig Dunkel conducts "a diverse program of classical and popular music by Ravel, Rodgers, Gilbert and Sullivan, Mozart, Barber and others." Among those others: Saint-Saens, whose A minor concerto introduces the 22-year-old Scarsdale cellist Michael Hershenson. "It is exciting to watch a young artist develop and blossom," Mr. Dunkel said, "and equally exciting for me to be able to provide Michael with his professional orchestral debut." Concertgoers can bring lawn chairs, blankets and picnic baskets to the concert, which will move across the street to the Hastings Elementary School in case of rain.

title: WEDDINGS;Emily J. Kriegel, K.W. Dearden Jr.
description: Emily Jane Kriegel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Kriegel of Englewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Kenneth Walter Dearden Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dearden of Shrewsbury, Mass. The Rev. Clifford C. Gerber, an Evangelical Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony at Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Clinton's Policies Fuel Drug Use, Dole Says
description: In his radio message today, Bob Dole, the likely Republican Presidential nominee, blamed "three years of misguided policies of the Clinton Administration" for an increase in drug use.

title: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;To Some Hasidim, Brooklyn Is Not Forever
description: The rapid expansion of the Hasidic communities in Brooklyn has had its consequences. Families of 12 live in homes made for four. Yeshivas are filled to capacity. The population doubles every decade.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- NOTEBOOK;Television Ratings Soar
description: Friday night's 4-hour-45-minute opening ceremony generated a stunning 27.2 overnight Nielsen rating, a 65 percent jump from the opening in Barcelona, Spain (16.5). The rating peaked at a 29.5 from 10-10:30 P.M., but was as high as 29.0 from midnight-12:30 A.M., before settling in at a 24.7 for the final 15 minutes, which concluded at 12:45. RICHARD SANDOMIR

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: A s an actor and board member of the Creative Coalition, I have learned that environmental protection is a complex equation. Recycling is one of its essential components. The environment itself is our greatest natural and economic resource. Its protection will produce dividends through reduced health-care costs, protection and creation of jobs and energy conservation.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;Eisenman's Spatial Extravaganza in Cincinnati
description: Peter Eisenman's new building here is a stunning feat of interior decoration. To describe it thus is not to belittle it in any way. Wedged between two older buildings and an earth berm, the University of Cincinnati's Aronoff Center for Design and Art has no exterior to speak of. Its entrance, framed by a tumbling stack of candy-colored slabs, is plopped unceremoniously atop a parking garage. Step inside, however, and it is open-sesame time.

title: OFF THE RACK;Making Do With Less, Voluntarily or Not
description: OH, the importance of timing and the advantage of hindsight.

title: MARKET WATCH;Beware The Risk Of Seeking Protection
description: You survived the plunge in stocks, and you didn't panic. Maybe you took a long lunch on Tuesday and didn't even see the worst of the slide until it was over. And now stocks have made up a significant part of what was lost. Congratulations.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about the regulation of home-based businesses by local governments misstated the affiliation of Ron Wohl, who discussed zoning laws that affect such businesses. He is a director of the American Association of Home-Based Businesses, not the American Home-Based Business Association.

title: Waste Order at Nursery
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation shut down a controversial composting operation at A. Alfredo Nurseries in Greenburgh late last month, after nearly three years of complaints by neighbors about odors.

title: Westchester Q&A: Dr. David S. Breslin;Treating an Embarrassing Ailment
description: IT is a problem that people are often embarrassed to say they have, but an estimated 20 to 30 million Americans, mostly women, suffer from some form of incontinence. Dr. David S. Breslin, a urologist and surgeon, says many of them can be helped.

title: Corrections
description: An article on page 5 of the Arts and Leisure section today about Stephen Sondheim refers incorrectly in some copies to the winner of the Tony Award this year for best revival of a musical. It was "The King and I," not "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum."

title: ON POLITICS;An Old-Timer's View Of the Modern G.O.P.
description: Republican leaders who often talk about attracting black voters to "the party of Lincoln" might want to pay attention to people like Leo C. Fields. Mr. Fields, 79, who calls himself a political junkie, remembers the days when there was no question about the value of a black vote. "Each vote was worth $2," he said.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: THE SHADOW OF DESIRE By Rebecca Stowe. Pantheon, $22.

title: HAUNTED TREASURE -- A special report.;In Brazil, Indians Call on Spirits to Save Land
description: It is at night when the mountain spills its secrets. The Macuxi shaman prepares for the moment with devotion, darkening the room, washing his mouth with tobacco juice and crooning. He beats leaves against the ground and through the air, so the mountain spirits come rushing to him, as if through a forest.

title: WEDDINGS;Brooke Masters, John L. Farry
description: Brooke Alison Masters, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jon J. Masters of New York, and John Leo Farry, a son of Prof. and Mrs. Joseph P. Farry of St. Joseph, Minn., were married yesterday at the Meeting House in New Marlborough, Mass. The Rev. Joseph Bishop, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. John Kulas, a Roman Catholic priest, participated.

title: WEDDINGS;Gary Winterbottom, Elizabeth Kellogg
description: Elizabeth Chambers Kellogg, a daughter of Gail and James Kellogg of Short Hills, N.J., was married yesterday to Gary Lee James Winterbottom Jr., the son of Corintha Pohle of Kula, Hawaii, and Mr. Winterbottom of Kailua, Hawaii. The Rev. Herbert G. Draesel Jr., an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Bay Head (N.J.) Chapel.

title: 10,000 Miles on Foot Around America
description: WHILE standing on a train platform one Sunday night after visiting his sister in Fairfield, Charlie Bell, then 24, started thinking about the ride back to his Manhattan apartment and the Monday morning subway commute to his job selling computers for International Business Machines. And then he said to himself, "I don't want to go to work tomorrow."

title: U.S. Bomb Drops in Mishap
description: An American plane accidentally dropped a 500-pound bomb that exploded near a United States military base in northern Bosnia today, NATO officials said.

title: An Antiques Store on Almost Every Corner
description: WHEN Lloyd Gerard began as an auctioneer in 1970, his first sale was a pile of horse manure that he sold to a farmer for $1.50.

title: A LA CARTE;Greek Dining and the Portions Are Prodigious
description: THE colossal appetizer platter made heads turn and eyes pop as a waitress carried it through the dining room at the Hellenic Snack Bar and Restaurant in East Marion. The four smug, self-satisfied diners who ordered the off-the-menu sampler were peppered with questions from nearby tables: "What's that?" "How much does it cost?" and "Where is it on the menu?" The inquiries were followed by comments like "It looks terrific" and "I wish we'd ordered that."

title: Poems Into Plowshares
description: THE SPIRIT LEVEL By Seamus Heaney. 82 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.

title: Who Owns the Night? Promoters
description: THE early-morning crowd in line outside the gate at World Yacht seemed ready for a riot. More than 1,000 partygoers had shown up for the mid-June reopening of Obsession, a weekly Friday-night party sponsored by Chi-Chi Silva and his partners, but they were not being allowed on board because the boat was overcrowded.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Delving Into the Dementia of Richard III
description: EVEN with all those radical interpretive variations of "Richard III" for modern times, one of Shakespeare's most overexposed villains has suffered no categorical alteration. The "poisonous bunch-back'd toad" -- in the guise of Denzel Washington or Ian McKellen, Al Pacino or Richard Thomas -- has remained the instigator of a tragical or historical play. Or, to follow Polonius-like couplings, tragical-historical or historical-tragical.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;A Handsome Payday for Eddie George
description: The Heisman Trophy winner, EDDIE GEORGE, met with BUD ADAMS, the Houston Oilers' owner, on the first day of training camp Friday in San Antonio and then left the room $1.195 million richer. Adams caught up with George in the lobby of the player's dormitory on the Trinity University campus.

title: FILM;Earthlings Have Just One Question for These Visitors: Friend or Foe?
description: ALIEN-EARTHLING RELATIONS JUST AREN'T what they used to be. Will Smith establishes that in "Independence Day," when, as Capt. Steven Hiller, he announces his eagerness to "get up there" and "whup" E. T..

title: WEDDINGS;Eve D. Durra, Emile van den Bol
description: Eve Deborah Durra and Emile van den Bol, vice presidents at New York financial concerns, were married yesterday at the St. Regis in New York. Rabbi Roger Ross performed the ceremony with his wife, the Rev. Barbara Ross, an interfaith minister.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT/Page 4/ Companies that sponsor the Olympics bet that their largess will pay off. Our very own index of Olympic angels puts that thinking to the test. By Jon E. Hilsenrath.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Rodman and the Bulls: No Deal Yet
description: After two days of talks, there is still no deal between the Chicago Bulls and the free agent DENNIS RODMAN.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Guide column last Sunday about the Summer Music Festival at the Staller Center on the Stony Brook campus of the State University misspelled the surname of the director of the "Moviemakers" interview series. He is Michael Edelson, not Edelman.

title: Residential Resales
description: MANHATTAN

title: FILM VIEW;Giant Flying Saucers! Better Run and Hide.
description: THE NIGHT AFTER "Independence Day" opened, an intensely serious talk-show host asked her guest, a NASA expert, whether we should worry about the movie coming true. What's that? Should we worry that creatures from outer space will arrive in 15-mile-wide Scooter Pies that emit deadly green rays, killing millions and generally ruining the weekend?

title: A Dentist and His Dog Survive Tooth Surgery
description: ABOUT the worst thing a dentist could do to his puppy is smash him in the teeth. But that's exactly what occurred with Dr. Robert B. Amsterdam and his German shepherd Max.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: SECURITY;To Troubled Airline Industry, Keeping Up With Strict Safety Rules Is Costly Challenge
description: Under Government orders to steadily increase security since the 1988 bombing of a jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, airlines and airports have been forced to spend hundreds of millions of dollars to protect passengers against an ever more proficient terrorist threat.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Muster Gains Final

title: WEDDINGS;Matthew S. Hall and Cecilia M. Petit
description: Cecilia Marie Petit, a performance artist, and Matthew Sutton Hall, a novelist, were married on Thursday evening at the Church of St. John the Evangelist in Leonia, N.J. The Rev. Hilary Milton, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 14 about Lincoln Center Festival '96 misidentified the subject of a pop music tribute that was originally included but then abandoned. He is James Brown, not James Taylor.

title: July 14-20;Anonymous Shows His Colors
description: In "Primary Colors," reporters are called scorps, short for scorpions. People were calling Joe Klein something worse last week. "Liar" was the word Tom Brokaw used on the "NBC Nightly News" after Mr. Klein, a Newsweek political columnist, finally admitted that he is Anonymous, the author of the scathing, not-thinly-veiled best seller about Bill Clinton's 1992 primary campaign. For months, Mr. Klein had denied vehemently that he wrote the novel.

title: Harriett Heywood Patton, 85, Founder of Recording for Blind
description: Harriett Heywood Patton, a founder of Recording for the Blind and a managing director of the Metropolitan Opera Guild, died on Wednesday at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. She was 85 and lived in Bronxville.

title: YOUR HOME;Ending Sponsor's Control
description: KERSTIN SABENE was elated when she and two other shareholders took control of the five-member board of their 75-unit co-op in Kew Gardens, Queens, in August 1994.

title: Slouching Toward Brentwood
description: Polaroids from the Dead By Douglas Coupland. Illustrated. 199 pp. New York: Regan Books/HarperCollins Publishers. $18. THE title essay in Joan Didion's 1968 collection, "Slouching Towards Bethlehem," ends with two chilling portraits: a 5-year-old whose counterculture mother feeds her hallucinogens and a 3-year-old who gnaws on an electric cord while his parents rummage for spilled drugs. Ms. Didion leaves readers wondering: what will become of those children?

title: Lamm Asks Perot to Debate Before Reform Party's Nomination
description: Former Gov. Richard D. Lamm of Colorado today challenged Ross Perot, his rival for the Reform Party's Presidential nomination, to three debates before the the party's national convention in Long Beach, Calif., in August.

title: WEDDINGS;Amy Kestnbaum, Jakob Janzon
description: Amy Sarah Kestnbaum, a daughter of Marcia Kestnbaum of Bethesda, Md., and Albert Kestnbaum of Greenwich, Conn., was married last evening to Bjorn Jakob Martin Janzon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bjorn Janzon of Vasteras, Sweden. The Rev. Dennis Albrecht performed the ceremony at St. John's Lutheran Church in Stamford, Conn.

title: In the Region/Westchester;Score Another for the Woodsy Corporate Culture
description: IN a search that lasted two years and pitted New York State against Connecticut, Swiss Re America finally decided to build its new North American headquarters in this countrified corporate community, best known as the home of I.B.M.

title: World News Briefs;Flooding Grows Worse In Southern China
description: Rain pushed flood waters higher today across southern China, stranding hundreds of thousands of people, and officials said they expected the situation to grow worse.

title: DINING OUT;On the Rye Waterfront, Plates Spill Over
description: JUST beyond beautifully tended Rye Town Park, the rose-lined path, promenade and handsome tile-roof pavilions of Oakland Beach lead to the Sand Bar. Perched on the edge of the beach, the cafeteria and bar provide daytime sustenance for bathers and others out to catch some rays.

title: Coke at a Price
description: To the Editor: I have just returned from Paris, with a cautionary tale.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-10

title: Talking Cures
description: To the Editor:

title: N.J. LAW;Citizen Solomon: How Volunteer Mediators Settle Disputes Without a Trial
description: It was the kind of dispute between neighbors, rife with accusations and countercharges, that demanded the wisdom of Solomon. On this day, the Solomons were a retired dentist and a former welfare official, who were using their life experience and training in mediation to seek a resolution.

title: INVESTING IT;Pain? This Was Torture
description: THE roller-coaster ride your portfolio took last week might have seemed breathtaking. But it was probably a kiddie ride compared with that experienced by the most fearless investors: those who buy stocks with borrowed money.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE INTERNET;Sympathy Flows on Web
description: At the PenNet office in Montoursville, Pa., where signs welcomed reporters and the phone lines and Internet help were provided free, Scott Frye was so busy helping people make deadline that he did not get a chance to put up the PenNet Dedication Page to Our Friends and Families of Flight 800 until Thursday afternoon.

title: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT: ROOSEVELT ISLAND;Pipeline From Albany Looks Drier
description: July 13 was a turning point for Roosevelt Island. That was the day the State Legislature, under the prodding of Gov. George E. Pataki, halved the state's contribution to the island's operating budget and, in Albany's argot, "zeroed out" its capital budget.

title: South Carolina Law Harms Pregnant Women
description: To the Editor:

title: CUTTINGS;Plant Names Say It All; Some Have Four Names
description: Jewelweed doesn't grow in my native western Kansas, so I needed a wildflower guide to identify the patch growing at the edge of the woods on my Pennsylvania farm. The book called it Impatiens capensis, also known as touch-me-not.

title: Old Fears and New Hope: Tale of Burned Black Church Goes Far BeyondArson
description: When three white teen-agers were arrested in May and accused of burning down an old slave church here, the authorities said the fire was the result of drinking and fireworks that went awry, not an act of racism.

title: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;For the Realm Where a Peasant Could Be Lord
description: CHINESE FURNITURE MADE for villagers a century or more ago looks like a simplified version of palace pieces. Compared with the elaborately carved and lacquered chairs, tables and cabinets produced in exotic woods for aristocrats, the folk furniture used common woods, had plainer surfaces and thinner finishes.

title: GOLF;Burton's Putter Paves the Way
description: While her opposition battled gusts of wind, Brandie Burton moved into the lead of the Friendly's Classic.

title: BOOKEND;Found Poetry: The Dude Typographers
description: As a letterpress printer, I've long been fascinated by the specimen books in which type manufacturers display the range of types and illustrations they offered. Beginning in the 19th century, the voice of the mostly anonymous printers whose job it was to compose the specimens began to show through. Since their only brief was to fill the pages with appropriate type, the texts often show an amusing mix of wit and nonsense, as well as references to current events.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Tagliabue Set to Decide on Irvin
description: National Football League Commissioner PAUL TAGLIABUE will decide this week on what disciplinary action, if any, to take against the Cowboys' MICHAEL IRVIN, who has pleaded no contest to drug possession.

title: Bosnia Gears Up for Election, With 25,000 Candidates
description: Sejfudin Tokic, 35, a former pharmacist, went today from a seminar on running a political campaign to a meeting in the suburbs with campaign workers, then back to his office, with its broken windows and stained carpets, for another meeting.

title: The World;A Bosnian Sort of Victory
description: RICHARD C. HOLBROOKE has done it again. With bravado, bluster and skill, the American negotiator has brought back from Belgrade an agreement where others before him have failed.

title: FOOD;Leftover Cooked Fish Becomes Lunch
description: LEFTOVER cooked fish or shellfish plus mayonnaise can equal lunch or perhaps even part of a summer dinner. To serve more than two people, a substantial amount of seafood, a pound or so, is needed. Another approach, of course, might be to buy and cook extra fish or shellfish to lighten the next day's mealtime marketing and preparation.

title: Q and A
description: Flying to the Antarctic

title: Architect of Mt. Laurel Deserves No Accolades
description: To the Editor:

title: Portrait of a Beast
description: BEAUTY By Susan Wilson. 200 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $16.95.

title: Girls School in Harlem Is Unlike Virginia Case
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHOOLS;The Weary and Worried Clash on Schools
description: Time is running out for New Jersey to adopt a plan to equalize spending in its richest and poorest school districts, but the State Department of Education, the Legislature and the public do not appear to be anywhere near consensus.

title: Gardens at Kew
description: To the Editor: In 1989 our family was living in Wimbledon. Of all our weekend haunts in London, the Royal Botanical Gardens at Kew ("Gardens Fit for a Queen," June 16) was among our favorites. Paula Deitz recalled for me the most magical experience I have had in London, my favorite city.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800;F.B.I. Looking for Witnesses to Plane Crash
description: In its investigation into the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has asked Long Island residents to get in touch with the agency if on the night of the incident they saw "events in the sky, events of things falling out of the sky" that might be related to the crash.

title: Hotel Hopping In Central Madrid
description: IT was a lust for art brought on by last fall's Goya exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum that inspired our trip. In six days in Madrid, my stepdaughter, Anne, and I reasoned, we could soak up the Prado's huge collection of Goyas and then easily walk to two other splendid and relatively new museums nearby: the Reina Sofia modern art center, which opened in 1990 and now houses Picasso's "Guernica," and the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum, opened in 1992 with about 700 works from the 13th to 20th century.

title: LIVES;The Insomniac
description: I would steal an hour of Steve's sleep if I could. I would slip beneath his eyelids and yank it right out of him. He would feel nothing. Nor would I -- neither remorse nor shame. One hour of perfect unconsciousness: one clean, soundless dive, deeper and deeper, as far as my lungs would take me. I would come up for air before he woke. Instead, I lie motionless, sewn to the sheets by the smallest demons, watching his silhouette against the bedroom blinds. Fondness becomes hostility. How does he do this for eight hours? I listen to his tranquil breathing, furious that he sleeps while I cannot.

title: The Dream, Deferred
description: GOSPEL CHOIRS Psalms of Survival for an Alien Land Called Home. By Derrick Bell. 228 pp. New York: Basic Books. $23.

title: PERSPECTIVES;The Empire State Building's Two-Front Campaign
description: FRESH from his descent from the observation deck of the Empire State Building last Monday, 6-year-old Andrew Munson pronounced the view from the top terrific. His father, James, a 36-year-old schoolteacher from Vista, Calif., concurred, but with a reservation.

title: Paul Schaefer, 87, Adirondack Expert
description: Paul A. Schaefer, a founder or co-founder of several organizations for the preservation of the Adirondack wilderness, died on July 13 after knee surgery at St. Clare's Hospital in Schenectady. He was 87 and lived in the Schenectady suburb of Niskayuna and in an Adirondack cabin.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: FOOD;Captain Crunch
description: WHEN MICHEL RICHARD, A POOR boy from Brittany, got his first glimpse of a restaurant kitchen, he thought he had died and gone to heaven. The white jackets, the white hats, the warmth and the smell. The copious food! Well, from that day forth there was no question of his destiny.

title: IN BRIEF;Public Hearing to Consider Ocean County Evacuation
description: How to move a large number of Ocean County residents to safe locations in case of a serious accident at the Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station will be discussed at a public hearing on Tuesday at 7 P.M. at the Ocean County Administration Building in Toms River.

title: A Rose Is Not a Rose
description: DAVID AUSTIN'S SEEDLING greenhouse, at his nursery in the West Midlands of England, is overflowing with 60,000 roses. Like puppies at a kennel, each rose seedling is different, and each is calling out to be chosen. The seeds were sown in December and January; by May, the plants are already flowering. Pink or yellow or apricot or white, their heads loll over wires that are strung down the rows to keep them in check. Austin walks up and down the aisles, marking with stakes the promising candidates, 4,800 in all, which will be budded onto rootstock and planted outside in test fields. Until this year, he culled all by himself. At 70, however, he has bowed a bit to age and hired an assistant to preselect for him.

title: The View From: Stamford;Where Everybody Learns to Sign
description: SIX-year-old Indira Izurieta stood at the top of the school steps, dancing and singing to the beat of "We're Having a Party," along with Northeast Elementary School's other 700 pupils.

title: MUSIC;Where Yale Summers, Faculty and Students
description: FOUR concerts take place this week at the Norfolk Chamber Festival, the summer home of the Yale School of Music. Student recitals take place at 7:30 on Thursday and again on Saturday morning at 10:30.
