title: Books in Brief: FICTION;Life Among the Worm Burners
description: Part coming-of-age story and part paean to life on the links, Turk Pipkin's charming first novel, FAST GREENS (Dial, $19.95), is narrated by Billy Hemphill, who wistfully recalls his childhood living with his grandmother in West Texas in the 1960's. "Golf is a noble game," he says early on, "a combination of uncertain skill and specific laws, untainted by ethical dilemmas or moral quandaries." It's the players who are tainted, of course, as Billy discovers at age 13 when he agrees to be a caddy in a bizarre grudge match between two grizzled old oilmen, Roscoe Fowler and William March, and their partners, Carl (Beast) Larsen, "the biggest, meanest, ugliest golfer that ever came out of Texas," and Sandy Bates, a fine player with a reputation for choking in head-to-head matchups with the Beast. In the course of nine holes on a torrid summer morning, with money, land, pride and a woman's affections at stake, the members of this foursome resort to a wild assortment of scams, cons and psych jobs to square a bitter dispute that goes back 27 years. It hardly matters that the plot is a bit predictable and the writing overly sentimental in places; the narrative is endowed with a vivid sense of time and place, the characters are wonderfully drawn and the dialogue is sharp and colorful. And at the heart of "Fast Greens" is the game itself, whose lore and wisdom are lovingly imparted. Amid all the talk of "mulligans," "worm burners" and "duck hooks" lies an unmistakable -- and infectious -- passion for a pastime that is "more religion than sport, a religion with a very tiny and unforgiving goal: perfection." Scott Veale

title: STAGE VIEW;For Sondheim, The New Has Always Been Old
description: WHEN Stephen Sondheim took on the score for "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum" in the late 1950's, he was going on 30 and musically frustrated. Broadway knew him only as the lyricist for Leonard Bernstein's "West Side Story" (1957) and Jule Styne's "Gypsy" (1959).

title: Rationed Health Care Serves the Bottom Line
description: To the Editor:

title: July 14-20;They Did Inhale
description: President Clinton may not have inhaled when he smoked marijuana in his youth, but several other White House officials apparently did that and a lot more.

title: IN BRIEF;History Commission Reprieved: More Study Time for Task Force
description: A task force studying how New Jersey might better promote its history through tourism and education now has an extra year to report to the Legislature.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800;Security Breach Delays a Flight
description: Passengers aboard a United Airlines flight from Frankfurt to Washington were evacuated before takeoff at the Frankfurt airport today after someone breached the aircraft's security, an airline spokeswoman in Chicago said.

title: INVESTING IT;Is It a Bear, Or the Cub That Roared?
description: EVEN the most complacent investors must have winced over the rumbling of the stock market last week. It gyrated wildly early on, recovered a bit but still ended on a down note.

title: Research Continuing On Migraine Headaches
description: I read with interest the article concerning Dr. Mark Friedman's investigations with a new, noninvasive technique for treating migraine headaches ["Migraine? A Doctor Comes Up With Relief," June 16].

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: A s a 16-year-old student and a firm believer in the motto "Think globally, act locally," I believe that Linnette Aponte's conservation message was not wasted on her students. Tierney ignores the first two parts of the environmentalist's war cry, "reduce and reuse." Recycling should be touted as a last resort, after conservation.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- NOTEBOOK;Waiting Games: Trains Offer Some Hotly Contested Races
description: Despite the discomfort of Atlanta's heat and the inconvenience of imposing transportation snarls in the congested Olympic ring, the mood among athletes and spectators was festive during the first day of competition today.

title: Doctors Call Dole's Health Excellent
description: Bob Dole, the likely Republican Presidential nominee, who celebrates his 73d birthday on Monday, is in excellent health, Mr. Dole and two of his doctors said this week in extensive interviews about his health.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE SEARCHERS;For Some in Coast Guard, a First Encounter With Disaster
description: Aboard the Coast Guard Cutter Juniper, July 20 -- The older sailors on the Coast Guard Cutter Juniper had warned their younger crew mates that they might see terrible things when they reached the patch of ocean where a 747 jetliner had crashed on Wednesday night.

title: VCR RECORDINGS;Add It to the Pile
description: To the Editor:

title: A Feel of Asia, Generations Ago and Now
description: FOLLOWING on the heels of the Metropolitan Museum's blockbuster "Splendors of Imperial China," the New Canaan Historical Society, albeit more modestly, is showing "Shadows from the East."

title: Amy Fisher's Time
description: IT SEEMS POSSIBLE AT THIS POINT TO WRITE anything about Amy Fisher without actually having to meet Amy Fisher. Force-fed "Amy" as cultural phenomenon, the source of endless alliteration ("Lethal," "Long Island," "Lolita"), most people remember the essential story line: how, in 1991, the Merrick, L.I., high-school junior fell in with Joseph (Joey) Buttafuoco, a charismatic auto mechanic with ties to the hookerish after-hours world of diner parking lots and "boatels."

title: GOOD EATING;Warm and Intimate In West Village
description: CAFE ASEAN ++ (212) 633-0348; 117 West 10th Street (Avenue of the Americas); (c) no credit cards

title: PRO FOOTBALL;As Elias Rushes Forward, Wheatley Is Standing Still
description: One of them came from a big-time school. His talent is undisputed and his I.Q. is high, but his head is harder to get into than a Pearl Jam concert. He refers to this phenomenon as "Wheatley's World." He has a bright smile and an outspoken personality, and he admits that that is a no-no around this Giants coaching staff.

title: ATLANTIC CITY;Doublespeak by the Sea
description: IT was love at first sight. Within seconds of hitting the Boardwalk, Bill Lutz had found his prey: a blue-and-white banner hanging over an entrance to Merv Griffin's Resorts casino, announcing, "We're Here to Make You Happy!"

title: HOME CLINIC;Maintaining Your Asphalt Driveway
description: ASPHALT, also called "blacktop," is basically aggregate (crushed stones or gravel) held together by a petroleum binder. An asphalt driveway may look durable and impervious to the elements, but, in fact, seasonal temperature fluctuations can quickly cause it to deteriorate into an eyesore. During the summer months, the sun's intense heat dries out the asphalt surface and causes it to oxidize. Soon a network of hairline cracks will develop in the surface.

title: DANCE;'Coppelia' in the Land Of Contemporary Illusions
description: PRONOUNCED IN THE WAY THE Academie Francaise would have it, Maguy Marin's surname sounds convincingly French. Indeed, born and brought up in Toulouse, she is widely recognized as one of France's most innovative choreographers. And when the Lyons Opera Ballet performs her mischievous modern-day version of "Coppelia" at the opening of Lincoln Center Festival '96 tomorrow night, it will naturally fly the French colors.

title: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT: CHELSEA/CLINTON;Room for Megastores but Not Megaparking
description: Last year, the barren stretch of warehouses and other huge buildings on 12th Avenue seemed set for an invasion of megastores. Price Club and Home Depot were scouting the area. Moreover, zoning regulations that would increase by 20 times the limit on sizes of certain stores in manufacturing areas like the West Side were about to be introduced.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- FENCING;Newcomers Capture The Medals In Epee
description: The old guard of the swashbuckling set was caught off guard today by a feisty and unawed cast of Olympic newcomers who claimed all three medals in the individual epee event at the Georgia World Congress Center.

title: The View From: Greenburgh;Ballroom Dancing Is Just a Step Away From the Olympics
description: HIGH diving or broad jumping it is not, but ballroom dancing is athletic. So say proponents of the pursuit, observing that, like figure skating, it takes excellent muscle control, coordination and stamina. Indeed, for the first time ever, ballroom dancing has received provisional recognition from the International Olympic Committee.

title: World News Briefs;Police and Rioters Battle In Northern Ireland
description: Police officers firing plastic bullets fought stone-throwing protesters in Northern Ireland today, after rival parades set off more sectarian violence in this British-governed province.

title: World News Briefs;Accused U.S. Sailor Turned Over to Japanese
description: The United States turned over a sailor alleged to have attacked a Japanese woman to the Japanese police today, opening a new legal era for American forces in Japan.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/1997 Jeep Wrangler;From Rough Rider to Charm School
description: RENOVATING a Frank Lloyd Wright house? Writing a screenplay called "Casablanca, the Next Generation"? If you tinker with icons you'd better proceed with caution. In the mid-1980's, for instance, American Motors made several changes to Detroit's most recognizable veteran of foreign wars, the Jeep CJ-7, and capped the effort with a new front end. Before long, purists were wearing T-shirts that proclaimed, "Real Jeeps don't have square headlamps."

title: Community Interests Vs. Property Rights
description: A SWEET summer breeze sends shallow waves rippling through the blue canvas awning on the terrace at the Bonnie Briar Country Club in Mamaroneck. Diners gaze over 150 acres of rolling landscape, a verdant palette of a dozen hues, from the deep emerald of the fir trees to the pale jade of the willows.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- ROUNDUP;SOCCER: United States Cannot Surprise Argentina
description: For a while, the United States was outplaying heavily favored Argentina. Then Hernan Crespo and Diego Simeone scored second-half goals and the Argentines beat the Americans, 3-1, yesterday in the first round of Olympic soccer.

title: BASEBALL;Hutton Offers Hope on Rotation
description: Pitching in the first inning? This was something new for Mark Hutton, who had not started a major league game for almost three years. A fresh start to a game? This was Hutton's appetizing opportunity in a crucial contest. He did not fumble it.

title: SPENDING IT;More Than One Way to Pay Off That Student Loan
description: WHEN Jane Penn graduated last year from New York University with a master's in fine arts, she planned to repay her $23,000 in student loans over the usual period: 10 years. But the $300 monthly payment was more than she could afford.

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: A fter eight years in the recycling business, I agree that the only way recycling will make a difference is if it can turn a profit. Tierney's article was a welcome antidote to the usual oversimplification and disinformation from "green" industries.

title: WEDDINGS;Jannell Wilkins, Bradley Ackerman
description: Jannell Christine Wilkins, the daughter of Jeannette Black Wilkins of Long Beach, Calif., and Bradley David Ackerman, a son of Mrs. Daniel H. Ridder of Long Beach and Jack R. Ackerman of Pound Ridge, N.Y., were married on Friday evening at Mr. and Mrs. Ridder's house in Pebble Beach, Calif. The Rev. Paul Woudenberg, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: John G. Harter, 69; Altered Steroid Use
description: Dr. John Gamble Harter, a clinical researcher who pioneered a revised treatment for people suffering from asthma and arthritis, died on July 11 at Shady Grove Adventist Hospital in Rockville, Md. He was 69 and lived in Darnestown, Md.

title: Waterside Tenants Have Reason to Be Suspicious
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- BOXING;Americans Win Bouts And Build Momentum
description: Fernando Vargas voluntarily missed the opening ceremony on Friday night because he wanted to sleep well before his first-round bout today. He did, however, see Muhammad Ali lighting the Olympic flame with the torch on television.

title: The Ones Who Stayed
description: To the Editor:

title: Teaching Right From Wrong
description: WHEN Raymond O'Connell was the principal of Stratford High School, he often met after school with James Ewing, a history teacher, for long chats on subjects that interested them. One topic that kept coming up, Mr. Ewing said, was "the lack of ethical literacy." It seemed to them that Americans no longer knew right from wrong.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- SWIMMING;Dolan Knows the World Is in Pursuit of Him, and He Loves It
description: It is an unfamiliar position for American swimmers: underdogs in their own pool. The gold medals are supposed to come sparingly at these Olympics, like relief from the Atlanta heat.

title: WEDDINGS;Lara B. McElroy, A.G. Olivieri
description: Lara Bassett McElroy, a financial analyst at the Museum of Modern Art in New York, was married yesterday to Alessandro Giovanni Olivieri, an associate at Morgan, Lewis & Bockius, a New York law firm. The Rev. Charles Temple performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.

title: WEDDINGS;Kyle J. Johnson, Alexis Chen
description: Alexis Wan-Hua Chen, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Lincoln C. Chen of Brookline, Mass., was married yesterday in Cambridge, Mass., to Kyle Jamal Johnson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul N. Johnson Jr. of Teaneck, N.J. The Rev. Thomas G. Cleveland, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the Harvard Memorial Church with the Rev. Robert C. Alter, a Presbyterian minister who is the bride's great-uncle.

title: In Peacetime, Vietnam's Army Turns to Business Ventures
description: In a recently refurbished army museum here, an exhibit on the war against the Americans has shrunk slightly to make room for a new display showing the military's role in the civilian economy, building dikes and electrification projects.

title: A Deal to Save Bosnia's Election
description: Credit Richard Holbrooke with getting closer than anyone else has to protecting Bosnia's election from manipulation by Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb leader indicted for war crimes.

title: Victory Over Veins
description: To the Editor:

title: So You Want to Be a Shaman
description: LADY WITH A LAPTOP By D. M. Thomas. 246 pp. New York: Carroll & Graf Publishers. $22.

title: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT: WILLIAMSBURG;Bridge Goes From Woe to Woe
description: Neighbors of the Williamsburg Bridge consider the $140 million reconstruction job at their doorstep a full-fledged fiasco.

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: J ohn Tierney's "Recycling Is Garbage" (June 30) made my decade. Aside from its economic message, the article exposed the "eco-babble" that has become a virtual state-sponsored religion in the nation's public schools. At a deeper level, Tierney correctly identified recycling as just another form of materialism. Recycling simply represents an obsession with excretion as opposed to consumption.

title: Corrections

title: U.S. Weighs Lifting Curb on Arms Sales to Latin America
description: At the urging of Defense Secretary William J. Perry, the Clinton Administration is considering easing a decades-old ban on sales of high-technology weapons like advanced fighter jets to Latin America, raising fears of a new arms race in a region that has been relatively calm after years of military conflict and dictatorship.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;An 'Ultimate Bunglow' in Berkeley

Thorsen House in Berkeley, Calif., a classic 1909 Arts and Crafts mansion by the Pasadena architects Charles and Henry Greene, is temporarily open to the public for an exhibition titled "Last of the Ultimate Bungalows." The timbered house has been restored by its longtime owners, the Berkeley branch of the Sigma Phi fraternity, and for the first time in more than 50 years, it is furnished with original Greene and Greene furniture, metalwork and pottery.

Impromptu jam sessions sprang up in unlikely places all winter and spring, and be-bop buffs kept calling the empty club, hoping someone would answer the phone and announce the weekend lineup.

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: T ierney speaks of "the needless public alarm about landfills." Obviously, he has never been to Staten Island, where the stench from the world's largest landfill wafts over our 57 square miles. Certainly, landfills create jobs -- but that's all they do. Even Tierney admits that garbage buried in a landfill lasts indefinitely.

Barker of Wakefield, Mass. The Rev. Richard A. Weisenbach performed the ceremony at the First Parish Congregational Church in Wakefield.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies last Sunday about a legal challenge to rent control in Long Beach, L.I., included a quotation from a tenant, Shirley Weber, misstating her rent. Figures supplied by her landlord, Samuel Walton, and now confirmed by Mrs. Weber show that her 1976 apartment rent was $340 a month, not $300; her present rent is $741, not "almost $800." The current figure, however, includes an $80 garage charge; the apartment is $661.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;A Vermont Museum at Revolutionary War Site
description: A visitors center and museum is scheduled to be inaugurated this Saturday on Mount Independence in Orwell,, Vt., the site of a military hospital and fortification during the Revolutionary War. During the winter of 1776-77, hundreds of the 10,000 American soldiers stationed there froze and died, many of smallpox, while holding off a British invasion from Canada. The campaign culminated in the American victory at the Battle of Saratoga. It is one of a trio of Revolutionary war sites overlooking the narrowest section of Lake Champlain (the other two are Fort Ticonderoga and Mount Defiant on the New York side of the lake).

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;A.M.A. Urges Standards For Care on Cruises
description: The American Medical Association is calling for standards to be set for medical care on cruise ships.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;Managers' Personal Trades: What the S.E.C. Wants You to Know
description: IF your mutual fund allowed its manager to trade for himself at the same time that he was trading for you, wouldn't you want to know?

Donlin of Iselin, N.J., was married yesterday to Christopher William Mitsinikos, the son of Eileen Pierce of New York and William Mitsinikos of Commack, L.I. The Rev. description: NEW York's club scene has changed strikingly over the years, as promoters have increasingly become a factor in the city's night life. Here is a guide to some of the promoters' parties held during the week of July 7. GORDON F. SANDER

title: EARNING IT;The New Jobs: A Growing Number Are Good Ones
description: LAST fall, Kevin J. Mattakat was studying telecommunications and computer science at the University of Wisconsin. In his spare time, he tended bar and did computer work for the college. He earned about $5,700 in 1995.

title: FILM;Psst. The One With Third Billing Is the Star.
description: SOMETIME LAST WINTER THE drumbeat began sounding in Hollywood for an unknown actor named Matthew McConaughey. The 5 foot 11 inch, curly-haired, unfailingly polite Texan had just completed filming "A Time to Kill," an adaptation of the John Grisham novel. Suddenly the word was out all over town: the fellow who had been discovered in a hotel bar in Austin, Tex., was going to be a star. A big star. By the time he returned to Los Angeles after shooting was completed in Mississippi, Mr. McConaughey was overwhelmed with calls from agents, directors, writers and studio executives who had seen the movie trailer. He fled.

description: THE signs are hopeful along the 577 miles of New York and Connecticut coastline that embrace Long Island Sound.

title: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTH JAMAICA/SPRINGFIELD GARDENS;Racial Anger Over Schools Flares Again
description: For years, there has been both underlying and overt racial tension in Community School District 28. And when a black school board member told black parents last week that white officials want "a return to the whip, the ball and the chain," it was clear that things had gone from bad to worse.

title: POP VIEW;Birth and Rebirth On the Airwaves
description: FOR SOME TIME NOW, THE concept behind top-40 radio has been dead. Take a look at the charts. The music in the top 40 -- hard-core rap, bedroom rhythm-and-blues, Latin pop, alternative rock, techno dance, country ballads, classic rock, ska reggae, children's songs, gospel, novelty tunes -- is so varied that no commercial radio station could ever play it all and hold on to an audience. Yet the artists performing this mix have plenty in common. They're all making music in and about the same period in history, living under the same Government, recording for the same record labels, using the same technology, touring the same cities.

title: His Hipness;Bob Dole's Done There, Been That
description: BOB DOLE likes to tell audiences that when he was growing up, the worst crime anyone could think of was joy riding. Visiting a school earlier this year and seeing his campaign's home page materialize on a computer screen, he brightened with uneasy familiarity: "That's my whatchamacallit!" Last week he lamented: "I was amazed to learn recently that some schools don't even allow spelling bees anymore."

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: T he thesis underlying Tierney's article is that we urbanites need not waste time and money recycling as long as impoverished rural counties can be coerced by benefits of increased tax revenues to allow privately run garbage dumps in their communities. Once again, it seems the solution to America's problems lies in the poor's shouldering more of the burden.

title: Helicopter Sets Off Noise Suit
description: SHOUTS and murmurs can be heard in the summer throughout most neighborhoods in the state. Open windows allow other lives to waft into one's own. But in wealthy Bedford, the quiet can be deafening, even at this time of year. Manicured lawns separate houses by a city block or two, and the sounds of silence generally prevail.

title: SUNDAY: July 21, 1996: LISURE;Guardians of Summer
description: Like a mean trickster imp, summer promises pleasure but often delivers pain -- which is why the season brings with it a supplementary armada of gear, gadgets and potions to guarantee good, safe fun. It's the responsibility of many humble and insufficiently hailed scientists and product testers to insure that the job is done right. Here's a peek at all they endure.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE INVESTIGATION;Search for Clues of Flight 800 Focuses on Ocean Floor
description: As the weather improved yesterday at the scene of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, rescue workers turned their search to the ocean floor off Long Island where they hope to find the bulk of the wreckage, the 130 missing bodies and important clues to the apparent explosion that turned the 747 jetliner into a fireball on Wednesday night.

title: ART;'What Will Live On After I Die Is Important'
description: KEITH HARING STARTED OUT as a graffiti artist in the New York City subways, drawing with white chalk on the black paper pasted on unused advertising spaces. By late 1980's he had achieved worldwide fame as the creator of icons like the barking dog and the radiant baby. Until shortly before his death of AIDS in New York on Feb. 16, 1990, at the age of 31, he kept copious diaries and sketchbooks. Here are excerpts from "Keith Haring: Journals," to be published this month by Viking.

title: No Frills, No Doubts, No Excuses
description: Dec. 30, 1995: I was sitting on a bar stool on the Upper West Side of Manhattan with my friend Glenn. I had recently run in the national cross-country championships, finishing a dismal 74th. I was angry, depressed and wondering how in the world I would be able to improve enough over the coming months to achieve my dream of running the 10,000 meters in the Olympics.

title: July 14-20;'Friends' Hang Together
description: Actors usually go it alone when they negotiate salaries. Pioneering a bold, '90's strategy, the six-member cast of the NBC hit series "Friends" has banded together and demanded $100,000 each per episode plus a percentage of syndication profits. The stars have threatened no-shows when taping for the new season begins next month.

title: SUNDAY: July 21, 1996: RELIGION;Gimme That Old Testament Religion
description: Tovia Singer never meant to convert Christians, but they're coming anyway. "Half the calls I get now," he says, "a Christian with a Southern drawl is telling me he wants to switch." Singer, an Orthodox rabbi, heads Outreach Judaism, a group based in Monsey, N.Y., whose real purpose is to reconnect with lapsed Jews. One tool used is "Let's Get Biblical," an 18-part scriptural-analysis series that aggressively refutes Jesus' claim of being the Messiah. Unexpectedly, opposite-direction converts have sprung up: in a small-but-tangy pay-back at a time when the Southern Baptist Convention has re-upped its efforts to reel in Jews, the series has also changed the minds of a few dozen evangelical Christians in Texas. Singer refers such hopefuls to local rabbis, but he recently flew to Texas to celebrate a Sabbath with Michael Flanigan, a former pastor who is shepherding his family through the arduous conversion process. What turned the tide? "I was shocked to see how much of the New Testament is, for lack of a better word, fictitious," says Flanigan, a quietly serious man. "But all along I've been driven by a simple truth. One day I'm going to have to explain myself before God."

title: THE CAPITALIST;God Is in the Packaging
description: A FEW YEARS AGO, the Harvard Business School gave its blessing to the Willow Creek Community Church. In a distinctly flattering case study, the school sought to explain why this particular interdenominational evangelical church was booming. In less than 15 years, Willow Creek had grown from a hole in an Illinois wheat field into the largest church in America. Each week, more than 20,000 people attended its services; each year, they gave nearly $15 million to the church to cover the salaries of the church's 192 full-time employees. Now, nearly 1,400 other churches in North America have now joined the newly formed Willow Creek Association to learn how to adapt what were already being called the "Willow Creek principles" to their own markets.

title: Getting Into Business, and Surviving
description: IT was nearly midday, and inside a hotel conference room in Cromwell, Aldonna Ambler was asking a hushed, spillover crowd how they would eliminate potential rivals.

title: Commercial Property/Union Square;And Now, Offices Blossom Around the Revived Park
description: WHEN we opened in 1985, people said we were crazy to put a restaurant in this neighborhood and crazier to name it after Union Square Park," said Paul Bolles-Beaven, managing partner of the Union Square Cafe.

title: Myopic Diversity Isn't Colleges' Role
description: In regards to "Top L.I. Students Fall Victim to Colleges' Balancing Plans" [June 30], it is not the function of our elite institutions of higher learning to contrive a utopic society within the confines of their ivy-covered walls. Undesirable from the perspective of institution, student, and society, the myopic policy of artificial diversity orchestrated by affirmative-action-conscious admissions officers sow the seeds of self-destruction.

title: FARM LIFE -- The importance of faith.;Tilling the Soil, Flowering the Soul
description: ONE Sunday John Halsey, a farmer who attends the Presbyterian Church in Bridgehampton, a church that has been there as long as his family has,listened to a special service, called Children's Day, dedicated to the achievements of the Sunday school students.

title: GOLF;Magic Touch Escapes Nicklaus
description: This wasn't exactly what Jack Nicklaus had in mind. Here he was, in the penultimate pairing of the day, walking up the 18th fairway with a very makable birdie putt on the green . . . for a round of 77.

title: Strangers in a Familiar Land
description: FOR every single summer of my childhood, my family packed a stack of suitcases in late June and traveled up the East Coast to a foggy little seaside town on Cape Cod, and there we remained until Labor Day. In that same town my uncle and cousins and grandfather were also "summer people," and had been for years. My great-grandfather had summered on Cape Cod as far back as the turn of the century. But the year I turned 8, my father -- who loved the Cape and hated the end of summer -- made the radical decision not to migrate in September with everyone else we knew. He put our house in Virginia up for sale (our "real house," as I persisted in thinking of it); my younger sister and I were enrolled in the local public school, and it was understood that from now on we were no longer summer people, we were "year-rounders."

description: NBC PAID $456 MILLION FOR the United States television rights to the 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, which opened on Friday, and it is spending at least $100 million more to broadcast those Games. For the rights to the two previous Summer Games -- in Barcelona, Spain, and Seoul, South Korea -- the network laid out more than $700 million. And it has agreed to pay $3.5 billion for the rights to all Olympic Games from 2000 to 2008.

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: T ierney failed to mention New York City's recycling revenue-enhancement feature. Property Owner X puts his trash and recyclables out on the sidewalk in the late evening or early morning. The city sanitation truck may or may not come by. But homeless people are certain to arrive and rummage through the trash looking for returnable bottles and cans, followed shortly by trash inspectors eager to meet their ticket quotas.

title: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE;Kaleidoscopic Astor Place: Will the Funk Go?
description: Ever since the Flower Power revolution took hold of the East Village in the 1960's, Astor Place has had a split persona as a neighborhood where well-behaved Greenwich Village bumps up against its rough-and-tumble cousin to the east. But over the past year, the area's chaos has been partly tamed by the arrival of stolid chains like Barnes & Noble, Starbucks and Kinko's Copies. And thanks to the persistence of a new business improvement district, the junk peddlers that once clogged sidewalks have all but vanished.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: THE CONSPIRACY & OTHER STORIES By Jaan Kross. Harvill/HarperCollins, $24.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: DISPATCH FROM A COLD COUNTRY By Robert Cullen. Fawcett Columbine, $21.

title: For Jeep Owners, Bonding on the Rocks
description: IMAGINE driving your personal vehicle through waist-deep mud, across treacherous slabs of granite and up nearly vertical mountain slopes. Hundreds of Jeep owners do just that each year at Jeep Jamborees, two- and three-day gatherings devoted to off-road adventures.

title: Foreign Affairs;The Beijing Bullets
description: It's all Nafta's fault.

title: Liberties;Gulp Fiction
description: Now we know. "Primary Colors" was not a social satire. It was a story of unrequited love, the literary consequence of a romance turned sour between a journalist and a politician.

title: IN THE KITCHEN;Leftover Fish Becomes a Quick and Easy Lunch
description: LEFTOVER cooked fish or shellfish plus mayonnaise can equal lunch, or perhaps even part of a summer dinner. To serve more than two people, a substantial amount of seafood, a pound or so, is needed. Another approach, of course, might be to buy and cook extra fish or shellfish to lighten the next day's mealtime marketing and preparation.

title: I'm Sorry, I Won't Apologize
description: ALMOST DAILY, NEWS reports include accounts of public figures or heads of companies being forced to say they're sorry. In a recent case, Marge Schott, managing partner of the Cincinnati Reds, at first did not want to apologize for her remark that Hitler "was good at the beginning but he just went too far." Under pressure, she finally said that she regretted her remarks "offended many people." Predictably -- and especially given her history with such comments -- many were not satisfied with this response and successfully lobbied for her resignation.

title: COPING;In the Peace of Vermont, the Fires of New York
description: THE summer is the worst time for the children I know," writes Geoffrey Canada. "More of them are outside. Too hot and boring to be inside. There are few jobs for teen-agers. Life is lived and lost on the streets."

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;Age Pays Off, If You Ask
description: A CLERK taking your reservation is not going to ask if you are entitled to a senior discount. So if you are shy, you may pay more than necessary for a flight, a night or a bite. You get no discount if you don't ask.

title: DRIVING;The Spots To Avoid
description: A look at trouble spots you may encounter in the next week -- or month, or months -- courtesy of Transcom, an interstate transportation agency.

title: At the U.N., A Proposal To Speed Aid During Crises
description: A mobile military headquarters capable of fielding command teams within hours of Security Council action on any crisis is likely to be established here soon, officials said today.

title: Thanks, but No Thanks
description: Hidden Latitudes By Alison Anderson. 223 pp. New York: Scribner. $21.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: COLD SNAP: Stories By Thom Jones. Back Bay/Little, Brown, $10.95.

title: Books in Brief: FICTION
description: ANNAPOLIS By William Martin. Warner, $24.95.

title: The Next Pro-Lifers
description: LISA JARRELL WAS SITTING ON HER CRISPLY MADE BED not long ago at the University of Virginia's hospital in Charlottesville, her tiny legs saucily crossed, daring Dr. Carlos Gomez once again to keep her alive. Jarrell was born 31 years ago with cerebral palsy, one of its cruel adjuncts being an esophagus that ended abruptly in a pouch, unconnected to her stomach. Five surgeries to fix this anomaly had riddled her frail chest with scar tissue, and over the past four years she had lost the ability to ingest and keep down food. Now for 12 hours each day, a ghastly viscous liquid seeped down a feeding tube imbedded in her abdomen to sustain her 72-pound body. Her daily list of medications, a pharmacological cornucopia addressing everything from pain to nausea to depression, filled a double-spaced sheet of paper.

title: Filling County Center, Fans Cheer On Knicks
description: THE near-capacity crowds for the New York Knicks Summer League in midmonth at the County Center here support the view that in New York, a promoter could sell tickets to a cockfight in an alley. In sweltering heat, more than 3,000 fans a night filled the center over a four-day period to watch frenetic, foul-filled games.

title: Traders Who Sit at Ringside When Stocks Bob and Weave
description: IT was barely 7 A.M. on July 17 at the Jefferies & Company trading floor here, and Glen McIlvaine was encouraging his traders, plying them with double chili cheeseburgers from a big box as his company's virtual stock market was already in its second hour of business. These traders were well into their workday, having traded shares like Intel and New World Communications even before dealings had commenced in New York.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC;Operas as a Mirror of Diversity
description: IF AN ABUNDANCE OF NEW work is an appropriate measure, opera in America must be very healthy. This week alone, three major American festivals will present premieres of American operas, two of them on the same day. On Tuesday, Tod Machover's "Brain Opera" will receive the first of nearly 100 hourly performances at the Juilliard School as part of the Lincoln Center Festival '96. On Saturday, Tobias Picker's "Emmeline" will be unveiled at the Santa Fe Opera in New Mexico, and Michael Torke's "King of Hearts" at the Aspen Music Festival in Colorado.

title: Big Money Spoils Spirit of the Olympics
description: To the Editor:

title: ART REVIEW;Redemption Through Pain, Solitary or Shared
description: MIRIAM BEERMAN is a painter of pain: physical and emotional, her own and the world's. This was never more evident than it is in the artist's recent work, examples of which are on view here in the unlikely setting of the Bergen Museum of Art and Science.

title: Smoky Aisles
description: To the Editor: I was a passenger on Sabena flight 533, Brussels to Boston, on May 15. I had a nonsmoking seat. When I used the toilets at the rear of the plane, there were several people smoking in the aisles. I brought this to the attention of the cabin attendants, and was told that this was contrary to Sabena policy. Nevertheless the smoking continued throughout the flight, despite my request that the smoking be stopped.

title: Godmother to the Politically Committed Film
description: THE MOVIE "STONEWALL" was on the editing table when the director, Nigel Finch, died suddenly of AIDS. That left the producer, Christine Vachon, to finish his film about the Stonewall uprising of 1969, which is often cited as the impetus for the modern gay rights movement.

title: BEST SELLERS: July 21, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: July 14-20;Mr. Yelstin Appears
description: Vice President Al Gore's scheduled meeting with President Boris N. Yeltsin last Monday was supposed to have been an opportunity to express support for the newly re-elected Russian leader. But Mr. Yeltsin's abrupt decision to forego the session and head off to a sanitarium outside of Moscow sent off a political tremor among supporters familiar with his history of heart disease. Mr. Yeltsin dispelled reports he was incapacitated by receiving Mr. Gore at the sanitarium the next day. But the President's pale and stiff appearance did little to put an end to the persistent questions about his health -- or the power struggle already under way in the Kremlin. MICHAEL R. GORDON

title: Trade Center Skating Rink Deserves Another Try
description: To the Editor:

title: Dole and His Doctors Address Health Issue
description: Bob Dole, who would be the oldest man ever to assume the Presidency should he win in November, says his health is excellent, and two doctors who have treated him agree.

title: WEDDINGS;Ms. Kappagoda, Mr. Mordecai
description: Samantha Kappagoda, the daughter of Subadra and Nihal Kappagoda of Ottawa, was married there on Thursday to David K.A. Mordecai, the son of Vinette Mordecai of Montclair, N.J., and the late Kenneth Mordecai. Sterling Irvine, an Ontario registrar, officiated at the civil ceremony at the home of the bride's parents. A religious service was performed yesterday by the Rev. Stephen K. Hayes, a Buddhist priest, at the Canadian Museum of Civilization in Hull.

title: July 14-20;Genes Used in Arthritis
description: Researchers at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center last week became the first to try gene therapy against rheumatoid arthritis, the crippling, incurable disease of the joints. It was the first time gene therapy has been tried for a chronic, disabling disease instead of a life-threatening condition like cancer.

title: Man Without a Country
description: LETTERS By Patrick White. Edited by David Marr. Illustrated. 677 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $35.

title: IN BRIEF;Why Are Oaks Turning Brown? Ask Those Pesky Locusts
description: Something is happening to the oaks of North Jersey.

title: Sports of The Times;Cuban Defectors Will Not Climb This Fence
description: TWELVE feet high, the cyclone fence surrounds the Olympic Village, with a white-on-green sign posted every so often.

title: BASEBALL;Wilson Gets the One He's Been Waiting For
description: The smile said it all.

title: In the Region/New Jersey;Reviving Those Vacant Department Stores
description: OLD department stores vacated by bankruptcies or corporate restructurings in the late 80's and early 90's are making a comeback. The evidence is in a crop of conversions under way or planned across the state.

title: WEDDINGS;Amanda MacGruer, Robert Davis
description: Amanda Marshall MacGruer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm MacGruer of Madison, Conn., was married at her parents' house yesterday to Robert Jay Davis, a son of Orpha Davis of Binghampton, N.Y., and the late Harold Warren Davis. The Rev. Walter Wagoner, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTH JAMAICA/SPRINGFIELD GARDENS;Pathmark Plan Awaits Call From Nynex
description: Although the bickering over building a Pathmark superstore at the corner of Springfield and Merrick Boulevards was quick and heated last year, construction of the store has not even hit a sketch pad.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: LOOKING BACK;Backtracking to Find Reasons for a Tragedy
description: To Gina Trombetta on her deck in Westhampton Beach, L.I., the strange light in the sky looked like a Roman candle dropping gently into the sea. To hundreds of others who saw it Wednesday night, it looked like a shooting star, a distress flare, a meteor, a ball of fire.

title: Retirement Communities Are Neighbors, Not Islands
description: To the Editor:

title: COVER STORY;Gossip, Gossip, and That's the News
description: MICHAEL Jackson or Hosni Mubarak? Alan Greenspan or Brett Butler? The People's Choice Awards or the Senate Subcommittee for Oceans and Fisheries?

title: After Hours at White House, Brain Trust Turns to Politics
description: They are like no other meetings in the Clinton White House. One night a week, the President, the Vice President and their closest political advisers gather in the family quarters. As if following precise protocol for a superpower summit, participants take regular seats. To make sure no one gets distracted, food is forbidden.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: VIEWS OF OLD GLORY

title: POSTINGS: Something New, Something Old for TriBeCa;A Fraternal Twin for an Oldtimer
description: A 15-story Art Deco industrial building overlooking the Holland Tunnel ramps in TriBeCa is to be converted to lofts and linked to a new building to rise on what is now an adjacent parking lot under plans now undergoing New York City's approvals process.

title: RESTAURANTS;Istanbul Express
description: THIS part of Anderson Avenue is like the neighborhood where I grew up: no privacy and ample ethnic food. And these restaurants, unlike those in the "international food court" of your nearest mall, are run by the people who own them.

title: SOAPBOX;Watching the Drug Dealers
description: I ASSUMED my usual position at the window, fingers splaying a small peephole in the blinds. Usually my sessions of vigilance over the past two and a half years were due to idle fascination with the drug den across the street, but tonight there was real action.

title: Behavioral' Problems Are Physical Conditions
description: I am writing in response to Dr. Thomas E. Stone's letter ["On Ritalin and Prozac for Children," July 14] in which he commented on your interview with Dr. Harold S. Koplewicz ["Helping to Combat Child and Adolescent Mental Disorders," June 16].

title: WEDDINGS;Deirdre Douglas, Daniel W. Carey
description: Deirdre Hunt Douglas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archibald Douglas 3d of Princeton, N.J., was married yesterday to Daniel Willets Carey, a son of Charles J. Carey of Sunapee, N.H., and the late Gertrude C. Carey. The Rev. Russell G. Ruffino performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. Peter's by-the-Sea in Narragansett, R.I.

title: DIARY
description: CONTRACTS In Another League

title: When Worlds Collide
description: There is something both normal and frightening about our reaction to the explosion that blew T.W.A. Flight 800 out of the air and killed 230 innocent people. Normal in that the unexplained destruction of any symbol of American power and influence -- a military base, a government building, a corporate headquarters, an American-based airline -- immediately leads us to suspect terrorists. Frightening in that such acts lie beyond the customary rules of innocence and guilt, cause and effect, by which we organize our lives. If this should prove to be an accident rather than a crime, the best that we will be able to say is that it was not terrorism this time.

title: Corrections
description: A picture in the Gazetteer chart on June 23, with an article about Tottenville in Staten Island, was published in error. It illustrated the previous week's feature. The caption also misstated the address of the the Tottenville house being described. It is at 253 Barnard Avenue, not 243 Barnard Road.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFING;THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Florida Democrats Hope To Reverse a Trend

title: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT;MANHATTAN UPDATES
description: MORNINGSIDE HEIGHTS Local residents won a 10-year battle with Saint Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital on Thursday when officials announced they would keep the obstetrical unit at its division at 1111 Amsterdam Avenue, near 114th Street. The hospital's plan to move all obstetric services to its building on West 58th Street was met with intense opposition from the community. A hospital spokesman, Jason Stewart, said the obstetrical unit, which will be expanded to accommodate more patients, "is going to be a revenue-enhancer for us as well as provide a vital service to the community."

title: MARKET TIMIMG
description: Today

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Brent Scott Is U.S.B.L.'s Top Player
description: BRENT SCOTT of the Portland (Me.) Mountain Cats has been named the United States Basketball League's player of the year, one of three post-season awards announced by the league. Scott led the U.S.B.L. in scoring with a 29.8 average. He was second in rebounding with an average of 13 and third in assists with 8. He won player of the week honors four times in the seven-week season. ERIC MUSSELMAN of the Florida Sharks was named coach of the year and MIKE LLOYD of the Atlantic City Seagulls was named rookie of the year. (AP)

title: Connecticut Q&A: Sidney J. Holbrook;Clean Air, Clean Water, Tough Rules
description: SIDNEY J. HOLBROOK manages 1,100 employees and a $90 million budget in an effort to keep the state's air and water clean, the fish and wildlife healthy. As Commissioner of the Department of Environmental Protection, he is also responsible for boating safety, hunting, controlling forest fires and monitoring Long Island Sound. The department also oversees its own saw mill in Portland Depot to supply boards for picnic tables and a 13-acre seedling nursery in Voluntown.

title: The Week of Investing Dangerously
description: IS it the Big One? That's what Californians ask every time crystal trinkets start to tap-dance on the bookshelves. And that's what investors ask these days every time this space-traveling stock market slips.

title: DINING OUT;It's a Sit-Up-and-Take-Notice Experience
description: THE harried-looking woman turned to her husband and said, "My head is spinning; my ears are ringing and you are still shouting." Indeed he was, for shouts had been the only means of communication between tablemates on a recent Saturday night at the Stone Creek Inn in East Quogue. The woman, who had waxed enthusiastic over every bite she ate, added, "I wouldn't come back here".

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction;Renaissance Men
description: A sense of anticlimax pervades Joachim Poeschke's MICHELANGELO AND HIS WORLD: Sculpture of the Italian Renaissance (Abrams, $125), a feeling that no artist who followed Michelangelo could rival his excellence. Mr. Poeschke emphasizes the serendipity of Michelangelo's era, the great luck that patrons, popes and artists could all agree that "the human figure was the most perfect image of the divine in the earthly realm." It was an era ideal for sculpture; cities like Florence and Rome ordered colossal, freestanding works for the first time since antiquity. Mr. Poeschke, an art historian who teaches at the University of Dusseldorf, chronicles the triumph of this medium with a comprehensive set of 399 photographs, 52 of them in color. He includes all of the major sculptural achievements of this period; many are shown in various angles and with specific details enlarged. The final portion of the book describes the artwork, piece by piece. Mr. Poeschke often chides art historians for engaging in overinterpretation; he very sensibly refuses to believe that much of this artwork is meant to convey esoteric messages to a privileged few. This final section would serve as an excellent textbook; however, few readers will need or desire such minutiae. Only a specialist would be interested in each successive plan for the tomb of Pope Julius II, a project that engaged Michelangelo intermittently for 40 years. Douglas A. Sylva

title: Corrections
description: A listing last Sunday of Nassau delegates to the Democratic National Convention misstated several hometowns and given names. The affected entries should have read: Estelle Bressler of Lawrence; Seretta McKnight of Roosevelt; Todd Richman of Lawrence, and Edwin Lopez of Valley Stream.

title: WEDDINGS;Amanda Fugazy, Scott Brennan
description: Amanda Marie Fugazy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis V. Fugazy 3d of Glen Cove, L.I., was married yesterday to Scott W. Brennan, the son of Mrs. and Mrs. Gerald Brennan of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. Vincent Brennan, the bridegroom's uncle, performed the ceremony at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Glen Cove. Sister Irene Fugazy, the bride's aunt who is a Roman Catholic nun, participated in the service.

title: CHATTER;On Teaching and Coaching
description: Chatter recently asked for opinions on year-round schools and for advice to Coach Dan Reeves of the Giants. Here are some replies.

title: SUNDAY: July 21, 1996: POLITICS;Spinning Chicago
description: At the Democratic National Convention in 1968, Marilyn Katz oversaw security for Students for a Democratic Society, a radical group at the eye of the Chicago protests. She was there.

title: Summer Fun?
description: There's a mystique about summer jobs. Those who have held them look back fondly on their brief stints as a lifeguard, or perhaps as a clerk in Aunt Jane's law office. But those of you actually working those jobs this summer might have a different opinion of the experience. Is the job what you expected? Are you learning skills that will be useful after you graduate? Have you spotted flaws in corporate life? Sometimes the best advice comes from those with the newest perspective. Send your story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include a phone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: July 14-20;Security in Saudi Arabia
description: The Pentagon, accused of underestimating the terrorist threat to American troops in the Middle East, clearly does not intend to be accused of it again.

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: I 'm so glad you finally got the word out about how delighted we little people in the boondocks are to have all your New York trash buried under our cheap, uncivilized land. I'm sure our future generations of three-eyed mutants will be thrilled as well.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2;The South's Struggle to Define Itself
description: The images from the opening ceremony Friday of bubbly cheerleaders, chrome pickup trucks or Gladys Knight singing "Georgia on My Mind" were so bright and vibrant, it was possible to think the South's transformation from America's pariah region to sparkling center of its population and economic growth was complete.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Learning to Paint The Tuscan Landscape
description: Landscape painting courses in Tuscany are being offered through October by a New York organization called Etruscan Places.

title: NEIHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;Lincoln Center Tunes Up for Subway Work
description: The bustling area around Lincoln Center, one of the fastest-growing sections of the city in the 80's, could become even busier in September when renovation begins on the 66th Street subway station.

title: Sports of The Times;Lesson by the Poolside: Life's More Than a Gold
description: SHE has called herself a "macho swimmer," but in the moments following the most important race of her 23 years, Amy Van Dyken could not walk without help. Coming through the narrow path with the journalists barricaded behind wire fences, she leaned on the shoulder of a swim team aide, waiting for him to lead.

title: SIGNOFF;Mornings, Local and Unpredictable
description: CALL it the little program that could. It's the Channel 5 morning show, "Good Day New York," which went on the air on Aug. 1, 1988. Eight years later, this good-natured pip-squeak upstart, the new kid in the weekday 7 to 9 A.M. time block long dominated by network hulks like NBC's "Today" and ABC's "Good Morning America," has grown into a muscular morning presence.

title: OUT OF ORDER;The Rise and Fall of Summer Camp
description: MY parents never sent me to summer camp. They believed that families should go on vacation together, no matter how painful the experience was for all concerned. But a lot of things have changed since my childhood. In particular, Dr. Benjamin Spock dreamed up the idea that children should not be repressed by arbitary discipline and must be allowed to express themselves. Since then, the family vacation has unaccountably declined, and thus summer camp industry has boomed.

title: Help for Expansion Of Aviation Museum
description: County Aid Sought by Community Colleges" [June 23] stated that the Nassau Community College board of trustees reversed its action regarding the Cradle of Aviation Museum. Not so. While the trustees were concerned about loss of student parking spaces the expansion would incur -- a matter which has been resolved by swapping land with the county -- the college board did not at any time defeat the proposal. The matter simply was tabled until the trustees were assured that the college's interest would be protected.

title: Our Men in Havana
description: BATTING AGAINST CASTRO Stories. By Jim Shepard. 197 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $22.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;On Stage With Senator Impresario
description: IT was a pure Marty Markowitz moment.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- JUDO;Frenchman Wins Gold With Little Drama
description: In the days leading up to the Olympics, this city was filled with lofty talk about dedication, perseverance, the hard road to glory that symbolizes the Olympic spirit.

title: Wheelchairs
description: To the Editor: On a recent USAir trip between New York City and Akron with my elderly mother, the airline failed to promptly provide wheelchairs for her at Kennedy and Pittsburgh, despite our having reserved them, with attendants, for both legs of her trip.

title: Girls School in Harlem Is Unlike Virginia Case;Boys Need More Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Styles pages on June 30 about the wedding of Melissa Sadlier Dinger and Justin Peter Gibbons misstated the department at J. P. Morgan & Company where Mr. Gibbons's father, Michael J. Gibbons, is a managing director. It is the global credit group, not corporate finance.

title: The Unmaking of a Deal: How School Reform Failed in Albany
description: State Senator Roy M. Goodman swerved around a klatch of lobbyists and entered the Senate chamber last week, holding a hastily scrawled plan that addressed what he called the most pressing issue of the year: improving the way that the faltering New York City schools are governed.

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;A New Ball Game for La Russa
description: Perhaps Tony La Russa has adopted the philosophy that "this game is built on what you do, not what you did" because that kind of thinking comes with the job. Or maybe the St. Louis Cardinals' manager gets it from experience.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- BASEBALL;Tardy Team Shakes Off Slumber
description: Its bus to Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium was late, but maybe it was an omen for the United States baseball team, which scored four late runs to take a 4-1 victory today over Nicaragua in the opening game of the Olympic tournament.

title: SPOTLIGHT;Far From Home
description: There are several solid components to THE L-SHAPED ROOM (1963), Bryan Forbes's drama set in a cheap boardinghouse in London. The Anchor is Leslie Caron's superb performance as a young, pregnant, single Frenchwoman. Forbes's script and direction and his excellent cast do the rest in this bleak but persuasive slice of life that probes some harsh realities. Other tenants include Brock Peters, Tom Bell as a writer drawn to Caron (above) and Ciceley Courtneidge as an aging lesbian (a rare screen cameo by the beloved British stage star). Quiet, unpretentious, threadbare and entirely persuasive, this "Room" at times almost seems to breathe - SUNDAY at NOON on MAX.

title: SOUND IN THE THEATER;Don't Blame The Sound Designer
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S DOING IN;Edinburgh
description: Summer in Edinburgh means hours of languorous northern light and days that last well into evening. It means the Edinburgh Festival, an annual extravaganza of music, drama, dance and alternative entertainment that takes place from Aug. 11 to 31. And this year, in a city that loves to honor its past, summer means a bicentennial celebration of Robert Burns, Scotland's great poet and bon vivant, who died in 1796 and whose short but eventful life is being remembered with readings, events and museum exhibits.

title: Teeing Off with Brio in Italy
description: GOLF in Italy is not only about hitting that ball, it's also about cuisine, couture and culture. When you stripe a drive down the middle, there are no muted murmurs of "nice shot." Instead, there are full-throated cries of "bravo," "bravissimo" and even an occasional "mamma mia."

title: In the Region/Long Island;Coupling Conservation With Farmland Development
description: A PRISTINE tract of farmland and forest has become the setting for a land-conservation plan here that preserves 50 of its 80 acres from development while offering the property owners substantial financial advantages.

title: INVESTING IT;The Great Olympic-Sponsor Challenge
description: Will this summer's Olympic sponsors see their big investment pay off in gold?

title: Culture Shock
description: PEREIRA DECLARES A Testimony. By Antonio Tabucchi. Translated by Patrick Creagh. 136 pp. New York: New Directions. $19.95.

title: SCHOOLS;Doing the Math: How the Aid Formula Works
description: At the heart of the Whitman administration's proposal to overhaul state aid to public education is an exercise in eighth-grade algebra: a six-step formula by which the state intends to calculate how much each district must spend to achieve a "thorough and efficient" education.

title: VCR RECORDINGS;The Next Generation
description: To the Editor:

title: Constitutional Conventions
description: ORIGINAL MEANINGS Politics and Ideas in the Making of the Constitution. By Jack N. Rakove. 439 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: POP VIEW;Headbangers vs. Hippies at Festival Time
description: A BAND FROM THE BAY AREA was on stage, playing favorite old songs under summer skies, and thousands of fans sang along on verse after verse, chorus after chorus. That wasn't all that the Lollapalooza Festival, headlined by Metallica, and the Furthur Festival, featuring former members of the Grateful Dead, had in common when the two reached the New York City area on consecutive July nights.

title: A Reporter in Hell
description: SEASON OF BLOOD A Rwandan Journey. By Fergal Keane. 198 pp. New York: Viking. $22.95. JOURNALISTS often glimpse the face of evil as they record the social and political upheavals that shape history. But that encounter is seldom as profound as it was in the African republic of Rwanda in mid-1994, when as many as one million Tutsis were hacked, clubbed and burned to death by the country's Hutu majority. The raw emotions of reporting that slaughter are vividly recounted in "Season of Blood: A Rwandan Journey," the first-person narrative of Fergal Keane, a British television correspondent who visited the country while the carnage was still under way.

title: THE CRASH OF FLIGHT 800: THE PRESIDENT;Clinton Uses Radio Address To Remember Crash Victims
description: President Clinton used a portion of his weekly radio address today to pay tribute to the 230 people who were killed this week in the crash of a Trans World Airlines jet, giving special praise to the 16 Pennsylvania high school students who were among the victims.

title: What Do Women Want Anyway? Better Health Care
description: WHEN Janet B. Henrich graduated from medical school in 1972, only 10 percent of the 200 members of her class were women, medicine was based on research on male subjects, and most illustrations in medical textbooks showed the male body. "We didn't talk about gender differences," Dr. Henrich said.

title: Art at Work
description: THE Prudential Insurance Company's Washington Street offices here make a first impression that is dramatic, but also disarmingly lighthearted. On a luxurious Italian terrazzo pavement stands a grove of treelike sculptures gaily overlaid with multicolored stone-and-glass mosaics. Farther in stand a gold-colored orb, an azure pavilion and a row of columns, similarly covered with mosaics.

title: JERSEY;Builder's Dream, Preservationist's Fear
description: THE cleared land on the 7,100-acre site meanders flat as a prairie toward the wall of scrub pines and dwarf oaks half a mile away. Beyond the trees, the giant dirigible hangar at Lakehurst, where the Hindenburg blew up in 1937, looms like a elephant's back. The only sounds are the rustle of the wind, the shriek of a hawk in the forest.

title: The New Sound of Early Music
description: PEOPLE WITH SHORT MEMORIES Americans, say -- may see the early-music movement as a relatively recent invention, dating from the 1950's and 60's, when it began to command a major segment of the classical recording industry. They may see it, too, as a product of American ingenuity -- that of the sainted early-music pioneer Noah Greenberg and the New York Pro Musica Antiqua -- later taken over by the English, who have ruled the roost ever since.

title: GARDENING;In the Defense of the Lowly Earthworm
description: EARTHWORMS may be considered the lowliest of all creatures, but many admire them and for good reason. Fishermen in search of bait probably rate somewhere near the top of the admiration list. Biology teachers use them in classrooms and, of course, robins relish them for lunch. Some entrepreneurs make a business of raising and selling earthworms.

title: STYLE;The Garden Path
description: It started insidiously, this exchange. All through high school and into college I had plucked my eyebrows to arched ribbons. But then, one spring, a tiny baby strapped to my chest, I decided to plant strawberries. By the time I had filled my raised beds with dirt and peat, mulched, planted, watered and fussed, my eyebrows had grown entirely back. I shrugged at my wilder image in the mirror, and then, instead of tweezing, I went out and snipped the runners off the main plants of my June-bearing crop. It had begun.

title: DINING OUT;Dragons on the Walls, Seafood on the Plate
description: OCEAN PARADISE in Branford is a Chinese restaurant that follows its own drummer. No mere clone of others, this unusual restaurant offers dishes new to the Chinese restaurant scene in Connecticut.

title: Madagascar in Crisis;The Land of Endangered Species in Danger
description: MADAGASCAR'S newish Prime Minister gave his State of the Nation address last month, and nobody came.

title: Sports of The Times;Choosing Ali Elevated These Games
description: MUHAMMAD Ali floats above the Summer Games, no longer an elusive butterfly but a great glowing icon as large as a spaceship. He casts his light on every athlete, every spectator, every volunteer, all the people who walk these humid streets with just a little more zip in their step, now that they have seen Ali.

title: WEDDINGS;Casey Sheldon, Nicholas Seidenberg
description: Casey Dickinson Sheldon, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew M. Sheldon of Sea Girt, N.J., was married yesterday in Princeton, N.J., to Nicholas Huber Seidenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Otto W. Seidenberg of Long Lake, Minn. The Rev. Daniel W. Hardy, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: Tracking and Cataloguing the Wild Flora;A Taxonomist and Volunteers Keep Tabs on Regional Diversity
description: A man walks very slowly next to a chain-link fence topped with razor wire, enclosing a subway yard. In the dust is a broken half-pint liquor bottle and many empty motor-oil containers. Inexplicably, a dollar bill drifts by on a lazy wind.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: SADE'S WIFE The Woman Behind the Marquis. By Margaret Crosland. Peter Owen/Dufour Editions, $35.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: OUTRAGE The Five Reasons Why O.J. Simpson Got Away With Murder. By Vincent Bugliosi. Norton, $25.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- BOXING;Lone Afghan Is Scratched
description: The Afghan boxer Mohammed Jawid Aman trained under rocket fire in a cold and dirty Kabul gym to pursue his dream of competing for his war-ravaged country in the Olympics.

title: BACKTALK;Atlanta Waits to Learn Its Place in Olympic History
description: Every Olympic Games has a defining identity, a personality and legacy that survive the test of time. The question that will linger through the heat and hot competition for the next two weeks in the Games of the XXVI Olympiad in how Atlanta will be catalogued into the Olympic movement.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: TOPSPIN Ups and Downs in Big-Time Tennis. By Elliot Berry. Holt, $27.50.

title: Providing Access to Nature to Everyone
description: PERHAPS the Pinecliff Wildlife Sanctuary is no more beautiful than any other patch of woods and wetlands. Sunlight filters through a canopy of trees, casting dancing patterns along the path. Water bugs skate above the surface of the pond, sending ripples of concentric circles over to a family of mallards, which swim in the dappled shade around lily pads and ferns. A score of gentle sounds -- wind rustling through the trees, competing calls of the birds and a lone but busy woodpecker -- seem only to underscore the tranquillity of the sequestered spot.

title: The World;Talk Multilaterally, Hit Allies With Stick
description: THE Clinton Administration came to office three years ago heralding a new age to end the constant economic warfare among the world's trading nations -- an age in which countries could settle their arguments in a host of new international courtrooms.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;You're Stung by Stocks. Are Bonds the Balm?
description: AS the stock market seesaws, investors may be tempted by the security of the bond market. But in recent years bonds have quietly shed their image as safe investments for a much racier one. Moreover, their newfound volatility seems to be here to stay.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ON A STREET CALLED EASY, IN A COTTAGE CALLED JOYE By Gregory White Smith and Steven Naifeh. Little, Brown, $23.95.

title: American Legion Posts Seeking the Young
description: THE American Legion has always been in the forefront of promoting youth athletics and preserving the memory of veterans who have fought and died for their country.

title: ON LANGUAGE;Of Galoots and Flaps
description: THE GRILLING OF A USEFUL Galoot" is how Newsweek headlined a column about Craig Livingstone, the former bar bouncer in charge of personnel security at the Clinton White House and the man responsible for the flap-caper-affair-scandal (choose one) that permitted nearly a thousand confidential F.B.I. files to be examined by White House political operatives. "It was a moment," wrote Joe Klein, breaking new ground with the old slang noun, "when galootery had leverage."

title: Wage Bill's Rule on Tax-Free Bonds Could Dampen Plans for Lilco
description: A PROVISION in the minimum-wage bill could mean the loss of some tax-exempt financing for Lilco, a move that could cost customers more than $30 million a year, officials have warned.

title: Strawberry Warning Costs Growers Millions
description: California strawberry growers are still trying to recover from a wave of negative publicity and more than $20 million in losses that began when health officials in Texas blamed the fruit last month for outbreaks of intestinal illness.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- FIELD HOCKEY;Tie Game: Little Rest For Weary In Opener
description: The opening ceremony of the Olympics ended just before 1 o'clock this morning. The United States women's field hockey team had its first Olympic game at 9 A.M.

title: Health Delivery at the Town Hall Level
description: IN 1963, when Dr. Jack Shiller was the director of public health for the town of Westport, the Sabin vaccine for polio was introduced. His goal was to get every person in the town vaccinated and so started a "Sabin on Sunday" campaign to encourage participation on peoples' day off.

title: Embassies Shine With a Little Help
description: THE gardens have been restored at the United States Embassy in Rome; the Embassy in Beijing has an expanded terrace with a new awning, and in Prague, the Embassy is scheduled for much-needed refurbishing. All of the improvements are thanks to the Friends of Art and Preservation in Embassies, a private, nonprofit organization that works with the State Department to enhance embassies around the world. The group was honored last week at the White House.

title: WEDDINGS: VOWS;Barbara Shinn and David Page
description: THE owners of the Greenwich Village restaurant Home, David Page and Barbara Shinn, describe it as a modern-day mom-and-pop business. Their tiny storefront on Cornelia Street is in a Civil War-era building, and the decor is cozy but not corny. Each table top is carved in patterns taken from American quilts, the candles burn in small Mason jars, and bluegrass music is almost always playing. The house matches read: "Home Restaurant. Fine Wine. Fine Ketchup" (they make their own).

title: Waterside Tenants Have Reason to Be Suspicious
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;May McDonnell, Alfred Brittain 3d
description: May Sandoz McDonnell and Alfred Brittain 3d, both of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday at Mr. Brittain's home. The Rev. Hugh Tudor-Foley, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Summertime and Jets Are Optimistic
description: After all those years of false springs and summers, falls and winters as well -- the Jets felt wonderful about themselves on today's first day of summer camp for the entire team.

title: THE NIGHT;In Search Of a Proper Pen Shape
description: WHERE'S your syringe?" Sharyn Rosenblum, the director of publicity at William Morrow publishing, asked Bret Easton Ellis at the Bowery Bar on Monday.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 2 -- ROUNDUP;WATER POLO: Americans Hope to Forget Loss to Italy
description: The United States lost, 10-7, to Italy in its opening game of the Olympic water polo tournament yesterday in Atlanta but remained in medal contention because of the round-robin format of the preliminary round.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;FUNDS WATCH
description: Beating the Index

title: On the Margins
description: BEFORE WOMEN HAD WINGS By Connie May Fowler. 272 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $22.95. LIKE many child narrators, Avocet Abigail Jackson, who tells her story in Connie May Fowler's third novel, "Before Women Had Wings," is wise beyond her years. A keen observer of human foibles, she's had the opportunity to study them at close range, since both her parents display a hefty share of destructive urges. Set first in rural Florida and then on the outskirts of Tampa in the mid-1960's, hers is a tale of deep poverty, forsaken goals, broken promises, infidelity and violence.

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: T alk about wasteful activity. Tierney's sneering treatment of recycling manages to be as irrational as the supposedly fuzzy-minded recycling evangelism he parodies. He takes the worst case -- mandatory recycling administered by a city with notoriously inefficient solid-waste operations -- and passes it off as exemplary of recycling economics and the "big brother" mentality of environmentalists. I would like to know why recycling is economically successful in cities like San Jose and Seattle.

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;Colleagues, Critique Thyselves
description: THE MUSIC CRITICS ASSOCIATION OF North America is assembling in New York on Thursday for one of its periodic conclaves. Members have not asked for my advice, but the unwritten subtitle of a column like this is "Unsolicited Opinions." So here are a few of mine.

title: Israel to Be Given Remains of 2 Soldiers
description: Hezbollah, the militant Islamic group that has been fighting the Israeli presence in southern Lebanon, said today that the remains of two Israeli soldiers held for years would be exchanged within 24 hours for Arab prisoners and the remains of guerrillas.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Orioles' Anderson Has Appendicitis
description: Baltimore Orioles outfielder BRADY ANDERSON has appendicitis, but still hopes he won't need surgery that would force him to miss six weeks.

title: Paul Shepard, Professor and Author, 71
description: Paul Howe Shepard Jr., a professor of natural philosophy and human ecology who wrote or edited books that won critics' praise, died on Tuesday at his home in Salt Lake City. He was 71.

title: Gore Says He Expects an Accord on Welfare
description: Vice President Al Gore said today that some features of a Republican welfare bill moving through Congress were unacceptable, but he said he believed that the final product would be acceptable to President Clinton.

title: A Magazine Only a Mother Could Love?;Seeking Younger Audience, Reader's Digest Tries to Lose Its Stodgy Image
description: Commuting to his Manhattan office the other day, Gregory G. Coleman, the publisher of Reader's Digest, watched with interest as a young man who had been reading the magazine tucked it inside the pages of a newspaper before getting off the train.

title: Metal Company Rejects Accord
description: Metallgesellschaft A.G.'s supervisory board has decided not to approve an out-of-court settlement with two former top managers, saying their responsibility for the company's near-bankruptcy in 1994 must be stated more clearly.

title: Sports of The Times;Softball Strikes While It's Hot
description: HERE on the banks of the Chattahoochee River, at Golden Park off Lumpkin Boulevard, the first pitch in Olympic softball medal history was thrown a few minutes after 9 A.M. by an American buzz saw named Michele Granger. It was a fastball that arrived in the catcher's mitt with a considerable clap, for a called strike.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Safety Fine for Gas Plant
description: The owners of a gas manufacturing plant that blew up in March have been fined $14,000 by the Federal Occupational Safety and Health Administration. OSHA found that Hunterdon Industrial Gases did not have an emergency plan in place and had failed to assign shutdown responsibilities to its employees, The Associated Press reported yesterday. More than 200 homes had to be evacuated around the plant, which manufactured acetylene and other gases, after a gas line broke and set off an explosion.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Cable Inspections Faulted
description: The steel restraining cables that failed to stop a car from driving off a fourth-floor parking deck at the Claridge Casino Hotel were not subject to safety inspections, The Press of Atlantic City reported yesterday. Two sisters, Erna and Gertrude Martin, were killed July 11 when their car fell from the parking lot less than two weeks after it opened. Investigators have determined that the moorings that held the cables in place popped out when the Martins' car struck the cables.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;European and African Strains Merge at Lincoln Center
description: History and power have a habit of making themselves heard in music. When Malavoi and Charanson, from Martinique and the Bronx respectively, played at Lincoln Center on Friday night as part of the Midsummer Night Swing series, all the joy they presented couldn't hide where they came from.

title: Bosnia G.I.'s See Themselves as Lucky After Bomb Mishap
description: While the Navy investigated why one of its aircraft accidentally dropped a 500-pound bomb on the edge of a United States military base near here, soldiers at the base were asking similar questions today and counting themselves lucky that there were no injuries.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- BOXING;Big Man From Cuba Comes Out Sluggish
description: The straight right hands missed often, as did the looping left hooks. One of Cuba's most celebrated boxers looked awfully average tonight, giving the obscure heavyweight class reason for optimism and inspiring one fight fan to voice his displeasure: "Let's go, Felix. Show us something."

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;Dole Sends Message of Inclusion To Abortion-Rights Republicans
description: Seeking to reach beyond his party's conservative core, Bob Dole brushed aside the need for an endorsement from the National Rifle Association and asserted that Colin L. Powell's address at next month's Republican national convention should send a message of inclusion to abortion-rights supporters.

title: Technology: CONNECTIONS;'Independence Day' is the least of it; alien encounters and invasions are everywhere.
description: HAVE you any unusual scars or marks? Ever awakened at night startled? Have you experienced a self-esteem problem or had the feeling of being watched? Any unusual nose bleeds? Or compulsive or addictive behavior? Have you ever been afraid of your closet? Or heard strange humming or pulsing sounds? Do you have a difficult time trusting other people, especially authority figures?

title: Off the Bench and Into Classrooms, Judges Unite to Fight Bias
description: In courtrooms and classrooms across New York City, several dozen judges have been convening to consider not robberies or murders or petty crimes, but how to fight bigotry.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- NOTEBOOK;Heat Got to Shooter
description: China's Wang Yifu, who collapsed after a last-shot error cost him the air-pistol gold medal on Saturday, was probably a victim of Atlanta's heat, Games organizers said today.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- GYMNASTICS;Miller Gives United States High Hopes For a Gold
description: They held the women's compulsory exercises in the Georgia Dome today. And when the American women's rousing performance had come to a close with the reassuring thud of Kerri Strug's tiny feet safely meeting rubber mat, hugs were compulsory, as well.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- SOCCER;World's Best Held to Tie By Brazil
