description: On the first day of women's soccer in Olympic history, a last-minute goal at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium in Washington produced one of the most stunning results in the history of the women's game.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- BASKETBALL;The Confident and Annoyed
description: The basketball players were separated by a few miles, but their emotions were worlds apart. At the Georgia Dome this morning, Charles Barkley spoke with the Dream Teamer's mixture of confidence and annoyance.

title: World News Briefs;Rash of Basque Bombings Hurt 35, Mostly Tourists
description: A bomb attributed to Basque separatists injured 35 people on Saturday night, and the Spanish police defused a bomb at a beach resort hotel today.

title: Magazines You Won't Find In Publishers Clearinghouse
description: What has four colors, lives for barely two weeks and makes a lot of money?

title: Yanks Pursue A Javelin Star
description: Tom Pukstys, the American record-holder in the javelin, has been offered a tryout as a pitcher by the Yankees.

title: Vermont's Treasure: Country Stores With Everything, IncludingPersonality
description: Walk into the Ripton Country Store here, and you can only be in Vermont. The tiny store, with its wood-plank floor and pot-bellied stove, sells bread, beer, beef jerky, locally grown organic tomatoes, People magazine and, on a shelf near the door, beneath the Vermont maple syrup, poetry by Robert Frost. Why Robert Frost? The poet spent summers in Ripton.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Microsoft Plans to Blend Windows and the Web Microsoft, in its push to control the Internet market the way it dominates personal computing, is preparing to release software that could bring a fundamental change in the way people use PC's.

title: Treasury Will Offer Both Bills and Notes at This Week's Auction
description: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and two- and five-year notes being auctioned tomorrow and Wednesday.

title: Katharine Elmore, 92; Led Nature Preserve
description: Katharine Huyck Elmore, the chairwoman of the Edmund Niles Huyck Preserve and Biological Research Station in Rensselaerville, N.Y., died Monday at the Meadow Lakes retirement community in Hightstown, N.J. She was 92 and formerly lived in Rensselaerville.

title: U.N. Agency Report Lists Food Needs
description: Africa will need to increase its food production by 300 percent by the year 2050 to satisfy growing population demands, the United Nations' Food and Agriculture Organization said today.

title: Media: PUBLISHING;The unmasking of the author of "Primary Colors" creates a marketing quandary.
description: WHAT do you do when Anonymous becomes Notorious?

title: POLITICS: THE YOUTH VOTE;Music Industry Promotes Voter Registration by Mail
description: Registering to vote will be as painless as ordering a pizza beginning today.

title: Patents;Some pharmaceutical companies pay $25 million for nonexclusive rights to the new AIDS drugs.
description: AS a new type of medication has shown considerable promise in fighting AIDS, it might be expected that the value of patents covering these drugs, called protease inhibitors, would soar. But $25 million in cash for a nonexclusive license to a patent that has not been issued yet?

title: As the Millennium Nears, A City's Wheels Churn;New York as Party Central. Details to Come.
description: It is only a moment, but in the language of the hype that is already preceding it, a moment like no other. A momentous moment, if you will -- though come to think of it, there will be 24 of them, an hour apart, one for each time zone.

title: Behind the Exchange Is Kohl's Elusive Point Man of Mideast Policy
description: At the center of Germany's mediation in today's exchange between Lebanon and Israel stands a figure part shadowy, part power broker and mostly elusive, whom German headline writers like to call "Agent 008" -- Bonn's successor to James Bond.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- NOTEBOOK;Yachtsmen Welcomed In the Rain and Wind
description: Savannah's satellite venue for Olympic yachting may be 260 miles from Atlanta, but its Olympic flame burns no less brightly -- even in the pouring rain.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: MONDAY

title: Boyfriend Is Sought in Killing of a Woman
description: A 19-year-old Queens woman was fatally shot early yesterday while fleeing in a car after she argued with a boyfriend at a dance club, the police said. The woman, Kaydia Dooaney, was killed about 4:15 A.M. after a night of partying at LiGuanea International in Queens Village.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- SWIMMING;U.S. Earns First Gold, In the Pool
description: For three years, they had trained as tense rivals in the same pool at the University of Michigan, and midway through tonight's 400-meter individual medley at the Summer Olympics, it became clear that Tom Dolan and Eric Namesnik would decide the United States' first gold medal between them.

title: Looking Glass;The Games People Play
description: Anyone who has walked by a video arcade knows that the overwhelming majority of the gamers are boys, and many never outgrow the habit.

title: BASEBALL;Top Yankee Prospect Gets A Seven-Day Suspension
description: In the Yankees' own version of "The Young and the Restless," the team has suspended the prized outfield prospect Ruben Rivera for seven days for insubordination.

title: No Headline
description: You do realize how cheap life can be. This isn't a war zone. This isn't Beirut. And it isn't Saudi Arabia. It is -- or was -- a peaceful little town. ROGER WALLER, at a memorial service in East Moriches, L.I., for victims of Flight 800. [B5:5.]

title: Equity Offerings for This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Doors Shut to Poor Seeking Homes
description: For two decades, the Federal Government's Section 8 housing subsidy program has helped poor working people like Wanda Schott get off welfare. After spending two years on a waiting list, Ms. Schott, a divorced mother of two boys, became eligible for one of those precious Section 8 vouchers and, in 1994, used it to rent a trailer in this suburb of Canton.

title: Lily Tomlin to Join 'Murphy Brown'
description: Needing to win back viewers, CBS has hitched its prime-time schedule to a handful of big-name stars for the new season, hoping they can pull the network out of third place.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800;Pipe Bomb Found At O'Hare Airport
description: A small pipe bomb was found at O'Hare International Airport and detonated Sunday night by the Chicago police. The authorities at the airport had tightened security after receiving bomb threats earlier in the day.

title: A Hardware Team Offers A Mouse That Can Zoom
description: When Microsoft reports its earnings this afternoon, it is a safe bet that no one on Wall Street will be focusing on how well Rick Thompson's business did. The 36-year-old Mr. Thompson runs a fast-growing operation within the Microsoft Corporation that gets little attention, no analysts' questions, no magazine stories and no business school case studies.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- WRESTLING;A Lightning-Fast Throw Costs American a Gold
description: He expected the move that crushed him, had foretold it hours before when he recalled how his foe had used it on him before. But Dennis Hall, the United States' best hope for gold in Greco-Roman wrestling, could not escape being lifted from the mat and thrown today into an insurmountable 4-point hole by Yuri Melnichenko of Kazakstan.

title: Few Engineers Commit Most Of Rail Errors
description: A relative handful of engineers at New Jersey Transit, Metro-North Commuter Railroad and the Long Island Rail Road account for about half the violations of several major train-operating rules, a review of disciplinary records shows, yet the railroads almost never dismiss or demote the engineers in that small group.

title: With Sound and Light, A Festival Comes Alive
description: For months, Lincoln Center Festival '96 has been a big idea with a small presence. As a physical fact, the $8.5 million festival, which begins tonight and runs through Aug. 11, has been limited to some modest banners affixed to a few street-light poles along Broadway.

title: Microsoft Sees A Major Shift For Computers
description: The Microsoft Corporation, seeking to translate its dominance of personal computing into an upper hand on the Internet, is preparing to release new software that would bring the most fundamental change to personal computers since the machines were invented in the 1970's.

title: CYCLING;The Tour No Longer Belongs to Indurain
description: Bjarne Riis rode across the last finish line of the Tour de France today with his arms raised in a V and some big questions in his slipstream.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- FENCING;Russians and French Score With Swords
description: Russia and France, two nations where swordplay is a tradition, at least among Olympians, monopolized fencing's medal podium today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RONALD H. BROWN, the Commerce Secretary who was killed when his plane crashed on a Croatian mountaintop in April, had always planned to write his autobiography someday, his daughter, TRACEY BROWN, said the other day.

title: Sports of The Times;The Great Ones All Have Egos to Match. Gretzky's Is Just Hidden.
description: HE was only 20 years old then. He had completed only his second season with the Edmonton Oilers, but when someone mentioned to Wayne Gretzky that Darryl Sittler, then a sturdy center with the Toronto Maple Leafs, was arguably the National Hockey League's best player, he quietly disagreed.

title: If Bob, Bill, Ron Were the First Men . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Rethinking Sybase From the Top Down
description: Deciding to quit the company might not always land you the chief executive's job, but in the case of Mitchell Kertzman, it did just that.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- BASEBALL;Cuba Edges Japan in 10 Innings
description: Cuba's baseball team, the favorite to win a gold medal but rattled by the July 9 defection of pitcher Rolando Arrojo, rallied to defeat Japan, 8-7, in 10 innings tonight.

title: Updating Tolstoy, A Russian Director Faces War's Anguish
description: War movies are not always the finest expression of Russian cultural achievement. Yes, of course, "Battleship Potemkin" is one of the great treasures of modern cinema. But sentimental propaganda films from World War II, still appearing on television almost every day, are painful to watch, usually for the wrong reasons.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Emerson Quartet Makes It a Schubert Night
description: Performances by the Emerson String Quartet are rarely dull, but everyone is entitled to an off night, and the Emerson had one on Thursday. The program, part of the Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall, was devoted entirely to Schubert and included the Quartet in C minor (D. 703), the "Rosamunde" Quartet (D. 804) and, with Lilian Kallir, pianist, and Timothy Cobb, bassist, the "Trout" Quintet (D. 667). As a preconcert bonus, they played the Dvorak "American" Quartet.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Leo Burnett Promotes Executives
description: The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago has expanded top management by promoting several executives as a leading creative executive leaves.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE MEMORIALS;Few Answers in Quest for Disaster's Meaning
description: The prayer offered by the Rev. Ashley Harrington at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church yesterday was not just for Bob and Betty Miller, two members of the Tenafly, N.J., parish who died when Trans World Airlines Flight 800 plummeted into the sea.

title: Myth and Reality At Avignon Festival
description: With wandering minstrels, mimes, fire-eaters, African drummers and droves of youths handing out fliers for plays and performances all competing good-naturedly for control of the streets of this medieval Provencal city, Avignon seems once again to be the principal star of its annual celebration of theater.

title: La Lima Journal;Where Banana Is King, a Revolt Over Farmlands
description: From the moment American fruit producers installed themselves in northern Honduras a century ago, this has been the quintessential company town. The large Chiquita banana logo on the water tower here announces it, and the dusty streets are dominated by faded company posters promising "riches and progress for Honduras."

title: More Power for Voters
description: To the Editor:

title: Tribe Is Now Wanted as a Resource
description: They saved Lewis and Clark from starvation, helped many an Oregon Trail straggler find the way west, and outfoxed the United States Army in battles that are studied by military historians to this day.

title: BASEBALL;Playoff Race Heats Up; Mets Freeze Up
description: The Expos crashed over the Mets' view of the wild card like a wave tackles beach sand, stealing ground from beneath a team that stood imperfectly still yesterday.

title: ON BASKETBALL;They're Ambassadors Of the Women's Game
description: An hour before their first-round game against Cuba, Sheryl Swoopes and Jennifer Azzi of the United States women's basketball team stood at opposite ends of the court going through highly refined rituals.

title: Olympics Stung By Technology's False Starts
description: Atlanta's Olympic organizers, who had promised the most technologically sophisticated Games ever, were scrambling today to repair their most basic information systems.

title: AN AMERICAN PLACE;Less for the Poor
description: Even in a time of relative prosperity in Stark County, Ohio, which has a tradition of volunteerism, the government's safety net for the poor seems to be unraveling. Page A8.

title: Rev. Lawrence M. Jenco, 61, Hostage in Lebanon in 1980's
description: The Rev. Lawrence Martin Jenco, the Roman Catholic priest who was held hostage in Lebanon by Islamic radicals for 18 months in the 1980's, died on Friday. He was 61.

title: Mr. Zedillo Wavers
description: Mexico, battered by corruption scandals, deep recession and mysterious guerrilla violence, is passing through difficult and dangerous times. But instead of stepping up to the challenge with a bold plan of action, President Ernesto Zedillo now appears to be retreating from the promises of open, honest government he made at the start of his term 20 months ago. That is exactly the wrong response.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Transit Ads Win Reprieve
description: In May, New Jersey Transit announced that starting in June it would no longer accept advertising for cigarettes or alcohol. But the ads are still there -- on buses, in train cars, and in terminals -- and agency officials say a recent United States Supreme Court ruling upholding the right of liquor stores to advertise their prices has made them more cautious about adopting the ban. The agency now plans to schedule public hearings on the change to let liquor and cigarette manufacturers comment. "We believe that the industry may challenge this policy in the courts, so we have, on the advice of counsel, opted to enact it through rule-making procedures," said Jeff Maclin, a transit spokesman.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- SOCCER;American Women Enjoy a Perfect Day in the Sun
description: They were buoyed by the large crowd and the familiar Florida heat, but the United States women's soccer team would have won today's game in a snowstorm with no witnesses.

title: As Mainstream Papers Cut Back, the Ethnic Press Expands
description: Even as dozens of newspapers in the United States have closed in recent years, dozens more have sprung up. The ethnic press, operating in the shadow of mainstream newspapers, has quietly been building circulation and advertising revenue.

title: Eddy Manson, 77, Master of the Harmonica
description: Eddy Lawrence Manson, a harmonica virtuoso who composed for television and films, died on July 12 at Brotman Medical Center in Culver City, Calif. He was 77 and lived in Hollywood.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Knowing a Place Better By Not Going There
description: SAHARA UNVEILED A Journey Across the Desert By William Langewiesche Illustrated. 302 pages. Pantheon. $24.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Cracking Down on Cats
description: Cats are generally considered low-impact pets, but neighbors say the 27 mostly stray cats that are fed by the owners of a house on Atlanta Avenue in Wildwood Crest are a problem. "They're everywhere," said Joyce Gould, a member of the borough's board of commissioners. "In their yard, in the neighbors' yard; they tear up lawns and hop up on neighbors' windows and spray into the houses." This week, the commissioners will discuss whether to join the 251 other towns in the state that require cat licenses.

title: Advertising;Statistics show that cyberpitches aid in sales to upscale, highly educated mainstream families.
description: EVER since marketers began surging into cyberspace, they have wondered whether the rapidly increasing budgets being allotted to advertising aimed at computer users represented dollars spent well or simply wasted. Now a business unit of the A. C. Nielsen Company is offering demographic data and other information about who goes on line that is linked to purchasing behavior off line.

title: POLITICS: THE THIRD PARTY;While Voters Watch Perot and Lamm, the Reform Party Is Busy Organizing
description: The bank account of the Reform Party of Maine has only a couple of hundred dollars in it, and the party's political ambitions for 1996 look nearly as modest.

title: World News Briefs;Sri Lanka Navy Tries To Aid Base Hit by Rebels
description: After an attack by separatist rebels and four days of heavy fighting, the Sri Lankan Navy tried to ferry in hundreds of reinforcements today to protect a northern military base.

title: Philadelphia Keeps Strawbridge Name but Loses a Retail Tradition
description: A decision to sell the family-owned Strawbridge & Clothier department store chain to a St. Louis company has workers and shoppers alike worried about changes at the 128-year-old local institution.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE FAMILIES;Angry Relatives Yearn For Strengths of Home
description: They yearn for the familiarity of home: the innocence of their children's bedrooms, crammed with computers and posters of athletes and heartthrobs. The soothing smell of coffee brewing on their kitchen counters. The uncomplicated routine of morning, noon and night, predictable, stable, ready to give them strength.

title: Sir Geoffrey Jellicoe, Leader in Landscape Design, Dies at 95
description: Sir Geoffrey Jellicoe, one of the 20th century's leading landscape architects, died on Wednesday, in Devon, England. He was 95.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jones Is Back, Sparking The Jets
description: Marvin Jones showed today why he is not just another football player, and why the possibility of what he could be has tantalized the Jets since the moment they made him their top pick in 1993.

title: Taking In the Sites;Free Maps for Travelers on the Web
description: Free customized maps are becoming one of the handier features of the World Wide Web. They might soon take the place of that tattered road atlas in the trunk.

title: Bridge
description: Major changes in the organization or scoring of competitive bridge rarely happen since the inertia of players and bureaucracies around the world is hard to overcome. Consider these three suggestions that have been made recently:

title: Spanish Journalist Didn't Merit Post;In Russia, Reprisals
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Toll Rising, Japan Warns Against Eating Raw Meat
description: The Japanese Government warned the public today not to eat raw meat as the toll grew from an epidemic of food poisoning.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE TIMETABLE;Length of Crash Inquiries Varies Based on Time Needed to Recover Evidence
description: After the crash of Pan Am 103 at Lockerbie, Scotland, in December 1988, it took investigators seven days to announce that the cause was a bomb.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- CYCLING;Veteran of the Roads Finally Gets Her Gold
description: Her major rivals acknowledged beforehand that she was the best. She was certainly the most decorated, with five world titles in road races and two in individual pursuit. And at 37 years 10 months and near retirement, she was the oldest in the race.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE AFTERMATH;Ensnared by a Nightmare, a Seaside Village Slowly Shakes Itself Free
description: Michael O'Reilly says he's fine now. He takes a sip from a mug of vodka and cranberry juice, nods his head in halting assurance, attempts a smile. Really, he says, he's fine. Now.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- SWIMMING;South Africa's Wait Ends
description: As Penny Heyns prepared to swim the 100-meter breast-stroke tonight, South Africa had not produced a gold medal since the 1952 Summer Games, when Joan Harrison won the 100-meter backstroke and Esther Brand won the high jump. The country was banned from the Olympics from 1964 until 1992 because of the racial policies of apartheid.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-7

title: Huge Power Failure Is Laid to Short-Circuit
description: A power failure on July 2, which affected two million people from Canada to Mexico, began with an Idaho transmission line that short-circuited when electricity jumped to a tree that had grown too close, investigators say.

title: Warriors Sign Mark Price
description: Mark Price, once one of the National Basketball Association's best guards but limited to seven games last year because of an injured foot, signed today with the Golden State Warriors.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants Sign Second Pick
description: The Giants signed their second-round pick, former Michigan receiver Amani Toomer, to a three-year contract today, leaving only their top pick unsigned.

title: BASEBALL;Yanks Are Sitting Pretty Despite a Mediocre Trip
description: The longest journey of the season began with the euphoria of Baltimore, stooped to the exasperation of Boston and deteriorated into the frustration of Milwaukee. The Yankees snared the first four critical games of the trek, promised they would not celebrate and then hobbled through the next two cities as if they had violated curfew.

title: Multi-Ethnic Bosnians Share Lunch and Scorn for Politics
description: In a gravel parking lot in this serene mountain village, the license plates alone told a story today. On a red Opel, the plate bore the red-and-white checkerboard Croatian shield. A blue Yugo had the blue-and-yellow shield of Bosnia and Herzegovina. On a white Mercedes, the letters on the license plate were Cyrillic, evidence that the car was from Bosnian Serb territory.

title: Economic Calender
description: Listed below are the expected release dates for major economic indicators this week.

title: Populist's Victory in Ecuador Worries the Elite
description: Six years ago, as Abdala Bucaram waited out charges of corruption by fleeing to Panama, it was Jaime Nebot, a political rival and leader of the Social Christians, who pushed for Mr. Bucaram's pardon, confident that the one-time Mayor of this city would wither at the polls.

title: HOCKEY;Messier, Not Money, Made Gretzky a Ranger
description: Wayne Gretzky could have gone somewhere else for more money. In the end, though, the man called "simply the greatest hockey player ever to play" by Rangers President Neil Smith decided that playing with one of his oldest friends, Mark Messier, on a team that would give him a legitimate shot to win another Stanley Cup, was more important to him.

title: Gutting the Money for Poor Countries
description: Congress is threatening to renege on a worthy commitment made by President Clinton to wipe out America's debt to the World Bank program that lends money to desperately poor countries. The House voted to appropriate only $525 million of the $934 million the United States owes. A Senate committee voted for $626 million. Unfortunately, the Administration is not fighting very hard to restore the original target.

title: GOLF;Hard-Working Lehman's Reward Is British Open Crown
description: All day long he had worked his way through hostile territory. In the company of a thoroughly dangerous man, wending through a sea of bunkers, and in an ocean of fans who screamed for his playing partner and rooted openly for his demise, Tom Lehman labored.

title: An Upstart Mexican Network Gets a Bit Personal
description: A prominent politician is gunned down on a city street. The police commander in charge of the investigation is up to his badge in the international cocaine trade. The bumbling young journalist who tries to get to the bottom of it all is deceived and disdained by the authorities.

title: Spanish Journalist Didn't Merit Post
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Universal Studios Names Agency
description: The Universal Studios Recreation Group division of MCA Inc. in Universal City, Calif., has named two units of Foote, Cone & Belding to handle theme park advertising, an assignment that had been divided for four years between Seiniger Kaufman Advertising in Beverly Hills, Calif., which handled creative duties, and the DDB Needham Los Angeles unit of the Omnicom Group, which handled media. Billings were estimated at more than $20 million.

title: Believe the Victims of North Korean Torture
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- BASKETBALL;U.S. Bench Is Too Deep For Cuba In Opener
description: They had advanced so far, with a now-meaningless 52-0 record and more than 100,000 miles behind them, that the women from the United States had to feel something when their first Olympic basketball game arrived. When nervousness, created by each of their personal investments, struck them at the start of their game against Cuba, the Americans could call upon all those months of work for Coach Tara VanDerveer, and the reality they have built.

title: Welfare Reform in Name Only
description: I have spent much of my professional life seeking to reform welfare. I have worked with Republican and Democratic governors. And until I returned to academia a year ago, I was fortunate to be a co-chairman of President Clinton's welfare reform effort. I deeply believe that the well-being of the nation's children depends on real reform. We must turn away from the failed system focused on determining eligibility and check writing and create a new one based on work and responsibility.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stock prices were trading lower here today. At the end of the morning session, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 156.86 points, or almost three-quarters of a percent, at 21,319.43. On Friday, the Nikkei index fell 90.13 points.

title: Goldman Agrees to Acquire British Coal's Pension Unit
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company and British Coal said yesterday that Goldman, Sachs had agreed to buy British Coal's pension fund management company. Though no price was given, the bid, one of several, is said to have been between $65 million and $75 million.

title: If Bob, Bill, Ron Were the First Men . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Popcorn, Traffic and, Yes, 3 Tenors
description: The 45-yard line was as good a place as any to witness the Three Tenors at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., on Saturday night. Placido Domingo, Luciano Pavarotti, Jose Carreras and friends looked like ants on their Temple-of-Karnak-comes-to-New-Jersey stage put up in one end zone, but two huge television screens and a roaring sound system let ticket buyers know what they were missing.

title: Israelis and Hezbollah Exchange Prisoners and Bodies
description: Israel and the Iranian-backed guerrilla group Hezbollah today carried out the largest swap of prisoners and bodies since their conflict in southern Lebanon began 14 years ago.

title: Why Waste Money on Flawed Legal Services?
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Going for the Olive?
description: If there were a medal for the oldest piece of Olympic-related flora, a century-old branch on display at Princeton University would be guaranteed at least a tie for the gold. In a case in Firestone Library sits the laurel bough awarded to a Princeton student, Albert C. Tyler, for finishing second in the pole vault at the first modern Olympics in Athens in 1896 (winners received olive branches). The laurel, which is part of a show of 1896 Olympic memorabilia that includes the discus used by Princeton gold medalist Robert Garrett, will be on display until Aug. 15. ANDY NEWMAN

title: CHRONICLE
description: How do you trace the history of the City University of New York in one quilt? ADRIENNE YORINKS, an artist who was asked to create a work of art to commemorate the university's 150th anniversary next year, did it through photographs.

title: The Art Of Being No One
description: In an ideal world uncontaminated by ego and individual "identity," all works of art, if not entertainment, might well be attributed to "Anonymous." These works would then be judged solely on their intrinsic merit; the attachment of specific creators, whether for the enhancement of the works or their detriment, would be irrelevant. What freedom for creators and consumers alike: we would have no expectations, thus no disappointments; we would retain a childlike attitude to art, willing always to be surprised.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- JOURNAL;Atlantans Revel in Their Olympic Moment
description: Sure, much of downtown has been reduced to a tacky carnival midway, with a steer-roping rodeo and a giant inflatable Gumby and barkers hawking everything from corn dogs to silly hats. Sure, the humidity is stifling and the trains are more crowded than a New York subway at rush hour.

title: Why Waste Money on Flawed Legal Services?;Against the Crowd
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;In New Attack, Russians Hit Chechen Rebel Base
description: Russian troops carried out a new attack in Chechnya over the weekend, on what they described as a well-fortified rebel base in southern Chechnya.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: THE CRASH

title: POLITICS: THE CANDIDATE'S HEALTH;Dole Backs Idea of Independent Health Check
description: Bob Dole, who turns 73 on Monday, said today that if he was elected President, he would submit to an independent medical review of his health in the event that questions arose about his mental or physical ability to serve.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: A EUROPEAN VIEW;On Continent, Crash Is Seen As Debunking Security Myth
description: In the opinion of some European newspapers, Americans can no longer afford to be smug about the effectiveness of security precautions at airports in the United States.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- SWIMMING;Irish Swimmer's Golden Honeymoon
description: Her face, creased with incredulity, between laughter and tears, said everything about the improbability of what Michelle Smith had just done. She had pulled off one of the great upsets in Olympic swimming history, and for Ireland, no less, which doesn't even have an Olympic-sized pool and had never produced a women's champion. Not in swimming. Not in any sport. No Irish woman had ever won an Olympic medal, much less a gold.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Gravel Mining Is Debated
description: Should a mining company be allowed to dredge sand and gravel off the New Jersey coast from Sandy Hook to Surf City? The Federal Interior Department thinks so, but many environmentalists and local elected officials do not. On Wednesday, the state's Beach Erosion Commission will hold a public hearing to learn more about the Federal Government's proposal to lease the mining rights to 1,400 square miles of ocean bottom. A South Amboy-based firm, Amboy Aggregates, wants to dredge the area, but critics say that disturbing the ocean floor will damage underwater wildlife.

title: Dire Details Plague a Grand Olympics
description: ATLANTA  In one day the Centennial Olympics established a trend that will be difficult to undo. The Atlanta organizers were getting the big things right, wonderfully right, and the little things disastrously wrong.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Gingrich's Message Is All Too Clear on Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Murray Traded To the Orioles
description: Eddie Murray, who began his career in Baltimore, was traded back to the Orioles today in a swap that sent pitcher Kent Mercker to the Cleveland Indians.

title: INSIDE
description: Calming Lebanon's Border

title: 300 Slain in Attack on Camp For Refugees in Burundi Strife
description: An attack by rebels on a refugee camp in Burundi has left more than 300 people dead and 100 wounded, local journalists said today.

title: Don't Pull the String Yet on Superstring Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: Planners of a New Public School for Girls Look to Two Other Cities
description: Planners of a new public school for girls in New York City have looked to the country's last two all-female public schools, one here and one in Baltimore, for indications that such a concept can succeed -- even in the face of legal challenges.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- NOTEBOOK;'Dixie' Dropped From Routine
description: Amy Chow had planned to perform an optional floor exercise routine that was a tribute to the South. She and her coaches, Diane Amos and Mark Young, chose to incorporate part of the song "Dixie" in her routine.

title: POP REVIEW;Ronstadt and Orchestra vs. the Wind
description: The wind was light but brisk, surging and subsiding as if blown from a bellows over Long Island Sound as Linda Ronstadt performed tonight at Jones Beach, with the Pittsburgh Pops, conducted by Marvin Hamlisch.

title: Progress on Pesticides
description: In a remarkable bipartisan effort, and after more than a decade of trying, House Democrats and Republicans have reached agreement on regulating pesticides in food. This is a welcome and indeed surprising achievement given the House's 18-month effort to roll back important environmental protections.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 3 -- ROUNDUP
description: ROWING Redgrave in Contention for Gold

title: In America;The Mouths of Babes
description: There is something very creepy about the welfare debate.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Cancer Reports to Be Ordered
description: State health officials are still not sure what, if anything, is responsible for high cancer rates among children in the area around Toms River. But in the course of investigating 54 cancer cases in Ocean County, they have learned one thing: the state lacks an effective system for keeping track of cancer statistics. Ralph Hahn, an aide to Assemblyman James W. Holzapfel, Republican of Brick Township, said the state inquiry took months longer than it should have because of inadequate reports from health care professionals. Today, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is to sign a bill that would provide $400,000 to set up a statewide cancer registry. The bill, sponsored by Mr. Holzapfel, would also set fines of up to $1,000 per day for doctors and medical centers who fail to report cancer cases.

title: Mob Figure's Mother Is Robbed
description: A Harlem man was arrested yesterday after he took $90 from the 94-year-old mother of Vincent Gigante, the suspected boss of the Genovese organized crime family, the police said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * SFD Inc., San Bruno, Calif., to Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, San Francisco, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., as the first agency to handle advertising for the software technology company.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE OVERVIEW;AIR CRASH INQUIRY FAILS ANOTHER DAY TO FIND WRECKAGE
description: Frustrated by equipment breakdowns, Federal officers searching the tossing waters of the Atlantic Ocean off Long Island failed for a fourth day yesterday to reach the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800.

title: Burmese Win Observer Status in Southeast Asian Group
description: The military Government of Myanmar took a major step toward international legitimacy this weekend as its Southeast Asian neighbors welcomed it into a regional partnership and told Western countries not to interfere.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Wood Finally Wins

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-8

title: Action Urged to Stem Invasion of Species From Ships' Ballast
description: BESIDES hauling over 80 percent of the world's commodities, cargo ships can carry trouble in their ballast holds. Animals and plants can be carried far across the seas in the water a ship carries for stability and then discharged into new surroundings, causing serious environmental harm.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;New and Familiar Faces In News Channel Debut
description: Surfing through the debut week of MSNBC, the new cable news channel ("The Revolution Begins Here"), I noticed no revolution, but found a potential rival to CNN, with special attention to the Internet generation. This 24-hour-a-day collaboration between NBC News and Microsoft invites E-mail questions to add to the call-in questions, the interviewers' questions and the panelists' comments that keep talk television babbling along. Thousands of Web residents are hastening to put in their two bytes' worth, but CNN has its own Internet address (as well as a much bigger audience), and old-fashioned computer-challenged viewers couldn't care less one way or the other.

title: Correction: Women's Favorite Video Games
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday about results of a survey of people who play video games reversed the gender labels on bars showing women's favorite games. Here is a corrected chart.

title: Panel Admonishes Family Court Judge
description: A Family Court judge has been accused by New York State's judicial oversight body of exerting "improper" pressure on Child Welfare Administration workers to look into a case involving his lover's 9-year-old daughter.

title: RU-486, Nearing Approval
description: RU-486, the abortion-inducing pill, is finally nearing approval for marketing in the U.S. after a decade of controversy. An advisory committee has recommended that the drug be considered safe and effective, thus clearing the way for likely final approval by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: THE CRASH

title: Carnival Orders 2 Ships
description: The Carnival Corporation said today that it had given a $600 million contract to build two cruise ships to the Italian shipyard Fincantieri Cantieri Navali Italiani S.p.A. The Miami-based cruise line said the ships -- for its Holland America line -- would be delivered in 1999, one early in the year and the other late. The ships will carry 1,440 passengers.

title: U.S. Allows Crew's Move Against Board
description: The United States Department of Justice handed Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew a significant legal victory yesterday in his attempts to oust Carmelo Saez Jr., the resilient former president of Community School District 9 in the Bronx, who has been removed by three chancellors but returned to office by voters each time.

title: It's U.S. Arrogance, Not Values, That Offends;The Victims' Fault?
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: MISHA and CIPA DICHTER, the pianists, are also celebrating a milestone this week, the 25th summer of their performing together. They are to give a two-piano recital at the Venetian Theater at the Caramoor International Music Festival in Katonah, N.Y., on Sunday. "In the summer of 1971, when we were expecting our first son, I was reading articles about postpartum depression," Mr. Dichter said yesterday, "and I thought that a good way to get her past that would be to shock her. So I arranged to have her play the Mozart double piano concerto with me, at the Hollywood Bowl, and we made our professional debut as a duo the following summer."

title: Grand Central's Departure Board, Gone!
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: MONTOURSVILLE;A Family Searches for Order in a House Dominated by Memories
description: Monica Weaver was graceful and generous, a top student and a swimmer who played the flute in a local symphony. She had had her driver's license for just two weeks, and was just beginning to flirt with independence. And her departure for Paris, aboard T.W.A. Flight 800, was one of her happiest moments.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- NOTEBOOK;Older Is Faster for U.S.
description: Kent Bostick started racing bikes when Gerald Ford was President, and Bostick was already 21 years old. Connie Paraskevin-Young is on her fifth Olympic team after making the first two in speed skating.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- NOTEBOOK;Johnson Wants to Return to Lakers
description: Now that Shaquille O'Neal is a member of the team, Magic Johnson is apparently headed back to the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Music;Opening With a Bang, Courtesy of the Kirov
description: Anyone who went to last night's opening concert of Lincoln Center Festival '96 expecting a theme, a manifesto or some sort of guiding set of principles must have exited Avery Fisher Hall a little confused. The confusion, I think, is intentional. Indeed, the Kirov Orchestra and Chorus under Valery Gergiyev, playing two unlikely paeans to Soviet accomplishment, simply affirmed what may be this festival's only real message: that the world makes little sense but in its variety is interesting to behold.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- SWIMMING;The U.S. Women Are a Surprise; Popov Just Wins
description: While Aleksandr Popov of Russia was expected to win his riveting duel with Gary Hall Jr. in swimming's version of the 100-meter dash, the American women were not projected to win a single gold medal at the Summer Games.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday about results of a survey of people who play video games reversed the gender labels on bars showing women's favorite games. A corrected version appears today on page D7.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Peter J. Quigley was named to the new position of marketing director at Parade Publications, New York, a unit of Advance Publications. He had been director for sales and marketing at 3M Media Networks, Stamford, Conn. a unit of Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co.

title: POP REVIEW;Grinning Mischief-Makers Breaking Country Rules
description: Country bands usually keep poker faces, but the one at Tramps on Friday night couldn't help grinning. They were backing Ween, and between the rudely funny lyrics and the uproarious audience, they loosened up fast.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Rhythms And Rock From Africa
description: To American listeners, African rock is no longer the revelation it was in the early 1980's. The impassioned voices, the mesh of drums and guitars, the incantatory melodies and the music's ever-changing proportions of local, pan-African and Western ingredients are all familiar to attentive listeners. But as the music's general novelty has worn off, its pleasures have proved to be enduring, even if most American listeners can't understand the lyrics. On Sunday at the Prospect Bark Bandshell, Celebrate Brooklyn presented its fifth annual Africa Mondo Festival, a six-hour show of African and Caribbean groups, and five of the six bands on the bill made for a jubilant afternoon.

title: Warily, Hong Kong Greets a General From Beijing
description: As the wail of "Highland Cathedral" wheezed from bagpipes played by Ghurkas in crisp green and white uniforms, the British Army welcomed the first Chinese Communist general to visit Hong Kong.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- NOTEBOOK;A Cultural Timeout
description: At the same time the basketball Dream Team was playing Angola tonight, the Cultural Olympiad's own "Dream Team" was playing at Atlanta's Symphony Hall.

title: Home Ownership At 15-Year High
description: Home ownership in the United States has reached a 15-year-high of 65.4 percent as buyers take advantage of good times and relatively low mortage rates, the Clinton Administration said today.

title: Village in Finland Faces a Gold Rush Fed by Margarine
description: If a 57-year-old farmer-owned company here, Raisio Group, a maker of french fries, wheat flour and pet food, plays its margarine right, it may produce one of those success stories usually associated with California software companies or, say, the maker of Nutrasweet.

title: INSIDE
description: Stocks Continue Decline

title: CHRONICLE
description: LORE NOTO, the producer of "The Fantasticks," which will have its 15,000th performance at the Sullivan Street Playhouse tomorrow, has yet to become blase about its record-breaking longevity.

title: TV Notes;Emmy Nominations for News
description: Andrew Heyward, president of CBS News, had a hatful of announcements yesterday -- about political convention coverage, new assignments for producers and correspondents, and even the theme music for the new CBS morning show, written and sung by Carly Simon. Perhaps nothing made him happier, though, than announcing that CBS News had earned 19 nominations for 1995 News and Documentary Emmy awards.

title: Bankers Trust to Pay $210 Million for Wolfensohn
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation disclosed today that it would pay about $210 million in cash and stock to acquire Wolfensohn & Company. The price was higher than analysts had speculated.

title: Geneticists Arm Corn Against Corn Borer But Pest May Still Win
description: FROM the two-lane road alongside Steve Pitstick's field here on the prairie an hour's drive west of Chicago, the close green rows of six-foot corn look uniform and healthy. Close up, though, a stark pattern emerges: eight shiny rows of corn that look as if they are right out of a seed company's sales brochure alternating with eight rows of stalks with leaves scarred by feasting insects.

title: I.M.F. WILL DELAY MONEY TO RUSSIA OVER TAX PROBLEM
description: Citing the Yeltsin Government's problems with tax collection, the International Monetary Fund said today that it would delay its $330 million payment to Russia this month for the first time.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Federal Home Loan Bank is selling $50 million of notes due in 2001 through the First Tennessee Bank. The notes have a one-time call on Nov. 13, 1996, carry an interest rate of 7 percent and are priced at par.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Natural Gas Prices Tumble On Mild Weather Across U.S.
description: Natural gas prices tumbled for the fourth consecutive session on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, as mild weather across the United States eased concern that inventories would be dangerously low at the start of the heating season.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE MOURNERS;At the Ocean's Edge, a Wrenching Farewell
description: Under a mass of blue-gray clouds that cast deep shadows along the shore, about 600 relatives and friends of the victims of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 gathered here today to gaze over the waters where the jet fell. They also came to remember their loved ones in a ceremony that, for many, provided the first semblance of a funeral since the disaster.

title: Hallwood to Pay S.E.C. in Insider Trading
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the Hallwood Group and its chief executive had agreed to pay $1.7 million in connection with insider trading in the stock of Showbiz Pizza Time Inc.

title: Peter Ludwig, 71, German Art Collector, Dies
description: Peter Ludwig, a German chocolate manufacturer who amassed an immense art collection and gave or lent many artworks to public institutions in Germany and elsewhere, died yesterday in a hospital in Germany. He was 71 and lived in Aachen.

title: Washington Mutual Plans Expansion Into California
description: In a sign that the California housing market might be rebounding, Washington Mutual Inc., the largest savings institution in the Northwest, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the American Savings Bank, California's second-largest mortgage lender, for $1.2 billion in stock.

title: Volcano in California Springs Unusual Carbon Dioxide Leak
description: DURING a heavy snowstorm in March 1990, Fred Richter, a Forest Service supervisor, sought refuge in a remote cabin on Mammoth Mountain, a popular recreational area in the Sierra Nevada range in California. He had used the cabin before as a place to eat lunch, dry out his equipment and rest before skiing on to various sites in the back country.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WILLIAMS TO REPURCHASE UP TO $800 MILLION OF ITS STOCK
description: The Williams Companies said yesterday that its board had cleared the repurchase of as much as $800 million of the company's common stock. Based on Friday's closing price, the company, a natural-gas pipeline, processing and marketing concern based in Tulsa, Okla., would buy back 16.5 million, or 15.7 percent, of its 104.8 million common shares outstanding. Shares of Williams fell 87.5 cents, to $47.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. In July 1994, the board authorized the buyback of up to $800 million in stock.

title: PATTERNS
description: BCBG Buys Browner

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Nestle Adds to Stake In Israeli Concern
description: Nestle S.A., the world's largest food maker, has bought 25 percent of Osem Investment Ltd., an Israeli food producer, for $140.3 million, according to Claridge & Kolber Trust, which sold some of the shares. Nestle, based in Switzerland, now owns almost 40 percent of the company, Claridge said on Sunday. Osem's 10 plants produce more than 800 brands of pasta, baked goods, snacks and coffee. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: COMPANY REPORTS;NABISCO HOLDINGS CORP. (NA,N)
description: The Nabisco Holdings Corporation reported a second-quarter net loss of $216 million yesterday and cited restructuring expenses intended to improve its long-term profitability.

title: Media General to Expand In Southeast With Purchase
description: Media General Inc., which has been spending heavily in its effort to become a leader in the communications industry in the Southeast, moved today to increase its holdings by agreeing to buy Park Acquisitions for $710 million in cash.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4;It's Business as Usual, And Nobody Is Happy
description: For a lot of Atlanta businesses, the Olympics coming to town held out the promise of hordes of customers and tons of new business. But from the downtown Underground entertainment complex to nearby restaurants and malls, it isn't turning out to be Christmas in July.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- NOTEBOOK;Fraser Is Hospitalized
description: The former swimming star Dawn Fraser, Australia's most successful Olympic athlete, was admitted to an Atlanta hospital today apparently suffering from chest pains, team officials said.

title: FOOTBALL;Jets' Summer School Is in Session, and Brady Is Star Pupil
description: No, that isn't 12 men in the Jets' huddle. But for all their togetherness, Kyle Brady and the assistant coach Pat Hodgson might as well be joined at the hip.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Mitsubishi-Led Group Wins Saudi Contract
description: An international consortium led by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries Ltd. of Japan has won a $1.1 billion contract to build a power station in Saudi Arabia. The consortium, which includes the Bechtel Corporation of San Francisco, signed the contract with the Saudi Consolidated Electricity Company, a Government-controlled company, the Saudi company said Sunday.

title: No Headline
description: You always feel a little older in the morning. By noon I'll feel about 55. -- BOB DOLE, celebrating his 73d birthday. [A12:4.]

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- NOTEBOOK;Pae Won't Defend Gold
description: One of North Korea's few hopes for a gold medal in these Olympics was Pae Gil Su, the defending Olympic champion on the pommel horse. Pae was given a wild card here by the International Olympic Committee. He needed it because North Korea stopped competing internationally after the death of its longtime leader, Kim Il Sung, in July 1994. "We were in mourning for our great leader, so we could not do sports outside the country," he said.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE SEARCH;Frenzied Search Evolves Into a Systematic Sweep
description: A host of government agencies converged on the waters off Long Island late last week in search of the sunken wreckage from T.W.A. Flight 800, and for several days the search seemed characterized by frenzy, confusion and equipment breakdowns.

title: Clinton Will Sign Bill, Dole Asserts
description: Bob Dole predicted today that President Clinton would sign the welfare bill moving through Congress.

title: Cirrus Logic Is Set To Sell Picopower
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said today that it had agreed to acquire the Picopower unit of Cirrus Logic Inc. and that it would take a charge of $10 million, or 5 cents a share, on completion of the acquisition.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- NOTEBOOK;Lewis Won't Run Relay
description: It would take a major calamity for Carl Lewis to make the 400-meter relay team, the United States the men's track coach, Erv Hunt, said today.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- TRAFFIC;Athletes' Challenge: Getting There
description: Burt and Barbara Gordon of Beverly, Mass., knew they might be in for trouble when they asked their Olympic bus driver how long the trip would be to the equestrian events he was taking them to Sunday.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Seems That Beauty's Not Skin Deep, After All
description: THE POWER OF BEAUTY By Nancy Friday 589 pages. HarperCollins. $27.50.

title: PERIPHERALS;Perplexed? More Help
description: IF you have anything resembling a life," Scott Spanbauer writes at the beginning of his discussion of Windows 95 memory managers, "you probably don't spend much time getting your system's memory and hard disk into top form." There follow 14 pages of questions and answers on Windows memory devices and tricks.

title: Gertrude Crain, 85, Chairwoman Of Business Publishing Company
description: Gertrude Crain, who was chairwoman of the Crain Communications publishing company for more than 20 years, died July 20 at her son's summer home on Cape Cod. She was 85 years old and lived in Chicago.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HCIA IN DEAL TO ACQUIRE A UNIT OF HEALTHVISION
description: In a merger of companies that track health care costs and productivity, HCIA Inc. agreed yesterday to buy a unit of Healthvision Inc., LBA Health Care Management Inc., for $130 million. HCIA, based in Baltimore, plans to use LBA's clinical information from about 250 hospitals to expand its own data base. HCIA expects to record a one-time charge of $41.2 million in the quarter ending Sept. 30 to cover the research and development projects already begun at LBA. Shares of HCIA fell $4.625, to $61.75, in Nasdaq trading.

title: N.F.L. TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: Atlanta Falcons

title: A Few Bad Engineers
description: The railroad engineer is the first line of defense when it comes to train safety. Yet yesterday's New York Times report by Richard Perez-Pena shows that a small number of the engineers on New York-area commuter lines have a record of multiple violations of major safety laws, like running red lights or speeding. Because most engineers have very good records, this handful of repeat offenders accounts for the bulk of all moving violations.

title: State Panel Accuses Judge Of Using Post to Aid Lover
description: A Family Court judge has been accused by New York State's judicial oversight body of pressuring child welfare workers to look into a case involving his lover's 9-year-old daughter.

title: Chess
description: Each game has its own pace, and it is essential for the players to pay attention to it. In some games, it is easy find a plan, but in others a deeper scrutiny is required.

title: Researchers Track Down a Gene That May Govern Spatial Abilities
description: SCIENTISTS have found a gene that seems to underlie a higher form of human thinking -- the ability to take things apart mentally, like pieces of an imaginary puzzle, and to reassemble the parts into a whole.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Publisher Resigns At USA Weekend
description: Brette Popper, president and publisher of USA Weekend, a supplement that the Gannett Company distributes through Sunday newspapers, said yesterday that she would resign at the end of the month. Two executives at USA Weekend were promoted to succeed Ms. Popper, 38, who joined Gannett 11 years ago. Marcia Bullard, 43, editor, becomes president and takes a new post, chief executive. And Charles M. Gabrielson, 46, executive vice president, becomes publisher.

title: Senate Votes to Ease Work Requirement in Welfare Overhaul Bill
description: The Senate voted today to ease work requirements for food stamp recipients as it moved toward passage of a Republican bill overhauling the nation's welfare programs.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4;Computer Glitches Continue
description: Summer Games officials and a technology sponsor, I.B.M., said they were making progress today in their efforts to repair problems with Olympic technology systems.

title: BASEBALL;Rogers Can't Stop Yankees' Slide
description: It was like any reunion, high school or otherwise. He wanted to look his best, show everyone how he had hit the big time.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Retailers Change Agencies
description: Two retailers are changing agencies in decisions that both involved the Publicis/Bloom unit of Publicis S.A. in New York.

title: Don't Sell High-Tech Arms to Latin Nations
description: To the Editor:

title: New Hope for Bangladesh
description: In 25 years of independence, Bangladesh has been plagued by wars, violent coups and military dictatorships. But last month the nation opened a potentially hopeful period by holding the most peaceful election in its history, with nearly three-quarters of eligible voters going to the polls. The winner was the left-of-center Awami League led by Sheik Hasina Wazed, whose father brought the nation to independence in 1971. If Mrs. Wazed honors her pledge to govern by accommodation and with moderate economic policies, Bangladesh could emerge with stronger democratic institutions and economic conditions.

title: BASEBALL;Perez Eager to Rejoin Team
description: Melido Perez couldn't bear to watch the TV at times last fall. The Yankees were in the playoffs. And where was he? In the Dominican Republic.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4;ROUNDUP
description: FIELD HOCKEY U.S. Women Win One the Hard Way

title: Leonard Cronkhite Jr., 77, Health Plan Organizer
description: Dr. Leonard Wolsey Cronkhite Jr., an expert on radar and human survival in space, and an industrial physician who organized health plans and medical-care groups for industry and labor, died on Saturday at his home in Brunswick, Me. He was 77.

title: Sports of The Times;Competitors Without a Competition
description: WAGERS were being taken on how badly Dream Team III would route Angola last night in Game 2 of its gold-medal tour. Twenty-five points? Thirty? Thirty-five? Forty?

title: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRAT;Clinton Plays Favorite Tunes in Western Trip
description: President Clinton returned to some of his favorite places today to sound a few of his favorite themes, promising new efforts to crack down on parents delinquent in child-support payments and praising a school district here for its efforts to combat truancy.

title: TV Notes;Cable Deadline at CBS
description: Trying to shed its status as the only major broadcast network without a cable network, CBS has been working the marketplace hard this summer. And a deadline looms: Peter Lund, president of CBS, said yesterday that if he was going to buy a cable network, he would have to do so within six weeks.

title: Dole's California Hurdle
description: At the outset of the 1988 Presidential campaign, the Republican strategist Lee Atwater regularly pointed to California as his party's trump card. He knew George Bush could win a national election without the state's truckload of electoral votes, but recognized that for the Democrats it would be almost impossible. "They need it," he said. "So I want it."

title: A Butter Lover's Verdict: Texture but Not Much Taste
description: There are butter people and there are margarine people. Butter people love its rich, creamy flavor and find margarine a poor compromise. Margarine people think margarine is fine and can't understand what butter people are so excited about.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- SWIMMING;A Pool Medley: Controversy and Close Calls
description: Only three days into the Olympic competition, swimming became roiled in a controversy regarding fair play and possible drug use, the suspicion of which now pervades the sport like the smell of chlorine.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CISCO SYSTEMS AGREES TO BUY TELEBIT
description: Cisco Systems Inc., a network-computing concern based in San Jose, Calif., agreed yesterday to acquire the Telebit Corporation and its modem ISDN channel aggregation, or MICA, technologies in a complicated transaction valued at about $200 million. In total, Telebit shareholders would receive $13.35 a share. Telebit stock gained $1.9375, to $12.8125, in Nasdaq trading. Under the agreement, Telebit, a maker of data transmission products based in Chelmsford, Mass., would sell its analog modem business, Net Blazer and Mica Blazer products and certain other assets and liabilities to a new company formed through a management buyout for a $31.5 million promissory note and $3.5 million in redeemable preferred stock. Cisco would assume the $35 million financing for the management buyout.

title: Keeping Families in the Dark
description: MONTVILLE, N.J. Last Wednesday night, when I heard about Trans World Airlines Flight 800, I could barely breathe.

title: FOOTBALL;New Starting Guard Must Balance Joy With Grief
description: It should have been the time of his life. Ron Stone had signed a contract with the Giants that would make him a rich man, a five-year deal worth $10 million. He was building a new home. He was leaving Dallas to become a starting offensive lineman in New York. The world was opening up to him.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- WRESTLING;Karelin Puts His Shoulder Into Tough Victory
description: Superman looked to be experiencing physical discomfort here today. Aleksandr Karelin, unbeaten in Greco-Roman international wrestling in almost a decade of competition, lowered his left shoulder into a Moldovan opponent named Serguei Moureiko for much of an afternoon match, appearing to protect the surgically repaired right one.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;German Economy Recovers, Fueled by a Cheaper Mark
description: Germany's economy rebounded in the second quarter, as a cheaper mark stimulated exports and warmer weather spurred construction, the Economics Ministry said today.

title: Tips for Drug-Busters
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Microsoft Has 52% Net Rise; Sees Expansion In Core Areas
description: The Microsoft Corporation reported a 52 percent earnings increase for its fiscal fourth quarter today, slightly exceeding Wall Street's expectations.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;A Tale of Love and Lies In Shakespeare's Family
description: Writers from Virginia Woolf to Edward Bond have made fictional conjectures about Shakespeare's life. It was Woolf, of course, in "A Room of One's Own," who suggested that if Shakespeare had had "a wonderfully gifted sister" named Judith, she would never have been allowed to fulfill her genius. In his play "Bingo," Mr. Bond considered Shakespeare in retirement as a disgruntled landowner and eventual suicide.

title: Chip Makers, Japan Fail to Reach Accord
description: Industry groups representing United States computer chip makers, which are seeking to preserve their market share in Japan, failed over the weekend to agree with Japanese chip makers on a framework for a new agreement.

title: Councilman Is Angered by a 'Nazi Salute'
description: A New York City Councilman criticized the radio station WABC-AM for the behavior of one of its talk show hosts, who he said gave him a Nazi salute at the end of an interview.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Sunday about the air rifle performer who won the first gold medal of the 1996 Olympics misspelled her name in some editions. She is Renata Mauer.

title: 3 Top Pataki Aides Were Paid by Inaugural Fund
description: Three top advisers to Gov. George E. Pataki said today that they had each received payments of at least $20,000 from a fund created from private donations to finance Mr. Pataki's inauguration and transition.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;In a market where names seem to blur together, Luxottica sees a chance to become the next Nike.
description: IN ambitious attempt to bring the principles of branding to a so-called commodity category of consumer goods is asserting -- with apologies to the Communist Manifesto -- that eyeglass wearers ought to unite because they have nothing to lose but those funny little indentations on the sides of their noses.

title: Courtship of U.S. Talent for Export
description: Even at its most virulent, the presumption that American culture -- with its movies, McDonald's and military might -- would dominate the rest of the world never pointed an accusatory finger at fashion. It has been the lot of American designers to be considered also-rans behind the chic French, the intellectual Japanese and those great apparel industrialists, the Italians.

title: Let Victims Attend Bombing Trial and Testify
description: To the Editor:

title: Bad Neuenahr Journal;To Tighten Germany's Belt, Take a Look at the Spa
description: For the last 20 minutes or so, Gerd Ruhs, still as a pharaoh's mummy, happy as a hippo, has been encased in a coating of volcanic mud whose temperatures run to 120 degrees.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Court Bars Some Plea Deals
description: The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that a person who lets a drunken driver take the wheel should not be allowed to plead to a lesser charge. In a unanimous decision, the court said that plea bargains in such cases undermined legislative efforts to curtail drunken driving.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Jazz CD's;Inspiring The Old And New
description: Cecil Taylor Ensemble

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;New Coach for Quinnipiac
description: Quinnipiac College in Hamden, Conn., which is upgrading its athletic program to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I level, announced the hiring of a new men's basketball coach. JOE DeSANTIS was an assistant coach last season at St. John's, and an assistant at Pittsburgh from 1992-94.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: It's U.S. Arrogance, Not Values, That Offends;Insurance Isn't Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;MEMTEC IN ACCORD TO ACQUIRE GELMAN SCIENCES
description: Memtec Ltd. agreed yesterday to acquire Gelman Sciences Inc. for about $35 a share, or $278.3 million. Memtec, based in Windsor, Australia, makes purification and separation-equipment products. Gelman, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., is a leading maker of microfiltration products used in health care, laboratory research, environmental monitoring and high-technology manufacturing. Shares of Gelman rose $2.375, to $29.125, on the American Stock Exchange. Under the agreement, each share of Gelman would be exchanged for about 1.05 of the American depository receipts of Memtec. Memtec A.D.R.'s fell 50 cents, to $32.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Native Hawaiians Vote in Referendum on Creating an Ethnic Government
description: Elaine Kaopuiki, a renowned hula teacher from the island of Lanai, fondly surveyed her teen-age troupe of white-clad nymphs in halos of ferns. These Hawaiian girls, she said, were the reason that she chose "yes" in a plebiscite on whether to create a native Hawaiian government, a state-sponsored vote that is roiling these islands beneath their dreamy surface of swaying palms and hips.

title: By Design;Cooling Off in Short Dresses
description: On steamy midsummer days, there's nothing cooler to wear than a short dress, with bare legs and sandals. And although the first fall styles are in stores, there are still some sleeveless bare-neck dresses around.

title: NYC;Who Owns Ellis: Stirring Melting Pot
description: NEW JERSEY is a fine place, and does not deserve nearly all the verbal abuse that it puts up with from New Yorkers. But let's be serious. It is hard to imagine that any man in the dark days of czarist Russia turned to his wife after a pogrom and said: "Malke, we're going to where people can live free. We're going to New Jersey."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;U.S. Plant Explosion Harms Tate & Lyle
description: Tate & Lyle P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit this year will be cut about L10 million ($15 million) because of a weekend explosion at a sugar-beet plant in the United States. The company, a British producer of sugar and sweeteners, posted a pretax profit last year of L311.1 million after an exceptional charge of L25.5 million. The company was expected to post pretax profit of L300 million ($450 million) this year.

title: COMPANY NEWS;REXENE REJECTS A $442 MILLION BID FROM HUNTSMAN
description: The Rexene Corporation said yesterday that its board had unanimously decided to reject an unsolicited bid from the Huntsman Corporation that was valued at about $442 million, including the assumption of $175 million in debt. Rexene, a maker of plastic film and resins based in Dallas, said it and its shareholders would fare better if the company remained independent. Huntsman, a privately held plastic and petrochemical company based in Salt Lake City, made the offer last week after years of discussions between the two companies. The announcement was made after the stock market closed. Earlier, Rexene stock fell 75 cents, to $12.625, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: GOLF;For Lehman, the Major Signs Were There
description: Only when you examine how far Tom Lehman has come can you appreciate how much his victory in the British Open means, both to him and to the sport of golf. The case can be made that this baldish, good-natured, 37-year-old man from Minnesota is, right at this moment, the best golfer in America.

title: M. L. Rosenthal, Who Championed Poetry, Dies at 79
description: M. L. Rosenthal, a poet, a critic of 20th-century poetry and a teacher, died on Sunday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Suffern, N.Y. He was 79 and lived in Suffern.

title: Congress Staff May Not Gain Right to Union
description: One of the first things the Republicans did when they took control of Congress last year was to pass, with great fanfare, a law that included a provision allowing Capitol Hill workers to form and join unions, just like workers in the private sector.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DT INDUSTRIES PAYS $77 MILLION FOR MID-WEST AUTOMATION
description: DT Industries Inc., based in Springfield, Mo., said yesterday that it had paid $77 million for Mid-West Automation Enterprises Inc., a maker of integrated assembly systems. Shares of DT Industries rose $4, or 22 percent, to $22.25, in Nasdaq trading. Closely held Mid-West, based in Buffalo Grove, Ill., is expected to post $18 million in operating profit on revenue of more than $85 million for the year ended May 26. Its backlog as of June 30 was about $70 million. DT makes automated production equipment and metal components.

title: Enron Will Buy Oregon Utility In Deal Valued At $2.1 Billion
description: The Enron Corporation, the nation's largest natural gas supplier, said today that it would buy the Portland General Corporation, Oregon's largest power provider, for $2.1 billion and the assumption of $1.1 billion in debt.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Media General to Buy Owner of 10 TV Stations On a busy day of corporate mergers and acquisitions, Media General moved to increase its holdings dramatically by agreeing to buy Park Acquisitions for $710 million.

title: I.B.M. Enters Chip Accord With Mitsubishi
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said today that it had an agreement with the Mitsubishi Electronics Company for the Japanese company to sell specialty Power PC chips with the Mitsubishi logo.

title: ON BASEBALL;Pitching Uncertainties Cloud Yanks' Outlook
description: It would probably be an overstatement to say that the Yankees' series against the American League West-leading Texas Rangers represents gut-check time.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- BASKETBALL;Argentina Rises To Stun Lithuania
description: The buzzer sounded, and a new order began to take shape. The basketball team from Argentina, overlooked in its loss to a sluggish Dream Team on Saturday, constructed the upset of the Olympic tournament tonight with a 65-61 victory over Lithuania.

title: Leon Shenandoah, 81, Leader Of the Iroquois Confederacy
description: Leon Shenandoah, the head of the Six Nations of the Iroquois Confederacy, died yesterday at Syracuse University Hospital after a long illness. He was 81.

title: TV SPORTS;It's Live in Atlanta, But Not Often on NBC
description: We know NBC's coverage is not fair. It is successful, with ratings up 32 percent from the 1992 Barcelona Games, but it is skewed. A foreign athlete rarely gets the hero treatment, even if he or she has trounced an American. In last night's appalling call of the women's 4x100 swimming relay, Dan Hicks and Summer Sanders -- so excited, so unfair -- forgot that any of the foreign teams were alive. Not until the fourth leg of the relay was any other swimmer, a Chinese, mentioned by the pair.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;Bertelsmann Affirms It Wants Digital TV System in Germany
description: Bertelsmann A.G., which has planned to start a digital television system in Germany, said today that it was talking with a rival, the Kirch Group, about how best to do so. But Bertelsmann denied that it wanted to take a stake in Kirch's digital channel and said it still wanted its own.

title: POLITICS: THIRD PARTY;Perot's Committee Refuses to Give Rival the List of Reform Party Supporters
description: Officials of Ross Perot's national Reform Party movement have formally turned down a request from Richard D. Lamm's Presidential campaign for a list of the 1.3 million people who are eligible to take part in the candidate-preference survey and the August vote that will determine the nascent party's nominee.

title: For the Third Time, a Gold in His Pocket
description: Naim Suleymanoglu of Turkey, above, winning the 141-pound weight lifting competition. Known as Pocket Hercules because he is not quite 5 feet tall, Suleymanoglu managed 738.25 pounds in two lifts to become the first weight lifter ever to win three Olympic gold medals. Page B11.

title: Widow of Alf Landon Dies
description: Theo Cobb Landon, the widow of Gov. Alfred M. Landon of Kansas and the mother of Senator Nancy Landon Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, died on Sunday at her home in Topeka. She was 97.

title: Bosnia War-Crime Tribunal Mustn't Be Flouted
description: To the Editor:

title: Acquisitions at Seagull Energy Expand Its Overseas Presence
description: The Seagull Energy Corporation, an oil and natural gas company with operations primarily along the Texas and Louisiana coasts, announced two transactions today that would expand its presence overseas.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column on July 11 about the auction of an unpublished novel by Francois Mitterrand, the former President of France, who died in January, misstated the sale price. It was $7,600, not $76,000. The report also misstated Mr. Mitterrand's military affiliation and his relationship with Marshal Philippe Petain. He enlisted in the army of France, not the Vichy collaborationist army, which in fact did not exist. After escaping from a German prison in 1941, he assisted the Vichy government of Marshal Petain.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Sprewell Still a Warrior
description: The Golden State Warriors re-signed the free-agent guard LATRELL SPREWELL to a multiyear contract. Terms were not released, although The Oakland Tribune reported that it was a four-year, $30 million deal.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- BOXING;Two More Americans Advance With Ease
description: Coach Al Mitchell compares it to a train slowly building steam. His United States boxers, thought to be more decent than dangerous before the Olympic Games, are 6-0. It is not a cheap 6-0, either.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KEMET REJECTS VISHAY'S OFFER OF MERGER
description: The Vishay Intertechnology Corporation said yesterday that the Kemet Corporation, a rival electronics maker, had rejected its offer to buy Kemet for $22 a share, or about $850 million. Shares of Kemet rose $1.375, to $17.75, in Nasdaq trading, while Vishay shares were unchanged at $18.875 on the New York Stock Exchange. Vishay, based in Malvern, Pa., has been pursuing Kemet, based in Greenville, S.C., since last month, when it suggested a friendly merger without specifying a price. Vishay is the largest American maker of passive electronic components including capacitors. Kemet is the largest American maker of capacitors.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- WEIGHT LIFTING;The Adventures of Hercules Continue
description: Naim Suleymanoglu became the first weight lifter in history to win three gold medals, and he also set a world record, in the 141-pound competition today at the Summer Games.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;A Swimmer Splashes Suspicion
description: THE Olympic motto is, "Citius Altius Fortius." Faster Higher Stronger.

title: In Election Fallout, Hard-Line Russian Communist Is Ousted
description: Viktor I. Anpilov, a leader of the hard-line Communist Workers' Party, and by far its noisiest and best-known member, has been dismissed as first secretary of the Moscow party organization in an internal power struggle that became public today.

title: Woman, 47, Is Held in Husband's Killing
description: Edward Murphy spent much of last weekend caring for his wife as she recovered from surgery at the couple's Brooklyn home. But on Sunday, he told her he was going fishing for a few hours, and put a six-pack of beer into a cooler before taking off.

title: POP REVIEW;Fun House With a Touch Of the Surreal
description: Pere Ubu's stout, ruminating singer, David Thomas, has been referring to Brian Wilson a lot these days. On Friday night at Irving Plaza, introducing a new song, "Beach Boys," Mr. Thomas evoked a "private movie" in which the good guy, Mr. Wilson, is pitted against the bad guys, John Lennon and Paul McCartney. But on closer inspection this preoccupation is nothing new: the lyrics to "My Dark Ages," a thumping anthem from 1978 that the band also performed, are like Mr. Wilson without the delusions: "I don't get around/I don't fall in love much."

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE OVERVIEW;Divers Report Dozens of Bodies in Wreckage of Crash
description: Recovery workers searching the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 found the bodies of dozens of victims of the crash yesterday in a large area of debris on the ocean floor off Long Island.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;South African Deal For Big Timber Holding
description: Mondi Ltd., a South African paper and forest products company, bought HL&H Timber Holdings Ltd. yesterday for 1 billion rand ($227 million), including the assumption of 325.7 million rand in debt.
