Mondi said it had paid 362.8 million rand in cash to Hunt Leuchars & Hepburn Holdings Ltd. for 50 percent of HL&H Timber. It bought the other 50 percent for cash and shares worth 321.7 million rand from Mondi's parent company, the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa. The HL&H Timber operations consist mainly of hardwood forests in South Africa, as well as sawmills and related assets. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;Jim Carrey Oozes Across Screens
description: KAI KRAUSE has been hailed as a "demo god" for his stunning public demonstrations of his powerful professional graphic arts programs. Kai's Power Goo (from Metatools Inc., for Windows 95 and Macintosh, at about $50), his latest design, is his first aimed at a more mainstream audience, including children. Although it received wild applause at early public showings, Goo demonstrates that there is more to software than the way it looks in demonstrations.

title: Not 'Ironic Science'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Young & Rubicam Buys Media Edge
description: Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York has, as expected, acquired Media Edge, the media services unit of N. W. Ayer & Partners in New York, from Adcom Investors Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FIRST USA TO TAKE OVER GENSAR HOLDINGS
description: First USA Paymentech Inc., a credit card transaction processing company, said yesterday that it would buy the closely held Gensar Holdings Inc. for $170 million. First USA Paymentech expects to take a one-time pretax charge of $15 million for costs related to the acquisition of Gensar, a company that handles electronic messages related to credit card transactions. First USA Paymentech, a unit of the credit card issuer First USA Inc. of Dallas, currently depends on outside vendors for many services that the acquisition would allow it to provide in-house. Gensar processes about 300 million transactions a year and provides services to 120,000 merchants nationwide.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Bad Back Has Ended Daugherty's Career
description: BRAD DAUGHERTY, the Cleveland Cavaliers' 7-foot center, confirmed yesterday what had long been expected. His National Basketball Association career is over.

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;Potential Running Mates: Down to About a Dozen
description: Bob Dole has narrowed his list of potential running mates to about a dozen names, a group dominated by governors, officials familiar with the process said today.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: LEGAL FALLOUT;Judge to Ask Bomb Trial Jury About Prejudice From Crash
description: The Federal judge presiding over the terrorism trial of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef agreed yesterday to ask the jurors whether they had been swayed by the torrent of news coverage of the midair explosion of T.W.A. Flight 800.

title: An Elegant Blow to Kitsch
description: The tide is turning on 57th Street. Just yesterday, it seemed, the proliferation of theme stores and restaurants was threatening to reduce this prestigious thoroughfare to a junky outpost of Burbank. But two new projects, next-door neighbors on the north side of 57th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenues, are tilting the balance away from Tinseltown pit stops like Planet Hollywood and the Warner Brothers Studio Store back in the direction of civilized, urbane design.

title: Market Place;A 250-point fall. The Big Board shuts for a half-hour. Then?
description: WHAT would happen if the Dow Jones industrial average fell 250 points one hectic morning?

title: Suspicious Fire at Meeting Hall in Hasidic Village Sets Off an ArsonInquiry
description: A suspicious predawn fire on Sunday destroyed the main meeting hall in a Hasidic village troubled by communal strife, forcing nurses and mothers in an adjacent center to flee with newborn infants through billowing smoke.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Seattle Signs McIlvaine
description: JIM McILVAINE, a 7-1 free agent who was a backup with the Washington Bullets last season, signed a seven-year, $35 million contract with the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Tambrands Puts Account in Review
description: Tambrands Inc., the marketer of Tampax tampons, said yesterday that it had placed in review its worldwide account, which the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group in New York has handled since 1993. Billings were estimated at $65 million.

title: Verisign Security System Is Selected by Visa
description: Visa International Inc. said yesterday that it had chosen Verisign Inc. to verify the identity of credit card users when they make purchases using the Internet.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Springer Posts a Gain For Year's First Half
description: The German publishing company Axel Springer Verlag A.G. said yesterday that its profit rose 12 percent in the six months that ended on June 30, to 80.5 million marks ($54.2 million), from 72 million marks the previous year. Revenue for the period was not reported. Springer said the rise in profit came despite a 26 percent increase in paper costs during the period and worsening advertising trends.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Thorn EMI Profit Up 13% in Quarter
description: Thorn EMI P.L.C. reported yesterday that it had a 13 percent gain in pretax profit in the April-June quarter, led by gains in its Thorn rental unit. Thorn EMI, which is to split up in August, reported a profit of L68 million ($104.6 million), up from L60.1 million. Sales were L1.11 billion ($1.7 billion), up from L1.05 billion.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Sri Lanka Gets Troops To Besieged Army Base
description: Sri Lanka sent reinforcements through a hail of mortar fire today to try to save an army base with 1,200 troops that rebels said they had captured.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE MEDICAL EXAMINER;Pathologists Explain Difficulty of the Task
description: After a Valujet airplane crashed and sank into the Florida Everglades earlier this year, it took two weeks to make positive identifications of the first 13 passengers, and only 57 of the 110 victims have been identified so far.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LONE STAR DECIDES AGAINST SALE OR MERGER
description: Lone Star Industries Inc. said yesterday that it had "terminated conversations with all parties" interested in an affiliation or merger. Lone Star, a maker of construction materials in Stamford, Conn., said it had received "numerous unsolicited expressions of interest" since the start of the year but decided an affiliation or sale would not be in its stockholders' best interests. Lone Star also said it expected to resume open-market purchases of its common stock under a $20 million buyback program announced on Nov. 10, 1995. The company's stock fell 50 cents, to $30.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League BALTIMORE ORIOLES--Recalled LHP Rick Krivda from Rochester of the International League. Placed LHP Arthur Rhodes on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to July 14.

title: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
description: Stocks were higher here today, after Monday's selloff. At the close, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 158.06 points, or three-quarters of 1 percent, at 21,163.69. On Monday, the Nikkei fell 470.66 points.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about victims of the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 referred incorrectly to the residence of Eric and Virginia Holst. They were new to the community of Center Moriches, not to Long Island itself.

title: Why Babies Are Born Facing Backward, Helpless and Chubby
description: CHILDBIRTH: it's a miracle, right? One minute you're standing there, an awkward, frightened and comically proportioned woman, face twisted with the first contractions of labor, uterus lurching to your epiglottis, mind suddenly skeptical that it's feasible to do the pelvic equivalent of expelling a Crenshaw melon through your nostril, and the next minute . . .

title: On My Mind;Invitation To Murder
description: Six months after Pan Am 103 and all aboard were blown up over Scotland in 1988, a commission appointed by President Reagan came to a specific central conclusion about defeating international terrorism and presented it in the first paragraph of its report:

title: Curfews Are for Parents to Set
description: One reason I was able to grow up in the South Bronx of the 1950's and 1960's without getting into major trouble was that I lived under a curfew. The penalty for violating the curfew was swift and severe. Although I got to plead my case -- a watch didn't work, the train was running late -- the judge was seasoned and cynical (she had heard it all before). The usual verdict: guilty. The sentence: confinement to the apartment, when I wasn't at school, for a whole week.

title: It's U.S. Arrogance, Not Values, That Offends
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Adds Hearings to Its Election Arsenal
description: Fresh from Congressional hearings on the Clinton Administration's mishandling of F.B.I. files, which followed hearings on the Clinton Administration and Whitewater, which were preceded by hearings on political skulduggery in the Clinton Administration's travel office, the Republican majority in Congress plans something new.

title: TV Notes;A Chance to Swing the Bat
description: Bill Cosby acknowledged yesterday that he is under enormous pressure to hit a home run with his new comedy series to bring CBS back from the ratings doldrums. But he asked instead only for a chance to "swing the bat."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Harrah's to Expand Casino
description: Yet another company is putting its money on the Atlantic City boom. Harrah's Entertainment said yesterday that it would add 1,500 hotel rooms and 30,000 square feet of casino space to its existing property. Once this $325 million project is completed, Harrah's Atlantic City will have 2,700 rooms -- more than any other hotel in New Jersey, the company said.

title: BASEBALL;Twins Spoil Murray's Return to the Orioles
description: Twins 9, Orioles 5

title: In Egypt, On-Screen Sex Receives Mixed Reviews
description: In this summer's hit movie here, three working women from a poor Cairo neighborhood fret about their meager choice of marriageable louts.

title: Executive Changes
description: CS FIRST BOSTON, New York, rehired John Fitzgerald from Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. as a director specializing in the debt of Canadian borrowers and United States lending agencies. Mr. Fitzgerald, who worked at CS First Boston for four years before joining Lehman in 1993, reports to Scott Ulm and John Romanelli, both managing directors.

title: Observer;Down With All That!
description: It is not true, as commonly believed, that only the young can rebel. The crustiest geezer can pretend he doesn't know how to tie his shoelaces. Any middle-aged drone can pretend he can't tell the front of a baseball cap from the back.

title: Inscription at Philistine City Shows: This Is the Right Place
description: ARCHEOLOGISTS dream of turning over a temple stone and finding an inscription saying this is the place you are looking for. For a team of American and Israeli archeologists, the dream came true early this month.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Capitals Sign Housley
description: PHIL HOUSLEY, one of the National Hockey League's top two-way defensemen with Buffalo and Winnipeg, joined the Washington Capitals yesterday.

title: William Caunitz, 63; Wrote Thrillers Inspired by His Police Career
description: William J. Caunitz, a writer who drew on his experiences as a New York City policeman in "One Police Plaza" and other thrillers, died on Saturday at Sarasota Memorial Hospital in Florida. He was 63 and lived in Longboat Key, Fla.

title: Intel Introduces Phone Software
description: In its quest to make the personal computer an indispensable tool, the Intel Corporation introduced software today that it said would make it easy to place long-distance phone calls over the Internet.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- FENCING;An Italian and a Romanian Go to Head of the Foil Class
description: A couple of aspiring gym teachers who have already mastered the art of fencing dueled their way to the head of the foil class today and took home the ultimate objects for show-and-tell in their respective gymnasiums, the Olympic gold medal in individual foil.

title: I.B.M. Joining With Xylan to Make Switches
description: Struggling to tap into the fast-growing market for networking hardware, I.B.M. plans to announce today that it has entered into a broad alliance with the Xylan Corporation, a network switch maker that was one of the hottest initial public offerings this year.

title: Unisys Officer Goes To Siemens America
description: The chief financial officer of the Unisys Corporation, Edward A. Blechschmidt, resigned today to lead the North and South American computer operations of Siemens A.G. of Germany.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Revenge in Mind and Ax in Hand, Lizzie Borden's Back
description: For 22 years Glimmerglass Opera, nestled idyllically near Otsego Lake in the northern Catskills, has mostly lived up to its mission: to present summer seasons of new or seldom-heard works not from a sense of duty but with a sense of adventure, and to present familiar works in innovative productions.

title: POLITICAL BRIEFING;The Campaigns For Congress
description: North Carolina Outside Money Fuels Helms-Gantt Race

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;New Rules on Child Support
description: Collecting overdue child support got a little easier under new rules announced yesterday by the State Supreme Court. Probation officials can now freeze a delinquent parent's bank account, and a judge can award the other parent as much as the entire amount due. Until now, late child support was usually paid out weekly in small amounts taken from a parent's bank account or paycheck. Parents in New Jersey currently owe a total of about $1 billion in overdue child support, said Daniel Phillips, a research analyst with the Administrative Office of the Courts.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Refugee Lawyer Called Bogus
description: In the last four years, Manuel Gaitan represented about 800 immigrants from Central and South America seeking political asylum, charging them about $1,500 each, the authorities said yesterday. But there was one problem: he is not a lawyer. Last Thursday, Mr. Gaitan, 56, of Jersey City, was arrested and charged with the unauthorized practice of law, said Charles R. Buckley, the Acting Prosecutor for Bergen County. He was caught when an officer for the Immigration and Naturalization Service became suspicious and contacted the New Jersey State Bar Association, Mr. Buckley said. Lori Nessel, director of the immigration clinic at the Seton Hall Center for Social Justice, said the case showed "how desperate people without legal immigration status are."

title: Q&A
description: Sense of Direction

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE AIRLINE;For Executive, Pressure to Give Answers When There Aren't Any
description: Yesterday began as one more frustrating day for Jeffrey H. Erickson, the 51-year-old chief executive of Trans World Airlines.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- BASKETBALL;Angola Is Closing the Gap On Dream Team . . . Slowly
description: The last time they met, the futility of the Angola basketball team and the bullying tactics of Charles Barkley came to represent the arrogance and power of American professionals. Tonight, with smiles replacing angry elbows, Angola's progress was more dramatic than the Dream Team's control.

title: SUNY Cuts Hospital Funds To Retain Tuition Levels
description: Faced with a budget gap of $47 million, the trustees of the State University of New York voted yesterday to cut the state subsidy to the system's three hospitals by about $24 million rather than raise tuition or reduce the amount they will be able to spend on undergraduate education.

title: HORSE RACING;Fans Scarce as Belmont Wraps Up for Summer
description: Belmont Park ended its summer season yesterday with continuing signs of its arrival into racing's simulcast era. There were expected drops in attendance and betting at the track -- only 7,777 attended yesterday's closing program -- but overall gains in television betting around the country.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: GST TELECOMMUNICATION INC., Vancouver, British Columbia, a telecommunications network operator, reached a preliminary agreement to acquire Call America Business Communications Corp. of San Luis Obispo, Calif., a reseller of long-distance services, for $16 million in stock.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- BASEBALL;South Korea Loses to U.S.
description: The United States defeated South Korea, 7-2, tonight at Fulton County Stadium in a game marked by sloppy play and losers' distress at the home plate umpire, Jose Reyes of Mexico.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Friday comparing Fiat's strategies for selling cars worldwide with those of the Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation misstated 1995 sales for G.M. The company sold 4.9 million vehicles in the United States, 1.67 million in Western Europe and 1.76 million in the rest of the world.

title: Arkansas Banker Testifies in Own Defense
description: An Arkansas banker charged in the second trial brought by the Whitewater independent counsel's office took the witness stand today and denied that he had conspired with Bill Clinton's 1990 campaign for governor to conceal large cash withdrawals.

title: Envoy's Nomination Begs Vietnam Issue
description: The Clinton Administration thought it had a perfect candidate for the new post of Ambassador to Vietnam: a Congressman and onetime prisoner of war whose record would help him pass through the needle's eye of Senator Jesse Helms's Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Korean War Memorial Set
description: Before a roomful of grateful veterans of the Korean War, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed a bill yesterday establishing the Korean Veterans' Memorial Committee and providing $25,000 in seed money. The committee will select a site for the memorial and raise funds to build it. The state's Vietnam Veterans' Memorial opened last year, but many veterans of the earlier conflict, which took the lives of more than 800 New Jerseyans, complained that they had been forgotten.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Americans Given Option Of Leaving Saudi Arabia
description: Four weeks after a bombing in Saudi Arabia killed 19 American servicemen, the State Department today authorized the departure of Saudi-based dependents of American military and civilian employees.

title: Corrections
description: A review of Connecticut art exhibitions in Weekend on July 12 misspelled the given name of a poet participating in "No Doubt: African-American Art of the 90's," which runs through Sept. 1 at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield. The poet is Tish Benson, not Trish.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;DePaul Refuses Fields
description: RONNIE FIELDS, one of the nation's top high school basketball players, has been denied admission to DePaul University after failing to meet academic requirements.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRECISION CASTPARTS BUYS AE TURBINE COMPONENTS
description: The Precision Castparts Corporation of Portland, Ore., said yesterday that it had bought the assets of AE Turbine Components Ltd. from T & N P.L.C. of Britain for $63.6 million in cash. AE Turbine makes turbine blades and castings for aircraft-engine and gas-turbine manufacturers. Precision Castparts makes castings for the aerospace, automotive and medical industries. Shares of Precision Castparts rose $1.50, to $40.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. T & N, an auto parts maker, said it sold AE Turbine because it did not fit with T & N's other operations.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Drug Money for Gun Checks
description: Two Democratic lawmakers are drafting legislation that would set aside money confiscated during drug arrests to help municipalities track gun sales to minors, a spokesman for the Assembly Minority Office said yesterday. The bill, sponsored by Assemblymen Neil M. Cohen of Elizabeth and Joseph J. Roberts Jr. of Brooklawn, would provide a total of $250,000 for 30 high-crime cities and towns to buy computer equipment so they can tap into a state police gun-tracking system. The information would help the authorities go after people who supply weapons to juveniles, said the spokesman, Joe Donnelly.

title: Vermont Royster, 82, Pulitzer-Winning Editor
description: Vermont Royster, a former editor of The Wall Street Journal who won two Pulitzer Prizes and helped to shape his newspaper into the country's leading business daily, died yesterday in a retirement community in Raleigh, N.C., The Journal said. He was 82.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 4 -- GYMNASTICS;Russians Dazzle And Take The Gold
description: The record book will show that Russia won its first Olympic gymnastics gold medal in the team competition tonight.

title: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS;Zimbabwe Lifts Ban On Gay Group at Fair
description: Zimbabwe said today that it would allow a homosexual organization to take part in an international book fair, reversing a ban last year that was condemned worldwide.

title: It's U.S. Arrogance, Not Values, That Offends;Who Handles Security?
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Put .500 Mark on Their Priority List
description: The Mets were caught looking too far in front of themselves this weekend. And when that happens, there is usually a price to pay.

title: U.S. Warns U.N. on Campaigning for Post
description: The Clinton Administration threatened today to take action against the United Nations and any employees found to be campaigning for the re-election of Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali at the organization's expense.

title: Mandela's Successor Skillful But Lacks a Common Touch
description: At a Youth Day rally outside Durban recently, the stage was filled with African National Congress officials dressed in bright African fabrics and sports shirts. The sun was hot, music was playing and with a certain regularity, party officials revved up the crowd -- mostly the very poor from a nearby township -- into chanting, "Viva A.N.C.!"

title: Stocks Continue Their Decline, Heightening Investor Concern
description: The relief investors felt last week was short-lived as stocks declined yesterday for the second consecutive trading session, heightening concerns that the worst may not be over.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Norsk Hydro Reports 28% Drop in Net
description: Norsk Hydro A.S., Norway's biggest industrial company, reported yesterday that its profit had dropped 28 percent in the quarter that ended on June 30 because of higher taxes on its oil business and sharply lower profits from metals and petrochemicals. Norsk Hydro said it earned 1.41 billion kroner ($220 million) in the quarter, down from 1.95 billion kroner a year earlier. Revenue was 21.6 billion kroner ($3.37 billion), up from 20.3 billion kroner.

title: Rostenkowski Enters Prison (and Hospital)
description: Former Representative Dan Rostenkowski, once one of the most powerful men in Washington, entered a prison hospital today to begin serving a 17-month sentence for mail fraud.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;UNION CARBIDE CORP. (UK,N)
description: The Union Carbide Corporation reported a 24 percent drop in second-quarter profits yesterday, citing falling prices for one of its key chemical products, ethylene glycol.

title: Suburbia Can't Kick the Nozzle;As Gas Guzzling Becomes a Way of Life, Oil Imports Soar
description: Like most residents of this fast-growing bedroom community 20 miles north of Albany, Janet Mulvey cannot do anything away from home without first hopping into one of the cars in her driveway.

title: Trial Run for Court Cameras
description: Hoping to increase chances for an impartial jury, the Federal courts in February moved the forthcoming bombing trial of Timothy McVeigh and Terry Nichols from Oklahoma City to Denver. That transfer created a hardship for families and victims of the April 1995 explosion who wanted to attend the trial. Then, last week, the trial judge ruled that the Denver proceedings could be transmitted by closed-circuit television to a limited audience in the Oklahoma City courthouse.

title: Officials Offer Expanded Plans to Rebuild Columbus Circle
description: New York City and state officials yesterday outlined their most comprehensive approach yet to rebuilding Columbus Circle, home to some of the city's most valuable real estate and some of its most reviled architecture.

title: Fixing the Reform Party
description: Ross Perot's new Reform Party has gotten off to a peculiar start in its crusade to open up the political process. It is choosing a Presidential candidate by mail-in vote, and only one of the two candidates has a copy of the list of voters.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF SCIENTIFIC GAMES HOLDINGS DROP 32 PERCENT
description: The stock of the Scientific Games Holdings Corporation skidded more than 32 percent yesterday, after the company, a lottery-ticket maker, warned of a slowdown over the coming months. The company, based in Alpharetta, Ga., cited lower prices because of competition in the lottery industry and sluggish international sales for its prediction of "moderate growth" in the next few quarters. On Monday, after the market closed, the company reported earnings for the period ended June 30 that were in line with Wall Street's expectations. Scientific Games' stock slipped $9.625 yesterday, to $19.625, in Nasdaq trading of almost 1.7 million shares.

title: 85 Million For Payton
description: Gary Payton, a member of the United States Olympic basketball team, has received a contract to stay in Seattle. The 28-year-old guard re-signed with the SuperSonics today, agreeing to a seven-year, $85 million contract.

title: Utility Shuts Atom Plant, Last of Four To Be Closed
description: Northeast Utilities shut down its Connecticut Yankee generating plant on Monday because of safety concerns, leaving Connecticut with none of its four nuclear power plants operating and increasing the risk of blackouts during a heat wave.

title: New Editorial Board Member
description: Tina Rosenberg, an author and winner of the Pulitzer Prize for general nonfiction this year for her book "The Haunted Land: Facing Europe's Ghosts After Communism," has joined the editorial board of The New York Times. Her appointment was announced by Howell Raines, editorial page editor.

title: About Real Estate;Alcoa Vacating Its Downtown Pittsburgh Landmark
description: A corporate restructuring at the Aluminum Company of America has brought with it a decision to relinquish the company's 31-story aluminum headquarters building in downtown Pittsburgh, a landmark on the city's skyline since its construction in 1952.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;South African Plans a Casino
description: A Bahamas company run by a South African gambling executive, Sol Kerzner, has joined the stampede to build in Atlantic City. Sun International Hotels Ltd., which owns 32 hotels, casinos and resorts in South Africa, the Bahamas, France and elsewhere, applied to the Casino Control Commission yesterday for a casino license. The company said it wanted to build a $700 million resort with 2,000 rooms in the city's South Inlet. MGM Grand Inc., based in Las Vegas, Nev., has announced plans to build a $700 million resort in the same part of town. A hearing on MGM's license application is set for today.

title: BASEBALL;Gooden's Arm Shows Plenty Of Life
description: What a drag. That's what Dwight Gooden's arm had been, drooping by his side like a snow-covered branch, overburdened from his first season since 1994.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;Lee Denies Accusations
description: ROBERT LEE, the International Boxing Federation president, is being investigated by Federal officials on charges that he accepted payoffs in exchange for fixing boxers' rankings, The New York Post reported yesterday. The report said the promoter BOB ARUM was given immunity for his testimony, which said he paid Lee to rig the ratings, used to determine which fighters get title shots.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HORIZON MENTAL HEALTH BUYS DAY TREATMENT CENTERS
description: Horizon Mental Health Management Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy American Day Treatment Centers Inc. for $16.5 million in a stock swap. Horizon, which is based in Denton, Tex., a manager of mental-health programs, has proposed swapping 717,213 shares of its common stock for all of the closely held Annapolis, Md., company's shares. Horizon shares fell 50 cents yesterday, to close at $22.25, in Nasdaq trading. American Day, an operator of 22 centers for treating mental and emotional disorders, had revenues of $13.9 million and a loss of $250,000 for the six months ended June 30.

title: World News Briefs;Congressman Remains Pick as Vietnam Envoy
description: The Clinton Administration is going ahead with the nomination of a Florida Congressman as Ambassador to Vietnam after lawyers concluded that the appointment does not violate the Constitution, the State Department said today.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: VOICES;Far Away, Expressing Anxiety
description: A thousand miles from the misery, a sign outside an old stone church reminds neighbors: "Pray for the families of the TWA plane crash victims."

title: Foreign Affairs;Russia's NATO Fax
description: While in Moscow for the elections, I requested an interview with Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov. I was politely told that Mr. Primakov rarely granted interviews, but would answer questions in writing. So I submitted questions, waited several days, never heard back and assumed that was the end of the matter. Well, the other day the fax lit up and, lo and behold, over came Mr. Primakov's answers -- including an intriguing hint that Russia might be ready to consider a "compromise" on NATO expansion.

title: Hospice Care Often Starts Too Late
description: Terminally ill patients who enroll in hospices die a more comfortable and less expensive death, but patients often do not enroll soon enough to take full advantage of the benefits, researchers have found.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Rider, Then Anderson, Join the Trail Blazers
description: The Portland Trail Blazers signed point guard KENNY ANDERSON, a free agent, yesterday, capping a hectic day of deal making that saw eight players change teams and three others turned loose.

title: Infection Sickens Whitman
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman said today that she is being treated for what her doctor believes is a tick-borne blood infection, possibly Lyme disease. She underwent a test today, hoping for a definitive diagnosis.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Earnings Leap at Allstate but Are Off at American General
description: The Allstate Corporation said yesterday that its net income rose 47.2 percent in the second quarter, primarily because of a strong increase in the collection of premiums.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on May 10 about Serge Chermayeff, former head of the Harvard and Yale architecture departments, attributed the design of the Bexhill Pavilion in England incompletely. It was a joint effort by Mr. Chermayeff and Erich Mendelsohn, who shared an architectural practice in London in the 1930's. A reader's letter dated May 10, pointing out the error, was lost, and another letter, dated June 18, was delayed in routing at The Times.

title: FOOTBALL;Nebraska Bans N.F.L. Scouts
description: Coach Tom Osborne has told the National Football League that he will not allow scouts on the Nebraska campus this season for a "combination of things," including the drafting and release of the former lineman Christian Peter by the New England Patriots, who cited his criminal behavior.

title: Political Newcomer Wins Plum Role at a Convention
description: Jeannie Rhoads signed up for her campus Young Republicans Club, but it never had any meetings.

title: Ex-College President Enters a Guilty Plea
description: The man who resigned as president of the University of South Carolina six years ago amid allegations of excessive spending has pleaded guilty to bankruptcy fraud.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ROBERT DOWNEY Jr., unshaven and handcuffed, pleaded not guilty to drug and gun charges in Malibu, Calif., on Monday, and a judge set bail at $100,000 on the condition that the actor check into a drug rehabilitation center.

title: Our Towns;Time Passes, But the Pain Never Fades
description: SUSAN COHEN watched the mourners toss single roses into the sea, heard a reporter talk about "a sense of closure," and turned off her television, shuddering with sadness and disgust.

title: U.S. JUDGE UPSETS RULES ON RUNNING JAILS IN NEW YORK
description: Responding to a plea from the administration of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Federal judge yesterday struck down a series of legally binding agreements that have governed living conditions in New York City's jails for nearly two decades.

title: Casino County
description: Congress has passed legislation to create a commission to examine the rapidly expanding gambling industry, and President Clinton has said he will sign it. All this comes not a day too soon. It's too bad, in fact, that the commission wasn't in place before the casinos came to Tunica County.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- SWIMMING;Rouse Exorcises the Ghosts of Barcelona
description: Four years ago, Jeff Rouse of the United States stood on the medal podium after a crushing defeat in the Olympic 100-meter backstroke and vowed that he would keep swimming until he won the gold medal. In defeat, he would find indomitable resolve for victory.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: ATLANTA: DAY;OLYMPIC DIARY
description: There will be no executions on Georgia's death row during the Olympic Games. Even though at least one inmate has run out of appeals and hope, state officials did not schedule any deaths by electrocution while the eyes of the world are on the host city, human rights advocates said.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;MONSANTO CO. (MTC,N)
description: The Monsanto Company said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 26 percent, which was stronger than expected, on increased sales of its agricultural products and drugs.

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;Dole at Ease In Preparing A Film View Of the Man
description: Bob Dole spent his day today making memories to share with the country next month at the Republican convention in San Diego.

title: Clinton Will Sign Bill on Taxpayers' Rights
description: President Clinton is preparing to sign legislation offering new help to taxpayers who battle the Internal Revenue Service, including a clause that would force the agency to pick up the lawyers' bills in many tax-collection suits that it loses.

title: POLITICS: THE AD CAMPAIGN;House G.O.P. Mounts a Drive To Buttress Besieged Members
description: House Republicans today announced a new television advertising campaign to promote their legislative record and assist their most vulnerable colleagues, battered by a months-old broadcast attack by the Democrats and organized labor.

title: World News Briefs;U.N. Aide Denies Staff Assists Re-election Bid
description: A United Nations aide said today that allegations by the United States that United Nations staff members and resources were being used to help Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali win another term was a "disgraceful disinformation campaign."

title: Market Place;Tandy's history of unkept promises worries analysts.
description: When the Tandy Corporation announced last Thursday that its second-quarter earnings had declined 37 percent, largely as a result of poor performance at its Incredible Universe and Computer City stores, its stock nonetheless popped up $2.50, to $42.75.

title: Disney in Pact for Films of the Top Animator in Japan
description: The Walt Disney Company may be the world's most famous producer of animated films, but in Japan, it is Hayao Miyazaki who reigns supreme. The full-length movies produced by Japan's greatest animator routinely outdraw Disney films like "Aladdin" and "The Lion King" at the box office here.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Salomon Inc. Earnings Are Stronger Than Expectations
description: Salomon Inc. yesterday reported surprisingly strong earnings for the second quarter, as revenue from bond trading and investment banking surged.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PAINE WEBBER CLASS ACTION SETTLEMENT APPROVED
description: A Federal judge has approved a settlement estimated to be worth $200 million in a class-action lawsuit against Paine Webber Inc. related to its sale of limited partnerships. Paine Webber Group Inc., the parent company of the brokerage, said the settlement would not cost it anything more than the reserves it had already set aside. The settlement provides $125 million in cash and additional guarantees valued at $75 million, according to Nicholas Chimicles, the lawyer who headed a committee of law firms that represented 150,000 disgruntled investors. The value of the guarantees could change as the value of the partnerships fluctuate. Paine Webber guaranteed that some of the plaintiffs would get their original investments back by the year 2000. It guaranteed for others, depending on which partnership they had invested in, minimum payments by the same year. Paine Webber will pay the $125 million in cash to those who had invested in partnerships without guarantees, Mr. Chimicles said. Paine Webber brokers sold about $2.5 billion in real estate, energy and other limited partnerships between 1980 and 1992. Investors contended the brokers misrepresented the risks involved, used fraudulent marketing materials and collected inflated fees. In January, Paine Webber said it had agreed to pay $292.5 million to settle client claims.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- ROUNDUP;MEN'S SOCCER: Italy Stunned and Falls to 0-2
description: Ghana's Christian Sabah connected twice and eliminated perennial powerhouse Italy from the Olympic soccer tournament in a hot-tempered, foul-filled game last night at R.F.K. Stadium in Washington. Sabah sent in blistering shots from 23 and 20 yards as the 1992 bronze medalists capitalized on a second-half ejection in a 3-2 victory.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Pepsico Earnings Rise 20%, Meeting Analyst Predictions
description: Pepsico Inc. reported strength in its worldwide snack business, its domestic soft-drink system and its international fast-food restaurant operations yesterday, in a second-quarter performance that analysts said could enable the company to return to its traditional double-digit earnings growth by the end of the year.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- BOXING;First Loss, to a Cuban, Makes U.S. Take Notice
description: For all the promise of its unbeaten start, the United States boxing team finally traded blows with reality today. The image of a fighter from Cuba raining punches off the headgear of one of their own told the Americans much about their road to Olympic gold:

title: CHRONICLE
description: Students taking a course called Topics in Urban Education Policy at Teachers College this fall can be confident their instructor hasn't been sequestered in an ivory tower.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;In Old Japan, Human Horror and Nature's Revenge
description: SHIPWRECKS By Akira Yoshimura Translated by Mark Ealey. 180 pages. Harcourt Brace. $21.

title: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;G.O.P. Leaders Seeks Tax Cuts Wide in Scope
description: With Presidential politics and Congressional races both clearly in mind, the Republican leadership on Capitol Hill called today for a program of broad tax cuts, raising the pressure on Bob Dole to follow suit as he formulates his own economic platform.

title: Newspaper Takes a $1.3 Million Charge
description: The Providence Journal Company said today that it had taken a $1.3 million charge in the second quarter because more employees than expected accepted voluntary severance packages. The charge follows one of $1.1 million taken in the first quarter, also because of the severance program, and $6.8 million in restructuring costs taken in the fourth quarter of 1995 in anticipation of the job cuts in the publishing division.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;U.S.-Japan Trade Talks To Resume This Week
description: The United States and Japan will resume talks this week in Vancouver, British Columbia, on access to the Japanese markets for insurance services and semiconductor products, Tokyo said yesterday. President Clinton and Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto agreed last month to end the talks by July 31.

title: Jessica Mitford, Incisive Critic of American Ways and a BritishUpbringing, Dies at 78
description: Correction Appended

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Bounces Back on News From Germany and Japan
description: The dollar shrugged off a drop in Wall Street stocks yesterday, as currency traders took heart from growing prospects of lower interest rates in Germany and receding fears of higher rates in Japan.

title: Robert Wilentz, 69, New Jersey Chief Justice, Dies; Court Aided Women and the Poor
description: Robert N. Wilentz, who in 17 years as Chief Justice of the New Jersey Supreme Court tried to streamline the state courts, make them more accessible and use them to promote his vision of social progress and equality, died yesterday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 69.

title: Auto Workers May Pick G.M. As Target in Contract Talks
description: Top officials at the United Automobile Workers are having second thoughts about their plans to choose the Chrysler Corporation as the target for labor talks this autumn and are considering the General Motors Corporation instead, people close to the union and G.M. said today.

title: A Family 'Disaster' As One-Woman Theater
description: My father is starting to look more and more like somebody's gardener," the performance artist Sandra Tsing Loh says of her Chinese father in "Aliens in America," now playing at the Second Stage Theater. He has "old eyes slitted wearily," Ms. Loh says, scrunching her face up in a caricature of Chinese features, eyes squinting, chin jutting out. "He's the sort of person one would refer to as 'Old Dragon Whiskers.' '

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Haselrig to Stand Trial
description: The former Pittsburgh Steelers offensive lineman CARLTON HASELRIG has been ordered to stand trial on drunken driving and related charges in Johnstown, Pa.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;College Plans New Ball Field
description: Even after winning Division 3 national championships in 1987 and 1993 and reaching the N.C.A.A. eastern regional finals the last three years, Montclair State University's baseball team still plays on a field hemmed in by campus buildings and with bleacher seating for just 200 fans.

title: T.W.A. Workers Resent Giuliani's 'Posturing'
description: To the Editor:

title: Plan Developed By White House To Clear Harbor In New York
description: The Clinton Administration has devised a plan for dredging and disposing of toxic-contaminated sediments that are building up on the bottom of New York Harbor and threatening to choke off shipping, Administration officials said today.

title: BASEBALL;Twice, Henry Undoes Good That Hitters Do
description: You would think scoring six runs in an inning of two games would be enough to ensure a pair of victories. But those two rallies weren't enough to keep the Mets from being swept in a day-night doubleheader against the Colorado Rockies today at Coors Field.

title: FOOTBALL;ABC Deal Locks Up Bowl Game for No. 1
description: ABC Sports moved yesterday to guarantee an annual college football national championship game on its network for seven years by uniting the Rose Bowl and three other bowl games in an estimated $500 million deal that will begin with the 1998 post-season. The deal takes effect when the current three-year bowl alliance deal shared by ABC and CBS Sports expires.

title: Heinz to Close Utah Plant
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said today that it would close a Budget Gourmet plant in Clearfield, Utah, by the end of September, dismissing about 350 workers to cut production costs at its Weight Watchers Gourmet Food Company. Heinz, based here, closed a Budget Gourmet plant in Atlanta in January and said earlier that a second plant would be closed after its $200 million acquisition of All American Gourmet in 1994.

title: Justice Dept. Drops Packwood Inquiry
description: The Justice Department will not prosecute former Senator Bob Packwood over accusations that he altered his diaries to obstruct an investigation into sexual and official misconduct, his lawyers said.

title: Advertising;The Olympics start to look more and more like the Super Bowl.
description: HIS just in from the BBDOlympics: Visa Gold, Centrum Silver, Clinique Bronze Gel.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- NOTEBOOK;A Breach in Security Is Revealed by Officials
description: Even as problems with technology and transportation continued to plague the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games, the revelation that an armed man had made his way into the opening ceremonies led to sharp questioning today about security here.

title: Start Budget Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Congress Passes Sanctions Against Iran and Libya Trade Setting up another conflict with America's trading partners, Congress approved legislation that would require the President to impose sanctions on foreign companies that invest heavily in Iran and Libya.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;A Shake-Up of Management At Bay Networks Is Expected
description: A management shake-up may be imminent at Bay Networks Inc., a computer network equipment maker that reported earnings below analysts' expectations.

title: A Major Step for Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
description: The United States and Russia agreed today to press for international ratification of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty though they said it does not fully satisfy either of them.

title: EATING WELL;Hold the Mayo: The Mega-Bar Is Here
description: DON'T talk to me," the guy in the blue work pants and shirt said as he rushed around the hot-food section at Pranzo in Manhattan one day last week. "They've got stuffed cabbage today!"

title: Let a Microwave at That Cutting Board
description: A NEW use for the microwave: cleaning sponges and cutting boards.

title: HOCKEY: NOTEBOOK;Berg Will Be Back, but Will Kurri?
description: The Ranger puzzle, built around Mark Messier and Wayne Gretzky, is still missing a few pieces. But one fell into place yesterday and another might not be far behind.

title: France Seizes a Spanish Basque Rebel Leader
description: The French police arrested the chief of weapons and logistics of the Basque separatist group E.T.A. today at a farmhouse in southwest France, Spanish officials said.

title: All Chefs Cook. Now Let's Talk 4-Minute Miles.
description: THERE was a day when the quality of a chef's cooking was considered to be in direct proportion to his or her girth. Just think of the profiles of Paul Prudhomme, Paul Bocuse, Michel Richard and the late James Beard.

title: World News Briefs;Lightning at Palace Misses Royal Family
description: A lightning bolt slightly injured two women at a Buckingham Palace garden party today, knocking them to the ground and burning their skin.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- ROUNDUP;FIELD HOCKEY: Controversial Call Costs the U.S.
description: A goal wiped out by an official's call helped hand the United States women's team its first loss of the Olympics last night, a setback in its quest for the first American field hockey medal in 12 years.

title: Saks and Isetan Plan to Bid for Barney's
description: The suitors for Barneys New York are beginning to flirt openly.

title: New Executive At Times Co.
description: Donald S. Schneider, a lawyer and longtime personnel executive, is joining The New York Times Company as senior vice president for human resources.

title: Church Leaders Split on Plan for School Prayer Amendment
description: Deeply divided religious leaders clashed today over a House Republican plan to amend the Constitution to permit organized prayer in public schools.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- BEACH VOLLEYBALL;America's New Olympians Find a Place in the Sand
description: Two hundred and thirty miles from the nearest beach, the best beach volleyball players in the world took a giant step toward respectability today by introducing the Olympics to a sport often maligned for its associations with light beer and even lighter bathing suits.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- ROUNDUP;MEN'S VOLLEYBALL: For Home Crowd, It's Payback Time
description: The United States team showed Argentina what it can do when it has a cheering, flag-waving crowd on its side, sweeping Argentina by 15-7, 15-8, 15-11 at the University of Georgia to improve to 2-0.

title: Corrections
description: A map in Science Times yesterday with an article about archeologists' excavation of the Philistine city of Ekron misidentified the body of water northeast of Arabia. It is the Persian Gulf, not the Caspian Sea. The map also understated the extent of the Neo-Assyrian empire of the seventh century B.C. It included Egypt and Cyprus.

title: Behind Americans' Love of Bottled Water
description: All water is not created equal, nor are the taste buds of the people who drink it. For every S. Pellegrino lover, there is a Perrier person; for every jogging Bill Clinton cradling a bottle of Mountain Valley, there is a Princess of Wales exiting her gym clutching Evian. And for every municipality with ready access to crystal clear, cryptosporidium-free water, there is another city with its water literally going down the drain.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-12

title: COMPANY NEWS;WEYERHAEUSER SELLING MILLS AND FORESTS IN OREGON
description: The Weyerhaeuser Company agreed yesterday to sell some mills and 600,000 acres of Eastern Oregon forest land to U.S. Timberlands for $309 million. The sale includes hardboard, particleboard and plywood manufacturing plants at Klamath Falls, Ore., and nursery and seed orchard facilities. U.S. Timberlands said it would sell the manufacturing plants to Collins Products and concentrate on managing the timberland. Weyerhaeuser employs 700 people in Klamath Falls. An earlier deal to sell the holdings to the Roseburg Forest Products Company collapsed early this year. The deal is the first for U.S. Timberlands, a limited partnership based in Bandon, Ore., and New York City.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Magic Signs Evans
description: The Orlando Magic signed its first-round draft selection, BRIAN EVANS, yesterday to a three-year contract worth $1.58 million. Evans, a forward from Indiana, was drafted 27th over all by Orlando. He is scheduled to undergo surgery today in Orlando, Fla., to repair a dislocated right shoulder. (AP)

title: Sweatshops Contribute to Global Wage Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: A Plan to Deepen New York Harbor
description: The Clinton Administration has devised a plan for dredging and disposing of toxic sediments that are threatening to choke off shipping in New York Harbor, Administration officials said. They said they hoped the arrangement, worked out in months of negotiations with environmental groups and shipping interests, would resolve disputes that had virtually paralyzed dredging operations because of concerns over where to put the contaminated sediments.

title: CHRONICLE
description: PAULA YATES, the British television personality and former wife of BOB GELDOF, the Irish rock star, certainly has a knack for naming children.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about payments from Gov. George E. Pataki's transition and inaugural fund to members of his administration misstated a response from his director of communications, Zenia Mucha. She said that she had received payments to help compensate her for having lost five months in accumulated vacation time from the Federal Government; she did not say five weeks.

title: GOLf
description: New York State Open

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- TENNIS;Agassi and Seles Do Their Things
description: Andre Agassi complained about the tenacity of Atlanta's mosquitoes. Monica Seles confessed not only to asking for Muhammad Ali's autograph, but to trying to copy his footwork.

title: BOXING;Garden Will Be Put to Test
description: Buster Mathis Jr. and Lou Savarese are boxers with a lot to prove. Madison Square Garden, the arena where their fight will be held next month, has a lot to prove, too.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Treasuries Up On Soft Retail Indicators
description: Prices of Treasury securities rebounded from early lows yesterday to close higher on a combination of factors, including a weak stock market, neutral remarks by the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and softness in retail-industry indicators.

title: Spanish Journalist Has Impartial Record
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Acquittal in Odd Drug Case
description: When Matthew Jack of Plainfield got into a minor auto accident in Montgomery Township in February 1995, the police found something in his wallet that looked like a bouillon cube and contained the hallucinogen bufotenine. Mr. Jack, 31, an unemployed metal worker from Guyana, was charged with drug possession, but he claimed that the cube was "Black Stone," an over-the-counter product that is used to delay ejaculation.

title: Sports of The Times;Strug Took Her Chances For the Gold
description: IN the old war movies, which were always about men, the American platoon always had a hero who took the hit on the last patrol but carried the flag up the hill anyway.

title: FILM REVIEW;Fighting for the Oppressed In a Totalitarian Canada
description: As champions of democracy and the beleaguered go, Johnny Shortwave will make no one forget Robin Hood or Winston Churchill.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Daimler Announces Fewer Job Cuts at Airbus
description: Daimler-Benz Aerospace A.G. of Germany, a subsidiary of Daimler-Benz A.G., said yesterday that it would cut 3,300 jobs at its Airbus unit, a smaller total than it had announced earlier.

title: WEIGHT LIFTING: World Records Are Set by Chinese
description: Zhan Xugang of China broke the world record in winning the Olympic gold medal in the 154 1/4-pound weight lifting division with a combined effort of 788 pounds. Zhan, 22, also set world records in the snatch at 358 pounds and the clean and jerk at 429 3/4 pounds. Kim Myong-Nam of North Korea had set the records in all three categories at a meet in April. Kim won the silver medal with a total of 760 1/2 pounds. (AP)

title: SENATE APPROVES SWEEPING CHANGE IN WELFARE POLICY;BIG ROLE TO STATES
description: The Senate approved a comprehensive welfare bill today that would end the longstanding Federal guarantee of cash assistance for the nation's poorest children and give states vast new power to run their own welfare and work programs with lump sums of Federal money.

title: Goldman to Acquire a Unit of J. E. Robert
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company has agreed to buy a unit of the J. E. Robert Companies, a firm that has been a partner with Goldman in some 37 real estate investments worth more than $8.7 billion.

title: Canal Plus Says It Joins TV Talks
description: The French pay television company Canal Plus said today that along with Rupert Murdoch it was participating in talks involving Bertelsmann and Kirch, two German media companies, about digital television in Germany.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- SHOOTING;17-Year-Old Turns Clay Pigeons to Gold
description: She was only 10 years old then, but she was in South Africa on safari with her parents, three years after she had begun shooting wild doves in the desert around Yuma, Ariz.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Docks de France Agrees To Takeover by Auchan
description: The French retailer Docks de France S.A. succumbed yesterday to a sweetened takeover offer worth nearly $4 billion from a rival, Auchan S.A., after the company raised the offer price to 1,270 francs a share from 1,250. The bid values Docks at 19.4 billion francs ($3.84 billion).

title: Chase Manhattan Will Offer Discounted A.T.M. Accounts
description: Bank customers who swear off using tellers will get a break from the Chase Manhattan Bank after its merger with Chemical Bank is completed over the Labor Day weekend.

title: Swimming in a Media Pool
description: CHATHAM, N.J.

title: Head of Philadelphia Schools Faces Battles on All Fronts
description: The last school board meeting of the summer had been billed as a sleeper, a quick rubber-stamping of budget details and a welcome half hour of predictability for David W. Hornbeck, whose brief tenure as Philadelphia's school superintendent has been marked by a maze of crises, including a recent threat by a local judge to throw him in jail.

title: INSIDE
description: Chief Justice Wilentz Dies

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE FAMILIES;As Shock Turns to Anger, Friction Arises Among Mourners
description: It was late Saturday night, and Shelagh Winter, a friend of one of the victims of T.W.A. Flight 800, could no longer bear the shouting and finger-pointing inside the crowded ballroom of the Ramada Plaza Hotel.

title: A.C.L.U. Sees Unequal Education, But . . .;Girls Deserve Help
description: To the Editor:

title: Sri Lanka Rebels Said to Seize Army Camp
description: The Sri Lankan armed forces sent in reinforcements today to try to regain control of a strategic military base that has been under assault by Tamil rebels in one of the fiercest battles of the 13-year separatist war.

title: Personal Health
description: ANGELICA Divinagracia of Van Nuys, Calif., tapes her foot every night before bed and again before teaching her thrice-weekly step classes. Richard Erde of Brooklyn got custom-made orthotic devices for his tennis shoes and sleeps on his stomach with his feet hanging over the end of the bed. Both are trying to reduce the strain on a much-talked-about tissue in the foot -- the plantar fascia -- that few Americans had even heard of before being bitten by the fitness bug. The painful problem that Angelica, Richard and many thousands of runners and others share is called plantar fasciitis (faa-she-EYE-tis).

title: T.W.A. Workers Resent Giuliani's 'Posturing'
description: To the Editor:

title: Journal;Cybernews Is No News
description: When the news first broke about T.W.A. flight 800, I did what any self-respecting American would do: glued myself to the TV. As a cable subscriber, I now had the added inducement of two all-disaster-all-the-time channels to surf between -- CNN and the spanking new MSNBC. Your cable box may not offer MSNBC yet, but surely you've seen the oppressively chic, laptop-laden promos. It's the future, it's the revolution, it's the Internet!

title: Foreigners Investing In Libya or in Iran Face U.S. Sanctions
description: Setting up another conflict with United States trading partners, Congress today approved legislation that would require the President to impose sanctions on foreign companies that invest heavily in Iran or Libya.

title: Likud Hard-Liner, in a First, Sees Arafat
description: Israel's new Foreign Minister, David Levy, held talks for the first time today with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, in a sign that a partnership fractured by the elections in May may be on its way to a slow mend.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- BASKETBALL;Bolton's 2d-Half Barrage Lifts U.S.
description: After all the months of work and all the years of waiting, this was not the time for Ruthie Bolton's left knee to become useless. She had stepped on the leg of an opponent near the end of a game in Vancouver on June 7, the 49th of 52 games on the worldwide tour of the United States women's basketball team. The opening ceremonies were six weeks away. A ligament was stretched. She thought the worst.

title: Clinton Seeks $65 Million For State AIDS Programs
description: Facing sharply rising costs as new antiviral drugs come on the market, states would receive a $65 million boost for their AIDS Drug Assistance Programs from the Government next year under a budget request that President Clinton is to submit to Congress.

title: 2 New Convictions Cast More Shadows on Colombian President
description: Two former political associates of President Ernesto Samper have been convicted of charges that they knowingly funneled drug traffickers' money into the President's campaign, the very activities for which Mr. Samper was exonerated by the Colombian Congress last month.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- GYMNASTICS;For the Magnificent Seven, It Hurts So Good
description: The American gymnasts who had just won the first women's Olympic team gold medal in their nation's history filed into the Georgia Dome tonight for the medal ceremony.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Camden Gets 62-Page Guide
description: Officials here say it is time to show the world that their waterfront city is more than just the murder capital of New Jersey. Corporate sponsors have spent $50,000 on a 62-page guide to showcase the more upbeat aspects of Camden, officials said yesterday.

title: A Different G.O.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Will the Millennium Arrive First?
description: To the Editor:

title: Cow Disease May Infect Other Animals
description: Preliminary scientific findings announced by the European Union may lead to restrictions on the consumption of certain parts of sheep, goats and deer because of the discovery that mad cow disease, which has ravaged Britain's beef industry, may be transmissible to those animals.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Music;Opening With a Bang, Courtesy of Gergiyev and the Kirov
description: Anyone who went to Monday night's opening concert of Lincoln Center Festival '96 expecting a theme, a manifesto or some sort of guiding set of principles must have exited Avery Fisher Hall a little confused. The confusion, I think, is intentional. Indeed, the Kirov Orchestra and Chorus under Valery Gergiyev, playing two unlikely paeans to Soviet accomplishment, simply affirmed what may be this festival's only real message: that the world makes little sense but in its variety is interesting to behold.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 18 about the career of a psychiatrist at the Westchester County Jail who discontinued antidepressant medication for a 17-year-old who later committed suicide misstated the reason Massachusetts did not renew its contract with the psychiatrist's employer, EMSA Correctional Care. (A related article on July 19 repeated the error.) The Massachusetts contract was not renewed because the company did not submit the lowest bid, not because of the deaths of three inmates in the state's jails.

title: A Lack of Kosher Recipes
description: To The Living Section:

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Professor Lights Up Proteins
description: One of the biggest challenges for students in the rapidly expanding field of biotechnology is that many of the processes they are studying are invisible. But William Ward, a professor at Rutgers University, has a solution: green fluorescent proteins. The antifreeze-colored substances, extracted from jellyfish, let researchers watch things like a single cancer cell as it grows, divides and is attacked by the immune system.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;A Chicken Hash Without the Cream
description: Chicken hash comes from the days when people dressed for breakfast. It usually had cream in it and, no doubt, was exceptional. But chicken hash does not have to be discarded these days when every teaspoon of cream is measured. It just has to get its flavor from something besides fat. Try ginger, and serve with a spicy peach salsa.

title: FOOTBALL;Slaughter Makes a Deal, Joining Jets as Receiver
description: If the Jets have a year that is anything like their off season, it will be one to remember.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;2 Media Companies Make Changes
description: Two interactive media companies are making changes.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RALCORP SELLS SKI OPERATIONS TO VAIL RESORTS
description: Ralcorp Holdings said yesterday that it would sell its ski operations to Vail Resorts Inc. in a transaction valued at $310 million. The purchase will make Vail Resorts, which is controlled by the investment banker Leon Black, a skiing powerhouse in the Rocky Mountain region. Vail Resorts will pay $135 million in cash and assume about $30 million in debt, and Ralcorp will get a 25 percent stake valued at $145 million in the combined company. The sale leaves Ralcorp, based in St. Louis, with its cereal business, including the Chex brands. Vail Resorts owns the Vail and Beaver Creek Resort.

title: Swissair Enters Gambling
description: Interactive Flight Technologies Inc. completed a contract yesterday to install its in-flight entertainment network, which includes casino-style gambling, on 21 of Swissair's long-haul jets. Interactive Flight said that the base purchase price of the system was $70 million to $80 million. The company will also get a share of the gambling revenues.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- WRESTLING;Ghaffari Quest for Gold Is Crushed by a Russian
description: Matt Ghaffari's excellent adventure continued today, though not with the gold medal he still believes awaits him at the end of the rainbow. He climbed the man-mountain known as Aleskandr Karelin one more time, but couldn't quite make it over the top.

title: Sweatshops Contribute to Global Wage Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Wine Talk
description: THREE centuries ago, there were two famous wines in Europe; both were sweet, and neither was from France. One was Constantia from the Cape of Good Hope; the other was Tokay, made then as it is now here in northeast Hungary.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE EVIDENCE;What Made Flight 800 Explode? A Chemical Answer Could Come Down to a Speck
description: The chemists delving for evidence that could reveal whether T.W.A. Flight 800 was brought down by a bomb or missile have tools that can identify a speck of explosive weighing as little as one trillionth of a gram. But they will need luck to find that speck.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TEXAS INSTRUMENTS SELLS ITS GLOBAL PRINTER BUSINESS
description: Texas Instruments Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its worldwide printer business to Genicom Corporation for an undisclosed price, as part of an effort to focus on portable computers and educational calculators. Texas Instruments said that the printer business, including its Omni 800 impact printers and the MicroLaser line of laser printers, generated about $170 million in revenue last year. Genicom had about $150 million in printer-related revenue last year. Shares of Genicom, based in Chantilly, Va., slipped 4.625 cents, to close at $4.0625, while while Texas Instruments shares fell $1.625, to close at $41.75.

title: District of Columbia's Budget Wins Senate Panel's Approval
description: The Senate Appropriations Committee today unanimously approved the District of Columbia's $5.1 billion budget for the 1997 fiscal year, the second sign this week that Congress is satisfied with the city's progress toward solving its financial crisis.

title: Stocks Resume Drop as Rally Fails to Hold
description: A morning rally in stocks faded yesterday and share prices closed broadly lower amid renewed investor concerns about corporate profits. Most major market indexes, including the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq composite index, fell to their lowest closing levels since January.

title: With Karadzic Out, 'Moderate' Serbs Are Hopeful
description: As they try to carry out the Dayton peace accord and its vision of a unified, multi-ethnic Bosnia, American and European officials have spoken hopefully about the emergence of "moderate" Bosnian Serbs.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ARROW ELECTRONICS INC., Melville, L.I., a distributor of electronic components and computer products, said it planned to buy back at least $100 million of its common stock.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COASTAL GETS WORD OF INTEREST FROM POTENTIAL BUYERS
description: The Coastal Corporation said yesterday that it had received "expressions of interest" from a number of potential buyers for its coal business, which was offered for sale earlier this year. Coastal declined to identify the potential buyers. Coastal, based in Houston, announced plans to sell the unit on Feb. 28 in an effort to free up capital for faster-growing businesses including natural gas and electricity. Analysts estimated the coal unit, the nation's most profitable, could fetch between $700 million and $900 million.

title: Computer Expert Testifies in Terror Trial
description: A Microsoft computer expert yesterday led the jury at the terrorism trial of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef on a virtual tour of the contents of a Toshiba laptop computer that prosecutors say implicates Mr. Yousef in a failed plan to bomb American jetliners overseas.

title: Politics: Political Memo;Clinton's Use of Incumbency: The Little Plans Loom Large
description: As President Clinton barnstorms the country these days -- ahead in the polls but running like an underdog -- his campaign proposals do not so much constitute a platform as a portable, flag-decked front porch planked with row after row of small but worthy ideas.

title: Alfred L. Plant, 84, Advertising Executive
description: Alfred L. Plant, an advertising executive who resisted pressure from the National Rifle Association to withdraw his company's ads from a television program critical of hunting, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan after a brief illness. He was 84.

title: Court Rules Against Government on Nuclear Fuel
description: The Federal Government must begin accepting tons of used fuel from the nuclear industry by 1998 even though a permanent storage site will not be ready by then, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BAUSCH & LOMB SELLING ITS DENTAL IMPLANT BUSINESS
description: Bausch & Lomb Inc. is selling its dental implant business, Steri-Oss Inc., to a health care investment company in New York and the unit's senior management. Bausch, an optics and health care products maker, said that it expected to make an after-tax profit from the buyout. Terms were not disclosed. The buyers are the Finisterre Fund, an equity firm that invests in high-growth segments of the health care industry, and senior management at Steri-Oss, which employs about 180 people in Yorba Linda, Calif. Revenues from Steri-Oss make up less than 2 percent of Bausch & Lomb's $2 billion in annual sales.

title: Defense Rests in Arkansas Case
description: The defense wrapped up its case in the second Whitewater-related trial today after an Arkansas banker denied that $500 he received from his bank in 1993 had been used for a $500 contribution the same day to Gov. Jim Guy Tucker, who has since resigned.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- ROUNDUP;TABLE TENNIS: U.S. Women Outlast Dutch Duo
description: The United States team of Wei Wang and Lily Yip opened Olympic competition with a 21-18, 11-21, 21-11 victory over Emily Noor and Huberta Vriesekoop of the Netherlands. Wang, from Pasadena, Calif., and Yip, from Metuchen, N.J., were the only American winners on the first day of eliminations in doubles.

title: British Airways In French Deal
description: British Airways P.L.C. announced today that it would exercise its option to buy the remaining 50.1 percent of its French partner TAT European Airlines.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;UAL Reports 42.8% Climb In Its Earnings
description: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines and the Shuttle by United, reported a 42.8 percent increase in quarterly earnings today on strong bookings by business travelers, who typically buy the most expensive seats.

title: Security, and the False Sense of It
description: Whether or not the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 was caused by terrorists, Americans are demanding heightened airport security to insure against another tragedy. Yet while there's no question that security measures at airports must be enhanced, we are deluding ourselves if we think that is the way to prevent terrorist attacks.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- NOTEBOOK;Super Wheels for U.S. Cyclists
description: They look like something that aliens might ride in an Arnold Schwarzenegger movie. The handlebars point 45 degrees to the side and 45 degrees down. The rear wheel is bigger than the front.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Gospel;Lusty Shouts With a Liturgical Echo
description: A gospel concert in a church sounded like a fine idea for Lincoln Center Festival '96. But the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, a few blocks from the center, is a Catholic church built for hushed liturgical music. On Monday night, its echo sent drumbeats caroming all over and turned up-tempo songs to sludge. Only the adaptability of the Institutional Radio Choir and Tramaine Hawkins came close to salvaging the show, as it tested their Christian ideals of trust and forgiveness.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- ROUNDUP;WATER POLO: Victory Puts Americans in Quarterfinals
description: After a few uneven performances, the United States was ready to show why it considers itself a medal contender in the Olympic tournament.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Ahmanson Branch Plans
description: H. F. Ahmanson & Company said today that it would close 25 bank branches after its planned acquisition of 61 First Interstate branches from Wells Fargo & Company. Ahmanson is closing branches in areas where its Home Savings and First Interstate branches conflict.

title: Sports of The Times;Carrying the Weight Of a Nation's History
description: THEY represent two distinct strains of nationalism expressed through judo. Yesterday, Yael Arad of Israel and Toshihiko Koga of Japan carried the weight of their respective worlds into competition.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- ROUNDUP;SOFTBALL: Smith's 3-Hitter Keeps U.S. Unbeaten
description: The pitching-strong U.S. Olympic staff showed its human side last night, finally giving up a run in the third day of competition. It didn't matter.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Probation for Erving's Son
description: The son of the Basketball Hall of Famer JULIUS ERVING was convicted of buying $5 worth of crack and will spend one year on probation. CHEO ERVING, 23, was sentenced Monday by Municipal Judge J. EARL SIMMONS in Philadelphia. (AP)

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE DIVERS;Underwater Search Demands Skill and Willingness to Take Risks
description: While hundreds of investigators work feverishly above ground to determine why Trans World Airlines Flight 800 exploded over the Atlantic Ocean last week, dozens more are working underwater, gliding through the murky seas off Long Island for airplane wreckage and, most of all, for human remains.

title: Montezuma Creek Journal;Despite Prayers, a Navajo-Mormon Culture Clash
description: At dusk, the Whitehorse clan filed inside a tepee to spend the night chanting, drumming and eating hallucinogenic peyote. At midmorning, the Navajo Indians filed out just as the many Mormon residents of this southeastern Utah county were pulling up to the tidy brick churches that poke spires higher than any tepee poles into the horizons of San Juan County.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: LEGAL IMPLICATIONS;Families and Lawyers Are Warned That Airline's Liability May Be Limited
description: Although many bodies from the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 last week have yet to be found, some lawyers have already found clients to sue the carrier. The frenzy is on: lawyers have sent out press releases praising their expertise, and inquiries to members of the small coterie of aviation-law specialists are pouring in. A handful of families have already signed on.

title: A.C.L.U. Sees Unequal Education, But . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Little Buffalo Journal;In a Poisoned Forest, A Tribe Canada Forgot
description: He shot and killed a fat bull moose last spring, his first moose in more than two years. Its antlers crown the tawny roof of the log cabin that Joel Laboucan built in happier days, before hundreds of oil jacks, a sour gas processing plant with the smell of rotten eggs and clear-cut logging scarred the land and scared off the wildlife.

title: A.C.L.U. Sees Unequal Education, But . . .;Rights Get in the Way
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- SWIMMING;There's Vindication for Van Dyken in the Butterfly
description: Three days earlier, Amy Van Dyken of Denver had collapsed on the pool deck, suffering from hyperventilation and severe cramps in her thighs and her neck. Tonight, she finished the Olympic 100-meter butterfly in a churning rush, looked up at the scoreboard and mouthed the words "Oh, my God," in excited disbelief. The cramps were gone now, replaced by the astonishment of victory.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- ROUNDUP;YACHT RACING: American Teams Trailing
description: Bronze medalists from 1988 lead both keelboat divisions in the Summer Games competition being held in Savannah, Ga. In the Soling, Germany's Jochen Schumann, the 1988 Soling bronze winner and 1976 Finn gold medalist, with his crew members Thomas Flach and Bernd Jaekel, leads the American Soling trio of Jeff Madrigali, Kent Massey and Jim Barton. In the Star, the American double medalists Mark Reynolds and Hal Haenel (Star gold '92, Star silver '88) trail Brazil's Torben Grael and the crewman Marcelo Ferreira by a point.

title: Investigators Focus Closely on Terrorism As Cause of Explosion : Chemicals Found on Jet Victims, U.S. Reports
description: WASHINGTON  A White House official said Tuesday that a chemical residue had been found on the bodies of some victims and on debris salvaged from the Atlantic off the New York coast following the explosive crash of TWA Flight 800.

title: Immigrant Father Is Fatally Shot Outside a Restaurant in Queens
description: An immigrant father of two who was playing cards in a Queens restaurant was fatally shot Monday night, an innocent victim of gunfire involving some dice players outside, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about technical difficulties at the Olympic Games misstated the nature of the computer-related problems in reporting results of the competitions. They did not involve I.B.M.'s Lotus Notes software. The company says it is investigating the cause of the problems.

title: A.C.L.U. Sees Unequal Education, But . . .;Teach Bias Awareness
description: To the Editor:

title: Arrest in Apartheid Killings Called Move to Stifle Truth
description: A former police captain who confessed seven years ago to heading a Government assassination squad and became South Africa's best known whistle-blower said today that his recent arrest was an attempt by remaining elements of the "old regime" to scare off others who might want to confess past atrocities.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Music;Recalling Schuman, Bernstein and Company in the Groundbreaking Days
description: The big-ticket event on opening night of the Lincoln Center Festival '96 may have been the Kirov Orchestra and Chorus concert at Avery Fisher Hall, but a competing performance next-door at Alice Tully Hall drew a nearly full house.
