As the first of its three festival concerts, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center offered an American program on Monday, of works by composers with connections to the center in its early days.

title: FOOTBALL;Tension Seems Rife At Giants Camp
description: Giants Coach Dan Reeves was asked today whether Coleman Rudolph, a defensive end converted to linebacker, was getting accustomed to the position and if the move was made more for this season or for next season.

title: Magazine Extends Vacation For 'Primary Colors' Author
description: Richard M. Smith, the editor in chief and president of Newsweek magazine has asked Joe Klein, the Newsweek columnist, to extend his vacation to reflect on the controversy surrounding Mr. Klein's book, "Primary Colors," and talk the issue over with members of his staff.

title: A Polite Warning to Mr. Yeltsin
description: The International Monetary Fund delivered an appropriately gentle wake-up call to the Russian Government this week. It delayed a $330 million disbursement in loans pending Moscow's action to raise tax collections toward previously agreed levels.

title: New Chief Is Chosen For French Railway
description: Louis Gallois, chief executive of the state-controlled French aerospace company Aerospatiale S.A., will be named head of the French state railways, SNCF, the Transportation Ministry said today.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;RJR Nabisco Says It Lost $27 Million
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation reported a second-quarter loss of $27 million yesterday as a result of the costs of revamping its food business, but its operating profits slightly exceeded Wall Street forecasts.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Vindication for Ex-Detective
description: A veteran former police detective who exposed a cocaine ring within his own department was awarded $3.1 million in compensatory and punitive damages yesterday. The department dismissed the detective, Gary Sutley, in 1992, on grounds that he had used cocaine himself.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Australian Account Goes To D.M.B.& B.
description: The Australian Tourist Commission said yesterday that it had named D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles to handle its consolidated worldwide account, which had been divided among three agencies, including D.M.B.& B. Combined billings were estimated at $60 million.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- ROUNDUP;FENCING: Italy Captures the Gold Medal
description: After having blood cleaned out of his right eye following a freakish accident with his mask, Angelo Mazzoni used a quick stab to give Italy the gold medal in team epee with a 45-43 victory over Russia at the Georgia World Congress Center.

title: Bitter Ex-Prosecutor, After the Acquittals;Says Rape Verdicts Prove His Point
description: One of New York State's most notorious rape cases is finally over. But not for Richard V. Manning, who will forever be known as the prosecutor who was removed from the case.

title: Hamilton Fish Jr., 70, Dies; Part of a Political Dynasty
description: Hamilton Fish Jr., a New York Republican from an old Hudson River family who continued its tradition of Congressional service into the fourth generation, holding a House seat from 1969 to 1994, died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 70 and also had a home in Millbrook, N.Y.

title: Bosnian Officials Make First Visit to Serbia
description: For the first time since the start of the Bosnian war in 1992, high-ranking Bosnian officials and businessmen made an official visit to rival Serbia today.

title: European Beachhead For Korean Ambition
description: Oceans away from his home base, in a dark cavernous factory here covered with decades of grime left by Communist neglect, the South Korean magnate and chairman of the Daewoo Group, Kim Woo Choong, sees the future. He walks the aisles of antiquated metal pressing machines, unruffled by the thunderous noise or the disheveled Polish auto workers peering at their new boss.

title: Food-Pesticide Overhaul Wins House Passage
description: On a vote of 417 to 0, the House of Representatives today approved an overhaul of laws regulating pesticide residues in food.

title: No Headline
description: The last thing America needs is a new First Amendment. A stronger role for religion in American public life? Yes. A fairer and more respectful treatment in public schools? Absolutely. But a new constitutional amendment on religion? God forbid."

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Interest Rates in Japan Won't Rise, Bank Says
description: The Bank of Japan said yesterday that the nation's economy was still on a path of "moderate recovery" and signaled that it had no intention to raise interest rates for the time being. The central bank released its quarterly economic outlook, "josei handan," in which it painted much the same picture of the economy as it had since Japan began emerging from recession.

title: Bakker Prevails in Suit Over His Ministry
description: A jury decided in favor of Jim Bakker, the television evangelist who founded PTL, in a multimillion-dollar lawsuit filed by followers who sought refunds for "partnerships" sold by the ministry.

title: The Keeper of the Chilies: Part Hermit, Part Crowd Pleaser
description: PEOPLE who know Diana Kennedy say that she cooks like a Mexican grandmother, even though she was born in England, and that she is so dogged about her chosen cuisine that she will pursue a recipe as far as the Sierra Madre mountains, on a donkey if need be.

title: To the Hopeless, a Cancer 'Cure' Beckons
description: Correction Appended

title: Land Clearing Starts for Brooklyn Hotel
description: After years of setbacks and with little fanfare, bulldozers began uprooting dozens of trees in a scruffy Brooklyn park last weekend to make way for a major development that will give Brooklyn its first large hotel since the 1930's and is widely considered a key to downtown renewal.

title: Drug Choices for Easing Migraines May Grow
description: FOR years, people with migraine headaches faced a difficult choice: they could resign themselves to being incapacitated for at least a day, or they could take a drug called sumatriptan that has serious side effects. But the choice should get easier soon because several safer drugs are showing promise of rapid relief for migraines.

title: No Evidence of Explosive So Far in Crash Inquiry
description: Investigators examining the small amount of wreckage recovered so far from the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 said yesterday that they had not yet found any concrete evidence that the plane was destroyed by an explosive device.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Philadanco, Exuberant But Sleek
description: Philadanco is a company of happy, invigorating contrasts. At 26, this Philadelphia-based troupe is a venerable institution in dance terms. But the company has not lost its youthful verve or the freshness of its strong technical grounding. The program it presented on Monday night at the Joyce Theater was longer on sleek modernity than some in past years. But in George Faison's classic "Suite Otis," Joan Myers Brown, the founder and director of Philadanco, made a bow to tradition that drew loud cries of "Work it, baby!" from the infectiously exuberant audience.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Dance;Classical Guys and Dolls, With an Edge
description: For reasons best known to the inner child, ballets that feature doll dances are among the most popular. As an enterprise that has declared its interest in combining the old and the new, the Lincoln Center Festival could hardly miss on Monday night with a witty updated version of "Coppelia," a ballet named after a pretty automaton.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5 -- ROUNDUP;WOMEN'S SOCCER: U.S. Triumphs, but Hamm Is Hurt
description: In Atlanta, the United States women's team assured itself of advancing to the semifinals with a 2-1 victory over Sweden yesterday, but an ankle injury to forward Mia Hamm put a damper on the achievement.

title: School Prayer Politics
description: For a while it seemed as if the Republican leadership in Congress had abandoned its quest for a constitutional amendment to bring organized prayer back into schools and otherwise lower the wall wisely crafted by the nation's founders, and vigorously upheld by the Supreme Court, to separate church and state. Now, however, a big push is under way for the House to vote on a prayer amendment well before Election Day.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Copper Prices Head Higher In Unexpected Summer Rally
description: Copper prices rallied in New York yesterday as a decline in stockpiles was taken as a sign of unexpectedly strong demand.

title: Food Notes
description: Weekend Beer Camp

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a new margarine made by the Raisio Group of Finland, which is said to reduce cholesterol in the bloodstream, referred incorrectly in some editions to the number of countries in the European Union. It is 15, not 12.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CAPSTAR BROADCASTING BUYING OSBORN COMMUNICATIONS
description: Capstar Broadcasting Partners agreed yesterday to acquire the Osborn Communications Corporation for about $100 million in cash. Osborn, based in Greenwich, Conn., owns radios stations in the eastern United States. Capstar said the agreement values Osborn stock at $15.375 a share. Osborn's stock closed up $2 a share, at $14, in Nasdaq trading. Under terms of the agreement, Osborn Communications will retain its corporate identity and operate as an autonomous unit. Osborn owns or is acquiring 11 FM and 6 AM radio stations in West Virginia, Florida, Tennessee, Alabama, North Carolina and Ohio. Capstar Broadcasting was formed by Hicks Muse Tate & Furst Inc., a Dallas investment firm, to invest in middle-market radio stations.

title: Meadow-Sweet Ricotta of Childhood Memory Is Back
description: WHEN it comes to Italian cheese, Parmesan is unquestionably the king. As for the queen, most Americans would probably crown mozzarella. Fontina, Gorgonzola and mascarpone might be lesser royalty. But what about ricotta? With the exception of Parmesan, no cheese is more widely used in Italy.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO BASKETBALL;Smith Stays With Hawks
description: Guard STEVE SMITH, a free agent, re-signed with the Atlanta Hawks yesterday, agreeing to a seven-year deal that reportedly is worth at least $45 million. Smith, who averaged a team-high 18.1 points last season, said the recent addition of the free agent center DIKEMBE MUTOMBO was a factor in the decision. (AP)

title: METRO DIGEST
description: THE CRASH

title: Tokyo Stocks Plunge 2.5%
description: The Nikkei index of 225 issues slid today. At the close of trading, the index was down 532.66 points, or 2.52 percent, at 20,631.03.

title: Business Travel;The Regional Airline Association touts the improved safety record of commuter carriers.
description: SHORTLY after a Valujet plane crashed in the Florida Everglades on May 11, killing all 110 people aboard, the Regional Airline Association started a campaign to educate travel agents and the public about the steadily improving safety record of the commuter airline industry. The timing, it turns out, was a coincidence, for Valujet was not a commuter carrier, and the campaign had been in the planning stages for almost a year, to allay fears arising from two commuter plane crashes in late 1994.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 5;NBC's Ratings Are Soaring
description: NBC's Olympic broadcasts soared to a 23.0 Nielsen rating Monday night, 17 percent above the first Monday night of competition four years ago in Barcelona. The night rated higher than any night of competition in either the 1988 or 1992 Summer Games, and was the highest-rated Monday prime time in any Olympics since the 1976 Montreal Games.

title: FILM REVIEW;A Father's Revenge For His Child's Rape
description: This must be an author's dream: to start in obscurity, write books that make their way to every airport and drugstore, then belatedly sell a favorite first novel to the movies. And have one's fictionalized stand-in (in the case of John Grisham, a dashing and principled young Mississippi lawyer), played by a bright new matinee idol who sends the film's Adonis factor through the roof.

title: Nasdaq Sinks as Investors Turn to the Blue-Chips
description: Small-company stocks, which for more than 18 months acted as the engine of growth for the stock market, mutual funds and the economy as a whole, continued to erode yesterday, as investors turned further away from that increasingly volatile sector of the market in favor of blue chips.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IRIDEX STOCK DECLINES ON REPORT OF FLAT EARNINGS
description: Shares of the Iridex Corporation fell 28 percent yesterday, one day after the eye laser company said second-quarter earnings were nearly flat despite a 14.7 percent jump in sales. The results were well below the expectations of analysts. The company noted that expenses rose nearly 30 percent, but did not disclose any reasons. Iridex, based in Mountain View, Calif., said that it expected to begin shipments of its Oculight semiconductor-based visible laser system in its second half, though the company is still working out problems that will delay international deliveries. Yesterday, Iridex shares fell to as low as $7.50 before closing at $8.25, down $3.25.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Courts Honoring Wilentz
description: Attorney General Deborah T. Poritz has ordered the State Supreme Court and the superior courts closed at noon today in memory of Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz, who died Tuesday. Justice Wilentz is to be buried today. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday on the continuation of a front-page article about the use of alternative medical therapies by Dr. Stanislaw R. Burzynski referred incorrectly in some editions to the Federal agency investigating his practice. It is the F.D.A., not the F.A.A.

title: Calendar: A Lecture, Exhibitions And Tours
description: Downtown, U.S.A. Urban Center, 457 Madison Avenue (51st Street); (212) 753-1722.

title: Communists Defeat Yeltsin Plan to Lure Investment
description: In a stinging rebuff to President Boris N. Yeltsin, the Communist-dominated Parliament has rejected legislation intended to encourage billions of dollars of foreign investment in the oil and gas industry.

title: Harbor Plan Is Detailed: 2 Governors Cry Politics
description: For more than a year, the Governors of New York and New Jersey have pushed for a plan to dredge and dispose of the millions of tons of toxic mud that have begun to clog New York Harbor. Today, the Democratic White House finally announced such a plan.

title: Clive S. Menell, 65, Mining Executive In South Africa
description: Clive S. Menell, the deputy chairman of Anglovaal Ltd., a South African mining conglomerate, died yesterday at the age of 65.

title: Mexican Hasn't Failed To Deliver on Reforms
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-China Talks Continue; Tone Is Warmer Despite Differences
description: As relations between the nations continue their tentative thaw, the United States and China agreed today on an ambitious schedule of high-level meetings that could lead to the first Chinese-American summit meeting since 1992.

title: Market Place;Municipal bond investors could wind up in an I.R.S. crackdown.
description: BUYERS of municipal bonds beware: The Federal Government is cracking down on an illegal price-gouging practice in which bond underwriters overcharge municipal issuers for securities used to set up bond escrow funds. In the process, the I.R.S. may wind up hurting investors who bought the bonds.

title: Currents;A Wright House, Not a Shrine
description: TEN years ago, Peter Palumbo, an English real estate millionaire and arts patron, took his daughter to Fallingwater, the 1937-39 masterpiece house designed by Frank Lloyd Wright in Bear Run, Pa. They were impressed, then intrigued. As he recalled yesterday from his London office: "The curator said, 'By the way, do you realize there's another Wright house here, for sale? Would you like to see it?' "

title: Sumitomo Bank Helps Affiliate
description: The Sumitomo Bank said today that it had extended fresh loans to the Sumitomo Corporation, a fellow member of the Sumitomo Group, to help it cope with a $1.8 billion loss in the copper market.

title: Technology's Edict: Adapt Or Lose Out;Change Drives Growth, But Puts Labor at Risk
description: Louie Pokrywka made a false start before bringing an elaborate schematic of the Kleenex production line to his computer screen. "Until a few weeks ago I hadn't sat down at a keyboard since high school typing class," apologized the line operator at Kimberly-Clark's paper products mill here. But his job is rapidly evolving from grunt work -- such as lifting boxes -- to the more demanding tasks of monitoring precision machinery.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;USAir and America West Report Big Earnings Gains
description: Two airlines, USAir and America West, reported healthy gains yesterday in second-quarter earnings.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Volvo Sets $40 Price In Pharmacia Share Sale
description: Volvo A.B. set a price of $40 a share yesterday in its sale of 46 million shares in Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. The car maker, which announced the sale on June 25, said the sale would reduce its stake in Pharmacia & Upjohn to at least 4.7 percent from 13.7 percent. The sale price would yield $1.84 billion.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6;Atlanta Bristles at All the Criticism
description: Fortunately for Atlanta, the athletes at the 1996 Summer Olympics are starting to produce indelible memories. The gymnast Kerri Strug sacrificing herself to salvage a gold medal for her American team. Naim Suleymanoglu, the Pocket Hercules from Turkey, winning a record-shattering weight-lifting duel with his archrival from Greece.

title: 2 Bombs Planted on Train in Sri Lanka Kill 54
description: Two bombs ripped through separate cars of a commuter train today, killing at least 54 people and wounding more than 350. The police blamed Tamil separatist rebels.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- ROUNDUP;WEIGHT LIFTING: Cuban Fights Off Pain to Win
description: Pablo Lara of Cuba lifted a combined 810 pounds at the Georgia World Congress Center to win the gold medal in the 167 1/2-pound weight class. Lara tore a callus at the base of his right ring finger during the second of his three lifts in the snatch and failed on his third lift, but came back strong in the clean-and-jerk. Yoto Yotov of Bulgaria won the silver with 793 1/2 pounds and Jon Chol Ho of North Korea won the bronze with 788 pounds. (AP)

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;United Airlines Is Put Up for Review
description: The United Airlines unit of the UAL Corporation unexpectedly placed its account in review yesterday after 31 years at the Leo Burnett Company in Chicago. Billings were estimated at $60 million to $70 million.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- BASKETBALL Australia Shuts Down a Scoring Machine
description: As the game dragged on and on, and Oscar Schmidt struggled to find his shot, the man assigned to guard the greatest scorer in Olympic basketball history wanted to send a message. So Scott Fisher, an Australian by way of Northern California, was sure to make eye contact with his Brazilian opponent and smile. "I was tired, too," Fisher said, "but I tried not to let him know that."

title: Cuban-Born Commissioner Is Elected Mayor of Miami
description: Joe Carollo, a Cuban-born "comeback kid" who has been exhorting Miami to play a larger role in global commerce, was elected on Tuesday as mayor of Miami and was sworn in at noon today on the steps of City Hall.

title: MOMUMENT TO DECAY;No Shortage of Proposed Solutions, Starting With a Cap on Income Taxes
description: There was little fanfare this spring when a coalition of liberal and conservative lawmakers unveiled their plan to save the nation's capital with drastic cuts in Federal taxes for all District of Columbia residents.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- TENNIS;Reneberg's Groin Injury Means Doubles Trouble
description: Who will replace the home team's replacement players?

title: Welfare as We Know It
description: Opponents of the welfare reform bill passed by the Senate on Tuesday have painted a nightmarish vision of a world where millions of children are in poverty, with their parents leading lives of desperation and hopelessness.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HAMBRECHT & QUIST POSTPONES ITS INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING
description: Hambrecht & Quist Inc. rescheduled its $80 million initial public offering for the middle of August, according to people familiar with the situation. The San Francisco-based investment bank, which specializes in bringing technology companies public, is expected to sell a 15 percent to 20 percent stake to the public, analysts said when the offer was announced in June. Hambrecht & Quist put off its offering amid waning investor appetite for new stock. The sale would be priced the week of Aug. 12. The company has yet to file with the Securities and Exchange Commission the number of shares to be sold or the price at which they will be sold.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- ROUNDUP;EQUESTRIAN: Broken Bones Can't Stop Australia
description: Australia beat the United States, 203.85 penalty points to 261.10, for the gold medal in the three-day team event even though two of its riders competed with broken bones. Wendy Schaeffer, who broke her leg in a fall in May and rode with it held together by pressure pads and screws, produced the outstanding performance of the show-jumping section yesterday at Conyers, Ga., to insure that Australia kept its Olympic title. Her teammate Gillian Rolton completed Tuesday's cross-country after breaking her collarbone and two ribs in a fall, but did not jump yesterday. (Reuters)

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6;Olympic Moments, but Hours Later on TV
description: When the gymnast Kerri Strug stuck a gold medal-winning vault Tuesday night, hopping on her right foot to avoid the pain in her left, the moment radiated the drama of something happening before our very eyes.

title: Raphael Patai, 85, a Scholar of Jewish and Arab Cultures
description: Raphael Patai, a cultural anthropologist who turned the stories of the Jewish people into the story of his life as a preeminent scholar of Jewish and Middle Eastern studies, died on Saturday at the home of a daughter in Tucson, Ariz. He was 85.

title: Possibility Of Arson Is at Center Of Inquiry
description: A fire that destroyed a two-story meeting hall early Sunday in the strife-torn Hasidic community of Kiryas Joel in Orange County, N.Y., is being investigated as an arson, the New York State Police said yesterday.

title: English as Official Language Wins Backing of House Panel
description: A House committee narrowly approved a bill today making English the nation's official language.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- GYMNASTICS;Li Wins All-Around by the Thinnest of Margins
description: Only 38-hundredths of a point separated Aleksei Nemov and his pursuer, Li Xiaoshuang, as they prepared for the final rotation of the men's individual all-around gymnastics competition.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- BASKETBALL;In This Year's Version, Dream Team Is Winning With Dunks, Not Routs
description: Maybe they're just bored. Maybe this is just another business trip for the group of basketball players that inherited the ill-fitting designation of Dream Team. This stay in Atlanta is just longer, a lot warmer and infinitely more crowded than a stop in a National Basketball Association season. So far, it has been about as inspiring.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Arthur Miller, Still Feeling the Pain After the Fall
description: Professional theologians aside, few writers since John Milton have made quite the career Arthur Miller has of lamenting man's exile from Eden. Not for nothing did Mr. Miller title his 1964 autobiographical play "After the Fall." Guilt, shame and visions of paradise lost have always hovered like dark biblical thunderclouds over his troubled, groping characters.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Life Term for Third Offense
description: A convicted carjacker, armed robber and rapist yesterday became the first New Jerseyan sentenced under the Federal "three strikes and you're in" law. James E. Fraction Jr., 37, of Burlington City was sentenced to life in prison without parole. His third strike was kidnapping a woman in her car in Cinnaminson in 1995 and taking her to Philadelphia.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 referred incorrectly to comments by Maj. Frederick Meyer of the Air National Guard, who witnessed it. While he described a streak of light that preceded two explosions and a fireball, he said he saw no indication of a missile.

title: Burundi at the Edge
description: The festering crisis in Burundi is of a kind that sorely tests the wisdom and capacity of outsiders. As in neighboring Rwanda, Hutu comprise 85 percent of Burundi's population, while nearly all the rest are Tutsi. The two ethnic groups have teetered in a precarious equilibrium. Burundi's armed forces are dominated by Tutsi, while the President, Sylvestre Ntibantunganya, is a Hutu. But unable to quell a rebellion by Hutu, and physically threatened by furious Tutsi, the President took asylum Tuesday in the American Embassy in Bujumbura, Burundi's capital, and remained there yesterday.

title: Under Solar Bill, Homeowners Could Cut Electric Cost to Zero
description: New York state residents may soon be able to turn their rooftops into small-scale solar-power plants and see their electric bills drop to zero or even register a credit.

title: As for Welfare, Where Have the Liberals Gone?
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Bibles Are Just the Beginning
description: Just what can one find for sale in a Christian bookstore these days?

title: COMPANY NEWS;JUDGE RULES INSURERS OWE EXXON $161 MILLION IN INTEREST
description: A judge has ruled that insurers owe the Exxon Corporation $161 million in interest, bringing the total award in a civil case stemming from the 1989 Exxon Valdez disaster to approximately $410 million. Earlier this month, State District Judge Carolyn Marks Johnson in Houston entered a final judgment assessing 10 percent interest for about five years prior to the $250 million verdict that was returned by a jury June 10. Jurors found that Lloyd's of London and some 250 other underwriters should make good on a policy that covered Exxon as the owner of 11 million gallons of oil that spilled when the Exxon Valdez ran aground in Alaska's Prince William Sound.

title: That Atlanta Applause Was Cosmopolitan
description: To the Editor:

title: METRO DIGEST
description: THE CRASH

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Theater;Vietnamese Puppets, Each With a Story to Tell
description: The Thang Long Water Puppet Theater of Hanoi, a presentation of the Lincoln Center Festival '96, is charmingly exotic. But there was an odd familiarity to the dancing, diving, cavorting animals and humans and the vignettes they enacted on Tuesday night at Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center, where the company performs through Saturday.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE MOURNING;Tears, Sunflowers, Prayers, Photos, Carnations and More Tears
description: The white-robed priest who waved incense around the coffin was John Cardinal O'Connor. The dark-suited man who rendered a special eulogy was Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Samuel Toledano, 66, Advocate for Jews of Spain
description: Samuel Toledano, former secretary general of Spain's Jewish federation and an architect of the agreement that brought full legal recognition for Jews in Spain and in effect overturned the expulsion order of 1492, died in Madrid on Monday. He was 66.

title: ON BASEBALL;The Stuff Cy Youngs Are Made Of
description: Major league players and managers do not give out Cy Young Awards any more than they do medals for valor.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Studios bet that if you saw a trailer in December, you'll remember to love the film in May.
description: WHEN the producers of this summer's blockbuster, "Independence Day," saw the first special effects footage, they knew they had the makings of a great movie preview.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Jeffrey Wolf was named senior vice president and associate director for account planning at Deutsch Inc., New York, succeeding Richard Cohen, who left. Mr. Wolf had been account planning director at TBWA Chiat/Day, New York, a unit of the Omnicom Group.

title: Gleason Repurchase Plan
description: The Gleason Corporation said today that its board had approved the buyback of as much as 10 percent of its common stock. Gleason, a gear production equipment maker based here, has about 5.2 million shares outstanding. Since 1992, it has bought back about 585,000 of its shares. Gleason shares rose $1, to $33.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Germany Blames Turk Infighting for Firebombings
description: The German authorities expressed concern today that a rash of firebombings of Turkish-owned properties in Germany and Switzerland this week might be the result of a spillover protest by left-wing Turks supporting hunger strikers in Turkey.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- SWIMMING;Pankratov Sets Record In Butterfly
description: Denis Pankratov, the 22-year-old Russian butterfly swimmer known for his impressive underwater dolphin kicks, has always said that the Olympics are the only competition in which the gold medal is more important than the winning time. Tonight, he could be doubly satisfied: He got both a gold medal and a world-record time, winning the 100-meter butterfly in 52.27 seconds.

title: Currents;Better Than Paint Chips
description: ONE of the worst parts of house painting is economic: buying a $10 quart just to decide if you like the color enough to buy a $25 gallon. Dulux, a British paint company known for its crisp, clear colors (Min Hogg, the editor of The World of Interiors, swears by its bright shell pink), has a revolutionary solution. The company offers plastic samplers inspired by nail-polish bottles. Under a twist-off cap is a nylon-bristle brush and 1.7 ounces of one of Dulux's 120 premixed interior and exterior colors, enough to cover six square feet. The price? $3. Information: (800) 663-8589.

title: The Pop Life
description: Deja Vu All Over Again

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;LGT Asset to Buy Chancellor For as Much as $300 Million
description: LGT Asset Management, the San Francisco-based money management subsidiary of Liechtenstein Global Trust, said yesterday that it would buy the American institutional asset manager Chancellor Capital Management for a price that could reach $300 million.

title: 3 Florida Players Suspended
description: The junior tailback Fred Taylor won't be the only Florida player facing suspension when the season begins, Coach Steve Spurrier said today.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Compaq Profits Rise Strongly, And Analysts Are Impressed
description: Bolstering the confidence of nervous technology investors, the Compaq Computer Corporation reported surprisingly strong second-quarter earnings yesterday and predicted that its business would remain robust for the rest of the year.

title: Senate Backs Bill to Require Data on Drugs for Consumers
description: The Senate today agreed to require for the first time that pharmaceutical companies provide consumers with detailed information on the use and risks of prescription drugs.

title: Fox TV Turns to Sports Unit for a Top Executive
description: David Hill, the hard-driving president of Fox Sports, has been promoted to president and chief operating officer of Fox Television, the division of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation that encompasses Fox's television operations.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE EVIDENCE;Experts Say 'Black Boxes' May Lack Essential Clues
description: The on-board signal device that continually transmitted the location of T.W.A. Flight 800 stopped working well before the plane crashed into the ocean, investigators say, suggesting a large-scale electrical failure that would also have shut down the cockpit voice and data recorders.

title: Currents;Cooler That Plugs In
description: A HOT summer outing can turn into an ordeal when the cooler ice melts and cold drinks become lukewarm. But the Koolatron by Comtrad keeps food and drink chilled or hot for up to 24 hours. The cooler has a thermoelectric module developed by NASA that can be charged at home or in the car on the way to the beach (it plugs into the cigarette lighter). The Koolatron comes in two sizes: a 7-quart ($79), and a 30-quart ($99). Information: (800) 704-1210.

title: O.A.S. Rights Panel Visiting Mexico Hears of Widespread Abuses
description: An international human rights delegation here this week heard new testimony from a witness who said he saw Mexican soldiers in a rural church in Chiapas state torture three young farm boys who later were found dead along a highway.

title: I Earned This Divorce
description: The woman who once stood with me before an altar, promising to share her life with me, is now holding my computer hostage until I give her the VCR. Though the Defense of Marriage Act, passed last week by the House, bars Federal recognition of gay marriages, I find myself wishing our marriage was legal for a reason I never anticipated. I want a divorce.

title: Sports of The Times;Payne on Defensive About Games
description: LIFE was simpler when Billy Payne was an all-America defensive end for the Georgia Bulldogs. Back then you were aggressive in public only on Saturday afternoon. If an opponent tried to block you from the quarterback, you could shove him back. There were always 11 men on a side. And the rest of the week, you smiled and said "sir" and "ma'am" and tried to get along.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: GOLF;Thomson Is Captain
description: The five-time British Open champion PETER THOMSON was appointed captain of the International team in the Presidents Cup yesterday, less than a week after a players' revolt forced DAVID GRAHAM to resign.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Sunbeam's New Chief Cleans House After Earnings Setback
description: On his third day at the Sunbeam Corporation yesterday, Albert J. Dunlap, the company's tough-talking new chairman and chief executive, used the announcement of disastrous second-quarter earnings as an occasion to begin housecleaning.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FOUNDER OF INDIVIDUAL TAKES LEAVE AND SHARES FALL 37%
description: The shares of Individual Inc. plunged 37 percent yesterday after its founder and chief executive, Yosi Amram, took a leave amid a debate with the company's board about the pace of acquisitions. Individual, an electronic information services company, also said two board members had resigned. Shares of the company, a provider of personalized information services, which is based in Burlington, Mass., fell $3.50, to $6, in Nasdaq trading.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DU PONT BUYS BACK 156 MILLION WARRANTS FROM SEAGRAM
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company has bought back 156 million stock warrants owned by the Seagram Company for $500 million, Seagram said Wednesday. The beverage and entertainment company, based in Montreal, said that it had received the warrants in April 1995 when Du Pont redeemed 95 percent of its common stock from Seagram for $8.8 billion. Seagram said it continues to retain 8.2 million shares of Du Pont.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Falcons Lose Lineman
description: Atlanta's rookie defensive tackle, SHANNON BROWN, is out for the season after injuring his knee yesterday during the Falcons' second day of practice. Brown, a third-round pick out of Alabama and the Falcons' first choice, sustained a torn ligament and torn cartilage, team officials said. The 6-foot-5-inch, 290-pound Brown is to undergo an operation in early August and will be out for a year, the team said. Brown had been an all-Southeastern Conference first team defensive tackle last fall for the Crimson Tide. (AP)

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Back on Familiar Turf: Noisy Flows the Don
description: THE LAST DON By Mario Puzo 482 pages. Random House. $25.95.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TRAVELERS/AETNA PROPERTY TO BUY BACK SHARES
description: The board of the Travelers/Aetna Property Casualty Corporation has approved the repurchase of as much as $100 million in stock, or about 1 percent of total outstanding shares. Travelers/Aetna also declared its first dividend, 7.5 cents a share on its class A and class B common stock, which will be payable Aug. 23 to shareholders of record Aug. 5. In April, Travelers Group Inc., which is based in New York, merged its insurance subsidiary with the Aetna Life and Casualty Company's property and casualty unit, which it bought for $4 billion. Based on today's closing stock price of $25, down 25 cents, the $100 million would buy four million shares. The Hartford-based insurer has 400 million shares outstanding.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Banco Santander Posts 6-Month Profit Gain
description: Banco Santander, Spain's biggest commercial banking company, said yesterday that its profit in the first half rose 13 percent. The profit increase, to 35.9 billion pesetas ($365.6 million), was in line with analysts' estimates of a rise of 10 to 15 percent.

title: Company Briefs
description: ITT CORP., New York, the hotel and gaming company, has postponed a planned offering of 7.5 million shares, which was expected to bring in as much as $565 million, because of poor stock market conditions.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Polygram Says Profits Rose a Bit in First Half
description: Polygram N.V. of the Netherlands said yesterday that its profit was almost flat in the first half of the year on a lack of major music releases and continued losses in its film division. The entertainment company, three-quarters of which is owned by Philips Electronics, said its profit was 272 million guilders ($162.9 million) in the six months ended June 30, up from 270 million guilders a year earlier. Sales rose 7 percent, to 4.31 billion guilders from 4.02 billion.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800;Clinton to Meet Families
description: President Clinton will fly to New York City on Thursday to meet with the families of the victims of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 and to get a personal briefing from Federal officials investigating the cause of the crash, the White House announced tonight.

title: POLITICS: THE ISSUES;Poor May Take the Brunt Of Deficit-Cutting This Year
description: Democrats and Republicans alike maintain that to balance the budget, something must be done to stem the growth of entitlements, the Government programs that pay benefits automatically to elderly people, farmers, veterans and the poor.

title: Jean Muir, Actress Penalized By 50's Blacklist, Dies at 85
description: Jean Muir, whose dismissal from the television series "The Aldrich Family" in 1950 brought widespread attention to the television industry's practice of blacklisting suspected Communists, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Mesa, Ariz. She was 85.

title: As for Welfare, Where Have the Liberals Gone?;Punishing Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: House Approves Bill Increasing Money For Fighting Crime
description: The House voted today to increase money to fight crime and illegal drugs while freezing or cutting other programs in a spending bill for Commerce, Justice and State Departments for the 1997 fiscal year.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: LEGAL IMPLICATIONS;Jurors Say Crash Coverage Hasn't Swayed Them
description: The jurors in the terrorism trial of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef assured Judge Kevin Thomas Duffy yesterday that the widespread coverage of the Trans World Airlines crash had not prejudiced their opinion of the case. Taking the jurors at their word, Judge Duffy resumed the trial without further comment.

title: Basketball Largess
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Nets and Pack Agree on Deal
description: Robert Pack, plagued by injuries the past two seasons, reached an agreement tonight with the Nets on a multiyear contract.

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;Dole Appeals for Businesswomen's Support
description: Bob Dole made a big pitch for the women's vote today, highlighting small businesses owned by women and bringing the Republican National Convention's keynote speaker, Representative Susan Molinari of New York, on the campaign trail with him to vouch for his commitment to women's interests.

title: Quaker Deal's Price
description: Van de Kamp's Inc. disclosed today that it had paid the Quaker Oats Company $188 million for its Aunt Jemima frozen waffles and Celeste frozen pizza businesses. Van de Kamp's is a closely held subsidiary of VDK Holdings Inc. and is controlled by Fenway Partners Inc. The purchase was completed on July 9.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE SEARCH;Hunting for Flotsam That Offers Truths
description: Less than an hour into the sixth day of their search for floating wreckage or human remains from Trans World Airlines Flight 800, the eight-person crew on this 285-ton ship made a sighting.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- BOXING;Nothing Is Prime Time In Tarver's First Bout
description: Antonio Tarver is miffed that NBC has decided not to televise boxing in prime time. Evander Holyfield and Muhammad Ali were part of the opening ceremony, he pointed out, and yet his sport still manages to "get shut out."

title: ATLANTA: Day 6: First Pain. Then Glory.
description: KERRI STRUG won't be able to compete for the women's all-around title today. But unlike in past years when she was always overshadowed by other Americans, Strug is still very much in the limelight because of a dramatic performance that made her an instant Olympic legend.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- BADMINTON;Shuttlecock Isn't Fluttering The United States' Way Yet
description: Kevin Han realistically says it might take 20 or 30 years before the United States wins a medal in badminton, one of Asia's most popular sports. It will be four years before he has another chance. Han was eliminated in the first round of the Summer Games by Mark Knowles of Britain, 2-15, 15-10, 15-7, today at the courts at Georgia State University.

title: Citadel Accepts 4 Women
description: Four women have been accepted as cadets at the formerly all-male Citadel military college, and at least one is planning to enroll this fall, a judge was told today.

title: Jewish Studies: Part of the Canon
description: The quarrel at Queens College over the selection of a non-Jewish professor to lead the school's Jewish studies program provides a lesson in the dangers of combining academic disciplines with identity politics.

title: Mr. Clinton's Duty on Welfare
description: President Clinton says he might sign welfare legislation if Congressional negotiators improve the House- and Senate-passed bills in a conference committee. He should stop shadow-boxing. The House's bill is odious. The Senate's is only slightly less so. The conferees will produce a compromise somewhere in between. That is not a place a Democratic President should stand.

title: BASEBALL;Despite Pain, Pettitte Notches Victory No. 15
description: The crowd of reporters staking out Andy Pettitte's locker after the Yankees beat the Texas Rangers, 4-2, yesterday looked like riders waiting for a subway line that had been discontinued. They waited almost 55 minutes next to Pettitte Place, but the pitcher who has become the first 15-game winner in the American League did not arrive on schedule.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- ROUNDUP;BASEBALL: Four American Homers Sink Italy
description: The United States hit four homers yesterday, two by Mark Kotsay, in a 15-3 drubbing of Italy at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium that kept them unbeaten in the round-robin tournament.

title: 702 Million Award for Litton Is Rejected
description: A jury award for Litton Industries that would have been worth $702 million was thrown out today by a Federal judge, handing Honeywell Inc. a victory in a six-year-long antitrust case.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Death After a Police Struggle
description: A 34-year-old man who had been taken into custody died early yesterday after police officers used pepper spray to subdue him during a struggle outside his apartment, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, the Peripherals column in Science Times on Tuesday about several computer books misstated the E-mail address for No Starch Press. It is info

title: POLITICS: THE MEDIA;Artist as Pool Reporter: The Reviews Are Mixed
description: Newsweek yesterday found itself explaining how it was that a performance artist, Anna Deavere Smith, wound up representing the news weekly on Air Force One.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- ROUNDUP;WOMEN'S VOLLEYBALL: China Continues to Dominate U.S.
description: The United States waited and waited for something good to happen last night, and when it did, it was too late. China took advantage of every error and won, 15-8, 15-2, 12-15, 15-12, to take control of Pool A at 3-0. The United States, the defending bronze medalist, fell to 2-1.

title: INSIDE
description: Plan on Disciplining Lawyers

title: Where to Find It/Folding Chairs
description: FEW furnishings are as useful as the classic metal folding chair. But with their whiff of P.T.A. meetings and bridge parties, folding chairs, the Rodney Dangerfield of the home-furnishings world, are stashed in a closet when not in use. And for good reason: they're just not very nice to look at.

title: Topics of The Times
description: Olympic Highs

title: Official Says U.S. Exit May Undo Bosnia Pact
description: The head of American military intelligence warned Congress today that Bosnia is likely to return to civil war unless an international peacekeeping force remains there next year -- past the deadline set by the Clinton Administration for pulling out American peacekeepers.

title: World News Briefs;Britain Says the Risk In Sheep Is Theoretical
description: The British Government, smarting from criticism that it mishandled the crisis over mad cow disease, acted today to allay concern that the disease can be transmitted to sheep.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Reuters Earnings Gain, But Warning Is Issued
description: Reuters Holdings P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 19 percent in the first half of the year, but warned that the gain might not be sustained because of higher costs.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- FIELD HOCKEY;India Proves This American Outfit Is Not a Dream Team
description: For those who have grown weary of Dream Team basketball routs, consider the United States men's field hockey team.

title: Trying to Fix Capital Where 'Everything Is Broken'
description: On any given day here in the capital of the richest nation in the world, nearly a third of the 16 water-pumping firetrucks are kept out of service to save money. Police officers dip into their own pockets to buy tires and put gasoline in squad cars. City clinics periodically stop testing for the AIDS virus because they cannot afford supplies. Local officials are dumping extra chlorine in drinking water to battle elevated levels of bacteria caused by eroding pipes.

title: Pesticide Legislation Wins Senate Passage
description: The Senate by voice vote today approved an overhaul of pesticide rules that would subject all foods to new limits on pesticide residue.

title: Colombian Anti-Drug Tax
description: President Ernesto Samper said today that he would ask the legislature to approve a one-time tax to raise $500 million to fight guerrillas and drug traffickers. The tax would buy equipment for security forces.

title: A FOOD INFECTION ALARMS JAPANESE
description: As scientists struggled to find the source of an outbreak of a deadly strain of bacteria that has caused food poisoning in 8,000 Japanese and killed seven of them, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto called an emergency Cabinet meeting today and pledged that the Government would take measures to combat the situation, which he called "a national problem that has deeply entered into the Japanese people's life."

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Small-Plane Crash Reported
description: A single-engine plane crashed into the ocean yesterday about eight miles east of Sea Bright, the Coast Guard said. It reported finding aircraft debris and a fuel slick, but no bodies or survivors.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Mason Spends Day in Jail After Scuffling With Police
description: Anthony Mason, the former Knick, was arrested early yesterday after a scuffle on a Manhattan street with 10 police officers. The incident left three officers slightly injured.

title: U.N. Asks Intervention Force As Burundi Nears a Collapse
description: Fearing that Burundi is on the verge of a political collapse, the United Nations is assembling an intervention force that could be used to prevent the country's ethnic Tutsi and Hutu from beginning a genocidal civil war, the head of peacekeeping operations said today.

title: Prisoners' Lawyers Challenge Ruling on How Jails Are Run
description: The Federal judge who on Tuesday gave the city more authority to run its jails will hear an appeal a week from today from lawyers representing prisoners, who want him to change his mind.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Prices Fall Second Day After China Cancels Big Order
description: Wheat prices fell for the second day after China announced that it had canceled a purchase of more than 725,000 tons of United States hard red winter wheat.

title: Liberties;President Pothole
description: The big story on President Clinton's Western swing this week was that Newsweek sent Anna Deavere Smith as its White House correspondent.

title: Extra Pay for School Custodians Is a Waste
description: To the Editor:

title: The F.C.C. Endorses Return Of 23 Television Channels
description: Setting the stage for a clash between the White House and the broadcasting industry, the Federal Communications Commission will propose today that the Government may take back 23 television channels after it switches broadcasters from analog to digital transmission.

title: Wither' and Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;CALDERA SUES MICROSOFT FOR ANTITRUST VIOLATIONS
description: Caldera Inc. said yesterday that it had filed a lawsuit against the Microsoft Corporation for antitrust violations. Caldera said it was seeking unspecified damages and an injunction stopping what it contends is Microsoft's anticompetitive conduct. The lawsuit echoes complaints filed years ago by the Department of Justice, which charged Microsoft with preventing other companies from selling operating system software to personal computer makers. Microsoft and the Justice Department reached a settlement two years ago.

title: CREDIT MARKET;Treasury Prices Post Sharp Fall
description: Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday after demand at an auction of five-year notes was weaker than expected.

title: Michael Ference Jr., 84, Physicist for Ford
description: Michael Ference Jr., a physicist who was in charge of scientific research and development at the Ford Motor Company for almost 20 years, died yesterday in San Antonio. He was 84.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- ROWING;U.S. Women Row to Final
description: The American women's eight advanced to the final on Sunday in its second-chance race today.

title: Christian Bookstores Take a Worldly Lesson
description: At first glance, Ken Hite's bookstore invites comparison with any number of polished, specialty retailers who cater to the leisure-time tastes of the suburban middle class.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- GYMNASTICS;From Shadows, Strug Vaults Into Spotlight
description: Until Kerri Strug landed and grimaced in front of a large crowd and very large television audience on Tuesday night, she had spent her gymnastics career quietly excelling in the shadows of others.

title: Executive Changes
description: BOWNE & CO., New York, appointed Denise K. Fletcher vice president for finance and chief financial officer, succeeding James P. O'Neill, who was recently promoted to president and chief operating officer.

title: World News Briefs;2 Are Acquitted in Death Of a Haitian Minister
description: Two men accused of killing a former Justice Minister, Francois Guy Malary, were found not guilty today. The Ministry of Justice had hoped the trial would mark a new era in which human rights violators would be brought to justice.

title: Brian E. Bent, 35, Chemistry Professor Known for Research
description: Brian E. Bent, an accomplished researcher who was appointed a professor of chemistry at Columbia University this month, died on Tuesday while cycling with his family in Superior National Forest in Minnesota. He was 35 and lived in Manhattan.

title: POP REVIEW;Lovelorn But Edgy, Like Elvis
description: Let all the other cowboy-hatted young country singers try to be the 1990's versions of George Jones or Merle Haggard (minus the private demons). Dwight Yoakam, who helped start country's new traditionalism, has a more ambitious model: Elvis Presley. Of course, Presley never confined himself to country.

title: Stop Carping About 'Primary Colors' Episode
description: To the Editor:

title: JAZZ REVIEW;An Idol in a Playful Mood
description: Branford Marsalis was in a playful mood on Tuesday night at the Village Vanguard. He talked to his brother Jason in the audience and walked around the stage, taking in the scene.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks End Mostly Lower, But Dow Rises 8.14 Points The stock market was weaker yesterday, in another roller-coaster day on Wall Street. But the Dow Jones industrial average managed to snap a three-session losing streak, gaining 8.14 points to close at 5,354.69.

title: Engelhard Says Some Officers Are Targets of S.E.C. Inquiry
description: The Engelhard Corporation said today that the Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating stock sales by certain of its officers following an announcement about a new smog-eating technology for cars.

title: Sports of The Times;Irvin Deserved an Eight-Game Ban by Tagliabue
description: IN his travels with the three-time Super Bowl champion Dallas Cowboys, wide receiver Michael Irvin had a reputation for getting open for passes by pushing off illegally, separating himself from the defensive back trying to cover him.

title: 2 MORE HOSPITALS DECIDE TO MERGE IN NEW YORK CITY
description: In a health care market suddenly overcome by merger fever, two of the oldest and most prestigious hospitals in New York City -- New York Hospital and Presbyterian Hospital -- announced yesterday that they would unite, creating one of the largest not-for-profit health care systems in the country.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Trade Group Concerned About Radio Takeovers
description: The American Association of Advertising Agencies has signaled its unease about a flurry of acquisitions of companies that own radio stations, fearing a result could be steep increases in the cost of radio commercial time.

title: No Headline
description: I heat everything, even salad."

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: Goldwin Golf Inc., Carlsbad, Calif., to Foote, Cone & Belding, San Francisco, a unit of True North Communications, as the first agency to handle advertising for the maker of golf clubs. Billings were estimated at $5 million to $8 million.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Rises Against the Yen On Doubt Over Rate Increase
description: The dollar rose against the Japanese yen as stocks in the United States erased most of their losses and currency traders bet that the Bank of Japan would refrain from raising interest rates anytime soon.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article about Bosnia yesterday misstated the given name of the President of neighboring Serbia. He is Slobodan Milosevic, not Radovan.

title: Economic Scene;Banking help for inner cities: not needed, its critics say.
description: THE creation of a community-owned development bank was not the most newsworthy event in Atlanta yesterday, but will be remembered long after the Olympic gold is gathering dust on mantelpieces. That, at least, is the hope of Andrew M. Cuomo, Assistant Secretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, whose agency is supplying the seed money. "Community banking is critical to empowering people in inner cities," he said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Royals and Appier Close In on Contract
description: KEVIN APPIER and the Kansas City Royals are nearing agreement on a three-year deal, compromising on a no-trade clause that had been the sticking point in negotiations. "We're moving much, much closer," General Manager HERK ROBINSON said yesterday at Fenway Park.

title: Street Divided Hatfield-McCoy Style;Feud Escalates, Block Suffers In Brooklyn
description: There was a time, before the feud, when Blanca Ramirez and Sonia Torres were never apart, their neighbors say. They were friends like that for more than 20 years. Hermanas. Sisters, almost. They double dated. They baby-sat each other's children, bathed them, changed their diapers; Blanca is the godmother of Sonia's oldest boy. When they needed to talk, all the two had to do was open a window and shout across the street.

title: Officer Is Arrested In Shooting in Bronx
description: A transit police officer was arrested yesterday after he shot a man during an off-duty argument in a Bronx restaurant, the police said.

title: World News Briefs;In Reversal, Zimbabwe Bans Gay Rights Exhibit
description: The Government banned a gay rights exhibit from Zimbabwe's annual book fair today, saying that Zimbabweans view homosexuality as "moral repulsiveness."

title: Currents;1,001 Stencils, From Capitals To Columns
description: WHEN Helen Morris, an English decorator, went stencil hunting for a "grand, elaborate" project, all she could find was treacle. "Just fuzzy ducklings and folk-art flowers," she said. So in 1988, she and her partner, Michael Chippendale (yes, related to the furniture maker), opened the Stencil Library to fill the gap. Among the gutsy 1,000-plus motifs designed by Mr. Chippendale are a chinoiserie column (right), giant chess pieces, Napoleon III passementerie, even stencils that mimic crumbling stucco. Cut from polyester film, the stencils cost from about $5 for an Ionic capital to $350 for a 16.5-foot baroque fountain. A 120-page catalogue, about $10, can be ordered from 011-44-1661-844-844, or by sending a fax with credit card information to 011-44-1661-843-984.

title: Planned U.S. Sanctions Anger Europeans
description: Congress's approval of sanctions against countries investing in the energy sector in Libya and Iran has drawn stinging criticism from Europe as another manifestation of United States muscle-flexing, but industry officials say the measures will have little immediate impact on the ability of the two countries to produce oil.

title: Israel Drug Maker Deal
description: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries Ltd. said today it had agreed to buy the British generic drug maker Approved Prescription Services Ltd. and its subsidiaries for $52.7 million in cash from Rhone-Poulenc Rorer Inc., a drug company in Collegeville, Pa., controlled by Rhone-Poulenc S.A.

title: E.P.A.'s New Rules Will Fight Pollution by Watercraft
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is expected to issue Federal regulations next week that for the first time would cut pollution from new recreational watercraft ranging from jet skis to yachts.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;European Commission Clears Air France Aid
description: The European Commission cleared a final installment of state aid worth 5 billion French francs ($1 billion) for Air France yesterday, overriding objections from rival airlines. Other carriers said they wanted the commission to block the last round of aid amid complaints that Air France used subsidies to reduce fares on European routes.

title: Curfew Laws Benefit the Children of Neglect
description: To the Editor

title: Art and Sobriety, One Day at a Time
description: THE asphalt-shingled house in Troy looks like thousands of others that were built for laborers in the late 1800's, when work abounded. Such houses faded, like the ambitions of those who inhabited them, when opportunity moved elsewhere.

title: As for Welfare, Where Have the Liberals Gone?;Connecticut Model
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Saturday about the recommendation by a panel of advisers to the Food and Drug Administration that an abortion-inducing drug, RU-486, or mifepristone, be approved for marketing referred incorrectly to the building in Gaithersburg, Md., where the panel met, and an editorial on Tuesday repeated the error. The building has windows on one side; it is not windowless.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- NOTEBOOK;Some Gymnastics Trickery?
description: In 1992, a talented teen-ager, Tatyana Gutsu, ranked only fourth on her team after the team gymnastics competition concluded. Because three gymnasts from each nation can qualify for the all-around final, that should have been meant the end of Gutsu's all-around hopes.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- ROUNDUP;FENCING: Flessel Leads France in Team Epee
description: Laura Flessel claimed her second fencing gold as she led France to a 45-33 victory over Italy in the women's team epee at the Georgia World Congress Center in Atlanta. France trailed by 10-15 when Flessel faced Elisa Uga in the fifth bout. The French left-hander, winner of the gold in the individual epee on Sunday, rattled up 15 points to put her country ahead by 25-23.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Use of Evidence Is Widened
description: The State Supreme Court ruled yesterday that statements given to police during an illegal interrogation may be used to impeach a defendant's credibility during cross-examination even though they cannot be used as the principal evidence in his trial. The ruling came in the case of Kristina Burris of Deptford, whose 1992 conviction for killing her mother was reversed in 1992, The Associated Press reported.

title: Political Briefing;THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Strategy Republicans Counter Gingrich Scare

title: Deaths of Executives Cancel a Merger
description: Midland Financial Group Inc. and the Danielson Holding Corporation canceled their coming merger yesterday after the deaths of three executives involved in the transaction.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-14

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF FRITZ FALL MORE THAN 55% ON NEWS OF LOSS
description: The shares of the Fritz Companies lost more than half their value yesterday after the company reported a fourth-quarter loss. Fritz, the nation's largest customs broker, also restated third-quarter earnings. It attributed the problems in part to its dismissal of 200 more workers than expected after last year's $210 million acquisition of the Intertrans Corporation. The company said it would take charges totaling $14.6 million to cover employee severance and the integration of the Intertrans accounts with its own. Fritz's shares fell $15.25, to $12.25, in Nasdaq trading of about 15 million shares.

title: Jed Johnson: Grace Interrupted
description: IN an age noted for its "signature" designs, Jed Johnson's signature was grace. Mr. Johnson, who died last week in the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 at the age of 47, became one of the celebrated interior designers of our time not by inventing a style, or by creating anything anyone might call a "look." He seemed to have had a love of all styles, and sought only to practice them softly and respectfully. Yet no one could call Jed Johnson hesitant; if there was anything that marked his designs, it was a forthright determination to make space resonate, to make it glow with that peculiar form of perfection that comes when objects of great quality are well placed in carefully wrought surroundings.

title: SENIOR CLASS;Face-Lift Surgery Gains Adherents
description: THE artist from Manhattan was slim, elegant and 67. "I was having some hard times," she said, "and when I looked in the mirror, I felt I was seeing all that sadness and pain in the wrinkles. It was some stranger in there." That was one reason she decided to have a face lift, but there were others: "I was old, and I was invisible. It was hard getting waited on in stores. Gallery owners wouldn't even look at my work. Something had to be done."

title: Sports of The Times;Every Man's Sacrifices And Pains
description: DAY 6 of the Centennial Olympics, and my Dream Team boycott is holding firm. The schedule says the American rich men are playing medal-contending Lithuania at the Georgia Dome. Couldn't care less. I am returning to my favorite place, the World Congress Center, to be a stranger in a strange land.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- ROUNDUP;WATER POLO: United States Edges Croatia
description: With Chris Duplanty making decisive saves in goal, the United States beat Croatia, 10-8, yesterday at the Georgia Tech Aquatic Center in Atlanta to finish second in its preliminary group and will play Spain for a place in the water polo semifinals. In Barcelona four years ago, Spain took the silver medal while the Americans finished fourth. (AP)

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's;3 Ways To Go Astray
description: 'Romeo et Juliette'

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Bankers Trust New York Corp. is selling $250 million of senior notes due in 1999 through UBS Securities Inc. The notes are priced at 99.755 to yield 6.716 percent and are rated A2 by Moody's Investors Service, A by Standard & Poor's and A by Duff & Phelps.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- SOCCER;Draw With Portugal Is Last Game for U.S.
description: In need of a victory to become the first team to advance to the quarterfinals, the United States men's soccer team was eliminated tonight as it played to a 1-1 tie with Portugal before a record crowd of 58,012 at Robert F. Kennedy Stadium.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;N.F.L. Makes the Call on Irvin: Receiver Suspended for 5 Games
description: In a move that came as no surprise, but dealt a significant blow to the defending Super Bowl champion Dallas Cowboys, National Football League Commissioner Paul Tagliabue yesterday suspended Michael Irvin, the team's Pro Bowl receiver and one of its most vocal leaders, for the first five games of the 1996 season. The ban came nine days after Irvin halted his trial in Dallas by pleading no contest to a felony charge of cocaine possession.

title: Fierce Microbe Is Rising Worldwide Problem
description: Outbreaks of food poisoning caused by a fierce strain of E. coli bacteria like the one now going on in Japan have been growing around the world.

title: Stop Carping About 'Primary Colors' Episode
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS: THIRD PARTY;Perot Aide Now Says Party List Was Never Filed in Colorado
description: Even if the staff of Richard D. Lamm's Presidential campaign played by Perot Reform Committee rules and tried to obtain the list of Reform Party supporters from the Department of State in Mr. Lamm's home state of Colorado, they would not find the data there.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- NOTEBOOK;Hamm's Soccer Status in Doubt
description: Mia Hamm, the star of the United States women's soccer team, was on crutches yesterday when the team arrived in Miami to prepare for its showdown with China tonight at the Orange Bowl.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Music;Composers Wanted, No Experience Needed
description: For the next two weeks, large tracts of the Juilliard School will be overrun by Tod Machover's "Brain Opera," an electronic, computerized and Internet-connected work presented under the auspices of Lincoln Center Festival '96. As technology, it is striking: the audience contributes by playing with electronic gizmos in the lobby before each performance (seven a day, and absolutely free). As music, it is tedious and unpleasant. Such at least was my impression on Tuesday afternoon.

title: Top Judges Back Public Disciplinary Hearings for Lawyers
description: New York State's top judges proposed yesterday that disciplinary hearings for lawyers should be opened to the public as one of several ways to improve confidence in the legal system.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE INFORMATION;Sifting the Rumors
description: A week later, precious few facts are known about the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 that were not known last Wednesday night, shortly after witnesses reported seeing a fireball erupt in the gathering dusk off the coast of Long Island and plunge into the ocean.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Mass Marketing Goes Mass Transit
description: TDI, the outdoor advertising division of Infinity Broadcasting in New York, is introducing advertising in two places it has not appeared before: between the headlights of city buses and on the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan. TDI signed the Arizona Beverages unit of Ferolito, Vultaggio & Sons in Lake Success, L.I., as the first advertiser for what it is calling "headlight displays." The ad posters on the fronts of all 3,400 buses operated by the Metropolitan Transit Authority will be 20 inches by 44 inches. The first posters will promote a new Arizona flavor, green tea with ginseng and honey; they were created by Jean Pettine Graphic Design in Mount Laurel, N.J.,

title: To Aid Vietnam Veterans, Senators 'Lengthen' the War
description: The Senate Veterans' Affairs Committee voted today to rewrite an important part of Vietnam War history. As a result, hundreds of indigent Vietnam veterans moved a step closer to receiving disability benefits.

title: Swaggering Back to 1950's Luxe
description: CIGARS and martinis are back in style. So is that most 1950's of fashion fabrics, duchesse satin. With this return to good old postwar indulgence -- when cars had fins and Dior-clad divas like Thelma Chrysler Foy walked the earth -- it should come as no surprise that old-fashioned haut decor, the home-furnishings equivalent of haute couture, is back on the esthetic radar.

title: Hong Kong Journal;Remnants of Chiang's Army Are Routed Again
description: Along the pathway that tumbles down the hill between banyan and red pine trees, metal door after wood plank door is pasted with white notices in a tidy bureaucratic prose that heralds the death of one of Hong Kong's oldest distinct communities.

title: BASEBALL;Deals for Carter and Gaston
description: Outfielder Joe Carter and Manager Cito Gaston, who helped lead the Toronto Blue Jays to consecutive World Series titles, today agreed to contract extensions through the 1997 season.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants and Top Pick Are Still Miles Apart
description: Cedric Jones has been running wind sprints in the hot sun on a track at the University of Oklahoma. He has been keeping in good shape. But when will Jones, the Giants' top draft pick, report to camp and begin his professional career? That remains a mystery.

title: Longer Terms In New York Lose in a Poll
description: A day after Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani officially placed a referendum on the November ballot asking voters to extend term limits for elected city officials, a new poll released yesterday found that most voters want to keep term limits just the way they are.

title: COMPANY NEWS;COMDISCO BUYING BACK ITS SHARES AND DEBT
description: Comdisco Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy back $100 million in outstanding common and preferred stock, as well as certain debt securities. The company had 50.4 million shares outstanding on June 30. The number of preferred shares and the value of the debt securities was not immediately available. Comdisco, based in Rosemont, Ill., leases and sells computers and other equipment. On the New York Stock Exchange, Comdisco shares were down $1.25, to $22.75.

title: Bridge
description: Bidding in the face of a one no-trump opening presents problems. If the no-trump bid is strong, it is usually wise to stay silent. But it will generally pay to enter the fray with a two-suiter, and there are several conventions designed for this.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- SWIMMING;Ireland's Smith Makes It 3 Golds in the Pool
description: Like a pitcher who has thrown too many innings, Michelle Smith of Ireland awakened today with a sore right shoulder. And she felt tightness from a strained ligament near her rib cage. There was some question whether she would compete in the 200-meter individual medley.

title: Stocks Rebound in Japan
description: Stocks were rebounding somewhat here today, a day after they plunged to their sharpest one-day loss of the year. At the end of the morning session, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 59.28 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,690.31. On Wednesday the Nikkei fell 532.66 points, or 2.52 percent.

title: Civilian Complaint Board Weak, Rights Group Says
description: Only about 22 percent of civilian complaints about excessive force, racial insults and other misconduct by police officers were fully investigations by the Civilian Complaint Review Board over the last two and a half years, and of the cases studied, investigators failed to reach conclusions on 92 percent, according to figures released yesterday by the New York Civil Liberties Union.

title: 2d Home Test for H.I.V. Is Approved
description: A new test for the AIDS virus that can be taken at home went on sale nationwide today, two days after gaining approval by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: PRO FOOTBALL;Ex-Cardinal to Turn 100
description: On Aug. 3, RALPH HORWEEN, a running back for the Chicago Cardinals in 1921-23, will become the first former National Football League player to turn 100 years old, according to the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CARDINAL HEALTH TO BUY PCI SERVICES FOR $145 MILLION
description: Cardinal Health Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire PCI Services Inc., a pharmaceutical packaging company, for $145 million in stock, based on Tuesday's closing price, and the assumption of $56 million in PCI debt. Cardinal Health, a distributor of pharmaceuticals based in Dublin, Ohio, would issue 2.1 million shares, exchanging 0.336 Cardinal Health share for each share of PCI. Shares of Cardinal Health fell $2.125, to $67, on the New York Stock Exchange, while PCI shares rose $5.375, or 33 percent, to $21.50, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Zenith's Chief Executive Resigns
description: Albin Moschner, the president and chief executive of Zenith Electronics, the struggling manufacturer of televisions, has resigned, the company said yesterday.

title: Nasdaq Reports Rise of 1.3% In Its Uncovered Short Sales
description: Open positions of short sales on the Nasdaq market rose 1.3 percent in the most recent month, the National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- ROUNDUP;SOFTBALL: U.S. Pitchers Continue to Dominate
description: Lori Harrigan scattered two hits and Sheila Cornell hit a two-run homer as the United States beat Taiwan, 4-0, at Golden Park in Columbus, Ga. The United States pitchers -- Harrigan, Michele Granger, Christa Williams and Michele Smith -- have allowed only one run as the Americans, the only team without a loss, have outscored their opponents by 29-1 in four games. (AP)

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Davis Traded by Knicks To Raptors for '97 Pick
description: The Knicks had one shooting guard too many. Hubert Davis became the odd man out.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Do-It-Herself Speed Trap
description: Laura Romano recently called the police to complain that cars were speeding in front of her house. Now Mrs. Romano has her very own radar gun, at least for the next few days, thanks to a loan from the Morris Township police.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WANG LABORATORIES PLANS TO ACQUIRE I-NET
description: Wang Laboratories Inc., the computer software maker, announced yesterday that it was buying I-NET Inc., a computer network services company, for $167 million. Wang plans to pay I-NET $100 million in cash and a $66.7 million one-year interest-free note. It plans to also assume about $40 million of existing I-NET debt. The acquisition would add more than $300 million to Wang's revenues in the 1997 fiscal year, the company said. I-NET specializes in network computing services, one of the fastest-growing segments of the data technology services market. Wang, based in Billerica, Mass., also said that it earned $34.6 million, or 13 cents a share, in its fourth quarter, which ended on June 30, compared with earnings of $33.3 million, or 9 cents, in the period a year earlier.

title: Last of 13 Rail Unions Agrees to Contract
description: Freight railroads reached a tentative agreement on a new contract with the last of their 13 major unions on Tuesday night three hours before the end of a 30-day cooling-off period.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Cigarette Tax Rise Doubtful
description: Legislation to raise the cigarette tax by 25 cents a pack and ask voters to set aside the additional revenue for school construction appeared to be in trouble yesterday, and Senate President Donald T. DiFrancesco said he would not schedule the bills for a vote today without assurance of some Democratic votes.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;E. I. DU PONT DE NEMOURS & CO. (DD,N)
description: Du Pont said yesterday that second-quarter earnings rose nearly 7 percent on higher petroleum prices and higher profits from Lycra spandex fibers and plastics.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- NOTEBOOK;Reynolds Feels Rage And Is Ready to Run
description: When Butch Reynolds walked into Olympic Stadium for the opening ceremony of the Atlanta Games, tears welled in his eyes.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6
description: Irish Swimmer Continues to Strike Gold

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Tiger Economy Has Become a Fading Vision For Vietnam
description: After a Communist Party congress in early July, the American assessment of Vietnam's newly announced economic policies came down to this: "Nothing horrible happened."

title: THEATER REVIEW;If a Black Doll Is Bad, A Child Sees the Racism
description: The majesty of the law, the humble people who challenge entrenched injustice, the indefatigable lawyers whose vision of society accepts no shackles on Constitutional promise may seem unlikely subjects for children's theater.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800 -- THE OVERVIEW;Navy Retrieves 2 'Black Boxes' From Sea Floor
description: The Navy retrieved two "black boxes" from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 on the ocean floor early today following a weeklong, painstaking search of the murky waters off East Moriches, L.I.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Meadowlands Land Trust
description: The agency that is guiding development of the Meadowlands took a step yesterday to create a private organization to preserve open space within the environmentally sensitive 21,000-acre district.

title: College Tours, Yes. But Camp Scouting?
description: GRIDLOCK alert: There could be huge traffic jams this weekend on rural roads from New York to Maine. What's going on? The new family ritual: scouting out summer camps.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 6 -- CYCLING;Kelly, All-World on Wheels, Falters at Start
description: The 1,000-meter time trial is the killer of velodrome cycling. In a little more than a minute, the riders race one at a time against the clock for almost five-eighths of a mile. No trials, no second-chance heats, just one all-out blast of raw speed.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Propagating Calycanthus
