title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Roenick Wants Out
description: JEREMY ROENICK, arguably the best center on the United States hockey team, will not play in the World Cup tournament if he doesn't have a new contract by Aug. 1, his agent said.

title: BASEBALL;Coors Field Is an Extra Nightmare For Mets
description: It's just as well that the Mets are finished with Coors Field for the season. They can't out-pitch the Rockies and they can't out-hit them, either. Not even four home runs, including two by Bernard Gilkey, could produce a victory in this chamber of horrors.

title: Background Checks
description: To The Home Section:

title: ART REVIEW;Celebrating Size and Rough Simplicity. Still.
description: Too bad "Big," the title of a Broadway musical, is taken. It could go up in lights on the Ace Gallery, just beyond SoHo's western edge and currently filled with extra-large sculptures by Jene Highstein. Mr. Highstein, 54, emerged in the early 1970's, when sculpture increased substantially in size and artists were sorting around for alternatives to Minimalism. Mr. Highstein's solution, shared with other young artists like Joel Shapiro, Elizabeth Murray, Judy Rifka, centered on simplified single shapes of a relaxed geometry that felt somewhat organic and handmade.

title: FILM REVIEW;D'ja Hear the One About the Bowlers?
description: The team that gave the world "Dumb and Dumber" returns today with something feeble and feebler.

title: ON BASEBALL;Some Want Tradition to Stay Intact
description: Yankee Stadium, with its tradition and grandeur, means different things to different people.

title: South African Court Approves Amnesty for Apartheid Crimes
description: South Africa's top court ruled today in favor of the country's new Truth and Reconciliation Commission, confirming its right to offer amnesty to those who come forward and testify about their role in past atrocities.

title: Fixed-Rate Mortgage Dips
description: Thirty-year fixed-rate mortgages averaged 8.19 percent this week, down from 8.23 percent last week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. It was the lowest rate since June 3, when rates averaged 8.14 percent. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 6.01 percent, up from 5.97 percent last week. Fifteen-year mortgages averaged 7.71 percent this week, down from 7.76 percent a week earlier.

title: FILM REVIEW;From Hong Kong, Thrills, Chills and Stunts Galore
description: To put it plainly right at the outset, "Supercop," as its title implies, is a moving comic book. The plot of this new Jackie Chan film is so ready-made it could come in a can from H. J. Heinz. The heroes are impervious. The villains are made of cardboard and just as easily disposable. So the only real question is this: Once the action begins to accelerate, how's the ride?

title: COMPANY NEWS;TRANSAMERICA TO ACQUIRE CONTAINER LEASING COMPANY
description: The Transamerica Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire Trans Ocean Ltd. of San Bruno, Calif., a closely held container leasing company, for $110 million in stock. Transamerica, a financial services concern based in San Francisco, said the acquisition would complement its Transamerica Leasing unit. The company also announced that it planned to buy back another two million of its shares. Transamerica has already bought 1.6 million shares under a similar program approved in March. Shares of the company slipped 12.5 cents, to $70.875.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800;The President's Remarks at Kennedy to the Families of the Crash Victims
description: Following is the text of President Clinton's remarks after meeting the families of the victims of Trans World Airlines Flight 800. The remarks were transcribed by the Federal Document Clearing House.

title: Home Video
description: Delay of the Disk

title: 25-Cent Cigarette Tax Rise Dies in Trenton Senate
description: The State Senate President withdrew legislation tonight that would have allowed voters to decide in November whether to raise the cigarette tax by 25 cents a pack to help pay for a $1 billion school construction program.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;Swimming Lake Hopatcong
description: As his fellow American swimmers go for the gold in Atlanta today, Bill Bulger will be reaching for his own moment of glory: he is trying to become the first person in living memory to swim around Lake Hopatcong, the state's largest lake. Mr. Bulger, a 5-foot-10, 220-pound, 53-year-old elevator repairman, was scheduled to hit the water last night. Except for a few 30-second breaks to refuel with pasta, Gatorade and pureed stew, he does not intend to stop until 24 hours later. Although the lake has a shoreline of more than 45 miles, Mr. Bulger said he intended to shave off a few coves and do his lap in about 25 miles. TERRY PRISTIN

title: City Seeks Inquiry Into Foster Agency
description: Financial irregularities at a foster care agency in Harlem, including an alleged misappropriation of $1 million, has prompted the commissioner of the city's Administration for Children's Services to ask the Manhattan District Attorney's Office to seize control of its records, officials said yesterday.

title: FILM REVIEW;That Boy of the Telltale Nose Who's Too Good to Be Wood
description: Anyone who competes with a classic has to take the consequences.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bid From Hays For Christian Salvesen
description: Christian Salvesen P.L.C. said yesterday that it had received a bid from Hays P.L.C., a British office services company. Salvesen, a distributor of consumer goods and food, did not disclose the bid, which it said it was considering. As of yesterday, Salvesen's had a market capitalization of around L1 billion ($1.56 billion). The acquisition would catapult Hays into the ranks of Britain's 100 largest companies, at around 75th place. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: Moscow Journal;Secrets of the K.G.B.: A Very Discreet Disrobing
description: When the secret police came for Osip Mandelstam in 1938, the one book that this century's greatest Russian poet managed to take with him on his lonely road to Siberian exile and death was Dante's "Inferno."

title: Art in Review
description: 'Delirium' Ricco Maresca Gallery 152 Wooster Street SoHo Through Sept. 8

title: COMPANY NEWS;HAMBRECHT & QUIST EXPECTS $59.5 MILLION FROM ISSUE
description: Hambrecht & Quist Group of San Francisco said it planned to raise $59.5 million in its initial public offering, which was expected to be priced in the week of Aug. 12. The investment bank, which specializes in taking technology companies public, filed to sell 3.5 million shares at $15 to $17 each, or a 15.8 percent stake, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. The offering valued the company as high as $357.7 million. The firm, which postponed its offering from July 15, filed the details of its offer yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Diner's Journal
description: At this time of year, many of us are so eager to eat outside that we pay big prices for mediocre food, often sitting in some sad excuse for a garden.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;U S WEST COMMUN. GROUP INC. (USW,N)
description: U S West Communications Group, the regional Bell company based near Denver, said yesterday that its profit rose 10.6 percent in the second quarter, as it installed a record number of new telephone lines.

title: On My Mind;A Certain Treason
description: Day after day now America's allies deliver warnings to its people and government. These democracies, which the U.S. counts as its best friends, warn they will take reprisals against America if it tries to reduce their investments in three dictatorships America counts among its worst enemies -- Iran, Libya, Cuba. Heed our threats, say our friends.

title: Virginia Christine, TV's Mrs. Olson, 76
description: Virginia Christine, a character actress who portrayed the motherly Mrs. Olson in Folger's coffee television commercials for 21 years, died on Wednesday at her home in the Brentwood section of Los Angeles. She was 76.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7;Olympic Diary
description: The menu at the Mambo Restaurante Cubano on shady Highland Avenue has nourishment for the displaced Cuban's soul. It features black beans, garlic-scented yucca, plantains, paella and instructions on how to help a Cuban Olympian to defect.

title: New Video Releases
description: City Hall 1996. Columbia Tri-Star. $102.95. Laser disk, $34.95. 112 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: New Video Releases
description: Homeward Bound 2: Lost in San Francisco 1996. Disney. $22.99. 89 minutes. Closed captioned. G. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Flooding in China Sweeps Thousands of Villages
description: Floods have ravaged several central provinces in China in recent days, as heavy rainfall and a swelling Yangtze River have waterlogged thousands of villages and towns, destroyed hundreds of thousands of homes and damaged millions of others.

title: Mother Sentenced to Life in a Killing That Shook Chicago
description: It was a crime that convulsed this city. On a spring day three years ago, Amanda Wallace wrapped a brown extension cord around the neck of her 3-year-old son, Joey, waved to him as he waved goodbye, and hanged him from a transom.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Every fashion designer should have a fan as devoted as WYNTON MARSALIS, the trumpeter and artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center.

title: Durable Goods Orders Fell More Than Forecast in June
description: Orders for durable goods declined in June, weighed down by weaker demand for aircraft, cars and business equipment, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DEMAND FOR SATURNS EXCEEDS PRODUCTION
description: Saturn could sell about 50,000 more cars a year if it could produce them, the president of the General Motors Corporation's small-car unit said yesterday. While Don Hudler said Saturn continued to make improvements to increase production at its Spring Hill, Tenn., plant, he gave no indication when or if G.M. would foot the bill to expand the plant or build another. An additional 50,000 cars sold would generate more than $600 million in annual revenue. Mr. Hudler also said Saturn was studying a possible expansion of its three-model lineup. His comments came as Saturn showed off its redesigned coupe, the 1997 SC1 and SC2, to Detroit's automotive press. The company sold 285,674 cars last year, about the same as 1994, which amounted to a 10 percent share of the combined small-car and sport coupe segments. The company said sales are up about 4 percent so far this year.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: SOCCER;Tired and Missing Hamm, U.S. Can Only Tie China
description: The United States women's soccer coach, Tony DiCicco, was not exactly thrilled tonight that his team had to travel here from Orlando for its final qualifying game, even though a crowd of 43,525 -- an American record for women's soccer -- showed up at the Orange Bowl.

title: Make the New Technology Fit the Worker
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: Roy Fowler 'Paintings Project II' 155 Mercer Street, SoHo Through Aug. 31

title: In America;Finance The Meat Bill
description: Three weeks ago President Clinton announced that the Department of Agriculture was adopting a set of new regulations designed to improve the nation's meat inspection system.

title: Sports of The Times;Prime Time Gets Invaded by Outsiders
description: BAD for ratings. Bad for business. The foreigners are taking away the medals. This isn't the way it was supposed to turn out for American television or commerce, with Liliya Podkopayeva of Ukraine winning the all-around gold medal in last-second dramatics.

title: Girl Meets Bug: It's Love, and Very Educational
description: MY daughter loves bugs. I do not. But I love my daughter, and so, on a recent Saturday morning, she and I hopped on the No. 7 subway train at Times Square and headed for the New York Hall of Science in Queens, where an exhibition called "Backyard Monsters: The World of Insects" is ensconced through Oct. 27.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: SWIMMING;Ireland's Smith Eyes 4th Gold
description: Michelle Smith of Ireland is the most successful and controversial athlete at the Summer Games. With a victory Friday night in the 200-meter butterfly, Smith would become only the third swimmer to win four individual gold medals at one Summer Games, equaling the achievements of Mark Spitz in 1972 and East Germany's Kristin Otto in 1988. And that would enliven rumors of performance-enhancing drug use.

title: Sri Lankans Counterattack In Rebel Area
description: Sri Lankan Air Force planes bombed Tamil rebels near a besieged northern army base today, a military spokesman said. The counterattack came a day after two bombs killed 78 people on a packed train near the capital.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball Major League Baseball American League BALTIMORE ORIOLES -- Placed OF Mark Smith on the 15-day disabled list, retroactive to July 23. Recalled RHP Garrett Stephenson from Rochester of the International League. KANSAS CITY ROYALS -- Agreed to terms with RHP Kevin Appier on a three-year contract. National League ATLANTA BRAVES -- Claimed LHP Dean Hartgraves off waivers from the Houston Astros.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;GATEWAY 2000 INC. (GATE, NNM)
description: Gateway 2000 Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose 48 percent in the second quarter, as sales continued to grow at one of the fastest rates in the personal computer industry.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: VOLLEYBALL;Cuban Men Hand Erratic U.S. Team Its First Setback
description: Going into tonight's first-place showdown with Cuba, Bob Ctvrtlik, the team captain and a veteran of two Olympics, was hoping the young United States men's volleyball team would hit a steady groove.

title: TV Debate Set for Congressional Leaders
description: Officials of the Public Broadcasting Service said today that they were planning a live, nationally televised night of debates this fall featuring the Republican and Democratic leaders in Congress.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800;Experts Say Greek Airport's Precautions Against Bombing Are Better Than Kennedy's
description: Immediately after the crash of T.W.A. Flight 800 on July 17, speculation focused on the possibility that the plane had been sabotaged at its previous stop before New York, the airport in Athens.

title: NYC;The Ways Of Taking Responsibility
description: IF you want to learn how some top executives shoulder responsibility at moments of truth, you can do worse than to examine recent news stories of New York origin and national import. The picture, many would agree, is not a pretty one.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: MOURNERS;They Lived and Died Together. Now a Town's Youths Will Rest Together.
description: In the small town hit hardest by the crash of Flight 800, people have begun attending two funerals a day, a pace they will most likely keep up for a week or more as Montoursville buries its 21 dead.

title: INTERNTIONAL BUSINESS;Mexico Says It Will Repay $7 Billion To the U.S.
description: The Mexican Government helped the Clinton Administration neutralize a potentially difficult election-year problem today, announcing that early next month it would pay back $7 billion to the United States.

title: Company Briefs
description: LIVING CENTERS OF AMERICA INC., Houston, a provider of long-term health care, said it would sell one of its training units, Living Centers-DevCon, to American Habilitations Services Inc., for $47.5 million. It also said it would buy back $20 million of its common stock.

title: 25 and Under
description: Any place named Moustache would seem to exude mischief, but things are serious at this tiny Middle Eastern restaurant on a pretty block in the West Village.

title: Stocks Rebound in Japan
description: Stock prices were continuing to rebound here today from a steep selloff on Wednesday. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 135.35 points, or 0.65 percent, at 21,019.19. On Thursday, the Nikkei rose 252.81 points, or 1.23 percent, almost half of the ground lost on Wednesday, when the Nikkei plummeted 532.66 points, or 2.52 percent, its biggest one-day loss of the year.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE DIVERS;Scouring a Cold, Dim Ocean Floor
description: For the last week their world has been where their bodies are not biologically equipped to be: more than 100 feet below the surface of the Atlantic Ocean, in waters as dark as dusk, moving gingerly around and above the metal and human remains of Trans World Airlines Flight 800.

title: Let's Get Smart About Those 'Smart' Weapons
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about new account policies at Chase Manhattan Bank following its merger with Chemical Bank misstated the balances required to avoid fees by a rival New York bank, Republic National Bank of New York. Republic's customers must keep $1,500 in any combination of accounts to avoid the fees; the bank does not require customers to keep $1,500 in a checking account or $3,000 in combined accounts.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7;To Foreign Press, Games Are an Olympian Blunder
description: From warm Cokes to overheated American chauvinism, from snarled traffic to computer mix-ups, the foreign press has jumped all over the Olympic Games in Atlanta this week, slamming the organizers for an event that headline writers around the world have already summed up as "chaotic."

title: Primary Colors' Author Resigns As Commentator at CBS News
description: CBS News yesterday accepted the resignation of Joe Klein, the political journalist and Newsweek magazine columnist who has been under fire for lying to preserve his anonymity as the author of the novel "Primary Colors."

title: COMPANY REPORTS;I.B.M. Soars as It Beats Quarterly Expectations
description: I.B.M. said yesterday that its profits declined much less in the second quarter than analysts had expected and that its business would improve in the second half of the year. The combined reports sent I.B.M. shares soaring nearly 13 percent and sparked a rally that lifted the rest of the market.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE FUTURE;Delays for Travelers and Higher Costs for Airlines
description: The new aviation security measures imposed today by the Clinton Administration will confront passengers between American cities with the kinds of long lines, detailed searches and interrogations that international voyagers are used to, and flights out of the country will be scrutinized even more intensively.

title: First Nationwide Said to Be in Talks for Cal Fed
description: The First Nationwide Bank FSB, which is controlled by the financier Ronald O. Perelman, is in talks to acquire California Federal Bancorp Inc. in a deal valued at more than $1 billion, a person close to the negotiations said today.

title: AT&T and Microsoft in Software Distribution Pact
description: AT&T and Microsoft said yesterday that they had formed an alliance in which each would distribute the other's on-line software. The alliance is similar to ones Microsoft forged earlier this year with America Online and Compuserve.

title: New Video Releases
description: Othello 1995. Columbia Tri-Star. $100.71. Laser disk, $39.95. 123 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;Banning Unwanted Papers
description: The Senate passed a bill yesterday that would ban the delivery of newspapers to people who do not want them, The Associated Press reported. Democratic opponents said the measure infringed on the newspapers' First Amendment rights to disseminate their publications, but Republican supporters said it was needed because throwaway newspapers were a nuisance. Under the bill, which goes to the Assembly, a newspaper would have 14 days to halt delivery after receiving a written request. After that, employees who make unwanted deliveries could be charged with littering, punishable by a $100 fine.

title: COMPANY NEWS;READICARE BOARD REJECTS BID FROM OCCUSYSTEMS
description: Readicare Inc. said yesterday that its board had rejected an acquisition offer from Occusystems Inc. worth about $60 million. Occusystems, of Dallas, a physician practice management company that focuses on occupational health care, had proposed a stock swap valued at $7 for each share of Readicare common stock. As of May 31, Readicare had about 8.5 million shares outstanding. Readicare said it believed its shares were worth more than $7. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., operates 41 outpatient medical centers in the West. It specializes in occupational health care services. Shares of Readicare jumped 87.5 cents yesterday, to $4.875.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Boeing Earnings Stronger Than Expected
description: Buoyed by the settlement of some longstanding disputes regarding military contracts with the Government and a pickup in orders for commercial aircraft, the Boeing Company reported unexpectedly strong earnings yesterday. Excluding the effect of the settlement and other nonrecurring items, the company, based in Seattle, modestly outperformed estimates by most Wall Street analysts.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;AMERICAN INT'L GROUP INC. (AIG,N)
description: The American International Group, the insurance company, said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 14 percent.

title: Alerts in Hawaii as Undersea Volcano Erupts
description: The world's most active volcano, now in its 14th year of continuous eruption, is generating swarms of earthquakes powerful enough to concern Civil Defense officials here.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Quarterly Profits Slip At British Telecom
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said yesterday that its pretax profit slipped in the latest quarter as staff-cutting costs more than doubled and profits tightened in the cellular telephone business. Pretax profit in the quarter that ended on June 30 was L869 million ($1.34 billion), down from L874 million a year earlier. Sales were L3.64 billion, up from L3.5 billion.

title: New Israelis With Ideas as Big as the Russian Sky
description: Glancing through a sheaf of papers while rattling off the fine points of a debate he had just attended in Parliament, Yuri Shtern talked to visitors in his spartan office with the air of a practiced legislator.

title: War in Bangladesh Was Ignited by a Massacre
description: To the Editor:

title: Gene May Be Clue to Nature of Nurturing
description: Mutant mice that ignore their own infants, allowing them to die from neglect, provide new evidence that in mammals the very essence of mothering -- the ability to nurture the young -- has an important genetic component.

title: FILM REVIEW;Love on the Literate Side
description: What, you ask, is the pompatus of love?

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;Tick Did Infect Whitman
description: Results of a blood test show that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman has indeed been infected by a tick, as was suspected, but do not establish whether she has Lyme disease or some other tick-borne illness, a spokesman said yesterday. The Governor is feeling well enough to leave for Alaska later today for a family vacation, the spokesman, Carl Golden, said.

title: Wall Street Bond Rating Firm Faults New York Budget
description: Moody's Investors Service, one of the Wall Street firms that rates New York State's bonds, sharply criticized the new state budget today, saying it failed to solve the problem of recurring deficits and virtually insures long and bitter budget fights in the coming years.

title: Sports of The Times;The World's Fastest Human Fish
description: IN their teeny-weeny bikini swim suits, their long, hairless bodies are so smooth they resemble undressed male mannequins in a department store window. Each is all long arms, long torso and long legs. And all athlete. But each is also all fish.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;Dead Pilot Is Identified
description: The pilot who was killed Wednesday when his single-engine plane crashed eight miles out at sea was identified yesterday as Albert J. Battifarano, 76, of Howell Township. Mr. Battifarano, who was flying solo, took off from Allaire Airport in Wall Township, where he was a familiar figure for the past 20 years. The cause of the crash is under investigation.

title: Indian Heritage Law Saps Adoption System
description: To the Editor:

title: Senate Approves a Bill to Track Cooperation Against Terrorism
description: The Senate voted unanimously today to require the State Department, as part of its reporting on terrorism, to give detailed information on how much individual countries cooperate in helping the United States fight terrorists.

title: Bank of Boston Picks President
description: The Bank of Boston today named Henrique de Campos Meirelles, president of its Brazilian subsidiary, as its president and chief operating officer.

title: House Panel Backs Rescue of S.& L. Fund
description: In a surprise move, the House Banking Committee approved a plan today that would revive the savings and loan industry's shaky deposit insurance fund by having the Federal Reserve pay part of the bill.

title: FILM REVIEW;One Bar, One Uprising And Countless Changes
description: I don't do tears! I don't do angry!" huffs LaMiranda (Guillermo Diaz), a lean, streetwise drag queen, after being roughed up by the police during a routine raid on the Stonewall Inn, a gay bar in Greenwich Village. It is 1969, only weeks before the famous Stonewall uprising that officially ushered in the gay liberation era, and LaMiranda has just had her face repeatedly dunked (or "washed" as the police sneeringly put it) in a dishpan full of dirty water. Her defender, Matty Dean (Frederick Weller), who has recently arrived in New York from the Midwest, is sobbing after being punched in the nose by a policeman. All he did was point out that LaMiranda wasn't hurting anyone by applying her lipstick.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: BASEBALL;U.S. Home Run Derby Bashes Japan, 15-5
description: The final piece to the United States baseball team has been found.

title: Hartford School Integration Panel Formed
description: Gov. John G. Rowland took the first step today toward complying with a State Supreme Court order to integrate Hartford's schools with its suburban neighbors, establishing a panel to develop recommendations for the next legislative session.

title: House Rejects Gingrich Plan For Spending On Elections
description: With Democratic opposition unbroken and Republicans deserting in droves, the House of Representatives today defeated Speaker Newt Gingrich's election-year effort at passing a law on financing Congressional campaigns.

title: On Stage, and Off
description: How Little Deals Add Up to a Big Deal

title: FILM REVIEW;Ghosts Inspiring a New Life
description: Small and serenely peculiar, Sara Driver's "When Pigs Fly" summons two ghosts and a rocking chair into the life of a lonely musician. The spirits, a formidable woman (Marianne Faithfull) and a sprightly little girl (Rachael Bella), are forever linked to the chair because each of them died there, though their deaths were a century apart.

title: Kodak to Expand Output
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it would start production of disposable cameras at its new factory in Guadalajara, Mexico, by the end of 1997. Kodak said the plant would meet growing demand, particularly in Latin America. The company will continue to make the cameras at Rochester and in France. The Rochester plant will support the Guadalajara operation by exporting film.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;First-Half Profit Increase At Software Maker SAP
description: SAP A.G., the world's fifth-largest software maker, said yesterday that its first-half operating profit rose a better-than-expected 60.5 percent, to 374 million marks ($251 million), as costs rose more slowly than sales. Revenue at SAP, which is based in Germany, rose 38.1 percent, to 1.594 billion marks, from 1.154 billion marks in the corresponding period last year, as it added 500 new institutional customers and sales soared in international markets. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE OVERVIEW;CLINTON SETS TOUGH RULES FOR TIGHTER AIR SECURITY; TAPE REVEALS SUDDEN NOISE
description: After spending almost three somber hours with relatives of the victims killed in the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, President Clinton announced yesterday that he had ordered several steps to tighten security at the nation's airports, including heightened scrutiny of passengers, luggage and cargo.

title: ART REVIEW;Honing the Cutting Edge Of Conservative Styles
description: The National Academy of Design's annual juried exhibitions have an uninterrupted track record dating back to 1826, and have showcased some major talent in their time. Several of the paintings in the much-praised Winslow Homer retrospective now at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, for instance, made their public debut under the academy's auspices more than a century ago.

title: MONUMBENT TO DECAY;Toll Is Even Greater In Forgotten Anacostia
description: Markeisha Richardson is a tall, athletic 13-year-old who lives in Valley Green, a public-housing development built in 1961. By the 1980's, it had come to be known as Death Valley, for all the killings in and around its 312 apartments.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Xerox Net Rose 23.1% In 2d Quarter
description: The Xerox Corporation said yesterday that its earnings rose 23.1 percent in the second quarter, driven by revenue from its business of managing document processing for other companies and by cost cuts.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TEREX TO SELL CLARK MATERIAL UNIT FOR $135 MILLION
description: The Terex Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its worldwide Clark Material Handling Company business for $135 million to a unit of Nesco, a privately held company based in Cleveland. Proceeds from the sale would be used to retire debt. Terex, based in Westport, Conn., makes a range of heavy-duty off-road trucks, mobile cranes, aerial work platforms and forklifts. Shares of Terex rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $9.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Documents Tie Hiring of Aide in Files Case to First Lady
description: Less than two months after President Clinton took office, the White House counsel told an F.B.I. agent that the First Lady had recommended Craig Livingstone as head of the White House security office, according to documents disclosed today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Fruitopia Changes Its Campaign Slogan
description: The Coca-Cola Company has changed the slogan for its Fruitopia line of beverages after a complaint from Saab Cars USA Inc., which uses a similar slogan.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PRONET AND TELETOUCH END MERGER AGREEMENT
description: Pronet Inc.'s plan to buy Teletouch Communications Inc. for $181 million has been ended by mutual agreement, Teletouch said yesterday. Shares of Teletouch fell 62.5 cents, to $2.75 a share. Pronet stock was up 87.5 cents, to $8.25. Both companies provide paging services. Pronet, based in Dallas, had agreed in April to buy Teletouch, of Tyler, Tex., for $75 million in common stock, the assumption of $91 million of debt and the purchase for cash of about $15 million of preferred stock.

title: JAZZ REVIEW;Prodding His Big Band Into Ever Hotter Rhythms
description: There aren't too many young straight-ahead jazz pianists longing to lead a big band. Today's standard pianistic role models weave convoluted harmony into small ensembles, McCoy Tyner and Keith Jarrett, for example. An effective big-band pianist has to throw most of that away: he must prod with marshaling chords, ring octaves over the din and keep well out of the way of the band's various sections.

title: ART REVIEW;When Faster and Cheaper Is Not Necessarily Better
description: The eloquent process of photogravure, once widely used for reproducing photographs, is finding favor again with contemporary artists. The method, which involves creating a copper printing plate from a photographic positive, was developed in the late 19th century but gave way after World War I to faster, cheaper and less intricate ways of printing multiple copies. Still unsurpassed for high-quality reproduction, however, with its capacities for conveying subtle tones, retaining the crispness of details, and thick, lustrous inking, hand-pulled photogravure has been rediscovered today by such artists as John Baldessari, Lorna Simpson, William Wegman, Christian Boltanski and the team of McDermott and McGough, for works that range from cutting edge to deliberately old-fangled pastiche.

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows in the New York metropolitan region that are to close soon:

title: Corrections
description: A sports article on Sunday about the Olympic water polo rivalry between Hungary and Russia misidentified the leader of the Soviet-backed Hungarian regime in 1958. He was Janos Kadar. Imre Nagy, his predecessor, was removed from power in 1956 and hanged two years later.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Philips Posts a Surprise Loss And Plans a 6,000-Job Cut
description: Philips Electronics N.V. reported an unexpected second-quarter loss today as it took a charge of $454 million to pay for 6,000 job cuts worldwide in its consumer electronics division.

title: Unit of B.A.T. Plans to Sell 6 Cigarette Lines
description: The Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to sell six discount cigarette brands and a North Carolina factory to a small maker of off-price cigarettes.

title: Bob Dole, on the Road
description: Bob Dole has found his campaign slogan, and if punctuation is power, this one is a winner.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-12

title: Man Pleads Guilty in Shooting Of Stagehand on Midtown Street
description: A man who shot and killed an NBC stagehand because, he said, television networks had spied on him pleaded guilty to manslaughter and weapons charges yesterday, and will receive a sentence of 12 1/2 to 25 years in prison, the District Attorney's office in Manhattan said.

title: IN HIS OWN WORDS: BOB DOLE
description: Speaking to a group of Republicans yesterday in Harrisburg, Pa.:

title: Kenneth Straus, Macy's Heir And Philanthropist, Dies at 71
description: Kenneth Hollister Straus, a New York philanthropist and the last of the Straus family to be a top executive of R. H. Macy & Company, died on Wednesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 71 and had homes on the Upper East Side of Manhattan and in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Profit Rises in First Half At Commerzbank
description: Commerzbank A.G., Germany's third-largest publicly traded bank, said yesterday that its operating profit rose 47.6 percent in the first half as heavy stock market trading helped commission income. Operating profit rose to 1.32 billion marks ($886 million), from 897 million marks in the first half of 1995, exceeding analysts' expectations. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;A TV News Marriage That Might Have Been
description: Television couples don't get much odder than this: CBS News and Fox Broadcasting. But those two entities held serious high-level discussions about the possibility of becoming partners in an all-news cable channel.

title: INSIDE
description: Burundi Army Stages Coup And Names New President

title: In Ancient Egypt, the Beer of Kings Was a Sophisticated Brew
description: No temple friezes and certainly no billboards proclaimed it the king of beers, but it was the beer of pharaohs, and of their workers whose labors on pyramids and stately tombs were rewarded with a generous flow of the brews that made ancient Memphis or Thebes famous.

title: DEAL IN CONGRESS GIVES HEALTH BILL A NEW MOMENTUM
description: Two of the most powerful members of Congress announced tonight that they had solved the major problem blocking passage of legislation to make health insurance more readily available to millions of Americans.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: SWIMMING;Golden Torch Passed From Evans to Bennett
description: When she was 8 years old, Brooke Bennett watched raptly from her living room as Janet Evans won three gold medals at the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul. With her medal haul, Evans gave Bennett an unintentional but indelible bit of career counseling.

title: T. Clark Hull, 75, Ex-Politician and Judge
description: T. Clark Hull, a former lieutenant governor and State Supreme Court justice who was one of Connecticut's most irreverent and popular politicians, died yesterday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 75 and lived in Danbury.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: ROUNDUP
description: FIELD HOCKEY

title: CHRONICLE
description: Is it time for a kinder, gentler JACKIE CHAN? The Hong Kong superstar seems exceedingly concerned that he draw women and families to his daredevil movies.

title: A Surly New York As Olympic Host?
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurant Reversal For Japanese Company
description: Restaurant Associates, the company that launched such legendary Manhattan restaurants as The Four Seasons and the Brasserie plans to buy back all its stock from its Japanese owner of six years. The buyback reflects a continuing about-face by the Japanese on the American business landscape, as their companies have been divesting themselves of major United States investments that have included MCA and Rockefeller Center.

title: Mr. Clinton Moves on Air Security
description: After a week of frustrating search for the wreckage and victims of T.W.A. Flight 800, yesterday was a day of progress. While investigators examined the voice and data recorders recovered from the ocean floor, President Clinton moved to tighten airport security and console the distressed and confused relatives of the 230 victims.

title: New Video Releases
description: Diabolique 1996. Warner. $100.71. Laser disk, $34.98. 107 minutes. Closed captioned. R. Release date: Tuesday.

title: Perry Is to Seek Saudi Funds To Build Safer Troop Quarters
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry is to return to Saudi Arabia next week to try to persuade Saudi leaders to approve and help pay for a major overhaul of security for American troops there, Administration officials said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There are debuts left to make, or at least there are for GENE WILDER, the veteran actor, who will make his first appearance on a British stage in "Laughter on the 23d Floor," The Times of London reported this week.

title: About Real Estate;Westchester Development Is On Again
description: At Rosecliff, a development of single-family houses overlooking the Hudson River in the Westchester County community of Briarcliff Manor, construction has been stop and go since it began in the building boom of the mid-1980's.

title: Doctors in Sweden Document That a Severed Spinal Cord Can RepairItself
description: In what one scientist called a tour de force, a group of researchers in Sweden has succeeded for the first time in growing nerve cells across gaps in severed spinal cords in rats.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: YACHTING;Windy Day in Savannah
description: With a southerly breeze building to 22 knots, yesterday was the windiest race day Olympic sailors have seen. For the third day in four, afternoon thunderstorms reached towering heights, whipping waves to four feet and causing gusts to 36 knots. A number of heavy-air specialists leap-frogged their competition, but three consistent sailors widened their leads in Savannah, Ga.

title: No Headline
description: How can it fail to ease the pain? It's an act of kindness. It makes me feel good that the President is coming down to console us. He represents the country."

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Mark Surges and Dollar Falls As Germany Fails to Cut Rates
description: The mark surged and the dollar fell yesterday after the Bundesbank surprised currency traders by leaving German interest rates unchanged.

title: 3 More Prisoners Die in Turkish Hunger Strike
description: Three more prisoners died today in a nationwide hunger strike by nearly 2,000 inmates in Turkey's jails, bringing the death toll to six.

title: Market Place;To some newspaper publishers, TV has never looked better.
description: NEWSPAPER companies' earnings in the three months from April through June, lifted by advertisements for Easter sales and summer travel promotions, are normally second only to those in the last quarter, when papers are thick with ads for holiday shopping. But this year, without the strong earnings of their broadcast divisions, some newspaper companies would have reported profits that were flat, at best.

title: Inquiry Exonerates 2 In Death of Heiress
description: A criminal investigation into the death of the tobacco heiress Doris Duke has found "no credible evidence" that she was murdered.

title: Will Dole Pick Gov. Ridge? Tease Adds to Speculation
description: Until a month ago, Tom Ridge was just another Republican governor dutifully escorting his party's apparent Presidential nominee around his state.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7;Atlanta Train Misses Station
description: Marta, Atlanta's mass-transit system, is making news even when it is not carrying passengers. Early this morning, a system train overshot the station platform and went off the track at the turnaround station in this eastern Atlanta suburban neighborhood.

title: Advertising;Consumers are urged to relax, light a cigar and pour a Red Label
description: AN unconventional campaign for Johnnie Walker Red Label Scotch whisky seeks to capitalize on a celebration of traditional elements of American culture and life style that is known as retro-chic.

title: A Drug Center Finds Itself Caught In a Crossfire;For Some, It's Rehabilitation; For Others, Forced Labor
description: Eileen Mary Henson says she checked into Deerpark Farms Resort here on Nov. 19 and paid $1,400 to what she thought was a drug and alcohol rehabilitation center, after finding it listed in the Yellow Pages under Alcoholism Information and Treatment Centers.

title: 2 Editors Quit Outdoor Life After Article Is Killed
description: The two top editors of Outdoor Life magazine resigned in protest yesterday after an executive at Times Mirror, which owns the publication, pulled an article on bear baiting that was to have run in the September issue.

title: Corrections
description: A picture yesterday with an obituary of Samuel Toledano, a Jewish leader in Spain, was published in error. The picture, provided by The Associated Press, showed Shmuel Toledano, an Israel Government official who is no relation to the Spanish Mr. Toledano.

title: Buddhist Symbol at Home in the Catskills
description: To the Editor:

title: Restaurants
description: The first time I walked into Cendrillon, the sensory experience was so intense it halted me in the door. Vinegar hit a hot pan and escaped into the air, releasing a cloud of fragrant steam. Then a tidal wave of chili made my nose twitch. It was followed by the aroma of ginger, then curry and finally the sweet rich perfume of coconut milk.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the writer Jessica Mitford on Wednesday omitted the titles of her surviving sisters and misidentified the hometown of one. One sister is Deborah, Duchess of Devonshire. Her hometown is Bakewell, in Darbyshire; Chatsworth is the name of her house. The other sister is Lady Diana Mosley.

title: Critic's Choice/Film;Erotic Fantasies, 50's Style
description: Today it probably wouldn't be worth more than a PG-13 rating (if even that), but in 1955, the "Moon glow" and "torn shirt" sequences from the movie "Picnic" were about as steamy as Hollywood could get in evoking explosive sex.

title: Art in Review
description: Jonas Mekas 'Frozen Film Frames' Laurence Miller Gallery 138 Spring Street SoHo Through Aug. 16

title: No News From Alpha Centauri (Yet)
description: I have never been abducted by an alien spaceship. This is a shame, because as an astronomer I could ask aliens pretty good questions -- about their home star, its planets and the secrets of crossing vast distances between stars.

title: Milder Burmese Sanctions
description: The Senate adopted a measure today that would tone down proposed economic sanctions against Myanmar, formerly Burma, whose military rulers are accused of violating human rights and stifling a pro-democracy movement.

title: Executive Changes
description: AYDIN CORP., Horsham, Pa., appointed James Henderson chief financial officer.

title: Burundi Army Stages Coup, and New Fighting Is Feared
description: After two days of confusion about who was running Burundi, the Tutsi-dominated army announced a coup today, named a new President and dissolved Parliament.

title: Corrections
description: A sports article and picture caption yesterday about the men's all-round gymnastics competition at the Olympics misstated the margin of victory for Li Xiaoshuang of China over Aleksei Nemov of Russia. It was 49-thousandths of a point, not 49-hundredths.

title: BASEBALL;Franco Never Appears in Thin Air
description: John Franco tried to play the part of a good soldier, not wanting to create controversy while his team is in a tailspin. But the Mets' closer seemed frustrated at not being used in any of the team's three narrow defeats to the Colorado Rockies at Coors Field.

title: A Surly New York As Olympic Host?
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Rookie Leaves Yankees Scratching Their Heads
description: Who is Jose Rosado? Did anyone expect the 21-year-old left-hander to thoroughly dominate the best team in the American League in his fourth major league start? Maybe Rosado did, since he steered the Royals past the Yankees, 7-0, on one of the home team's most listless evenings of the season. The Yankees looked lethargic against another lefty.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7;The Mascot Vanishes? Where Is Izzy?
description: Word on Peachtree Street was that Izzy had vanished. Had the bug-eyed Olympic mascot defected to Disney? Did Olympic organizers detach him for graduate studies at Phillie Phanatic Tech? Did he get lost driving to the cycling venue?

title: FILM REVIEW;Of 2 Lost Girls and a Makeshift Mom
description: At the start of Lisa Krueger's stirring debut feature, the story's two young heroines are introduced as Manny (Scarlett Johansson) and Lo (Aleksa Palladino) and seen waking up on a lawn in a soulless suburban development, which they mistook for a park the night before. By the film's end, these two have turned into Amanda and Laurel, and they are in a real park, in a tranquil wilderness. What changed? Everything. How? Therein lies a lovely tale.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SUN COMPANY SELLS LAST OF ITS OILFIELDS TO ENI
description: The Sun Company said yesterday that it had sold its North Sea oilfields off the British coast to ENI S.p.A. of Italy for $260 million. With the sale, Sun, based in Philadelphia, has shed its last remaining production business to focus on refining and gasoline marketing. Sun said it would use the cash from the sale to either invest in its remaining businesses or buy back some of its stock. Shares of Sun were unchanged yesterday at $26.125. The stock has fallen 20 percent in two months.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Incentive Agrees to Sale Of Electricity Company
description: Incentive A.B., a Swedish company controlled by the Wallenberg family, agreed yesterday to sell an electricity company, Skandinaviska Elverk A.B., for $646 million to Gullspaangs Kraft A.B. The deal will make Gullspaangs, which is controlled by Imatran Voima Oy of Finland, the fourth-largest utility in Sweden. (Bloomberg Business News)

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Rise as Worries About Earnings Ease Disappointing earnings reports from technology companies have racked the stocks of late, so the market was happily relieved by I.B.M.'s news that its profits declined less than had been expected. Indeed, the gain in I.B.M. shares accounted for more than half of the Dow industrials' advance of 67.32 points, to 5,422.01.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;A Fan's Notes: When the Dodgers Were Brooklyn
description: BROOKLYN'S DODGERS The Bums, the Borough and the Best of Baseball By Carl E. Prince

title: Italian Issues a Warning At War Crimes Tribunal
description: The Italian law professor who is president of the war crimes tribunal here is known for his cheerful nature, his expertise in international law and his even temper. So his public outburst in a quiet hall here the other day was all the more shocking.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: GYMNASTICS;U.S. Gymnasts Take Back Seat in All-Around
description: First, Shannon Miller walked off the floor exercise and began to sob. Then, Dominique Dawes did the same.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Military Contracts Go To British Companies
description: The British Ministry of Defense said yesterday that it had awarded British companies L3.5 billion ($5.4 billion) worth of contracts to upgrade aircraft and supply two new classes of missiles, shutting out United States weapons makers. British Aerospace P.L.C. and the General Electric Company P.L.C. walked away with the bulk of the contracts. Trade Secretary Ian Lang heralded the orders as a boost to the British manufacturing industry that will sustain about 5,000 jobs.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: SWIMMING;Evans Dries Herself Off And Calls It a Career
description: She thought this a folly six years ago. When Janet Evans helped endorse Atlanta's bid to be the host of the 1996 Summer Games, the chief organizer, Billy Payne, asked whether she planned to swim. No way, Evans replied. She would be 24. But she would appreciate it if he sent her tickets.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: THE CRASH

title: EE-eye, EE-eye, OH!
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: 'To Carry Me Home' From the Studio: Artists in Residence, 1995-1996 Studio Museum in Harlem 144 West 125th Street Through Sept. 15

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Brown Is a Brand-New Man After Off Season of Retooling
description: His passes have been almost perfect. He is more confident in the huddle. He tells people what to do. He doesn't take nonsense from anyone. He even walks differently, as if he were bulletproof. He has a look on his face that says: "Don't bother me, I'm working."

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;Teacher Charged in Beating
description: A Newark kindergarten teacher accused of ordering 10 students to punch a misbehaving classmate was indicted yesterday on charges of official misconduct and endangering the welfare of a child. The teacher, Cynthia Johnson, 47, who has taught in Newark since 1985, faces up to 20 years in prison if convicted. On Feb. 13, prosecutors said, one of Ms. Johnson's 5-year-old students at the Avon Avenue School tore up some papers. At her instruction, prosecutors said, 10 students lined up and punched the boy in the back two times each. Ms. Johnson has been suspended from work with pay since the incident.

title: Syracuse Officials Offer Reward For Student Missing for 2 Months
description: Syracuse University has posted a $20,000 reward for information about a student who disappeared two months ago without a trace.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bank in Thailand Told To Shut U.S. Operations
description: Bangkok Metropolitan Bank of Thailand was ordered yesterday to shut down its banking operations in the United States and was fined $3.5 million. The bank also pled guilty in Federal District Court in Manhattan to a charge of obstructing bank examiners.

title: A Crackdown on Taxis Would Save Pedestrians
description: To the Editor:

title: Art in Review
description: 'The Baseball Show' Curt Marcus Gallery 578 Broadway, near Prince Street SoHo Through Aug. 9

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: TENNIS;Rosset Keeps Moving Ahead but Could Still Use a Lift
description: Asked to be a good sport and represent his country again in the Olympics, Marc Rosset, that 6-foot-7-inch strawberry blond party animal from Switzerland, had to think twice.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE SECURITY GAP;Despite Warnings, Most Air Cargo Is Unscreened
description: In early 1995, American Embassy officials in Pakistan interviewed Istiayaak Parker, a student, who told them a chilling story.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE FAMILIES;Sense of Solace From the President
description: The families showed him photographs of their smiling sons and daughters, now lost. The relatives handed him the freshly printed funeral programs for their brothers and sisters, newly buried.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;50 Ill at Boy Scout Camp
description: About 50 Boy Scouts and staff members at a camp at the Delaware Water Gap have come down with an unknown illness over the last two weeks, county health officials said yesterday. The scouts and staff members at the Yard's Creek Boy Scout Camp have suffered nausea, vomiting and diarrhea. Camp officials said the illness was probably caused by a 24-hour virus rather than food or water contamination, The Associated Press reported.

title: BASKETBALL;Harper Appears Headed To Mavs
description: Derek Harper, last season's starting point guard with the Knicks, is expected to sign with the Dallas Mavericks, according to several league executives.

title: Top Restaurateur Will Buy Stock Back From Japanese
description: The management of Restaurant Associates Corporation, which has blazed a trail in the American restaurant industry and has managed some of Manhattan's most popular restaurants, signed an agreement yesterday to buy back all its stock from its Japanese owner of six years.

title: Washington's Troubles Hit Island of Affluence
description: The crucial votes had barely been counted in Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s resurrection from jailhouse to City Hall two years ago when he offered some hard-eyed advice to those who had voted against him as the personification of this city's breakdown.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Weak Reports On Economy Bolster Bonds
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose yesterday on renewed optimism that the economy would slow enough to keep inflation from accelerating, an outlook that was bolstered by reports of weaker orders for durable goods and lower sales of existing homes.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Patti LuPone's Arrival Changes the Effect Of McNally's Script
description: When Patti LuPone first strides onto the stage at the Golden Theater, where she opened last night as Zoe Caldwell's replacement in Terrence McNally's "Master Class," she is as encumbered as the woman she's playing. Like Maria Callas, Ms. LuPone carries her own sort of diva-luggage: associations that don't have much to do with the current performance but that inevitably help shape one's responses to it and to her.

title: Art in Review
description: Eric Drooker, Paul Garrin and David Rokeby Holly Solomon Gallery 172 Mercer Street SoHo Through Aug. 31

title: Leo Martinuzzi, 99, Executive for Macy's And U.S. Consultant
description: Leo Martinuzzi, a former executive of R. H. Macy & Company and an exporting consultant, died at his home in Garden City, L.I., on Tuesday. He was 99.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Magic Mountain Ski Area, Londonderry, Vt., to Lassalle O'Brien Advertising Inc., Baltimore, to handle advertising and marketing to promote the reopening of the resort.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: BOXING;Two More Americans Out, One in a Controversial Loss
description: Zahir Raheem lay on the ring floor, almost in the same spot where, moments earlier, he had been sent tumbling by a left hook. He was crying uncontrollably. His teammate, Fernando Vargas, was overcome, too, with emotion. He cried foul.

title: COMPANY NEWS;U.S. ROBOTICS SHARES FALL ON REPORT OF SLOWER GROWTH
description: Shares of the U.S. Robotics Corporation plunged yesterday after the company warned analysts late on Wednesday that its fourth-quarter sales growth could slow. Shares of the company, a maker of telecommunications equipment, fell $11.484, to $54.516, in Nasdaq trading of 17.2 million shares. The company, which is based in Skokie, Ill., had told analysts in a conference call not to expect the 15 percent quarter-to-quarter sales growth it had previously predicted. Some analysts said that yesterday's stock decline was an overreaction and that U.S. Robotics' business remained strong.

title: Korea Order to Raytheon
description: The Raytheon Company has received a contract that could exceed $250 million to supply South Korea with an airborne reconnaissance system. The system will use reconnaissance equipment developed and integrated by Raytheon's E-Systems unit and will be installed on four of Raytheon's Hawker 800XP jet aircraft. South Korea will also buy another four Hawker 800XP jets for similar purposes. The military contractor, based in Lexington, Mass., did not disclose when it would deliver the system.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DURACELL MAY TAKE A CHARGE FOR A REVAMPING
description: Duracell International Inc. said yesterday that it might take a charge of $60 million in the second half of the 1997 fiscal year for revamping of its European operations. The company, which makes alkaline batteries, also said its profit from operations rose 11 percent, to $55.5 million, or 46 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of the 1996 fiscal year. Duracell, based in Bethel, Conn., said it was evaluating plans to simplify and reduce costs in its European operations in expectation that sluggish conditions and depressed consumer demand would continue. Shares rose $1.375 yesterday, to $44.50.

title: Where the Play Is Everything
description: EVERYWHERE you looked, there was drama.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Art Flickers From Video Screens
description: WHEN you walk into the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center, a quick glance to the right will draw you into the Frieda and Roy Furman Gallery, where a bizarre man is yelling. In this life-size video installation by Tony Oursler, "Keep Going," the man's body is a mismatched suit of garish plaid (he is literally a man in an empty suit) and his head is a puffy oval on which a video image of a face is projected. The head is distorted, fun-house style, in Mr. Oursler's familiar manner. The character's endless loop of monologue reveals him to be some hack movie director. With a frown on his face and an angry Nixonian tone to his voice, he orchestrates the filming of a fire and a car crash. "Now, kiss!" he snarls at his invisible actors.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday with an article about the planned merger of Presbyterian Hospital and New York Hospital misstated revenues and expenses for New York Hospital. Revenues for 1995 were $676.3 million, not $384 million. Expenses were $661.7 million, not $371 million.

title: BASEBALL;Berra Steering Clear of Yanks
description: It has been a long time since Yogi Berra put on a Yankees uniform, and that is not going to change at the annual Old-Timers Game at Yankee Stadium tomorrow afternoon.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: BASKETBALL;American Women Inspired In Rout
description: The crowd in the Georgia Dome, 31,230, had been the largest in world basketball history solely for women's competition. And when the subject of seating capacity was raised, the players and coaches from the United States and Zaire smiled for different reasons.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;After Holding Jets' Hope for Future, Foley Now Holds Just a Clipboard
description: Glenn Foley has played in seven offensive systems over the last eight years. But this is the first time since the string began at Cherry Hill (N.J.) East High School that a system has repeated itself.

title: Lambs Among the Bulls and Bears
description: As the stock market retreats from its Himalayan heights of early June, investors have started to suspect, with stomach-churning queasiness, that it's not the cozy, inviting place depicted by their brokers. This sudden cooling of middle-class ardor may well slow the small investor's striking evolution from the pariah of the stock market to its motive force, a trend that gathered strength with the mutual fund boom.

title: Ousted Head Of Police Admits Fraud
description: Only five weeks after being ousted as Newark's Police Director, William R. Celester pleaded guilty today to three charges of fraud as part of the Federal Government's crackdown on government corruption in New Jersey's largest city.

title: Headaches Ahead
description: New security measures imposed by the Clinton Administration will confront passengers between American cities with the kinds of long lines, detailed searches and interrogations that international voyagers are used to, and flights out of the country will be scrutinized even more intensively.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE DATA;Record of Quick Destruction: Briefest Sound, Then Silence
description: The cockpit voice recorder from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 captured "a brief fraction-of-a-second sound" just before it stopped recording, the chief of the crash investigation said this afternoon.

title: Keep the Ban on Latin Weapons
description: American arms producers, backed by the Pentagon, are lobbying hard to get President Clinton to lift a 20-year-old ban on the export of advanced conventional weapons to Latin America. The defense industry, faced with shrinking military budgets around the world, is eager to open up new markets for its wares. The Pentagon, for its part, likes to keep weapons production lines busy, an activity it refers to as sustaining the defense industrial base. But allowing these arms sales, which the State Department opposes, runs counter to America's best interests.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Disney Has 27.7% Rise In Earnings
description: The Walt Disney Company reported a 27.7 percent rise in third-quarter profits today, with improvements in all three of its major businesses.

title: Trump Shows a Different Profile;His New Business Style Puts the Deal Ahead of Ego
description: Donald J. Trump was in his element. Striding through the garish Trump Taj Mahal casino here, he was shaking hands with awestruck customers and gabbing nonstop with a reporter who was struggling to keep up, when he stopped at a table of intense poker players and, like a seasoned entertainer, stole the show.

title: Jury Begins Its Deliberations In Trial of Arkansas Bankers
description: In closing arguments today in the second trial brought by the Whitewater independent counsel's office, a prosecutor attacked Bruce R. Lindsey, a senior Presidential aide, describing him as an integral part of a criminal conspiracy and his testimony as untruthful.

title: Inside Art
description: Happy Accident and Benign Oversight

title: Dole Considers Tax-Cut Plan Of as Much as $600 Billion
description: The tax-cut proposals being considered by Bob Dole's Presidential campaign range as high as $600 billion over six years, but Mr. Dole has not made any decision on the size of the reductions or how to pay for them, campaign aides said today.

title: Justice Dept. Defends Corrupt-Union Accord
description: The Justice Department said today that White House officials had exerted no influence over its handling of a case involving a union leader with reputed ties to organized crime who has been a major Democratic campaign contributor.

title: James W. Near, 58, Chairman of Wendy's
description: James W. Near, the chairman of the restaurant chain Wendy's International Inc., died on Monday in Atlanta, where he was attending the Olympic Games. He was 58 and lived in Bonita Springs, Fla.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Corn Prices Continue to Slip As Good Weather Is Forecast
description: Corn prices fell on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, their eighth decline in nine days, amid forecasts for almost ideal pollination weather in the days ahead.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: TRACK;The Heart of the Games Starts Beating Tonight
description: After a week of sensational competition throughout the Olympics, track and field, regarded by many as the bedrock of Olympic competition, begins Friday morning with enough plots and subplots to fill a shelf of novels.

title: Justice Powell's Wife, 85
description: Josephine Rucker Powell, the wife of former Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell, died on Wednesday at her home in Richmond. She was 85.

title: Gtech's Chief Is Cleared in Bribery Inquiry
description: An independent investigator has found no evidence that the head of the Gtech Holdings Corporation tried to bribe the chairman of the Virgin Group, Richard Branson, to drop out of the race to run the National Lottery, the Office of the National Lottery said this week. Mr. Branson, said on television on Dec. 11 that Guy B. Snowden, Gtech's chairman, tried to bribe him in 1993 to drop a bid to operate the lottery. Gtech, based in West Greenwich, R.I., is in the group that won the license.

title: Cable Company to Give New Yorkers Rate Refund and 3 Free Movies
description: Faced with the daunting prospect of a drawn out and expensive legal battle over cable television rates, New York City and Time Warner Cable, the city's largest cable provider, yesterday agreed to settle their differences and send cable customers to the movies.

title: Clinton in a Box as a Welfare Bill Edges Closer
description: Above the spindly semi-issues of the 1996 campaign, overhauling the nation's welfare system stands tall, shadowing President Clinton's unmet 1992 promise to "end welfare as we know it" and the Republicans' claim that they know how to undo three decades of dependency run amok.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Ammirati Puris Lintas And Citrus Group Part
description: Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York yesterday unexpectedly resigned the Florida Department of Citrus advertising account, with billings estimated at $25 million to $27 million, after only five months.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;Birth Rate Drops Among Poor
description: The birth rate for women on welfare in New Jersey's 10 poorest cities has declined since the state's welfare laws were altered, according to a study by two sociologists. Between 1991 and 1994, the birth rate for these women dropped 12 percent, the study by Ted Goertzel, of Rutgers University's Camden campus, and Gary Young, at Cooper Hospital in Camden, showed. In 1992, the state's welfare laws were altered to deny mothers extra benefits for additional children born while they were receiving public assistance. The reduced birth rate suggests that "the message may be getting through," John McKeegan, a spokesman for the Department of Human Services, said yesterday.

title: Some Funds Report Cash Flowing Out
description: Mutual fund investors, long characterized as ignoring short-term market swings in favor of long-term results, may be more likely to take the money and run than many fund companies ever thought.

title: BASEBALL;Numbers for Pettitte Can't Alleviate Pain
description: Andy Pettitte wiggled and stretched his left elbow yesterday, wishing he could magically make the lingering stiffness disappear. He knew it would not work. Nothing has worked for Pettitte's elbow.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: CYCLING;A Californian's Long Run Ends With a Goodbye Lap
description: It was wonderful while it lasted, and it lasted a long time.

title: For Children
description: 'Winslow Homer' Metropolitan Museum of Art Fifth Avenue and 82d Street (212) 535-7710 Recommended ages: 4 and up Through Sept. 22

title: COMPANY NEWS;WARNACO AND AUTHENTIC FITNESS END DEAL
description: Warnaco Group Inc. and the Authentic Fitness Corporation, a fitness-wear maker that was spun off by Warnaco six years ago, said yesterday that they had dropped an agreement to merge after it became clear Authentic Fitness would report a loss in its fourth quarter. The companies said the results for the fiscal year that ended on June 30 would fall below Wall Street analysts' expectations, largely because of the loss of a major customer, Herman's sports stores, which filed for bankruptcy in May. Early last month, Warnaco, the clothing company based in New York, offered to acquire Authentic Fitness in a stock swap valued at about $500 million. Authentic Fitness, whose products include Speedo swimsuits, agreed to terminate the agreement after being advised by Warnaco's board that it would not recommend the merger. Warnaco's stock jumped $2.75 yesterday, to $25.25, and shares of Authentic Fitness fell 37.5 cents, to $17.875.

title: Heated Bonn-Moscow Debate About Art: Prize or Plunder?
description: More than half a century has passed since the Soviet occupiers of a defeated Germany perpetrated what Germans regard as the art theft of all time: By German accounts, more than 200,000 works of art and countless books and documents were carried off to the Soviet Union at the end of World War II.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;DOW CHEMICAL CO. (DOW,N)
description: The Dow Chemical Company said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings rose 8.5 percent from the corresponding period last year, as improved productivity helped overcome a decline in sales.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Donna Karan Features Acting Couple
description: The designer Donna Karan is sending a valentine to Bruce Willis and Demi Moore in the form of a campaign featuring the acting couple for her fall Donna Karan New York Collection of women's and men's clothing.

title: ATLANTA DAY 7: GYMNASTICS;Strug Heading for Fame
description: She has talked with President Clinton. She has received a telegram from Bob Dole and appeared on almost as many morning programs as the actors in "Independence Day."

title: ON BASKETBALL;Russians Just Might Sneak Up on the U.S
description: THERE is little or no doubt which is the most gifted and talented of the women's basketball teams here at the Centennial Olympics, but there will be no equivocation in the following assessment that doubles as a warning to the corporately ballyhooed American protagonists: They do not -- repeat Do Not! -- want to be knee deep in a 1-point game with the ball in the hands of Irina Sumnikova.

title: Horse Racing;Saratoga's New Season, and Zito's New Horse
description: For the 128th year, racing in New York moved upstate today to the pastoral old Saratoga Race Course, where 34 days of racing in the country will open on Friday and where next year's Kentucky Derby favorite may open his major league career. But the buzz at Nick Zito's barn was being aimed at the newest member of the family: Unbridled's Song, last year's juvenile star who became this year's troubled soap-opera star.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Business Day yesterday reported the resignation of two editors of Outdoor Life magazine over a decision to remove an article about hunters' use of bait to lure bears into shooting range. Because of an editing error, the Business Day article omitted a comment from the magazine's owner, the Times Mirror Company.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;Education Head Is Sworn In
description: A retired United States Army brigadier general and former casino executive was sworn in yesterday as the chairman of the state's Commission on Higher Education. The official, Alfred J. Cade, 65, of Linwood, resigned as a senior vice president at Caesars Atlantic City earlier this year. The commission develops long-range plans for higher education.

title: In Age of AIDS, Love and Hope Can Lead to Risk
description: In a time of mortal peril, Carlos Cordero believed he had found romantic sanctuary.

title: ATLANTA DAY 8 -- DIVING;Semifinals Are Next For Clark
description: Mary Ellen Clark has been in high and awkward positions before. She has overcome a fear of heights. She has overcome large deficits with late heroics. And today, during the preliminaries of the women's 10-meter platform Olympic diving event, Clark was in a difficult spot again.

title: That First Summer of the Nez Perce
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Remains of U.S. Soldier Retrieved in North Korea
description: Skeletal remains believed those of an American soldier have been recovered in North Korea in the first such search for remains since the Korean War ended more than 40 years ago.

title: Anger at Turkey Intensifies After 8 Die in Prison Fasts
description: Facing its first serious crisis only weeks after taking office, the Islamic-led Government came under growing pressure today to reform prison conditions after an eighth leftist hunger striker died in jail and radical Kurds said they were joining the 68-day-old "death fast."

title: Grand Central Boards
description: To the Editor:

title: Tangshan Journal;Rumbles in the Body Politic, Rumbles in the Earth
description: Five bare-chested men sat around a knee-high table in a back alley, sipping beer and picking at cold noodles, their hairless skin gleaming with sweat in the afternoon heat. They talked about what this town is famous for -- the tremendous earthquake that struck in 1976 -- and about whether another earthquake is coming this year.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Lloyds TSB Group Profit Rose 12% in First Half
description: Lloyds TSB Group, Britain's largest provider of retail financial services, reported a 12 percent rise yesterday in its pretax profits in the first half of the year, to L1.14 billion ($1.77 billion). The company was formed last year through the merger of Lloyds Bank with TSB and the Cheltenham and Gloucester Building Society.

title: A Quick Fix for New York Harbor
description: The shipping trade in New York Harbor provides the metropolitan area with billions of dollars in annual revenues and more than 100,000 jobs. But this robust economic engine has been sputtering. Three years ago a combination of new Federal regulations and an executive order from Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey effectively stopped ocean dumping of toxic sediments that collect at the bottom of the harbor. Dredging stopped, the harbor clogged up and shippers began sending their deep-water container vessels to more accessible ports in Maryland and Virginia.

title: Developer Carves a Niche In Small Boutique Hotels
description: In a trend toward smaller, less expensive hotels in New York City, a development firm that has carved out a niche in that category said yesterday that it planned to convert a gracious brick office building on East 44th Street east of Grand Central Terminal into a 162-room hotel.

title: SCORES ARE HURT IN AN EXPLOSION AT OLYMPIC PARK
description: A massive explosion rocked Centennial Olympic Park early today, injuring hundreds of people, fire officials said.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants Breathe More Easily as Jones Signs
description: Giants Coach Dan Reeves was asked today what he wanted to see in Saturday's scrimmage. "I don't want anyone hurt," he responded.

title: COMPANY NEWS;LOCKHEED SELLING MARTIN MARIETTA MATERIALS
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, the world's largest aerospace and military contractor, said yesterday that it would divest itself of its 81 percent stake in Martin Marietta Materials Inc. of Raleigh, N.C., a supplier of sand, stone and gravel aggregates used to build roads and other projects. The holding is worth an estimated $840 million. Lockheed Martin said it would offer its own shareholders the chance to swap stock for a total of 37.35 million shares in the materials company. Lockheed has not disclosed how many material shares will be given to holders for each Lockheed share turned in.

title: ATLANTA DAY 8 -- SWIMMING;Van Dyken Swims to History With 4th Gold
description: Amy Van Dyken began the centennial Olympic Games lying on the pool deck with severe muscle cramps. She ended the swimming competition by standing on the victory podium as the first American woman to win four gold medals at one Olympics, winter or summer.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;Utility Regulator Is Ousted
description: A state ethics panel has unanimously voted to remove a member of the Board of Public Utilities because of ethics violations ranging from accepting free dinners to having personal relationships with employees of two regulated utilities. The Executive Commission on Ethical Standards voted Thursday to remove Edward H. Salmon, one of three commissioners on the board, from his $92,500-a-year post immediately. But yesterday, the commission granted him a stay until his appeal is heard on Wednesday, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Salmon has denied the charges.

title: Mayor Opposes Some Revisions In Welfare Plan
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani says that a welfare bill speeding through Congress would impose immense new costs on New York City by cutting Federal aid for poor children, disabled people and legal immigrants.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Linotype-Hell Shares Soar After Stake Offer
description: Shares in the troubled German printing company Linotype-Hell A.G. soared yesterday after Heidelberger Druck said late on Thursday that it wanted to buy 75 percent of Linotype for 95 marks a share. Linotype-Hell shares gained 28 marks, to 94.1, in trading in Frankfurt.

title: Articulating the Tug-of-War for Ellis Island
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;Man Charged in Chase Death
description: A man accused of leading the police on a chase last month that resulted in the death of a 37-year-old woman was indicted yesterday on charges of felony murder, prosecutors said. Patrick J. Pantusco of Washington Township, a suspect in three robberies, was being pursued by police officers when the stolen car he was driving struck a car driven by Stephanie Carroll of Oradell, killing her and slightly injuring her two children. Charles R. Buckley, Acting Prosecutor for Bergen County, said Officer Richard Skinner of the Washington Township Police and Officer Albert Lepera of the Paramus Police acted within police guidelines in conducting the chase.

title: Leader of Coup in Burundi Hints at Tribal Reconciliation
description: A day after he took power in a so-far bloodless coup, Burundi's new President told a skeptical world today that he had seized power only to prevent more ethnic killings in a country where massacres seemed to be spiraling upwards in recent weeks.

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICANS;Dole Appears Moving Toward Tax-Cut Stand
description: During his days as the Senate's deficit-fighter-in-chief, Bob Dole liked to joke about a bus carrying a group of supply-siders that plunged off a cliff. The bad news, he said, was that three of the seats were empty.

title: A Director Quits Egghead Board
description: Egghead Inc., the software retailer, said today that Paul G. Allen, a co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, would step down from its board after serving as a director for more than nine years.

title: In Performance
description: JAZZ Drawn Along by the Power Of Guitaristic Logic Ron Affif The Zinc Bar

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Banged-Up Jets Cutting Back on Practices
description: Suddenly, all those little things that seemed unimportant in the team's big picture loomed large today because the Jets, for all their renowned off-season dealings, are in pain.

title: COMPANY NEWS;IMPERIAL HOLLY AGREES TO SELL 27% STAKE TO GREENCORE
description: The Imperial Holly Corporation, a sugar refiner, agreed yesterday to sell a 27 percent stake to the Dublin-based Greencore Group P.L.C. for $50.4 million. Imperial Holly said its directors yesterday approved the sale of 3.8 million newly issued common shares to Greencore -- the only sugar processor in Ireland -- for $13.25 a share. Greencore, which is also a leading marketer of malt and flour in Britain, will name two directors to Imperial Holly's board, the company said.
