Imperial Holly, based in Sugar Land, Tex., said proceeds from the sale would initially be used to partly repay indebtedness.

title: Metro Digest
description: THE CRASH Crippled Jet Flew for 24 Seconds Radar records show that T.W.A. Flight 800 continued to fly for at least 24 seconds after the cataclysmic event that doomed it, raising the possibility that some of the passengers and crew may have been alive in the last horrifying seconds before the crippled jetliner broke apart in a fireball, investigators said. The radar information does not give a clue to whether the cockpit crew had any functioning controls to work with after the plane was disabled at 13,700 feet. [Page 1.]

title: POLITICS: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK;No Echo of Past Rancor as Bush Welcomes Dole
description: Today's trip to this coastal resort, the summer home of George Herbert Walker Bush, must have been a long one for Bob Dole.

title: ATLANTA DAY 8;Cubans Suffer First 2 Losses
description: Infallible for nearly a week, the Cuba boxing team finally showed signs that it is not unbeatable tonight.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the actress Jean Muir on Thursday misstated the title of one of her films. It is "And One Was Beautiful," not "One Is Beautiful."

title: Clinton Campaign Resists Proposal of Free-TV Advocates
description: A surprising snag is hampering efforts to carve out uniform blocks of free television time for Presidential candidates this fall: the Clinton campaign, a consistent advocate of free broadcast time in election races.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Kellogg Earnings Plunge 42.5% On Price Cuts and Competition
description: The Kellogg Company reported a 42.5 percent slide in second-quarter profits today, citing stiff competition and industry price cuts for ready-to-eat cereals.

title: Balkan Agreement Is a Band-Aid on a Disease
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA DAY 8
description: A Not-So-Perfect Softball Adventure The United States pitcher Lisa Fernandez was a strike away from a perfect game against Australia when a shocking homer sent the American women to only their second loss in 117 games, dating to 1986. Page 31.

title: ATLANTA DAY 8 -- ROUNDUP
description: BEACH VOLLEYBALL

title: ATLANTA DAY 8;Spanish Team Eliminates U.S.
description: Jesus Rollan made spectacular saves to stop nearly everything the Americans threw at him in a 5-4 victory for Spain tonight in water polo.

title: Last Seconds of Flight
description: Radar records show that T.W.A. Flight 800 apparently continued to fly for 24 seconds after it exploded, raising the possibility that some of the passengers were alive in the last seconds, investigators said, and the jetliner's engines probably continued to run as it moved over the water.

title: Herb Edelman, 62, A Character Actor
description: Herbert Edelman, a Brooklyn-born character actor best known for his portrayal of archetypal New Yorkers, died on Sunday at the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 62 and lived in Oxnard, Calif.

title: Black, Successful and Safe And Gone From Capital
description: Richard Jones moved here to the suburbs in 1979 to shield his children from the drugs and street crime that were rampant in his southeast Washington neighborhood. Yet 17 years later and now retired as an air traffic controller, Mr. Jones still does volunteer work with poor children in his old neighborhood, and every now and then he yearns to move back into the city.

title: U.N. Won't Punish Cuba in Downing of Planes
description: Unable to gain international support for strong action against Cuba over the shooting down of two civilian planes in February, the Clinton Administration got backing today for only a mild resolution of regret over the incident.

title: Insurance Deal Is Eluding U.S.
description: The United States and Japan remain "pretty far" apart in talks on increasing access to Japan's $470 billion insurance market less than a week ahead of a deadline, a senior United States official said today.

title: Judge Displays His Patience as the Freemen Display TheirContentiousness
description: One defendant has threatened a judge. Last week, another sprained his thumb trying to resist fingerprinting. Almost all have rejected their court-appointed lawyers and the authority of American courts.

title: Edmund Mirassou, Wine Maker, 78
description: Edmund Mirassou, patriarch of one of the country's largest family-owned wine-making operations, died at his home here on Wednesday. He was 78.

title: Picking Up the Tab For Fields of Dreams;Taxpayers Build Stadiums; Owners Cash in
description: In Baltimore, the Ravens, formerly the Cleveland Browns, are coming to a $200 million football stadium to be built on their behalf. Nashville has lured the Oilers from Houston with the promise of a sparkling new $389 million stadium. In New York, there is talk of a new ballpark for the Yankees, while discussion continues about replacing venerable Tiger Stadium in Detroit and Fenway Park in Boston, both now celebrating their 84th anniversaries.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE FLIGHT DATA;Backing a Bomb Theory: Devices Stopped in Unison
description: The flight data recorder on board Trans World Airlines Flight 800 showed that all systems were operating normally until the device suddenly stopped functioning -- at virtually the same moment the cockpit voice recorder picked up a final, loud noise, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about a boy playing in a fountain in Great Neck, L.I., misidentified him. He was Shawn Behnam, not Joe Kim.

title: Pataki's Records Show Double the Contributions Reported
description: Under court order, the private corporations set up to pay for Gov. George E. Pataki's elaborate inauguration and transition released records today showing that they had raised $2.5 million during the six months after his election, more than twice as much as the Pataki administration had previously claimed.

title: World News Briefs;Indonesia Police Storm Opposition Party Base
description: The police took over the headquarters of the opposition Indonesian Democratic Party today after more than two hours of battles with activists holed up inside.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Harper Back With Mavericks
description: The Dallas Mavericks and the former Knicks guard DEREK HARPER have agreed to terms on a contract reportedly worth $3 million over two years. "It's expected to be a two-year deal," a Mavericks spokesman, TONY FAY, said yesterday of the contract that would return the free agent to Dallas. "We don't disclose the dollar amount."

title: Eye Doctors Told Not to Use Unapproved Lasers to Treat Myopia
description: Federal regulators issued a warning today to eye doctors not to use unapproved machines for laser surgery on nearsighted patients.

title: Officer Says He Was Hurt For Aiding An Inquiry
description: It is an unwritten rule of police work: if you rat on your colleagues, you are going to make enemies.

title: The Risk of Carnage in Burundi
description: Strong declarations of international support for Burundi's legitimate President failed to stop a coup by that country's Tutsi-led armed forces on Thursday. Washington, the United Nations and others are right to continue protesting this violent takeover, which also overturns a hopeful power-sharing arrangement between Burundi's two main ethnic groups -- President Sylvestre Ntibantunganya's Hutu majority and the Tutsi minority.

title: Stocks Given Lift by Rise In Confidence
description: Stocks advanced for a second consecutive session yesterday as investors regained confidence that corporate earnings growth was not slowing.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;No Charges in Pipeline Blast
description: No criminal charges should be filed in the March 1994 gas pipeline explosion that injured more than 100 residents of an apartment complex in Edison Township, a state grand jury has concluded. The panel's report, released yesterday, also recommended a series of changes in Federal regulations to protect people living near pipelines, the state Attorney General's office said yesterday. Most of these suggestions -- including requiring operators to inspect the interior of pipelines in densely populated areas -- were also recommended by the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: No Headline
description: I wouldn't come back into the city because of all the problems that have cropped up since I left, basically the poor city services. I love Mount Rainier. It's like a little town with a mayor you can call up and who will come over on his bike."

title: COMPANY NEWS;UNITED DOMINION IS ALLOWED MEETING ON HOSTILE BID
description: United Dominion Industries Ltd. said yesterday that a Federal court had ruled it could call a special meeting of Commercial Intertech shareholders about Dominion's $465 million hostile bid. United Dominion said it sought to call the meeting to remove the obstacles to its tender offer of $30 a share. United Dominion said the United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio had denied a motion by Commercial Intertech, which also sought to block United Dominion from soliciting proxies for the Aug. 30 meeting at which Commercial Intertech shareholders will consider United Dominion's bid.

title: Giuliani Ousts Commissioner, But Quietly
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has dismissed Marilyn G. Gelber, the Commissioner of Environmental Protection, who has played a major role in New York City's efforts to negotiate ways to protect its upstate water supply, senior administration officials said yesterday.

title: Hannah Arendt, Campaign Pundit
description: Hannah Arendt's friends and academic colleagues thought of her as a German phenomenologist whose comments on day-to-day politics were couched in the abstract and impenetrable discourse of her mentors Karl Jaspers and Martin Heidegger. But an unpublished radio script I found in papers she bequeathed to the Library of Congress offers a clue to an Arendt who more closely resembles the American political scientist she always claimed to be. Arendt watched the 1960 Democratic and Republican conventions and on Aug. 12 of that year played the pundit for WBAI, a socially conscious New York radio station.

title: School Governance Is Moving Right Along
description: To the Editor:

title: Peppy, Plucky -- and Overtrained?
description: The gold-medal performance of the American female gymnasts on Tuesday was remarkable, and that achievement will far outlast memories of their low scores and tears in the individual competition on Thursday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;WESTERN RESOURCES AGREES TO IMMEDIATE RATE CUTS
description: Western Resources Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to immediate rate cuts in a case that has been tied to Western's hostile takeover attempt of the Kansas City Power and Light Company. Western originally proposed phasing in rate cuts over seven years, which critics said was an attempt to drag out the rate reduction while it continued efforts to buy Kansas City Power. Lower rates would conceivably make the Western offer less attractive to Kansas City Power shareholders. Kansas City Power directors have rejected Western's merger proposal and are pursuing a merger with Utilicorp United Inc., the fellow Kansas City utility.

title: ATLANTA DAY 8 -- WATER POLO;A Croatian Victory That Means More Than a Medal
description: They dunked each other, they clawed each other, they gouged each other, they kneed each other. It was just a normal water polo game.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Peugeot Citroen Sales Gained 3% in First Half
description: The French car maker PSA Peugeot Citroen said yesterday that its sales rose 3 percent in the first six months of the year to 89.04 billion francs ($17.8 billion), helped by a sharp improvement in the second quarter. After rising 1.3 percent in the first quarter, the group's car sales climbed 4.9 percent in the April-June quarter.

title: Journal;The Man From Russell
description: Forever blowing and stepping on his lines, Bob Dole is hands down the worst actor to fret on the national stage in a modern Presidential election year -- or would be if only Ross Perot had not dreamed up the amazement that was Admiral Stockdale.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Most Prices Off as Data Are Awaited
description: Prices of most Treasury securities sagged yesterday heading into the weekend, as the bond market braced for a barrage of economic data next week that will set the tone of the market for weeks ahead, and perhaps even lead the Federal Reserve to alter its monetary policy.

title: Colin Mitchell Is Dead at 70; British Hero in Aden Battles
description: Colin Mitchell, a British officer who sacrificed his military career for one moment of glory in 1967, died last Saturday at his home in London. He was 70.

title: ATLANTA DAY 8 -- TRACK AND FIELD;Mammoth Final Put Wins Shot For Barnes
description: Track and field, the showcase sport of the Olympic Games, began today with seemingly sleeping Americans awakening in time to grab the gold and silver medals in the men's shot-put. On the last of his six attempts, Randy Barnes won the gold medal with one prodigious put of 70 feet 11 1/4 inches. One round before, John Godina had exploded for 68-2 1/2 that held up for the silver.

title: MAJOR-PARTY DEAL IN MEXICO TO BRING POLITICAL REFORMS
description: After 19 months of often bitter negotiations, Mexico's Government and ruling party late Thursday signed a sweeping agreement with the opposition parties aimed at eliminating electoral fraud, modernizing the political system and guiding the transition from seven decades of one-party rule.

title: Hijacker Seizes Airliner And Forces It to Miami
description: A man claiming he had a bomb hijacked a plane bound for Cuba today, forcing it to land in Miami, where he eventually surrendered, according to the Federal Bureau of Investigation. None of the plane's 217 passengers or 14 crew members were injured.

title: COMPANY NEWS;VALUE HEALTH EXPECTS A DECLINE IN PROFITS
description: The health benefits manager Value Health Inc. said yesterday that it expected profits in the second half of the year to fall short of expectations as more companies switch employees' mental health coverage to health maintenance organizations. The news pushed Value Health's stock down 14 percent, or $2.75 a share, to $16.25, on the New York Stock Exchange. Value Health said it expects to earn between 35 and 40 cents a share in both the third and fourth quarters. Analysts had been expecting 40 cents in the third quarter and 44 cents in the fourth quarter, according to a survey by First Call Inc. Value Health has two main businesses: providing employers with mental health programs and managing their prescription drug benefits plans.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE SEARCH;From Shore, Calls for Quicker Results Add Pressure to Underwater Efforts
description: The high-technology team running the undersea search at the crash site of T.W.A. Flight 800 has previously explored sunken jumbo jets in the stormy waters off the Irish coast and 15,000 feet beneath the surface of the Indian Ocean.

title: Beliefs
description: For the first half of this year, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Milwaukee, Rembert G. Weakland, had been out of sight and out of the news, taking a sabbatical to finish a doctoral dissertation on ancient church music at Columbia University.

title: N.A.S.D. Fines Rochester Brokerage Firm
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said this week that H. J. Meyers & Company and 22 of its current and former brokers had been ordered to pay fines and refunds to investors totaling $1.5 million for overcharging 3,000 customers.

title: ATLANTA DAY 8;Leap to First in Laser Class
description: With three races remaining in the Laser Class, Ben Ainslie of Britain made the biggest jump on the scoreboard today in Olympic yachting. The 19-year-old Ainslie posted a score of 2-1 to move from fourth place to first.

title: Letters Ilumine Adelphi Head's Rich Deal
description: The trustees of Adelphi University have given its president, Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos, a compensation package that allows him to seek reimbursement if he has to pay income taxes on his fringe benefits and to be paid for sabbaticals he doesn't take, university records show.

title: Strug's Hopes Lie in the Floor
description: The leap of Kerri Strug's life was most likely her last in the Olympics.

title: House G.O.P. Strikes Deal to Save New York Forest From Development
description: After a year of internal squabbling, House Republicans came to an agreement yesterday that marked the biggest step forward to date in preserving Sterling Forest, the 20,000-acre woodland mostly in New York that provides drinking water to one-quarter of New Jersey.

title: Beware False Messiahs
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Warns of Hazard in Mexican Face Cream
description: A beauty cream produced in Mexico and distributed in the United States contains mercury, which can be poisonous, said Federal health officials who warned that anyone who has the cream should stop using it.

title: BASEBALL;On-Again, Off-Again Wilson Off Again
description: They were supposed to be two of the young phenoms who would carry the Mets to glory. Yet, for both Jason Isringhausen and Paul Wilson, the first full season in the major leagues has been a torturous adventure in futility. Instead of restoring success, they have had to learn to deal with failure. They are more headaches than heroes.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE SECURITY GAP;AIRPORT INQUIRY FAULTED SECURITY BEFORE EXPLOSION
description: Two weeks before the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, the inspector general for the Department of Transportation completed a report on airport security that described how undercover Government agents -- some of them carrying fake explosives -- had been able to breach security at four of the nation's largest airports, entering secure areas that would have given them access to airplanes.

title: Protecting Pirates, Not Software
description: With gusto and fanfare, the Clinton Administration has been chasing down software pirates in China, Thailand and Mexico, and with good reason. High-tech products, especially software, are our fastest-growing exports.

title: Art in Odd Places, a London Specialty
description: The ballroom of 50 St. James's Street is empty except for an oval billiard table with a red ball suspended like a pendulum above its center. Some visitors pick up a cue and take a shot at it, others just stare as the ball sways hypnotically back and forth.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;Casinos Can Have Corridors
description: New Jersey took another step yesterday in the effort begun under the Florio administration to loosen regulations for casino operators. Under current law, a casino is defined as a single room, and companies are not allowed to operate separate gambling halls connected by corridors. A bill signed by Governor Whitman will do away with that restriction. "The industry made a good case that this was needed," said Carl Golden, a spokesman for the Governor. TERRY PRISTIN

title: Articulating the Tug-of-War for Ellis Island;Mangia, Mangia
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Unplugged: After Drought, 21 Hits
description: The sign across the clubhouse door before last night's game with the Kansas City Royals informed the Yankees that batting practice would be optional today because of the Old Timer's Day festivities. Of course. Old Timer's Day or not, no manager would even try to convince the Yankees that they needed extra swings after the 15-1 pasting they dished out last night.

title: Stock Offering Delayed
description: Stage Stores Inc. said yesterday that it had postponed its planned $144 million initial public offering, citing a weaker market for new stocks. The Houston-based operator of small-town clothing stores had planned to sell 9.6 million shares at $14 to $16 this month, but it said current market conditions caused it to postpone the sale. Stage Stores manages 301 stores in the central United States under the names Stage, Bealls and Palais Royal.

title: E. Lloyd DuBrul, 87, Authority on Teeth
description: Dr. E. Lloyd DuBrul, an authority on dental anatomy and a noted author on the subject, died on Wednesday in Chicago. He was 87 and lived in Chicago.

title: Move High-Speed Train Idea Away From Coast
description: To the Editor:

title: With Netanyahu, U.S. Mideast Envoy May Be 'Starting Over'
description: When Dennis B. Ross came calling here Thursday and today, American officials thought it important to mention that he was shown directly into the office of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.

title: City Center Schedules New Dance for Fall Season
description: New dances from Monte Carlo, Madrid and Seattle are featured in the first half of the 1996-97 season just announced by City Center.

title: Militia Says It Captured Somalia's Main Airport
description: A militia opposed to Somalia's self-proclaimed President, Mohammed Farah Aidid, claims to have captured an important airport, cutting the supply line to Mr. Aidid's troops in Mogadishu.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Allianz Health Insurer To Be Sold to Munich Re
description: The German insurer Allianz A.G. agreed yesterday to sell DKV, Europe's largest private health insurer, to the world's largest reinsurer, Munich Re, allowing it to avoid a battle with regulators over its dominance in health insurance. Financial terms were not disclosed, but industry officials and analysts estimated the price was about 4 billion marks ($2.7 billion).

title: Fight Over Cab Rules Has Commissioner Vowing to Roll Back Fares
description: Four months after New Yorkers saw taxi fares climb 20 percent, an escalating squabble over cab regulations has led a city official to make a remarkable threat (or promise, depending on your point of view):

title: COMPANY NEWS;AUTHENTIC FITNESS STOCK FALLS AFTER MERGER FAILS
description: The stock of the Authentic Fitness Corporation sank yesterday after the swimsuit maker's merger deal with the Warnaco Group Inc. clothing company was called off. Stock in Authentic Fitness, whose products include Speedo swimsuits, fell $5.125, to $12.75, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. Warnaco slipped 75 cents, to $44.50. Investors had punished the stock earlier this month on news of the deal. The companies said late Thursday that they had terminated their agreement after it became clear Authentic Fitness would report a loss for its quarter that ended on July 6. Early last month, New York-based Warnaco, which spun off Authentic to investors in 1990 for $85 million, offered to buy the company in a stock swap valued at about $500 million.

title: U.N. Police Monitors Faltering in Bosnia
description: Bosnian Serb police officers lurk in pairs behind the bushes and trees at the NATO checkpoint on the outskirts of town. Muslims brave enough to cross into Bosnian Serb territory, if only for a brief visit with old friends, quickly learn their mistake when the local police emerge to threaten them or rob them or beat them, just out of sight of the NATO troops posted there.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Rhone-Poulenc Profit Up 39% in 2d Quarter
description: Rhone-Poulenc S.A., France's biggest chemical company, said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 39 percent as it began to benefit from newly formed joint ventures, especially in the health care industry. Profit in the period rose to 777 million French francs ($155 million) from 559 million francs last year.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Johnson Won't Rejoin Lakers
description: MAGIC JOHNSON, a television commentator at the Olympics who said during several interviews at the Atlanta Games he was leaning toward a return to the Los Angeles Lakers, won't be doing so, his agent said yesterday. Instead, LON ROSEN said from his Los Angeles office, Johnson is planning to buy back his percentage of ownership in the team from JERRY BUSS. (AP)

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Aetna Shows A Comeback In Quarter
description: Aetna Inc. said today that it had earned $288 million in the second quarter in contrast to a loss of $297 million in the corresponding period last year.

title: ATLANTA DAY 8 -- FIELD HOCKEY;India and Pakistan Are Out of Medal Contention
description: Ananda Mahaderan watched with increasing frustration today as the field hockey teams from India and Pakistan careered up and down the field at Morris Brown College, with neither able to score.

title: Archivists Fear Plan to Move A Branch Of History;Researchers Say U.S. Relocation Would Steal Soul Of New York's Past
description: The National Archives branch in lower Manhattan, a big, well-lighted space containing millions of Federal documents, is a window to the region's social history, a musty pastiche of changing attitudes and great events.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday with an article about the Eugene O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, Conn., misspelled the surnames of a director and an actor who worked on the play "Most Wanted" there this month. The director is Bill Partlan, not Partian. The actor is Paul McCrane, not McCrain.

title: The Beckett Canon: So Little Is So Much
description: By bringing productions of all 19 stage plays of Samuel Beckett to New York for the Lincoln Center Festival '96, the Gate Theater of Dublin is offering theatergoers the dramatic equivalent of a museum retrospective of a major artist. In this festival within a festival (from Monday through Aug. 11), audiences can see the sweep of Beckett's theater and trace the diverse periods of his writing, from the tragicomic vaudeville of "Waiting for Godot" through the late, dead-of-night soliloquies.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Deutsche Bank Profit Rose 15% in First Half
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., Germany's largest bank, said yesterday that its profit rose 15 percent in the first six months of 1996 on stronger commission income and trading profits. Deutsche Bank said it earned 1.17 billion marks ($790 million) in the first half.

title: ATLANTA DAY 8 -- NOTEBOOK;Spectator Injured in Shooting at Transit Station
description: An Olympic spectator was shot in the arm early this morning at a rapid transit station after being confronted by a gunman who jumped out of some bushes in a parking lot, transit officials said.

title: ATLANTA DAY 8;Slaney Fails to Reach Final
description: Mary Decker Slaney's bid for an Olympic medal ended tonight when she failed to make the 5,000-meter final.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Dust Bowl Of the 30's, With Blare And Glare
description: It's a fine idea to present summer performances in parks. But not all works look equally good outdoors, as Marta Renzi and the Project Company revealed on Thursday evening at Bryant Park. The dance program featured two New York premieres and was part of the New Work New York series at the park.

title: Claudia Cassidy, 96, Arts Critic; Did Not Mince Words in Chicago
description: Claudia Cassidy, whose arts criticism for The Chicago Tribune made her a dominant figure in the city's cultural scene for decades, died on Sunday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. She was 96 and lived in Chicago.

title: Registered Partnership'
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Sri Lanka Mounts Attack Against Rebels in North
description: Sri Lanka's military, seeking to avenge its worst defeat in 13 years of civil war, sent jet fighters, field guns and tanks on a new offensive today against Tamil guerrilla strongholds in the northern jungles.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;President Ousts Finance Chief In Argentina
description: The Finance Minister, Domingo Cavallo, the architect of a program that brought economic stability to Argentina, was dismissed this afternoon after a heated argument with President Carlos Saul Menem over the pace of those policies.

title: Richard Kneeland, 68, Actor; Helped Start Rhode Island Group
description: Richard Kneeland, for 25 years a leading actor with the Trinity Repertory Company in Providence, R.I., was found dead on July 19 in his home in San Diego, Calif. He was 68.

title: In Performance
description: JAZZ Percussion-Driven Band Makes the Dancers Respond Tito Rodriguez Jr. S.O.B.'s

title: Balkan Agreement Is a Band-Aid on a Disease;Wrong Equivalency
description: To the Editor:

title: World News Briefs;Aid Bill With Sanctions On Burmese Passes Senate
description: The Senate passed a $12.25 billion foreign aid bill today that would impose limited economic sanctions on Myanmar.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Prices for Wheat Move Lower As World Crop Outlook Rises
description: Wheat prices fell sharply on the Chicago Board of Trade as concern grew that a larger worldwide crop would reduce demand for United States exports.

title: Plea by Pollard Is Denied
description: President Clinton has rejected a clemency plea from the convicted spy Jonathan Pollard despite pleas from Israel for his release, the White House announced today.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in the Calendar column of The Home Section on Thursday about a crafts fair in Woodstock, N.Y., misstated the dates. It is next Friday through Sunday, not this weekend.

title: School Governance Is Moving Right Along;Make Changes Now
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM REVIEW;Bugs as Cute as (Let's Say) Pigs? Well, They Sing
description: MTV has sapped some of the creativity from feature film making (thanks to cliches like quick cutting and detachable music video montages) but now MTV is ready to give something back: "Joe's Apartment," a film featuring cockroaches by the thousands. Though this first MTV feature is much less beastly than it sounds, its buggy humor still plays unevenly. Anthropomorphism in the barnyard (a la "Babe") is one thing, but adding antennae makes it a distinctly acquired taste.

title: INSIDE
description: Clinton Resisting Free TV?

title: Israel Seals West Bank After 2 Die
description: Israel sealed off the West Bank today after suspected Palestinian militants killed two Israelis and critically wounded a third in a drive-by shooting on a road outside the capital.

title: COMPANY NEWS;STEWART & STEVENSON MAY TAKE AN EARNINGS CHARGE
description: Stewart & Stevenson Services Inc. said yesterday that it might take a charge of $13.4 million if a judge did not throw out a jury verdict that awarded Serv-Tech Inc. $30 million in connection with a manufacturing agreement. The charge would amount to 40 cents a share and would be taken in the quarter ending next Wednesday. In a retrial, the jury found that Stewart & Stevenson had breached an agreement about making certain equipment for cleaning heat exchangers. The jury awarded damages against Stewart & Stevenson of $30 million, plus 40 percent for attorneys' fees. Stewart & Stevenson makes diesel and gas turbine- powered equipment.

title: In Performance
description: THEATER A Marriage of 2 Works On Marriage Not Working New American Stage Company St. Peter's Church

title: ATLANTA DAY 8 -- BASKETBALL;Dream Team Routs. China Rolls With It.
description: For three games, all they heard about was unfulfilled expectations. Since the Olympic flame was lighted, it was difficult to tell who was more bored, the United States men's basketball team or the people watching them. But tonight, at last, the group burdened with the Dream Team legacy began to have a little fun.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Psion Ends Talks To Acquire Amstrad
description: Psion P.L.C. pulled out of talks to buy Amstrad P.L.C., a British computer maker, because the sides could not agree on a price, the companies said yesterday. Psion, a consumer electronics company, said in June that it was discussing a bid of no less than 200 pence a share that would value Amstrad at L234 million ($363 million).

title: Ford Shifts $3.5 Billion in Industrial Leases
description: The Ford Motor Company will sell $1.8 billion in leases to the BankAmerica Corporation, and another $1.7 billion to a partnership formed by Ford and BankAmerica, the companies said yesterday

title: Successful High-Tech Union Shows Signs of Strain
description: When Wellfleet Communications of Billerica, Mass., and Synoptics Communications of Santa Clara, Calif., announced plans to merge two years ago, the skeptics had a field day. "Technology mergers tend not to work," Paul Johnson, an analyst with Robertson, Stephens & Company in New York, said at the time. "I would bet against this one."

title: Child Killed When Truck Jumps a Curb
description: A 19-month-old boy was killed and three other children were critically injured last night when they were struck by a pickup truck that jumped a curb in Brooklyn.

title: David Valinsky, 81, Statistician on Rights Cases
description: Dr. David Valinsky, a statistician who applied his skills to civil rights issues ranging from voting rights to police hiring, died on July 19 at the Westchester County Medical Center. He was 81 and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: France Moves to Rescue Troubled Lender
description: A year after rescuing one troubled lender, the French Government moved today to salvage another, allowing shareholders of Credit Foncier de France S.A. to sell their battered stock at more than twice the market price.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Rare 'Rite of Spring' for One
description: With its mighty orchestral sonorities, Stravinsky's "Rite of Spring" usually inspires choreography for large casts. Occasionally, however, a daring soul stages it as a solo. The latest is Laurence Rawlins, whose "Nocturnal Diary," to a recording of the piece, was offered by the Anima Dance Theater on Tuesday night on a program called "Rites of Passage" at Here, the performance space in SoHo.

title: Company Briefs
description: ASTRAL COMMUNICATION INC., Montreal, agreed to sell its 103-store retail photographic division to Black Photo Corp., a photographic retailer based in Markham, Ontario. Terms were not disclosed.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;118 Officers to Hit Streets
description: Joseph J. Santiago, Newark's new police director, said yesterday he planned to beef up his street patrols by redeploying 118 officers who are now assigned to administrative and investigative duties. The goal is to have at least 600 of the city's 1,197 officers on patrol to improve emergency response time, said Sgt. Derek Glenn, a spokesman for the police department. In addition, 110 recruits will join patrol units after they graduate in December. The transfers will allow each of the city's four patrol districts to create a quality-of-life task force concentrating on drug dealing and noise complaints, the department said.

title: S.P. Schlesinger, 77, Developer of Laser Used as Surgery Tool
description: S. Perry Schlesinger, who helped develop a type of laser used in operating rooms, died on Monday in Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 77 and lived on the Upper West Side.

title: BASEBALL;Cone Has Comeback in Mind
description: The crucial dates have been in David Cone's mind for weeks, the landmark days when he will pitch off a mound for the first time, make his first minor league start and pitch again for the Yankees.

title: ROCK REVIEW;Golden Oldies of Effects Take Kiss Back to Basics
description: Things go boom at a Kiss concert. Sparks fly, flames whoosh, bright lights flash and, yes, the band does play songs, including some that became teen-age anthems in the 1970's. At Madison Square Garden on Thursday night, starting a three-night stand that had sold out in 58 minutes, the whole package was in place.

title: Some Outflows Are Recouped By Stock Funds
description: Nearly half the $4 billion that rushed out of equity mutual funds a week ago trickled back into those funds in the week ended Wednesday, data released yesterday showed. But over all, the amount of cash flowing into mutual funds that invest in stocks continues to slow and has fallen by about 75 percent over the last two months. AMG Data Services of Arcata, Calif., an independent fund-tracking company, reported that investors put $1.9 billion into equity funds in the week ended Wednesday. While that turnaround is encouraging, "we're still seeing a continuing decline in sentiment toward equity mutual funds," said Robert Adler, president of AMG.

title: New Jersey Daily Briefings;State Loans for Sewer Work
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman signed legislation yesterday to help municipal governments and sewer authorities improve the treatment of wastewater and control the pollution that drains out of their local watershed. Low-cost loans to 21 governments and utilities will be made from $75 million held in the New Jersey Wastewater Treatment Trust, plus another $65 million from issuing new bonds, said Jayne Rebovich, a spokeswoman for the Governor. Flemington, for example, is expected to use part of its $1.8 million loan to replace a sewer line to stop raw sewage from overflowing on East Main Street.

title: F.B.I. Move Disturbs Whitewater Counsel's Office
description: Lawyers in the office of Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, have expressed concern that the Federal Bureau of Investigation might have meddled in their investigation of how the White House improperly obtained hundreds of confidential files, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Finally, a Health Bill
description: Congressional leaders have struck an acceptable, though troubling, compromise on medical savings accounts that should allow Congress to pass a useful health-care bill. President Clinton eagerly awaits the moment he can sign something, anything, that carries the mantle of health-care reform and thereby blunt the memory of the greatest legislative fiasco of his Administration.

title: Rachmael Weinstock, 86, Violinist and Teacher
description: Rachmael Weinstock, a violinist who specialized in chamber music and was renowned as a teacher, died on July 19 at the Split Rock Nursing Home in the Bronx. He was 86.

title: ATLANTA DAY 8 -- BOXING;U.S. Dances Its Way Toward Medal Rounds
description: Terrance Cauthen traipsed around the ring in the third round as if he were in the middle of aerobics class. He held his hands high, moved his head to and fro and, once in a great while, jerked his left arm forward in something resembling a punch.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Hall of Fame Inductions Today
description: DAN DIERDORF is going home, ending a journey that began nearly a quarter of a century ago just a mile from the Pro Football Hall of Fame in Canton, Ohio. It was in 1962 that Dierdorf accompanied his father to the hall's groundbreaking ceremony in his hometown. This time, he won't need a ticket to enter.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-5

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE OVERVIEW;Flight 800 Flew for 24 Seconds After the Initial Catastrophe
description: Radar records show that T.W.A. Flight 800 apparently continued to fly for at least 24 seconds after the cataclysmic event that doomed it, raising the possibility that some of the passengers and crew may have been alive and conscious in the last horrifying seconds before the crippled jet broke apart in a fireball, investigators said today.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Has Broad-Based Gain, Aided by Rise in U.S. Stocks
description: The dollar rose against leading currencies yesterday as stocks rallied in the United States for a second day, easing concern that global investors will flee American assets and shed their dollar holdings.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Bertelsmann-Kirch Accord on Decoder
description: Bertelsmann A.G. and Kirch Group, rival German media giants, said today that they would develop a common decoder standard for digital television, ending a long battle over which technology would dominate.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Climb as Earnings Buoy Investor Confidence Stocks advanced as positive corporate earnings reports restored investor confidence. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 51.05 points, to 5,473.06, a day after rallying 67.32 points. That brought its gain for the week to eight-tenths of 1 percent, despite sharp slides on Monday and Tuesday. The Nasdaq composite index rose 17.05 points, to 1,079.44, and the S.& P. 500 climbed 4.73 points, to 635.90.

title: Sports of The Times;Low-Profile, High-Drama Competition
description: THE first day of track and field carried the glow and feel of a big event that was accompanied by great competition.

title: AMERICAN TOPICS
description: Lowriders, the street-hugging cars with hydraulic lifts, have become the top export to Japan from Los Angeles's inner city, enjoying a bad-boy cachet among some young Japanese, reports the Los Angeles Times. There are about 2,000 to 3,000 lowriders cruising Japanese streets, compared with 75,000 in the United States.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Allen Signs With Bucks
description: RAY ALLEN, the fifth pick in the 1996 National Basketball Association draft, signed a three-year contract yesterday with the Milwaukee Bucks, who acquired him in a trade with the Minnesota Timberwolves on draft day. Terms of the contract weren't announced.

title: ATLANTA DAY 8 -- SOFTBALL;A False Step, a Fat Pitch, a Stunning Loss
description: The home run that wasn't was followed by the perfect game that got away and the sad realization that even with Lisa Fernandez pitching for the United States women's softball team, it's not over till it's over.

title: Man Convicted of Murder
description: A 22-year-old Bronx man was convicted yesterday of murdering a Marine Corps sergeant home on leave for Mother's Day in 1993.

title: Greek Premier Emerges From Predecessor's Shadow
description: For months after he resigned as Prime Minister in January, Andreas Papandreou continued to haunt Greek politics, even from his sickbed. It was not until his death last month that his successor, Costas Simitis, finally stepped from under the shadow of the man he had alternately challenged and revered.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Unilever Seeks Rest Of Lyons Irish Shares
description: Unilever offered yesterday to pay 323.3 Irish pence a share to acquire the 25 percent of Lyons Irish Holdings, Ireland's largest tea maker, that it does not already own. The offer follows the completion of Unilever's acquisition of Allied Domecq P.L.C.'s 75 percent stake in Lyons Irish for 76.41 million Irish pounds, or about $124 million.

title: Observer;Soaring With Angels
description: Watching President Clinton campaign as Dr. Feelgood tempts one to write cynical burlesque like the following:

title: ATLANTA DAY 8 -- JOURNAL;Yachting Crowds Create Barely a Ripple
description: Olympics or no Olympics, midday feels as quiet as midnight here in the garden of good and evil.

title: ATLANTA DAY 8 -- TENNIS;Agassi and Washington Seem to Play Along Nicely
description: Not your average doubles specialists, Andre Agassi and MaliVai Washington, the 11th-hour partnership that almost wasn't, made their Olympic debut in a late but often great matinee this afternoon at Stone Mountain Park.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Inspec Group to Buy A Royal Dutch Unit
description: Inspec Group P.L.C., a former unit of the British Petroleum Company, said yesterday that it would buy the specialty chemical unit of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group for L200.5 million ($311 million) in a bid to expand its product mix. The acquisition of Shell Fine Chemicals is the biggest ever for Inspec, which was created in a 1992 management buyout and has grown by acquiring specialty chemical units of big companies.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Farm Woes Curb British Growth
description: Britain's economy grew four-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, less than economists were expecting, as the "mad cow disease" scare brought a sharp drop in farm production.

title: PRO BASKETBALL;Knicks Seal Up Buck Williams
description: Buck Williams became the tape on the Knicks' express-mailed package yesterday, the last detail needed to wrap up their frenzied off-season attempt to assemble a team that can get past the Chicago Bulls and win a National Basketball Association championship.

title: Bridge
description: In most deals, a good player looking at the 52-card layout can quickly determine the most desirable contract, particularly if there is freak distribution. But there are exceptions. Study the diagramed deal, played in January in a social game in Hobe Sound, Fla., and decide how North-South will fare in various game contracts. Assume the best defense.

title: COMPANY NEWS;GE CAPITAL TO BUY UNIVERSAL DATA CONSULTANTS
description: GE Capital Services, based in Stamford, Conn., will buy Universal Data Consultants Inc., a supplier of computer network services with $50 million in revenue, the company said yesterday. Terms were not disclosed. GE Capital Services, a unit of the General Electric Company, provides financing, insurance and consumer services to businesses and individuals. It will fold Atlanta-based Universal Data into its technology management services unit.

title: Lieutenant Governor Hires a Consultant
description: Lieut. Gov. Betsy McCaughey Ross has hired a veteran political consultant who predicted today that she would make a splash at next month's Republican National Convention.

title: POLITICS: THE DEMOCRATS;President's Theme: Layoffs Fall and Wages Rise
description: As Republicans ready an attack on President Clinton's economic record, Democrats are working to offset widespread anxiety among workers over layoffs and stagnant wages by arguing that the worst days of the downsizing era are over.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CONTRACT WON TO BUILD FASTEST SUPERCOMPUTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has won a $93 million, four-year contract with the Department of Energy to build the world's fastest supercomputer. The supercomputer, which will be some 300 times faster than existing systems, will be "up and running by 1998," said Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary. I.B.M. will team up with the Government's Lawrence Livermore Laboratories in Livermore, Calif., to develop the supercomputer, which will use new multiple parallel switching technology to achieve its super speed. It is being developed to assist in verifying an international nuclear test ban treaty.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 19 about Americans who were imprisoned in the Soviet Far East during the cold war misstated the record of the U.S.-Russian Joint Commission on P.O.W.'s/M.I.A.'s, which was established to look for any missing Americans who might still be alive in the former Soviet Union. Though it has not turned up any living Americans, the commission has retrieved and sent home the remains of one American, an Air Force captain whose plane was shot down near the Kurile Islands in 1952.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TELECOMMUNICATIONS CONCERN HIRES FINANCIAL ADVISER
description: The Diana Corporation said yesterday that it had retained the investment banking firm Hambrecht & Quist as a financial adviser to evaluate the company's alternatives, including separating the company's units. The company, a Milwaukee-based maker of telecommunications equipment, has been struggling of late and has said its board is looking into a major reorganization. The company's stock price, which was above $100 a share in May, has been buffeted by speculation about the prospects for its Internet-switching technology, which it has touted as allowing Internet-service providers cheaper access to the Net.

title: HORSE RACING;Romp in the Mud Opens Saratoga
description: The 128th season of summertime racing at Saratoga opened in the mud today with virtuoso performances by a pair of very fast 2-year-old horses: Kelly Kip, who swept the Sanford Stakes by 101/2 lengths and the filly How About Now, who won the Schuylerville by a length and a quarter.

title: Jackhammer Kills Worker in Bronx
description: A construction worker was killed in the Bronx yesterday after he was struck on the head by a three-ton jackhammer used to remove soil and dig holes, the police said.

title: Survival Found At the Tip Of a Paintbrush;One Sing Sing Prisoner Uses Art as a Defense
description: In his first weeks and months in a windowless cell, Anthony Papa missed the sky. So he drew a window on the wall, complete with a sylvan landscape. Since then he has painted obsessively, through days and nights, producing hundreds of watercolors and acrylics.

title: Style and Taste In the East 60's
description: ARIZONA 206 ***

title: Bronx Convict In Job Program Is Arrested In Slaying
description: A Bronx man who had spent 11 years in prison for manslaughter and had fought to take part in a work-release program has been arrested and charged with murder in the shooting death of a teen-ager.

title: Be Only Burundian, Coup's Leader Urges Ethnic Rivals
description: The new President of Burundi took his message of reconciliation to the people today, explaining his reasons for the coup he led this week and asking them to "calm all the ethnicities, to let everyone know that there is no Hutu, no Tutsi, but only one Burundian people."

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-11

title: Is This the Twilight Of the Scientific Age?
description: To the Editor:

title: VIDEO VIEW;When the Best Seat in the House Happens to Be at Home
description: It's a familiar pitch: a "live" concert recording is the next best thing to being there; or perhaps, just like being there. But what about better than being there? A collection of six laser disks, embracing most of Tchaikovsky's major orchestral works, forms a compelling argument that a video recording can really offer an advantage over a top ticket to the actual event. Thanks to the camera's privileged eye, no seat in the house -- in this case, the Alte Oper in Frankfurt -- can compare to a favorite seat at home.

title: A Small, Uncivil War Within the Larger One
description: ALL this time I thought we were friends and you were planning on killing me,'' Jefferson says to Daniel.

title: Hear Me Roar, a Woman's Symphony on the Road
description: ANN FERRAR was riding her 650-cubic-centimeter BMW R65 motorcycle along the country roads just west of Westhampton near her home in Mastic Beach on a sunny day last week.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BRONX UP CLOSE;Concourse's Open-Shut Case
description: The Grand Concourse, the majestic eight-lane thoroughfare running along the spine of the Bronx, turned into a political battlefield last week after Mayor Giuliani ended a five-year-old tradition there. Since 1991, Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx has ordered the four center lanes of the Grand Concourse closed to cars on Sunday afternoons in the summer. But this year, the Mayor demanded that the Borough President apply for a street activity permit before opening the street for public use like bicycle riding and volleyball games.

title: Nature Explored, Indoors and Out
description: SPEND much time in the country and you come to realize that nature doesn't present itself all at once, like a neatly packaged video, but comes in haphazard flashes and flurries that can't be forced. This can be a bit maddening for those whose understanding is in a rush, or those who have only a short time in the country each year. We'd like, say, warblers to jump out of the pines in their brightest colors, give a quick identifying whistle, pose long enough for pictures, build a nest, lay some eggs, turn an aerial somersault, then do all these again in slow motion. In the real country such sightings tend to come scattered and slow, like a jigsaw puzzle only one piece of which is issued you each year. Luckily, there are places where these pieces are collected for us, identified, displayed and interpreted: first-class science museums. Here in north-central New England we're fortunate to have four excellent museums spaced within the radius of an easy half-day's drive, and there's no better way to deepen your understanding of regional flora, fauna and landscape (and sky scape!) than by spending some time at any or all, hiking their trails, studying the exhibits, listening to their resident naturalists explain what nature is up to in these hills. Vermont Institute of Natural Science, Vermont Raptor Center High on a meadow above Woodstock is the Vermont Institute of Natural Science, with barnlike headquarters, nature trails and a quiet beaver pond. These are interesting in their own right (there's no better place to study nature than an old hill farm reverting back to forest), but the big attraction here is the Vermont Raptor Center, where hawks and owls and other birds of prey that have been wounded by accidents are rehabilitated so that they may be sent back to live in the wild. Birds that can't be released, those that are permanently disabled by car accidents or gunshots, are enclosed in spacious flight habitats connected by a gravel path. Bald eagles, great horned owls, the tiny three-ounce saw-whet owl (Vermont's smallest raptor), peregrine falcons, a plump snowy owl -- there are more than 26 species here, sent to the center from as far away as Alaska. Since raptors tend to be among the most elusive species to spot in the wilds, particularly those that are nocturnal (in a lifetime of hiking these woods, I've only spotted an owl three or four times), such a venue provides a priceless opportunity to get to know these birds better. The remarkable thing about raptors, of course, is their eyes, their visual acuity. Walking from the enclosure, stopping to read at the helpful interpretative stations, glancing back up, you have the uncanny sense you're not watching the raptors at all, but that they are watching you, and not only that, but watching you more intensely than you've ever been watched. Montshire Museum of Science Just over 20 miles to the east off I-91 is the Montshire Museum of Science in Norwich, Vt. This is my family's favorite -- not only is it our rainy day old-reliable, but it provides the best learning tools we've found to help us understand the environment we live in. The museum itself is a striking, modern structure that sits on a promontory of land between the Connecticut River and the marshy bay at the mouth of Bloody Brook; one of the gentlest, most interesting nature trails leads down through tall white pines to the bay's shady banks. Inside the museum is what must surely be one of the greatest assemblages of hands-on, child-friendly exhibits ever gathered in one place, all of which, in a most entertaining way, introduce children to the basics of the natural world -- physics, optics, electricity, gravity, biology. The enchanting physics of the bubble, for example, comes to life in a play area where children explore bubbles with a variety of tanks, hoops and wands. There's a special museum called Andy's Place, which has exhibits for pre-schoolers, from crawl-through dens to animal puppets and exploratory mazes. Even the building's interior contributes to the lessons; a color-coded ventilation system, the see-through elevator shaft and exposed trusses all quietly demonstrate how a building "works." My children love the freshwater aquariums the best, finding the bass, perch, trout and frogs much more relevant to their own experience than the exotic tropicals most aquariums feature. We also enjoy the brand-new Hazen Trail, which leads a mile and a half along the banks of the Connecticut, and gives many insights into this unique riverine environment. (Pick up a coded guide at the desk for explanations of what you're seeing.) Unlike some children's museums, the Montshire (whose name comes from the last syllables of Vermont and New Hampshire) offers plenty of interest for adults, from star-watching nights to lectures on the environment to courses on the natural history of the nearby river. Save a long morning or afternoon for this museum, to explore it right. Christa McAuliffe Planetarium Both the Vermont Institute of Natural Science and the Montshire got started through the efforts of dedicated bands of local volunteers. The planetarium in Concord, N.H., had a quite different origin: a national outpouring of grief. Almost immediately after the Challenger disaster of Jan. 26, 1986, some kind of memorial was planned to honor the New Hampshire school teacher Christa McAuliffe, who taught in Concord and was one of the astronauts killed (indeed, letters and donations began pouring in before there was even any kind of foundation to accept them). The Christa McAuliffe Planetarium, an hour's drive east of the Montshire off I-393, was the outcome. The planetarium, quite literally, is a bright triangle of light, with its modern pyramidlike structure rising skyward above the nondescript suburban plain. Inside are displays not only about the night sky but also about Christa McAuliffe's life, including examples of those cards and letters sent after her death from children around the world. The atmosphere, with this background, could be gloomy, but it's anything but, and seems to tap into some of Christa McAuliffe's own vivacity and enthusiasm. The centerpiece attraction is the planetarium's comfortable 92-seat theater, where sky shows that use a state-of-the-art sound system, vivid animation, computer graphics and hand-held "voting" machines (which let the audience vote on such things as which planet they'd like to explore next) combine to produce a realistic, entertaining and, yes, educational science experience, this time centered on the glories and mysteries of the night sky. The planetarium is a rainy-day backup when it's too soggy to explore the outdoor museums, but it's more than that, too, and since it's right on one of the main routes to the White Mountains, it makes a great place to break up the long drive north. The schedule of shows changes fairly often here, so more than in most places, it's best to call ahead to find out what's up. Science Center Of New Hampshire An hour's drive up I-93 to Route 3 is the Science Center of New Hampshire, set on 200 acres of gently rising upland on the western shore of Squam Lake (of "On Golden Pond" fame) in the busy resort center of Holderness. Here the shopworn notion of a "nature trail" has been taken in new and creative directions. Called the Gephart Exhibit Trail, it's a beautifully designed walkway three quarters of a mile long, linking live animal displays (wounded or orphaned animals including bobcats, bears, otters and raptors), and hands-on children's activities in a huge cedar barn, including games, puzzles and interpretative displays. This is supplemented by two other linked trails: the Ectome trail, with exhibits based on the four major ecosystems that can be found on the property, and the Mount Fayal trail, which leads to the rocky summit of a 1,067-foot mountain with excellent views of big Squam. This is primarily an outdoor museum for children, with many activities all season long, but the kind of place any adult will enjoy as well. One of my own favorite spots to visit, when things get a little hectic down below, is the site of the old Piper Homestead (well marked on the trail map you can pick up at the visitor center), where the old foundation holes under the pines, the ruins of the old stone walls, speak volumes of the lonely, hardscrabble life led by the farmers who tried to wrest a living from this rocky soil a century ago. The lake country of New Hampshire can be a busy place in summer months, but the Science Center as a whole, and this quiet, shaded corner of it in particular, are a most welcome refuge -- and not only for animals but for those of us who seek out such spots, where nature and man can share the space of a summer day.

title: Sunday: July 28, 1996;Fit To Be Ross?
description: 1. Former Colorado governor Richard Lamm, who is challenging Ross Perot for the Reform Party's presidential nomination, sure seems Perovian. In 1976 he grew visibly upset when a roomful of journalists failed to rise during his entrance. 2. In his famous 198X "duty to die" speech criticizing lifesaving medical procedures, he compared dead people to forest-floor humus. 3. Lamm's 1988 novel, A California Conspiracy, stars a candidate who is egged on by a power-mad billionaire. 4. Last fall Lamm denied he would make this run, saying: "I don't want the defeat of Bill Clinton on my conscience." 5. Perhaps he needn't feel guilty. If Lamm runs, one poll shows him pulling 5 percentage points, all from Clinton -- but the President still coasts with 49 percent.

title: WHy Condos Sprout Where Mammoths Roamed
description: DINOSAURS, no. But woolly mammoths, mastodons and giant beavers are all part of the vivid history of the New Jersey Highlands over 1.3 billion years -- a wild ecological ride that has seen the landscape change from mountain range to ocean bed and back.

title: Sports of The Times;Our Man On Line: One Hand on Remote, One on Mouse
description: From out of the pulsing fields of cyberspace come the words of fans with one hand clutching the TV remote and one hand pushing the mouse. "Soon Internet will take over covering the Olympics," declares Ute. "At least then we will be able to make our own program and I will gladly pay for it, instead of having airheads dictate how my money should be spent."

title: State Looks for Solution for a 300-Foot Jetty
description: FOR more than 30 years a 300-foot jetty built out from a North Shore inlet in the Town of Southold has provided protection from beach erosion for the people who live west of it. But the jetty causes nothing but headaches for those to the east.

title: EARNING IT;Workers Who Signed Away a Day in Court
description: WHEN Michele Peacock left the Great Western Mortgage Corporaton in January 1996, she and her lawyers thought they had an ironclad sexual harassment suit, one rife with examples of on-the-job innuendo. At an Atlantic City convention, she said, one executive tried to maneuver her into bed as a chance "to get to know you better." Ms. Peacock sued. "I wanted my trial by jury," she said. "There is no doubt in my mind that I would win. None."

title: BASEBALL;Yankees Bail Out Rogers With Just Enough Support
description: Kenny Rogers cut through a dining room at Yankee Stadium before yesterday's game, dressed as if it were a corporate casual day at work: polo shirt and jeans. Nothing fancy.

title: A LA CARTE;Where Pasta Nights Are Just Outstanding
description: ON Tuesday nights, a cannonball shot down the center aisle of most local restaurants would not hit anyone. But on a recent Tuesday, every seat at the Crossroads Cafe was filled and, at times, people were waiting in the bar as well. Most Tuesdays are like that at this East Northport restaurant. Its pasta night consistently draws crowds while many others fail to stimulate much interest. Pasta nights are very common on the Island, only the outstanding ones succeed and the Crossroads' $10.95 all-you-can-eat affair is outstanding. The comfortable, white-tablecloth restaurant at 26 Laurel Road (754-2000) gave diners six choices at the time of my visit: penne alla vodka with shrimp; linguine, with red or white clam sauce; salmon and asparagus with Gorgonzola sauce on fusilli; rigatone primavera, eggplant Parmesan with penne and mussels Fra Diablo on rigatone. The Crossroads also offers an agreeable milieu of candles, mirrors and flowers, as well as nice little touches like crusty warm bread, herbed butter and a plate of garbanzo beans and bean spread.

title: Backtalk;After Sweat and Tears, Women Must Give Blood
description: What a shame. Every time a female athlete makes great improvement in her performances, red flags go up all over the place and even well-mannered people forget they were told not to point fingers. It doesn't happen often in subjective sports like gymnastics and diving, but it does in the objective sports of swimming and track and field, where incidents of "mutation performances," as one physiologist calls them, crop up at most major competitions.

title: THE CUTS THAT GO DEEPER
description: Regarding Charles Siebert's article about the boom in cosmetic surgery, "The Cuts That Go Deeper" (July 7), I believe that a distinction should be made between surgery that alters a so-called normal condition (modifying the shape of one's nose or increasing the size of one's breasts) and restorative surgery (a brow lift or dermabrasion) that carries with it the rewards of the appearance of regained youth and vigor. The latter is very much in keeping with our modern concerns about good health, as it applies to eating habits, activity and general care of the body.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Mountain Lakes, N.J.;A 20's Community Frozen in Time
description: WITH nearly half of its 1,400 homes built before 1930, Mountain Lakes seems frozen in the early part of this century. The narrow, winding roads, fringed by puddingstone fences, follow the contours of the land. The large wooded lots surrounding nine manmade lakes afford residents swimming, boating and water views.

title: Alas! We're All Connected
description: EARLY one evening, while traveling south from Manhattan, I found myself transported not only by New Jersey Transit but also by the radiance of a sun that was setting behind the outlet stores of Metuchen.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- BASKETBALL;McClain and Edwards Lead U.S. Women Over Australia
description: The conflicting thoughts could have been overpowering. The United States women's basketball team is housed close to Centennial Olympic Park, which brought the pipe bomb explosion there early this morning even closer to home. When the crowd of 33,952 at the Georgia Dome, the largest solely for a women's basketball game, stood for a moment of silence for the victims, the American players pressed their eyes shut and some reached to the sides for the comfort of each other's hands.

title: Teacher Memorialized After Flight 800 Crash
description: FOR nearly a quarter of a century, she considered her classroom at Edgemont High School home. An English and drama teacher since the early 1960's and single for most of her life after an early divorce, Lois Van Epps drew her family from the students and colleagues she encountered over the years at the school here.

title: The Good and Bad of Indulging in Fantasy and Daydreaming
description: IN ''By Force of Fantasy: How We Make Our Lives'' (Basic Books)Dr. Ethel S. Person discusses how and why people fantasize, the advantages of daydreams, how one's fantasy life affects their personal and professional goals, the ways that fantasies enrich lives and how fantasies influence relationships.

title: New Arson Task Force Raises Conviction Rate
description: Five years ago last Wednesday, a house burned down in Manchester Township. The case was unsolved until the Ocean County arson task force uncovered enough evidence to indict the owner and her boyfriend just a week before the statute of limitations was to expire.

title: THE CUTS THAT GO DEEPER
description: Aside from all the other implications of young, normal-looking people drastically changing their appearance, I worry about how all this face changing will affect the next generation. People who endure these procedures for the sake of looks are likely to choose mates by their appearance.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE OFFICIALS;The Burden of Responsibility: Five Men's Lives, Bound Tightly by Tragedy
description: They are five people with little in common, drawn together by the deaths of 230 people on a jetliner on a warm summer night.

title: WEDDINGS;Pamela Rivlin, Robert Mandell
description: Pamela Rose Rivlin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Rivlin of New York, is to be married today to Robert Mandell, a son of Rabbi and Mrs. Gordon Mandell of Lakewood, N.J. Rabbi Abraham Ekstein is to officiate at the Marriott Financial Center in New York.

title: SPOTLIGHT;Tale of Terror
description: A huge, unblinking eye fills the screen - a chilling moment before a killer strikes in THE SPIRAL STAIRCASE (1946). The victims, in a turn-of-the-century New England village, are young women with infirmities. Now he (or she) stalks a mute servant-companion (Dorothy McGuire) to a bedridden matriarch (Ethel Barrymore) in a gloomy but busy old Gothic mansion. This superb suspense puzzle, from a novel by Ethel Lina White, is Grade-A Hollywood. Under Robert Siodmak's direction, his technicians and a fine cast have spun a tingling, atmospheric tapestry and knockout whodunit. Don't call out when McGuire fumbles and drops her key in the rain - near a lurking silhouette. Hang on and hold tight - TUESDAY at 8 A.M. on MAX.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: THE NATION'S MOOD;For Some, Danger Now Snarls in the Next Seat
description: At the Greyhound Bus terminal on the edge of the Loop, people gathered around a 19-inch color television a few hours after the explosion in Atlanta, shaking their heads at the pictures of ordinary Americans like themselves suddenly covered in blood, sprawled on the ground or being loaded, dazed, into ambulances.

title: WEDDINGS;Anne K. Dowling, Matthew R. Auer
description: Anne Kristin Dowling, a daughter of Rita C. Dowling of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Dr. John A. Dowling, was married yesterday to Dr. Matthew R. Auer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter L. Auer of Ithaca, N.Y. The Rev. James Eckrich performed the ceremony at Mother of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church in Centreville, Md.

title: Mondello's Stand On Abortion
description: ''Two Parties Cast Wide Net for Delegates to National Conventions'' $(July 14$) incorrectly stated my position on the issue of abortion. Throughout my public career I have been a staunch advocate of the pro-life position, not an abortion-rights advocate, as your article states.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the so-called third market in stocks, where shares can be traded after big exchanges are closed, misidentified an employee of Jefferies & Company, the largest firm in that market. He is James McKenzie, an account executive, not Glen McIlvaine, the head of the equity desk.

title: WEDDINGS;Todd Larsen and Kimberly Morris
description: Kimberly Lynne Morris, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Charles Morris of Glens Falls, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Todd Hamre Larsen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Larsen of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. John Barclay performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: Wind-Whipped Utah Forest Fire Grows, Consuming 8,000 Acres
description: More than tripling its size in one day, a wind-whipped fire charred 8,000 acres of the Dixie National Forest in southwestern Utah today. .
