description: THE WHITE BOY SHUFFLE

title: POLITICS 1996;Been There
description: REFLECTIONS OF

title: WEDDINGS;Ms. Douglas, Mr. Arnold Jr.
description: Constance Douglas, a daughter of James A. M. Douglas of Bedford, N.Y., and the late Florence Palmer Douglas, was married yesterday in Mount Kisco, N.Y., to Christopher Bentley Arnold Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold of Providence, R.I. The Rev. Ned Edwards, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco. The Rev. Douglas Phillips, a Presbyterian minister, assisted in the service.

title: The Lighthouses of Long Island Sound
description: BENJAMIN F. RATHBUN has known eastern Long Island Sound -- its waters, shores, shoals, rocks and islands -- for decades. Now a marine surveyor and appraiser, he's also been a fisherman, a lobsterman and an operator of ferries and charter boats.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, the What's Doing column on July 14, about Toronto, misstated the conversion rate for Canadian currency. It was 76 United States cents to the Canadian dollar. (The prices given were correct.)

title: WEDDINGS;Miss Carchman And Mr. Levine
description: Rebecca Maya Carchman, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Philip S. Carchman of Princeton, N.J., is to be married today to David Michael Levine, the son of Prof. and Mrs. George Levine of Highland Park, N.J. Rabbi Dov Peretz Elkins is to perform the ceremony at the LaFollette Vineyard in Belle Mead, N.J.

title: Heated Words in Cold Print
description: In an effort to determine if threats were made during a heated school board meeting this month, some board members took the unusual step last week of having a recording of the meeting professionally transcribed.

title: Plan to Tame Wild Asphalt To 7 Lanes
description: Broadway, Manhattan's crooked spine, is an urban planner's worst nightmare, foiling the city's near-perfect grid system. As this former cow path runs diagonally up the island, hopelessly tangled intersections like Herald Square, Union Square and Columbus Circle are left in its wake. And at Madison Square, woe to the hapless pedestrian who tries crossing Broadway at 23d Street in a single bound. Stretching 180 feet from curb to curb, the intersection along the north side of 23d Street is three times the normal width of an avenue, and many of those who insist on crossing without pause end up dodging a sea of oncoming cars.

title: The End Is Near
description: With the first day of August falling on Thursday, summer is almost over. If you're a student with a summer job, that can be good news or bad news. We know how important these jobs are financially, and how they can provide valuable experiences to take back to school. But we want to hear about your summer job. Did you learn anything, or was it a waste of time? Send your story to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include a telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;Rub a Boombox, and Shaq Fans Get Their Wish
description: Kazaam Shaquille O'Neal, Francis Capra, James Acheson Directed by Paul M. Glaser PG 93 minutes

title: Word for Word/Officially English;A Law to Learn 'Em a Thing or Two About the American Language
description: WILL Los Angeles change its name to "The Angels" if a new bill making English the official language of the United States becomes law?

title: Authors of a School Essay Are More Than Observers
description: To the Editor:

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Picturesque Brahms in Black and White
description: HERE'S A TRICK QUESTION. Brahms's Serenade in D was scored for solo instruments, for chamber orchestra and eventually for full orchestra; in what form has it been played most often? Answer: In the version for piano, four hands.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- TRACK AND FIELD;A World-Record Finish to a Somber Day: Devers and Bailey Win in the 100
description: Ato Boldon of Trinidad "absolutely, 100 percent" guaranteed a world record in the Olympic 100 meters tonight, and he was right. But he wasn't the one who set the record in a race that produced a startling result and a humid dispute.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;Connected, Yes, but Is It a Clear Connection?
description: Since it started up two weeks ago, MSNBC, the 24-hour cable-news channel owned by NBC and Microsoft, has been trotting out its stars in an endless series of promos. Katie Couric, one of the hosts of "Internight," an interview show equipped to take E-mail and telephone questions from viewers, gushes, "In a show like this, everybody's the host." (Has anyone told Larry King about this crazy concept?)

title: Dispatches From a War of Nerves
description: To the Editor:

title: July 21-27;Japan's Sickening Wave
description: Japan's Government vowed last week to increase efforts to stem a frightening wave of food poisoning that has swept through the nation since May, sickening more than 8,000 people and killing 7.

title: MUSEUM;Plant of Many Colors
description: Touring the new Crayola Factory at Two Rivers Landing, in Easton, Pa., is like walking into a perpetually new box of crayons. There was a two-year waiting list for tours of the original Crayola factory in Easton, before visits there were ended in December. At the company's new site, visitors can watch crayons being molded and see the Crayola Hall of Fame, which salutes among others a colorblind crayon maker and Bingo, a dog who draws with crayons.

title: Dispatches From a War of Nerves;Jaywalking Law Is Ignored And the Toll Is Staggering
description: To the Editor: David Finkle's Soapbox essay on the merits of diagonal street-crossing ("How to Walk the New York Walk," June 23) points up a longstanding, basic traffic-control problem that New York City has been ignoring for years: jaywalking.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'MOBY DICK,' ALOUD Beginning at noon on Wednesday and continuing until noon on Thursday, all 135 chapters of Herman Melville's "Moby Dick" will be read aboard the whaling ship Charles W. Morgan at Mystic Seaport. The event marks the author's 177th birthday and the 11th annual reading of his epic novel of the sea, attended by dozens of staunch literary insomniacs. It will end with the sharing of a giant birthday cake at noon on Thursday. Jack Putnam of the South Street Seaport Museum in Manhattan has memorized several chapters which he will recite, assuming the character and voice (so far as anyone can determine) of Melville. Readings are also handled by members of the seaport staff and the audience, and there will be costumed role players and chanteymen to lend atmosphere. While there is no obligation to stay for 24 hours, some people do, fortified with food and something comfortable to recline on. Others may wander in and out at random. Admission is free with Seaport admission of $16, $8 for children 6 through 15. Mystic Seaport is 1 mile south of Exit 90 from Interstate 95 in Mystic. The number for more information is 572-5315.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: THE OVERVIEW;OLYMPICS PARK BLAST KILLS ONE, HURTS 111; ATLANTA GAMES GO ON
description: A pipe bomb spiked with nails and screws shattered the Summer Olympic Games today, transforming an international celebration of sport and fellowship into a symbol of the dark side of modern life.

title: THEATER;Gershwin Tunes, Musical History
description: WHEN "Crazy for You" opened on Broadway in 1992, the show's less-than-sparkling leading man and leading lady did not get in the way of the smash-hit status Broadway simply had to confer upon a makeshift musical. Even though "Crazy for You" showed off great songs and tricky dances, the musical comedy connoisseur could indeed ask for plenty more, but Broadway's new musical pickings -- "Nick and Nora," "Metro," "Five Guys Named Moe" -- were dubious if not downright scary. And the need was desperate for an upbeat hit. Only "Jelly's Last Jam" was a contender, but it was not upbeat.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on page 17 of the Travel section today, with an article about Scotland, misidentifies a plant in some copies. It is a primrose, not a gorse blossom.

title: A Little Deadheading, Some Looking Around
description: THIS is midpoint time for gardeners. The major planting has been done, with only a few touch-ups now needed. In the vegetable garden, the seeding of early fall crops should be well underway.

title: Rx for Travelers From a New Clinic
description: AFTER choosing a china pattern, a dress and a fast-approaching wedding date, the young couple moved on to planning the honeymoon. They bought tickets to Thailand and Indonesia, then took a detour along the way to the big event by visiting Dr. Donald Thea in New York.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Jazz Piano's Heavyweight Champ
description: The jazz piano occupies a world of its own. It leads a triple life, at once a harmony instrument, a melody instrument and a percussion instrument. Unlike a trumpet or a saxophone, a piano is not confined to a single melodic line; it potentially offers at least 10 separate melodic lines -- one for each finger -- and infinite gradations and permutations of melody and self-accompaniment. And of all jazz instruments, it is the one with the most daunting heritage from European classical music.

title: A Playhouse's Revival
description: THIS month, two dozen board members of the only Equity playhouse in South Jersey decided that Will Stutts had really pulled off a miracle.

title: WEDDINGS;Katherine Betts And Chip Brown
description: Katherine Hadley Betts, a daughter of Glynne Robinson Betts of New York and Hobart Dominick Betts of Sag Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Sandford Brown 2d, a son of Claire and Allan Sandford Brown of Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Christine Grimbol performed the Presbyterian ceremony at the Old Whalers Church in Sag Harbor.

title: Authors of a School Essay Are More Than Observers
description: To the Editor: In the biographical note identifying Thomas Corcoran and Nathan Scovronick, the authors of the essay "School Finance: A Way Out" (Soapbox, July 14), you neglected to mention that they were among the chief architects of the Quality Education Act, the school-financing plan signed into law by former Gov. Jim Florio and declared unconstitutional by the State Supreme Court in July 1994. Mr. Corcoran and Mr. Scovronick piously criticize the Whitman plan, but they do not acknowledge that it was their own failure to enact a constitutional financing system that has placed the state in this situation. This is hypocrisy of a high order.

title: The Path of Capitalism
description: To the Editor:

title: Construction Firm Makes Savings a Hallmark
description: WHEN the Philipse Manor Railroad Station in North Tarrytown closed more than a decade ago, its chestnut wood paneling, stone arches and views of the Hudson River were seen only by four-footed trespassers.

title: BASEBALL;Borders Goes To White Sox
description: The Chicago White Sox, looking for catching depth after losing Chad Kreuter to a season-ending shoulder injury, acquired the veteran Pat Borders from the California Angels today. Chicago sent the Angels the minor league pitcher Robert Ellis.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CLINTON HILL/FORT GREENE;Pratt's Dream Is Thwarted By a Fire
description: By the time Thomas F. Schutte, the president of Pratt Institute, arrived in front of Higgins Hall last Sunday, a pre-dawn blaze had already swallowed up the building's north wing. Only a few beams of the roof remained in place, a tattered shield against the sky. Windows were knocked out. The college's precious film and video archives were presumably consumed. And with the fire, the $1.5 million recently spent renovating Higgins Hall as part of Pratt's larger rebuilding plans literally turned into ashes. "This sets us back in a way," Dr. Schutte said. "I came to campus and was just in total shock. It was a moment of quick depression."

title: Like Emma, Setting Her World All Astir
description: PERHAPS NOT SINCE infancy has 23-year-old Gwyneth Paltrow been so much the center of her own universe. In the last three years, she has received fawning reviews for playing mostly ancillary characters in so-so movies. When she ventures out in public with her boyfriend, curious onlookers gather, if not precisely because they know who she is, but because the man who is gazing at her so adoringly is Brad Pitt. This month, she swans through her first leading role, in "Emma," based on the Jane Austen classic, making it look easy to be an American passing as England's most beloved heroine in a film overflowing with acclaimed British actors.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: A ZEN ROMANCE

title: Despite His Reversals, Clinton Stays Centered
description: His hands in restless motion, Bill Clinton sat in the Oval Office earlier this month assessing the Presidency he calls "this great adventure."

title: Adding Flavor With a Dash
description: CERTAIN ingredients can add another dimension to a dish. A pinch of curry powder or ground chili, a dash of soy sauce or sesame oil, can sometimes make a surprising difference. They should, of course, be added judiciously so they don't overwhelm or compete with the other ingredients.

title: Barnum's-Eye Views of Fashion
description: THE next best thing to going to the circus is to visit the Barnum Museum in Bridgeport where a third-floor permanent exhibition gallery brings the circus to life in miniature. It's worth seeing over and over again, just for itself.

title: Science Fiction
description: When a former astronaut writes science fiction, you have every reason to expect that it will champion the benefits of space travel against the doubters and penny pinchers in the scientific and political establishment. ENCOUNTER WITH TIBER (Aspect/Warner, $21.95), by Buzz Aldrin and John Barnes, delivers the goods, and then some.

title: MAKING IT WORK;Anything for a Smile
description: YOUNG Brandon Weiss is dressed like an adult in his striped red, white and blue Polo shirt, designer blue jean shorts and Docksiders, but he behaves like a typical 2-year-old. This Thursday afternoon he is having his portrait taken for the first time and is clearly uninterested. He runs through the trees, fills his pockets with rocks, beats the air with a stick and leaves his chair a dozen times -- everything except look at the camera. All the while a photographer, Kate Burton, is right behind him. Halfway through the 90-minute shoot, Ms. Burton is worn out. Her brown hair is tousled and sweat runs down her forehead and the nape of her neck. Yet she says this is one of her easier shoots.

title: Smoking or No
description: To the Editor: The 14th Amendment to the Constitution guarantees to all citizens both equal and unabridged privileges and rights, which historically include equal privileges to travel -- and to travel equally.

title: School Board Members Take Crash Course at Summer School
description: With his move to gain more control over the city's 32 community school boards scuttled in Albany, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew embarked yesterday on a different tack to change the way board members do business: He sent them back to school.

title: IN BRIEF;New Arson Task Force Raises Conviction Rate
description: Five years ago last Wednesday, a house burned down in Manchester Township. The case was unsolved until the Ocean County arson task force uncovered enough evidence to indict the owner and her boyfriend just a week before the statute of limitations was to expire. Formed in March 1995, the unit has amassed a record that has won it the Outstanding Accomplishment Award of the International Association of Arson Investigators in Oklahoma City.

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: Sputnik went into orbit at the time I was starting high school. In the years that followed, science received greater emphasis in school as North America geared up to recapture global technological leadership.

title: World News Briefs;Battles in Somalia Focus on Large Airport
description: A Somali faction leader, Gen. Mohammed Farah Aidid, has regained tenuous control of his main airport, a top aide said today. The official also denied reports that General Aidid had been wounded in recent fighting.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Southeast Asian Art Displayed in Singapore
description: The new Singapore Art Museum opened earlier this year with a permanent collection of more than 3,000 contemporary paintings and sculptures from Southeast Asian artists.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTH JAMAICA;Heated Words in Cold Print
description: In an effort to determine if threats were made during a heated school board meeting this month, some board members took the unusual step last week of having a recording of the meeting professionally transcribed. During an uproar over the possible dismissal of the principal of Junior High School 8 in South Jamaica, some people in the audience berated the board, saying the principal, Jermaine Garden, was being made a scapegoat for the school's failures because he is black. The board voted 7-2 to allow, but not require, the district superintendent to "discontinue" the principal if the school does not improve.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: How Her Garden Grows

title: The Bard as a Man of Fewer Words
description: AFTER intermission, they do ''Hamlet.''

title: A Family Awaits The Miraculous
description: WILLIAM KOSBOB says he rarely gets angry, really angry. That requires too much energy, he says. Thoughts of vengeance would only clog his mind, which must remain focused on keeping his family intact.

title: POLITICS 1996;In His Soul He Knows He's Right
description: ACTIVE FAITH

title: THEATER;'Damn Yankees' Revival
description: In the happy time of "Damn Yan kees," musical comedy audience friendly and unamplified -- was a presumed way of life. And live theater was the entertainment of choice. Now, more than 40 years later, no one needs to be told that big new musical comedies are history and theatergoing on Broadway is less a spontaneous act than a stressful negotiation.

title: Where Pasta Nights Are Just Outstanding
description: ON Tuesday nights, a cannonball shot down the center aisle of most local restaurants would not hit anyone. But on a recent Tuesday, every seat at the Crossroads Cafe was filled and, at times, people were waiting in the bar as well. Most Tuesdays are like that at this East Northport restaurant. Its pasta night consistently draws crowds while many others fail to stimulate much interest. Pasta nights are very common on the Island, only the outstanding ones succeed and the Crossroads' $10.95 all-you-can-eat affair is outstanding.

title: Hunger Strike in Turkish Jails Reveals Nation's Divisions
description: It did not take to long to show where the power lay.

title: DINING OUT;Ups and Downs in Food and Presentation
description: DEJA VU in Westhampton Beach. Entering Sam's Hampton Square, a friend, who sometimes has trouble distinguishing Westhampton from West Hempstead, said "We've been here before." Indeed we had. This was our third foray since 1993. Then, the name was simply Hampton Square. The restaurant was loud and crowded with erratic food and service. In 1994 Starr Boggs, the legendary Westhampton Beach superchef, turned it into Starr's Hampton Square. It was still loud and crowded but his food and well-trained staff gave the place new life.

title: A Swimmer's Peak
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Hebron Is Tense Over Delay in Israeli Withdrawal
description: By now, the brown and yellow concrete blocks placed in this city's heart were to have marked a clear line between Israeli and Palestinian authority.

title: WEDDINGS;Joan McNichol And Ray Nieves
description: Joan Melissa McNichol, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James B. McNichol Jr. of Edison, N.J., was married on Thursday to Ray Anthony Nieves, a son of Clifford Nieves of Tampa, Fla., and the late Amparo Nieves. The Rev. Peter Padro, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Manor, a restaurant in West Orange, N.J.

title: Babe Ruth Signature Inspires Awe and a Lawsuit
description: LUMPY and soiled, its hemp stitching tight in some places and loose in others, it looks like any old baseball: no way to tell immediately that it has a connection to the original field of dreams.

title: Smoking or No
description: To the Editor: Your report on the growing restrictions against accommodating smokers left me wondering how many of these "laws" stem from a vindictive, fear-driven prohibitionist mind-set.

title: July 21-27;Israel's Hard Line Softens
description: With two small steps, Israel's conservative new Prime Minister showed his willingess last week to deal with historic foes -- at least up to a point.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- ROUNDUP;BEACH VOLLEYBALL: Brazilians Are First
description: The pre-tournament favorites, Jackie Silva and Sandra Pires of Brazil, captured the first Olympic gold medals awarded in the sport yesterday.

title: THEATER REVIEW;A Small, Uncivil War Within the Larger One
description: ALL this time I thought we were friends and you were planning on killing me," Jefferson says to Daniel. Or something like that. The two wounded soldiers on the Confederate side in 1863 are waging a private bedside war in a plantation house in Virginia for reasons only the playwright John J. Wooten knows for sure.

title: Plane Crashes and Politics;The Latest Casualties Are Factual
description: The day after T.W.A. Flight 800 exploded in the skies south of Long Island July 17, the local congressman announced that one of the black boxes had been found. Over the next few days, the President's chief of staff said investigators were looking closely for signs of terrorism and had detected "chemical leftovers" on plane debris. The Governor told the world, including the anxious families, that divers had found "dozens and dozens" of additional bodies.

title: Residential Resales
description: MANHATTAN

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9;This Time, Games Go On Without Delay
description: Unlike the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich, Germany, where 11 Israeli athletes and officials were killed by Palestinian gunmen, international Olympic officials decided today that the centennial Games should continue without delay despite the explosion of a pipe bomb early this morning that killed 1 person and injured 111 more.

title: GOOD EATING;Style and Taste In the East 60's
description: ARIZONA 206 *** (212) 838-0440; 206 East 60th Street; $$(c) all major credit cards A loyal crowd of stylish habitues frequents this spirited midtowner for its refined and inventive Southwestern fare in an inviting setting of molded plaster walls, plank floors and blond wood tables. Begin with the mixed green salad with steamed asparagus seasoned with pumpkin-seed vinaigrette and topped with red chili croutons or ostrich carpaccio drizzled with chili oil and complemented with white cheese and a caperberry and poblano relish. Main courses are just as compelling, including the barbecued sea bass enchilada rolled in fresh tortillas and enhanced by a jicama and leek sauce, grilled loin of rabbit coupled with a braised rabbit quesadilla in a toasted cumin sauce, Peking duck tamale with an ancho and plum sauce, and smoked venison in a red wine sauce accompanied by a sweet potato and corn risotto. (Review: 2/19/93)

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants Are a Mixed Bag In Defensive Backfield
description: To find the most interesting group of personalities on the Giants, a true mix of styles, cultures and athletic abilities, go immediately to the secondary.

title: The Path of Capitalism
description: To the Editor:

title: EARNING IT;Albany Bill Expands Managed Care in Worker Injuries
description: FOR the thousands of New York State businesses that pay a total of $5 billion for workers' compensation insurance each year, the significance of recently approved legislation revamping the system should be as clear as the numbers on their premium bills: it will help reduce rates by as much as 25 percent, state officials say.

title: A New Vision for Long Island
description: THIS summer, as usual, Long Islanders are experiencing the tiresome hardships that result from sprawl and pollution. Once again there are world-class traffic jams, many related to road-widening projects whose completion will bring no relief. Shellfisheries and beaches will shut down. Garbage crises will recur, and economically harmful brown tides will most likely return. Subtle but worrisome threats to the quality of the drinking water in the aquifers will jangle the nerves. Decisions favoring poorly designed forms of "growth" will add to many citizens' tax burdens while detracting from the quality of their lives.

title: ELLA FITZGERALD;Serendipity In San Francisco
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;Tunnel Visions: Subway Fanatics Tell Their Tales
description: Last Wednesday evening, a little bookshop on Rockefeller Plaza resounded with discussions of intricate detail and exquisite scholarship. "The D-types were my favorite cars but the fact is they had to go," said one man who gestured excitedly to his nodding conversation partner. "They were old and slow. Sometimes you have to kill the sacred cows." Said another man to a rapt young lady: "When people ask me whether the PATH train is better than the subway, I say what time of day? What day of the week?" They were among the trainophiles gathered at New York Bound Bookshop, which specializes in works about the city. In theory the attraction was a book signing in honor of the publication of James Clifford Greller's "Subway Cars of the BMT" and Susie Tanenbaum's "Underground Harmonies." In practice the signing party was a nice excuse for a gathering of that rare breed of New Yorker, the subway fanatic. People at the party said the city has about two dozen hardcore subway scholars, who write detailed monographs on the subject and maybe a few thousand assorted trainspotters, who record subway movements, and hobbyists, who just love to think about trains. Almost all are men -- this is somehow a male fixation -- and most are middle-aged. Although there are clubs for them like the 500-member Electric Railroaders Association, many work alone. So the 40 enthusiasts who came to the bookstore renewed old acquaintances with pleasure as they drank wine and listened to Jon Graseck, a violinist who usually plays in the subway. Mostly they get along, but there are some burning issues that divide them. Some claim that specific lines like the No. 3 are superior to others. Some believe that Fiorello La Guardia saved the subway by unifying it under the control of the city in the 1930's and others think he ruined it. "You get people who will argue over what train stopped where in 1932," said Joe Cunningham, a 44-year-old engineer from Jackson Heights, Queens, and habitual No. 7 rider who writes about trains full time. "If it's relevant to history it makes sense, but at other times it becomes absurd." The star of the night was Mr. Greller, a New Jersey Transportation Department executive who has published three transportation books. He worked the room, signing books and cracking jokes. Typical for a local train fanatic, he is city born, in his case Brooklyn, and motivated both by a romance for powerful machines and by a nostalgia for New York the way it used to be. "Brooklyn was like the Florence of the transportation business," he said, relating the building of the BMT to the flowering of the Renaissance. Most in the room love to toss off arcane facts like the old name of the G line (the GG) and the reason that IRT trains can't run in the rest of the system (the IRT cars are narrower to fit into tunnels that are older and tighter than the rest). These fanatics say they are also motivated by the idea that without them much subway history would be lost. Said Mr. Geller, his fist pumping the air for emphasis: "I got angry that some of the big advances that the city made in transportation weren't even documented." EDWARD LEWINE

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Bengals Sign Pelfrey to Five-Year Deal
description: DOUG PELFREY, who had been on the verge of ending talks with the Cincinnati Bengals about a multiyear contract, signed a five-year deal Friday with the team. The Dayton Daily News, citing unidentified sources, said the kicker's contract is worth $3.4 million, including a $500,000 signing bonus. Last year, the former University of Kentucky star set a team record with 121 points and bettered his own team mark with 29 field goals. He has converted 81 of 100 attempts in three seasons with Cincinnati. (AP)

title: In the Region/Long Island;For Some Historic Houses, History Is No Shield
description: THE house at the corner of East Main Street and Cove Neck Road here was built in part in 1650, 30 years after the landing of the Mayflower. A plaque notes that "George Washington rested here on April 23/24, 1790, while on his Long Island tour."

title: Italian Menu and a Touch of Cabaret Style
description: WITH the new Crown SoNo Regent theater complex serving as an anchor on the North Main Street end, South Norwalk's development continues with the opening of Cafe LuLu, also on North Main.

title: Keeping Cool in a Roomful of Smoke at RJR Nabisco
description: PICTURE this job listing: Wanted, chief executive for tobacco/food company with restive shareholders; duties include shedding highly regarded food operations, reviving tobacco products that have been declining for decades and competing at home and overseas with larger, deeper-pocketed rivals; must have thick skin and get used to being called a "merchant of death."

title: Her Specialty, Playing the Goofy but Lovable Heroine
description: Not every actress can give a character dignity and pathos while hobbling barefoot with a bicycle chain clamped around her ankles. Mary Kay Place pulls that off in "Manny and Lo," a black comedy about teen-age sisters, one pregnant, who are on the lam from separate foster homes.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE LAST MAGIC SUMMER

title: ON POLITICS;The Uncomfortable Case Of the Governor's Friend
description: In early October 1993, a newspaper poll showed Gov. Jim Florio with a substantial lead over his rival, Christine Todd Whitman. Since few campaign contributors want to back a loser, the Whitman campaign worried that contributions would dry up, making it difficult for Mrs. Whitman to start a television advertising blitz in the final days before the election. But Michael D. Francis, chairman of the campaign's finance committee, kept the money flowing. Although he made few public appearances with Mrs. Whitman and was rarely mentioned in the press, he held one of the most influential positions in the campaign. After the election, he was chairman of her inaugural committee. And several months later, Mrs. Whitman rewarded him with one of the most prestigious political plums she can bestow: the chairmanship of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.

title: Corrections
description: A review on June 30 about "Omon Ra," by the Russian writer Victor Pelevin, misstated the history of translation of his works. While "Omon Ra" was his first novel translated into English, his novella "The Yellow Arrow" was published simultaneously with it in Britain in a single volume in 1993. "The Yellow Arrow" was published in the United States by New Directions in May.

title: Children's Books
description: Great-Uncle Alfred Forgets

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Subaru Outbacks;Traction Down Under
description: PROCRASTINATION ought to be an Olympic event. I'd qualify, hands down, and the nice thing is that I seem to get better with age, putting off more and more as the years go by. Take bottles, for instance. I had been meaning to make a trip to the crusher to recycle my household's empties just as soon as I could get to it. Actually, they had been piling up since sometime in 1992, and I had successfully not found the time until the furnace man arrived.

title: 5 Die and 16 Are Injured in Cruise Ship Fire
description: Fire broke out today aboard a cruise ship in Alaska's Inside Passage, killing five crew members and injuring 70 people, the Coast Guard said.

title: Mrs. Great Adventure
description: WILMA DEL SONTRO was in grade school when she first ventured onto a roller coaster, lured by her father and a family friend. So jolting was the ride -- it was the Cyclone, on Coney Island -- that the friend's false teeth went flying. And young Wilma fell in love.

title: Couple Who Stirred Issue of Same-Sex Marriage Still Hopeful
description: Having fallen in love at first sight at a disco dance lesson and spent 19 inseparable years from that very moment, Joseph Melillo and Patrick Lagon tend to believe in kismet.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: KIPS BAY;Moldy Walls Put Tenants on Edge
description: Troy Lang is sure his apartment is killing him. Like dozens of tenants at the Henry Phipps Plaza South, a federally subsidized housing complex on Second Avenue and 26th Street, Mr. Lang, 59, says an epidemic of poisonous mold is causing the chronic fatigue and wheezing that keep him from work as an entertainer. Swelling joints make it painful to walk, and at night, he wakes up with pounding headaches. "Until recently, I was never sick a day in my life," said Mr. Lang, president of the complex's tenant association. Marie Alston, 76, no longer sleeps in her apartment and enters only with a surgical mask tethered to her face. Her stucco walls sprout black wisps of Stachybotrys atra, a highly toxic organism she blames for skin rashes, heart palpitations and respiratory problems. The mold, she says, has killed her parakeets, tropical fish and house plants. "For years, everyone thought I was crazy," said Ms. Alston, a retired nurse. "Now at least I'm not the only one complaining."

title: N.Y.U. Fined In Animal Research
description: Although ''In the Maelstrom of Animal Medical Studies'' $(July 7$) reports that the Department of Agriculture cleared N.Y.U. of retaliation against Dr. Jan Moor-Jankowski, two incidents discredit that. On June 28 the Agriculture Department fined N.Y.U. a record $450,000 for egregious violations of the Federal Animal Welfare Act. The fine, by far the largest in the history of the Agriculture Department, upheld the allegations Dr. Moor-Jankowski had made as a whistle-blower.

title: Gershwin Tunes, Musical History
description: WHEN ''Crazy for You'' opened on Broadway in 1992, the show's less-than-sparkling leading man and leading lady did not get in the way of the smash-hit status Broadway simply had to confer upon a makeshift musical.

title: Comeback at Ascot
description: Pentire, ridden by Michael Hills, came from last to first to win the King George VI and Queen Elizabeth Diamond Stakes today.

title: A Stylish House, A Sunken Garden
description: THE Hill-Stead Museum in Farmington, part of the 11-member consortium of the Connecticut Impressionist Art Trail, remains open all year. But summer is the charmed time to visit the landmark -- not only for its inspired architecture, impressive Manet and Degas paintings (displayed in a fully furnished domestic setting), but also for its hilltop view of fields, orchards and its crowning jewel: a restored sunken garden designed by Beatrix Farrand.

title: L.I. VINES;Champagne
description: Blanc de blanc, Pugliese Vineyards, Cutchogue, 1992. (Paper label, $14; hand-painted bottle, $22.)

title: Children's Books;Bookshelf
description: NOW I WILL NEVER LEAVE THE DINNER TABLE. By Jane Read Martin and Patricia Marx. Illustrated by Roz Chast. HarperCollins. $14.95. (Ages 4 to 8) Patty Jane Pepper is condemned to sit at the table until she eats the spinach that her sister, Joy, the bossy baby sitter, claims she hid in her pocket. An amusing revenge fantasy that captures sibling rivalry nicely. Very funny illustrations. MY FATHER'S SCAR. By Michael Cart. Simon & Schuster. $16. (Ages 12 and up) In this thoughtful novel, Andy Logan, a college freshman who is both a runner and a reader, looks back on some of the torments of growing up all too aware of being a misfit in his family and his hometown.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Astros Acquire Wilkins for Manwaring
description: A change of scenery. That's the label both teams have put on a trade of catchers Friday night. The San Francisco Giants sent KIRT MANWARING and an undisclosed amount of cash to the Houston Astros for RICK WILKINS.

title: Skulking Danger or Ecological Beauty? Going After Coyotes
description: NEW regulations allowing expanded trapping of coyotes with leg-hold traps are being recommended by biologists at the State Department of Environmental Protection, with final approval pending from its commissioner, Sidney J. Holbrook.

title: Smith Is for Real
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: YOUR HOME;Insurance: Reading the Fine Print
description: WHEN was the last time you curled up with your homeowner's insurance policy for a good read?

title: Safety Plan for Puerto Rican Projects
description: The change that everyone talks about is safety. "You don't have to be afraid of a stray bullet," Luz D. Quinones, a resident of the Yuquiyu housing project, said recently.

title: DIG-gity DIG-gity DIG-gity ja-BAH-doh-be'
description: NAW, NAW," SAVION GLOVER SAYS. "THERE'S too many in there. Just diggity boom boom."

title: ART;A New Generation Emerging On Often Irreverent Terms
description: THE Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield frequently resembles a funhouse. The galleries are a series of rooms on two floors, and the sensation is one of anticipating what's in store in the next room. That the current show should be fun -- to put a finer point on it, brash and sassy -- is somewhat unexpected, for it would seem to have a sober mission: putting the spotlight on a new generation of African-American artists. What clearly emerges is that these artists, born in the 1950's and 60's, are entering the art world on their own, often irreverent terms.

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Burrowing for Treasure, and Finding Some
description: It is easy to understand why musicians of a historically inquisitive sort enjoy poring over neglected scores. The hope of discovering lost treasure is a powerful driving force, and the consolation prize -- finding music that may not be of masterpiece quality but offers respite from the standard repertory -- is thoroughly respectable as well.

title: WEDDINGS;Stephanie Syrop, David Webster
description: Stephanie Anne Syrop, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Syrop of New York, is to be married today to David Aram Webster, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Webster of New Canaan, Conn. Rabbi Mark Lipson is to perform the ceremony at the Water's Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: The Fresh Air Fund;Games of Olympic-Caliber Enthusiasm
description: Just as the Olympics got under way in Atlanta last weekend with a fantastic display of internationalism and personality, Fishkill completed its own version of the Games.

title: RUNWAYS;And Now, Men's Wear Of a Different Stripe
description: STRIPES must be the ultimate symbol of respectable men's wear: boring chalk-stripe bankers' suits, pin-striped white-collared shirts and the O.K.-for-the-office ties in dreary combinations of colors like maroon and navy.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- ROUNDUP;BASEBALL: U.S.-Cuba Matchup Set
description: The United States homered its way to another victory and headed into its long-awaited matchup with Cuba with a medals-round berth clinched and a perfect record in hand. The Americans hit five homers -- two by Jacque Jones -- for a 15-5 victory over Australia that set up the Olympic tournament's marquee first-round game today.

title: Sports of The Times;Olympics Not 'Games' Anymore
description: IN the darkness, before dawn broke over Centennial Park's bloodied bricks, Francois Carrard, the deputy general of the International Olympic Committee, proclaimed that "the Games will go on. I repeat, the Games will go on . . . the Games will go on."

Rubin, the son of Justice and Mrs. Isaac Rubin of Rye, N.Y., were married last evening at the Arthur Danziger Gallery in New York. The bridegroom's father, who is retired from State Supreme Court in White Plains, officiated.

description: ONE of Woodstock's many current attractions is monarch butterflies; another is plein-air sculpture. Both are available at the Elena Zang Gallery, which requires a detour to this tiny hamlet, four miles west of Woodstock on Route 212.

title: A DEAD LANGUAGE, YIDDISH LIVES
description: I was surprised to see Tony Kushner's disparaging reference to Zionism in Jonathan Rosen's fine article "A Dead Language, Yiddish Lives" (July 7). I find it odd that an American Jew, who is proudly militant in other aspects of his identity, recoils at an ideology that returned both a nation and ethnic pride to the Jewish people. It's not enough to value dead Jews and their culture. It's the living Jews of Israel, the guarantors of Jewish physical and cultural survival, who merit Kushner's admiration. It's too bad that they embarrass him.

title: July 21-27;Union on the Hill
description: Eighteen months ago, for the first time, the House and Senate liked the idea of allowing Capitol Hill workers to join unions. And so legislators overwhelmingly approved a union provision as part of a broader law requiring Congress to abide by many of the same workplace rules as the private sector does.

title: Lee Lescaze, Editor And a Reporter, 57
description: Lee Adrien Lescaze, the weekend editor of The Wall Street Journal and a former assistant managing editor of The Washington Post, died Friday night at his home in Greenwich Village. He was 57.

title: Protesters Angered by Raid Battle Police in Indonesia
description: The most serious rioting in decades erupted today in downtown Jakarta, with anti-Government protesters hurling rocks and setting fire to buses, cars and several office buildings, then fleeing wildly as police and soldiers charged at them with bamboo canes.

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;INVESTING WITH: Christopher H. Wiles
description: THE current stock market, dipping and swaying as it is, "is our kind of market," says Christopher H. Wiles, manager of the Federated Equity-Income fund. "It's like shopping in a nice jewelry store and all of a sudden they've got a blue-light special on Rolex watches."

title: VOICES: VIEWPOINT;Playing the Game Of the Name
description: THE season of quarterly earnings reports has just passed. Again, companies have recited their litanies of, "We are attempting to maximize shareholder value," or, "We are rededicating ourselves to our core business."

title: If It Feels Good, Don't Do It
description: The Pleasure Police

title: A New Vision for Long Island
description: THIS summer, as usual, Long Islanders are experiencing the tiresome hardships that result from sprawl and pollution. Once again there are world-class traffic jams, many related to road-widening projects whose completion will bring no relief. Shellfisheries and beaches will shut down. Garbage crises will recur, and economically harmful brown tides will most likely return. Subtle but worrisome threats to the quality of the drinking water in the aquifers will jangle the nerves. Decisions favoring poorly designed forms of ''growth'' will add to many citizens' tax burdens while detracting from the quality of their lives.

title: Cyclist Wins a Top National Ranking
description: WHEN Jason Gould played college lacrosse at Plymouth State College in New Hampshire, some of his best games as a goalie were games that his team lost. Frustrated, he turned to an individual sport, that of highly competitive bicycle racing where he has become one of the top nationally ranked amateurs in the Northeast.

title: Connecticut Q&A: Debra K. Pasquale;A Fiscal Profile of Biomedical Research
description: DEBRA K. PASQUALE is executive director of Connecticut United for Research Excellence, a group known as CURE that promotes biomedical research. Recently CURE surveyed the biomedical industry in the state, concluding that it is contributing nearly $2 billion a year to the economy, and that there is potential for much more. "No other state," she said, "has quantified the enterprise the way we just have." CURE has five employees and an annual budget of about $500,000. Ms. Pasquale is a registered nurse with degrees from the University of Hartford School of Nursing and Yale who started in critical care and specialized in oncology and clinical trials before joining CURE. Recently she answered questions about CURE in an interview in Groton at Pfizer Inc., a founding member of CURE. Following are excerpts from that conversation. Q. Could you sum up what your studies concluded? A. Twenty-five years ago there was one company in Connecticut, Pfizer, and it had about a $15 million research and development budget. Today there are four large companies, which spent $1.2 billion in 1995. That represents 10 percent of all pharmaceutical research and development in the country. There are also a lot of Federal research dollars that come in; Connecticut ranks fourth in the nation per capita, and in the top 10 in total dollars. And we really haven't capitalized on the little companies. They love to associate with the big pharmaceuticals, which are already here. We have a tremendous opportunity to attract small biotechnology companies to the state.

title: Ideas & Trends;The Smallest Olympians Face the Biggest Risks
description: THE teen-agers on the American women's gymnastics team arrived in Atlanta for the Olympics with their prospects for victory clouded by injuries: one had a four-inch stress fracture in her leg, another had tendonitis in her forearm and wrist. The team members played through the pain and won a gold medal. But their quest for glory might cost them their health, doctors say.

description: CAN'T afford summer air fare to London? Then take a cheap seat in the living room section for telly nights on public channel WLIW, where broad English accents are as common as fund-raising drives and the sensibility is equal parts London and Long Island. WLIW, which is based in Plainview, L.I., has grown into one of the most highly watched public television stations in the United States, in part by eschewing most traditional Public Broadcasting System programming.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.;Where to Hoist in Red Hook
description: IN the fall of 1945, John Balzano came back from World War II in Europe and made local history. He immediately wrote off all the outstanding tabs at John's Restaurant and Bar, which he and his brother Rafael had owned together since the late 1930's, and thus became a legend along the docks of Red Hook, Brooklyn. In what was then a rough waterfront neighborhood, respect was the measure of a man, and John Balzano never took it for granted. "The fact that this place still exists after all these years, after all that has happened to Red Hook, is a testimony to the respect that my uncle John got from the people," said Antonio R. Balzano, 62, Rafael's son. "People remember this place because of him." John's Restaurant and Bar, at the foot of Conover Street, has outlived by 15 years the last of the 30-odd other saloons that were once in the area. It is a virtual time capsule from the 1940's, a remnant of what was a bustling wartime port half a century ago. But it is also a symbol and the centerpiece of a revitalized Red Hook. John's nearly faded into history like the surrounding neighborhood when John Balzano died in 1994. He didn't leave a will -- and that, Antonio Balzano said, left a "wall of obstacles" to keeping the place going. "I was ready to let it all go," he said, dragging on his umpteenth Marlboro of the day. The liquor license held by John Balzano expired on Jan. 31, and with legal delays keeping the bar closed, Mr. Balzano decided to reopen it as a nonprofit organization, with the support of John Balzano's 15 other heirs. "I had a mailing list of people -- artists, everybody -- and when I wrote them this idea," he said, "I got a tremendous response. More than 200 people replied." For now, John's operates as the nonprofit Red Hook Canoe and Yacht Club -- but to add to the confusion, patrons call it Sonny's, after Antonio Balzano's nickname. Its status as a club, however, is hardly exclusive -- upon entering, nonmembers need only hook up with one of the regulars, most of them local artists who pay a $25 annual membership fee, and sign a guest book. There is a suggested donation of $3 per drink, and tabs are scribbled on paper casters. As Red Hook undergoes a slow renaissance sparked by artists seeking to escape the high rents of Manhattan, John's has become a focal point of this rebirth, and conversation now dwells on the Edward Hopper-like quality of sunlight in the neighborhood rather than shipping schedules. On Fridays evenings -- the only time the club currently operates -- people drift down to the end of Conover Street to admire the sunset over the harbor and pour back into John's afterward. Around the original hand-carved oak bar, which stretches the length of the first of its three rooms, the club's yellowing walls are lined with prints of Holland-America line ships, models and paintings of boats and military memorabilia. In the 1940's, Red Hook was home to Navy drydocks and to hundreds of ships moored between Piers 41 and 49. Among other period pieces like a Blatz Beer boiled-egg dispenser, hand-painted plaster statues of the Marx brothers, Mark Twain, Humphrey Bogart and Louis Armstrong peer through the half-light toward three massive coffee urns that Antonio Balzano said served up to 3,500 cups of a coffee a day during the 1940's. "Nothing in here has been changed," he said. "If you take three or four things out of the place, it won't be the same anymore." The restaurant, with a view over the Buttermilk Channel toward the Statue of Liberty, was founded by Marc Antonio and Angelina Balzano, immigrants who arrived from Naples in 1890. Their daughter, Grace, born March 17, 1906, is the oldest surviving member of the family. During the 1920's, the restaurant operated under a complicated partnership, and a yellowed certificate issued by New York City's Licensing Department and dated July 1924 certifies that John Balzano's brother-in-law, John Happe, was permitted to operate a pool table on the premises at $5 per annum. The several apartments above the restaurant are the exclusive domain of the Balzanos -- no one outside the family has ever lived there. Twenty-six thousand people lived in Red Hook by the mid-1950's, but the advent of container ships that were too large for the channel meant a loss of jobs for longshoremen and other dock workers and brought the neighborhood to the brink of extinction. Today, Red Hook is home to no more than 3,500 people, said John McGettrick, a local historian and co-chairman of the Red Hook Civic Society. Antonio Balzano was among the thousands who left. He was an aspiring artist and actor, but after four years in the Air Force in California, he ended up going to work for a jeweler in Manhattan's diamond district. Unsatisfied, he soon quit to paint full time in the early 1960's. His first break came when he was commissioned to paint murals at Le Boeuf a la Mode, a restaurant on East 81st Street, which led to an offer to work as an assistant to Larry Rivers and Willem de Kooning. "But I was brash," he said. "I wanted to be a real artist." He turned down an offer to teach at Southampton University and spent the rest of the 1960's on the party circuit. In 1970, emotionally spent, he decided to seek spirituality in India, where he spent most of the next decade. In 1980, after his father became ill with cancer, Mr. Balzano returned to Red Hook to help out in the bar, eventually taking over when Rafael died in 1987. But when John Balzano died without a will, ownership of the bar was not immediately clear. In the club's basement, Mr. Balzano's girlfriend, Tona Johansen, pointed out a huge pile of yellowing documents. "John kept everything, every piece of paper, but never kept it in any order," she said. "It has made things difficult, complicated." But with the help of Ms. Johansen and other friends, accounts have been sorted out, junk cleared and refrigerators rewired. Mr. Balzano has applied for a liquor license and, if it is approved, plans to rename the place Balzano's. The influx of artists and young people into the area has brought with it new energy, and on Friday nights aspiring musicians play to an appreciative crowd. The mix is eclectic: country rock alternates with Lou Reed-style rock poetry, and the later the hour, the darker the lyrics. Kim Faiella, a painter from Brooklyn Heights, is positively possessive about Sonny's, as she calls it. "This place is so special, it has not changed at all," she said. "It has attracted its own artist community from all over Brooklyn. There is great energy here, and we are very excited about what is happening in Red Hook now." Mr. Balzano said: "This place does not belong to me. It belongs to all the good people here."

title: After Sweat and Tears, Women Must Give Blood
description: What a shame. Every time a female athlete makes great improvement in her performances, red flags go up all over the place and even well-mannered people forget they were told not to point fingers. It doesn't happen often in subjective sports like gymnastics and diving, but it does in the objective sports of swimming and track and field, where incidents of ''mutation performances,'' as one physiologist calls them, crop up at most major competitions.

title: Car Owners Feel the Heat as the Price of Freon Climbs
description: If your car air-conditioner is blowing Caribbean trade winds instead of Arctic cold fronts, beware: tuning up the system may cost more than you expect.

description: To the Editor:

title: STYLE;The Spirit Is Willing
description: It is true that Dr. Jean Houston, the human-potential researcher and the occasional guest of Hillary Rodham Clinton, recently came to spend a weekend with me at my country retreat. I was having difficulty writing this column, and she suggested a "brainstorming" session using some of the creative thinking techniques she has developed over years of lecturing at distinguished universities and consulting with executives from major corporations. It is also true that we conducted an imaginary dialogue with Halston in order to help us grapple with some of the more difficult issues facing fashion today. But allegations that we were "channeling" Halston are completely unfounded, and any reference to our sessions as "seances" is a gross distortion of what actually took place. I have never been to a seance.

description: To the Editor: I was a longtime supporter of Miriam Friedlander and worked as a volunteer on Margaret Chin's 1993 campaign against Kathryn Freed ("The War of Nerves Downtown," July 14). I have since become a supporter of Ms. Freed.

Gavay of Danbury, Conn. The Rev. Peter Connelly, a Roman Catholic priest, is to perform the ceremony at Rosecliff, the historic house in Newport, R.I.

title: TV SPORTS;Coverage Was Rapid, But Perspective-Free
description: When a pipe bomb shattered the peace yesterday morning, Mark McKay of CNN was walking through Centennial Olympic Park from the network's headquarters. He heard a blast from the AT&T Global Olympic Village that "shook me from head to toe." He ran to the adjacent Nike Park, where CNN has a studio during the Olympics, and was on the air in minutes, at 1:30 A.M., reporting a "loud, concussive explosion."

title: BASEBALL;For Some Mets, Tough Talk Takes On Sense of Urgency
description: It was only eight days ago that the Mets were enjoying their best stretch of the season and talking of reaching a .500 record and contending for a wild-card spot. Since then, they have lost eight of nine games, including a losing streak that stretched to six today with a 7-5 defeat to the Reds.

title: World News Briefs;Islamic Militant Leader In Algeria Is Killed
description: The fundamentalist Armed Islamic Group of Algeria said today that its leader, Djamel Zitouni, also known as Abu Abderrahman Amin, was killed on July 16 near Medea, 70 miles south of Algiers.

title: Investigation Is Dropped In Plan to Sell Wild Horses
description: Citing a lack of evidence, the United States Justice Department has dropped an investigation based in Texas into allegations that James D. Galloway of the Bureau of Land Management participated in a scheme to sell federally protected wild horses to slaughterhouses.

title: Miami Fetes 100 Years of Hyperbole
description: Henry Flagler had no intention of building anything here, where the Miami River pours into Biscayne Bay. But the 19th-century railroad tycoon, responsible for much of South Florida's early development, changed his plans after meeting Julia Tuttle, a local landowner bearing an orange blossom and big dreams for a new American city.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about the quality of new jobs in the economy misstated the previous job of Jeffrey Pelkey, systems administrator at Viatech Laboratories. He had been a systems administrator for a hospital, not a hospital administrator.

title: Dispatches From a War of Nerves
description: To the Editor: Your profile gives the impression that M. B. Lee and John Wang speak for the vast majority of Chinese-Americans living in District 1. They do not. Many Chinese-Americans in the community are bored with the politics they practice. If objections to Councilwoman Freed exist, they are not on the grass-roots level. It is because some cynical political operators are stirring the muck.

title: ART;A Sculpture Show With Butterflies
description: ONE of Woodstock's many current attractions is monarch butterflies; another is plein-air sculpture. Both are available at the Elena Zang Gallery, which requires a detour to this tiny hamlet, four miles west of Woodstock on Route 212. Although it houses a show by contemporary artists, the gallery is upstaged by its terraced garden, which comes with babbling brook, trees and the sculpture exhibition. Foreground distractions to the contrary, this begins with the view beyond the bridge across the brook, centering on a sculpture by Tom Doyle.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;SoHo to Get a Hotel And a Canine Amenity
description: Hartz Mountain won't have its name on the marquee of its new SoHo Grand Hotel in Manhattan, but the property will offer a clue to the owner's identity: a stone basin at the door where passing pooches can get a drink of water.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction;Wired
description: At the outset of Mary Kay Zuravleff's engaging first novel, THE FREQUENCY OF SOULS (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23), we learn a crucial piece of information about its hero, an electrical engineer named George Mahoney. It seems that from the time he built his first radio set "from glass tubes and a spool of lead," George has been convinced that "the universe was soldered together with logic." So it isn't surprising that he reacts with "fatherly embarrassment" to his new junior office mate's revelation that she experiments with radio frequencies in order to listen for the dead. In fact, George knows that Niagara Spense, who is partly deaf in one ear, has difficulty hearing many things. What is surprising -- most of all to George himself -- is that, despite his disbelief, Niagara inspires in him "a burning curiosity that had not flared in some 20 years." And in no time curiosity becomes obsession. When he awakens his wife, Judy, yelling, "Niagara," she replies, "You had better be screaming about vacation." For George, who has had no complaints or extramarital liaisons during his largely unexamined 16-year marriage, Niagara is an improbable love object. Ungainly, untidy and chaotic, she is the antithesis of Judy, "a Georgia brand of Southern belle." But Niagara's presence makes George aware of the fine line between contentment and stagnation. As he explains it, "If you leave a car parked long enough, the tires go flat and the battery won't hold a charge." By the end of the novel, when Niagara and her research have enabled George to recapture a few sparks, Ms. Zuravleff's insightful yet gentle rendering of the absurd has also allowed readers to connect fully with her quirky and endearing characters. Janet Kaye

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 7 about plastic surgery referred erroneously to a surgical procedure for men. Gynecomastia is a medical condition -- excessive development of the male breasts -- and not a surgical procedure. The condition is altered by reduction mammoplasty.
