title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: THE BOMB SITE;From Fun Under the Summer Stars to Terror
description: The city's downtown was alive in a way it had never been before the Olympics. The streets were still busy and vibrant even as 1 A.M. came and went, and at the heart of it all was the Centennial Olympic Park. Thousands of people sat on the grass under the spotlights and the stars, danced barefoot to the throb of live electric guitars, or rambled the brick walkways with plastic cups of beer, pleasantly numb.

title: Astor Place Stylists Weren't Forced Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Foresters Facing a Tough Test
description: DONALD A. Du BOIS of Killingly said that after spending $100,000 getting forestry degrees, including a master's of science from Yale University, he was disappointed to find there were no educational requirements when the state began licensing foresters this year.

title: The Chinese Menu Guys
description: ZHU Q. JUEN is a mild-mannered 39-year-old immigrant from Fujian, China with a ready smile. But every afternoon, Mr. Zhu, who has delivered Chinese food for the last three years, joins the army of other deliverymen known as the Bicycle Brigade and goes into warrior mode. He flings a happy-face plastic shopping bag over the handlebars of his black mountain bike, races through the canyons of the Upper West Side, and charges his way into some of its best-guarded fortresses, bringing meals to those who have ordered them and menus to those who have not. Along the way, he dodges speeding buses and swerving cars and braves baseball bats, lit cigarettes and angry fists.

title: Votes in Congress;Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate 1. Welfare: Vote on an amendment to a welfare reform bill that would continue food stamps and many forms of public assistance for legal immigrants already in  the United States. (The bill bans most forms of assistance for legal immigrants  who have not become citizens.) Rejected 52 to 46, July 23. 2. Welfare: Vote on an amendment to a welfare reform bill that would eliminate part of the bill that would allow states to receive their food stamp money as a lump sum, or block grant. Approved 53 to 45, July 23. 3. Welfare: Vote on an amendment to a welfare reform bill that would let states  use Federal money to provide vouchers to families who reach the five-year limit  on cash assistance. Rejected 51 to 48, July 23. 4. Welfare: Vote on a major overhaul of the welfare system that would end the longstanding Federal guarantee of cash assistance for poor children and give states vast new power to run their own welfare and work programs with lump sums  of Federal money. Approved 74 to 24, July 23.
description: Connecticut

title: In the Region/Connecticut;Roiled Northwest Corner Acts on Gravel Mining
description: A DEMAND by residents for more stringent regulations or outright banning of the old established practice of gravel mining has been simmering for years in the Northwest Corner towns of Brookfield, Cornwall, New Milford, Roxbury and Woodbury, among others. This summer it came to a boil.

title: INVESTING IT;As Market Wavers, Cash Calls. Now What?
description: FOR four days when the stock market began to falter, Marilyn Wronko went on a "crash" diet. "I was so nervous about the market I couldn't eat," said Ms. Wronko, 53, an executive assistant at Newsweek. "I made call after call to the Vanguard '800' line to find out how much I was losing." At one low point, she said, she was down $4,000.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: OSWALD'S TALE: An American Mystery

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FREE CHOICES

title: Correction
description: The government listing in the Gazetteer chart last Sunday, with an article about living in the Midwood section of Brooklyn, omitted a City Councilman who represents part of the area. He is Noach Dear, a Democrat.

title: Where Lenin Ruled, Stocks Gain
description: WHERE are the world's hottest stock markets? Not in the economic powerhouses of Asia, but in a region that largely spurned capitalism until recently: Russia and its former satellites in Eastern Europe.

title: Sunday: July 28, 1996: POLITICS;Let No Man Be Blamed
description: Resentments have long simmered over San Francisco's Pioneer Monument, a series of statues that sit outside the city's new main public library. And last spring, after completion of the $138 million building -- a citadel of multiculturalism that contains no Nancy Drew books but does hold a lesbian parody of them -- the bad feelings boiled over.

title: Pratt's Dream Is Thwarted By a Fire
description: By the time Thomas F. Schutte, the president of Pratt Institute, arrived in front of Higgins Hall last Sunday, a pre-dawn blaze had already swallowed up the building's north wing. Only a few beams of the roof remained in place, a tattered shield against the sky. Windows were knocked out. The college's precious film and video archives were presumably consumed. And with the fire, the $1.5 million recently spent renovating Higgins Hall as part of Pratt's larger rebuilding plans literally turned into ashes.

title: Liberties;Plagues, Comets, Values
description: It's hard to tell who is more obsessed with disaster, Republicans or Hollywood executives. One group is scrambling to avoid it, while the other is scrambling to peddle it.

title: Plea Bargain For a Woman In a Holdup
description: A 71-year-old woman who tried to hold up a gas station for money to pay her back taxes apologized to the clerk on Friday and cried as a judge read the terms of her plea agreement: either three years of probation or as much as one year in prison.

title: ATLANTA DAY 9
description: OFFICIAL DECISION The International Olympic Committee chose to continue the Games, just as it did in 1972 when 11 Israeli athletes and officials were killed in Munich. Most athletes said they agreed with the decision.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- ROUNDUP;MEN'S VOLLEYBALL: Brazil Stuns U.S.
description: A rejuvenated Brazil team shocked the United States, 15-11, 15-11, 15-7, in preliminary round play.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;How Hot It Isn't: A Record-Breaking Cool
description: This July has had just about everything New Yorkers have come to expect in midsummer. There have been busloads of tourists, Lollapalooza at Randalls Island and Shakespeare in the Park. The Yankees are in first place and the Mets are, well, promising. And yes, the air has been muggy and full of curious smells. But the one thing this month hasn't had, according to weather statistics, is heat. In fact, if the trend holds -- and predictions for this week imply that they will -- this July will be the first since 1889 that the temperature in Central Park has not topped 90 degrees. Moreover, it's the first time since meteorologists began keeping records in 1869 that there hasn't been a 90-degree day in June or July. "It's truly exceptional," said Fred Gadomski, a meteorologist at the Penn State Weather Service. "People must be wondering who hit the wrong button."

title: WEDDINGS;Jennifer Hudson, Richard Marcou
description: Jennifer Sue Hudson, the daughter of Susan Jensen of Jackson, Wyo., and John Hudson of Evergreen, Colo., was married Friday evening to Richard Adam Marcou, a son of Joyce and Joseph Marcou of New York. Judge Thomas Jordan of the Jackson Municipal Court officiated at the J Bar S ranch, which is owned by the bride's mother and her stepfather, Paul Singer.

title: Smoking or No
description: To the Editor: Nothing was said about whether nonsmoking rooms in hotels received air through ventilating systems from smoking areas of the building.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD: PARK SLOPE;Women's Weekend, in Dance and Song
description: TWO vibrant women will take the stage this weekend in Prospect Park: the dancer-choreographer Amy Pivar on Friday night and the pop singer Nona Hendryx on Saturday. The performances are part of the Celebrate Brooklyn Festival. Characterized by explosive and athletic dancing, Ms. Pivar's ensemble, Amy Pivar Dances, is an unusual collaboration between Ms. Pivar; Freda Rosen, a social therapist, and Phillip Carroll, a singer-composer. The program will explore women's relationships and social issues. One piece, "Not a Concession," deals with rape and incest. Ms. Pivar, in foreground at right, was one of the winners, in 1986, of the New York Dance and Performance Awards, popularly known as Bessies, after Bessie Schonberg, a noted teacher of dance composition. On Thursday at 7 P.M., an open workshop at the Prospect Park Picnic House will explore live music for dance and give the public an opportunity to talk with Ms. Pivar, Ms. Rosen and Mr. Carroll. Nona Hendryx was 16 when she and Patti LaBelle and Sarah Dash formed the rhythm-and-blues trio Patti LaBelle and the Bluebelles back in the 1960's. They broke out of the traditional girl-group mold and evolved into the rock-soul group LaBelle, which achieved enormous popularity and influence before breaking up in the 1970's. Ms. Hendryx went on to a notable solo career, with forays onto the cutting edge of funk, though these days, she performs only a few times a year. The opening act at Saturday night's concert will be the group Sepia, whose music is said to reflect the African-American diaspora. "Vibrant Women in Music and Dance": Amy Pivar Dances, Friday at 8 P.M., and Nona Hendryx, Saturday at 7 P.M., both at the Prospect Park Bandshell, Ninth Street and Prospect Park West; free, with a suggested contribution of $3; (718) and Prospect Park West; free, with a suggested contribution of $3; (718) 855-7882 ext. 52

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: ON DIALOGUE

title: Mondello's Stand On Abortion
description: Two Parties Cast Wide Net for Delegates to National Conventions" [July 14] incorrectly stated my position on the issue of abortion. Throughout my public career I have been a staunch advocate of the pro-life position, not an abortion-rights advocate, as your article states. I have appeared numerous times at pro-life events and have been quoted extensively in the media concerning my pro-life views. I firmly believe in the sanctity of human life and feel that our society has a moral and ethical obligation to protect the unborn. I find the currently prevailing trend in support of unrestricted abortion on demand, including the so-called "partial birth" abortion procedure, to be abhorrent and a tragic flaw in the moral fabric of American society.

title: July 21-27;A Nice Place to Visit, But...
description: New York, New York: the Bronx is still up, the Battery's still down, and the people still ride in a hole in the ground. But most Americans don't think it's as hellish as they did two decades ago, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll of 979 people nationwide, taken between July 11 and 13.

title: Accessible Broadway: The Cheap Seats
description: Tickets to Broadway shows may cost more than $65 apiece these days, but reduced-price tickets for many shows are available at the two TKTS booths -- the main one in Duffy Square at 47th Street and Broadway, and a satellite at 2 World Trade Center.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on June 16 about troops on the Great Wall of China in 1937 misidentified them. They appear to be Chinese, not Japanese. Complaints from Japanese and other readers led to further research, which established that the photograph had been mislabeled in The Times's archives.

title: The Language Wars;To the Barricades, Speaking in Tongues
description: NEVER mind the French military might that rumbled down the Champs Elysees and roared overhead on Bastille Day. The struggle closest to French patriotic hearts is being fought out at the Olympic arenas of Atlanta -- and not by the athletes.

title: Dole Focuses on Terrorism And Drugs in a Radio Talk
description: Bob Dole began his radio address today by asking for a moment of silent prayer for the victims of the bombing in Atlanta, which he called a "cowardly act."

title: MUSIC;Recitals on City Island Continue
description: WHEN the harpsichordist Ilan Rechtman began a series of Sunday recitals on City Island in the Bronx three years ago, he developed what may be the only nonstop concert cycle in the New York City region. "We haven't missed a week yet, and our audiences tend to come back again and again because they find it a unique listening experience," Mr. Rechtman said of the programs at Le Refuge B&B Inn. "We can only accommodate about 50 people -- less when we have larger performing groups -- so it's almost like hearing chamber music in your own living room, with a reception afterward to meet the artists."

title: Tradition, Venetian Style, in Mount Kisco
description: THIS venerable Victorian has undergone another major renovation, and before we get to the chef, praise is in order for the designer. The glassed-in ground floor has been deconstructed and the space rendered fluid. Tables seem to spill out to the patio.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- ROUNDUP;SHOOTING: Italian Wins Skeet Gold
description: Ennio Falco of Italy, nearly perfect through two days of shooting, won the gold medal in skeet. Falco's score of 149 at the Wolf Creek Shooting Complex in Atlanta was one target short of the world record of 150 shared by his countryman, the bronze medalist Andrea Benelli, and Jan Henrik Heinrich of Germany.

title: Smoking or No
description: To the Editor: On the subject of "No Smoking: A Travelers' Status Report" (June 30): a nonsmoking section in a restaurant or an airplane is completely ineffective. Either you get to smoke or I get to not smoke. It's just that simple.

title: Firebombs in Basque Area
description: Thirty hooded attackers threw gasoline bombs at banks in a Bilbao suburb early this morning at the start of a Basque country festival, the police said. The group also smashed windows at two banks and set fire to an insurance company office, a car dealership and a van.

title: A Phantom Hall Filled With Discord
description: IT FLOATS ABOVE DOWNTOWN LOS ANGELES, a mirage in the California sun. For Walt Disney, it offers remembrance with dignity; for Frank Gehry, a hometown monument to an architect's career. For the Los Angeles Philharmonic, it is an emblem of long-sought international eminence. For local politicians, it sings a siren song to far-flung Angelenos, drawing them inward to the troubled center of this exploding universe of a city.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- ROUNDUP;WATER POLO: A Croatia-Spain Final
description: Croatia will meet the 1992 silver medalist Spain for the championship. Croatia upset the Italians, 7-6, with Josko Krekovic scoring his fourth goal on a penalty shot 11 seconds before the end of the second overtime. Spain beat Hungary, 7-6. Italy and Hungary will go for the bronze.

title: Correction: Pay Levels of New Jobs
description: A chart last Sunday with an article about the quality of new jobs in the economy mislabeled one pay category. Here is a corrected chart.

title: POLITICS 1996;Bill and Bob's Excellent Adventure
description: THE CHOICE

title: COPING;A Director in a Hurry, Creating Her Own Myth
description: GALT NIEDERHOFFER has a meeting at Fox tomorrow on a possible distribution deal for her first featurefilm, but before she left for Hollywood last week she had time to dictate, on request, an opening sentence for this story: "Despite the disadvantages of an Upper East Side upbringing, this 20-year-old woman, crafty, quick, obsessive, hopes to effect the marriage of business and art." The trace of self-mockery was only for effect. The film, "Myth America," may be a satire about chaotic young downtown women making a voie to find their identities, but Ms. Niederhoffer is as organized as a clock, and she thinks it's her time. She has raised $2 million - all from strangers, she insists - and she has just finished 24 days directing an interesting group of young actors. Ms. Niederhoffer takes herself seriously, although she does describe herself as "shameless." It isnot hard to imagine her chasing a celebrity downt he street, waving her script. She has a press agent, which is how we came to have lunch. She ascribes to a handy brand of social Darwinsim. "Capitalism and the free market weed out the bad stuff," she said. "If you're good, you'll get out there. And making a movie is all about the art of the bluff. You bluff the investors about the actors you have and you bluff the actors about the investors. But write down that I never lied." We were sitting in a downtown dinner. I wrote it down. She picked at my french fries. "Do you ahve disdain for all this?" "Only bewilderment," I said. "Could we take it from the top?" Ms. Niederhoffer is tall, blonde, blue-eyed and rosy-cheeked. She looks as though she played varsity squash at Harvard, which she did, after Chapin and Milton Academy. She was indeed raised on the Upper East Side. Her father, Victor Niederhoffer, is a wealthy investor, Harvard graduate and former national squash champion. Her parents are divorced. Ms. Niederhoffer says she always thought of herself as a writer and a film maker - while at Harvard she helped found a lampoon of the Lampoon (The Harpoon) and produced a short film - but it was not until doctors told her she had temporal lobe epilepsy, a disease of partial seizures that affect memory, perceptions of reality and visceral senations, that she felt the urgency to get on with her career. She was 19. "Don't write all that down." she directed. "i have disdain for people who use their illnesses to explain their lives. But it was a trigger. Six days before last New Year's Eve, when I was still in and out of hospitals, I decided that if I didn't do something meaningful that year I never would. I wrote the first draft of 'Myth America' in six days. I am not a creative genius. I listen to people and do revisions." At that moment I thought Ms. Niederhoffer might be some kind of genius after all. The people at Fox, Miramax, all those who sign at the X, love to give money to Gen X, but only if they will show humility and do revisions. I pushed the plate of fries to her side of the table. She dropped out of Harvard to start "Myth America" and "Hurricane," a second feature film, out of an office on Wooster Street. She raised the money, she said, in large chunks, from "wannabe moguls." She said she never went to family or to friends of her father because "self-funded art is devalued." Besides, the world is filled with rich people desperate to get into movie-making and with hungry actors who will audition for other people's dreams. "Getting others to believe in your bluff is what raising money and directing actors is all about," she said, "and believing in your own bluff, having faith in your concept, is how you get well. By acting on your belief you have created it. I got well by believing I could get well. This is William James. Am I making sense? Would you like to see dailies?" The scenes looked smart and promising, but maybe I was jsut buying into the bluff. Ally Sheedy looks haunted as a heroin addict, and there are rising young actors, Eric Mabius, Justin Pierce and Brendon Sexton 3d int he cast, as well as Ms. Neiderhoffer's Harvard friend Rashida Jones (Quincy's daughter); Dechen Thurman (Uma's brother), Jennifer Stander (Lionel's daughter) and Anika Poitier (Sidney's daughter). Production notes underline these relationships. Elizabeth Wurtzel (the author of "Prozac Nation") plays herself; she and Ms. Niederhoffer have the same therapist. Having written the opener, Ms. Niederhoffer suggested a closer, her favorite lines in the script. "It's impossible to say anything original. I'm on a quest to recover mythic glamor in a culture where heroes do voice-overs, heroine's a drug, the American glamour girl overdosed and the matinee idol is our ideal." I explained that I was the director here, so we would close with my favorite line in the script, "That's why I want to make movies, to control the atmosphere.

title: Quality of Life? Not for Homeless, Advocates Say
description: A fresh crackdown by the New York City Police Department on so-called quality-of- life crimes in Manhattan has prompted concern among advocates who say the move is aimed at homeless people.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE OVERVIEW;Workers Recover First Large Piece of T.W.A. Jetliner
description: Salvage workers recovered their first large piece of the Trans World Airlines jet from the ocean floor yesterday and sent the portion of the right wing to the building where the 747 is being reconstructed, hoping it would offer some clues to the cause of the fiery crash 11 days ago.

description: A triple load of suspense and a delectable double dip for the youngsters rise to the top of the movie menu this week.

description: If furniture could talk, one wonders what a pink leather couch would say of its downward trajectory from centerpiece of a scandal in the Dinkins administration to obscurity in a tidy recreation room of a Greenpoint public housing project.

title: FOOD;Adding Flavor With a Dash
description: CERTAIN ingredients can add another dimension to a dish. A pinch of curry powder or ground chili, a dash of soy sauce or sesame oil, can sometimes make a surprising difference. They should, of course, be added judiciously so they don't overwhelm or compete with the other ingredients.

title: CUTTINGS;An Unlikely Prairie Thrives in Brooklyn
description: There's a prairie growing on a triangle of concrete in Brooklyn.

title: Legal Aid Agencies Have a New Cause, Their Own Survival
description: South Brooklyn Legal Services has always had a weighty roster of class-action lawsuits on behalf of the city's poor. Among those it has won are a case for women with AIDS who had been denied disability benefits, and another for special-education students who had not been properly screened.

title: ATLANTA DAY: 9 -- TRACK AND FIELD;U.S. Triumphs Tempered By Joyner-Kersee's Pain
description: Kenny Harrison, a Californian who has dominated his event when healthy, won a gold medal tonight for the United States in the centennial Olympic Games.

title: Women Base Their Votes On More Than Abortion
description: To the Editor:

title: Driver Surrenders in Fatal Crash
description: A Brooklyn man who lost control of his pickup truck on a Bedford-Stuyvesant street and crashed into a group of children, killing one, surrendered yesterday, the police said.

title: Let Lawmakers Put Brakes On 'Hot Pursuit' by Police
description: To the Editor: Joe Sharkey's column "When a Police Car Is a Lethal Weapon" (Jersey, July 7) shows that "hot pursuit" chases pose a serious threat to the public, especially in a densely populated state like New Jersey. At least 5 people were killed and 251 injured in 1,237 pursuits last year, according to incomplete statistics from the State Attorney General's office. Yet New Jersey is moving backward by easing some of the legal restraints that can curb irresponsible actions by officers who engage in high-speed chases. Last month, the State Supreme Court ruled that police officers responding in good faith to emergencies cannot be sued for injuries to innocent bystanders. At the same time, the Assembly passed a bill shielding the police from lawsuits for injuries inflicted during chases. These judicial and legislative actions clearly favor law enforcement at the expense of innocent bystanders. In an attempt to strike a better balance, Assemblyman Joseph Charles Jr. and I have drafted a measure that would hold government agencies liable for the negligent acts of their officers. Injured parties could seek compensation if they were injured as a result of a police officer's "willful misconduct" in failing to abide by state guidelines for police chases. The threat of a civil monetary penalty would certainly insure that officers and departments think twice before entering into high-speed, high-risk chases.

title: BEST SELLERS: July 28, 1996
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction

title: WEDDINGS: VOWS;Brigitte Devine, Daniel Delaney
description: ALTHOUGH Daniel Delaney lives in Manhattan, he spends almost every weekend in hiking clothes or waders at his family's farm in Windham, N.Y. On Saturday nights, he sometimes sits outside by a bonfire and reads long narrative poems by Robert W. Stevens, who chronicled the adventures of woodsmen and gold prospectors a century ago.

title: DINING OUT;Italian Menu and a Touch of Cabaret Style
description: WITH the new Crown SoNo Regent theater complex serving as an anchor on the North Main Street end, South Norwalk's development continues with the opening of Cafe LuLu, also on North Main. The name evokes an image of a belle epoque cabaret, an image echoed by posters and dashing paintings of cabaret performers (reminiscent of Toulouse-Lautrec's work) on several cream- colored interior brick walls. Though a low black ceiling, dark carpet and black booths and chair seats suggest gloominess, the restaurant is actually well lighted. A separate bar can be glimpsed through windows above the wall-long banquette, an ingenious device that allows you to view the bar's action without enduring the noise. Soft taped jazz throughout dinner supplied congenial background music unobtrusively.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: THE VICTIM;A Friend Is Lost, and a Street Is Full of Bewilderment and Pain
description: The word spread fast from door to door on Oglethorpe Boulevard in Albany, Ga., the way bad news always does. It passed from the fish house to the hair stylist to the shoe store.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PROSPECT PARK;Fee at Botanic Garden Proves a Thorn in the Side for Many
description: Last December, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's board decided to impose an admission fee for the first time in its history to make up for a budget shortfall. Since then, community groups around the 52-acre garden have protested. Now, the politically formidable groups fighting the $3 fee are trying to divert state money away from the garden unless the fee is eliminated. Botanic Garden officials say they are confused by the protesters' rage. Like other cultural institutions, they say they had little choice but to charge admission since the city cut cultural affairs funds.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: THE STAKES;Pipe Bomb in a Park Trumps Games' Advanced Security
description: Whoever planted a pipe bomb in the park that has become the centerpiece of Atlanta's Olympic festivities struck unerringly at one of the weakest points in what officials had touted as the largest peacetime security operation for a public event in American history.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- ROUNDUP;MEN'S SOCCER: Portugal Edges France
description: Portugal defeated France, 2-1, on a penalty kick in the final minute of sudden-death overtime before 19,464 at the Orange Bowl in Miami. The victory put Portugal into the semifinals on Tuesday against Argentina, a 4-0 victor over Spain, the defending champion, in Atlanta.

title: The View From: Yale-New Haven Hospital;Cold Wet Noses That Lift The Spirits of Young Patients
description: THE patients wear pajamas decorated with dancing animals. The visitors wear fur topped by snappy red uniforms. In the children's acute-care units of Yale-New Haven Hospital, smiles are all too often missing. Tuesday afternoons, however, it's another story. Then, an unusual breed of volunteers arrives at the wards, tails wagging, enormous paws on beds, and tongues tickling every little face that leans forward. The canine candy-stripers tour the rooms with their handlers: Chukker and Sirius, golden retrievers, and their respective owners, Barbara McCullough and Marian Spiro; Rufus, a chocolate lab, with Vicki Chave Clement, and Cricket, a mixed breed, with Bonnie King. Each team visits once a month on a rotating basis. The Dog Visitation Program that spreads such cheer through the children's, adolescent and psychiatric pediatric units is a one-year pilot that was started in March. Its popularity is evident not only in the patient rooms but also in the corridors, where each dog, like a wooly Pied Piper, collects a trail of staffers, visitors and children in wheelchairs. While the dogs obviously share in the enjoyment, they can be distracted. Chukker is reluctant to tear himself away from a nose-level aquarium in the hallway and, Ms. McCullough admitted, "We have to turn off television during the visits. Chukker would rather watch the Muppets than visit. He's also very turned on by stuffed animals." Permission to enter a room is always obtained from the parent and care taken that the dog visit is appropriate. For instance, a child who is in the hospital as a result of a dog attack is not a likely prospect. Usually, however, wan children perk up and reach out to pat when the dogs appear. Most children leave the hospital in less than a week but those who stay longer form a close bond with the dogs. One 8-year-old boy, hospitalized for a liver transplant, was even allowed a visit while in intensive care. "It was very touching to see the child reach out to the dog; the only thing he could move was his hand because he had tubes everywhere else," recalled the volunteer program coordinator, Annie Garcia Kaplan. Another child, who had been receiving chemotherapy, could not have a dog in his room. No problem; he and the dog were held up on opposite sides of the room window, giving each other kisses through the glass. It was Ms. McCullough, a former nurse, who proposed the dog visitations. "I'd read about these programs in nursing homes, and I knew about the one at Gaylord Rehabilitation Hospital," she said. "I thought, 'I haven't been back to the bedside in so long and this is the way I want to do it.' But I wanted to do it in the acute care, because I felt the need was so great." She approached the director of volunteer services at Yale-New Haven, Jeannette Hodge, who suggested looking at the program at Newington Children's Hospital, which then helped in the planning. The trial program took more than two years to develop, Ms. Hodge said. "It was a very novel idea," she said. "There are not a lot of large medical centers like ours doing this kind of program. Most are convalescent homes, children's hospitals or rehab settings. We needed to look at all the ramifications of bringing animals into a setting where many of our patients are very, very sick. "The challenge came in being certain that we had thought of everything single thing in terms of vet protocol, screening of the owners, screening of the dog, the timing. All things took time to really think through to be sure we thought of everything." Ms. McCullough also recruited Dr. Eleanor Weir, a veterinarian and professor of comparative medicine at Yale School of Medicine. Dr. Weir is a Madison resident as are the dog and owner teams, except for Ms. King who lives in New Haven. In developing the veterinary protocol Dr. Weir talked with colleagues involved in similar programs. An epidemiologist also was consulted to be certain the young patients were not exposed to unnecessary health problems as a result of bringing in animals, and to determine how to screen patients who could not see the animals for medical reasons. "The dogs have to go through two types of testing," Dr. Weir said. "They have to have passed the Kennel Club Canine Good Citizen's test, which is just to show the dog is well-mannered and will tolerate a certain amount of stress, like hair pulling. They also have a behavioral and physical exam by a vet, for health reasons." The physical exams are rigorous and are repeated every six months to be sure the dogs are not harboring organisms that put the patients at risk. In addition, the dogs, particularly the long-haired golden retrievers who love their daily swim in Long Island Sound, must be arduously groomed and scrutinized for fleas and ticks before each hospital visit. Why are dogs so quick to touch the hearts of children who are otherwise unresponsive? "Animals are not threatening," explained Ms. Kaplan. "When children come here, unfortunately, they may perceive humans as doing all sorts of poking and examining, but they know the animal is only coming to give them love. They feel the hair, the sense of tranquillity. It also may be that the child misses a pet at home." She recalled the experience of one young patient in the psychiatric inpatient children's unit. "He had a serious, aggressive behavior problem and wanted nothing to do with the dog. But once he sat down with the dog, the change was instantaneous. He even insisted on giving it his own stuffed animal. The rest of the day and the next morning, his behavior was perfect." The staff later learned that the boy's own dog had been shot in a housing complex as he watched. If there is any problem with the trial program, it is that there are not more dogs. Everyone wants the visitors. "Once while we were going up to the unit with one of the dogs, we ran into a lady here in the hallway," Ms. Kaplan recalled. "She insisted we come up to see her son. But he was in the adult unit and we didn't have permission. This young man was hooked into a heart monitor and his mother went upstairs, got permission to unhook him, and the next thing we knew, he was down here." Ms. McCullough noted that nurses in neonatal unit staff have requested that the dogs visit to relieve stress there. "We hope we can meet these special needs and recruit more dogs once the year's trial is over," she said. Meanwhile, her wish for the program is "For children to say their strongest memory of the hospital was that, 'A dog came to visit me.' Then I'll know we've been a success."

title: Corrections
description: An article last week about the renovation of the Metropolitan Life building at 11 Madison Avenue and its effect on Madison Square Park misstated the source of $650,000 for work on the park. It was not part of the state budget. Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, set aside $500,000, and Councilman Thomas K. Duane set aside $150,000.

description: The music stopped at Augie's, a popular Upper West Side jazz club, early in the morning on July 8, at approximately 3:05. That is the time that a wall clock stopped inside the club, a funky little neighborhood haunt at 2751 Broadway near 105th Street that was known for its cheap beer and free music.

title: HORSE RACING: NOTEBOOK;4th Straight Victory For Fast Capote Belle
description: She is named Capote Belle, and she is a 3-year-old filly who missed all of last year with a stress fracture of the leg before she finally got to the races two months ago and started to win. And today at Saratoga, she won for the fourth straight time with her fastest and classiest performance yet, capturing the Test Stakes by more than two lengths and matching the record time for the race in its 71st running.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LAST LOOK;A Window of Opportunity Closes for Chowder on the Run
description: It was the last call for Eddie Argueta, a regular for the last 16 years at the takeout window of the Oyster Bar in Grand Central Terminal. He finished his New England clam chowder and shrimp cocktail around 5:40 P.M. the other Friday. As usual, he let Carlos Arenas, who has worked the window the last three years, surprise him with dessert, this time coffee sorbet. "Like frozen cappuccino," said Mr. Argueta, a manager of the Sentry Parking garage two flights up at the Met Life building. "This is the best," he said of the takeout window. "This is, let's say, 'Cheers.' "

title: RECORDINGS VIEW;Can Rap Move Beyond Gangstas?
description: Bit by bit, blustering all the way, hiphop is moving toward the post-gangsta era. Gangsta rap has been a windfall; it has sold millions of albums and reached an audience that couldn't care less about police brutality in the ghetto but responds to the music's macho swagger and blunt anger. Gangsta fans remain one of the most dependable cults in popular music, flocking to buy new albums the moment they're released. The latest beneficiary is Nas, a New York rapper whose second album, "It Was Written" (Columbia), zoomed to No. 1 when it was released earlier this month.

title: Paul Lammers, Theater and TV Director, 74
description: Paul Lammers, a theater and television director, died on July 16 at his home in Washington, Conn. He was 74.

title: MUSIC;Summer Jazz From Young Artists
description: THE Young Artists Philharmonic, directed by Sal Princiotti, and the Stamford Center for the Arts have joined forces in sponsoring a summer jazz workshop under the direction of the saxophonist John Mastroianni. And, beginning tomorrow, young musicians will be attending master classes with prominent faculty and guest artists as well as taking lessons in theory, improvisation, arranging and performance. The culmination of all this intensive work will be a concert on Aug. 9 for which reservations are required (325-4466).

title: Anything for a Smile
description: YOUNG Brandon Weiss is dressed like an adult in his striped red, white and blue Polo shirt, designer blue jean shorts and Docksiders, but he behaves like a typical 2-year-old. This Thursday afternoon he is having his portrait taken for the first time and is clearly uninterested. He runs through the trees, fills his pockets with rocks, beats the air with a stick and leaves his chair a dozen times -- everything except look at the camera. All the while a photographer, Kate Burton, is right behind him.

title: Mountain Time
description: David Moore, who was leading the hike up Pyramid Mountain on a crystal summer day, stopped at a clearing, climbed onto a rock and admired the view. It was something to brag about, all right. Below was a summer camp surrounded by tidy squares of farmland. To the right, the dappled waters of Deer Lake. And in the distance, green ridges undulating all the way to the Manhattan skyline.

title: ON THE STREET;Clean Sweep In Men's Style
description: A clean cut, a shave and a smile are back. Change in men's style often starts with the length and cut of hair. A new look called the freestyle was observed last week on young models at the New York men's-wear shows for spring 1997. The hair is cut to expose the ears and a bit of the neck above the shirt collar.

title: Editorial Notebook;Signs of Bad Times

Commuters sprinting by ticket windows glance reflexively upward at a vast empty space that until recently was occupied by a big board that posted arrivals, departures, track numbers and destinations, all in legible white letters on rotating black shutters.

title: Sports of The Times;Forty Years Later, Larsen Still Delights in His Perfection and His Luck
description: IT was a pleasant fall day nearly 40 years ago. Nothing, it seemed, out of the ordinary. A weekday afternoon, Oct. 8, with leaves turning on the Chicago streets. My father had picked me up from high school and we were headed to a factory outlet in regard to some business. As I got into the car, he had the radio on. It was the fifth game of the World Series between the Yankees and Dodgers at Yankee Stadium.

title: National Parks: Nature's Dead End
description: At the south edge of this little town, just across from the Yankee Jim Trading Post and the Bear Country Restaurant, stands a massive stone arch marking the north entrance of Yellowstone National Park. The cement plaque reads, "Created by Act of Congress March 1, 1872," testimony to the fact that here beyond lies a piece of demarcated terrain, 2.2 million acres of woodland and meadows and geyser basins, holding special status: the world's first national park. Almost 125 years later, it's still the most treasured square of more or less natural landscape on the continent, visited by several million tourists every summer.

title: N.Y.U. Fined In Animal Research
description: Although "In the Maelstrom of Animal Medical Studies" [July 7] reports that the Department of Agriculture cleared N.Y.U. of retaliation against Dr. Jan Moor-Jankowski, two incidents discredit that. On June 28 the Agriculture Department fined N.Y.U. a record $450,000 for egregious violations of the Federal Animal Welfare Act. The fine, by far the largest in the history of the Agriculture Department, upheld the allegations Dr. Moor-Jankowski had made as a whistle-blower. Last week the Agriculture Department released its investigative report on the case. It listed 15 separate instances of retaliation and concluded that the N.Y.U. Medical Center "did in fact bring reprisals" against Dr. Moor-Jankowski for reporting violations of the Animal Welfare Act. Yet somewhere in the agency's hierarchy, Dr. Moor-Jankowski's retaliation case was killed. An official, Terry Medley, readily acknowledges that "politics" prevented his department from upholding the law.

description: By 1 P.M., all 350 spaces in the parking lot were filled, and the cars were still coming. A park staff worker was directing traffic. "There are too many people," he said, shaking his head.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MADISON SQUARE;Plan to Tame Wild Asphalt To 7 Lanes
description: Broadway, Manhattan's crooked spine, is an urban planner's worst nightmare, foiling the city's near-perfect grid system. As this former cow path runs diagonally up the island, hopelessly tangled intersections like Herald Square, Union Square and Columbus Circle are left in its wake. And at Madison Square, woe to the hapless pedestrian who tries crossing Broadway at 23d Street in a single bound. Stretching 180 feet from curb to curb, the intersection along the north side of 23d Street is three times the normal width of an avenue, and many of those who insist on crossing without pause end up dodging a sea of oncoming cars. In just one two-year period -- from 1993 to 1995 -- at least 91 accidents involving cars, pedestrians and bicycles occurred at Madison Square, where Fifth Avenue, Broadway and four crosstown streets spill into one another.

Person discusses how and why people fantasize, the advantages of daydreams, how one's fantasy life affects their personal and professional goals, the ways that fantasies enrich lives and how fantasies influence relationships. Dr. Person is a professor of clinical psychiatry at the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University, and she has a private psychiatric practice in Manhattan. She is a graduate of the New York University College of Medicine, and from 1981 to 1991 she was the director of the Columbia University Center for Psychoanalytic Training and Research.

title: Foreign Affairs;The Learning Curve

It was the sound of breaking glass, simulating the sound of a terrorist incident, followed by old news footage of Yasir Arafat and Shimon Peres walking hand-in-hand. I don't think we'll be seeing that commercial anymore. Last week, Israel's Foreign Minister, David Levy, went to Gaza and warmly shook hands with Mr. Arafat on behalf of Benjamin Netanyahu's new Government. As Israeli commentators noted the next day, "There was no sound of broken glass."

title: LITTLE LEAGUE BASEBALL;Little League Playoffs Make Rare Sight in Manhattan
description: It has never happened here before, and when or if it will happen here again, no one is sure. But one thing is certain: Just about everyone involved in this year's New York State Little League Championships hopes that playing the tournament in Manhattan is the start of a new tradition.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;Legal Aid Agencies Have a New Cause, Their Own Survival
description: South Brooklyn Legal Services has always had a weighty roster of class-action lawsuits on behalf of the city's poor. Among those it has won are a case for women with AIDS who had been denied disability benefits, and another for special-education students who had not been properly screened. Those days are over. Squeezed by Federal financing cuts and a new law that bars its lawyers from pursuing class-action suits, South Brooklyn Legal Services has lost half of its staff through layoffs and attrition over the last year, and must farm out about 30 pending class-action cases to private lawyers and other organizations. Under the budget passed by Congress and signed by President Clinton in April, legal services agencies nationwide, which are financed with Federal, state and private contributions, are required to dispose of class-action suits by the end of this month. Republican critics in Congress had asserted that Legal Services lawyers filed suits to advance their political agenda rather than serve the poor. Congress also cut Federal financing for the Legal Services Corporation, which distributes money to Legal Services of New York and more than 300 other agencies nationwide, by 30.5 percent, to $278 million from $400 million. Citywide, Legal Services agencies, which represent the poor in civil court, lost 20 percent of their staff members since last year, according to the Legal Services Staff Association. But South Brooklyn -- one of the city's largest with a staff of 50 last year -- has been among the hardest hit, in part because its lawyers have historically clocked dozens of hours each week on class-action suits against city, state and Federal agencies. Fees generated from successful suits accounted for about 10 percent of its annual budget, the agency's director, Chip Gray, said. "It was a significant part of our work and now it's going to be gone," he said. "It doesn't keep us from representing individual clients. But in terms of protecting the rights of poor people as a group, we are somewhat less capable than we were in the past." A Fordham University law professor, Matthew Dillard, said the bar on class-action suits had eviscerated the power of Legal Services to challenge government policies and hindered poor people's access to the courts. "If you can't have class action, lawyers have to work retail, rather than wholesale," said Professor Dillard, a former staff lawyer for the Legal Aid Society of New York, which no longer receives Legal Services money. "The class action was one way of bringing legal services to people so they could be served indirectly, if not directly." The Federal cuts have rippled across the Legal Services system throughout the city. The Legal Services Corporation was forced to drop out of its 20-year-old case against the city charging racial quotas favoring the Hasidim in public housing in Williamsburg, according to its director, Martin Needelman. He said the Puerto Rican Legal Defense Fund, which had been involved in the case, will take it over. Mr. Needelman said his agency also lost about 10 percent of its staff. Bronx Legal Services handed off more than a dozen class-action suits and lost 10 of its 60 staff members. In Manhattan, MFY Legal Services consolidated its five offices into three, according to its director, Wayne Hawley. SOMINI SENGUPTA

title: Concourse's Open-Shut Case

Since 1991, Borough President Fernando Ferrer of the Bronx has ordered the four center lanes of the Grand Concourse closed to cars on Sunday afternoons in the summer. But this year, the Mayor demanded that the Borough President apply for a street activity permit before opening the street for public use like bicycle riding and volleyball games.

My 10-year-old son and I had come in hopes of finding my eyeglasses, which had fallen out of a canvas bag at the concert and fireworks the night before. The profusion seemed promising.

He finished his New England clam chowder and shrimp cocktail around 5:40 P.M. the other Friday. As usual, he let Carlos Arenas, who has worked the window the last three years, surprise him with dessert, this time coffee sorbet.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;The Wait Ends for Creekmur and Friends
description: Joe Gibbs had to wait. He went 0-5 in his first five games as a coach before eventually winning three Super Bowl titles. Charlie Joiner, Mel Renfro and Dan Dierdorf had to wait. All three overcame early setbacks in their pro football careers to reach the fabled steps here at the Pro Football Hall of Fame. But Lou Creekmur had to wait the longest.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Club-Hopping Frenchman Now Jumps to a Bistro Beat

title: Cunningham, Cage and a Circle of Completion
description: EARLY ONE EVENING IN April, Heidi Schweiker, a 20-year-old dance student sporting pink hair and a turquoise nose stud, stood near the front of a line of about 2,000 people who were waiting for the American premiere of "Ocean," the final project of a half-century of collaboration between the choreographer Merce Cunningham and the composer John Cage. Ms. Schweiker confessed that she had never seen a live Cunningham show before, just "lots of videos," but she felt she was present at a historic moment.

title: Smoking or No
description: To the Editor: The reports on smoking show clearly the influence of pressure from antismoking propagandists of America, seeking to impose their puritanical standards on other countries. Thank our former Surgeon General Koop and the Environmental Protection Agency, who are trying to brainwash not only us, but also the rest of the world.

title: RECYCLING IS GARBAGE
description: In "Recycling Is Garbage" (June 30), John Tierney describes the ill-fated 1987 voyage of the garbage barge Mobro 4000 as instigating some kind of needless national guilt trip that had the "strange effect on America" of making its citizens "obsessed with personally handling their own waste."

title: July 21-27;Pardon Us
description: The truth about what really happened during South Africa's apartheid years might never be told if those who committed the atrocities were not given amnesty. That was the conclusion of South Africa's top court last week, when it put the final mark of approval on the country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission.

title: Women's Weekend, in Dance and Song
description: TWO vibrant women will take the stage this weekend in Prospect Park: the dancer-choreographer Amy Pivar on Friday night and the pop singer Nona Hendryx on Saturday. The performances are part of the Celebrate Brooklyn Festival.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;Rub a Boombox, and Shaq Fans Get Their Wish
description: Multiplicity Four Michael Keatons, Andie MacDowell Directed by Harold Ramis PG-13 117 minutes

title: A Storm Surge of Terror
description: Olympic officials and the Atlanta host committee made the correct decision in going ahead with the Games yesterday. The fact that they announced the decision promptly does not indicate they made it casually. They consulted with the White House and Federal law enforcement officials before dawn. As a result, most Americans awakened to receive simultaneously the news of the attack at Centennial Olympic Park and the announcement that the events scheduled for yesterday would continue.

title: A Pink Couch, Reincarnated
description: If furniture could talk, one wonders what a pink leather couch would say of its downward trajectory from centerpiece of a scandal in the Dinkins administration to obscurity in a tidy recreation room of a Greenpoint public housing project.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Rockies Demote Nied to Class A
description: DAVID NIED, the Colorado Rockies' first-ever draft pick in 1992, was demoted Friday from Colorado Springs to Class A Salem, N.C., of the Carolina League. Nied, often injured after starting the first game in franchise history in 1993, was shelled in his last start for Colorado Springs, the Rockies' Class AAA farm club. In an 11-10 home loss to Vancouver, Nied lasted just three and one-third innings, allowing seven runs on nine hits. He walked two batters and struck out two. He pitched behind in the count to 12 of the 20 batters he faced. Nied was 17-16 with a 4.87 e.r.a. in parts of three seasons for Colorado.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- TRACK AND FIELD;A Concerned Husband Ends His Wife's Quest
description: For the last few weeks, indeed for the most of his tenure as Jackie Joyner-Kersee's coach, Bob Kersee has waged a battle between being a taskmaster and a caring husband.

title: When Working With Plastic Pipe
description: IN the early days of American plumbing, pipes were made of lead sheets hammered into shape around a pole. Back then lead was usually called by the Latin name ''plumbum,'' and the pipes were ''plumbing.'' The term ''plumbing'' is still with us, but the lead pipes have been replaced by galvanized steel, brass, copper or plastic pipes.

title: Picture From An Institution
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer Jazz From Young Artists
description: THE Young Artists Philharmonic, directed by Sal Princiotti, and the Stamford Center for the Arts have joined forces in sponsoring a summer jazz workshop under the direction of the saxophonist John Mastroianni.

title: Dissident Monk Said to Die in Prison in Chinese-Controlled Tibet
description: A leading dissident monk died this month in a prison in Tibet, where the Chinese authorities are carrying out a campaign for tighter political control, international human rights groups reported late Friday.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: How Her Garden Grows IF Eunice Juckett Meeker says, "Leave it in the mailbox," you had better ask which one. Her house in the Village of East Hampton has 3 mailboxes by the front door and one out by the road. But that is just the beginning. The backyard has 52 more mailboxes. Interspersed among flora and fauna are mail holders of every shape and design, including a White House mailbox and a dragon mailbox. They all sit on posts, making it appear as if they sprouted. Mrs. Meeker has created a mailbox garden. It's not that she doesn't trust the postal service. "It's just that I've always been interested in mailboxes," she said. "I'm writing a book on the human side of mail delivery." At 81, Mrs. Meeker is writing on many subjects, she said, including traveling. She has been around the world six times. It was on her travels that she started taking pictures of mailboxes. It seemed a logical step to start collecting the boxes, she said. Some that she collected she had created. Others she ordered. And some were sent to her, like the Anheuser-Busch mailbox and the Big Apple mailbox. "I did so much writing about New York City," she said, "they sent me a big red apple." She stuck it on top of a mailbox. It's incredible how many items she has transformed into mail holders. Last summer she placed them all in her backyard, making it resemble a miniature golf course. Not that it is rinky dink, but there is that wonder of not knowing what you are going to see around the next bend. Each mailbox has landscaping surrounding it and a path that winds in front of it. Some boxes cause "Ooohs!" when first seen, like the fire-engine-red box with a tiny Dalmatian perched on the seat. "Oh, I have a Dalmatian mailbox, too," Mrs. Meeker said, heading down another path. And there was the whole Dalmatian. The head was the mailbox. The post had been expanded into four legs and a body. There are lighthouses, windmills and a covered-wagon mailbox. Then there is the Santa Claus mailbox. "A man in Massachusetts," Mrs. Meeker recalled, "advertised that he had a Santa in a sleigh that you could put on a mantle. I thought I can put him on a mailbox." She has animal mailboxes and a stable mailbox, complete with 12 horses. It wasn't easy finding horses the size of a mailbox, she said. Plus there are the people mailboxes, including Uncle Sam and a horseback rider. Those were created by a woman, Mrs. Meeker said, "who likes to add legs and a person to a mailbox." Mrs. Meeker allows others to view her garden. "I had my garden club over last week," she said. The public is invited, as well. "But they must call me first," she said. The number is 324-0645."This is not a commercial venture. This is a big part of my life." There are mailboxes that her husband, John, created, mailboxes that her yard worker, Miquel Garcia, created, and many that were handcrafted by Peter Reichart of Springs. "He's a retired woodworker," she said. "I tell him what I want, and he creates it." The garden has an early variety, a 1903 model, that Mrs. Meeker bought out West. "Do you know when rural delivery started?" she asked. "It was 1896. Do you know where it started? West Virginia." If there was a mailbox category on "Jeopardy!" Mrs. Meeker would sweep it. From other countries come the Bali box and the Irish box, on top of which Mrs. Meeker put a leprechaun inside an overturned Mountain Dew bottle. (Well, it is green.) So many wonderful mailboxes, but none are in use at the road. "Oh, you wouldn't dare put a good one out there," Mrs. Meeker said. In the Hamptons? In the summer? "It wouldn't last a minute," she said.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- DIVING;Clark's Comeback Ends With A Bronze
description: One won her first world title at 12 and her first Olympic gold medal at 13. The other did not compete in her first Olympics until the grand old age of 29.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CLINTON HILL/FORT GREENE;Away From the City's Gay Center, a Place for Minorities
description: The opening of the Audre Lorde Project is perhaps as important for what it is not as for what it is. It is the city's only gay and lesbian center devoted to minority New Yorkers. It is not in Chelsea or Greenwich Village. It is housed atop a 130-year-old Presbyterian church in Fort Greene. In some ways, it is not surprising that such a center could sprout amid a forest of brownstones in Brooklyn's black cultural mecca. "So many lesbian and gay services are concentrated in Chelsea and the Village," said the center's administrator, Joo-Hyun Kang, of East Flatbush, "and that's not where most queer people of color live."

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;At New Globe, the Play's Not the Only Thing
description: IF William Shakespeare were somehow to sail through the past 380 years and plop down on London's South Bank, one busy bit of turf would make him feel right at home. Seeing the pit for the "groundlings," the white "sandwich" walls of lath and lime plaster, and the thatched roof of Norfolk reed, he would know instantly that he was back inside his beloved "wooden O," the Globe Theater.

title: Smoking or No
description: To the Editor: Your articles suggested that it was difficult, if not impossible, to find a smoking section on a trans-Atlantic flight.

title: The Asteroids Are Coming! The Asteroids Are Coming!
description: Look how beautiful he is!"

title: Running From The World
description: Ben Johnson is a lonely man. Now more than ever. Always with him, not far behind those protruding eyes, not far beneath his often defiant demeanor, are the harsh judgments and sustained mockery of those how condemn him for testing positive for steroids after he won the 100-meter dash in a record-shattering time of 9.79 seconds at the 1988 Olympics in Seoul.

title: City Seeking Decorator'
description: To the Editor: With all the current hue and cry over the malling of SoHo, it seems strange that no one appears to find the proposed standardization of so-called "street furniture" equally esthetically distressing ("City Seeking an Exterior Decorator," June 2).

title: POLITICS 1996;Christie Whitman Had a Farm
description: GROWING UP REPUBLICAN

title: WEDDINGS;Jonathan Mauer and Jennifer Fron
description: Jennifer Anne Fron, the daughter of Mrs. Casey Michael John Fron of Wilton, Conn., and the late Mr. Fron, was married yesterday to Jonathan Scott Mauer, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence Mauer of Wilton. The Rev. Dudne M. Breeze performed the ceremony at the Wilton Congregational Church.

title: Aliki Vouyouklaki, A Film Actress, 63
description: Aliki Vouyouklaki, a film actress who was the darling of towns and villages throughout Greece and who never seemed to age over a career that spanned more than four decades, died of cancer on Tuesday at the Athens Medical Center. She was 63.

title: After Mr. Mandela
description: Few leaders in recent history have forged a popular sainthood as durable as Nelson Mandela's. The veneration the South African President received on his trip to Britain and France early this month inspired one cartoonist to portray him walking across the English Channel. More important, two years after his election, Mr. Mandela retains the trust and support of his people. South Africa's transition has been astonishingly smooth, largely due to Mr. Mandela's commitment to democracy and reconciliation.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;Quality of Life? Not for Homeless, Advocates Say
description: A fresh crackdown by the New York City Police Department on so-called quality-of- life crimes in Manhattan has prompted concern among advocates who say the move is aimed at homeless people. The crackdown, described in an unpublished, internal Police Department memo, as "a major initiative aimed at achieving additional improvements in quality-of-life conditions in the midtown area," began last week. Offenses like peddling, panhandling and prostitution are priorities, along with squeegee wielding, open consumption of alcohol, public urination and ticket scalping, the memo says. It specifies the area between 30th and 59th Streets, from river to river, although advocates for the homeless say the scope has widened to include everything below 110th Street.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Surprise in Heartland

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LINCOLN CENTER;Orchestra's Green Thumbs Make Beautiful Veggies Together
description: Corn and tomatoes, brussels sprouts and string beans, cucumbers and green peppers? On top of Lincoln Center? Ever since Avery Fisher Hall got a new roof a few years ago, Barbara Haws, the archivist of the New York Philharmonic and an emigre from Nebraska, had glumly looked out on it from the orchestra's executive offices and decided in May that it needed a garden. The Philharmonic's executive staff agreed, and the project got the green light and seed money -- pun intended.

title: The Nation;America's Quiet Rebellion Against McDonaldization
description: AS millions of tourists flocked here for the Centennial Olympics this summer, many expected to find Tara and Scarlett and Rhett.

title: For Some Directors, the Web Is Their Studio
description: ONE WITNESS CALLS IT "KIDS with Quickcams and Power books, doing their guerrilla thing." The time was February 1995, and the scene was the Sundance Film Festival in Park City, Utah. Around town, a cadre of electronics-toting young people poked about, gathering information for posting on an Internet site called Festival.

title: WEDDINGS;Gordon Witkin, Stacy J. Ettinger
description: Stacy Joy Ettinger, the daughter of Sheila and Jerry Ettinger of Raleigh, N.C., is to be married today to Gordon Witkin, a son of Kate and Richard Witkin of Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Eric Polokoff is to perform the ceremony at the bridegroom's parents' summer house in Bridgewater, Conn.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 7 about bed-and-breakfast establishments in France misspelled the name of a cave in the Dordogne that houses prehistoric paintings. It is Font de Gaume, not Font de Baume.

title: Democrats See Double Over Politics
description: Gone are the days when the city's bountiful political clubs provided the faithful with jobs, English lessons and turkeys on Christmas Day. Patronage has all but dried up and community boards have largely usurped the clubs' role as ombudsman between government and the grassroots. Apathy and political cynicism have taken their toll; there are fewer than 150 clubhouses in the city, down from more than 1,000 before World War II.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: THE SPECTATORS;Grim Reality Doesn't Scare Most Fans From the Games
description: Kathleen Olivieri peered over at her 2-year-old daughter on a plastic tether and then looked up with an expression that mixed defiance and resignation at this morning's track and field events at the shiny new Centennial Olympic Stadium.

title: Stock in the Team
description: To the Editor:

title: WEDDINGS;Suzanne De Vito, Miles Cary 3d
description: Suzanne Elizabeth De Vito, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carmine De Vito of Malverne, L.I., was married yesterday to Miles Cary 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cary Jr. of Richmond. The Rev. Joseph H. Hanks performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Old Saybrook, Conn.

title: Blithe Spirit
description: BECOMING MODERN

title: WEDDINGS;Mishaela Rubin, Jeffrey Rubenstein
description: Dr. Mishaela Ruth Rubin, a resident in internal medicine at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, is to be married today to Dr. Jeffrey Lawrence Rubenstein, an assistant professor of Hebrew and Judaic studies at New York University. Prof. David Weiss-Halivni, a rabbi and a professor of religion at Columbia University, is to perform the ceremony at the Radisson Hotel at Newark International Airport.

title: The View From: Croton-on-Hudson;Plunging Into Memory, Flowing Into Time
description: WHEN the river rises, Bill McGowan runs to it. He travels from his home in Brooklyn Heights to the home here where he grew up, from his life as a successful author to his life as a child, from the glass and steel of the city to the rushing water and ancient rocks of the Croton River.

title: Man Escapes Arson Charge in Fire He Set
description: A man whom neighbors called a hero for burning down an unoccupied crack house in his neighborhood has been cleared of arson, though he was convicted of four lesser charges.

title: Jaywalking Law Is Ignored And the Toll Is Staggering
description: To the Editor:

title: MILLENNIUM MUSIC;Here's an Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: Wooing The Women
description: In the small world of political pollsters, the word is out that Linda DiVall is sick, sick, sick of talking about the gender gap. "I may have said that," admitted DiVall, a prominent polling expert and now a senior adviser to the Dole campaign. She's giving a slightly cranky phone interview -- it is, she claims, the first of 26 calls she's supposed to return from reporters who've called to ask why women seem to be abandoning the Republican Party in droves. "As I already told you," she says, sighing in the manner of a teacher who has drilled the same lesson over and over to stubbornly dimwitted pupils, "yes, there is a gender gap. Yes, it is significant. But it can be closed."

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: MILITIA;Investigators Reviewing Previous Bomb Case
description: Federal agents investigating today's bombing at the Centennial Olympic Park are taking another look at a case in which two men linked to paramilitary groups were arrested near here on April 26 on charges of making pipe bombs and conducting test explosions of the devices.

title: EVENING HOURS;Carnival Fantasies Uptown And Down
description: Fireworks (real ones) at Lincoln Center, a new Patricia Field store and a museum benefit.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Dent Moves From Bears to Colts
description: RICHARD DENT agreed to a one-year contract with Indianapolis on Friday, reuniting the former Chicago Bears defensive lineman with the Colts' director of football operations, BILL TOBIN, who was in Chicago's front office from 1975-93. Dent, the most valuable player in the 1986 Super Bowl, is attempting a comeback after being out of football for most of last season. The 35-year-old Dent had a franchise-record 124 1/2 sacks for Chicago. (AP)

title: The World;For Europeans, Cuba Hasn't Lost Its Magic
description: EUROPE and the United States are clearly at odds over Cuba. The new Helms-Burton law, which could allow American courts to punish foreign companies that "traffic" in property confiscated from Americans, could yet provoke a serious crisis between America and some of its principal allies. In a sense, the issue isn't so much Cuba as the extent to which one country can force others to comply with its own legislation. But the quarrel reveals something deeper -- the different perspectives in which the United States and Europe view Cuba itself.

title: Designs From the Dutch That Prompt a Smile
description: Today's designers of furnishings are thumbing their noses at some traditions and embracing others, finding fresh ways of merging high and low technologies. A plastic sack is filled with soil to become a flowerpot; broken bits of pottery are recycled as bowls, and space-age fibers are woven into a hammocklike chair and stiffened with epoxy.

title: Champagne
description: Blanc de blanc, Pugliese Vineyards, Cutchogue, 1992. (Paper label, $14; hand-painted bottle, $22.)

title: DINING OUT;Tradition, Venetian Style, in Mount Kisco
description: THIS venerable Victorian has undergone another major renovation, and before we get to the chef, praise is in order for the designer. The glassed-in ground floor has been deconstructed and the space rendered fluid. Tables seem to spill out to the patio. Winged lions flank the bar, perhaps to remind diners of those on the facade of San Marco in Venice. And perhaps the name of this restaurant (similar to many in Venice) suggests that Cafe Antico is also following the trend in Venice today of returning to the old traditions, Waverley Root informs us, of carefully executed, highly varied cuisine. If so, this Cafe Antico in Mount Kisco is right on track.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN;Rub a Boombox, and Shaq Fans Get Their Wish
description: Fled Laurence Fishburne, Stephen Baldwin, Will Patton, Robert John Burke Directed by Kevin Hooks R 105 minutes

title: ON A BUDGET;Accessible Broadway: The Cheap Seats
description: Tickets to Broadway shows may cost more than $65 apiece these days, but reduced-price tickets for many shows are available at the two TKTS booths -- the main one in Duffy Square at 47th Street and Broadway, and a satellite at 2 World Trade Center. Tickets for selected shows are sold at Duffy Square beginning at 3 P.M. on the day of performance for evening shows and at 10 A.M. for Wednesday and Saturday matinees, noon for matinees on Sunday. The World Trade Center booth opens at 11 A.M. and also sells matinee tickets for the next day. Tickets cost either 50 percent or 75 percent of box-office prices, determined by the producers, plus a $2.50 service charge per ticket. Only cash and traveler's checks are accepted. Information: (212) 768-1818.

title: Bill Kurtis: Anchor, Producer, Idea Man
description: AFTER Bill Kurtis quit as anchor of ''The CBS Morning News'' in 1985, discouraged by the nonjournalistic track the program was taking, he all but disappeared from national screens. ''I wanted to climb the mountain,'' he says now, ''but the mountain had changed.''

title: HOME CLINIC;When Working With Plastic Pipe
description: IN the early days of American plumbing, pipes were made of lead sheets hammered into shape around a pole. Back then lead was usually called by the Latin name "plumbum," and the pipes were "plumbing." The term "plumbing" is still with us, but the lead pipes have been replaced by galvanized steel, brass, copper or plastic pipes.

title: No Headline
description: I was like, 'That's a bomb,' and nobody believed me. Then a piece of metal came down and hit my leg."

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOHO;Authenticity First, or Trees?
description: If you were to engage in a game of Franco-American word association in this city, chances are "plein air" would not be linked with SoHo. But starting in October, the city will plant 39 trees around the historic cast-iron district, under a ruling last week by the Landmarks Preservation Commission that reversed its earlier anti-tree position. Because SoHo in its 19th-century inception was an all-but-treeless zone of factories and warehouses, the commission in 1994 took the view that it would be historically incorrect to plant trees. But neighborhood residents have argued that trees are necessary to combat the pollutants released by trucks traveling through.

title: PERSPECTIVES;From a Laundry to a Perfume Factory to a Church
description: THE Art Moderne industrial building in Long Island City, Queens, that once served as the Knickerbocker Laundry plant is a familiar sight to commuters on the Long Island Rail Road. Katherine Petrin calls it "stunning."

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- BOXING;A Long Wait Does Nothing To Help the U.S. Captain
description: Lawrence Clay-Bey had to wait impatiently for his Olympics to begin. Because of the bye he drew in the first round of the superheavyweight division, the captain of the United States boxing team watched his teammates for seven days before he had a chance to contribute to their modest success.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- ROUNDUP;CYCLING: France Adds 2 Titles
description: France completed an Olympic triple at Stone Mountain, Ga., adding the women's sprint and men's team pursuit to the kilometer title won by Florian Rousseau on opening day.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- TENNIS;Focusing Only on Court, Seles Trounces Sabatini
description: Just when these Olympic Games were restoring some sense of innocence to Monica Seles and her outlook on life, experience interfered.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASEBALL;Puckett Tribute Proving a Popular Ticket
description: The tribute for KIRBY PUCKETT scheduled for Sept. 7 in Minneapolis is proving so popular that the Minnesota Twins will remove the outfield curtain in the upper deck to increase the Metrodome's capacity back to about 55,000. More than 40,000 tickets already have been sold for the game against the California Angels. Puckett, forced to retire July 12 because of irreversible retina damage, will address the crowd during a pre-game ceremony. The largest crowd ever to see a baseball game at the Metrodome was 55,376 during the 1987 World Series. The curtain, installed at the start of this season, covers about 10,000 seats. (AP)

title: STAGE VIEW;Theater for the Free Mind And the Strong Stomach
description: WHAT? NOT THOSE OLD CLICHES about the grimness and obscurity of Samuel Beckett all over again.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS;Heart Ailment Kills War Survivor in Altanta
description: Melih Uzunyol, who died in the Atlanta bombing today, was the chief cameraman of the state-owned Turkish Television. He had survived coverage of wars in Azerbaijan, Bosnia and the Persian Gulf but finally fell victim not to bullets, but to a weak heart, colleagues said today.

title: How Hot It Isn't: A Record-Breaking Cool
description: This July has had just about everything New Yorkers have come to expect in midsummer. There have been busloads of tourists, Lollapalooza at Randalls Island and Shakespeare in the Park. The Yankees are in first place and the Mets are, well, promising. And yes, the air has been muggy and full of curious smells.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- ROUNDUP;YACHTING: Some Races Put Off
description: Because of light winds off Savannah, Ga., the men's and women's Mistral classes had to postpone their races, while the Stars and Finns each sailed one of two scheduled races. Spain's 1994 world champions, Fernando Leon and Jose Ballester, moved into first by 4 points in the Tornado fleet, while the Americans Jeff Madrigali, Jim Barton and Kent Massey broke their tie with Germany to take the top spot in the Soling fleet. In the women's 470 division, the Americans Kris Farrar Stookey and Louise Van Voorhis were tied for first with the 1992 gold medalists, Theresa Zabell and Begona Via Dufresne of Spain. BLAIRE LARGAY

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: GREENWICH VILLAGE;Democrats See Double Over Politics
description: Gone are the days when the city's bountiful political clubs provided the faithful with jobs, English lessons and turkeys on Christmas Day. Patronage has all but dried up and community boards have largely usurped the clubs' role as ombudsman between government and the grassroots. Apathy and political cynicism have taken their toll; there are fewer than 150 clubhouses in the city, down from more than 1,000 before World War II. "They may not be dinosaurs yet but they're well on their way to becoming obsolete," said Norman Adler, a political consultant who wrote a book on the club system two decades ago.

title: Ups and Downs in Food and Presentation
description: DEJA VU in Westhampton Beach. Entering Sam's Hampton Square, a friend, who sometimes has trouble distinguishing Westhampton from West Hempstead, said ''We've been here before.''

title: Tale of Terror
description: A huge, unblinking eye fills the screen - a chilling moment before a killer strikes in THE SPIRAL STAIRCASE (1946). The victims, in a turn-of-the-century New England village, are young women with infirmities. Now he (or she) stalks a mute servant-companion (Dorothy McGuire) to a bedridden matriarch (Ethel Barrymore) in a gloomy but busy old Gothic mansion. This superb suspense puzzle, from a novel by Ethel Lina White, is Grade-A Hollywood. Under Robert Siodmak's direction, his technicians and a fine cast have spun a tingling, atmospheric tapestry and knockout whodunit. Don't call out when McGuire fumbles and drops her key in the rain - near a lurking silhouette. Hang on and hold tight - TUESDAY at 8 A.M. on MAX.

title: NEW YORKERS & CO.
description: Club-Hopping Frenchman Now Jumps to a Bistro Beat

title: INSIDE
description: IN PERSON The life and Looney Tunes times of Wilma Del Sontro. 4

title: Lost and Found, on Metro-North
description: THE lost and found at Grand Central Terminal has long been home to both the mundane and the bizarre. But the repository for things forgotten on Metro-North trains has gained a decidedly new look, as both the nature of the items and the route to their recovery has become distinctly high tech.

title: Political Briefing;THE CAMPAIGNS FOR CONGRESS
description: Wisconsin Write-In Effort For an Incumbent

title: Serbs in Pragmatic Pullout from Albanian Region
description: In 1989 the Serbian strongman, Slobodan Milosevic, swooped down in a helicopter onto the field where 600 years earlier the Turks had defeated the Serbs at the Battle of Kosovo. In a fervent speech before a million Serbs, he galvanized the nationalist passions that two years later fueled the Balkan conflict.

title: Corrections
description: The What's Doing column on page 10 of the Travel section today, about San Diego, carries an incorrect listing of vital statistics. It was prepared for another issue, about Mount Desert Island, Me. The correct listing appears in the main news section today, on page 39.

title: Cold Wet Noses That Lift The Spirits of Young Patients
description: THE patients wear pajamas decorated with dancing animals. The visitors wear fur topped by snappy red uniforms.

title: ON LANGUAGE;Breaking the Rules
description: FEW THINGS IN LIFE ARE AS SATISFYING as puncturing the inflated ego of a grammatical know-it-all. You know the type. The kind of person who wouldn't put a predicate pronoun in the objective case ("it's me") if his life depended on it, who wouldn't split an infinitive or end a sentence with a preposition if you put a gun to her head.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Hyatt Expands Option Of Electronic Check-In
description: Hyatt is increasing the number of hotels at which guests with reservations can check in using an electronic kiosk in the lobby similar to an automated teller machine.

title: Bed and Breakfasts Gaining on East End
description: IN the late 1800's, when East Hampton residents began enlarging their houses to accommodate vacationers, running bed and breakfasts became a cottage industry.

title: Smoking or No
description: To the Editor: We too, lament Betsy Wade's plight as shared in her essay "Got a Light?" (June 30) We light our older gas stove with a match each time we cook. The "house rule" has always been that only matches collected on personal travels can be used; whether they are from a Roman hotel or the local steak house -- never can they be purchased from the store.
