Our search is becoming desperate -- watch out when we do find matches in the reception area!

title: Dispatches From a War of Nerves
description: To the Editor:

title: Moldy Walls Put Tenants on Edge
description: Troy Lang is sure his apartment is killing him. Like dozens of tenants at the Henry Phipps Plaza South, a federally subsidized housing complex on Second Avenue and 26th Street, Mr. Lang, 59, says an epidemic of poisonous mold is causing the chronic fatigue and wheezing that keep him from work as an entertainer. Swelling joints make it painful to walk, and at night, he wakes up with pounding headaches. ''Until recently, I was never sick a day in my life,'' said Mr. Lang, president of the complex's tenant association.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: UPPER WEST SIDE;Free Music and Cheap Beer Couldn't Keep Jazz Haunt Going
description: The music stopped at Augie's, a popular Upper West Side jazz club, early in the morning on July 8, at approximately 3:05. That is the time that a wall clock stopped inside the club, a funky little neighborhood haunt at 2751 Broadway near 105th Street that was known for its cheap beer and free music. The story of Augie's demise is chronicled in loud, neon orange and lime posters and a newspaper clipping plastered across the windows: "Seized by the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance July 8," reads one. "Notice of Public Auction," pronounces another. The Upper West Side Resident News described the closing of Augie's as "a sad loss" to the community.

title: Doctor Faces Murder Charge in '76 Killing
description: Twenty years ago Martin T. Dillon, a 30-year-old lawyer and father of two, was shot to death while skeet shooting near here with a friend.

title: A Director in a Hurry, Creating Her Own Myth
description: GALT NIEDERHOFFER has a meeting at Fox tomorrow on a possible distribution deal for her first featurefilm, but before she left for Hollywood last week she had time to dictate, on request, an opening sentence for this story: ''Despite the disadvantages of an Upper East Side upbringing, this 20-year-old woman, crafty, quick, obsessive, hopes to effect the marriage of business and art.''

title: What Cuts Pollution Best? Carrots or Sticks?
description: Sixteen months ago, Joan Bjornson traded her management job at Hoechst Celanese, the chemical manufacturer in Bridgewater, for something more creative. She became the company's first ''trip reduction coordinator,'' encouraging other employees to car pool, bike or even walk to work instead of driving alone at rush hour.

title: THE NIGHT;Handsome, Clever And Rich
description: HER gown was showing a lot of her back, and her cascading hair was piled up in an intentionally careless style that would have caused a disturbance in Jane Austen's time.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: KATONAH EXHIBITIONS

title: WEDDINGS;MaryEllen Fogarty, Sean Donovan
description: MaryEllen Susan Fogarty, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Fogarty of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Patrick Sean Donovan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis V. Donovan of Meriden, Conn. The Rev. Donald J. Desmond performed the ceremony at Most Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in East Hampton, L.I.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WEST SIDE;Con Man Preys on Gay Samaritans
description: Smooth, Southern and down on his luck -- or so he tells people -- William Bowen, 34, has been "borrowing" cash and clothes from dozens of gay men and merchants around the West Side in recent weeks after winning their confidence and sympathy, according to the New York City Gay and Lesbian Anti-Violence Project. In fliers that it is handing out in the West Village, Chelsea, Clinton and the Upper West Side, the group says Mr. Bowen goes either by the name Billy Bowen or Steven McCormick and comes across as charming, articulate and attractive. He picks up men on the street or drops by a store or restaurant and begins spinning a story: "New to New York" or "Can't cash my check" or "My boyfriend just kicked me out." Those who believe him soon find their wallets or wardrobes a bit lighter. "He will rip you off," the fliers declare.

title: MARKET TIMING
description: Monday

title: Sunday: July 28, 1996: YOU ARE THERE;Slim Jim: Present at the Creation
description: Every year, the folks who make Slim Jim, the world's best-selling salted-beef snack, produce enough skinny product to circle the globe twice. How? you ask. Public tours of the main factory in Gardner, N.C., are not available, but officials let us in for a one-time peek.

title: STEVEN BOCHCO;And Have You Heard The One . . . ?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dispatches From a War of Nerves
description: To the Editor:

title: Recitals on City Island Continue
description: WHEN the harpsichordist Ilan Rechtman began a series of Sunday recitals on City Island in the Bronx three years ago, he developed what may be the only nonstop concert cycle in the New York City region.

title: Samuel A. Kirk, 92, Pioneer Of Special Education Field
description: Samuel A. Kirk, an immigrant homesteader's son who became so intrigued by his childhood experiences teaching illiterate farmhands to read that he went on to an acclaimed career as the father of special education, died on July 21 at his retirement home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 92.

title: Joseph F. Miller, 89, U.S. Lawyer in Wars
description: Joseph F. Miller, a lawyer, wartime Government counsel and former president of the National Electrical Manufacturing Association, died on Monday at his home in Deal, N.J. He was 89.

title: Willy Not Free, But Mending
description: ON Jan. 7 of this year thousands of people lined Highway 101 south of Newport, Ore., to welcome a 7,720-pound, 21-foot-long celebrity from Mexico City. Keiko, the 16-year-old orca whale who starred in the movie "Free Willy," arrived by U.P.S. B-130 cargo jet. He was loaded onto a flatbed truck and hauled past cheering crowds to his new home, the Oregon Coast Aquarium. Several aquariums wanted Keiko, but the Oregon Coast was chosen because it was the only one with the space to build a pool large enough to rehabilitate him for possible release into the wild -- the first such attempt ever made with a captive orca.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9;Athletes Coexist With Fear
description: Jing Jun Hong of Singapore still did not know about the bombing in Centennial Olympic Park by midafternoon when she went out to play table tennis. There are advantages to not speaking English and not turning on the television.

title: WEDDINGS;Christina Weeks, Geoffrey S. Morin
description: Christina Marianne Weeks, the daughter of Anita Hills Weeks of Penn Valley, Pa., and Christopher Weeks of Cranbury, N.J., was married yesterday to the Rev. Geoffrey Stewart Morin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph G. Morin of Greenwich, Conn. The Right Rev. Clarence Coleridge, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut, performed the ceremony at Christ Church in Greenwich.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;America as Seen Through an Array of Lenses
description: VERY different aspects of the American scene are chronicled in two photography exhibitions at the Montclair Art Museum. The pictures in "Street Engagements: Social Landscape Photography of the 60's" are urbane, gritty, often frenetic and sometimes shocking. Much more placid and pastorally ideal images go into "Laura Gilpin: Photographs of the Southwest." "Street Photography," a traveling exhibition that originated at the George Eastman House in Rochester, N.Y., focuses on what was a consciously new development in photography. Robert Sobieszek, who wrote the essay in the accompanying brochure, likens a new visual esthetic to Jack Kerouac's "loose and heated literary take on the contemporary American scene of the 1950's." The antecedents might go back even further, to the painters of the Ashcan School in the early years of this century who made commonplace urban life, with its unselfconsciously colorful characters, their subject. The photographs have an air of spontaneity, but it is obvious that formal attitudes are also at work.

title: In Canadians' Retort on Trade, Politics of the Absurd
description: They say they are speaking for 3 million Canadians whose Loyalist ancestors fled a revolutionary United States more than 200 years ago and who now want their family property back.

title: Remembering Pan Am 103;Off Long Island, Echoes From Lockerbie
description: MORNING after morning, they stood shoulder-to-shoulder in their identical dark uniforms, meticulously combing the muddy hillsides for the shredded remains of a jumbo jet.

title: Where Cooks and the British Reign
description: CAN'T afford summer air fare to London? Then take a cheap seat in the living room section for telly nights on public channel WLIW, where broad English accents are as common as fund-raising drives and the sensibility is equal parts London and Long Island.

title: Texans Look Above Clouds for Drought Relief
description: The denominations were different, but the prayers were the same. Send rain, soon.

title: Corrections
description: The cover article on July 14 about Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed misstated the location of the SoHo Grand Hotel, a 367-room project she had opposed vigorously. The hotel, to open next Sunday, is on West Broadway between Grand and Canal Streets, not at West Broadway and Houston Street.

title: Coward Double Bill At Bay Street Theater
description: IN his final theater work Sir Noel Coward's talent to amuse was darkened and deepened by his capacity to reflect.

title: WEDDINGS;Tracy Brennan, Thomas R. Lynch
description: Tracy Maria Brennan, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. C. Edward Brennan of Locust Valley, L.I., was married on Friday in Dorset, Vt., to Thomas Robert Lynch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Lynch of Buffalo. Msgr. Patrick Keleher performed the ceremony at the United Church of Dorset.

title: Authenticity First, or Trees?
description: If you were to engage in a game of Franco-American word association in this city, chances are ''plein air'' would not be linked with SoHo. But starting in October, the city will plant 39 trees around the historic cast-iron district, under a ruling last week by the Landmarks Preservation Commission that reversed its earlier anti-tree position.

title: Orchestra's Green Thumbs Make Beautiful Veggies Together
description: Corn and tomatoes, brussels sprouts and string beans, cucumbers and green peppers? On top of Lincoln Center?

title: WEDDINGS;Sara E. Rosenfeld, Kurt R. Dassel
description: Sara Ellen Rosenfeld, the exhibitions coordinator at the American Federation of Arts in New York, was married last evening to Kurt Rees Dassel, a John M. Olin Fellow at the Center for International Affairs at Harvard University. Leonard D. Cherlin, a chaplain of the Society for Humanistic Judaism, performed the ceremony at the Puck Building in New York.

title: Crew's New Strategy: Send Boards to School
description: Stymied in his effort to gain more control over New York City's 32 community school boards, Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew embarked yesterday on a different tack to change the way board members do business: he sent them back to school. Dr. Crew opened a two-day training program intended to give the board members a crash course in how to do their jobs, supervising the city's elementary and junior high schools and administering budgets of $50 million or more.

title: Our Welfare System Is Hardly a Total Failure;Democratic Imperative
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE INVESTIGATION;While Cause of Crash Is Sought, Parallel Criminal Inquiry Goes On
description: While Federal officials have yet to conclude that an act of sabotage destroyed Trans World Airlines Flight 800, an elaborate criminal investigation has been under way from the first moments after the 747 smashed into the sea on July 17.

title: WEDDINGS;Lauri Freidenburg, David K. Skelly
description: Lauri Kealoha Freidenburg, a daughter of Linda Freidenburg of Aloha, Ore., and Lee Freidenburg of Beaverton, Ore., was married yesterday to Dr. David Kiernan Skelly, the son of Barbara and Richard Skelly of Wilton, Conn. The Rev. Williams Sachs, an Episcopal minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents.

title: From Bears to Bulls and Back Again
description: WHEN David Shulman, the chief equity strategist for Salomon Brothers, announced last December that he had finally turned bullish on the stock market, it seemed as if the last bear on Wall Street had gone into hibernation. Suddenly, though, the bears are foraging everywhere.

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: SOUTH STREET SEAPORT

title: July 21-27;A Coup and More Blood in Burundi
description: Africa lost another democracy last week, amid renewed fighting between the Tutsis and the Hutus. The Tutsi-led army of Burundi overthrew the civilian Government and its Hutu President, Sylvestre Ntibantynganya. Maj. Pierre Buyoya, a European-trained Tutsi military officer who has been president once before, was named president again.

title: Samuel Beckett Gets an Irish Embrace
description: SAMUEL BECKETT SPENT most of his adult life in Paris. Indeed, when he died on Dec. 22, 1989, the novelist, poet, playwright and Nobel laureate had not visited Dublin, his birthplace, in 21 years. Occasionally, he would reminisce about walking the Dublin mountains with his father. He once asked an Irish friend if Greene's bookshop still stood on Clare Street. He never lost his taste for Irish whisky. But he felt no great yearning to return to his roots. For the relatively few Dubliners who knew his work, he was another home-grown writer who preferred somewhere else to Ireland.

title: The Executioner's Song
description: A Perfect Execution

title: MUTUAL FUNDS;When a Manager Borrows From a Fund
description: IF cocktail party chatter used to dwell on stock tips, today the talk is about mutual funds -- what manager is burning up the performance rankings, and which fund has turned cold.

title: On The Town
description: MUSIC

title: WEDDINGS;Yael Wasserman, Raphael Rosenblatt
description: Yael Meira Wasserman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett J. Wasserman of Fair Lawn, N.J., is to be married today to Raphael Mark Rosenblatt, the son of Prof. and Mrs. Jason P. Rosenblatt of Silver Spring, Md. Rabbi Gedaliah Anemer is to perform the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: Innocent Till . . .
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Get a Job;The New Contract With America's Poor
description: AS the movement to repeal welfare boiled across the Senate last week, a noteworthy chart appeared on the chamber floor. Decorated with a sketch of a creeping infant, it advertised a Democratic amendment to provide vouchers to those children -- as many as four million -- who could be dropped from government rolls if the bill becomes law.

title: All the Young Punks
description: PLEASE KILL ME

title: School Prayer Proponents Reject U.S. History
description: To the Editor:

title: Away From the City's Gay Center, a Place for Minorities
description: The opening of the Audre Lorde Project is perhaps as important for what it is not as for what it is. It is the city's only gay and lesbian center devoted to minority New Yorkers. It is not in Chelsea or Greenwich Village. It is housed atop a 130-year-old Presbyterian church in Fort Greene.

title: Habitats/79th Street and First Avenue;To an Architect, 1 Plus 1 Equals 3
description: WILLIAM M. BERNSTEIN wanted to psych out the real estate market, and he thought he had a smart way to do it.

title: POSTINGS: The Price Is $1 a Share;Realty Company Gives Employees Stock Options
description: The owners of the Coldwell Banker Hunt Kennedy real estate offices have begun handing out stock options to their employees -- sales agents and secretaries alike -- based on length of employment and sales performance, with everyone receiving at least 100 share options.

title: BACKTALK;Echoes of Munich's Olympic Nightmare
description: The early morning explosion that jolted Centennial Olympic Park produced painful reminders of another sorrowful time and place in the Olympic movement: Munich 1972.

title: Streetscapes/Lever House;Park Avenue's First Glass House to Get a Face-Lift
description: WHEN Lever House was built in 1952, the dowdy old Park Avenue buildings neighboring it seemed instantly obsolete. Now, four decades later, the typical 1920's Park Avenue apartment house is holding up pretty well, but even with careful maintenance by its original owner, Lever House needs a completely new facade -- at a cost of $7 million.

title: What Not to Drive to the Recycling Center
description: WHEN a large family gathered for a barbecue last Sunday in Westwood, Mass., the inevitable jabs were made at several smokers in the group. But rather than defending themselves, they came up with a quick and unusual riposte: their cigarettes were not nearly as bad for the environment as the Jeeps and other sport utility vehicles crawling the suburb's streets.

title: Backtalk;Running From The World
description: Ben Johnson is a lonely man. Now more than ever. Always with him, not far behind those protruding eyes, not far beneath his often defiant demeanor, are the harsh judgments and sustained mockery of those how condemn him for testing positive for steroids after he won the 100-meter dash in a record-shattering time of 9.79 seconds at the 1988 Olympics in Seoul.

title: Fee at Botanic Garden Proves a Thorn in the Side for Many
description: Last December, the Brooklyn Botanic Garden's board decided to impose an admission fee for the first time in its history to make up for a budget shortfall. Since then, community groups around the 52-acre garden have protested. Now, the politically formidable groups fighting the $3 fee are trying to divert state money away from the garden unless the fee is eliminated. Botanic Garden officials say they are confused by the protesters' rage. Like other cultural institutions, they say they had little choice but to charge admission since the city cut cultural affairs funds.

title: IN PERSON;Mrs. Great Adventure
description: WILMA DEL SONTRO was in grade school when she first ventured onto a roller coaster, lured by her father and a family friend. So jolting was the ride -- it was the Cyclone, on Coney Island -- that the friend's false teeth went flying. And young Wilma fell in love. From that moment on, she was a seeker of thrill rides, hustling anyone who was game onto machines that twisted, scrambled and twirled. She married in 1955, moved to Lakewood, Ocean County, and had eventually had eight children, but her gusto for amusement parks remained. So in 1975, when Mrs. Del Sontro's 16-year-old daughter applied for a job at Six Flags Great Adventure here, the 39-year-old mother did, too.

title: On Tour at the Cape
description: IT'S 6:15 P.M. on a stifling Tuesday in July. For two hours, I've been trying to call Louisa's, the teeny restaurant in Cape May that's as hard to get into as Fort Knox. This time, however, I'm determined.

title: In the Beginning There Was Anonymity
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR MOVIES;Waste and Glory
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Welfare System Is Hardly a Total Failure;The System Coerces
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: FINAL JEOPARDY

title: 2 Pianists at the Top of Their Mountain, and Their Profession
description: MISHA and Cipa Dichter can practically see Aspen, Colo., from the three-story tower atop their hilly property here. Aspen, a musician's paradise, is like home to the couple, who perform together every summer there amid the splendor of the Rocky Mountains.

title: CLASSICAL VIEW;The Abstract Expressionist of Music
description: Some events really are life-altering, and for Morton Feldman, the American composer whose music will be performed this week as part of the Lincoln Center Festival, meeting John Cage in 1949 at a concert in Carnegie Hall was one of them. By then Cage already knew everyone worth knowing in the arts, or at least he knew people who knew those people, and they gathered at his loft on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

title: Looking for No. 2;Try an Unknown Catholic Female Governor?
description: AROUND Bob Dole's headquarters, they are known as the "pudgy white guys": the list of obvious candidates Mr. Dole might ask to run with him in November.

title: WEDDINGS;Jennifer Falkove, Alexander Dymerets
description: Jennifer Alyse Falkove, a daughter of Lynn and Dr. Michael Falkove of East Norwich, L.I., is to be married today to Alexander Dymerets, the son of Tatiana and Naum Dymerets of Aventura, Fla. Rabbi David Nesenoff is to perform the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Locking the Tower
description: To the Editor: A postscript to Ellen Perry Berkeley's very informative article, "You Can Look, but Ask First" (June 16):

title: Pros and Cons of a Late Budget
description: WHEN Gov. George E. Pataki introduced his bare-bones budget proposal for 1996-97 back in December, state legislators pulled in their belts an extra notch and prepared for the worst.

title: GARDENING;A Little Deadheading, Some Looking Around
description: THIS is midpoint time for gardeners. The major planting has been done, with only a few touch-ups now needed. In the vegetable garden, the seeding of early fall crops should be well underway.

title: SPENDING IT;When the I.R.S. Agent Peeks Under the Mattress
description: WHEN an Internal Revenue Service agent said she wanted to audit Dave and Lucille Miller's 1993 and 1994 tax returns, the couple thought it sounded like a simple thing.

title: July 21-27;The Vietnam War Gets Longer
description: History is usually made, not legislated. But the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee voted last week to revise the date of the start of the Vietnam war.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: WHERE THE BODY MEETS MEMORY

title: POLITICS 1996;Fixers and Favors
description: PARTNERS IN POWER

title: In Farewell to Hamilton Fish Jr., Praise for Service and Integrity
description: Calling him a personal inspiration and the most trusted politician he had ever known, Gov. George E. Pataki joined scores of mourners and dignitaries today at a memorial service for Hamilton Fish Jr., a New York Republican who carried his family's tradition of Congressional service into a fourth generation.

title: A Track Where Everybody Can Sample Life in the Fast Lane
description: Donald Frasier Dyno, to his racing buddies checked the emergency parachute behind the wide, gleaming blue-striped spoiler on his Corvette. He checked the silk rose he keeps in his car for luck. ''I like going fast,'' he said. ''And I like being around afterward to talk about it.''

title: WEDDINGS;Adrienne Marks and Michael Griffen
description: Adrienne Marie Marks, a daughter of Michelle C. Marks of Olean, N.Y., and the late Philip J. Marks, was married yesterday to Michael Casey Griffen, the son of Lorraine and Frederick Griffen of Binghamton, N.Y. The Rev. Lawrence D. Ford officiated at St. Mary of the Angels Roman Catholic Church in Olean.

title: MARKET WATCH;Stock Watchdogs Can't End Abuses
description: Bull markets come and go. But penny stock rip-offs are always with us.

title: President Says He Can Sign Welfare Bill, Within Limits
description: President Clinton today expressed a strong desire to sign a bill overhauling welfare this year and hinted broadly that he might accept a version close to that passed by the Senate this week. But he also warned that he could not support "another extremist bill" like ones he has twice vetoed.

title: CHOICE TABLES;In St. Petersburg, Surprising Quality, Steep Prices
description: ST. PETERSBURG has been called the Venice of Russia, but not for its food. Based on the gloomy advice of friends who had been there recently, my husband, Richard, and I were prepared to numb our taste buds with iced vodka and make the best of it in hotel dining rooms.

title: A New Generation Emerging On Often Irreverent Terms
description: THE Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield frequently resembles a funhouse. The galleries are a series of rooms on two floors, and the sensation is one of anticipating what's in store in the next room. That the current show should be fun -- to put a finer point on it, brash and sassy -- is somewhat unexpected, for it would seem to have a sober mission: putting the spotlight on a new generation of African-American artists.

title: Minority Students in Private School
description: TEN years ago Rye Country Day School began an experiment that posed this question: would a group of minority students brought from public schools to an exclusive prep school for a month each summer realize a positive difference in their education?

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;Bridge Reduces Travel Time to Wales
description: A new $535 million bridge linking England and South Wales opened last month. By relieving traffic congestion at the Severn estuary, which the bridge spans, the crossing cuts the approximately three-hour journey from London to Cardiff by at least 20 minutes.

title: SIGNOFF;Bill Kurtis: Anchor, Producer, Idea Man
description: AFTER Bill Kurtis quit as anchor of "The CBS Morning News" in 1985, discouraged by the nonjournalistic track the program was taking, he all but disappeared from national screens. "I wanted to climb the mountain," he says now, "but the mountain had changed."

title: WEDDINGS;Ms. Schwartz, Mr. Rodriguez-Naaz
description: Laura Ederer Schwartz, a daughter of Howard N. Schwartz of New York and the late Jane Ederer Schwartz, is to be married today to Ernest Rodriguez-Naaz, the son of Sarita Rodriguez of New York and the late Jose F. Rodriguez.

title: Sunday: July 28, 1996: FAME;Thanks for the Offers, but I'm Keeping Rights to My Baby
description: Madonna is notorious for baring all, but she has been circling the strollers around her unborn child. According to Liz Rosenberg, her New York publicist, she is besieged with offers for what might be called umbilical tie-ins. Rosenberg says USA Weekend (the newspaper supplement published by Gannett) wanted her client to pose with diaper pins in her mouth. Another company proposed a line of baby togs and accessories bearing the Material Kid's image. More bizarre was a $10,000 offer to film the delivery -- along with a soothing promise not to show Madonna's face. Madonna said no, emphatically, and declined to discuss the ongoing assault.

title: July 21-27;Believe It's Not Butter
description: In the latest move in the endless chess game between nature and humanity, a Finnish company has developed a new margarine that not only controls cholesterol in the bloodstream but actually lowers it.

title: Let Lawmakers Put Brakes On 'Hot Pursuit' by Police
description: To the Editor:

title: Culture Zone;Ready for His Close-Up
description: Billy Wilder's office is not located in the old Hollywood of "Sunset Boulevard," not even in the old Hollywood where he made movies like "Sabrina" and "The Apartment." Billy Wilder's office is located smack in the middle of Beverly Hills, deep in the heart of "Clueless" territory, where "philosophy" is the name of a cosmetics line sold at Barneys and rich Japanese tourists cruise Chanel and Armani and Prada.

title: WEDDINGS;Jill Schwartz and Eric Wilson
description: Jill Nicole Schwartz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Steven Schwartz of Kings Park, L.I., was married last evening to Eric Lewis Wilson, a son of Jack Wilson and Barbara Rako, both of Boston. Rabbi Sholom Stern performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Cedarhurst, L.I.

title: WEDDINGS;Thomas Davidson, Melissa Lynch
description: Melissa Ann Lynch, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert F. Lynch Jr. of Noroton, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas Anders Davidson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Davidson of Wellfleet, Mass. The Rev. Edward Howley performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Darien, Conn.

title: Park Victim Has Set Out On Long Road To Recovery
description: One month after she was brutally beaten during an afternoon stroll in Central Park, a 32-year-old piano teacher took her first tentative solo steps between two parallel bars at the Kessler Institute for Rehabilitation. A physical therapist helped support her and coached her on where to place each foot and hand.

title: Bake a Pie to Celebrate The Blueberry's Big Month
description: There's still time to celebrate National Blueberry Month, preferably by eating New Jersey blueberries, of course.

title: Electronics Store? No, Lost and Found in Grand Central Terminal
description: THE lost and found in Grand Central Terminal has long been home to both the mundane and the bizarre. But the repository for things forgotten on Metro-North commuter trains has gained a decidedly new look, as both the nature of the items and the route to their recovery has become distinctly high tech.

title: THEATER;The Bard as a Man of Fewer Words
description: AFTER intermission, they do "Hamlet." And the 154 sonnets. As daunting as "Hamlet" is -- "really a hard-core play, so many words," one of the actors moans -- it's the reason for both the actors and the audience to return to the theater after Act I, during which Shakespeare's other 36 plays are tossed off. Some literally. "The Compleat Works of Wllm Shkspr (Abridged)," with text by the Reduced Shakespeare Company, at the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's Other Stage, clocks in at 90 minutes. That includes time out for taking pratfalls, doing "aerobic choreography," in the director's words, and other digressions, as when an actor playing Claudius accosts a patron on the aisle and threatens to kill her. To what method is such madness assigned? Ask James Michael Reilly, one of the company's three actors; Joe Discher, the director, or Bonnie J. Monte, the festival's artistic director, and you'll get answers stuffed with sanity and logic. "To send up the sacred and the familiar -- the English say 'to cock a snook,' which means to thumb your nose -- provides a necessary release," Mr. Reilly said. Ms. Monte declared: "One of the missions of our Other Stage is to reinvent classical texts, and to present derivatives of Shakespeare in order to show how the modern world is riffing on them. And it's an important audience-building tool -- to entice people to come to the classics on our main stage through an indirect route. Some people say Shakespeare is frightening. This is a great way to start. When I first saw this piece, I laughed till my make-up came off. Maybe this will get people to try one of the comedies." Mr. Discher added: "It gives people exposure to the plays they might not otherwise get. And it opens their hearts to Shakespeare. But it can't be all about silly physical gags. It can't be joke, joke, joke, joke. For me, it's about exploring the language and finding the humor that can come out of it, which knocks down the staid museum-piece approach to Shakespeare. "The set with an upper and lower deck looks traditional, like you're coming to see something highfalutin at the Globe." Kings. Queens. Witches. The three actors are outnumbered by their backstage dressers (four). "It's written so that it can barely be done," Mr. Reilly said. "We sometimes change costumes after eight words," he added, although tights, knee pads and footwear -- "your basic white Converse high tops" -- remain constant. But not the roller skates. To Mr. Reilly goes "all the girl stuff," he said: Gertrude, Ophelia, Lavinia. "And more wigs than the others," not to mention overuse of falsetto. Such specialization enables Mr. Reilly to articulate "the pattern of response" of Shakespeare's heroines to imminent death: "they throw up," he said, citing Juliet's reaction to poison and Ophelia's to madness. And what else is Cleopatra to do after uttering the line, "Is this an asp I see before me?" "It's all a little grossed out and hysterical." As for "Hamlet," the segment lasts 20 minutes, only to be followed by a speedier version (one minute 20 seconds) and then one that runs backwards (one minute 30 seconds). Sample: "Melt would flesh solid too too this that O." From what source, a student of theater is sure to wonder, comes the training required for actors to take on the concept of reduced Shakespeare? Mr. Reilly mused upon the question. "It draws on a lot of skills we all developed in the third grade," the actor answered.

title: Ideas & Trends;RU 486: It Isn't Just Popping a Pill
description: MARCIA B., a 30-year-old married sociologist who lives on the West Coast, knew she was pregnant as soon as she missed her menstrual period, and she knew she did not want to have the baby. "I did not want to be pregnant one second longer," she said. It was too early for a suction abortion, but she discovered she had another option. A clinic nearby was participating in studies of an abortion pill, called RU 486 in France and mifepristone in this country, and she could have an abortion with this method immediately. So she seized the opportunity.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: THE ARCHITECTURE OF VISION

title: IN BRIEF;Bake a Pie to Celebrate The Blueberry's Big Month
description: There's still time to celebrate National Blueberry Month, preferably by eating New Jersey blueberries, of course. Last week was one of the peak harvesting weeks of the season, said Al Murray of the State Agriculture Department. Last year, New Jersey produced 40 million gallons of blueberries, valued at $26.5 million. This year's crop should be at least that good, Mr. Murray said. The cultivated blueberry was first developed in the Pine Barrens town of Whitesbog. Today the state's blueberry industry is centered in Hammonton, Atlantic County, home of the Atlantic Blueberry Company, the world's largest. Here's a recipe from Anita Galletta, whose husband, Al, runs Atlantic Blueberry. Her pie recipe won first prize in the National Crisco Pie Baking Contest.

title: A Correction: San Diego's Vital Statistics
description: The What's Doing column on page 10 of the Travel section today, about San Diego, carries an incorrect listing of vital statistics. It was prepared for another issue, about Mount Desert Island, Me. Following is the correct listing:

title: Corrections
description: The "On the Map" article on page 3 of the New Jersey section today, about the Hambletonian harness race at the Meadowlands track, misstates the date of the event. It is next Saturday, not next Sunday.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY;West Virginia Opens a Crafts Showcase
description: A state-run shopping center called Tamarack opened last month in the mountains along the West Virginia Turnpike in Beckley, W.Va., marking a public-private partnership that the state hopes will attract half a million tourists and local visitors in the first year.

title: World News Briefs;Storms in Bay of Bengal Kill Almost 300 People
description: A storm in the Bay of Bengal has sunk 18 fishing trawlers, killing at least 16 people, a fishing community spokesman said today. A hundred people are missing.

title: WEDDINGS;Karen H. Granby, Charles J. Brisky
description: Karen Helene Granby, the director of human resources at Talbot Perkins Children's Services in New York, was married yesterday to Charles James Brisky, a deputy assistant director of the New York City Office of Management and Budget. Jean Somerville Kotkin, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society, officiated at the Beekman Tower Hotel in New York.

title: A Highland Hill Walk
description: THE road north from Ullapool, in Scotland's northern Highlands, cuts through low hills, mottled gray with outcroppings of rock, completely treeless but covered with a thin skin of closely grazed green. In the distance, peaks rise darkly to meet a lowering sky. Like bits of pewter mirrors, rain-slick rocks and murky lochans (little lochs) reflect luminous-edged clouds. "Take Care Lambs" reads a hand-painted sign by the roadside. The mass of Suilven (pronounced SOOL-vun) on our left is only the first of the extraordinary mountains that characterize the wild landscape of Assynt -- each soaring abruptly and individually from an undulating sea of low hills.

title: Dispatches From a War of Nerves
description: To the Editor: The Times has played fast and loose with the the very fixed boundaries of SoHo. The SoHo Grand Hotel, despite its name, is not in SoHo, at least within the Cast Iron Historic District. If it were, it never could have been built with the height and density it now possesses.

title: INVESTING IT;Marvel Superheroes Take Aim at Hollywood
description: ON the comic book pages, there isn't much that Spiderman can't accomplish. But the superhero can't seem to solve the most pressing problem of the company that employs him, Marvel Entertainment Group.

title: Con Man Preys on Gay Samaritans
description: Smooth, Southern and down on his luck -- or so he tells people -- William Bowen, 34, has been ''borrowing'' cash and clothes from dozens of gay men and merchants around the West Side in recent weeks after winning their confidence and sympathy, according to the New York City Gay and Lesbian Anti-Violence Project.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction;Newman's Own
description: Eric Lax, the author of a biography of Woody Allen, has turned his attention to Paul Newman with a big book of pictures and text. He faithfully recounts the facts about Paul Leonard Newman, born in 1925 and reared in comfort in Shaker Heights, an affluent suburb of Cleveland: the year in the Navy during which he catapulted six inches, up from 5-foot-4; his 38-year marriage to Joanne Woodward, with whom he fell in love when he was already married, with three young children; the Academy Award for "The Color of Money" (1986) and the eight other Oscar nominations; the car racing; the salad dressing; the spaghetti sauce; the popcorn; the drug-education foundation in memory of the eldest of his six children, Scott, who died in 1978 of an accidental overdose of drugs and alcohol at the age of 28; the camps for ill children. There is a story here, but, as Mr. Lax writes in PAUL NEWMAN: A Biography (Turner, $29.95), "He has always been guarded about his personal life, especially his marriages." Mr. Lax sums up at one point, "We are left to our private wonder." He also quotes Mr. Newman on his problems with alcohol: "I don't know why those times should be for public consumption." We don't need to be dragged through the mud with Mr. Newman, who seems to be an extraordinarily decent man; however, it would have been helpful to try going behind those baby blues to reach into the soul instead of simply sliding over the surface. But, oh, these pictures are divine! There's Paul, on the cover, as the title character in "Hud": sexy. And there's Paul in his 20's, whose face, as Mr. Lax describes it, "was something from an ancient coin." And Paul at 71, who "has aged gracefully, and now his face has the finely etched look of someone on a postage stamp." Coins, stamps, whatever. Who buys a book about Paul Newman for the words, anyway? Andrea Higbie

title: Colombia Cases Cast No Cloud on President
description: To the Editor:

title: Q and A
description: Buses in Mexico

title: FUNDS WATCH;Whip Inflation Now? Lessons From the 70's
description: PRICES of commodities like oil, natural gas, wheat and corn have been rising this year; the question is whether the pricing pressures are merely a blip or signs of a longer-term inflationary trend.

title: TELEVISION VIEW;Revisiting the 50's Disney With 90's Children in Tow
description: Several weeks ago, when a fellow parent confided to me that he had decided to let his family's recently expired television stay dead, I recalled one of my parents' favorite anecdotes. One afternoon when I was 4 years old, my mother entered our living room and saw me perched on a sofa, staring at a blank wall. Concerned, she asked what I was doing. I glanced at her, replied that I was watching television, then shifted my eyes back to the wall.

title: Westchester Q&A: Amber N. Harris;Program Puts Faces on People Worldwide
description: HOW she went eyeball to eyeball with a pride of lions is one of the stories Amber N. Harris of New Rochelle likes to tell about her recent trip to South Africa, but along the way, she said she learned a lot about people, too.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 9 -- ROWING;For Redgrave, Four Golds in Four Olympics Are Enough
description: Steven Redgrave of Britain became the fourth athlete to win a gold medal at four consecutive Olympics, teaming with Matthew Pinsent today to win rowing's coxless pairs.

title: Economy Is Big Test For Premier Of Spain
description: Jose Maria Aznar fought long and hard to become Spain's Prime Minister, but now that he has moved into Moncloa Palace, the conservative leader seems to have quickly discovered that he faces many of the same problems that his Socialist predecessor, Felipe Gonzalez, did.

title: Dispatches From a War of Nerves
description: To the Editor: Did it ever occur to Mr. Finkle that drivers who follow traffic procedures have been put upon by the pedestrian or jogger who tries to beat the red light? What if the drivers adopted the same idea -- don't stop for red lights and weave between walkers?

title: BASEBALL: NOTEBOOK;From Also-Rans to Pennant Contenders in a Day
description: In the next few days, an undetermined number of players will very likely get the opportunity to experience what John Flaherty and Chris Gomez have experienced this season, what Mike Aldrete has experienced this season and last and what David Cone has experienced twice in the past. In fact, it happens to different players every season: They are traded from teams that are far out of division races to playoff contenders.

title: Sunday: July 28, 1996: THE LAW;Hug Me -- Or I'll Sue
description: Hey, lawyers: looking to boost your courtroom aggressiveness while getting spiritually centered? Then pack your bags, Powerbooks and buckskin drums and head for Gerry Spence's Trial Lawyer's College, a monthlong, $2,900 retreat that starts Aug. 1 on Spence's ranch in Dubois, Wyo. Drawing on big-name legal and media talent (this year's invitees include Johnnie Cochran and Larry King), Spence, the folksy lawyer best known for defending Imelda Marcos, uses New Age trappings to teach students to turn their repressed emotions into jury-swaying power. "I would rather have a skilled nurse represent me than a young lawyer," says Spence. Why? Because nurses, at least, have "learned how to listen -- how to love."

title: LIVES;A Virtual Life
description: After too long on the Net, even a phone call can be a shock. My boyfriend's Liverpudlian accent suddenly becomes indecipherable after the clarity of his words on screen; a secretary's clipped tonality seems more rejecting than I'd imagined it would be. Time itself becomes fluid -- hours become minutes, and alternately seconds stretch into days. Weekends, once a highlight of my week, are now just two ordinary days.

title: WEDDINGS;Jane Sullivan, John Roberts Jr.
description: Jane Marie Sullivan and John Glover Roberts Jr., lawyers for Washington law firms, were married yesterday at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Washington. Msgr. Peter Joseph Vaghi performed the ceremony.

title: 'Damn Yankees' Revival
description: In the happy time of ''Damn Yan

title: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;The First Thing We Do, Let's Sue All the Lawyers
description: Q. I think my lawyer mishandled my personal-injury case. Is it difficult to sue a lawyer for malpractice?

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: THE RESPONSE;Clinton Says The Olympics Will Not Bow To Terrorism
description: Calling the bombing in Atlanta "an evil act of terror" and contrasting the cowardice of the act to the courage of Olympic athletes, President Clinton today said that the Games should continue as a signal that the nation and the world would not bow to terrorism.

title: Sunday: July 28, 1996: LAW ENFORCEMENT;Is This Man Amusing Anymore?
description: Most of this is generalized observations," grouses Sheriff Joe Arpaio of a recent report of a preliminary Justice Department investigation documenting civil rights violations at his jails in Maricopa County, Ariz. The 200-page roundup describes routine abuse of prisoners, including an episode in which detention officers used a stun gun on an inmate's testicles.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS;Threats Across Nation
description: Bomb threats disrupted several sites around the nation:

title: A Fiscal Profile of Biomedical Research
description: DEBRA K. PASQUALE is executive director of Connecticut United for Research Excellence, a group known as CURE that promotes biomedical research.

title: Sports of The Times;A Mixing Of Softball And Politics
description: IT was the bottom of the second inning, no score, runners on second and third. You make the call. Play the infielders back and concede a run? Move them in for a play at the plate? Walk the bases loaded and set up a force at any base? .np

title: In America;A Medal For Humanity
description: This time the evil came packed in a Tupperware container that was slipped into a green knapsack and quietly placed in an unsuspecting crowd of Olympic revelers. The sadistic offering of a twisted being.

title: No Headline
description: I believe that the more there is terrorism, the more pressure we're under to find systematic ways to solve it." NEWT GINGRICH, Speaker of the House [B7:1.]

title: Bessy Pupko, 99, Investigator Who Found Holocaust Survivors
description: Bessy Pupko, who spent 50 years locating witnesses to Nazi war crimes, died on July 26 at her home on the Upper West Side. She was 99.

title: Patents;The owner of a direct-mail company creates a system to send electronic ads to specific viewers.
description: AN increasing number of patents are being issued to inventors to protect innovations in information and entertainment technology, especially the emerging methods of exploiting the Internet.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Candidates From New Jersey
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman may not be interested in being Vice President, but there will be no shortage of New Jerseyans on the Presidential ballot this November. Two state residents can be found on independent party petitions that have been filed ahead of today's 4 P.M. deadline. Monica Moorehead of Jersey City is running for President under the Workers World Party banner, and Madelyn Hoffman of Flanders is Ralph Nader's running mate on the Green ticket. Another candidate, Rose Zeidwerg Monyek of Rahway, plans to file today to run on the "Harmonized Tariff 9802.00.80" ticket.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: THE NATION;Even in a Sheltered Valley, Fear Intrudes
description: On a soft summer afternoon in the California wine country, Mark E. McComb was pushing his young daughter around town in her stroller and remembering how much simpler things had seemed when he was growing up.

title: ATLANTA, July 28;Memorial for Munich Victims
description: A memorial service was held here tonight for relatives of the 11 Israeli athletes and coaches killed during the 1972 Munich Olympic Games.

title: No Safe Place
description: The explosion early Saturday morning in Centennial Olympic Park did more than cast a shadow on the largest gathering of nations and athletes in history. It exposed the truth about what has been called the biggest mobilization of law enforcement and crime-fighting technology in American history. A lowly pipe bomb -- relative of the Molotov cocktail in its crude simplicity -- destroyed the confidence that there is anything anymore called security.

title: BASEBALL;Jones Comes Through When Mets Need Him
description: It is often difficult to predict how Bobby Jones, the Mets' finesse pitcher, is going to perform. He can be good. He can be bad. He can be average. Today, when the Mets needed him most, he was great.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;For Leo Burnett, a United review signals unwanted clouds moving into the friendly skies.
description: AFTER three decades of friendly skies for United Airlines and the Leo Burnett Company, the fasten seat belt sign is flashing.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CROWN PRINCE and CROWN PRINCESS PAVLOS of Greece, who live in Greenwich, Conn., are parents of a daughter born on Thursday night at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: In Burundi's Capital, Waterfront Strollers Praise Coup
description: I think the coup is very good, because it will mean peace," said Janine, who was admiring the sunset from a stone breakwater that stretches into Lake Tanganyika. "Before, there were too many massacres."

title: Acquisition of California Federal Is Called Near
description: First Nationwide Bank is close to reaching an agreement to acquire California Federal Bank, and the two sides could announce a deal early this week, executives close to the talks said today.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE SECURITY GAP;Limited Checks on Workers Who Have Access to Planes
description: Despite the visible reassurance offered by crisply uniformed guards tending metal detectors and airline safety rules that have been strengthened since the explosion of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, security experts say one of the weakest links may be the very people who work in the nation's airports.

title: Orders for Machine Tools Rise by 18.7%
description: Orders for American industrial tools rose 18.7 percent in June from the previous month as demand from domestic customers soared, the Association for Manufacturing Technology said today.

title: World News Briefs;Israeli Dumping of Blood Ruled Medically Sound
description: An Israeli commission set up to investigate the dumping of blood donations from Ethiopian Jews for fear of AIDS concluded today that discarding the blood, while insensitive, was medically sound.

title: BASEBALL;Strawberry Hits Milestone And Saves Day For Yankees
description: If only they could have been there. Here was Darryl Strawberry, slowing to a trot with his arms held high, with the roar of a New York crowd as his soundtrack to circle the bases by.

title: Mr. Netanyahu's Cautious Diplomacy
description: Israel's new Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, has come under pressure to take a tougher line with the Palestinians following Friday's drive-by terrorist shooting that left three dead. Mr. Netanyahu won election on a slogan of peace with security and has promised to pursue a far more cautious diplomatic strategy than his Labor predecessors, Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Rabin.

title: Scaled-Back White House Conference Will Follow Up on Children's TVProgramming
description: Six weeks ago, President Clinton summoned the chief executives of America's television networks to the White House on July 29 for a high-level discussion on children's television. Since then, the "summit" has been downgraded to a "conference," and the network chiefs have decided to send proxies to Washington today to meet with Mr. Clinton, Vice President Gore, Hillary Rodham Clinton and Tipper Gore.

title: Republican Congress Matched Promises
description: To the Editor:

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Without Playmaker, the Game Goes on for Cowboys
description: The Dallas Cowboys needed two touchdowns in the final 1 minute 35 seconds to pull out a 35-34 victory over the Oakland Raiders in their first preseason game on Saturday night. Coach Barry Switzer was exhilarated by the thrilling nature of the victory, but disappointed that the game was sloppy and error-plagued.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10: ROUNDUP -- TEAM HANDBALL;U.S. Women Ousted
description: Hungary beat the United States women, 30-24, to eliminate them from medal contention. After trailing by 19-8 at halftime, the Americans got to within 25-21 after scoring five straight goals. Then came a momentum-breaking mistake: With about six minutes left in the game, Carol Peterka earned a two-minute suspension for returning to the court too soon after a previous penalty. (AP)

title: Meanwhile, Waiting in the Wings . . .
description: Rupert Murdoch calls each of his children "darling," but one day he hopes one will be called "chief executive."

title: Where's Rose Mary Woods When You Need Her?
description: Nixon: The CD-ROM" could have used a Rose Mary Woods.

title: Maki Journal;Japan's New Local Politics: It's a Fog of Politeness
description: Sugio Ishitaka, a fruit store owner, knows how he will vote next month on the question of whether a nuclear power plant should be built on the outskirts of town. "But because of my business, I can't talk about it," he said, explaining that he did not want to ruin relationships with customers who might have the opposite view.

title: I.B.M. Seeks Its Footing After Atlanta Stumble
description: From the beginning, it looked like an impossible mission.

title: Buyouts Leave School Board Racing to Fill 3,000 Jobs
description: For the second consecutive summer, the Board of Education is scrambling to cope with a self-inflicted staffing headache: the departure of thousands of the most experienced teachers in New York City's public schools, who are planning to retire early under a buyout program.

title: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;Education Technology recruits a masterful marketer of games to be its leader.
description: IT may be a sign of the times when the former president of Sega of America, Thomas Kalinske, leaves his job -- as he announced earlier this month -- to join a start-up called Education Technology L.L.C.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- ROWING;A Sluggish Final Day For Both U.S. Eights
description: The American women's eight, last year's world champions and the United States' best hope for a gold medal in rowing, was soundly beaten today, fading to fourth behind Romania, Canada and Belarus on the final day of rowing competition.

title: A Chastened Latin Left Puts Its Hope in Ballots
description: The Communists were here, and so were the Intransigents, the Laborites, the Radicals and the Socialists. Former Sandinista, Tupamaro and Montonero guerrillas were here too, all under one roof to discuss the issue that has preoccupied the Latin American left throughout this decade: how to rebuild in a world dominated by capitalism and the United States.

title: If Immigrants Lose U.S. Aid, Local Budgets May Feel Pain
description: The elaborate tattoos that adorn Bech Chuom's chest are meant to protect him from wayward bullets, and he trusts the precepts he follows as a strict Buddhist to safeguard his soul.

title: Political Memo;Council Faces Lonely Fight For Long Life
description: In the four months since City Council members started talking publicly about weakening the term limits that voters imposed on them and other elected city officials in 1993, they have been labeled self-serving, arrogant and, above all, desperate.

title: Mubarak Visits U.S. to Win Assurances on Arab-Israeli Talks
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt traveled to Washington today to seek assurances that the effort for Arab-Israeli peace will not be deferred by Israel's switch to a Government that is harshly critical of existing agreements and negotiating blueprints.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Music;Japan's Sounds and Rituals, Bridging the Centuries
description: Reigakusha, the Japanese ensemble that performed at Alice Tully Hall on Friday night, made its entrance a ritual procession. The musicians, wearing robes and hats, arrived in single file and knelt silently until they were all in place; then they took up their instruments. The silence was an essential part of their music, gagaku, which for more than a millennium has been heard in the Japanese imperial court, in temples and at solemn ceremonies. Through the centuries, gagaku transformed material from Japan, China, India, Korea and Central Asia into music that is stately and austere, with a timeless aura.

title: Turkish Inmates End Hunger Strike After Deal Is Reached
description: Leftist prisoners abandoned their 69-day-old hunger strike today under a deal that provided the strikers and the new Islamic-led Government with the grist for claims of victory.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- TRACK AND FIELD;Christie Still Blaming System
description: The electronic starting blocks were not responsible for the first of two false-start calls that resulted in the disqualification of Linford Christie in Saturday's 100-meter sprint, Olympic officials said today. And Christie maintained that the system was in error when it charged him with the second false start.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- CYCLING;German Uses Wits To Outrace American
description: Since Wednesday, when the five days of track cycling began, Marty Nothstein had been the powerhouse of the men's match sprint. Day after day, he blew by some of the world's best sprinters. He was favored to do the same in today's final against Jens Fiedler, a 26-year-old product of the old East German sports machine and the gold medalist for Germany in 1992.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE SEARCH;Crews, Aided by Robots, Turn Focus to Evidence
description: Some salvage crews turned their primary attention today to recovering evidence instead of human remains from Trans World Airlines Flight 800, increasing the hope that they are close to finding the first piece of physical evidence that will resolve whether the fireball in the sky was an accident or a crime.

title: Terrorism Must Not Drive Us Behind a Wall;Airport Security
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- SOCCER;Overtime Goal Sends U.S. Women to Final
description: Norway against the United States is fast becoming one of the great sporting rivalries in the world. Maybe in these parts it does not yet match the Georgia-Florida football game, but there should be a place in the collective Georgian memory for the glorious game these two women's soccer teams played today.

title: Treasury to Auction Bills This Week
description: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: This Is the Life: Raise Bridge. Cook Chicken.;Unsung Chef Dreams Big High Above the Gowanus
description: The Chicken Man looked out over the ditch full of dark green water that juts into South Brooklyn like a broken finger. "Maybe there will be a barge today," he said.

title: In Farewell to Hamilton Fish Jr., Praise for Service and Integrity
description: Calling him a personal inspiration and the most trusted politician he had ever known, Gov. George E. Pataki joined scores of mourners and dignitaries today at a memorial service for Hamilton Fish Jr., a New York Republican who carried his family's tradition of Congressional service into a fourth generation.

title: Police Bias Delayed Brooklyn Slaying Inquiry
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;CNET and Lexmark Make Some Changes
description: Two technology companies have made changes on their accounts.

title: HORSE RACING;Invader From the West Whips Field at Saratoga
description: On Friday, opening day, it was Kelly Kip stealing the show. On Saturday, it was the filly Capote Belle in a record-tying performance. And today, it was the filly Exotic Wood, leading all the way, winning for the eighth time in nine starts and becoming the third star born in three days at Saratoga's 128th meeting.

title: SOCCER;MetroStars Exit Grass In Triumph
description: From Tony Meola in goal to the last player on attack, the MetroStars are playing with more confidence and purpose.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- GYMNASTICS;Golden Night for Melissanidis and Greece
description: Little more than three months ago, Ioannis Melissanidis was running through the streets of his native Thessaloniki with the Olympic torch in his hand and Olympic dreams in his head.

title: On World Stage, Many Lessons for Clinton
description: Every evening, President Clinton, the baby boomer who came to office vowing not to be consumed by problems beyond America's shores, receives a brief personal note from Warren Christopher, his cautious, 71-year-old Secretary of State and veteran of four Democratic administrations.

title: Cray to Accuse NEC Of Trade Violations
description: Cray Research Inc. said yesterday that it plans to outline today what it says are trade law violations by the NEC Corporation.

title: CLINTON PROPOSES HARSHER MEASURES AGAINST TERRORISM
description: Spurred by the bombing at the Atlanta Olympics, President Clinton today called on Congress to pass expanded provisions against terrorism, including new Federal wiretapping authority, that were dropped from the anti-terrorism bill before it was enacted this spring.

title: With Elections Drawing Near, Legislative Logjam Breaks and CongressBuckles Down
description: Congress has shaken off months of gridlocked lethargy and is passing bills it can go home and campaign on, from fighting terrorism to putting more police officers on the street.

title: Murdoch Bets Heavily on a Heavily on a Global Vision;Despite the Risks, News Corp. Pursues an Aggressive Expansion
description: It was vintage Rupert Murdoch. On Thursday evening, July 18, Mr. Murdoch, the Australian-born chairman of the News Corporation, and the American entrepreneur Ronald O. Perelman lingered after dinner on the outdoor deck of the investment banker Herbert Allen's home in Sun Valley, Idaho.

title: Peru to Bar Military From Business Role
description: Peru will suspend all commercial operations by its navy and air force to help stop the use of military ships and aircraft for drug trafficking, President Alberto Fujimori said today.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- BASKETBALL;Dream Team Takes Care of a Formality: Winning Group
description: Aleksandr Gomelsky, whose 1988 gold-medal team from the Soviet Union led directly to the unleashing of the Dream Team, was standing in a quiet Georgia Dome the other day and talking about an Olympic basketball competition that from the start has featured brave and passionate efforts.

title: Murdoch Places Bets On a Global Vision
description: Rupert Murdoch, the chairman of the News Corporation, is willing to act quickly and spend heavily to enhance his strategy of having a finger in every major form of programming, in every corner of the world.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10;Olympic Diary
description: People get even in different ways.

title: Small Explosive Device Damages Doors of a Synagogue in Queens
description: A small explosive detonated in front of a Queens synagogue Saturday night, tearing a hole in the building's heavy wooden double doors.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10: ROUNDUP -- YACHTING;Hong Kong Gets Medal
description: Hong Kong claimed its first Olympic medal in any sport when Lai Shan Lee clinched the women's windsurfing gold in Savannah, Ga., with one race still to sail. Lee, 25, was a medal favorite in the Mistral competition, but she faced a stiff challenge from the 1992 gold medalist, Barbara Kendall of New Zealand. Her confidence helped. "I had a little bit better boat speed and I think better physical fitness than the others," Lee said. Her triumph made her a hero at home, as this is the last Olympics for Hong Kong before it reverts to China.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * Mary Ann Packo was named president of PC Meter L.P., Port Washington, L.I., a World Wide Web tracking service owned by NPD Group Inc. She assumes responsibilities from Steve Coffey, vice president and general manager, who was promoted to vice chairman and chief technology officer. Ms. Packo had been executive director of Ipsos-NFO Europe, Paris, a unit of NFO Research. * Sarah Hatch, senior vice president and strategic planning director at Bates USA, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., was promoted to executive vice president and head of strategic planning. * James Meyer rejoined the New York office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, a unit of the MacManus Group, as senior vice president and executive account director in a realignment of account duties. Mr. Meyer, who will handle the Procter & Gamble health care and CPC Internationalcoei Best Foods Bakery accounts, had been senior vice president and management director on the Kellogg Company account at the J. Walter Thompson New York unit of the WPP Group.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- TRACK AND FIELD;First Day As World's Fastest
description: The fastest man on earth was 30 minutes late, one of the many charms of Donovan Bailey. "He's famous for missing airplanes, he likes to shop, his diet is sometimes lax and anything over 200 meters he has a strong aversion to," Dan Pfaff, Bailey's coach, said at a news conference. "He's also a terrible dominoes player."

title: Dividend Meetings
description: A partial list for this week.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: * Holiday Inn Worldwide, Atlanta, a unit of Bass P.L.C., to Draft Direct Worldwide, Chicago, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle direct marketing in North America, previously handled by various agencies. Draft handles direct marketing assignments throughout Asia. Billings were not disclosed. * Gaylord Entertainment Co., Nashville, to ABP Interactive, New York, a unit of Adler Boschetto Peebles & Partners, as the first agency to handle interactive marketing. Billings were not disclosed. * Hannaford Brothers Co., Scarborough, Me., to Pedone & Partners, New York, to handle advertising for the operator of Shop 'n Save supermarkets and the Hannaford Food and Drug stores, which had been handled by Houston Herstek Favat, Boston. Billings were not disclosed. * Primeco Personal Communications L.P., Westlake, Tex., an alliance of Air Touch Communications, Bell Atlantic, Nynex and U S West, to Fox Pavlika & Partners, New York, as its first direct marketing agency. Billings were not disclosed.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE FAMILIES;Going Home So That Life Can Go On
description: As the number of bodies being recovered from the ocean floor continues to diminish, many of the families still waiting to bury their loved ones are taking the first painful step toward reclaiming their lives after the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800: They are going home.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: MONTOURSVILLE;Global Village Comforts a Tiny Town
description: With people around the world sending their condolences by computer to this tiny town that lost 21 people on Flight 800, its residents have been helped through their grief by the global village.

title: Guard for Irvin Is Accused
description: Now that they are through with Michael Irvin, prosecutors want to target the football star's bodyguard on charges of working without a valid private investigator's license.

title: Gingrich Ally Under Siege at Home
description: When Representative Andrea Seastrand first arrived on Capitol Hill in January 1995, the first thing she did was pledge undying fealty to Speaker Newt Gingrich and unalloyed support for his strongly conservative Contract With America.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- EQUESTRIAN;Gibson Earned Bronze Hard Way
description: For the umpteenth time, Michelle Gibson, horse-crazy at the age of 13, was being chauffeured by her father to her after-school job. She would muck out stalls and provided basic valet service to a barnful of horses in exchange for riding lessons. Both father and daughter were tired of the commute, but neither was ready to bail out Gibson's dream of riding one of the noble beasts for a noble cause.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10: ROUNDUP -- WEIGHT LIFTING;Greek Sets Record
description: Akakide Kakhiashvilis of Greece broke the world record for the 218 1/4-pound division while winning his second Olympic gold medal. Kakhiashvilis lifted a total of 925 3/4 pounds at the Georgia World Congress Center, breaking the record of 920 1/4 pounds. Kakhiashvilis also set a world record in the clean-and-jerk by lifting 518 pounds. (AP)

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Opposing Abortion Plank
description: New Jersey's delegation to the Republican National Convention is overwhelmingly opposed to a plank in the party platform calling for a constitutional ban on abortion, according to a survey by The Associated Press. The poll, released yesterday, found that 33 of the state's 48 delegates do not want the anti-abortion language. The same poll found that only 34 percent of G.O.P. delegates nationwide oppose the anti-abortion stance.

title: Eric Ridder, 78, Former Publisher Of Business Paper
description: Eric Ridder, a former publisher of The Journal of Commerce, a New York-based business newspaper, died on Tuesday at his home in Locust Valley, L.I. He was 78.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;A Move to Rehire Workers
description: When the state adopted its tax-cutting $16 billion budget last month, no agency took a bigger hit than the Department of Environmental Protection. Although Republican legislators restored some of the money Governor Whitman wanted to cut, the D.E.P. still lost nearly $10 million and laid off nearly 200 workers.

title: Arafat Seeks Saudis' Help
description: Yasir Arafat arrived in Saudi Arabia today to seek political and financial support for the Palestinians in their peace effort with Israel.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: THE CITY;Simple Prayer Reflects Hope For Atlanta To Rise Again
description: As he finished his sermon to a joint service of his own First United Methodist Church and the Norwegian Seamen's Church, whose members are here for the Olympics, Dr. Sam Matthews ended with a prayer no doubt offered in endless variations across Atlanta today.

title: Lawyer Hired in Mall Suit
description: One of the lawyers who won acquittal for O. J. Simpson has joined the legal team representing the family of a black teen-ager in a case that led to accusations of racism against the owners of suburban shopping mall.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Tougher Rule for Engineers
description: New Jersey Transit engineers who run two or more red lights will automatically be dismissed under a new agency rule. The policy change took effect April 3, but was first reported yesterday by The Star-Ledger. It replaces a more lenient Federal standard that calls for a one-year suspension for any engineer who commits two serious moving violations within three years. John DeCurtis, an engineer on a New Jersey Transit train that crashed after running a red light on Feb. 9, was cited for failing to stop at red signals in 1986 and 1989. Mr. DeCurtis and two other people were killed in the crash.

title: Dole Reverses Stand on White House Security
description: Bob Dole reversed himself today and said that he opposed President Clinton's decision last year to close a two-block stretch in front of the White House to guard against a catastrophic terrorist attack on the President's home.

title: Corrections
description: A headline in Business Day on July 17 about cutbacks at Malden Mills Industries, a family-owned textile company in Lawrence, Mass., referred incorrectly to the company's action. As noted in the article, the recall of 400 hourly workers was postponed for a year or more and 50 salaried employees were laid off; the company did not cut 450 positions.

title: ON BASEBALL;A Mets Owner Is Tired of Excuses
description: Living in the wake of the Atlanta Braves in the National League East can be devastating.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-7

title: METRO DIGEST
description: THE CRASH

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Sports Authority Seeks New Agency
description: Ross Roy Communications in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., has resigned the broadcast advertising account of the Sports Authority Inc. chain of sporting-goods stores after five years.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10: ROUNDUP -- TENNIS;U.S. Doubles Team Out
description: The emergency partnership of Andre Agassi and MaliVai Washington went down in doubles yesterday, losing to Ellis and Wayne Ferreira of South Africa by 7-5, 6-7 (2-7), 6-0 in the second round in Stone Mountain, Ga. A partisan crowd of 5,000 cheered on the Americans, but the Ferreiras pulled away after escaping two break points in the opening game of the third set.

title: Terrorism Must Not Drive Us Behind a Wall;For a Global Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Indonesia Tense After Riots

title: ATLANTA: DAY 10
description: Breaking Through

title: Cruise Ships Remain Safe, Industry Says
description: Despite four major accidents involving cruise ships around Alaska over the last two summers, including a fatal fire on Saturday, industry officials said today that the ocean liners have good safety records.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: THE INVESTIGATION;With Scores of Tips, and Photos, Bomber's Description Is Emerging
description: Federal investigators said today that they had begun assembling composite sketches of a possible suspect in the pipe bombing that staggered, but did not stop, the Olympic Games.

title: Ratings Exceed NBC's Promises For The Games
description: At least until Saturday, when a terror bomb moved the nation's attention away from the Olympic competition, the first week of NBC's coverage of the Olympic Games in Atlanta has been among the most successful and profitable weeks in network television history, with ratings reaching levels not seen since Nadia Comaneci was swinging on a bar in the 1976 Olympics in Montreal.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Deadline Near in Talks On Japan's Chip Market The United States and Japan have entered last-ditch negotiations to renew a semiconductor trade agreement. If the pattern of past trade talks holds true, negotiators will squabble right until Wednesday's deadline before reaching a vague agreement that both sides will call a victory.

title: Offerings Scheduled This Week For Equity and Convertible Debt
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: In a Far-Flung Empire, Some Winners, Losers and Works in Progress;Patience, Pluck And Satellites
description: Rupert Murdoch's empire spreads across six continents and includes books, magazines, newspapers, broadcasting, satellite televison, cable and a movie studio. The following is a glimpse at how some parts of that empire are doing as Mr. Murdoch engages in a frenzy of new expansion aimed at locking up both programming and distribution outlets around the world.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- BEACH VOLLEYBALL;Golden Sand For Kiraly And Steffes
description: Now we know what a beach volleyball star wears to an Olympic medal ceremony: a red, white and blue warm-up suit, a pink cap and bare feet.

title: Daniel Brustlein, 92, a 'Painter's Painter'
description: Daniel Brustlein, a painter who also worked as a cartoonist under the name of Alain, died on July 14 at his home in Paris. He was 92.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;J. Walter Thompson Gets Schick Account
description: The Warner-Lambert Company has named the J. Walter Thompson Company in New York to handle the consolidated worldwide account of its Schick shaving products group, which is based in Milford, Conn. Billings on the consolidated account, which includes advertising for the Schick and Wilkinson brands, were estimated at $65 million to $75 million.

title: Questionable Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- TRACK AND FIELD;As Mighty Fall, Long Shots Leap to New Heights
description: Olympic champions and Olympic favorites dropped like exhausted, cramped runners tonight in track and field at the centennial Games. Even Carl Lewis came within one jump from the premature end of his career until he dramatically rescued a place in the long jump finals Monday night with his best jump in two years.

title: THE CLINTON RECORD: Foreign Policy;Clinton's Three Big Objectives Include Peace Through Trade
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Clinton conducted on July 8 with reporters and editors of The New York Times:

title: A Cap on Taxes in Washington Draws White House Opposition
description: The Clinton Administration opposes a broad cut in Federal tax rates for District of Columbia residents, the Republicans' favorite idea for bailing out the city, a senior White House official said today.

title: Hector Perez Garcia, 82, Dies; Led Hispanic Rights Group
description: Hector Perez Garcia, a South Texas doctor who founded one of the nation's most influential Mexican-American civil rights organizations, died on Friday in Memorial Medical Center in Corpus Christi, Tex.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Exploring the Genesis of the Two Jesse Jacksons
description: JESSE The Life and Pilgrimage of Jesse Jackson By Marshall Frady Illustrated. 552 pages. Random House. $28.50.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- BASEBALL;Cuban Bats Silence Chanters
description: Depending on who's counting, Cuba's baseball winning streak is now 140, 131 or 123 games, and the "U.S.A.! U.S.A!" chant couldn't quite conquer Communism as it did in Lake Placid.

title: Terrorism Must Not Drive Us Behind a Wall;State Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: Deadline Nears for Renewal of Chip Pact
description: The United States and Japan have entered last-ditch negotiations to renew a semiconductor trade agreement that expires on Wednesday. If past trade talks are any guide, negotiators will squabble right up until Wednesday's deadline before reaching a vague agreement that will be interpreted as a victory by both sides.

title: For New York Lawyers, Client Management 101
description: To the Editor:

title: Crowd Battles the Police in Passaic After a Fight at a Soccer Match
description: A crowd of 200 to 300 people, many perched on tenement roofs, pelted the police in Passaic, N.J., with rocks and bottles yesterday after officers tried to arrest people at a local soccer game, the authorities said. Six people were arrested for assaulting a police officer and rioting, but no one was seriously injured, the police said.

title: Leading Bank in Harlem Faces Hostile Takeover
description: Carver Federal Savings Bank, a Harlem institution that is the country's largest black-run financial services company, is the target of a hostile stock offer to take over a sizable portion of the company.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Girl and Fetus Die as a Friend Shows Off His Gun, Police Say
description: A pregnant 15-year-old died yesterday morning after she was accidentally shot Saturday night in Queens by a friend showing off his new pistol, the police said. Her 4-month-old fetus was struck in the skull and died instantly.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- WATER POLO;Victory Over Croatia Ends Spain's Long Wait for Gold
description: When Spain's water polo team returns to Barcelona, Manuel Estiarte should treat Jordi Sans to dinner.

title: Recycling Without Tears
description: Mundane as it sounds, the subject of recycling garbage in New York City provokes fierce emotional responses. Joining what has become a serious debate, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani argues that recycling may be more of an expensive nuisance than it is worth. He has also cut back on recycling in his budget and assembled experts to compare the costs and benefits of all the city's refuse programs.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10: ROUNDUP -- TABLE TENNIS;Champions Eliminated
description: Even the presence of the king and queen could not help Jan-Ove Waldner defend his Olympic crown.

title: AN AMERICAN PLACE;A Time for Volunteers
description: In Stark County, Ohio, a spirit of volunteerism contradicts Americans' supposed decline in civic involvement. Page A8.

title: Stocks Higher in Japan
