description: Stocks were trading higher here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 56.07 points, or about a quarter of a percent, at 21,180.97. On Friday, the Nikkei closed up 241.06 points.

title: MSNBC Is Making News on Reporting News
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: CARMAN MOORE is a composer who believes that Central Park has gotten a bad rap in recent years. He is trying to remedy that with a series of three music and dance performances in the park, though not in the usual locales for cultural events.

title: In a Far-Flung Empire, Some Winners, Losers and Works in Progress;Fox TV Network Raises Concern
description: Rupert Murdoch's empire spreads across six continents and includes books, magazines, newspapers, broadcasting, satellite televison, cable and a movie studio. The following is a glimpse at how some parts of that empire are doing as Mr. Murdoch engages in a frenzy of new expansion aimed at locking up both programming and distribution outlets around the world.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- TRACK AND FIELD;Roba Wins Marathon, and Ethiopia's Heart
description: When she crossed the finish line at Olympic Stadium after running 26.2 miles, Fatuma Roba dropped to her knees and kissed the track.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;MacManus to Keep An Ayer Operation
description: The MacManus Group in New York, formerly known as D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Inc., has decided not to sell the Chicago office of N. W. Ayer & Partners, which MacManus has agreed to acquire along with the Ayer parent, Adcom Investors Inc. Other agency companies like the Interpublic Group of Companies had been considering buying Ayer Chicago. Dean Proctor will continue to head Ayer Chicago as president, reporting to Mary Lou Quinlan, chief executive of Ayer.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10: ROUNDUP -- DIVING;Chinese Stand One-Two
description: The defending champion, Mark Lenzi, rallied after two poor dives in the preliminaries and joined his American teammate Scott Donie in the Olympic springboard semifinals.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Honor for Turf Researcher
description: For three decades, C. Reed Funk, a professor of plant science at Rutgers University's Cook College, has been a giant in the field of grass. The founder of Cook's turf grass breeding program, Mr. Funk developed a hardy strain of ryegrass that is used in soccer stadiums all over Europe and earns the university about $1.6 million a year in royalties.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Alcohol Board Inquiry
description: In Hoboken, the state's unofficial bar capital, a scandal in the city's Alcoholic Beverage Control Board is cause for considerable concern. At the city's request, auditors from the state will arrive today to review five years of license transfers and other transactions in the wake of the arrest of the board's secretary, Patrick Cecala, on charges of soliciting a $1,000 bribe. Mr. Cecala, who is accused of taking the money to facilitate approval of a license transfer, was dismissed on July 16.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- BOXING;Tarver Feasts in Ring, Instead of Dining Hall
description: Only Thursday, he was booed and the consensus deemed him overblown hype, all mouth and no malice. Three days later, he was creating a 15-person pileup in the foyer of the arena.

title: Ex-Sybase Executive Named Inktomi Chief
description: The Inktomi Corporation, a start-up Internet technology company, said today that it was naming David Peterschmidt, the former chief operating officer of Sybase Inc., to the post of chief executive.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10 -- TRACK AND FIELD;Deal Thinks He's Through, Then Takes 2d in Hammer
description: It was hammer time at the Summer Olympics today, and after three throws, Lance Deal of the United States thought his time was up. Only 8 of the 12 hammer throwers would advance to the final round. Or so Deal thought. He squatted and put his face in his hands. He took off his glove and removed his shirt and shoes. It looked as if he might be crying.

title: Bridge
description: A famous episode in English history concerned the arrival of the Spanish Armada in 1588. Word that the Armada had been sighted was brought to the British Admiral, Sir Francis Drake, who was known as the first ship's captain ever to sail around the world. At the time he was pleasantly occupied playing bowls -- lawn bowls with heavy wooden balls. On being told that the Armada was in view, he calmed his captains who were eager to be off with the words: "We can finish the rubber and beat the Spaniards, too." And they did.

title: Three Athletes Disqualified
description: Three athletes, including two Russian bronze medalists, were disqualified from the Summer Games today after testing positive for an illegal stimulant. They were the first positive tests in these Olympics.

title: Corrections
description: The Company News column of Business Day on July 17 carried an erroneous corporate logo in some editions with a report about an alliance between SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., Human Genome Sciences Inc. and Merck K.G.a.A. of Germany. The symbol was that of Merck & Company of Whitehouse Station, N.J., which has no relationship with Merck K.G.a.A., an affiliate of E. Merck of Darmstadt, Germany.

title: Taking In the Sites;From Tips on Air Travel To the Fear of Flying
description: A student pilot's Cessna hits a four-foot snowbank in Springbrook, Wis. A crop-duster loses power near Lost Hills, Calif. A Boeing 747 explodes off East Moriches, L.I.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Fila Offers Arnell 2 New Assignments
description: Fila USA Inc., the athletic footwear and apparel company, has awarded the Arnell Group in New York two new North American assignments that involve women's shoes and promoting technology performance for Fila USA. Billings have not been determined. Howe Burch, vice president for advertising and communications at Fila USA in Hunt Valley, Md., said Arnell was awarded those assignments without a formal review. FCB/Leber Katz Partners in New York, a unit of True North Communications, continues as Fila's lead agency.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE OVERVIEW;Plane Split in Sky, Officials Say, Suggesting Bomb
description: The front end of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 broke away, plunging toward the Atlantic Ocean, while the rest of the plane continued to hurtle through the air before bursting into an enormous fireball seconds later, law enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: In a Far-Flung Empire, Some Winners, Losers and Works in Progress;Independence Day For 20th Century Fox
description: Rupert Murdoch's empire spreads across six continents and includes books, magazines, newspapers, broadcasting, satellite televison, cable and a movie studio. The following is a glimpse at how some parts of that empire are doing as Mr. Murdoch engages in a frenzy of new expansion aimed at locking up both programming and distribution outlets around the world.

title: Sports of The Times;When a Park Is Something More
description: ON the perimeter of Centennial Olympic Park here yesterday, in a steady afternoon rain, Vic Catechis put a hand on the shoulder of a man who huddled under an umbrella next to his wife.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Music;Kirov Ends Its Bold Run With a Stravinsky Fling
description: Valery Gergiyev and the Kirov Orchestra and Chorus of St. Petersburg, Russia, flirted with ordinariness at the end of their four-concert stand in the Lincoln Center Festival '96 on Friday evening but, true to form, left it in the lurch.

title: In a Far-Flung Empire, Some Winners, Losers and Works in Progress;For TV in China, The Problem Is Ads
description: Rupert Murdoch's empire spreads across six continents and includes books, magazines, newspapers, broadcasting, satellite televison, cable and a movie studio. The following is a glimpse at how some parts of that empire are doing as Mr. Murdoch engages in a frenzy of new expansion aimed at locking up both programming and distribution outlets around the world.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;Pop Veterans, Still Giving, Still Taking
description: In the mercurial world of pop music, surviving (while remaining relevant) can be a form of genius. This makes the Isley Brothers, who performed on Saturday night at the Theater at Madison Square Garden, as close to genius as any other pop act. After more than 40 years of performing -- moving from rhythm-and-blues party anthems in the late 50's and 60's to bedroom ballads in the 70's -- they still have music all over the pop charts. This includes not only albums and singles they make music on (their new record, "Mission to Please" on T-Neck/Island; R. Kelly's Jeep anthem "Down Low"; Quincy Jones's "Q's Jook Joint" album, and the soundtrack to "Friday") but also recordings they influenced, by everyone from the Beatles to Bone Thugs-N-Harmony to Boyz II Men.

title: Foreman Plans Return to Ring
description: George Foreman, who has not fought in 15 months, said yesterday he would return to the ring with a fight in Japan on Sept. 15.

title: POP REVIEW;Sounds of Classic Rock Up From the Underground
description: Chavez, a New York underground-rock quartet, is lunging for the overground. With a clobbering, classic-rock disposition and the singer Matt Sweeney's anguished stage presence, the band's jumbo gestures feel mannered in a small club. Consciously or not, it's practicing for the coliseums.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10: ROUNDUP -- ARCHERY;Records Fall
description: South Koreans set one world record and tied another in team preliminaries at Stone Mountain, Ga.

title: Market Place;Hambrecht & Quist shows faith in the Nasdaq by proceeding with an initial offering of its own.
description: WITH the market hellbent on learning to hula these days, many investment bankers have advised clients preparing a public stock offering to head for the sidelines and wait.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10: ROUNDUP -- FIELD HOCKEY;American Woes
description: In women's play, Australia, led by the sisters Katrina and Lisa Powell, scored all of its goals in the first 24 minutes and beat the United States, 4-0.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Enter The Queen, The King, Whoever, Bald and In a Caftan
description: Phaedra" is the title of the Ridiculous Theatrical Company's very bizarre and risky new production, which opened last night at the Theater for the New City, but Everett Quinton, the star and adapter of the piece, takes his time easing the audience back to ancient Greece. It's almost as if he were avoiding the evening's moment of truth.

title: Town Cheers Football And Its Volunteerism
description: This is Pro Football Hall of Fame Week in Canton, an annual festival with a fine, small-town feel that includes three nights of fireworks, two parades, a downtown street fair, a hot-air balloon competition, a Marine Band concert, an Air Force Band concert, an Eddie Money concert, "the largest fashion show luncheon in Ohio," and finally, on Saturday, the opener of the exhibition season, and the big moment, the induction of five former stars into the football-shaped Hall of Fame here.

title: World News Briefs;China Sets Off Atom Test, Then Invokes Moratorium
description: China conducted an underground nuclear test today, then promised it would join a moratorium on such tests as of Tuesday. The announcement came only hours before the resumption of negotiations in Geneva for a global test ban treaty.

title: Equal Time for Nonsense
description: Four months ago, when his Presidential campaign still seemed viable, Patrick Buchanan appeared on a national television program and argued in favor of creationism. This, by itself, is not so remarkable, given some of Mr. Buchanan's other views.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: ON THE WATER;From Debris, a Carving 'Really Got' to Searchers
description: In a week of sweeping the Atlantic over the wreckage of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, the crew of the Driftmaster, an Army Corps of Engineers vessel, retrieved all manner of debris: seat cushions, children's sneakers, life vests.

title: Microsoft's Latest Web Venture: Making Critical Mass to Pay
description: The Microsoft Corporation's plan to fold World Wide Web capabilities into the company's Windows 95 PC operating system software is in many ways similar to technology under development by other companies, including Apple Computer Inc. and the Netscape Communications Corporation.

title: Economic Calender
description: Expected dates for the release of major economic inicators this week.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10: ROUNDUP -- VOLLEYBALL;U.S. Places 2d in Pool
description: Another powerful performance by the captain, Tara Cross-Battle, and exceptional bench play led the United States women to a 10-15, 15-13, 15-9, 15-3 victory over South Korea yesterday that clinched second place in Pool A.

title: Hard Times for Millions As Argentina Slims Down
description: When Francisco Pena, a 48-year-old mechanic, hears talk of the "economic miracle" that Domingo Cavallo performed in Argentina as Finance Minister, he shakes his head and wonders if he is living in the same country.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS;Bombing Victim's Home Is Burglarized
description: One day after Alice Hawthorne was killed by the bomb in Atlanta's Centennial Olympic Park, someone burglarized her home, police said today.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Workers to be Deported
description: On Friday, dozens of laborers at the Mitzel Corporation garment factory in North Bergen showed up for their morning shift. Today, 33 of them will be deported and flown back to Mexico. The 33 workers were among 52 who were detained in a raid on Friday at what immigration officials described as a sweatshop. The other 19 workers, who did not agree to be deported, are awaiting deportation hearings.

title: World News Briefs;Serbian Protesters Ask Delay in Croatia Rule
description: Several thousand Serbs demonstrated today in the last Serbian-held enclave in Croatia, demanding a delay in a scheduled transition to Croatian rule.

title: What Went Wrong at SUNY? Departed Chancellor Speaks
description: It was late 1994 when Thomas A. Bartlett came out of a brief retirement. He sold off his cattle, leased his Oregon farm and set out for the East Coast to take the reins of the State University of New York. Eighteen months later, some would say a bit sore from the bumpy ride, he abruptly handed the reins back.

title: THE CLINTON RECORD: Foreign Policy;Bosnia Policy Shaped by U.S. Military Role
description: Two snapshots of Bill Clinton capture his decision to come to terms with the foreign policy crisis that has dominated his Presidency: Bosnia.

title: ATLANTA DAY 10: ROUNDUP -- SOCCER;Brazil to Semifinal
description: Brazil, which has never won a gold medal in men's soccer despite four World Cup titles, moved a step closer to ending that drought.

title: Terrorism Must Not Drive Us Behind a Wall;Spending Scare Tactics
description: To the Editor:

title: Behind Screens
description: One of the vestigial pleasures in an un-air-conditioned summer is looking at the world through a window screen. During a hot dusk in the suburbs, whole families seat themselves inside screen-tents marshaled on lawns, looking for all the world like occupants of the human habitat at the zoo. Are the bugs that bad? Or is there a special pleasure in feeling enclosed but unenclosed, in looking at the world with a new granularity?

title: Jewish Studies
description: To the Editor:

title: OLYMPIC ARTS REVIEW/Dance;Energy to Try Just About Anything
description: The Olympic Arts Festival presentation of the Phoenix Dance Company here on Saturday afternoon opened, as did all festival performances that day, with a moment of silence for the victims of the bombing at Centennial Olympic Park early that morning. But the performance that followed softened the gloom. Phoenix, based in Leeds, England, is a strong, vibrant modern-dance company with a thought-provoking repertory and history.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Jets' Smith Welcomes Challenge
description: Otis Smith is hoping he can get off to the same type of start he had last season. The 30-year-old cornerback had an interception in each of the Jets' first four games and finished the season with a team-high six.

title: Howard Fried, 75, Tenor and Physicist
description: Howard Fried, a tenor in supporting roles with several major American opera companies, died on July 10 at a hospital in San Diego. He was 75 and lived in East San Diego.

title: Terrorism Must Not Drive Us Behind a Wall
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Ashes of Arson at Kiryas Joel, Tensions of Bitter Factionalism
description: For Jewish mothers and their newborns from New York City and as far away as Toronto and Montreal, the Hilltop Maternity-Convalescent Center was a serene haven for recovery from childbirth. And for new mothers in this Hasidic village of 12,000 ultra-Orthodox Satmars, the center offered a few days' respite from the nasty political and religious infighting that years ago split Kiryas Joel into two angry camps. It was a neutral sanctuary, open to all regardless of their loyalties in the squabble dividing the village's neighborhoods.

title: TELEVISION REVIEW;Tasteless, Infuriating and Successful
description: A bit of commiseration, please, with the reviewer for a family newspaper faced with writing about anything to do with Howard Stern, superstar of shock schlock. Hedged in by the proprieties, how is one to convey the, uh, flavor of shticks about body parts, functions and aromas?

title: World News Briefs;Bosnian Serbs Press Case To Indict Muslim Leader
description: A Bosnian Serb delegation seeking war crimes charges against the President of Bosnia met today with officials at the Yugoslav war crimes tribunal.

title: Doctor and Wife Accused of Insurance Fraud on L.I. Home and Yacht
description: After their 46-foot yacht sank in Long Island Sound two years ago and their waterfront home burned down in September, Dr. Arthur Graff, a prominent plastic surgeon, and his wife, Marnette, decided to build a new life in North Carolina.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Trolley Work to Begin
description: The Hudson-Bergen Light Rail Transit System, the state's largest mass transit project, is on its way to becoming a reality. A contractor has been selected for the first phase of the $1.1 billion trolley system, which will link trains, buses and ferries along the Hudson River waterfront, and work is expected to begin later this summer, officials said yesterday.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- BASEBALL;Cuba Stays Unbeaten
description: Orestes Kindelan hit his tournament-record seventh homer as Cuba defeated Nicaragua, 8-7, in Atlanta. Cuba (7-0) will be the top-seeded team in medals-round play, which begins Thursday, with the United States second. Nicaragua (4-3) qualified, and the final berth is still open. Pairings will be determined today.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- NOTEBOOK;Armstrong Thinking Time Trial
description: The American road race team was put together to give the cyclist Lance Armstrong a shot at a gold medal. Nothing against his teammates, but Armstrong said he was more excited about Saturday's individual time trial than for Wednesday's road race.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- TABLE TENNIS;Chinese Win Doubles
description: Deng Yapeng of China took the first step toward a second straight singles-doubles sweep yesterday, teaming with Qiao Hong to win the women's doubles gold medal.

title: A Reasonable Response to Terror
description: Terrorist attacks like the weekend bombing in Atlanta understandably generate pressure to give law enforcement agencies enhanced investigative powers. The measure of wise leadership in Washington is whether the White House and Congress can resist the temptation to lunge for superficially attractive proposals that would undermine the liberties and privacy of Americans.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11;Smooth Sailing for Brazilians
description: With their teams locked in a tie, Torben Grael and Marcelo Ferreira of Brazil and Colin Beashel and David Giles of Australia began dueling at the start of the final Star race off Savannah, Ga., today. But when Beashel started prematurely, Grael knew he had won the gold. Beashel's error also cost him the silver, which instead was won by Sweden's Hans Wallen and Bobbie Lohse. The Australians finished third.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Argentine Financial Markets Hold Steady
description: Argentina received a much-needed vote of confidence today as its financial markets remained steady, defying dire predictions that investors would abandon the debt-pressed country after the ouster of its Finance Minister, Domingo Cavallo, last week.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Accounts
description: David's Bridal, Ardmore, Pa., to W. B. Doner & Co., Baltimore, to handle media planning and buying for the retailer's account, with billings estimated at $3 million to $5 million. Those duties had been handled by Harmelin & Associates, Philadelphia. The creative part is handled in-house.

title: World News Briefs;18 Remain Critically Ill After Protest in Turkey
description: Eighteen Turkish prisoners remained critically ill today following a two-month hunger strike that ended over the weekend, human rights workers said.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;A New World Brought to You by . . .
description: TAKE cover! The paradigms are shifting again.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- NOTEBOOK;Clark Wears Wrong Clothes
description: Mary Ellen Clark, who won the bronze medal in diving, has been reprimanded by the United States Olympic Committee for wearing the wrong outfit during her award ceremony.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: SOCCER;Top Price for Transfer
description: In what is believed to be the largest transfer fee in soccer history, the English star ALAN SHEARER was sold by Blackburn to Newcastle yesterday for $23.25 million.

title: Britain and Ireland Agree to Revive the Peace Talks on Ulster
description: Two weeks after violence swept across Northern Ireland, the British and Irish Governments and Protestant and Roman Catholic political leaders reported progress today toward reviving talks on the British province.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- TV SPORTS;Taped Confessions, Live From NBC
description: With Bob Costas's words Sunday night "What you saw moments ago" -- and the implicit admission that the action shown had been taped, NBC surrendered the central tenet of its Summer Olympic coverage, that not everything is being broadcast live as you see it. The admission of the use of videotape! Costas might as well have admitted that John Tesh, not Whittaker Chambers, possessed the Pumpkin Papers!

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Crossing Party Lines
description: Both candidates to succeed Senator Bill Bradley are trotting out endorsements from members of the opposing party. Last week, Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of Englewood, announced that he had the support of several Republicans from Bergen County, including John F. Zisa, the Mayor of Hackensack; Larry McClure, a former county prosecutor, and John A. Steuert Jr., a former Mayor of Maywood. Yesterday, the Republican candidate, Representative Richard A. Zimmer of Delaware Township, discussed Democratic endorsements from Mayor Thomas G. Dunn of Elizabeth and John Connor, former executive director of the Democratic State Committee.

title: For Gay Men, A Cultural Change?
description: To the Editor:

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE MOOD;Bomb Scares Increase in New York and Around the Nation, as a New Edginess Is Found
description: The explosion on Trans World Airlines Flight 800 and the bombing in Atlanta appear to have put Americans on edge. In recent days, there have been dozens of evacuations because of bomb scares, as otherwise ordinary events suddenly seemed dangerous.

title: Mass Extinction Of Permian Era Linked to a Gas
description: AROUND 250 million years ago, something so devastating occurred that about 90 percent of Earth's animal species were wiped out. While the cause of this greatest of all mass extinctions remains uncertain, a new study by biologists and geochemists suggests that a huge upwelling of carbonated water from the depths of the oceans may have played a lethal role.

title: Shock Upstate At Dismissal Of Negotiator On Watershed
description: Upstate leaders who reached agreement with the city last year on a historic pact to protect New York City's water supply expressed surprise and dismay yesterday at Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's dismissal of Marilyn G. Gelber as Commissioner of the city's Department of Environmental Protection.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;In His 13th Season, Clifton Knows the Angles
description: It is odd to think of Kyle Clifton as a necessary link to a better Jets past, but the team likes having him here, for his presence as well as his play.

title: Stocks Lower in Japan
description: Stocks were lower here today. At midday, the Nikkei index of 225 issues stood at 20,815.31, down 152.23 points, or 0.73 percent. On Monday, the index fell 157.36 points.

title: Hopes Are Rosy On Alzheimer's, But Results Slim
description: THE researchers who study Alzheimer's disease are a relentlessly upbeat bunch. They are on the verge, they say, of finding a way to diagnose the disease with a simple blood test. Quite soon, they say, they will turn up a way to delay its onset or slow its course. Any day now, they say, drugs will emerge that prevent the disease in people who would otherwise get it.

title: COMPANY NEWS;SHARES OF SUNGLASS HUT INTERNATIONAL DECLINE 15%
description: The shares of Sunglass Hut International Inc. fell 15 percent yesterday as investors reacted to fears about declining same-store sales and earnings, analysts said. Shares in the company, a retailer of prescription and nonprescription sunglasses that is based in Coral Gables, Fla., fell $1.875, to $10.75, in trading of 6.74 million shares, more than six times the three-month daily average. It was its lowest closing price since January 1995.

title: Pity the Perils of the Birth Experience;Women and Childbirth
description: To the Editor:

title: American Exchange Cuts Jobs and Costs
description: The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that it would eliminate 50 jobs and consolidate administrative duties to cut costs.

title: For Gay Men, A Cultural Change?;Safety Agreements
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- TEAM HANDBALL;U.S. Men Lose Again
description: The United States men's team, still searching for its first victory in this tournament, kept the score close for a half before collapsing after intermission and losing to Switzerland, 29-20, in Atlanta.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: LEGISLATION;Bipartisan Panel to Frame An Anti-Terrorism Package
description: President Clinton and Congressional leaders agreed today to work quickly to pass additional measures to combat terrorism, perhaps before Congress leaves for summer recess at the end of the week. But after an hourlong meeting, it was clear that Republican leaders and the White House remained divided over specifics.

title: The Faltering Metrocard Sets Transit Officials Scampering
description: When the Metrocard was first introduced to New York City subway riders in 1994, transit officials were confident that riders would accept it as a convenient alternative to the token. In fact, they were so confident of this new technology that they decided against offering fare discounts to use it, and did little marketing to promote its use.

title: COMPANY NEWS;FOUNDATION HEALTH SHARES FALL AS EARNINGS RISE
description: The stock of the Foundation Health Corporation fell yesterday, even though the company released earnings in line with Wall Street estimates. The company said that its fourth-quarter earnings rose 12 percent, citing one-time gains from the sale of two independent practice associations and lower taxes. The company, based in Rancho Cordova, Calif., operates managed-health-care plans. It said its net income rose to $43.6 million, or 74 cents a share, from $38.8 million, or 68 cents, a year ago. Wall Street had been expecting earnings of 74 cents. Shares of Foundation fell $1.875, to $25.875.

title: Kronos Cancels Performance Of Feldman Quartet No. 2
description: The Kronos Quartet has canceled its performance of Morton Feldman's String Quartet No. 2, saying that its players are no longer up to the physical demands of the uninterrupted six-hour work. The performance, scheduled at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday at 5 P.M., was to have been the centerpiece of a Feldman retrospective at the Lincoln Center Festival '96.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- NOTEBOOK;Jordan Says Hello and Pushes Briefs
description: Promoting his latest line of designer underwear, Michael Jordan made a stop at the Olympics today and said it would take the rest of the basketball world at least another 10 years before it could begin to compete with the United States.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Japan's Tack On Trade: No More 1-on-1
description: In the seemingly endless trade frictions between Japan and the United States, Tokyo is taking a different tack. In short, it is telling United States trade officials: We have got to stop meeting like this.

title: 'Resting Room' in Tokyo:Rent-a-Nap in Private
description: TOKYO  A Japanese television crew has brought its own "salaryman," a weary-looking fellow who appears to be in his 40s.They position him between rows of men's suits and have him act as if he is doing a little shopping.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bass Seeks Stake In Beer Venture
description: Bass P.L.C. said yesterday that it was in talks to buy a 50 percent stake in the Carlsberg-Tetley brewing venture, a move that would reinstate Bass as Britain's largest brewer. The announcement followed reports in the British press that Bass wanted to buy all or part of Carlsberg-Tetley, a joint venture between Allied Domecq of Britain and Carlsberg A.S. of Denmark.

title: HORSE RACING;Fourstardave Reigns Once Again at Saratoga
description: They even named the race for him, the Fourstardave, and he came out of benign retirement on the backstretch at the age of 11 to preside over it, the star of Saratoga seasons past, leading the 13 other horses in the post parade like a grand marshal, watching them run from the chute alongside the grass course and coming back later to the winner's circle when the trophy was presented to Da Hoss today.

title: Cast-off U.S. Jeans Are Prized Items
description: OMAHA, Nebraska  Cheryl Sellhorst sat in her car in the gas station parking lot,waiting for Nebraskans to bring their cast-off Levi's jeans.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- TRACK AND FIELD;The Greatest? Lewis Not Ready to Step Aside
description: Michael Johnson won a medal at 400 meters tonight to match his golden shoes, but he will have to wait to win the title as the world's greatest track and field athlete. Carl Lewis upstaged Johnson at the Summer Olympics with his fourth consecutive victory in the long jump and his record-tying ninth gold medal in his Olympic career. He is 35 now, but conceding nothing in these golden years.

title: Opponents of Indecency Rules On Internet Win Another Case
description: Adding emphasis to an earlier decision that affirmed First Amendment rights in cyberspace, a panel of three Federal judges in New York ruled unanimously yesterday that the Government's efforts to halt indecent material on the Internet were unconstitutionally broad.

title: Pataki Names Former Dancer to Arts Post
description: A former dancer and former state arts administrator in Vermont, Nicolette Clarke, has been named executive director of the New York State Council on the Arts, filling a post vacant since March 1995, Gov. George E. Pataki announced yesterday. The agency this year is to distribute $32 million -- $3 million more than in 1995 -- to about 1,200 groups statewide.

title: COMAPNY REPORTS;GRACE (W. R.) & CO. (GRA,N)
description: W. R. Grace & Company reported yesterday that second-quarter net income more than quadrupled, to $333.9 million, after extraordinary items, compared with profits of $78.7 million in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- DIVING;Chinese Men Take Gold and Silver
description: China continued its domination of world diving tonight as Xiong Ni and Yu Zhuocheng took turns holding the lead, before Xiong won the gold medal in the springboard.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Citrus Account Goes To Richards Group
description: The Florida Department of Citrus said yesterday that it had reassigned its account, with billings estimated at $25 million, to the Richards Group in Dallas. The decision came four days after Ammirati Puris Lintas in New York unexpectedly resigned the account, which that agency had been awarded only five months ago.

title: Mayor Thrives on Political Theater
description: Almost every Saturday after his regular soccer match, Mayor Yuri M. Luzhkov leaps into his black Volga limousine and speeds in a police convoy to construction sites across the metropolitan region to give local administrators a taste of his inimitable style of hands-on governance.

title: 2 Killed at Mosque in India
description: A grenade exploded inside a Muslim shrine today, killing two people and wounding 100 others. In another attack, a bomb in a wooden cart blew up in a market, wounding 25 people, as celebrations were being held for Mohammed's birthday.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;Honda to Import Civics Into U.S.
description: The Honda Motor Company said today that it would import Japanese-built Civic sedans into the United States for the first time in a year because of strong demand for the small cars.

title: Metro Digest
description: THE CRASH

title: COMPANY NEWS;HANGER ORTHOPEDIC IN DEAL FOR J. E. HANGER
description: Hanger Orthopedic Group Inc., which operates rehabilitation clinics, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy J. E. Hanger Inc., an orthotic and prosthetic services company, for $49 million in cash and stock. The acquisition would create the country's largest orthotic and prosthetic management company, with revenue of more than $110 million, the companies said. Under the terms of the agreement, Hanger Orthopedic, which is based in Bethesda, Md., plans to pay $44 million in cash and one million shares of its common stock for all of the shares of J. E. Hanger, a closely held company based in Alpharetta, Ga. Though the companies are unrelated, both trace their origins to James Edward Hanger, the first amputee of the American Civil War, who was instrumental in the early manufacture of artificial limbs for wounded war veterans, the companies said.

title: Powerful but Ill-Defined : Rising India Middle Class
description: NEW DELHI  More than fiveyears ago, when India was shaken by a foreign resources crunch, it shrugged off its socialist image, liberalized its economic policies and opened its arms to foreign capital.

title: Olympic Terrorism
description: To the Editor:

title: The City Gets Bigger, Better Hospitals
description: The announced merger between New York Hospital and Presbyterian Hospital is the third proposed union involving New York City's large hospitals in seven weeks. The medical centers at New York University and Mount Sinai have already decided to join forces, as have the Beth Israel and Long Island Jewish medical centers. Where dozens of not-for-profit hospitals once operated in the city, six to eight networks seem likely to emerge.

title: BASEBALL;An Era Concludes in the Dodgers' Dugout As Lasorda Steps Down After 2 Decades
description: Tom Lasorda, who was planning to manage the Los Angeles Dodgers for infinity, retired today at the age of 68.

title: ROCK REVIEW;Gentler Post-Punk Shenanigans
description: If time heals all wounds, it also opens all ears. Bands that began their career more than a decade ago making idiosyncratic, uncompromising rock are discovering that they have not been working in vain: in addition to influencing scores of other groups, their music is finally being embraced by a mainstream audience. This has been especially true of inventive psychedelic bands like the Flaming Lips, the Meat Puppets and the Butthole Surfers, all of which had their first hit singles in the past few years.

title: Cray's Battle Might Be for A Lost Era
description: Cray Research Inc. formally opened a trade battle over supercomputers yesterday, charging that the NEC Corporation had unfairly won a Federal contract by "dumping" its machine on the market at a price below the cost of building it. But unless Cray moves nimbly, it may find itself making the old soldier's mistake of fighting the last war.

title: BASEBALL;Pettitte Plays Down Talk of a Cy Young Award
description: Andy Pettitte claimed that when he pulls on his uniform for his start tonight against the Texas Rangers, the possibility of winning the Cy Young Award will not float into his mind.

title: Chess
description: Almost everyone believes that Garry Kasparov, the Professional Chess Association's world champion, is the strongest player on earth. But where he used to reign like a lion tamer who holds the beasts firmly in their places around the ring, he cannot turn his back now without one or another taking a swipe at him.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Review Announced By USA Networks
description: USA Networks said yesterday that it had placed its account in review after 12 years at Messner Vetere Berger McNamee Schmetterer Euro RSCG in New York, which resigned instead of participating. Billings were estimated at $12 million.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- WEIGHT LIFTING;Ukrainian Sets Record
description: Timur Taimazov of Ukraine broke his own clean-and-jerk world record on his way to the gold medal in the 238-pound class in Atlanta.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- TENNIS;Seles's Dream of Gold Snuffed Out by Novotna
description: This was not a round that was supposed to separate Monica Seles from what had appeared to be her Olympic destiny. In fact, that round did not exist in the mind of the top-seeded Seles, who didn't need to spell out her designs on a gold medal. Let other people wear their hearts on their sleeve. Seles prefers to wear a champion's instinct to cut to the quick of whatever competition she lands in.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Prices for Natural Gas Drop As Stockpiles Begin to Grow
description: Natural gas prices tumbled on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesteday, as cooler weather eased demand from utilities and allowed more gas to be stockpiled.

title: Jury Weighs Verdict In Slaying of Girl, 12
description: The fate of the man who killed Polly Klaas was put in the hands of a jury today after a prosecutor demanded justice while a defense lawyer begged for mercy for her client.

title: COMAPNY REPORTS;2 Savings Institutions to Join In $1.2 Billion CalFed Deal
description: First Nationwide Bank FSB has agreed to buy Cal Fed Bancorp for $1.2 billion in cash, or $23.50 a share, combining two of California's biggest savings institutions, the two companies said today.

title: 8 in Anti-Government Group Are Arrested on Bomb Charges
description: The founder of an anti-Government group, the Washington State Militia, and seven other people have been arrested for conspiracy to make explosives, Federal authorities said today.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 Dynamic Duo on the Track
description: TRACK AND FIELD

title: New Leader of Burundi: Authoritarian Democrat
description: Perhaps the best indication that Pierre Buyoya is telling the truth about being reluctant to be appointed President again in last week's coup was what his wife did that morning.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: TV Broadcasters Agree to 3 Hours of Children's Educational Programs a Week
description: Under political pressure to reach accord before President Clinton convened a White House conference on children's television this morning, negotiators for the broadcast industry agreed early today to a compromise that would require stations to show three hours of children's educational programming a week.

title: AGREEMENT STRUCK ON MOST ELEMENTS FOR WELFARE BILL
description: House and Senate negotiators said today that they had reached agreement on most provisions of a welfare bill they will send to President Clinton. On several issues, it appears, they have disregarded his appeals for changes in the legislation.

title: Ex-Pianist Seeks Harmony as Landlord;Keeping Peace Among Supers and Tenants Is Her New Challenge
description: Pieces of Claudette Sorel's past surround her, each in its proper place.

title: Cups, Pots and Rituals:Hong Kong Museum Traces All the Tea in China
description: HONG KONG  Whatever differences exist between the British and the Chinese, one belief has never been challenged by either: a cup of tea is more than just a cup of tea.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Top Pick Irks Giants By Arriving Late, Hurt
description: When Cedric Jones took part in his first practice today, he looked a little lost. That's understandable. Being lost and being a National Football League rookie go together like Richard Nixon and Watergate. But the Giants were a little surprised when Jones told them he had a hamstring pull. Actually, surprised might not be the word. And the fallout from the injury was just the beginning of what was a wild day for Jones, the team's No. 1 draft pick.

title: POLITICS;Party Certifies Race: It's Perot vs. Lamm
description: The Reform Party certified Ross Perot and Richard D. Lamm today to face each other for the party's Presidential nomination, although some Lamm supporters complained that the selection process was tilted in Mr. Perot's favor.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;Bond Prices Drop Sharply Ahead of Data
description: Prices of Treasury securities dropped sharply yesterday as investors braced for a blizzard of new economic data this week.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: Jason E. Klein, senior vice president of Times Mirror Magazines, New York, and president of its Field & Stream and Outdoor Life titles, was named to an additional new post, president of Today's Homeowner, formerly Home Mechanix. Michael Rooney, publisher of Field & Stream and Outdoor Life, was also named to an additional new post, group publisher of Today's Homeowner. John Young, publisher of Home Mechanix, becomes publisher of Today's Homeowner.

title: Sketch Is Compiled In Atlanta Attack
description: The authorities have compiled a sketch of the man they believe planted a bomb that killed one woman at the Olympics in Atlanta, a Federal law-enforcement official said.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS;Dollar Is Steady as Traders Await Week's Economic Data
description: The dollar was little changed yesterday despite news of a decline in Japanese industrial production and comments from a Bundesbank official that German interest rates could be cut further.

title: Corrections
description: An article on July 20 about the struggle for reinstatement by a dismissed Federal regulator of credit unions misidentified the legal framework that governs the replacement of credit union regulators whose terms have expired. It is the Federal Credit Union Act, not agency bylaws.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Nader Petitions Are Filed
description: Leaders of a committee formed to put Ralph Nader's name on the Presidential ballot in New Jersey as the candidate of the Green Party said yesterday that they had gathered 2,994 signatures, well beyond the 800 needed. The petitions will be turned over to the Secretary of State's office so that the signatures can be verified.

title: No Headline
description: We're reopening a park but we're also rekindling or restoring the faith in the Olympic dream and the American dream. The truth is that people are ready. Nothing has brought this city together like this attack." ANDREW YOUNG, Former Atlanta mayor who is co-chairman of the Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games [C18:1.]

title: The West Caters to Eastern Palates
description: PARIS  McDonald's and Pizza Hut may have made beachheads in every Asian capital, but making Western foods palatable to highly traditional Japanese and South Korean tastes can still be tough.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- BASKETBALL;American Women Respond To Call
description: The motion, the screens and the pass work all came from a time when basketball was played in cages, not domes. The high-arching shots -- feet planted, hands held chest high, nets barely rippling -- belonged to the days of grainy, black and white images.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Norway Merger Deal In Oilfield Supplies
description: Two of Norway's main suppliers to the oil industry, the oil and gas technology unit of Aker A.S. and the Maritime Group, said yesterday that they had approved a proposal to merge and form a new company, Aker Maritime A.S. The merged company would have sales of about 10 billion kroner ($1.6 billion) this year. It will be listed on the Oslo bourse as soon as the merger is completed, probably in November.

title: Johnson & Johnson Fights to Retain Its H.I.V. Test Unit
description: Johnson & Johnson filed suit today, seeking to overturn an arbitrator's ruling that it must hand control of its H.I.V. home-testing business back to an executive whom the arbitrator said the company had wrongfully dismissed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Put down your rotary-dial phone and listen up: Women are big buyers of high-tech products.
description: THERE was once a time when the image of women using technology was best represented by a telephone operator. Though that picture has become as outdated as rotary dialing, many agencies and advertisers involved in selling technology products still seem to perceive women as secondary or subordinate to men, as evidenced by a preponderance of male images populating hardware and software campaigns.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-6

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- MEN'S VOLLEYBALL;U.S. Is Eliminated
description: The string of Olympic medals won by the United States men's volleyball team came to a stunning end last night when it was knocked out by a 1-2 foreign punch. First, brawny Bulgaria won a dramatic fifth-set tie breaker over the Americans to take one of the final two quarterfinal spots in Pool A. Then, with some Americans watching from the stands, Brazil, the defending gold medalist, grabbed the final spot with a straight-set victory over Cuba, which had clinched the top seeding in Pool A.

title: Pity the Perils of the Birth Experience
description: To the Editor:

title: Destructive Engagement in Myanmar
description: The Burmese dissident leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi's quiet eloquence and courage have always spoken louder than her Government's attempts to silence her. But last week that Government won a double victory over the dissident. Her voice, it seems, cannot be heard over the rustle of money.

title: Patterns
description: New Barneys Catalogue

title: Clinton Is Seeking Some Limited Goals
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Clinton, conducted on July 8 with reporters and editors of The New York Times:

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- GYMNASTICS;Miller Goes Out a Stylish Champion on the Balance Beam
description: It was Shannon Miller's last chance at one of the few prizes missing from her Oklahoma trophy case: an individual Olympic gold medal.

title: Observer;Cheer at the Grocery
description: While waiting for terrorists to turn the country into a police state, I keep my chin up by reading morale-boosting literature. This used to be People magazine, but now it's the grocery tabloids. Grocery journalism and People operate on opposing theories of how to make humanity feel better, and People's theory no longer works for me.

title: COMPANY NEWS;BEN FRANKLIN RETAIL STORES FILES BANKRUPTCY PETITION
description: Ben Franklin Retail Stores Inc. said yesterday that it had filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The company, which operates a crafts retail chain, said the filing would not affect two other units, the Ben Franklin Insurance Agency and Auto Artistry business. Ben Franklin, based in Carol Stream, Ill., made the filing in Bankruptcy Court in the Northern District of Illinois. In the fiscal year that ended on March 31, the company lost $27.1 million, or $4.95 a share, on sales of $374.7 million.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;A Commentator on the Receiving End
description: The departure of Joe Klein from CBS News, after being revealed as the prevaricating author of "Primary Colors" (you finally said it was so, Joe), draws attention to the job of television commentator. Being bumped out of such a sinecure is cruel punishment. Amnesty International, where are you when Joe Klein needs you?

title: Summary of Major Actions in the 219th Session of the Legislature
description: The New York State Legislature concluded its 219th session at 5:28 P.M. on July 13 in a mad, confusing rush to adjournment, as Gov. George E. Pataki linked final negotiations on the state budget to many nonbudget bills.

title: For This Postal Route, Mailmen Need Sea Legs
description: Charles F. Wundrach gave the black metal wheel a twist and gently steered this 40-foot tugboat alongside the towering, 700-foot-long iron ore freighter steaming up the Detroit River between the steel mills of Detroit and a concrete factory in Windsor, Ontario.

title: Moscow's Raid on Sin Leaves The Biggest Stones Unturned
description: A chill wind of rectitude is sweeping this city, which simmers with vodka, licentiousness and vice.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Outlandish Hollywood Doings (Some Are Fiction)
description: HIT AND RUN How Jon Peters and Peter Guber Took Sony for a Ride in Hollywood By Nancy Griffin and Kim Masters 479 pages. Simon & Schuster. $25.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KMART PLANS TO REORGANIZE ITS MERCHANDISING UNIT
description: The Kmart Corporation, the struggling retailer, said yesterday that it was reorganizing the way its merchandisers buy goods, in an effort to cut costs. The company, based in Troy, Mich., said that its general merchandise managers would be provided with a team of experts in planning, sales, advertising, finance and product development. Under the new structure, rather than each buyer making decisions for each order placed, experts in apparel product development and international sourcing would determine where best to make the garments, Warren Flick, president of merchandising for Kmart, said.

title: World News Briefs;U.S. Agrees to Lease Jordan F-16 Fighter Jets
description: The United States signed an agreement with Jordan today to lease it 16 F-16 fighter jets.

title: Vineyards Planned In China and India : Italian Firm Puts Wager On Wine
description: VICENZA, Italy  Nestling unobtrusively among neat terraces of vines in the foothills just west of this attractive town in northeastern Italy, Gambellara has a deceptively sleepy air. From outside, the central winery buildings look much like many others in this part of the world.

title: On My Mind;The Realities of Terrorism
description: Domestic terrorism is treason. International terrorism is war. It is the duty of every democratic nation to protect itself and its people from both. Until Western governments do so before, during and after the commission of terrorism, and let its perpetrators know they always will, terrorism will continue. So far these governments have taken some steps against domestic terrorism but in total insufficient. Against international terrorism the West has failed to act with any efficacy at all. The chief reason is that trade profits have become more important to Western society than human lives or even national stability and safety.

title: Rights Suit Voided in Rape Case
description: A Federal district judge has dismissed a woman's suit against two football players at Virginia Polytechnic Institute, declaring unconstitutional a law allowing women who allege rape to sue those they accuse for civil-rights violations.

title: Sunbeam Hires More Executives
description: The new chairman and chief executive of the Sunbeam Corporation, Albert J. Dunlap, continued overhauling the company's management yesterday by naming two executives to newly created posts.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: A Gene for Hair Growth
description: An international research team has isolated a gene involved with hair growth, which may provide clues to the treatment of baldness.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: THE INVESTIGATION;The Bomb's Aftermath: The Search for Clues
description: After a bombing, investigators try to recover every piece of the bomb because "there's a lot left and it tells you a lot about the motivation, sophistication, design and background" of the bomb and the person who made it, said Brian Jenkins of Kroll Associates, an investigative and consulting company. Here are some of the things investigators can learn from bomb fragments.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: THE INVESTIGATION;F.B.I. Says It Has Sketch of Atlanta Bombing Suspect
description: As Atlantans prepared for an emotional reopening of Centennial Olympic Park on Tuesday, the authorities have compiled a sketch of the man they believe planted a pipe bomb that killed one woman and cast a pall over the 1996 Summer Olympics, a Federal law enforcement official said today.

title: Exporters Scramble To Find Their Niches : The World Vies to Feed Asia's Rich
description: HONG KONG  On Wednesday once a month in Picton, New Zealand, 100 kilograms (220 pounds) of salmon, pulled from their watery pens that morning, are gutted, scaled, carved up and packed in ice and put on the next day's morning flight to Hong Kong.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Raid at Housing Project
description: More than 100 officers from the F.B.I., the United States Marshal's office, and the state and local police raided a housing project in Atlantic City early yesterday, arresting 14 people and putting the last of three violent drug-dealing gangs out of business, the authorities said. Among those arrested were Darryl Williams and Curtis Shelton, both 33, whom the police identified as the leaders of the the Pitneys, The Associated Press reported. Since last year, the police taken action against two other gangs based in housing projects.

title: COMPANY NEWS;REEBOK TO BUY BACK UP TO 24 MILLION SHARES
description: Reebok International Ltd. said yesterday that it planned to buy back up to 24 million shares -- about 33 percent of its outstanding shares -- for $30 to $36 a share. Reebok, the maker of athletic shoes and clothing based in Stoughton, Mass., said the offer, known as a Dutch auction, would begin today and would expire on Aug. 27. Under a Dutch auction, shareholders offer to sell a number of shares at a specific price within the stated range. Reebok would then determine a final price to repurchase up to the 24 million shares from those shareholders who agreed to sell at or below the selected purchase price. Reebok shares closed yesterday at $34.75, up $3.50.

title: Election Day': The Movie
description: Although it is dominating the box office, "Independence Day" grossly distorts the methods aliens would use in any reasonable attempt to conquer Earth. Consider a sequel that will open your eyes to the true dangers that lurk in our universe -- "Election Day."

title: POLITICS: THE REPUBLICAN;Dole Finds Environment A Problem And an Issue
description: For the second successive day, Bob Dole used a Western setting today to assail President Clinton's environmental policies, asserting that local economies had suffered from the Administration's allegiance to protecting wildlife and open land.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's;New Sound Takes Root And Grows
description: Few things in music are more exciting than watching a new sound slowly change from being strange and unfamiliar to euphonious and pleasing. This is what has happened with the dance style drum-and-bass and its more reggae-oriented cousin, jungle, in the last few years as their unique approach to rhythm has attracted an increasingly wide array of artists. Unlike styles of dance music in which the art is in arranging samples over a steady beat, jungle and drum-and-bass (which evolved from the break-beat records that disk jockeys use as rhythmic additives to their mixes) make an art of cutting up, rearranging and accelerating drumbeats, usually over a deep, floor-shaking bass line.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- TRACK AND FIELD;Johnson Makes a Name for Himself By Winning Gold in the 110 Hurdles
description: He could have had an identity crisis, right there on the Olympic Stadium track, before he lept from the blocks.

title: Indonesia's Political Quake: Sense of Stability Shaken
description: Bomb threats forced the evacuation of several office buildings in Jakarta today, but the real explosion had already occurred: a major riot over the weekend that has shaken confidence in Indonesia's tightly controlled political order.

title: World News Briefs;Perry to Meet Saudis On Threat to U.S. Troops
description: Defense Secretary William J. Perry flew to Saudi Arabia today to discuss improving security conditions as officials from both countries investigated new indications that militants may be planning more attacks against American troops there.

title: COMPANY NEWS;CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER OF CHANTAL RESIGNS
description: The Chantal Pharmaceutical Corporation said yesterday that its chief financial officer had resigned and that the company would move to Florida from Los Angeles. The chief financial officer, Gary Burnison, who joined Chantal three weeks ago, left for "personal reasons," the company said in a statement. Chantal said that it had "identified" a new chief financial officer, but did not reveal that person's name. The company also did not say where in Florida it was moving. For the nine months ending March 31, the company lost $6.9 million, During that period, Chantal Pharmaceutical spent more to market its Ethocyn anti-wrinkle cream than it took in from sales. Chantal announced the resignation and its relocation plans after the market closed. Earlier, its shares fell 75 cents, to $3.25, on the Nasdaq small capitalization market.

title: Q&A
description: Zebroids

title: Carver Bank Stockholders Approve Reorganization
description: Shareholders of Carver Federal Savings Bank voted yesterday at the annual meeting to approve a reorganization plan after a former Wall Street executive who had said on Friday that he wanted to buy part of the Harlem bank -- and also wanted the meeting postponed -- failed to show up.

title: A King's Chicken Soup Wins a Loyal Following
description: SINGAPORE  At first glance, it may seem odd that an Asian company can build a successful international food and beverage empire on a health tonic that originated 161 years ago in the kitchen of the British monarch.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- BOXING;Nine Cubans Are Headed Toward the Medal Rounds, With History in Their Corner
description: The Cuban boxing coach Alcides Segarra issued an edict: To prepare for the medal rounds, his fighters will not give interviews until the Olympics are over.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE EVIDENCE;Terror's Signature, Writ In Metal, Is Round Dent
description: In the days since the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800, Federal investigators in Washington have been examining pieces of the 747-100 jetliner for signs that a bomb downed the plane. So far, they have not come up with conclusive proof.

title: BASEBALL;State Final Is Set In Little League
description: New York's Little League championship will be decided today when South Shore of Staten Island plays Rockville Centre of Long Island in the final of the state tournament at the Battery Park fields in lower Manhattan at noon.

title: Japan Premier Visits Shrine to War Dead
description: Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto visited a shrine for Japan's war dead today, the first by a serving Japanese leader in nearly 11 years.

title: Carjack Sentence: Death
description: A gang member was sentenced to death today for killing two college students from Japan during a 1994 carjacking.

title: Oil Fire Raging In South Russia
description: A huge fire has been raging at a southern Russian oil refinery, and local authorities said it would not be brought under control for two to three more days, Itar-Tass news agency reported.

title: American Express and Microsoft to Create On-Line Travel Service
description: The American Express Company and the Microsoft Corporation announced yesterday that they would create an on-line service enabling business travelers to book air, hotel and rental car reservations with their personal computers.

title: Corrections
description: A dance review yesterday about the Phoenix Dance Company at the Olympic Arts Festival in Atlanta misspelled the given name of a choreographer for whom the troupe's director, Maggie Lewis, was a soloist before his death in 1993. He was Alwin Nikolais, not Alvin.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: BANK OF BOSTON CORP., Boston, said it had completed the acquisition of Baybanks Inc., creating the nation's 15th-largest bank, with more than $60 billion in assets. The merged companies will be called BankBoston Corp.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11;Wheelchair Archer Loses
description: Paola Fantato of Italy, the only athlete in the Olympic Games who uses a wheelchair, failed today in her bid to win an individual medal.

title: Bankers Still Avoid Inner-City Lending
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;I.B.M. Pulls Print Ads After Woes at Olympics
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has at least temporarily withdrawn print advertisements that were part of a large campaign promoting its role at the 1996 Summer Olympics.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Welcome to the family: Princess Margaret's daughter, LADY SARAH CHATTO, gave birth to a son on Sunday, with her husband, DANIEL CHATTO, at her side. The baby is 14th in line to the throne, the first grandchild for Princess Margaret and the seventh great-grandchild for the Queen Mother.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- BADMINTON;Indonesia Romps
description: Rexy Mainaky and Ricky Subagja of Indonesia moved into tomorrow's gold-medal match in men's doubles by routing Beng Kiang Soo and Kim Her Tan of Malaysia, 15-3, 15-5.

title: Sports of The Times;Johnson Grabs Share Of Limelight
description: MICHAEL JOHNSON'S Olympic Odyssey has been filled with remarkable feats, incredible performances and lessons along the way.

title: Albany to Limit Special Program For Preschoolers With Disabilities
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders have agreed to impose significant changes on the state's system of special education for preschoolers, seeking for the first time to limit the number of students being placed in segregated classes taught at privately run centers.

title: INSIDE
description: Sign From China on Test Ban

title: Bankers Still Avoid Inner-City Lending
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY NEWS;COLONY CAPITAL ADDS FLORIDA SHOPPING CENTERS
description: Colony Capital Inc. said yesterday that it had bought a portfolio of South Florida shopping centers valued at about $157 million from a partnership that includes the financiers Nelson Peltz and Peter May, the developer Michael Swerdlow and Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. Terms of the purchase were not released. Colony said the sellers would retain an interest in the properties. The portfolio is made up of about 2 million square feet of space and includes the one million-square-foot Oakwood Plaza in Hollywood, Fla., and the 450,000-square-foot Kendall Lakes Plaza in Miami. The properties were developed by Mr. Swerdlow's Michael Swerdlow Companies, which plan to continue to manage and lease them. Colony Capital, based in Los Angeles, has bought $4.5 billion in real estate assets since 1991.

title: BASEBALL;Indians Send Baerga To Mets
description: If anyone had suggested a year ago that the Mets would be in a position to acquire a three-time All-Star who batted in the lofty No. 3 position for the mighty Cleveland Indians, the whole world would have laughed.

title: By Design;Accessory for the Unbuttoned
description: All those shirts that designers have been showing unbuttoned to the waist cry out for something to fill in all that bare skin. A suggestion from Tom Ford in Gucci's fall show was a delicate neck wire -- a rigid gold circlet nestled at the base of the throat with a dangling pendant. Like so many high-fashion styles for fall, it was last popular in the 1970's. And a neck wire looks just as good even if only two or three shirt buttons are left undone.

title: Protect the Innocent
description: One of our lawyers who represents abused children attended the funeral recently of a 5-year-old girl who had died of AIDS. Her 7-year-old sister is H.I.V.- positive. Her mother is pregnant again.

title: AIDS Drugs Alter An Industry's Math;Recalculating Death-Benefit Deals
description: A longer life means a lower return to the decade-old financial industry that buys life insurance policies from terminally ill patients at discount prices and profits by collecting the death benefits. So recent breakthroughs in the fight against AIDS are intensifying the industry's search for new areas of growth, hoping to attract people with cancer and other diseases.

title: Roger Peterson, 87, The Nation's Guide To the Birds, Is Dead
description: Roger Tory Peterson, the ornithologist whose "Field Guide to the Birds" inspired and instructed millions of bird-watchers the world over, died on Sunday at his home in Old Lyme, Conn., where he had lived for many years.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- TRACK AND FIELD;Russian Is Upset Winner in Women's 800
description: With enough energy to hurry another 400 meters in a victory lap, Svetlana Masterkova of Russia surprised the co-favorites, Ana Quirot of Cuba and Maria Mutola of Mozambique, in the Olympic women's 800-meter run tonight.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Music;A Different Perspective On East Meets West
description: The courtly music and folk arts of Asia have been an important component of Lincoln Center Festival '96, with the Reigakusha gagaku orchestra from Japan and the Thang Long Water Puppets from Vietnam the principal emissaries from that vast continent's diverse cultures. But there is also a place in the world of contemporary concert music where East and West have become thoroughly entwined.

title: Hurricane Kills 35 and Threatens Mexico
description: A hurricane that began in the Caribbean killed at least 35 people in its sweep across northern Colombia and Central America and emerged today in the Pacific.

title: Mayors Fear Welfare Cuts May Increase Homelessness
description: For the second time in a week, more than 100 homeless people marched on City Hall today, protesting the city's decision to restrict access to shelters because of cuts in state and Federal social programs over the last few years.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE OVERVIEW;Airliner Bombings Are Reviewed For Similarities to T.W.A. Crash
description: Federal officials investigating the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 are making a detailed study of several airline crashes caused by bombs, searching for clues that could help them determine whether the T.W.A. 747 was also brought down by a bomb.

title: G.M.-Union Talks to Resume After Accord
description: The General Motors Corporation, removing a thorn in the side of the United Automobile Workers union that has held up contract talks, said on Friday that it had agreed to reinstate a U.A.W. official who was dismissed in April.

title: Market Place;A brokerage firm under scrutiny is going public.
description: PEDDLING penny stocks can be very profitable in a bull market.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Judges Rule Against Law To Ban Internet Smut Three Federal judges in New York ruled that the Government's attempts to halt indecent material on the Internet were unconstitutionally broad and voted to grant a temporary injunction against enforcing the Communications Decency Act, which President Clinton signed on Feb. 8.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Earnhardt Competing In Brickyard 400
description: With a record eighth Winston Cup title beckoning, DALE EARNHARDT isn't about to give up points in the standing without a fight, no matter how painful. Earnhardt, 45, fractured his left collar bone and sternum on Sunday in a crash during the DieHard 500 at Talladega Superspeedway in Alabama.

title: So, Let the President Fill Our Potholes
description: To the Editor::

title: Review/Fashion;Clean Lines With Hints of Clean Living
description: When John Bartlett rolled over in the hammock suspended high above the runway at his show on Thursday night, removing his Cubano hat to reveal that he had been lying there throughout, he received one of the few standing ovations ever seen at a men's wear show. Aided and abetted, perhaps, by the two dozen beefcake models in skimpy trunks, each seated teasingly tete-a-tete with the front row audience.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Help Centers Planned
description: Older New Jerseyans should have an easier time getting government services under a state program, announced yesterday, to create one-stop information and assessment centers in every county. The first four centers, in Atlantic, Morris, Ocean and Union Counties, should be open by the end of the year, said Marilyn Riley, a spokeswoman for the Department of Health and Senior Services.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- NOTEBOOK;A Heroine for Hong Kong
description: The windsurfer Lai Shan Lee sailed into history and into the heart of her homeland when she became Hong Kong's first Olympic medalist by winning the women's Mistral gold in yachting competition in Savannah, Ga., on Sunday.

title: BOMB AT THE OLYMPICS: THE VICTIMS;Woman Who 'Lost Her Life While Celebrating the Human Spirit'
description: Although Alice S. Hawthorne did not run a single lap or win a single competition, her name is likely to be long associated with the 1996 Summer Olympics as a casualty of the Games' spirit of harmony and openness.

title: Fearing Strife, U.N. Withholds Report on Death of Burundian
description: Apparently fearful of provoking more violence in Burundi in the wake of a military coup last week by the Tutsi-dominated army, the Security Council is withholding from publication a report on the 1993 assassination of the country's first freely elected President, a Hutu.

title: President Finds Benefits In Defeat on Health Care
description: It has been three years since President Clinton and his wife, Hillary, set out to transform American medicine with a plan for universal, affordable health care. And today, signs of revolution are everywhere.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- NOTEBOOK;Fighter Loses, but Triumphs
description: Hard luck, Francey," a fellow Irishman said in consolation. But Francis Barrett, who had just lost his boxing match, had also won.

title: Jewish Studies Isn't Part of Western Canon
description: To the Editor:

title: Baldwin City Journal;A Piece of Prairie Forever England
description: For the historically minded, the eastern Kansas prairie offers evidence of pioneer trails, antique buildings and frontier farms that have been preserved as museums.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- SOFTBALL;One More Victory to Nail U.S. Gold
description: The United States is one victory away from winning a gold medal in softball.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Exactly 36 years ago last Sunday, when he was Vice President, Richard M. Nixon predicted in a speech that Nikita S. Khrushchev's grandchildren would live in freedom. His remarks contrasted with Khrushchev's warning that communism would bury the capitalist way of life.

title: A Humana Executive Resigns
description: Humana Inc. said today that its chief financial officer, W. Roger Drury, had resigned, and that it was reorganizing to improve cost controls and customer service.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about Burundi misstated a size comparison with Connecticut. Burundi is more than twice the size of Connecticut, not the same size.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Brawl at Bayside Prison
description: The 1,300 inmates of Bayside State Prison in Cumberland County were confined to their living quarters most of the day yesterday in the wake of a brawl on Sunday in which two prisoners were injured, corrections officials said. Six inmates believed to have instigated the fight against members of a rival gang were transferred to other institutions, said Bob McHugh, a spokesman for the State Department of Corrections.

title: POLITICS: Political Briefing;THE STATES AND THE ISSUES
description: Tennessee Double Challenge To Memphis Family

title: Snapshots To Improve The Tallies Of Tigers
description: DESPITE growing concern about people's ability to protect tigers, most wildlife managers in the "tiger range" states of Asia still rely on methods for monitoring tiger populations that are largely based on unsubstantiated guesswork, casting doubt on population estimates, a researcher with the Wildlife Conservation Society says.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BOXING;McCall in Drug Arrest
description: The former World Boxing Council heavyweight champion OLIVER McCALL was arrested on charges of possessing crack cocaine and marijuana, his second drug-related arrest in four months.

title: China Sets Off Nuclear Test, Then Announces Moratorium
description: China conducted a nuclear test today, and promised that it would be its last.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTERS;The Camera Never Lies, But the Software Does
description: IF you think the camera never lies, you have somehow missed that notorious picture of you and your very good friend Madonna holding hands on the moon. Today, when almost anything is possible, digitally retouched photos are as American as bearded moms, green baseballs and apple pie charts.

title: Novel Rocket Chosen to Power Shuttle Successor
description: USING an approach that in a sense turns rocketry inside out, engineers are building a new type of engine to power what could be the next generation of spacecraft to haul payloads into orbit.

title: Securing RU-486
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: DAVID GEFFEN, the entertainment baron, has turned down many a would-be biographer. Now, he has agreed to allow THOMAS R. KING, 32, the chief entertainment reporter in The Wall Street Journal's Los Angeles bureau, to write the story of his life. Random House is planning to publish the book in 1999.

title: ON PRO FOOTBALL;Harbaugh Ready to Prove He's for Real
description: There was Jim Harbaugh once again scrambling, darting, dancing, escaping the pass rush, whirling and throwing a five-yard touchdown pass. It was nullified by a penalty, but the Indianapolis Colts won anyway, 10-3, over the New Orleans Saints in the annual Hall of Fame game here last Saturday.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Surgery for Fittipaldi
description: EMERSON FITTIPALDI was transferred from Michigan to a hospital in Florida yesterday for surgery to repair a neck fracture. Fittipaldi, injured in a crash early in Sunday's Marlboro 500 at Michigan International Speedway, was in serious but stable condition yesterday when taken from St. Joseph Mercy Hospital, hospital officials said, where he was to have surgery last night at the University of Miami/Jackson Memorial Hospital in Miami. The hospital said Fittipaldi's prognosis was good.

title: COMPANY NEWS;USA WASTE SERVICES TO ACQUIRE OPERATIONS FROM PHILIP
description: USA Waste Services Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy two municipal and solid waste businesses, with operations in the United States and Canada, from Philip Environmental Inc. for $118 million. USA Waste, the third-largest American trash hauler, said it planned to buy Philip Environmental's Quebec municipal and commercial solid nonhazardous waste business for $75.5 million and the Ontario and Michigan municipal and commercial solid nonhazardous waste business for $42.5 million. Philip, based in Hamilton, Ontario, said proceeds would be used to pay down debt.

title: MUSIC REVIEW;'Grimes' Returns to Its Beginnings at Tanglewood
description: Benjamin Britten's "Peter Grimes" is so implacably rooted in English places and moods that its American origins are easily forgotten. Serge Koussevitzky commissioned the opera for the first incarnation of his Tanglewood Music Center, and the composer began work on the libretto while living in the United States in the early 1940's. Although "Grimes" had its fabled first night in London in 1945, a Tanglewood performance followed quickly, under Leonard Bernstein's direction. Fifty years after the fact, Tanglewood returned to "Grimes" with a very handsome fully staged production on Sunday night in the Theater at Tanglewood.

title: Two Road Workers Killed by Crew's Truck
description: Two workers from the City Department of Transportation were crushed to death yesterday when an asphalt truck struck them while backing up, department officials said.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Gilliam May Join Bucks
description: The former New Jersey Net ARMON GILLIAM has drawn the attention of several teams during free agency, but appears close to working out a deal with the Milwaukee Bucks. "We've talked to him and we're hopeful," JOHN STEINMILLER, the Bucks' vice president of operations, said yesterday.

title: Governor Says Aides Earned Inaugural Pay
description: Gov. George E. Pataki today defended payments made to top campaign aides by corporations established to finance his inaugural celebration and transition into the Governor's office.

title: COMAPNY REPORTS;3M Earnings Climbed 7.9% in 2d Quarter
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that its second-quarter earnings rose 7.9 percent, bolstered by strong sales in the United States and lower raw material costs.

title: BASEBALL;Alfonzo Responds Well to Mets' Trade
description: When the Mets added an All-Star second baseman to their lineup with the acquisition of Carlos Baerga from the Cleveland Indians yesterday, they also added life to the stalled career of Edgardo Alfonzo.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;House & Garden Reappears on a Crowded Stage
description: The sheer number of titles begs the question.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Surfers Face Charges
description: The battle between surfers and litigation-minded municipal authorities appears to be escalating. On July 10, a surfer in Point Pleasant Beach was given a summons for refusing to get out of the water fast enough, and three days later, five surfers in water roiled by Hurricane Bertha were charged with disorderly conduct and violating bathing hours.

title: POLITICS: THE CONVENTION;Buchanan Angrily Rejects Party's Offer of a 15-Second Videotaped Message
description: Patrick J. Buchanan's Presidential campaign today angrily rejected an offer by Republican officials to feature him fleetingly at the party's convention next month.

title: ISRAEL MAPS ROADS ACROSS WEST BANK
description: Signaling that it will resist Arab demands to trade land for peace, Israel's new conservative Government has revived plans to build two highways through the West Bank and two new bridges to the Golan Heights.

title: THEATER REVIEW;Putting Ancient Greeks On the Talk-Show Grill
description: Describing sensational murders in the ennobling terms of Greek tragedy is a favorite device of mass-media journalists, so it seems only fitting that Greek tragedy should return the compliment.
