In "Orestes: 'I Murdered My Mother,' " at the One Dream Theater, tabloid television invades the world of Euripidean drama, and the medium seems remarkably at home.

title: Error Inflated Estimate Of Rising Sea Levels, Researchers Report
description: RESEARCHERS say an error in a computer program analyzing data from a United States altimeter led them to overestimate the rise in Earth's oceans over the last three years.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Finalists Named In Acura Review
description: The Acura division of the American Honda Motor Company yesterday named four finalists to compete for its account, with billings estimated at $125 million, in a review that began in May.

title: COMPANY NEWS;KIWI PLANS TO END MAJORITY CONTROL BY EMPLOYEES
description: Kiwi International Air Lines Inc., seeking to attract outside investors, plans to end majority control of the company by employees. The airline, which is based in Newark, plans to do away with a stock plan that guaranteed some 1,200 workers the right to elect a majority of Kiwi directors, according to a proxy statement filed last week with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The proposed change coincides with a July 1 agreement that calls for Recovery Equity Investors of San Mateo, Calif., to invest as much as $10 million in Kiwi. Recovery Equity has already acquired $4 million of Kiwi notes that are convertible into preferred stock. Kiwi will propose the change at a shareholders meeting in Newark on Sept. 4.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Loss at Groupe Bull Widened in First Half
description: Groupe Bull, the biggest computer company in France, said yesterday that its net loss more than quadrupled in the first half, mainly because of losses at Zenith Data Systems, a former Groupe Bull subsidiary.

title: Fibreboard's Plan On Asbestos Cleared
description: The Fibreboard Corporation said today that a Federal appeals court had approved the company's settlements of personal injury and insurance cases related to asbestos.

title: Hollywood Reeling As Many Blockbusters Become Quick Busts
description: The head of a major movie studio sighed deeply this morning as he surveyed the box-office wreckage of the last two weeks. "I'm scared," he said. "The business is frightening."

title: Irish Pubmaster Discovers Pot of Gold in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG  It was a problem Clayton Parker had not anticipated when he hired a top chef born in Dublin to cook authentic Irish food in Hong Kong.

title: French Company Controls Subsidiaries From India to New Zealand : Danone Nurtures a Pan-Asian Empire
description: HONG KONG  Ten years ago, France's Group Danone had no businesses in Asia outside Japan, even though it had already been searching for opportunities in China for at least three years.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 11 -- TRACK AND FIELD;Lewis Takes One Last Leap Into History
description: He knew it from the moment he landed because, as the world surely knows, Carl Lewis had been there before. He had been there eight times, and he knew what it takes to get to the gold medal stand.

title: Alexandria Journal;Poor Egypt's Golden Coast: The Lure (and Leer)
description: As an infant in the 1920's, King Farouk brandished a platinum, crown-shaped rattle encrusted with emeralds. Older royals swatted flies with gold-handled whisks, idled over gold chess sets and nibbled on bonbons plucked from gold boxes.

title: FESTIVAL REVIEW/Music;Just Plain Beethoven, on the Instruments of His Day
description: The two enthusiastic receptions that greeted the Orchestre Revolutionnaire et Romantique and Monteverdi Choir over the weekend indicate some return to normalcy in musical politics. These did not seem like listeners cheering for valveless horns, gut strings, short phrases and fast tempos, but rather people responding to music scrupulously prepared and earnestly projected.

title: Wattles and Kurrajong:Australia's 'Bush Tucker' Cuisine Goes Up Market
description: SYDNEY  After years in the bush leagues, Australian cuisine has gone upscale.Over the past 10 years, an unparalleled array of food formerly called "bush tucker" has been elevated to Australia's finer restaurants and hotels. Along the way, it has reached a commercial scale.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Rams Sign Kennison
description: With contract negotiations out of the way, EDDIE KENNISON is ready to get down to the business of playing football. Kennison, a former Louisiana State receiver drafted 18th by the St. Louis Rams, signed a five-year deal on Sunday for $5.8 million, including a $2 million signing bonus.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Kirin Brewery Posts 11% Drop in Profit
description: The Kirin Brewery Company, the biggest brewer in Japan, said yesterday that its pretax profit for the first half of the year fell 11.5 percent, to 27.5 billion yen ($254.9 million). Sales declined two-tenths of 1 percent, to 612 billion yen ($5.67 billion). Revenue from beer was not sufficient to offset rising promotional expenses, falling prices for Kirin's line of drugs and meager returns on financial investments because of Japan's record low interest rates, the company said.

title: POLITICS: THE MOVIE;Dole Sees U.S. Conquer Evil. Good Film, He Says.
description: With a box of Goobers and a basket of popcorn, Bob Dole took on two missions today -- celebrating his wife's 60th birthday and preparing for another speech on Hollywood movie values -- by settling into a nearly empty theater for a matinee showing of "Independence Day."

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- SOFTBALL;U.S. Softball Team Has Its Golden Moment
description: In a showdown that probably won't improve diplomatic relations, the United States softball team won the first Olympic gold medal in the sport by defeating China, 3-1, on the strength of Dot Richardson's two-run homer tonight at Golden Park.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- Sports of The Times;Mountain Biking Debut Has Ups and Downs
description: MOUNTAIN biking started out as a way to commune with nature, rattling your coccyx on tree roots and rocks and gullies in places where nonmotorized, two-legged vehicles were not supposed to go. Now it has its own World Cup, complete with support trucks and a European tour and doctors who improve your blood.

title: Combat Terrorism, But Don't Sacrifice Freedom;Expanded Wiretapping
description: To the Editor:

title: FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE OVERVIEW;JET'S LANDING GEAR IS SAID TO PROVIDE EVIDENCE OF BOMB
description: The front landing gear of the Boeing 747 that crashed off the coast here on July 17 shows such heavy damage that some investigators are convinced that it is the strongest evidence yet that the plane was destroyed by a bomb, Federal investigators said tonight.

title: Wine Talk
description: The French were the first to fight the heat by chilling their red wine.

title: FOCUS ON TERRORISM: THE LEGISLATION;Dispute on Marking Explosives Stalls Effort to Reach Accord
description: An effort by the White House and Congress to draw up new counterterrorism legislation hit a snag today over the Administration's desire to add chemical markers to explosives to make them easier to trace.

title: FOCUS ON TERRORISM: THE CITY;Altanta Police Change Rules on Handling Bomb Alerts
description: For 10 minutes, the city's 911 command center failed to report the bomb threat against Centennial Olympic Park because operators did not know the park's address and could not enter the report in their computers without it, The Associated Press was told today.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Deutsche Bank to Open Supermarket Branches
description: Deutsche Bank A.G., Germany's largest bank, said yesterday that it would open branches in supermarkets, in what analysts saw as a bid to breathe life into its stagnating retail banking business. The move followed a trend by banks and other businesses in Germany that are trying to become more customer-friendly as telephone banking is being offered and Germany's restrictions on shop-closing hours are eased.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RANGER OIL AND ORYX IN DEAL TO BUY ASSETS FROM CHEVRON
description: Ranger Oil Ltd. said yesterday that its Ranger Oil (U.K.) Ltd. unit and the Oryx Energy Company had agreed to buy interests in various North Sea properties from Chevron (U.K.) Ltd. of London, a subsidiary of the Chevron Corporation, which is based in San Francisco, for $140 million. Ranger, an oil and natural-gas producer based in Calgary, Alberta, said the properties included several producing fields as well as several nonproducing assets. Oryx, an energy concern based in Dallas, would acquire a 65 percent share of the assets for $91 million, and Ranger would acquire 35 percent for $49 million. Oryx is already the operator of several of the fields being sold.

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Digital Posts $433 Million Deficit in Quarter
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation posted a $433 million deficit in its fiscal fourth quarter today after taking a $492 million charge to pay for 7,000 job cuts and plant closings.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on July 21 about Merrill C. Gilfillan, an Ohio conservationist and author, attributed five books to him erroneously. He wrote "Moods of the Ohio Moon: An Outdoorsman's Almanac," but his son, Merrill D. Gilfillan, wrote "Magpie Rising: Sketches from the Great Plains," "Sworn Before Cranes" and three volumes of poetry, "To Creature," "Light Years: Early Selected Works" and "River Through Rivertown."

title: METROPOLOITAN GOLF REPORT
description: Connecticut Open

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- VOLLYBALL;Rout by Cuba Leaves U.S. Disappointed
description: This was to have been a breakout for the United States women's volleyball team.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;MCA in $2.5 Billion Sale of Shows to German TV
description: MCA Inc. said today that it was selling the German rights to its television shows and movies in two long-term agreements that MCA valued at about $2.5 billion.

title: Former Charity Head Ordered to Prison
description: With charismatic leadership, Frank L. Williams transformed the American Parkinson Disease Association into one of the top charities in its field, raising tens of millions of dollars for research and support services for suffering patients.

title: Russia's Purveyor of 'Truth', Pravda, Dies After 84 Years
description: When its devoted readers reached into their mailboxes this morning for Russia's oldest and most famous Communist newspaper, they came up with a big surprise: nothing.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Billboards Not Taxable
description: In 1991, the administration of Gov. Jim Florio said in a legal opinion that municipalities could charge property tax for billboards, and since then the appellate courts have agreed with that view.

title: Moderate Bosnian Serbs Plot in Secrecy for Unity
description: To meet the main political opponents of the Bosnian Serb ruling party in this town, one must slip by a police checkpoint to arrive at a private house on a street that is lined with trees but canopied with fear.

title: Ohio-Born Bishop Appointed To Head Greek Church in U.S.
description: An American-born Greek Orthodox Bishop, Metropolitan Spyridon of Italy, was named yesterday to head the Greek Orthodox Church in the United States.

title: Look What We've Done to Our Demons
description: To the Editor:

title: In South Africa, Crash Courses in Zulu
description: AS far as passing myself off as a Zulu is concerned, I blew it in the first five seconds, on the handshake. I quickly shifted from my plain vanilla American to the hand-thumb-hand African triple that the instructor used. But she told me my grip was too firm: "An African's handshake is typically mild."

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Vote on Sterling Forest
description: Following through on an agreement announced last week, the House of Representatives voted yesterday to authorize $17.5 million in Federal money to help save the 20,000-acre Sterling Forest from development.

title: Betting That Lots of Israelis Will Take to American Bagels
description: IT was a sweltering day in late July on King George Street in downtown Jerusalem. Standing in the large plaza in front of the Mashbir department store were Gary and Laurie Heller and their son Rafael, who was somewhat reluctantly spending his 17th birthday helping his father realize a dream.

title: Sports of The Times;Lewis's Face Belongs on Mt. Olympus
description: IF a sculptor ever chiseled faces on Mount Olympus as if it were Mount Rushmore, Carl Lewis would be up there alongside Jesse Owens, Al Oerter and Paavo Nurmi. And maybe just slightly above the others.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY;Avalanche Extends Roy's Contract
description: PATRICK ROY, whose goaltending helped bring the Stanley Cup to Denver, signed a multiyear contract with the Colorado Avalanche, the team announced yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- TABLE TENNIS;Kong and Liu Win an All-Chinese Final
description: Kong Linghui and Liu Guoliang of China won the gold medal in men's doubles, defeating the defending champions Lu Lin and Wang Tao of China, 21-8, 18-21, 21-19, 21-17.

title: Wrong on Prayer
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;Baerga Comes Through Right Off the Bat, and the Mets Take Two
description: The Mets, riding a tide of emotion after the acquisition of Carlos Baerga, turned the positive energy into their first doubleheader sweep of the season last night by using two late-game rallies to stun the Pittsburgh Pirates at Shea Stadium.

title: For U.S. Jazz Players, Europe Is the Place to Be
description: Finding a big-name jazz musician in New York in the hot months of July and August is almost as rare as finding a native New Yorker on Fifth Avenue. It is summer, and jazz musicians have flown across the Atlantic. With a festival circuit that is a huge feeding ground, Europe provides the most intense period of the year for American jazz players, a time of strenuous work, elation and a shot at fame.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- SOCCER;Argentina Defeats Portugal to Reach Final
description: Argentina clinched a place in the final for the first time in 68 years as Hernan Crespo scored both goals in a 2-0 semifinal victory over Portugal in Athens, Ga. It will be Argentina's first trip to the final since 1928, in Amsterdam, where they lost to Uruguay. Argentina will meet either Brazil or Nigeria in Saturday's final. The second semifinal is today, and Portugal will play the loser Friday for the bronze medal. (Reuters)

title: Perot Easily Wins His Party's Straw Poll
description: Ross Perot won a solid majority of votes in his Reform Party's straw poll to determine potential Presidential nominees, the party said today.

title: Tantalizing Data Suggest Estrogen May Prevent or Delay Alzheimer's
description: AS the number of patients with Alzheimer's disease continues to climb, researchers are studying the possibility that a common and already approved drug, estrogen, may help to prevent or delay it, and even reverse some of its symptoms.

title: Battles on Conservation Are Reaping Dividends
description: A rust-colored river runs through the valley where Barbara Miller is trying to rear her four children, in a town of brittle-boned homes holding off age and gravity. Neighborly howdies blend with nervous talk about the poison that keeps showing up in the blood of local children.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- DIVING;Two Americans Advance to Semifinals
description: The Americans Melisa Moses and Jenny Keim advanced to the semifinal of the springboard competition while the world champion Tan Shuping of China dropped out of contention with two near-bellyflops.

title: Personal Health
description: AS I sit here nibbling on chocolate-covered raisins (in an attempt to conquer my addiction to chocolate-covered coffee beans), I wonder, what would my readers say if they saw me now?

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;NatWest's Drop in Net Is Less Than Expected
description: The National Westminster Bank P.L.C. said yesterday that its profits fell 65 percent, less than expected, in the first half as strong growth in interest and fee-related income part ly offset one-time charges. The bank company, Britain's fourth largest in market capitalization, also said it had bought back as many as L450 million worth of its shares.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Swissair Tells Workers To Expect Lower Pay
description: Philippe Bruggisser, the designated chief executive of Swissair A.G., warned the company's 32,000 workers yesterday that unsatisfactory business trends, lower fares and high costs had left the company no choice but to adjust salaries and other compensation.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- TRACK AND FIELD;A New Title For Lewis: High-Profile Alternate
description: Having won his ninth gold medal with a victory in the long jump, Carl Lewis began campaigning today for a chance to win his 10th Olympic title. And while he is not listed in the current lineup to anchor the United States 4x100-meter relay team on Saturday, the door has not completely shut on his Olympic career.

title: F.C.C. to Set Strict Local Phone Rules
description: Signaling that it wants to be a potent force in the new world of telecommunications, the Federal Communications Commission plans to release a voluminous set of rules tomorrow governing local telephone competition.

title: FOCUS ON TERRORISM: THE INVESTIGATION;Report of a Hero-Turned-Suspect Rivets Attention in Atlanta
description: Coverage of the investigation of the bombing at the Olympics here was dominated for hours today by a report in The Atlanta Journal naming a local security guard as the leading suspect.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Whitbread Makes Offer For Restaurant Company
description: Whitbread P.L.C., the British brewer, said yesterday that it had offered L133.1 million, or $207.4 million, for the Pelican Group P.L.C., which operates restaurants and cafes. Whitbread said its bid would give Pelican shareholders a 17 percent premium over Pelican shares' recent price on the London Stock Exchange.

title: FUTURES MARKETS;Wheat Prices Drop Sharply As Spring Crop Looks Healthy
description: Wheat prices tumbled yesterday as traders noted signs that spring wheat was faring better than the drought-stricken winter crop.

title: Public Endorses Uplifting Movies, Dole Tells Hollywood
description: Returning to the place and theme that helped jump-start his Presidential campaign 14 months ago, Bob Dole today offered a revised view of Hollywood, asserting that the public rewards films that celebrate American values and rejects those that depict excessive sex and violence.

title: Claudette Colbert, Unflappable Heroine of Screwball Comedies, Is Dead At 92
description: Claudette Colbert, the versatile stage and film star whose flair for light comedy cheered audiences during the Depression and for decades afterward, died yesterday at Belle-rive, her home on the island of Barbados. She was 92 and also had a home in Manhattan.

title: COMPANY NEWS;OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM SELLS STAKE IN OILFIELDS TO CONGO
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had sold royalty stakes in three oilfields in Congo to the African nation for $215 million. Occidental, which is based in Los Angeles, acquired the interests in the offshore fields for $150 million in 1993. The interests entitled Occidental to a share of the Government's portion of oil from the developments. Occidental's net production in the Congo was 9,000 barrels a day in 1995, 3.2 percent of the company's total worldwide production of 278,000 barrels.

title: Paella Bonanza for One or Dozens
description: PAELLA for one, two, four or 30 is the specialty of Bistro Latino, 1711 Broadway (at 54th Street), which opened yesterday.

title: Will a Tax Cut Help Dole?
description: So here's Bob Dole, trying to decide what to do about taxes. All of his associates, many of whom want him to win so they can be big shots in a Dole administration, want him to come out for a big tax cut. They say that he's so far behind that it is the only thing that will save him.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- BOXING;Three From U.S. Are in Line For Medals
description: Terrance Cauthen, the kid with the babyish grin from Joe Frazier's Philadelphia gym, stayed out of trouble again. Nate Jones, the Chicago heavyweight with a bit of a past, is suddenly in the midst of an illuminating future. Roshii Wells? Never mind his critics. The middleweight with the permanent smile from the Atlanta suburb of Riverdale is stunning even his coaches.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;Bridgestone Reports 81% Gain in Profits
description: The Bridgestone Corporation, the Japanese tire maker, said yesterday that its net income in the first half of the year rose 81 percent on a 34 percent gain in exports, which were lifted by the drop in the value of the yen. Bridgestone raised its forecast for the year, citing stronger tire sales in Asia and the Middle East.

title: Corrections
description: An obiturary on Saturday about Dr. S. Perry Schlesinger, emeritus professor of electrical engineering at Columbia University, omitted the name of a surviving sister. She is Harriet Blum of Hamilton, N.Y.

title: DANCE REVIEW;Martial Athletes and Cosmic Forces
description: Dancers celebrated the prowess of athletes and the cosmic force of creation itself when the Bahia Ballet came to the Joyce Theater on Monday night. The program was exciting not only for its own sake but also for the way it proved that modern dance is an international language that can take on the accents of whatever region it flourishes in.

title: Sale of Italian Bank Stake
description: Banca Commerciale Italiana has signed a letter of intent to buy 55 percent of Biverbanca for 360 billion lire ($236 million) over three years. Biverbanca was formed by the Cassa di Risparmio di Biella and Cassa di Risparmio di Vercelli merger.

title: No Headline
description: I don't feel the least bit jealous of the people in the Hamptons who went there to escape the heat."

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- SYNCHRONIZED SWIMMING;Three Perfect Scores Put U.S. in the Lead
description: With the toughest part of its program working to perfection, the United States played off the enthusiasm of a flag-waving crowd at the Georgia Tech Aquatic Center with an almost flawless routine to lead after the technical round.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Money for Flood Areas
description: A plan to buy 5,350 acres of flood-prone property along the Passaic River in Passaic and Morris counties for $194 million was approved yesterday by the House of Representatives. The buyout plan, which was recommended by the Army Corps of Engineers over a much more costly proposal for a flood tunnel, was among 160 projects included in the $5.1 billion Water Resources Development Act. The Senate has already passed a $3.1 billion version of the bill, but that measure does not include the buyout, said Dan Delich, a staff member of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee.

title: Stop Crime Where It Starts
description: The nation's juvenile crime problem is grave and growing. Unfortunately, the debate over how to respond to violence by teen-agers is being waged along the usual ideological and partisan lines.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-8

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- WEIGHT LIFTING;Grand Gesture by American, but Russian Wins Gold
description: Last Saturday, the world's fastest human was crowned at the Olympic Games. Today, the world's strongest man was coronated.

title: Q & A / Amnuay Viravan : ASEAN and Burma
description: Asian and Western nations are divided over how to treat the military regime in Burma. Amnuay Viravan, Thailand's deputy prime minister and foreign minister, discussed the issue with Michael Richardson of the International Herald Tribune.

title: Journal;Dukakis on Dole
description: Just when you think his campaign has finally bottomed out, Bob Dole finds the most creative new ways to top himself.

title: FOCUS ON TERRORISM: THE WORLD;Global Powers Announce Steps to Counter Terrorism
description: After a wave of terrorist bombings in the United States, Europe and the Middle East, most of the world's major powers decided in meetings here today that by the end of the year, they would carry out a package of new, tougher measures to prevent, investigate and prosecute terrorism.

title: World News Briefs;Protesters Fight Police in Hong Kong
description: Demonstrators fought with the police in Hong Kong today during efforts to clear Rennie's Mill, a shantytown that has long been the home of Nationalists who fled China.

title: Our Towns;A Radar Gun Is a Fast Track To Celebrity
description: IT became obvious to Laura Romano that Harter Road was suffering from a chronic case of suburban driving.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;People
description: * Thomas Groves was named to the new post of chief planning officer at Warwick Baker O'Neill, New York. He had been a senior partner and deputy director for account planning at the J. Walter Thompson New York unit of the WPP Group. Also at Warwick Baker, Margaret Lewis, associate media director, was promoted to media director, succeeding Mike Haggerty, who left to join Wells Rich Greene BDDP, New York, a unit of BDDP Worldwide, in a similar capacity.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- GYMNASTICS;Will Cheering Stop At the End of the Gala?
description: There have been American gold medalists in gymnastics before: Mary Lou Retton and Julianne McNamara and the men's team in 1984; Trent Dimas in 1992.

title: Corruption Fighter Quits
description: Thomas D. (Toby) Thacher 2d, who developed an anticorruption program at the New York City School Construction Authority that was praised by legal experts as a national model, will resign as vice president and inspector general in September to start a consulting firm, the authority announced yesterday.

title: Head of Racing Board Resigns Under Fire
description: The head of the State Racing and Wagering Board, under fire for maintaining an ownership interest in stallions while overseeing the state's horse racing industry, resigned today.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- BASEBALL;U.S. Team Builds Momentum With a Rout
description: Finishing the preliminary rounds with a flourish, the United States headed into the semifinals following a 17-1 victory over the Netherlands at Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium. The United States (6-1) finished round-robin play in second, behind Cuba, which is undefeated in seven games.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;This Time It May Be Injury That Sidelines Reich
description: When Frank Reich was pro football's most famous backup quarterback, practice time was easy to come by.

title: Republicans Finish Writing Welfare Measure; Clinton May AnnouncePosition Today
description: Congressional Republicans said today that they had finished writing a bill that would reverse six decades of social welfare policy, and President Clinton continued to express ambivalence toward the legislation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Two Developments In Ads on Taxicabs
description: Two developments involving taxicab advertising were announced yesterday.

title: COMPANY NEWS;TORCHMARK TO REPUCHASE SOME OF ITS SHARES
description: The Torchmark Corporation said yesterday that it would repurchase some of its shares and take other steps to try to help its underperforming stock, though it abandoned a reorganization plan to split apart. Torchmark, an insurance and financial services concern based in Birmingham, Ala., said seven months ago that it would consider a plan to reorganize. After a review with the investment bank Morgan Stanley Group Inc., the company now says it hopes to raise its stock price through less drastic measures. In addition to buying back some shares, the company said it might sell part of its remaining 27 percent stake in Vesta Insurance Group Inc. of Birmingham, which it took public in November 1993. Torchmark also said it was close to selling several businesses, including Torch Energy Advisors. An April 1995 agreement to sell Torch Energy Advisors for $115 million fell through, the company said.

title: Fish Market Ouster Upheld
description: A state judge yesterday upheld the ouster of a Fulton Fish Market businessman who the authorities say is the Mafia's enforcer in the market.

title: Public Lacks Strong Opinions On Health Bill, Survey Shows
description: Though Congress has been arguing for months over the details of legislation to make health insurance coverage portable from job to job, the American public has no decisive view of the legislation, a new survey by the Kaiser Family Foundation and the Harvard School of Public Health shows.

title: Can a Kosher Snack Climb to Stardom?
description: ON good days, Susan Moskowitz dreams of being the next Mrs. Fields. On bad days, she has nightmares of bankrupting her family.

title: Inaugural Fund Paid for Part of Pataki Trip
description: Aides to Gov. George E. Pataki said today that the privately financed corporations established to finance his inauguration and transition also paid $4,227 to cover part of the cost of a vacation Mr. Pataki took at a Vermont resort a week after his election.

title: Workers' Pay Rises Again, But Benefits Lag Behind
description: In the clearest signal yet that wages and salaries are moving up, the Labor Department announced yesterday that its broadest measure of what American workers receive in their paychecks rose by nine-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter. That was the fourth consecutive quarterly increase greater than the inflation rate.

title: Look What We've Done to Our Demons
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- NOTEBOOK;With Fears of Reprisals, A Cuban Coach Defects
description: When Jose Barrientos, general secretary of the Cuban Boxing Federation, was asked before the Atlanta Games about the possibility of defections, he promptly replied: "There is nothing we can do. If they go, they go."

title: COMPANY REPORTS;Bear Stearns Records 82% Surge in Profits
description: The Bear Stearns Companies reported yesterday that its fiscal fourth-quarter earnings surged 82 percent, to a record $162.8 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the families of the crash victims from Trans World Airlines Flight 800 misstated the occupation of one victim, Judy Penzer. She was a muralist, not a neurologist.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- TENNIS;Washington Bows Out, But Agassi Stays Alive
description: There was the same moral to the story of both of today's marquee quarterfinal matches that starred the Olympic hopefuls -- one of them no longer a medal hopeful -- of the two-man United States tennis squad: When you serve for the match, you had better end the match.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Gain on Signs Of a Slowing Economy Signs of slowing economic activity drove interest rates lower, buoying stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 47.34 points, to 5,481.93, while the S.& P. 500-stock index gained 4.35 points, closing at 635.26, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 5.48 points, to 1,071.95.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Confusion on Police Chief
description: After John Scalese, the Lyndhurst Police Chief, stepped down on Friday to take a two-year leave that will ultimately result in his retirement, Deputy Chief Robert B. Giangeruso moved into his office. But another man, Capt. James O'Connor, had already been named acting chief by the township's public safety director. That left everyone wondering just who really was in charge.

title: W. J. Alley, 66, Head of American Brands
description: William J. Alley, the former chairman and chief executive of American Brands Inc., died Friday at his home in New Canaan. He was 66.

title: FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE DIVERS;Slow Walk With Danger In a Cold, Dim Junkyard
description: Put on two or three heavy jackets, but still feel the cold seeping through. Imagine that each step is a struggle against the forces of nature. Close your eyes. Now take a walk through a junkyard of razor-sharp metal and booby traps.

title: INSIDE
description: New Steps to Halt Terrorism

title: Back Land-for-Peace Stand, Egyptian Leader Urges U.S.
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt has spent the last two days here seeking vocal American support for an old idea that the new Israeli Prime Minister has rejected: trading Israeli-occupied land for a comprehensive peace in the Middle East.

title: USAir Sues British Airways Over Pact With American
description: One of the airline industry's most notable marriages appears to be headed for a nasty divorce.

title: CHRONICLE
description: There's more than one way to help a musician. Or so DAN GORGOLIONE has learned over the years.

title: Curtain Falls Again For Shakespeare Store
description: After weeks of vacillating, the owners of Shakespeare & Company announced yesterday that they had finally decided to close the eclectic bookstore on the Upper West Side, which has struggled to compete with superstores.

title: Latin Weapons Ban
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL;More Worries for Yanks As Pettitte Is Pummeled
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., July 30

title: Tokyo Stocks Fall
description: Stocks fell here today. At the close of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was down 187.50 points, or nine-tenths of 1 percent, at 20,692.83. On Tuesday, the Nikkei fell 87.21 points.

title: Lawsuit Says Christian Coalition Gave Illegal Help to Candidates
description: The bipartisan Federal Election Commission sued the Christian Coalition today, asserting that the nation's largest group of religious conservatives had acted illegally to promote several Republican candidates, including former President George Bush, Speaker Newt Gingrich, Senator Jesse Helms and Oliver L. North.

title: P.L.O. Forces Said to Have Tortured Prisoner
description: A Palestinian prisoner in a West Bank jail was beaten by Palestinian P.L.O. security forces and is brain dead, a human rights group said today.

title: Buchanan to Push for Trade and Tax Planks
description: Trying to reclaim the initiative on issues central to his faded Presidential campaign, Patrick J. Buchanan plans to make an announcement on Wednesday revealing planks on taxes and trade that he wants included in the Republican platform.

title: At the Nation's Table: Bloomington, Minn.;A Jungle Canopy In America's Mall
description: The air is cool. Lush plants form a canopy overhead. Parrots, macaws, and toucans call, while tropical fish dally in huge tanks. Periodically, a flash of lightning and a clap of thunder interrupt the patter of light rain.

title: Water-Saving Flush Toilets Did Neither, Hevesi Asserts
description: A New York City program that has led to the installation of 1.1 million water-saving toilets has squandered more than $7 million and has been plagued by mismanagement, leaving some residences with faulty new plumbing that is just as inefficient as before, City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi charged yesterday.

title: Republicans Balk at Some Anti-Terror Proposals
description: WASHINGTON  A growing number of Republican legislators voiced serious doubts Tuesday about tough new anti-terrorism measures sought by the Clinton administration.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Hampton Is Ready And Willing But Not Able
description: There's a smile on Rodney Hampton's face, a carefree step in his trot, a few extra pounds on his already bulky 230-pound frame.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: MOBIL CORP., Fairfax, Va., said it would buy a 26 percent interest in a production-sharing contract that included the Natuna gas field of Indonesia. The oil company will work in partnership with Pertamina, Indonesia's state-owned petroleum company that has a 24 percent interest in the contract, and Esso S.A.F., a unit of the Exxon Corporation, with a 50 percent stake. Terms were not disclosed.

title: PLAIN AND SIMPLE;Lamb Pizza: Hold the Cheese, Add the Sumac
description: This recipe for a "pizza" topping calls for sumac, an ingredient not well known in this country. It adds a sour and peppery flavor to food.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a meeting of stockholders of the Carver Federal Savings Bank misstated the given name of the bank's president and chief executive. He is Thomas L. Clark Jr., not Donald.

title: BASEBALL;Baerga's Heart in Cleveland
description: The last time Carlos Baerga visited New York City, the then All-Star second baseman for the Cleveland Indians helped a Puerto Rican delegation carry the Olympic torch on its pass through the five boroughs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When guests gather at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass., on Aug. 9 to celebrate the opening of the dance center's archives, it will be the culmination of a longtime dream for MARGE CHAMPION, the choreographer and dancer.

title: Combat Terrorism, But Don't Sacrifice Freedom;Letting Truth In
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- Sports of The Times;The Doctor Steps Up For Her At-Bats, Too
description: SHE grew up in Orlando, an unsophisticated town in a less enlightened time. As a 10-year-old who could spank the baseball, she was told to cut her hair and call herself Bob. The girls she played competitive sports with as a teen-ager quit the games, and not all because they wanted to.

title: World News Briefs;2 Palestinians Held In Hijacking of Plane
description: Two Palestinians who said they were involved in the hijacking to Miami of a Havana-bound Iberia Airlines flight last week have been arrested in Germany, authorities said today.

title: Netanyahu Infuriates Unions By Assault on Welfare State
description: Like every parent in Israel, Yoram Wexler gets an allowance, regular as clockwork, that on the 15th of every month enriches his bank account by $43 for each of his two children.

title: COMPANY NEWS;HEALTHSOURCE FALLS AFTER ANNOUNCING LOWER EARNINGS
description: The shares of Healthsource Inc. fell yesterday after the company warned that second-quarter earnings would fall as much as 60 percent from levels a year earlier. The company, which is based in Hooksett, N.H., cited competition and rising health-care costs in the managed-care industry. Shares of Healthsource fell $1.50, or 12 percent, to $11.375, in trading of 6.24 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock, which touched a 52-week low of $9.75 earlier yesterday, has fallen from an all-time high of $40.875 on Feb. 27. Healthsource owns health maintainance organizations in the Northeastern, central and Southern United States.

title: FOCUS ON TERRORISM: THE LEADER;Atlanta's Ex-Mayor Calls for Renewal
description: Andrew Young wears many hats in this town: ex-Mayor, civil rights veteran, former United Nations delegate, former Representative, Olympics booster. Today, he was called on to wear the hat of the minister he was originally trained to be, preaching about peace, redemption and renewal.

title: PRO FOOTBALL;Giants Work the Kinks Out of Jones's Contract
description: Now it is officially done.

title: At the Nation's Table: Palermo, Calif.;Organic Olive Oil Runs in the Family
description: The children of Tofick Sadeg, a California rancher, came to understand their father's passion for 7,000 organic olive trees in the pastoral town of Palermo only after his death.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Eagles Set Fiedler Loose
description: The Philadelphia Eagles granted quarterback JAY FIEDLER his release yesterday after the three-year veteran asked Coach RAY RHODES for it in order to catch on with another team. Fiedler, 24, a Dartmouth product, knew his days were numbered when the Eagles drafted Ohio State's BOBBY HOYING in the third round. (AP)

title: Environment and White House Policy
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with President Clinton, conducted on July 8 with reporters and editors of The New York Times:

title: Horse Racing;Argentine Trainer Is Odds-On Now
description: For the trainer and his horse, the odds were looking a lot better today than they were 34 years ago.

title: India to Block Completion Of Pact to Ban Nuclear Tests
description: India has decided to block an international nuclear test ban treaty now in the final stages of negotiations, saying it is coercive, the country's chief negotiator said today.

title: For Judges in the H(2) Olympics, It's an Exercising of Taste Buds
description: All that sipping, slurping and swishing at midday yesterday at the main entrance to the American Museum of Natural History was not an assessment of Beaujolais nouveau.

title: The Bucks Stop With Pataki
description: Gov. George Pataki's 1995 inauguration has lingered in memory as a series of crowded celebrations that took place in very cold weather. But its size and the mysterious way in which it was financed always raised questions about conflict of interest. Now that some of the financial records have been released, it is clear that the New York Governor's fund-raising was even seedier than we thought.

title: Goal of 25% In Recycling Is Attainable, Report Says
description: New York City can easily meet its court-mandated recycling goals, despite Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's contention that they are impossible to achieve, according to a report to be released today.

title: Business Travel;An industry executive questions the F.A.A.'s assessment of aviation safety around the world.
description: WITH air safety uppermost on travelers' minds, the head of one of the world's biggest travel management organizations is questioning the way in which the Federal Aviation Administration assesses the safety of aviation around the world. Because he finds that assessment lacking, Ivan Michael Schaeffer, the chief executive of Woodside Travel Trust, believes that the agency sometimes unfairly penalizes foreign airlines and has the potential to put at risk passengers on all airlines, including those from the United States who fly to and from a number of foreign countries.

title: THE FATE OF FLIGHT 800: THE HISTORY;Investigators See 'Eerie Similarities' With Other Airliners That Blew Up
description: When an explosion ripped through a French airliner flying over the Sahara in 1989, the blast severed the DC-10's front end from the rest of the plane, which stayed aloft for about 20 seconds before plunging into the ground. The black boxes showed that everything on board was normal until a jarring, split-second noise, followed by silence.

title: Rail Settlement Reached
description: Conrail and the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees reached agreement on a new contract today, completing nearly two years of bargaining between the nation's railroads and their labor unions.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Telebrands Settles Suit
description: It would seem that Superman had nothing on a user of the Telebrands Corporation's Whisper XL hearing aid. According to national print ads, someone wearing a Whisper, which sold for $29.95, could hear a pin drop from 50 feet away, a whisper from 100 feet, and could even "hear deer coming before they hear you."

title: 90degrees? Only in May. But Summer Brings The Missing Spring.
description: Some summer.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: AUTO RACING;Fittipaldi Receives Good News
description: In good spirits and moving about his hospital room a day after neck surgery, the race car driver EMERSON FITTIPALDI was told yesterday that he could race again, as soon as this fall.

title: When Salad Dressing Moonlights as Sauce
description: SOME culinary practices are most often pursued in private. One such habit, indulged in by many a fan of haute cuisine when no one else is watching, is pouring bottled salad dressings on food. Italian dressing, for example, often finds its way onto grilled steak, while blue cheese dressing frequently tops potatoes or green beans.

title: Mexico City Journal;How Brazen Can You Get? In Mexico, Not Quite as Far as This
description: The blonde looks out from the big billboard with eyes at once sultry and coy, displaying a sumptuous bosom barely contained in a satin brassiere.

title: At the Nation's Table: Robinhood, Me.;Wealth of Choices On Maine Coast
description: Maine vacationers in search of something other than lobster rolls and fried seafood often come up short. But luckily for the mid-coast diner, Michael Gagne has created a culinary oasis for summer people and local residents. Last March, he opened the Robinhood Free Meetinghouse restaurant, outside Bath.

title: Relocation of Records Will Cause Big Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Invalidates Louisiana Primary Setup
description: Louisiana's "open primary" system violates Federal election law intended to insure that all states elect members of Congress on the same day, a Federal appeals court ruled today.

title: The Short, Scorned Life Of an Esthetic Heresy;Designed in Defiance of Modernist Tenets, 2 Columbus Circle Awaits Its Fate
description: Those "Independence Day" aliens have nothing to teach New Yorkers about the joys of blowing up buildings. We're old pros at this sport. Nobody takes greater pleasure in watching architecture smashed to smithereens.

title: Israel Recovers Remains of Missing Soldier
description: Acting on information supplied by the Palestinian Authority, Israeli search teams have found what appear to be the remains of a soldier kidnapped and killed seven years ago by the militant Islamic group Hamas.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- NOTEBOOK;Three Ejected for Drug Use
description: A Russian swimmer and two Lithuanian cycling officials were dropped from the Olympics today in drug-related cases.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12;Frazier Throws Ali Jabs
description: More than 25 years after he first stepped in the ring with Muhammad Ali, Joe Frazier took verbal shots at the three-time heavyweight champion today and wondered aloud why he was bestowed the honor of lighting the Olympic caldron.

title: Roger Tory Peterson
description: One of the interesting facts about Roger Tory Peterson's long, rich and immensely valuable career as an ornithologist is that nobody paid much attention to him at the beginning. Convinced that Americans did not care enough about birds to invest in a book, four publishers rejected Mr. Peterson's "A Field Guide to the Birds." Houghton Mifflin, which accepted the manuscript in 1934, was so sure it would fail that it printed only 2,000 copies and asked Mr. Peterson to forgo royalties on the first 1,000.

title: Mr. Armey's Party
description: To the Editor:

title: Over the Blues, Back in the Pink;Asbestos Woes Shed, Morale Revives at Owens Corning
description: When Glen H. Hiner left General Electric in January 1992 to head Owens-Corning Fiberglas, he thought the miasma that enveloped his new corporate home was the gloomy residue of an enormously costly takeover defense some six years before.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- OLYMPIC DIARY;After the Terror, Preaching, Praying and Singing
description: In a city that likes to call itself international, in a time when the world really does stand at the doorstep, the organizers of the Summer Olympic Games discarded their pretensions for a moment and reached back into Southern history for a way to honor the victims of a terrorist bomb and reopen the gathering place of the Games, Centennial Olympic Park.

title: OLYMPIC ARTS REVIEW/Dance;From Ninja to Classicist to Thai Monkey, in Atlanta
description: Audiences somehow managed to find the time between sports events to nearly fill two theaters on Monday for Olympic Arts Festival performances. In the afternoon, the Atlanta-based Ballethnic Dance Company presented dances by a resident choreographer and by a guest who works in Africa and Europe. In the evening, there was theatrical dance by the Royal Thai Ballet.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: FOOTBALL;Phillips Agrees to Deal With Rams
description: LAWRENCE PHILLIPS, the tailback from Nebraska who slipped to sixth over all in the National Football League draft in April because of his troubles with the law, signed a unique three-year, pay-as-you-play contract with the St. Louis Rams yesterday. He immediately began making up for 16 missed days of training camp.

title: Clinton Aide Is Ruled Likely Conspirator
description: A Federal judge has ruled that the deputy White House counsel, Bruce R. Lindsey, probably took part in a conspiracy to illegally conceal large cash withdrawals by Bill Clinton's 1990 campaign for governor.

title: Head of Adelphi Testifies About Escalating Income
description: Dr. Peter Diamandopoulos, the president of Adelphi University, never asked its trustees for a raise in 11 years, even as they more than tripled his salary and gave him hundreds of thousands of dollars in benefits, Dr. Diamandopoulos testified yesterday on the opening day of a rare proceeding by the State Board of Regents.

title: Italians Sue The Barnes Because Show Didn't Go to Rome
description: After months of legal wrangling with neighbors and local officials over other issues, the Barnes Foundation near Philadelphia is facing a new challenge, this one from abroad.

title: COMPANY NEWS;MUZAK POSTPONES ITS INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING OF STOCK
description: Muzak Inc. of Seattle postponed yesterday its planned $69 million initial public offering amid a weaker market for new stocks. The company, a provider of background music to fast-food and department stores, had planned to sell 4.6 million shares at $14 to $16 this month. The lead underwriter, Paine Webber Inc., said current market conditions caused it to postpone the sale. The market for new issues has faltered in recent weeks as a stumbling broader market keeps investors from buying shares in unproven companies.

title: COMPANY NEWS;AETNA TO CUT 1,700 JOBS BY END OF SEPTEMBER '97
description: Aetna Inc. said yesterday that it planned to cut 1,700 jobs by the end of September 1997 as it stops administering Medicare fee-for-service programs. Last week, Aetna announced that it would not renew contracts with the Federal Health Care Financing Administration, whose programs pay for services as they are rendered and allow participants to choose their own doctors. Instead, Aetna said it would focus on the growing managed-care Medicare business, in which participants are enrolled in health maintenance organizations. Employees who lose jobs could be placed with the companies receiving the new Medicare contracts, Aetna said. Aetna, based in Hartford, has 30,000 employees.

title: Canada's Chief Protester Picks New Cause: Suicide
description: When a terminally ill woman ended her life by an illegal, doctor-assisted suicide in 1994, Svend Robinson was at her side, risking up to 14 years in prison.

title: KPMG Says Robust Results Are Evidence of Turnaround
description: KPMG Peat Marwick L.L.P. reported robust revenue and net income per partner yesterday -- evidence, it said, of its success in transforming itself into a broad-based accounting and consulting firm.

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;Foraging for Cracks in the Olympic Spirit
description: By now we all recognize the diver who overcame vertigo, the gymnast whose wife nearly died in a car crash, the 14-year-old swimmer with the teddy bear. We know there's bad blood between the American runners Gail Devers and Gwen Torrence. And we know that somebody forgot to tell John Tesh that the cold war is over. In the middle of all that, athletes have been hurling their bodies through air and water like magicians, but in these televised Olympic Games, athletics is often the least of it.

title: The Golden Finale
description: Other men have run faster and jumped farther than Carl Lewis, but few have ever sustained such a high level of performance for so long. Lewis's soaring leap to a gold medal in the long jump on Monday vaulted him into the pantheon of legendary Olympic athletes, giving these Summer Games a place in sports history.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Foundation Official To Leave in October
description: The Advertising Research Foundation in New York yesterday named James Spaeth as president, succeeding Michael J. Naples, who will step down on Oct. 1, after 15 years in that post. Mr. Spaeth, 47, comes from ASI Market Research Inc. in Stamford, Conn., where he had been executive vice president for ventures, responsible for research services for interactive media. Mr. Naples, whose age was not available, will become a consultant to the foundation.

title: Hospital Mergers Do Not Guarantee Savings
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Notes
description: A Bit More Credit for PBS?

title: One Mother's Ordeal With Life on Welfare
description: In her rusting house trailer on a patch of thistles and stones in the Mississippi River valley, Manda Seefield clearly feels embarrassment about her plight: a welfare recipient for most of the last six years. But as her words tumble out, they are tinged with anger. She knows that many Americans, including some in Congress, believe that all a welfare beneficiary needs is a stronger backbone, and maybe a swift kick in the pants.

title: COMPANY NEWS;RAYTHEON AND MCDONNELL RISE ON NEWS
description: The stock prices of the Raytheon Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation rose yesterday after reports that the companies were talking about combining some of their operations. Neither company would comment on the reports, which appeared in The Wall Street Journal and The Boston Herald. Raytheon stock rose $1.875, to $47.125, and McDonnell Douglas gained 37.5 cents, to $44.75, on the New York Stock Exchange. McDonnell Douglas, based in St. Louis, is the largest maker of military aircraft in the country. Raytheon, based in Lexington, Mass., produces military electronics.

title: Ship Group Adds 2 Vessels
description: Global Ocean Carriers Ltd. said today that it had bought two container ships from Neptune Orient Lines Ltd. for $41 million. Global Ocean, which is based here, said the ships, built in Japan in 1980, would increase its fleet's carrying capacity by 25 percent. Under the transaction's terms, Neptune Orient, based in Singapore, will charter both vessels, NOL Crystal and NOL Amber, for five and a half years. Global Ocean's president, Nikolas Tsakos, said other shipping companies had wanted to buy the ships, and that long-term debt financing and a bridge loan enabled Global Ocean to obtain them. Global Ocean said the purchase brought its fleet to nine vessels.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Honors
description: * Aubrey Balkind, president and chief executive at Frankfurt Balkind Partners, New York, was named entrepreneur of the year by Ernst & Young.

title: Mervyn Cowie, Champion of African Wildlife Who Helped Create ParkSystem, Dies at 87
description: Mervyn Cowie, a British Kenyan who grew up with lions, frolicked with hyenas and later spurred the creation of the vast network of East African parks that have protected his childhood playmates from modern encroachment, died on July 19. He was 87 and had retired to Suffolk, England, in 1979.

title: COMPANY NEWS;ROYAL AHOLD GROCERY CHAIN TO REALIGN SOME STORES
description: Royal Ahold N.V., the Dutch grocery chain that owns the Edwards and Giant chains in the United States and recently bought Stop and Shop, said yesterday that it would realign some of its stores from one chain to another to give them more distinct geographical presences. Thirty-five Edwards stores will be turned over to Stop and Shop to eliminate much of their overlap in the Northeast. Stop and Shop will then have 192 stores, mostly in New England and the northern suburbs of New York City. Edwards and Giant will be merged into one company but will keep their store names. Edwards will take over the 16 Mel's supermarkets owned by Stop and Shop on Long Island. The merged Edwards and Giant will have 135 stores on the East Coast.

title: Real Estate;The News Corporation finds a home for its Fox cable news channel coming in the fall.
description: THE News Corporation, the media behemoth controlled by Rupert Murdoch, has leased an additional 120,000 square feet at 1211 Avenue of the Americas to house the new 24-hour Fox cable news channel it plans to introduce in the fall.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Wednesday about Dr. Stanislaw R. Burzynski, who claims to have discovered a cure for cancer and other diseases, misstated a contention made in a Federal indictment charging him with introducing an unapproved drug into interstate commerce and other counts. The indictment said the gross income of Dr. Burzynski and an institute he runs was $40 million from 1988 to 1994; it did not say the amount was his gross income alone.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the investigation of the crash of Trans World Airlines Flight 800 included an incorrect attribution in some editions. It was a senior Clinton Administration official -- not a senior American intelligence official -- who said the United States had no evidence of a connection between the crash and a recent visit to Libya by a French official.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;Lancome's ubiquitous rose grows into a full-blown icon to compete with higher-priced rivals.
description: AMONG better-known roses, there are Gypsy Rose and Lida Rose, Rose Marie and Red Rose tea, Rose of Washington Square and the Yellow Rose of Texas, not to mention the roses in the garden you were never promised in that song by Lynn Anderson. Now Lancome, the international marketer of beauty products, hopes to transform its own rose into a similarly familiar flower.

title: 114 Million Campaign Lifts a Black College to the Elite ofFund-Raisers
description: The campus of Spelman College is a quiet oasis in these days of the Olympics. As athletes, tourists and residents elbow their way through the city of the Games, little of the frenzy touches Spelman. But within the buildings shaded by magnolia and Dutch elm trees, there is an Olympic-sized joy over a fund-raising achievement that many say merits a gold medal not just for the historically black women's college, but also for its president, Johnnetta Cole.

title: COMPANY NEWS;PHILIP MORRIS APPOINTS NEW CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: Louis C. Camilleri will become chief financial officer of the Philip Morris Companies on Nov. 1, the tobacco and food company said yesterday. Mr. Camilleri, who is president and chief executive of the Kraft Foods International Inc. unit of Philip Morris, will replace Hans G. Storr, who is approaching retirement. John D. Bowlin, the current president and chief operating officer of Kraft Foods North America, will succeed Mr. Camilleri as president and chief executive of Kraft Foods International.

title: Combat Terrorism, But Don't Sacrifice Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12;Day 12 Will Lewis Be Back?
description: SOFTBALL The United States won the first softball gold medal, defeating China, 3-1, in a game marked by a couple of controversial calls. Page B9

title: Anne Simon, 82, Who Wrote of Threats to the Sea
description: Anne W. Simon, an environmentalist whose books explored the perils to the world's seas and shorelines, particularly on her beloved Martha's Vineyard, died on Monday at her Manhattan home. She was 82 and also had a home in Chilmark, Mass.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;France Picks Agency To Promote Tourism
description: The French Government Tourist Office said yesterday that it had named Select New York Corporate Communications L.P. to handle its account, which has been handled by Jerry & Ketchum in New York since 1989. Billings on the account, to promote French tourism among Americans, were estimated at $600,000. The decision came after a two-month mandated review that had been narrowed to three finalists: Select New York; Jerry & Ketchum, a joint venture of Jerry Della Femina and the Ketchum Communications unit of the Omnicom Group, and Blum/ Herbstreith in New York, the American agency for Air France.

title: Test-Ban Gains and Losses
description: After one final underground blast this week, China has decided to suspend further nuclear weapons testing. This belated but welcome decision means that all five declared nuclear powers -- the others are the United States, Russia, Britain and France -- are now observing a voluntary moratorium. But the chance of converting this suspension into a binding treaty is rapidly receding, in large measure because of unwise and unnecessary bargaining concessions by the Clinton Administration.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- YACHTING;U.S. Team Misses a Chance for Medal
description: Fernando Leon and Jose Ballester of Spain clinched the gold medal in the Tornado event on Monday, but with just 11 points separating the next seven teams, yesterday's race for bronze and silver was wide open. John Lovell and Charlie Ogletree of New Orleans began the day in third, 5 points out of second and 1 point in front of fourth, but started poorly and never recovered. A 12th-place finish on the Savannah, Ga., course dropped them into eighth over all. Lovell and Ogletree, both 28 and competing in their first Olympics, chalked one up to experience.

title: Sales of New Homes Plunge, Suggesting Slower Economy
description: Sales of new homes fell in June, while consumer confidence surged in July, two reports showed yesterday.

title: Food Notes
description: Cookies to Delight the Eye

title: In Pollard Case, Clinton Disappoints
description: To the Editor:

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- NOTEBOOK;U.S. Volleyball Team Baffled
description: It was early this morning when the last of the American volleyball players straggled out of the Omni and out of the Olympics. They had been beaten on the court by Bulgaria, and then were beaten out of the last playoff spot by Brazil.

title: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;Lawyer Is Charged
description: From his law office in Newark's Ironbound section, Anthony Cabelo represented the real estate interests of fellow members of the area's Portugese community for two decades. But on nine occasions between 1990 and 1995, Mr. Cabelo, 48, misappropriated insurance settlement checks totaling $250,000 that had been made out jointly to him and his clients, said Osborne Carter, an assistant prosecutor for Essex County. Mr. Cabelo, who agreed in November not to practice law in the state again, was indicted yesterday on charges of theft and misapplication of entrusted property.

title: COMPANY NEWS;DISCREET LOGIC TO DOWNSIZE BY 28%
description: Discreet Logic Inc. said yesterday that it would cut its work force by 28 percent as part of a reorganization. Discreet Logic, a maker of special-effects software, said it planned to consolidate its research and development functions into its headquarters in Montreal. The company said it had closed or would close its Cambridge, Mass., sales and research and development office; its New York and Boca Raton, Fla. sales offices; its Irish manufacturing and integration center, and several research and development offices. Discreet said the cuts of 105 workers would bring its staff to about 275.

title: Childbearing Deaths Underreported
description: The number of American women who die or suffer serious health consequences from pregnancy and childbirth appears to have been greatly underestimated, a Government report said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;Looking at Pornography (the Idea, Not the Image)
description: BOUND AND GAGGED Pornography and the Politics of Fantasy in America By Laura Kipnis 226 pages. Grove Press. $22.

title: METRO REPORT
description: THE CRASH

title: A Trout Species Is Declared Endangered
description: The Federal Government today declared a cutthroat trout species in Oregon endangered and proposed Federal protection as well for several steelhead salmon runs along the West Coast.

title: CREDIT MARKETS;U.S. Reports Push Bonds Up Sharply
description: Treasury securities prices rose sharply yesterday, as Government reports on wages and housing eased investor concern that the current rate of growth would accelerate inflation and cause fixed-income investments to drop in value. In fact, bonds turned in their best performance in more than a week and nearly recouped all the Monday losses.

title: U.S. Wins Softball
description: The Americans took the first Olympic gold in softball, beating China, 3-1, in a game marked by controversy.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- BASKETBALL;Routine Victory for U.S., But a Stunner for Australia
description: There was no last name on the blue No. 14 jersey. The back of the Brazil uniform simply read, OSCAR. To the rest of the world, the leading scorer in Olympic history needs no other identification. In the last meaningful game of his fifth Olympiad, at the age of 38, Oscar Schmidt lost his last chance for a medal tonight.

title: ATLANTA: DAY 12 -- MODERN PENTATHALON;A Stumble on Final Leg Turns Gold Into Silver
description: They shoot, they fence, they swim, they ride a horse and they run. They get no money, to speak of, for their athletic troubles. Nor fame. Nor commercial endorsements.

title: BASEBALL;L.I. Squad Stays Alive
description: South Shore of Staten Island had history on its side.

title: Edward Birkenmeier, 48, Leader In Using Mice for Medical Studies
description: Dr. Edward H. Birkenmeier, a geneticist who was a leader in the use of mice as models for studying human diseases, died on Saturday at his home in Bar Harbor, Me. He was 48.

title: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;BMW Says New Models Helped Increase Profits
description: Bayerische Motorenwerke A.G., the German luxury car maker known as BMW, said yesterday that its first-half net income rose 9.8 percent, crediting the success of the new 5-Series, the sold-out Z3 roadster and new models of its Rover subsidiary in Britain. Profits grew to 335 million marks, or $226 million, in the first half, from 305 million marks last year, within analysts' expectations.

title: World News Briefs;Indonesian Military Says Rioters Will Be Shot
description: Indonesia's military said today that rioters would be shot on sight as rumors of fresh disturbances spread panic and forced some shops and businesses to close early in Jakarta, the capital.

title: Judge Rejects Effort to Link Implant Suits
description: A Federal judge in Detroit yesterday refused to consolidate thousands of lawsuits over silicone breast implants in her court.

title: Market Place;Biovail is so angry over its stock drop that it's suing.
description: YOU might think that a company whose stock had risen more than 800 percent since the end of 1994 would be happy about its share price.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;Lowe Buys Stake In Asian Agency
description: The Lowe Group in New York and London said yesterday that it had acquired what was described as a substantial minority stake in Live Communications in Hong Kong, which has been renamed Lowe & Partners/Live. Further terms of the deal -- Lowe's first venture in Hong Kong -- were not disclosed.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: YACHTING;Bertrand to Skip Whitbread
description: JOHN BERTRAND, captain of the victorious Australian team in the America's Cup in 1983, has dropped plans to enter next year's Whitbread round-the-world yacht race because of a lack of financial backing, he said yesterday in Savannah, Ga. (Reuters)

title: Pataki Signs Bill Allowing Possession of Self-Defense Sprays
description: New Yorkers, for the first time in nearly three decades, will be allowed to possess and use self-defense sprays like Chemical Mace under a law signed today by Gov. George E. Pataki, over the objections of New York City Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and law enforcement officials across the state.

title: AT WORK WITH: Thomas McKenna;Playing Role Model To Hollywood's Rookie Detectives
description: THE detectives' squad room in East Harlem looks like, well, exactly like the detectives' rooms in "N.Y.P.D. Blue," "Homicide" and countless other television shows and movies about cops.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE: BASKETBALL;Nets' Pack Passes Physical
description: ROBERT PACK passed his physical with the Nets yesterday, clearing the way for the 27-year-old point guard to sign a five-year, $15 million deal with the team. An announcement is scheduled for today. Pack agreed to terms last week, but the deal was delayed until doctors examined a nerve injury in his right leg that caused him to miss 50 games last season with the Bullets.
